title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Woes Hurt Bombardier
description: Bombardier posted its first loss in six quarters after Northwest Airlines canceled an order and the company incurred costs from job cuts at its train operations. Shares fell 6.6 percent. The company lost $9 million in the quarter ended Oct. 31. Northwest canceled five planes in September, Bombardier's chief executive, Laurent Beaudoin, said.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: 2 Women Win Seats In A Landmark Election
description: Two Saudi businesswomen won election to the Jidda Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the first women to win any election in Saudi Arabia. The chamber elections this week were the first polls in the country in which women were allowed to run. There were 17 women among the 71 candidates in the elections, and the two, Lama al-Sulaiman and Nashwa Taher, were part of an alliance that swept most of the 12 seats on the chamber's board. Women could neither vote nor run in the kingdom's first nationwide municipal elections, earlier this year. But the chamber elections are thought to be a prelude to voting by women in municipal elections in 2009. Hassan M. Fattah (NYT)

title: Britain, the Continent and the Issue of Foreign Ownership
description: LONDON, Nov. 30 - It had been a sinew of empire, a shipping line that ferried soldiers and diplomats, even royalty, on the Victorian mail runs that tied Britain to its outposts far to the east and beyond.

title: Supreme Court hears a rare abortion case
Much Is Riding on a Cowboys-Giants Face-Off
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 30 - In many ways, the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys are mirror images of each other.

The State of AIDS
description: AIDS is outrunning us. The annual report of the United Nations' AIDS agency, released last week to mark World AIDS Day today, informs us that this year there will be 5 million new infections, a record, and more than 3.1 million deaths, another record.

description: WellPoint, the health-insurance provider, said yesterday that its chairman, Leonard D. Schaeffer, had resigned from the board and that the chief executive, Larry C. Glasscock, would add those duties to his current positions.

description: REDMOND, Wash. - THE waiting room for Hilarie Cash's practice has the look and feel of many a therapist's office, with soothing classical music, paintings of gentle swans and colorful flowers and on the bookshelves stacks of brochures on how to get help.

description: MOSCOW, Nov. 30 - A man at the center of one of the scandals that touched off the Orange Revolution in Ukraine last year returned Wednesday after five years in exile and promised to help prosecute former President Leonid D. Kuchma in the killing of an investigative journalist.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - Titled "The Sands Are Blowing Toward a Democratic Iraq," an article written this week for publication in the Iraqi press was scornful of outsiders' pessimism about the country's future.

description: Ten years ago, Les Smith was a corporate bigwig, overseeing more than 350 employees as the manager of an oil refinery in the former Soviet Union. Today, he works in an industry he knows little about, supervises no one and reports to a very demanding boss: his wife.

description: ROME, Nov. 30 - It is not only anger that is rising in Europe over possible secret American prisons on the Continent, kidnappings of terror suspects and transfers of prisoners on C.I.A. airplanes.

description: THE entrance to the garage seems normal enough.

title: City's Schools Cut Racial Gap in Test Scores
description: BOSTON, Dec. 1 - New York City has made substantial gains in narrowing the gap in achievement between black and Hispanic students and their white counterparts, largely outpacing 10 other large urban school districts, according to federal reading and math scores in fourth and eighth grades that were released here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELZ, ALLAN
description: KELZ--Allan. Age 75, on November 30, 2005. Beloved husband of Joyce of 51 years. Dear father of Robin Rudnitsky and Stacey Kelz. Fatherin-law of Dr. Gary Rudnitsky. Cherished grandfather of Seth and Dana. Son of Sol and Diana Kelz. Graduate of NYU. Commercial real estate broker for over 30 years in the Tri-State area. He will be remembered for his brilliant sense of humor and love of his family. Funeral service today, 10:30AM, GuttermanMusicant, Hackensack, NJ. Please make all donations to American Cancer Society.

title: U.S. Lawyer in Tobacco Suit Is Leaving Post
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - The Justice Department lawyer who has led the government's civil racketeering case against the tobacco industry for the past five years is leaving the department after clashing with some of her supervisors over the direction of the multibillion-dollar case.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Tuesday about the naming of a new editor for Harper's Magazine misidentified its owner. It is the Harper's Magazine Foundation, not the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. (That foundation and the Atlantic Richfield Company established the Harper's Magazine Foundation.)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economy Up 8%, Beating Forecasts
description: India's economy expanded 8 percent in the quarter that ended in September, according to data released yesterday. The expansion outperformed expectations in both manufacturing and services. In the previous quarter, ending in June, the economy grew 8.1 percent. Financial services grew 9.9 percent in the July-September quarter, compared with 8.3 percent in the previous three months, and manufacturing grew 9.2 percent, below the previous quarter's 11.3 percent. In the last few years, both manufacturing and services have propelled economic growth, while farming, the traditional occupation of most Indians, has grown far more slowly.

title: Inquiry Begins on Florida School Friendly to Athletes
description: Florida authorities have launched an investigation into the correspondence high school that allowed 28 athletes to quickly raise their grades high enough to be eligible for college athletic scholarships, a spokesman for the Miami-Dade County State Attorney's Office said today.

description: OK, you've heard of Mad Libs, right?

description: FOR four decades, through booms, busts and bubbles, Silicon Valley has maintained an amazingly innovative business environment.

description: KENNETH COLE, who sometimes pushes the boundaries of good taste in his pun-laden, socially conscious advertising, will introduce a public service campaign tied to World AIDS Day today. It is one he anticipates will elicit more attention, and probably controversy, than any of his prior statements.

title: People: White Stripes, Peter Gabriel, Julia Roberts
A Police Death in Brooklyn
description: When a police officer dies in the line of duty, there is a natural desire to look for ways to prevent such tragedies in the future. Gov. George Pataki responded to the fatal shooting of Officer Dillon Stewart this week with a call for reinstating the death penalty. That is unlikely to save the lives of officers who find themselves facing violent suspects. Most potential cop killers are not the kind of people likely to consider the consequences of their worst impulses. The allegations about the man accused of killing Officer Stewart -- that he was a man already wanted by the authorities who sped through a traffic light while carrying 53 bags of marijuana -- provide a perfect description of a person who would not be prudent enough to resist grabbing a handy gun.

title: Wanting to Help in Africa but Asking if It's Possible
description: Watching "Orphans of Nkandla," a documentary this evening on Cinemax about the impact of AIDS on rural families in South Africa, will prompt your charitable impulses. It may make you want to seek out the sort of charitable organization that can guarantee that a contribution of two or three dollars a day -- and don't you spend more than that on coffee? -- would supply the retroviral drug therapy needed to prolong the life of one of the millions of mothers and fathers suffering from H.I.V. on the African continent.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: More Long Islanders Want to Go, Poll Finds
description: Last year, Anthony Panariello, 49, sold his home on Long Island for $510,000, making a hefty tax-free profit. He spent about half of that to buy a brand-new, mortgage-free house in Florida with 4,200 square feet and five bedrooms -- more than double the size of his old residence.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Hollywood Star That Walked
description: It may not be a case worthy of Atticus Finch, but Gregory Peck's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame grew legs sometime last month. And both the late actor's relatives and the authorities are at a loss, if not quite spellbound. The thief used a concrete saw to cut through terrazzo and sidewalk, then carted off the 300-pound, five-pointed pink star bearing Peck's name and the motion-picture logo, both rendered in brass. It was not the first caper involving a star's star, said Johnny Grant, the civic figure known as the mayor of Hollywood: James Stewart's and Kirk Douglas's stars were once lifted from a storage area by a construction worker. And Gene Autry's star, according to legend, once disappeared to the wilds of Iowa. All three stars were quickly replaced, as was Peck's, which was unveiled again yesterday afternoon. Mr. Grant said the thieves had very likely struck sometime before the middle of November, though no one could pin it down. "It is bizarre," said his widow, Vronique Peck. "It reminds me that the word 'fan' comes from 'fanatic.' " She said she had visited her husband's star with their grandchildren a year ago and appreciated its importance to tourists. "It's a crime to the city, but I think it's almost amusing," she said. "Frankly, I think Greg would chuckle." DAVID M. HALBFINGER

title: You Can Take It With You, and Now You Can Play It, Too
description: Copy video, audio and photo files to a portable hard drive by a U.S.B. connection, and you can easily carry them to your living room or your office. But playing those files when they reach their destination is another story.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - Robotic explorers probing neighboring planets have found evidence of hidden impact craters on Mars and dynamic weather, possibly including lightning, on Saturn's giant moon Titan, scientists reported on Wednesday.

description: PARIS, Nov. 30 - Peter Mandelson, the trade representative for the European Union, said Wednesday that talks to reach a new global trade deal were "too big to fail," but refused further cuts to Europe's contested farm tariffs.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Tribunal Jails One, Frees 2 In Trial Of Kosovo Albanians
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal handed down verdicts in its first trial of Kosovo Albanians, a commander and two lower-ranking members of the former Kosovo Liberation Army, a guerrilla movement, who were accused of torturing and killing prisoners at a camp in 1998. The commander, Fatmir Limaj, who later became a politician, was acquitted and released, along with a co-defendant, Isak Musliu, The third defendant, Haradin Bala, was convicted and sentenced to 13 years in prison. The acquittals were greeted with celebrations in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, which technically remains a part of the Yugoslav remnant known as Serbia and Montenegro but has been administered by the United Nations since 1999. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Results Certified In Mayoral Race
description: The Board of Elections certified yesterday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was re-elected with 753,089 votes to 503,219 for Fernando Ferrer, a 19-percentage-point margin that fell just short of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's record victory in 1937. Mr. Bloomberg, who received 8,332 more votes than in 2001, spent about $100 for each vote he received. Christopher X. Brodeur, a political gadfly who won 4 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary, led the field of write-in candidates in the Nov. 8 election with 35 votes, compared with 31 for Representative Anthony D. Weiner, 26 for former President Bill Clinton and 11 for City Council Speaker Gifford Miller. Sam Roberts (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETTY, HENRY L.
description: PETTY--Henry L. Of Westport, CT, died Wednesday, November 23, 2005. Husband of Lois Petty, stepfather of Giulietta Drake, beloved son of the late William and Helen Petty, brother of William C. Petty III of Bronxville, NY, Michael Petty of Silver Springs, MD, Dr. Barbara Heuer of NYC, Deborah Dalton of Cooperstown, NY & Connee Young of Petaluma, CA, step grandfather of Hazel Drake. Memorial service Sunday, December 4, 2 PM, St. Paul Lutheran Church, Westport, CT.

title: Campaign Finance Changes Gain Ground in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 30 - The Connecticut Senate on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved campaign finance reforms that would prohibit donations from lobbyists, contractors and others and create a new, voluntary system of state financing and spending limits for political races.

title: Agency Uncovers Problems in Drug Discount Program
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - Congressional investigators said Wednesday that they had found serious, widespread problems in a government program that issued drug discount cards to 6.4 million Medicare beneficiaries, as a precursor to the full-fledged drug benefit that takes effect next year.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a debate over maintaining traditions at Southern universities gave an incorrect first name in some copies for the chancellor of Vanderbilt University, who said if an institution is to survive it must grow. He is Gordon Gee, not George Gee.

title: Making Tracks Out of the City, Onto the Ceiling
description: IT was early in 1999 that Joshua Suzanne Ethier, a proprietor of Rags-A-GoGo, a vintage clothing store on West 14th Street and an avatar of downtown style, reckoned that she'd like a muscle car for spring. Ms. Ethier, 42, hoped to match, in a vehicular way, the adventuresome, evolving aesthetic she has cloaked herself in since high school in West Dennis, Mass. Today, she sports a softened Mohawk hairdo -- a fauxhawk, as she put it recently -- articulated with color and a clothing style she describes as gladiator-cowboy: union suits, 70's-era athletic wear, well-worn calf-high lace-up Frye boots, sheepskin vests and so forth.

title: Conjuring 30's Mitteleuropa in Songs of Austrian Expatriates
description: The Austrian Cultural Forum has been presenting concerts for only a few seasons, but it has quickly established a track record for offering interesting and offbeat works in persuasive performances. The music and the musicians, not surprisingly, are mostly Austrian, and vocal music has been a prominent part of the programming from the start.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, NICHOLAS
description: YOUNG--Nicholas. The Members of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the loss of their colleague, Dr. Nicholas Young. He was instrumental in the Education Program of the Institute, a highly esteemed teacher and a mentor to many of our present members. His wise counsel and wry humor will be sorely missed. Our condolences to his wife, our member, Dr. Marianne Young, and his stepsons and family. Paul Rosenbaum, M.D., Pres.

title: Masai Nomads Meet Jet Set; Goats and Wives Abound
description: SAPARINGO, Kenya - Special guests arriving in Masailand cannot expect to be greeted with a red carpet. But a cup of bright red goat's blood is a possibility, followed by goat liver, goat pancreas and goat ribs, all flavored with copious amounts of salt.

title: In 3rd Round of Egyptian Vote, Police Kill Political Activist
description: CAIRO, Dec. 1 - Egyptian riot police killed one person today and blocked voters from getting to the polls in the third round of voting in parliamentary elections, repeating a pattern of violence and intimidation that began after a strong showing by candidates of the Muslim Brotherhood, according to independent poll watchers and election monitors.

title: ECB lifts rate for first time in 5 years
BlackBerry Patent Case Is Nearer Showdown
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 30 - Research In Motion moved closer Wednesday to a showdown with NTP, a patent holding company, over BlackBerry service after a court dismissed its request to impose a failed settlement agreement on the two companies.

title: Gift-Giving, Unplugged
description: CLOTHES, as numerous spending reports have described since the holiday shopping season began in earnest last week, hold about as much appeal for electronics-fixated consumers this year as a lump of coal. Those telltale oblong tie and sweater boxes have been all but relegated to the island of misfit toys, judging by their nonexistent ranking of desirability on lists that start with an iPod or flat-screen television.

title: Stretching and Straining for Numbers That Uplift
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - When 2,500 American and Iraqi troops began an offensive in the western Iraqi town of Hit on Wednesday, the latest push against insurgents in the Euphrates River Valley near Syria, the Americans outnumbered their Iraqi partners four to one.

title: French Court Overturns Pedophilia Convictions
description: PARIS, Dec. 1 - A French appeals court today overturned the conviction of six people accused of participating in a pedophilia ring in northern France five years ago, unraveling one of the most mismanaged cases in French judicial history and leaving the nation asking how the court system could have gone so awry.

title: A vow to see Kuchma tried
Paid Notice: Deaths   POLLITZER, ERIC
description: POLLITZER--Eric. You will always be etched in our family's memory. You survived Kristallnacht and were rescued from Nazi Austria and brought to England on the Kindertransport wearing only a short-sleeve shirt, shorts and shoes in the dead of the English Winter. Grateful and humbled by your rescue you went on to serve in the United States Army. You would often say that only in America could one own a home, drive a car anywhere, work hard and love life. Ever so kind and loyal to every manner of man and beast. You were truly a Prince among Princes. Our heartfelt sorrow goes out to David, Robin, Lauren and Haillie. Debra, Peter, Andrew, Harrison and Grant Till

title: Two Sides Trade Barbs as Rap Producers' Trial Closes
description: The final phase of the money-laundering trial of one of the rap world's most successful producers played out in Brooklyn federal court yesterday, as prosecutors and defense lawyers traded bitter and sarcastic barbs before an audience including some of the biggest stars in hip-hop.

description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 30 - The European Commission fined 15 makers of plastic bags 290.7 million euros ($324.4 million) on Wednesday for fixing prices, and in a novel approach, presented incriminating documents recovered in raids on the companies.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Dates for Internet Domain Registration
description: European government agencies and owners of trademarks would be able to register for a .eu top-level domain name starting Dec. 7, as the European Union seeks to stamp its identity on the Internet, the European Commission is expected to announce today, a spokesman for the commission, Martin Selmayer, said. Companies would be able to register starting Feb. 7 and the general public starting April 7 by contacting one of the registrars around Europe.

title: The Secrets of the Moors, Transplanted to California
description: BRANDON TYSON dropped out of college in 1969 and moved from southern Georgia to San Francisco in search of excitement. He found it in plants. "Everything growing here was exotic to me," he said. "It was a revelation. I felt like I'd entered the Garden of Eden."

Survived by his sister Norma Fischer, brother and sister-in-law, Joe and Bev, his lady friend and dancing partner, Connie Ebers and many nieces and nephews. description: WEINER -- Hyman Joseph. Died 25 years ago. We remember his loving and productive life. He will live in our hearts forever. Shirley, Robert, Susan and David, Daniel and friends

title: GEAR TEST WITH: John Eustice, Pro Racing Cyclist; Taking a Toasty Winter Spin
description: BICYCLISTS need to wear much more clothing in cold weather than runners or cross-country skiers do. "The higher speed of the bike blows the warmth right off the body," said John Eustice, a two-time winner of the United States pro cycling championship and a veteran of the European pro racing circuit. To meet the demands of winter cyclists, bike clothing manufacturers have introduced materials that insulate and also wick away moisture, gloves and booties that don't impede function and skullcaps and helmet covers to retain heat. Recently, when the temperatures dipped into the 30's and low 40's, Mr. Eustice, 50, tested cold-weather gear on a 50-mile round-trip from Midtown to Nyack, N.Y., and in Central Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, GEORGE Q
description: HOROWITZ--George Q on November 28, 2005. Beloved husband of Renee. Loving father of Seth, his wife Lori and Robin. Devoted son of Libby. Dear brother of Don, Linda, Ruby and Jackie. George became CEO and Chairman of Everlast Worldwide Inc., in October 2000 after spending over 30 years in the apparel business, prior to which he was an educator in the NYC school system. He was very active in charitable organizations and a board member at the American Heart Association and the S.G.M.A. He left an everlasting impression on everyone he met with his dynamic personality and warm heart. A memorial service will be held Monday, December 5, 2005, 10:00 A.M. at Temple EmanuEl, Fifth Ave at 65th St. Contributions may be made to Dr. Theodore A. Atlas Foundation, PO Box 140998, Staten Island, NY 10304 and SloanKettering Kidney Cancer Research, New York City.

description: LONDON, Nov. 30 - Private equity funds continued their bold march through Europe on Wednesday, as a consortium including the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts secured a $12 billion cash deal for Denmark's largest telecommunications company, TDC.

title: Abuse case thrown out in France
National Briefing | Washington: Children's Products Recalled
description: A company has recalled about six million children's necklaces and zipper tags because they contain high levels of lead, federal officials said. The company, Stravina Operating Company of Los Angeles, announced the recall with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Studies have found that even small amounts of lead, if ingested, can cause permanent neurological damage or behavior or learning problems. The necklaces and tags, which have packaging that reads "Personalized Zipper Pull" and "Great for Backpacks and Keyrings too," were sold at discount, party, grocery and drug stores beginning in March 2002. The commission said the products should be taken away from children immediately. Consumers can call (800) 964-0029 toll free, for more information. John Files (NYT)

title: A Judiciary in Disrepair (and Denial)
description: WHAT a friendly morning. Everything was going along just fine last Tuesday as the corporation counsel, the city's top lawyer, talked about the complexities of torts, consent decrees and public safety during a breakfast gathering in Queens.

title: G.O.P. Dispute Over Pirro's Bid Grows Fiercer
description: Searing divisions among New York Republicans deepened yesterday as a growing number urged Jeanine F. Pirro to drop her bid to unseat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Concerns also emerged that departing Gov. George E. Pataki was no longer able to unify the party.

description: New York City's health commissioner says government should become much more aggressive about monitoring and caring for people infected with H.I.V. and preventing the spread of the virus -- in short, treating H.I.V. more like other dangerous infectious diseases.

title: Fox Looks at 'Idol' Schedule and Decides It's Just Fine
description: After weeks of speculation that the Fox network might alter the schedule of its hit talent-show franchise "American Idol," Fox executives announced yesterday that the series would return in January in its customary slots on Tuesday and Wednesday nights.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Improvements For Child Welfare
description: The Department of Human Services yesterday announced plans to add 200 child welfare workers, retrain its front-line staff in the next year and add 450 foster homes by June 30. The proposed steps supplemented the state's year-old reform efforts, which a Manhattan-based advocacy group, Children's Rights Inc., declared inadequate. On Friday, the group will ask Judge Stanley R. Chesler of Federal District Court to put the Division of Youth and Family Services in receivership, said Susan Lambiase, associate director of Children's Rights. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Scientists Say Slower Atlantic Currents Could Mean a Colder Europe
description: Scientists say they have measured a significant slowing in the Atlantic currents that carry warm water toward Northern Europe. If the trend persists, they say, the weather there could cool considerably in coming decades.

title: Plan: We Win
description: We've seen it before: an embattled president so swathed in his inner circle that he completely loses touch with the public and wanders around among small knots of people who agree with him. There was Lyndon Johnson in the 1960's, Richard Nixon in the 1970's, and George H. W. Bush in the 1990's. Now it's his son's turn.

title: Wanted: Market for lauded films
From a Couple of Collectors, a Curated Remix
description: A select group of visitors to the annual Art Basel Miami Beach fair, which opens today, will stop by the modernist house of Debra and Dennis Scholl, left and center, to see its latest incarnation. For each of the past eight years, predating the fair, the Scholls have enlisted a different museum curator to reinstall their contemporary art collection. This time, Debra Singer, on right, a curator of the 2004 Whitney Biennial and the new director of the Kitchen, an arts organization in Chelsea, selected about 55 pieces from over 350 works across media, including Carla Klein's "Untitled, 2005," shown behind Mr. Scholl, a venture capitalist and winemaker, who said it "got pride of place in the living room."

title: Europe and the CIA: How close?
U.S. Men's Ski Team Ready for Trip Up the Downhill Course
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Nov. 30 - It was one year ago in Beaver Creek, with the world's best skiers in town, that the United States men's ski team stunningly put its stamp on a World Cup season that had barely begun. In the downhill, the featured race of the Beaver Creek weekend, Bode Miller dashed down the feared Birds of Prey course to beat the field for first place. Right behind him, in second place, was his teammate Daron Rahlves.

title: U.S. seeks consensus on Myanmar inquiry

Retailers Miss Sales Forecasts for November
description: The nation's retailers missed sales forecasts for November, dragged down by sluggish performance at department stores, warehouse club chains and even usually invulnerable luxury merchants.

title: Bill Clinton Finds Better Relief Coordination in Tsunami Area Tour
description: BANDA ACEH, Indonesia, Nov. 30 - For the thousands of people still living in tents here in this tsunami-ravaged region, rain is often unwelcome. The rain fell all through Tuesday night and Wednesday morning, sometimes in torrents, only letting up as former President Bill Clinton began to tour Aceh Province.

title: Americans Hoping to Match '02 Glory
description: When the United States Olympic Committee decided in 2000 to pour an extra $18 million into its winter sports programs, its goal was to build a powerhouse team for the 2002 Games in Salt Lake City. It never guessed the results would extend much further.

title: For New Court, Abortion Case Takes Old Path
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - Well before the argument in a New Hampshire abortion case was over, the question that had drawn the crowds to the Supreme Court on a crisp Wednesday morning had an answer. No, abortion law was not about to undergo a major change in the hands of the new Roberts court, at least not yet.

title: A Monumental Man of God: Two Takes on the Life of John Paul II
description: Correction Appended

title: British Air Announces Big Job Cuts for Managers
description: British Airways announced one of the most drastic white-collar layoffs in recent European corporate history yesterday, saying that it would eliminate half its executive staff positions and almost one-third of its managers over all.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DOUGHERTY, JAMES W.
description: DOUGHERTY--James W. 11/25/40 to 12/1/95. 10 long sad years without you. How wonderful life was when you were in my world. Love, Tish

title: The French tackle discrimination
Belgian Police Arrest 14 in Suspected Terror Cell
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 30 - The Belgian police arrested 14 suspects on Wednesday in a series of dawn raids aimed at breaking a terrorist network that the authorities said was involved in attacks on American targets in Iraq, including a suicide bombing by a Belgian woman in Baghdad three weeks ago.

title: Britons Ask: Do You Know Who'll Be No. 1 at Christmas?
description: On Monday, the curators of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame announced that after years of rejection, Black Sabbath had finally been voted in (either despite or because of the yearly protests of its singer, Ozzy Osbourne). So in March, the pioneering heavy-metal band is to be honored alongside Blondie, Lynyrd Skynyrd, the Sex Pistols and -- oddly enough -- Miles Davis, who had to wait even longer than Black Sabbath for his Hall pass. (Davis died in 1991, and one doesn't imagine this particular slight was high on his list of concerns.)

title: South Africa's High Court Rules in Favor of Gay Marriage
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 1 - South Africa's highest court ruled today that same-sex marriages enjoy the same legal status as those between men and women, effectively making the nation one of just five worldwide that have removed legal barriers to gay and lesbian unions.

title: Dress Like Your Dad? He Rocks
description: DEBORAH DEJAH, a New Yorker and the mother of two, has long shared her daughter's tastes in music. Now she shares her dress size too. So it was probably inevitable that Mrs. Dejah, 48, and Olivia, 14, would find themselves at Marsha D. D., a Third Avenue store specializing in children's fashion, squeezing their diminutive frames into identical Doors T-shirts, the image of Jim Morrison emblazoned on the front.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Final Step In Janitor Unionization
description: The Service Employees International Union announced that the American Arbitration Association had certified that a majority of the janitors at four of Houston's largest cleaning companies had indicated that they wanted to join the union. As a result, 4,700 janitors at those companies will unionize in what is one of the largest organizing successes ever in the private sector in the South. The arbitration association had found a majority based on union-support cards signed by the janitors. The union also announced that it had given the arbitration association union-support cards signed by janitors at a fifth cleaning company, Pritchard Industries Southwest. The union said this would assure union recognition for another 600 janitors. The janitors, most of them immigrants, work part time and average $5.25 an hour. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: The Age of Skepticism
description: War is a cultural event. World War I destroyed the old social order in Europe and disillusioned a generation of talented young Americans. World War II bred a feeling of American unity and self-confidence. Vietnam helped trigger a counterculture.

title: Files show complicity on Timor
When I'm 92 (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Irking Conservatives, Schwarzenegger Replaces Top Aide With a Democrat
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 - In an abrupt political shift after a drubbing at the polls three weeks ago, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger named a former top Democratic official on Wednesday as his chief of staff. The move touched off howls from conservative Republicans, who called the appointment a betrayal of the party that helped him win the governorship two years ago.

title: After Storm, Riding His Heart Out
description: During his 35-day journey from Brooklyn to Miami Beach, Lee QuiAones licked sweat from his lips to stay hydrated, swerved for alligator road kill and took his meals where he could, impressing scores of people along the way with the sheer lunacy of his trip.

British Panel Urges Retiring Later and Private Investment Accounts
description: LONDON, Nov. 30 - After three years of studies, an authoritative panel urged Wednesday that Britain's retirement age be raised to 67 from 65, and possibly higher, as part of a major pension change that would include the introduction of individual investment accounts.

title: Held for 7 Days, Man Says New Jersey Profiling Continues
description: TRENTON, Nov. 30 - A Burlington County man has accused the state police of racial profiling after a traffic stop in South Jersey led to his being jailed for seven days last spring on an outdated arrest warrant.

title: Sports Books
description: BASEBALL BEFORE WE KNEW IT: A Search for the Roots of the Game. By David Block. (University of Nebraska, $29.95.) Who invented baseball? The author says legitimate claims to its origin can be made by several countries, including France.

title: Body Found in Car Is Said to Be Mob Figure's
description: Federal authorities believe that a decomposed body discovered yesterday in the trunk of a car outside a New Jersey diner is that of a mob figure who disappeared during his federal fraud trial and was later acquitted, law enforcement officials said.

title: Holding On With Oxygen and a Computer
description: In a tiny apartment on East Ninth Street in Manhattan, Linda Hirsch is anchored to an oxygen tank. In three years, she has largely ventured no farther than the tank's tube will allow.

title: For All the Fans of 20th-Century Design on Your Gift List
description: December is big-ticket time for 20th-century design collectors. On Dec. 4 Wright in Chicago (wright20.com) begins a three-part auction, concluding with "Ca. 70" on Dec. 6, a 1960's and 70's design sale that includes a Georges Laporte chair, left, and a lamp by Jean-Pierre Vitrac, near right. In New York: On Dec. 7 Christie's (www.christies.com) will sell French midcentury furnishings collected by Scott Rudin and his partner, John Barlow, including a Serge Roche hanging fixture, far right; Phillips de Pury & Company (phillipsdepury.com) will hold its sale on Dec. 8; and the next day Sotheby's (sothebys.com) will offer French and American modernism.

title: Wanting to Help in Africa but Asking if It's Possible
description: Watching "Orphans of Nkandla," a documentary this evening on Cinemax about the impact of AIDS on rural families in South Africa, will prompt your charitable impulses. It may make you want to seek out the sort of charitable organization that can guarantee that a contribution of two or three dollars a day - and don't you spend more than that on coffee? - would supply the retroviral drug therapy needed to prolong the life of one of the millions of mothers and fathers suffering from H.I.V. on the African continent.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The threat today is not someone taking over an aircraft with scissors or a knife."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LEWIS
description: HOROWITZ--Lewis. The Department of Pediatrics at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourns the passing of Lew Horowitz, a wonderful man and huge spirit, who, as a volunteer, provided his warm heart, his engaging and humorous stories, outlandish hats, popcorn and cookie nights and unstinting hours of support and encouragement to the courageous children we treat, their steadfast parents and all of us who knew him and treasured his friendship.

title: Dream Lives On, but the Gallery Is No Longer There
description: WINTER GARDEN, Fla., Nov. 30 - On days when his putts fell, and on days when they missed, Nate Lashley could usually look up from the green and spot his parents in the gallery. This was Charlene and Rod Lashley's routine, to follow Nate, their son, around the country, to take his girlfriend, Leslie Hofmeister, to tournaments, to provide a cocoon in a stressful sport.

title: The death of a GM dream
Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPRIN, MAURICE S.
description: PAPRIN--Maurice S. The Staff and Board of Directors of iEARN-USA mourn the loss of a good and committed friend, Maurice Paprin. His boundless energy and contagious enthusiasm inspired us to look for good in life and to work for what is just. We will miss him greatly.

title: Mixed Results on a New Beauty Fix
description: ON her talk show Oprah Winfrey promoted the new barbed-suture face-lift as a "one-hour lunch-break lift" and a "cutting-edge procedure with no cutting edges." On "Today" Matt Lauer described it as a "new alternative to a face-lift." And "Good Morning America" called it "one of the hottest new beauty fixes."

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - As a lawyer in the Reagan Justice Department, the Supreme Court nominee Samuel A. Alito Jr. played an integral role in devising legal strategy to pare back the landmark abortion rights case Roe v. Wade, documents disclosed Wednesday show.

Lewis Horowitz, 70, Promoter of Financial Futures Trading, Dies
description: Lewis J. Horowitz, who helped usher in a new wave of high-octane financial trading as chairman of the New York Futures Exchange, died on Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Retirement Age at 60, Not 55, in Trenton Plan for Pensions
description: TRENTON, Nov. 30 - A sweeping new report on New Jersey's troubled pension and health benefits system recommends several drastic changes that could save the state hundreds of millions of dollars a year, but are also likely to anger thousands of government workers and retirees.

title: De Beers Will Pay $250 Million to Settle Diamond Pricing Suits
description: LONDON, Nov. 30 - De Beers, the world's biggest diamond miner and marketer, said Wednesday that it had agreed to pay $250 million to settle four civil class-action lawsuits filed against it in the United States.

description: Older, lower-cost medications for schizophrenia raise the risk of premature death in elderly people, researchers are reporting today.

description: Like big businesses, many households now have several computers running on a single network. But the methods used by corporations to make files and programs accessible from computer to computer are probably not something most people want to try at home.

Tales From the Too-Much-Information Era
description: First things first: "Super Vision," a multimedia triptych about personal data and identity in the microchip age, is cool to look at. It's worth the trip to the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music just for the video gimmickry and gadgetry on display. Yet for something so technically sophisticated, the piece is all too simplistic and familiar in its central idea: Data accumulation=bad.

It was won Sunday in convincing style for the second consecutive year by Nick Nickell of New York; Dick Freeman of Atlanta; Bob Hamman of Dallas; Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash.; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Tenafly Councilman Arrested
description: Narcotics investigators arrested a councilman from Tenafly yesterday afternoon after they discovered 40 envelopes in his car containing a powdery substance believed to be heroin, said the Essex County prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. The councilman, Jeffery Romano, 43, was arrested after an officer stopped him in his 2006 Corvette. Mr. Romano, who was re-elected in November, is charged with third-degree possession of heroin with the intent to distribute and other charges. A phone call to his home was not immediately returned. Mayor Peter Rustin said he was speaking with borough attorneys to determine if Mr. Romano, a married father of two, would be removed from office. "No one was expecting this," Mr. Rustin said. John Holl (NYT)

title: Stockings Waiting for Dreidels
description: The world may not lack for holiday television specials. But if Michael Feinstein were to bring his annual Christmas-meets-Hanukkah cabaret show to television, the mood would be a lot cozier than in many of those hollow spectacles spreading chilly corporate tidings of comfort and joy.

title: Two Young Radicals and Their Dovetailing Destinies
description: The ironies of "Exist: Not a Protest Film" begin with the title. This is a protest film insofar as it addresses a subject all but ignored by mainstream culture: the personal and political struggles of young radical activists. By dramatizing their lives with candor, sympathy and a healthy strain of skepticism, the director, Esther Bell, offers an antidote to the whimsy and solipsism endemic to much of what passes for independent filmmaking.

title: Jurassic Bark
description: IT looks like something you hope never happens to a tooth, so why is it on the cutting edge of furniture fashion?

title: Bringing a South African Craft Back From the Edge of Extinction
description: Barbara Jackson and Shirley Fintz, owners of MonkeyBiz in Cape Town, are reviving the art of beading by training hundreds of local women, providing them with beads and buying pieces from them for stores like ABC Home. "The type of beading we've brought back was becoming extinct because people couldn't afford to buy the beads," Ms. Jackson said. Creations include a foot-tall horse ($30), left, and a doll ($40), right. Two beaders will demonstrate the art at ABC Home on Dec. 8 (4:30 to 6 p.m.) and on Dec. 10 (11 a.m. to 2 p.m.); 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 473-3000.

title: No Mere Babe in Toyland
description: IF you relied purely on circumstantial evidence, I might not at first seem like the obvious person to recommend the perfect holiday gift for a child.

description: The former director of immunization at Becton, Dickinson & Company, which makes hypodermic syringes, has filed a lawsuit against the company saying that he was wrongfully terminated.

title: Racing Association Won't Sell Art to Pay Bills
description: ALBANY, N.Y. (AP) -- A Manhattan auction house won't sell historic racing paintings submitted by the New York Racing Association to pay its bills, state and NYRA officials said Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALKER, GEORGE W.
description: WALKER--George W. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George W. Walker, associated with The Times from April 1956, until retiring in February 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERSTEIN, HERBERT
description: GERSTEIN--Herbert. On November 29 at age 85. Loving husband of Beatrice. Devoted father of Ken (Ellen Weiss), Judy Wasserman (Lee), Lisa Weinstein (Richard). Grandfather of Sam, Eve, Hilary, Edward, Jane, Alex, Elizabeth and Jonathan. Services 12PM Friday at Temple Judea of Manhasset, 333 Searingtown Rd, Manhasset, NY.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Little Cheer On Chirac's Birthday
description: President Jacques Chirac celebrated his 73rd birthday. As usual, international notables sent birthday greetings, but the influential newspaper Le Monde offered a political obituary that described him as so weakened by adversity and illness that even his own center-right majority had written him off. "Jacques Chirac Facing His Own Fade-Out," the headline said. That followed a poll published on Sunday that indicated that just 25 percent of the French feel the president, who in September suffered what many people believe was a stroke, still has some say in domestic affairs. Seventeen months of his presidential term remain, but, as Le Monde put it, "Everyone has realized that power has crossed from one bank of the Seine to the other: from the lyse to Matignon," or, from the presidential palace to the office of the prime minister, Dominique de Villepin. Katrin Bennhold (IHT)

description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 1 - Venturing gingerly on to a path of tighter credit in Europe, the European Central Bank nudged up its benchmark interest rate today by a quarter point, to 2.25 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, ARTHUR W.
description: FEINBERG--Arthur W. Cohen Hennessey & Bienstock P.C. and its entire staff mourn the passing of Dr. Arthur Feinberg, the husband, best friend and true love of our founder, Harriet N. Cohen. As one of Arthur's many extended family groups, we will miss and never replace his intelligent nurturing, his wise counsel, and his calm approach to life's vagaries. Our only solace is the knowledge that we can continue to face our daily challenges by asking always "What would Arthur do?" Our hearts go out to Harriet's and Arthur's entire family.

title: Small Scissors in Your Carry-On? Welcome Aboard
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - The Transportation Security Administration is making some of the most significant changes in the screening of airline passengers since procedures were revamped after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Controlled Mayhem and Noise Reduction, but the Weirdness Endures
description: What happens to a veteran noise-rock band? Korn, which once seemed unstoppable, has spent the last few years finding out. In 2002 it released "Untouchables" (Epic), a strong, grand album meant to push their caustic, lurching sound further into the mainstream. It didn't, and Korn followed it with "Take a Look in the Mirror" (Epic), a back-to-basics album that included "Y'all Want a Single," which sounded like a bilious retort to hit-hungry executives.

title: French, in First, Use a Transplant to Repair a Face
description: Surgeons in France have for the first time performed a partial face transplant, a surgeon who led one of the two teams that performed the operation said yesterday.

title: Inquiry Begins on Florida School Friendly to Athletes
description: Florida authorities have launched an investigation into the correspondence high school that allowed 28 athletes to quickly raise their grades high enough to be eligible for college athletic scholarships, a spokesman for the Miami-Dade County State Attorney's Office said today.

title: Credit for Bush?
Arts, Briefly; Restoring Berlin's Museums
description: The Bode Museum in Berlin, above, which houses the city's sculpture collection and a trove of Byzantine art, has completed a five-year, $152 million renovation. It is the second building on the city's historic Museum Island to be restored, after the Old National Gallery, in a $2 billion project that has been plagued by financial problems. The Bode Museum, a neo-Baroque building opened in 1904 and badly damaged in World War II, is scheduled to reopen in May. This weekend, visitors can tour the restored building and also get a look at the master plans for Museum Island's full restoration through interactive, three-dimensional computer models that will be installed at the Pergamon Museum, next to the Bode. Museum Island was listed as a Unesco World Heritage Site in 1999, and the full renovation of all its buildings is to be complete by 2015. Next up is the New Museum, now under construction and scheduled to be reopened in 2008. SARAH PLASS

description: SHERMAN--Guelda Kirkwood. Of Scarsdale, N.Y. Died November 16. Mrs. Sherman was a graduate of the Eastman School of Music where she honed her skills as a professional cellist. Her natural love of music blossomed into a rewarding career which filled her life with beauty. She is survived by her husband Bertram, son Spencer of Burlington, Vt and daughter Heather of Marco Island, Fl & grandchildren Natalie & Nicole. We will always love her as her memory will live in our hearts forever.

description: An appeals court overturned the life sentence for Metin Kaplan, the Islamic militant known as the Caliph of Cologne, and ordered a new trial on technical grounds. Mr. Kaplan was deported by Germany last year and was tried and convicted here in connection with a failed terrorist attack in 1998. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has begun to rearrange his administration for a second term, naming his longtime aide Patricia E. Harris as his top deputy mayor. Ms. Harris will succeed Marc V. Shaw as Mr. Bloomberg's ranking deputy, the mayor told reporters yesterday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HSU, DR. SHU YING LI
description: HSU--Dr. Shu Ying Li, 85. A world-renowned parasitologist and professor emeritus of Epidemiology in the College of Public Health at the University of Iowa, died in Iowa City, Iowa, on Saturday, November 19, 2005, after a brief illness. Funeral services for Dr. Li Hsu were held Tuesday, November 29, 2005, in Iowa City. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Hsu-Li Distinguished Lectureship in Epidemiology Fund through the University of Iowa Foundation, P.O. Box 4550, Iowa City, IA 52244-4550. For info, Gay & Ciha Funeral and Cremation Service of Iowa City, IA @ www.gayandciha.com.

description: GROSS--Ruth B. Of Huntington, NY, died November 29, 2005. Naturalist and educator of children. She will be missed by her three children, Jane Miller, Diane Kingsley, and William Gross III; five grandchildren; and very dear friend, David Johnson. Private Cremation by A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc. A gathering will be held on Saturday, December 3, 2005, from 1-3 PM, at the Old First Presbyterian Church, 125 Main Street, Huntington, NY. Donations may be made to The Nature Conservancy, 4245 N. Fairfax Drive, Suite 100, Arlington, VA. 22203, 1-800-628-6860.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Arraigned In Lounge Killing
description: A 21-year-old man who the authorities said fatally shot a Bronx woman and wounded two other people outside a Washington Heights nightclub was arraigned in State Supreme Court yesterday on charges that include murder. The man, Alexander Hall, who his lawyer said was an apprentice financial adviser, was ordered held without bail. Shortly after 4 a.m. on Oct. 12, Mr. Hall shot three people outside the Viva Bar and Lounge, killing Tabitha Perez, 24, and wounding Jeremy Soto and Ruben Batista, prosecutors said. Mr. Hall, of Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side, and three friends had been thrown out of the club, investigators said. After a dispute outside with club employees, Mr. Hall left and then returned and began shooting into the crowd, the authorities said. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: Rutgers Uses Tight Defense, and Temple Shoots Poorly
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 30 - Rutgers did not exactly turn in a stellar performance Wednesday night. Then again, a stellar performance was not necessary in a 67-53 victory against offensively challenged Temple at the Louis Brown Athletic Center.

description: THIS year for the first time, Art Basel Miami Beach, the four-year-old annual art fair, is being accompanied by a series of high-profile design events, including installations by Zaha Hadid, the architect, and Ron Arad, the furniture designer, and an exhibition of furnishings organized by Murray Moss, proprietor of Moss, the influential SoHo design store.

title: Sashaying Friends and Lovers
description: There was the usual endearing mix of business and pleasure at the opening gala of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Wednesday night at City Center. Joan H. Weill, of the Ailey board, got the evening off to a rousing start by announcing from the stage that the gala had raised $2.5 million for the company.

description: The emotional bonds between Jamal Crawford and Eddy Curry run deep, through two major cities and four N.B.A. seasons and more disappointment than either one cares to recall. When one of them hurts, the other feels his pain.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about a loan program meant to foster high-speed Internet access in rural areas referred incorrectly to the property of two Iowa homeowners who lack such access. The homeowners, Daniel and Linda Hawkins of Dallas Center, live adjacent to a farm but not on one.

title: The Multimedia Frank Gehry Now in Cardboard and on Film
description: At 76, the architect Frank Gehry, above right, has announced the reissue of his 1972 cardboard furniture line, including the Wiggle Side Chair, which has a new lacquered side. Now $850, it originally sold for $35 at Bloomingdale's. "I was trying to be the Volkswagen of furniture," Mr. Gehry said. It is shown on top of a new piece, Block ($250), and next to a new set of three tables ($1,270), all available through Vitra, 29 Ninth Avenue (13th Street), (212) 463-5750. Sydney Pollack, above left, has meanwhile made a revealing documentary, "Sketches of Frank Gehry," to be shown tomorrow at Art Basel Miami Beach and by PBS next fall. Along with an exploration of Mr. Gehry's personal life, the film cites professional critics and friends alike. "Frank still doesn't know how to use a computer," Thomas Krens, director of the Guggenheim museums worldwide, wryly observes, "except to throw it at somebody."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

The man, whose identity was not released because his family had not been notified, fell about 3 p.m. and landed on a beam above the bridge deck, said Steve Coleman, the spokesman. He was taken to a nearby hospital, where he died about 7 p.m., Mr. Coleman said. The man worked for Atlantic-Heydt Corporation of Brooklyn, Mr. Coleman said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

Federal prosecutors had charged in a civil complaint that from 1992 through 2001, the hospital improperly charged for reimbursement from Medicare, the federal program that pays for health care for the elderly. Beth Israel will pay $36 million to reimburse Medicare, an $18 million penalty and another $18 million for reimbursements that the hospital itself identified as improper and volunteered to prosecutors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Terror Defendant Arraigned
description: Mahmud Faruq Brent, a Maryland hospital technician, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges that he trained in a terrorist warfare camp in Pakistan. Arrested on Aug. 4, Mr. Brent is accused of traveling, shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks, to camps run by Lashkar-e-Taiba, a group designated as terrorist by the State Department. The complaint says Mr. Brent discussed his training with Tarik Shah, a New York jazz musician who is accused in the same indictment of aiding Al Qaeda. Mr. Shah and a third defendant, Rafiq Sabir, a physician, restated their not guilty pleas yesterday. Julia Preston (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   CONKLIN, GEORGE TAYLOR JR.
description: CONKLIN--George Taylor Jr. The Board of Directors, officers and associates of The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America are saddened by the death of its former CEO and Chairman of the Board, George Taylor Conklin Jr. Ph.D., who retired in 1995 and passed away on November 4, 2005, at the age of 90. The funeral services were private, in Manhasset. L.I. We offer our deepest condolences to his widow Julie Pokorny Conklin, also four children, Sandra ConklinWright, George T. Conklin III, Heather Conklin Raduazzo and Holly Conklin Graham, nine grandchildren and one great-grandson. A summa cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College, with advanced degrees in finance and economics from Amos Tuck, Columbia and NYU, George Conklin joined The Guardian in 1939, was appointed Assistant to the President in 1944, and moved through the executive ranks to President and CEO in 1971 and Chairman of the Board in 1977, retiring from active service in 1980, and from the Board of Directors in 1995. Over the years George Conklin also served as Adjunct Professor of Finance at NYU, and as an officer, President or Chairman of such professional organizations as the Conference of Business Economists, American Economist Society, American Statistical Association and the National Bureau of Economic Research. He also served as a Director of Guardian subsidiaries and mutual funds, TIAA/CREF, Central Savings Bank, Adelphi University, The Life Insurance Council of New York, Woodlawn Cemetery and The Solomon Brothers Center for Study of Financial Institutions. George Conklin was one of the industry's leading-edge figures in the investment field, moving Guardian into the computer revolution and new management and decentralization concepts. George Conklin's contributions to the company were manifold and his legacy will always be remembered.

title: Peres Hails Sharon's Leadership as He Supports New Party
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 30 - Capping a month of political upheaval in Israel, Shimon Peres announced Wednesday that after more than four decades of membership he was leaving the Labor Party and would back Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's new centrist party in parliamentary elections in March.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Manslaughter Charge Against Doctor Is Sought
description: Concluding a six-month, $11 million inquiry, a high-level commission has recommended that the authorities pursue manslaughter, assault and fraud charges against an American-trained surgeon, Jayant Patel. In its report the commission, which does not have the authority to bring criminal charges, said that 13 patients had died as a result of Dr. Patel's negligence and that others had been left in seriously worse condition than before the operations. It also recommended criminal action against two officials at the hospital in Bundaberg, the rural town in Queensland that hired Dr. Patel in 2003. He was hired without officials' checking on his background, which included having been disciplined by the authorities in New York and Oregon. Dr. Patel is believed to be in Oregon and could not be reached, but in the past, his lawyer has said he was not guilty of any improper medical conduct. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGEL, FREDERIC B.
description: VOGEL--Frederic B. On November 29, 2005. Theater Producer On and Off-Broadway, Independent Film Producer. Founder and Director of the Commercial Theater Institute and one of the theatre community's most respected and knowledgeable management advisors. Co-Founder of Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, the nation's leading industry-based HIV/ AIDS fundraising and grantmaking organization. Head of FEDAPT (Foundation for the Extension and Development of the American Professional Theatre) for 17 years. Survived by niece, Kathie Packer of Chicago; nephews, Daniel J. Zitin of New York and Gary M. Zitin of Philadelphia; sister, Naomi V. Zitin, and brother-in-law, Williard Zitin of Philadelphia. In lieu of a funeral, a theatre community memorial will be held at a later date. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRESKY, MARCIA
description: PRESKY--Marcia. Age 50, on November 28, 2005. Beloved daughter of Albert and the late Esther. Loving sister of David. Marcia was a dedicated, generous and giving advocate of international women's health. Some of Marcia's many accomplishments during over 14 years at American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee include championing international women's health programs and helping to raise over $18 Million dollars for South Asia tsunami relief. She had an enormous impact on many lives by working with SHARE, a peer support organization for women who had breast or ovarian cancer, as a member of the Board of Directors where she helped build their breast cancer programs in Eastern Europe and Israel. Marcia will be deeply missed by her family, colleagues and friends. Service Friday 11:30AM at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Mr. Rosenstein, 51, was described by Israeli authorities as one of that country's most notorious mob leaders. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: On the Circuit
description: W.H. Auden is one of those poets who has a poem for every mood, and for a surprising number of occasions, too. For those about to undertake a lecture tour, the poem to turn to is On the Circuit, which he wrote after undertaking a tour at the behest of his lecture agency, Columbia-Giesen-Management. Auden describes sitting in his plane, being whisked off to various destinations in fulfilment of his agencys unfathomable will. This tour, he tells us, exposes him to various excruciating experiences, including girl organists in bars (these must surely have largely disappeared) and reading Conrad Hiltons Be My Guest (this has not disappeared). What makes it bearable for Auden, though, is coming across the odd delightful face or a chance meeting with a Tolkien addict. And at the end of the day, as he implies in the poems final line, he is being paid to do it.

title: On the Trail of a Missing Caravaggio
description: The prospect of discovering a lost masterpiece in the attic is one of those primal fantasies shared by "Antiques Roadshow" devotees and art scholars alike - a dream not merely of instant riches, but also of restoring to the world a great artist's vanished work and a missing piece of history. This fantasy provided the premise for Michael Frayn's delightful 1999 novel, "Headlong," and it's also the subject of Jonathan Harr's captivating new book, "The Lost Painting," which tells the real-life story of the rediscovery in the early 1990's of one of the Italian artist Caravaggio's most sought-after paintings, "The Taking of Christ."
