title: A Fauve's London journey
36 Hours in Whistler, British Columbia
description: MYRTLE and Alex Philip found their own pot of gold when they came from Maine and built the Rainbow Lodge by the shores of Alta Lake in 1914. There were several dozen year-round residents living on Alta, a fishing hole 75 miles north of Vancouver. The locals were intrigued by the sound made by the western hoary marmots at the lake, so they called the area Whistler. The 1960 Winter Olympics in Squaw Valley in California inspired a group of Vancouver businessmen to build a ski resort and bid for the Games. London Mountain was rechristened Whistler Mountain and opened for skiing in 1966. A dozen years later, an area used as a dump was transformed into a European-style town. Now there are 115 places to stay -- from ski chalets to luxury hotels -- almost 100 bars and restaurants and 200 places to shop. Those Olympic dreams? They'll come true in February 2010 when events like skiing and sledding are held in and around Whistler. Now is a good time to visit, before the gold rush starts. BOB MACKIN

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: U.N. Inquiry To Continue After Investigator's Report
description: Detlev Mehlis, the German prosecutor leading the United Nations investigation into the assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri last February, will leave his post this month, as planned, but is being asked to maintain an "association" with the inquiry, which is now expected to continue into next year, said Stphane Dujarric, a spokesman for Secretary General Kofi Annan. Mr. Mehlis, who began his inquiry in May, is scheduled to interview five suspects, among them the brother-in-law of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, in Vienna next week and report to the Security Council by Dec. 15. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Pfizer Fires a Vice President Who Criticized the Company's Sales Practices
description: Pfizer has parted ways with Peter Rost, its not-so-favorite whistle-blower.

title: U.S.-Iraq Force Presses Sweep Against Rebels
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 1 - The American military said on Thursday that four American servicemen died Wednesday, including two marines who were killed during sweeps aimed at disrupting insurgent networks in Anbar Province prior to the Dec. 15 elections.

title: China aims to reassure public on mine blasts
Dutch at the Edge of Design
description: Fashion and Textiles From the Netherlands The Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology Seventh Avenue and 27th Street, Manhattan Through Dec. 10

title: The Passion of Collectors: They'll Always Have Paris
description: For more than 200 years, Americans have made pilgrimages to Paris in search of culture, fashion -- and antiques. They still do. Americans, often accompanied by their interior designers or art advisers, make the rounds of the best Right and Left Bank dealers on highly focused buying trips.

title: Arts, Briefly; Biff-Bang Stamps
description: Batman, Superman and other DC Comics characters will be featured on commemorative stamps from the United States Postal Service next year. The series of 20 stamps, which will be issued next summer, will salute 10 costumed heroes. Half the stamps will feature portraits of the characters, including Aquaman; Hawkman, above; and Wonder Woman. The other 10 are to showcase classic and modern comic book covers, the post office announced. Other commemorative stamps scheduled for next year include "Favorite Children's Books Animals," "Art of Disney: Romance" and "Baseball Sluggers." GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, ARANKA
description: KAPLAN--Aranka. On November 30, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Devoted mother of Dorothy. Cherished Ome. Services Sunday, 11:30 a.m. at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Among Terrorists, a Hero Is Lurking
description: "Sleeper Cell" is better than "24."

title: Israel Shoots Down Incoming Missile in Test of Arrow System
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 2 - Israel conducted a successful test of its missile-interception system today, shooting down an incoming missile intended to simulate those in Iran's arsenal, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Women's Bodies, Men's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (CBS) KNOTS LANDING REUNION: TOGETHER AGAIN -- Those were the days (December 1979 to May 1993). Gary and Val Ewing (Ted Shackelford and Joan Van Ark), having left behind his oil-rich family in Dallas, moved to a California cul-de-sac, setting the stage for almost a decade and a half of nighttime-soap affairs, divorces, pregnancies, dirty politics, dirty business deals and, of course, murders. Cast members who reminisce include (above, from left) Lisa Hartman-Black, Mr. Shackelford, Donna Mills, Kevin Dobson, Julie Harris, Ms. Van Ark, Michele Lee, Michelle Phillips and William Devane. Alec Baldwin, who did one season (1985-86); Don Murray, whose character died after the first two seasons; and Nicollette Sheridan, who played young, scheming Paige for seven years, also turn up. (Where do you think Ms. Sheridan learned all that "Desperate Housewives" shtick?)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Election Boycott Widens
description: A fourth opposition party withdrew from elections on Sunday for all 167 seats in the National Assembly. The move caused supporters of President Hugo Chvez to demonstrate in Caracas and accuse the United States of orchestrating the boycott. The parties accuse the electoral authorities of favoring pro-government candidates, while polls have indicated that opposition candidates would fare poorly against allies of Mr. Chvez. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Diversions Criticized
description: City Council members yesterday criticized the frequent weekend diversion of subway routes. Councilman John C. Liu, a Queens Democrat and the Transportation Committee chairman, said the population had grown along lines such as the L and the No. 7, where diversions had been particularly frequent. Barbara R. Spencer, executive vice president of New York City Transit, said that 58 percent of work requiring track access had been scheduled for weekdays, either midday or late at night, when fewer people were riding -- but that some work could not be done overnight. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: This Time, Jets' Kicker Doesn't Mind Being Upstaged
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 1 - Mike Nugent has had a tough time getting attention this season, even when he kicks with flair. Late Sunday night, after many TV viewers had presumably gone to sleep, Nugent missed a 53-yard field-goal attempt that would have given the Jets a lead over the New Orleans Saints with 10 seconds remaining.

title: 2 Talk Show Titans Are Speaking Again
description: Oprah Winfrey ended a 16-year absence from David Letterman's couch in grand style last night, appearing as a guest on his "Late Show" on CBS and then receiving a personal escort from him down Broadway to the premiere of "The Color Purple," the new musical she is producing.

title: Pirro Stands by Bid for Senate, but Talk With Pataki Is Set
description: Under mounting pressure to end her faltering campaign for the United States Senate, Jeanine F. Pirro broke her silence yesterday and said that she was committed to challenging Hillary Rodham Clinton next year. Yet plans for a meeting today between her and Gov. George E. Pataki led some Republicans to predict a forthcoming change in her plans.

title: Honestly, We Were Really Great, Weren't We?
description: "You still look 28!"

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Ferry Captain Sues The City
description: The captain of the Staten Island ferry that crashed in October 2003, killing 11 passengers, sued the city last week, claiming that he had been made a scapegoat for the accident. The captain, Michael J. Gansas, left, asserted in the suit, filed in federal court in Brooklyn, that city officials had falsely claimed he had violated regulations requiring two captains in the pilot house when a ferry is docking. The assistant captain, Richard J. Smith, was alone at the wheel when he lost consciousness before the fatal crash. Mr. Gansas said in court papers that there had been no rule requiring him to be in the pilot house. Mr. Gansas, who was fired in November 2003, is demanding that the city agree to arbitrate his claims before a labor panel, or reinstate him with back pay. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: With interest: The case of the negative saving rate
Plan for an 'iPod Tax' in Japan Unravels
description: TOKYO, Dec. 1 - A plan to charge an "iPod tax," or royalties on portable digital music players, unraveled Thursday after a government committee failed to reach agreement on the measure.

title: Great Meaning in Asian Small Works
description: Traditions are not monuments. "We always do it like that" should be a cue to give whatever "it" is a swat. That's what confident cooks and ambitious artists do to the recipes they inherit. In revamping a model, they make it new and preserve its essence. A vegetable curry or a peach cobbler can take many inventive forms and still be intensely curryish or delectably peachy.

title: 2 Companies Plan to Expand and Add Jobs in Hunts Point
description: Two companies, Baldor Specialty Foods and Anheuser-Busch of New York, will expand their New York City operations as part of the city's redevelopment plans for a wholesale food distribution center in the South Bronx.

title: Environment chief resigns in China
Etienne Vatelot: Taking life by the strings
'The Apprentice' to Try Out Palm Trees
description: LIKE "Law & Order" and "Sex and the City," NBC's reality show "The Apprentice" relies heavily on New York imagery, from sweeping aerial shots of the Manhattan skyline to contestant challenges with Central Park as a backdrop.

title: Another Simms in the Pipeline
description: Tucked in a classroom above the locker room at Don Bosco Prep on Wednesday, the offensive linemen intently studied a big-screen television.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Lost' vs. 'Rudolph'
description: This Wednesday night, as usual, CBS was No. 1 in total viewers, while ABC drew in more 18-to-49-year-olds over all. But while "Lost" (an estimated 21.3 million viewers) continued to deliver a large audience for ABC, it didn't get much help from the rest of the network's lineup. Because of the weak performances of the network's "George Lopez" (7.94 million), "Freddie" (8.19 million) and "Invasion" (10.92 million), ABC took the 18-to-49 demographic by only one-tenth of a ratings point. CBS was also helped by the perennial favorite "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer," whose very shiny nose (not to mention the songs of Johnny Marks and the voice of Burl Ives) attracted 15.75 million viewers at 8 p.m. And though it is broadcast at the same time as "Lost," CBS's "Criminal Minds" has grown into one of the few new hits of the season, with 15.87 million viewers. Wednesday was the final night of the ratings sweeps period, and CBS was far ahead in total viewers, followed by ABC, NBC, Fox, UPN and the WB. In the race for adults 18 to 49, it was too close to call between ABC and CBS until the final numbers were tallied. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKALET, JOSEPH
description: SKALET--Joseph. On November 30, 2005, age 95. Husband of the late Lucile (nee Adels). Father of Steven (wife Linda) Skalet and Barbara Strutin. Brother of Helen Stein and the late Philip Skalet. Grandfather of four, great-grandfather of two. Service Sunday 11:30AM at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck. Interment Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Soothing Survey: Coffeehouses to Cellphones
description: Thirty years ago, Robert Klein received an invitation to perform his increasingly popular brand of stand-up for the fledgling HBO network's first comedy special. Mr. Klein, a Bronx native and Yale drama school dropout, had made his first appearance on "The Tonight Show" in 1968; more than 80 would follow. His fame had grown in the early 70's with the release of his first comedy album, "Child of the 50's," which won a Grammy nomination in 1973 and took its place among the essential furnishings of East Coast college dorm rooms -- if not necessarily the ones belonging to the bong-and-fringed-suede set, then those inhabited by professional-class aspirants who wore ribbed turtlenecks and fondly recalled their upstate New York summer camps.

title: Investing: Developing strength
Palestinian Dreaming: Resistance and Joy
description: El-Funoun Palestinian Popular Dance Troupe may have called its program "Dancing Tragedies and Dreams," but outside Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, the atmosphere was all flashing cameras and unabashed delight. A woman approached a circle of friends to exclaim, "I just saw my sister!" Clearly, the company, as its name indiscreetly hints, is extremely popular. But its polished assortment of dancers was attractive on many levels -- and not simply because opportunities to see Palestinian dance are rare.

title: In Transit Talks, Little Mention of Wages
description: A negotiating round between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the union representing 33,700 subway and bus workers ended last night with little discussion on a key issue -- wages -- and no agreement on the authority's demands for productivity increases and reductions in benefits.

title: Mr. Fussy's shopping tip? Don't do it!
Merrill Unit Subpoenaed on Pensions
description: Merrill Lynch acknowledged yesterday that its pension consulting unit in Florida, which advises nearly 100 funds in the state, had received a subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of an investigation into conflicts of interest among advisers to pension funds.

title: Britain sends France suspect in bombing
Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about efforts by Starbucks workers in New York to form a citywide union referred imprecisely to three Starbucks coffee shops where organizing has taken place. Although some workers at the three shops have joined the union, no Starbucks shops are unionized. The article also misstated the minimum number of hours required per workweek to qualify for health benefits. It is 20, not 30.

title: Frederic B. Vogel Is Dead; Taught Broadway Production
description: Frederic B. Vogel, the founder of the Commercial Theater Institute, a teaching program for prospective Broadway producers, and a longtime expert on theater management, died on Tuesday night at his home in New York. He was in his 70's, but his family could not provide an exact age.

title: Afleet Alex Is Retired
description: The injury bug that has seemingly left no marquee horse alone struck again yesterday with the announcement that Afleet Alex, the 2005 Preakness and Belmont Stakes champion, has been retired.

title: Rights Group Lists 26 It Says U.S. Is Holding in Secret Abroad
description: ROME, Dec. 1 - Human Rights Watch has released a list of 26 "ghost detainees" it says are being held incommunicado by the United States at secret foreign prisons.

title: TRACK AND FIELD
description: SIX INDUCTED INTO HALL -- Formally inducted into the National Track and Field Hall of Fame last night were Roger Kingdom, a two-time Olympic 110-high hurdles champion; the world-record long jumper Mike Powell; Jim Fuchs, the former world-record holder in the shot put; the miler Wes Santee; shot-putter Earlene Brown; high hurdler Fred Woldcott; and Arkansas Coach John McDonnell. Elliott Denman

title: Getting Jibby At Ski School
description: IT'S 8:30 a.m., the first day of your ski vacation, and as you try to hustle the family out of the condo, your 10-year-old's face starts to wrinkle and redden like an overripe tomato. He doesn't want to go to ski school. Ski school is boring. It's uncool. Try mentioning "terrain park" and "halfpipe," however, and watch his pout morph into an eager grin.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Hearing Is Set On Iraq Propaganda The Senate summoned Pentagon officials to a closed-door session today to explain reports that the military puts paid propaganda in Iraqi news media. The White House spokesman also expressed deep concern over the reports. PAGE A10

title: TRANSACTIONS
Spare Times
description: Attractions

title: Golf: Monty gets closer to pacesetter
Briefs: Icahn seeks control of Fairmont Hotel group
Right Out of Film Noir, a Shadowy New York
description: NEW York is Film Noir City: as I move through it, I scout locations for my imaginary 1947 thriller. All I need is a little night -- plenty of that this time of year -- and the last six decades are gone.

title: Singapore Hangs Smuggler
description: SINGAPORE, Friday, Dec. 2 - As a small group of protesters stood silently outside the prison in the early light, the authorities here on Friday hanged a 25-year-old Australian man convicted of trying to smuggle heroin through Singapore.

title: Arts Guide
World Briefing | Europe: France: Britain Extradites Mtro Bomb Suspect
description: Britain extradited to France Rachid Ramda, an Algerian accused in a bombing at the Saint-Michel Mtro station in 1995 in which eight people were killed. He was arrested in Britain shortly after the attack, but began a long legal battle against extradition. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Michael Evans, Photographer of Ronald Reagan, Dies at 61
description: Michael A. W. Evans, a photographer whose picture of Ronald Reagan in a well-worn cowboy hat was on the covers of Time, Newsweek and People after Mr. Reagan's death last year, died yesterday at his home in Atlanta. He was 61.

title: After 24 Years on Death Row, Clemency Is Killer's Final Appeal
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Nov. 30 - Stanley Tookie Williams, once a leader of a notorious street gang and now perhaps the nation's most prominent death row inmate, leaned over a small wooden table in a cramped visiting cell here and tried to explain what he used to be and what he has become.

title: U.S. reaches death penalty milestone
Ruling for Maker of BlackBerry
description: Research in Motion won a second ruling yesterday from the United States Patent and Trademark Office over one of the patents at the center of a dispute over its BlackBerry wireless e-mail device.

title: Women's Bodies, Men's Rights (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks: Shares fall as report fuels fears over rates
Phillies Sign Gordon After Losing Wagner
description: It is a good winter to be a free-agent reliever, and Tom Gordon became the latest to capitalize yesterday. Gordon, who pitched in nearly half the Yankees' games the last two seasons, agreed to terms with the Philadelphia Phillies on a three-year, $18 million contract last night.

title: Was Bush Persuasive About Iraq? (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Same-Sex Unions to Become Legal in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 1 - South Africa's highest court ruled Thursday that same-sex marriages enjoyed the same legal status as those between men and women, effectively making the nation one of just five that have removed legal barriers to gay and lesbian unions.

title: Get Me the Head of the Hunt Scammer
description: For all the anxiety that new tax legislation can generate among bipeds, a bit of mercy is being offered for the fleet African springbok and other big-game targets. Senator Charles Grassley, the Iowa Republican who heads the Finance Committee, is trying to close a loophole that allows hunters to write off safaris as charity by giving game trophies to museums. This scheme lets appraisers tote up the costs of things like travel, equipment and guides to inflate the value of the trophies, which often end up at places that market themselves as a way to "Hunt for Free."

title: THE CHURN
description: Deal Makers

title: It Takes a Statehouse Scandal
description: Galvanized by the imprisonment of a disgraced governor, the Connecticut Legislature has become the first in the nation to set campaign finance restrictions on its own initiative, including a ban on donations from lobbyists and state contractors. The extraordinary reform not only takes aim at the corrosive power of special interest money, but also creates the first statewide system set up by a legislature to provide voluntary public financing of campaigns. The commendable result is an instant model for other statehouses where incumbents have long shown meager impulse to bite any insider's hand that feeds them.

title: Buying used: As good as new and a lot cheaper
Verdict in L.I. Rezoning Case Tests Towns' Authority
description: Towns in Suffolk County routinely use their zoning powers to curtail development on a broad scale. But a recent jury verdict involving a rezoning case in Brookhaven Town is raising questions about how far towns can go without compensating landowners who see their rezoned properties decline in value.

title: Handing over power in an Iraqi cauldron
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Retired Detectives To Stand Trial
description: Two retired detectives accused of being Mafia assassins will stand trial on racketeering charges, a federal judge ruled yesterday. Lawyers for the detectives, Louis J. Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa, had said that the indictment, to artificially build a conspiracy case, had improperly charged that recent crimes in Nevada were connected to older crimes in New York. On that basis, they had sought a dismissal of the charges under the statute of limitations. Judge Jack B. Weinstein said the indictments were valid and set a trial date of Feb. 21. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Collinsworth and Madden Would Unite Analytic Minds
description: The talent search to find a play-by-play partner for John Madden starting next season on NBC's Sunday night football broadcasts is in its sixth month.

title: French Court Rejects Pedophilia Convictions
description: PARIS, Dec. 1 - A French appeals court on Thursday overturned the conviction of six people accused of participating in a pedophilia ring in northern France five years ago, unraveling one of the most mismanaged criminal cases in recent memory and leaving the nation asking how the court system could have gone so awry.

title: Achievement or Disaster: Which Is Remembered Best?
description: CONISTON, England - It was Jan. 4, 1967, and the fastest speedboat in the world, the jet-powered Bluebird K7, seemed poised once again to break the water-speed record. Then, at over 300 miles per hour, catastrophe struck.

title: Supreme Court Pick Assures Key Senator on Abortion Views
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. should be given a fair chance to explain his views on abortion and the law before senators vote on his nomination to the Supreme Court, Senator Arlen Specter, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said today. Mr. Specter emphasized that he himself is undecided.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Shares Move Higher as Reports Indicate Low Inflation
description: Economic reports showing few signs of inflation pushed shares higher yesterday, ending a three-day string of declines amid a five-week rally.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: County Budget Approved
description: Nassau County's $2.4 billion budget for next year won unanimous approval yesterday from a state oversight panel, the Nassau Interim Finance Authority. But panel members expressed concern over $10 million in spending added by the County Legislature. The budget freezes the county portion of the property tax. County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi agreed with the panel's concerns. He also announced that the Standard & Poor's credit rating agency had raised the county's bond rating to A from A-. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Roadside bomb kills ten marines near Falluja
Paid Notice: Deaths   PURCELL, WILLIAM
description: PURCELL--William. 55, Ft. Lauderdale, FL, on November 10, 2005. Beloved son of Robert and Edyth. He will be deeply missed by his eleven brothers and sisters and nieces, nephews and friends.

title: City Council Revokes Landmark Status for Brooklyn Warehouse, Upsetting Preservationists
description: Correction Appended

title: AHEAD | Christmas Trains; All Aboard the Iron Reindeer
description: THE heyday of train travel in America may be over, but this Christmas season at least, there are plenty of special trains, trams, trolleys and steam engines -- more than 70 special holiday rides on the rails nationwide.

title: For Brown, a Trip With Much Baggage
description: Larry Brown is returning to his previous place of employment, a ritual as inevitable and predictable as his compulsion for leaving jobs in the first place. When one has coached eight N.B.A. teams over three decades, there is always a homecoming on the horizon.

title: Was Bush Persuasive About Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHMIERER, HY
description: SCHMIERER--Hy, 86, December 1, 2005. Devoted husband of Horty for 56 years, loving father of Susan and Matthew Silverman & Merri and Harry Bragg. Adored "Poppy" of Rachel, Jaime, and Abbey Silverman. Cherished Uncle and Great Uncle to many nieces and nephews. Veteran of the US Army Air Corps in World War II. Founder, Owner and Director of Camp Starlight, Starlight, PA for 53 years. Loved and will be missed by thousands of campers and staff whose lives he touched and influenced. Former President of the Association of Independent Camps. Served on the Board of Governors of the New York Section of the American Camping Association. With his love for children and their well being, following his retirement in 1999, he became a board member of the Non-Violence Project in Miami, FL and an advisor to the Shake-A-Leg Foundation in Coconut Grove, FL. He continued to remain active in the Hancock (NY) Community Education Foundation. Funeral Services will be at "Gutterman's", 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY at 12:00 noon on Sunday, December 4, 2005. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hancock Community Education Foundation, 38 West Main Street, Hancock, NY 13783.

title: Shell's Sakhalin oil project should be reined in
The Neediest Cases; A Hard Life, Then Epiphany in Pregnancy
description: There is heaven, and there is hell. Deborah Web has seen both and now lives, like many people, in between the two. But she now welcomes each day that she gets to spend with her sons.

title: Police Searches of Bags in Subways Are Ruled Constitutional
description: A federal judge ruled today that random police searches of bags and backpacks in the New York subways are constitutional, finding that they are effective in helping to deter a terrorist attack.

title: Profusion of Rebel Groups Helps Them Survive in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 1 - Here is a small sampling of the insurgent groups that have claimed responsibility for attacks on Americans and Iraqis in the last few months:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILTON, HARVEY DANIEL
description: SILTON--Harvey Daniel. Former Executive Director of Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, NY, Attorney and Air Force Veteran. 84, of Media, PA., and Long Boat Key, FL. November 30, 2005. Beloved husband of Leah. Devoted father of Merrill Solan (Andrew), Jessica Farkas (Raymond), Richard Silton (Debra) and Myles Silton. Loving grandfather of Amy and Josh Solan, Jason and Lisa Farkas, Rachel and Matthew Silton. Service today, 12:30 P.M. at Gutterman Musicant, Hackensack, NJ. Information: 800-522-0588

title: Croatian and Slovakian Teams Square Off in Davis Cup
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia, Dec. 2 - On a day when the flag-waving and noise-making was unusually evenhanded for a Davis Cup final, Croatia's and Slovakia's tennis teams ended up on even terms, too.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: School Security Reviewed
description: The Education Department will review security procedures at Public School 33 in University Heights after a man entered the school and tried to kidnap a 6-year-old girl in the cafeteria on Wednesday, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday. The girl screamed when confronted by the man, apparently a stranger to her, alerting a school aide and prompting the man to flee. An Education Department spokesman said it was unclear how the man got in the school. Yesterday the police arrested a homeless man, Carlos Negron, 50, and charged him with the attempted kidnapping. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Epsilon Is Upgraded to Hurricane
description: Tropical Storm Epsilon was upgraded to a hurricane today, two days after the official end of the busiest hurricane season on record.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Money-Laundering Case To Jury
description: The jury in the federal money-laundering trial of the hip-hop mogul Irv Gotti and his brother, Christopher, began deliberating yesterday. The jury requested copies of the testimony of three government witnesses and documents that prosecutors argued showed that the men covered up fake loans. Prosecutors have charged that the brothers, whose real last name is Lorenzo, used their rap label, Murder Inc., to wash $1 million in narcotics profits for a Queens drug dealer,cocaine kingpin Kenneth McGriff. Lawyers for the two men have said that Mr. McGriff helped provided a service to the record label, now known as The Inc., keeping at bay "the street element" and anyone who might have sought to extort money from the company. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Senate Panel Will Investigate Paid Articles in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - A secret military campaign to plant tailored "news" in Iraqi papers caused a fresh stir today as the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said he would bring the affair before his panel and the Senate Democratic leader called on the Bush administration to "come clean."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCBRIDE, JOSEPH A.
description: McBRIDE--Joseph A., 86. Of Franklin Lakes formerly of Ridgewood on November 30, 2005. Beloved husband of Wendy McBride (nee Michie). He is predeceased by his first wife, the late Barbara McBride (nee O'Connor)(1994). Devoted father of Terence McBride and his wife Mary of Franklin Lakes, Sheila James and her husband David of Villanova, PA, Michael McBride and his wife BethAnn of Ridgewood and Dr. Mark McBride and his wife Virginia of Madison. Dear stepfather of Louise Wright, James Harrison, Jason Fisher and Jonathan Fisher. Loving grandfather of fifteen and great-grandfather of two. Funeral services Monday 9:30 AM at Vander PlaatVermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes followed by a 10:00 AM Mass at Most Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church. Interment Christ The King Cemetery. The family will receive friends Sunday 24 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial donations be made to Most Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church, 787 Franklin Lake Road, Franklin Lakes, N.J. 07417 in Mr. McBride's memory. For further information www.vanderplaat.com

title: Cy Twombly
description: Bacchus Gagosian Gallery 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street Through Dec. 23

title: Metro Briefing | New York: MTA Completes Bus Takeovers
description: City officials have made an agreement with four publicly subsidized bus companies that clears the way for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to take over 700 buses on 50 routes. The city will pay $25 million for the bus companies' assets and lease four depots from the companies for $7.5 million per year. These companies, in Brooklyn or Queens, will be transferred: Command Bus Company on Dec. 5, Green Bus Lines on Jan. 9, Jamaica Buses on Jan. 30 and the Triboro Coach Corporation on Feb. 20. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Portrait of a Problem Child With a Songwriter's Soul
description: "I'd like to write songs that are so good nobody understands them, including me," the Texan singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt remarks half-seriously in Margaret Brown's tender, impressionistic film biography, "Be Here to Love Me." The words evoke the shadowy images in many of the songs written by Van Zandt, a country-folk troubadour who died of a heart attack on Jan. 1, 1997, while recovering from a broken hip; he was 52.

title: Nicholas: The Epic Journey From Saint to Santa Claus
In Letter, the Vatican Expands Gay Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 - A cover letter attached to a Vatican directive that would bar most gay men from entering seminaries also prohibits priests with "homosexual tendencies" from teaching or running seminaries.

title: A Bygone Era Evoked, Whiny Saxes and All
description: The German singer Max Raabe is fascinated with the cabaret music of the Weimar Republic, and has built a career recreating the sounds and songs of the 1920's and 30's. He has assembled an ensemble for the purpose, the Palast Orchester, and its dozen players have assimilated the style and interpretive moves of a period swing band. The timbres and articulation you hear on old film soundtracks or shellac discs -- the muted trumpets and trombones, the slightly whiny sax section (or vibrato-laden solo saxophone), the occasional soaring violin line and the solid but supple rhythm section -- all sound exactly right, and are suitably tuxedoed and polished.

title: New York Story Closes With a Deal
description: The final chapter of Lebenthal, a New York institution made famous by its quirky radio ads extolling the virtues of tax-free municipal bonds, comes to an end today.

title: Meet David Carr
description: David Carr is a general assignment reporter for the culture section of The New York Times and writes a column for the paper's Monday Business section that focuses on media issues involving print, digital, film, radio and television. Carr fancies himself something of a film fan, in part because he is willing to go to a movie, almost any movie, by himself. Even so, he avoids screenings, because they neither serve nor allow popcorn, an essential substance he prefers in a 55-gallon tub with just a frisson of topping. He thinks that movie theaters should be equipped with flying monkeys that drop out of the ceiling and attack people who insist on talking during films.

title: Women's Bodies, Men's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about patients' experiences with difficult doctors, referred incorrectly to a spinal test that a patient said her doctor had mislaid. In the test, a myelogram, dye is injected into the spinal canal, not the spinal cord.

title: Bill Murray Introduces Jim Jarmusch
description: Bill Murray Introduces J im Jarmusch

A Clash of Exchange Titans
description: On Tuesday, the 1,366 owners of the New York Stock Exchange are likely to end an era and begin a new one by voting to convert the 213-year-old nonprofit public utility into a for-profit publicly traded company. The deal will give the Big Board a verve it has lacked: it will have the currency to acquire other exchanges, the freedom to make swift decisions without waiting for a consensus among its members and the ability to act like an entrepreneur and pursue sources of faster-growing revenue.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Retail Sales in November Confirm Consumers' Preference for Discounters November retail sales confirmed a buying pattern that first emerged over the holiday weekend: consumers, who are paying more for gas this year and preparing to spend more on home heating as temperatures drop, are flocking to discount chains like Wal-Mart and Target, purchasing more online, but skipping many full-priced shops at the mall. Wal-Mart said sales rose 4.3 percent. [Page C1.]

ROY DeFOREST
description: Back in the 1970's, regionalism was a dirty word. In the thoroughly global outside-is-in art world of today, it is barely a word at all. But the artists at whom it was aimed -- postwar Americans working outside New York and Los Angeles -- continue to suffer from its fallout. The singular greatness of Jim Nutt and Peter Saul has only recently started to come into focus; the achievements of H. C. Westermann, Robert Arneson and Joan Brown are less fixed in art world consciousness than they should be. Ditto for Roy DeForest, who is showing new paintings for the first time since 1997 at the George Adams Gallery in Chelsea. At 75, Mr. DeForest is painting pretty much what he has painted for years: dogs, men in hats or headdresses, and supernatural beings against a flattened terrain. Angular, masklike, brusquely rendered, they all seem shamanistic and slightly crazed; their bright, staring eyes imply the ingestion of hallucinatory substances. Mr. DeForest continues to favor dense compositions and oppressively bright colors unrelieved by much in the way of white. (The white goat in "Goat Daze," above, is an exception.) His signature technique persists: tiny dollops of paint, whose culminating twists suggest chocolate chips but also thumbtacks, with their points facing out. His new works have become slightly more structured: compartmentalized into patchworks of portraits, friezes and pictures within pictures, as if the artist had a new appreciation for classic American folk art. They are also more inventive and sensuous in their handling of paint. The bristling textures have diversified -- new additions include mosaiclike sections of dried acrylic paint -- and the clearer composition increases their impact. These works have a blatant, consummate ease. If Mr. DeForest's goal is to transfer the ecstatic experience of the world from his creature-subjects to his creature-viewers, it has never been more clearly or radiantly stated. (525 West 26th Street, (212) 564-8480, through Jan. 28.) ROBERTA SMITH THE LISTINGS | DEC. 2--DEC. 8

title: First Descent
description: "First Descent" purports to trace the evolution of snowboarding from a primitive backwoods hobby to global phenomenon. At the same time, it follows a multigenerational group of pros on a spectacular 10-day adventure in the Alaskan mountains. The filmmakers, Kemp Curley and Kevin Harrison, ought to have taken a cue from the simplicity of their sport by strapping into a single story and taking it for a breakneck ride. Instead, they crisscross clumsily, stumbling over their double narratives.

title: Swinging Back Onto the Scene
description: Around 1997, the young jazz bassist Omer Avital seemed ready to be taken very seriously. Given a chance to play regularly at Smalls in the West Village, he had organized an ironclad band, a sextet with four saxophones and no piano. Its music was rugged swing and harmony and texture and sweeping, singable tunes, acoustic jazz full of a reason for being. Mr. Avital is a physical, knockabout player, and the same feeling spread out through his band; the vamps and long solos were worth waiting for, but even the written lines had integrity. He knew how to pare down a melody to the notes that stick. Anyone could understand it.

title: JOHN JASPERSE
description: Mr. Jasperse structured last year's "California" (seen by New Yorkers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music) around a monumental architectural element. In "Prone," above, which opens tonight at the Kitchen, he's gone small. Seating (so to speak) is extremely limited, with audiences splitting time between inflatable mattresses arranged within the dancers' space and chairs set up around the performance area. Lying on their backs, viewers can watch the action unfold as reflected in a mirrored ceiling or rely more on their peripheral vision. The choreographer, always interested in perception and spatial configuration, has experimented with mirrors before; in 2003's "just two dancers" at Dance Theater Workshop, audience members used hand-held mirrors to watch various sections of the dance. Likewise, in "Prone," viewers are expected to become active participants and decision makers, figuring out how best to watch the dancers Luciana Achugar, Levi Gonzalez and Eleanor Hullihan. Don't let those mattresses fool you; Mr. Jasperse demands just as much from his audiences as he does from his dancers. "Prone" is danced to a commissioned score by Zeena Parkins, performed live. Mr. Jasperse is both visual and lighting designer, with Joe Levasseur. If the choreographer's previous works are any indication, all of the artistic elements will more than pull their own weight. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, thekitchen.org, through Dec. 17) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO THE LISTINGS | DEC. 2--DEC. 8

title: New Checks Planned for Illegal Workers and Their Employers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 - Employers in the United States will soon be given a more reliable way to verify the immigration or citizenship status of new hires, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said Thursday. That system will then be followed up with tougher enforcement of immigration laws, he said.

title: DAMIAN MARLEY
description: Bob Marley's youngest son, Damian Marley, 28, has been working at his music career for longer than a minute. His album "Halfway Tree" (Universal) won the 2002 reggae Grammy Award without causing much of a popular stir. But this year Mr. Marley, above, had a big hit with the rueful social critique "Welcome to Jamrock." Absent any trendy braggadocio or bullying electronics, the song is a throbbing throwback to the observational political style of Jamaica's pre-dancehall days. But this retro ploy isn't a sign that the hip-hop-savvy Mr. Marley is stuck in the past. Rather, he has proved to be a step ahead of a game saturated with booty beats and gruff toasters, both righteous and clownish. He saw an opening in reggae for the sort of incantatory agit-prop that would remind people of his country's continuing exploitation at the hands of drug traffickers, opportunistic government sellouts and, of course, hedonistic tourists. The radio and remix crowd ate it up. Its haunting vocal sample, taken from an Ini Kamoze song -- "Out in the streets, they call it murder" -- resonated not only with Jamaican poverty but also with the strife of the disenfranchised, from Iraq to the American South. That pointed, ghostly refrain became the DJ segue of the summer. The song still had traction as the Katrina tragedy unfolded, when another passage seemed to voice the collective frustration of places like the Lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans: "To see the sufferation sicken me/ Them suit no fit me/ To win election they trick we/ And they don't do nuttin' at all." (Mr. Marley plays on a bill with X-Clan. Tomorrow at 9 p.m., Nokia Theater Times Square, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street. Tickets on sale at MTV Store, 1515 Broadway, www.mtv2.com; $2, sold out.)

title: Brazil Congress Expels President's Former Top Aide
description: Jos Dirceu de Oliveira e Silva, President Luiz Incio da Silva's former chief of staff, was expelled from Congress as a result of his role in the corruption scandal that has crippled the government for the past six months. Mr. Dirceu, who returned to Congress in June after resigning as Mr. da Silva's top aide, will now be ineligible to hold elective office until 2016 and is likely to face criminal charges. He was accused of having organized and administered a multimillion-dollar slush fund that secretly financed the election campaigns of members of the governing Workers' Party and paid members of allied parties in Congress to vote for bills the government wanted passed. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABINOWITZ, HARRY
description: RABINOWITZ--Harry, 78. A dedicated family man and pillar of the Jewish community, a man who touched many lives, died on November 30, 2005. Harry lived a life where generosity and giving to others was his main priority. He lived in Merrick, NY, for 39 years, working as a Partner with S.D. Leidesdorf and later Ernst and Young. Harry's passion was supporting Temple Israel in South Merrick (where he served as President), as well as other causes. In addition to helping family and friends, Harry was a consistent donor to charities including UJA and YMHA. Harry was a major fund raiser and a driving force in helping the Plainview YMHA build a community swimming pool. He was founder and President of the United Jewish Y's of Long Island. He was most recently Treasurer of Hudson House in Irvington, New York, and an active member of Temple Beth Abraham in Tarrytown. Harry is survived by his wife of 48 years, Barbara; son, Michael, and wife, Susan; daughter, Risa, and husband, Steven; grandchildren, Sammy, Samantha, Joshua and Rianna; sister, Eve, and husband, Nat; brother, Louis, and wife, Beverly; brother, Joseph, and wife, Selma; and many loving nephews, nieces, cousins and friends. Services will be held Friday, December 2nd, 10:00AM, at Temple Beth Abraham, 25 Leroy Ave., Tarrytown, NY.

title: A Complex Metamorphosis of the Most Fundamental Sort
description: To call Felicity Huffman's performance in "Transamerica" persuasive would be an understatement, as well as somewhat misleading. Her character, Bree (short for Sabrina), is a pre-operative transsexual who lives in a modest bungalow in Los Angeles and in a condition she refers to as "stealth." In other words, though still technically male, Bree passes for a woman, though there is nothing very stealthy about her elaborate, almost theatrical displays of femininity. In her tasteful pink outfits and meticulously applied makeup, she presents an image of womanliness that harks back to an earlier era. Her voice soft and breathy, she avoids cursing and peppers her conversation with Latinate words and foreign phrases.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Guilty Pleas In Police Killings
description: Two members of a drug gang pleaded guilty yesterday to federal racketeering and drug conspiracy charges linked to the murders of two undercover police detectives. The detectives, James Nemorin and Rodney J. Andrews, were shot in the head on March 10, 2003, during an undercover gun purchase on Staten Island. The gang members, Michael Whitten, 22, and Paris Bullock, 23, admitted to taking part in robbing the detectives and acknowledged that they had discussed the possibility that the men might be undercover officers. Under their plea agreements, Mr. Whitten faces a 27-year prison term and Mr. Bullock, who provided the gun used in the shootings, faces a 25-year term. Ronell Wilson, the accused gunman, is scheduled for trial in September and faces the death penalty. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Detectives Reject Contract
description: By a slim margin, New York City detectives rejected the city's offer of a four-year contract and 17 percent pay raise, officials said yesterday. The ballots, which were due by Wednesday, rejected the pact with 1,946 against and 1,835 for the contract, which also included some productivity gains, like extending the workday by 18 minutes and requiring the detectives to practice shooting at the police range on their own time, said Michael J. Palladino, the president of the Detectives Endowment Association. The contract will be renegotiated, and will probably offer a raise of as much as 10 percent over two years and seek approximately 5 percent in productivity gains, Mr. Palladino said.

title: Magic Eludes Miller Again as Reichelt Wins Super-G
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Dec. 1 - Bode Miller's attempt to recreate the racing magic he exhibited at last year's World Cup event in Beaver Creek lasted 38 seconds on the first day of competition Thursday as he missed a gate and skied off the super-G course. Miller, as usual, was skiing the most aggressive line on the steep top portion of the challenging course and paid for it, skidding so wide on a left-to-right turn that he had little chance of recovering to make the next gate.

title: Rail Officials Are Faulted on Crash Investigations
description: The Federal Railroad Administration should stop accepting the word of railroads when they blame drivers for most collisions at grade crossings and should instead do more of its own research into the accidents' causes, the Transportation Department's inspector general said in a report released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, GEORGE
description: HOROWITZ - George. The American Heart Association mourns the passing of our longtime volunteer and New York City board member, George Horowitz. George's unflagging energy and dedication to our mission to save lives from heart disease and stroke will be missed. Our deepest condolences to George's wife, Renee, children, Seth and Robin, his sister, Ruby Edelman and his colleagues at Everlast Worldwide Inc. Gil Bashe, Chairman NYC Board Ralph L. Sacco, M.D. President, NYC Board Michael L. Weamer Executive VP Heritage Affiliate

title: Claes Oldenburg

title: China, Reflected in a Chemical Slick
description: Industrial accidents do not normally make big international news stories, especially when they happen in China, where coal mine disasters and fatal factory fires are all too common occurrences. China, the world's most dynamic economy, is also, regrettably, one of its least effectively regulated, and it seems to have more than its share of unenlightened and corrupt managers. But when a fatal explosion at a state-owned petrochemical plant spewed a 50-mile-long slick of toxic benzene compounds into a major river, forcing a cutoff of the water supply for nearly a week to a city of several million people, the world paid some overdue attention.

title: All work / All Play: A vacation that helps others, too
Little Man
description: In 2002, Nicole Conn, a filmmaker, and her partner, Gwendolyn Baba, chose to have a surrogate mother carry their second child. Because of pre-existing (and undisclosed) health problems, the surrogate was found to have a life-threatening condition at 25 weeks of gestation, and the baby boy was delivered through a Caesarean section, 100 days early. Weighing in at almost exactly one pound and unable to breathe or eat on his own, Nicholas James Baba-Conn seemed doomed to a very short life; his chance for survival was calculated at close to zero.

The White House also expressed deep concerns about the program.

Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Somerset: Man Accused Of Kidnapping
description: Authorities arrested a 34-year-old man yesterday and charged him with kidnapping the wife of his former employer at her home in Bernardsville. Wayne J. Forrest, the Somerset County prosecutor, said that the man, Edgar Rene del Cid-Perez of Bernardsville, abducted Karen Maffucci, 44, bound her with duct tape and drove her to a barn several miles away. When Mr. del Cid-Perez left to make a $1 million ransom demand, prosecutors said, Ms. Maffucci cut the tape from her wrists and escaped. Mr. del Cid-Perez was arrested several hours later. Mr. Forrest said Mr. del Cid-Perez was fired from his landscaping job three months ago and was angry with his former boss, Ms. Maffucci's husband, David. John Holl (NYT)

title: Go Your Own Way
description: Washington - LIFE'S Good." That's the message proclaimed on huge billboards in the Gaza Strip these days -- albeit by an importer of European refrigerators. It was also a message conveyed by last weekend's pictures of Palestinians crossing from Gaza into Egypt, no longer scrutinized by Israeli soldiers.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: United Arab Emirates: Limited First Voting Planned
description: The country's leader, Sheik Khalifa bin Zayed al-Nahyan, announced plans to hold a limited election, an effort to broaden political participation and keep up with reform efforts in other Arab states. The election would be for half of the 40 seats in the Federal National Council, a consultative parliament that advises the government and can approve or veto laws proposed by the cabinet. While 20 members will continue to be appointed by the rulers of the seven emirates that make up the country, the rest will be elected by citizens appointed to electoral councils in each emirate. It was not immediately clear when the election would be held or who would be eligible for the voting councils. Hassan M. Fattah (NYT)

title: One Woman's Awakening, in Double Time
description: TIME doesn't just fly in the exhaustingly eventful world of "The Color Purple," the musical adaptation of the Alice Walker novel and film of the same title that opened last night at the Broadway Theater. It threatens to break the sound barrier. In faithfully adapting Ms. Walker's incident-crammed 1982 Pulitzer Prizewinner about Southern black women finding their inner warriors, the show's creators have fashioned a bright, shiny and muscular storytelling machine that is above all built for speed.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an interview in jail with Allan Cameron, the man charged with killing a New York City police officer, included erroneous information about the gun that the police believe was used in the shooting. It was found in an alley near the apartment of Mr. Cameron's girlfriend, as police officials originally reported. It was not found in her apartment.

title: Corrections

title: Meet David Carr
description: David Carr is a general assignment reporter for the culture section of The New York Times and writes a column for the paper's Monday Business section that focuses on media issues involving print, digital, film, radio and television. Carr fancies himself something of a film fan, in part because he is willing to go to a movie, almost any movie, by himself. Even so, he avoids screenings, because they neither serve nor allow popcorn, an essential substance he prefers in a 55-gallon tub with just a frisson of topping. He thinks that movie theaters should be equipped with flying monkeys that drop out of the ceiling and attack people who insist on talking during films.

title: In Guarded Tones, European Bank Raises Rates for First Time in 5 Years
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 1 - Venturing gingerly onto a path of tighter credit, the European Central Bank on Thursday nudged up its benchmark interest rate by a quarter-point, to 2.25 percent.

title: It's Lonely, at the Top, and a Little Scary, Too
description: The lives of celebrities have become such public fodder that it's a wonder anyone still reaches for the spotlight and all that it brings -- the mass adulation, the slabs of male and female prime, the ready-made retinues and hired sycophants, the designed homes and designer threads, the Autobahn-ready guzzlers and private jets, the best (and always free) seats in the house, and the goody bags stuffed with useless junk and silky unguents that the rest of us can only dream about with stars in our eyes and murder in our hearts.

title: U.K. pushes plan to stop all subsidiesto EU farms
Music From the Holler, the Hood, Havana and the Punk Heart
description: JUNE CARTER CASH "KEEP ON THE SUNNY SIDE: HER LIFE IN MUSIC" (Columbia/Legacy) Long before she was Mrs. Johnny Cash, June Carter was in the Carter Family, whose mountain-rooted songs are pillars of the country repertory. This two-CD collection starts with Ms. Carter and her family in 1939, and ends with a family singalong in 2003. Her tangy voice held a growl that led her at first toward comic songs, often about straying men. She wrote at least one country classic, "Ring of Fire" (with Merle Kilgore). But she was more collaborator than star, releasing only three albums of her own. Carter Family songs are included, 1950's singles, her hit duets with Cash and her entire 1975 album, "Appalachian Pride," her fullest statement about heritage and the present. What's missing is a fuller selection from her later albums; a 1999 version of "Will the Circle Be Unbroken," sung solo to an acoustic guitar, finds the song's mournful essence. JON PARELES

title: Calculus of Consequences

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Miami Approves Condominium Behind Historic Tower
description: Miami commissioners approved a plan to build a 62-story condominium behind the historic Freedom Tower, despite complaints from preservationists that it will eclipse the tower. The tower's owner, Pedro Martin, donated it this week to Miami-Dade College, which will use it for a museum on the Cuban exile experience. Mr. Martin also scrapped a plan to demolish the tower's rear entrance. More than half a million Cuban exiles were processed at the yellow tower in the early years of Fidel Castro's rule. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Execution shows friction between Australia and Singapore
Soothing Survey: Coffeehouses to Cellphones
description: Thirty years ago, Robert Klein received an invitation to perform his increasingly popular brand of stand-up for the fledgling HBO network's first comedy special. Mr. Klein, a Bronx native and Yale drama school dropout, had made his first appearance on "The Tonight Show" in 1968; more than 80 would follow. His fame had grown in the early 70's with the release of his first comedy album, "Child of the 50's," which won a Grammy nomination in 1973 and took its place among the essential furnishings of East Coast college dorm rooms - if not necessarily the ones belonging to the bong-and-fringed-suede set, then those inhabited by professional-class aspirants who wore ribbed turtlenecks and fondly recalled their upstate New York summer camps.

title: Seasonal Offerings of the Tried, the True and the Offbeat
description: NEVER mind the decorations: the holiday season begins when radio stations start slipping Christmas songs onto playlists and record stores deck the shelves with holiday albums. Dozens of musicians release seasonal albums each winter. Their motivations range from piety to careerism, from whim to mission. They bring to the songs the same tangle of seasonal associations their audiences have: reverence, indulgence, family, parties, belonging, loneliness, the comfort of tradition and the chance to fool around. Some write new songs for the occasion, either as novelties or in the hope of creating new perennials; some remake familiar songs, while others dig out obscurities. The albums appear barely longer than poinsettias, though with hopes of becoming part of every Christmas to come.

title: Corrections

Bullets haven't subdued the insurgents in Iraq, but the administration hopes that bullet points will subdue the critics at home.

The opera being rehearsed, Tobias Picker's "American Tragedy," has been in the works for nearly a decade: the Met, in one of its rare bursts of enthusiasm for new opera, commissioned it in 1997, and it will have its premiere tonight. But at this piano rehearsal two weeks before the opening, the party scene wasn't working.

title: 'STANDARD GAUGE: FILM WORKS BY MORGAN FISHER'
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art continues to journey down avant-garde memory lane, with a retrospective devoted to Morgan Fisher. Like the films of Owen Land (a k a George Landow), the subject of a recent museum retrospective, Mr. Fisher's work falls under the rubric of structural film in that it calls attention to its own materiality as well as to the conditions of its production and reception. One significant difference is that like many filmmakers who work in the shadow of Hollywood, the Santa Monica-based Mr. Fisher has long explored the space that segregates art cinema from industrial moviemaking. A film like the one-minute-30 second-long "Wilkinson Household Fire Alarm" (1973), an eye-blink homage to Marcel Duchamp, is more obviously engaged with conceptualism than with studio manufacturing. Yet many more of Mr. Fisher's films explore the divide between art and industry directly, including his autobiographically inflected 1984 short "Standard Gauge," above, in which he traces the history and uses of 35-millimeter film through discarded bits of celluloid and a voice-over that waxes both pedantic and poetic. This dialectical engagement continues in the 2003 short "( )," in which the filmmaker shows his editing skills to bravura effect by stringing together insert shots -- those discrete images of, say, a newspaper headline or a pointed gun that fix your attention on narrative details and actions -- that he has lifted from other movies. Although Mr. Fisher includes clocks and dice in his entrancing cavalcade -- which ebbs and flows like a series of unfinished stories -- what seizes the imagination are all the hands clutching weapons and knees, flying across typewriter keys and cooking and serving. Here, from the detritus of the movie industry, Mr. Fisher has created singularly, authentically handmade art. ("Standard Gauge: Film Works by Morgan Fisher 1968-2003" runs through Feb. 12 at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Kaufman Astoria Studios Film and Video Gallery, second floor, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street; information: (800) 944-8639) MANOHLA DARGIS THE LISTINGS | DEC. 2--DEC. 8

title: A Pair of Brothers Learn How Strong Gravity Can Be
description: It takes about 28 days for the moon to orbit the earth and approximately 60 minutes for "Far Side of the Moon" to reveal its full splendor. Written and directed by Robert Lepage, the French-Canadian stage director, filmmaker and actor, this alternately rewarding and frustrating drama concerns two estranged brothers who, shortly after the death of their mother (Anne-Marie Cadieux), find themselves in each other's gravitational pull. For each brother, the other man represents the far or dark side of the moon, that mysterious and hidden realm so beloved by both progressive rock bands and the metaphorically minded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, WOOD, ELIZABETH JUNE
description: LORD - WOOD -- Elizabeth June, a music lover who dedicated her life to disarmament, peace and justice in the world, died on Tuesday, November 29, 2005, at the Amsterdam House in Manhattan from natural causes after a short illness. She was 83. A native of Glenolden, PA, June graduated from Friends Central School, Wynnewood, PA. After a brief stint in Baltimore, where she studied voice, June came to New York to study and work at Columbia University and to join The Riverside Church community. She was on the staff of Columbia University Library, working in the Departments of Special Collections and Cataloguing until retirement. At Columbia University, she received her Bachelor Degree and M.A. in music. An active member of The Riverside Church, June dedicated her work to the mission of Global Justice and Peace Ministry. June was a most gracious person who is loved by so many and will be deeply missed by all those whose lives she touched. Viewing and Funeral Services will be held at 12:30 PM on Saturday, December 3, at The Riverside Church, Christ Chapel, the entrance from 91 Claremont Avenue, Manhattan. A reception will be held after the Funeral Services at the Tower on the 18th floor. June's body will be cremated. Some of her ashes will repose at the Columbarium of The Riverside Church; some of them will be scattered over Mount Mansfield in Stowe, Vermont, where June spent summers on family estate. Contributions to her memory may be sent to The Riverside Church, Global Justice and Peace Ministry, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, N.Y. 10027.

title: Cutting Off Their Phones
description: I had an interesting email from Sammy, an electrical engineer and naval officer, who suggests that one of the more effective sanctions that could be placed on Sudan would be to cut off satellite telephone service. He notes that everyone in the area uses Thurayas, little phones a bit bigger than cell phones that work off a satellite signal, and adds: It seems possible that Thurayas service to the janjaweed and the government of Sudan may be a critical vulnerability of the genocidal campaign. Interruption of that service might deal a significant blow to their command and control capabilities and save some of the refugees.As the only American shareholder in Thuraya, and the provider of their core technology, Boeing stands in a unique position to influence Thuraya to cut off service to the government of Sudan and the janjaweed militia, as much as possible. I have emailed Boeings Thuraya representative in the U.S. about this as well as Boeings board of directors, but I have received no response.
