description: John Yang, whose photographs of New York's stone faces are on view at the Urban Center, talks about his works and his inspirations. Reviewed by Robin Pogrebin. Produced by Erik Olsen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIESS, ANNELIESE, PH.D.
description: RIESS--Anneliese, Ph.D. On December 1, 2005. Loving sister of Elsa and sister-in-law of Ruth. She will be profoundly missed.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Annan Cancels Trip Over Budget
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan canceled a two-week trip to Asia because of a looming impasse over a United States proposal to delay approval of the usual two-year budget and replace it with a four-month interim budget to push through reforms. Telling a staff meeting that the action would produce a "financial crunch," he said, "We should not take any initiative that will not only risk the reform, but also the ongoing activities, and that's one of the reasons I decided to stay here." Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Medicare Balks at Covering Johnson Heart Drug in Some Cases
description: The bad news continued yesterday for Johnson & Johnson's heart-failure drug Natrecor, with the Medicare program announcing that it wants to stop paying for the product's use in some patients.

title: HealthSouth Files 2004 Results With S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - HealthSouth, the troubled outpatient health care provider, filed its long-awaited annual report for 2004 with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

title: With Merger, a New York Studio May Finally Get a Hollywood Ending
description: Culver Studios of California, where "Gone With the Wind" and "Citizen Kane" were filmed, is in discussions with Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens over a deal that would join the two historic production houses.

title: Yes, the Military Needs Bodies. But Hold the Bodywork.
description: Correction Appended

title: Leak Ruling Has Mystery, 8 Blank Pages
description: There are eight blank pages in the public version of a decision the federal appeals court in Washington issued in February. The decision ordered two reporters to be jailed unless they agreed to testify before a grand jury investigating the disclosure of the identity of a C.I.A. operative, Valerie Wilson. What is in those pages is one of the enduring mysteries in the investigation.

title: At Norway Festival, a Duet Inspired by a Mythic Gaze
description: Norway in New York, a festival of Norwegian dance and theater, opened its season at Performance Space 122 with a striking yet inconsistent duet choreographed by Ina Christel Johannessen of zero visibility corp. Before the start of "...it's only a rehearsal" on Thursday, Dimitri Jourde and Line Tormoen chatted softly and greeted audience members with warm smiles. But for the most part, they just stared.

title: Sure, He Was Smart, but Was He Happy?
description: Among the early scenes in "Da Vinci & the Code He Lived By," a documentary tomorrow night on the History Channel, is the image of a small Leonardo, perhaps about 5, playing in a brook, wearing a little Robin Hood suit. He is toying with an object that looks a bit like a miniature Ferris wheel -- maybe it will turn out that he invented Great Adventure, too -- as the voice of his peasant mother calls him home.

title: Democrats Sense Chances in Ohio for 2006 Vote
description: UPPER ARLINGTON, Ohio., Dec. 1 - Democrats are hard to find in this upscale Columbus suburb, home to Representative Deborah Pryce, the highest-ranking Republican woman in the House. Yet Democrats now think they can do the unthinkable: unseat Ms. Pryce in 2006.

title: Ring Tones to the Rescue
description: TECHNOLOGY, which has clearly hurt music industry sales by offering the ability to burn copies of CD's and swap music files online, is coming to its aid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIENSTOCK, MARTIN
description: BIENSTOCK - Martin. Be loved husband of the late Doris. Devoted father of Andrew and Michael. Loving companion of Nathalie Fisher. Services Sunday 11:30 A.M. atGramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave., (near East 10th St.), NYC.

title: Bush's Slipping Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Halls Will Share Theaters and Funds
description: Carnegie Hall and City Center, separated by a strip of West 56th Street, announced a partnership yesterday that will lead to a $150 million fund-raising effort to renovate City Center, and give Carnegie Hall's increasingly ambitious programmers access to a dance and theater space.

title: Nominee Says His Views on Abortion Would Not Affect His Decisions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - Seeking to tamp down a furor over his views on abortion rights, the Supreme Court nominee Samuel A. Alito Jr. told the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Friday that his "personal views on a woman's right to choose" would not affect his judicial decisions, even as liberal groups ratcheted up their attacks on Judge Alito's credibility.

title: INSIDE
description: Football Revival at West Point After bottoming out in football, Army is trying to revive its athletic programs. Cadets waited to watch the team practice at West Point for today's game against Navy in Philadelphia. PAGE D1

title: Police Raid Raises Fears of Bosnia as Haven for Terrorists
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina - A recent police raid on an apartment near this city's airport uncovered evidence of an imminent suicide bombing, intensifying the fears of Western security services that Bosnia is becoming a haven for Islamic militants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCMAHON, REV. GEORGE J., S.J.
description: McMAHON--Rev. George J., S.J. Beloved brother of Joseph. Dear uncle of Ken & Jerry McMahon. Cherished friend of many. Mass of Christian Burial at the Fordham University Church, Saturday at 10 AM. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc, Directors 718-654-0500.

title: Army's Newest Mission: Operation Win
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 2 - They are building a sports fortress on the high ground of the Army campus along the Hudson River, much of it for football. Two new buildings -- large, serious-looking structures -- have risen next to the old stadium like big blockers in a pass pocket.

title: Sleek Entrance for El Museo del Barrio
description: It is somehow fitting that El Museo del Barrio has made its home for the last 28 years in a former orphanage on Fifth Avenue in East Harlem. When the museum was founded in the neighborhood in 1969 by a group of artists, teachers and political organizers, its mission was to serve as a home for Puerto Rican art, a cultural orphan in the mainstream museum world in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HECTOR, LOUIS
description: HECTOR--Louis. The Board of Directors of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center notes with sadness the passing of Louis Hector, a longstanding board member and board member emeritus. An elegant and sophisticated man, he loved his Sunday afternoon chamber music concerts and was a loyal and generous patron. The broad experience he brought to our organization from the worlds of business and culture made him a wise and valued colleague, and we will miss him. Peter Frelinghuysen Chairman Donaldson C. Pillsbury Vice-Chairman The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center

title: A Cellphone Just Made to Be Run Over by a Porsche
description: I DROPPED down on all fours and crawled across Denise Salomon's loose-gravel driveway, clutching a Styrofoam pad and one of the world's most expensive cellphones -- a $5,700 Vertu Ascent Motorsport.

title: Police Searches in the Subways Are Upheld
description: Citing a "real and substantial" threat of a terrorist bombing in New York's subways, a federal judge ruled yesterday that random police searches of passengers' bags and backpacks were constitutional because they were effective in helping to prevent an attack.

title: Imported Brains
description: On one side, there's the risk: one of the plotters in the first World Trade Center bombing was on a student visa. On the other, there's the benefit: last year, 565,039 foreign students contributed about $13.3 billion to the United States economy.

title: The Annual Gratuity Guilt Trip
description: TO tip or not to tip -- and whom to tip and how much? These questions get sticky during the holiday season, when the spirit of giving, or at least tipping, becomes fraught with anxiety, guilt and pressure.

title: Blues Sass With a Broadway Sheen
description: "I've got a lot of family here tonight, being a daughter of Broadway," Bonnie Raitt said at her show at the Beacon Theater on Thursday. Between the songs, the famously flame-haired blues-pop singer and slide guitarist invoked her father, the Broadway singer John Raitt, and her musician mother, Marge Goddard, who both died in the past year.

title: Bush Did Not Mention Attacks in Rose Garden Appearance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - As he went before the cameras in the Rose Garden on Friday morning, President Bush was aware of bad news that had not yet been made public: that 10 marines had been killed by a bomb in Iraq. But he made no mention of the attack, sticking to the sunny White Houses message of the day that the economy is strong and the outlook "as bright as it's been in a long time."

title: Wal-Mart and the Social Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: Image Isn't Everything
description: Here are the most notable transactions from each of the last five winter meetings. Often, the more obscure moves have produced the most impressive results.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: 5 Leading Columnists Face Prison
description: An Istanbul prosecutor filed charges against five prominent newspaper columnists who had criticized court rulings that tried to block an academic conference on the Armenian genocide, its first public discussion in Turkey. The conference, blocked by a court in May and again in September, was held on Sept. 24 after organizers changed its location. The journalists, Ismet Berkan, Murat Belge and Haluk Sahin of the liberal newspaper Radikal, and Hasan Cemal and Erol Katircioglu of the center-right newspaper Milliyet, were charged with "influencing judicial procedures" and "publicly insulting members of the judiciary." They face up to 10 years in prison. A court hearing is expected on Feb. 7. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: Remorseful or Not, Buyers Start to Return to Japanese Real Estate
description: IN the United States, there is talk about real estate bubbles. In Japan, there is knowledge, and plenty of it, about what happens after one pops.

title: Push to Loosen Abortion Laws in Latin America
description: PAMPLONA, Colombia - In this tradition-bound Roman Catholic town one day in April, two young women did what many here consider unthinkable: pregnant and scared, they took a cheap ulcer medication known to induce abortions. When the drug left them bleeding, they were treated at a local emergency room -- then promptly arrested.

title: World Briefing: Europe, Middle East, Asia, Africa, United Nations
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the New York City Council's decision to revoke landmark status for the Austin, Nichols warehouse in Brooklyn misstated the number of times the council has revoked such a designation. This was the fifth time it had done so in 15 years, not the fourth.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: U.N. To Discuss Human Rights
description: The United Nations Security Council agreed unanimously to an American request to discuss human rights in Myanmar, where the military junta has just extended the house arrest of the opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, left. The agreement fell short of placing the issue on the Council's formal agenda for follow-up action, but it called for a closed-door briefing of the 15 members arranged by Secretary General Kofi Annan. The move followed a report from an Asian human rights group, the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners, accusing the Burmese military of "brutal and systematic" abuse and torture of political prisoners. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Antimissile System Tested
description: Israel conducted a successful test of its Arrow missile defense system, shooting down an incoming missile intended to simulate Iran's long-range Shahab-3.

title: Stars in Los Angeles Belong to U.S.C. and U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 - Each summer, University of Southern California Coach Pete Carroll gives a speech in the Trojans' locker room.

title: Greenspan Points to Danger of Rising Budget Deficits
description: LONDON, Dec. 2 - Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned of the dangers of rising budget and trade deficits in two speeches on Friday.

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Arts, Briefly; A Tie in TV Sweeps
description: Depending on which network you listen to, either CBS and ABC tied for first among adults 18 to 49 for the November sweeps period, or CBS won outright. CBS announced on Thursday that it was ahead of ABC by 16,000 viewers in that demographic. Regardless, in ratings points it was a tie, and it represented ABC's first No. 1 finish in the 18-to-49 demographic since May 2000. NBC was third in that age group, and Fox, which is counting the days until "American Idol" returns next month, finished fourth. On Thursday, with sweeps over, the networks rolled out plenty of repeats. The night's winner, according to Nielsen's estimates, was CBS, as usual. Its "CSI" (23.02 million) and "Without a Trace" (15.3 million) were both reruns, but "Survivor" was new (19.8 million). Nearing its season finale, "Survivor" drew its highest 18-to-49 rating for this season. Stephenie LaGrossa, a popular contestant from the previous season of the show who was brought back to play again, made it to the final five.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'In My Life' to Close
description: "In My Life," the surreal and severely criticized new Broadway musical written, directed and produced by Joe Brooks, will close on Dec. 11 at a loss of more than $8 million. The show, which tells the story of a singer with a case of Tourette's syndrome, a phobic Village Voice reporter and the effeminate angel who brings them together, received some of the worst reviews of the year. Nevertheless, Mr. Brooks, who made a fortune writing advertising jingles and the ballad "You Light Up My Life," plowed $1.5 million into television spots and other advertising to try to save the show; it did not work for long. Last week, the show played to less than 30 percent of its capacity at the Music Box Theater. At the scheduled closing, "In My Life" will have played 23 previews and 61 performances. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUGHES, PATRICIA E.
description: HUGHES--Patricia E. On November 30, 2005. Beloved daughter of Veronica and the late William. Loving sister of Mary Ann Lovetro, William Jr. and Veronica DiVerniero. Cherished aunt of Anthony, Denise, William, Kristyn, Michael, Richard, Lauren and Irene. Great-aunt of sixteen great-nieces and nephews. Dearest friend of Lynn, and also survived by numerous loving family members, friends and colleagues. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, Inc, 325 W. 14 St, New York City Saturday 7-9PM & Sunday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10AM St Veronica's Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about suicide bombings directed at the judicial system in Bangladesh misstated the country's population. It is 144 million, not 44 million. In some editions, the article also misstated the number of people wounded in the suicide bombing on Thursday. It was 30 people, not 100, which was the total number wounded in three suicide bombings this week. (Go to Article)

title: Judge Alito and Abortion
description: Judge Samuel Alito Jr., President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, promised yesterday that his personal views would not be a factor in how he approached abortion cases. The trouble is that there is mounting evidence that Judge Alito has been hoping for years to overturn Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision recognizing women's abortion rights. His attempts to explain away his record of insisting that the Constitution does not protect abortion are becoming more tortured, and harder to believe.

title: General Says Militias Split Loyalties of Iraqi Security Forces
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 2 - The American commander overseeing the building of Iraq's security forces asserted Friday that many units had made impressive strides in the past year, but he acknowledged that the training of the Iraqi police was complicated by the armed militias still claiming the loyalties of many officers.

title: Struggling NYRA Kept From Selling Paintings
description: The 19 paintings that the New York Racing Association had hoped to auction off yesterday to temporarily halt a cash-flow crisis will soon be heading back to it.

title: Judge Facing Removal Seeks Paid Suspension
description: A justice of the State Supreme Court in Queens who is facing removal from the bench notified New York State's highest court yesterday that she would appeal to keep her job. But in a highly unusual move, the judge, Justice Laura D. Blackburne, asked the court to suspend her with pay during the proceedings.

title: Father Knew Best
description: Minneapolis - IN a recent article in The New Yorker, Brent Scowcroft, a close friend of and former national security adviser to President George H. W. Bush, sharply criticized the current administration and, in all but name, its leader, President George W. Bush. That set tongues wagging anew about filial relations in the Bush family, which had earlier been brought into sharp relief in the book "Plan of Attack," by Bob Woodward. Asked by Mr. Woodward if he had discussed Iraq with his father, the younger Bush said: "You know, he is the wrong father to appeal to in terms of strength. There is a higher father that I appeal to."

title: Democracy in Ethiopia
description: To the Editor:

title: Beethoven Provides a Rousing Finale
description: There was no question what the big event was at the Orchestra of St. Luke's concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night: Beethoven's Violin Concerto, played by Joshua Bell, with Donald Runnicles and the orchestra providing robust accompaniment. The concerto, traditionally the pre-intermission crowd pleaser in a classical concert, was placed at the end of the evening to give fans a true sense of climax, and it did. But although it was the best part of the program, it was none too good.

title: Teams May Play Let's Make A Deal
description: The winter meetings are intended to be the perfect gathering place for all 30 teams to try to sign players, acquire players and conduct crucial off-season business. But it may feel as if the calendar has gone awry when the meetings begin in Dallas on Monday, because some splashy maneuvering has already been completed.

title: Learning Not to Believe What You're Seeing
description: A mirror is the first object the naked Miguel Gutierrez brings onstage in his new solo "Retrospective Exhibitionist." He issues a seemingly simple command: "Repeat after me: 'I am Miguel Gutierrez.' "

title: Lineman Got Out When the Getting Was Good
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 2 - Kareem McKenzie has never wondered how life would have been had he re-signed with the Jets instead of joining the Giants in the off-season.

title: Just When Consumers Feel Confident ... Wham
description: MURKY, often conflicting signals about the holiday shopping season and gyrating energy prices drained some of the fun out of good news about the economy and consumer confidence this week.

title: National Briefs
description: MIDWEST

title: Corrections
description: Two pictures in The Arts on Thursday with an article about the making of the film "Bobby," about Robert F. Kennedy, carried erroneous credits. The pictures, of Elijah Wood and Lindsay Lohan, and of Emilio Estevez, were by Sam Emerson/Bold Films.

title: Pirro Won't Give Up Senate Bid (Well, at Least Not 'Right Now')
description: As if the sun were finally shining upon her, Jeanine F. Pirro strode coatless onto a chilly Manhattan sidewalk yesterday and declared to reporters that her campaign to unseat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was "going extremely well," and she was in it to win it.

description: GROSSMAN--Gilbert K. 12/27/11. Beloved and much missed husband, father and grandfather. Lil

title: Scissors Ban On Airplanes Will Be Lifted Despite Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - Rejecting criticism from some flight attendants, air marshals and victims of the September 2001 attacks, the Transportation Security Administration moved ahead on Friday with plans to lift the ban on carrying some scissors and tools aboard airplanes.

title: Mexico Agents Kidnapped 4, Prosecutor Says
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Dec. 2 - Federal agents from Mexico's elite antidrug force were involved in the kidnapping and torture of four assassins linked to a drug cartel who appeared in a grisly video that ended with the murder of at least one of them, according to a senior Mexican federal prosecutor.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mozart Composes, Then Plays a Role
description: A few years back, Kristjan Jarvi, the dynamic young Estonian-born conductor with a passion for hip contemporary music in all styles (complex modernism, jazz, funk, you name it), was drawing loudly enthusiastic and youngish audiences to his bracing New York concerts with the Absolute Ensemble, the group he had founded in 1993. But more recently, Mr. Jarvi's commitments in Europe, where he is the chief conductor of the Tonknstler Orchestra of Vienna, have kept him mostly abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKALET, JOSEPH
description: SKALET--Joseph, on November 30, 2005, age 95. Husband of the late Lucile (nee Adels), father of Steven (wife Linda) Skalet and Barbara Strutin. Brother of Helen Stein and the late Philip Skalet, grandfather of four, great-grandfather of two and devoted companion of Beverly Green. Service Sunday 11:30AM at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck. Interment Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Cornell Mayer, 83, Pioneer in the Study of the Planets, Dies
description: Cornell H. Mayer, a pioneer in radio astronomy who found the first signs of searingly hot temperatures on the surface of Venus, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 83.

title: Saturday's Top Games
description: No. 2 Texas (11-0) vs. Colorado (7-4) Big 12 Championship, Houston, 1 p.m., ABC

title: Mixed Feelings, Clear Result
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Dec. 2 - If two years is enough to establish N.B.A. residency, then two and a half hours was easily enough for Larry Brown to become horribly homesick Friday night.

title: A Carnival of Art, Money, Surf and Sand
description: MIAMI, Dec. 2 - Miami the first week in December is something like an opening of the Venice Biennale without the biennale, a decentralized sprawling mass of excitement and display, plus lots of disposable wealth. It is the art world's version of Mardi Gras, and not surprisingly, the word carnival is ubiquitous in conversation.

title: The Need for Speed Binds a Pair of Opposites
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Dec. 2 - They have always been an unusual pair, Daron Rahlves and Bode Miller. Rahlves is blond and boyish, a native Californian who is tranquil by nature. Miller is dark-haired and wary, a son of the idiosyncratic New Hampshire hill country.

title: What Good Is Sitting Alone Killing Fiends?
description: More than once, playing Microsoft's new Xbox 360 has made me remember what it's like trying to bicycle down a steep road slick with water and maybe even an ice patch or two.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the growth in the number of young children in Manhattan misidentified the neighborhood of Citibabes, a club for children and their parents. The club is in SoHo, not TriBeCa.

title: Arts, Briefly; Russian Art Sets Records in London
description: Sales of Russian art set records at London auctions this week in what is becoming a new tradition as wealthy Russians buy homes in London and stock up on art. Sotheby's racked up sales of $38.4 million on Thursday. Ivan Aivazovsky, a 19th-century painter of moody seascapes, was a favorite, as usual, but the highest price for a painting was nearly $3.7 million for a work by Ilya Mashkov of the fashionable Bubnovy Valet ("Jack of Diamonds") school of Czanne-inspired artists in the years before the Bolshevik Revolution. At Christie's earlier in the week, the Russian sales totaled $37.7 million, which the house described as "the highest combined sales total ever achieved for Russian pictures and works of art." World auction records were set for six 19th- and early-20th-century artists, nine of whose pieces sold for more than $1 million. Other sales included a soup plate from the Imperial Porcelain Factory for $113,000, above, and a Soviet propaganda porcelain plate for nearly $245,000. With the growing success of the Russian sales, other auction houses have jumped in; Bonhams held its first Russian auctions, which totaled nearly $3.3 million.

title: North Carolina Man Is 1,000th Person Executed Since 1976
description: A North Carolina man who said he did not want to be remembered as a number has become the 1,000th person executed in the United States since the death penalty was reinstated in 1976.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about two men who have opened cultural institutions in their homes in Manhattan misspelled the surname of a hip-hop artist who attended the dual opening night, and rendered another part of his name incorrectly. He is Fab 5 Freddy Brathwaite, not Fab Five Freddy Braithwaite.

title: Bomb Threats Force Closing of Courts in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 2 - A series of bomb threats prompted the evacuation of about 50 state court buildings across Connecticut on Friday, halting judicial hearings and sending workers home so investigators and bomb-sniffing dogs could sweep every building, the authorities said.

description: Should Aslan, the lion Christ-figure at the center of "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe," really be a donkey?

title: Dire Wounds, a New Face, a Glimpse in a Mirror
description: LYON, France, Dec. 2 - The world's first person to wear a new face awoke Monday, 24 hours after her operation in the northern city of Amiens, and looked in the mirror.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT?
description: 8 P.M. (WE) CHARLES & CAMILLA: WHATEVER LOVE MEANS -- And so it begins for the middle-aged, proudly dowdy Duchess of Cornwall, the former Camilla Parker Bowles. She has already been named Barbara Walters's most fascinating person of 2005. Now she may know the agonies of less than brilliant television movies suffered by her husband's first wife. This one (starring Laurence Fox and Olivia Poulet, above) begins in 1970, when the young Camilla and Prince Charles first met, and ends on the morning of his wedding to Lady Diana Spencer.

title: Eyeballs Are Back, or Maybe Not
description: THE blog pioneer Jason Calacanis, who sold his Weblogs Inc. to America Online in October, took exception this week to an article in Business 2.0 by Om Malik, a technology journalist and blogger.

title: Bartok and Rachmaninoff, Distinct in Their Orbits
description: Bartok and Rachmaninoff make a curious pairing. They were born only eight years apart, but they often seem to have lived in completely different centuries. Bartok could write hauntingly, even violently modernistic music. Rachmaninoff basked in the great 19th-century Romantic tradition, even as he lived into an era of two world wars, dying in 1943. "I feel like a ghost wandering in a world grown alien," he confessed in later life. "I cannot cast out the old way of writing, and I cannot acquire the new."

title: U.S. Propaganda In the Iraqi Press
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Workers' Union Leader Refuses to Rule Out Subway Strike
description: The president of the union that represents New York City's subway and bus workers refused yesterday to rule out a strike later this month as he rejected most of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's contract demands.

title: A Young Man With a Future Has It Wrested From Him
description: The shooting of a 21-year-old man on a Brooklyn street in early September went largely unnoted.

title: A Violin Doctor in Sync With the Strings
description: PARIS - IT was the 1980's and the virtuoso violinist Yehudi Menuhin was performing at the Salle Pleyel in Paris. "He played an encore, and I'm sitting in the orchestra and I said to my wife, 'Something happened to his violin,' said tienne Vatelot, one of the world's great violin restorers, warming to the story.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 10 about Guatemalan villagers trying to dig out bodies of people killed in a mudslide in an area hit by rainstorms from Hurricane Stan incorrectly described an episode in 1990 in which troops killed people in the village, Panabj. The villagers were killed when troops fired into a crowd of protesters, and reports at the time said there were as many as 13 dead. They were not farmers suspected of being guerrillas. A reader reported the error at the time, but his e-mail message was misdirected at The Times.

title: U.S. Propaganda in the Iraqi Press (3 Letters)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Parliament Outlaws Criticism
description: Parliament approved legislation to make it a crime to organize protests, join banned organizations or speak against the national interest. President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, who is running for a third term next year, submitted the legislation last week, calling for its urgent passage in the wake of popular uprisings in Georgia, Ukraine and Kyrgyzstan. The legislation would impose prison sentences of up to three years for anyone convicted of advocating the overthrow of the government and up to two years for "discrediting the country." An opposition leader, Anatoly V. Lebedko, compared the legislation to repressive Soviet-era laws. "These actions show that Lukashenko knows he cannot win the election honestly," he said in an interview. The European Union and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe denounced the legislation as a threat to political opposition and civil society. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: The Pentagon's Vanity Press
description: Now that the Pentagon has been outed for planting articles in Iraqi newspapers, we're faced with one of the easiest questions of the year: Is it proper for the government to manipulate public opinion through self-serving, one-sided journalism?

title: Acting Head Named for Auditing Board
description: Willis D. Gradison Jr. was named acting chairman of the auditing oversight board yesterday as the Securities and Exchange Commission outlined how it planned to select a permanent chairman and fill future openings on the panel.

title: Commentator Acquitted in Fraud Trial
description: Courtney D. Smith, a financial commentator who was accused of failing to disclose payments by the now-defunct GenesisIntermedia to promote the company's stock, was acquitted by a federal jury.

title: Judge Clears Way for City to Sue Gun Companies
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that New York City's lawsuit against gun manufacturers and distributors can go forward, despite new federal legislation devised to protect gun makers from such lawsuits.

title: Play It Close to the Muzzle and Paws on the Table
description: Cassius Marcellus Coolidge, the wry commercial artist who gave us dogs playing poker, was born in upstate New York in 1844 to abolitionist Quaker farmers, who named him after one of the most eloquent antislavery politicians of the antebellum South, the Kentucky senator Cassius Marcellus Clay. Ninety-eight years later another great son of the Bluegrass State -- the greatest of all time, it's been said, and one whose ancestors may have been owned by Clay's slave-holding brother Henry -- would be named for him, too, for a spell.

title: Local Rivalry Has the Nation's Attention
description: LOS ANGELES - THE focal point of college football today is in Hollywood -- not in Houston, where Texas plays Colorado; not in Atlanta, where Louisiana State plays Georgia. The center of the college football universe is Los Angeles, where a unique local rivalry between Southern California and U.C.L.A. has become a fascinating national game.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Party Barred From Moscow Vote
description: The Supreme Court barred candidates of the nationalist party Motherland from tomorrow's election for the Moscow legislature because of a campaign ad that likened migrants from the Caucasus to trash. The ruling upheld a lower-court ruling on a complaint from a rival nationalist party, the Liberal Democratic Party, that accused Motherland of inciting ethnic tension. Alexander Nurnberg (NYT)

title: Back in Town, Embracing Everything (Just About)
description: Karole Armitage is home at last. This is a good thing: her new, hourlong dance, "in this dream that dogs me," which will be at the Duke Theater until Dec. 18, is a winner. Even more exciting will be to see what impact Ms. Armitage can now have on dance in this country.

title: In Debate Over Safety, No Neutral Corner
description: In the last decade, Dr. Margaret Goodman, a neurologist in Las Vegas, has developed a reputation as one of the most aggressive ringside doctors in the country. Boxing promoters have criticized her for stopping fights too soon, while fellow regulators have praised her efforts to make an inherently violent sport safer.

title: Declarer Sees a Cold Wind Blow From the East
description: At the American Contract Bridge League's Fall North American Championships in Denver, three major titles were decided on the final day, last Sunday. Today we look at the Bill Keohane North American Swiss Teams. (Thursday's column covered the Reisinger Board-a-Match teams.)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Leader Calls Bail-Jumper 'Shameful'
description: Speaking publicly for the first time on the graft scandal that has engulfed the oil-rich state of Bayelsa since its governor, Diepreye Alamieyeseigha, left, jumped bail in London last month and, dressed as a woman, fled money-laundering charges, President Olusegun Obasanjo said the governor's conduct was "shameful" and condemned the crowds that gathered to cheer him. Mr. Alamieyeseigha, accused of stealing millions of dollars from the state treasury, was expelled from the president's party this week. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: The Mayor Who Ran, Ran and Ran
description: THE mayor of Central Park lives in an S.R.O. on the Upper West Side. His one room has an unkempt bed, two small dressers that belong on the curb, lumps of clothes on the worn carpet, and a rusted hotplate that he means to throw out. The telephone permits him to dial only 911.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the death of a Queens man who was pushed into the path of an oncoming No. 7 subway train misstated the weight of each of the train's 11 cars in some copies. It is about 74,000 pounds, not almost 37,000 pounds (which is the weight of the car's undercarriage).

title: The Neediest Cases; After Mother Dies, Siblings Look to Older Brother as Parent
description: There are 29-year-old boys, and there are 29-year-old men. The difference between them is a source of anxiety for many teenagers on the streets of New York City, where machismo and manhood are often confused. For them, "What makes a man?" is not an awkward philosophical question; it's a genuine concern.

title: Sale Alters the Media Balance in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 2 - The Canadian telecommunications company BCE ended its foray into the media business Friday, selling most of its stake in Bell Globemedia, owner of Canada's largest private television broadcaster and The Globe and Mail newspaper.

title: Little Surprise at Redistricting Document From Democrats Who Lost 2004 Race
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 2 - It was too late for him, "but it's never too late to have the truth come out," said Charles W. Stenholm, the former Democratic representative from West Texas whose 26-year career in the House fell to the Republican Congressional redistricting of 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOEB, JANET
description: LOEB--Janet. Died on December 1, 2005. Janet was a teacher, publicist and journalist. She had a long and active life. Survivors are her brother Lawrence E. White, his wife Clarice, nephews and nieces and grandnephews. Services will be at Riverside Chapel at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Sunday, December 4, 2005 at 9:45AM. Burial will be at Cedar Park Cemetery, Forest Ave, Paramus, N.J.

title: A Tree-Lighting Tinged With Sadder Ceremony
description: They will light the lights on Park Avenue tomorrow evening, in the familiar, cheery annual public ceremony that has been a staple of the holiday season for 60 years. The children's choir will be 40 voices strong. Some 5,000 onlookers are expected, and carols will be sung.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GANSBERG, AGATHA, 80, NEE MILLER
description: GANSBERG--Agatha, 80, nee Miller, of Rutherford, NJ, on Thursday, December 1st. She was born in Passaic, NJ, lived in Paris, France, then moved back to Passaic, before settling in Rutherford, NJ, 30 years ago. She graduated the University of Michigan in 1946, receiving her Bachelor of Science in Psychology. She was a housewife, a 30-year volunteer at the Y.M. and Y.W.H.A. in Clifton, NJ, the Past President of the #

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Thursday about the arrest of a police detective on sexual abuse charges misstated the sex of the victim in some copies. It was a boy, not a girl, as law enforcement authorities first reported.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Anemia Drugs Pose Risk
description: Three popular drugs for anemia may damage red blood cells in rare cases, the Food and Drug Administration said. Their manufacturers, Johnson & Johnson and Amgen, have notified doctors that the drugs -- Aranesp, Epogen and Procrit -- should be discontinued if patients develop the bone-marrow disorder known as pure red-cell aplasia, in which the body fails to make new red blood cells. The three drugs, called erythropoietins, are used to treat anemia in cancer and kidney dialysis patients.

title: Senate Panel to Review American U. Board's Actions on Spending
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee said yesterday that he would investigate whether board members of American University acted properly in handling accusations about spending by the university's former president and his $3.7 million severance package.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, MARILYN (MINDY)
description: STERN -- Marilyn (Mindy). Succumbed to cancer December 1st. She will be missed by her husband Lou, sons Mike, Dave and Jon, brothers Abe and Alvin Bober, and her friends at the Summit and Randolph YMCA's, and at the bridge table. Mindy supported organizations involved with educating children and equal justice and opportunity for all people. Donations may be made to The American Cancer Society. The funeral will be on Sunday, December 4, 2:30 P.M. at Temple Shalom, 215 South Hillside Ave., Succasunna, NJ. For information please call: 973-422-0600.

title: Gains in City Schools
description: As the nation's largest school system -- with about 1.1 million students -- New York City schools are often seen as the proxy for public education in general, especially when it comes to the question of whether the public schools can do better by impoverished and minority children, who often arrive poorly prepared to learn.

title: U.S. Goals for Iraqi Forces Meet Success and Challenges in Najaf
description: NAJAF, Iraq, Dec. 1 - On the palm-lined avenues leading into this Shiite holy city and among the twisting alleyways at its center, next to the golden-domed Shrine of Ali, police officers with Kalashnikovs patrol where American troops once fought two fierce rebellions led by Moktada al-Sadr, the militant cleric.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on June 13 about Americans attending the Paris Air Show this year after shunning it in 2004 misstated the date of the first such show. It was 1909, not 46 years ago. A reader pointed out the error in June, but the notice was misdirected at The Times.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Calpine Given Deadline to Restore Funds to Bondholders A Delaware judge yesterday gave the Calpine Corporation until Jan. 22 to put $313.6 million in proceeds from the sale of its natural gas supplies back into an escrow account. Judge Leo E. Strine Jr. of Chancery Court rejected Calpine's offer to restore $199 million to the account within 90 days and ordered the company to come up with all of the $313 million, plus interest. He also refused a request by trustees for the bondholders to restore the money sooner. Judge Strine ruled last month that the company's use of the proceeds of asset sales to buy gas ran afoul of agreements with noteholders. (AP)

title: Jobs Surged Last Month in Rebound From Storm
description: The nation's employers added 215,000 jobs last month, the government reported yesterday, as the economy rebounded from the devastating impact of Hurricane Katrina.

title: The Knockout Punch Heard Round the World
description: Beyond Glory Joe Louis vs. Max Schmeling, and a World on the Brink By David Margolick Illustrated. 423 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

title: Corrections
description: A credits listing on Thursday with a television review of "Pope John Paul II," on CBS misspelled the surname of a producer and an executive producer. They are Luca and Matilde Bernabei, not Benabei.

title: Singles Matches Leave Slovakia and Croatia Tied in Davis Cup Final
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia, Dec. 2 - On a day when the flag-waving and noise making were unusually evenhanded for a Davis Cup final, it seemed fitting that Croatia's and Slovakia's tennis teams ended up even, too.

title: Year-Round Resident Elected Mayor of New Village on Eastern L.I.
description: SAGAPONACK, N.Y., Dec. 2 - When residents of this hamlet in Southampton Town voted overwhelmingly on Sept. 2 to incorporate the first new village in New York State in seven years, they won control over Sagaponack's future and ended any chance that wealthy oceanfront homeowners would create their own local government here.

title: Bush's Slipping Support
description: To the Editor:

title: After Gordon Departs, Yanks Land Farnsworth
description: All along, the Yankees told Tom Gordon that they would not give him a three-year contract. Gordon is 38 years old, and no matter how well he handled his role as the setup man for Mariano Rivera the last two seasons, the Yankees were not comfortable paying him into his 40's.

title: The Dead's Gamble: Free Music for Sale
description: The Dead did a quick turnabout -- call it a half-step uptown toodleloo -- this week. First, band representatives told the Live Music Archive, at www.archive.org, which includes countless jam-band concerts in its repository of freely downloadable music, to stop making available its trove of live Grateful Dead recordings, which have been free online for years. Grateful Dead Merchandising (www.gdstore.com) now sells downloads of the band's own concert recordings, and didn't want free competition.

title: Iraq Fixer, No Exp. Needed, $1B-up
description: Anyone who caught a glimpse of President Bush's speech on Iraq this week -- delivered from an elaborately decorated stage confidently plastered with "Plan for Victory" placards -- may have thought the administration believes that a detailed victory plan is in place. But there's still work to be done, especially if you're in the business of blue-sky consulting.

title: Torture Is 'Widespread' in China, U.N. Investigator Says
description: BEIJING, Dec. 2 - A high-level United Nations investigator condemned the "widespread" use of torture in Chinese law enforcement and said Beijing must overhaul its criminal laws, grant more power to judges and abolish labor camps before it can end such abuses, according to a summary of his findings released Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEITNER, SYLVIA TZIPPY
description: LEITNER--Sylvia Tzippy. In 1940 I was blessed with a beautiful bride. Children and grandchildren made us thrive. In 1989 came the accident and you did not survive. Today only precious memories remain like an antidote for my loss and pain. With love, Nat

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Hip-Hop Producers Get Acquittal, Then Hugs, From Jurors
description: A federal jury acquitted the hip-hop impresario Irv Gotti and his brother of money-laundering charges late yesterday, prompting jubilant cheers and pandemonium in the packed courtroom in Brooklyn. The verdict ended a three-year ordeal for the two men and dealt a stunning blow to federal prosecutors.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Governing Party Close To Majority
description: The third and final round of parliamentary elections produced the greatest number of irregularities at the polls, monitors said, and the fewest number of winners. Of the 136 seats being chosen, just 9 were resolved, with the rest to be decided in a runoff on Wednesday. The Muslim Brotherhood, which did unexpectedly well, eating into the majority held by the governing National Democratic Party, will have 35 candidates in the runoffs. The Brotherhood and poll watchers said that the police had blocked opposition supporters from getting to the polls and that thugs with knives and machetes had intimidated people from voting. By the end of the last round, the N.D.P. had accumulated 222 seats out of 444 elected seats in the Parliament. Another 10 seats are appointed by the president and will go to the N.D.P. The party needs another 70 seats to have a controlling two-thirds majority. Mona el-Naggar (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Bodies May Be Slain Youths'
description: Bodies found near Hudson, Ohio, may be those of two New Hampshire children killed by their father in July 2003, the authorities said. The father, Manuel Gehring, confessed to shooting Sarah, 14, and Philip, 11, and burying their bodies in the Midwest off Interstate 80, near a well. He said he placed crosses made of duct tape on their chests. He was arrested in Gilroy, Calif., days later, and killed himself in prison. The authorities said a man walking his dog found the bodies Thursday. A police spokeswoman said the bodies were probably the children's and were found near a well. The children's mother, Teresa Knight, above, who hunted for the bodies along I-80 last summer, said the authorities confirmed that the two bodies had crosses of duct tape. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,106 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following American yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIL, ELSBETH
description: WEIL--Elsbeth. Beloved wife of Lothar, loving mother of Susan and Robert and grandmother of Kyle, died at home in La Jolla, California on November 29, 2005 at the age of 91. Donations may be contributed in her name to Holy Cross Hospice, Private Bag 00287, Gaborone, Botswana (holycross@mega.bw).

title: Two Musical Worlds Meet, and Occasionally Touch
description: More than most jazz musicians, the trumpeter Wadada Leo Smith has pondered the confluence of world music and jazz improvisation. He has a theory about it, in fact, and a system of hieroglyphic notation to match.

title: Dreiser's Chilling Tale of Ambition and Its Price
description: For a company of such international standing, the Metropolitan Opera has had an inexcusably timid record of commissioning operas in recent decades. Consequently, when the Met presents a new work, the stakes are almost impossibly high.

title: New Twist in Texas Districting Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - The Justice Department acknowledged on Friday that top officials had overruled a determination by its civil rights staff in 2003 that a Congressional redistricting plan for Texas, advantageous to Republicans, would violate the voting rights law.

title: Wal-Mart and the Social Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARGO, MURRAY
description: MARGO--Murray. On December 2. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Sari Kushner and Mitch Margo. Loving grandfather of Robert and Brian Kushner and Sam Margo. Murray was a Renaissance man before his time and a family man with social skills beyond compare. A collector of antiques and marvelous friends of all ages, he will be missed by all who knew him. Service Sunday 2PM at "The Riverside", 76th at Amsterdam Ave, NYC

title: Beethoven Provides a Rousing Finale
description: There was no question what the big event was at the Orchestra of St. Luke's concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night: Beethoven's Violin Concerto, played by Joshua Bell, with Donald Runnicles and the orchestra providing robust accompaniment. The concerto, traditionally the pre-intermission crowd pleaser in a classical concert, was placed at the end of the evening to give fans a true sense of climax, and it did. But although it was the best part of the program, it was none too good.

title: Wearying Wait for Federal Aid in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 - They are the faces and voices of a city's desperation. Stepping wearily up to a Federal Emergency Management Agency help center here, all have a similar story of ruin in the past, anxiety over the future and frustration in the present, suffered differently each time.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a task force that will investigate the balloon accident at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade last month misstated the former title of an official, Jerome M. Hauer, who helped investigate an accident at the 1997 parade. As head of the city's Office of Emergency Management, he was its director, not commissioner. (The position was renamed after it was elevated to the mayor's cabinet in 2001.)

title: Daily News Editor Resigns After Less Than a Year
description: Michael Cooke, the editor in chief of The Daily News in New York, announced his resignation yesterday after less than a year at the paper. His last day will be Jan. 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREILICHER, JACK
description: FREILICHER--Jack. Died November 30 at 89. Beloved husband of Frances. Caring father of Mel, Bruce and wife Nancy and David. Grandfather to Emily and Luc. After a successful career as President of Rite Foam Sleep Products, he enjoyed his retirement in Florida. His warmth, good humor and wit will be truly missed. Services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York, N.Y. Sunday at noon.

title: Disney Names Two Directors to Its Board
description: The Walt Disney Company named two new directors yesterday and said that the board chairman, George J. Mitchell, would remain through 2006, delaying his retirement.

title: New Orleans Election in Doubt
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 2 - The state's top election official recommended on Friday that New Orleans postpone its February municipal elections for as long as eight months because of the impediments created by Hurricane Katrina.

title: Peter D. Eimas, Expert in How Infants Learn, Dies at 70
description: Peter D. Eimas, a Brown University scientist who found that babies can distinguish different sounds of speech as early as their first month and published his findings in a groundbreaking study explaining how infants acquire language, died Oct. 28 at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 70.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza Strip: Militants Let Back Into Gaza
description: Palestinians have allowed 10 to 15 militants expelled or sought by Israel to enter the Gaza Strip through a border crossing now controlled by the Palestinians, Israel said. Palestinians formally assumed control of the Rafah border crossing, on the southern frontier with Egypt, a week ago. Israel receives videotape and can object to those entering, but the Palestinian Authority has the final say on who may enter. The militants were either expelled by Israel or they fled. Those who have returned include Fadel Zahar, a brother of Mahmoud Zahar, a senior leader of Hamas. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIM, ALFRED
description: SIM--Alfred. On November 30, 2005. Beloved husband of Nita Sim. Beloved son of Charlotte Sim. Beloved father and brother. Funeral Mass Saturday 2:00 PM at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 E. 62nd St., Manhattan. Visiting at Central Funeral Home, 136-25 41st Ave, Flushing, NY on Saturday from 6:00 PM-9:30 PM.

title: Trading Chic for Volume in Shoe Sales
description: A little over three months ago, Matthew E. Rubel gave up a job many would have labeled a dream. As the chief executive of Cole Haan, Mr. Rubel, 48, had presided over the company's resurgence, from little-known shoemaker to a hot brand, maker of some of the chicest shoes and handbags around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCBRIDE, JOSEPH A.
description: McBRIDE--Joseph A., 86. Of Franklin Lakes formerly of Ridgewood on November 30, 2005. Beloved husband of Wendy McBride (nee Michie). He is predeceased by his first wife, the late Barbara McBride (nee O'Connor)(1994). Devoted father of Terence McBride and his wife Mary of Franklin Lakes, Sheila James and her husband David of Villanova, PA, Michael McBride and his wife BethAnn of Ridgewood and Dr. Mark McBride and his wife Virginia of Madison. Dear stepfather of Louise Wright, James Harrison, Jason Fisher and Jonathan Fisher. Loving grandfather of fifteen and great-grandfather of two. Funeral services Monday 9:30 AM at Vander PlaatVermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes followed by a 10:00 AM Mass at Most Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church. Interment Christ The King Cemetery. The family will receive friends Sunday 24 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial donations be made to Most Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church, 787 Franklin Lake Road, Franklin Lakes, N.J. 07417 in Mr. McBride's memory. For further information www.vanderplaat.com

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: HAPPY TIMES -- The economy's strong performance continues to surprise just about everybody. This week, the news came out that consumer confidence surged in November; that the economy grew at a revised 4.3 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the fastest pace in a year and a half; that retail sales were robust and the housing market remained reasonably healthy despite a lot of gloomy talk. On Tuesday, we can revisit some of those trends with the release of a major store-sales index, a retail-sales index, October factory orders and the ABC-Washington Post consumer-confidence index.

title: Time for Hope, Not Tears, in Upended Lives
description: The Primary Stages production of "In the Continuum" reopened this week at the Perry Street Theater (21 Perry Street, West Village; (212) 868-4444), where it runs through Jan. 14. Following are excerpts from Charles Isherwood's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 10 after the production's opening at the 59E59 Theaters in Manhattan. The full text is online at nytimes.com/theater.

title: U.S. Propaganda In the Iraqi Press
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with a theater review of "Super Vision," at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misstated an actress's given name. She is Kyle deCamp, not Lyle.

title: W.'s Head in the Sand
description: In the Christmas spirit, the time has come for the reality-based community to reach out to the White House.

title: An Ace in the Hole
description: PERHAPS more than most people, I was shocked by the news this week about Representative Randy Cunningham of California. For me, it wasn't just about being disappointed in a man who accepted among other things a Rolls-Royce, Persian rugs, a lavish graduation party for his daughter and a yacht in exchange for political favors; it was much deeper. For me, it was about not just the fall but the complete and utter collapse of my hero.

title: Britain Urges End to Europe's Farm Subsidies
description: Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the British Exchequer, urged yesterday that Europe completely phase out subsidies, price supports and export refunds to its farmers to help unlock stalled global trade talks.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Argument Closes Pakistan-Afghan Crossing
description: Afghan and Pakistani border guards confronted each other at a main border crossing linking Chaman, in Pakistan, and Spinboldak, in Afghanistan, causing the crossing to be closed for the day, police officials said. The argument broke out after Afghan soldiers accused Pakistanis of beating Afghans crossing the border and then detained and beat a Pakistani soldier. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHMIERER, HY
description: SCHMIERER--Hy, 86, December 1, 2005. Devoted husband of Horty for 56 years, loving father of Susan and Matthew Silverman & Merri and Harry Bragg. Adored "Poppy" of Rachel, Jaime, and Abbey Silverman. Cherished Uncle and Great Uncle to many nieces and nephews. Veteran of the US Army Air Corps in World War II. Founder, Owner and Director of Camp Starlight, Starlight, PA for 53 years. Loved and will be missed by thousands of campers and staff whose lives he touched and influenced. Former President of the Association of Independent Camps. Served on the Board of Governors of the New York Section of the American Camping Association. With his love for children and their well being, following his retirement in 1999, he became a board member of the Non-Violence Project in Miami, FL and an advisor to the Shake-A-Leg Foundation in Coconut Grove, FL. He continued to remain active in the Hancock (NY) Community Education Foundation. Funeral Services will be at "Gutterman's", 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY at 12:00 noon on Sunday, December 4, 2005. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hancock Community Education Foundation, 38 West Main Street, Hancock, NY 13783.

title: Retired Founder of the Interpublic Group Opens an Advertising Agency of His Own
description: Sir Frank Lowe, the founder of the Interpublic Group agency now known as Lowe Worldwide, is coming out of retirement to open an agency in London. Paul Weinberger, chairman of the Lowe London office, resigned on Thursday to join Sir Frank at the new agency. Sir Frank, left, who founded Lowe in 1981, retired at the end of 2003 and agreed with Interpublic not to poach Lowe clients or employees for two years. The Web sites of the trade publications Advertising Age and Campaign reported that Sir Frank's new agency would open with the Tesco account, the largest handled by Lowe London; Mr. Weinberger has for many years supervised the creative part of the account. The loss of Tesco, which spends $75 million on advertising, would be a blow to Lowe, which has lost assignments from clients like Century 21, HSBC, Macy's and Unilever in Britain and the United States. Interpublic has installed new management at Lowe in an effort to turn around the agency. "Interpublic remains committed to Lowe and the path it is taking," Michael I. Roth, chief executive at Interpublic, said in a statement. Stuart Elliott (NYT) BUSINESS BRIEFS

title: Two Halls Will Share Theaters and Funds
description: Carnegie Hall and City Center, separated by a strip of West 56th Street, announced a partnership yesterday that will lead to a $150 million fund-raising effort to renovate City Center, and give Carnegie Hall's increasingly ambitious programmers access to a dance and theater space.

title: Russia to Sell Antiaircraft Missiles to Iran in Billion-Dollar Deal
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2 - Russia has agreed to sell antiaircraft missiles to Iran as part of a $1 billion arms deal that would significantly increase Moscow's military cooperation with Tehran, Russian news media reported Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAHONEY, PHILIP T.
description: MAHONEY--Philip T. On November 19, 2005, of Pawleys Island, SC. Beloved husband of the late Margot M. Mahoney and survived by his wife Agnes Farley Mahoney. Devoted father to Philip T. Mahoney Jr., Dianne M. Hoffman and G. Daniel Mahoney. Cherished brother to Helen M. Gaffigan and Thomas F. Mahoney. Loving grandfather to three grandchildren. Services were held on Monday November 28 in Severna Park, MD. Interment was held at Maryland Veteran's Cemetery in Crownsville, MD. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to MADD, 511 E. John Carpenter Freeway, Suite 700, Irving, TX 75062, or the American Heart Association, 7272 Greenville Ave, Dallas, TX 75231. For info www.barrancofuneralhome.com

title: Buying Used Just Could Turn Out to Be the Next New Thing
description: The idea of buying used goods, especially when advanced around the holidays, sounds rather pathetic, as if one is living a real-life version of a Charlie Brown Christmas. Who would want something used?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Robert C. Clark, who is a director of both Lazard and Time Warner at a time when Lazard has been hired to help wage a shareholder fight against Time Warner, misstated one of his affiliations. He is on the TIAA board of trustees, not a director of the TIAA Real Estate Account.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, LEA
description: DIAMOND--Lea. 88, died December 1, 2005. She is survived by her loving daughters and sons-in-law Sharon (Roger Nathaniel) Diamond, Lois (Thomas) Gueli, her cherished grandchildren Allison, Jonathan, Lydia, Jeremy, Jasper and Emma, two devoted brothers and sisters-inlaw Murray (Nina) Migdal and Julie (Gloria) Migdal. Her beloved husband Herbert died in 1999. Her family was her world. Service 12 noon Sunday, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, NY (Saw Mill exit 17). Memorial to Palliative Care Institute, Mt Sinai School of Medicine, 1 Gustave Levy Place, Box 1070, NY, NY 10029 or Phelps Hospice, 710 N. Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591.

title: U.S. Propaganda In the Iraqi Press
description: To the Editor:

title: For All Its Cost, Sarbanes Law Is Working
description: "I WAS trying to keep things in balance," Senator Paul S. Sarbanes said a few weeks ago. "I didn't want people to say we had gone too far and acted in the heat of the moment."

title: Search for Philanthropist's Plane Is Called Off
description: The Coast Guard yesterday ended its rescue effort for George F. Baker III, a philanthropist whose twin-engine plane disappeared under a cloudy drizzle Thursday evening off the coast of Nantucket.

title: In 2415, There are Still Bad Hair Days
description: Set four centuries into the future, "Aeon Flux," which crept into theaters yesterday, invites you to ponder many intriguing questions. I don't mean the obvious ones, like why it was not screened in advance for critics (that pretty much answers itself) or why it was made in the first place (that we may never know).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRACI, ANGELO
description: GRACI -- Angelo. Retired Judge, Queens County Supreme Court. Beloved husband of Patricia; devoted father of Marianna Graci and the late Patricia Pansini. Father-in-law to Saverio (Sal) Pansini; grandfather to Raffaele, Nicholas, Catherine and Paul Angelo. Reposing at the James Romanelli - Stephen Funeral Home, 89-01 Rockaway Blvd., Ozone Park, N.Y. until Monday 8:30am. Mass of the Resurrection, St. Fortunata RC Church, 9:30am. Visiting Saturday & Sunday, 2-5 & 79pm. Entombment Holy Cross Chapel Mausoleum, North Arlington, N.J.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAICES, FLORENCE
description: RAICES--Florence. Retired Brooklyn school teacher in her 98th year. She is survived by her niece, Judith Raices; nephews, Harry and Richard Marsh; and their families. Graveside services 11 AM on December 4 at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

title: Waiting for Deer, the Mind Plays Tricks
description: GALILEE, Pa., Nov. 28 - At sunrise , the sun was nowhere to be seen and the sky was like the roof of an old gray canvas tent, leaking fat drops of rain. The snow that had surprised us with a white Thanksgiving was quickly evaporating into fog, reducing visibility to about 35 yards. It was the worst opening day of deer season that I could remember.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Military Admits Planting News in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 - The military acknowledged Friday in a briefing for a ranking Senate Republican that news articles written by American troops had been placed as paid advertisements in the Iraqi news media and not always properly identified.

title: Bye Bye BlackBerry?
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 2 - What if your BlackBerry screen went dark?

title: At Norway Festival, a Duet Inspired by a Mythic Gaze
description: Norway in New York, a festival of Norwegian dance and theater, opened its season at Performance Space 122 with a striking yet inconsistent duet choreographed by Ina Christel Johannessen of zero visibility corp. Before the start of "...it's only a rehearsal" on Thursday, Dimitri Jourde and Line Tormoen chatted softly and greeted audience members with warm smiles. But for the most part, they just stared.

title: New Jersey Court Clears Way for Bear Hunt
description: TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 2 - New Jersey's second black bear hunt in 35 years will begin as scheduled on Monday after the New Jersey Supreme Court rejected a last-minute effort by animal rights groups on Friday to block it.

title: Blast in Falluja Kills 10 Marines; 11 Are Wounded
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 2 - A year after marines led an American assault force in recapturing Falluja, 10 marines conducting a foot patrol on the edge of the city were killed at dusk Thursday by a bomb fashioned from several large artillery shells.

title: Now Showing: God
description: Once, New York was home to magnificent temples devoted to film. Today, some of these places have embarked on a new, more spiritual and arguably far grander mission.

title: A Gallery of Diet Gurus
description: In "Terrors of the Table," the biophysicist Walter Gratzer gives a sprightly history of our often tragicomical efforts to understand - and improve - our diets.

title: Clip from James Fotopoulos's Film
description: A scene from "Shattered," a film by James Fotopoulos.

title: Living in Wilton, Conn.
description: The New York Times visits this historic community, a haven for preservationists and the well-to-do.

title: Next Step on Darfur
description: The White House just sent out its Christmas card. But if it really wants to do something to reflect the season, then it should get out and get $50 million to the African Union forces in Darfur.

title: Bushs Briefing Book
description: Check out Bushs secret briefing book on climate change. Its very funny:http://www.energyaction.net/cop/George-Brief.pdf

title: Thanks Giving
description: On modern to-do lists, writing thank-you notes usually ranks about as high as polishing the silver. But it need not be a chore, according to the stationer Drew Souza, of IS on Crosby Street. The only imperative when it comes to thank-yous, he confides, is to send them. He suggests you write at least three sentences, avoid clichAs (an evening- or gift-specific anecdote is thoughtful) and do it by hand, no matter how keyboard-weakened your penmanship. Souza also advises waiting until January to send holiday-related thanks: "If it arrives on Dec. 22, no one will have time to open it." Let us now give thanks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   STEINBERG, MEYER ''MIKE''
description: STEINBERG--Meyer "Mike". Beloved father. Thank you for the gift of unconditional love. It has given me tremendous strength and inner peace. I think of you daily and miss you dearly. Sue

title: Japanese Art
description: Part of the charm of Japanese prints is their apparent simplicity -- the clean lines, the rich colors, the traditional focus on animals or landscapes or beautiful women. Like the best comic books or advertising posters, these things pop.

title: Council Wants to Extend Term Limits
description: Twelve years after New York City voters adopted term limits for many of their local officials, the City Council is poised to allow its members to serve one more term, -- without asking voters how they feel about changing the term limits law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOOTTON, GORDON
description: WOOTTON--Gordon. In memorium January 21, 1931-November 11, 2005. We will deeply miss your insight, guidance and good humor. Your love of family, passion for breeding champion thoroughbred racehorses and contributions to the educational betterment of the children of Wainscott will be long remembered. We have lost a colleague, a mentor and a dear friend. The New York Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc Richard A. Violette, Chair

title: Strange Bandfellows
description: MIAMI BEACH - THE Citizens Band was born a little over a year ago, soon after President Bush was re-elected, because its members felt politically frustrated and annoyed. So they started a cabaret act, based on post-World War I Germany and the discontent of the Weimar Republic, with tattered fishnets, lacy corsets and bleak eye makeup. The group soon grew into a collective of 30 artists, musicians and part-time acrobats, including the model Karen Elson, Rain Phoenix, (Joaquin Phoenix's sister), Craig Wedren (a musician who has composed scores for films like "School of Rock") and occasionally Maggie Gyllenhaal and Billy Corgan.

title: Moscow for millionaires
Paid Notice: Deaths   KOBRIN, SALLY (SARAH GOLDSTEIN)
description: KOBRIN--Sally (Sarah Goldstein). 84, an avid reader, a Queen of bingo and the Daily Jumble, left us peacefully on Thursday, December 1. Resident of Brooklyn, NY, Tamarac, FL, and Paramus, NJ. Wife of the late Teddy. Devoted mother of Trudi Gunsberg (Frank) and Gloria Froug (Ron). Dear sister of Ruth Joseph and the late Ethel Friedberg. Loving grandmother of Alan Kantrowitz (Melissa), Meredith Bluestine (Jay), Shari Rayburn (Josh), Rachel Gunsberg and the late Risa Kantrowitz. Great grandmother of Taylor, Owen, Tyler, Reese and Bradley. Memorial service today, 10:30 am, at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ. We will all miss you. Information: 800-522-0588.

title: Recession coming? Maybe it's the wrong question
The Center No Longer Holds
description: My thanks to Jacob S. Hacker and Paul Pierson for their succinct analysis of how a right-wing minority has hijacked our government (Nov. 20). If only some altruistic invaders would arrive to restore democracy, I'm sure we'd all throw flowers at their feet.

title: Modern Man
description: Italy in the 1960's was as cool as a Campari and soda. Designers like Achille Castiglioni, Marco Zanuso, Vico Magistretti and Ettore Sottsass sought to express the speed of postwar technological advances in consumer goods that balanced sleek, seductive form and user-friendliness. Today, when a million design trends have come and gone, and the pace of technological change is light-years ahead of what it was in the 60's, the Italians' work resonates anew. Joshua Holdeman, the head of the 20th-century decorative arts department at Christie's, says that for the "leaders of the pack who have a voracious appetite for the next new thing," the next new thing is 60's Italian design.

title: A Promising Start With the Grizzlies Has Jones Happy
description: Eddie Jones did not ask for this trade, as he did in 1999, when he was with the Lakers. Jones was jolted when he heard during a family vacation last summer that he had been traded to Memphis from Miami.

title: Of Time and the River
description: THE HUDSON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITE, JEFFREY J. (JJ)
description: WHITE--Jeffrey J. (JJ) Our best friend and Uncle (Fuff) only wanted to make everyone happy. There is a special place in our hearts forever. We love you and miss you. Stacy, Troy, Casey and Kori

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKOLNICK, ESTELLE PINTO
description: SKOLNICK -- Estelle Pinto. Died in England on November 22, 2005, peacefully in her sleep, after a long illness. Wife of the late Irving Skolnick, and mother of the late Alan Skolnick, she is survived by her daughter, Betty, son-in-law David Watson, and grandchildren, Sarah & Michael. Donations to Hadassah.

title: Other Views: Sydney Morning Herald, Straits Times, The Independent
Sad Clown and Mocking Onion
description: BELUSHI A Biography. By Judith Belushi Pisano and Tanner Colby. 288 pp., Rugged Land. $29.95.

title: The Prodigy Puzzle
description: It is easier to be a genius when you don't have to pay the rent. We live in a world that values dependability over brilliance and where jobs that reward curiosity may not support a family. The time to explore and take bold risks is a luxury few of us, genius or not, can afford once we leave school. Measuring programs for gifted children by the success of their adult graduates overlooks the significant hurdles that lie just after graduation.

title: Wanted for hire: Iraq fixer
The War in Iraq And Our Self-Esteem
description: To the Editor:

title: In Task Force Report, a Challenge
description: On page after page, the new report from a task force appointed by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey to reform New Jersey's pension and employee benefits system is striking for its blunt language and its bold recommendations.

title: China warns of job losses unless oversupply is tamed
Paid Notice: Deaths   BENJAMIN, AUDREY
description: BENJAMIN--Audrey. December 2, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Bruce Benjamin. Loving mother of Keith and Bonnie. Cherished Nana of Kelsey, Jackson, Bruce and Peri. Lovingly cared for by her cherished Polo, Samantha and Jenny. She will be deeply missed by her extended family and all who knew and loved her. Memorial Service Wednesday, December 7, 2005, 11 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Correction
description: A Photo-Op on Nov. 13 misstated the location of one of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's campaign offices. It was Riverdale Avenue, not Johnson Avenue, in the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: A graphic on this page last Sunday about the week's developments in media misstated two facts about the Apple iPod. The price of downloading an episode from an ABC show to an iPod is $1.99 per episode, not 99 cents. And the service is available now, not in the future.

title: Real Protection for Our Children (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Conservative Poland Roils European Union
description: BRUSSELS - When Polish members of the European Parliament placed an anti-abortion display in a parliamentary corridor in Strasbourg, France, recently, Ana Gomes, a Socialist legislator from Portugal, felt compelled to act, she said.

title: Kazakhstan votes in presidential election amid accusations of dirty tricks
CALENDAR
description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, ARTHUR W. COHEN
description: FEINBERG--Arthur W. Cohen Hennessey & Bienstock P.C. and its entire staff mourn the passing of Dr. Arthur Feinberg, the husband, best friend and true love of our founder, Harriet N. Cohen. As one of Arthur's many extended family groups, we will miss and never replace his intelligent nurturing, his wise counsel, and his calm approach to life's vagaries. Our only solace is the knowledge that we can continue to face our daily challenges by asking always "What would Arthur do?" Our hearts go out to Harriet's and Arthur's entire family.

title: Deal or a Steal? Thornton Leaves Boston Blue
description: After Boston General Manager Mike O'Connell traded Joe Thornton to San Jose on Wednesday, Thornton said he felt that he had been made the scapegoat for the Bruins' poor start this season.

title: Whitelist
description: At last month's annual conference of the Computer Security Institute, the keynote speaker was one of those privacy nuts who exhorts businesses to tighten up their software and databases lest they threaten customers with ever-more-dangerous identity theft.

title: A CURIOUS CASE
description: Host America, an institutional caterer in Hamden, Conn., fired its president and chief executive, Geoffrey W. Ramsey, last week. It also fired his sister, Anne L. Ramsey, who had been Host's human resources director. It offered no reason for the departures in a public filing.

title: INSIDE
description: Investigators Say F.B.I. Mishandled Terror Case F.B.I. officials mishandled a Florida terrorism investigation, falsified documents in the case and retaliated against a veteran undercover operative who complained about the problems, Justice Department investigators have concluded. PAGE 37

title: Briefs: Subway security checks are ruled constitutional
CALENDAR
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Marlene Cooper and Aleksandar Vasilic
description: Marlene Calista Cooper, a daughter of Calista Dennis Cooper of Alexandria, Va., and the late John Lewis Cooper Jr., is to be married today to Aleksandar Vasilic, a son of Marija Vasilic and Tode Vasilic of Novi Sad, Serbia. The Rev. Terrence Gordon is to officiate at the Half Moon resort in Montego Bay, Jamaica.

title: U.S. and Britain Try a New Tack on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 - In a new effort to pressure Iran to allow strict controls on its nuclear program, Britain and the United States are trying to persuade Russia and China to endorse their conclusion, derived from what officials call new evidence, that Tehran intends to build nuclear weapons, American and European diplomats said.

title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Canadian Troops in Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Dec. 4 - A suicide bomber threw himself at a convoy of passing Canadian troops in this southern city today, killing himself and a passing civilian and wounding several other civilians and a policeman, police officials here said.

title: Puerto Peasco, Mexico: Boom Time for 'Next San Diego'
description: AS the last edge of sun slipped into the Sea of Cortez on a Saturday night in October, the Old Port corner of Puerto Peasco, Mexico, kicked into high gear. Bunches of sunburned tourists rolled in, fresh from the beach, poring over vendors' seashell necklaces and slipping into open-air cafes for fish tacos and margaritas. It was a classic seaside resort town scene: casual, small and quaint.

title: Middlesex Is Highest In a Measure of Income
description: In 2003, Middlesex County residents had a median household income of $61,770, the highest in Connecticut, according to United States Census Bureau data released on Tuesday.

title: Hello, Columbus
description: PHILIP ROTH

title: Meanwhile in Iraq | Nov. 27 -- Dec. 3
description: LEADING THE FIGHT

title: Court Is a 'Stress-Free Zone' for Tennessee's Parker
