description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 3 - Had the teenage journalist not stopped her newspaper column to focus on what many believe could become the greatest career in women's college basketball history, Candace Parker might have begun her opus Wednesday by talking about the stress.

title: The Call Goes Out For Santas' Help: Bring a Lap, an Ear and Quick Thinking
description: IT'S the typical seasonal sighting at shopping centers, strip malls and many a store: a guy in a red suit saying, "Ho, ho, ho, Merry Christmas." So how does someone who wants to play Santa Claus get the job?

title: Romancing the Stone
description: THE DIAMOND

title: For Those Left Behind, a Guide to Combat Readiness
description: WASHINGTON - THE bookstores are full of how-to guides: on dieting, investment, personal growth, retirement. But until now there hasn't been a how-to-cope manual for those who stay behind when a son or daughter in uniform heads off to war.

title: The Remix: Kids; Little Stars
description: These days, celebrity children's lines are supplanting celebrity children as a celebrity sideline. Madonna hawks a girls' label called the English Roses (based on her best-selling book) at Neiman Marcus and specialty boutiques. The actress Phoebe Cates recently opened Blue Tree on the Upper East Side and stocked it with a downtown mix. Chocolate, records and grown-up couture share floor space with $25 party favors, velvet pig purses, papier-mch trucks and whimsical Claude vintage T-shirts (this pirate-stenciled version costs $70). And in cyberspace, the London music impresario Malcolm McLaren will introduce Fashionbeast, a collection for tykes ages 4 to 12 that is based on 70's video games. Look for it this month on Yoox.com. Alexandra Zissu

title: At Bear Mountain Inn, a Plunge Into Environmentalism
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y. - It sounds almost as mysterious as an underwater adventure film: divers steer a barge away from the shore, drop a 1,400-pound box overboard, jump into the water and guide the box to its resting place, 35 feet or so below the surface.

title: Witchfinders: A Seventeenth-Century English Tragedy
Paid Notice: Deaths   ORANS, SYLVIA (NEE KORNREICH)
description: ORANS--Sylvia (nee Kornreich). Her energy, vitality and commitment to improving our world will be missed by all who loved her. Donations to: Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, Attention: Dr. K. Dahlman, Mount Sinai Hospital, Box 1230, 1 Gustave Levy Place, New York, NY 10029. Memorial: Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., 2-5 P.M., December 29th.

title: Look Out Below
description: SNOWSTRUCK

title: Smoothing the Transition
description: The sudden collapse of a corrupt power structure, even after years of misrule, does not necessarily mean a wrenching or chaotic transition period. Look at what happened in Munchkinland after the stunning demise of the Wicked Witch of the East. Within minutes the civil authorities there had regrouped, completed a coroner's investigation and report, issued an official mayoral proclamation and pulled off a show-stopping production number. The big bosses may think they call the shots, but it's the little people, properly motivated, who hold everything together.

title: Shopping Around For More Shopping
description: IF there is one issue about which almost everyone on Roosevelt Island agrees, it is the need to expand and upgrade the limited shopping and dining.

title: His Guitar Needs No Limelight
description: FOR the guitarist Peter Calo, being part of the seven-piece band backing the pop star Carly Simon during her recent performance at Rose Hall in Manhattan meant accompanying her in a wide range of musical styles and changing guitars on practically every song.

title: Win Some, Lose Some
description: NEXT MAN UP

title: Nostalgia, Wearing Stilettos
description: BACK in the days of sock hops and bobby socks, before girls went wild and there was pornography for every imaginable (and unimaginable) fetish, there lived a more innocent brand of voyeurism. It was the era of the pinup girl.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 20 about Bangkok misstated the name of the road on which Siam Square, an outdoor mall, is situated. It is on Rama 1 Road, not Sukhumvit Road; Rama 1 Road is an extension of Sukhumvit Road.

title: Some oil executives worry prices may fall
Architecture, Posed and Pondered
description: WHO says architecture can't be art? Just as recent installation art often aspires to architecture, several of the projects featured in "Transcending Type," a touring exhibition of architectural models and designs at the Yale School of Architecture Gallery, border on the purely aesthetic, and are even dilettantish.

title: 2 Architects' Brief Journey Into Design Pyrotechnics
description: Correction Appended

title: Mob Assails Former Prime Minister in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 4 - Former Prime Minister Ayad Allawi was assailed by a mob today during a campaign visit to the Shiite holy city of Najaf, police officials said. The politician, who escaped unharmed, later characterized the attack as an assassination attempt.

title: Snared in the Web of a Wikipedia Liar
description: ACCORDING to Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia, John Seigenthaler Sr. is 78 years old and the former editor of The Tennessean in Nashville. But is that information, or anything else in Mr. Seigenthaler's biography, true?

title: Exploration
description: For all that the lure of the unknown has become a clich, the world's great explorers still hold a fascination for us. A new crop of books offers some grand overviews of the history of exploration and attests to our abiding attraction to the feats of those who went where no one had gone before.

title: Scarlett
description: Shopping with Woody Allen would be a nightmare," Scarlett Johansson, who is the director's new favorite actress, said recently. She stars in his movie "Match Point," opening later this month, as an alluring but demanding ingnue, and she recently completed another Allen movie as well. "Woody has a very specific idea about everything," Johansson explained. "And he hates everything I've ever worn. Every dress -- he hates. He's extremely fashion-conscious, so I asked him if he would design a gown for me or, at least, pick my outfit for any major 'Match Point' event. I would never want to go shopping with him. He is too particular." Johansson laughed her low, throaty laugh.

title: Hong Kong
description: WHY GO NOW Because the Hong Kong of today is rapidly being replaced by a new, more showy incarnation of itself - with the recently opened Disneyland just a hint of what the future holds. This fall, the Four Seasons and a boutique version of the city's famous Mandarin Oriental have opened outposts in the city's financial district. New nightclubs are luring fashionable people from across Asia. And a nearly completed cable car system will soon vault from the airport up over a steep hillside to a well-preserved monastery and its immense outdoor statue of Buddha.

title: Eight Is Enough
description: New Paltz, N.Y. - THIS year, New York voters rightly rejected constitutional changes to the state budget process as a legislative power grab in the guise of reform. But we did not reject the idea that state government needs to change the way it is structured and operates.

title: So Far, the Grades Don't Look Good For the 2001 Class
description: As a vintage, the 2001 draft has so far proved to be as aromatic as gym socks, suitable for a box. The first-rounders make up one of the more underachieving classes in recent N.B.A. history. The last pick in that round, Tony Parker, has a better chance of making the All-Star team for the first time this season than the first pick, Kwame Brown, probably ever will.

title: Palm Springs, Calif.: The Parker Palm Springs
description: THE BASICS -- Jonathan Adler, the designer of ceramics and home furnishings, took one of the kitschiest places in Palm Springs -- the former Givenchy Resort and Spa owned by Merv Griffin -- and somehow made it both kitschier and more glamorous. Out went the faux Versailles colonnade and topiaries; in went the zebra-print rugs, thrift-store Picassos and tangerine macram. The result is not so much a hippy-chic makeover, as it is a kind of dandy Betty Ford clinic for those who overdosed on the W Hotel's much-copied sleek and minimalist vibe. The resort's particular brand of tongue in cheek is not for everyone. But a year after it opened, the fashionable Hollywood set is still smirking about it.

title: 'The Gruesome Guide to World Monsters' and 'Fantasy Encyclopedia'
description: "Cannibal Baby, Hoop Snake, the Rolling Head -- the inventive beasts of the world's folklore put Hollywood's movie monsters to shame. The Gruesome Guide to World Monsters (Candlewick, $18.99, ages 6 and up), by Judy Sierra, is presented as a kind of global travel guide to recognizing and avoiding local legends. Peppered with Henrik Drescher's exuberantly creepy mixed-media illustrations, the book takes a geographic joy ride through the international imagination, finding folk monsters like the Ovda of Finland, which tickles its victims, and the Adaro of the Solomon Islands, which likes to throw poisonous flying fish at people for no reason. More familiar characters are found in Fantasy Encyclopedia (Kingfisher, $24.95, ages 9 to 14), by Judy Allen, with a foreword by Jonathan Stroud, which takes a more comprehensive approach to cataloging creatures from ancient mythology to modern fiction. Lavish illustrations by John Howe, Nicki Palin and Patricia Ludlow complement photographs of cultural artifacts and document a few nonimaginary subjects, including the Romanian tyrant Vlad the Impaler, who sounds just as unnerving as the boggarts, trolls and basilisks roaming through the book.

title: Music Chronicle
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH TOM PETTY. By Paul Zollo. (Omnibus Press, $24.95.) Admit it: You, too, have had the fantasy where Tom Petty becomes your best drinking buddy. Over a few rounds of Pabst Blue Ribbon, you tell him that "Damn the Torpedoes" is a classic document of American rock; he confesses to you that the Traveling Wilburys were a better idea in theory than in execution. But don't hate Paul Zollo, an editor at American Songwriter, for fulfilling the dream first and confirming what you've suspected all along: that Petty is an undeniably fascinating guy to talk to. Sure, there is some dead air in these interviews, but it's abundantly offset by Petty's indelible stories of his Florida upbringing by a father who liked to poke alligators in the eye for fun, and the time the supposedly laid-back Petty became so frustrated with a recording session that he punched a wall, shattered his fist and spent eight months retraining himself to use his left hand. And the chapter devoted to Petty's memories of a bassist who eventually died from a heroin overdose may be the most chilling deglamorization of the rock 'n' roll lifestyle since "Sid and Nancy."

title: Bridgett Luther and Timothy Ahern
description: Bridgett Leigh Luther and Timothy Christopher Ahern were married yesterday at Calvary Presbyterian Church in San Francisco. The Rev. Dr. Laird J. Stuart, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Shrinking Budgets For Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Danger Signs
description: In the mid-1980's, David Shaffer, a psychiatrist, became disturbed by an increase in teenage suicides. After declining for decades, the rate started climbing in the late 1950's, especially for boys. By the 1980's, it had tripled -- to 11.3 per 100,000 teenagers 15 to 19, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In more recent surveys of teenagers, the C.D.C. has found that about 8 percent of high-school students answer yes when asked if they had attempted suicide during the past year. About 1,500 succeed annually, making suicide the third-leading cause of death in teenagers after accidents and homicides. Shaffer wanted to know what was happening -- and whether anything could be done about it.

title: Cheever Aside, Few Signs of A Vice Storm
description: NEW ROCHELLE - LIKE it or not, John Cheever's midcentury suburban nation of listless characters involved in prodigious numbers of extramarital affairs has given the area a certain mystique.

title: Again, the U.S. Attorney Is on a Statewide Blitz
description: TRENTON - WITH the frenzy of the campaign season just behind them, federal prosecutors in New Jersey were on a tear.

title: Star Spotting, and Trying Not to Say: 'Aren't You ?'
description: DID you ever wonder how Andy Rooney gets to work?

title: In Some Kitchens, a Turkey Is a Sign of Hunger
description: Hempstead - THEY stood quietly in the cold rain. Some huddled under umbrellas. A few protected their heads with plastic bags. Within an hour, the line of people outside the Mary Brennan Inn, a soup kitchen here, doubled in size.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Manhattan

title: Can't We All Just Get Along? Nah
description: One of the more colorful developments in the soap opera known as "who will Jon S. Corzine choose as his successor for the United States Senate" was the latest flare-up between the former Senator Robert Torricelli and Representative Robert Menendez.

title: Carrie Brandon and Cameron Elliot
description: Carrie Lynn Brandon, a lawyer, was married yesterday to Cameron Robert Elliot, a federal prosecutor. The Right Rev. Andrew St. John, a former assistant bishop of the Anglican diocese of Melbourne, Australia, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan, where he is now the vicar.

title: A Domestic Play Takes a Stormy Path
description: The title of David Caudle's play "The Sunken Living Room" is supposed to be a metaphor, a reference to the architectural style familiar decades ago to television families like the Bradys. Recently, however, it has taken on a more literal ring, as the play has fallen victim to not one, but two hurricanes.

title: Designing Woman
description: Starting a fashion company is hard enough for those with bottomless bank accounts; it's quite another matter for designers with nothing to fall back on, like Jamila Payne, 28, who began sewing at the age of 10. Three years ago she started Milla by Mail, a company that organizes discount shopping parties and also sells designs by Ms. Payne and others online at www.millabymail.com. She received assistance along the way from the National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship, a nonprofit group based in New York that helps young people from lower-income communities start their own businesses. Ms. Payne's vintage-inspired skirt is $98. The sweater, by BCBG is $120, and the necklace $25 on her Web site. More information about the foundation is at www.nfte.com. PAUL WISENTHAL PULSE

title: A Radiant New 'Messiah' and Other Musical Gifts
description: Handel: 'Messiah'

title: TALK ABOUT BUYING VOTES
description: The final number was $75 million. That was what Senator Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester spent, combined, out of their fortunes in the most expensive governor's race in state history. According to finance reports submitted last Monday by the campaigns, Mr. Corzine, a former chief executive of Goldman Sachs who defeated Mr. Forrester by 9 percentage points, spent $39 million in the general election, and $5 million in an uncontested primary. As for the $31 million spent by Mr. Forrester, a founder of a pharmacy benefits management company, $19 million was spent during the general election, and $12 million in a hotly contested primary.

title: Kathryn Van Pelt and Nicholas Stein
description: Kathryn Ann Van Pelt, the daughter of Elizabeth A. Van Pelt and David S. Van Pelt of New York, was married yesterday to Nicholas David Stein, a son of Ellen C. Stein and David F. Stein of New York. The Rev. John L. McCausland, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Contributors
description: Simon Procter

title: Places, Everyone
description: A good mix of people is necessary for any party. But why stop there? Shake up the whole table. Combine pewter and silver, flatware and jewels, and always stick a stuffed fox below for good measure. Carlos Mota, the New York (by way of Venezuela) stylist who created this elaborate spread, drew upon Dutch Renaissance tableaus and an obsession with eclectic ephemera to create a scene that, somehow, "just works." Along the 21-foot-long table -- the new standard in chic entertaining -- he incorporated some of his favorite things: pewter balls, goblets and, from the Deyrolle taxidermy and curiosities shop in Paris, peacocks and pigeons. "I want to have my funeral there," said Mota, whose personality is as baroque as his backdrops -- in this case, wallpaper made from 8,000 hand-stapled magnolia leaves.

title: The Remix; NOW SERVING | BOUTIQUE BUBBLY
description: Dom who? Discriminating Champagne lovers are eschewing highly hyped houses in favor of small-batch bubbly from family-owned estates. And for once, rare doesn't require a Centurion Card: some top-notch sparklers are less than $50. Terry Theise is one of a handful of wine merchants backing the trend. "You can drink a superior wine for the same or even a fraction of the price of a bottle from one of the big guys," he says. He touts H. Billiot Fils and Larmandier-Bernier for their nonvintage bottlings: "They both make the liquid equivalent of a Brooks Brothers suit: effortlessly impeccable and incredibly well priced." (H. Billiot Fils Brut Rserve and Larmandier-Bernier Premier Cru Blanc de Blancs, $37 each at Astor Wines and Spirits, 12 Astor Place.) For a party splurge, there's the 1997 Coeur de Cuve Brut from Vilmart & Cie ($85 at Astor). It's riveting, he says: "The only problem is that it's a conversation stopper. Everyone at the party will be asking, 'What in God's name is this?"' SANDRA BALLENTINE

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the backgrounds of business and political leaders made an imprecise generalization about "every new justice" of the Supreme Court since 1969. While it is true that every one of them attended Harvard, Yale, Stanford or the University of Chicago, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg did not graduate from one of the four. She went to Harvard Law School and then graduated from Columbia Law School.

title: A Radiant New 'Messiah' and Other Musical Gifts
description: 'Altre Follie: 1500-1750'

title: Intelligent Design Might Be Meeting Its Maker
description: TO read the headlines, intelligent design as a challenge to evolution seems to be building momentum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, LEA
description: DIAMOND--Lea. 88, died December 1, 2005. She is survived by her loving daughters and sons-in-law Sharon (Roger Nathaniel) Diamond, Lois (Thomas) Gueli, her cherished grandchildren Allison, Jonathan, Lydia, Jeremy, Jasper and Emma, two devoted brothers and sisters-inlaw Murray (Nina) Migdal and Julie (Gloria) Migdal. Her beloved husband Herbert died in 1999. Her family was her world. Service 12 noon Sunday, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, NY (Saw Mill exit 17). Memorial to Palliative Care Institute, Mt Sinai School of Medicine, 1 Gustave Levy Place, Box 1070, NY, NY 10029 or Phelps Hospice, 710 N. Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591.

title: Pack Man
description: He knows how to stay ahead of the game.Discretion is the better part of glamour. Ask any Tom, Dick or Ari. Today's master of the universe wants hidden luxury, not a conspicuous designer logo that's so five minutes ago-go. And nothing says reverse snobbery like Valextra, the venerable Italian company known for its anonymous but stately leather goods.

title: Women's Alpine Skiing: Kildow blows through the swirl
Mediate or Secede: Has It Come to This?
description: IT is not exactly the Confederacy versus the Union. It is not even Quebec versus Canada. But the fight over money, respect and independence that has divided Greenburgh in recent years appears almost as intractable as either of those battles.

title: THE GET: Tutorial; Mix Mastery
description: Here's a typical holiday entertaining quandary: you have 12 people coming to dinner, but not enough of anything for 6, let alone 12, place settings. Do not despair. It is possible to use your great-grandmother's fancy china and silverware along with your own minimalist-mod dishes, cheapo stainless-steel cutlery from the mall and those vintage dessert plates you couldn't resist on your last trip to L.A. -- without making the whole thing look like a rummage sale. After all, this isn't a state dinner. The secret is in the mix. Just follow these six simple rules, and even the most mismatched table will look fashionably eclectic. (Tableware credits on Page 175.)

title: Don't Fly Over Cheney, Weekend Pilots
description: WASHINGTON - Anyone who doesn't know what Mickey Mouse, Saddam Hussein, Dick Cheney and the odd volcano have in common better not be a pilot. It's the no-fly zone.

title: Lemieux Makes Time for Cancer Victims
description: Pittsburgh's struggles weigh on Mario Lemieux, but that has not stopped him from sharing the experiences of his battle against Hodgkin's lymphoma with others who are fighting the disease. On Friday, the NBC series "Three Wishes" showed a segment in which he spends time with 9-year-old Mitch Konkle of Marshall, Mich., whose diagnosis was made in June.

title: Exploration Books
description: ADVENTURE DIVAS: Searching the Globe for a New Kind of Heroine. By Holly Morris. (Villard, $23.95.) The author's quest to film intrepid women from other cultures for her TV series.

title: Big Doesn't Always Mean Bad for Some Mutual Funds
description: BIG mutual funds have gotten a bad reputation as ungainly investment vehicles that cannot keep up with smaller, nimbler competitors.

title: Model Behavior
description: "TWO guys?" the doorman at Stereo, a new club in Chelsea, asked a pair of clubgoers. "I'm sorry, I can't help you."

title: Stocking Stuffers
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELOCA, CORNELIUS E.
description: DeLOCA--Cornelius E. The Executive Committee, Foundation Board and staff of the Metropolitan Golf Association mourn the passing of their former President and Chairman on December 1st. Connie DeLoca was more than a dedicated volunteer, he was a friend and leader. His many contributions to the MGA, and in particular to junior golf, will have a lasting impact on the game he loved. We offer our deepest sympathies to his wife Ann, children, grandchildren and to the entire DeLoca family. Donald J. Hendler, President Jay Mottola, Exec. Dir.

title: Remembrance Of a Porch Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Living by the Kick, or Dying by the Kick
description: The lone full-time place-kicker in the Pro Football Hall of Fame watches the end of these games from the comfort of retirement. He sees balls miss left, right and short. He sees balls clear the bar between the uprights. He sees the wild celebrations and the tortured expressions, emotions divided by the color of the uniform.

title: Robot Rock
description: It took more than a year, but Beck finally found the performers he wanted for his new video: they are about two feet tall, with shining eyes, silver skin and killer moves. Thanks to them, the video for "Hell Yes" has been enjoying heavy rotation on MTV2 since its premiere several weeks ago. (It can also be seen on Beck.com.) And thanks to the video, the QRIO (as in "curious"), a robot manufactured by Sony, is now a rising cyberstar.

title: She Loved Him, Yeah, Yeah, Yeah
description: IF I hadn't called my ex-husband the last time a Beatle died, I wouldn't have had to do anything. But I did track him down after George Harrison died in November 2001, which is when he learned that I was living in New York, which is when he asked me to take a letter to Strawberry Fields in Central Park and place it there with a single candle.

title: 'Tte--Tte: Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre'
The Gamer as Artiste
description: LAST week, I spent several days living -- and dying -- inside the new Xbox 360 console, with four popular games pegged as particularly cinematic. I entered as a curious novice, less concerned with breaking the games than with exploring the worlds they opened, and the worlds you die in.

title: Bad Year for Tommy But Not for Thomas J.
description: The last year may have been a cruel one for Tommy Hilfiger, the corporation, but it has been kinder to Thomas J. Hilfiger, the corporation's honorary chairman and principal designer.

title: Fed's 'oracle' advises his young successor
For a 'Veggie Car,' Grease Is the Word
description: THE fryers run all day at the Super Duper Weenie outlets in Fairfield and Monroe. The modest hot dog stands have been celebrated in magazines like Gourmet and Cigar Aficionado and on David Letterman's show, and every time there's more exposure, the lines grow.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Hoboken History, Illustrated by Children

title: All Visitors Must Be Announced
description: DOORMEN

title: Haverford Debates Impact of Athletics
description: With a duck pond at its main entrance, a nature trail encircling the campus and more than 1,400 labeled trees and shrubs defining the grounds of its arboretum, Haverford College hardly looks like a jock school.

title: A Modern Monument Among the Vines
description: AFTER a drive that took us through several small towns in the Austrian countryside and past flat stretches of vineyards, the stark modernity of the Loisium resort came as something of a shock. We arrived late at night, and the primarily glass three-story building stood there glowing, standing out like a U.F.O., set amid an expansive parking lot and muddy fields of fledgling vines.

title: The status of Kosovo
A Simmering Rivalry, Another Life Lost
description: NEW ROCHELLE - THE tributes to the memory of Raymond Harris have begun to fade. The candles placed at the site of his death in a shooting on Halloween are gone, leaving mosaics of melted wax. The Hartley Houses courtyard where he passed the time on countless nights is now locked up. It has been ever since the death of Mr. Harris, 25, known as "Ray Ray."

title: Sports Books
description: BASEBALL BEFORE WE KNEW IT: A Search for the Roots of the Game. By David Block. (University of Nebraska, $29.95.) Who invented baseball? The author says legitimate claims to its origin can be made by several countries, including France.

title: Rangers Cannot Stop the Capitals' Rookie
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 - Don't concede rookie of the year honors to Sidney Crosby just yet.

title: In Winnowing the Candidates at Haverford, Every Little Thing Counts
description: Wherever he goes, Jess Lord, the dean of admissions and financial aid at Haverford College, says he hears the same thing: An athletic career is a good way to improve your chances of getting into an elite college. It is no myth.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the revival of the No-Cal soda brand included a quotation that misstated the product line of the Ben & Jerry's ice cream company. It does indeed sell vanilla and chocolate.

title: 'Shopping in the Renaissance'
description: In February 2001 the British artist Michael Landy took over an empty department store in central London. Before a fascinated and occasionally distraught audience of friends, fellow-artists and strangers drawn in from the streets, he and his assistants placed all his personal possessions on a conveyor belt. Looping round the complex, mechanised route, Landy's furniture, record collection, clothing and even his car were first inventoried and then systematically dismembered, divided and shredded. The work attracted considerable press attention and provoked a powerful public response. Landy's emphasis on destruction was seen as a challenge to the champions of consumerism and as a strong commentary on the seductions of acquisition and ownership. The setting, the bare interior of a store stripped of its lighting, counters and displays, was central to the work's meaning (Figure 1). As shoppers moved on from the performance into the still-functioning department stores and shops nearby, they were invited to reflect on the ultimate purposelessness of their purchases.

title: Dorsoduro, Venice: On the Grand Canal but Out of the Mainstream
description: LA PISCINA, an enchanting open air barge of a restaurant, is moored permanently quayside in the Giudecca Canal in Venice. Dinner -- inky squid, grilled radicchio, Mediterranean fishes roasted in salt -- is served under a white canopy of market umbrellas; the backdrop of night sky and wide water shimmers, dark and glittering. Here, in the Dorsoduro district, just across the Grand Canal from San Marco, Venice feels suddenly quieter, more like an island and distinctly less touristy.

title: CHANGE RECOMMENDED IN PENSIONS
description: A new report on New Jersey's troubled pension and health-benefits system recommends several drastic changes that could save the state hundreds of millions of dollars a year, but are also likely to anger thousands of government workers and retirees. According to people who have seen the report, the state should increase the minimum retirement age to 60 from 55 for public employees other than police officers, firefighters or judges. The report also supports adjusting the salary base by which pensions are calculated, potentially reducing each employee's pension by 2 to 3 percent.

title: The Remix; The Paper Boy
description: Try this on Boxing Day. Perhaps as an act of absolution for our consumerist culture, Yuken Teruya is giving paper back to the forest. Teruya, a Japanese artist based in Brooklyn, carves delicate trees out of shopping bags from the Gap, Louis Vuitton and Godiva (above). He turns the sacks on their sides and painstakingly cuts out the pristine dioramas; the slices from the top shed a dappled light that creates an ethereal-looking landscape. Teruya's trees, which include paper from less rarefied provenances like cardboard toilet-paper rolls and McDonald's bags, can be seen currently at the Yokohama International Triennial in Japan. Waste not, want not.

title: Searching for the Point of No Return
description: LATELY, special-effects blockbusters on television have seemed preoccupied with the weather ("Category 7") and Armageddon ("Revelations"), which makes this week's mini-series on Sci Fi almost seem like a throwback: the focus is that familiar, foreboding chunk of ocean called the Bermuda Triangle. But if the six-hour series, "The Triangle," seen in three parts Monday through Wednesday, seems to start from an old-school premise, that's just what the creators, Bryan Singer and Dean Devlin, wanted.

title: Houses and Gardens
description: Some people aren't interested in real estate -- but not many. After all, a house (yours, your neighbor's, your rich uncle's) is always more than a home: it's a source of gossip and speculation, competition and outright fantasy. With a click of your TV remote, whole networks of architects, decorators, gardeners and contractors prove the point -- and so, especially at this time of year, does a high-end niche of the publishing business.

title: Moscow election seen as bellwether of Putin's political changes
Cookbooks
description: AGAINST THE GRAIN: 150 Good Carb Mediterranean Recipes. By Diane Kochilas. (Morrow, $24.95.) Low-calorie diet food from the author of "Meze" and "The Glorious Foods of Greece."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIESS, ANNELIESE, PH.D.
description: RIESS--Anneliese, Ph.D. On December 1, 2005. Loving sister of Elsa and sister-in-law of Ruth. She will be profoundly missed.

title: Comics Chronicle
description: "Do you wanna see a great new comic strip?" Charlie Brown asks Patty, running up with a distinctively oblong sheet of drawing paper. "It's about these two guys in an office, see?" he explains. "One guy offers the other guy this piece of English toffee, see? Then this other guy says, 'Thank you very much. I'll eat this during toffee-break!' Get it?"

title: Local Democrats On the Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal Stabbing in Brooklyn
description: A 41-year-old man whom relatives said had struggled with drug problems was found stabbed to death in his Brooklyn apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: Buy a Pie and Help Save a Family Farm
description: THANKSGIVING and Christmas are crunch time at Youngs Farm in Old Brookville. It's peak pie season.

title: A Long, Long Haul From the Curb
description: TULLYTOWN is probably not a place many Long Islanders have ever heard of, much less visited. But the community, a small borough in Bucks County, Pa., on the Delaware River north of Philadelphia, does the Island a big favor every day. It accepts truckloads of a growing Long Island export: garbage.

title: Muslim women take charge of their faith
A Vision for Reviving a Wreck
description: "I HAVE an idea!" said Alexander Gorlin, walking around the small one-bedroom apartment at 140 East 40th Street, a 1931 Art Deco apartment house designed by Bien & Prince only a few blocks from Grand Central Terminal. Strolling through the place -- with its peeling paint and the smallest kitchen known to woman -- Mr. Gorlin said he was far from shocked. "Actually it reminds me of one of the first apartments I ever did, 15 years ago," he said. "That had belonged to an agoraphobic and was -- like this one -- untouched."

title: Queen for a Day
description: She was a lovely blonde girl with soaring cheekbones and Baltic green eyes, tall as a linden tree, but with curves. She learned the piano, went to school and to church, dreamed of boys and the world beyond the small town where she knew everyone and everyone knew her. She wanted to teach, but her father wanted her to learn stenography and English. Her mother, a colonel in the Salvation Army, wanted the same. "Do as the colonel says, her father would command. And so she did.

title: The Remix: Kids; Lodge Ball
description: Taking the kids on safari is a natural. Conservation Corporation Africa offers programs that give parents a moment to enjoy the lions (or something equally wild) while their offspring attend the children's program. At Kwandwe Ecca Lodge, a Relais and Chteaux property, rates start at $782. Go to www.ccafrica.com. The Whiteface Lodge in upstate New York has more kid distractions than your average luxury hotel. Starting this month, it boasts a year-round ice rink, bowling lanes, a 60-seat movie theater and an on-site chocolate maker, as well as skiing and hiking in the Lake Placid environs. Studios sleep four and start at $345 a night. Go to www.thewhitefacelodge.com.For a quirky experience, head to the Appalachian town of Cleveland, Ga., to see Cabbage Patch Kids being "born" at BabyLand General Hospital (below). Admission is free. About 75 miles north of Atlanta, the region has some down-home lodging options, like the Country Inn and Suites (706-878-9000). You can also roost rustically at the Black Bear Lodge and Cabins (706-865-0093). Go to www.cabbagepatchkids.com. A.Z.

title: In On the Political Act
description: Q: You were recently nominated by President Bush to serve on the board of the U.S. Institute of Peace, which was founded in the wake of the Vietnam War to promote peace. When will the Senate vote on your nomination?

title: Lynne Truss Has Another Gripe With You
description: I wonder how many other British readers turned to Deborah Solomon's article on Lynne Truss (Nov. 20) and exclaimed, "There's Sooty!" How lovely to see a furry friend from my childhood. Thanks for posing her with Harry Corbett's hand puppet Sooty in the photo.

title: The War in Iraq And Our Self-Esteem
description: To the Editor:

title: On Their Toes
description: Correction Appended

title: Briefs: Doctors say patient pleased with new face
For Swedish mayor, a monumental task
Rome: Fincato Pipes
description: Even though Einstein, Darwin and Millicent Fenwick all smoked pipes, Emiliano Fincato warns not to assume too much about pipe smokers' brainpower. "It used to be said that pipe smokers were more reflective," he said. "It's not true."

title: Girls With Their Eyes on a Goal, and a Puck
description: BREWSTER - WHEN Ann Derrey and Caroline Cooley played women's ice hockey for St. Lawrence University in the late 1970's, school officials refused to make their club team a varsity squad.

title: All Things Helen
description: HELEN OF TROY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANDMAN, SHIRLEY (NEE KRAENDIS)
description: HANDMAN -- Shirley (nee Kraendis). Loving mother, wife, friend, humanist, activist. Bright, bold & beautiful.

title: The Soft Touch
description: Blazers may have been the standard fare for fall, but as the December holiday season approaches, shoppers are looking for something hipper than tweed and less predictable than velvet. This month super-thin leather blazers by June have become the hot commodity. Worn over a skirt or a pair of jeans for evening or dress pants for work, the buttery-soft toppers are swiftly proving themselves to be the chic go-to jackets of the moment. In bone, black or claret, June's blazers have a feminine, tailored cut, a hint of sheen and are lined with luxurious vintage-look floral patterned silks that evoke 30's-via-70's-era styles ($395 at Gatsbys in Great Barrington, Mass., 413-528-9455). PULSE

title: In California, Border Is Focus of an Election
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 - With a special election on Tuesday, one of the strongest Republican Congressional districts in California has become a focal point for national immigration policy, thanks to a long-shot independent candidate who helped organize a volunteer border patrol group.

title: The Remix; It's all about ...
description: TAHITI ... GIVING THANK-YOUS ... Sports cars for kids ... SPIRITS OF THE SEASON ... playing your cards right ... a very special detox.

title: Shrine to Hours of Tinkering in a Garage on the Ground Floor of Silicon Valley
description: Correction Appended

title: Thousands march in Hong Kong
Editors' Choice
description: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

title: Now Serving: Bar Necessities
description: When the first frost hits SoHo, look for the Tom & Jerry bowl at the Pegu Club, where the owner, Audrey Saunders, will be ladling out mugfuls of the hot, frothy drink. Spiked with Cognac and aged rum, it combines the childish pleasure of warm milk with the adult pleasure of good booze.

title: Why employer-based health insurance lasts in U.S.
My Life as It Wasn't
description: MAKING IT UP

title: From Pants to Paper
description: I'M an only child. My father died when I was 12, after which my mother and I were left to run our men's clothing store until I graduated from college. My mother had never worked in the business. After she was forced to let the seamstress go, I had to learn how to take up hems. I'm the only C.E.O. I know who can alter a pair of men's pants.

title: Mac Programs That Come With Thinking Caps On
description: IT'S time for another look at "thinking tools" -- software for storing, retrieving and generally making the best use of information. Today the focus is on programs for the Apple Macintosh.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2006 Chevrolet Impala LT; Teaching an Old Antelope to Jump Through New Hoops
description: CLEVELAND - WITH the redesign of its Impala family sedan, Chevrolet claims to have revamped its entire line of passenger cars. Still, the Impala could be forgiven for having a hand-me-down complex.

title: Wheels and Deals in Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO - RANDY KOMISAR, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist, used to consider his cycling habits extreme even by the standards of the fanatically fit Bay Area.

title: Courting Europe, Turkey Tries Some Soul-Cleansing
description: VAN, Turkey - THE 10th-century Akhtamar Church, its stone facade alive with vivid images of birds, animals, saints and warriors, dominates a small island just off the southern shore of Lake Van. For nearly a millennium, this spectacular Armenian monument was a seat of great religious and political power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTON, HAZEL B.
description: GOLDSTON--Hazel B. On Friday, December 2, 2005. Formerly of East Meadow, NY. Devoted mother of David and Lori Goldston. Cherished grandmother of Isaac Hansen. Interment will be on December 5 at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions may be made to The Shakespeare Theater in Washington, DC.

title: Pave My Road and You'll Get Your School
description: KABUL, Afghanistan - AFTER two and a half tortured decades -- Russian invasion, civil war, Taliban rule, a hunt for members of Al Qaeda and a war to oust the Taliban -- Afghanistan is finally getting a glimpse of what representative national rule will look like.

title: Simplifying Choices on New Homes
description: HERE'S a new option in home building: fewer options.

title: On Baseball; General Management By Committee in Boston
description: WITH no general manager on board but with Manny Ramirez still on the roster, the Boston Red Sox will visit Dallas this week with their unique operating staff. No other team at the winter meetings, which begin tomorrow, will have anything like it.

title: Building Homes for Disabled Soldiers
description: EARLY last year, John Gonsalves, a construction supervisor from Taunton, Mass., decided to use his skills to help build houses for soldiers returning from Iraq. The soldiers he had in mind were paralyzed, or missing arms or legs, or blind or deaf. Or more than one of the above.

title: 'Elsewhere,' by Gabrielle Zevin
description: ELSEWHERE

title: The Greening of Hunter Orange
description: NOW that the courts have given the go-ahead for New Jersey's second bear hunt in 35 years, let the real battle begin: animal-rights activists jumping up and down for the cameras, hunters on parade lugging around 600-pound bear carcasses, the usual overheated morality play (Critters good! Hunters bad!) in denim and camo.

title: An Explosive Incentive To Donate Food
description: The City of New Haven plans a big reward for someone who donates food to the needy this holiday: the right to implode the New Haven Coliseum.

title: 'The Highest Tide'
A United Nations of Weird-Looking Sketches
description: About three months ago, Peter Edmunds, a 22-year-old communications student at the University of Canberra, in Australia, began SwarmSketch.com with the idea of producing a sketch of "the collective consciousness" every week.

title: War, Rape, Barbed Wire: Remember, It's a Comedy
description: IT'S okay to laugh at an Ariel Dorfman play. Although this Chilean author is a prolific chronicler and dogged opponent of torture, repression and human rights abuse in that Land Where Terrible Things Happen, he insists that laughter is sometimes an entirely appropriate response to grim events.

title: Yoga Assumes a Social Position
description: ON a recent Friday night Valentine Remusat om'd and saluted the sun and arched her back in the cobra posture at a yoga class, until she came into final resting pose 90 minutes later, lying on her back in shivasana.

title: Study Endorses A Village Police Force
description: It would be feasible legally and financially to create a village police force in Mineola, according to a study presented to the village board in mid-November.

title: Building Stories
description: PART 12: 8 a.m.

title: Franz Jolowicz, 86, Dies; Owned a Noted Record Store
description: Franz Jolowicz, the owner of the former Discophile record shop, a Greenwich Village institution that was for decades a mecca for classical record collectors, from the ardent to the insatiable to the merely obsessive, died on Nov. 8 at his home in the Village. He was 86.

title: NOT MY JOB
description: With all the concern about keeping track of the tens of billions of dollars in federal reconstruction aid pouring into the Gulf Coast, one might think that fighting mismanagement and corruption would be high on the list of priorities for President Bush's handpicked on-site coordinator, Donald E. Powell, the former chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Commission.

title: G.O.P. to Roll Out A Big Gun for Kean
description: While matters remain somewhat unsettled on the Democratic side in New Jersey, the national Republican Party is providing its blessing on the candidacy of State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr. for United States Senate in 2006.

title: Deborah Marcus and Kenneth Auslander
description: Deborah Esther Marcus, a daughter of Rene and Henry Marcus of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Kenneth Jay Auslander, the son of Herman M. Auslander of Livingston, N.J., and the late Florence Auslander. Rabbi Herman L. Cohen is to officiate at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan.

title: Man Injured in Fire Dies
description: A Brooklyn man died apparently of a heart attack after suffering smoke inhalation from a fire in his apartment building in Bedford-Stuyvesant about 3:30 a.m. yesterday morning, officials said.

title: The Changing Landscape of Roosevelt Island
description: IT was to have been the quintessential urban utopia: a small town within yards of the city, a waterfront paradise with abundant open space and a demographer's dream bringing together a broad sweep of nationalities, ages and income levels.

title: All Hail the Mighty SpongeBob ArtPants
description: WHEN Larry Mantello bought his first SpongeBob SquarePants item -- a pair of slippers -- in 2003, he was clueless. He didn't know the name of the four-cornered yellow creature with the skewed grin. He had never heard of the wildly popular television cartoon. And he was unaware that some vigilant congressmen, forsaking the option of don't ask, don't tell, had accused SpongeBob of being a bit swishy, and therefore a poor role model for children. Mr. Mantello simply liked the look.

title: Pacific Heights
description: Like Marlon Brando before them, wealthy travelers are turning to Tahiti as the dropout destination du jour, the new Christmas capital of inconspicuous consumption. "If you really want to show off, you go to St. Bart's," says the photographer and makeup magnate Franois Nars, who splits his time between Manhattan and his private Polynesian motu, or islet. "But the Tahitians let you live your life. It's great for movie stars." Even the local bakers are discreet; daily baguettes are delivered to cylindrical mailboxes at the end of each driveway.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 13
description: Dallas Cowboys (7-4) at Giants (7-4) 1 p.m.

title: What Artists Do When Not Suffering
description: The artists and poets who frequent Yaddo and MacDowell might already have predicted what two psychologists at the University of Newcastle Upon Tyne and the Open University in Britain announced last week: creative types of both sexes have more sexual partners than their nonartistic counterparts, according to their research, which will be posted on the Web site of the Proceedings of the Royal Society B, a British journal.

title: Man Attacks Driver; Dies Moments Later
description: A Bronx man died Friday evening after he attacked the driver of a van in the Bronx Park South neighborhood and was held down by bystanders until the police arrived, witnesses and the police said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,117 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans Friday and yesterday:

title: In Odessa, Friday Night Pizza
description: Emily Weinberg and her husband, Jason Lagapa, were living in Tempe, Ariz., in July 2004 when Mr. Lagapa, an English professor at Arizona State University, was offered and accepted a tenure-track position at the University of Texas of the Permian Basin in Odessa, the West Texas city immortalized in the book and movie "Friday Night Lights."

title: Blair to unveil his proposals on EU budget
Multiple Reality Syndrome
description: Most serious people who spend time in Iraq report that reality there is contradictory and kaleidoscopic. The Sunnis are participating in the democratic process; the Sunnis are supporting the insurgents. The Shiites are building a national government; the Shiites are creating death squads. The Americans are securing neighborhoods; the Americans are inciting violence.

title: Mother Must Muzzle the Nuzzle
description: I'M in Powell's bookstore cafe, and the young couple next to me are canoodling: staring deeply into each other's eyes, holding hands across the table and smooching.

title: The Prodigy Puzzle
description: I read with great interest Ann Hulbert's article (Nov. 20). My son was a Davidson fellow two years ago at 17 and was awarded the round of Washington Senate visits and dinners. I found much in the article compelling. But a major theme is that kids of prodigious ability may be pushed by well-meaning but overbearing parents and mentors.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Arts & Leisure

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 4-Dec. 10; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: Sunday is your last chance to visit Art Basel Miami Beach, the world's most popular contemporary art fair (it closes at 6 p.m.), but there is more to see in southern Florida if you happen to be staying on. Most notable is the United States premiere of a new work by the British avant-garde filmmaker ISAAC JULIEN at the Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami. Titled "TRUE NORTH," the film is based on the story of Matthew Henson, who, on an expedition with Robert Peary in 1909, became the first African-American to reach the North Pole. The exhibition remains on view through Feb. 5; (305) 893-6211 or www.mocanomi.org.

title: Out of the Nest, Into a Studio
description: TURNING 30 and still living with her mother -- that was one milestone Marlie Hall did not want to reach. Ms. Hall had reasons for staying so long in the house where she grew up in Bay Shore, on Long Island. As an only daughter (she has three brothers), she was reluctant to leave her divorced mother. And, as a television reporter and anchor, she was aware that a job opportunity could arise somewhere far away.

title: If a Student Can Major in Piano, Why Can't a Player Major in Passing?
description: It has become evident to me that we are living a double standard. This is even more apparent in light of the revelation that University High School, a correspondence school in Miami, gave athletes who struggled academically a quick and easy path to qualifying for college scholarships.

title: Attack Kills a Top Leader of Al Qaeda, Pakistan Says
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Dec. 3 - A senior operational commander for Al Qaeda was killed Thursday in what was thought to be a missile attack on a house in Pakistan's northern tribal strongholds, officials in Pakistan and the United States said Saturday.

title: Socialites in Borrowed Clothing? Quick, Take a Photograph
description: THIS week, a few days before the Winter Wonderland Ball at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx on Friday, Tinsley Mortimer will go to pick out her dress. One of six junior chairwomen of the party, Ms. Mortimer will not be visiting Bergdorf Goodman or Saks Fifth Avenue; she will drop by the showroom of Paco Rabanne to chose a dress from the spring collection designed by Patrick Robinson, which will be lent to her for the night.

title: Boats With Attitude
description: If you head to the East River before sunset, you're likely to catch a glimpse of a doughty little tugboat gliding under the necklace of lights on the 59th Street Bridge, accompanying a string of giant scows. Dwarfed by its massive charges, the tug calls to mind a dog escorting a herd of cattle. But appearances are deceiving: if you look closely, you'll see that the tug leaves a powerful wake. Its engine is mighty, and its pilot knows not just the treacherous local tides and currents but the tiny adjustments necessary to keep a chain of barges from going astray. He has to. As George Matteson writes in TUGBOATS OF NEW YORK: An Illustrated History (New York University, $39.95), "It takes relatively little power to get them moving and a long time to get them to stop, and anything that gets in their way is done for."

Animal House
description: In the Roberto Cavalli animal kingdom, Eva Cavalli is queen. The wife and business partner of Roberto -- the Florentine fashion baron with a penchant for jungle prints -- Eva is a key player in the diverse brand, which now includes fashion, eyewear, fragrances, housewares, restaurants, vodka, even handmade chocolates. She is also responsible for the lavish parties that are as disco-decadent as the shredded chiffon that bears her name. But she is a purist at heart. "The most important things are the atmosphere, the good mix of people, good food and fantastic wine," says Eva, who met Roberto at the 1977 Miss Universe pageant in the Dominican Republic, where she was Miss Austria and he was a judge. Who better to explain what it takes to make a party purr?

title: Photography
description: One of the best photography books of the year, Friedlander (Museum of Modern Art, $75), is also clearly the definitive volume about this important photographer. While the banality of Lee Friedlander's subject matter fuels a continuing debate about his stature, his pictures are by no means banal. The engaging biographical essay by Peter Galassi is an anatomy of the photographer's life and art, and, after paging through the book's 860 reproductions, you're likely to think that Friedlander has shown you something essential about the way you see the world.

description: ONE Sunday afternoon in March, my family and I drove up to our suburban Detroit home to find four fire trucks, two police cars and all our neighbors surrounding our house. It was the beginning of a financial, logistical and emotional ordeal that's still not over.

title: Goodbye, Moon
description: Portland, Ore. - "Goodnight Moon," the children's classic by Margaret Wise Brown, has gone smoke free. In a newly revised edition of the book, which has lulled children to sleep for nearly 60 years, the publisher, HarperCollins, has digitally altered the photograph of Clement Hurd, the illustrator, to remove a cigarette from his hand. HarperCollins said it made the change to avoid the appearance of encouraging smoking.

title: Park and Ride and Provoke
description: The commuter lot at my train station is reserved for Scarsdale residents. I live in a neighboring town, so I park on the street. Although this is legal, a few people on the block take umbrage with my doing so. Is it unethical or even impolite for me to leave my car there for the day?

title: In This Round, Taylor Leaves Little Doubt
description: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 3 - More relaxed, with more experience and with the belts in his corner, Jermain Taylor had a slightly easier time convincing the judges Saturday night that he indeed was the undisputed middleweight champion.

title: A Modern Monument Among the Vines
description: AFTER a drive that took us through several small towns in the Austrian countryside and past flat stretches of vineyards, the stark modernity of the Loisium resort came as something of a shock. We arrived late at night, and the primarily glass three-story building stood there glowing, standing out like a U.F.O., set amid an expansive parking lot and muddy fields of fledgling vines.

title: The Remix; Sweet Charity
description: Double your giving power with chic charity gifts that go beyond ribbon pins. Gucci is donating 20 percent of its sales from the likes of ostrich handbags and logo candles to Unicef programs helping children affected by H.I.V. or AIDS. It makes their red-and-green ribbons seem so seasonal. Evelyn Lauder has taken up her camera to benefit the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. Fifty boxed sets of her "Ten Beauties" portfolio (left) are available for $3,750 each (www.bcrfcure.org features other goodies from Coach and Burberry). And Mercedes-Benz is putting its money where its motor is, pledging $1 million from the sales of its 750 Signature Edition R-Class to the Saks Fifth Avenue Key to the Cure women's cancer campaign. Bergdorf Goodman has asked the designers from Bottega Veneta, Gucci and others to trim its tree. The original ornaments will go for $350, while replicas will sell for $30, all of which goes to God's Love We Deliver (www.godslovewedeliver.org). For the do-gooder on the go, Jack Spade's travel Scrabble helps Book Relief restock libraries hit by Hurricane Katrina. New Orleanians will also benefit from sales of Box of Questions holiday sets, 35 cards that give family dinner conversations a kick under the table ($20; www.theboxgirls.com). Give and ye shall receive. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: South Korea's Cloning Crisis
description: South Korea's high-flying stem cell researchers -- reputedly the best in the world at cloning -- have stumbled badly in handling the ethical issues of their controversial craft. Worse yet, the research team's leader, a national hero in his homeland, lied in an effort to hide his ethical lapses. We can only hope that he has not also lied about the astonishing scientific achievements of his research team.

title: Bush Administration Unyielding on Secret Terror Camp Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 - With Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice setting off for Europe amid a storm of concern over reports of secret C.I.A. interrogation centers there, the Bush administration appeared to stake out an unyielding position on the matter today.

title: Sales of Impotence Drugs Fall, Defying Expectations
description: Seven years after Pfizer made Viagra a cultural touchstone and commercial blockbuster, the market for impotence medicines appears to have fallen well short of what was once predicted.

title: The Originals; 'TIS THEIR SEASON
description: Alkalay | Entrepreneur

title: The Remix; L.A. Stories
description: Shearling may be all the rage this season, but L.A. fashionistas are craving an altogether different kind of fur. Hypoallergenic dogs that don't cause your guests' eyes to water and their skin to itch have replaced Priuses as the new politically correct status symbol. Concerned celebrities like Britney Spears and Jessica Simpson are doing their part by snapping up a Maltese and a maltipoo, respectively. But the top dog, which has a waiting list and costs as much as a Fendi Spy Bag, is the nonshedding labradoodle ($2,500) -- a mix of Lab and poodle that the California breeder Heather Hale describes as "smart, loving and having absolutely no odor." If only it would come with shoes to match.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 4-Dec. 10; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Opera has a new love couple, and they're the big news this week: ANNA NETREBKO, the Russian soprano, and ROLANDO VILLAZN, the Mexican tenor, are arriving at the Met in "RIGOLETTO" on Saturday night. Both singers have been the objects of considerable hype, but while I haven't heard them together live in an opera house, there are indications that they're at least partly as good as their billing. Mr. Villazn has an ardent blood-and-guts Domingo-esque delivery; what people seem to be asking is just how big the sound is in the opera house. (It seemed perfectly adequate to me in recital last year.) Ms. Netrebko's "Sempre Libera" aria album struck me as a little bloodless and machinelike, but on the recording of their "Traviata" in Salzburg this summer, which came out earlier this month, she seems if anything overemotional. It's a tossup whether you want to spend the money for the "Traviata" recording -- on which Thomas Hampson does not do much to further his case as a Verdi baritone -- or on one of the few tickets left for "Rigoletto," a show that spotlights the baritone even more: CARLO GUELFI appears in the title role. 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000.

title: Ohio Bodies Are Those Of Children Slain in 2003
description: On a desperate quest last summer for the bodies of her murdered children, Teresa Knight searched 650 miles of Midwestern highway and came up empty.

title: Holiday on Ice
description: IT'S TIME TO CELEBRATE -- WITH A TWIST

title: Cooking
description: MORE than an irresistible new technique, a fantastically exotic ingredient or even the promise of a better marriage, what inspires us to go into the kitchen is the voice of a writer, seducing and prodding and bucking us up.

title: For Many Reasons, Tracks Turn Deadly
description: Ever since Leidschnudel Dreispul, described as a middleaged Bronx man, was struck dead at 137th Street and Broadway by Express Train 3051, on Nov. 3, 1904, hundreds of people have died on the subway tracks, victims of murder or suicide, accident or folly. Here are some memorable examples.

title: Correction
description: The "Going To" column on Nov. 13, about Salt Lake City, misstated the legal status of polygamy in late 19th-century Utah. It had been prohibited under federal law since 1862, not 1890, and it continued to be illegal after Utah became a state in 1896.

title: The Rock Wife
description: Jo Wood, a designer of organic beauty products and the wife of Ron Wood, the Rolling Stones guitarist, is making an effort to wear colors in bleak winter. "Ronnie complained that I always wear black," she said, "and so I'm trying to branch out. It's not easy because I love black, even in summer. I especially like to mix it with gold."

title: The Prodigy Puzzle
description: I have found that there is often an inverse relationship between what I perceive to be a genuinely innovative thinker in my third-grade classroom and the attitude of the parents. The most intellectually curious and imaginative problem solvers have parents who are supportive of rather than ambitious for their child. And each year I am struck by how some of the most perceptive children come from families whose parents have no time to advocate for them and no "gifted" agenda to pursue.

title: What's Become of Bedside Manner?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINTHROP, LOWELL M.
description: WINTHROP--Lowell M., of Mount Vernon, NY, died on November 24, 2005. Call 1-917566-4190 for more info.

title: Matter; The Sugar Land Express
description: Will Cotton is inspecting a frilly white bra in the window of a lingerie shop on the Rue St. Honor in Paris. The 40-year-old artist, known for his sticky, sugary landscape paintings of gingerbread houses, chocolate forests and ice-cream caverns, is doing research. Lately, Cotton has peopled his Candy Land scenes with girls clad in panties, various underpinnings and hats made from fondant icing. They sit perched odalisque-style, naturally, on cotton-candy clouds. The boutique's lacy display reminds him of some of his own confections. Cotton deals with temptation and excess, but he is not one to comment on overconsumption or the dangers of trans fats. "I'm interested in depicting an imagined utopia, a place that's only about pleasure," he says.

title: AT SUNSET, IN THE WADI RUM DESERT, SEPT. 24, 2005
description: Tom Panas, 56, a media consultant from New York: "I was part of a tour to the desert. We were spending the night in a Bedouin camp and the tour guide said 'Would anybody like to walk the rest of the way?,' which was about a mile. I said I would. What struck me most was how comfortable I felt amidst that beauty. It was awesome but it didn't seem overpowering. And as twilight came, it added to the beauty: the colors, as the sun set, became kind of bluish-purple. As the desert hills and rocks were darkening, you could still see them very clearly, but they began to be silhouetted, dark silhouettes against a grayish-blue twilight. It's the beauty of the desert that it creates those kinds of hues."

title: Beasts of No Nation
Pro-Democracy Groups Are Harassed in Central Asia
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 - Groups paid by the United States to promote democracy in Central Asia are under sustained assault, not only from those governments but also from Russia, which is locked in conflict with Washington for dominance in the region's former Soviet republics.

title: Kazakh President Headed Toward Re-election Amid Fraud Charges
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan, Dec. 4 - The presidential election in Kazakhstan passed peacefully today, and early signs indicated that President Nursultan Nazarbayev, the former Communist boss who has ruled this country since it declared independence from the Soviet Union, was heading to a landslide victory over four opponents.

title: Bush's Speech on Iraq War Echoes Voice of an Analyst
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 - There could be no doubt about the theme of President Bush's Iraq war strategy speech on Wednesday at the Naval Academy. He used the word victory 15 times in the address; "Plan for Victory" signs crowded the podium he spoke on; and the word heavily peppered the accompanying 35-page National Security Council document titled, "Our National Strategy for Victory in Iraq."

title: Staying Within the Lines on Homework Help
description: LISA JACOBSON runs a tutoring business, Inspirica, in Manhattan, and she has seen parents at their worst, their most enmeshed, their pushiest. Parents who do their children's art projects for them, so the third-grade classroom looks, she said, "like a gallery at MoMA." Parents who tinker with science labs and correct math homework and edit English essays until the child does not recognize more than a comma in an opening sentence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODZELEWSKI, ZYGMUNT
description: MODZELEWSKI--Zygmunt born Roman Berger, 101, died on November 26, 2005, in Manhattan, New York. He was born near Krakow, Poland, where he attended the Jagiellonian University. During World War II, in great danger, he and his wife and daughter evaded incarceration in the Jewish Ghettos of Poland and he then recorded his experiences under Nazi occupied Poland in a book, "Hiding In Plain Sight" (Capstone Publishing Company, New York, N.Y., 1993). After the war Zygmunt Modzelewski joined the Polish Provisional Government, becoming the first Polish Director of UNRRA (United Nations Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Administration). He then held a series of positions concerned with the reconstruction of Poland. He was appointed Chief Delegate to the UNRRA Council in London and Chief of Mission to purchase American and British industrial and communication war surplus. He came to the United States as President of the Polish American Supply Corporation but, disappointed with the political direction of the increasingly communist government, he resigned his position and, with his wife, the late Jadwiga Eva (nee Hechtkopf), and daughter, received political asylum in the United States. He is deeply mourned by his daughter, Alice Coleman Schelling (nee Berger) of Bethesda, Md.; son-in-law, Thomas C. Schelling, and former son-in-law, Roy M. Coleman M.D.; grandsons, David Daniel Coleman of Mountainview Ca., and Robert Berger Coleman of Portland Or., as well as their families, and by nieces, Wladyslawa Tracz, Barbara Grannis, Erica Mitsidis, Crystal Feldman, and cousin, Miriam Karr. Memorial services will be held in late January, 2006.

It is the only place in the United States where it is sold, as this is (appearances notwithstanding) the most exclusive perfume shop in New York.

title: 'Triksta: Life and Death and New Orleans Rap'
Still Magnolias
description: It was bound to happen. I got married, bought a house big enough to hold the combined families of my husband and me at Christmas, and a Category 4 hurricane all but takes out the city I'd finally chosen to call home. We were lucky -- our house is mostly intact, and one of our first purchases for it, from my friend Patrick Dunne at Lucullus in the French Quarter, was a glorious walnut dining-room table that seats 28. Among the few things we didn't have to replace when we first started our renovation (which is now shaping up to be among the longest in the history of the world) was a commercial South Bend stove, so enormous that it takes up almost a whole wall in the kitchen. Given these fortuitous facts, I am relieved, grateful and imbued with not just a touch of survivor's guilt, the combination of which has made me more determined than ever to create the most joyous, festive and delicious holiday ever. I feel I owe it to my adopted city -- after all, its reputation and much of its economy have long been based on celebration and fine cuisine.

title: In Search of the Venus of 37th and Madison
description: JOHN YANG doesn't make a searing physical impression. Dressed in a button-down flannel shirt and khaki pants, his glasses dangling on a string around his neck, he looks more like a New England professor than an intrepid New York photographer. If you spotted him pointing his Leica at the carved faces on the facades of Manhattan's tenements and row houses, you probably wouldn't break your stride.

description: I first saw the artist Agnes Martin lecture in 1982 in Albuquerque. She said: "My paintings are not about what is seen. They are about what is known forever in the mind." I thought she was speaking directly to me.

title: Paperback Row
description: RUNAWAY: Stories, by Alice Munro. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) Set in rural Canada, these brilliant stories render the characters' lives with almost Tolstoyan resonance. "Trespasses" pivots around a couple's revelations to their daughter about the traumatic circumstances surrounding her birth. Three overlapping stories provide an affecting portrait of a woman and her harrowing life. Our reviewer, Jonathan Franzen, called this collection -- Munro's 11th -- a "marvel of a book." The Book Review named "Runaway" one of the best books of 2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARONOFF, WILLIAM
description: ARONOFF--William. Of Delray Beach, FL. Born July 21, 1917, died November 30. Beloved husband to Ruthe, father to Bonni and Elyse.

title: Vienna Calling
description: Designers headed to Mitteleuropa for the spring collections. Carolina Herrera translated early-20th-century Vienna in homespun floral appliquAs and embroideries (above). Proenza Schouler showed hand-folded hems and a trove of brocades, crewelwork and passementerie. The long silhouettes and petal sleeves at Rochas evoked Gustav Klimt. And Dior treated its Paris show guests to an after-hours preview of the "Vienna 1900" exhibit at the Grand Palais. Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler speculates that this yearning for fin de siA cle Vienna is a reaction to mass production. "It seems very appropriate now, he says, "because in today's competitive world, time and details are the truest form of luxury."

So here is our request for anyone running for governor next year to start tugging on that fateful thread.

title: Report Finds Cover-Up in an F.B.I. Terror Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 - Officials at the Federal Bureau of Investigation mishandled a Florida terror investigation, falsified documents in the case in an effort to cover repeated missteps and retaliated against an agent who first complained about the problems, Justice Department investigators have concluded.

title: Samuel Beckett Is Ready for His Close-Up
description: AT 83, Barney Rosset could be forgiven if he spent his days dwelling on his adventures of the last half-century. Grove Press, which he purchased in 1951 for $3,000, cracked open the federal censorship statutes by successfully defending the United States publication of D. H. Lawrence's "Lady Chatterley's Lover" in 1959, Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer" in 1961 and William S. Burroughs's "Naked Lunch" in 1962. The Evergreen Review, begun in 1957, expanded America's literary, political and psychic palette, providing the first widespread domestic access to political figures like Che Guevara and Malcolm X and literary figures like Jean Genet, Eugne Ionesco, Harold Pinter and the Beats. And he published almost all of Samuel Beckett's oeuvre, and served as his American agent for more than 35 years.

title: That's Good
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 4-Dec. 10; TELEVISION
description: "O.K., he's hot," says KYAN DOUGLAS (the grooming expert) when JOE UVA, the straight-guy subject of the first episode of "QUEER EYE: THE WEDDING SEASON" (BRAVO, Tuesday at 10 p.m.), puts on his new suit. Maybe this season all the stories won't seem so excruciatingly alike. Mr. Uva is proposing to his girlfriend of 10 years, who has finally had it with his failure to commit. The half-hour also includes sailing lessons, group bouquet-making and a jury duty theme (that's how the couple met). The show's impish fashion expert, CARSON KRESSLEY, makes a dangerous comment: "Sometimes no is just a slow yes." Luckily he's talking about replies to marriage proposals.

title: 'In Lucia's Eyes'
In Morocco, One Man's Oasis Is Another's Watering Hole
description: AS the sandstorm grew suddenly fierce, I hopped onto the camel and my turban unraveled in the wind. Raindrops strafed my face, and the startled camel growled like a creature from "Star Wars." Abbas, my guide, rolled his eyes. I couldn't blame him. This was not the way I'd envisioned making my entrance into the great Sahara.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHMIERER, HY
description: SCHMIERER--Hy, 86, December 1, 2005. Devoted husband of Horty for 56 years, loving father of Susan and Matthew Silverman & Merri and Harry Bragg. Adored "Poppy" of Rachel, Jaime, and Abbey Silverman. Cherished Uncle and Great Uncle to many nieces and nephews. Veteran of the US Army Air Corps in World War II. Founder, Owner and Director of Camp Starlight, Starlight, PA for 53 years. Loved and will be missed by thousands of campers and staff whose lives he touched and influenced. Former President of the Association of Independent Camps. Served on the Board of Governors of the New York Section of the American Camping Association. With his love for children and their well being, following his retirement in 1999, he became a board member of the Non-Violence Project in Miami, FL and an advisor to the Shake-A-Leg Foundation in Coconut Grove, FL. He continued to remain active in the Hancock (NY) Community Education Foundation. Funeral Services will be at "Gutterman's", 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY at 12:00 noon on Sunday, December 4, 2005. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hancock Community Education Foundation, 38 West Main Street, Hancock, NY 13783.

title: Inside the list
description: MAKING BOOKER: John Banville's Booker Prize-winning novel, "The Sea" is No. 28 on this week's extended hardcover fiction list, and it seems unlikely to climb much higher -- making it the third Booker selection in a row, after DBC Pierre's "Vernon God Little" (2003) and Alan Hollinghurst's "Line of Beauty" (2004) not to rise into The Times's top 15. The last Booker winner to make a deep impression on this country's readers was Yann Martel's "Life of Pi" (2002), which spent three months on the Times list in hardcover. Banville's novel is selling well in independent bookstores -- if this week's list were based only on sales from indie booksellers, omitting the chain stores, "The Sea" would move up 20 spots to No. 8. Banville's novel has taken a beating since the Booker announcement. (Writing in The Independent of London, Boyd Tonkin said the jury made "the most perverse and perhaps the most indefensible choice in the 36-year history of the contest.") Banville didn't help his case when he said, while accepting his award, "It's nice to see a work of art winning the Booker Prize." Banville, at this point, may feel some sympathy with Pierre, who accepted his 2003 Booker by commenting, "As Lloyd Bridges said, 'I think I picked the wrong week to give up sniffing glue.' "

title: The Tile-High Club
description: Now that poker is played out, young New Yorkers are reviving the Chinese tile game of mah-jongg. Jane Morledge, a creative director at Jay Records in Manhattan, rolls to mah-jongg parties with her stylish friends, including Adam Yauch of the Beastie Boys and Patrick Li, a design consultant for companies like Calvin Klein and Hussein Chalayan. "We'll talk and drink," Morledge says. "But some people are more serious than others, like Adam. He's careful about the rules - he downloaded them from the Web - and he's even got this amazing set of tiles." Perpetually popular in Asia and along Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn, mah-jongg marries gin rummy and dominoes and requires four players at a square table. (The rules for Hong Kong mah-jongg, the most common form of the game, are available at ww.mahjongnews.com.) As with poker, if you have no friends, you can play alone online.

Movies on TV
description: THE FOUR FEATHERS (1939) Saturday at 10 p.m. on TCM. Lt. Harry Faversham (John Clements) is descended from a long line of military heroes, but he's a pacifist himself. When he faces up to that and resigns his commission, the men in his unit call him a coward. But after they are captured during a mission in Sudan, he proves them thoroughly wrong by disguising himself as an Arab fighter and setting out to free them. When this action film first opened in New York, B. R. Crisler, writing in The New York Times, declared it "fine, stirring, gorgeously Technicolored" and "explosively cinematic." The film also stars C. Aubrey Smith, as a general who loves telling people how he won the Crimean War, and a very young Ralph Richardson (above). Zoltan Korda (brother of Alexander) directed.

title: BEAR HUNT OPPOSITION
description: Two animal rights groups, the New Jersey Animal Rights Alliance and the Bear Education and Resource Group, last Monday asked the State Superior Court to block this coming week's scheduled black bear hunt. Kevin Barber, a lawyer representing the groups, said the justification for the hunt was not based upon proper scientific research. If the court permits the six-day hunt, set to begin tomorrow, it will be New Jersey's second in 35 years. Karen Hershey, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Environmental Protection, would not comment on the lawsuit.
