title: The Remix; Do-it-yourself Detox
description: Detoxification is not a gentle process. It's best done someplace where you don't have to be too active or too pleasant. (Being in a warm climate helps.) The Lake Austin Spa Resort in Austin, Tex., offers a one-week Metamorphosis Gentle Detoxification Program, based on the regimen that the celebrity gourmet natural-food chef Alex Jamieson created to slim down Morgan Spurlock after he shot "Supersize Me." It promises to help rid guests of everything from artificial sweeteners to information overload (from $2,700; go to www.lakeaustin.com). At the five-night Mini-Week group fast at the New Age Health Spa in Neversink, N.Y., the three daily "meals" consist of a 16-ounce glass of raw juice, and the hydro-colon therapy will get you squeaky-clean ($970; go to www.newagehealthspa.com).

title: The New Berlin Wall
description: On the night of Feb. 7, 2005, Hatun Surucu, 23, was killed on her way to a bus stop in Berlin-Tempelhof by several shots to the head and upper body, fired at point-blank range. The investigation revealed that months before, she reported one of her brothers to the police for threatening her. Now three of her five brothers are on trial for murder. According to the prosecutor, the oldest of them (25) acquired the weapon, the middle brother (24) lured his sister to the scene of the crime and the youngest (18) shot her. The trial began on Sept. 21. Ayhan Surucu, the youngest brother, had confessed to the murder and claimed that he had done it without any help. According to Seyran Ates, a lawyer of Turkish descent, it is generally the youngest who are chosen by the family council to carry out such murders -- or to claim responsibility for them. German juvenile law sets a maximum sentence of 10 years' imprisonment for murder, and the offender has the prospect of being released after serving two-thirds of the sentence.

title: Palm Springs, Calif.: The Parker Palm Springs
description: THE BASICS Jonathan Adler, the designer of ceramics and home furnishings, took one of the kitschiest places in Palm Springs - the former Givenchy Resort and Spa owned by Merv Griffin - and somehow made it both kitschier and more glamorous. Out went the faux Versailles colonnade and topiaries; in went the zebra-print rugs, thrift-store Picassos and tangerine macram. The result is not so much a hippy-chic makeover, as it is a kind of dandy Betty Ford clinic for those who overdosed on the W Hotel's much-copied sleek and minimalist vibe. The resort's particular brand of tongue in cheek is not for everyone. But a year after it opened, the fashionable Hollywood set is still smirking about it.

title: The Quietly-Filling-Up Corner
description: CONNECTICUT'S northeastern edge, in Windham County, has long been known as the Quiet Corner. It is a place of rolling hills, small towns and family-owned dairy farms, where thousands of acres of farmland hang on to a disappearing way of life, where old stone markers establish property borders as they did two centuries ago. This is home to the University of Connecticut, where herds of cows chew grass along the college's main roadway. Drivers can go for miles without hitting a gas station, a Dunkin' Donuts or, sometimes, even a house.

title: Up Front
description: This issue of the Book Review, once again the year's largest, includes a number of features. One of them is our selection of the year's 100 Notable Books, chosen from those reviewed since last year's Holiday Books issue. Some readers will remember that for many years the list of Notable Books was considerably longer. That's because almost all the books that made our weekly choice of recommended titles automatically landed on the year-end list. Last year we trimmed the list to 100 and have done so again this year. Why? Simply put, the longer list had become unwieldy -- a dauntingly expansive grab bag rather than a concise guide to exceptional books. Not that limiting the number to 100 is an ideal solution, or that the results are authoritative. On the contrary, the choices are wholly subjective. Had each member of our editorial staff drawn up a separate list, no two would be identical. What we present here, then, is a rough consensus. For this reason, a forum has been set up on our Web site where we encourage readers to respond to our choices and to guess which books, drawn from this week's 100, will end up on our list of the 10 Best Books of the Year that will appear next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NADEL, BRUCE
description: NADEL--Bruce. 60, on November 8, 2005. Innovative commercial award-winning film director who developed a distinctive style of tabletop and live action cinematography. Mr. Nadel began his career on the production side of the commercial film industry. He started as an Assistant and protege of the legendary Elbert Budin, the pioneer of the modern tabletop aesthetic. As a director for over 25 years he brought his unique vision and flexible style to a variety of commercial film projects on the national and international stage. Mr. Nadel developed a lush visual style that relied on beautiful surfaces, rich textures, sophisticated propping in a unique, fluid, camera technique. A modern-day renaissance man, his intellect and experimental outlook drove his creative thinking bringing tremendous energy and passion to his work. Mr. Nadel brought a new aesthetic to a previously unappreciated segment of the advertising industry, elevating the beauty and sensuality of food to an art form. Distinguished by his powerful presence, personally and professionally, he touched and influenced countless people in the commercial film and advertising community. Mr. Nadel leaves as a legacy the Manhattanbased Nadel Productions, a close-knit team who will continue to execute his vision. Nadel, a resident of Nantucket and Pawling, N.Y., is survived by Arlene, his wife of 32 years; his mother Miriam "Micky" Nadel of Manhattan, his brother Dr. Scott Nadel, his five children Ben, Emily, Zoe, Dr. Eric Cohen, Ari Cohen; daughters-in-law Dr. Maud Lemercier, Stefanie Mazva, three grandchildren Max, Gabrielle and Sofia, his niece and nephew Jessica and Jason. Also Khing Xaysittiphone, the beloved family assistant. A memorial in celebration of his life will be held at 50 Mile Radius, 619 W. 54 St., NYC on December 8th at 6pm.

title: Illness as More Than Metaphor
description: My mother, Susan Sontag, lived almost her entire 71 years believing that she was a person who would beat the odds. Even during the last nine months of her life, after she was discovered to have myelodysplastic syndrome, or M.D.S., a particularly virulent blood cancer, she continued to persevere in the belief that she would be the exception. M.D.S. is technically a precursor to acute myeloid leukemia. On average, its survival rates across the generational cohorts are no better than 20 percent, and far worse for a woman in her early 70's who had had cancer twice before. It wasn't that she didn't know that the biological deck was stacked against her; as someone who prided herself on her ability to grasp medical facts, she knew it only too well. In the immediate aftermath of her diagnosis, she went online to learn all she could about M.D.S. and despaired as the fact of its lethality sank in. But that despair was almost the flip side of a lifelong confidence in her ability to defy the odds. "This time, for the first time," she told me, "I don't feel special."

title: 'Alexander II'

title: Abundant Energy or Floating Bombs?
description: LOGAN TOWNSHIP - A FRIGID wind rips up the Delaware River and across the mucky shoreline, rustling the marsh grass. The chill makes the battle over British Petroleum's plan to build a $600 million terminal to receive liquefied natural gas from Trinidad all the more biting.

title: Are Lawyers Being Overbilled for Their Test Preparation?
description: Correction Appended

title: Let's Make a Deal: A Democracy Arrives, Afghan Style
description: THE new political landscape in Afghanistan is closely tied to old rivalries and the decade-long war against the Soviet occupation. Here is how those factors influence the recently elected lower house of the Afghan Parliament. (The 68 elected members of the upper house mirror the lower house in composition. But the upper house is incomplete because President Karzai still must name the 34 of its members who are appointed.)

title: Roundup: Leader's stumble aids Montgomerie
Giverny It's Not
description: THREE weeks ago, after 180 years of hawking seafood on the wind-whipped waterfront in Lower Manhattan, the fishmongers of South Street packed up their equipment and their camaraderie and headed north to a gleaming, climate-controlled indoor facility in Hunts Point in the Bronx. Along with their scales and desks made of halibut crates, they took with them another distinctive fixture of the old Fulton Fish Market: a tirelessly observant 59-year-old artist named Naima Rauam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLEHER, JAMES J. III.
description: KELLEHER--James J. III. September 27, 1952--November 9, 2005. in Brewster, NY. You are always in our hearts. Survived by his loving family.

title: When Larry David Calls, You Answer
description: SHELLEY BERMAN, the veteran actor and comedian, balled up a fist and held it against one of his ears. "This is the way you hold a phone," he said. "This" -- he extended his thumb and pinky in imitation of a telephone receiver -- "is ridiculous! This is not how you hold a phone."

title: What's Become of Bedside Manner?
description: To the Editor:

title: The War in Iraq And Our Self-Esteem
description: To the Editor:

title: All Dollars, All the Time For Harried School Boards
description: SINCE Tom Murphy was first elected to the school board of the North Shore school district eight years ago, his role as a trustee has changed drastically.

title: Still Searching for Equilibrium in the Work-Life Balancing Act
description: Benefits like the flexibility to see a child's soccer game or leave work in time to get to a night class play a vital role in job satisfaction, workers say. Those saying that include an increasing number of men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITNEY, FRANCES J.
description: WHITNEY--Frances J. Died peacefully on November 29, 2005 at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. An artist and designer her entire life, in 1939 she invented the "millinery mobile". In the 1960's she was one of the first artists to create the exhibit "Body Sculpture". In the early 70's she invented and held a patent on "Sculptured Light", a plastic-encased electroluminescent tape molded by heat. The last 20 years of her working life were devoted to collaboration with the renowned laser artist, Norman Ballard, experimenting with lasers, video, and relationship between sound and shape. Her work was extensively exhibited both in the USA and abroad from the 1940's through 2002. From 1992 through 2004 she was cared for in her home by her daughter, Colette with her fiance James Johnson. Their love and support enabled her to continue creating and exhibiting her art through her 2002 retrospective at the Century Association. She will be deeply missed. She is survived by her daughter, Colette Whitney, her sister Theodora Taggart, her niece, Patricia Lannon and her nephews William and James Lannon. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM on Monday December 12, at the Mary Manning Walsh Home Chapel, 1339 York Ave., at 72nd St.

title: Rival Drug Gangs Turn the Streets of Nuevo Laredo Into a War Zone
description: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico - The lucrative drug trade on the Mexican border seemed up for grabs after Mexican authorities arrested the powerful leader of the Gulf Cartel nearly three years ago. The rival Sinaloa Cartel sent Edgar Valdz Villarreal, a young upstart known as La Barbie, to do the grabbing.

title: Healing Waters in the Shadow of the Alps
description: "TAKING the waters" has such an anachronistic ring that it's hard to believe anyone does it anymore. The practice dates back to Roman times, but in Europe plenty of people seek out the healing properties of mineral water with great gusto and gravity. The area around Lake Leman in Geneva is particularly welcoming to les curistes, as the seekers are known.

title: Against Raptors, Nets Are Worse Than the Worst
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 3 - The Nets on Wednesday failed to earn their 1,000th victory since joining the National Basketball Association by losing to the Detroit Pistons, the team with the league's best record. On Saturday night, they failed to reach the milestone again, this time against the Toronto Raptors, the team with the worst record.

title: Wit and Wisdom From an Annual
description: "Hugh Johnson's Pocket Wine Book 2006" (Mitchell Beazley), winedom's ultimate hardcover micro-encyclopedia, is unsurpassed as a gift. This 29th edition, blending the common sense, urbanity and grace of Britain's pre-eminent wine writer, inspires serendipity. For Christmas mince pie, Mr. Johnson recommends tawny port and Pedro Ximnez, Spain's divine sherry. For frankfurters: "German riesling, Beaujolais or light pinot noir." His "small compilation of choice bottles" alone repays Barnes & Noble's $11.96. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: After a Long Journey, a Famed Gun Comes Home
description: Garibaldi's revolver, it is probably safe to say, can no longer fire a shot. It is corroded, and the red paint that marked it as the property of the hero of Italian independence is reduced to a few flecks on the handle. Although the gun must be handled gingerly, with white cotton gloves, its imposing weight in hand reminds the holder of its first owner's power and place in history.

title: And the Winner Is  Well, Ask Jeff Tittel
description: You might say he has a way with words. Or you might not.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENTHAL, HAL
description: ROSENTHAL--HAL. Dear Mucka, I hold you in my heart everyday and know that I was truly blessed that you always held me in yours. Love Hon, Joy

title: Comfort to the Enemy: Chapter 12: Jurgen and Otto on the Lam
description: Jurgen and Otto have escaped from prison in the film projectionist's truck and headed to Shemane's house. As soon as Carl learns of the escape, he, too, goes to see Shemane. But when she tells him she hasn't seen Jurgen, he doesn't press to come inside, instead leaving Gary Marion to watch the house. Shemane, Jurgen, Otto and Shemane's mother, Gladys, all pile into Shemane's Lincoln Zephyr and pull away before Gary can follow them.

title: 19 Iraqi Army Soldiers Are Killed as Insurgents Fire on a Convoy
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 3 - Insurgents attacked an Iraqi Army convoy north of Baghdad on Saturday, killing 19 Iraqi Army soldiers and wounding 4 others in a well-coordinated ambush that started with a roadside bombing, an Iraqi Army officer said.

title: Corrections
description: The "Going To" column on Nov. 13, about Salt Lake City, misstated the legal status of polygamy in late 19th-century Utah. It had been prohibited under federal law since 1862, not 1890, and it continued to be illegal after Utah became a state in 1896.

title: Let Nothing You Dismay
description: In my mother's basement, the Christmas after my grandmother had died, I found the top of a box that had belonged to her. My mother and I were down there retrieving ornaments and lights so that we could decorate the tree, a painful Christmas that year, 1995. My stepfather had died not long before my grandmother. The box top -- 18 inches by 18 inches, watermarked, frayed and torn -- had once covered a wreath, but the wreath was long gone, and now the box held ornaments, each one neatly wrapped in tissue. I lifted the lid off the box, and immediately I noticed my grandmother's handwriting, a jumble of words that spilled out to fill the room. My mother would later tell me that she had known about the box top but had never read it, that after seeing her mother's handwriting she had shut the lid: Pandora's box. But I could not shut the lid. I had to know what was written there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, KATHERINE STERN
description: WILSON -- Katherine Stern. Age 79, died on Friday, November 25, surrounded by members of her devoted family. Death was due to complications of cancer and came only after a long and courageous fight. She is survived by her husband Philip, two daughters: Lucy and Elizabeth Watson; three sons: William Watson, Patrick and David Wilson; and ten grandchildren, all of whom are overcome by their loss, and struggling with the reason as to why. Kit was a delightful, caring person who made the world a better place in which to live. She was an avid reader, but enjoyed social interaction and had a quick wit. She could exchange jokes with the best. She was also proficient in many athletic pursuits, but the game of tennis, the skills of which she acquired as a teenager from the incomparable teachings of Dorothy Wightman, was her first love. She practiced it artfully and effectively much to the dismay of opponents, the gratitude of partners and the admiration of all. Kit also derived much pleasure from the intimate and enduring friendships she maintained with many persons from all over. These relationships were of utmost importance to her and remained at the top of her mind until the bitter end. Were she able, she would be the first among her family to thank all those dear friends for their tender condolences, for which the severity of her illness impaired direct and timely acknowledgement; likewise to express her and our gratitude to the loving and tireless caregivers who comforted her and her family during her passing. No burial service is planned.

title: If They Build It, Who Will Come?
description: There will be baseball in the Meadowlands, state officials say.

title: 'The Water Mirror'
description: Chapter 4: Phantoms

title: Puerto Peasco, Mexico: Boom Time for 'Next San Diego'
description: AS the last edge of sun slipped into the Sea of Cortez on a Saturday night in October, the Old Port corner of Puerto Peasco, Mexico, kicked into high gear. Bunches of sunburned tourists rolled in, fresh from the beach, poring over vendors' seashell necklaces and slipping into open-air cafes for fish tacos and margaritas. It was a classic seaside resort town scene: casual, small and quaint.

title: An American in Europe Bridges a Cultural Divide
description: AMERICAN women can lead European companies successfully if they are sensitive to cultural nuances, says Nancy McKinstry, the chief executive of Wolters Kluwer, based in the Netherlands. It is a provider of information, software and services to professional customers, and she has been its chief since 2003. She is the only female C.E.O. of a Dutch company. Here are excerpts from a conversation:

title: The Remix: Beat the Parents; The Tile-High Club
description: Now that poker is played out, young New Yorkers are reviving the Chinese tile game of mah-jongg. Jane Morledge, a creative director at Jay Records in Manhattan, rolls to mah-jongg parties with her stylish friends, including Adam Yauch of the Beastie Boys and Patrick Li, a design consultant for companies like Calvin Klein and Hussein Chalayan. "We'll talk and drink," Morledge says. "But some people are more serious than others, like Adam. He's careful about the rules -- he downloaded them from the Web -- and he's even got this amazing set of tiles." Perpetually popular in Asia and along Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn, mah-jongg marries gin rummy and dominoes and requires four players at a square table. (The rules for Hong Kong mah-jongg, the most common form of the game, are available at ww.mahjongnews.com.) As with poker, if you have no friends, you can play alone online. JONATHAN S. PAUL

title: The Week Ahead: Dec. 4 - Dec. 10
description: THEATER

title: Going Undercover
description: Have you heard this one? True story. A man walks into a bar. He sits down at a table with Elle Macpherson. He says, "What are you wearing?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEUMAN, LISA A.
description: NEUMAN--Lisa A. On December 2, 2005, age 92, late of New York City. Born in Austria. The only child of Jaques Neuman and Hedwig Stohr. Retired after a long career as a psychiatric social worker with the NYC Board of Education. She will be deeply missed by her many devoted friends because of her sparkling wit, gracious hospitality and wonderful memories.

title: Republicans Will Take One Where They Can
description: EVEN as Suffolk County Republicans nurse the wounds they suffered in last month's election and contemplate how to recover some political ground, much of their attention has been diverted to how to fill one of the few posts that they can still control: county clerk.

title: Season's Drippings
description: There is little good in any Christmas cookie except the thought behind it. This may be doubly true for Swedish ginger cookies, a recipe that I have cherished for years, but I often feel it should come with a special warning. The principal ingredient in a batch of Swedish ginger cookies -- the one that really does the trick -- is three-quarters of a cup of bacon fat. You can never be too certain these days about what people will allow themselves to enjoy. Their ideas about what is good for them may be circumscribed by their upbringing, their religion or their proximity to a pig. However, I suspect that the Swedish cook who came up with this recipe was simply hemmed in by her larder. She had a pan of drippings and some extra sugar and spices, and she made a thin, brown cookie that tasted sweetly of smoke.

title: 'Snowstruck'
description: Jerry had been shoveling for days, it felt like mud, but it was only snow, snow, and more snow. His town was more a battleground than the dreamy winter scene of paperweight globes. Trees were toppling, roofs were in danger, and telephone poles plastered with wind-driven snow appeared double their normal diameter. Most mornings the lean fifty-year-old flooring contractor and occasional longshoreman didn't bother to throw on more than flannel slippers and bathrobe to shovel a soggy furrow from house to car. But this January 2000 morning in the isolated fishing port of Cordova, Alaska, the monitor heater in his house was down and Jerry had burned the last of the firewood stored close at hand, so he told Martha, his partner of more than twenty years, that he would dig his way out to the detached garage for another load. Knowing this wouldn't be a trivial project, he pulled on gray sweatpants and a hooded shirt, ribbed cotton socks and shoes.

title: HIGHLY EFFECTIVE, INDEED
description: He may be 73 and his best-known work may be 16 years old, but Stephen R. Covey can still draw a paying crowd. Mr. Covey, who started a cottage industry when he wrote "The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People" in 1989, earned more than $4 million in speaking fees over the last year, according to a proxy statement filed by the Franklin Covey Company.

title: Let Me Tell You About the Very Gift-Wrapped
description: For those who aspire to something a bit fancier than off-the-rack wrapping, Carolyne Roehm has luxury gift-wrap kits complete with paper, ribbons, berries, artificial flowers and leaves. The wrapping sets dress up presents in Ms. Roehm's style and turn the plainest box into an ornate formal presentation. To cater to all aesthetic types, she has created a palette of colors and themes, including violets, ruby red cherries, polka dots and stripes. The wrapping kits ($30 to $75), will swathe seven to nine packages of varying sizes. They can be ordered from www.carolyneroehm.com, where instructions for wrapping the perfect package and tying a spectacular bow can also be found, as well as a place to order the new book "Presentations," a collection of the designer's 200 favorite gift wraps. MARIANNE ROHRLICH PULSE

description: Correction Appended

title: The Drink Is Not Drinkable
description: LOWER TOWNSHIP - IN Cape May County, a peninsula surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean on one side and Delaware Bay on the other, residents lug home gallons of bottled water from the grocery store each week because the tap water tastes so bad.

title: Mile by Mile, India Paves a Smoother Road to Its Future
description: NEW DELHI, India - In the middle of the old Grand Trunk Road a temple sits under a peepul tree. The surrounding highway is being widened to four lanes, and vehicles barrel along either side. But the temple and tree thwart even greater speed, and a passing contractor says they soon will be removed.

title: Courts Say Man Can Sue Despite Signing Waiver
description: THE State Supreme Court said in a ruling released on Tuesday that a man who broke his ankle while snow-tubing at the Powder Ridge Ski Area in Middlefield could sue the resort even though he had signed a waiver that said he wouldn't. It's a decision that lawyers expect will open the door to new liability concerns for operators of recreational activities, like sky diving and rock climbing, where customers are asked to sign waivers to participate.

title: On Climate Change, a Change of Thinking
description: IN December 1997, representatives of most of the world's nations met in Kyoto, Japan, to negotiate a binding agreement to cut emissions of "greenhouse" gases.

title: What's Become of Bedside Manner?
description: To the Editor:

title: Responsibility From Home Gives Terry His Direction
description: Jason Terry proudly counts on his fingers his seven siblings spread throughout the country, from Seattle where his mother, Andrea Cheatham, reared them all as a single parent, to Atlanta, to Maine, where he helps support two in boarding school.

title: Comics History
description: Fans in the United States would never have imagined two decades ago that comic art would emerge as the popular literary genre it is today. While in Europe comics have long enjoyed such stature, here they were considered mere funny books. But when Art Spiegelman won a 1992 Pulitzer Prize for "Maus," about his parents' ordeal at Auschwitz, comics began to be taken more seriously. Since then, lavish exhibitions and books have chronicled the leading artists and artifacts both past and present.

title: The Soul of Sundance's Machine
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. - IT was early November, and John Cooper was in his office here, staring as if hypnotized at a bulletin board. Over the next few weeks, the board, which was covered in color-coded cards bearing the names of movies, would coalesce into the slate for the 2006 Sundance Film Festival.

title: All the President's Flacks
description: WHEN "all of the facts come out in this case," Bob Woodward told Terry Gross on NPR in July, "it's going to be laughable because the consequences are not that great."

title: Femme Retail
description: Susan tabak,who shops all around ze town, opens up her little black book -- and out falls paris.It took Susan Tabak some 25 years to realize that her Paris spending sprees could be a source of revenue, and not just for the labels she so generously supports. Most women in her position would satisfy their retail cravings by flaunting a new Kelly bag or clacky mule over lunch at Swifty's; instead, Tabak founded Paris Personal Shopper. She regularly shuttles from her Park Avenue apartment to Htel le Bristol on Faubourg Saint-Honor to take rich clients on customized shopping excursions. For her, fashion is about mixing the traditional and the new. She is not oblivious to the power of designer brands -- she remembers one Middle Eastern princess arriving by private plane with "about 30 trunks full of DKNY and Juicy." But Tabak's personal preferences hang elsewhere. Here, in the spirit of the season, she offers a peek into her little black book.

title: On Milton Friedman's Birthday, We Get the Present: Him
description: ONE of the infinite number of ways in which I have been blessed is in the friends I inherited from my parents. Peter M. Flanigan, investment banker and aide to my former boss, Richard M. Nixon, and ambassador to Spain. Roy L. Ash, a co-founder of Litton Industries and a budget director in the Nixon and Ford administrations. Mr. Nixon, president and peacemaker. Paul W. McCracken, genius economist and adviser to three presidents. C. Lowell Harriss, a super teacher and emeritus professor of economics at Columbia University. Anna Jacobson Schwartz, a renowned economist and statistician. And the list goes on and on.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Former Student on Page 1, for All the Wrong Reasons

title: A Toy Story
description: What do kids want? According to the people who track this sort of thing, the most popular toys this season are high-tech games and gadgets. On the Hot Dozen list put out by Toy Wishes magazine, there is a bilingual talking kitchen, a video camera and a cuddly creature with voice-recognition abilities that enable it to be bossed around. And, of course, you can make any kid happy nowadays with a computer, iPod or cellphone. You can make me happy with these, too; but please send along a kid to install, program and fix everything.

title: Iraqi Exile, Anti-War Mime
description: White Plains - WHILE the war in Iraq persists, one Iraqi here is fighting the causes of war the way he knows best, with art. Louay Assaf, an Iraqi migr living in Brooklyn, uses theater to explore the roots of violence and human conflict.

title: A Star Is Reborn
description: THERE are 36,000 lights on the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, but there's only one star. For decades that biblical symbol of satellite navigation has sat silently more than 65 feet above the ground, picked out by carefully positioned spotlights while thousands of multicolored light bulbs below vied for onlookers' attention.

title: Hong Kong
description: WHY GO NOW -- Because the Hong Kong of today is rapidly being replaced by a new, more showy incarnation of itself -- with the recently opened Disneyland just a hint of what the future holds. This fall, the Four Seasons and a boutique version of the city's famous Mandarin Oriental have opened outposts in the city's financial district. New nightclubs are luring fashionable people from across Asia. And a nearly completed cable car system will soon vault from the airport up over a steep hillside to a well-preserved monastery and its immense outdoor statue of Buddha.

title: Ocean's Thirteen
description: THE HIGHEST TIDE

title: A Man of Many Words
description: DEFINING THE WORLD

title: After Attack, Cruise Ships Rethink Security
description: UNTIL last month, the greatest worry for cruise passengers may have been Norwalk virus or having their vacations disrupted by a hurricane. Now the armed attack on the Seabourn Spirit off Somalia on Nov. 5 has the cruise industry checking its bearings on security.

title: A Condominium in TriBeCa Blends Two Eras in One Complex
description: A Condominium in TriBeCa Blends Two Eras in One Complex

title: Acquiring Tastes
description: Somewhere between the sixth floor of Barneys New York and the first, I realized that I had not completely licked my problem: I was still a shopping bulimic. Years ago, I would spend and purge -- buying up shoes and dresses and a vast array of sweaters at establishments that fully refunded any purchase (as opposed to the dreaded store credit that many small boutiques extend). I would satisfy any craving -- cashmere cardigans in every color, an alpaca fedora that had nothing to do with my wardrobe, a purple silk evening gown that was wildly out of my price range -- and then, the next day, I would return everything. I was disciplined: I never wore the clothes out of the house, and I never snipped off price tags. There were, of course, items that I kept -- a Comme des Garons gray wool dress that falls in long folds and remains the most avant-garde garment I own, and most of the shoes (long since discarded) -- but the majority of the clothes went back to their store home.

title: The Prodigy Puzzle
description: No one can dispute that leading scientists and mathematicians have very high intelligence. But surely, outstanding ability in music, literature and other creative arts is not solely the province of those with extremely high I.Q.'s. If brilliant writers, artists and musicians were tested, I suspect many of them would not make the cut. It should be simple enough to test a group of outstanding people in the creative arts to find out if their intellectual candlepower matches those in math and science.

title: The Remix; Vienna Calling
description: Designers headed to Mitteleuropa for the spring collections. Carolina Herrera translated early-20th-century Vienna in homespun floral appliqus and embroideries (above). Proenza Schouler showed hand-folded hems and a trove of brocades, crewelwork and passementerie. The long silhouettes and petal sleeves at Rochas evoked Gustav Klimt. And Dior treated its Paris show guests to an after-hours preview of the "Vienna 1900" exhibit at the Grand Palais. Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler speculates that this yearning for fin de sicle Vienna is a reaction to mass production. "It seems very appropriate now, he says, "because in today's competitive world, time and details are the truest form of luxury." ARMAND LIMNANDER

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 20 about finding New York apartments in the range of the nation's median price, $220,000, misstated the address of one. The ground-floor studio for $239,000 is at 185 Prospect Park Southwest, Brooklyn, not Prospect Park West.

title: An Ode to Skronk
description: PRINCETON - TIMES are tough for experimental music in New York. Club owners say the economics of presenting noncommercial music are not favorable in real estate-crazed Manhattan. But a trip to Princeton University tells a different story. A concert series called Free-Form Mash-Up harks back to the freewheeling artist lofts and performance spaces of Lower Manhattan in the 1970's and 1980's.

title: A Boy Soldier's Heart of Darkness
description: BEASTS OF NO NATION

title: After Attack, Cruise Ships Rethink Security
description: UNTIL last month, the greatest worry for cruise passengers may have been Norwalk virus or having their vacations disrupted by a hurricane. Now the armed attack on the Seabourn Spirit off Somalia on Nov. 5 has the cruise industry checking its bearings on security.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 4-Dec. 10; FILM
description: In "MRS. HENDERSON PRESENTS," the director Stephen Frears takes a lighthearted approach to a wartime tale of British grit and girls, girls, girls. DAME JUDI DENCH plays the title character, a wealthy widow who buys a theater and mounts a nudie revue in the West End during the blitz in World War II. BOB HOSKINS plays her house manager, chafing under the boss's imperious ignorance of theater but putting her in her place when necessary. The film has the most fun when the two are bantering on screen, and if fireworks never do quite break out between them (wouldn't that have been interesting?), Dame Judi is reliably quirky. Note to the curious: Dame Judi remains fully clothed throughout. The same cannot be said for her co-star. The film opens in New York and Los Angeles on Dec. 9.

title: In On the Political Act
description: Q: You were recently nominated by President Bush to serve on the board of the U.S. Institute of Peace, which was founded in the wake of the Vietnam War to promote peace. When will the Senate vote on your nomination? That hasn't been scheduled yet. I think they have bigger fish to fry right now. I think they are more concerned with Alito than Ron Silver.

description: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

title: The Number One Reform
description: If somehow there were one dangling thread that could unravel the dysfunction of New York's Legislature, it would be attached to the unfair system that allows state lawmakers to draw their own election districts every 10 years. So here is our request for anyone running for governor next year to start tugging on that fateful thread.

description: FROM the looks of it, Connecticut's cellphone law, in effect since Oct. 1, is news to some drivers.

description: The Mets have extended offers to the top two free-agent catchers, but it is becoming increasingly likely that they will fill their catching void by trading for Paul Lo Duca.

title: WEALTH BUILDER
description: How can you lend $3 million and get back $40 million in just eight years? As Jeffrey P. Orleans knows, it helps to control the company you are lending to.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: KIDS FLY FREE -- The Gunnison-Crested Butte Tourism Association in Colorado along with American Airlines is offering free flights for children 2 to 12 as part of four-night family ski packages available from Jan. 2 through Feb. 16. Departures are from every state except Alaska and Hawaii. The package includes air fare, lodging in a two-bedroom condominium, three days of lift tickets and airport transfers. Prices start at $899 a person plus $103 for each child (to cover lodging and lift tickets). Prices are based on two adults and two children traveling together. Taxes and airport fees are extra. For reservations call (800) 814-8893 or see www.gunnisoncrestedbutte.com.

title: Navy Marches to a Lead in Its Series Against Army
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 - Sure, Army is better now, good enough this year to take the lead twice against Navy during their season-ending football showdown Saturday.

title: Kerry McInerney and Michael Kinnane
description: Kerry Ellen McInerney was married yesterday in Brooklyn to Michael Gerard Kinnane. Msgr. James Spengler performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Troubling Memo
description: We already know why the removal of PCB's from the Hudson River promises to be the largest and most complex environmental cleanup in history -- it has to do with the sheer volume of toxic material buried beneath an enormous, flowing river, and the delicacy of removing the mess without leaving a worse one behind.

If He Keeps Up Torrid Pace, Gagn Will Be Seeing 50/50
description: Flyers right wing Mike Knuble said his linemate Simon Gagn was "kind of like a dirty little secret in Philadelphia" before the season. But before Gagn scored two goals last Tuesday to lead the Flyers to a 4-3 road victory over the Islanders, Knuble said Gagn was not such a secret anymore.

title: Issues Raised by Firefighter's Fall From Truck
description: A firefighter whose skull was fractured after he was thrown from a fire truck on Friday night remained in critical but stable condition last night at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, his condition improving slightly, fire officials said.

title: When Parcells Became Ordinary
description: Nearly nine years ago, Bill Parcells boarded a plane for New Orleans carrying a reputation as perhaps the finest coach in the National Football League. He was taking the Patriots to the Super Bowl in his fourth season in New England, after having won two titles with the Giants.

title: On the Curriculum, A Palette of Choices
description: ASK Steve Lampasona what his students enjoy most about their painting classes, and he will talk about light and shadow, color values and texture, style and spontaneity. But delve a little deeper and another truth comes out: The classes are fun and refreshing, he says, and offer one of the best creative outlets around.

title: A Headline Deal Maker Stays Off the Beaten Path
description: DON'T be fooled by the cheery red tie dotted with yellow beach umbrellas. There is very little laid back about Andrew L. Farkas, the founder and chief executive of Island Capital Group.

title: Slayer of Taboos
description: D. H. LAWRENCE

title: The Prodigy Puzzle
description: Genius develops alone in the dark like a photograph and can't be cultivated in a petri dish. Imagine Leonardo da Vinci being given an I.Q. test by his contemporaries. He would have failed, of course, because he was conceiving ideas and inventions 400 years ahead of his contemporaries, breaking domains, not excelling within them. So while it may look as if Johns Hopkins University's Center for Talented Youth and Davidson fellowships are nurturing gifted children, they are in fact simply "growing" others like themselves: mechanically dexterous conformists.

title: The Remix; FASHION ROCKS | VAN CLEEF & ARPELS
description: The Van Cleef & Arpels boutique, at 744 Fifth Avenue, just underwent a centennial face-lift. Not that the company was showing its age. At the spring 2006 shows, its archive looked young again sparkling on the Lanvin runway (pictured at right), while its contemporary bijoux dazzled at Behnaz Sarafpour. Now the New York space, with its fireside seating and Art Deco chandelier, impresses as well. Shoppers seeking privacy will be ushered into separate viewing rooms, where they can play with the new Pierres de Caractre collection, designed around exceptional stones, including a necklace with a 127-carat old mine emerald. Just in time for Christmas. ALEXANDRA ZISSU

title: For Spa-Goers, Wine by the Glass, or by the Bath
description: A fire flickers. The moon falls on persimmon trees outside. The rooms are full of roses, soft mood-setting music. And on a soft autumn night alive with sounds of water splashing in pools and leaves crackling in the wind, here in the heart of the Sonoma Valley, at the nation's first vinotherapy spa, who wouldn't be in the mood for a cabernet bath.

title: Loss hurts Taiwan leader, analysts say
Hooked on Classics
description: From Dickens to DKNY, today's wise men are brushing up on the canon.

title: The War in Iraq And Our Self-Esteem
description: To the Editor:

title: Floral
description: Yes, there is a high-fashion silhouette that is defining the style of a new generation: a slim, elongated look emphasized by low-slung jeans and a defined torso and the all-important element, a bolero or jacket. For others, there are hip-defining jackets in shearling or fur trim, both suggesting a long-stemmed flower. ON THE STREET

title: Going Postal
description: The Samurai Shopper holds these truths to be self-evident: Kids should never be sent to bed hungry; passport photos always require one do-over; and horizontal shopping beats braving the holiday crowds. Though the Web is fast turning catalogs prehistoric, the souvenir quality of printed matter trumps the evanescent pixel, at least for now. Besides, flipping pages packed with goodies means stretching out catlike and surrendering to sumptuous photographs and perky blurbs, all in the service of whetting your whistle for acquisition.

title: Lufthansa is taking on low-cost competitors
What's Become of Bedside Manner?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 4-Dec. 10; THEATER
description: The title alone was too irresistible, given that it is the last play to date by a man who has just won the Nobel Prize in Literature. So this weekend, a special, starry performance of HAROLD PINTER's "CELEBRATION" was staged in London, celebrating both the Nobel and Mr. Pinter's 75th birthday. In the meantime, across the ocean, that same play has been in previews at the Atlantic Theater Company in New York, on a double bill with Mr. Pinter's first produced play, "THE ROOM." (The timing is purely serendipitous for the Atlantic, which had made up its schedule before the Nobel announcements.) In any case, seen together, these short plays, which officially open Monday, offer a splendid opportunity to compare the angry young Pinter with the angry old Pinter and to note how little his voice his changed, even if his settings have grown posher. ("Celebration" takes place in a deluxe West End restaurant; "The Room" in a seedy boardinghouse.) 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 239-6200.

title: The Number One Reform
description: If somehow there was one dangling thread that could unravel the dysfunction of New York's Legislature, it would be attached to the unfair system that allows state lawmakers to draw their own election districts every 10 years. So here is our request for anyone running for governor next year to start tugging on that fateful thread.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Renaissance Man
description: PISCATAWAY - BOB MULCAHY made a detour on his way to the sideline, striding down the steps at Rutgers Stadium and taking his place in front of the school's marching band. As the football team wrapped up its 31-21 victory over Navy on Oct. 29, Mulcahy, the Rutgers athletic director and a lifelong New Jersey resident, conducted the band in a rendition of "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling."

title: For a Campus Closing, a Bronx Cheer
description: At 7 p.m., on a desolate block of Courtlandt Avenue in Mott Haven, the Bronx outpost of Metropolitan College spills light onto the sidewalk through long windows. In one window is Metropolitan's signature advertising poster, a staple of the subways, featuring a beaming young woman in a crisp red blouse. Below the photo are the triumphant words " 'I did it!' "

title: Using Factory Sites for Other Purposes
description: MYSTIC

title: Bistro Heartiness That Chases the Chill
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS - FOLLOWING the trend for scaled-down restaurants with upscale food, the Heights Bistro & Bar is a terrific addition to dining spots near the triangular shopping center here, and would be welcome anywhere else. The dining rooms are plain but cheery, and the prices are reasonable for food and wines of this quality. And the dishes are painstakingly designed.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 4-Dec. 10; DANCE
description: SASHA WALTZ, one of Germany's leading younger choreographers, will charm the ears as well as eyes of dancegoers with the New York premiere of "IMPROMPTUS." The evening-long piece, part of the 2005 Next Wave Festival, is set to live piano and vocal music by Schubert. The choreography is filled with sensual duets, some playful, some hypnotic. Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 7:30 p.m., Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100 or www.BAM.org.

title: College Acceptance Made Easy
description: JERSEY CITY - AFTER school, Maria Abello washed her hair and changed her jeans for a businesslike pair of black pants and a striped shirt. Then she and her girlfriend took the bus from Bayonne, found the admissions office here at New Jersey City University, and filled out applications.

title: A Playground for Preservationists
description: LAURA AND BOB RYAN planned to move out of Manhattan before their son, William, reached nursery-school age and the academic frenzy that comes with it. But this summer, with William not yet 2, the Ryans started exploring Wilton, Conn., a town with historic houses and rolling fields in Fairfield County.

title: 'Teacher Man'
Re-Meet the Beatles
description: The first Beatles song I ever heard was "I Want to Hold Your Hand." I must have been about 3, and my father was singing it as we walked through the hall of our apartment building, my hand in his. The way he sang, it was as if he had just made it up and he was singing it just for me. In his Brooklyn accent, it sounded like a nursery rhyme.

title: A Push to Reopen A Hospital as a Clinic
description: The mayor of Hempstead Village, Wayne J. Hall Sr., said on Monday that he was in talks with the owner of the defunct Hempstead General Hospital's building on Front Street to reopen it as a community hospital and clinic.

title: QUICK BITE/Teaneck; And Please Lick Your Fingers
description: If you've ever made the long drive to Florida, you know that one unspoken reason for not flying is the opportunity to leave the Interstate behind during the trip, then follow your nose along some blue highway and into some small town to ferret out local barbecue. But if you don't have time to make that succulent pilgrimage south, you can have an almost authentic experience here at home by visiting Fat's Chicken and Ribs Joint in Teaneck.

title: Soccer: Ronaldo returns as Real hangs on for lackluster victory
Pro-Democracy Protesters March in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 4 - A huge throng of pro-democracy protesters poured through the skyscraper canyons of Hong Kong this afternoon, defying warnings from senior Chinese officials, who have refused to set a timetable for general elections here.

title: The View From Down Under
description: The air mattresses onstage are the first sign that John Jasperse's "Prone" is not your typical dance performance. Instead of being seated, audience members will be invited to lie down on them. (Eight chairs are reserved for the pregnant or infirm.) "Keep your arms and legs on the mattress," he warned at a recent rehearsal. "Don't sit up, probably. But you can move your head however you want."

title: The End of Shopping
description: I thought I got a sweet deal on my first car. It was a compact pickup, American-made, and the salesman who approached me on the lot told me that if I bought it that afternoon, he was prepared to double the advertised rebate and throw in a premium sound system free. I played hard to get by mumbling the word "Toyota," and the salesman took off an extra $500. I could see by his shirt's dark armpits that he was nervous, and when we went into his office to sign the papers, he vanished into an adjoining room, where I heard his superior loudly chew him out, just as he'd predicted to me would happen if he let me "steal" the vehicle. I drove off euphoric -- I'd beaten the system -- but the very next morning I realized I'd been toyed with. Reading the local paper, I spotted an ad for a truck identical to mine priced at a cool $1,000 less. Nearly identical, that is. The other, cheaper truck had leather seats and eight mighty cylinders, not a feeble six. It also had tinted windows and dual chrome pipes.

title: 'Wonder Years,' by Way of Bed-Stuy
description: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT is used to having its reputation defined by outsiders. For years this Brooklyn neighborhood had the rap of being so perilous a landscape that in 1980 a Long Island boy named Billy Joel sang, "I've been stranded in the combat zone/ I walked through Bedford-Stuy alone." By contrast, in the current overheated housing market, Bed-Stuy has been ballyhooed as the last frontier of affordable brownstones, a place overrun by real estate speculators panning for original wainscoting.

title: The Remix: Beat the Parents; Play Your Cards Right
description: A card or board game with your nearest and dearest can turn as ugly as your uncle in an elf suit. To maintain peace on earth, follow these simple rules.

title: Health Coverage of Young Widens With States' Aid
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 - The number of American children without health care coverage has been slowly but steadily declining over the past several years even as health care costs continue to rise and fewer employers provide insurance, creating a breach that states have stepped in to fill with new programs and fresh money.

title: Re-examining the Red Cross
description: The widespread devastation wrought by Hurricane Katrina has forced us to rethink the government's response to disasters. But one key pillar of that response stands apart. That organization is the American Red Cross, which has become the de facto human side of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: Where, Exactly, to Get a Glimpse of Global Trade
description: It's no secret that a lot of stuff sloshes into and out of this country every year -- nearly $2.3 trillion worth in 2004, according to recent statistics from the Transportation Department. (Far more in than out, of course; this nation is an insatiable shopper at the global mall.)

title: Dead Marines Had Expected Iraq Deployment
description: BYRON, Ill., Dec. 3 - Like Lance Cpl. Andrew G. Patten, most of the 10 marines who died on Thursday in the worst attack on American troops in months were young, young enough to have joined the military already knowing they might well be sent to Iraq.

title: Sept. 11, as Seen and Felt at 30,000 Feet
description: The Threepenny Review devotes much of its 100th issue to memory. In "You Can't Even Remember What I'm Trying to Forget," Rebecca Brock, a flight attendant, recalls Sept. 11, 2001, from aloft.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARKS, ELAINE MILLER
description: MARKS--Elaine Miller. We dedicate the monument and CLL Leukemia Research Project 5154 at Sloan-Kettering Hospital to the memory of Elaine M. Marks, realizing that her remains are not only in this plot of ground, but in every heart her life did touch. We are grateful for the years we shared with her, when she brought us so many pleasures and taught us so much by her example. To the world she was one person, to us she was the world. Alvin, Evan, Wendy, and Jeffrey

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENZIE, CLARENCE A.
description: McKENZIE--Clarence A. Died November 9, 2005 in Croydon, England. Your decent soul soars in Heaven. We love and miss you. Emma, Bernice and Minerva

title: Drunken-Driver Deaths Put State on Stark List
description: Connecticut ranked 13th out of the 15 states with the highest percentage of alcohol-related traffic deaths last year, according to a list released on Monday by the Coalition to End Needless Deaths on Our Roadways, and the National Safety Council.

title: Lynne Truss Has Another Gripe With You
description: Deborah Solomon, in her excellent article, describes Ann Coulter as a "right-wing bully." So many pundits, writers, jurists, foundations, etc., are described as right-wing or conservative. I wonder if Solomon thinks there's such a thing as a left-wing bully in the news media.

description: An article on Nov. 20 about Bolivia referred incorrectly to the city Cochabamba. It is the country's third-largest, behind Santa Cruz de la Sierra and La Paz, not the second-largest.

title: The Remix: Kids; THE $10,000 (AND UP) STOCKING STUFFER
description: For 10 grand, you can sponsor a playground in Central Park for a year. It doesn't buy you the right to kick nonsponsoring children off the swings during rush hour, but you do get your name on a poster that will be prominently displayed on the playground's bulletin board. And it's tax deductible, Mom and Dad. For information, call (212)310-6617. Mini-cellphones are now the norm, so it's no shocker that there are tiny sports cars too. Mobileation's Web site has a so-called Luxury Car Lot, complete with a two-seater Audi ($12,980) and a LeMans Junior Race Car ($29,000). Both require gasoline. Hello, Toyota? It's high time for a mini-hybrid. Go to www.mobileation.com. Kids will always want to build treehouses. Parents with $98,720 to spare can avoid splinters and snag Junior his very own Barbara Butler-designed castle (left). Butler, who is based in San Francisco, offers (relatively) less expensive forts, theaters and playhouses, too. Go to www.barbarabutler.com. A.Z.

title: Engines Go Back to the Future
description: GERMAN automakers gave up pushrod engines long ago, in favor of more complex overhead-cam power plants. The Japanese have essentially quit making the old-design engines. Ford is down to just a couple.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 4-Dec. 10; POP/JAZZ
description: SINEAD O'CONNOR's excellent recent album, "THROW DOWN YOUR ARMS," is a roots-reggae primer, but not in the usual way: the songs, many of them written by Burning Spear, are all righteous protests in behalf of the Rastafarian faith, and she approached them, she has said, "as sacred text." She made the album with ROBBIE SHAKESPEARE and SLY DUNBAR, the solid-gold Jamaican rhythm-section team of the 70's and 80's, and she is bringing them on the road with her, for a tour that arrives at Webster Hall on Friday. Be advised: this is her first tour in seven years, and she has made it clear that she will not be singing the old songs that made her famous. 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 353-1600.

title: A Record for Ridership On a Bus to Westchester
description: A record high of 11,675 passengers rode the I-Bus, or Interstate Bus, between Stamford and White Plains in Westchester County in October, the State Department of Transportation announced on Monday.

Corzine Defies The Status Quo
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rock Band Regroups, One Show at a Time
description: LEAVING Boulder, Colo., on the night of Oct. 30, Nick Ghanbarian could feel his life falling into place. His rock band, Bayside, was playing better than ever, and to bigger crowds, more than halfway across the country from his home in Deer Park. Three days earlier, while stepping onstage in Indianapolis at the start of the six-and-a-half-week tour, he had felt no jitters, only a sense that he had finally arrived where he was meant to be.

title: Bridge's Completion Delayed Until June
description: WHEN the first half of the new Sikorsky Bridge opened in November 2003, the more than 70,000 motorists who use it each day were finally able to cross the Housatonic River in peace. There was no more annoying road noise and uneasy feeling of their car swaying that came from the steel grate of the old span. The old bridge was so unpleasant to cross, that drivers often slowed down on the bridge, causing traffic tie-ups.

title: Waiting in the Wings, Singing to Themselves
description: IN 1941, Astrid Varnay, then 23, jumped in on a few hours' notice for an ailing Lotte Lehmann as Sieglinde in "Die Walkre" at the Metropolitan Opera; it was the start of a long and illustrious international career. In 1944, Regina Resnik, 22, was thrust onto the Met stage as Leonora in "Il Trovatore" when Zinka Milanov got sick; Ms. Resnik remained an operatic fixture for decades. In 2002, Salvatore Licitra, at 33, replaced Luciano Pavarotti at the 11th hour in a long-planned "Tosca" at the Met and gave patrons who had paid as much as $1,800 a ticket something to cheer about; Sony Classical rushed out a solo recording.

title: The Remix; Clean Start
description: If only we could exchange what we gave ourselves for Christmas: dull, lifeless skin, complete exhaustion and a body that could launch a thousand gym memberships. Welcome to the dark side of holiday cheer. How to undo the effects of prolonged overdoing it? January is the annual Big Flush, the only time of the year that the word "detox" doesn't imply the Betty Ford Clinic. But luckily, it's not all about laying off the cake and Champagne and catching up on sleep: spas and skin-care companies are ringing in the new year by making it easier for you to get your glow back. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: The Queen of Sci Fi Gets Ready to Rumble
description: ON a November day in her office in Rockefeller Center, Bonnie Hammer, the president of the Sci Fi Channel, kept glancing at a poster for "The Triangle," a new mini-series about a team of investigators in the Bermuda Triangle. It wasn't the luminous hologram in the poster's center that captivated her. It was the idea of grabbing it, and putting it up on the train she takes each day to her home in Westport, Conn. "They still have U.S. Open posters up," she said. "I want to rip them down."

title: The Adventures of TV Writer Guy
description: Nearly every Wednesday, Damon Lindelof plays hooky from his 70-hour-a-week job co-producing "Lost," the ABC series he created with J. J. Abrams, and heads for the comic-book store to pick up his weekly fix of graphic fiction. "I can say without doubt that if it weren't for comic books, 'Lost' would not exist," he said. "J. J. and I were both steeped in the serialized nature of comic books where a story would span the course of a year, or two years, or even three years," Mr. Lindelof said. "When you bought an issue of 'X-Men' or 'Justice League of America,' you never knew which superhero it was going to focus on because you had these vast ensembles that let you track characters with complicated individual histories interconnecting with each other."

description: I will soon be in Kyoto on my own for a few days and wonder whether there are small group tours focusing on a single craft. -- M. C., Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: A View of the Political Storm After Katrina
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 - It was Thursday, Sept. 1, three days after Hurricane Katrina had ripped across the Gulf Coast. As New Orleans descended into horror, the top aides to Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco of Louisiana were certain the White House was trying to blame their boss, and they were becoming increasingly furious.

title: The Master of Reinvention Finds a New Role: Patron
description: IN October a worthy New York organization called Career Transition for Dancers celebrated itself with its annual gala. It is part of a worldwide movement designed to help dancers, as they approach their cruelly early retirement age, to reinvent themselves for the rest of their lives.

title: Skiing From Hip, Miller Veers to Victory
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Dec. 3 - One day after Daron Rahlves stole past him to win the World Cup downhill here, Bode Miller stood in the start house of the giant slalom Saturday, staring at revenge through a driving snowstorm. At the finish line below, Rahlves had just completed the second of his two giant slalom runs and held the lead. Miller was the last skier of the day.

title: Connecticut Town Helps Create an Architectural Anomaly: An Appealing Water Plant
description: HAMDEN, Conn. - It could have been a pitched battle: a snug, Bohemian neighborhood versus a big construction project in a historic enclave. But instead of saying not in my backyard, some of the architects, artists and teachers who live here collaborated with a utility company to make a workaday water treatment plant architecturally dazzling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULZBERGER, MAYE
description: SULZBERGER--Maye. Died on Saturday night November 26th after a long life well lived. Maye is survived by her loving and beloved family. Services were held at Frank E. Campbell's; interment is at Beth-El Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Comprehensive NY Times obit ran earlier this week. Memorial contributions, if desired, to Mt. Sinai Hospital (NYC) attn: Dr. Alvin Teirstein.

title: 'The Diamond'
description: On October 16, 1816, on the foul island of Saint Helena, in the middle of precisely nowhere in the South Atlantic Ocean, I watched the emperor's hair being cut. As the hairs floated to the floor, I was waiting my chance. The emperor seemed to be staring at a portrait of the King of Rome riding a sheep. Santini, the barber, had spread a cloth over his green coat and was holding the razor aloft. The window was open on the usual evening smell of something tropical and crushed.

title: The Populist Party
description: Lunch on the New Zealand set of "The Chronicles of Narnia" was a taut, Balkanized affair. According to several people who worked on the film, giants sat with giants, centaurs with centaurs. It felt like a high school cafeteria at Halloween -- that is, until Allison Sarofim flew herself to New Zealand. "At my table, there was always a giant, a little person, a Cyclops," Sarofim explains. "We didn't discriminate."

title: Chilling in National Parks
description: Most people dreaming of a winter getaway don't immediately think, "Let's visit a national park." But there are at least two reasons to give those wide-open spaces a second glance: lower prices and fewer crowds.

title: Surf, Shave Ice and Sunsets on Kauai
description: WE are on Hawaiian time. Every shave ice is made custom for you. So please relax -- enjoy and aloha!" So reads the sign at Wishing Well Shave Ice in Hanalei, Kauai. It is a fair assessment of how things work in this laid-back hamlet, situated between the Pacific Ocean, soaring green pali (cliffs) and elegant taro fields on the verdant North Shore of Kauai: nothing moves as fast as it does on the mainland.

title: Adriana Pezzulli and Tony Newman
description: Adriana Dorffi Pezzulli, the daughter of Sandra Pezzulli and Dr. Fred Pezzulli of New York, is to be married today to Tony Newman, the son of Annie and Steve Newman of Santa Cruz, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Jacqueline J. Lewis, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate at the nondenominational ceremony at the Monkey Bar, a restaurant in New York.

title: The Remix: Beat the Parents; Hotel Deals
description: Numbing your hotel doldrums usually means hitting the minibar and channel-surfing before passing out. But now hotels are offering more playful diversions. Sure, everyone from the Hyatt to the Plaza Athne supplies playing cards, but you haven't played high-stakes solitaire until you've dealt a hand with the Ritz Paris embossed deck. Even better, kill a rainy Parisian night by solving Le Meurice's cartoon jigsaw puzzle. And when it's too cold to swim, put together the Beverly Hills Hotel's puzzle version of its pool and cabana. Picking up the pieces has never been so easy. Paul l. Underwood

title: In Germany, Muslims grow apart
Paris
description: A burning car may temporarily have replaced the Eiffel Tower as its iconic image, but Paris remains the City of Light. This season brings several books that evoke an earlier, more romantic Paris.

title: IS 'HYPE-R SUNDAY' NEXT?
description: He is not a marketer. But Scott Silverman, the executive director of Shop.org, the National Retail Federation's trade group for online merchants, pulled off one of the year's best marketing coups. He dubbed the Monday after Thanksgiving "Cyber Monday," the online counterpart to the Black Friday that kicks off the holiday shopping season for brick-and-mortar merchants.

title: The Prodigy Puzzle

Most children of poverty attend schools that focus on basic skills and test preparation. Without advocates, the potential of these children is not often realized.

title: 'Ice'
description: To someone who lives in the temperate north, the event seems simple enough. When the air turns cold, the water in ponds and brooks, lakes, rivers, ditches, and water glasses freezes on top. If the air stays cold, the ice on top gets thicker. It may get thick enough, in lakes and ponds at least, that as the Christian knight told the disbelieving Saracen in Sir Walter Scott's novel The Talisman, a horse could carry you "over as wide a lake as thou seest yonder spread out behind us, yet not wet one hair above his hoof." To the Saracen, this preposterous claim was evidence that the knight belonged to a nation that loves to laugh. "Neither the Dead Sea," he scoffed, "nor any of the seven oceans which environ the earth will endure on the surface the pressure of a horse's foot." He was misinformed; several of the Earth's seas and many thousands of its lakes and ponds can take the pressure of a horse's foot in winter, and more besides. Yet there are things that happen when a body of water turns to ice that seem almost as improbable, when you find out about them, as the knight's claim, made under a knot of palm trees by a plashing fountain, seemed to the Saracen.

title: The Remix; Thanks Giving
description: On modern to-do lists, writing thank-you notes usually ranks about as high as polishing the silver. But it need not be a chore, according to the stationer Drew Souza, of IS on Crosby Street. The only imperative when it comes to thank-yous, he confides, is to send them. He suggests you write at least three sentences, avoid clichs (an evening- or gift-specific anecdote is thoughtful) and do it by hand, no matter how keyboard-weakened your penmanship. Souza also advises waiting until January to send holiday-related thanks: "If it arrives on Dec. 22, no one will have time to open it." Let us now give thanks. MARK ELLWOOD

title: The Month When Our Culture Collapses Into a Pile of Preferences
description: I am not a list-making person. There is a list of reasons, but I'm not about to make it. Something eludes me in the 1. 2. 3. of it, the a. b. c. of it. I have known a few great list-makers, among them my stepmother. She used to keep a daily record in the form of penciled lists on a neatly folded square of paper. It accorded almost exactly with my sense of her character -- not a moment was to be wasted and the best way not to waste a moment was to map out the day ahead as if she were keeping a ship's log of the immediate future.

Real Border Security
description: President Bush went to the nation's Southwest border states recently to talk tough about keeping out illegal immigrants. His rhetoric was hard as he warned of murderers, child molesters and other criminals slipping onto American soil. Gone was the gentler voice of the former Texas governor who talked about how people were coming to America to feed their children, about how "Family Values Don't Stop at the Rio Grande." As a result, many who listened figured that he'd "tacked right," as some Democrats complained, or that he had simply deserted his five-year-old plan for a comprehensive immigration program. A careful reading of the president's comments raises hopes that Mr. Bush is staying his course but selling it a little differently.

description: FROST--David, M.D. Public Health Advocate, died in San Francisco at age 95, on Thanksgiving in the company of his devoted family. Born April 13, 1910, in New York City, he attended New York University (BS), St. Louis University (Maryland) and Harvard (MPH). In public health, he served local, state (California, New York), and federal governments. Twice widowed, he is survived by two children, Philip Frost and Ruth Foy, their spouses Velia and Dennis, grandchildren David, his wife Stefanie, and Jeana, two great-grandchildren and stepdaughter Pamela Slipyan. He will be laid to rest at Arlington National Cemetery December 9, with a memorial on December 18, in San Francisco, CA. Condolences: dfkids@mac.com

Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMUNTZ, RUTH
description: GOLDMUNTZ--Ruth. 73, died peacefully in Santa Barbara, CA, on December 2nd, after a courageous fight with emphysema. Her sons, David and Michael Goldmuntz, were with her. Born in 1932 in Frankfurt, Germany, to Arthur and Gerda Loewengart, she came to the United States in 1937 with her family and grew up in Forest Hills, Queens. Following her father's commitment to Zionism, she was a tireless worker for the State of Israel with a special commitment to The Jerusalem Foundation founded by Teddy Kollek with whom she had a lifelong friendship. She also worked closely with, and was a cherished friend to, the late Itzhak and Leah Rabin and the Dayan family. She is survived by her sons, David and Michael Goldmuntz, her daughter-in-law Leesa Wilson-Goldmuntz, her sister Mimi Schwartz and her grandchildren, Jennifer, James, Jeffrey, Gail, Sarah and Elizabeth. Her daughter Susan preceded her in death. Ruth will be buried beside her sister Hannah at the Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. Funeral services will be private, but the family will hold visiting hours for friends and relatives at 200 East 71st Street, Manhattan, on Tuesday, from 4-8 pm, and on Wednesday, from 1-6 pm. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to The Jerusalem Foundation or the American Lung Association.

Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHINSON, ARLINE JUDITH
description: NICHINSON--Arline Judith. Of Boca Raton, Florida left us on December 2, 2005 at the age of 79. She was, and in our memories, will always be vital, exciting, young in heart, gentle and genuine. She was a truly beautiful lady. Arline was the lasting love of her husband David, with a marriage of 54 years, and the devoted and giving mother of Laurel Nichinson and Dr. Brad Nichinson. She was the sister to Ed, Robert and Howard Wiener, and like a sister, to their wives, as well as a beloved aunt to their many children. In addition, Arline truly cherished her many friends. Arline loved to dance and began in New York's Borscht Belt, followed by Vaudeville with the Caites Brothers and as Arline Castle, with the Castle Sisters. Arline was a dancer in "As the Girls Go" on Broadway and one of the original June Taylor dancers in Jackie Gleason's weekly TV Show. She also appeared on TV with Milton Berle and Patti Page. Arline excelled in everything she undertook. Her interests varied from her love of ballet and opera, to golf and bridge and our tennis trophies were all hers. She will be sadly missed. Services will be held Monday, December 5, 2005 at 1:00 PM at the Star of David, 7701 Bailey Road, North Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33068, 954722-9000. Donations may be made to the Boca West Cancer Research Unit, c/o Helene Miller 6697 Woodbridge Drive, Boca Raton, FL 33434.

It is a model that has been used by government agencies to measure everything from the nation's wealth to the financial condition of the country's households. Based on those figures, the United States is in very good shape. But these balance sheets do not give a complete picture. There are hidden long-term problems facing the nation that do not show up among assets and liabilities. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

Arts Briefly; 'Harry Potter' Stays at No. 1 for Third Week
description: Despite competition from Charlize Theron as a 25th-century assassin in skintight black, "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" (Warner Brothers), starring Daniel Radcliffe, right, handily retained the top spot at the box office this weekend, taking in $20.4 million since Friday, according to studio estimates. Its three-week total stands at nearly $230 million, making it already one of the top-grossing movies of the year. "Aeon Flux" (Paramount), starring Ms. Theron and directed by Karyn Kusama ("Girlfight"), opened at No. 2 with $13.1 million. It was the only new film in wide release this weekend, but the studio did not screen it in advance for critics, so it had a one-day head start over the widely unfavorable reviews it received on Saturday. "Walk the Line" (Fox), the Johnny and June Carter Cash love story, dropped one spot to No. 3 with an even $10 million, bringing cumulative sales over three weeks to $68.7 million. "Yours, Mine and Ours" (Paramount), the remake of the 1968 Lucille Ball-Henry Fonda picture starring Dennis Quaid and Rene Russo, was No. 4 with $8.4 million in its second weekend, bringing its total gross to $34.5 million. The romantic comedy "Just Friends" (New Line), moved up one spot to No. 5 in its second week out; it took in $5.9 million, for cumulative sales of $21.4 million.

title: Arts Briefly; Film Museum Closes in Moscow
description: The Moscow Film Museum has shut the doors of its longtime home after a protracted real estate struggle that drew rare street protests from Russian film lovers. The museum, which housed a collection of memorabilia from Tarkovsky and Eisenstein, had been in the Kino Center, a huge building in central Moscow that was constructed in 1980's for the Soviet Filmmakers' Union, but since 1991 has been gradually taken over by casinos, restaurants and strip clubs, and also has a commercial movie theater. The director of the museum, Naum Kleiman, said earlier this year that he had been served with eviction papers, and it closed down on Thursday. "We have to say goodbye to these quarters," he told the newspaper Izvestia. "It's the past, which has now ended up in the hands of people who are strangers to film." The Russian Filmmakers' Union last year sold its stake in the building to a company said to be linked to Nikita Mikhalkov, the Oscar-winning director and the chairman of the union, a connection that raised eyebrows in Moscow. Mr. Mikhalkov recently announced that he was taking a break from his position with the union to complete several film projects. The museum's collection is being moved to Mosfilm Studios, and is to have screenings at a government-run cultural facility, but still hopes for a new permanent home. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Craig Starts Charging
description: Craig Newmark, creator of Craigs List, says he will start charging for real estate ads on his free service. According to a column on Newmark in Fortune, he is set to collect a nominal fee, no more than $10, from New York City real estate brokers for their property listings. The Fortune columnist, Adam Lashinsky, predicts a massive migration to Googles Base service.

title: What Will the Boomers Do?

A study from the Federal Reserve says that it is possible to account for the rise in housing prices and the fall in interest rates through a model the author, Robert Martin, has developed.

title: The Pig Through the Python
description: Speaking of boomers, one of the best economic blogs, Calculated Risk, has a wonderful animated GIF file of the population distribution through the last century. Check it out to watch the Baby Boomers start to die off.

title: What Is To Be Done?
description: A friend writes that he cant get out of his mind the comment from the late Senator Paul Simon that if only 100 people in each Congressional district had written to their member of Congress, that would have been enough to galvanize the government to stop the genocide in Rwanda. He adds: To get the Eagle Scout rank, a boy has to do a service project. I have the perfect service project of the moment: Call on candidates for the Eagle rank to organize a Paul-Simon-inspired letter writing campaign in their congressional districts. I cant think of a more worthy Eagle Scout service project than ending the genocide in Darfur. I second the motion, and there must be an equivalent for girl scouts as well.

title: Should We Cull Columnists?
description: I had plenty of indignant letters from deer, or at least deer supporters, after my column on Sunday that favored hunting for Bambi. Doris wrote: Your editorial today took my breath away with the one-sided pick up a rifle cry to arms. I had been quite a fan of Kristofs sensitive attention to the plight of the abused, the marginalized, the suffering in our world. Disgraceful that the NY Tiimes should save Sundays center editorial page location read by millionsfor his murderous plan for the deer. Hes advocating violence. Is this the model we want for our young: the gun? [Im] dismayed and disappointed.

title: Changes at Security Checkpoints
description: Joe Sharkey describes how changes in Transportation Security Administration policy will affect frequent fliers.

title: Nascar Rolls In for a Midtown Victory Lap
description: A pedestrian in a thick blue jacket wandered last week past Cipriani, the chic Manhattan restaurant across from Grand Central Terminal, and asked the doorman why in the world a bunch of stock-car racers would gather in New York to have lunch.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Sears to Buy Rest of Chain
description: Sears Holdings offered 835.4 million Canadian dollars (about $719 million) for the 46.2 percent of Sears Canada it does not own. The move followed an announcement last week that Sears Canada is to pay shareholders 2 billion Canadian dollars in a special dividend after raising 2.3 billion Canadian dollars on the sale of its credit card division. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: 9/11 Panel Issues Poor Grades for Handling of Terror
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 - The members of the Sept. 11 commission gave dismal grades to the Bush administration and Congress on Monday in measuring the government's recent efforts to prevent terrorist attacks on American soil, concluding that the government deserved many more F's and D's than A's.

description: A freshman who was found dead in his dorm room at Syracuse University on Sunday afternoon died of coronary arterial sclerosis, the Onondaga County medical examiner's office said. Two friends discovered Babak Najafi, 18, in his bed around 3 p.m. on Sunday. A memorial service is planned for early next year. Michelle York (NYT)
