title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, JOHN M.
description: MURPHY--John M. Of Breezy Point, NY, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, and Rockville Centre, on December 4, 2005, at the age of 84. Born April 18, 1921, John was the youngest of four boys. He was a decorated veteran of WWII serving in Europe. Founder and President of East America, Inc., a commodity trading firm in New York. He was a fabulous cook, master storyteller and a devoted husband and father. With his loving wife Grace, he enjoyed his retirement on the beaches of Breezy Point and Hutchinson Island, FL. His warmth, wit and sage counsel will be profoundly missed. In addition to his wife Grace, John is survived by his beloved children: Kathleen (Spangler), Michael, James, John, Robert and the late Charles, with whom he now rests. He will also be deeply missed by his fourteen adoring grandchildren. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor, Inc., 9105 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point, on Friday at 11:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Covenant House, PO Box JAF 2973, New York, NY 10116-2973.

description: As enchanting as the children are in the first act of George Balanchine's "Nutcracker," their indelible charm can fade to dust if the Sugarplum Fairy isn't at her most magnificent. If she embodies the magical grandeur of the part while gliding through Balanchine's intricate steps, the second act unfolds like a dream. On Sunday evening, Jennie Somogyi returned to the New York State Theater in her first major role with New York City Ballet since tearing a tendon in her foot in January 2004. Her performance was no fantasy, but a flesh-and-bone triumph.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOLYNEUX, PETER E.
description: MOLYNEUX--Peter E. Of New York City, formerly of Old Greenwich, died November 21, 2005. He was 45 years old. Mr. Molyneux attended Greenwich High School and Drew University and was a member of the Economics Honor Society. He was Chief Financial Officer of Northbridge Capital Holding Company for 20 years. Peter is survived by his mother, Donna Gorham Molyneux of West Chester, PA, his father Edward Molyneux of Rhinebeck, NY, a sister Carol Petraglia of Radnor, PA, a nephew Alexander and a niece Katie. Memorial services will be held on December 10 at 10:30AM at First Presbyterian Church, 48 Fifth Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Habitat for Humanity.

title: Failing on Homeland Security
description: The former members of the 9/11 commission issued a report card yesterday that gives the federal government shockingly low grades on protecting the nation from another terrorist attack. These disastrous marks, which apply to both Congress and the Homeland Security Department, came at a crucial moment. Right now, Congress may be about to make more terrible decisions in two important areas: the homeland security financing formula and chemical plant security.

description: FRENCH--Lauretta. Of New York City. Died December 3, 2005. Beloved mother of Lauretta Hicks Jones of Tallahassee, FL and Frenchie Longino of Washington, DC. title: Raised as Catholic in Belgium, She Died as a Muslim Bomber
description: MONCEAU-SUR-SAMBRE, Belgium, Dec. 5 - Muriel Degauque, believed to be the first European Muslim woman to stage a suicide attack, started out life as a good Roman Catholic girl in this coal mining corner of Belgium known as the black country. She ended it in a grisly blast deep inside Iraq last month.

title: Edwards Tells Dungy: Stop Calls or Colts Will Pay
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 5 - More than once over the past several weeks, Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy has reached for the telephone to call Herman Edwards, the Jets' coach.

title: Mileage Rate Retreats
description: MILEAGE RATE RETREATS -- For travelers who drive their own cars on business trips, the Internal Revenue Service has just published the mileage deduction rate for 2006. It's 44.5 cents a mile. That's down from 48.5 cents a mile for the last four months of 2005, which reflected a special adjustment for rising gasoline prices; during the first eight months of 2005, the rate was set at 40.5 cents. "The 2006 mileage rates reflect that gas prices have dropped," Mark W. Everson, the agency's commissioner, said in a statement.

title: German Sues Over Abduction Said to Be at Hands of C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - A German citizen who says he was abducted, beaten and taken to Afghanistan by American agents in an apparent case of mistaken identity in 2003 filed suit in federal court today against George J. Tenet, the former C.I.A. director, and three companies said to have been involved in secret flight operations.

title: 2 Killed in Separate East Harlem Shootings
description: A 16-year-old boy and a 38-year-old man were killed yesterday in separate shootings in East Harlem, and a 30-year-old man was wounded, the police said.

description: My mother believed in the verities of life. Don't wear white after Labor Day. A phone call does not replace a thank-you note. Everything should have a place, and everything should be in its place.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Former Schools Chief Sentenced
description: The former schools superintendent Angelo Petrone, who was convicted of perjury and tampering with public documents, was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation and 750 hours of community service. In September, he pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to lying to the city's inspector general during an investigation of the hiring of an inexperienced accountant for a $90,000-a-year job. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: A Sense of Moment for New Settings of Poems by 3 Poets
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center was excited about its new piece. The program notes for its concert on Sunday afternoon included thoughts from Fred Sherry, the cellist, about playing a new work. Before the performance, Wu Han, one of the organization's artistic directors, spoke from the stage, invoking the most famous premiere of modern times, Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring," in 1913. The audience, she suggested, would be able to say, "I was there when Melinda Wagner's piece 'Four Settings' had its New York premiere."

title: Productivity Rise Is Fastest in Two Years
description: Productivity rose at its fastest pace in two years in the third quarter, far more quickly than earlier predicted, as output rose and labor costs fell, the government reported today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manager Sought For Memorial
description: A construction manager is being sought for the memorial and memorial museum at ground zero, under a request for proposals issued yesterday by the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. John C. Whitehead, the chairman of both groups, said the manager would help ensure that construction starts early next year, sticks to a three-year timetable and stays within its budget, estimated at $500 million. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site, said that it would not submit a proposal but "would be willing to serve as construction manager if asked." David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Lifting the Art of Name-Dropping to a Cosmic Level
description: Even social-climbing New Yorkers, the most shameless name-droppers on the planet, might feel compelled to cut back on celebrity-citing after meeting the wistful waiter now serving boldface dish at the Atlantic Theater Company. An employee of a sweller-than-thou London restaurant, this logorrheic fellow, deliciously played by David Pittu, shows up in the enjoyably boisterous production of Harold Pinter's "Celebration" that opened last night.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Subway Rules Take Effect
description: Rule changes for subway passengers -- the first since 1994 -- took effect yesterday. Riders are now prohibited from jumping turnstiles even if their MetroCards are not working, straddling a bicycle, wearing skates, standing on a skateboard or a scooter inside a train, moving between subway cars except in an emergency or when directed by a police officer or conductor, and placing their feet on a subway train or bus seat. The rules were passed by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board in September after more than a year of discussion. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, FRANK
description: SHAPIRO--Frank, 60. On December 3, 2005, after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Beloved husband of Carol; devoted father of Lisa and her husband Craig Berry, and Amy Shapiro; doting grandfather to Max and Alex Berry; and brother to Alan Shepherd. Services for Mr. Shapiro will be at 10:30 A.M. Tuesday, December 6, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard. (718896-9000). Donations may be made to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Boulevard, Woodbury, NY 11797. $(6$)SHAPIRO--Frank. The partners of Anchin, Block & Anchin LLP mourn the loss of their esteemed partner Frank Shapiro, 60, of Wantagh, Long Island, on Saturday, December 3, 2005, after a long and courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. His spirit and his demeanor throughout his lengthy illness were an inspiration to all who knew him. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Carol; his children, Lisa and her husband Craig Berry, and Amy Shapiro; his grandchildren, Alex and Max Berry; and his brother, Alan Shepherd. He was a long-time partner of Seymour Schneidman & Associates and Anchin, Block & Anchin LLP. We extend our deepest sympathies to the family.

title: Kazakh President Re-elected; Voting Flawed, Observers Say
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan, Dec. 5 - President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan secured a third term in office in the election over the weekend with an overwhelming victory, the country's election commission announced Monday, while a prominent international observer mission said the election did not meet democratic standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, MARVIN
description: ROSENTHAL--Marvin. We join the Rosenthal family in mourning the loss of our friend and colleague, Marvin Rosenthal. Marvin was a cherished member of the CBRE family for the past six years and a highly regarded member of the New York City real estate community. Marvin was full of vigor and optimism, even as he waged a fierce fight following complications from surgery. His spirit, courage and dignity are an inspiration to us all. Our thoughts and prayers go out to Marvin's family, including his wife Elaine, daughter Jane Knudsen, son-in-law Chris Knudsen, and three grandchildren, as well as to his longtime friend and business partner, Paul Muratore. We will miss Marvin dearly. CB Richard Ellis $(6$)ROSENTHAL--Marvin. Loving devoted husband, father and grandfather. Our relationship started 14 years ago and developed into something so special and irreplaceable. He embraced our family as his own and was a true friend and partner. His spirit and approach towards life was inspirational. His guidance and wisdom made us all better individuals. He will be with us forever. Love, Love, The Muratore Family Paul, Linda, Nicole, Danielle, Christopher & Michelle $(6$)ROSENTHAL--Marvin. We mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Marvin Rosenthal. Our condolences to his wife Elaine and their family. Marvin was part of the bedrock of the New York real estate community. He was a pleasure to work with and a gentleman. We will miss him. Stephen B. Siegel Michael R. Laginestra Scott L. Gottlieb

title: History Is Slipping Away as Collections Deteriorate, Report Says
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2 - Slipping on a pair of white gloves, Joshua Fox, a curator at the Soldiers and Sailors National Military Museum and Memorial here, motioned toward a tattered bunch of silk in a musty attic storage room. It was the battle flag of a Pennsylvania regiment dating from the Civil War era, disintegrating after decades of inattention and poor climate controls.

title: Questions About Secret Prisons Follow Rice in Europe
description: BUCHAREST, Dec. 6 - Questions about covert prisons and a mistaken, secret arrest dogged Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on a visit to three European nations today, but she declined to answer most questions, even after Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany called for "a certain degree of transparency" on the matter.

title: 2 Men Rescued By Divers on L.I.
description: PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y., Dec. 5 - Police divers on Monday night rescued one man who drove his car into 10 feet of water at the end of a boat ramp here and a second man who went in to try to save him. Both men, whose names were not released, were being treated at hospitals late Monday night.

BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Verizon to Alter Managers' Retirement Plans As Part of Attempt to Cut Costs by $3 Billion Verizon Communications, one of the nation's largest phone companies, said that it would stop making contributions to the guaranteed pension plan covering 50,000 of its managers and offer them 401(k) plans instead. Verizon also said that it would contribute less to the health care benefits of those managers when they retire. Over all, the company hopes to save about $3 billion over the next decade by taking these steps. "This restructuring reflects the realities of our changing world," said Verizon's chief executive, Ivan Seidenberg, above. [Page A1.]

title: Ringleader in Arsons Gets the Maximum Sentence
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 - The man convicted of being the ringleader in arsons that heavily damaged expensive new houses in a subdivision in southern Maryland last December was sentenced on Monday to nearly 20 years in prison.

title: N. Korea ties talks to end of U.S. sanctions
Britain's budget for EU is assailed
For Economy Talk, Bush Visits Bright Spot
description: KERNERSVILLE, N.C., Dec. 5 - President Bush traveled to a bright spot in North Carolina's manufacturing industry on Monday, a plant that makes excavators used in construction and disaster relief, to tell Americans that the economy was better than they thought and that his administration deserved some credit for it.

title: Labor Advocate to Oppose Clinton
description: A labor advocate who has recently taken on Wal-Mart plans to run against Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, and is basing his campaign on her past support for the war in Iraq.

title: The Claim: Never Drink on an Empty Stomach
description: THE CLAIM -- Never drink on an empty stomach.

title: Liu Binyan, a Fierce Insider Critic of China, Dies at 80
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 5 - Liu Binyan, the forceful dissident writer who repeatedly exposed official corruption and openly challenged the Chinese Communist Party to reform itself before and after he was exiled to the United States in the late 1980's, died Monday.

title: Metro Briefings
description: NEW YORK

title: Constant Travelers Wear Their All-Nighters as a Badge of Pride
description: Mark Stevens, the chief executive of MSCO, a marketing firm in White Plains, is away on business 150 to 200 days a year and typically gets one to four hours of sleep a night. But he's not complaining.

title: China to pay E7.7 billion for 150 Airbus planes
Remarks haunt Deutsche
Investigator in Beirut Assassination Is Leaving
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 5 - As United Nations investigators began questioning five Syrian officials in Vienna in connection with the assassination of a former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, the German prosecutor leading the investigation, Detlev Mehlis, said Monday that he would leave his post in two weeks.

title: Giants Take Pass on Playoff Math
description: By winning three of their last four games, the Giants would clinch the National Football Conference East title. But even finishing without another loss would guarantee them nothing more than that. For the Giants to improve beyond the N.F.C.'s No. 4 playoff seeding, they would need the teams currently ahead of them to lose, maybe a couple of times.

title: Some new EU members feel betrayed
Firefighters Call for Independent Inquiry Into Use of Older Vehicles
description: Criticism over the Fire Department's reliance on older vehicles, which may have contributed to a firefighter's injury on Friday, intensified yesterday as the firefighters' union called for an outside investigation. The union contended that "outdated and unsafe equipment" was jeopardizing the safety of firefighters and the public.

title: Agency faces scrutiny over heartworm drug for dogs
Knicks Are Facing an Identity Crisis
description: For a telling snapshot of just how befuddling and karmically adrift the Knicks are, one only needed to track their steps this past weekend. On Friday, they lost to Coach Larry Brown's former team. On Saturday, they waived one of their strongest perimeter defenders. On Sunday, unable to guard a pair of great perimeter scorers, the Knicks lost again.

title: The soothing balm of films set in the past
Japan finally putting nightmare of recession behind it
Weicker May Return to Politics Over Lieberman's Support of War
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 5 - Former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. on Monday criticized Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's continued support of the war in Iraq and said that if no candidate challenged the senator on the issue in the 2006 election, he would consider running.

title: A haircut, in real life
Go West, Young Astronaut
description: NASA still doesn't have the money to go back to the Moon, much less head to Mars, but there is good news for space explorers. Someone else is on the job.

title: Ads Portray Nominee as Protector of Christmas
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 - It is the time of year when bedtime stories and television specials often recall the plucky reindeer and the little girl of Whoville who managed to save Christmas. This year, some conservative groups are hoping to add a new name to that pantheon of heroes: Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr., the Supreme Court nominee.

title: 'Year of Magical Thinking' Headed for Broadway
description: Continuing a journey from personal testament to cultural touchstone, "The Year of Magical Thinking," Joan Didion's best-selling account of the death of her husband, the writer John Gregory Dunne, and the fatal illness of their daughter, Quintana Roo, is being prepared for a completely new arena: Broadway.

title: Peter Haas, 86, Executive During Levi Strauss Heyday, Dies
description: Peter Edgar Haas Sr., who with his brother Walter engineered the explosive growth of the family business, Levi Strauss, into the world's biggest maker of brand-name jeans, died Saturday at his home in San Francisco. He was 86.

title: Therapies: A Dose of Dolphins for Moderate Depression
description: Researchers working in Honduras have taken an unusual approach to treating mild to moderate depression: they teamed their patients up with dolphins.

title: Blast Plotter Arrested, Bangladesh Says
description: GAZIPUR, Bangladesh, Dec. 5 - A man suspected of masterminding two suicide bombings aimed at legal offices here last week was arrested Monday.

title: Reviving slice of avant-garde
Six People Walk Into a Bar, and a Drama Breaks Out
description: John Lennon's creepy cover of "Be My Baby," the perky 1963 hit by the Ronettes, is playing as the lights go down at the start of "Coronado," a seductive new throwback of a play by Dennis Lehane. Two hours and many revelations later, it becomes clear what an apt choice of scene-setting music this is, full of double meaning and tapping into that unsettling place where the familiar turns eerie.

title: U.N. Fires Head of Elections Office Ahead of Iraqi Vote
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 6 - The United Nations fired the head of its highly regarded elections services office today following accusations of sexual harassment and abuse of authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRICE, LEO, CPA
description: PRICE--Leo, CPA, on December 5, 2005. Beloved husband of Doris, loving father of Sandra and Helene. Dear fatherin-law of Charles Gropper. Loving grandfather of Jaime. Dear brother of Hattie Stein and Sylvia Drucker. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM "Parkside" Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (near Ave V.)

title: Corrections
description: An illustration and a caption with an article in Science Times last Tuesday about the continuing quiet eruption at Mount St. Helens in Washington misidentified a tectonic plate involved in the volcanic activity. The mountain sits above the boundary of the Juan de Fuca plate and the North American plate, not the Pacific and North American plates. (The collision of the two plates sets the volcanic activity in motion.)

title: Yen at 32-Month Low as Japan's Small Investors Look Abroad
description: TOKYO, Dec. 5 - The Japanese yen fell to a 32-month low against the dollar on Monday, continuing an almost yearlong slide that helps Japanese exporters, but raises pressure on American producers.

title: In the Bronx, This One's for the Children
description: THE BRONX has a zoo, a baseball stadium and acres and acres of parkland. It has a symphony orchestra, an opera company and the oldest public golf course in America. But as far as 4-year-old Tyzella King is concerned, the borough is missing something rather important: a children's museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LITTENBERG, ROSLYN HALPER
description: LITTENBERG--Roslyn Halper. Of Manhattan, NY. Died December 4, 2005 at age 88. Beloved wife of the late Eli, devoted mother of Ronnie and Laurence, grandmother of Liza, Michael, and Jeff. Mourned also by sister Naomi, brothers Norman and Ted, sisters-in-law, Roz and Carol, son-in-law Phil, daughter-in-law Marcia, loving nieces and nephews, and dear friends. Social worker, feminist, counselor to all who knew her, she will be deeply missed. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 PM and services Wednesday 1PM, both at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FROST, DAVID, M.D.
description: FROST--David, M.D. Public Health Advocate, died in San Francisco at age 95, on Thanksgiving in the company of his devoted family. Born April 13, 1910, in New York City, he attended New York University (BS), St. Louis University (MD) and Harvard (MPH). In public health, he served local, state (California, New York), and federal governments. Twice widowed, he is survived by two children, Philip Frost and Ruth Foy; their spouses, Velia and Dennis; grandchildren, David, his wife, Stefanie, and Jeana; two great-grandchildren & stepdaughter, Pamela Slipyan. He will be laid to rest at Arlington National Cemetery December 9, with a memorial on December 18, in San Francisco, CA. Condolences: dfkids@mac.com

description: NEXT time you board a plane, consider visiting the restroom first.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERSTEL, ILONA
description: GERSTEL--Ilona, 96, On December 3, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Frederick Gerstel; loving aunt, cousin and friend. A woman of charity, dignity and caring.

Corrections
description: The Consumer column in Science Times last Tuesday, on potential poisoning hazards from the pain reliever acetaminophen, misspelled the generic name of an opiate that is combined with acetaminophen to produce the painkiller Vicodin. It is hydrocodone bitartrate, not hydroconebitartrate.

title: Intel and J.P. Morgan Chase to Expand Indian Operations
description: BANGALORE, India, Dec. 5 - Intel, the world's largest chip maker, and J. P. Morgan Chase, the global investment banker, said on Monday that they would outsource significant operations to India, an indication that more complex high-value work was moving here.

title: Power Chords and Tragic Sentiments. And Tragedy.
description: There's nothing surprising about the continuing popularity of emo. The genre's best and biggest bands have found ways to revive the rock 'n' roll love song, murmuring hypersentimental lyrics or screaming them. And they've also found something even more important than that: a strong support system. A nationwide network of clubs and fans and magazines and Web sites helps nurture obscure bands and rewards the ones that no longer are.

title: Dispute likely limited to U.S.
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rapper Seeks Reduced Charge
description: Foxy Brown, left, a rapper, appeared in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday in connection with charges that she struck two employees of a nail salon in August 2004. Ms. Brown's lawyer, Joseph Tacopina, said the rapper had become nearly deaf from an illness he could not precisely describe, and was communicating with him through written notes. But her hearing problem did not prevent Ms. Brown, whose original name is Inga Marchand, from chatting with a fan in the courtroom or answering reporters' questions about her aqua coat and quilted white leather bag. Ms. Brown has been ordered to return to court on Dec. 23. Anemona Hartocollis (NYT)

title: A nightmare for corporate America: Life without the BlackBerry
National Briefings
description: PLAINS

title: Iranian Military Plane Carrying 94 Crashes
description: At least 116 people were killed when an Iranian military transport plane carrying 94 people crashed in a residential area of Tehran today, killing all of the passengers and crew as well as people on the ground, according to reports in the Iranian media. The state Islamic Republic News Agency said in a report on its Web site that the C-130 transport plane crashed into the Tohid area, in southwest Tehran, at about 2:10 p.m. local time. The area is close to Tehran's Mehrabad International Airport, which handles domestic, international and military flights, it reported.

title: Gay Britons Signing Up as Unions Become Legal
description: LONDON, Dec. 5 - From Brighton to Birmingham and beyond, gay and lesbian couples began registering Monday for the first ceremonies later this month legally recognizing same-sex unions in Britain.

title: G.M.A.C. Sells Auto Loans to Unit of Canadian Bank
description: The finance unit of General Motors said yesterday that it had agreed to sell as much as $20 billion in auto loans over five years to the corporate and investment banking unit of the Bank of Nova Scotia. The deal is occurring as G.M. seeks cheaper sources of financing after its debt rating was cut to junk status.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Simon Starling Wins Turner Prize

title: In Mongolia, an 'Extinction Crisis' Looms
description: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia - On a highway west of this capital, roadside signs advertise marmot, fox and other wildlife, and stacks of skins stand on display. In open markets, traders conduct a gritty commerce in furs and hides, much of it illegal. Similar markets flourish elsewhere in Mongolia, especially along the border with China.

title: Looking at Polls for 'Victory' in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Protests Continue At N.Y.U.
description: Hundreds of protesters picketed at New York University yesterday in support of a union to represent graduate student teaching assistants, despite an ultimatum that the assistants who did not end their strike yesterday would lose teaching assignments and stipends next semester. A student council committee proposed on Sunday that a new organization be formed to represent graduate students at the university, and that the deadline to end the strike, now in its fourth week, be put off until tonight. N.Y.U.'s president, John Sexton, and provost, David McLaughlin, accepted the proposal. But pro-union graduate students rejected it yesterday, saying that it did not respond to their demand for a union to represent them as employees. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Soldier Cleared Of Murder Charges
description: Murder charges against Second Lt. Erick J. Anderson in connection with the killings of two unarmed Iraqis were dismissed after an Army investigator called the charges unfounded and unsupported. Lieutenant Anderson, 26, of Twinsburg, Ohio, was accused of ordering two killings, one that had been described as a "mercy killing" of an injured teenager and one during a house search. At a military hearing at Fort Riley last month, a soldier convicted in one of the killings said he had lied when he implicated Lieutenant Anderson, his platoon leader, so he could get a shorter prison sentence. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

He once shared a green room with Lindsay Lohan and was "Punk'd" by Ashton Kutcher. He goes on national television wearing a red velvet sports coat with his name sewn inside.

title: Chicago Keeps Low Profile
description: DALLAS, Dec. 5 - The Chicago White Sox are the World Series champions, and they looked the part Monday. While most team executives had meetings with other teams or were working the phones, White Sox General Manager Kenny Williams, Manager Ozzie Guillen and Dave Wilder, the director of player development, were relaxed as they lounged in the lobby.

title: Virtual Stars Compete for Real Money
description: Fatal1ty and Vo0 stood on opposite sides of a darkened theater while an announcer boomed their introductions to an appreciative crowd. Their faces magnified on giant overhead monitors, the two stared straight ahead while artificial smoke swirled around them. They met at center stage and shook hands before starting what the announcer called their grudge match.

title: Buy, Play, Trade, Repeat
description: Los Angeles - THE record company Sony BMG recently got in trouble after attempting to stem piracy by encoding its CD's with software meant to limit how many copies can be made of the discs. It turned out that the copy-protection software exposed consumers' computers to Internet viruses, forcing Sony BMG to recall the CD's.

title: In the Ballade, Emanuel Ax Finds a Prism of Possibilities
description: The ballade is a notion disguised as a musical form. It doesn't adhere to formal dictates, like a sonata, or a defined rhythmic pattern, like a waltz. It doesn't even evoke a particular mood or distinct imagery, like a nocturne or a barcarolle. In theory, its roots are in the simple contours of the ballad, but most composers who have used the title have offered something structurally and dramatically grander.

title: Texas Judge Lets Stand 2 of 3 Charges Against DeLay
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 5 - A Texas judge dismissed one charge against Representative Tom Delay on Monday but let stand two more serious charges, complicating Mr. DeLay's hopes of regaining his post as House majority leader when Congress resumes in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASNICK, BEATRICE B.
description: STRASNICK -- Beatrice B. Wife of the late Irving Strasnick, widow of Joel M. Lieberman and William J. Adler. Beloved sister of Shirley Rich, cherished aunt of Jonathan, loving (step) mother of Gloria and Bill Adler and Shelley and Dr. David Drath; devoted grandmother of Diane, Bill jr., Erica and Stephanie; caring great grandma of Madaline, Karen, Claire and Amanda. Crypt side services will be held Tuesday 1:15 PM at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. 718-377-7300.

title: INSIDE
description: Rice Says U.S. Interrogations Save European Lives Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Europeans complaining about secret jails for terror suspects in Europe should know that information from interrogating these suspects has helped "save European lives." PAGE A3

title: Venezuela to Help Bronx Residents With Heating Oil Bills
description: About all that Belkis Bejaran had ever heard about the firebrand leader of faraway Venezuela was that the combative populist often hurled verbal insults at President Bush.

title: Roundup: Sacchi joins exodus from Real Madrid
The Hubris of the Humanities
description: The best argument against "intelligent design" has always been humanity itself. At a time when only 40 percent of Americans believe in evolution, and only 13 percent know what a molecule is, we're an argument at best for "mediocre design."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Spitzer Campaign Announces Endorsements
description: Eliot Spitzer's campaign for governor announced endorsements yesterday from 35 mayors and mayors-elect across the state, a demonstration of political strength as Mr. Spitzer, the state attorney general, faces a possible challenge for the 2006 Democratic nomination. Among the 35 are the outgoing and incoming mayors of Buffalo and Rochester, as well as the leaders of Albany, Ithaca, Poughkeepsie, Schenectady and Syracuse. About half of the group had already endorsed Mr. Spitzer, but his campaign made a show of producing the big list at a time when Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, is considering a challenge to Mr. Spitzer. Patrick D. Healy (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUNGUIA, HARRIET K.
description: MUNGUIA--Harriet K. On November 7, 2005, in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Gilberto Munguia; mother of Kenneth L. Greif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDNER, ALBERT H., DDS.
description: RUDNER--Albert H., DDS. In his 98th year beloved husband of the late Gladys Rudner for 66 years, loving father of Jane and Maurice (Reese) Sherman and Judy and Jerry Kessel. Adored grandfather of Cathy and John Fiebach, Susan and Les Morgenstern, Danny and Kristin Stiebel and Lynn and John Fitzgerald. Dear great grandfather of Charlie, Josh, Aidan, Jamie, Matthew and Lucy. During W.W. II he was a captain in the calvary. He practiced dentistry in NYC for over 60 years, he loved people and he loved life. Private services were held. $(6$)RUDNER--Albert H., DDS. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Albert H. Rudner. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. George Asch, Sec'y.

description: The Liberty Media Corporation, owner of the QVC home-shopping network, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Provide Commerce for $477 million to add flowers and meat to the goods it sells online.

description: Nassau County prosecutors said yesterday that the longtime companion of the former Roslyn schools superintendent, Frank A. Tassone, was not protected by the privilege that prevents spouses from testifying against each other in court.

title: At Impasse With Network Star, ABC Picks 2 Youthful Anchors
description: ABC News named Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff yesterday to succeed the late Peter Jennings as anchors of "World News Tonight," but only after the network failed to reach agreement with one of its biggest stars, Charles Gibson of "Good Morning America."

title: Another Catwalk for Fashion Series
description: In tomorrow's premiere of the second season of "Project Runway," a young woman from Atlanta shows her portfolio to the show's judges during an open audition in Miami. Printed on its inside-cover page are the words "I so want to be 'IN,' " a reference to the signature catchphrase of Heidi Klum, the show's host. "In fashion, one day you are in, and the next day you are out."

title: Berlin Journal; Germans Told to Cheer Up. 'Why Should We?' Some Say.
description: BERLIN, Dec. 5 - First there are trees silhouetted against a pastoral horizon; then a distinguished-looking elderly lady appears on screen looking you right in the eye as she says, "You are Germany's miracle."

title: Tories Elect Young Moderate as New Opposition Leader
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 - In a triumph of svelte youth over rugged experience, Britain's opposition Conservatives chose David Cameron today as their new leader and likely candidate for prime minister in the next elections.

title: Tesco Leaving Lowe For New Agency
description: Tesco, the food retailer in Britain, dealt a blow yesterday to Lowe Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, by deciding to leave the Lowe London office after 17 years. Tesco spends an estimated $75 million to $80 million a year on advertising.

title: Youth takes a bow in British vote
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Groundbreaking For Museum Expansion
description: City leaders broke ground yesterday for an expansion of El Museo del Barrio on Fifth Avenue. Planned changes to the museum, which occupies the city-owned Heckscher Building at 104th Street, include a new glass facade, a redesigned courtyard, upgraded elevators and an expanded museum shop. The city will give $12.7 million toward the $13.6 million project, officials said. The work is scheduled for completion in spring 2007.

title: New Questions on a Breakthrough in Human Stem Cell Research
description: New questions have arisen over a human stem cell experiment that was hailed as a tremendous advance when it was announced in May.

title: Exhaling or Sighing at End of Six-Day Quest for PGA Tour
description: WINTER GARDEN, Fla., Dec. 5 - If quiet is treasured at a regular PGA Tour event, it is the law at the qualifying tournament. Birdies tumble into the cup to the sound of the wind. Double bogeys drown in lakes to silence. Parents cover their mouths with their fingers.

title: Divisions Over Money Await Congress in Year-End Push
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 - The House reconvenes on Tuesday for a critical year-end legislative push, with lawmakers trying to wrap up a series of contentious budget, tax and spending measures against a backdrop of ethics inquiries and differences over Iraq policy.

title: Profiles in Pusillanimity
description: Q. When is a self-proclaimed moderate Republican lawmaker just another malleable vote?

title: Former Brooklyn Party Leader in Rematch With Prosecutor
description: Clarence Norman Jr., the former Brooklyn Democratic leader and assemblyman, took the stand in his corruption trial yesterday as its focus narrowed to this question: What was Mr. Norman thinking when he deposited a check written to his re-election campaign committee into his personal bank account?

title: Bombers Kill at Least 36 at Baghdad Police Academy
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 6 - Powerful explosions from a pair of suicide bombs ripped through the capital's main police academy today, killing at least 36 police officers and injuring 72 others, including an American contractor, according to an Interior Ministry official and the American military.

WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE: THE WEDDING SEASON -- The Fab Five kick off a block of new episodes with the sad story of Joe Uva, whose girlfriend of 10 years broke up with him when he bought a motorcycle instead of an engagement ring. Mr. Uva doesn't exactly need a makeover, just a little sprucing up while Jai Rodriguez, Kayan Douglas, Thom Filicia, Carson Kressley (above left, with Mr. Uva) and Ted Allen set up an elaborate marriage proposal. As usual, everything is fabulous.

title: Payment Concern to Acquire Rival
description: Pay by Touch said yesterday that it expected to announce today the acquisition of its chief rival, BioPay, for $82 million in cash and stock. The move ends a yearlong legal dispute in the nascent payment-by-fingerprint industry.

title: The Next Iraq Offensive
description: Doha, Qatar - WHILE the Bush administration and its critics escalated the debate last week over how long our troops should stay in Iraq, I was able to see the issue through the eyes of America's friends in the Persian Gulf region. The Arab states agree on one thing: Iran is emerging as the big winner of the American invasion, and both President Bush's new strategy and the Democratic responses to it dangerously miss the point. It's a devastating critique. And, unfortunately, it is correct.

title: Blasts Kill 7 Sri Lankan Soldiers, Threatening Cease-Fire
description: JAFFNA, Sri Lanka, Dec. 6 - In the second precision attack on the Sri Lankan Army in three days, two explosive devices, strapped to trees along the side of a road, struck a military tractor today, killing seven soldiers, injuring an eighth and sharply raising the alarm over the prospect of renewed conflict in this country.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Ruling on Lumber
description: The Canadian government said it would seek authorization to start trade retaliation against the United States after a panel of the World Trade Organization ruled in its favor in the long-running softwood lumber dispute. The W.T.O. said that its dispute-settlement body found that the method used by the United States to calculate countervailing duties against Canadian lumber was inconsistent with international trade rules. The ruling follows another by the W.T.O. in August concluding that the United States had not demonstrated that Canada subsidizes its lumber producers. Not all W.T.O. decisions have gone in Canada's favor, however. Another panel concluded last month that the laws used by the United States to impose the duties on Canadian exports meet the trade pact's terms. Ian Austen (NYT)

French Engineer Is Latest Westerner Kidnapped in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 5 - Gunmen abducted a French engineer outside his house in an upscale neighborhood of the capital on Monday, police officials said, the latest in a wave of kidnappings of Westerners in Iraq.

title: Court to Rule on What Constitutes Employer Retaliation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 - For more than 40 years, federal law has prohibited employers from retaliating against employees who complain about discrimination on the job. But neither Congress, which included the anti-retaliation protection in the Civil Rights Act of 1964, nor the Supreme Court has ever defined "retaliation."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALAM, SAMUEL ROBERT
description: MALAM--Samuel Robert, 87. Formerly of White Plains, NY, died in Worcester, MA on November 27, 2005. Husband of his late wife, Jeannette for sixty-one years, loving father and grandfather, accomplished architect, builder, and artist, he was a beacon of intelligence, integrity and humility. He will be sorely missed.

title: Productivity rises in U.S.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIESS, ANNELIESE, PHD.
description: RIESS--Anneliese, PHD. On December 1, 2005. Dr. Riess was indeed a remarkable woman. After leaving her native Germany, because of rising anti-semitism in the 1930's she continued her studies in Anthropology in Italy and earned her PHD. After coming to the United States and working as a baby nurse she became interested in Child Development and Psychology. She studied for her second PHD at NYU. She was adjunct professor at the Graduate Department of Psychology at CCNY for many years and was in private practice. She enriched the lives of many of her students, friends and patients with her warmth and wisdom. Her autobiography was published in Germany in 2000 on the occasion of her 90th birthday. She will be sorely missed by her immediate and extended family and by her many friends. Barbara and Dan Sugarman

title: Arts, Briefly; Low Papal Audience
description: ABC's combination of do-gooders, housewives and doctors once again put the network in first place on Sunday night. Its lineup, particularly "Desperate Housewives" (25.4 million) and "Grey's Anatomy" (20.75 million), dominated the Sunday primetime landscape in total viewers. Among adults 18 to 49, its margin of victory was even greater: ABC's overall rating in that age group more than doubled second-place CBS's. That network had a football spillover into prime time on the East Coast, helping "60 Minutes" draw the most viewers from 7:30 to 8:30 p.m. But the first part of CBS's "Pope John Paul II" movie did not fare as well. The pope tale (shown too late to obtain an exact tally of viewers) was beaten not only by ABC but also by NBC's "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" (11.81 million) and "Crossing Jordan" (12.44 million). NBC did not do as well with the post-sweeps return of "The West Wing" at 8 p.m., which brought in an audience of a mere 7.22 million. KATE AURTHUR

Paid Notice: Deaths   GRILL, MAX
description: GRILL--Max. Yeshiva University and Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) mourn the passing at 105 years of our humble giant in good deeds. A Benefactor with his late wife Marion, he named the Max and Marion Grill Deanship at RIETS, and a host of scholarships at the university's undergraduate and graduate schools, and at the Yeshiva University High Schools to ensure future generations of knowledgeable and committed Jewish leaders for our community and nation. A CPA of renown for his integrity, he was admired and revered by all who knew him. His kindness, compassion, and gentle manner, as well as his sharp wit and humor enriched the lives of all his family and friends. May his many beloved nieces, nephews and kinsmen as well as his devoted executors, Dr. Jay Barnett and Robert Metzger, find solace among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. His memory will live on forever within our institution. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees $(6$)GRILL--Max. The Board of Camp Sussex records with sorrow the passing of of longtime friend and Honorary Life President. He shall be sorely missed. Richard G. Schwartz, Pres. Robert Silver, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAAS, PETER E.
description: HAAS--Peter E. The Board of Trustees, staff, docents, and volunteers of the Skirball Cultural Center, Los Angeles, express our sorrow upon the passing of a founding and pioneering member of the Board of Trustees, Peter E. Haas of San Francisco. Peter was an early champion of the vision of the Skirball Cultural Center meant to explore the connections between four thousand years of Jewish heritage and the vitality of American democratic ideals. Through his active participation, he deepened his own understanding of the bridge between his Jewish heritage and that of the democratic America he loved so very much. During the past decade as a member of the Board, Peter helped refine the Skirball Cultural Center's mission and guided the Center's growth as a cultural and educational institution into the largest of its kind in the world. His commitment to the institution paralleled his dedication as a businessman, civic leader, and philanthropist to help create a more civil society for all. As a driving force in the growth of Levi Strauss & Co., his unprecedented devotion to corporate responsibility made him a role model for business leaders worldwide. His generosity to the community as a supporter of social causes helped improve the lives of millions of workers, children, and the poor. His integrity, humility, and humanity will inspire us and all future generations who visit the Skirball Cultural Center. We mourn his loss with his family and friends throughout this land and beyond. Peter's memory will always remain a blessing and source of strength to those who follow in his footsteps. Howard I. Friedman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Skirball Cultural Center Uri D. Herscher, Founding President and CEO Skirball Cultural Center

title: No Respect (and Soon, a Crew of One)
description: It is the only major subway line in New York that does not enter Manhattan. Its route is short: 16 stations at peak hours. Its trains, 4 cars instead of the usual 8 or 10, seem oddly truncated. Even the color of its route symbol, a sickly lime green, suggests unease.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Family Tries to Recover From a Destructive Flood
description: The water came through the woods, Charles Hildebrandt remembers, surging like a river toward his family's home of 15 years. Just eight minutes after the police arrived to tell the Hildebrandts to evacuate, his son, Scott, 24, stood waist-deep in water in his first-floor bedroom. That floor and the attached garage would be heavily damaged along with cars, furniture, electronic equipment and everything else inside.

title: At Hussein Trial, Witness Tells of Torture
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 6 - At the end of two long days of listening to witnesses accuse him of torture and assasinations, Saddam Hussein blew up at the judge today and shouted that he would not come back to "an unjust court" when it reconvenes on Wednesday.

title: A Family's Moves, Centuries Old
description: There were two audiences in attendance at a recital by Aniruddha Knight on Friday night at the Asia Society. One had seen performances by his grandmother, Balasaraswati, one of the great interpreters of South Asian classical dance, and found poignant traces of her distinctive style in Mr. Knight's dancing. The other audience had not seen Balasaraswati, and for them the evening may have been a disappointment.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Post For Ex-Amtrak Chief
description: David L. Gunn, who was president of Amtrak from 2002 until he was fired by the railroad's board last month in a dispute over restructuring the company, was named as an adjunct scholar by the conservative Free Congress Foundation. Free Congress's founder, Paul M. Weyrich, is a former member of Amtrak's board and of the Amtrak Reform Council, a group chartered by Congress that called for introducing more competition in passenger rail service. Mr. Weyrich said in a statement about Mr. Gunn that "his firing, which was engineered by the White House, was a travesty." David Laney, the chairman of the Amtrak board, had no comment on Mr. Gunn's new job. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Blithe Spirits Wrapped Up in Some Unlikely Bodies
description: The lights go down and a scuffling, dragging noise is heard. A bald head comes into view, attached to a body that is attached to another and another, all of them forming a human centipede inching along on their backs down an aisle into the stage space. Seven performers stand and are revealed as bespectacled, older-than-usual dancers, several with the uncertain midriffs of middle age spreading inside their black and white unitards. Baktruppen has arrived, part of the Norway in New York festival at Performance Space 122, where the company performed on Saturday night.

title: Taking a Serene Approach to a Difficult Brahms Work
description: Technique is not about playing large numbers of the right notes in short spaces of time; it is the gift to listeners that allows them to hear with confidence. The average virtuoso approaches Brahms's "Handel Variations" with admirable tenacity. The impression conveyed is of a fiercely difficult opponent being wrestled to the ground. Garrick Ohlsson played the piece at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon with wondrous serenity. Mr. Ohlsson made it a point not to hurry, but at the moments when Brahms turns vicious we knew better than to worry about the outcome.

It is a fine train journey, this, beginning with a snaking through the rich farm land of East Lothian, which is dark earth, ploughed for the winter crop. Across the other side of the Forth of Forth there is Fife and St. Andrews, the hills blue in the clear northern light that we get in the East of Scotland. There is such cold beauty here.

title: Arts, Briefly; Big Win Loses Viewers
description: With the November ratings sweeps over, and the holidays approaching, Monday featured repeats galore in prime time. But ABC's "Monday Night Football" was new, so the Seattle Seahawks' 42-0 destruction of the Philadelphia Eagles won the night for ABC in Nielsen's estimates. Because the game was so uneven, viewers lost interest as it went on, and CBS's lineup of repeats placed a strong second. At 10 p.m., a rerun of "CSI: Miami" drew 15.02 million viewers. NBC sandwiched a new episode of "Las Vegas" (12.59 million) at 9 p.m. between a repeat of that series and one of "Medium." NBC ranked No. 3 over all for the night. On Fox, the shelved critical favorite "Arrested Development" made its temporary return to the schedule and delivered an audience of 4.28 million. The similarly doomed "Kitchen Confidential" followed and did even worse, with 3.38 million viewers.
