Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, GEORGE F. III
description: BAKER--George F. III, 66. Of Houston, TX, formerly of New York City, on December 1, 2005. Eldest son of George F. Baker, Jr. and Frances Drexel Munn Baker. Beloved husband of Sarah. Devoted father of George and his wife Anne, and Joanna. Stepfather of John Roady and his wife Shawn and David Roady. Brother of Anthony Baker, Pauline Baker Pitt, Kane Baker and Lavinia Baker. A graduate of St. Paul's School, Harvard College and Harvard Business School. He began his career at Lehman Brothers, co-founded First Security Company and later Cambridge Capital and Baker Nye. He was an avid yachtsman and pilot. He served on numerous charitable boards, including New York-Presbyterian Hospital, St. Paul's School, the Wildlife Conservation Society and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, December 13, at 11AM, at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made in his memory to The New York-Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORNIK, SAUL G.
description: HORNIK--Saul G. Of Jericho, New York and Marlboro, NJ. Beloved Husband of Debbie Weinberger. Devoted father of Melissa Wight, Jonathan, Amit and the late Adam Hornik. Brother of Janice Weber Unger. Loving and Adoring grandfather of four. Services will be held 11:30 A.M., Thursday at Marlboro Jewish Center, Congregation Ohev Shalom, 103 School Road West, Marlboro, NJ.

title: Red Cross Volunteer Is Arrested in Theft of Debit Cards for Aid
description: A Red Cross volunteer in Texas and his sister were arrested on Tuesday on charges of stealing more than 100 debit cards from the charity to obtain goods fraudulently, a plot that may have cost the Red Cross more than $230,000 donated for Hurricane Katrina victims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STOLLMACK, BURTON
description: STOLLMACK--Burton. Age 82, on December 4, 2005. Beloved husband for nearly 50 years of the late Estelle. Dear father of Susan Stollmack and Kathy Stollmack Sieck. Father-in-law of John Sieck. Loving grandfather of Eric and Barbara. Brother of the late Ralph Stollmack.

title: Judges in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Crawford Becomes a Hometown Hero for the Knicks
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 6 - Jamal Crawford was at home, and with that scheduling happenstance came a privilege accorded to all of Coach Larry Brown's players. Crawford, the former starter and reluctant reserve, had the option to start in front of family and friends.

title: Door Locks Examined in Harlem Fire Inquiry
description: A cramped Harlem apartment where a 7-year-old girl died in a fire on Monday night had heavy locks on bedroom doors that may have been in violation of city law, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Amid Party Struggles, House Republicans Say They Won't Move to Fill DeLay Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - Senior House Republicans said Tuesday that they saw no need to rush party leadership elections to replace Representative Tom DeLay while he contests criminal charges in Texas.

title: China grows as study hotspot for U.S. students
Putting a Bit o' Bounce Into the Dark Comedy
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 - With its unpalatable cast of opportunists, moralists and politicians who publicly punish the vices they privately pursue, "Measure for Measure" often seems to be a comedy in name only, classified as such only for purposes of Shakespearean taxonomy.

title: Not a Bloomberg Voter, We Suppose
description: The after party for Tuesday night's premiere of "Memoirs of a Geisha" was at the Central Park Boathouse, which had been transformed entirely: paper screens, sushi platters, sake bars, yakitori buffets.

title: Glasgow greets UEFA's next round - and hails its coach farewell?
Members back deal by NYSE
INSIDE
description: Mel Gibson Developing Mini-Series on Holocaust Mel Gibson, whose "Passion of the Christ" was assailed by some critics as an anti-Semitic Passion play -- and whose father has been on record as a Holocaust denier -- has a new project under way: a nonfiction mini-series for television about the Holocaust.

title: Of Christmas and Commerce
description: To the Editor:

title: Survival as a Woody Allen in the Region of William Faulkner
description: The tradition of the Southern taleteller is so well established that you merely have to invoke it to embody it. That, at least, is the premise of "Walking in Memphis: The Life of a Southern Jew," an autobiographical monologue that's not sure whether it wants to be a stand-up comedy act or a Frank McCourt-style memoir and, though eminently endearing, manages to be neither.

title: For Red Sox, Ramirez Problem Won't Go Away
description: DALLAS, Dec. 6 - The specter of Manny Ramirez hangs over these winter meetings, just as it did five years ago, the last time the meetings were held here. Then, Ramirez signed an eight-year, $160 million contract with the Boston Red Sox. Now, the Red Sox are trying to trade him, but with the Mets an increasingly unlikely partner, they are not optimistic they can.

title: Torturing the Facts
description: Our secretary of state's tortuous defense of supposedly nonexistent C.I.A. torture chambers in Eastern Europe was an acid flashback to Clintonian parsing.

title: Adding a Dose of Desperation to Old-Fashioned Disco
description: Alison Goldfrapp, who leads Goldfrapp, makes it easy to mistake her for a lightweight electropop act. Goldfrapp's current album, "Supernature" (Mute) -- a hit in Europe, though not due for an American release until March -- is full of synthesizer hooks and come-hither lyrics. At the Nokia Theater on Monday night, in Goldfrapp's only United States performance this year, disco lights flashed as Ms. Goldfrapp sang lines like "I need la la la la la la/ I need ooh la la la la" or "You're my No. 1/ I'm like a dog to get you."

title: Not Guilty Verdicts in Florida Terror Trial Are Setback for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - In a major defeat for law enforcement officials, a jury in Florida failed to return guilty verdicts Tuesday on any of 51 criminal counts against a former Florida professor and three co-defendants accused of operating a North American front for Palestinian terrorists.

title: Eritrea expels UN peacekeeping forces
Paid Notice: Memorials   OSCARD, FIFI
description: OSCARD--Fifi. A memorial service will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club on Friday December 9th at 4:00 pm, 122 E 66th Street, New York, NY 10021.(212) 734-5950

title: Equity Firm Planning to Acquire German Cable Operator
description: Providence Equity Partners plans to acquire two-thirds of Germany's largest cable operator, Kabel Deutschland GmbH, valued at 3.2 billion euros, from Apax Partners and Goldman Sachs, according to an executive briefed on the matter.

title: New Allegations Against Police Officers Charged in Sexual Attacks
description: Two veteran New York City police officers, already charged with sexually attacking one woman while on duty in Brooklyn, are now facing charges that they assaulted two more women after responding to a complaint about noise at their home, the authorities said today.

title: A College That Specializes in Dropouts Is Under Siege
description: Desiree Rosa dropped out of high school, following in the path of five of her six brothers and sisters. Now 21, she is looking for a career and is back at school, in her second year at Interboro Institute.

title: Gadgets of the week: Nostalgia calling
Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMS, MELVIN THURSTON
description: WILLIAMS--Melvin Thurston 1935-2005 died peacefully at home, surrounded by his wife and three children, on Friday, December 2 after an eightmonth battle with lung cancer. Born on March 20, 1935, Mel was the son of the late Allton Thomas and Dorothea Danver Williams of Darien, Connecticut. Two brothers predeceased him, but he is survived by his sister, Lois Williams Adams of Milford, Connecticut. A graduate of Tufts University (1957), Mel began a 34 year career at the Reader's Digest Association in Plesantville, New York. He was involved in domestic and international production and retired, at the age of fifty-seven , as Vice President of Operations in 1992. Mel served on local boards and received many awards during his tenure in publishing. His love of family, sailing, travel, music, photography, his country and his passion for the value of each day will be forever remembered by all who knew him. Mel is survived by his loving wife (and childhood sweetheart) of forty-seven years, Marty, and their three children, Christopher Wilson of Nairobi, Kenya; Stephen Thurston of Delmar, New York; and Amy Williams of Ossining, New York. He is also survived by three grandchildren: Myles, Savannah and Sophia. A Celebration of Life Service will be held on Friday, December 16, at 3:00 PM at the Presbyterian Church of Mt. Kisco, New York. In lieu of flowers, kindly make donations to: Hospice Care in Westchester and Putnam, in Memory of Mel Williams, at 100 South Bedford Road, Mt Kisco, New York 10549 or Mel Williams Memorial Fund/Thoracic Oncology Service, MSKCC (Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center), P.O. Box 27106, New York, New York 10087.

title: Most Mexican Immigrants in New Study Gave Up Jobs to Take Their Chances in U.S.
description: A report about the work lives of recent Mexican immigrants in seven cities across the United States suggests that they typically traded jobs in Mexico for the prospect of work here, despite serious bouts of unemployment, job instability and poor wages.

title: For Sears Shareholders, Silence Stirs Anxiety
description: FOR Edward S. Lampert, the hedge fund manager who is leading Sears, silence has not been golden, at least over the last few months.

title: It's Traditional. It's Religious. It's Poison.
description: When Venice Levy had a problem with roaches, she looked for the strongest insecticide she could find. A friend told her about a mystery powder called Tempo.

title: 'Goodnight Moon,' Without the Sharp Edges
description: To the Editor:

title: Leave the Vacuuming (and Other Domestic Bliss) to Us
description: THE high-technology kitchen of the future, ballyhooed a decade ago, has yet to arrive. But if the kitchen has not gotten "smart," many gadgets used around the house are becoming smarter, from irons that go cold if they accidentally fall to vacuum cleaners that remember when to clean up the living room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, MARVIN
description: ROSENTHAL--Marvin. We mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Marvin Rosenthal. Our condolences to his wife Elaine and their family. Marvin was part of the bedrock of the New York real estate community. He was a pleasure to work with and a gentleman. We will miss him. Stephen B. Siegel Michael R. Laginestra Scott L. Gottlieb

title: Words on Wine, From Opposing Shores
description: FOR two entirely different perspectives on wine, you can do no better than Robert M. Parker Jr. and Hugh Johnson. They are American and British, Venus and Mars, Vidal and Mailer, with each representing for the other much of what's irritating, if not dangerous, in the world of wine. What, then, could be more delicious than for both men to have written new books?

title: Chilean's plays: Grim, absurd, now funny
Of Christmas and Commerce
description: To the Editor:

title: Lines Are Drawn for BigSuit Over Sodas
description: It is lunchtime at Grover Cleveland High School in Portland, Ore. A steady stream of thirsty teenagers poke dollars into the three Coca-Cola machines in the hallway. By the end of lunch period, the Coke With Lime, Cherry Coke and Vanilla Coke are sold out.

title: Don't Marginalize The United Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 killed during voting in Egypt
Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the postponement of a hearing for Lionel Tate, a Florida teenager on probation in the 2001 stomping death of a young girl, incorrectly described an examination ordered by the judge. Mr. Tate is to undergo a mental competency examination by a psychologist, not a psychiatric exam.

title: Richardson's Brother Is Killed in Robbery
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 6 - Quentin Richardson has left the Knicks indefinitely to be with his family after the fatal shooting of his brother in Chicago.

title: How a Black Entertainer's Shuffle Actually Blazed a Trail
description: Stepin Fetchit The Life and Times of Lincoln Perry By Mel Watkins Illustrated. 338 pages. Pantheon Books. $26.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALINA, AMY
description: KALINA--Amy. On December 3, at age 53. Survived by her husband Steven, son Daniel, brothers Richard and Jon, sisters-in-law Valerie, Leslie, and Marjie, brother-inlaw Greg, niece Nathalie and nephew Benjamin. She was loved by all who knew her. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 8, from 1-3 pm, in the Parish Hall at St. Mark's Church. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be sent to The Amy Rose Kalina Memorial Fund at St. Mark's Church: St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery, 131 E. 10th St., NY, NY 10003.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Body Identified As Missing Defendant
description: A body found last week in the trunk of a car parked at a New Jersey diner has been identified as a Genovese crime family figure who disappeared during his federal criminal trial, several officials said yesterday. The man, Lawrence Ricci, 60, was shot twice in the back of the head and once in the back, the officials said. Mr. Ricci, who disappeared on Oct. 7 during his trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, was identified through dental records on Friday, one official said. The car had been in the parking lot of the Huck Finn Diner on Morris Avenue in Union, N.J., for at least six weeks, investigators said. "I think they're going through their mourning all over again," Mr. Ricci's lawyer, Martin L. Schmukler, said of the family. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: U.S. responseon detainee inadequate, Berlin says
So Many Acting B.A.'s, So Few Paying Gigs
description: On a rainy Monday evening in a small rehearsal studio in the Flatiron district of Manhattan, Rachel Hoffman, a casting director for theatrical musicals, was holding in her thrall a host of hopeful young performers, all of them college juniors and seniors, acting students at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts.

title: 'Goodnight Moon,' Without the Sharp Edges
description: To the Editor:

title: Finance Chief Is Out at G.M.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 6 - General Motors, which is battling to reverse losses in North America and energize its sagging market share, replaced its chief financial officer on Tuesday with a longtime company executive who has experience in cost-cutting.

title: A bright star in 'Night of the Iguana'
George Baker III, 66, Financier and Pilot, Is Presumed Dead
description: George F. Baker III, the retired financier who has been lost since last Thursday, when the small plane he was flying disappeared off Nantucket, and is now presumed to be dead, was the senior trustee of the George F. Baker Trust, a family philanthropy. Mr. Baker was 66 and lived in Houston, Nantucket and, formerly, Manhattan.

title: The Depths of Despair, as Plumbed by Artists
description: PARIS, Dec. 6 - An art exhibition called "Depression" might not sound too appealing, even if the word does describe the cyclical angst of some artists. So, instead, the new show at the Grand Palais here through Jan. 16 has been given the more ambiguous -- the perhaps more Hamletian -- name "Melancholy."

title: Builder Under Growing Pressure to Cede Part of Trade Center Site
description: State, city and Port Authority officials are increasing pressure on Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who controls the World Trade Center site, to relinquish at least a portion of the 16-acre property so that the rebuilding effort can proceed more quickly.

title: So Refreshingly Spine-Tingling
description: The crucial difference between eating household pets and babies, explains a demon (T. Ryder Smith) in "Apparition," is not the taste. (He seems to assume both are delicious.) It's that human bones are easier to chew. "Crunch, crunch, crunch," he says gleefully, like a foodie from the underworld.

title: White House and McCain Near Deal on Torture
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - The White House has all but abandoned its effort to persuade Senator John McCain to exempt Central Intelligence Agency employees from legislation barring inhumane or degrading treatment of prisoners in American custody. But a top presidential aide continued to negotiate a deal on Tuesday that would offer covert officers some protection from prosecution, administration and Senate officials said.

title: Shortlist of Short Stories
description: Three collections of stories, from a writing heavyweight, a small-press author and an Irish immigrant, have been named finalists for the second annual Story Prize, a $20,000 award for short fiction that will be presented after a reading by the authors at the New School in Manhattan on Jan. 25. The finalists are Jim Harrison, the acclaimed novelist, poet and essayist, for "The Summer He Didn't Die," three novellas published by Atlantic Monthly Press; Maureen F. McHugh, best known for her science fiction novels, for "Mothers & Other Monsters," 13 stories published by Small Beer Press of Northampton, Mass.; and Patrick O'Keeffe, a lecturer at the University of Michigan who immigrated to the United States from Ireland in the mid-1980's, for "The Hill Road," four stories published by Viking.

title: British Tories Pick Leader to Challenge Blair at Polls
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 - In a triumph of svelte youth over rugged experience, Britain's Conservatives chose David Cameron on Tuesday as their new leader and likely candidate for prime minister in the next elections.

title: Publishers Assess the Fall Season's Winners and Losers
description: When Rodale Books signed Martha Stewart to a $2 million contract in the summer, it was betting that the queen of domesticity was back and as popular as ever, unstained by the stock-trading scandal that sent her to prison for five months.

title: Correction
description: A brief report in Off the Menu last Wednesday, about the opening of Barbounia at 250 Park Avenue South, misstated the given name of one of its owners. She is Danielle Billera, not Daniel.

title: Rice avoids answers on CIA jails as trip starts
New Partnership for Rap Producer
description: The rap producer Irv Gotti, who was acquitted last week of federal charges that he laundered money for a Queens drug kingpin, has been in talks to form a record label partnership with the Warner Music Group, according to executives briefed on his plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VERGER, MARCELLO
description: VERGER--Marcello. On December 4 2005, beloved husband of Cristina. Loving father of Cristiano, Lorenzo, Enrico and Massimiliano. Dear brother of Enrica. Fond grandfather of Mattia, Uncle of Silvia, Michele & Lodovica. Son-in-law of Ndue Gjomarkaj. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th St. and Lexington Avenue, Thursday 10 AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the resignation of Don Forst as editor in chief of The Village Voice misidentified the newspaper that won the Pulitzer Prize for international reporting in 2000, during his tenure. It was The Village Voice, not Newsday.

title: Running a Seattle-Area Mall as a Family Business
description: BELLEVUE, Wash., Nov. 30 - It has been more than a decade, but Kemper Freeman Jr., the owner of the leading enclosed mall in the Pacific Northwest, can still taste his irritation as he recalls a briefing by a top Nordstrom executive to a group of young Wall Street analysts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-27

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEALEY, JOSEPH A.
description: HEALEY--Joseph A., Major General U.S. Army (Ret.). On December 6, 2005 of Rockville Centre, LI. Beloved husband of the late Claire Irene King. Dear father of Andrew, Monica, Maureen (Terry) Cashin, TJ (Marie) and Meaghan. Fond grandfather of Grace, Shane, Michael and Liam. Friend of Patricia Coggins. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Avenue, 2-4 & 7-9 PM Thursday and Friday. Funeral Mass at St. Agnes Cathedral, Quealy Place, Rockville Centre, Saturday 10:30 AM. Interment, Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mercy Medical Center, Cancer Care, 1000 N. Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY 11570.

title: Microsoft to invest US$1.7 billion in India
Supreme Court Weighs Military's Access to Law Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - The military wants access to law schools on the same basis as other potential employers seeking to recruit students, although openly gay law students, of course, need not apply. The law schools insist that only those employers who pledge not to discriminate, against gay men and lesbians or anyone else, are welcome.

title: Eritrea orders Westerners in UN mission out in 10 days
Holiday Season Is a Holding Action at Gap Stores
description: In an unusual advertisement that ran briefly in New York movie theaters, customers and employees suddenly begin to trash a Gap store. One man tackles a mannequin, tearing off its shirt with his teeth, while another slices through a display case with a chain saw. A woman, spotting the pandemonium, drives her minivan through the front doors.

title: Rice, in Ukraine, Criticizes Russia
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Dec. 7 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice criticized Russia today, saying she had serious concerns about a proposed law that could shut down private groups, including some funded by the United States, that promote democracy, human rights and related issues.

title: Shuffleat Barclays unsettles investors
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Charged In Four Killings
description: On Nov. 26, 2004, the bodies of Kyhron Ward, 26; his brother Jarmeil, 24; Carmen Estronza, 34; and Camilo Reyes, 32, were found in an abandoned lot in the South Ward. Now the authorities have charged a man with the killings, the Essex County prosecutor, Paula T. Dow, said yesterday. She would not release the name of the suspect, who is to be arraigned on murder charges this morning, with a news conference scheduled afterward. John Holl (NYT)

title: Windows Ruling in Korea
description: South Korean regulators have found that Microsoft breached antitrust rules, a ruling the company has said may force it to withdraw its Windows operating system from the nation.

title: C.I.A. Leak Prosecutor Weighs New Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 - The prosecutor in the C.I.A. leak case is exploring a range of possible crimes, according to lawyers in the case, suggesting that the investigation has moved well beyond its initial focus on whether anyone in the Bush administration illegally disclosed the identity of an undercover C.I.A. officer, according to lawyers in the case.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ford drops ads in gay media but denies caving to pressure
Arts, Briefly
description: New Law Raises Fears of Undersea Plunder

title: G.O.P. Puts Its Muscle Behind a Younger Kean
description: NEWARK, Dec. 6 - In an early sign of the importance of next year's contest for the United States Senate in New Jersey, national and state Republican leaders signaled their support Tuesday for State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr., the namesake son of one of New Jersey's most popular former governors.

title: Justices Agree Benefits May Be Cut to Cover College Debts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the government may offset Social Security benefits in order to collect old student loan debts.

title: United States Isn't Included in Seedings for World Cup
description: After safely negotiating the road to the World Cup, the United States careered head-on into a significant speed bump yesterday when it was not included among the top eight seeded teams for Friday's draw in Leipzig, Germany.

title: Implant Maker Says Offer By Allergan Beats Rival's Bid
description: Inamed, which makes breast implants, said yesterday that it had determined that a $3.3 billion buyout offer from Allergan was superior to one from Medicis Pharmaceutical, a condition necessary to terminate the Medicis bid.

title: Syria Attacks Evidence as U.N. Case Turns More Bizarre
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 6 - The United Nations investigation into the assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, is beginning to show some cracks: one witness is dead, another is in jail and still another has recanted his testimony with a fantastic story of abduction, drugging and bribery.

title: House Would Put Off Big Tax Increase for a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - Under fire from Democrats for ignoring a looming tax problem for middle-income families, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives approved a bill today that would stave off a big increase in the alternative minimum tax for one year at a cost of $30 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUFER, HARRY
description: LAUFER--Harry. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and member, Harry Laufer. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. Jeffrey J. Siegel, Pres. Solomon S. Greenspan, Secy.

title: Rice and NATO to set rules for Afghan force
Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTMANN, BERNICE (NEE ADELSON)
description: GOTTMANN--Bernice (nee Adelson). On December 3, 2005. Widow of Jean Iona Gottmann, sister of Shirley Adelson Siegel, aunt of Eric D. Siegel and Ann Siegel Fischer, great-aunt of Samuel H.M. Fischer.

title: U.S. calls North Korea a 'criminal regime'
Cannery Row II, Starring the Sardines
description: Monterey, Calif. - IN a plot twist that would have pleased John Steinbeck, sardines have returned to Monterey Bay decades after they supposedly vanished forever. When Steinbeck opened his 1945 novel "Cannery Row" by describing Monterey's waterfront zone of sardine factories as "a poem, a stink, a grating noise, a quality of light, a tone, a habit, a nostalgia, a dream," California's prodigious sardine industry was the largest fishery in the Western Hemisphere. But the end of the Row as he knew it was already in sight. The silver river that for years had poured out of boats and into Monterey's 19 canneries and 20 meal and oil reduction plants was drying up. By the 1950's, it had disappeared altogether, and the Row eventually became one long tourist trap with a terrific aquarium at the end.

title: For Cellphones, More Choices in Fashion and Features
description: YOU can do more on the go than ever before, but that also means the choices keep getting more complicated, with an increasing number of fashions, features and services.

title: An Elegant Stroll in Orange Clogs
description: EXPECT $240 rack of veal, $220 shoulder of pork and a $200 whole king salmon for four to eight people, to be carved within view of the table, in a flourish of high ceremony from the Old World.

title: What They Thought of Next: Clever Little Gifts for Less
description: IF the holidays have the gadget mavens in your circle shopping for $4,000 plasma televisions, $1,500 laptop computers or $350 cellphones, it may be a relief to know that there are less costly technology presents to be found as well. From literary works stored on flash drives to U.S.B.-powered cup warmers, here is a selection of interesting, clever and -- best of all -- inexpensive objects.

title: Israeli Airstrike Kills Palestinian Militant in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 7 - An Israeli airstrike killed a Palestinian militant in the southern Gaza Strip today and wounded at least nine other Palestinians as Israel stepped up its military actions in the wake of a suicide bombing.

title: Battle of Pennsylvania Goes to the Wildcats
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Dec. 6 - Later this season, Bucknell and Villanova will play for their respective conference championships and, most likely, in the N.C.A.A. tournament. They are that ambitious and they may be that good.

title: Invisible New Yorkers
description: Melissa Ann Odom, 42, goes by the name Mao.At left is a photograph of Mao, and at right is a sketch of Maoby the photographer. Mao is a hermaphrodite who livesin El Barrio. Mao was raised as a girlbut is searching for the answer to one question:Is Mao male, female or both?Mao has relied on poetry and faith in God to help find an answer. A reading of Mao's poetry is online at nytimes.com/nyregion. LENS

title: China warns of Harbin penalties
M.T.A. Scales Back Midtown Ventilation Project
description: Bowing to opposition from St. Patrick's Cathedral and real estate interests, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has backed away from a plan to build a 16-story ventilation tower in Midtown as part of its $6.3 billion project to connect the Long Island Rail Road with Grand Central Terminal.

title: The Children of a Fruitful Restaurant Marriage
description: Mario Batali and Joseph Bastianich own or have invested in a number of restaurants. Here is a list of restaurants they own jointly.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   JOHNSON, LISA M.
description: JOHNSON--Lisa M. Dec. 7, 1990. Dear Mom, I will always treasure your memory. Hope Dad is with you. Your son, Robbie

title: Manager Goes Long and Keeps Going
description: The minor league manager trotted from his folding chair beside the dugout to the mound to talk to a pitcher who was young enough to be his grandson, and who was having problems getting the ball over the plate.

title: Risk of Renewed Conflict After 7 Sri Lankan Soldiers Are Killed
description: JAFFNA, Sri Lanka, Dec. 6 - In a second precision attack on the Sri Lankan Army in three days, two explosive devices, strapped to trees along the side of a road, struck a military tractor on Tuesday morning, killing seven soldiers, wounding an eighth and sharply raising the alarm over the prospect of renewed conflict in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKER, BERTHA
description: BECKER--Bertha. Passed away in Boynton Beach, FL. at the age of 92 in the company of her devoted family. Our world has changed forever. We miss and love you so much. Your strength will be carried on through all of us. Your grandchildren and great-grand children Kerri, Craig, Glenn, Allison, Darren, Ari, Courtnie, Griffin and Gaige. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Bethesda Unit 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407, in memory of Bertha Becker.

title: A Nobelist's cri de coeur
Alternative Rx For Xbox Fever
description: THE great thing about shopping for video games is that the person you're buying the gift for almost certainly knows more about it than you do. If you have gamers in your life, no matter what age, odds are that they already know exactly what they want. You need only shut up and fork over the credit card.

title: A Showpiece for Percussion, With More Than a Bit of Dash
description: Christoph Eschenbachis in his third season as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, and grumblings from the musicians about his work have circulated among insiders and made it in to press reports. He is a richly experienced and comprehensive musician. Still, players are said to find him overly assertive and prone to hypercharged performances.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 24 about efforts by Kane County, Utah, to claim roads under federal control at the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument and encourage the use of recreational vehicles there referred incorrectly to Kristin Brendel of the Wilderness Society, who said the vehicles could cause widespread damage. She is not a lawyer.

title: A Shop to Serve Harlem's New Real Estate
description: Emperor's Roe, a new boutique in Harlem, is stocked with caviar, smoked fish, foie gras, cheeses, pts, tinned delicacies like escargots, olive oils and various condiments. "With million-dollar condominiums, the neighborhood is begging for luxury products," said its owner, David Mills, left, who had been the manager of Caviarteria.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Nov. 14, about "Elia Kazan," a biography by Richard Schickel, misspelled the surname of Kazan's first wife, following the misspelling in the book. (A review in the Book Review on Nov. 27 repeated the error.) She was Molly Day Thacher, not Thatcher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALAMENT, EDWARD
description: MALAMENT--Edward. Died December 4, 2005 of Alzheimer's disease age 88. Husband of the late Ida (Lupion). Survived by beloved children Linda and David Greenbaum and granddaughters Rebecca and Amanda. Also survived by his devoted companion Sonia Matz & her family. For the last 4 years he was lovingly cared for by Falcon Ramos.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: U.S. Reduces Lumber Duties
description: The Commerce Department substantially reduced duties on softwood lumber imports from Canada yesterday, with the average duty falling to 10.8 percent from 21 percent. The Canadian government, however, continued to argue that decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement as well as a review by the World Trade Organization require the United States to eliminate the duties entirely. "This is a positive step, but we will keep pressing for the full respect of Nafta," the international trade minister for Canada, Jim Peterson, above, said in a statement. "We want to see the duties dropped entirely." The Commerce Department said Canadian provinces continued to subsidize lumber producers by charging too little for tree-cutting on government land, the source of most Canadian logs. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pataki Seeks DNA From More Criminals
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that he was bypassing the State Legislature and issuing an executive order to the state to begin collecting DNA samples from some convicted criminals who are not currently required by law to provide them. A small state board with regulatory power over the DNA database debated the order for several hours without approving it. More debate is scheduled, and aides to the governor said they were confident the order would be approved. State law requires people convicted of violent felonies, sex crimes and several other types of crimes to provide the state with DNA samples. For years, Mr. Pataki has pushed the Legislature to require all convicted criminals to provide their DNA, but the Democratic-led State Assembly has blocked him. The executive order was reported by The Daily News yesterday. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Productivity Rises, Wages Fall and Inflation Seems in Retreat
description: Productivity rose at its fastest pace in two years in the third quarter, far more quickly than was earlier estimated, as output rose and labor costs fell, the government reported yesterday. The report eased some economists' fears of rising inflation.

title: Saddam Hussein's trial recessed until Dec. 21

description: As most experienced cooks know, you can't brown food unless you preheat your skillet, and I frequently transfer food from stove top to oven.

title: Secretary Rice's Rendition
description: It was a sad enough measure of how badly the Bush administration has damaged its moral standing that the secretary of state had to deny that the president condones torture before she could visit some of the most reliable American allies in Europe. It was even worse that she had a hard time sounding credible when she did it.

title: Tech-Inspired, but Toys Just the Same
description: IF this month's pressing question for parents is what to get the children for Christmas, it may come with the caveat "just don't tell us to buy a Game Boy or an iPod."

title: Now at a Store Near You: Pixels Aplenty and Cheaper, Too
description: CONSUMER digital cameras have come a long way since the mid-1990's, when the Casio QV-10 (with its revolutionary liquid-crystal-display screen on the outside and 250,000-pixel pictures on the inside) hit the shelves for slightly less than $1,000. Today, both picture quality and prices have gotten much better for holiday shoppers. Not only are three-megapixel cameras available for less than $100, but digital camcorders can also record right to DVD; tiny storage drives give you a reliable place to stash gigabytes of photos; and all sorts of other gadgets can be found for the person on your gift list who is obsessed with photographs or videos.

title: Federal Advisory Group Calls for Change in Food Marketing to Children
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - A federal advisory group said Tuesday that there was compelling evidence linking food advertising on television and the increase in childhood obesity.

title: Pushing the Envelope
description: Gov. George Pataki wants New York to get tougher on sex offenders. Frustrated for years by the State Assembly's refusal to pass a bill to lock up violent sex offenders in mental hospitals when their prison terms end, he recently told aides to "push the envelope" and try to accomplish the same end through an existing law that was intended for the dangerously mentally ill. A judge predictably rejected that effort as an abuse of the mental-health system, and Mr. Pataki has appealed.

title: Mel Gibson Developing Holocaust Mini-Series
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 - Mel Gibson, whose "Passion of the Christ" was criticized by some as anti-Semitic -- and whose father has said that the Holocaust did not happen -- is developing a nonfiction mini-series about the Holocaust.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - President Bush offered a wide-ranging defense of his Iraq policy today, acknowledging problems with reconstruction and conceding the inevitability of more bloodshed but declaring that the work and sacrifice are essential for American security.

description: Aleksandr Shteyn made two bold moves as an adult. Each, he says, touched off a plunge into misery.

description: NBC Universal said yesterday that it would start to sell downloadable versions of 11 of its current and older television shows through the iTunes Music Store of Apple Computer.

description: RECREATION and sports used to be ways to escape everyday life and all its accouterments. But electronics have steadily crept out of the home and office and into the great outdoors.

title: Business Week streamlines overseas
The State of New Orleans
description: HOW will we know when New Orleans is rebuilt? Will it be when all the jobs and public services are back in place? Will it have to do with the amount of money spent? Or will it be when the number of displaced families receiving federal housing aid dwindles from 600,000 to just a few?

title: Gesture From Venezuela Heats the Bronx
description: About all that Belkis Bejaran had ever heard about the firebrand leader of faraway Venezuela was that he had often hurled verbal insults at President Bush. Then this week, with a sort of bemused gratitude, she heard that Hugo Chvez, the president of Venezuela, which sits on the Western Hemisphere's largest oil supply, would provide discounted heating fuel to her landlord. In turn, the landlord will pass on the savings, reducing her monthly rent this winter by more than $100.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Monitors Say Distrust Fed Low Turnout
description: Two days after allies of President Hugo Chvez swept all 167 seats in congressional elections, monitors from the European Union and the Organization of American States said the elections were fair but marked by a deep distrust that led to voter turnout of just 25 percent. The five main opposition parties boycotted the election on Sunday.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Jailed Opponent To Challege President
description: The government ruled that the opposition leader Kizza Besigye can challenge President Yoweri Museveni in the election for president next year even though he is being held in prison on charges of treason, terrorism and rape. Mr. Besigye's supporters in the Forum for Democratic Change accuse the government of arresting him on trumped-up charges to damage his election bid. The prosecution, however, says the charges are solid. The ruling by the attorney general's office allows Mr. Besigye to file his nomination papers from the Luzira maximum-security prison, enabling him to beat the Dec. 15 deadline to get his name on the ballot. The election is scheduled for February or March.

title: Group Opposed to Nominee Rallies Its Hollywood People
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - With a battle over the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. just around the corner, a little slice of Hollywood arrived in the capital Tuesday night to raise money for People for the American Way, the liberal advocacy group leading the charge against the judge's confirmation.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press last Wednesday about Jocelyn Brando, an actress and the sister of Marlon Brando, misstated the origin of the surname she used in private life, Pennebaker. It was her mother's maiden name, not her married name. (Her first husband was Don Hanmer and her second husband was Eliot Asinof.)

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 30 - With their digital population starving, North Korea's civilian leaders cut military spending, triggering a military coup by a "General Jung." The renegade general then threatens the South with conventional and nuclear weapons.

title: Arts, Briefly; A New Family Theater
description: The Kennedy Center in Washington will open its new family theater on Friday with the premiere of "Alice," a commissioned adaptation by the playwright Kim Hines of the children's book written by Whoopi Goldberg, below. The 14,000-square-foot, 320-seat theater, which took 11 months and $9 million to build, is the first effort in a broader commitment by the Kennedy Center to invest $125 million in performing-arts education over the next five years. In the 2005-6 season, the theater will play host to four world premieres, including "Citizen 13559: The Journal of Ben Uchida," about a Japanese boy whose family is sent to an internment camp during World War II, and "Walking the Winds: Arabian Tales," a musical collaboration with the Performing Arts Center of Amman, Jordan, featuring American and Jordanian artists. "Alice" runs until Jan. 2. LYNETTE CLEMETSON

title: F.D.A. Official Becomes 3rd to Quit Agency Since Summer
description: A Food and Drug Administration official whose office was involved in a recent controversial application for drug approval said yesterday that he was resigning to join private industry.

title: Looking for a Nod by Winking at Italy
description: VENETIAN glass dangles from the ceiling, Campari spikes one of its signature cocktails, and polenta and prosciutto come out to play. But at the gorgeous and perplexing new restaurant Jovia, Italy seems less a calling than a calculation, less a matter of inspiration than a case of opportunism.

description: Correction Appended

title: Movies With a Message and Their Money Trail
description: Film production companies don't usually have missions beyond the obvious one of making money. But two relatively new companies -- Participant Productions, whose recent movies include "Syriana" and "North Country," and Walden Media, a producer of "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" -- have overt social purposes and activist campaigns attached to their movies. The old Watergate-era dictum "Follow the money" has suddenly become relevant to moviegoers.

description: SOUTH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARONEY, MARY F.
description: MARONEY--Mary F. Of Glen Cove, NY, died peacefully at her home in the morning of December 2, 2005, at the age of 97. Her late husband Vincent predeceased her 56 years ago. She leaves four children William (Aimee), Janet (Leonard) Connolly, Vincent (Alice) and Frances (the late John) Magenheimer; ten grandchildren, eight great grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Mary grew up in Brooklyn and graduated from Hunter College where she made close and lifelong friends. After the untimely and sudden death of her husband, she earned a Master's degree in education from Long Island University and began to teach in elementary school. She moved her four young children from Brooklyn to Garden City after she accepted a position teaching in the Great Neck School District where she taught for more than 20 years. Throughout her life Mary was devoted to her family, was a thoughtful and progressive person. She loved literature and music, especially opera. She was as well a lover of all animals. After her children were grown, she travelled with family members and friends to Ireland and other countries of Europe; to Alaska and took one trip around the world. In her later years she was well cared for by her loving caregivers, Teresa Gambino, who had been with Mary since 1990 and Geraldine and Tony Pearl. She will be missed. Visiting at the funeral home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, Monday 7-9PM. Mass St. Patrick RC Church, Tuesday, December 13 at 10AM. Interment St. John Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please donate to a charity of your choice.

title: Menendez Will Replace Corzine in Senate
description: TRENTON, Dec. 7 - After months of speculation and aggressive campaigning by several candidates seeking the job, Governor-elect Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey has selected Robert Menendez of Hudson County to replace him in the United States Senate.

description: RUSKIN--Lucy. Beloved sister. Lovingly remembered. Esther and Hy

title: Blue Jays Add Burnett, and Credibility
description: DALLAS, Dec. 6 - The Toronto Blue Jays have watched the American League East standings unfold in similarly annoying fashion for eight straight seasons. The mighty Yankees have finished in first place, the potent Boston Red Sox have been right behind them and the undermanned Blue Jays have lagged behind.

title: Amid Cheers for Clinton, Ire Over War
description: The thousands of Democrats snaking through Chelsea last night, waiting to enter a fund-raiser for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, represented a typical outpouring for the popular party leader. What was new, however, was the appearance of 75 antiwar activists nearby to heckle her on her position on Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCDANIEL, PAUL W.
description: McDANIEL--Paul W. Of Port Chester, NY died December 4, 2005. Born January 31, 1914, in Montgomery, W.VA. Graduated from WVU, served in WWII and Korea as Lt. Commander in the U.S. Navy. He worked for Union Carbide Corporation for over 30 years as a Senior Industrial Hygiene Associate. He is survived by his daughter and son-in-law Marta and Stephen Deely, his granddaughter and husband Katherine and Paul Fehrenbach, his grandson and wife Matthew and Elizabeth Deely and four great-grandsons. Family will receive friends from 4 to 8 P.M., December 7 at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York. Funeral service will be held 10 A.M., Thursday, December 8 at Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: Senator Clinton, in Pander Mode
description: Hillary Clinton is co-sponsoring a bill to criminalize the burning of the American flag. Her supporters would characterize this as an attempt to find a middle way between those who believe that flag-burning is constitutionally protected free speech and those who want to ban it, even if it takes a constitutional amendment. Unfortunately, it looks to us more like a simple attempt to have it both ways.

title: New Optimism About the Japanese Economy After a Bleak Decade
description: TOKYO, Dec. 6 - College graduates face the best job market in a decade, and wages are rising again. The lead stock market index has doubled in value in two years. Corporate profits are the highest in recent memory. And for the first time since 1990, land prices in Tokyo are up.

Besides the fact that you are covering territory that has been written about in countless memoirs and magazine articles -- almost everyone who knew the modernist poet wrote about him -- you're also inviting comparisons to one of the greatest novels of the 20th century, "Humboldt's Gift," Saul Bellow's roman  clef about his friendship and falling out with Schwartz.

title: Discovering Music, Legally
description: For some time, Real Networks' Rhapsody.com online music store has offered a sweet deal: you can listen to 25 songs a month, in their entirety, for free. You don't even have to provide a credit-card number. The company pays the record companies just as though you'd actually bought those songs, in the hopes of enticing you into upgrading to a paid plan.

title: Israel Arrests 15 Palestinians in Response to a Suicide Bombing
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 6 - In response to a suicide bombing on Monday, Israeli security forces arrested 15 suspected Palestinian militants in overnight raids that ended Tuesday. The suspects included the father and a brother of the bomber.

title: Detainee's Lawyer Says Captors Foment Mistrust
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - A lawyer for a Guantnamo Bay detainee facing war crimes charges before a military commission said in a court filing on Tuesday that the military authorities had been ignoring a court order and undermining the prisoner's confidence in his lawyers.

title: Ex-Chief of A.I.G. Seeks Executives' Shares
description: C. V. Starr & Company, a private firm run by Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, has offered to buy out A.I.G. executives who own shares in the company.

title: Frederik Philips Dies at 100; Businessman Saved Dutch Jews
description: NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, Dec. 6 - Frederik Jacques Philips, the former president of the Dutch electronics giant that bears his family's name, who was credited with saving hundreds of Jews during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands in World War II, died on Monday. He was 100.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Postal Service Erases Its Debt
description: The United States Postal Service said it had cleared its debt, once as high as $11 billion, for the first time since the 1970's. The service's chief financial officer, Richard J. Strasser Jr., said the final $1.8 billion of debt was paid this year. The post office said it recorded a $1.4 billion surplus on revenue of nearly $70 billion in the 2005 fiscal year. But the postmaster general, John E. Potter, said the service still intended to raise postal rates next year because of rising costs and a requirement from Congress that it place $3.1 billion a year into an escrow fund. The service, which has sought to block that requirement, has already said that it expects to have a $1.8 billion deficiency in 2006 related to the escrow plan.

title: Amid Squalor, an Aid Army Marches to No Drum at All
description: BLANTYRE, Malawi - Here in Malawi's second city and in the capital, Lilongwe, it is hard to find an office building without some benevolent organization come to help Malawi's throngs of poor.

title: 'Virtual fat' adds hope to losing weight and keeping it off

description: Carl C. Icahn's assault on Time Warner produced its first casualty yesterday -- however unintended it may have been.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALLON, JOHN W.
description: FALLON--John W. In his "Pompila", Robert Browning charged: No work begun shall ever pause for death! His words, however, might impede so profound a tribute for a lesser figure on the horizons of our journey. Not, however, for John Fallon, Board Chairman (Retired) of both Daytop Village, Inc. and Daytop International, Inc. Drawn from the ranks of elite leadership of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, he brought to the table of Daytop's concerns incomparable energy and dedication to the task of recovery of this Town's young. For three decades, we walked in the shadows of his immense devotion to our Cause. The march of the years will note the passing of all of us but few with such monumental impact upon our journey. May the good Lord welcome him home and may He grant solace and strength to his beloved Joan and the Fallon Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien, President Daytop Village, Inc.

description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 6 - Jacob G. Zuma, the charismatic leader whose dismissal as deputy president last June has unleashed a bitter power struggle in South African politics, was arrested Tuesday and charged with raping a family friend at his Johannesburg home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEFFEN, FLORENCE
description: GEFFEN - Florence. Born September 6, 1911 in Manchester, NH. Died peacefully in her sleep after a long illness. Mrs. Geffen was surrounded by a most extraordinary group of caregivers. She came to New York in 1931 to teach music theory at Teachers College. Florence was an accomplished pianist, who loved music deeply, from the Etudes of Chopin to the operas of Wagner. A terrific golfer, she had three holes in one. Florence was a great gal, full of fun and generous to a fault. She embodied beauty and elegance and we will miss her. Her husband Max and brothers Walter and Hap preceded her in death. She is survived by her son Pete, his wife Elaine and their son Will, who has inherited his grandmother's wonderful golf swing; also nieces Wendy, Bonnie and Barbara and stepchildren Melinda and Roger and their children. Memorial service Friday, January 13, 2006, 3:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: Port Authority Seeks Voiding of Jury Verdict
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is asking a court to set aside a jury verdict finding the authority negligent in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center.

description: CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 - Egyptian police killed at least six people today, fired live bullets and tear gas into crowds, beat voters, shut down polling sites and arrested opposition supporters during the final day of voting in parliamentary elections, according to independent poll monitors.

description: Although the name might suggest a bias toward dance, the new Baryshnikov Arts Center, at 450 West 37th Street, is meant to be a home for all the arts, and one way it is making the point is by presenting free hourlong chamber concerts in its fourth-floor Studio Theater.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Johnson & Johnson Defends Its Bid for Guidant In Response to Challenge From Boston Scientific Johnson & Johnson, in response to Boston Scientific's surprising bid of $25 billion for Guidant, the medical device maker, said that the $21.5 billion merger agreement it had reached with Guidant on Nov. 15 represented "full and fair value," an indication that it does not plan to enter a bidding war. [Page C1.]

He was a resident of Palm Beach, FL for30 years, where he was an active member of the Pundits, the Beach Club, the Old Guard, the English-speaking Union, and the Society of the Four Arts. Also mourned by daughters - in - law Nancy (Sheridan), Nancy (Donnoli), and grandchildren Christopher, Stephen, Katherine, and Samantha. title: Paying Tribute to a Master of Fastidious Elegance
description: The image I carry of George Perle's music is that of a composer listening to himself. The attention paid is acute. Any crudeness of gesture in the name of passion is disallowed, as is any misshapen phrase born of carelessness or any hint of grandiosity for dramatic effect. The Making Music series at Zankel Hall offered seven of his pieces on Monday night. Mr. Perle, frail at 90, sat in the balcony. Below him was an audience of colleagues -- performers and composers -- along with those who have long admired his fastidiousness.

description: Oggi's stainless steel thermal serving tray will keep food cold or hot without requiring an electrical outlet. That means that hors d'oeuvre tidbits or chilled shrimp and sushi rolls can go right on a cocktail table. The platter is most effective when food is put directly on it. Sealed inside is a gel that can be cooled by placing the tray in the refrigerator for two hours, or warmed in a 200-degree oven for six minutes. It will stay cool for more than two hours, and warm for about an hour, but longer if hot items are replenished on it. The tray is $39.95 from (800) 243-0852 or surlatable .com and at Sur La Table stores. FOOD STUFF

title: An Old Man and His Bike, Chasing an Impossible Dream
description: "The World's Fastest Indian," the based-on-fact story of a New Zealand coot who defies age by racing his motorcycle competitively, is a big mushy piece of ice cream cake for Anthony Hopkins. Playing its crusty but lovable hero, Burt Munro, who set the world's land-speed record in 1967 at the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah, Mr. Hopkins delivers an endearingly gruff performance from the encyclopedia of scenery chewing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERKEN, CONSTANCE L.
description: GERKEN--Constance L. December 5, 2005, Age 92 of NYC formerly of Ridgewood, New Jersey. Beloved mother of Constance E. Gerard, grandmother of Trish Harwood, great grandmother of Constance Harwood. Survived by her sister Miriam Hill of Ocala, FL. Special Education Teacher in Glenrock, NJ. for over 25 years. PHD in Linguistics from Columbia University. We loved her spunk and joy of life. We will all miss her. Mass at 11AM Blessed Sacrament RCC NYC Lutheran Cemetery Queens, NY. For more information contact Lawrence Funeral Chapel 137 Lawrence Ave, Lawrence, New York.

title: Hussein, at Lectern, Delivers Diatribe About U.S. and His Prison Treatment
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 6 - Standing at a courtroom lectern, his notes spread before him, Saddam Hussein delivered a long rambling diatribe on Tuesday in which he complained about his prison cell, boasted that he had survived three death sentences and excoriated America for running "a theatrical play which they call a trial."

title: Cashman Focusing on Future of Veterans

There are thick binders on the tables in Cashman's suite, and the Yankees are meeting with agents and other teams.

Citing Abuse of Authority, U.N. Dismisses Elections Chief
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 6 - The United Nations fired the director of its highly regarded elections services office on Tuesday on accusations of sexual harassment and abuse of authority.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Central Bank Raises Rate
description: As part of a previously announced monetary tightening program, the Bank of Canada increased its key lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point yesterday to 3.25 percent. It was the third increase since September in the rate the central bank charges commercial banks for overnight loans. Several of Canada's commercial lenders immediately followed by increasing their prime rates by 0.25 percentage point, to 5 percent. While inflation is at 2.6 percent, below the Bank of Canada's target of 2.8 percent, wages have been rising at an annual rate of 3.9 percent. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Blue Jays Sign Burnett, and Take Step Forward
description: DALLAS, Dec. 6 - The Toronto Blue Jays have watched the American League East standings unfold in similarly annoying fashion for eight straight seasons. The mighty Yankees have finished in first place, the potent Boston Red Sox have been right behind them and the undermanned Blue Jays have lagged behind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, JOHN M.
description: MURPHY--John M. Of Breezy Point, NY, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, and Rockville Centre, on December 4, 2005, at the age of 84. Born April 18, 1921, John was the youngest of four boys. He was a decorated veteran of WWII serving in Europe. Founder and President of East America, Inc., a commodity trading firm in New York. He was a fabulous cook, master storyteller and a devoted husband and father. With his loving wife Grace, he enjoyed his retirement on the beaches of Breezy Point and Hutchinson Island, FL. His warmth, wit and sage counsel will be profoundly missed. In addition to his wife Grace, John is survived by his beloved children: Kathleen (Spangler), Michael, James, John, Robert and the late Charles, with whom he now rests. He will also be deeply missed by his fourteen adoring grandchildren. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor, Inc., 9105 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point, on Friday at 11:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Covenant House, PO Box JAF 2973, New York, NY 10116-2973.

description: They were once punch-drunk with slam dunks off fast breaks. Kenyon Martin snared rebounds and spiked shots. Kerry Kittles stole passes from the perimeter. Richard Jefferson surged down the court alongside them, and Jason Kidd choreographed the scene at breakneck speed.

A 1994 epidemic -- reported as pneumonic plague -- that originated here caused national panic. It is the kind of place where the body of a woman killed by a passing truck is left in the street because no one knows her.

Poetic Justice for a Feared Immigrant Stop
description: ANGEL ISLAND, Calif., Dec. 1 - It was known, simply, as "the wooden building." For 30 years, from 1910 to 1940, the barren walls of the Angel Island Immigration Station gave mute testimony to the experiences of roughly 175,000 Chinese immigrants who were detained and exhaustively interrogated on this island in San Francisco Bay, the West Coast's insidious version of Ellis Island.

title: Mourning a Fallen Officer, and Paying Tribute to a 'True Hero'

Moscow's Empty Red Square
description: WASHINGTON - WHEN we visited Moscow earlier this fall, almost everyone we talked to agreed that Russia is becoming steadily less democratic. Yet Russia's society and economy are in many ways freer than ever. Our visit convinced us of the vitality and potential of Russian civic groups and nongovernmental organizations, much like the ones Western Europeans and Americans know in their own countries. Unfortunately this sector -- human rights monitors, environmental groups, policy research institutions, even public health advocates -- is now at risk.

description: A parks employee was killed early yesterday when he was accidentally hit by a snow-removal vehicle operated by a sanitation employee, the police said. The employee, Joseph Sordi, 58, of Brooklyn, was struck shortly after 1 a.m. in a parking lot near Sand Lane and Father Capodanno Boulevard, the police said. They said they thought Mr. Sordi and the operator of the vehicle were clearing snow from South Beach parking lot. Shadi Rahimi (NYT)

title: The Man Behind Rosa Parks
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5 - Almost everyone has seen the famous study in black and white, one of those rare photographs that entered the collective memory as a snapshot not of a moment but of an era and maybe something more. It's now on almost any bus in New York City and many of its suburbs, an invitation not just to remember but to reflect.

title: Bringing Out Schubert's Sensuous Side
description: Sasha Waltz, the Berlin-based modern-dance choreographer, made a splash with her United States debut three years ago in a spectacle called "KArper," full of naked bodies. Now she is back at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with what she has described as "something really precious, small and detailed."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRIMMER, HAROLD
description: DRIMMER - Harold. The Board of Trustees, the Foundation's Board of Directors, and the grateful student body of Westchester Community College grieve for their distinguished friend, benefactor, and leader. For more than two decades, Harold Drimmer served devotedly and successfully as Chairman of the Board of Trustees and as an organizing founder of the college's Foundation. This period brought enormous progress including economic stability and innovative academic programs. He received respectful admiration for his vital role in positioning the institution among the elite of community colleges not only in New York State but throughout the country. His unswerving belief in the value of higher education for all who seek it was consistent and constant and his intelligent leadership helped achieve his lofty goals. Gratefully, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to the Drimmer family. Hon. Timothy S. Carey Chairman, Board of Trustees Dr. Joseph N. Hankin President Betsy Stern, Chair Westchester Community College Foundation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELNICK, GOLDIE
description: MELNICK--Goldie. On December 5, 2005 in St. Petersburg, FL. Born May 31, 1925 in Liberty, New York, where she spent most of her life. Beloved teacher at the Rutherford Elementary School, Monticello, NY for 24 years. She leaves her son Andrew B. Melnick (Rae Koshetz) of NYC & daughters Cynthia Weisberg (Robert) & Stephanie Volk (Kenneth) of St. Petersburg, Florida, seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Graveside service at Ahavath Israel Cemetery, Liberty, NY on December 8, 2005, 2 PM.

National Briefing | Washington: Woman At Center Of C.I.A. Leak Case To Retire
description: Valerie Wilson, whose identity as a covert C.I.A. officer was leaked in 2003, will retire soon from the agency after a career of 20 years, a government official briefed on her plans said. In addition, a friend and former C.I.A. colleague of Ms. Wilson's, Larry C. Johnson, said she had told him that her last day at the agency would be this Friday and that she would officially retire when her leave is exhausted in January. The disclosure by the columnist Robert D. Novak that Ms. Wilson worked for the agency set off an investigation that led in October to the indictment of I. Lewis Libby Jr., then Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff, for perjury and obstruction of justice. The special prosecutor in the case, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, investigated whether the leak was part of an effort to retaliate against Ms. Wilson's husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, a former ambassador who had accused the Bush administration of distorting intelligence before the war in Iraq. Mr. Wilson, reached by phone, declined to comment on his wife's plans.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Inbound Flights Bring Their Own Fuel
description: International airlines serving Zimbabwe have begun to load extra jet fuel onto inbound flights to avoid the embarrassment of being stranded in a nation whose economy is so rickety that fuel is all but nonexistent, the South African newspaper Business Day reported. It said that some international carriers had begun bumping paying passengers from Zimbabwe-bound flights and using the freed-up weight for extra fuel. The nation's flag carrier, Air Zimbabwe, canceled international routes and grounded its entire fleet on Nov. 22 for lack of fuel, and some passengers said regional flights had recently been canceled. A spokesman for Air Zimbabwe called reports of the airline's canceled flights hearsay and "malicious."

OFF THE MENU
description: MINT -- Gary Sikka, right, has taken over the restaurant in the renovated San Carlos Hotel and opened Mint, an Indian restaurant designed by Wid Chapman with splashes of hot color and a waterfall. With a team of chefs, some from Devi and Caf Spice, he has assembled a menu of Indian specialties. Some dishes are from Goa and southern India, many of them fragrant with mint: 150 East 50th Street, (212) 644-8888.

title: Holiday Films We'd Like to See
description: Independent film studio, global television network, newspaper of record, far-reaching blog, the kitten you brought home but didn't get to keep. Many have tried to live up to the dream of synergy, and until now, all have failed. So it is with no small amount of pride that we announce the creation of the Underfinanced Production Company, a media giant which knows no boundaries, as our lawyers can attest. Movie picks, cutting edge interviews with the stars, original derivative films; we'll be bringing you all of that and more in the weeks to come.

description: GREAT sound and high fidelity are not just for those rococo home theaters the size of commercial movie houses. Call it a home theater, media room or den, watching the tube is becoming a more cinematic experience, even if it's taking place in a shag-carpeted basement.

title: Skepticism Seems to Erode Europeans' Faith in Rice
description: BERLIN, Dec. 6 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice did what was expected, many people in Europe said Tuesday, after her meetings with Chancellor Angela Merkel and other German officials. She gave reassurances that the United States would not tolerate torture and, while not admitting mistakes, promised to correct any that had been made.

title: Holiday Sweets That Have Had a Few
description: Soaked in port and dipped in dark chocolate, "drunken" figs made by Cocoa Vino could be an unusual indulgence at your holiday table. The figs (four for $13) are the latest creation of Alisha Lumea (far left) and Avril Pendergast-Fischer, who started selling their sweets, made with organic ingredients and some with fair trade-certified chocolate, on the Internet earlier this year (www.cocoavino.com). They now sell them at Murray's Cheese Shop in Greenwich Village and at Cocoa Bar, a cafe, wine bar and chocolate shop at 228 Seventh Avenue (Third Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Teenager With the Courage to Hide Pain and Share Joy
description: AS Sheena Georges took her place, a dimpled freshman standing before the judge in her first speech competition, she moved her palms in the motion of someone wiping a window. She had committed the gesture to memory long before this day last winter, just as she had learned the monologue from a one-act play entitled "Glass Houses." No sooner did she speak the opening line, though, than her brain went empty, all those practice sessions yielding nothing except silence, the evidence of her inadequacy.

description: After months of political erosion, President BushAs approval rating improved markedly in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, largely tracking AmericansA more positive attitudes toward the economy.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Janitors' Union Signs Security Guards
description: The city's largest janitors' union announced yesterday that it had won support from 1,100 security guards with Burns International Security Services, its first big victory in an effort to unionize more than 10,000 guards in New York City. The union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, said it would soon seek to negotiate better wages and benefits for the Burns guards, who work at City University campuses, Yeshiva University, AT&T and Pfizer. Local 32BJ's parent union is trying to organize more than 75,000 security guards nationwide. Facing intense union pressures, Burns's parent, Securitas, agreed not to fight unionization efforts. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: German Held in Afghan Jail Files Lawsuit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 - A German citizen who says he was abducted in 2003, beaten and taken to Afghanistan by American agents in what was apparently a case of mistaken identity filed a lawsuit in federal court on Tuesday against George J. Tenet, the former C.I.A. director, and three companies suspected of being involved in secret C.I.A. flights.

Mourned also by sister Naomi, brothers Norman and Ted, sisters-in-law, Roz and Carol, son-in-law Phil, daughter-in-law Marcia, loving nieces and nephews, and dear friends. They optimistically purchase Emeril's cookware, download Daniel's recipes and watch cooking shows. Yet they eat breakfast in their cars, lunch at their desks and chicken from a bucket.

title: Anderson Forecast: Sustained Decline Coming
description: The Anderson Forecast on real estate trends that emanates quarterly from the University of Californias Anderson School of Business is emanating as you read this. It usually gets wide coverage because Edward Leamer, the director of the forecast, isnt afraid to make a call. (Though, truth be told, the report has been predicting doom for a few years now.) The Daily Breeze has this initial report of a sustained decline in 2006. The good news: its not enough to trigger a recession although, the report says, eight out of the last 10 recessions were started by housing market slowdowns.That said, the slowdown is likely to last several years, with as many as 500,000 construction jobs and 300,000 financial sector positions lost, the quarterly Anderson Forecast predicted.

title: Scottish Fiction: The Noir and the Blanc
description: St. Andrew is the patron saint of Scotland, and, like all saints real or apocryphal, he has his day. Scotland is a somewhat reserved country; the Irish diaspora makes itself felt with various green activities, but we are much less . . . how should one put it? Enthusiastic. St. Andrews Day is, however, the national day, and that is the day on which people up and down Scotland  or one or two of them  don their kilts and discover that over the previous year the kilts have shrunk. Or so we tell ourselves.

title: Separating Noise and Signal
description: This week mortgage applications are up, the Mortgage Bankers Association says. Last week they were down. One can get bogged down trying to interpret the weekly numbers because there will be fluctuations as the broader trend line moves up or down.The index is up 5.2 percent from last week, but down 6.1 percent compared to a year ago.The upshot is that the market is in a state of flux, but the mortgage application numbers contine to provid ample evidence of what everyone is seeing: a market in decline.

But Democrats are having trouble coming up with a plan of their own, and some experts say they will suffer at the polls next year unless they can present a unified front in convincing the public that they would do better.

title: British Court Rules Against Evidence Gained in Torture
description: LONDON, Dec. 8 - Thrusting itself into the middle of a stormy international debate, Britain's highest court declared today that evidence obtained through torture - no matter who had done the torturing - was not admissible in British courts. It also said that Britain had a "positive obligation" to uphold anti-torture principles abroad as well as at home.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's trip to Europe incorrectly paraphrased remarks by Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, at a news conference with Ms. Rice. title: Old Governors Never Die. They Just Hang in Capitol.
description: SACRAMENTO, Dec. 7 - The hallowed tradition of hanging a governor's portrait in the third-floor corridor of the Capitol here dates to the 1930's, when, finally, California's first governor, Peter Burnett, who left office in 1851, was given his due: his face mounted on the wall, his legacy preserved in a painting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHN, MAX LEWIS
description: KAHN--Max Lewis. 82, died of cancer on Tuesday, December 6, 2005 at his home in Purchase, NY. Beloved husband of Marcella Kahn, to whom he was married for 58 years, devoted father of Lawrence Kahn, Philip Kahn and Joan Kahn; and loving grandfather to Daniel, Lisa, Alexander, Jeffrey and Andrew. Max (Mac) Kahn was born September 26, 1923 in Philadelphia, PA. At age 11 his family moved to New York City. Mac served in the U.S. Army Artillery during World War II in England, France and Germany. He spent his entire working career (57 years) with Alkahn Labels Inc., a firm supplying the apparel and home furnishings industries, working his way up from assistant designer to President and C.E.O. During the 27 years he led the firm, its sales grew by tenfold, making it the leading U.S. manufacturer of woven labels. Mac loved to travel with his wife, listen to classical music, enjoy the cultural offerings of New York City, and was an avid tennis player. Above all he was a loving husband, father and grandfather. A memorial service will be held on Sunday Dec. 11 at 3:00PM at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester (914-967-4382). In lieu of flowers donations may be made to White Plains Hospital Center or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: External Speakers Small Enough to Fit in a Purse
description: There are numerous external speaker systems that let you share the music stored on iPods or other MP3 players. Some are portable enough to fit in a backpack. And then there is Zelco's TriPod. Its name is also its description. The legs of the diminutive device, which weighs just over two ounces, act as the speakers.

title: Corrections
description: The Critical Shopper column last Thursday, about holiday gift shopping, misstated the address of Roberta Freymann, which offers clothing and jewelry from around the world. The shop is at 153 East 70th Street, Manhattan; 49 East 78th Street is its former location.

title: Gulf Planning Roils Residents
description: BILOXI, Miss. - EVER since the water rose over Andrea Harris's white bungalow on Elmer Street during Hurricane Katrina, Ms. Harris has been keeping a scrapbook. It holds three daily prayers, news clippings, the business cards of people who have helped her and angry letters to those who have not -- including the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which she said took two months to deliver trailers. Until then, she and her neighbors lived in tents.

title: The $199 Alternative to Checking the Weather by Looking Outside
description: Home meteorology has always been a combination of physical observation -- sticking your head out of the window -- and high-tech guesswork. The Complete Regional Weather Station from Oregon Scientific hopes to change that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALLON, JOHN W.
description: FALLON--John W. In his "Pompila", Robert Browning charged: No work begun shall ever pause for death! His words, however, might impede so profound a tribute for a lesser figure on the horizons of our journey. Not, however, for John Fallon, Board Chairman (Retired) of both Daytop Village, Inc. and Daytop International, Inc. Drawn from the ranks of elite leadership of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, he brought to the table of Daytop's concerns incomparable energy and dedication to the task of recovery of this Town's young. For three decades, we walked in the shadows of his immense devotion to our Cause. The march of the years will note the passing of all of us but few with such monumental impact upon our journey. May the good Lord welcome him home and may He grant solace and strength to his beloved Joan and the Fallon Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien, President Daytop Village, Inc.

title: A 60's Crush Lingers in Minds and Designs
description: MICHELLE BRAVERMAN remembers strolling down Madison Avenue on a wintry day in the early 1970's. She was all done up in a maxicoat and a cloche she had bought at Biba in London when she spied a slender figure approaching. The woman was trim and pretty, Ms. Braverman recalled, "and she could not take her eyes off my hat."

description: CAIRO, Dec. 7 - The Egyptian police killed at least six people Wednesday, fired live bullets and tear gas into crowds, beat voters, shut down polling sites and arrested opposition supporters during the final day of voting in parliamentary elections, independent poll monitors said.
