title: A Bottle Decked With Beads, And Topped by a Shiny Shade
description: Marie Christophe, a French sculptor known for her whimsical wire animals and crystal and wire chandeliers, has introduced a collection of table lamps. Her bulbous Bouteille, or bottle, lamp, below, is made of iron wire and brightly colored ceramic beads and is topped by a shiny shade. It was loosely inspired by 1960's French films, said Ms. Christophe, 34, speaking from her Paris workshop, adding that she was picturing a bottle filled with a bouquet. The lamp, which is part of a series of retro-contemporary bowls and lamps, is 31 inches high ($420). Ms. Christophe also makes a floor lamp version six feet high ($900 to $1,200). They are available in the United States through the Lisa Fontanarosa Collection, (505) 872-1929 or by e-mail, lfontanarosa@mac.com.

description: DALLAS, Dec. 7 - Brian Cashman does not like to speak for George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner. But Cashman was comfortable stating the obvious late Wednesday night, after the Yankees had decided to continue negotiating with center fielder Bernie Williams.

title: In Lima, Cab-Driving Veteran Boils With Rage of Alienation
description: Santiago Roman (Pietro Sibille) can't buy a refrigerator. The money he earns from taxi driving won't meet the minimum monthly payment, and when it comes to lines of credit, his status as a recently discharged sailor in the Peruvian Navy adds up to exactly nothing. Worse things have happened, and there is worse yet in store, but this latest hurt is one too many, and Santiago nearly cracks up with rage.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Vernon: Activists Arrested During Bear Hunt
description: Four animal-rights activists were arrested yesterday and charged with harassing hunters and other offenses, officials said, after they confronted hunters in the woods of Wawayanda State Park on the third day of New Jersey's black bear hunt. Martin McHugh, director of the Department of Environmental Protection Division of Fish and Wildlife, said that Angi Metler, director of the New Jersey Animal Rights Alliance, along with Janet Piszar, Albert Kazemian and Theresa Fritzges, were arrested by the forestry police and charged with harassment, disorderly-person offenses and resisting arrest.. By 2:30 p.m. yesterday, 216 bears had been killed, Mr. McHugh said. Lynda Smith, a spokeswoman for the Bear Education and Resource Group, said the activists "fell victim to a sting operation orchestrated by two hunters they had encountered in the woods yesterday, as well as park rangers and Division of Fish and Wildlife staff," a charge that officials denied.

description: HAYS--Constance. The directors and staff of Christie's deeply mourn the loss of Constance Hays, wife of our beloved Deputy Chairman, John Hays. John's tremendous success in the field of American Furniture & Decorative Arts has been supported for years by Connie's love, good humor, generous perspective and intelligence. Many of us at Christie's have had the privilege of knowing her, and we all admired their great love and respect for each other. We will miss Connie tremendously and send our deepest sympathies to John, their children Sophie, John and Henry, and all in their extended families. Stephen S. description: Before a packed fund-raising event last night that took in $5 million for his bid for governor, the state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, took a rare shot at a Republican line of attack that he is likely to face in next year's campaign. He rebuked a Republican rival for governor, Randy Daniels (though not by name), for arguing that Mr. Spitzer's cases against Wall Street firms have actually been aimed at business executives who were only seeking to achieve the American Dream. He ticked off several lawsuits of his that he said protected the interests of the poor, retirees and the environment. "What version of the American Dream do they believe in?" he said of Republicans.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Former City Director Charged In Theft
description: Donald Nolte, the former director of the city's Bureau of Day Care, was accused yesterday of stealing time from his $85,000-a-year city job so that he could work for Cicatelli Associates, a nonprofit consulting company. Prosecutors charge that he falsified time sheets to claim he was working for the city when he was really working for Cicatelli, which holds city contracts for H.I.V. and AIDS programs. From 1997 to his dismissal last year, prosecutors claimed, Mr. Nolte stole $30,000 in city salary. Over the same period, they said, he made more than $100,000 from Cicatelli. Mr. Nolte, 63, was fired after a baby suffocated under a pile of toys in a city-licensed day care center in Queens. He pleaded not guilty to grand larceny and fraud. His lawyer, Elizabeth M. Fink, said Mr. Nolte had been fabulous at his city job, and had stolen time, not money, while he was under stress supporting his companion of 30 years, who died in 2003. Anemona Hartocollis (NYT)

title: Port Authority Plans $5 Billion Budget, but No Toll or Fare Rises
description: Commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are expected to approve a $5 billion budget today that includes more than $600 million for security next year, but does not include an increase in PATH train fares or tolls on bridges and tunnels.

title: PADRES HOLD ON TO HOFFMAN
description: The San Diego Padres re-signed closer Trevor Hoffman to a two-year, $13.5 million contract. The deal includes an option that could bring the total to three years and $19 million and would be triggered by games finished.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the garage in Palo Alto, Calif., designated by the state as the birthplace of Silicon Valley, reversed the roles of the computer pioneers William R. Hewlett and David Packard in setting up shop there in 1938. It was Mr. Hewlett who rented the property that included the garage and Mr. Packard who drove from New York to join him.

title: The Titanic's Demise
description: Twenty years ago, a team of scientists led by Robert Ballard discovered the remains of the Titanic some 12,400 feet under the surface of the North Atlantic. It was a big deal. When the search team returned to Woods Hole, it held a brief service to honor those who died when the Titanic sank in the early hours of April 15, 1912. Now scientists have discovered large sections of the hull that suggest the ship may have split into three parts rather than two, and may have sunk much more quickly than was thought. This, Mr. Ballard said, is not a big deal. "It hit an iceberg and it sank," he said. "Get over it."

title: Bush Shifts Priorities in Rebuilding Iraq to Smaller Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - President Bush said Wednesday that the strategy for rebuilding Iraq was shifting to smaller, more visible projects, while he conceded that the American effort to rebuild Iraq had been ridden with early mistakes.

title: The Drips, a Band Ed Norton Could Love
description: IT is not easy to rock a party billed as "A Quality of Work Life Labor-Management Event," especially when it starts about 12 hours earlier than most respectable rock bands get going.

title: Remainders of the day
A Sofa Arranged Like a Faceted Gem
description: Luisa Ruge, a furniture designer in San Francisco, created the Neo Geode S2B sectional sofa for a shop in the East Village sponsored by Surface magazine and Bombay Sapphire gin and open for one month only. It is now available at the Conran Shop and at www.surfacemag.com (click on Pop-Up Shop). Blue felt wedges, some with backs ($2,500) and some without ($1,775), group around a matching hexagonal ottoman ($1,375) to resemble a faceted gem, left, or can be arranged in other ways. The Conran Shop is at 407 East 59th Street; (212) 755-9079.

title: Accounts
description: Clarity Media Group, Denver, owned by the billionaire investor Philip F. Anschutz, expanded its relationship with Maiden Lane, San Francisco, by naming the agency as the national agency for the planned Examiner chain of free tabloid newspapers. Maiden Lane, which became the agency for The San Francisco Examiner last year, will create campaigns for The Washington Examiner, introduced last winter, and The Baltimore Examiner, due in early 2006. Spending has not been determined.

title: A Tiny Shop in the East Village Pays Homage to Paris of the 1920's
description: The Paris Apartment, a shop owned by Claudia Strasser, is back after a nine-year hiatus. Tiny, painted pale gray and situated in the East Village, the shop specializes in French, Italian and American furniture from the 1920's to the present. Recent offerings included, above left: a 1970's American boudoir chair reupholstered in blue silk velvet ($750); a 70's two-piece sofa with a white slipcover ($700); and a 40's American mirror ($1,200). A 1930's chaise, above right, is a reproduction Louis XV upholstered in fake rabbit fur ($3,400); behind it is a 1920's American chair in pink tufted silk ($750).

title: Running Out of Steam
description: Conservatives are in power but out of sorts. Fifty years after the founding of the modern right, conservatives hold just about every important government job, yet the conservative agenda has stalled. Federal spending has surged. Social Security reform is dead. And when voters are asked which party they trust on key issues, they decisively reject conservative ideas.

title: Playback Problems With DVD's
description: Playback Problems With DVD's

title: Rice seems to shift policy on prisoners
Latest Chinese coal disaster kills 74, shaming government safety pledges
After 24 Years in Prison, Man Has a Reason to Smile
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Dec. 7 - It is rare to see a prison inmate with a life sentence who cannot stop grinning.

title: Letter from New York: What the King Kongs reveal
Committee Democrat Seeks More on Work Alito Did in the 80's
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the ranking Democrat on the Judiciary Committee, said Wednesday that he was seeking additional documents related to work done in the Reagan administration by Samuel A. Alito Jr., the president's nominee to the Supreme Court.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's trip to Europe incorrectly paraphrased remarks by Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, at a news conference with Ms. Rice. Referring to the 2003 abduction and five-month detention of a German, Khaled al-Masri, by the United States on suspicion of terrorism, Mrs. Merkel said that the United States had admitted error in the case, not that Ms. Rice had admitted error.

title: Suicide attack on bus to Nasiriyah kills at least 30
Egypt ponders price of Islamists' gains
Arrest in Newark Alters Story of Year-Old Quadruple Murder
description: When three men and a woman were found dead last year in a weed-strewn lot, side by side and face down with gunshot wounds to the head, Newark officials tried to calm what was then a jittery city by declaring that the victims were career criminals who had it coming.

title: CUBS ACQUIRE PIERRE
description: As the Yankees considered trading for center fielder Juan Pierre, they were skeptical of his decline last season with Florida. Pierre flustered the Yankees in the 2003 World Series, but his on-base percentage slid to .326 last season from .374 in 2004, and he had 40 fewer hits than he did in 2004.

title: On The Street: Then
description: STRIDING down Fifth or Madison Avenues in the autumn of 1990, each of these women fairly bristled with purpose and character, displaying, in retrospect, an oddly prescient fashion sense. Today the clothes they wore -- formal, fastidiously tailored and evidently little altered since the 1950's -- look surprisingly contemporary, from the cut of the jackets and the structured bags to the whimsical hats, cocked at a rakish angle.

title: Gap between allies widens over N. Korea
Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Assembly To Pass Sex-Offender Rules
description: The Democratic-led State Assembly will pass a bill early next year increasing sentences for sex offenders and allowing the state to confine some offenders in treatment programs after their sentences expire, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, announced yesterday. The Assembly has been under pressure to do so from the Republican-led State Senate and from Gov. George E. Pataki, who began ordering some offenders held after their sentences expired this year, even without a law.

title: Bank of Japan Sees End to Deflation
description: The end of the Bank of Japan's deflation-fighting policy is near, Toshihiko Fukui, the central bank governor said today, adding that prices will show solid gains in the first quarter of next year.

title: Harold D. Shapiro, 78, Law Firm Chairman, Dies
description: Harold D. Shapiro, a partner in the law firm of Sonnenschein Nath & Rosenthal and its first chairman, died last Thursday in Evanston, Ill. He was 78 and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Sunday about the race in California's 48th Congressional District mislabeled the highway running north and south through San Diego and located Los Angeles too far northwest of San Diego. The highway is Interstate 5, not Highway 1. Los Angeles is about 115 miles from San Diego.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, TANDY J.
description: MILLER--Tandy J. On December 7, after a fierce and valiant battle with cancer. Adored mother of Evan and Gillian Michaelson, beloved sister of Liane, Sheryl and Holly Miller, daughter of Algernon and Constance Miller. Renowned and valued clinical psychologist at Yale. Bold, beautiful and brilliant-she will be missed forever. Services on December 9, 11AM at the Unitarian Church, 10 Lyons Plains Road, Westport, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, JACK
description: SCHWARTZ--Jack. The Semel Society records with sorrow the loss of our esteemed member Jack Schwartz. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Henrietta and children Jill and James. Martin I. Semel, President

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
SORIANO BOUND FOR NATIONALS
description: Alfonso Soriano is headed to the National League East, but he is not going to the Mets. Soriano, who had interested the Mets early this off-season, was traded from the Texas Rangers to the Washington Nationals in a four-player deal Wednesday night.

title: Workouts Are Potent Medicine for the Mentally Ill
description: MATTHEW HASS is not sure what caused him to blow up to 300 pounds: his sedentary lifestyle, a diet devoid of fruits or vegetables or the medications he took for bipolar disorder. Not that the cause mattered. Mr. Hass knew he was at a crossroads: at 27 he said he felt like a "heart attack waiting to happen," so he decided to give exercise a chance. "I was ready to try something else that would help my moods," he said, "and maybe help me lose some weight too."

title: More Questions as Rice Asserts Detainee Policy
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, REBECCA
description: SLOAN--Rebecca, 1935-2005, died peacefully with family at her side at her daughter Andrea's home on December 6th of cancer. Born April 18 in Garden City, Kansas, to the late Dorine and Leland Sloan, Rebecca was the second of four children. She was preceded in death by her sister, Sara Ann, and brother, Phillip. Rebecca is survived by her brother and sister-in-law, Douglas and Fern Sloan; sister-in-law, Jane Sloan; children & spouses, Stephen and Wendy, Andrea and John, Robert and Cheri; and grandchildren, Rosalee, Ian, Rebecca, and Tea. A lifelong artist and musician, Rebecca devoted the later years of her life to early childhood Waldorf education, culminating in her teaching for nearly a decade at the Rudolf Steiner School in New York City. A funeral service will be held at 4PM, Friday, December 9, 2005, at the Christian Community chapel, 309 West 74th Street, New York. Donations may be made to the Rudolf Steiner School.

title: Arts, Briefly; R&B Star, 16, Is Rising
description: The 20th installment of the evergreen hits compilation "Now That's What I Call Music!" -- "Now 20" for short -- took the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week by a slim margin, edging out a No. 1 debut by a fast-rising R&B star, Chris Brown, who at 16 has a No. 1 single, "Run It!" Mr. Brown's self-titled album, released on the Jive label, sold 154,000 copies in the week that ended Sunday, just 4,000 behind "Now 20," according to Nielsen SoundScan. Last week was relatively slow at record stores; "Now 20," in its fifth week out, reached No. 1 with 45 percent fewer sales than it had the week before, when it was ranked third. Shakira's "Oral Fixation Vol. 2" (Epic) opened at No. 5 with 128,000 sales, 29,000 fewer than its Spanish-language companion, "Fijacin Oral Vol. 1," had in its first week six months ago. Carrie Underwood's "Some Hearts" (Arista) jumped four spots to No. 3, despite an 18 percent slip in sales from last week, and "The Road and the Radio" (BNA) by Kenny Chesney is at No. 4. BEN SISARIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POSNACK, ANN
description: POSNACK--Ann. A resident of Great Neck and Rye, NY, died December 4, 2005 at age 94. Born in New York to Jacob and Edith Bock, Ann worked as a social worker for the Peninsula Counseling Center. She is survived by her son Alan (his wife Anne), three grandchildren, and seven great grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to the Peninsula Counseling Center, 124 Franklin Place, Woodmere, NY 11598.

title: Suicide Bomber Hits Bus in Baghdad, Killing at Least 30
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 8 - Two near-simultaneous explosions, one detonated by a suicide bomber, tore through a crowded bus in the capital's main bus terminal today, killing at least 30 people and wounding 25, witnesses and police officials said.

title: 2 nations lift interest rates
House Speaker Suggests Ethics Refresher
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - In a sign that Republican leaders are increasingly anxious about the image of the House after bribery convictions, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert raised the prospect on Wednesday of new ethics training for lawmakers.

title: A House That Survives Tsunamis by Letting Water In
description: A $4,000, 450-square-foot house designed to survive a tsunami, right, is being tested by a family in Bala Pitiya, Sri Lanka. It was created by students at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, who made it more porous than the typical Sri Lankan house by adding floor-to-ceiling openings. The design won a competition at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the prototype was built by the Senseable City Lab, a research group at M.I.T.; Buro Happold, an engineering firm in London; Architecture for Humanity, a nonprofit group in Bozeman, Mont., and the Prajnopaya Foundation in Carlisle, Mass., which creates educational programs for developing nations. The house, designed without bathroom or kitchen fixtures, awaits local feedback, said Tenzin Priyadarshi, president of the Prajnopaya Foundation. ELAINE LOUIE CURRENTS: DESIGN

title: Charly Gaul, 72, Star Climber in Cycling During the 1950's, Is Dead
description: Charly Gaul, one of the great climbers in bicycle racing history and the winner of the Tour de France and the Giro d'Italia nearly half a century ago, died in his native Luxembourg on Tuesday. He was 72.

title: The land of Narnia, spirit intact
In Search of a Sofa to Go Under the Schnabel
description: Correction Appended

title: Feeling Warm, Looking Cool
description: BACK in the winter of 1957 -- at least the one portrayed in "Sweet Smell of Success" -- the simple act of not wearing a topcoat was enough to brand Sidney Falco, that sycophant of a Broadway press agent, as a lowlife. Wearing nothing more than a sport coat, he was able to scuttle in his slippery way in and out of theaters, bars and restaurants. It also meant that Sidney, played to sleazy perfection by Tony Curtis, never tipped a coat-check girl.

title: To the Rescue, Elves Who Come to Clean
description: A good cleaning service can rescue a home before a holiday party, or after. New York's Little Elves, in business nearly 30 years, has a staff trained in the cleaning and handling of fine art and furniture. Clients have included the Kip's Bay Decorator Showhouse. The service will send one or more elves anywhere in the tristate area, said Barbara Fierman, the owner, and charges $33 an hour per person, with a four-hour minimum, plus transportation if the client is outside the city. Information: (212) 673-5507.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OPPENHEIMER, EDGAR D. JR.
description: OPPENHEIMER--Edgar D. Jr. Passed away peacefully at 80 at his home in St. Petersburg, Florida, on December 5, 2005. He leaves his beloved wife of 54 years, Virginia Layton, his brother David E. Oppenheimer, his four children, Frances Oppenheimer, William L. and Barbara Oppenheimer, Carol Oppenheimer and Steve Zagerman, and Jill Oppenheimer and Alain Carriere. He also leaves ten grandchildren: Jesse, Arti, and Peter Boyd and Matthew Weigert; Michael and Claire Oppenheimer; Sophie and Willa Zagerman; and Olivier and Jean-Francois Carriere. He was preceded in death by his twin brother Frank. His parents were Dr. Edgar D. & Carolyn Weil Oppenheimer. Edgar served as a Naval Officer during World War II and remained an avid sailor all his life. He was a mechanical engineer and an expert in hightemperature welding. The family will hold a memorial service at the Academy of Senior Professionals at Eckert College (ASPEC) in St. Petersburg, Florida, on January 14, 2006. Contributions in memory should be made to the Hospice of the Florida Suncoast or the Florida Chapter of the ALS Foundation.

title: Cyberspace unity eludes Europeans
Egyptian Police Kill Six as Elections End
description: CAIRO, Dec. 7 - The Egyptian police killed at least six people Wednesday, fired live bullets and tear gas into crowds, beat voters, shut down polling sites and arrested opposition supporters during the final day of voting in parliamentary elections, independent poll monitors said.

title: Giants' Tyree Is Making Himself Really Something Special
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 7 - It takes 15 minutes to get to Giants Stadium from Montclair, N.J. David Tyree made the journey in five years, and it was one he never planned on taking.

title: Job Satisfaction Is Not Just a Matter of Dollars
description: EUROPEAN workers are united in at least one respect: they have reported declining levels of job satisfaction to pollsters over the last three decades. In Britain, for example, the proportion of workers who said they were completely satisfied with their jobs was down to 14 percent in 2001 from 23 percent in 1992.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOMAN, OLDRICH J.
description: TOMAN--Oldrich J., of Port Jefferson, on December 5, 2005. Beloved husband of Vera. Loving father of Peter. Dear father-in-law of Susan. Cherished grandfather of Ian and Oona. Dear uncle of Aglaia Peroutkova, in Prague. Mr. Toman was a librarian at the Melville Library, State University of NY at Stony Brook from 1968-1995. Friends may call at the Casimir Funeral Home, 523 Rt 112, Port Jefferson Station. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-10PM. Religious service, Friday 4PM, at the funeral home. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Hamilton, Ontario. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the National Children's Cancer Society would be greatly appreciated.

title: Hussein Exits, but Still Fills Courtroom
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 7 - On the day after he told the chief judge and the court that is trying him to "go to hell," Saddam Hussein stayed out of the courtroom on Wednesday. But even with his seat in the dock empty, he dominated the proceedings as much by his absence as he had by his relentless outbursts against the court and the American presence in Iraq in the trial's previous four days.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Westchester County: Hospital Projects Surplus
description: The board of directors of the financially troubled Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla approved a budget for 2006 last night that anticipates a $22 million surplus, a significant turnaround for the 1,000-bed hospital, which has lost more than $200 million in the past few years. Hospital officials reduced the projected deficit for this year to $30 million from $59 million. But they cautioned that the budgeted surplus was made possible by a one-time infusion of $40 million from the county.

title: In Berlin, Every Cheer Casts an Eerie Echo
description: BERLIN - When two national soccer teams trot onto the grassy field in the Olympic Stadium here next July 9 to play for the World Cup title, few of the 76,000 spectators or the many millions watching on television are likely to dwell on the history of the place.

title: Again, Torture Rears Its Ugly Head (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Artistic Trade-Offs at Glimmerglass Opera
description: Worried about offending moral sensibilities, Glimmerglass Opera has asked the creators of a new work coming next summer to take "whore" out of the title.

title: OPEC likely to trade boom for falling prices in 2006
Sports of The Times; Colts Are on a Path Completed Once, By the '72 Dolphins
description: WHEN the 1972 Miami Dolphins polished the Super Bowl VII trophy with a 17-0 record, Larry Csonka was their brute-force fullback. He didn't bother running around tacklers, he preferred to run over them, all the way to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Sometimes a Bumper Crop Is Too Much of a Good Thing
description: WARSAW, Ill. - The first architects of agricultural subsidies aimed to bail out farmers during bad harvests so that they would not abandon the vital task of producing food for the nation.

title: Pain Free, May Strives to Be Player He Was
description: WINTER GARDEN, Fla., Dec. 6 - Bob May never goes long without someone asking if he is that guy from five years ago. It's a funny question. He enjoys that people recall his tangle with Tiger Woods at the 2000 P.G.A. Championship before losing in a playoff, but there have been hundreds of days since, days searching for his old swing, days waiting for a surgeon's blade to slice into his lower back.

title: Piece togethera dramatic accent
Arts, Briefly; Charlie Brown Welcome
description: Absent the feel-good weight loss show "The Biggest Loser," which had its finale last week, NBC has subbed in the feel-sick "Fear Factor" on Tuesdays at 8 p.m. But the season premiere of the veteran reality competition wilted, drawing only 8.31 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. It was slain by ABC's "Charlie Brown Christmas," which delivered an audience of 15.35 million and a first-place finish in the hour among adults 18 to 49. NBC, however, brought in the most total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds over all. New episodes of the network's "My Name Is Earl" (13.89 million) and "The Office" (9.81 million), along with "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" (16.28 million) made up for "Fear Factor's" leadoff weakness. KATE AURTHUR

title: Skin Deep; Smelling Like a Wet Dog Doesn't Have to Be a Bad Thing
description: IN the interest of full disclosure: Animals were experimented on for the research and writing of this article. Well, one was: Zoey, 8, a black-and-white dog of uncertain parentage who is currently collapsed at a reporter's feet, worn out from four weeks of research.

title: Former Presidents Announce First Storm Grants
description: Former Presidents George Bush and Bill Clinton announced $90 million in grants yesterday from the charity they established for recovery programs in the region battered by Hurricane Katrina.

title: Down a Modernist Memory Lane
description: Most Continuum concerts explore a single composer or composers from a single country. But Cheryl Seltzer and Joel Sachs, who program and direct the ensemble, set aside the usual format on Tuesday evening and focused on Continuum itself. To celebrate its 40th year, they revisited seven scores composed for the group in a long, varied program at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Crawford's Emergence Is Nice Surprise
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 - To locate Jamal Crawford in the tunnel at Key Arena on Tuesday night, one had to wade through the dozens of well-wishers and autograph seekers, the friends and family, and those who just wanted a brush with greatness.

title: Arts, Briefly; Fisk University to Sell O'Keeffe Painting
description: Georgia O'Keeffe's painting "Radiator Building -- Night, New York" (1927) will be sold by Fisk University, the historically black university in Nashville to which O'Keeffe, below left, donated the work in 1949 as part of the Alfred Stieglitz Collection of Modern American and European Art. O'Keeffe, who died in 1986, married Stieglitz, the photographer and art collector, in 1924 and was based in New York when she painted the cityscape. The Tennessean of Nashville reported this week that Fisk expects to raise $16 million to $20 million by selling "Radiator Building" and Marsden Hartley's abstract "Painting No. 3" (1913) and will use the money for new buildings, the university's endowment, faculty positions and security for the remaining 99 works in the 101-piece Stieglitz collection, which had remained intact for 56 years. The collection also includes works by Picasso, Toulouse-Lautrec and Czanne, is housed at the Carl Van Vechten Gallery on the Fisk campus. Within Nashville's artistic community, reaction to the sale of two of the crown jewels of the Stieglitz collection was mixed. University president Hazel O'Leary, a 1959 Fisk alumna who was President Bill Clinton's first Secretary of Energy (1993-97), told The Tennessean that the decision to sell the pieces was difficult but necessary for the private college to remain competitive. Fisk also filed court papers in Nashville to verify its legal right to sell the pieces under O'Keeffe's original deed of gift; the Tennessee attorney general, Paul Summers, has approved the sale under certain conditions, two of which are that Fisk must use its best efforts to sell the paintings to Tennessee residents, and that the buyer or buyers must assure Fisk that the public will be able to view the pieces. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Cheers and Boos After Ruling
description: In the shopping centers of Boca Raton, Fla., the Supreme Court decision that the government could withhold Social Security benefits to pay back old student debt met with overwhelming approval yesterday, but also strong dissent. Everyone had an opinion.

title: U.K. acts to resolve fight on EU work rules
Arts, Briefly; Ousted '60 Minutes' Producer Lands at CNBC
description: Josh Howard, right, a longtime CBS journalist who was forced to resign as executive producer of the Wednesday edition of "60 Minutes" over its disputed segment about President Bush's National Guard service, has been hired by the financial news channel CNBC to preside over its documentary unit. Mr. Howard, who worked at CBS News for 23 years in a variety of roles, including deputy to Don Hewitt, the creator of "60 Minutes," will be CNBC's vice president for specials and long-form programming, said Mark Hoffman, president of the cable channel. In that job, a new post that he assumes on Monday, Mr. Howard will oversee the expansion of a unit that has produced several documentary-length specials in recent years. At CBS, Mr. Howard won 18 Emmy Awards for segments he produced or supervised. But his departure was tumultuous. Mr. Howard became executive producer of the weeknight edition of "60 Minutes" in the summer of 2004, not long before the program broadcast a report that sought to raise new questions about Mr. Bush's Vietnam Guard service. After initially defending the documents on which the report was based, the network said it could not vouch for their authenticity. After an outside panel found that the broadcast had been rushed under competitive pressure, CBS fired the producer of the segment, Mary Mapes, and demanded that Mr. Howard and two colleagues resign. Of Mr. Howard's role, Mr. Hoffman said: "He paid with his job. But there's a couple of decades of tremendous work that preceded that." JACQUES STEINBERG

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Former Officer Sentenced For Bombing
description: A former New York City police officer who initially had been praised as a hero was sentenced to one to three years in prison yesterday for setting off a pipe bomb in a Times Square subway station. The ex-officer, Joseph Rodriguez, left, pleaded guilty to reckless endangerment. He told the judge that he was suicidal after being traumatized by 9/11 when he set off the bomb on July 19, 2004, but that he had since "filled the void" with religious counseling. Mr. Rodriguez was hailed as a hero for telling people to stand back after the blast, on the mezzanine leading to the A, C and E lines. He was the only person injured. Anemona Hartocollis (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Group Charged In Identity Fraud
description: Twenty-one people were charged with operating a document mill in Jackson Heights that prosecutors said supplied fake identification papers to people across the country. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said officers seized more than 5,000 fake documents, including 700 drivers' licenses from 11 states and 2,400 Social Security cards. Seventeen of the suspects are in custody, and the police were seeking four others yesterday. A man who prosecutors claimed was the ringleader, Esteban Chavez, 32, is believed to have fled to Mexico, Mr. Brown said.

title: Guidantagrees to discuss Boston Scientific offer
Business Week Magazine to End Some Editions
description: LONDON, Dec. 7 - Business Week magazine said Wednesday that it planned to stop publishing its English-language European and Asian editions at the end of the month and replace them with one global edition in English.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBOWITZ, JANICE
description: LIEBOWITZ - Janice. Died December 6, 2005, age 78. Devoted and loving mother of Susan Liebowitz. Dear sister of Gerard Brisman. Mourned also by sister-in-law Eva and loving nephew and nieces. Steadfast advocate for the betterment of the Brighton Beach, Brooklyn Community. Services Friday, 12PM at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn.

description: Q. My living room has a window-lined turret. How do I hang curtains on a curved wall?

description: Rick A. Lazio, the former United States representative who ran against Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Senate in 2000, said yesterday that he would not run for office next year.

title: Student Debt Collectible by Social Security
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - The Supreme Court ruled unanimously Wednesday that the government may withhold Social Security benefits in order to collect old student loan debts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, GEORGE F. III.
description: BAKER--George F. III. The NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Cornell Medical College mourn the tragic death of our beloved and esteemed friend and Trustee George F. Baker. A creative and uniquely talented man of strong commitment and outstanding intellect, Mr. Baker was elected Governor of The Society of the New York Hospital in 1977 and went on to serve on the Board of the merged NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, the third generation of his family to do so. The family's deep interest and dedication to the New York Hospital dateback to 1899, and the Baker Pavilion of the NewYork - Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center stands as a monument to their loyalty and service to the Medical Center. During his 18 years of Board service, Mr. Baker served on several Board committees, including Executive, Finance, and Nominating. He was honored as New York Hospital's Trustee of the Year in 1996. Since 1981, Mr. Baker has been an outstanding Chairman of the Hospital's Investment Committee, where his astute stewardship of its endowment and retirement funds has been invaluable. He served as Vice Chairman of the NewYorkPresbyterian Fund, Inc. (formerly The Society of The New York Hospital Fund, Inc.), and Vice President, and later President, of The New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Medical Center Fund, Inc. (formerly The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center Fund, Inc.). We will profoundly miss his abiding friendship, his wit, and his wise counsel. We will cherish his memory with the greatest affection. Our deepest sympathies go to the Baker family. John Mack Chairman, Board of Trustees Dr. Herbert Pardes President & CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Jr. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in New York City will be suspended today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: N.Y.U. Graduate Assistants Keep Striking Despite Penalties
description: Leaders of the graduate assistants at New York University who are on strike said yesterday that they had no intention of ending their strike until N.Y.U. recognized them as a union, despite recent efforts by some professors and by other graduate students to bring the strike to a close.

description: BERRITT - Hal. You are forever in our hearts and we will love and miss you dearly. Ellen, Richard and Sean

description: The owners of Saks Inc., the department store chain, will express their pleasure -- or dismay -- with the company's executives and directors today at the annual stockholders' meeting in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Sharing the Sacrifice, or Ending It
description: If it is true, as President Bush and many others have argued, that horrific consequences will result if American forces are pulled from Iraq in the near future, then how is it that we are even considering a significant drawdown of troops in advance of next fall's Congressional elections?

title: MILLWOOD WANTS BIG MONEY
description: A. J. Burnett has a career record of 49-50 and has never pitched in the American League. The Toronto Blue Jays signed him to a five-year, $55 million contract Tuesday, and if that is the going rate for such a pitcher, the agent Scott Boras says Kevin Millwood deserves more.

title: Colombia's Highest Court Delays Abortion Ruling
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 7 - The Constitutional Court, Colombia's highest court, delayed a ruling on Wednesday on a lawsuit by an international women's rights group, Women's Link Worldwide, to amend the country's stringent abortion laws, which ban the procedure even when the life of the woman is in danger.

title: Croatian war crimes suspect arrested
Greenspan, in Letter, Opposes a Single Measure to Set Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's longtime chairman, said Wednesday that it was "unwise" to focus the bank's interest rate policy only on reaching a "neutral" level that neither spurred nor restrained economic growth.

title: Mets Want Zito, but It Seems A's Want Him More
description: DALLAS, Dec. 7 - The Mets are one of several teams that have inquired about the marquee left-handed pitcher Barry Zito, but they should not be hopeful about snagging him because the Oakland Athletics have been telling teams they probably will not trade him.

title: Original Pieces From a Modernist Mansion Go on the Block
description: Eric and Nannette Brill have spent 13 years restoring a modernist mansion in Bedford Hills, N.Y., designed in 1933 by the architect Edward Durell Stone and the interior designer Donald Deskey. The house has most of its original furnishings, including leather sofas, aluminum andirons and a Bakelite dining table. The Brills, who are about to sell the house for around $4.8 million, will partially empty it by auctioning 36 pieces at Sotheby's tomorrow. Estimates for the living room contents (the Shar-Pei, Rusty Brill, not included) include $5,000 to $7,000 for a steel side table and $30,000 to $50,000 for two aluminum floor lamps. James Zemaitis, Sotheby's director of 20th-century design, said he hopes museums will buy multiple lots "and consider doing more modernist period rooms."

title: Prosecutor in C.I.A. Leak Case Meets With New Grand Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 - The special prosecutor in the C.I.A. leak case returned on Wednesday to the federal courthouse for an initial session with a new grand jury in the criminal inquiry.

If that was meant to inspire his teammates during an unexpectedly mediocre start to the season, or to merely awaken them, the message worked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRINGTON, PEGGY
description: HARRINGTON--Peggy, was a brilliant star in the life of the Interfaith Center of New York, from its beginning in January 1997 until her death last week. A woman of rich imagination and hard work, Peggy was an inspiration to board, staff, and program participants of all religious traditions, ethnicities, and ages--and of particular support to the Center's founder and president, Dean James Parks Morton, with whom she had also worked as Program Assistant at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine since 1991. A gifted writer and cultural critic of theater, art, and politics, plus a tireless worker for environmental sustainability and social justice, Peggy was deeply respected and loved and will be sorely missed by her many friends and the board and staff of the Interfaith Center of New York. Memorial Service Sunday, December 18th, 2:00 PM, St. Mary's Episcopal Church, 521 West 126th St. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Interfaith Center of New York, 20 East 79th St, NY, NY 10021.

title: 'Gitmo' beneath the surface

But they also had a less predictable result: alarm bells rung by Britain's arts world about the threat posed to freedom of expression, notably by the proposed new crime of "glorifying terrorism."

It was written by Dr. Douglas Farrago, a family physician in Auburn, Me., and was first published in 2002 in his bimonthly publication the Placebo Journal, and subsequently appeared in his book "The Placebo Chronicles: Strange but True Tales from the Doctors' Lounge." Arnold Schwarzenegger met with prosecutors and defense lawyers but issued no decision on commuting the sentence of Stanley Williams, whose scheduled execution on Tuesday has drawn international attention. Mr. Williams, 51, also known as Tookie, is a co-founder of the Crips gang and was convicted of murdering four people in 1979. World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Industrial Output Rises
description: German industrial production rose more than expected in October, supporting the European Central Bank's forecast that European growth will accelerate through next year. Production at factories, utilities, construction sites and mines gained 1.1 percent from September, when it rose 1.5 percent, the economy and technology ministry said. In a two-month comparison, which smoothes out short-term fluctuations, manufacturing output increased 1.3 percent from the July-to-August period, the ministry reported.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Possible Bid For Exchange
description: Macquarie Bank, Australia's biggest investment bank, said that it might make a 1.48 billion ($2.6 billion) takeover offer for the London Stock Exchange. Macquarie "could be prepared to offer 580 pence" a share in cash, subject to conditions, the bank said. That is lower than the exchange's closing price of 612 pence yesterday. The bank said it maintained its interest in a possible consortium offer for the exchange, which runs a $2.9 trillion market. Earnings at Macquarie, which is based in Sydney, have quadrupled in four years through investments in highways and airports.

The Listings: Dec. 9 -- Dec. 15; PAULA SCHER: 'THE MAPS'
description: Paula Scher's engaging paintings resemble big maps of places like Europe, Africa and the United States or metropolitan areas like Los Angeles, Washington and Manhattan, but you would not want to rely on one for navigating the real world. Like Jasper Johns's paintings based on a standard map of the United States, they are paintings in the form of maps and not maps in the form of paintings. Measuring as large as 9 by 12 feet, the paintings are textured by innumerable hand-painted place names, laced by roads and borderlines and punctuated by all kinds of signs and symbols. Sometimes you find nongeographical information, like statistics from the last presidential election covering Gulf of Mexico waters in a map of Florida (above). Stylistically, the paintings have a zany, Outsider-like quality, though Ms. Scher is in fact a successful graphic designer whose rsum includes record album covers, a stint as art director for Time Inc. and logos for corporations and nonprofit groups. But though the Howard Finster-like navet is a sophisticated act, the paintings still look as if they were made by someone who lacks a clear grasp of the real world's geographical makeup. But then again, who does not have that chronically disoriented feeling that uncharted territories are growing at a faster rate than our ability to map them? (Maya Stendhal, 545 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 366-1549, through Jan. 21.)

description: A Medical Journal Says Merck Withheld Data On Heart Risks of Its Pain Drug Vioxx Almost four years before pulling Vioxx off the market over safety concerns, Merck misrepresented the results of a crucial clinical trial of the drug to play down its heart risks, the New England Journal of Medicine said. The journal's comments may play a critical role in thousands of lawsuits that Merck faces over Vioxx, a once-popular arthritis and pain drug. [Page A1.]

title: Seaside at 25: Troubles in Paradise
description: SEASIDE, Fla., which will be 25 years old in 2006, is America's most imitated town. With its pastel-colored houses and front porches overlooking narrow, brick-paved streets, it has influenced hundreds of communities, which combine a nostalgia for small-town life with a serious effort to reduce suburban sprawl -- and dependence on the auto -- by putting buildings close together.

title: Intimations of Betrayals Big and Small
description: When the singer David Gahan raised his arms to the sky during "Personal Jesus," Depeche Mode's smash from 1989, it may have looked as if he was positing himself as a savior to his synth-pop flock. Of course, that song is actually a simple lament for the kind of everyday isolation that Depeche Mode has, over its 25-year career, magnified into arena-size catharsis. Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, the crowd shouted along with its demand for connection, "Reach out and touch faith."

title: 20 Reported Killed as Chinese Unrest Escalates
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 9 - Residents of a fishing village near Hong Kong said that as many as 20 people had been killed by paramilitary police in an unusually violent clash that marked an escalation in the widespread social protests that have roiled the Chinese countryside. Villagers said that as many as 50 other residents remain unaccounted for since the shooting. It is the largest known use of force by security forces against ordinary citizens since the killings around Tiananmen Square in 1989. That death toll remains unknown, but is estimated to be in the hundreds.

title: 36 Hours in Tampa, Fla.
description: POOR Tampa. Upstaged by glitzy, sophisticated Miami and kid-frenzied Orlando, Tampa often seems like the forgotten middle child. Don't let that fool you -- this late bloomer has an easy charm and knows it. Downtown, the lazy Hillsborough River winds through a patchwork of history-filled neighborhoods, dotted with colorful cafes and museums. Visitors dive into rich cultural heritage with a Tampa Cuban sandwich (heavy on Genoa salami along with the usual ham) in Ybor City, or wander along the quaint, shop-filled streets of South Tampa. A few miles west, near St. Petersburg, powder-soft beaches lean into warm Gulf of Mexico waters. By the time night falls and the outdoor bars light up with music, you get the feeling this young urban paradise has just been biding its time.

Paid Notice: Deaths   WURLITZER, ANNA LEE
description: WURLITZER--Anna Lee. The Board, Officers, Medical Staff, staff and residents of The Fieldhome and its affiliates note with great sorrow the passing of its devoted Board Member, Mrs. Rembert Wurlitzer. Mrs. Wurlitzer served on the Board of The Fieldhome for more than 50 years, initially on The Women's Auxiliary Board, commencing her service just after World War II. Mrs. Wurlitzer stayed actively involved on the Board of The Fieldhome as it evolved and eventually moved from the city to Westchester County. Lee Wurlitzer will be remembered for her passion and commitment to the care of the elderly, for her wise and compassionate guidance and counsel, and for her generosity for time and spirit. All associated with The Fieldhome have lost a dear and devoted friend and express their deepest sympathy to the family of Lee Wurlitzer. Frederick N. Rossetter, President Field Home-Holy Comforter Ian D. Smith, President Catharine Field Home John R. Ahearn, C.E.O. Fieldhome

title: Riding the High Country, Finding and Losing Love
description: THE lonesome chill that seeps through Ang Lee's epic western, "Brokeback Mountain," is as bone deep as the movie's heartbreaking story of two cowboys who fall in love almost by accident. It is embedded in the craggy landscape where their idyll begins and ends. It creeps into the farthest corners of the wide-open spaces they share with coyotes, bears and herds of sheep and rises like a stifled cry into the big, empty sky that stretches beyond the horizon.

description: O'NEILL--Terence P. On December 7, 2005 of Rye, NY. Born in Cork City, Ireland. At age 26 he opened his first restaurant, The Green Derby, and went on to own many successful restaurants. He was also involved in the development of other business enterprises, including ventures in real estate, travel, golf, and airline industries. He was a founding partner in Waterville Golf Links and the creator of The Father Son International Golf Tournament. Beloved husband of Barbara Mary, devoted father of Terence Kane. Dear brother of Nellie Curzon, Nora Morey, Breda Dewis and the late Gerry, Kathleen and May. Family will receive friends from 3-7PM on Friday, December 9, 2005 at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. title: Chris Rock Will Not Return as Oscar Host

title: Arts, Briefly; NBC's Novelty Beats the Repeats
description: For the first time in a long time, "Law & Order" was Wednesday's most-watched show, with an estimated audience of 12.07 million. But the episode, a typical New York story in which real estate led to murder, gained that distinction because its popular Wednesday rivals were repeats. "Law & Order" helped NBC garner the most viewers over all, but ABC drew the largest number of 18- to 49-year-olds. Its repeat of "Lost" (10.97 million) was followed by an "Alias" rerun (6.44 million). The spy show performed as well after "Lost" as it did in its Thursday time period, when it was showing new episodes. On UPN, the finale of "America's Next Top Model," in which the shy and awkward Nicole Linkletter, right, was crowned the winner, brought in 6.35 million viewers. UPN won the 8 p.m. hour in adults 18 to 34 and women 18 to 49, and, for the night, came in fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic. It beat CBS in that measurement, which showed the second part of "Pope John Paul II" to a mere 6.33 million viewers. With Oprah Winfrey's Dec. 1 appearance on David Letterman's "Late Show" drawing 13.46 million viewers, the show beat NBC's "Tonight Show With Jay Leno" for the week that ended on Dec. 2, its first such triumph since February 2000.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Home Health Workers Strike
description: New York's largest health-care union, 1199 United Healthcare Workers East, began a four-day strike yesterday against People Care, a home-health agency that cares for the elderly and disabled in their homes. The union said that about 800 of People Care's 1,100 workers walked out to protest the company's failure to sign a contract that several other home-health agencies have signed. A company spokesman said that only 200 workers walked out. The union says People Care pays $6.50 an hour, and the contract calls for $10 an hour beginning in 2007. People Care said wages were competitive with the rest of the industry." Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Long Island: Layoffs Set For Health System
description: The North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System will lay off 152 employees on Dec. 31 because of financial problems, hospital officials said yesterday. The layoffs will affect management, clerical and support staff positions at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset and the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park. Terry Lynam, a hospital spokesperson, said there would be no effect on patient care because no bedside nurses would be laid off. The majority of those to be laid off are nonunion employees. The North Shore-LIJ Health System comprises 15 hospitals throughout Long Island and is the largest employer in the region, with 35,000 employees. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

We are an overwhelmingly Catholic country with a history that has been marked -- and continues to be marked -- by the power of its military.

title: Two Sides' Viewpoints on the War in Vietnam
description: "There never was a war that was not inward," the poet Marianne Moore wrote in the early 1940's. She could have been writing about the late 1960's. As the Vietnam war eviscerated Southeast Asia, it also tunneled into the American psyche like a devouring worm and made the country crazy with pain.

title: Defying Laws of Physics, and Seeking a Magic Space
description: CHRISTOPHER HARRISON, a once-upon-a-time Peter Pan who grew up and created the Manhattan aerial dance troupe AntiGravity, is performing pirouettes on his exotic Segway scooter in front of AntiGravity's longtime home -- due for demolition -- westward on 36th Street near 11th Avenue. His great-uncles were cowboys. Neat that he rides a battery-fueled urban version of a bucking bronco. And never falls off, especially not onstage: three Segways, as well as bungee cords and AntiGravity boots, are key players in several of the troupe's routines.
