title: The Listings: Dec. 9 -- Dec. 15; JAZZ GALLERY DUO PIANO SERIES
description: The Jazz Gallery, a nonprofit performance space on the far west fringe of SoHo, has always taken pride in pianism. For the last nine years, this narrow, second-story club has touted a seven-foot Baldwin with pedigree: it was the house piano at the beloved Greenwich Village club Bradley's for 18 years, and before that a possession of the alto saxophonist Paul Desmond. Another acquisition at roughly the same time -- a five-foot Yamaha that had belonged to the singer Carmen McRae -- made the Jazz Gallery one of the very few clubs in the city with two good pianos. This bounty was quickly put to practical use, with a duo series that has been a distinctive feature of Jazz Gallery programming. Next week, as part of the organization's 10th-anniversary season, the series returns with five piano pairings, each promising a slightly different chemistry. Tuesday night will feature Jason Lindner (above right) and Luis Perdomo (left), players known for percussive fluency and a command of Latin rhythm. On Wednesday, the versatile hard-bop veteran George Cables meets a highly regarded newcomer, Danny Grissett. Thursday's program pairs Orrin Evans and Gerald Clayton, who both balance traditional grounding with contemporary vision. The series will conclude with the experimentalists Amina Claudine Myers and Vijay Iyer, next Friday; and Mr. Clayton again, this time with the urbane elder Kenny Barron, Dec. 17. Before the run even begins, an uptown site, Merkin Concert Hall, will offer the latest installment of its own duet series (see Kenny Werner and Jean-Michel Pilc, below), so piano enthusiasts have something going every night next week. (Tuesday through Dec. 17 at 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063; cover, $15 to $20.)

title: U.S. Delegation Walks Out of Climate Talks
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 9 - Two weeks of treaty talks on global warming neared an end today with the world's current and projected leaders in emissions of greenhouse gases, the United States and China, still refusing to take any mandatory steps to avoid dangerous climate change.

title: Britain's Top Court Rules Information Gotten by Torture Is Never Admissible Evidence
description: LONDON, Dec. 8 - Britain's highest court thrust itself into the middle of a roiling international debate on Thursday, declaring that evidence obtained through torture -- no matter by whom -- was not admissible in British courts. It also said Britain had a "positive obligation" to uphold antitorture principles abroad as well as at home.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,127 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: A Showpiece for Percussion, With More Than a Bit of Dash
description: Christoph Eschenbachis in his third season as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, and grumblings from the musicians about his work have circulated among insiders and made it in to press reports. He is a richly experienced and comprehensive musician. Still, players are said to find him overly assertive and prone to hypercharged performances.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Banned Group Linked To New Blast
description: The police said they suspected that the banned extremist group Jamaat ul-Mujahedeen was behind a suicide bomb attack on a busy street in the northern town of Netrokana that killed 7 people and wounded 50, including commuters on their way to work. The group, which seeks the imposition of Islamic law, was also blamed for suicide attacks last week at a bar association office in Gazipur and a courthouse in Chittagong. The latest attack occurred outside a secular cultural center. The police said they suspected that two of those killed were suicide bombers. David Montero (NYT)

title: Message to Red Cross: About Time
description: It really is too bad that Syria and a number of other Arab states are still fighting the same tired old battles they've waged since 1948 to keep Israel out of international organizations. Damascus, for example, still seems to think it's worth spending its rapidly dwindling diplomatic capital on trying to bar Israel's entry into the relief agency movement represented by the Red Cross and Red Crescent symbols. We're just glad the rest of the world has finally come to its senses and approved a step that will allow Israel to become a member.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: New Cabinet Crumbles
description: President Mwai Kibaki faced a revolt as many of the ministers and assistant ministers he had named to his cabinet refused to take up the positions because they said he had not adequately consulted with dissenting lawmakers. Mr. Kibaki dissolved his cabinet last month after voters overwhelmingly rejected his proposed new constitution. On Wednesday, he announced a new slate of ministers that ousted all those who campaigned against him. The resulting political standoff has left Mr. Kibaki, 74, who was elected in December 2002 and plans to run again in 2007, struggling to govern. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Group Has Lead With Grocer Bid
description: An investor group led by Cerberus Capital Management took the lead yesterday in the auction for Albertsons Inc., the giant supermarket company, with a bid worth about $9.6 billion, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, JUDY
description: KAPLAN--Judy. The entire Maria Fareri Children's Hospital family mourns the loss of Judy Kaplan, daughter of one of the hospital's dear benefactors, Naomi Kaplan. Our deepest condolences to the Kaplan family at this difficult time.

title: Children's Events
description: Theater

title: Virtual Achievement for Hire: It's Only Wrong if You Get Caught
description: So there I was Sunday night, minding my own business in the World of Warcraft online computer game, killing a few rock elementals in the Badlands, when I received two unsolicited private messages from a player with the unlikely name Hfasdlf.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Telecommunications Stake Is Sold
description: Egypt's government raised 4.5 billion Egyptian pounds ($782 million) in the initial offering of the national telephone monopoly, Telecom Egypt, the country's biggest sale of a state-owned asset. The government sold 299 million shares, about 20 percent of the company, to individual investors, money managers, and Telecom Egypt workers, the company said in a statement. The initial offering values the phone company at about $4.6 billion.

title: Around the World in 90 Minutes
description: Around the World In 90 Minutes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHU, ELLEN F.
description: CHU--Ellen F. Of Stamford, CT. died peacefully on December 5th at the age of 74. Born in Nanking China, was graduated from Albertus Magnus College, she worked for the United Nations, Northwest Airlines and had a 30 year career with the Department of Justice as a language translator. Loving and devoted daughter of Yen Fu. Beloved wife of Shih-Lin (Fred) Chu and sister of Lorraine F. Lu. Inspiring and dedicated mother of Freda (Kevin Brown) and Edward (Kimberly Ratcliffe). Adoring grandmother of Nicholas, Arianna, Maddalena, Brandon and Samantha. Donations may be made in her memory to the Church of St. Patrick's in Armonk (POB 6, Armonk, NY 10504)

title: Corzine Selects Menendez to Replace Him in Senate
description: In his first major decision after being elected governor of New Jersey, Jon S. Corzine announced the selection of a Hudson County congressman to replace him in the United States Senate. Robert Menendez, the son of Cuban immigrants who became a lawyer then rose in the brass-tacks world of New Jersey politics, will fill Mr. Corzine's old post for at least a year, when he will face what may be a crowded run for re-election.

title: Sharing Friendship, and Then a Donor's Kidneys
description: As friendships go, the one sparked at a Brooklyn dialysis center was one Fred D'Amico and Izya Dukorsky could have lived without.

title: Where to Hear (and Sing) the Songs of the Season
description: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City, compiled by Jeremy Eichler. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) More holiday events this weekend are in The Listings on Pages 29 and 30. (Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.) An expanded listing is available online: nytimes.com/arts.

title: Currencies: Dollar trades mixed on outlook for rates
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a rift in the American Civil Liberties Union over fund-raising and leadership misstated the year that the organization defended the right of neo-Nazis to march through Skokie, Ill. It was 1977, not 1997.

title: Come On In, Dearie, for Gaudy Skits and Artsy Nudes
description: The first thing to know about "Mrs. Henderson Presents," a period British comedy laced with a dash of tragedy and straining with uplift, is that it is inspired by true events. Beginning in the 1930's and continuing through the early part of World War II, the film tracks the history of the famous Windmill Theater in London after it was given new life by a bored widow of means named Laura Henderson. Mrs. Henderson, played by Dame Judi Dench with her familiar mixture of starch and twee, swept the Victorian cobwebs out of the Windmill, located right off Piccadilly Circus, by conceiving of shows featuring live nude girls -- tastefully arranged, of course.

title: San Francisco Police Officers Are Suspended Over Skits
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 - In a black eye for a city that prides itself for tolerance, at least 18 police officers were suspended on Thursday for appearing in homemade videos for a Christmas party that parody the Police Department in skits described by officials as racist, sexist and homophobic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GALLIGAN, JOAN E. (NEE CULLINAN)
description: GALLIGAN--Joan E. (nee Cullinan). Age 58 of Glen Ridge, NJ. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved mother of Kimberly Cicala and her husband Joseph. Cherished grandmother of Kayleigh and Louis. Born in Elmhurst, NY, Mrs. Galligan lived in Brooklyn for 30 years and Glen Ridge the last five years. She was the Office Administrator for the law firm of Nixon and Peabody in NYC for the past five years. Previously, she held the same position for 15 years at the law firm of Mendes and Mount in NYC. Funeral Monday 10 a.m. from the Megaro Memorial Home, megaromemorialhome.com 503 Union Ave. Belleville. Mass 11 a.m. St. Lucy's Church Newark. Interment Glendale Cemetery Bloomfield. Visitation Saturday 2-4 and 7-9 and Sunday 1-5 pm.

title: Dance Listings
description: Dance

title: 4 bidders for Dunkin' Brands
Blairism without Blair
London Stock Exchange rejects bid from bank
Bruce Arena's European Adventure
description: Leipzig, Germany - FOR some people, returning to old Europe means the clang of the trams, the pungency in the coffee houses, the intimacy of ancient streets where Bach and Mendelssohn walked.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) THREE WISHES -- "I Wish to Be Bill Gates." In the season finale, three very young people enjoy a taste of their wildest career dreams. An aspiring actress is given a role on NBC's daytime soap "Passions." A future astronaut is sent to space camp. Kiyaan Vazirzadeh, a 10-year-old who wants to run Microsoft when he grows up, gets to try out the job for a day and meet the company's founder -- his idol, Bill Gates (above right, with Kiyaan and Amy Grant, the show's host) -- in the process.

title: ElBaradei warns Iran on stalling nuclear inquiry
Crime Database Often Wrong on Immigration, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 - More than 8,000 people have been mistakenly tagged for immigration violations as a result of the Bush administration's strategy of entering the names of thousands of immigrants in a national crime database meant to help apprehend terrorism suspects, according to a study released on Thursday.

title: Clemens Could Finish Where It All Began
description: ROGER CLEMENS may yet decide to retire and mean it this time, but in mulling his decision in the next weeks or months, he may want to consider an option that most likely hasn't crossed his mind.

title: Suicide Bombing Attack on a Bus in Baghdad's Main Terminal Kills 30
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 8 - A suicide bomber shoved aside a fare collector at Baghdad's main bus terminal on Thursday, forced himself onto a crowded bus and blew himself up, causing an enormous explosion that killed at least 30 people and reduced the bus to a charred, mangled husk, witnesses and police officials said.

title: Our Vision in Space (and Here on Earth)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bid for Prewar Iraq Files Raises Political Heat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 - Democrats pressed their demand on Thursday for White House documents on prewar intelligence on Iraq in the House Committee on International Relations, with one member only slightly outdoing his colleagues by repeatedly accusing President Bush and his top aides of lying about the threat posed by Saddam Hussein.

title: Youths Make Spirited Case at Climate Meeting
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 8 - On Wednesday night, as negotiations over the future of two international agreements on global warming ground on, it was time for a break.

title: Short-Track Speedskaters Face Trials to Make Team
description: When the American short-track speedskaters converge on a small rink in Marquette, Mich., next week, they will race in what has become increasingly rare in winter sports: a true Olympic trials.

title: Cashman, Now in Charge, Deals Womack
description: DALLAS, Dec. 8 - Before they left the winter meetings on Thursday, the Yankees found a taker for Tony Womack, a player they never had much use for in the first place. The deal symbolized the changes in the Yankees' front-office hierarchy.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Officials To Lobby On Immigration
description: The Republican mayor of Danbury, Conn., and the Democratic county executive of Suffolk County said yesterday that they would create a national coalition of local officials to lobby Congress and the White House to reform immigration laws. Mayor Mark D. Boughton and County Executive Steve Levy have sought to curb the impact of illegal immigrants in their areas by using code enforcement and other means to address overcrowded housing and other issues. They said they would invite 3,000 local officials to "a summit on illegal immigration" to be held in Washington in February, according to a news release. They said their agenda included stronger border enforcement and "federal financial assistance to local governments impacted by the current lack of federal border enforcement." William Yardley (NYT)

title: Strangers in the Dazzling Night: A Mix of Oil and Misery
description: EBOCHA, Nigeria - The sun had almost set, and another glum happy hour arrived at One for the Road. Veronica, its proprietor, put out her white plastic chairs and tables, checked her stock of chilled beer and waited for paying customers. There was no need to switch on the lights. Across from her tavern, day and night, burns a ghastly, eternal flame.

title: When Christmas Falls on Sunday, Megachurches Take the Day Off
description: Some of the nation's most prominent megachurches have decided not to hold worship services on the Sunday that coincides with Christmas Day, a move that is generating controversy among evangelical Christians at a time when many conservative groups are battling to "put the Christ back in Christmas."

title: Some Projects in the Works
description: Some Projects in the Works

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUFER, HARRY
description: LAUFER--Harry. The Board of Governors and Members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the passing of our longtime member and dear friend, Harry Laufer. His smile, wit and wry sense of humor will be sorely missed. Robert Fagenson, President Jane Guadagno, Secretary

title: Woman, 58, Is Found Slain in Peaceful New Jersey Town
description: A woman was found slain Wednesday in her house in a New Jersey suburb that has had only one other homicide in the last decade, investigators said.

title: After the Shame, Vikings Pursue Virtue in Victory
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 8 - The ultimate comeback story of the N.F.L. season includes all the most compelling elements -- drugs, sex, ticket scalping and an extended winning streak.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Parking Rules To Recognize Hindu Holiday
description: Beginning next fall, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended for the annual Hindu festival of lights known as Diwali. The City Council yesterday voted unanimously to override a mayoral veto that would have blocked the law. Diwali joins a list of 33 other parking holidays. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and sanitation officials had opposed the proliferation of parking holidays, saying they hamper the ability to keep the streets clean. But Council members and Hindu residents demanded equal treatment for their religious holiday. The fine for disregarding alternate-side parking rules is $65 for a single violation below 96th Street in Manhattan, and $45 elsewhere. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: When Future Generations View This Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review; Lari Pittman
description: Gladstone 515 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through Dec. 23

title: Our Vision in Space (and Here on Earth)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ogre to Slay? Outsource It to Chinese
description: FUZHOU, China - One of China's newest factories operates here in the basement of an old warehouse. Posters of World of Warcraft and Magic Land hang above a corps of young people glued to their computer screens, pounding away at their keyboards in the latest hustle for money.

title: Cost of Internal Control Audits to Fall, Study Says
description: Companies will pay less for audits of their internal controls in the second year the audits are required, a study for the world's four top accounting firms said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRINGTON, PEGGY
description: HARRINGTON--Peggy, was a brilliant star in the life of the Interfaith Center of New York, from its beginning in January 1997 until her death last week. A woman of rich imagination and hard work, Peggy was an inspiration to board, staff, and program participants of all religious traditions, ethnicities, and ages--and of particular support to the Center's founder and president, Dean James Parks Morton, with whom she had also worked as Program Assistant at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine since 1991. A gifted writer and cultural critic of theater, art, and politics, plus a tireless worker for environmental sustainability and social justice, Peggy was deeply respected and loved and will be sorely missed by her many friends and the board and staff of the Interfaith Center of New York. A Memorial Service Sunday, December 18, 2:00 PM, St. Mary's Episcopal Church, 521 West 126th St. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Green Belt Movement of Kenya, Poets and Writers, and PanCan.

title: Urban Loneliness, Ghostly Women and Lots of Blood
description: "Marebito," the latest movie by the Japanese horror auteur Takashi Shimizu ("Ju-on: The Grudge"), is in some ways a modest film, with a tiny cast, a 92-minute running time, minimal effects and a grainy, homemade look.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Utility To Trim 6,500 Jobs
description: lectricit de France, Europe's largest power company, said that it planned to cut as many as 6,500 jobs, about 4 percent of its work force, in the next two years by not replacing most of its retiring workers. Electricit de France plans to cut 6,000 to 6,500 jobs by replacing only one out of every three or four workers who retire. The company, which forecasts 9,000 employees will leave by 2007, has said that it will not lay off any workers and all departures will be voluntary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHN, MAX LEWIS
description: KAHN--Max Lewis. 82, died of cancer on Tuesday, December 6, 2005 at his home in Purchase, NY. Beloved husband of Marcella Kahn, to whom he was married for 58 years, devoted father of Lawrence Kahn, Philip Kahn and Joan Kahn; and loving grandfather to Daniel, Lisa, Alexander, Jeffrey and Andrew. Max (Mac) Kahn was born September 26, 1923 in Philadelphia, PA. At age 11 his family moved to New York City. Mac served in the U.S. Army Artillery during World War II in England, France and Germany. He spent his entire working career (57 years) with Alkahn Labels Inc., a firm supplying the apparel and home furnishings industries, working his way up from assistant designer to President and C.E.O. During the 27 years he led the firm, its sales grew by tenfold, making it the leading U.S. manufacturer of woven labels. Mac loved to travel with his wife, listen to classical music, enjoy the cultural offerings of New York City, and was an avid tennis player. Above all he was a loving husband, father and grandfather. A memorial service will be held on Sunday Dec. 11 at 3:00PM at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester (914-967-4382). In lieu of flowers donations may be made to White Plains Hospital Center or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Chinese protesters report a massacre
Qaeda-Iraq Link U.S. Cited Is Tied to Coercion Claim
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 - The Bush administration based a crucial prewar assertion about ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda on detailed statements made by a prisoner while in Egyptian custody who later said he had fabricated them to escape harsh treatment, according to current and former government officials.

title: Medical Journal Criticizes Merck Over Vioxx Data
description: An influential medical journal accused Merck yesterday of misrepresenting the results of a crucial clinical trial of the painkiller Vioxx to play down its heart risks.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: Movies

title: Small Tech-Astute Agency Wins a Small-Car Account
description: THE new agency for the Mini Cooper is just the type that is remaking the way marketers approach advertising: smaller, creatively focused, independent and knowledgeable enough about technology to develop some unusual new ways to reach consumers.

title: A Tragedy and a Romp, Paired in English One-Acts
description: Some musicians divide the world of Western music into two camps: French and German. This division is eminently relevant to the double bill that the Manhattan School of Music Opera Theater unveiled on Wednesday night -- although it may not seem, at first blush, to apply to an American production of a pair of English one-act operas.

title: Senator Clinton's Flag Maneuver
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOONG, FU, YUAN
description: SOONG--Fu-Yuan. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Robert Sterling Clark Foundation mourn the death of Soong on December 5, 2005. A gifted composer of chamber music, opera and symphonic work, Soong's pieces have been performed in halls throughout the United States including Lincoln Center, the Kennedy Center and Carnegie Hall. His work has also been performed across Europe and Asia. During the past year, his compositions for piano were performed on a world tour by renowned pianist Fou-Ts'ong. Soong is survived by his wife and life companion, Darcy Helen Hector, a long time program officer at the Clark Foundation. He is also survived by their son, Corey Ming-Sheng Soong. We will miss Soong, are saddened by his passing and offer our heartfelt sympathy to Darcy and Corey at this difficult time.

title: Whale Watching: Season of the Giants
description: GRAY whales engage in the longest migration of any mammal in the world, swimming 6,000 miles from feeding grounds in the icy waters north of Alaska to warm breeding lagoons off Baja California, Mexico, and 6,000 back. A few weeks ago, they began the annual conga line south that will last well into winter, providing visitors with a chance to view them all along the west coast of the United States.

title: Rock/Pop Listings
description: Pop

title: Video sets off furor between Malaysia and China
Senator Clinton's Flag Maneuver
description: To the Editor:

title: Driving From Ucross to Sheridan in the Depths of an Owlish Darkness
description: I can never quite get over how different the world looks at 3 a.m. It's the same old world, a few degrees colder though no darker than it was when I went to bed. But a squall blew through while I was asleep, and now the ground is covered with dry new snow. The car starts sluggishly. I sweep it off with a broom from the porch, clumsily, as if I had forgotten overnight which-handed I am. The tires squeal on the snow -- it is 3 degrees -- and I turn onto Highway 14, which will take me northwest from Ucross into Sheridan, Wyo., and to the interstate. The highway is a smooth white plain. There is one set of car tracks on it, heading the other direction.

title: Fighting on the Wrong Front
description: New Haven - THE Supreme Court is now considering whether to uphold the Solomon Amendment, a federal law barring federal funds to universities that deny the military the same access that civilian employers enjoy to recruit students.

title: Briefly: Dutch delay decision on Afghan peace force
World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Prime Minister Promises Handgun Ban
description: Prime Minister Paul Martin made a campaign promise to ban handguns in Canada to put an end to a rash of gang shootings in Toronto. There are already strong restrictions on ownership of handguns, so it is uncertain what impact an outright ban would have on the smuggling of guns north from the United States. Toronto, Canada's largest city, has had 74 murders this year, 50 of which were gun-related. That is double the number of murders by gunfire from the year before. The ban is likely to anger gun enthusiasts in the west, where Mr. Martin's Liberal Party is weak anyway. Politically, the announcement should play well in and around Toronto, a crucial battleground between the Liberals and the opposition Conservative Party in the general election on Jan. 23. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Bush Campaigns for a Kennedy, but This One's a Republican
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 - President Bush campaigned today in Minnesota, a state he failed to carry in 2000 and 2004, in an effort to help elect a Republican to the Senate.

title: Times Co. Names Research Executive
description: The New York Times Company has appointed Michael Zimbalist, president of the Online Publishers Association, to the new position of vice president for research and development operations.

title: Suspected militant appears in Thai court
Corrections
description: A television review on Wednesday about "Epitafios," a detective series from Argentina on HBO Signature, referred incorrectly to Jorge Luis Borges in citing Argentina's long tradition of detective fiction. While he wrote detective stories, his writings did not include any novels.

title: Thousands march for Irish labor
Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Nov. 29 misspelled the surname of the chairman of the Alliance for Downtown New York, who was appointed by the governor to the board of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. He is Robert R. Douglass, not Douglas.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: New Medicaid Plan To Begin
description: The Legislature approved Gov. Jeb Bush's proposal to overhaul the state's Medicaid program. Mr. Bush had wanted to roll out the program statewide, but lawmakers limited it to two counties. The proposal affects mostly women and children, although others, like hemophiliacs and H.I.V. patients, will also be enrolled in either a Medicaid H.M.O. or a provider-run managedcare plan. Mr. Bush, a Republican, received approval from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services on the plan but also needed it from the Legislature. Mr. Bush downplayed the smaller roll out. "We talk about only two counties, but if we add up the Medicaid beneficiares of Broward and Duval Counties, it is probably equal to more than 25 states," he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENFELD, STANLEY
description: CHRISTENFELD--Stanley. On December 7, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Loving father of Janet and Sam Argintar and Emily and Michael Grad. Dear brother of Adele and brother-in-law of Dr. Murray Golbey. Adoring grandfather of Caroline, Laura, and James. Service Friday 10AM at the "Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Virgin Group Gets Financing for Low-Fare Airline in U.S.
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 8 - The British holding company Virgin Group said Thursday that it had raised the $177.3 million needed to start a low-fare airline in the United States, disquieting news to domestic carriers hoping for an industrywide reduction in fleet to help push up fares.

title: Art in Review; 'Emerge 6'
description: Aljira, a Center for Contemporary Art 591 Broad Street, Newark Through Jan. 14

title: Brooklyn Congressional Contest Tests Traditions of an Ethnic Turf
description: The central Brooklyn Congressional seat held by Representative Major R. Owens has a storied history in black politics. It is the seat that Shirley Chisholm captured in 1968 to become the first black woman elected to Congress. She became a national figure and ran for president four years later.

title: Off the Charts: Where's the lift from tax cuts?
New Course, New Guides, Old Wounds
description: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 7 - The women's World Cup ski circuit comes to the United States once a year, so neither freezing temperatures, nor a deepening chill in the family, nor cancer will keep 70-year-old Doris Rudsill Kildow from Aspen Mountain this weekend.

title: An Israeli Perspective on New Spielberg Political Thriller
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 - Israeli officials braced for the worst when they heard that Steven Spielberg was tackling Middle East violence in "Munich," his forthcoming thriller about the massacre at the 1972 Olympics and the retaliatory assassinations of Palestinian terrorists.

title: Fretful Passenger, Turmoil on Jet and Fatal Shots
description: MIAMI, Dec. 8 - Lingering near his departure gate at Miami International Airport on Wednesday, Rigoberto Alpizar appeared flustered and loath to make the last, brief leg of his long journey home.

title: A heritage that makes two cities kin
2 County Hospitals Expect to End Their Budget Deficits
description: Officials at two major hospitals in the New York region said this week that the financial troubles they had faced in recent years appeared to be abating. Westchester Medical Center is expecting a surplus, and the Nassau Health Care Corporation, which runs Nassau University Medical Center, expects to break even next year.

title: Street Scene; THE CHURN
description: Deal Makers

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 39 Radicals Convicted In Sit-In
description: A Moscow court sentenced 39 left-wing activists who staged a sit-in last year to prison terms of from one-and-a-half years to three-and-a-half years on charges of mass disturbance. The defendants, members of the National Bolshevik Party, broke into the foyer of the Presidential Administration and barricaded the entrance for nearly an hour in an antigovernment protest. No violence or damage was reported, and the police quickly forced the protesters out. Most had their sentences immediately suspended, after a year in custody. Alexander Nurnberg (NYT)

title: Air Marshals Tell of Burden in Reacting to Mental Status
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 - Part of air marshals' training entails various attack exercises in which actors portray "bad guys" of differing kinds, including some who are mentally ill. But marshals say the mental status of a person they must confront on the job may have little effect on their response.

title: Roche step is positive signal on Herceptin
A Maker of Games Is Bought
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 - Electronic Arts, the video game publisher, said on Thursday that it had reached a $680 million deal to acquire Jamdat Mobile, which makes games to be played on mobile phones.

description: Correction Appended

Stocks: Wall Street gains on lower oil prices
From Conviction to Re-election and Beyond
description: Correction Appended

Compromise Reached on Renewing Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 - House and Senate negotiators reached a compromise agreement Thursday to extend the antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act, but critics from both parties said they found the plan unacceptable because it did not go far enough in protecting Americans' civil liberties.

title: In Detroit, the Lions Sleep Tonight, and Every Night
description: Over at FireMillen.com, they have introduced a new logo. It is a picture of Matt Millen, the Detroit Lions' president, with a Lions-blue X through it, and the plea "Save the Lions."

title: When Even The Gloomy Becomes Likable
description: Brad Paisley is country music's most likable overachiever: he's an affable guy who can sing, write, play guitar and, through it all, crack jokes. On Wednesday night he came to the Nokia Theater for a show that made most other big-name country shows seem downright lazy. One segment -- "How fast can we play?" -- wisely disguised an impressive display of virtuosity as a silly lark.

title: Gear for Warm Toes, Safe Wrists and More
description: HAVE you ever been in a ski lodge and seen people sprinkling chili powder in their boots? How about black pepper?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN WILSON, PHILLIP
description: VAN WILSON--Phillip, of New York City, died unexpectedly on December 5th. Mr. Wilson worked as a writer, photographer, commercial fisherman, and lighting designer. He directed Off-Broadway plays, and did lighting at New York's Fillmore East and the Woodstock Festival. He taught in the theatre department of the Walden School where he developed the "New Playwrights Project." He directed the film "Alley Cats" in 1975. Recently Mr. Wilson began postgraduate work on the study of race relations in America. Mr. Wilson was an active civil rights worker in the 1960's. He was widowed from Alice Lide and married Sharon Flynn in 1970. Surviving are wife Sharon Wilson; three sons: Mark, Paul and Isaac Wilson; a brother Paul Kaye Wilson of Nebraska; three grandchildren: Cailin, Lane and Auden Wilson; brothers and sistersin-law; and many friends. Funeral services Friday 10:30AM at Trinity Lutheran Church on West 100th St. Donations in memory of Phil Wilson may be sent to WWOZ c/o Louisiana Public Broadcasting, 7733 Perkins Rd., Baton Rouge, LA 70801-1199.

title: U.S. Criticized After Walking Out of Climate Talks
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 9 - Two weeks of treaty talks on global warming neared an end today with the world's current and projected leaders in emissions of greenhouse gases, the United States and China, still refusing to take any mandatory steps to avoid dangerous climate change.

title: Deconstructing the Realities of Politics and Terrorism
description: Originally broadcast as a three-part mini-series on the BBC, "The Power of Nightmares" is a sprawling, intellectually ambitious documentary about the political phenomenon usually referred to in journalistic shorthand as the war on terror. The source of the film's novelty -- and of its considerable provocation -- lies in its insistence that the enemy is more of a fantasy than an actual threat.

title: Rangers' Tandem a Hit in Nashville
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 9 - With a revival of "The Odd Couple" running on Broadway, the Rangers may have their own version this season.

title: The Future Is Now, as Curry and Frye Are Set to Start
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 8 - There is no telling when the wheel of whimsy in Larry Brown's head will stop spinning, but as the Knicks' past and present collide Friday night in Phoenix, their future might finally be on full display.

title: Labor to Press for Workers' Right to Join Unions
description: With the nation's labor unions divided and shrinking, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has organized 100 demonstrations nationwide this week to assert that the right of American workers to form unions is being systematically violated.

title: Entry Level: In the book market, the first word counts
National Briefs
description: WEST

title: Rice Appears to Reassure Some Europeans on Treatment of Terror Detainees

title: Anti-Americans? Not on my trip to Europe
Youth Movement on Hold as Mets Pursue Franco
description: DALLAS, Dec. 8 - Julio Franco could look across the diamond at Shea Stadium next season and see two players whose combined ages do not add up to his. Franco, the ageless wonder of baseball, may soon sign a two-year contract with the Mets.

title: 'JetBlue Factor' Expands Your Weekend Reach
description: FOR most people, there are two ways to get to a weekend home. You can drive, even if it means sitting in traffic from Friday to Sunday. Or you can hop on a bus or a train. But then there are those like Charles Gardel, a private investor from Manhattan who has turned his weekend trip into a highflying act.

title: Theater Listings
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a rift in the American Civil Liberties Union over fund-raising and leadership misstated the year that the organization defended the right of neo-Nazis to march through Skokie, Ill. It was 1977, not 1997.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Council Overrides Mayor's Veto
description: The City Council voted yesterday to override Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's veto of its decision to remove the landmark status of the Austin, Nichols Warehouse in Williamsburg. The override, which was expected, was 37 to 8, with 2 abstentions. The mayor vetoed on Monday the Council's decision on the warehouse, designed by Cass Gilbert in 1915. Preservationists implored Council members to vote against the override. Several Council members who did so explained their votes with passion. "I have never seen the Landmarks Commission landmark a property that didn't deserve to be a landmark," said Margarita Lpez. But David Yassky, whose district includes the building, said, "If we're going to landmark the industrial buildings along the waterfront, that will impede development." Robin Pogrebin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, BERNARD L.
description: COHEN--Bernard L. On December 8, 2005. Beloved husband of Pauline for over 57 years. Adored father of Diane & Jeffrey Schuman, June & Michael Cohen. Loving grandfather of Jamie & Matt, Allison, Kate, Amy, Nikki, & Stephanie and his aide Concordio. Co-owner of Baron & Port Lincoln Mercury with his partner of 55 years, Morris Baron. W.W. II Army Air Force Captain who flew 67 missions in the European theatre. His love of life inspired so many and made the world such a better place. His kindness to all will always be remembered and his legacy of love will live forever in our hearts. Services Sunday 10:30, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Textiles
description: COLD weather creates a need for coziness and texture. Winterize your country house and yourself with artfully woven goods rich in texture and color. Each of these items is created with the finest linen, wool and cotton fibers. Tactile examples of exquisite design, they are as pleasing to touch as they are to admire.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Race Tracks To Add Slot Machines
description: The Legislature approved a measure that would allow four parimutuel operations to install 6,000 slot machines by next summer. Gov. Jeb Bush is expected to sign it. Florida voters approved a constitutional amendment in 2004 that allowed Broward and Miami-Dade Counties to hold referendums on whether dog tracks, horse tracks and jai-alai frontons there could add slot machines. In March, voters in Broward County voted yes, while voters in Miami-Dade County voted no. Two horse tracks, one dog track and one jai-alai fronton in Broward County will be allowed to add up to 1,500 machines each.

title: Scot eyes a continent in turmoil
Nations Draw Their Spots in World Cup Tournament
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 9 - Brazil, the defending World Cup soccer champion, will play Croatia in its first game of the 2006 tournament, while the United States will face the Czech Republic, which is ranked second in the world and is regarded as an extremely dangerous opponent.

title: ViewPoints: Starting at impasse and going nowhere

Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTTENSTEIN, KALMAN, ''KAL.''
description: RUTTENSTEIN -- Kalman, "Kal." Senior Vice President, Fashion Direction. June 9, 1936--December 8, 2005. Kal has been part of our family for 28 years. He lived life on the edge of fashion and entertainment. He discovered. He taught. He mentored. He knew what was hot before it was. He loved dining and dishing at the restaurant of the moment. He had a unique sense of humor and was a master of style. He was larger than life, and life at Bloomingdale's without him will be different. We are all so sad. Michael Gould Chairman & CEO Bloomingdale's

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about the testimony of Karl Rove, President Bush's top political adviser, in the investigation of the leak of a C.I.A. agent's identity misstated the date when Mr. Rove went before the grand jury a second time. It was Oct. 15, 2004, not Oct. 14. (The error also appeared in an article on Nov. 3.)

title: The Pride and Terror of Those Who Fought to the Death
description: The Gladiators History's Most Dangerous Sport By Fik Meijer Illustrated. 267 pages. Thomas Dunne Books/St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: Light Reading Gone Wild
description: Some books are meant to be read closely. Some are meant to be skimmed. And some are meant to be opened at random so that they can reveal weird, little-known factoids that are meant to astonish. In the last case, unfortunately, the more common response is, "So what?"

title: Carnival and Splendor at the Gateway to the Smokies
description: GATLINBURG, where 3,400 people live year-round and a few million drop in, has the classic split personality of a frenetic tourist town set in a beautiful place. You can walk away the morning on a quiet trail where winter sunlight filters through a canopy of bare branches and spend the afternoon scooping up plastic rabbits in a crowded souvenir shop or staring at sharks in Ripley's Aquarium of the Smokies. Wiry, unshaven hikers pitch red nylon tents in splendid isolation on cloud-topped ridges, while down below, lines of cars snake their way toward town.

title: 36 Hours in Tampa, Fla.
description: POOR Tampa. Upstaged by glitzy, sophisticated Miami and kid-frenzied Orlando, Tampa often seems like the forgotten middle child. Don't let that fool you - this late bloomer has an easy charm and knows it. Downtown, the lazy Hillsborough River winds through a patchwork of history-filled neighborhoods, dotted with colorful cafes and museums. Visitors dive into rich cultural heritage with a Tampa Cuban sandwich (heavy on Genoa salami along with the usual ham) in Ybor City, or wander along the quaint, shop-filled streets of South Tampa. A few miles west, near St. Petersburg, powder-soft beaches lean into warm Gulf of Mexico waters. By the time night falls and the outdoor bars light up with music, you get the feeling this young urban paradise has just been biding its time.

title: Critical in Iran
Underneath the Mask of a Heroine
description: Swathed in silk and longing (mostly for a bald guy called Oscar), the big-screen version of "Memoirs of a Geisha" arrives with good intentions firmly in place. Based on the best seller by Arthur Golden, this lavishly appointed melodrama was directed by Rob Marshall, lately of "Chicago," and features the Chinese superstars Ziyi Zhang and Gong Li, and the Malaysian transplant Michelle Yeoh, as Japanese geishas swept up in jealous rivalries during the 1930's and 40's. In this cloistered world, men come and go as do history and warplanes, amid spectacularly unfortunate metaphors about male eels and female caves and one regrettably brief catfight in a kimono.

title: Surf Guitar and Mariachi Brass Meet Whispered Folky Vocals
description: On the surface, Calexico and Iron & Wine might seem unlikely to mesh. Calexico, from Arizona, plays rangy rock with surf-guitar reverb, steel guitar, vibraphone and mariachi trumpets. Iron & Wine is simply the Florida songwriter Sam Beam, whose songs usually revolve around gentle guitar and whispered imagery. Yet both Calexico and Iron & Wine invoke place, myth and memory in their songs: Calexico looking toward the Southwest, Mr. Beam toward the South. And both build far-reaching songs on modest patterns.

title: Use of Deadly Force In the Plane Shooting
description: To the Editor:

Corzine had selected Representative Robert Menendez as his replacement in the United States Senate, the focus of New Jersey's political establishment shifted to whether Mr. Menendez would face a challenge in the Democratic primary in June.

title: Appeals Court Voids Ruling In Favor of Gay Marriage
description: An appellate court yesterday reversed a lower court ruling that would have permitted same-sex marriage in New York City, saying it was up to the Legislature to change traditional views of marriage and family.

Now she is back at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with what she has described as "something really precious, small and detailed."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALEXANDER, BROOKE
description: ALEXANDER--Brooke, 93, on December 3, 2005. Beloved and dedicated husband of the late Elizabeth Burnett Alexander (Betty). He was predeceased by his daughter, the Reverend Brooke Alexander, and is survived by a son, Breckenridge Alexander, 3 grandchildren, Katherine Dodge, Alexander Leddy, and William Leddy, and eight great-grandchildren. A 1935 graduate of Princeton University, he was a lifelong resident and unabashed admirer of The City of New York. He spent his career in the service of Time, Inc., retiring in 1973 as Assistant Publisher of Fortune Magazine. He was a member of the New York National Guard (1936-1939) and the New York State Guard (1940-1945), a long-serving member of the vestry and lifelong communicant of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, a long-standing member and devotee of the Union Club, and a member since 1954 of The Society of the Cincinnati. A memorial service will be held Monday, December 12, at 11AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave at 90th St, NYC. Donations may be made to the Elizabeth B. Alexander Fund, NightingaleBamford School, 20 East 92 Street, NY, NY 10128.

title: Iraq's Powerful Shiite Coalition Shows Signs of Stress as Parliamentary Elections Loom
description: NAJAF, Iraq - As the debate got under way in a hotel assembly hall here recently, the governor of this Shiite holy city tried to stay on message when asked about his party's position on the hottest of the country's hot-button issues -- the American troop presence.

Israeli Missile Kills 2 Palestinians; Violence Threatens Rice Accord
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 - In increasing violence, an Israeli missile strike killed two Palestinian militants inside a house in the northern Gaza Strip on Thursday, and a Palestinian stabbed to death an Israeli soldier at a military checkpoint on the northern edge of Jerusalem.

title: Fast-Moving Winter Storm Turns Northeast White
description: A "vigorous" winter storm dumped fat, wet snowflakes throughout parts of the Northeast during the early morning commute, but the storm moved quickly out of the New York City region, giving way to sunshine, while New England continued to see snowy conditions in the afternoon.

Caring grandmother of Jesse and Eli. She leaves many who loved her and admired her. We will miss her beautiful smile. Memorial service on Saturday, December 17, at 1:30 P.M., at the Williams residence, 720 West End Ave. (at 95th Street), NYC.

description: If New York City transit workers go on strike, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to trade in his Upper East Side town house for a cot at the Office of Emergency Management's Brooklyn headquarters so he can walk to City Hall.

title: The Listings: Dec. 9 -- Dec. 15; HOOMAN SHARIFI
description: In a written statement about his hourlong solo, "We Failed to Hold This Reality in Mind," Hooman Sharifi explains that the audience has "to deal with memory, understanding, boredom and not understanding." Many arts presenters shudder at the very hint of audience boredom, but Vallejo Gantner, Performance Space 122's artistic director, says he is "very excited" to be showing the Iranian-born Mr. Sharifi's work as part of the space's Norway in New York festival of experimental theater and dance. Mr. Gantner describes the two-week event as the "opening volley" in creating more collaborative and touring opportunities between American and Scandinavian artists and presenters. He admits to a limited knowledge of contemporary Norwegian dance, but says he considers the festival "an indicative cross section of some of the best work that's happening in Norway at the moment." For his part, Mr. Sharifi, above, who immigrated to Norway by himself at 14, mixes Iranian music with improvisational, chaotic movement to create a work that Mr. Gantner reads as an "expression of alienation and the experience of being neither fully Iranian nor fully Norwegian." New Yorkers, whether or not they know Norway from North Dakota, can surely relate to that. (Tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m., P.S. 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 477-5288 or ps122.org)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OPPENHEIMER, EDGAR D. JR.
description: OPPENHEIMER--Edgar D. Jr. Passed away peacefully at 80 at his home in St. Petersburg, Florida, on December 5, 2005. He leaves his beloved wife of 54 years, Virginia Layton, his brother David E. Oppenheimer, his four children, Frances Oppenheimer, William L. and Barbara Oppenheimer, Carol Oppenheimer and Steve Zagerman, and Jill Oppenheimer and Alain Carriere. He also leaves ten grandchildren: Jesse, Arti, and Peter Boyd and Matthew Weigert; Michael and Claire Oppenheimer; Sophie and Willa Zagerman; and Olivier and Jean-Francois Carriere. He was preceded in death by his twin brother Frank. His parents were Dr. Edgar D. & Carolyn Weil Oppenheimer. Edgar served as a Naval Officer during World War II and remained an avid sailor all his life. He was a mechanical engineer and an expert in hightemperature welding. The family will hold a memorial service at the Academy of Senior Professionals at Eckert College (ASPEC) in St. Petersburg, Florida, on January 14, 2006. Contributions in memory should be made to the Hospice of the Florida Suncoast or the Florida Chapter of the ALS Foundation.

title: A Gala Success at La Scala; New Conductor Is Heralded
description: MILAN, Dec. 8 - For the first time in 19 years, the commanding gestures and flowing locks of Riccardo Muti did not stand between the audience and the stage at the gala opening of the Teatro Alla Scala's season, on Wednesday. Indeed, after a staff revolt prompted his resignation in April as the legendary opera house's longtime music director, his fans predicted that La Scala would never be the same.

title: Can't Tell the Red Sox, Even With a Scorecard
description: DALLAS, Dec. 8 - When the Boston Red Sox finally finish cobbling together a team for 2006, it will be significantly different from the club that won it all in 2004 and came up short last season. No, these are not Theo Epstein's Red Sox anymore.

title: Art in Review; Catherine Sullivan
description: The Chittendens Metro Pictures 519 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through Dec. 23

title: Greece and Bulgaria open bear-friendly crossing
Saks Holders Reject Annual Vote for Board
description: Saks Inc. shareholders voted yesterday against annual elections of the company's directors, who currently serve three-year terms. The measure, proposed by a New York City pension fund, garnered less support this year than in 2004.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Hospitals And Emergency Contraception
description: The State Department of Public Health must ensure that all Massachusetts hospitals offer emergency contraception, in accordance with a law that will go into effect next week. The department originally said Roman Catholic and private hospitals could choose not to offer the drug, known as the morning-after pill, because of a law allowing hospitals to opt out of programs that conflict with their mission. Gov. Mitt Romney said state lawyers concluded that the new legislation "superseded the prior legislation."

title: Dreaming and Frolicking on a Joyful Path to Spiritual Redemption
description: An elegantly suited upside-down man is poised on one shoulder, legs pushing straight up into the air, at the start of Ronald K. Brown's "Ife/My Heart," a new piece for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater that had its premiere on Wednesday night at City Center. The arrested hip-hop pose against the cool elegance of the dancer (Matthew Rushing), moodily spotlighted centerstage, aptly prefigures the work's blend of hyperkinetic energy and slower, more introspective musings.

title: Delicate Yet Direct Watercolors of a New York Dazzling Itself
description: Although a gifted and innovative watercolorist, the Canadian painter David Milne (1882-1953) was never on a star track. Arriving in New York City in 1903, the Ontario-born artist lived there for 13 years, moving among dynamos of the art world at the time, but always as an outsider. His quiet, spare vignettes of the city and its natural landscapes kept him at a distance from the avant-garde, which tended toward abstraction and salutes to the burgeoning skyline.

title: Whiff of Maple Syrup Is Back, and New York Smells a Rat
description: It's back and as maddening as ever, or so some noses supposed.

title: Before 9/11, Warnings on bin Laden
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 - More than three years before the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, American diplomats warned Saudi officials that Osama bin Laden might target civilian aircraft, according to a newly declassified State Department cable.

title: Chinese Abused for Complaints, Study Concludes
description: BEIJING, Dec. 8 - For centuries, Chinese with a grievance against the government have used an elaborate petition system in the hope, often in vain, of imperial redress.

title: Verizon Unpacks at Its Restored Ancestral Headquarters
description: Verizon, the corporate great-grandchild of the New York Telephone Company, came back yesterday to its ancestral home in Lower Manhattan -- an Art Deco landmark that was badly battered on 9/11 -- after a 33-year absence.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Prosecutors Seek To Seize Hotel
description: Federal prosecutors filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to seize the 194-room Greenpoint Hotel, arguing that an investigation by the Drug Enforcement Administration showed that the hotel, on Manhattan Avenue, has been used for trafficking in heroin and cocaine. Court papers charged that a drug organization led by Rafael Perez has openly distributed heroin and crack cocaine from rooms in the hotel, where 20 people have died of drug overdoses since 1998; there has also been one drug-related murder there, the court papers said. Mr. Perez was charged with narcotics trafficking last year and is awaiting trial. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, GEORGE F. III.
description: BAKER--George F. III. Lighthouse International mourns the death of George F. Baker III, a generous supporter of the Lighthouse mission to help people of all ages overcome the challenges of vision impairment, whose family commitment to the Lighthouse spans nearly a century. On behalf of the Lighthouse Board of Directors, our staff and clients, we offer our deepest sympathy to the family. Tara A. Cortes, President and CEO William B. Follett, Chairman, Board of Directors Lighthouse International

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: Does Peter Jacksons King Kong have a chance at Oscar time? The Carpetbagger to find out.

title: Making Room for Hipsters
description: Curbed LA, the blog that wants the City of Angels to feel more like Chelsea, found a book on Amazon this morning touting sprawl. And its not happy. The book, titled Sprawl, argues that many of the criticisms of suburban sprawl  e.g., that it is culturally deficient and environmentally noxious  are greatly exaggerated and ignore the very real benefits sprawl offers in terms of privacy, mobility and choice. (So says the Publishers Weekly review posted on Amazon. I didnt read the book.)But theres one argument that Curbed seems to like: sprawl makes room for hipsters:

title: 250 Square Feet and Happy
description: When the median price of homes hovers around $650,000 in Sonoma County, Calif., people who want to live in the rugged hills north of San Francisco have to look for creative alternatives. (Other than interest-only loans). Which brings us to Jay Shafers Tumbleweed Tiny Houses. Shafers little houses range, according to the Metro papers of the North Bay, from 70 square feet to 250 square feet. The 320-square-foot Gothic palace is actually rather striking as you can see in the online catalog.

title: Hissing Sound: Prices Drop
description: Many markets around the country are now moving into the phase that follows a run-up in prices, when a build-up in inventory leads to excess demand and then a drop in prices.Over the next several months there will be many reports like these. To save time, heres a round up of this weeks Hissing Sound.Boston: Homeowners trying to sell their houses are sharply reducing asking prices  in some cases, by $100,000 or more.Phoenix and San Diego: Some investor-owned properties are returning to the market for sale. With the pace of price appreciation slowing, some investors who were betting on quick profits are instead being squeezed.Loudoun County, Va.: Since 2000 its been the nations fastest-growing county, where eager homebuyers always seemed to outnumber happy sellers. Until now.

title: Mix Masters

title: Pulse
description: The perfect partridge for every pear tree: 12 gifts that will brighten the holiday season.

title: Latin America Tilting to the Left
description: Since 1998, three-quarters of South America has shifted to the left. That shift has a chance of spreading to Bolivia, Ecuador and north of the Panama Canal.

title: Churchills Folly, Cambridge Spies
description: It is time for another train ride, this time from Kings Cross in London to Cambridge on a train which calls itself the Cambridge Cruiser, a modest train that ambles along rather than cruises. Trains, it would seem, have a tendency to pretentious, or, more charitably, aspirational names. A few months ago I travelled from Kalka on the edge of the Indian plains up to the hill station of Shimla on a tiny train that called itself, rather grandiosely, the Himalayan Queen. The gradient was too much for the tiny locomotive, which stopped and then began to run backwards down the hill when we were within 10 miles of our destination. Everybody seemed very accepting of this, as this was India, where people are resigned to such things. Only in our neurotic latitudes, it seems, do people fume and shake their heads and look at their watches when they are delayed for a few minutes.

title: Letters from Masochists
description: After Tuesdays column on the hubris of the humanities, I thought I was going to get tons of indignant letters from Shakespeare lovers. I didnt. There is something in the intellectual psyche that is vaguely masochistic, and so I think some literature buffs derived a frisson of pleasure from being paid attention to, even if they were scolded.

title: When Giants Face Eagles, Punting Greats Compete

title: Accident Investigation Looks at Where Jet Touched Down on Runway
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 - The Southwest Airlines plane that slid off the end of a runway here on Thursday night, killing a 6-year-old boy in a car, apparently touched down closer to the end of the runway than normal on a snowy night, an official who was briefed on the accident said Friday. The landing came after other pilots had reported that the best traction was near the runway's start, the official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, REGINA GOLDMAN
description: MILLER--Regina Goldman, December 7, 2005, of Southbury, CT, formerly of NYC. Dearest wife of the late Milton H. Miller, M.D. Loving mother of Nancy Davis and the late Andrew. Grandmother of Valerie, Drew, Michael, Alex and Elizabeth. Greatgrandmother of three. Great bridge player.

title: A Scotsman Wields a Not-So-Invisible Hand in Africa
description: London - WHEN Tom Hunter says he plans to get serious about something, he seems to mean it. Earlier this year, after touring Africa with former President Bill Clinton, Mr. Hunter -- now Sir Tom -- resolved to get serious about philanthropy for a continent in turmoil. The result? A promise of $100 million, ponied up for projects to wrest Africans from poverty -- not bad for a man of 44 who started off his business career with borrowed money, selling sneakers.

title: U.S. Rebuffs Red Cross Request for Access to Detainees Held in Secret
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 - The United States said Friday that it would continue to deny the International Committee of the Red Cross access to "a very small, limited number" of prisoners who are held in secret around the world, saying they are terrorists being kept incommunicado for reasons of national security and are not guaranteed any rights under the Geneva Conventions.

title: Defining the Modern Conservative (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Atsuko Tanaka, 73, Artist Who Challenged Convention, Dies
description: Atsuko Tanaka, one of Japan's most important avant-garde artists, died on Dec. 3 at a hospital near her home in Nara, Japan. She was 73.

title: Defining the Modern Conservative
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LACEY, EDITH
description: LACEY--Edith. Temple BethEl of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Orioles Are Prepared to Drive a Hard Bargain for Tejada
description: One day after Miguel Tejada told The Associated Press that he was unhappy with the direction of the Baltimore Orioles and "wanted a change of scenery," the club said at least six teams called to inquire about him.

title: When the Military Seeks to Hire on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Thursday with an article about Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's comments on the treatment of detainees misstated the post held by Alberto R. Gonzales in 2002 when he prepared a memo on the subject. Mr. Gonzales was White House counsel at that time, not attorney general.

title: A Young Pianist's Journey from Episodic to Sustained
description: A Carnegie Hall recital is such a rite of passage that it sometimes seems a requisite first step out of an elite music school: rent Weill Recital Hall and give the world a taste of your young self. But there is much to be said for waiting until you're really ready.

title: Tracing Shadows
description: It began this spring without explanation: fire hydrants, street signs and bicycles all over Park Slope and Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn were suddenly standing watch over their own distorted chalk outlines, as if anticipating some violent demise. Whoever did this left no clue other than an ambiguous signature: "$; Ellis G. 2007," scrawled next to the chalk etchings.

title: Lieberman's Iraq Stance Brings Widening Split With His Party
description: Correction Appended

title: Chris Rock Won't Be Oscars Host Next Year
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 - The comedian Chris Rock, who gave the often staid Academy Awards a jolt this year by mocking movie stars and taking a camera crew into a black neighborhood to talk to moviegoers, will not be returning as host of next year's Academy Awards, his spokesman said.

title: False Positives From H.I.V. Test
description: Health officials in New York and San Francisco said yesterday that a widely used rapid test for the virus that causes AIDS had been producing too many false-positive results, frightening healthy people into thinking they might be infected.

title: Roger Shattuck, Scholar, Is Dead at 82
description: Roger Shattuck, a polyglot scholar and writer whose many subjects ranged from the emergence of modernism to whether some knowledge might be too dangerous to know, died on Thursday at his home in Lincoln, Vt. He was 82.

title: Defining the Modern Conservative
description: To the Editor:

title: Crossing Lines of Time, Age and Evolution
description: Jody Oberfelder's "LineAge" is about lineage and lines and age. It is well performed and terribly sincere. I saw it on Thursday evening, and I wish I had liked it more. But it seemed too earnest, too doggedly cute, too navely or artificially simplistic.

title: To Be Young and Underrated
description: EVERY National Football League general manger should buy and frame a copy of the photo that accompanies this column. Hang it in your offices and write this underneath it:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STUCKLER, RUTH
description: STUCKLER--Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Jacob (Jack). Devoted daughter, sister, sister-in-law, aunt and greataunt. Lovingly cared for her by her health companion Beverly Coleman. Graveside services Sunday, 2:00 P.M. at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Firefighter Crashes Into Officer's Car
description: A 28-year-old off-duty firefighter was arrested and charged with driving while impaired with alcohol after he drove the wrong way on the Long Island Expressway and hit a car driven by an off-duty New York City police officer yesterday morning, the police said. The firefighter, Jorge Alulema, hit the car shortly after 4 a.m. near Grand Avenue in Maspeth and was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center in critical but stable condition. The officer, who was not identified, was taken to Bellevue with neck and back injuries. Mr. Alulema was also charged with vehicular assault and reckless endangerment. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: New Fund Is Created for Ailing Tap Legend
description: Decades ago, the Nicholas Brothers -- Fayard and his younger brother, Harold -- dazzled fans around the globe with their stellar tap dancing and impeccable showmanship. Today, Fayard Nicholas lies in a hospital bed in California, recuperating from a stroke last month that left the entire left side of his body paralyzed.

title: Defining the Modern Conservative
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Flexes Its Muscle
description: CBS won every hour in Nielsen's estimates on Thursday, as it usually does on its strongest night. Its lineup was particularly strong, and, in total, it was CBS's biggest Thursday of the season so far. On "Survivor," which drew an audience of 20.38 million, four contestants now remain to be whittled down during tomorrow's finale: Stephenie LaGrossa, a popular contestant brought back from the previous season of the show, is one of them. Thursday's "CSI," with 30.8 million viewers, was the most-watched episode of the forensics crime show since last November. And "Without a Trace" delivered its best 18-to-49 ratings of the season. Sci Fi Channel's three-night miniseries "The Triangle," which ran Monday through Wednesday, attracted an average of 4.2 million viewers. Its biggest night was Monday, when Part 1 drew 4.31 million viewers. It was Sci Fi's highest-rated mini-series since "Steven Spielberg Presents Taken" in December 2002. KATE AURTHUR

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE (1946). Frank Capra's sentimental movie about a smalltown guy whose life falls apart on Christmas Eve is almost 60 years old now, and it's still the best 20th-century holiday story around. George Bailey (James Stewart) is on the verge of suicide when his mild-mannered guardian angel (Henry Travers) shows up and demonstrates what life for George's loved ones would have been like without him: kindly pharmacist in prison; wife (played by Donna Reed, above, with Stewart) as a spinster librarian afraid of her own shadow; war-hero brother dead in a childhood accident. But you know all that.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Inmate Found Dead In Cell
description: A man charged last year with abducting his wife from a Queens emergency room and shooting her co-worker was found dead in his cell at Rikers Island yesterday morning, a spokesman for the Department of Correction said. The inmate, Miguel Carrasquillo, 34, was found unconscious in his bed at 5:50 a.m. and was pronounced dead less than an hour later, said the department spokesman, Thomas Antenen. Mr. Antenen said that there were no signs of foul play, drug use or suicide, and that an autopsy would be conducted. Mr. Carrasquillo was accused of kidnapping his wife from Elmhurst Hospital Center, where she worked, on Sept. 11, 2004, apparently enraged that she had filed an order of protection against him, and of shooting a hospital employee, who survived. Mr. Carrasquillo was arrested two days later in North Carolina. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's stance in contract talks referred imprecisely to the origins of the pension rules allowing transit workers to retire with full pensions at age 55. The current system, called Tier IV, began in 1976 and originally allowed workers to retire with pensions at 62, but modifications adopted in 1994 lowered the retirement age to 55 for most workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHROG, MAURICE
description: SHROG--Maurice. On his 85th year. Beloved husband of Nettie. Dear father of Franklin and Renata Shrog, Susan and Steve Schwartz. Adored grandfather of Toni Anne, Eric, Micha, Ariel and great-grandfather of Crystal and Joseph. Loving brother of Lena and Adelle. A lifetime passion for the stage and screen, Maurice brought to his craft his love and professionalism in all his theatrical endeavors. Services Sunday, December 11, 11:15 AM at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: G.M. and Kerkorian Firm Fail to Reach Deal On His Attempt to Obtain a Seat on the Board General Motors and the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian said in a joint statement yesterday that they had failed to reach an agreement on Mr. Kerkorian's request to gain a seat on the automaker's board for his aide Jerome B. York, left. "Although the parties have had constructive discussions, they have not been able to reach a mutually satisfactory agreement," G.M. and Mr. Kerkorian's private equity firm, the Tracinda Corporation, said in the statement. G.M. and Tracinda said they expected to continue discussing the matter. G.M. confirmed on Wednesday that it was in talks with Mr. Kerkorian about a board seat. Mr. Kerkorian has been amassing G.M. shares and now has a nearly 10 percent stake in the automaker. He said in a federal filing in September that he might seek a board seat. (AP)

title: Hold the Limo: The Prom's Canceled as Decadent
description: Prom night, that all-American rite of passage that fell out of favor during the anti-establishment 1960's and then made a comeback in the conservative tilt of the Reagan era, probably always inhabited terrain destined to become a battleground in the so-called culture wars.

title: Louisiana Releases Details on Deaths From Hurricane Katrina and Later Flooding
description: Nineteen bodies were found on the overpass where Interstates 610 and 10 split, where they were dumped or where people died while waiting to be rescued. Nearly 80 people died in pairs, found together in or near their houses.

title: Head of Nuclear Agency Again Urges Iran to Cooperate
description: OSLO, Dec. 9 - Mohamed ElBaradei, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, warned Iran on Friday to stop hindering an investigation into the country's nuclear energy program, which the United States and many other observers suspect is a cover to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Odd Coalition Opposes Criminalizing Patent Violations
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 9 - For once, declared adversaries are on the same side of an argument in the technology industry: Both sides are urging European lawmakers to drop legislation that would impose prison time on patent violators and that they say would stifle innovation across Europe.

title: National Briefing | South: Texas: Criminal Charges Sought In Explosion
description: The Labor Department asked federal prosecutors to consider bringing criminal charges in an explosion that killed 15 employees and injured more than 170 at a BP refinery in Texas City, near Houston, on March 23. In September, the company acknowledged 300 "willful" violations of Occupational Safety and Health Administration standards and agreed to a $21 million civil penalty. But BP, in its final report, said its internal inquiry had failed to establish any deliberate disregard of safety procedures, although it admitted that mistakes were factors in the accident. BP declined to comment on the possibility of a criminal investigation. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Why Are We Losing Our Foreign Students?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cause Emerges for a Death in Glen Ridge
description: A woman found dead this week at her Glen Ridge, N.J., home with a bag over her face died from a blow to the head and suffocation, an investigator said yesterday.

title: Gifts for the Card Sharks on Your List
description: With Festivus looming again, harried shoppers may be scratching their dry, flaky scalps about what to pick up for the choosiest pokerati on their list. Here are some suggestions.

title: Snow, Winds and Misery From Plains to Northeast
description: Correction Appended

title: Hand-Helds and Palm: What's Next?
description: While the maker of the BlackBerry is operating under a cloud of uncertainty amid a patent dispute, competitors, including Palm Inc., are ready to take advantage. Ed Colligan, the chief executive of Palm -- which makes the Treo, among other hand-held devices -- recently spoke about the BlackBerry maker, Research in Motion; competition; and the future of hand-held devices.

title: Bush Likens Iraqi Action to Transition in 40's Japan
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 9 - President Bush suggested Friday that history will vindicate his decision to invade Iraq, saying he believed that a half century from now, it will be regarded as important a transition for the world as the democratization of Japan was after World War II.

title: Hugo Chvez and His Helpers
description: The kind of lucky breaks President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela has been getting lately could tempt even a modest man -- and Mr. Chvez is no modest man -- to dream grandiose dreams. High oil prices, a terminally inept opposition and the Bush administration's scandalous neglect of its Western Hemisphere neighbors have left the field wide open for Mr. Chvez to bully people at home, buy friends abroad and annoy Washington at every turn.

title: Yahoo Acquisition Expands Its Social Networking Services
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 - Yahoo, the online media company, said Friday that it had acquired Del.icio.us, a small Internet start-up company, in a move to expand its social networking services.

title: Former Officer Gets Probation in Homicide
description: A former New York police officer was sentenced to probation yesterday for fatally shooting an unarmed African immigrant in a Manhattan warehouse. The judge placed the blame for the killing primarily on the Police Department's training and supervision of the officer and the way the operation that resulted in the killing was carried out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRZELCZYK, BRUCE JOSEPH
description: STRZELCZYK -- Bruce Joseph, on December 7, 2005. Devoted husband of Maria for 28 years. Loving father of Christine (Joseph), Paul, Catherine, Karen & Susan. Also survived by his parents Joseph & Grace & brother James. Alumni of Xavier HS Class of '70 and Pace University Class of '73. Bruce was a former partner of accounting firms E & Y, Anderson, Eisner LLP and recently joined Sanders Morris Harris as Managing Director. Born in Brooklyn and long time resident of Glen Rock, NJ. Bruce will be deeply missed by his family and friends. For information Plaat Colonial Home Inc. Fairlawn, NJ 201-797-3500

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Protest Over Hiring Immigrants
description: More than 100,000 workers and students marched in Dublin and eight other cities to support the employees of Irish Ferries. The company wants to replace its staff with lower-paid Eastern European workers on passenger routes to Britain and France. The company's four boats are registered abroad, enabling it to pay the new workers less than half of Ireland's $9-an-hour minimum wage. The demonstrations were Ireland's biggest industrial protest in 20 years. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Doubts on Donors' Collection Cloud Met Antiquities Project
description: A decade ago, the Metropolitan Museum of Art embarked on a vastly ambitious project: the transformation of its dark and crowded Greek and Roman galleries into one of the premier spaces for antiquities in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Tommy Hanneford, 78, Performer in Longtime Family Circus Troupe, Dies
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 9 - Tommy Hanneford of the Royal Hanneford Circus, known as "the funniest man on horseback," died here on Monday. He was 78.

title: Arena Finds Reasons to Be Optimistic About Difficult Draw for U.S. Team
description: The United States was placed in a forbidding group at the 2006 World Cup draw yesterday, and will face Italy, a three-time champion, and the Czech Republic, the world's second-ranked team, in the opening round at soccer's world championship next summer in Germany.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The positive and negative reactions may have less to do with the substance of what I said than with the fact that a Democrat is saying it."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: U.P.S. Authorized To Ship Wines
description: The State Liquor Authority said yesterday that it had approved United Parcel Service as the first shipping company permitted to carry wine from other states directly to consumers in New York. The decision resolved an impasse that had prevented direct shipment of wine to consumers in the state, even though Gov. George E. Pataki signed a law during the summer to allow such shipments. New Yorkers have been able to order some out-of-state wines online or by telephone, but vineyards or businesses in other states have had to make arrangements with retailers or distributors in New York.
