That can drive up costs, increase delivery time and leave many wines, particularly from smaller vineyards, unavailable to New Yorkers. Susan Rosenberg, a spokeswoman for U.P.S., said she expected the company to be ready to ship early next week from wineries that have received licenses from the state. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: Questioning Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Landlord Cited On Two Violations
description: The landlord of the Elmhurst building where three young children and an elderly man living in a crowded basement died in a fire on Tuesday night was cited yesterday for making illegal changes to the building, at 40-77 Denman Street. A spokeswoman for the Buildings Department, Ilyse Fink, said two violations were issued to the landlord, Daniel Guaman, one for illegally converting the one-family house into a two-family dwelling, the other for installing a bathroom and a stove gas line in the basement without a permit. The maximum fine on each violation is $2,500. Juan Diaz, 27, a nephew of Mr. Guaman's, called the relatively light violations proof that housing conditions did not cause the deaths. "Even if the house was 100 percent legal, those kids would have died because the boy was playing with a lighter," Mr. Diaz said. Prosecutors said they had not determined whether criminal charges would be filed. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Consumer Confidence Rises for a 2nd Consecutive Month
description: Consumer confidence rose in the last month, a second straight monthly increase, according to an index published yesterday by the University of Michigan.

title: Viacom Seals Deal to BuyDreamWorks Movie Studio
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 - Moving swiftly after negotiations bogged down with a rival bidder, Viacom closed a deal on Friday to pay $1.6 billion to acquire DreamWorks SKG, the Hollywood studio founded by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, according to executives involved in the negotiations.

title: Jets' Legree, No Stranger to Losing, Tries to Stay Positive
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 9 - Lance Legree cannot pinpoint what prompted his string of bad luck during the past two seasons. Although the cause of his misfortunes may remain a mystery, the effect is painfully quantifiable.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the obituary page on Dec. 2 about Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, a Queens homemaker who had once been a Nazi death camp guard, referred incompletely to the coverage of her death, in 1999. Although her death appears to have gone unrecorded at the time in the United States, it was noted in passing by some newspapers -- including The Daily News and Newsday -- in their obituary coverage, in September, of Simon Wiesenthal, the Nazi hunter who tracked her down.

title: Justice Department Asks Court to Release Case of Terrorism Suspect
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 - The Bush administration pleaded with a federal appeals court on Friday to allow Jose Padilla, who is accused of terrorism, to be released from military custody so he could face criminal charges in a civilian court.

title: Murphy's Law and Forecasts for Next Year
description: YEAR-END forecasts are arriving earlier and earlier, like holiday shopping without the inconvenient parking. Here are some otherwise unexpected events that some investment advisers predict for 2006, along with ways to profit should they come to pass.

title: Defining the Modern Conservative
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWARD, KATHLEEN
description: HOWARD--Kathleen. December 9. Beloved wife of Hugh. Loving sister of Patricia Connelly, Sarah Beers and Mildred Reardon. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, December 11, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: O Fight, All Ye Faithful
description: 'Tis the season when even the most blas agnostic finds something special to fight about. But the Christmas battles are so complicated this year that you may be reluctant to join.

title: Boston Scientific's Guidant Bid Muddies the Water
description: HOLIDAY preparations did not slow the deal makers, who were busy from the heart of Wall Street to Beijing. The economy showed some encouraging signs of health, even while some doctors were concluding that junk food ads were to blame for the lack of health in young people.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: U.S. Envoy Presses Rights
description: The United States special envoy for human rights in North Korea, Jay Lefkowitz, called for international cooperation to press North Korea to improve human rights for its citizens. Speaking at a United States-backed rights conference in Seoul, he said respect for rights in North Korea would increase regional stability. South Korea, which has emphasized resolving the North's nuclear arms threat and has refrained from spotlighting its rights violations, did not send any high-ranking official. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Killing of Ex-President's Brother Is Still a Mexican Mystery
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 9 - It has been a year since the brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was found suffocated, but the state and federal authorities have yet to untangle the motives for his killing, much less arrest his killers and their accomplices.

title: London Stock Exchange Rejects Takeover Offer
description: LONDON, Dec. 9 - The London Stock Exchange rejected as "derisory" a 1.48 billion ($2.6 billion) preliminary bid from Macquarie Bank on Friday, but will be required nonetheless to open its books to its suitor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLEASON, JOHN M.
description: GLEASON--John M. On December 7, 2005. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Loving father of James and Mary. Devoted grandfather of Rosemary, John Peter and Grace. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150 St., Whitestone. Mass of Christian burial Monday 10:15 St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9.

title: Prize in Indian Talent Search Is a Year on Bill Gates's Team
description: BANGALORE, India, Dec. 9 - Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, announced a contest Friday to identify promising software students in India, offering as top prize an internship with his technical team for a year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Nov. 27 about the comedian Dave Chappelle referred imprecisely to a three-day comedy festival where he was the headliner. While it took place in Las Vegas, it was not the city's festival. It was presented by HBO and AEG Live. An article in The Arts on Tuesday about Comedy Central's plans to put together a third season of "Chappelle's Show" despite the absence of Mr. Chappelle misidentified the festival. It was The Comedy Festival, not the Las Vegas Comedy Festival.

title: Cavs Make a Late Run, but Nets Win in a Walk
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 - Against the giants of the Eastern Conference -- the Miami Heat, the Indiana Pacers and the Detroit Pistons -- the Nets had not fared well this season, losing all three of those games.

title: TRANSACTION
description: BASEBALL

title: Mets Still Shopping, For Pitchers
description: Omar Minaya's off-season makeover of the Mets is coming in bursts. He zeros in on a position and does not relent until it is upgraded, extravagantly and completely.

title: Mayor Says State Inaction Will Block New Schools
description: New York City will be forced to delay more than 23 major school construction projects scheduled to begin this fiscal year unless New York State begins to comply with a court order mandating billions more in aid for the city schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Employees Stole Millions Meant for 9/11 Work, Officials Say
description: The money was rushed to New York City after the Sept. 11 attacks, emergency federal aid to help the chief medical examiner identify the remains gathered from ground zero. But two city employees siphoned off at least $10 million for their personal use, according to charges announced yesterday by federal and city authorities.

title: A River Smallmouth Brings a Chill
description: Late autumn is a precious time. We savor every moment of daylight, each glimpse of sun. As the cold fronts from the north become more biting and frequent, we steal any hour we can for the pleasure of fishing without gloves or parka. A weekend that isn't totally miserable is seen as an opportunity, a gift.

title: Executive Gets 5-Year Term in Fraud Case
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 9 - A former chief financial officer at HealthSouth, William T. Owens, who cooperated with federal prosecutors, was sentenced Friday to five years in prison for his role in an accounting fraud at the company.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Jeff Probst Re-enlists in 'Survivor' Despite speculation to the contrary, Jeff Probst, left, isn't going anywhere, except to more of the wilderness outposts where "Survivor" flourishes. Mr. Probst, 44, has signed a new multiyear deal as host of the CBS reality show, The Associated Press reported. He said: "I was thinking about retiring and spending my time traveling to exotic locations around the world, meeting new and interesting people. Then I realized, uh, wait a second, I'm already doing that with 'Survivor' and getting paid for it as well." Since the show's debut in the summer of 2000, Mr. Probst has been the host of the competition to win $1 million among those surviving physical and mental challenges in difficult settings. "Survivor: Guatemala," the current contest and the 11th in the series, reaches its conclusion in a broadcast tomorrow at 8 p.m. The 12th installment, being filmed in an undisclosed location, is to be seen in the spring. Last month, CBS announced that it planned to show the 13th and 14th editions in the 2006-7 season. Comedy Central will bring back its Hollywood parody, "The Showbiz Show With David Spade," for a second season, Reuters reported. Thirteen half-hour episodes will be broadcast beginning on March 23. The first season will end on Thursday.

title: Bloomberg Aide Appointed to New Deputy Mayor Post
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that Kevin Sheekey, a longtime Democratic operative who managed his re-election campaign, would become the city's new deputy mayor for government relations.

title: Doctor Suggests Merck Trial May Have Led to Demotion
description: Less than a week after his videotaped lambasting of Merck was played in a Houston federal courthouse, Dr. Eric Topol, a prominent cardiologist, has lost his title as chief academic officer of the Cleveland Clinic's medical college.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the police firing on protesters in a Chinese village misstated the timing of the clashes in some copies. They were on Tuesday evening, not on Thursday, when the reports of the episode emerged.

title: Why Are We Losing Our Foreign Students? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefings: Europe, Americas, Africa, Asia, Middle East
description: EUROPE

title: When the Military Seeks to Hire on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges Weigh Hedge Funds vs. the S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 - A federal appeals court on Friday sharply questioned the Securities and Exchange Commission's plan to tighten oversight of hedge funds.

title: In Final Season, Dorfmeister Has the Wind at Her Back
description: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 9 - The perfect line for the Austrian ski racer Michaela Dorfmeister has always been a zigzagging one.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOLDSTEIN, HERMAN J.
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Herman J. Gone 40 years today, but remembered with love forever. Your Daughter, Karen

title: U.S. to Offer Cuts in Tariffs on Cotton
description: The United States will make new offers to cut tariffs on cotton next week at global trade talks in Hong Kong, the United States trade representative said yesterday.

title: With Loss, Another Trip Ends Badly for Knicks
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 9 - Road-weary and emotionally tapped out, the Knicks dragged themselves out of the desert late Friday night, the victims again of their own shortcomings. They could not even comfort themselves with the thought of heading straight home.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Church Reaches Out to the Very Young
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 - "May almighty God bless the mommies and daddies and brothers and sisters," the Rev. Patrick Gray of the Episcopal Church of the Advent here said to the Sunday school class. "And us, so we continue to grow big and strong."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LITWIN, THOMAS LEE
description: LITWIN--Thomas Lee, 72. Entrepreneur, philanthropist, optimist. Survived by Dorothy Litwin, wife for 49 amazingly happy years, children Laurie Cancellieri, Stuart Litwin, and Kathy Kronick, and seven adored grandchildren, Casey, Emily, Max, Brittany, Rebecca, Rachel and Jordyn. Beloved father-in-law to Brian Kronick and Laura Litwin, uncle and brother-in-law. Services will be held at 2 PM Sunday, in the Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ. Memorial contributions can be sent to the Litwin Family Scholarship Fund, Cornell University, P.O. Box 2600, Ithaca, NY 14851.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTTENSTEIN, KALMAN, ''KAL.''
description: RUTTENSTEIN -- Kalman, "Kal." Senior Vice President, Fashion Direction. June 9, 1936--December 8, 2005. Kal has been part of our family for 28 years. He lived life on the edge of fashion and entertainment. He discovered. He taught. He mentored. He knew what was hot before it was. He loved dining and dishing at the restaurant of the moment. He had a unique sense of humor and was a master of style. He was larger than life, and life at Bloomingdale's without him will be different. We are all so sad. Michael Gould Chairman & CEO Bloomingdale's

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the future of Knight Ridder Newspapers incorrectly described The Daily News in Philadelphia. It is published in the morning, not the afternoon.

title: Robert Sheckley, 77, Writer of Satirical Science Fiction, Is Dead
description: Robert Sheckley, a writer of science fiction whose disarmingly playful stories pack a nihilistic subtext, died yesterday in Poughkeepsie. He was 77 and lived in Red Hook, N.Y.

title: Two Kidnapped Hostages Armed Only With Words
description: There is an insurgency in an unnamed Latin American country. An opposing military. Kidnapped hostages. And, of course, their masked guards. Jorge Ignacio Cortias, a Cuban-American playwright, summons these familiar conditions and characters almost as an incantation in his drama "Tight Embrace," which opened on Tuesday in an Intar production at the Kirk Theater. With a dash of magic realism and flickering poetic fire, he settles down to his subject: the idea that the words and language human beings must employ to communicate -- think friendship, love or, go ahead, the United Nations -- they readily use as weapons, to trap and betray one another.

title: And Jonah Said, 'Can You Dig Me Here in This Fish?'
description: My lords and ladies, cats and kitties, listen up! The swinging, hip messiah has returned, and he wants to commune with your subconscious mind. Can you dig that?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Softens Law On Private Groups
description: President Vladimir V. Putin proposed softening -- somewhat -- legislation intended to exert greater government control over charities and other private organizations working in Russia. In a statement, he proposed striking a provision that would have effectively barred foreign organizations like Human Rights Watch or Amnesty International from keeping offices in Russia, though he suggested subjecting them to new oversight. Proposed restrictions on Russian organizations would remain largely unchanged by the legislation, which has been widely criticized. "The aims of the bill deserve support," Mr. Putin said. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Wealthy Blacks Oppose Plans for Their Property
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 9 - True Light Baptist Church is located in a down-and-out part of town here, but on Monday nights its parking lot fills with BMW's, Mercedes-Benzes and other late-model sedans that shine with a new-car sparkle.

title: Eugene J. McCarthy, Senate Dove Who Jolted '68 Race, Dies at 89
Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about House approval of a $56 billion tax cut gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of the Republican congressman from New York who voted against the measure. He is Sherwood Boehlert, not Boehlart.

title: Illegal, Immoral and Pointless
description: There are many reasons why Americans should not torture prisoners, but here is one that may help those who are still not moved by the fact that it is morally wrong and illegal, damages the nation's image, and puts American soldiers who are taken prisoner in mortal peril: It usually doesn't work.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Stabbed To Death In Elevator
description: A young woman was found stabbed to death early yesterday in the elevator of her apartment building in Homecrest, the police said. The woman, whom the police did not identify yesterday, was a college student who lived with her boyfriend, said Edward Rosado, the superintendent of the building, at 2035 East Seventh Street. Her boyfriend was at home when the police arrived and was being questioned yesterday. A friend said the couple had been dating for a few years, and Mr. Rosado said, "I've never seen any history of them being violent or them being angry." The woman had stab wounds on her neck and chest, but no weapon was found, investigators said. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Chvez Sees More Plots
description: President Hugo Chvez, who repeatedly accuses the Bush administration of plotting to assassinate him, turned his ire against election monitors from the Organization of American States and the European Union, whom he accused of plotting against Venezuelan democracy by issuing reports that said voters distrusted the government's electoral body. The reports by the monitors said that Sunday's congressional election, in which Mr. Chvez's allies swept all 167 seats, was largely fair, but they called for a new National Electoral Council because the current one is seen as biased toward the government. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLASTER, BETSY
description: CLASTER--Betsy. On December 7, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Sanford. Adoring mother of Bob and Scott. Loving grandmother of Max and Zoe. Service Monday 1PM at "The Riverside", 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave.

title: 'Liquid Candy' in Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefs
description: WEST

title: The Jobs Recovery Looks Good, Until a Longer Look Is Taken
description: THE Bush administration has begun an aggressive campaign to reassure Americans that the economy is doing well. It is highlighting the jobs numbers, which have shown steady gains since hitting a low in May 2003.

title: INSIDE
description: Promotion for New Jersey Congressman Representative Robert Menendez, right, was named New Jersey's new senator by Governor-elect Jon S. Corzine at Liberty State Park yesterday. Mr. Menendez, the son of Cuban immigrants, faces an election next year for the seat, which had been filled by Mr. Corzine, left. PAGE B1

title: A Transit Strike Could Cost Up to $10 Million a Day
description: A strike by subway and bus workers would cost New York City about $10 million a day in police overtime and other expenses, the city's top lawyer, Michael A. Cardozo, said during a court hearing yesterday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart on Thursday with an article about Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's comments on the treatment of detainees misstated the post held by Alberto R. Gonzales in 2002 when he prepared a memo on the subject. Mr. Gonzales was White House counsel at that time, not attorney general. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the playwright Harold Pinter's criticism of American foreign policy in his acceptance speech for the Nobel Prize in Literature described it incompletely. He said that both President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair -- and not just Prime Minister Blair -- should be tried before the International Criminal Court of Justice for the invasion of Iraq.

title: The Terrorist in the Art Gallery
description: IN New York, the Metropolitan Museum is considering what amounts to a plea bargain with Italian authorities for having acquired antiquities that Italy says were stolen. In California, the longtime curator for ancient art at the J. Paul Getty Museum has resigned to face trial in Rome on charges of conspiracy to receive stolen artifacts. In Iraq, a German archaeologist has been kidnapped by insurgents.

title: From Russia to Europe With a Natural Gas Pipeline
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENFELD, STANLEY
description: CHRISTENFELD--Stanley. On December 7, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Loving father of Janet and Sam Argintar and Emily and Michael Grad. Dear brother of Adele and brother-in-law of Dr. Murray Golbey. Adoring grandfather of Caroline, Laura, and James. Service Sunday 10AM at the "Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: When the Military Seeks to Hire on Campus (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Abbey Theater to Move
description: The Abbey, Ireland's national theater, will move from the heart of Dublin to a vacant site in the city's riverside financial district, where it will be surrounded by the glass and steel offices of dozens of international banks, officials said. The decision follows four years of uncertainty about the Abbey's location, and a disastrous centenary in 2004 that resulted in a new director, a revamped legal structure and record deficits that required emergency financing from the government. Culture Minister John O'Donoghue said he hoped to have a plan for the new building by March, possibly including an international architecture competition and partnership with private developers. The original theater, founded by W. B. Yeats in 1904, burned down in the 1950's, and its replacement has long been criticized for space constraints and outdated design. BRIAN LAVERY

title: la Carte? Nah, Hand Me the Remote.
description: I OWN a 47-inch Samsung high-definition television. My wife and I bought it a couple of years ago, when HDTV prices were still in the stratosphere, but we've never had a moment of buyer's remorse. I love the thing: the large screen, the vivid colors, the better-than-real-life picture. I can get downright rhapsodic talking up the joys of high definition; indeed, I become annoyed now when I'm forced to watch a program on "ordinary" TV because it's not available on high definition. Once you've been down the high-def path, you don't want to go back.

title: Smokers Fret, Others Cheer, Over New Ban in Northwest
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 9 - The wind blowing off Lake Washington whistled outside Bergie's Bar and Grill on Friday, chilling the little makeshift shelter where a huddle of cigarette smokers tried to stay warm.

title: Defining the Modern Conservative
description: To the Editor:

title: Wright Could Be So Good, No One Wants to Fight Him
description: For many years, Winky Wright has felt slighted.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,129 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Elections Could Tilt Latin America Further to the Left
description: MOROCHATA, Bolivia - In perhaps the quirkiest, most colorful of the many presidential campaigns gathering momentum in Latin America, Evo Morales, the Aymara Indian leader turned congressman, arrived in this mountain hamlet on a recent day, got out of his car a mile up the road and strode in like a conquering hero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEEHAN, ROSE M.
description: MEEHAN--Rose M. On December 8, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted mother of Arthur and mother-in-law of Dorothy. Dear grandmother of Sean. Companion of the late Mike. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompei Church. Interment Long Island National Cemetery. Friends may call Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Menendez Basks in Appointment to the Senate, if Only Briefly
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 9 - To introduce Robert Menendez as New Jersey's first Latino United States senator, Governor-elect Jon S. Corzine chose a setting intended to emphasize the arc of Mr. Menendez's life as the son of poor Cuban immigrants.

title: Private Equity and Paper Companies May Bid for Knight Ridder
description: Knight Ridder, the newspaper giant that put itself up for sale last month, received several preliminary bids yesterday from both rivals and private equity firms, according to people involved in the auction.

title: Regents Delay New Standard for Math Test in High School
description: New York State's Board of Regents voted yesterday to begin testing high school students under new mathematics standards in 2007-8 after a survey of school officials showed most had not adequately prepared for the new curriculum and favored having one more year.

title: For Online Star Wars Game, It's Revenge of the Fans
description: For two and a half years, Emily E. LaBeff, chairwoman of the sociology department at Midwestern State University in Wichita Falls, Tex., spent 30 hours or more each week playing the online computer game Star Wars Galaxies. Not for research, but for fun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, BERNARD L.
description: COHEN--Bernard L. On December 8, 2005. Beloved husband of Pauline for over 57 years. Adored father of Diane & Jeffrey Schuman, June & Michael Cohen. Loving grandfather of Jamie & Matt, Allison, Kate, Amy, Nikki, & Stephanie and his aide Concordio. Co-owner of Baron & Port Lincoln Mercury with his partner of 55 years, Morris Baron. W.W. II Army Air Force Captain who flew 67 missions in the European theatre. His love of life inspired so many and made the world such a better place. His kindness to all will always be remembered and his legacy of love will live forever in our hearts. Services Sunday 10:30, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Hong Kong Girds for Protests During World Trade Conference
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 9 - With the World Trade Organization ministerial conference scheduled to start here on Tuesday, Hong Kong is like a city preparing for a siege.

title: Delays and Suspense in Corzine's Choice for His Senate Seat
description: He consulted Bill Clinton, Vernon Jordan and Bill Bradley.

title: The Neediest Cases; Aid Lets 'a Bad Kid' Learn a Good Trade
description: Mirrors are everywhere you turn at the American Barber Institute in Chelsea. Mirrors on walls. Mirrors on doors. Mirrors in the middle of the room. Row after row of mirrors, ping-ponging reflections back and forth. For the narcissistic, this would be paradise. For the self-conscious, this would be hell.

title: Cuts, Cream, Claus and Coffee
description: TOO many chief executives lack courage and imagination, writes Jim Jubak, a columnist for TheStreet.com. And rather than standing up against the short-term profit demands of Wall Street, he says, they cut costs (meaning, jobs) and blame globalization for their woes.

title: The Act of Giving Makes a Nice Gift, if Done Correctly
description: THE message is everywhere: This holiday, give the gift of giving. Do good and feel good. The perfect gift is a gift to charity.

title: U.S. Forces Rely on Local Informants in Ferreting Rebels in West Iraq
description: AL ASAD, Iraq - On the final day of a town-to-town military sweep in November along the Euphrates River, hundreds of men in Ar Rabit, a farming village, were rousted from their homes by American and Iraqi troops and shepherded into long rows on a harvested cornfield.

title: Chasing a Girl on Kong's Island, and Other Pursuits
description: Everyone knows the story of King Kong. A film crew explores a mysterious island populated by dinosaurs where the lead actress is captured by a building-size gorilla. I imagine that the remake, directed by Peter Jackson, fleshes out that simple story with engaging performances, high drama and lots of dialogue, but you won't see much of that in Ubisoft's action game, Peter Jackson's King Kong: The Official Game of the Movie. In the game, dinosaurs rip the flesh from their deceased brethren, and something similar seems to have happened to the story, which has been reduced to a skeleton in service of a game that is not about story but purely about jungle survival.

title: Finding the Right Balance, and a Soprano on the Fly
description: For his Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall, Richard Goode is splitting his time between solo and chamber playing, pretty much the way he has arranged his career. The centerpieces of the chamber program he planned to play on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall were vocal works, with Dawn Upshaw scheduled to join him for Haydn and Mozart songs, and to join a vocal quartet for Haydn part songs and canons. But Ms. Upshaw became ill shortly before the concert, and although Mr. Goode was able to find another soprano to sing in the ensemble settings, he replaced the solo songs with piano works.

title: Hurdles Persist for Whitney's Expansion
description: Supporters and critics of the Whitney Museum's expansion spoke passionately Thursday night as the museum presented new details about its building plans to an Upper East Side community board.

title: Torture Is No Path To National Security
description: To the Editor:

title: On This Team, Good Hands Are a Given
description: IN a high school gymnasium where youthful exuberance is more felt than heard, the visiting team gathers at one end of the basketball court to stretch before the game. "One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten," they chant, then clap, clap, clap. One, two, three, clap, clap, clap.

title: U.S., Under Fire, Eases Its Stance in Climate Talks
description: MONTREAL, Saturday, Dec. 10 - The United States dropped its opposition early Saturday morning to nonbinding talks on addressing global warming after a few words were adjusted in the text of statements that, 24 hours earlier, prompted a top American official to walk out on negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Nov. 27 about the comedian Dave Chappelle referred imprecisely to a three-day comedy festival where he was the headliner. While it took place in Las Vegas, it was not the city's festival. It was presented by HBO and AEG Live. An article in The Arts on Tuesday about Comedy Central's plans to put together a third season of "Chappelle's Show" despite the absence of Mr. Chappelle misidentified the festival. It was The Comedy Festival, not the Las Vegas Comedy Festival.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Ramsey Clark, the former United States attorney general, who is helping to defend Saddam Hussein at his war-crimes trial in Iraq, incorrectly described the criminal conviction of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, a former client of Mr. Clark's who is serving a life term in an American prison. Mr. Abdel Rahman was found guilty in 1995 of conspiring to carry out a terrorist campaign of assassinations and bombings intended to destroy the United Nations and New York landmarks, not of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center.

title: Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: Abstract Expressionism, on a Modest Scale
description: The Abstract Expressionist painters reveled in canvases of heroic size. But James Brooks (1906-92), a member of the brotherhood, did not disdain small works, as this career-spanning show of 17 canvases attests.

title: World Briefing | Asia Bangladesh: Islamists Threaten The Unveiled
description: Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen, the banned Islamist militant group blamed for a series of recent bombings and suicide attacks, said in a statement sent to a Dhaka newspaper that it would kill women, including non-Muslims, if they do not wear the veil beginning next month. The group seeks the imposition of Shariah, or Islamic law, in the mostly Muslim nation. Tens of thousands of demonstrators protested nationwide against the violence, chanting, "Suicide bombers are Islam's enemies."

title: It Was Just One of Those 75-Minute Two-Man Improvisations
description: The age of superheroics in jazz is mostly behind us; musicians have found many other, more temperate strategies to hold an audience's attention. But every time Sonny Fortune and Rashied Ali play duets it's as if they've brought their capes and masks.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: California's Stem Cell Program Is Hobbled but Staying the Course
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 - After nearly an entire morning of sometimes heated debate the other day, the board overseeing California's $3 billion stem cell research institute took action. It asked the organization's president to draw up a plan for how to draw up a strategic plan.

title: The Flu Moat
description: Congress is expected to vote next week on a bill that would dedicate $7.1 billion to fight avian flu. It's good that the Bush administration, which wrote the proposal, is taking this disease seriously. What's bad is that the strategy seems to be to build a moat around America.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Hampton: Judge Reverses Himself In Synagogue Case
description: A judge who prohibited the congregation of a prestigious East Hampton synagogue from voting on whether to oust its board of trustees and renew the rabbi's contract reversed himself yesterday and ruled that the vote could be held on Dec. 25. The judge, Justice Ralph F. Costello of State Supreme Court, is expected to decide next month whether the vote is valid under state law and the constitution of the synagogue, the Jewish Center of the Hamptons. Allegations that Rabbi David J. Gelfand, left, plagiarized sermons and misused synagogue funds have sharply divided the 1,100-member congregation, which has supported the rabbi, and its trustees, who have said they would not renew his contract. The rabbi has denied wrongdoing. Julia C. Mead (NYT)

title: Spirited Songs Inspired by Timeless Japanese Stories
description: Three centuries ago in Japan, a former Buddhist priest turned musician named Miyako Itchu forged a style of narrative musical theater. His approach, Itchu-bushi, became the foundation of classical Japanese theater music, setting stories as suites that change seamlessly as a tale progresses. Itchu-bushi is sparse, somber music. Voices intone the stories in sustained phrases, swooping between speech and song. They are accompanied by a few notes plucked on shamisens -- banjo-like instruments with three silk strings -- and peeped from a wooden flute (hayashi), to be punctuated by hand drums. Every so often a rhythm takes over and a melody is shared.

title: Joint Venture Is Chosen to Build PATH Terminal and Transportation Hub at Ground Zero
description: In one of the most reliable signs yet that large-scale building is about to begin at ground zero, the Port Authority plans to award a $1.1 billion contract to four giant construction and engineering firms to oversee the World Trade Center PATH terminal and transportation hub.

title: Eli Lilly Predicts Latest Drugs Will Lift Its Earnings in 2006
description: Eli Lilly & Company, the drug maker, forecast yesterday that 2006 earnings per share would rise 63 percent on expanding sales of its newest products.

title: Draw Done, World Cup Stage Is Set for the Elite
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 9 - In an elaborately choreographed ceremony featuring Pel and the German supermodel Heidi Klum, 32 national soccer teams and hundreds of millions of fans worldwide were put through an exercise in high anxiety as the draw for next year's World Cup was determined Friday in Leipzig.

title: Root for $5-a-Gallon Gas
description: GASOLINE prices stubbornly hover near $2 a gallon, but $5 would be even better, writes Spencer Reiss in this month's Wired. The higher the price, he reasons, the more incentive there is to find alternatives.

title: Matching the Wide Screen With Clear Thinking
description: Consumers are snapping up digital TV's this holiday season. The market analysts at Gartner predict that 3.6 million high-definition TV's will be sold this holiday season, 80 percent of what was sold in all 12 months of 2004.

title: Lieberman's Iraq Stance Brings Widening Split With His Party
description: Correction Appended

title: A Spitzer Target Gets Even by Supporting an Opponent
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer is famous for conducting high-profile investigations of big business that are settled before trial. One target of his investigations, Kenneth G. Langone, a former director of the New York Stock Exchange, is not only fighting back in court, but fighting Mr. Spitzer in another arena: electoral politics.

title: With Field Fleshed Out, Now the Blood Starts to Boil
description: Leipzig, Germany - WHEN Bruce Arena was 6 years old, he visited the grocery store of his maternal grandfather, Salvatore Schembre, in Brooklyn. There on the wall was a photograph of a collection of sturdy lads in blue shorts and shirts -- the fabled Azzurri of Italy, although Arena was not overly impressed with soccer at the time.

title: Matt Damon Weds in City Hall
description: Matt Damon, 35, married Luciana Bozan, 29, in a small private ceremony yesterday morning in Manhattan, according to his publicist, Jennifer Allen. Ms. Allen said Ms. Bozan's 7-year-old daughter, Alexia, witnessed the ceremony.

title: New Criticism Rages Over South Korean Cell Research
description: A new round of criticism has broken out in South Korea over the accuracy of a recent article that reported a striking advance in human stem cell research.

title: A Republican Tom DeLay Problem
description: It may be dawning on House Republicans that Representative Tom DeLay's time as their majority leader is truly over, despite the bold Texan's resolve to regain his grip on Congress. Whatever the outcome of his trial on felony charges of laundering political money, Mr. DeLay's root problem has been laid bare. It is outsized hubris, which is ever clearer to the public and ever more a G.O.P. millstone.

title: Protesters Say Police in China Killed Up to 20
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 9 - Residents of a fishing village near Hong Kong said Friday that as many as 20 people were killed by the paramilitary police this week, in an unusually violent clash that marked an escalation in the widespread social protests roiling the Chinese countryside. Villagers said as many as 50 other residents remained unaccounted for since the shootings on Tuesday.

title: N.F.L. Draft Watchers Are Taking Note of Heisman Finalists
description: When the University of Southern California stars Reggie Bush and Matt Leinart visit New York this weekend, they may want to speak with a real estate agent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 2 about the C.I.A. leak investigation misstated a word in a quotation from an article about the case that appeared on Time magazine's Web site in July 2003. The Time article said "some government officials" -- not "some administration officials" -- had told Time and the syndicated columnist Robert Novak that "Valerie Plame is a C.I.A. official who monitors the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction." (Later developments in the leak case revealed that in fact the information had been disclosed by administration officials, I. Lewis Libby Jr. and Karl Rove.)

title: Republicans Acting Democratic
description: New York State Republicans tend to prefer solidarity. So when the G.O.P. in this Democratic state is of more than one mind, Republican elders smell trouble.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 6 Years For Neo-Nazi
description: A court in St. Petersburg sentenced Dmitri Bobrov, leader of the Schultz-88 neo-Nazi group, to six years in prison on charges of extremism and inciting hatred, after prosecutors established that he had brought together teenagers to fight Jews, Africans and people from the Caucasus. Russian news media reported that "88" stands for "HH," the eighth letter of the alphabet, and that in turn means "Heil Hitler." Alexander Nurnberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHN, MAX LEWIS
description: KAHN -- Max Lewis. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Max Lewis Kahn, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Charles J. Block, President

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the reopening of Tulane University referred imprecisely to its location. Modern-day Tulane is primarily in the Uptown neighborhood of New Orleans, not the Garden District, where it was founded.

title: Live Tracking of Mobile Phones Prompts Court Fights on Privacy
description: Most Americans carry cellphones, but many may not know that government agencies can track their movements through the signals emanating from the handset.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Defining the Modern Conservative
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: The Numbers: A Statistical Snapshot
description: Everyone has a theory about what's ailing Hollywood. But look closely: the film industry is still fairly flush.

title: The Week: Primary Addresses
description: President Bush promoted tax cuts and recent job-growth figures, while Harold Pinter, winner of the Nobel Prize for literature, called the U.S. "brutal, indifferent, scornful and ruthless."

title: Amazon Faces Record Drought
description: The Amazon River basin is grappling with a drought that has evaporated whole lagoons, the worst since record keeping began a century ago.

title: Richard Pryor Dies at 65
description: The iconoclastic standup comedian brought the biting, irreverent humor of the black ghetto into mainstream America's living rooms.

title: 'Jetsons' Made the Calls in 1962
description:
The 21st-century N.F.L. bears a striking resemblance
to an old episode of "The Jetsons," a futuristic
cartoon series.

title: What Would a Clone Say?
description: Gary Rosen (Nov. 27) makes a strange case against therapeutic cloning. His argument is based on what he takes to be "a bit of Kant from Ethics 101," namely the principle that one should always treat other people, "presumably even proto-people," as an end in themselves and never solely as a means to one's own ends. This is simply not a viable application of Kant, however, not even in a simplified Ethics 101. The feature of humans warranting respect, for Kant, was rationality, and insofar as embryonic cells certainly lack this feature, they don't have the moral status Rosen needs for his argument.

title: The Week Ahead: Dec. 11- Dec. 17
description: THEATER

title: The Many Colors of Black Dance
description: ALVIN AILEY founded his company in the late 1950's to provide jobs for gifted, well-trained dancers who, because they were black, had nowhere else to go. He conceived of a formal company that would be a living library of dances by choreographers whom he admired, in part to relieve himself of the burden of making pieces.

title: With Everything in Databases, Top Players Must Work Harder
description: In the stage of development of chess culture that we are in now, there are few games that feature outright tactical blunders of the sort that could be seen a century or two ago. One reason for this is that lesser players can at least get through the opening without disaster, thanks to a strong library -- or, better yet, a computer compendium of everything that has been played since the early beginnings of the game.

title: Reporter Recounts Talk About C.I.A. Leak
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 - A lawyer for Karl Rove, the senior White House adviser, learned in the first half of 2004 that Mr. Rove had probably been a source for the magazine's July 2003 article that mentioned the C.I.A. officer who has come to be at the heart of the C.I.A. leak case, a Time reporter wrote today.

title: After a Tragedy
description: Westchester's incoming district attorney, Janet DiFiore, and its Department of Social Services have agreed to create an independent team to investigate the deaths of children under county supervision.

title: A Passage to India: Asphalt and Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Gastronomic Reversals
description: Fried mayonnaise? Hot ice cream? Chocolate pudding that can be sliced and cut? This year witnessed the flourishing of an unusual culinary fashion: dishes that, with the addition of certain chemicals, turn hot into cold or moist into dry or create an invisible boundary between the two.

title: The Rich, Sometimes, Are the Best Medicine
description: THE Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation recently announced that it would give $450 million toward eclectic inventions to aid the world's poor: more nutritious bananas, easier-to-use vaccines and chemicals that leave mosquitoes unable to smell their would-be victims, for example.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Friday about a prewar Bush administration assertion of ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda based on statements made by a prisoner while in Egyptian custody described how the prisoner later said he had fabricated the statements to escape harsh treatment. While the article disclosed new information about the handling of the terrorist suspect, it should have acknowledged earlier reporting on the subject by other news organizations, including Newsweek, The Christian Science Monitor and The New Yorker.

title: Respite for Vegetarians, but Fit for Carnivores
description: OSSINING - WESTCHESTER is hardly awash in good vegetarian eating choices. Diners typically make do with a handful of possibilities -- and, if they are vegans, often none.

title: Thousands gather in Hong Kong for first WTO protest
Zanzibar: Of Sultans, Spices and White-Sand Beaches
description: FEW ferry rides in the world can conjure up the wealth of expectations that arise on the two-hour trip from the verdant Tanzanian coast to Zanzibar. The name alone has for centuries endowed this region with a promise of splendor.

title: Hi, Venice? It's Istanbul. Can You Send a Painter?
description: BOSTON - WHEN Rudyard Kipling wrote, "Oh, East is East, and West is West, and never the twain shall meet," he had obviously forgotten about the long history of the Venetian Republic. A child of Byzantium, Venice exploited its ancient ties to that crossroads of Europe and Asia to build up a thriving trade in goods and ideas that shaped its art, architecture and institutions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEEHAN, ROSE M.
description: MEEHAN--Rose M. On December 8, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted mother of Arthur and mother-in-law of Dorothy. Dear grandmother of Sean. Companion of the late Mike. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompei Church. Interment Long Island National Cemetery. Friends may call Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Open-Source Reporting
description: No liberal blogger could complain about a dearth of material in 2005. From the Bush administration's ham-fisted response to Hurricane Katrina to the indictment of the former Republican majority leader Tom DeLay, opportunities to lambaste the Republican Party were abundant. Of course, staying abreast of all these developing stories was not a facile proposition, at least in the experience of Joshua M. Marshall, editor of the left-leaning blog Talkingpointsmemo.com. And so this October he put out a plea for help, asking his readers to share their knowledge of the spreading Washington scandals. He termed the effort "open-source investigative reporting."

title: Iverson Only Latest Star To Expose Uneven Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 10 - Perhaps the best adjective the Nets could use to describe their performances so far this season is enigmatic. They have appeared on the verge of turning the corner several times, only to stumble on each occasion.

title: The Tricks of the Trade in Coping With Slower Sales
description: WAITING for an apartment to sell is surprisingly vexing, and the wait is growing longer. In Manhattan, properties are taking a month longer to sell than they did a year ago at this time, 133 days on average, according to third-quarter data from the appraisal and consulting firm Miller Samuel. As agonizingly long as that may sound to a seller, it is still within the norm for the last 20 years, which was 120 to 150 days.

title: WHAT ABOUT BICYCLES?
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed "Going to Portland, Ore." (Nov. 6), but there was no mention of something I think is critical: bicycles.

title: The stage is set for a 32-nation friendly mixer
Not Your Ordinary Classical Radio Station
description: IT is an unseasonably warm sunny Friday afternoon in early November, and music is in the air at WMNR Fine Arts Radio. But music is always in the air at WMNR, a public station (88.1 FM) with offices at the back of a two-story gray clapboard building in an office complex just off Route 25 in Monroe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOONG, FU, YUAN
description: SOONG--Fu-Yuan. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Robert Sterling Clark Foundation mourn the death of Soong on December 5, 2005. A gifted composer of chamber music, opera and symphonic work, Soong's pieces have been performed in halls throughout the United States including Lincoln Center, the Kennedy Center and Carnegie Hall. His work has also been performed across Europe and Asia. During the past year, his compositions for piano were performed on a world tour by renowned pianist Fou-Ts'ong. Soong is survived by his wife and life companion, Darcy Helen Hector, a long time program officer at the Clark Foundation. He is also survived by their son, Corey Ming-Sheng Soong. We will miss Soong, are saddened by his passing and offer our heartfelt sympathy to Darcy and Corey at this difficult time.

title: Congresswoman Kelly And Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Infrared Pet Dry Room, The
description: In September, at the FCI Seoul International Dog Show, the Korean engineering company Daun ENG introduced what may be the most radical new dog product since the chew toy. The Infrared Pet Dry Room is, as its name suggests, a chamber into which you place a wet dog in order to dry him or her via infrared radiation. Because infrared rays penetrate the dermis, they warm and dry an animal more quickly than a blow-dryer does, and they do so without resulting in the kinds of skin rashes that blow-dryers often cause.

title: Bullfights? Your Club or Mine?
description: HERE'S something you don't see every day: 33 mostly middle-age New Yorkers sitting around a television set in a Midtown restaurant, watching a bullfight.

title: Why Popcorn Doesn't Pop
description: Here's an undeniable fact: when you make popcorn -- no matter what brand you use, no matter how closely you follow the directions -- some kernels just won't pop. Here's another undeniable fact: at some point someone labeled those unpoppable kernels "Old Maids." That person was not Bruce Hamaker, who has never used the phrase but has received hate mail from people saying he's sexist because of it. They've got the wrong guy. Bruce Hamaker's only connection to unpopped kernels is entirely inoffensive. He has figured out why they don't pop.

title: In Transit Talks, Different Chips but Same Poker
description: The story is similar to what it was three years ago: five days from a contract deadline for New York City transit workers, the two sides, represented by the same powerful and colorful leaders, have dug in for intense, possibly round-the-clock negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, PAUL
description: GOLDMAN--Paul on December 7, 2005, formerly of Levittown, NY. Husband of the late Jane, father of Lisa, Alan and Alan's wife Doreen. Grandfather of Devon and Trevor. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc. Forest Hills, NY today, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Localized Food Aid
description: In emergency medicine, doctors often refer to the "golden hour," or the 60-minute window after a medical calamity when treatment is most likely to save the patient. Famine emergencies have a similar dynamic: if food arrives at the earliest signs of a shortage, more lives will be saved. Buying food locally often provides the greatest chance to prevent starvation. That's partly because of the geography of famine relief. About two-thirds of countries in need are in Africa, while many of the donor countries are congregated in North America and Western Europe. Shipping emergency food aid from the U.S. often takes five months or longer.

title: Present at the Disintegration
description: London - WASHINGTON and Baghdad will be tempted, with the adoption of a new Constitution and the election on Thursday for a four-year government, to declare victory in Iraq. In one sense, they are right to do so. The emerging Iraqi polity undoubtedly represents a radical break not only with the country's past but also with the whole Arab state system established by Britain and France after the collapse of the Ottoman Empire.

title: Confection Confidential
description: I FIRST met the New York tartuffo seven or eight years ago in a small restaurant in the West Village. It was a baseball-sized bombe, clothed in bittersweet chocolate: A candied cherry was at the center, wreathed in a halo of thin-sliced nuts and compressed between dense hemispheres of chocolate and vanilla ice cream. The dessert resembled the Dove bar and the chalky, utility-grade Eskimo Pie, but it was noticeably richer and apparently handmade, its simple flavors and colors making for a sweet, complex explosion. A corporation never could have produced it, I decided; mass packaging would have stifled whatever distinctiveness had survived the assembly line.

title: Nice Funds, Naughty Video Game
description: CHRISTMAS shoppers are bypassing video game bins with a vengeance, according to a report last week from the NPD Group, a market research firm. Raw data for November indicate that overall game sales dropped roughly 20 percent from the same period last year. One reason for the falloff is that buyers may be putting off software purchases until they buy the new hardware that is hitting the stores right now.

title: The Day the Sea Came
description: Thanks to Barry Bearak and to the magazine for telling the story of survivors of the tsunami with such depth, clarity and heart (Nov. 27). Bearak's choice of people, his respect for their experiences, values and beliefs and his eye for the details that allow us to enter that place and time were impressive. He offered a devastatingly intimate portrait of a nearly unimaginable disaster.

title: Nobody's Perfect
description: "Boy, you really butchered those 'Waltzing Matilda' lyrics!" exclaims a cheerful member of the Gotcha! Gang, Australian division. The version of A. B. (Banjo) Paterson's dialect lyric I recently quoted went "Once a jolly swagman camped by a billabong/Under the shade of a codibah tree,/And he sang as he sat and he waited for his billy-boil/Who'll come a-waltzing Matilda with me?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAFFE, SARAH
description: JAFFE--Sarah. 72. Daughter of Joseph Richardson and Gertrude Herring. Born in Colena, AL. on January 25, 1933, died October 26. She leaves a son, Aaron Jaffe, sister Laura Ericson, and brother Louis Richardson.

title: They're All Paying Customers to Wall Street
description: WHEN Bruce Wasserstein, the chairman of the investment bank Lazard, took on Carl C. Icahn as a client two weeks ago to go after Time Warner, rainmakers across Wall Street raised eyebrows. They worriedly whispered to each other: How could such a white-shoe firm back one of those unsavory characters called corporate raiders? What are big corporate clients going to think? Whose side is Lazard on?

title: PROGRESS LAGS IN FOSTER CARE
description: In an admission that may strengthen the case for a federal takeover of New Jersey's child welfare agency, the state's human services commissioner said last Monday that the system was likely to miss a deadline for its court-ordered overhaul at the end of the month. Speaking to members of the State Assembly's Budget Committee, Commissioner James M. Davy, whose department oversees the child welfare agency, conceded that the state had not made enough progress in parts of the improvement plan that deal with children's health care and the handling of cases. The state promised to revamp the agency, the Division of Youth and Family Services, when it settled a class-action lawsuit against the foster care system in 2003. Under the settlement, the state must meet predetermined benchmarks for improvement in areas including caseload reduction and hiring.

title: A Passage to India: Asphalt and Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ruling on Co-ops and Tax Deductions
description: A RULING by a federal appeals court last month could increase income taxes for thousands of co-op owners, co-op lawyers and accountants say.

title: Ready for Skating
description: Ready for Skating

title: Corey McNeill and Zachary Perles
description: Corey Staines McNeill, the daughter of Jennifer L. Staines of North Augusta, S.C., and Dennis L. McNeill of New York, was married last evening to Zachary Perles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Perles of Easton, Conn. The Rev. Rosemary Bray McNatt, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony in the sanctuary of the Landmark on the Park, part of the Fourth Universalist Society in New York.

title: CUBA WITHOUT CASTRO
description: To the Editor: "Waiting for Havana" (Nov. 27) by Luisita Lopez Torregrosa, about the anticipation of "the end of Fidel Castro" by the United States travel industry brings to mind a story that circulated in the early 1990's, when Miami was aflutter with rumors of Mr. Castro's impending demise from an unspecified illness.

title: Insurgents Attack Afghan Police Station, Killing 6 Officers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 10 - Afghan police officers suffered heavy casualties when they came under attack by suspected Taliban insurgents overnight in a police station in southern Afghanistan, police officials said Saturday.

title: CALENDAR
description: Theater

title: Two Students Honored for Scientific Projects
description: IT is not uncommon for scientists to be commended for their accomplishments -- unless they are teenagers.

title: Forget Nostalgia
description: To the Editor:

title: From 'Superfund' Town to Pristine Ski Resort
description: TO many who drive along Colorado's Highway 24 toward the Rocky Mountains, the town of Gilman sticks out like a sore thumb: a cluster of boarded-up shacks, dilapidated buildings and heaps of rusting mining debris accumulated over a century when the town sat atop the Eagle Mine, once the world's largest zinc mine.

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 11-Dec. 17; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: A rare glimpse into African-American social history has just gone on view at the INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY in Manhattan, where 70 photographs taken from 1860 to about 1930 offer a window into the everyday lives of black Americans during that period. "AFRICAN-AMERICAN VERNACULAR PHOTOGRAPHY: SELECTIONS FROM THE DANIEL COWIN COLLECTION" offers photographs depicting children at play, soldiers in uniform, family weddings and other snapshots from the personal histories of black Americans. It includes postcards, stereographs, cartes-de-visite and tintypes. The exhibition is drawn from more than 1,600 photographs that Mr. Cowin donated to the center in 1990. It remains on view through Feb. 26. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000.

title: Huge explosions at oil depot north of London leave 43 hurt
BENEFITS
description: Bernhardt Readings TOMORROW -- Cherry Jones and Debra Winger will read parts from roles played by Sarah Bernhardt at a performance and dinner at the Jewish Museum to raise money for the museum and Siti Company, a theater collective that provides training to theater artists. An exhibition of items from the actress's career will be on display beginning at 6:30 p.m., with performances at 7:30 and dinner with the performers at 8:30. Tickets, $250, from (212) 423-3278.

title: Iraqi Rebels Kill 5 U.S. Troops and Wound 11
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 10 - Five American soldiers were killed in rebel attacks in and near the capital, including one who died in a suicide car bombing on Friday against a group of soldiers in the Abu Ghraib neighborhood, the American military command said Saturday.

title: Prix-Fixe Indeed: 6 Luxury Hotels in Paris Fined for Collusion
description: In an embarrassing scandal that comes right before the beginning of the busy holiday season, six of the best-known luxury hotels in Paris have been fined for running an illegal price-fixing cartel that at one point pushed their room prices -- already among the highest in the world -- to an average of more than 700 euros ($840 at $1.20 to the euro) per night.

title: Kick Saves, Yes, a Savior, No
description: When the Chicago Blackhawks signed goaltender Nikolai Khabibulin to a four-year, $27 million contract in August, they did so in the hope that he would lead them to their first Stanley Cup in 45 years, the longest championship drought in the N.H.L.

title: He Says Yes to Legalized Torture
description: WASHINGTON - AS the debate over torture intensified earlier this month, Charles Krauthammer hit a nerve.

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: Embryo Adoption
description: This year, opponents of abortion stepped up their use of a carefully chosen phrase -- "embryo adoption" -- that describes a couples' decision to have a baby using the embryos of another couple.

title: Shanghai opens new shipping port
Consensual Interruptions
description: The problem is all too familiar: You're chatting with a group of people when someone's cellphone goes off, interrupting the conversation. What makes the intrusion irritating isn't so much the call itself -- the caller has no way of knowing if he has chosen a good time to cut in. It's that the group as a whole doesn't have any say in the matter. Until now.

title: CALENDAR
description: THEATER

title: Officer Dies Interrupting Burglary Near Bronx Home; Actor Is Held
description: Correction Appended

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Chelsea Loft $1,050,000

title: What's the Big Idea?
description: Q: Your ambitious new book, "Ideas: A History of Thought and Invention, From Fire to Freud," claims to chronicle all the major ideas in the world since the invention of the hand ax two million years ago. Are you trying to be a polymath? My wife says I am the know-it-all from hell.

title: Restaurants Where 'Check, Please' Won't Bring On Indigestion
description: SO let's say you make it to Manhattan and find a cheap place to stay. No small accomplishment. The next hurdle: eating well without eating through your entire budget. To that end, here are five spots where you'll be able to get a great meal and still walk away with change clinking around in your pockets.

title: Grazia Sorice and Gian-Carlo Ochoa
description: TO the 200 guests who gathered for their Nov. 20 wedding in Sarasota, Fla., Grazia Sorice and Gian-Carlo Ochoa appeared perfectly suited to each other. But only two years earlier they were sure they weren't each other's type.

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: Augusta Brown and Gill Holland
description: Augusta Wilson Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owsley Brown II of Louisville, Ky., was married there yesterday to John Gill Holland Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Holland of Davidson, N.C. The Rev. Ronald J. Knott, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Cathedral of the Assumption, with the Very Rev. Thomas C. Kelly, the archbishop of Louisville, assisting.

title: The Right Candidate In the Wrong Year?
description: Amid all the chaos surrounding Jon S. Corzine's attempts to select a successor in the Senate, Thomas H. Kean Jr. -- the presumptive Republican nominee -- had a solid enough week with a fund-raising visit by Senator Elizabeth Dole, chairwoman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, that doubled as a national party endorsement.

title: What Would a Clone Say?
description: Rosen's essay on the potential consequences of human cloning speculates that the clones themselves might oppose the process. However, it is just as easy to imagine a world in which children cloned for therapeutic purposes (for example, to donate bone marrow to a sibling with leukemia) are viewed as heroes, rather than as "creepy." While this practice might violate the rigid demands of Kantian ethics by using a human being as a means rather than an end, it can result in two happy, living children, rather than one dead one.

title: Artine Artinian, French Literature Scholar, 97, Dies
description: Artine Artinian, a noted manuscript collector and scholar of French literature who was immortalized as a fictional character by two of the most prominent American writers of the 20th century, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Lantana, Fla. He was 97 and had lived for many years in Palm Beach.

title: Playoff Paradigm, The
description: Team sports like football and basketball have long benefited from the frenzy of audience interest that attends the postseason. Now individual sports like golf, tennis and stock-car racing have realized that the playoff format can be viable -- and lucrative -- for their leagues too.

title: Satellite Radio: Out of the Car and Under Fire
description: IN the early 1990's, when the pioneers of satellite radio raised the first of the billions they needed to get their ventures aloft, the premise was fairly simple: create services that would be to old-fashioned radio what cable television was to broadcast TV. That meant providing scores of niche radio channels with high-quality signals in exchange for a monthly subscription fee. By blanketing the nation with signals beamed from on high, there would be no need for all those transmitting towers, no utter dependence on advertising and no pesky etiquette rules from the Federal Communications Commission to observe. And, the early prospectuses argued, there was a huge, natural market of people who spend hours in their vehicles, often bored out of their skulls.

title: Bring It on Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Jetliner Had Some Trouble With Equipment
description: The crew of the Southwest Airlines plane that slid off a runway at Midway Airport in Chicago on Thursday told investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board yesterday that when the plane touched down, they had some trouble with equipment meant to slow it down.

title: Letters
description: A Sense of Place

title: For a Train Tunnel, Still Very Little Light
description: IN Trenton and Albany, the race is on to build a new rail tunnel to Manhattan.

title: Water Cooler Chatter Suffers a Setback
description: O.K., so the average consumer of news in New Jersey will not notice that he is gone. They probably never even knew he was here.

title: Serialized Pop Song, The
description: Every summer has its jeep beats -- those inescapable radio hits that swell and subside with the passing S.U.V.'s. Last summer, though, one track was different: it had no chorus, no hook, no real beat even. In fact, it wasn't one song but five. It was R. Kelly's "Trapped in the Closet," a multipart urban operetta released to radio in "chapters" in anticipation of his 10th studio album, "TP.3: Reloaded." Each chapter is about three minutes long and has the same music, a nondescript slow groove, over which Kelly sings a tale of epic infidelity and improbable plot twists.

title: Nourishing Creativity With Order and Care
description: WITH her trim haircut, matching sweater set and ballet-slipper shoes, Eva Jana Siroka looks right at home in buttoned-up Princeton, N.J. But when she and her husband, Glenn MacEwen, moved there from Kingston, Ontario, nine years ago, they weren't seeking the camouflage of suburban respectability. Leaving behind a steady income, they had resolved to support themselves like free spirits, by their creativity and talents.

title: Clergy's Call Still Strong for Young Vietnamese
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 - When the Rev. Augustine Tran went to Vietnamese-American parishes as a seminarian a couple of years ago, pastors and worshipers would hand him money to help him with school, though they had little of their own. When he goes to the Vietnamese enclaves of suburban Virginia, where he now works, Roman Catholics often greet him like a celebrity, his siblings said.

title: Going to Extremes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILON, ARIE
description: GILON--Arie. New York University and the School of Continuing and Professional Studies mourn the loss of Arie Gilon, Professor Emeritus of Foreign Languages, on Nov. 29, 2005. Prof. Gilon was a member of the NYU Community for the past 45 years and was recognized for both teaching excellence and outstanding service. He was a veteran of the Korean War. Professor Gilon will be greatly missed and we offer our condolences to his wife, Lea, his son, Michael, and his grandsons Daniel and David.

title: Money and Mets
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The terrorist in the art gallery
Stalemate on Minimum Tax Would Cost Region's Households
description: Rob Cantor was doing well financially, or so he thought. College tuition for his two daughters was devouring his annual bonus, not to mention the $5,000 to $7,000 tax refund he got back every year from the federal government. But with just a few years of tuition left, he allowed himself to dream of flush days ahead.

title: CUBA WITHOUT CASTRO
description: To the Editor: I suppose I shouldn't be surprised at what I read in The New York Times anymore.

title: 'Truth and Duty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: War-Mood Metrics
description: A little less than a year ago, in the aftermath of the first Iraqi elections, the most irresponsible thing being said in Washington was that everything was going to be fine. Now, with the next set of elections scheduled for Dec. 15, the new irresponsibility is the increasingly respectable assertion that the war has already been lost. Irrational optimism has been replaced by unjustified pessimism. This is not some triumph of experience over idealism. One a priori ideological standpoint is simply giving way to another.

title: Remembering Well
description: To the Editor:

title: A Passage to India: Asphalt and Dust (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: CARING FOR SLED DOGS
description: To the Editor: In "Above the Arctic Circle, Answering the Call of the Wild" (Nov. 13), Nathaniel Vinton doesn't say if he is concerned with how the Jokkmokk Guiderna Service treats sled dogs, but he should be.

title: The Way We Eat: Sauced in Translation
description: Two of the most-talked-about cookbook releases this fall were originally published more than 50 years ago. Until now, "La Bonne Cuisine de Madame E. Saint-Ange" -- France's "Joy of Cooking" -- and "The Silver Spoon," a 2,000-recipe behemoth from Italy, had never been translated into English. They have little in common beyond being dated. "La Bonne Cuisine" is a tidy how-to treatise on traditional (and ambitious) home cooking by a working mother in Paris in the first half of the 20th century. If you have yet to master calf's-foot fritters or potatoes Anna, Saint-Ange will lead the way. "The Silver Spoon" exhibits the more relaxed standards of France's southeastern neighbor. Big and bountiful, it's a welcoming jumble of recipes like chicken-liver crostini, Hawaiian salad and meatballs with anchovies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PHILIPS, FREDERIK
description: PHILIPS - Frederik. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of Dr. Frits Philips, who we had the privilege of honoring with The Jan Zwartendijk Humanitarian Award at an International Dinner of Tribute in Amsterdam in 1997. Dr. Philips was cited for saving lives during the Holocaust. The award was named for Jan Zwartendijk, a Dutch executive at Philips, who, serving as Honorary Dutch Consul in Lithuania in 1940, likewise did the right thing simply because it was the right thing to do, saving lives during the Holocaust. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire Philips family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Raphael Benaroya, Chairmn Michael J. Scharf, President Josh Weston, Hon. Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. VP

title: Parking Meters That Don't Give You a Break
description: Pulling up to an overfed parking meter, and thus saving a quarter or two, is one of life's small pleasures. So the elders of Pacific Grove, Calif., seem like major killjoys for installing 100 high-tech meters that deprive motorists of this karmic reward. A wire grid beneath each parking space senses the magnetic disruption caused by a vehicle's departure, causing the meter's time to reset to zero.

title: Australia cancels boycott of Indonesian military
The Basics; Uptick for a Rough Second Term
description: President Bush got some good news last week: His ratings improved, somewhat, in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Forty percent approved of his job performance, up from 35 percent in November, his worst showing. Of the most recent two-term presidents, only Richard M. Nixon had a lower approval rating at the same point in his presidency. And last month's 57 percent Bush disapproval rate came perilously close to President Nixon's in December 1973, after news broke of an 18 3/5rsaquo 4/5-minute gap in a White House tape recording that was central to the Watergate investigation.

title: Limits on Registered Sex Offenders Are Also About Where the Law Can't Go
description: ONE by one, the calls came in at Kevin McCarrick's office. A convicted sex offender had moved into the hamlet of Sound Beach in Brookhaven Town, where Mr. McCarrick serves on the town board, and residents were worried.

title: Do-It-Yourself Cartography
description: The most influential mashup this year wasn't a Beatles tune remixed with hip-hop lyrics. It was an online street map of Chicago overlaid with crime statistics. Chicagocrime.org, which was created by the journalist Adrian Holovaty, was one of the first Web sites to combine publicly available data from one site (in this case, the Chicago Police Department's online database) with a digital map supplied by another site (in this case, Google).

title: Two-Dimensional Food
description: A picture may be worth a thousand words, but is it dinner? At Chicago's trendy Moto restaurant, it is: a 20-course tasting menu can begin with "sushi" made of paper that has been printed with images of maki and wrapped around vinegared rice and conclude with a mint-flavored picture of a candy cane. Should you fail to finish a course, Homaro Cantu, Moto's executive chef, will emerge from the kitchen with a refund: a phony dollar bill flavored to taste like a cheeseburger and fries. It may sound like some sort of Surrealist stunt with dire intestinal consequences, but here's the rub: the "food" tastes good. Good enough to lure diners back at $240 per head (including wine).

title: Santa Cruz: A Beach Town That Doesn't Shut Down
description: Correction Appended

title: In the Shadow of Vesuvius
description: FALLING PALACE

title: Those Anonymous Sources
description: Re "Anonymity: Who Deserves It?" (Nov. 20):

title: Old school ties bind 3 key Iraqi candidates
In Search of Good Soup? The Quest Ends Here
description: WHILE Westchester may not be the culinary mecca of the five boroughs to the south, it has great, great soup. In fact, a small passageway off South Moger Avenue in Mount Kisco should really be renamed Soup Alley, in honor of two shops there.

title: There Are Goals and There Are Goooooooals
description: "DARE TO DREAM: The Story of the U.S. Women's Soccer Team," a new documentary tonight on HBO, has plenty of clips of the team being cheered in packed stadiums, but one of the most striking pieces of film is remarkable for its emptiness.

title: Iraq, New Orleans And Bush's Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: Synesthetic Cookbook, The
description: Can't figure out what to have for dinner? Hugo Liu, a graduate student at M.I.T.'s Media Lab, has developed a "smart" cookbook that can recommend a dish on the basis of some of the tastes and emotions commonly associated with it.

title: Italy to review rail linkto France amid protest
N.F.L. Matchups | Week 14
description: Indianapolis Colts (12-0) at Jacksonville Jaguars (9-3) 1 p.m.

title: THE BANG-BUCK RATIO
description: Despite being the most expensive in state history, last month's gubernatorial election hit a low in voter turnout, according to the New Jersey Division of Elections, which has certified the results. Only 48.5 percent of registered voters went to the polls on Nov. 8. During the last gubernatorial election in 2001, 49.2 percent of registered voters cast a ballot. Jon S. Corzine defeated Douglas R. Forrester by 10.5 percentage points, getting 1,224,493 votes to Mr. Forrester's 985,235. Combined, the candidates spent $75.5 million on the increasingly nasty race that featured a number of negative television ads. John Holl
