title: Claudia Reitenbach and Michael Rudegeair
description: Claudia K. Reitenbach and Michael F. Rudegeair are to be married today in New York. Paul J. Weireter, a Roman Catholic deacon, is to perform the ceremony at St. Agnes Church.

title: Blasphemy Laws and Church Attacks Fuel Strife in Pakistani Town, Christians Say
description: SANGLA HILL, Pakistan - The people gathered inside Holy Spirit Church were quiet and somber. The altar was covered in debris. Pictures of Jesus and Mary lay in a heap nearby. Torn copies of the Bible were scattered about.

title: An Irish Paper Wants the Mother Country to Read All About It
description: When The Irish Echo was founded in 1928, more than 200,000 Irish-born people lived in New York, a result of a wave of migration that started 80 years earlier amid famine, joblessness and British colonial rule. Since the paper's founding, that number has shrunk steadily, but The Echo, which is a weekly based in Midtown Manhattan with a circulation of 20,000 in the United States, most of it in New York, has continued to chronicle the lives of the Irish who left home for a new life across the Atlantic.

title: DATEBOOK
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Carter's Mother Puts Him on a Pedestal
description: Vince Carter's mother, Michelle Carter-Scott, has always been an important presence in her son's life and career, whether cheering from the stands in New Jersey, raising her concerns in Toronto about the organization or watching him graduate from North Carolina on the day of the Eastern Conference semifinals in 2001.

title: Slain Officer Was Known for Calm, Friends Say
description: Officer Daniel Enchautegui, who was gunned down in the Bronx yesterday, patrolled the streets of the South Bronx preferring the soft weapons of language and reason, hoping that sometimes they would be disarming enough.

title: Movies on TV
description: THE MERCHANT OF VENICE (2004) Friday/Early Saturday at 4:15 a.m. on Cinemax. It says a lot about the perceived interest in Shakespeare that Cinemax is introducing this outstanding Michael Radford adaptation to television audiences in the middle of the night. The cast is certainly ready for prime time. Jeremy Irons is strong and complex as Antonio, the 16th-century title character, who takes out a loan, then runs into financial problems. Al Pacino (above) is both fierce and sympathetic as Shylock, the moneylender who made a deal for a "pound of flesh" and expects Antonio (a man who once spat on him) to pay up. The film's discovery is Lynn Collins, radiant and compelling as Portia.

title: Economics: In gas prices and bad service, a bigger picture
For the FairTax
description: To the Editor:

title: Back to the Start Of Search Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Rape Condom, The
description: The vagina dentata -- a vagina with literal or figurative teeth -- is a potent trope in South Asian mythology, urban legend, Freudian rumination and speculative fiction (the novel "Snow Crash," by Neal Stephenson, for example). But it took a step toward reality this August with the unveiling of the Rapex, a female "condom" lined with rows of plastic spikes on its inner surface.

title: Doing the Hollywood Math: What Slump?
description: SCANNING the weekly box-office reports has been a mighty sobering experience in 2005, the litany of gloom seemingly blurring into one recurring headline: Moviegoing Plummets Again. But a closer look at the movie business, in all its global reach and various outlets, tells a different story. "It's still a healthy business," said Stacey Snider, chairwoman of Universal Pictures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALMAN, MARTIN B.
description: KALMAN--Martin B. Beloved father, grandfather. Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY Sunday 10am

title: Winning and Losing On a Technicality
description: JONATHAN P. KAHN knows from parking tickets. Handling parking violations accrued by a small fleet of commercial vehicles he ran in New York City for 25 years taught him a thing or two.

title: The Economy of Desire
description: Analyzing a Sex Survey

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASHENFARB, BARRY
description: ASHENFARB--Barry. 52, of Coral Springs, FL, passed away Sunday, November 27, 2005. Your passing came too soon, but your love and spirit will forever be in our hearts. Mom (Rita), Sylvester, Ellen, Rick and Debby

title: Seven to Watch in Iraq's Election
description: Iraqis vote Thursday in a national election to establish a new four-year government.

title: Abby Kohn and Jason Linn
description: Abby Kohn and Jason Linn were married last evening at the Culinary Institute of America in St. Helena, Calif. Andy Feig, a friend of the bridegroom who was appointed deputy marriage commissioner by Los Angeles County, officiated.

title: Used Books Nestled In Coziness
description: CROSS into Union, on Interstate 84 from Massachusetts, and you immediately spy the towering sign that reads like a block-lettered welcome mat: "Traveler Books and Food."

title: Hoping for the Best? Bummer
description: HOPE springs eternal. And so, James Vanderberg hoped. He hoped that his girlfriend would not leave him, and that therefore they would not have to relinquish their cozy one-bedroom on the Upper West Side.

title: A Family Is Devastated One More Time
description: COUNTRY CLUB HILLS, Ill., Dec. 10 - On a clear and frigid morning in this snow-covered suburb south of Chicago, the first of the Knick players to come down the aisle at the packed Leak & Sons Funeral Home chapel on Saturday was the 6-foot-6 forward Quentin Richardson.

title: America's flu moat
Mancuso Is Drawing Her Own Lines in the Snow
description: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 10 - In the company of adults asking mostly boring questions, Julia Mancuso picked up a pencil, appropriated a piece of paper that was on the table in front of her and began working with the focus of a child trying to stay inside the lines with crayons in a coloring book.

title: 'Sesame Street' goes local, without some old friends
Paid Notice: Deaths   DOUGLAS, ANN C.M.
description: DOUGLAS--Ann C.M. Of Niantic, CT, died suddenly on December 8, in New London, CT. She was born in Springfield, MA, on September 27, 1934, daughter of Harvey H. and Catherine Allis Moses. She was married in Longmeadow, MA, on December 22, 1956 to R. Gordon Douglas. She was a trustee of Skidmore College, serving from 1999 to 2003, and was Vice President of Princeton Project '55. Other philanthropic interests included: public television and radio, her educational institutions, animal rights organizations, and the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme. She also endowed a chair at Skidmore College, the Douglas Family Chair in American Culture, History, Literary and Interdisciplinary Studies. Ann was a gracious lady always putting others before herself. Her greatest love was her family, her husband, three children and their spouses and nine grandchildren. Ann is survived by her husband of forty nine years, R. Gordon Douglas of Niantic, CT, her brother, C. Wicker Moses of Carbondale, CO, and her three children; Robert G. Douglas of Essex, CT, Timothy S. Douglas of Rye, NY, and Catherine L. Douglas of Providence, RI, and her nine grandchildren whom she cherished. Donations in her memory may be made to: The Development Fund of Lawrence and Memorial Hospital, 365 Montauk Avenue, New London, CT 06320 or The First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, 2 Ferry Road, Old Lyme, CT 06371. A memorial service will be held at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme at 2 pm, Tuesday, December 13, 2005.

title: CUBA WITHOUT CASTRO
description: To the Editor: If you read between the lines, "Waiting for Havana" exposes the muddle-headedness of United States policy toward Cuba. In terms of logic, it makes no sense to tie Mr. Castro's death to the end of the travel restrictions. Mr. Castro did not initiate the U.S. embargo. His continued existence is perfectly consistent with an end to the embargo. But Mr. Castro in fact favors the embargo because it provides him with a rallying cry, an excuse for all of the country's troubles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TALLAL, LISA, M.D.
description: TALLAL--Lisa, M.D. Of Dallas and New York, noted pediatric hematologist and child psychiatrist, passed away on October 16 after a long illness. She leaves behind many loving family members and devoted friends with whom she shared her incredible joy of living. Contributions may be sent to the Halcyon Foundation, 100 Park Ave, New York, NY 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALEXANDER, BROOKE
description: ALEXANDER--Brooke, 93, on December 3, 2005. Beloved and dedicated husband of the late Elizabeth Burnett Alexander (Betty). He was predeceased by his daughter, the Reverend Brooke Alexander, and is survived by a son, Breckenridge Alexander, 3 grandchildren, Katherine Dodge, Alexander Leddy, and William Leddy, and eight great-grandchildren. A 1935 graduate of Princeton University, he was a lifelong resident and unabashed admirer of The City of New York. He spent his career in the service of Time, Inc., retiring in 1973 as Assistant Publisher of Fortune Magazine. He was a member of the New York National Guard (1936-1939) and the New York State Guard (1940-1945), a long-serving member of the vestry and lifelong communicant of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, a long-standing member and devotee of the Union Club, and a member since 1954 of The Society of the Cincinnati. A memorial service will be held Monday, December 12, at 11AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave at 90th St, NYC. Donations may be made to the Elizabeth B. Alexander Fund, NightingaleBamford School, 20 East 92 Street, NY, NY 10128.

title: QUICK BITE/Carlstadt; All Hot Dogs, All the Time
description: There are those who would insist that we are not in hot dog season. They may claim that frankfurters can only be seriously considered from the first "Play ball!" of spring to the final out of the World Series. Such people are no friends of mine. And they are certainly not from New Jersey.

title: Zero Tolerance
description: TALK TO THE HAND

title: Kariya Sings the Praises of Nashville
description: Had they won in Nashville on Thursday night, the Predators would have leapfrogged Detroit into first place in the Central Division and in the Western Conference. But the Rangers pounded the Predators, 5-1. Nashville was 18-5-3 entering yesterday's game at Tampa Bay.

title: Jet carrying school children crashes in Nigeria, killing 103
Correction
description: An entry last Sunday in the Cross Westchester column misidentified the varsity regional champion at the Westchester County Regional Cheerleading Invitational. It was North Rockland High School, not New Rochelle High School.

title: Winter's Menu: Warmth Is Main Course
description: THERE are people who like Northeastern winters. I am not one of them. Sure, it is pleasant for the first couple of months when the novelty of cold-weather clothing and evening walks under a crystalline sky is still fresh. But by about mid-January, I'm sick of being indoors.

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: Collapsing the Distribution Window
description: In February, the film industry as we know it may change forever. That's when "Bubble," a low-budget murder mystery directed by Steven Soderbergh, will appear in theaters -- and on cable, and on DVD, all on the same day. The movie is the first in a six-film deal between Soderbergh and 2929 Entertainment, a partnership led by the media moguls Mark Cuban and Todd Wagner, which includes theaters, cable channels and production and distribution companies. While no one expects "Bubble" to break box-office records, even a modicum of success could indicate the arrival of something many in the movie business have anticipated -- and feared -- for years: universal release.

title: THE PANTHEON'S PULL
description: To the Editor: Thank you to Rachel Donadio, who wrote "A Grand Survivor in a Timeless City" (Cultured Traveler, Nov. 20), for the reminder.

title: ST. BARNABAS SETTLES CLAIMS
description: St. Barnabas Health Care System will pay the federal government more than $3.8 million in connection with Medicare claims, according to the office of United States Attorney Christopher J. Christie. St. Barnabas will settle claims that -- from Jan. 1, 1992, to Dec. 31, 1999 -- the hospital system violated the federal False Claims Act by wrongly submitted paperwork to Medicare that charged for multiple-day stays or a higher level of care when none was provided, Mr. Christie's office said. A St. Barnabas spokeswoman said it cooperated with the government's investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITESIDE, MARY NORMAN
description: WHITESIDE--Mary Norman. December 9, Skillman, NJ. Sister of Mabel Ehlert, of Skillman and the late Frederick W. Whiteside of Lexington, KY. Aunt of Katherine Whiteside Zalph, Louisville, KY, and Margaret Whiteside Chen, Fairfax, VA. Born in Atlanta, GA, 1914. Graduate of Randolph-Macon College and Columbia University. During forty-four years at The Chapin School, she was a distinguished and beloved teacher of English, Latin and Head of the Upper School. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Chapin School, Randolph-Macon College or Minds On at The Rensselaer Institute. A memorial service will be held on a later date.

title: A Surrogate Dries Her Tears
description: IN the bright California sunshine I'm watching a little girl run around the playground. Her wispy blond hair escapes once again from the ponytail one of her fathers carefully formed for her. She is adorable in her pink, black and white dress with matching shoes.

title: Hanging Up His Piano Man Shoes
description: In February 2001, Michael Cavanaugh was performing at the New York-New York casino in Las Vegas when Billy Joel walked in to hear him play. Mr. Cavanaugh, a Joel fan since childhood, was nervous, but he needn't have been; Mr. Joel was impressed, and within a year Mr. Cavanaugh was on his way to New York to play Billy Joel in "Movin' Out," for which he was nominated for a Tony Award.

title: Doctors and Patients Fighting a Giant
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWARD, KATHLEEN
description: HOWARD--Kathleen. December 9. Beloved wife of Hugh. Loving sister of Patricia Connelly, Sarah Beers and Mildred Reardon. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, December 11, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: Warming Trends: Build a Fire (or Fly to an Island)
description: JUDI BASS is a self-described "winter person" and lifelong skier whose husband, Duane, directs the ski racing program at Mount Southington. Aprs-ski at their home in Southington, the couple used to enjoy nothing more than curling up in front of a roaring fire except for one thing: it was cold.

title: Eugene J. McCarthy, Senate Dove Who Jolted '68 Race, Dies at 89
description: Eugene J. McCarthy, the sardonic Senate dove who stunned the nation by upending President Lyndon B. Johnson's re-election drive amid the Vietnam War turmoil of 1968, died early yesterday. He was 89.

title: Branding Nations
description: If the British consultant Simon Anholt had his way, sitting at the cabinet table with the secretary of defense and the attorney general would be a secretary of branding. Indeed, he foresees a day when the most important part of foreign policy isn't defense or trade but image -- and when countries would protect and promote their images through coordinated branding departments. "I've visited a great many countries where they have ministers for things that are far less important," he says.

title: Where It's Really the Last Picture Show
description: When Manhattanites gripe about their local cinema closing, it can seem like whining. The borough is so flooded with theaters, to complain about the loss of one would be like bemoaning the closing of a local Starbucks or the breakup of a Brooklyn band.

title: Taxonomy Auctions
description: Five years ago, the British primatologist Robert Wallace was trekking through the Bolivian rain forest when he glimpsed a new species of monkey -- a discovery that eventually gave him and his colleagues, per the rules of the taxonomy world, exclusive naming rights. Usually, species names derive from their physical or geographic characteristics, but biologists have christened their finds after everything from punk-rock bands to Ernest Hemingway. Even Bush, Cheney and Rumsfeld have been honored -- with a trio of slime-mold beetles, but honored nonetheless. Wallace and his partners, however, had a different idea: Why not sell off the naming rights and use the proceeds to finance the monkey's habitat? He and the Wildlife Conservation Society soon got in touch with Charity Folks, a New York venue for nonprofits, which this past spring conducted the world's first online taxonomy auction. Ellen DeGeneres made a bold stab at winning the bid -- even publicizing the auction on her talk show -- but the highest offer came from GoldenPalace.com, a gambling and entertainment Web site, which put up $650,000. Behold Callicebus aureipalatii -- roughly, the golden palace monkey.

title: Rocker Meets Soccer, Witheringly
description: Mark E. Smith

title: The Way to a Feast, Not Just for the Eyes
description: THE ARCH, Route 22 North, Brewster; (845) 279-5011. Lunch, Wednesday to Friday; dinner, Wednesday to Saturday, open Sunday noon to 8:30 p.m. Prix fixe four-course dinner, $65.

title: A Little Sleuthing Unmasks Writer of Wikipedia Prank
description: It started as a joke and ended up as a shot heard round the Internet, with the joker losing his job and Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia, suffering a blow to its credibility.

title: Keep Trucks Off the Parkway
description: Melville - THOUSANDS of Long Islanders (myself included) were late for work on Nov. 9, because of a horrendous traffic jam on the Northern State Parkway. Even by Long Island's lofty standards for traffic jams, this one stood out. The problem? Something much too common: a tractor-trailer driving illegally on the parkway hit an overpass at Hillside Avenue. Traffic was backed up for hours in both directions.

title: Soccer: No sleight of hand (even God's), unfortunately for Argentina
Conservative Blogs Are More Effective
description: When the liberal activist Matt Stoller was running a blog for the Democrat Jon Corzine's 2005 campaign for governor, he saw the power of the conservative blogosphere firsthand. Shortly before the election, a conservative Web site claimed that politically damaging information about Corzine was about to surface in the media. It didn't. But New Jersey talk-radio shock jocks quoted the online speculation, inflicting public-relations damage on Corzine anyway. To Stoller, it was proof of how conservatives have mastered the art of using blogs as a deadly campaign weapon.

title: The Bear Who Was There at the Start of It All
description: IN a courtroom scene from "The Simpsons" that has since entered into the television canon, an argument over the ownership of the animated characters Itchy and Scratchy rapidly escalates into an existential debate on the very nature of cartoons. "Animation is built on plagiarism!" declares the show's hot-tempered cartoon-producer-within-a-cartoon, Roger Myers Jr. "You take away our right to steal ideas, where are they going to come from?"

title: Accredited Bliss
description: If you think financing a motion picture is difficult, consider for a moment the fund-raising bench mark that the filmmaker David Lynch set this year for his new David Lynch Foundation for Consciousness-Based Education and World Peace: $7 billion. The director of "Mulholland Drive" hopes to finance seven "universities of peace," with endowments of $1 billion each, where students would practice Transcendental Meditation.

title: Sick as a Parrot
Explosions rock fuel depot north of London
The Complexities Of College Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Sleigh Bells Gurgle, Santa Swims With Sharks
description: NEWPORT, Ky., Dec. 7 - Calvin Freeman, age 4, has a question for Scuba Santa. "Do you only have nice sharks in there?" Calvin asks, pointing to a toothy, 270-pound tiger shark swishing past Santa's underwater sleigh. "Because some sharks chew people's legs off. They're bad sharks."

title: Nigeria plane crash kills 107, mostly children
Paid Notice: Deaths   EHRLICH, FRANCES BORG
description: EHRLICH -- Frances Borg. Passed away peacefully in her home on December 6, 2005. She was born in New York City on December 10, 1916, to Arthur and Maybelle Marx. She was a longtime resident of Scarsdale, New York City, and West Cornwall, CT. She was the wife of the late John Simon Borg and the late William Ehrlich. She leaves her two daughters, Wendy Furth and Cynthia Borg Mintz, and her stepson, Dr. Donald Cecil Borg, 11 grandchildren and 16 greatgrandchildren. The family plans a private commemorative service. Memorial donations may be made to "Gilda's Club" of Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROSS, ISABEL FLORENCE KENNEY
description: BROSS--Isabel Florence Kenney. On December 7, 2005, of NYC. Beloved wife of 60 years of the late Steward R. Bross Jr. Devoted mother of Donna Campagna of Ellicott City, MD, and grandmother of Christina Kapp and Brian Cunneff. Great-grandmother of Emily and Nora Kapp. A funeral service will be held Tuesday, December 13, at 2 pm, at the Trinity Church, Wall Street and Broadway, NYC. Following the service a reception will be held at the church. Entombment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice of Howard County, 5537 Twin Knolls Rd, Suite 433, Columbia, MD 21045.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 11, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Allison Davis and Edward O'Keefe
description: Virginia Lee Allison Davis, the daughter of Christina R. Davis and Richard R. Davis of New York, was married yesterday to Edward Fitzpatrick O'Keefe, a son of Heather O'Keefe and William G. O'Keefe of Grand Forks, N.D. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall officiated at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: National Smiles
description: Dacher Keltner, a professor of psychology at the University of California at Berkeley, contends that Americans and the English smile differently. On this side of the Atlantic, we simply draw the corners of our lips up, showing our upper teeth. Think Julia Roberts or the gracefully aged Robert Redford. "I think Tom Cruise has a terrific American smile," Keltner, who specializes in the cultural meaning of emotions, says. In England, they draw the lips back as well as up, showing their lower teeth. The English smile can be mistaken for a suppressed grimace or a request to wipe that stupid smile off your face. Think headwaiter at a restaurant when your MasterCard seems tapped out, or Prince Charles anytime.

title: Unlicensed (Part 1)
description: I don't have a driver's license, but it's not because anything is wrong with me, or because I once drove drunk, or because my religion shuns cars in favor of horse and buggies. It's because I grew up in Manhattan, where traffic, vandalism, the cost of a garage and the difficulty of parking made owning a car about as practical as owning a gondola. In high school, a few of my classmates took driver's ed, but almost all of them failed. The rest of us continued participating in enrichment programs, stepping over crack vials in our playgrounds, frolicking in open fire hydrants in the heat of summer -- all the things city kids do instead of learning how to drive a car.

title: Pleistocene Rewilding
description: The golden era of North America, in the eyes of today's North Americans, was about 200 years ago, when bison roamed the Great Plains by the millions. But even that is a watered-down memory. Thirteen thousand years ago, truly mega fauna, including lions, cheetahs, camels and five kinds of elephant, also walked the land -- and still would today, had humans not come along to speed their extinction.

title: Stream-of-Consciousness Newspaper, The
description: Hurricane Katrina transformed many things -- the city of New Orleans, the coastline of Louisiana, President Bush's approval rating -- but perhaps the most surprising change was the one it wrought on the American newspaper.

title: Paige Kahn and Jeffrey Perkins
description: Paige Alison Kahn, the daughter of Maida and David L. Kahn of Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Martin Perkins, a son of Shirley and Richard A. Perkins of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Levin officiated at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Winged Feet
description: Pedestrians seemed to be mimicking the swans in Harry Winston's holiday window, above, their arms outstretched for balance as they hopped and jumped over the slush-and-snow-clogged curbs at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street on Friday. The color of the day: orange. ON THE STREET

title: BUFFETT GOES ELECTRIC
description: Investing buffs, ready your pocketbooks. Through Thursday, those with cash to spare can bid on a white Fender Stratocaster guitar signed by Warren E. Buffett, George Soros and other legends of the investing world. The online auction is sponsored by Minyanville.com, a financial Web site.

title: Russia Tries P.R. to Brighten Its Dismal Image
description: The Web site for Foreign Policy magazine (www.foreignpolicy.com) has an essay, "Spinning Russia," by Julian Evans Page, that looks at how Russia under President Vladimir V. Putin is working on its image.

title: Chile looks set to hand presidency to a woman
Porn Suffix, The
description: Establishing a new Internet suffix like ".com" or ".org" takes deep pockets and patience. This has not deterred Stuart Lawley, a Florida entrepreneur, from trying to establish a pornography-only ".xxx" domain. In such a realm, Lawley could restrict porn marketing to adults only, protect users' privacy, limit spam and collect fees from Web masters. The .xxx proposal was finally slated for approval in August by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (Icann), but because of a flurry of protest, it has been shelved for now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORZENIK, SIDNEY S.
description: KORZENIK--Sidney S. Died December 6 at age 96. Husband of Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenik, father of David, Jeremy, Deborah and Joshua, grandfather of Alexander, Hannah, Daniel & Benjamin. He was adored by all of them and is for them the model of a humane, intellectual and virtuous life. He was a blessing to his family and his community. Friends and family will gather for a memorial service Sunday, December 11, 2005, 3 PM at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Reading Reform Foundation of NY, 333 W. 57th Street, Suite 1L, NY, NY 10019; American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel, 855 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 531, NY, NY 10001; New Israel Fund; and Human Rights First.

title: Those Anonymous Sources
description: I have worked in the offices of a United States senator, a federal circuit judge and a former president. I also have worked in a prominent law firm. Each of these employers had a common practice -- no one, other than a designated person, should talk to the press.

title: The Deal Must Go On, Even in New Orleans
description: New Orleans is still struggling to recover from Hurricane Katrina, but that isn't stopping some of Wall Street's top deal makers and merger lawyers from pursuing their annual takeover of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLMES, BROTHER EDMUND, O.S.F.
description: HOLMES--Brother Edmund, O.S.F. Died on Friday, December 9, 2005. Brother was born on August 11, 1908. He was a Fransciscan Brother of Brooklyn from 1929 until his death. Brother was a professor at St. Francis College, Brooklyn Heights, NY, for many years and a counselor at Camp Albernia in Centerport, NY, for over 50 years. Brother Edmund is survived by his sister Mary Bickford, brother Michael Holmes, three nieces, Barbara Tuck of Great Neck, NY, Virginia Fahey of Syosset, NY, and Maureen Lawrence. Wake will be held at St. Francis Monastery at Mount Albernia, 103 Prospect Rd., Centerport, NY, Monday, December 12, and Tuesday, December 13, from 2-4 and 7-9 pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Wednesday, December 14, 10:30 am, at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs R.C. Church, Prospect Rd, Centerport, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Wesbury, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRIMMER, HAROLD LEE
description: DRIMMER--Harold Lee. Age 91. On December 3. Of Rye, N.Y. and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Beloved husband of Sunny. Cherished father of Judy (Herb), Steve (Nadia) and Eric (Glenda). Stepfather of Karen, Peter and Susan. Adored grandfather of six and great-grandfather of five. Beloved brother of Helen Petziner & Muriel Glener.

title: Congressman Adds More Vegetables to Amtrak's Load
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 - Amtrak certainly knows how to lose money, but the railroad says it can lose less if only it can get out of the business of hauling cars of "premium" freight like perishables behind its cross-country trains.

title: Confusing Corner To Be Rebuilt
description: A tricky intersection on Route 25A in Kings Park that has plagued motorists and local residents alike could prove less troublesome after the State Transportation Department completes modifications at the corner next year.

title: Gardens on Ice, or Just Chilled, Still Provide Respite
description: WINTER in Connecticut can be bitter, but there is refuge in a thick coat and a warm hat and mittens, and serenity in a winter's walk.

title: The Rise of Illiterate Democracy
description: The nonfiction best-seller lists these days are often full of partisan screeds labeling Democrats as elitist traitors and Republicans as conniving plutocrats. But look over on the fiction side, and politics appears almost nowhere. Some critics read Philip Roth's "Plot Against America" as an allegory of the current White House, and there have even been a few blunt and appalling political fantasies, like Nicholson Baker's "Checkpoint," a brief dialogue between a man who wants to assassinate George W. Bush and a friend who wants to talk him out of it. But unlike the ubiquitous nonfiction tub-thumpers, today's novels rarely take the grubby business of ordinary politics, past or present, as a subject, let alone an activity in which their authors might participate. Contemporary party politics, which once inspired writers as different as James Fenimore Cooper, Mark Twain and Robert Penn Warren, is terra incognita. The separation of church and state is hotly contested; the separation of literature and state seems to have become absolute.

title: The Benefits (and Drawbacks): It's All in the Cards
description: Correction Appended

title: JUVENILE CRIME GUIDELINES
description: The New Jersey attorney general last Wednesday directed the state's police departments to adopt uniform guidelines for first-time juvenile offenders charged with minor infractions, to keep them out of court and free of a police record. The directive grew out of a survey of the local police in which 356 departments reported that they were already using various mechanisms to keep juveniles picked up on minor violations from going to court. But 40 more departments that responded had no such programs, according to the survey, creating a disparity in the treatment of juveniles within the state. Even those that did have such programs, state investigators said, had little documentation, formal guidelines or enforcement. Officials provided no details on which communities have the programs and which do not. The guidelines direct the police to use "station house adjustments" that in the past have informally been in effect for youths when they are arrested for the first time for ordinance violations, petty disorderly-conduct charges and other minor infractions.

title: Take Off Your Emotional Clothes and Sing
description: BARBARA COOK walked onstage recently at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Juilliard carrying what appeared to be a massive, mutant tangerine with handles. On closer inspection, it was revealed to be merely an oversize purse of a peculiarly vivid hue, but it still looked incongruous against her clean black ensemble. She plopped it down beside a chair, where it sat for the two-hour duration of the master class she conducted for aspiring singers.

title: Sonic Gunman Locator, The
description: The bombs get all the headlines, but gunfire is also a constant threat to American troops in Iraq. Between the shattered buildings, the rubble piles, the swirling dust storms and the roaring Humvees, shooters can be very hard to find. The Pentagon's response: start equipping Humvees with technology that can automatically pinpoint where the shots are coming from.

title: Holiday Getaways: There Are Places Other Than Home
description: Correction Appended

title: 'Truth and Duty'
description: To the Editor:

title: From Banality to Audacity
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - DURING Saddam Hussein's remorseless harangues from the dock last week, one spectator sitting in the glassed-off viewing galleries found his mind moving back more than 40 years, to a court in another Middle Eastern country where a man accused of mass murder stood on trial for his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, EVA
description: ROBERTS--Eva, 93. On November 24, 2005. Violinist and teacher. Taught for many years at the Third Music Settlement School and at the YMCA. Recognized and loved by all who knew her, as a fiercely independent woman who challenged everybody to achieve artistic and intellectual excellency. Eva, we love you. -Ivette, Jorge, Rene, Isabelle Lenard and Isaac, Iara and Dalia Sapoznikow. Memorial service TBA.

title: A taste of Syria's past in discreet splendor
Politics, Iraqi Style: Slick TV Ads, Text Messaging and Gunfire
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 10 - After putting up 100,000 posters across Iraq to promote his political party, Hamid Kifai discovered this week that they had all been torn down, even the ones on the front of his own campaign headquarters in the south.

title: Accepting Nobel, ElBaradei Urges a Rethinking of Nuclear Strategy
description: OSLO, Dec. 10 - The world should stop treating the nuclear ambitions of Iran and North Korea as isolated cases and instead deal with them in a common effort to eliminate poverty, organized crime and armed conflict, the director general of the United Nations' nuclear monitoring agency said Saturday in accepting the 2005 Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, BERNARD L.
description: COHEN--Bernard L. On December 8, 2005. Beloved husband of Pauline for over 57 years. Adored father of Diane & Jeffrey Schuman, June & Michael Cohen. Loving grandfather of Jamie & Matt, Allison, Kate, Amy, Nikki, & Stephanie and his aide Concordio. Co-owner of Baron & Port Lincoln Mercury with his partner of 55 years, Morris Baron. W.W. II Army Air Force Captain who flew 67 missions in the European theatre. His love of life inspired so many and made the world such a better place. His kindness to all will always be remembered and his legacy of love will live forever in our hearts. Services Sunday 10:30, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Alpine Skiing: Swiss disqualified for illegal skis
The 5th Annual Year in Ideas
description: This issue marks the fifth anniversary of what is becoming a venerable tradition at the magazine: The Year in Ideas. As always, we seek to gain some perspective on what has transpired since January by compiling a digest of the most noteworthy ideas of the past 12 months. Like the biographer Lytton Strachey surveying the Victorian Age, we row out over the great ocean of accomplishment and lower into it a little bucket, which brings up to the light characteristic specimens from the various depths of the intellectual sea -- ideas from politics and science, medicine and law, popcorn studies and camel racing. Once we have thrown back all the innovations that don't meet our exacting standards, we find ourselves with the following alphabetical catch: 78 notions, big and small, grand and petty, serious and silly, ingenious and. . . well, whatever you call it when you tattoo an advertisement on your forehead for money.

title: The 10 Best Books of 2005
description: FICTION

title: Readable Medicine Bottle, The
description: With their squeezed, blocky typefaces, odd assortments of inexplicable numbers and mysterious codings, the tops that come off too easily or not at all, prescription medicine bottles remind you, above all, not to expect too much from medicine. One look at the forlorn bottle and its dated, amber cast, and we can practically see the hospital walls in that milky green, the plastic wrap sweating over the canned fruit salad. Medicine, it seems, is supposed to resist the aesthetic touch. We have come to accept that unquestioningly, just as we've come to accept so much else about the way we move through the world of health care.

title: The Funny Pages
description: As a member of the medical profession and an occasional airline passenger, I was appalled at Todd Barry's "Mile-High Anxiety" (Nov. 20). I would have insisted that the airline-seat pocket be removed, whether I received a reward for it or not. A needle from the syringe could have become dislodged and trapped in the folds at the bottom of the pocket. For someone to put a hand inside the pocket was dangerous. And I was shocked to learn that flight attendants do not have disposable gloves on board.

title: Sweeney Todd's Game of Musical Chairs
description: During performances of the new pared-down Broadway revival of "Sweeney Todd," the 10 members of the cast also double as the orchestra. But an even more pared-down version takes place in the dressing rooms on the sixth floor, where the standbys practice their instruments note for note in time with the performance.

title: Town-House Block That Began in Brownstone
description: EAST 81ST STREET from Fifth to Madison Avenue was one of those solid brownstone blocks, built up from end to end with chocolate-colored row houses between 1878 and 1884. New residents in the early 20th century tuned up the architecture with an ambitious group of town houses. Today, only fragments of the original brownstone material remain -- but there's still plenty to see.

title: A Chance Discovery at Jones Beach That Led to a Series of Tough-Guy Roles
description: In 1993, Lillo Brancato Jr. was a 17-year-old unknown actor from Yonkers who scored the biggest of Hollywood breaks for his first film: appearing opposite his idol, Robert De Niro, in "A Bronx Tale."

title: Short Shrift for Shorts
description: To the Editor:

title: Toy Story 3-D, Next Generation
description: Pixar has had great success using cutting-edge technology to turn ordinary playthings into the stars of movies like "Toy Story" and "Toy Story 2." But in an unusual twist, the company is using equally sophisticated technology to turn computer-generated characters into 19th-century toys (or at least making them look like that).

title: Subadolescent Queen Bees
description: Anyone who has spent time in a middle-school cafeteria knows that girls can be nasty. As it happens, cattiness isn't confined to the pubescent set. According to a study released by Brigham Young University researchers earlier this year, girls as young as 4 manipulate their peers to stay atop the social hierarchy. "They'll spread rumors and give their peers the silent treatment," says David Nelson, an assistant professor of marriage, family and human development at B.Y.U. and an author of the study. "They do whatever works to maintain control." So much for the sugar-and-spice reputation of the sandbox set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAW, KENNEDY, BART J.
description: SHAW - KENNEDY -- Bart J. Kane Lodge No. 454 F.& A.M. mourns the loss with great sorrow of our esteemed brother on December 6 at his home in Charlottesville, VA. He was a Life Member for 55 years who loved to return to NYC and Kane Lodge frequently. He shall be missed and remembered. A memorial service is scheduled at 1:30PM on Wednesday, December 21, 2005, at Grace Episcopal Church in Keswick, VA. Contributions may be made to the SPCA of Charlottesville, PO Box 7047, Charlottesville, VA 22906. C. Christian Winslow, Master Paul D. Reitz, Secretary

title: Monkey Pay-Per-View
description: Entertainment moguls, take note: scientists are now one step closer to understanding what a monkey will -- and won't -- pay to see.

title: Now Showing on Cable
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec.11-Dec. 17; FILM
description: It's the season for scheming geishas, lovesick cowboys and computer-generated lions, tigers and Kong, oh my -- which means, of course, it's also the season for the dog-and-pony show part of the Oscar race. Though there is no official start date for the Oscar season, the race definitely quickens during the busy weeks leading up to Christmas, when an alphabet soup of awards-giving groups shake hands and brush elbows with contenders, plausible and otherwise.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about recent movie biographies of figures from the postwar era misstated a film title. The movie is "Where the Truth Lies," a fictional portrait loosely based on Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, which was released in October, not "What Lies Beneath," a 2000 thriller.

title: The Pride of Columbus
description: Columbus, Ohio - JUST after July 4, 2002, Jon and Donna Woods helped their 17-year-old daughter, Catherine, move to New York. They pulled out of their driveway in a minivan loaded with her clothes, dance shoes, photographs and the stuffed rabbit she had had since she was a baby. They drove all day, sweeping across Pennsylvania on the interstate.

title: Endpaper
description: In the realm of the inventive mind, some of this year's patents.

title: Touch Screens That Touch Back
description: Americans are familiar with the touch screens on A.T.M.'s, casino games and flight check-in kiosks. Curiously, though, none of these technologies actually take advantage of a user's sense of touch. Despite our skin's enormous ability to give us feedback about our surroundings, our eyes dominate our other senses.

title: One Man's Arabia
description: THE GREAT WAR

title: A Good Place For Our Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: A Passage to India: Asphalt and Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: When North Meets Nascar
description: The International Speedway Corporation -- which owns more than half of the 22 tracks that play host to Nascar's immensely popular and profitable racing circuit -- recently invited civic leaders and important politicians from Staten Island to a race in Florida. This clever interchange of Southern and Northeastern cultures was part of Nascar's strategy to persuade Staten Island that big-time stock-car racing is good clean family fun and an economic gold mine and that therefore Nascar should be allowed to build an 80,000 seat track on the island.

title: Zero-Emissions S.U.V., The
description: In the 90's, environmentalists could celebrate at least one success story: the "cap and trade" system, a market-inspired strategy for reducing harmful factory emissions. The way it works is simple. Companies that want to produce emissions beyond the legal limit are allowed to buy the right to release additional emissions from companies that have managed to keep their own emissions below the limit. Recently, Karl Ulrich, a professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, introduced a microversion of the same policy -- only applied to individual automobiles as opposed to factories. It allows a socially conscious driver to cancel out the environmental damage caused by his car.

title: Saving a Floor Made Messy by Pollock
description: THE story doesn't read like a thriller. Nor does it have movie potential like Jonathan Harr's newly published "The Lost Painting," an account of the discovery and restoration of a Caravaggio missing for two centuries. But its art historical importance is no less significant, especially on Long Island.

title: Moving Images Before Movies
description: Far from the Pixar show, another example of pre-film history is also being revived. Every film history buff knows that the Lumire brothers are credited as the inventors of motion pictures, in 1895. But fewer know that in 1781 Philippe-Jacques de Loutherbourg designed a small mechanical theater that was a forerunner of cinema. He called it the Eidophusikon (eye-duh-FOOZ-i-kon), a modern re-creation of which is at the Yale Center for British Art, 1080 Chapel Street, New Haven, through Dec. 31.

title: Constance Lynch and James Mabli
description: Constance Keefe Lynch, the daughter of Angela and James M. Lynch of Glastonbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Geoffrey Mabli, the son of Lynn and James J. Mabli of Harrington Park, N.J. The Rev. Robert D. Farrell officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Dunstan.

title: Glacial Gains in Global Talks on Cleaner Air
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 10 - Where do they go from here?

title: Scientific Free-Throw Distraction
description: Every basketball fan knows that the seats behind a backboard don't afford a great view of the court, but they do provide an opportunity to affect a game's outcome. By waving ThunderStix -- those long, skinny balloons that make noise when smacked together -- or other implements of distraction, fans sitting behind the basket can unnerve an opposing team's foul shooters and make them miss. But not, a new theory holds, unless the fans gesticulate in a particular way.

title: LONG KONG
description: At the annual NBC Universal holiday party for the news media, Bob Wright, the chairman, was in an expansive mood. In humorous remarks to the guests who assembled at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, he surveyed his TV, film and online empire, spending a few moments praising Universal's big holiday movie, "King Kong," which opens this week.

title: Lisa Hardy and John Summa
description: Lisa Louise Hardy and John Francis Summa were married last evening in Burlington, Vt. The Rev. David D. Wright, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the College Street Congregational Church.

title: Rangers Negate Blues' Late Tying Goal
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10 - In his first game back from an ankle injury, Rangers goaltender Kevin Weekes was more than ready to face the lowly St. Louis Blues here Saturday. His teammates apparently were not.

title: TV Stardom on $20 a Day
description: AMANDA CONGDON is a big star on really small screens -- like the 4 1/2- inch window she appears in on computer monitors every weekday morning or the 2 1/2 inches she has to work with on the new video iPod. Ms. Congdon, you see, is the anchor of a daily, three-minute, mock TV news report shot on a camcorder, edited on a laptop and posted on a blog called Rocketboom, which now reaches more than 100,000 fans a day.

title: CALENDAR
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILLS, DOROTHY S.
description: SILLS -- Dorothy S. Died peacefully on December 2, 2005 in Boynton Beach, FL. at the age of 86. Beloved wife of the late Col. Tom W. Sills; loving mother to daughters Cynthia Davis of Delray Beach, FL; the late Madeline (Gardner) Budzynski; step daughters Mary Ann Marks and husband Donald; Susan Wilson and husband Jimmy. She is survived by her grandchildren Jennifer Davis and partner Janet Barry; Michael Davis and wife Jennifer Davis; Paul Budzynski and wife Rachel; Jessica Brown and husband Jeffrey; Elizabeth Budzynski; Jeffrey Budzynski; Ann Harris and husband Leon; Tom Marks and wife Lorraine; great grandchildren Rosasharn Lilly and Shira Malka Brown; Isabella Madeline Budzynski; Jessica, Shannon and Zachary Harris; Brittney King and Heather Yeckley. She was a member of Agudas Achim Congregation in Alexandria, VA. and generously donated to many charities. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in her name to VB Cancer Research, care of Dorothy Dischler, 7195 Via Genova, Delray Beach, FL. 33446. She will be dearly missed by all who knew and loved her. Memorial service will be at Arlington National Cemetery, Old Post Chapel on December 20, 2005 at 9am.

description: A video feature on ice skating in New York City, including at Bryant Park (above), is at nytimes.com/travel.

title: Reinventing the Library As Literary Playground
description: White Plains - WHEN Sandra C. Miranda, director of the White Plains Public Library, first thought about expanding the children's rooms at the library, she knew only that she was aiming for something spectacular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDNER, ALBERT H., DDS.
description: RUDNER--Albert H., DDS. In his 98th year beloved husband of the late Gladys Rudner for 66 years, loving father of Jane and Maurice (Reese) Sherman and Judy and Jerry Kessel. Adored grandfather of Cathy and Jon Fiebach, Susan and Les Morgenstein, Danny and Kirstin Stiebel and Lynn and John Fitzgerald. Dear great grandfather of Charlie, Josh, Aidan, Jamie, Matthew and Lucy. During W.W. II he was a captain in the cavalry. He practiced dentistry in NYC for over 60 years, he loved people and he loved life. Private services were held.

title: Richard Pryor, Iconoclastic Comedian, Dies at 65
description: Richard Pryor, the iconoclastic standup comedian who transcended barriers of race and brought a biting, irreverent humor into America's living rooms, movie houses, clubs and concert halls, died Saturday. He was 65.

title: Wake Up and Smell the Coffee (And the Eggs, Toast, Bacon )
description: "LIFE, within doors, has few pleasanter prospects than a neatly arranged and well-provisioned breakfast." Nathaniel Hawthorne wrote the words in "The House of Seven Gables" in 1851, and few would argue today.

title: Commission Finds Irregularities in Iraqi Voter Registration
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 11 - With just four days to go until parliamentary elections, the Iraqi electoral commission said today that it had found irregularities in voter registration in the volatile northern oil city of Kirkuk.

title: Case Study: Terrorist Hides Bomb. Terrorist Is Captured, but Won't Speak. Is Torture O.K.?
description: To torture or not? In the Dec. 5 issue of the conservative Weekly Standard, Charles Krauthammer argued for the legalization of torture under strictly limited conditions, and criticized Senator John McCain's proposal to ban all "cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment" of detainees by American soldiers and intelligence operatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NADELL, RUTH
description: NADELL--Ruth. December 8, 2005. Passed away peacefully at the Williams Memorial Residence. Devoted mother of Carol Nadell and Ralph and his wife Jeannie Nadell. Caring grandmother of Jesse and Eli. She leaves many who loved her and admired her. We will miss her beautiful smile. Memorial service on Saturday, December 17, at 1:30 P.M., at the Williams residence, 720 West End Ave. (at 95th Street), NYC.

title: Juvenile Cynics
description: Adults often extol children for their innocence, but according to a recent study by researchers at Yale's department of psychology, kids are in fact the most hardened of cynics.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Despite concerns voiced by some airline passengers and flight attendants that the move might compromise their safety, the Transportation Security Administration has decided to end its ban on small scissors and a few other carry-on items. Effective Dec. 22, travelers will be able to take on the plane scissors with blades less than four inches long and screwdrivers less than seven inches long, along with knitting needles, tweezers and nail clippers. (Still banned: box-cutters, knives, hammers and ice picks.) T.S.A. officials said the move was part of a larger effort to focus more on finding explosives, instead of confiscating small items the agency doesn't feel pose a serious threat. In addition, the T.S.A. said it was going to increase the number of random searches of passengers. The development of a Las Vegas-style resort community, the first ever in Spain, is being planned for Ciudad Real, roughly 120 miles south of Madrid. The biggest name attached to the project so far is Harrah's Entertainment, which has just signed up to open a branch of Caesars Palace there by 2008. The planned Caesars complex will include an 850-room hotel, a 50,000-square-foot casino and a 3,000-seat theater. Speaking of Las Vegas, Atlantic City's loss is aparently Sin City's gain. After 84 years on the Jersey Shore, the Miss America pageant will be held in Las Vegas on Jan. 21 at the Aladdin hotel-casino and shown on the Country Music Television cable channel. James Denton, of "Desperate Housewives," will take over the old Bert Parks role, but no word on whether he will end the evening by singing "There she is ." ADVISORY: TRAVEL NOTES

title: Bringing the Mountain Much Closer to You
description: EVERY year around the first frost, Phil and Devon Dobson of New Milford, brothers who are avid snowboarders and skiers, start looking forward to the trips their family usually takes to big resorts in Vermont or Colorado.

description: Correction Appended

description: We're at the peak of the holiday music season, when the days are short and the nights are messianic. There are at least eight local performances of Handel's "MESSIAH" this week alone. Some listeners will be thrilled; others will want a good alternative.
