title: A Plan to Toughen Housing Enforcement
description: Suffolk County officials have proposed legislation that would encourage towns and villages in the county to crack down on overcrowded and illegal housing by adopting tougher housing-code enforcement laws.

title: After the Victorians
description: In 1900 there was published in Vienna one of the most extraordinary and revolutionary texts ever to come from a human brain. Die Traumdeutung (The Interpretation of Dreams) expounded the theory on which all subsequent psychoanalysis was based, even or especially those psychoanalytical theories which reacted most violently against it: namely, that the human mind consists of what might be described as two layers. With the outer layer, of our conscious mind, we reason and form judgements. In reasonable, well-balanced individuals, the pains and sorrows of childhood have been worked through, put behind them. With the unhealthy, however, neurotic or hysterical individuals, there is beneath the surface of life a swirling cauldron of suppressed memories in which lurk the traumas (the Greek word for wounds) of early experiences. Under hypnosis, or in dreams, we re-enter the world of the subconscious and with the care of a helpful analyst we can sometimes revisit the scenes of our early miseries and locate the origins of our psychological difficulties. The author of this world-changing book, Dr Sigmund Freud (1856-1939), was a happily married neurologist, born in the Moravian town of Freiberg, but for most of his life resident in Vienna, hub of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, where his consulting room in Berggasse 19, Vienna IX (from 1931), and his celebrated couch, on which patients lay to recite their sorrows, became a totemic emblem of the century which was to unfold. The need to return to some forgotten, irrational, dark place of our lost past became compelling, personal and collective, as the hysteria of the twentieth century reached its crescendo-point and as Dr Freud, a Jew, though a non-believing one, packed his belongings and took his family to live in London for the last year of his life, following the Anschluss, the joining together of Germany and Austria into a Great Germany, Grossdeutschland. He had already had the honour of having his books burned in Berlin in 1933, and in 1938 they were burned in Vienna.

title: Congresswoman Kelly And Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Unbundles of Joy
description: WHEN the Internet age dawned, the priests of this new technology spoke knowingly of "convergence," and so convergence has come to pass.

title: Solar Sailing
description: Solar sailing is a bit like a missing link between Carl Sagan and Patrick O'Brian. "Imagine hoisting a sail and being out there in space," says Louis Friedman, the project director of Cosmos 1, the world's first solar-sail spacecraft. "It's a beautiful idea, and it conjures up the idea of the great sailing ships and whole notion of exploration." On June 21, Friedman's team placed the unmanned Cosmos 1 inside an intercontinental ballistic missile and launched it skyward from a Russian submarine. The missile faltered, and Cosmos 1 crashed into the sea -- a scene recalling great shipwrecks more than great discoveries.

title: Building Stories
description: PART 13: 9 a.m.

title: Several Thousand Protest Trade Talks in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 11 - Several thousand protesters from around the world took to the streets peacefully here this afternoon as trade ministers began flying in for negotiations that appear increasingly likely to focus on commerce with the world's poorest nations.

title: Totally Religious, Absolutely Democratic Constitution, The
description: A decade ago, almost everyone across the political spectrum -- from neoconservatives to Islamic fundamentalists -- agreed that democracy and Islam were inherently incompatible. This consensus followed from definitions: democracy means the rule of the people, whereas Islam teaches the sovereignty of God. In October, though, Iraqis went to the polls and ratified a Constitution that committed itself with equal strength to both democracy and Islam. The document announced that Iraq would be a democracy with equality for all and declared that no law could contradict the principles of democracy. At the same time, it declared Islam the basic source of law and the official religion, and it decreed that no law could contradict "the provisions of the judgments of Islam." The country's leading Shiite clerics supported the Constitution and instructed their followers to vote for it. The neoconservatives in Washington took a deep breath and then hailed it as a milestone in Middle Eastern freedom.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a recent antitrust lawsuit against BAR/BRI, a provider of bar review courses for law school graduates, referred incorrectly to an earlier lawsuit, filed against the company in May 1992. While Eliot Disner, a lawyer, filed amended antitrust claims on behalf of the American Professional Testing Service and helped gather evidence in that case, the initial complaint was filed by the law firm of Richman, Lawrence, Mann, Greene, Arbiter & Chizever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAUL, ELI E.
description: SAUL--Eli E. On December 7, 2005 at age 92. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Devoted father of Dr. Barry Saul, Cheri Saul, and father-in-law of Ellen Saul. Proud grandfather of Dr. Karen Miller (Howard), Dr. Michael Saul, and Lauren Gidseg (Dr. David). Adored great-grandfather of Parker, Harris, and Grant Miller. He was a skilled machinist for the New York Times and a dedicated leader for the Boy Scouts of America. He excelled at woodworking, photography, and creating novelty chocolates. He leaves the legacy of a curious nature, sharp mind, and strong work ethic. A special life has passed from our sight but never from our hearts. Services Sunday, December 11 at 1 P.M. at BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: 'Cold Skin'
GIVING SILENTLY
description: When he took the lectern at the UJA-Federation of New York's annual Wall Street dinner at the New York Hilton on Wednesday, Alan C. Greenberg, chairman of Bear Stearns, did not -- for the first time in memory -- initiate a ritual known as "the calling of the cards," in which some of Wall Street's biggest names stand up to announce their pledges.

title: New Lawsuit in Colombia Over Abortion
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Dec. 10 - Days after Colombia's highest court rejected a case challenging the country's complete prohibition on abortion, an international women's rights group says it is planning to file another suit on Monday.

title: Russians Are Chasing Gold at Montclair State
description: LITTLE FALLS - THERE doesn't, at first, appear to be anything out of the ordinary about Floyd Hall Arena, where North Jersey comes to skate, play hockey, buy equipment and munch on nachos, fries and other snack-bar staples at the food stand. Suburban skating rinks tend to be pretty much the same.

title: What's the Return on Education?
description: SOCRATES once said that the more he learned, the more he became convinced of his own ignorance. It's a familiar feeling for anyone who tries to make sense of the American education system.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Vivendi talks to TF1 and M6 on pay-TV deal
Revolting High Rises
description: Living in high-density, high-rise buildings requires a particular set of social, educational and financial resources to make the experience tolerable. The bourgeoisie are virtually definable by their possession of exactly this kind of financial and, more crucially, social capital: how to interact in public to defuse anger, how to use existing official authority to further one's local aims, how to organize local, informal government (how late to allow playing loud music or where to put the garbage) and how to use and respond to mild social pressure to behave civilly. On the financial side, having the resources to keep buildings safe and in good repair is an essential component of keeping them from descending into chaos.

title: Tamara King and Michael Stark
description: Tamara Lael King and Michael Evan Stark are to be married this evening in Bal Harbour, Fla. Rabbi James L. Simon is to officiate at the Sheraton Bal Harbour Beach Resort, with Cantor Csar Beleniski taking part.

title: Academic Freedom And School Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Is a Polluter Getting Away Too Cleanly?
description: AT $132,000 a year, the Fishers Island ferry operations manager, Mark Easter, is the highest-paid municipal employee in the Town of Southold, earning almost $50,000 more than the town's supervisor. Lately, town officials and some island residents have begun to question why Mr. Easter is on the payroll at all.

title: Paperback Fiction
Lara Englebardt and Corey Metz
description: Lara Michelle Englebardt, a daughter of Bonnie Englebardt Lautenberg of Manhattan and Cliffside Park, N.J., and the late Henry S. Englebardt, was married last evening to Corey Jason Metz, the son of Susan Singer of Cresskill, N.J., and Robert Metz of Astoria, Queens. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan. The bride and bridegroom graduated from the University of Michigan, where they met.

title: What Would a Clone Say?
description: Rosen's point concerning human cloning is well taken, at once literary criticism and political journalism. Along with Kazuo Ishiguro's "Never Let Me Go," he might also have mentioned Joyce Carol Oates's short story "*BD* 11 1 86." It's about a clone applying for college and graduating from high school. Without passing judgment, Oates similarly offers a cautionary tale that challenges supporters of stem-cell research to stand their ground. While progress that extends life and reduces suffering cannot be stopped, we must be cognizant of what we could be getting ourselves into.

title: Bush and the Locked Door
description: I think you went way too easy on Martin Gottlieb, the associate managing editor who gave the green light to the Bush-exit photographs in the Nov. 21 paper, and on Bill Keller, the executive editor, who endorsed the call.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about high-profile nonprofit theater companies and their play choices misstated the name of a forthcoming production and, because of an editing error, misstated the name of a company in some references. The play is "Defiance," not "Denial," and it will be staged for the Manhattan Theater Club, not the Manhattan Theater Company.

title: Cricket: Another career test mark falls
Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMS, MELVIN THURSTON
description: WILLIAMS--Melvin Thurston 1935-2005 died peacefully at home, surrounded by his wife and three children, on Friday, December 2 after an eightmonth battle with lung cancer. Born on March 20, 1935, Mel was the son of the late Allton Thomas and Dorothea Danver Williams of Darien, Connecticut. Two brothers predeceased him, but he is survived by his sister, Lois Williams Adams of Milford, Connecticut. A graduate of Tufts University (1957), Mel began a 34 year career at the Reader's Digest Association in Plesantville, New York. He was involved in domestic and international production and retired, at the age of fifty-seven , as Vice President of Operations in 1992. Mel served on local boards and received many awards during his tenure in publishing. His love of family, sailing, travel, music, photography, his country and his passion for the value of each day will be forever remembered by all who knew him. Mel is survived by his loving wife (and childhood sweetheart) of forty-seven years, Marty, and their three children, Christopher Wilson of Nairobi, Kenya; Stephen Thurston of Delmar, New York; and Amy Williams of Ossining, New York. He is also survived by three grandchildren: Myles, Savannah and Sophia. A Celebration of Life Service will be held on Friday, December 16, at 3:00 PM at the Presbyterian Church of Mt. Kisco, New York. In lieu of flowers, kindly make donations to: Hospice Care in Westchester and Putnam, in Memory of Mel Williams, at 100 South Bedford Road, Mt Kisco, New York 10549 or Mel Williams Memorial Fund/Thoracic Oncology Service, MSKCC (Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center), P.O. Box 27106, New York, New York 10087.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BANKS, JOHN A. DAVIS
description: BANKS--John A. Davis. Of Rowayton, CT on November 29, 2005. Husband of the late Jean Flanagan. Father of Bonica (Hubert) Earle. Grandfather of Whitney Davis Earle and the late James Andrew McKenzie Earle. Sister of Emily Banks Dague. Memorial service Thursday December 15 at 11AM at Trinity St. John's Episcopal Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: The Unwhole Truth
description: Lydia Millet should have spent a bit more time with those "analytical philosophers" (Lives, Nov. 20). One of them might have introduced her to Aristotle, who cautioned that the virtue of honesty falls between two vices of excess, lying and tactlessness.

title: Self-Fulfilling Trade Rumor, The
description: Desmond Mason for Jamaal Magloire -- it was hardly the stuff of N.B.A. legend. A swingman (Mason) averaging 12.8 points a game over his career for a center (Magloire) averaging 9.5. But what was notable about the trade, which took place in late October just before the current N.B.A. season began, when the Milwaukee Bucks sent Mason to the New Orleans Hornets for Magloire, is that it was inspired by a Web site, hoopshype.com.

title: Video Podcasts
description: In October, when Steve Jobs announced Apple's release of the video-playing iPod, he spoke at length about the hit TV shows and music videos that could be purchased and downloaded for the device at the iTunes store. He spent less time talking up the free content available there that could, in the long run, be more significant: video podcasts.

title: Cartoon Empathy
description: For anyone who pays even the slightest attention to cartoons, the scene is familiar: birds flying, bunnies hopping, floppy-hatted Smurfs singing and dancing around a campfire. Then without warning a group of warplanes arrives and starts carpet-bombing. As the Smurfs scatter, their mushroom village goes up in flames. After the last bomb falls, amid the burning rubble and surrounded by dead Smurfs, Baby Smurf sits alone, wailing.

title: Christina Degaitis and Chad Curlett
description: Christina Eve Degaitis and Charles Nelson Curlett Jr. are to be married today at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan. The Rev. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, the dean of the cathedral, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Pentagon Expert on Detainees Plans to Leave for State Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 - The Pentagon's chief adviser on detainee issues is leaving to take a high-level policy job at the State Department, administration officials said on Saturday.

title: The Day the Sea Came
description: Bearak's article was nothing short of riveting. The personalization of the story, through six survivors, was an effective way to feel what they experienced. The trivialities we waste energy on fade when you try to imagine losing everything, literally everything, in a fateful sweep of nature. Kiss your spouse, hug your kids and remember what's really important.

title: Correction Officer Is Killed While Trying to Stop a Fight
description: An off-duty correction officer was shot to death yesterday and another was injured while trying to quell a predawn fight at a party that spilled out onto a Jersey City street, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in T: Holiday magazine last Sunday about luxury suitcases reversed the names of two of the cases that were numbered in an accompanying photograph. The Zero Halliburton was suitcase No. 3; the Flight 001 was No. 4.

title: Trust Spray
description: The hormone oxcytocin, which plays a role in childbirth, breast-feeding, orgasm and feelings of love, is usually thought to have a happy set of responsibilities within the body. But a new study suggests that the hormone could be put to more sinister uses. According to a paper published in the June issue of Nature, a research team at the University of Zurich has determined that a nasal spray containing oxcytocin can be used to make human subjects more trusting.

title: CALENDAR
description: Theater

title: Working Hard and Losing Out
description: PROJECT Hospitality's food bank on the north shore of Staten Island provides more than 460,000 meals a year to New Yorkers, many of whom are homeless or disabled. A federally financed program helps local churches organize food drives to supply the food bank with donations. But the money that pays for such innovative efforts to combat hunger will be eliminated if the budget package passed by the House of Representatives just before Thanksgiving becomes law in a few weeks.

title: It Never Sleeps, but It's Learned to Douse the Lights
description: More than 11,000 traffic lights and "Don't Walk" signals in New York City have been switched to light-emitting diodes that use 90 percent less energy than conventional fixtures.

title: Sex and Violet
description: SUE GRAFTON knows what she's doing. In the 19 alphabet-series novels she's written since 1982, she's never bowed to fad or fashion. Instead, she's kept her whip-smart private investigator, Kinsey Millhone, focused on modestly scaled domestic crimes that have a way of expanding to galvanize an entire community. In dealing with big themes on a small canvas, her clever but unpretentious mysteries reassure us that no life is insignificant, no death inconsequential.

title: Laptop That Will Save the World, The
description: Here in America, high-speed wireless Internet has become a commonplace home amenity, and teenagers with Sidekicks can browse the Web on a beach. For many people in developing nations, however, the mere thought of owning a computer remains pure fantasy.

title: Making Global Warming Work for You
description: If global warming occurs at the pace that most scientists anticipate, there is going to be money in it for those who have the right product in the right place at the right time. George Bernard Shaw once noted that profits are made in the dark; now they will be made in the heat.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Rice's Visit: Official Praise, Public Doubts
description: BERLIN, Dec. 10 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice left behind two Europes when she returned home this weekend from her diplomatic tour aimed at reassuring the allies of the United Sates that the Bush administration did not practice torture and abided by its international obligations.

title: Bringing the Mountain Much Closer to You
description: EVERY year around the first frost, Phil and Devon Dobson of New Milford, Conn., brothers who are avid snowboarders and skiers, start looking forward to the trips their family usually takes to big resorts in Vermont or Colorado.

title: Republican Elitism
description: For more than a generation, the most popular maneuver in the conservative playbook has been to denounce academic and cultural elites. In the 1960's, William F. Buckley Jr. quipped that he'd rather "be governed by the first 2,000 names in the Boston telephone book than by the 2,000 members of the Harvard faculty." In 2003, David Frum, a conservative columnist and former Bush speechwriter, denounced the "American elite" for its "combination of guilt and self-doubt." "With his 'axis of evil' speech," he continued, "President Bush served notice to the world: he felt no guilt and no self-doubt."

title: Congresswoman Kelly And Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Bottom of the World
description: COLD SKIN

title: Uneavesdroppable Phone Conversation, The
description: Sick of your colleagues listening in on your phone conversations? The traditional method of preventing eavesdropping in the workplace is to build dampers and baffles into cubicle walls. But now a device called Babble attacks the problem at the source, transforming the chatter emanating from your cubicle into a flow of meaningless mumblings.

title: Finding Savings Around the Fire
description: ERIC GEIGER thinks of the wood stove he just bought for his family's home in Norfolk, Mass., as an investment with benefits. Because the cost of natural gas is expected to soar this winter, he has bought a fireplace insert, a wood stove designed to fit into an existing fireplace.

title: Not-So-Hidden Treasures At Museum Gift Shops
description: MUSEUM shops offer a welcome shortcut to gift givers. Their managers have done the legwork -- calling or traveling all over the state, the country or even the world to find what you would have picked out had you jumped on a plane to, say, Turkey. And they offer a route away from the same old gifts for the same old season: another sparkly candle, another bottle of wine. As a bonus, many of the museums feature special events during December. Here are a few of the best shops.

title: DataBank; Stocks Are Down, Even After a T.G.I.F. Party
description: A rally on Friday wasn't enough to make up for earlier declines that sent the stock market into negative territory for the week.

title: Manipulating a Journal Article
description: When a prominent medical journal accused Merck-sponsored researchers of excising data from a scientific paper to play down the heart risks of the painkiller Vioxx, it further tarnished the reputation of a company once revered for its corporate ethics. The accusation may well have an impact on the myriad lawsuits filed against Merck because it undermines Merck's contention that it disclosed all it knew about the risks of Vioxx. More broadly, the incident underscores the danger that industry-backed studies may not tell the whole truth about products vital to a company's bottom line.

title: Israel threatens to limit Gaza trade
CREDITS
description: Cover Shirt and vest from What Comes Around Goes Around, 351 West Broadway;

title: Bilbao? Please, That Was So Eight Years Ago
description: TERENCE RILEY did not set out to mount a sprawling exhibition on architecture in Spain. In his mind, the country would figure briefly in a show he was organizing at the Museum of Modern Art about stadiums, auditoriums and theaters around the world. Tentatively titled "Being There," that show was to take note of the remarkable array of new places of public assembly and spectacle around the globe, upending predictions that such buildings would become obsolete in a post-millennial technological age.

title: Celebrity Teeth
description: Last year, if you walked into your dentist's office saying, "Hey, Doc, can you make my teeth look like Cameron Diaz's or Brad Pitt's?" the answer would have been, "Yeah, sure -- with a lot of anesthetic, drilling and permanent reconstruction." But things have changed.

title: Correction
description: An editorial last week mischaracterized the source of the more than $1 billion surplus reported by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The surplus is mostly due to larger than expected tax revenues and lower than projected debt-service costs, not increased fares and ridership.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday, about a dinner held by the Queen Sofa Spanish Institute, misstated the surname of a guest. She is Andrea Portago, not Andrea de Portago.

title: Urine-Powered Battery, The
description: In their quest to develop a smaller, cheaper battery for medical test kits -- like those used to detect diabetes by analyzing a person's urine -- scientists in Singapore had a eureka moment of sorts when they realized that the very urine being tested could also serve as a power source.

title: Defending French farmers
Illegal, immoral and pointless
Kick Saves, Yes, A Savior, No
description: When the Chicago Blackhawks signed goaltender Nikolai Khabibulin to a four-year, $27 million contract in August, they did so in the hope that he would lead them to their first Stanley Cup in 45 years, the longest championship drought in the N.H.L.

title: Working Hard and Losing Out
description: ON a small plot of land in North White Plains, N.Y., low-income women have been planting and harvesting their own squash, collard greens and tomatoes for the last three years. For the women, many of whom are returning to work after struggles with domestic violence and mental illness, the garden provides a lesson in self-sufficiency even as it lowers their food bills. Yet the money that pays for such innovative efforts to combat hunger will be eliminated if the budget package passed by the House of Representatives just before Thanksgiving becomes law in a few weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, GEORGE F. III.
description: BAKER--George F. III. The NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Cornell Medical College mourn the tragic death of our beloved and esteemed friend and Trustee George F. Baker. A creative and uniquely talented man of strong commitment and outstanding intellect, Mr. Baker was elected Governor of The Society of the New York Hospital in 1977 and went on to serve on the Board of the merged NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, the third generation of his family to do so. The family's deep interest and dedication to the New York Hospital dateback to 1899, and the Baker Pavilion of the NewYork - Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center stands as a monument to their loyalty and service to the Medical Center. During his 28 years of Board service, Mr. Baker served on several Board committees, including Executive, Finance, and Nominating. He was honored as New York Hospital's Trustee of the Year in 1996. Since 1981, Mr. Baker has been an outstanding Chairman of the Hospital's Investment Committee, where his astute stewardship of its endowment and retirement funds has been invaluable. He served as Vice Chairman of the NewYorkPresbyterian Fund, Inc. (formerly The Society of The New York Hospital Fund, Inc.), and Vice President, and later President, of The New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Medical Center Fund, Inc. (formerly The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center Fund, Inc.). We will profoundly miss his abiding friendship, his wit, and his wise counsel. We will cherish his memory with the greatest affection. Our deepest sympathies go to the Baker family. John Mack Chairman, Board of Trustees Dr. Herbert Pardes President & CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Jr. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

title: Dolphin Culture
description: Sometimes, when a dolphin in Shark Bay, off the coast of Western Australia, prepares to forage, she drops to the sea floor, rips a fat conical chunk of sea sponge out of it, covers her beak with the sponge cone and sets to work. After she finds the fish she wants, she drops the sponge. "Sponging," as the scientists at the Shark Bay Dolphin Research Project call this behavior, is an unusual instance of an animal using another animal as a tool, but that is not what makes the sponging interesting to biologists. It's that dolphins learn to use the sponges -- to probe deeply for food while protecting their beaks -- from their mothers.

title: Escape From the Cold, If Only Fleetingly, With Warm Stopovers
description: DOES the cold lay waste to your soul? Well, I feel your pain -- or I might, if I weren't so caught up in my own. Once winter rolls in, with its relentless machinery of snow and ice, those of us without the money or the frequent-flier miles for a Caribbean jaunt just have to frown and bear it.

title: Codey Can Now Bow Out With His Head Held High
description: IT is almost too perfect to note that Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey is a big fan of the Cincinnati Reds, dating to long before the redhead who grew up Orange broke into New Jersey's political major leagues.

title: Ergomorphic Footwear
description: Most people expect to break in a new pair of shoes by wearing them for a few weeks until the material softens and stretches to fit. But the shoe designer Martin Keen has a better idea.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: Politically Blind
description: I read for an organization that produces books and magazines on tape for the blind. Recently my assignment was to read articles from a John Birch Society magazine. As someone whose politics are somewhere to the left of left-wing Democrats, I felt uneasy, but I did my assignment, feeling that I had no right to censor what these folks had requested. Should I have refused?

title: The Broken Chord
description: Blacksburg, Va. The Audubon String Quartet was whimsically named 31 years ago by four young string players to evoke nature's lyrical beauty and an earlier, more innocent America. But in the world of classical music, it has since come to stand for an ugly, almost epic legal feud that has damaged lives and divided loyalties. It is a bitter story, in which music plays no redemptive role.

title: Mass-Produced Individuality
description: CafePress

title: Tales From Behind the Bar
description: WITH Champagne toasts and rounds of eggnog, late-night parties and family get-togethers, the holiday season often means one thing: drink up. For bartenders the weeks between Thanksgiving and New Year's are the busiest of the year. Though they can make extra money -- anywhere from hundreds to thousands of dollars in tips on New Year's Eve alone -- they also have to deal with alone-on-the-holidays sob stories, surly shoppers and that one guy who has a few too many at the office Christmas party.

title: Body Work
description: IT'S 11:28 on a Wednesday morning, and on the corner of West 29th Street and 10th Avenue, the detritus of yesterday's hours clings to the sidewalk like shells on a beach at low tide, parking tickets and offers for subscriptions to Playboy, invitations to nightclubs and the occasional tab from a can of Heineken.

title: From Smoldering to the Kitchen Sink
description: 'Where There's Smoke'

title: The Work Ethic Makes the Student
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Friend Is Also Your Boss
description: Q. You work for a good friend, but lately you've begun to have doubts about his business judgment. Is there a way to handle this without ruining the friendship?

title: Democratic Panel Calls for More Early Contests in '08
description: A Democratic Party commission recommended a major revision in its presidential nominating system on Saturday, calling for one or two states to hold nominating caucuses before the first-in-the-nation New Hampshire primary in January 2008.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEILL, KATHRYN DUNSCOMBE
description: O'NEILL--Kathryn Dunscombe. Died December 2, 2005 after a long illness in Milford, CT. Beloved mother of Tim O'Neill and his wife, Donna, of Milford, CT & Carol O'Neill & her husband, Carey Battersby, of Orinda, CA. Devoted grandmother of Will and Eliza O'Neill and Kate and Jamie Wendell. A memorial service will be announced in the spring.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 11-Dec. 17; POP/JAZZ
description: This Tuesday brings an onslaught of odds and ends: it seems as if a lot of rappers are cleaning out their closets before Christmas. SNOOP DOGG has a new compilation, "Big Snoop Dogg Presents Welcome to tha Chuuch: Tha Album" (Doggystyle/Koch). It's hard to know whether to be impressed or depressed by the guest list, which is full of the same aspiring stars (including the always entertaining LADY OF RAGE) who surrounded him more than a decade ago.

title: Eileen Dennehy and William Dorgan
description: Eileen Dennehy and William J. Dorgan were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Rosary and Shrine of St. Elizabeth Seton in New York. The Rev. Peter K. Meehan performed the ceremony.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-40

title: Academic Freedom and School Boards (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Passage to India: Asphalt and Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: PREP, by Curtis Sittenfeld. (Random House, $13.95.) Sittenfeld's sharp debut novel is a four-year, semester-by-semester tour of Ault, a fictional private boarding school in Massachusetts. Her heroine, Lee Fiora, is a Midwestern scholarship student thrust into a world of privilege. Our reviewer, Elissa Schappell, praised the "incisive and evenhanded way" Sittenfeld explores questions of class. In this issue, the Book Review names "Prep" one of the year's best books.

title: Big Houses, and an Even Bigger Wilderness
description: RELOCATING from Manhattan to Tuxedo Park, N.Y., held many benefits for Carl Whelahan, not the least of which was a chance to fire up his motorcycle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIORE, PETER P., M.D.
description: FIORE--Peter P., M.D. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, recently of Wyckoff, NJ, died at the age of 97, on Friday December 9, 2005. Dr. Fiore was born on February 4, 1908, on the Lower East Side and graduated Dewitt Clinton H.S., Syracuse University and Medical School. He completed a residency in Pathology and General Surgery at Kings County Medical Center, Brooklyn. From 1944-1947 he was a battalion surgeon in Normandy, Belgium, Luxembourg and Germany. During his eary medical practice, Dr. Fiore helped to develop blood banking at Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn. He had an active general surgery practice primarily at Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn. He was past President of the Brooklyn Surgical Society, past Vice President of the New York Colon and Rectal Society, and served at Strang Cancer Detection Center, Memorial Hospital, NY. He was on the Board of Trustees and past President of the medical staff for Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn. He was a gentleman who personified dignity, compassion and ethics with patients, family and friends. In addition to his wife Myrtle (nee Skaggs) of Wyckoff, NJ, he is survived by his two sons, Andrew C. Fiore, M.D. of St. Louis, MO, Peter P. Fiore Jr., Esq. of Belleville, IL, and daughter Gay Hartigan of Wyckoff, NJ, six grandchildren and two sisters, Grace Page of Keysport, NJ, and Phyllis Fiore of Oradell, NJ. No flowers. www.vanderplaatfuneral home.com

title: Love Advice, Color-Coded With Dollops of Sugar
description: The Dewey Color System for Relationships The Ultimate Compatibility Test for Love, Friendship, and Career Success. By Dewey Sadka. 240 pp., Three Rivers Press. $14.

title: Roundup:Allenby captures 3rd straight title
A Few Words on Beating the Rap
description: This has been a good month, jurisprudentially, for several embattled hip-hop figures. On Dec. 2, a federal jury acquitted Irv Gotti and his brother, Christopher, who run the label the Inc., of money-laundering charges. The same day, the Houston rapper Pimp C, who had been imprisoned for aggravated assault, was granted parole, cutting short an eight-year sentence. For other stars, though, trouble continues. Last week the rapper Foxy Brown appeared in a Manhattan courtroom, fighting a 2004 misdemeanor assault charge. Lawyers are fond of telling their clients not to comment. But these high-profile defendants present an unusual challenge: they are outspoken to begin with, leaving a long trail of lyrics.

title: Nigeria Plane Crash Kills 103; Most Were Children
description: ELMINA, Ghana, Dec. 10 - A plane carrying 110 passengers and crew members crashed Saturday in Nigeria's main oil city, Port Harcourt, killing all but 7 of them. It was the second deadly airline crash in Nigeria in less than two months.

title: Sitcom Loyalty Oath, The
description: In April, an unusual document appeared on the Web site www.getarrested.com. It was a "loyalty oath," which fans of the TV show "Arrested Development," Fox's critically beloved but anemically rated sitcom, could sign to make a formal declaration of their devotion.

title: The Day the Sea Came
description: The story of six survivors of that infamous tsunami was a gripping drama of human tragedy. It made me think of all those who died -- who could not tell their stories. They, too, prayed for rescue and bargained with God. But the throw of the dice sealed their lips, as they were hurled with furious finality into another world.

title: Those Anonymous Sources
description: It occurs to me that it would be helpful to readers if the term "senior official," used so often to describe an anonymous source, were decoded.

title: What Men Want: Neanderthal TV
description: THERE was a heart-wrenching moment at the end of last season's final episode of the ABC series "Lost" when a character named Michael tries to find his kidnapped son. Michael lives for his child; like the rest of the characters in "Lost," the two of them are trapped on a tropical island after surviving a plane crash. When word of Michael's desperate mission reaches Sawyer -- a booze-hoarding, hard-shelled narcissist who in his past killed an innocent man -- his reaction is not what you would call sympathetic. "It's every man for hisself," Sawyer snarls.

title: "The Crawl" Makes You Stupid
description: A few days after 9/11, Lori Bergen was watching television news and, in her words, "slowly going insane." She was glued to the tube but couldn't focus on what she saw. Bergen, a journalism professor at Kansas State University, blamed "the crawl" -- that stream of headlines, sports scores and weather updates constantly slinking across the lower portion of the TV screen -- for her inability to concentrate. "It was distracting, how it was moving all the time," she says. "It made it so easy to drift away." So Bergen took a piece of duct tape and placed it on the bottom of the screen. It let her focus. And it made her wonder: Was she the only one who became distracted?

title: Zombie Dogs
description: Just as dogs preceded humans in making the first risky voyages into space, a new generation of canines has now made an equally path-breaking trip -- from life to death and back again.

title: Congresswoman Kelly And Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Down at Memory Lanes, It's Duckpin Season
description: IF a hall of fame is any indication, New York gave the world baseball, Massachusetts basketball, and Rhode Island tennis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLASTER, BETSY
description: CLASTER--Betsy. On December 7, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Sanford. Adoring mother of Bob and Scott. Loving grandmother of Max and Zoe. Service Monday 1PM at "The Riverside", 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: CUBA WITHOUT CASTRO

title: Jets' Martin Scheduled for Knee Surgery
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 11 - Curtis Martin shuffled his feet and looked around the sideline, a black cap pulled tightly over his head. As the Jets prepared for kickoff, Martin was trapped in an unfamiliar moment: he was dressed in a black sweatsuit, inactive for the first time since 1998, his season stilled by a knee injury.

title: Ambassador Says Elections May Not Lead to Withdrawal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 - Four days before parliamentary elections in Iraq that the Bush administration has portrayed as a "significant milestone," the American ambassador there and a Republican lawmaker cautioned today against assuming that the vote would produce quick and dramatic improvement or lead to a rapid withdrawal of United States forces.

title: Other Voices: How Can The Times Report on Itself?
description: Re "When the Newspaper Is the News" (Dec. 4):

title: Soccer: Juve thrashes Cagliari to stretch Serie A lead
Dialing Under the Influence
description: The truest words are spoken not in jest but rather after one too many bourbon sours. Liquid courage can turn a normally taciturn individual into a confrontational blabbermouth, eager to tell co-workers or former lovers exactly how he feels about them. The results aren't usually pretty, as has now been immortalized in the popular culture: Paul Giamatti's wine-addled character succumbs to a bout of "drinking and dialing" in the movie "Sideways."

title: Military's Information War Is Vast and Often Secretive
description: The media center in Fayetteville, N.C., would be the envy of any global communications company.

title: Genetic Theory of Harry Potter, The
description: This summer, the journal Nature published "Harry Potter and the Recessive Allele," a letter that argued that J. K. Rowling's tales of the young wizard Harry Potter offer an opportunity to educate children in modern theories of heredity.

title: When Two Sisters Are Better Than One
description: TOGETHER again.

title: Was the Astrodome Named After a Dog?
description: Few football fans in 1962 could have envisioned today's N.F.L. The game may be the same, but much of what surrounds it -- Skycams, wireless communications, dome stadiums, ticket scanners -- has changed. It was all there in 1962, though, for viewers of "The Jetsons" (George, Jane, Elroy, Judy, the robotic maid, Rosie, and their dog, Astro).

title: Caution is voiced in U.S. ahead of Iraqi elections
Budgeting Football
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Excluded Middle
description: OFF CENTER

title: 10 New York Hotels for Under $250 a Night
description: SANDWICHED between an Indian and a Chinese restaurant, the new Holiday Inn Express near Times Square is the brand's first foray into Manhattan. Opened two months ago, the 125-room hotel is on a busy stretch of West 45th Street where trucks double-park, sidewalk peddlers hawk old magazines and office smokers huddle.

title: Katrina's toll also measured in bottles
When the Bubble Bursts
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Drought Cripples Life Along the Amazon
description: MANAQUIRI, Brazil - The Amazon River basin, the world's largest rain forest, is grappling with a devastating drought that in some areas is the worst since record keeping began a century ago. It has evaporated whole lagoons and kindled forest fires, killed off fish and crops, stranded boats and the villagers who travel by them, brought disease and wreaked economic havoc.

title: Celebrating Cabernet Franc
description: SINCE Schneider Vineyards went into business in 1994, its raison d'tre has been cabernet franc, a French grape central to Loire red wines and generally secondary in St.-milion and Pomerol blends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAVORI, MARY E.
description: LAVORI--Mary E. December 9, 2005 at home in Yarmouthport, MA, surrounded by her five children. Beloved wife of the late Dr. William P. Lavori. Mother of Philip, Nora, Joseph, Angela Lavori and Judith L. Keiser. Grandmother of Liana and Alexander Sterling, Daniel and Cathryn Lavori, William Keiser and Mary Marudas. A woman of unusual accomplishment, optimism and warmth. A gifted teacher, community activist and extraordinary friend. Donations in her memory to Hospice Foundation of Cape Cod, 270 Communication Way, Hyannis, MA 02601.

title: In Senate Selection, A Stuttering Start
description: TRENTON - WELCOME to Trenton, Senator Corzine.

title: Profile: Michelle Bachelet
An Old Naval Base in Search of Its Soul
description: The Homeport, a former naval base in Stapleton, Staten Island, has seen more than its share of false starts. Ever since 1995, when the city acquired the 36-acre site, grand redevelopment schemes have come and gone, among them a Formula One racetrack, a coal importing station, a pier for gambling ships and, most recently, a film studio, which the city forced out after less than three years.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Working Hard and Losing Out
description: ON a small plot of land in North White Plains, low-income women have been planting and harvesting their own squash, collard greens and tomatoes for the last three years. For the women, many of whom are returning to work after struggles with domestic violence and mental illness, the garden provides a lesson in self-sufficiency even as it lowers their food bills. Yet the money that pays for such innovative efforts to combat hunger will be eliminated if the budget package passed by the House of Representatives just before Thanksgiving becomes law in a few weeks.

title: Eyes Only for Each Other, at Least for the Next Three Minutes
description: Be clear about one thing: It's not a staring contest.

title: Other Views: The Economist, Daily Stars, New Nation
Grim in the garage
In Atlanta, a New Arts District Catches On
description: LIKE almost any activity in car-dependent Atlanta, browsing the city's contemporary art galleries normally involves driving -- largely between locations in the wealthy Buckhead district but also through midtown and elsewhere. Recently, though, the city's core has sprouted a place to visit a diverse array of galleries on foot: the emerging Castleberry Hill Arts District.

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: The Filthy Underbelly, Via Jersey City

title: Jennifer Lloyd and Andrew Dance
description: Jennifer Hill Lloyd, the daughter of Sally and Charles Lloyd of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Morley Dance, a son of Jamie Dance of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Peter Dance. The Rev. Anthony O. Ottey, an Anglican priest, officiated at the Tryall Club in Montego Bay, Jamaica.

title: China Overtakes U.S. as Supplier of Information Technology Goods
description: BEIJING, Dec. 11 - After almost a decade of explosive growth in its electronics sector, China has overtaken the United States as the world's biggest supplier of information technology goods, according to a report by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Gaza Accord on Crossings Is Stalled
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 10 - Israel and the Palestinians are at odds over an agreement on the Gaza Strip, which now appears stalled despite deadlines set when Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice brokered the deal less than a month ago.

title: The City Under the Tree
description: New York is a gift. That notion is easy to forget amid the honking of horns, the cost of shelter, the brutishness of everyday life. But if you walk along the streets, or through a park, perhaps in late December or in early April or on the summer solstice, and look around, listening to snippets of conversation, chances are you will want to rejoice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEMINGWAY, MARGI SMITH (NEE WILKINSON)
description: HEMINGWAY--Margi Smith (nee Wilkinson). Resident of Hornersville, MO. Died suddenly on November 24, 2005. Born October 11, 1942 in Port Jefferson, LI. An esteemed member of the food and wine community, she leaves her beloved husband and business partner, Joseph W. Hemingway. Their firm Smith & Hemingway Public Relations, is widely known in the hospitality industry in the U.S. and abroad. Contributions in memory to First Presbyterian Church of Kennett, MO., 63857 or SOS New York.

title: OPEC Should Not Curtail Production, Minister Says
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 11 - OPEC should not curtail its current oil production because strong demand has kept prices high, Saudi Arabia's oil minister said today, adding that it was too early to consider paring the group's output in anticipation of a slowdown in consumption next year.

title: Israeli Defense Minister Mofaz joins Sharon's new party
Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: Bush's Mad Dash Comes to Stop With the Heisman
description: Reggie Bush's broken-field run to the Heisman Trophy had a familiar feel.

title: Up Front
description: The British journalist Geoffrey Wheatcroft did not want to be a journalist -- and that has probably been good for his writing and his career. After attending Oxford, he took up typography and, he says, "spent several fruitless years in publishing, as a designer, publicity manager and editor." It was only after turning to journalism, "involuntarily but gratefully," that he found his calling. Now a freelance writer, he has been literary editor of The Spectator and a columnist for The Sunday Telegraph. Wheatcroft's strengths are those of an "involuntary" writer -- of someone, that is, who set out with no particular mission or political agenda. The extent of his interests is reflected in his books, which include: "The Randlords," an account of the South African mining magnates; "The Controversy of Zion," about Zionism's impact on the Jewish people; and "Le Tour: A History of the Tour de France." And as someone who is not given to polemical flights, he is unusually common-sensical, quick to perceive when one of his subjects has failed to keep his feet on the ground. Wheatcroft brings that common sense to his Page 1 review of Robert Fisk's "Great War for Civilisation." Looking at a fellow journalist who has been a lightning rod for controversy, he finds much to praise, but he also makes understandable why Fisk has provoked so much anger among so many.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ZIFF, CHARLES
description: ZIFF--Charles. 12/11/49--7/4/92. You are in my heart forever. Stephen

title: Revolting High Rises
description: There is one detail about high-rise public housing that always seems to get left out of the discussion: the skyscrapers crowded with poor people are not very different from the sparkling towers of upscale apartments and condominiums often just a short drive away. The problem is that the former are unmaintained, unpoliced and in every way send the message to residents that nobody cares about them. Poverty, whether stacked up or spread out, whether in the middle of a city or out in the suburbs, is corrosive and dangerous and will not go away just because the rent is a little lower. Public-housing directors miss an opportunity with every project they build or tear down. With a little more money, these very slums could be their own engines for social change: give the residents job skills and then employ them in the maintenance of their own buildings and watch what happens.

description: Weeks

description: Books Discussed in This Essay

title: A Museum Shop Is the Cure for Re-Gifting
description: ONE alternative to seeing the same items wherever you go for holiday shopping is the abundance of unusual and reasonably priced items to be found at museum gift shops throughout Westchester.

title: Preserving Family Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec.11-Dec. 17; TELEVISION
description: As reality television matures as a network genre, viewers' fervor for all things unscripted has clearly ebbed. But competitive shows like "SURVIVOR," "THE AMAZING RACE" and "THE APPRENTICE: DONALD TRUMP" continue to draw audiences even if, particularly in Mr. Trump's case, they have shrunk. This week, the fall editions of this troika will have their finales. This "Survivor" (CBS, Sunday night ) has distinguished itself by bringing back two players from the previous season, STEPHENIE LAGROSSA and BOBBY JON DRINKARD, as well as its apparent attempt to actually kill all of the contestants on their first day, with an 11-mile race through the jungle in 100-degree heat. (Many vomited, though everyone somehow lived.)

title: The Broken Chord
description: Blacksburg, Va. - THE Audubon String Quartet was whimsically named 31 years ago by four young string players to evoke nature's lyrical beauty and an earlier, more innocent America. But in the world of classical music, it has since come to stand for an ugly, almost epic legal feud that has damaged lives and divided loyalties. It is a bitter story, in which music plays no redemptive role.

title: The Siren Song of Sex With Boys
description: WHEN Sandra Beth Geisel, a former Catholic schoolteacher, was sentenced to six months in jail last month for having sex with a 16-year-old student, she received sympathy from a surprising source.

title: New Orleans Is Not Ready to Think Small, or Even Medium
description: NEW ORLEANS - THREE more bodies were found here last week, hidden away in forsaken homes where mold had crawled over the walls in a Jackson Pollock splatter. One hundred days after the hurricane, these belated discoveries seem to be one more sign of how far New Orleans has fallen. Even the dead are not yet at peace.

title: Human Rights Group Calls for Sanctions on Darfur's Leaders
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Dec. 11 - The United Nations should impose sanctions on top political and military leaders in Sudan and conduct an investigation of crimes against humanity committed in Darfur, Human Rights Watch said in a report today.

title: Local Museums Tapping Into Big-City Exhibitions
description: IT is always chancy to read trends into museum exhibitions, especially when examples are isolated and scattered. But at least one thing seems clear.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about high-profile nonprofit theater companies and their play choices misstated the name of a forthcoming production and, because of an editing error, misstated the name of a company in some references. The play is "Defiance," not "Denial," and it will be staged for the Manhattan Theater Club, not the Manhattan Theater Company.

title: The Fed Wears Its Feelings on Its Sleeve
description: THE Federal Reserve is a modern, sensitive central bank that likes to communicate how it feels. Its well-telegraphed signals to the market leave virtually no doubt that it will execute a 13th consecutive quarter-point increase in its benchmark interest rate this week; the debate among investors is whether the accompanying statement will reveal a change in mood about further increases.

title: Judith Silverman and Roberto Hodara
description: Judith Anne Silverman and Dr. Roberto Pablo Hodara were married last evening at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia. Rabbi Ira F. Stone officiated, with Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner participating in the ceremony.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: A 'Messiah' Remix

title: A New Body Language, for the Present and for the Ages
description: AS attitudes change, dancers change and audiences change, choreographers often find that they outgrow their past works. Permanence is a dubious expectation in something as ephemeral as dance.

title: Stoic Redheads
description: Redheads have long been portrayed in literature and art as strong-willed and fiery. Now there may be a scientific explanation for these traits. The key, according to researchers at McGill University in Montreal, is a gene that is linked both to red hair coloring and to higher levels of pain tolerance. It has been known since the mid-1990's that mutations of the MC1R gene are responsible for hair color -- and fair skin and freckles -- in about 70 percent of redheads. But when Jeffrey S. Mogil and his colleagues at McGill set out to find a genetic link to pain inhibition, MC1R wasn't at the top of their list of targets. "We normally only get excited about genes in the brain when it comes to pain," he says. "This is in the skin." There was, however, a little-noticed paper that said MC1R was in fact expressed in the brain. It was enough of a clue to go on.

title: Fireside Reading, Direct From the Shelves of the Famous
description: A good book and winter weather make ideal companions: sitting for a long stretch in a comfortable chair, ideally by a fire, is a fine way to discover a new author or reacquaint yourself with an old favorite.

title: The World's Most Popular Gay Postmodern Harpsichord Nerd
description: OWEN PALLETT'S personality, like his music, is full of incongruities.

title: In the Paris slums, no jobs, no sun
Who Are the Lawyers Packing All the Clout?
description: TRENTON - WHEN Jon S. Corzine was the chief executive at Goldman Sachs, its principal outside counsel was the archetypal Wall Street firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, established in 1879. The firm serves a large clientele in global capital markets and employs more than 100 alumni of the Harvard Law School.

title: Union Is Dealing With Issues It Did Not Bargain For
description: The players union and the N.B.A. worked fervently to complete a collective bargaining agreement this past summer.

title: Paramount's drive wins DreamWorks
Runaway Alarm Clock, The
description: Every morning, millions of Americans begin the day with the annoying beep of an alarm clock -- a noise they are likely to silence with a fumbling tap of the snooze button. While the few minutes' rest this affords is reprieve enough for some, many hit the snooze button again and again, prolonging their wake-up time and leaving themselves late for school or work. For these undisciplined dozers, a machine has arrived that promises to get them out of bed -- literally.

title: At World Cup, U.S. Will Call a Boisterous Port City Home
description: Hamburg, Germany - THE United States has come a long way since 1998, at least in soccer.

title: What's So Funny About Disability? Well . . .
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. - WHEN Edward Barbanell was growing up in Florida, he didn't have a quick retort for the kids who would bully him and call him names on the playground. "I just learned to walk away from it," said Mr. Barbanell, an actor who has Down syndrome. "They can call me what they want, but I am not a 'tard."

title: Real Estate Observes a Law Even Higher
description: TO be a real estate agent in Riverdale, the leafy enclave in the northwest Bronx, is to be mindful of not only the rules of property ownership but also the rules of the Torah. The neighborhood is home to an ever-growing number of Conservative and Orthodox Jews, and when hunting for houses or apartments, they tend to follow a stricter course than the typical New York talismans of hardwood floors and sweeping views.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, BUENGELER, KARL PAUL
description: PETERSON-BUENGELER-Karl Paul Passionate intellectual, educator, musician, chef and dedicated family man, died November 30, 2005 at Hackensack University Medical Center, Hackensack, NJ. Born May 25, 1948 in Wuerselen, Germany, he died at age 57 following a long and brave struggle against lymphoma. Peterson-Buengeler graduated from Cologne University in Cologne, Germany with a degree in Germanics and Philosophy. In 1986 he relocated to the United States to pursue a Mid-Career Fellowship at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of International Affairs and Public Policy. Upon graduation, he was named Director of University Programs at the Council on International Educational Exchange, retiring from that position in 1991. In addition to his work in international education, Peterson-Buengeler was deeply interested and involved in current affairs. He was an accomplished pianist and choirmaster, an avid gardener, loved fine cuisine and was a gourmet cook. Peterson-Buengeler is survived by his wife, Sandra, and sons, Geoffrey and Henry. Sandra Peterson, a well-known senior health care industry executive, is currently President and CEO of Bayer HealthCare's Diabetes Care Division headquartered in Tarrytown, NY. Geoffrey is a junior at Harvard University, and Henry is a ninth-grader at The Saddle River Day School. Peterson-Buengeler is also survived by his mother, Maria von Plettenberg Buengeler, sisters, Regina and Brigitte, and brother, Bruno. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Karl Paul Peterson-Buengeler Music Scholarship at The Saddle River Day School in Saddle River, NJ. Alternatively, donations can be sent to the Harvard Glee Club, Harvard University, to underwrite a choral work being commissioned in memory of Peterson-Buengeler. Funeral services were private and a Memorial Celebration will be held for friends and colleagues at a future date.

title: As NATO Forces Ease Role of G.I.'s in Afghanistan, the Taliban Steps Up Attacks
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Dec. 7 - Foreign soldiers in desert fatigues and helmets sealed off the main road of this southern city last Sunday to inspect the site where a suicide bomber, wrapped in a blanket, had thrown himself at a convoy of military jeeps, killing himself and an Afghan civilian.

title: Rain Forest Munch
description: TRENTON - ON the first visit to Quetzal, the waitress gave up her own tamales so that we could taste them. On the second, I was served a vegetable that looked like a breaded bouquet of a dozen knobby chicken feet without the claws. Both were delicious.

title: Dress for Respect
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At F.B.I., Frustration Over Limits on an Antiterror Law
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 - Some agents at the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been frustrated by what they see as the Justice Department's reluctance to let them demand records and to use other far-ranging investigative measures in terrorism cases, newly disclosed e-mail messages and internal documents show.

title: Magical Thinking
description: How odd to see the assembled forces of mass culture buzzing so furiously around an object as sorrowful and naked as Joan Didion's new book, "The Year of Magical Thinking." The book, a slender memoir of suffering, retraces Ms. Didion's forced march through grief after the death of her husband, John Gregory Dunne, and the severe illness of their daughter, Quintana Roo, in 2003. It is meticulous and honest, and has been enthusiastically reviewed.

title: Fair Employment Mark, The
description: For a decade now, Congress has declined to pass the Employment Nondiscrimination Act (ENDA), which would make it illegal for companies to fire or demote on the basis of sexual orientation. And yet some of the nation's biggest companies, including AT&T, I.B.M. and General Mills, say they'd be happy to abide by the legislation. The Yale Law School professor Ian Ayres and his wife, the Quinnipiac University School of Law professor Jennifer Gerarda Brown, wonder: Why wait for Congress to pass a law when you can, in effect, do it yourself?

title: Microblindness
description: People are distracted by naked supermodels; it doesn't take three Ph.D.'s to figure that out. But what psychology researchers at Yale and Vanderbilt Universities have discovered is that erotic -- and violent -- images are so distracting that they make people temporarily blind.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec.11-Dec. 17; THEATER
description: Is it still a roman  clef (or in this case, a play  clef) if more than one key turns the lock? In "THE LITTLE DOG LAUGHED," Douglas Carter Beane's new Hollywood satire, a hot young actor wants to come out of the closet, but his agent won't let him. Shades of Henry Willson, the notorious Hollywood manager who groomed many homosexual himbos for stardom -- sometimes literally. (In "The Man Who Invented Rock Hudson," a recent biography of Willson, Robert Hofler writes that Willson arranged a marriage between his secretary and Hudson.) Amazingly, it's much the same game 50 years later, in the real world and in Beane's, where the idea of a male star walking down the red carpet with his boyfriend is as ludicrous as the unnatural liaisons in the nursery rhyme that provides the play's title. Previews start Tuesday, Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422.

title: Death of an American City
description: We are about to lose New Orleans. Whether it is a conscious plan to let the city rot until no one is willing to move back or honest paralysis over difficult questions, the moment is upon us when a major American city will die, leaving nothing but a few shells for tourists to visit like a museum.

title: Worldwide Flat Taxes
description: In the United States, advocates of a flat tax -- a single rate applied to all taxpayers regardless of income level -- are generally regarded as the intellectual heirs to the flat-earthers. Arguments to replace the graduated income tax with a flat tax have won little respect in policy circles and even less among voters (witness Steve Forbes's two failed presidential bids).

title: INSIDE
description: Plane Crash in Nigeria Kills at Least 103 People A plane carrying 110 passengers and crew members crashed in Port Harcourt, Nigeria, killing all but 7 of them, officials said. Most of the passengers were schoolchildren on their way home for the Christmas holiday, according to family members interviewed at the airport. It is in the second deadly airline crash in Nigeria in less than two months.

title: Yanks Miss Cutoff in Bypassing Pierre
description: AS successful as they have been with a league-record eight consecutive division championships, the Yankees have made enough mistakes on players in recent years and they are not immune from making another one. They very likely made one by not jumping into Florida's fire sale and snatching Juan Pierre to fill their center-field gap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALCONE, JANET (KATHERINE)
description: FALCONE--Janet (Katherine) Wirth. 86, of Jamaica, Queens, NY, on July 26, 2005. Born July 6, 1919, Sandusky, OH. Recently of Westfield, NJ and Moraga, CA. Husband of the late Philip F. Falcone. Mother of Philip F. Falcone, Jr. of Westfield, NJ and Roger W. Falcone of Lafayette, CA. Grandmother of Joshua, Rachel, Elizabeth, & Michael. Sister of Richard Wirth and the late Frederick Wirth. After graduation from Western Reserve University, and then for more than 50 years, Janet worked in publishing as a respected copy editor for works ranging from highly technical to best sellers. A memorial service was held in NYC on August 20, 2005. Janet will be interred with her husband Philip at Trinity Church Cemetery in upper Manhattan.

title: Forget Silk and Cashmere, Try the Porcupine
description: NEWARK - DUMB luck, I confess, brought me to see "Power Dressing: Men's Fashion and Prestige in Africa" at the Newark Museum. But what a terrific exhibition it is, with the steady radiance of its 50-plus exhibits bewitching you pretty well instantly.

title: The Day the Sea Came
description: Following the tsunami last year, I became somewhat obsessed with what it must have been like to go through it. I downloaded countless amateur videos and watched them again and again. Your article allowed me to fully understand the unimaginable terror, the soul-crunching grief and the sudden and absolute loss of everything that those in Banda Aceh experienced on that fateful sunny day. Thank you.

title: Inside the List
description: THE ITALIAN JOB: For more than half a century, "Il Cucchiaio d'Argento" -- "The Silver Spoon" -- has been Italy's best-selling cookbook. It's the country's "Joy of Cooking," a volume given to brides on their wedding day. "The Silver Spoon" has now been translated into English, and the result -- a big, well-marbled slab of a cookbook -- is catching on with American readers; the book is No. 13 on this week's extended hardcover miscellaneous list, available on the Web. (The only other cookbook on that list is "Martha Stewart's Baking Handbook," at No. 8.) "The Silver Spoon" gives good value. It weighs in at 1,263 pages and has some 2,000 recipes, but it sells for $40. It's also full of surprises -- put the cheese on your pasta before the sauce, the authors advise -- and, happily, it hasn't been stripped of its Italian character. (There are piles of recipes here for things like buck's horn plantain, hard to come by in this country.) The classics are covered back-to-front -- there are 23 risotto recipes -- but "The Silver Spoon" also works in some interesting margins; you'll learn three ways to cook a calf's head, and methods for making both heart and eel kabobs. The authors can be sticklers. The recipe for costata alla fiorentina begins: "Those who wish to serve authentic Florentine T-bone steaks should follow the rules of the Articles of Association of the Florentine T-Bone Steak Academy, founded in 1991 by representatives of the Florentine Butchers' Association." Whew. It's like having the culinary carabinieri in your kitchen.

title: What Would a Clone Say?
description: The article condemns embryonic stem-cell research, including somatic cell nuclear transfer, as an instance of "the deliberate use of one (developing) person as the instrument of another." At the stage known as the blastocyst, from which embryonic stem cells must be extracted, the early embryo does not have even a rudimentary nervous system. To imbue it with personhood at this stage is a matter of religious dogma or a leap of faith -- not humanistic reasoning.

title: Giving Time, Getting Back Satisfaction
description: THE natural disasters of recent months -- Hurricanes Katrina and Wilma, the earthquake in Pakistan -- have led to an outpouring of generosity, with schools, religious groups and community organizations contributing to fund-raising efforts.

title: Other Voices: How Can The Times Report on Itself?
description: Re "When the Newspaper Is the News" (Dec. 4):

description: GABOR KARSAI, a Glen Cove real estate agent who is selling his one-bedroom houseboat for $75,000, had a question for the owner of the Manhasset Bay Marina, where the houseboat sits, along with about 30 other one- and two-bedroom floating homes.

King Mott, then an associate dean in the college of arts and sciences here at Seton Hall University, wrote a two-paragraph letter to The Star-Ledger critical of the Vatican's position on gay men.

title: Minimizing Revenge Factor, Austria Sweeps U.S.
description: VAL D'ISRE, France, Dec. 10 - Michael Walchhofer won a World Cup downhill here on Saturday, leading an Austrian sweep that he said had nothing to do with revenge against the United States ski team.

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: It Takes a Potemkin Village
description: WHEN a government substitutes propaganda for governing, the Potemkin village is all. Since we don't get honest information from this White House, we must instead, as the Soviets once did, decode our rulers' fictions to discern what's really happening. What we're seeing now is the wheels coming off: As the administration's stagecraft becomes more baroque, its credibility tanks further both at home and abroad. The propaganda techniques may be echt Goebbels, but they increasingly come off as pure Ali G.

title: What 'Munich' Left Out
description: Every generation of Americans casts Israel in its own morality tale. For a time, Israel was the plucky underdog fighting for survival against larger foes. Now, as Steven Spielberg rolls out the publicity campaign for his new movie, "Munich," we see the crystallization of a different fable. In this story, the Israelis and the Palestinians are parallel peoples victimized by history and trapped in a cycle of violence.

title: As Gas Prices Fall, Thirsty S.U.V.'s Regain Their Allure
description: Remember all those cosmic statements a month or so ago about how soaring gasoline prices had ended America's decade-plus infatuation with low-mileage sport utility vehicles -- and how drivers were returning to the snug-fitting embrace of small, efficient cars?

title: REIT's Poised to End 2005 on Another High Note
description: WALL STREET pundits expected 2005 to be a bad year for real estate investment trusts. Interest rates were heading north, economic growth was uncertain and many REIT's were already pricey after a two-year run-up.

title: Splogs
description: Newton's third law of motion applies on the Internet as well as in the physical world: for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. The convenience of e-mail messages triggered the annoyance of spam. And now the democracy of Web logs has brought forth the duplicity of spam blogs, or splogs.

title: The Unwhole Truth
description: To quote Tennessee Williams, "All cruel people describe themselves as paragons of frankness."
