description: HOPE springs eternal. And so, James Vanderberg hoped. He hoped that his girlfriend would not leave him, and that therefore they would not have to relinquish their cozy one-bedroom on the Upper West Side.

title: Hong Kong prepares for trade-talk unrest
Paid Notice: Deaths   KORYN, ANDREW, M.D.
description: KORYN--Andrew, M.D. Age 74, on December 2 in La Jolla, CA. Born 1931 in Amsterdam. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted and loving father of Ramona and Daniel. Dear brother of Ted Koryn. He was very much loved by his family and friends. Prior to retirement he practiced medicine in La Jolla, CA. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: TWINS. By Marcy Dermansky. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $21.95.) Writers love identical twins. What tidier way to show different sides of one character, explore possible life paths or test the limits of nature and nurture? Dermansky does all that, but her twins (who take turns at narrating) transcend the gimmick in a brainy, emotionally sophisticated bildungsroman-for-two. Chloe, the elder by four minutes, longs for a life of her own, independent of her clingy sister, Sue, who envies her (Chloe is an eighth of an inch taller) and thinks she's smarter and prettier. Sue adores Chloe, whose every gesture toward independence sends her into paroxysms of jealousy. On their 13th birthday, she wheedles and bullies Chloe into getting tattoos -- with each twin bearing the other twin's name. "Sue thought tattoos would prove to the world that the bond we shared went deeper than DNA," Chloe explains. "The funny thing was, the tattoos made us different. When we died, it would be easy for a forensic scientist to tell us apart. . . . After we got our tattoos, we were never really and truly the same." Both twins are obsessive, vulnerable, ambitious and hungry for love, but these qualities take on different forms. Chloe keeps her room in perfect order, setting herself apart from her untidy sister, while Sue vomits up her meals in an effort to stay the same weight as Chloe, who intently counts her calories. Yet as they mature and their circumstances change, they find themselves swapping roles. Most teenage protagonists have to learn what it means to be themselves, but Sue and Chloe have an extra task: learning what it means to be -- or not to be -- each other.

title: A Better Budget Fix
description: Last month, New York voters wisely rejected an amendment to the state Constitution that had been mislabeled "budget reform." Rather than actually reforming the unspeakable way Albany creates a budget each year, that amendment would have made matters unthinkable -- by shifting power over $100 billion or so a year from the governor to 212 hungry legislators. Now that we've managed to avoid making things worse, it is time for New York's lawmakers to start thinking about how to make them better. The state's budgeting system needs to be made modern, open and efficient.

title: Doctors and Patients Fighting a Giant
description: To the Editor:

title: Suburban Loft, The
description: The loft used to be a distinctly urban animal: empty downtown factories converted first into living spaces by struggling artists, then later into trendy up-market condos. But like many city dwellers, as it has matured, the loft has moved farther away from the hustle and bustle of downtown life. Last year, the National Association of Home Builders incorporated the "loft look" in its annual demonstration home in Las Vegas. A cross between SoHo and Pleasantville, the house featured an open plan, buffed-concrete floors and high ceilings, but it also sat amid a manicured lawn in a gated subdivision. It drew rave reviews and quickly sold for $1.9 million.

title: Yawn Contagion
description: Hanging out with Steve Platek will make you yawn. He'll get you thinking about yawning, reading about yawning, and sooner or later, your mouth's gaping. You can't help it. "My favorite way to induce a yawn," Platek says, "is a video clip of a good yawner paired with yawn audio." Platek, a cognitive neuroscientist at Drexel University, alternately describes yawning as "a primitive unconscious mechanism" or something that's "sweet," "totally cool" or "awesome." And he's finally figuring out why it's contagious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLINETZ, LEONARD
description: WOLINETZ--Leonard. The medical center's world-wide leadership expresses its sincerest condolences to Harvey Wolinetz, Brenda Schlanger and Jean Zucker on the loss of their cherished father and her dear brother. A quintessential and hardworking "family" man who enjoyed life, Mr. Wolinetz showered love and affection on his family, especially on his beloved "diamond" Edith, of blessed memory. As a "Patron of Medicine" in support of our Department of Oncology, Harvey continues the legacy of tzedekah and chesed that he learned from his parents. May Harvey and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Prof. Jonathan Halevy, Director-General Menno Ratzker, Vice Chair Jack C. Bendheim, President Paul S. Glasser, Nat'l Executive Director

title: Newly Bankrupt Raking In Piles of Credit Offers
description: TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 9 - As one of more than two million Americans who rushed to a courthouse this year to file for bankruptcy before a tough new law took effect, Laura Fogle is glad for her chance at a fresh start. A nurse and single mother of two, she blames her use of credit cards after cancer surgery for falling into deep debt.

title: MOTOWN NO-SHOW
description: What if a company gave a party and the host did not make it?

title: The Funny Pages
description: It baffles me that people who consider themselves intelligent saddle their children with names that, rather than distinguishing a child from the norm, will give other children hours and hours of entertainment on the playground ("A.K.A." Nov. 27). Of course, Jennifer Belle could have just gone along with the current trend of giving her child the name of a president -- Madison, Taylor, Tyler or, to be really innovative, how about Polk or Buchanan? What a parent may think is cute a third grader won't.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LITWIN, THOMAS
description: LITWIN--Thomas is deeply mourned by the Advisory Council of the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art, Cornell University. He was a man of effervescent good humor, a love of life, and a fondness for magic tricks, a personality that charmed everyone he met. Combined with his warmth and optimism were strength and courage. He was a model to us all, and will be greatly missed.

title: Do-it-yourself dreams at an affordable price
Correction
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Oct. 30 about the "Unknown Paintings of Rembrandt" exhibition at the Rembrandt House Museum in Amsterdam misstated the location of the Linda and Daniel Bader Collection. A reader's e-mail message received Nov. 21 pointed out that it was in Milwaukee, not Minneapolis.

title: Climbing Up the Musical Ladder
description: Ossining - CRAMMED into the front parlor of KJ Denhert's two-story house here are a half-dozen acoustic guitars (all of which the singer and songwriter performs with), several hand drums and African percussion instruments, an accordion, a ukulele, two ancient banjos and an upright piano.

title: Stash Rocket, The
description: For years, various freethinkers among us have been at work on the problem of how to unload the hooch when parents or teachers or law-enforcement officials close in. To this end, immeasurable amounts of drugs have been swallowed and flushed and fed to witless mutts inside Little Debbie snack cakes, but not until the night of June 24 had the distinguished practice seen its highest expression.

title: How to Make Your (Accounting) Relationship Work
description: WHEN Lisa Ludovici, 45, received a letter of inquiry from the Internal Revenue Service last year regarding her 2001 taxes, she immediately forwarded it to her accountant, who said he would take care of it, she recalled. Months passed, she said, and nothing happened: the accountant failed to return her calls, even when the government eventually billed her $1,500 for the supposed discrepancy. In the end, Ms. Ludovici said she consulted another tax preparer who told her that the problem was minor and said that it appeared that the I.R.S. had made an incorrect assumption.

title: Enter, a Chef Extraordinaire
description: THE owners of Stresa in Manhasset and Stresa East in Woodbury, Giorgio Meriggi, Pasquale Cervera and Tony D'Arcangelo, are consummate restaurateurs.

title: Brooklyn Bridge, Bought and Sold
description: To the Editor:

title: To Catch a Thief
description: IF you were driving down Court Street in Cobble Hill some morning last fall, or rushing to catch the F train at the start of your midmorning commute, you might have seen me. I was the one in the blue bathrobe and slippers, darting out the front of my building onto the busy sidewalk to pick up my newspaper before trudging back up the stairs for a bleary-eyed cup of tea and a bowl of cereal.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Manhattan

title: China calls clash result of 'chaotic' mob attack
Corrections
description: The Economic View column on Nov. 27, about federal jobs that are likely to be filled by academic economists, referred imprecisely to one such position. While that job, assistant secretary of the Treasury for tax policy, could be filled by an academic economist, it has recently been held by lawyers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLIOT, SALLY N.
description: ALLIOT--Sally N., 77. Passed away on December 2, 2005. She had resided in North Haven, CT, with her loving husband of 56 years, Eric Alliot, Jr. Born in Erie, PA, on May 18, 1928, a daughter of the late Douglas and Eleanor Nagle. Sally was devoted to music, reading, family and friends. She will be missed by many. For info, call Beecher & Bennett, 2300 Whitney Ave., Hamden, CT. A memorial service and burial will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Rapper in da Hizzouse
description: AT 5 p.m. on a frigid Friday on Amsterdam Avenue in Harlem, a line of kids wrapped around West 149th Street, waiting to enter Santana's Town, a store owned by Juelz Santana, 22, the youngest member of the hip-hop crew the Diplomats.

title: Jets' Robertson Is Driven; His Cars Show How Far
description: When Dewayne Robertson talks about the cars in his garage, he does it in the way clotheshorses might describe their wardrobes.

title: 'Copperfield' as a Fond, Fine Farewell
description: DON'T go, Joanne!

title: Villagers Tell of Lethal Attack by Chinese Forces on Protesters
description: SHANWEI, China, Dec. 10 - Four days after a lethal assault on protesters by paramilitary forces, a village in southern China remained under heavy police lockdown on Saturday.

title: Japanese Cuisine That's Suited for Fusion
description: I CAN'T remember when I first heard the term "fusion cuisine" to describe a style that combines the cooking of several cultures in one dish.

title: Shari Fineman and Sanjai Sinha
description: Shari Fineman and Dr. Sanjai Sinha were married last evening at the Museum of the City of New York in Manhattan. The Rev. Laurie Sue Brockway, an interfaith minister, officiated, and her husband, the Rev. Vic Fuhrman, also an interfaith minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Montreal: Htel Godin
description: THE BASICS --Visitors to Montreal tend to stay in the central business district (where options include a sleek Sofitel and a vintage Ritz-Carlton) or the old city (which has a Marriott and several quaint auberges). But much of Montreal's night life takes place on Boulevard St. Laurent. The Godin (with 136 rooms) is one of the first hotels in this hip district, and it aims to be part of the scene. The hotel's slogan, printed on practically everything, is: "There's the day, and then there's the night." This is a hotel of the night.

title: Econophysics
description: Victor Yakovenko, a physicist at the University of Maryland, happens to think that current patterns of economic inequality are as natural, and unalterable, as the properties of air molecules in your kitchen.

title: Congresswoman Kelly And Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris demands Blair accept cuts in EU rebate
Yoo Presidency, The
description: Can the president of the United States do whatever he likes in wartime without oversight from Congress or the courts? This year, the issue came to a head as the Bush administration struggled to maintain its aggressive approach to the detention and interrogation of suspected enemy combatants in the war on terrorism. But this was also the year that the administration's claims about presidential supremacy received their most sustained intellectual defense, rooted in a controversial theory known as the unitary executive. The defense was set out in a book called "The Powers of War and Peace: The Constitution and Foreign Affairs After 9/11," written by John Yoo. A law professor at Berkeley and a former deputy assistant attorney general in the Office of Legal Counsel, Yoo is most famous for his contributions to memos arguing that the Geneva Conventions -- as well as criminal laws prohibiting torture -- don't apply to enemy combatants.

title: Separatists in Quebec Rely on Votes of Migrants
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 8 - Viviane Barbot, a Haitian immigrant and parliamentary candidate for the separatist Bloc QuAbAcois, was passing out leaflets at the city's northern Jarry subway station the other morning to the Chinese, Iranian, Moroccan, Vietnamese and Mexican immigrants rushing to work.

title: Can This Man Reprogram Microsoft?
description: Redmond, Wash. - THINK back to Round 1 of the Internet, when things really got rolling in 1995. The computing landscape was shifting, and a cool, fast-growing young company symbolized the new order: Netscape. At the time, Microsoft looked to be a lumbering old war horse, trapped in the yesteryear of desktop personal computer software, word processors, spreadsheets and operating systems. It seemed, in other words, so 1980's.

title: Briefs: North Africans expelled under new terror laws
Downtown Condos, Armani Style
description: STARTING next month, the developer Shaya Boymelgreen will be playing a game of "can you top this" -- with himself.

title: Porn Suffix, The
description: Establishing a new Internet suffix like ".com" or ".org" takes deep pockets and patience. This has not deterred Stuart Lawley, a Florida entrepreneur, from trying to establish a pornography-only ".xxx" domain. In such a realm, Lawley could restrict porn marketing to adults only, protect users' privacy, limit spam and collect fees from Web masters. The .xxx proposal was finally slated for approval in August by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (Icann), but because of a flurry of protest, it has been shelved for now.

title: CUBA WITHOUT CASTRO
description: To the Editor: The title of this article alone is typical of the American approach to international affairs: pressuring foreign regimes to change in the expectation that eager businesses will somehow restore the great U.S.A. style of democracy and development.

title: After Injury, Kwan Is Set to Start Another Olympic Quest
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10 - A little more than a month ago, the most successful American figure skater of her generation was limping around her home in Southern California, wincing in pain when she tried to do something as simple as climb out of a bathtub.

title: You'll Probably Like the Food Served in These Recovery Rooms
description: When adults go under the knife on national television and teenage girls sport new noses as if they were a trendy shade of lip gloss, it's clear that plastic surgery patients have come out of hiding. Now, some postoperative patients are turning their surgeries into an excuse to get away for a little rest, relaxation and recovery, better known as a vacation.

title: Dear God: Dee-Fense!
description: EAST RUTHERFORD - WITH his team trying to hold on to the lead in a game that could put the New York Giants in sole possession of first place, Jay Swoope suddenly got religion.

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: A Dry Taste of Alpine Air
description: In Italy, Alois Lageder's wines enjoy a reputation as high as his alpine vineyards in Alto Adige (a k a South Tyrol), the northernmost growing region. His 2004 Portico dei Leoni Bianco, a crystalline blend of pinot grigio, pinot bianco and Mller-Thurgau grapes, demonstrates why.

title: A Passage to India: Asphalt and Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYNSTER, RICHARD W.
description: LYNSTER--Richard W. On December 9, 2005. Beloved husband of Pat (nee Flood). Loving father of Katie and Coleen. Dear brother of Timmy. Fond brother-in-law of Sherrod Lynster, Ginny and Tom Flood and Marilyn and Rich Closs. Most beloved uncle of Teig Lynster, Tim, Kara, Ellen, Amanda and Megan Flood, and Matthew, Brian, Kevin and Travis Closs. Former union delegate and mechanic at Keyspan and famous Harbor Light bartender. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor F.H., 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Funeral Mass at St. Francis DeSales Church on Wednesday, at 11 am. Visiting Monday, 7-10 pm, and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-10 pm. Donations may be made to the American Lung Association in his memory.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: BRITTANY
description: VALLEY OF NO RETURN, FROM ATOP THE ROCK OF FALSE LOVERS, OCT. 27, 2005 - Michel Le Page, a retired doctor, from Camaret-sur-Mer, France. "I'm glad that I was able to witness the beauty of that countryside, the interior of Brittany -- deep Brittany, if you prefer. Not having known it before, I'm glad to be discovering it now, even though I, myself, am a Breton. I was literally filled with wonder by its beauty, by its splendor. The climb to the top was strenuous. For someone in shape, it's easy. But for someone of my age -- I'm not so young anymore -- climbing to the top isn't the obvious thing that comes to mind. But I tried it anyway, because I was attracted to that summit, and I didn't regret it. As told to Austin Considine

title: Giving Yourself a Tax Cut on Investments
description: THOUGH tax rates have come down in recent years, the government's cut of capital gains and dividend income is still one of the biggest drags on many investors' portfolios.

title: Congress Passes on the Needs of Boxers
description: IN a revealing display of selective jock infatuation, politicians are running for fantasy league commissioners over the presidency, turning in their reservations at the Capital Grille to be barflies at a sports pub, ditching their drive time with Rush Limbaugh to tune in "Mike and the Mad Dog."

title: CUBA WITHOUT CASTRO
description: To the Editor: I am the general counsel to Global Exchange, a human rights organization that, until the Bush administration's travel crackdown, led hundreds of "reality tours" to Cuba.

title: Bush Meets St. Peter
description: If a meteorite crashed down on the White House today, the conversation at the Pearly Gates might go something like this.

title: Serialized Pop Song, The
description: Every summer has its jeep beats - those inescapable radio hits that swell and subside with the passing S.U.V.'s. Last summer, though, one track was different: it had no chorus, no hook, no real beat even. In fact, it wasn't one song but five. It was R. Kelly's "Trapped in the Closet," a multipart urban operetta released to radio in "chapters" in anticipation of his 10th studio album, "TP.3: Reloaded." Each chapter is about three minutes long and has the same music, a nondescript slow groove, over which Kelly sings a tale of epic infidelity and improbable plot twists.

title: Time for Civilized Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Anne Astley and Ryan Padnuk
description: Anne Christine Lockhart Astley, the daughter of Christine and Roy Astley of Worcester, Mass., is to be married today to Ryan Serge Padnuk, a son of Deborah and Andrew Padnuk of Fort Myers, Fla. Ma Jaya Sati Bhagavati, an interfaith minister, will officiate at Kashi Ashram, a spiritual center in Roseland, Fla.

title: Yikes. A Texas Woman Kosherizes Her Kitchen.
description: The customer from Texas wanted the holiday menu simple: a little stuffed cabbage, some nice Nova, a good helping of potato latkes. There would be about 500 guests for dinner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEITCHMAN, GERTRUDE ''GOLDIE.''
description: DEITCHMAN -- Gertrude "Goldie." Our very special friend, died in Coral Springs, FL, December 9, 2005. Widow of Sam, mother of Bruce, Rosalie, and the late Martin, and beloved grandmother. A true woman of valor, Goldie touched the lives of everyone who knew her. We were glad to share her life as part of her extended family. Rita, Richard, Jill and Elizabeth Chouinard

title: 'Truth and Duty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Congresswoman Kelly and Indian Point (9 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of Two Streets
description: THE neighborhood gang I was in growing up on Dyckman Street in Manhattan wasn't like your jailhouse types with the tattoos, everybody shooting each other. While it wasn't uncommon for somebody to carry a knife, the fights were street fights, not knife fights. We had names like the Tiny Tots or the Redskins, like the football team.

title: Moskowitz, Critic of Education Department and Union, Will Head a Charter School
description: As chairwoman of the City Council's Education Committee, Eva S. Moskowitz held exhaustive hearings and lobbed frequent criticisms, becoming the scourge of both the Department of Education and the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Ethics of the Face Transplant: Focus on the Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: Penalty Box? No, a Great Pretender
description: TESTED: 2006 Kia Rio 5 SX

title: Jay Leno, Conan O'Brien and Jon Stewart
description: Jay Leno

title: Hawaii Calls, With Clarity
description: IF there is a ukulele stashed in your closet, chances are that it's a flimsy model bought during a Hawaiian vacation. It might have been played once upon your return home, at which point everyone within earshot complained about its shrillness. And so it was cast into storage, to languish beside old blankets and jigsaw puzzles.

title: Comfort to the Enemy: Chapter 13: Shootout at Shemane's
description: Carl and Louly have been arguing about Shemane, with Louly questioning why Carl didn't demand to search her house after Jurgen and Otto escaped. Meanwhile, when the Tedesco brothers go to the prison to shoot the Germans, they find that there is no one in the yard, and Bones ends up shooting their driver, Maurice, and stealing his car. Carl and Gary and the Tedescos all end up at Shemane's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, JEANNE
description: GOODMAN--Jeanne. On November 30, 2005. Beloved and devoted mother of Hollace and Adrienne, both privileged to be at her side to the end. Jezzie, you live in our hearts and minds, and continue to guide us, eternally.

title: As Island Home Prices Climb, School Aid Migrates Upstate
description: PATTY MASSA is a happy parent. She lives in the Jamesville-DeWitt school district in the southeastern suburbs of Syracuse, where the academic program, she believes, is uniformly superb and where most pupils score well on statewide tests. She and her husband, Anthony, chose the area five years ago as the place to build a house and get her two children out of the Syracuse city schools, and she has never looked back.

title: Bush and the Locked Door
description: When has The Times ever before had such humor on the front page? I certainly don't remember any Democratic president being presented that way. I think the "one non-fan of the president" you quoted says it best: the photos (in his mind) represented the presidency -- "a metaphor for a man who can't hide anymore."

title: His-and-Her TV, The
description: When two people curl up on a couch, absorbed in their respective novels, that state of affairs seems somehow companionable, even if the two have been transported to opposite ends of the imaginative universe, with one traipsing down the lush green paths of a 19th-century English estate and the other checking out the interstellar sex in one of Frank Herbert's sci-fi novels. Modern technology, of course, has made this kind of apart-while-together bonding all the more possible: picture a pair of lovebirds, their fingers entwined as they walk down the street, their free hands holding up cellphones as they talk to third and fourth parties.

title: Seeing With Your Ears
description: Seeing is something that most of us expect to do with our eyes. But what if you are born blind or lose your sight later in life? Peter Meijer suggests you consider seeing with your ears instead.

title: Medical Maggots
description: Most people associate maggots with death and disease. But if Ronald Sherman has his way, you may soon think of them as lifesavers. Sherman, a doctor who runs the BioTherapeutics, Education and Research Foundation in Irvine, Calif., is a leading proponent of maggot debridement therapy (M.D.T.) -- the use of maggots to consume dead tissue, kill bacteria and stimulate new tissue growth. "They exert these actions 24 hours a day," Sherman says, "without the need for a highly trained surgeon and without the high cost of many other comparable treatments." Sherman has been working with maggots for two decades. The Food and Drug Administration recently cleared maggots for marketing and distribution as "medical devices" -- the first living organisms to receive full F.D.A. approval.

title: On an Open Fire, Much More Than Chestnuts
description: FOR Tom and Denise Haywood of New Milford, it started one snowy night last winter. They were basking on a blanket in the glow of their crackling fireplace, and their 5-year-old daughter, Alisson, asked if they could roast marshmallows.

title: Tweaking Girls' Night
description: FINDING a new mate has not been easy for Alma Cardenas, 42, a computer engineer from Nesconset who was married for seven years before her divorce five years ago. Since her most recent romantic relationship broke up last summer, Ms. Cardenas said, she had been to five events for singles and was lucky to get a guy's phone number -- or be asked for her own -- at one of them.

title: Christine Anderson and Jake Siewert Jr.
description: Christine Lynn Anderson, a public relations director, and Jake Siewert Jr., a former White House press secretary in the Clinton administration, were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Mountains Roman Catholic Church in Jackson, Wyo. The Rev. Leo O'Donovan, president emeritus at Georgetown University, performed the ceremony.

title: Trial-Transcript Dramaturgy
description: When the judge in the Michael Jackson child-molestation trial banned cameras from the courtroom, he left the producers at the E! network with a serious problem. How could they satisfy their audience's appetite for celebrity news without footage of the king of pop squirming next to his lawyer? There was only one thing to do: fake it.

title: When It Comes to Taxes, Older Is Better
description: IF you can afford the many millions you need to live at 720 Park Avenue -- and you squeak past the co-op board -- you will find yourself in a building with all the advantages New York has to offer. It is one of the great old Park Avenue luxury apartment buildings, with tasteful 12-room apartments and neighbors who grace the social pages, the business pages and the lists of the world's richest people.

title: The Neediest Cases; Staving Off Eviction for a Family Burdened by Illness
description: "She lights up the apartment," Carlos Colon said of his 4-year-old daughter, Chlea, as she smiled broadly and offered an ebullient "Hi!" to a recent visitor to the family's home.

title: The Next Retirement Time Bomb
description: SINCE 1983, the city of Duluth, Minn., has been promising free lifetime health care to all of its retired workers, their spouses and their children up to age 26. No one really knew how much it would cost. Three years ago, the city decided to find out.

title: Taking Out the Trash
description: Long Island has a garbage problem. It is producing trash in ever larger amounts, with no place to put it all -- not around here, anyway. We have no landfills, no more room at our incinerators and no realistic chance of ever building new ones. But the amount of waste we produce keeps rising, year by year, ton by ton.

title: Lessons From Sports That Pave the Way For the Next Step
description: BOBBY NYSTROM, Marty Lyons and John Nitti were all professional athletes in New York in the 80's. They all wound up on Long Island after their playing careers. And they all made the transition from the glitter of the sports world to the daily grind of business.

title: Still Swinging, Center Stage, at 78
description: Mount Vernon - THE saxophonist Carmen Leggio said he was in a weakened state at a Presbyterian Jazz Society concert here last month, blaming a bout with food poisoning several days earlier. Neither the other musicians nor the audience could tell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LACEY, EDITH GORDON
description: LACEY--Edith Gordon. Of Tamarac, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY, passed away on December 9, 2005, at the age of 95. Most beloved wife for 70 years of the late Robert Irving Lacey; adored mother of Carol and Edward Sacks, Joan and Ronald Rothaus; most loved grandmother of Jonathan and Barrie Sacks, Bonnie and Robert Moses, Robin Sacks, Rod and Samantha Rothaus, and Merryl Rothaus; most special GG Ma of Evan, Andrew, Ariella, Elijah and Sadie Rose. Also survived by her devoted brother Victor Gordon and brother-inlaw Julie Pepper. She was a graduate of Hunter College. Her incredible energy, her zest for life, her kind and giving nature and her unselfish love were an inspiration to all who had the good fortune to know her. She will live and be loved forever in all our hearts. Services Sunday, December 11, at noon, Temple Beth-El, Old Mill Road, Great Neck. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: In Vitro Meat
description: In July, scientists at the University of Maryland announced the development of bioengineering techniques that could be used to mass-produce a new food for public consumption: meat that is grown in incubators.

title: A Man With a Plan (and Boy, Is It a Plan)
description: TIME flies, they say, but it also creeps, crawls, drags and comes to a standstill: startlingly supple for a supposedly fixed phenomenon. And in Venice, the setting for John Berendt's new book, "The City of Falling Angels," time is even more acrobatic, seeming to bend, bubble, warp and vanish. Sinking? To anyone who spends more than a few days there, it seems possible that the city of islands is being slowly pulled into a different dimension.

title: Doctors and Patients Fighting a Giant
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Report:A Third Way for firms
WTO leaders lay out priorities
FEMA Extends Hotel Program for Evacuees
description: Under pressure from state and local leaders who say they cannot move thousands of hurricane evacuees from hotels into longer-term housing by the Federal Emergency Management Agency's Dec. 15 deadline, officials said Saturday that FEMA would continue paying hotel bills, on a case-by-case basis, for at least three more weeks.

title: Dim Lights and Hot Tubs
description: THE floodlights were out for the opening of Pacha, a new megaclub in Hell's Kitchen. An offshoot of a European chain, Pacha covers a cavernous 30,000 square feet over four stories. It has the feel of a club-land McMansion; there are even several glass-walled showers on the third floor. (For more modest types, there are also a few hot tubs.) A platform for go-go dancers is the focus of the main floor, and a warren of velvet ropes and V.I.P. or V.V.I.P. areas snake up the upper levels, all of which were put to good use for the private opening on Wednesday. The club opened its doors around 10 p.m. By 12:30 a.m. bouncers were advising the invite-only crowd freezing outside that the place was full.

title: In the Rear Window, Tributes to the Dead
description: PALM DESERT, Calif. - WHEN David Atchison, a high school senior from Palm Desert, Calif., died in a car accident in April, one of the first things his brother and friends did was begin designing his memorial decal. They came up with two designs, working on a computer at a decal kiosk at a local mall, and the day before the funeral, they presented them to his parents. Friends and family members could buy their own at the kiosk, where the design was kept on file.

title: In Study, a History Lesson on the Costs of Hurricanes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 - To better understand the potential for catastrophic damage from future hurricanes, scientists are looking to the past.

title: Local Museums Tap Into the Big City
description: IT is always chancy to read trends into museum exhibitions. But at least one trend seems clear: The region's art museums are making a bid to be part of a wider cultural conversation by staging exhibitions that shadow or complement New York City shows, or that are presented collaboratively with city counterparts. And it does not hurt that such exhibitions are good for business. With companion shows, the regional museums can piggyback on the publicity for a bigger exhibition in the city and snare more visitors, even from the city.

title: False-Memory Diet, The
description: According to the results of a study released in August, it is possible to convince people that they don't like certain fattening foods -- by giving them false memories of experiences in which those foods made them sick.

title: Saudi urges keeping OPEC's output high
Santa Cruz: A Beach Town That Doesn't Shut Down
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARSH, PENELOPE (PENNY)
description: MARSH--Penelope (Penny). 02/14/41-12/11/04. Remembering you with love and gratitude. Miss you. Love, Val

title: Letters
description: The Day the Sea Came

title: Buffalo Bills America
description: The Former Pony Post rider will show how the Letters and Telegrams of the Republic were distributed across the immense Continent previous to the railways and the telegraph.

title: A New Hotel in Its Parent's Backyard
description: IN its first hotel venture for Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide in Westchester, work has started on a 150-room Sheraton in Tarrytown, just five miles away from the company's corporate headquarters in White Plains.

title: Class, Brass and 23 Doors
description: Beulah Smith lived for 44 years in a brownstone at Park Place and Brooklyn Avenue in Crown Heights. She never took in boarders, and after the death of her husband, Ivan, she lived alone among the oak paneling, stained glass and flowery wooden fretwork of her turn-of-the-century house.

title: What Would a Clone Say?
description: Those who wish to console themselves with the "clear, bright line" that a clone will not be implanted in a woman's uterus might be alarmed to learn that artificial wombs are being developed by researchers. The implantation of a cloned embryo into an artificial uterus allows for the real possibility of harvesting differentiated tissues and fully formed organs from humans that have developmentally progressed to the fetal stage and beyond. We owe Gary Rosen,

title: Showman of the Wild Frontier
description: BUFFALO BILL'S AMERICA

title: Toothbrush That Sings, The
description: Brushing your teeth is a drag -- particularly when you're 3 years old. You can't see over the counter, the toothpaste tastes weird and it all brings you one step closer to bedtime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURRY, JOHN (JACK)
description: CURRY--John (Jack). Of Sarasota, FL. Born February 9, 1920 in Buffalo, NY. Died December 6, 2005 in Sarasota. Predeceased by his cherished wife of 51 years, Elizabeth. Loving father of Christopher, Paula and Barbara. Loving brother of Barbara, Mary, Margaret and Alexia. A retired Foreign Service Staff Officer, he served in Dublin, Port of Spain, Madras, Thessaloniki, Tel Aviv, Oslo, Lisbon and Washington.

title: 2006 Subaru B9 Tribeca: Plan B9 From Outer Space
description: WHEN I started the Subaru B9 Tribeca for the first time, I almost expected to hear it say "Take me to your leader."

description: ART-SITES GUIDES TO CONTEMPORARY ART AND ARCHITECTURE By Sidra Stich Art SITES, all volumes, paperbacks, are $19.95

title: One Shivers, the Other Doesn't
description: I'VE been thinking lately about my wedding vows. My husband and I have been married for more than 22 years, and a lot of those promises have come in handy. Take "in sickness and in health." We have both been tested by various maladies and have come through fine so far.

title: From Ivory Tower
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Laura Spielman and Russell Williams
description: Laura Anne Spielman, a daughter of Amy Spielman and Charles H. Spielman of San Diego was married yesterday to Russell Allen Williams, a son of Jan F. Williams and Dr. Robert N. Williams of Denver. The Rev. Dean Kauka, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Four Seasons Hualalai Resort in Kona, Hawaii.

title: Scrooge's Ghosts, With Shtick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK - IF a camel may be said to have all the attributes of a horse designed by a committee, what is the result when a group of actors and their artistic director join to write a farce, especially one that features the Theater, beloved and beleaguered, as leading lady?

title: A Sense of Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Folksonomy
description: In 1876, Melvil Dewey devised an elegant method for categorizing the world's books. The Dewey Decimal System divides books into 10 broad subject areas and several hundred sub-areas and then assigns each volume a precise number -- for example, 332.6328 for Jim Rodgers's investment guide, "Hot Commodities." But on the Internet, a new approach to categorization is emerging. Thomas Vander Wal, an information architect and Internet developer, has dubbed it folksonomy -- a people's taxonomy.

title: Real Estate Housewives
description: HERE'S a sure sign that the housing boom may be about to fizzle: All the women in my life are turning into real estate agents right before my eyes. Which makes it really hard to make fun of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDOVITZ, JACK B.
description: LANDOVITZ--Jack B. Died December 9, 2005. Beloved husband of Tilda and loving father of Steven and Karen. Decorated WWII veteran. Retired Vice President Macy's NY. Board member Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale. Services Sunday, 1 pm, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to the Synagogue, 475 Henry Hudson Pkwy, Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Oslo
description: WHY GO NOW -- "The shortest day of the year," an old Rodgers and Hart ballad reminds us, "has the longest night of the year." Few cities on earth have longer winter nights than Oslo and, surely, in even fewer have the natives been more creative about turning the sunless months into an enchanted time of candlelit coziness.

title: A Passage to India: Asphalt and Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: What Would a Clone Say?
description: "Data," an android on "Star Trek: The Next Generation," gets along fine with humans, as long as they respect him, although he has no feelings or emotions. Who knows, humans might be more human with clones around.

title: Keep 'Adam and Steve' Out of His In-Box. Is That So Hateful?
description: Wayne, N.J. - IF it weren't Women's History Month, if he weren't an observant Muslim, if no one had sent him the e-mail invitation to view a film billed as "a lesbian relationship story," no one would be accusing Jihad Daniel of harassment and hate speech.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 6 about the making of "Memoirs of a Geisha" misstated the English-language experience of Gong Li, who is one of its stars. Ms. Gong spoke English in the 1997 film "Chinese Box"; she is not making her English-language debut in "Memoirs of a Geisha." A reader informed The Times of the error last week.

title: Condo Board and Common Elements
description: Q. We live in a 65-unit condominium that has an indoor pool and health club with a small landscaped patio. A previous board of managers reduced the size of the patio by erecting a bicycle storage shed and then sold the 16 spaces to unit owners on a first-come, first-served basis. These owners pay no additional common charges for the use of what was previously a common area. The current board has now amended the house rules to permit individual unit owners to reserve the health club and patio for private parties for periods of up to five hours. During these times other unit owners cannot use the facilities. Does the board have the authority to reduce or restrict access to the common elements like this? Jim O'Neill, Long Beach, N.Y.

title: Primary Addresses | Dec. 4-10
description: NORTH CAROLINA

title: An Actor, a Writer and the Silent Border Between Them
description: TOMMY LEE JONES started thinking about directing what would become his first feature on a deer hunt deep in the unforgiving landscape of West Texas. There was no script yet. But he already knew the film's dominant character wouldn't utter a single line.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "What is happening is not our fault. We didn't heat up the atmosphere or chop down our trees. But we are paying the price with the suffering of our people."

title: Ensemble Made Just For Gilbert & Sullivan
description: Briarcliff Manor - IT was a blustery night, worthy of an opera subtitled "The Witch's Curse." But pouring rain did not stop the Westchester Gilbert and Sullivan Group from meeting at Emily Perl Kingsley's house here to sing and laugh their way through "Ruddigore."

title: Corrections
description: A capsule guide with the Practical Traveler column on Page 6 of the Travel section today about credit cards and frequent flier miles omits mention in some copies of the United Airlines Mileage Plus Visa platinum card from Chase. Its annual fee is $140. New cardholders get 20,000 miles, a $25 discount certificate, an upgrade and a free companion ticket. In addition, the guide misstated the number of miles that new gold card users get; it is 20,000 miles, not 15,000.

title: What Cards Are Friendliest to Frequent Fliers?
description: Correction Appended

title: On Advertising: Billboards paint the town pink
A Defense Jells, Then It Hardens
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 9 - Reformers need a low point, and for the Giants it struck in a flash on Sept. 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEMAN, HELEN
description: FREEMAN--Helen. The Graenum Berger Bronx Jewish Federation Service Center expresses profound sorrow at the passing of Helen Freeman, beloved wife of our devoted Management Committee member and officer, Melvin D. Freeman. May the Almighty comfort Mel, his daughters, Phyllis & Susan and the entire family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and spare them further sorrow.

title: A Quarterback's Personal Rally
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 7 - A vertical scar begins just below David Garrard's navel. He can see it when he lifts up his shirt, when he gets in and out of his Jaguars uniform, when he prepares for bed.

title: Breathtaking Redick Leaves Texas Winded
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 10 - For Duke, beating Texas, with its undefeated record and its three imposing frontcourt players, was supposed to be a difficult assignment. As it turned out, it was anything but. On an afternoon when J. J. Redick was shooting so well, no one was going to beat Duke.

title: Why Female Directors Are Broadway's Smallest
description: OF the 39 plays and musicals that opened on Broadway this year, 3 were directed by women (a husband-and-wife team directed a fourth, the short-lived "Blonde in the Thunderbird"). Of the 34 new shows in 2004, women directed 2. These are not particularly encouraging figures for those looking for the new female directorial voices. Many women can be found directing shows off Broadway and running regional theaters, but the best-known and biggest-budget venue has not been all that welcoming.

title: Hypomanic American, The
description: For centuries, scholars have tried to explain the American character: is it the product of the frontier experience, or of the heritage of dissenting Protestantism, or of the absence of feudalism? This year, two professors of psychiatry each published books attributing American exceptionalism to a new and hitherto unsuspected source: American DNA. They argue that the United States is full of energetic risk-takers because it's full of immigrants, who as a group may carry a genetic marker that expresses itself as restless curiosity, exuberance and competitive self-promotion -- a combination known as hypomania.

title: Paperback Row
description: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: DRIVE FREE IN HAWAII -- United Vacations and Alamo offer visitors to Hawaii five days of a free economy car rental throughout 2006. The rental must be part of a five-day-minimum vacation package on one island, and renters must pay about $30 in local taxes, plus a $3 daily state surcharge and any optional insurance. Free rentals are not available from June 15 to Aug. 19 or Dec. 16 to 31. For more details call 888-328-6877 or see www.unitedvacations.com.

title: New devices free satellite radio from the car
Revolting High Rises
description: Christopher Caldwell (Nov. 27) was right to examine the failures of Modernist design in the troubled French banlieues. However, the idea Le Corbusier and his contemporaries had was to design housing that transcended residents' low position in the social and economic hierarchy. Modernists focused on universal human needs instead of cultural markings: no matter your class or race, you would benefit from ample sunlight, flexible spaces and technological conveniences.

title: Dishes So Robust, They Chase Away the Chill
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, winter has not officially arrived, but try telling that to the weather. Dropping temperatures demand robust food that heats the body to its chilled bone: thick soups, roasts, stews. Those seeking a snug fireside meal in elegant surroundings or a casual stop on the way to ski slopes or weekend retreats have a number of up-county restaurants to choose from.

title: Cobblestones are Good for You
description: According to a study published in August in the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society, if you want to be a fitter, more relaxed, more agile retiree, the prescription is to walk on cobblestones.

title: Iraq, New Orleans And Bush's Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Cinema's Flu Taboo
description: LOS ANGELES - To see how leukemia ravages beauty, go straight to Ali MacGraw in "Love Story." To understand the destructive power of AIDS, there was "And the Band Played On" or "Philadelphia." But don't expect to get much enlightenment about the threat of bird flu from the big or small screens of Hong Kong.

title: In a Club Full of Comics, The King Is Also a Jester
description: FREDDIE ROMAN was just finishing his salad when he raised his fork and pointed it at a middle-aged woman.

title: The Perfect Partridge for Every Pear Tree
description: 1. One pear tree decorates the front of Good Charma's Tree of Life necklace in 22-karat gold vermeil on a 32-inch chain; the words Live, Love, Life are engraved on the back ($260, 413-528-9455 to order).

title: Aiming for a Zero-Energy Home
description: PATERSON - ON a hill over Route 20 here, dozens of businesses are collaborating to create something good for the environment: a completely "green" home.

title: Elisa New and Lawrence Summers
description: Elisa New, a Harvard professor, and Lawrence H. Summers, the university's president, are to be married today at Elmwood, the president's residence on the Harvard campus in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Norman Janis, a chaplain at Harvard, is to perform the ceremony.

title: The French: Married to the Past, and Thinking of Divorce
description: PARIS - THE French, the historian Danielle Domergue-Cloarec says, "have always had problems with their history." She should know. She specializes in French colonial history, which her compatriots can't decide whether to love or hate. They feel the same about Napoleon, and this month both problems have been on vivid display.

title: Alpine Skiing: Rienda stays hot in giant slalom
THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 11-Dec. 17; DANCE
description: One of the nicest signs of the vitality of dance is the audience's appetite for the new. Last spring the New York City Ballet put on a season-opening gala of five premieres. Imagine such a thing with the New York Philharmonic. ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER, currently settled into CITY CENTER for its annual season there, is offering -- along with a steady diet of Ailey staples -- three world premieres, two new productions and one company premiere. On Friday and Saturday nights, and three more times thereafter, a varying assortment of these premieres will be grouped under the title "All New." You can see work by mature choreographers and young choreographers, and by Alvin Ailey, too, because one of the new productions is his "Witness." 8, City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212 or alvinailey.org or nycitycenter.org; $25 to $110, with $10 student rush tickets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, SELMA MODELL
description: ROSEN--Selma Modell. On December 9, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Charles H. Rosen. Devoted mother to Jane and Richard. Adoring grandmother to Dana, Brette, and Kitty. Loving sister of Arthur B. Modell, Pat Breslin Modell, the late Pansy Modell Bloom, and Bernard Bloom. Loving aunt to all her nieces and nephews. A true woman of valor. Goodness, kindness, generosity and forgiveness prevailed throughout her life. A tireless and selfless leader of the Kitty Modell League of the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, Charles H. Rosen Scholarship Fund of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, and Hadassah. Committed to Jewish tradition and Israel, she created a home of warmth and dignity. A brilliant sculptor and pianist, she imparted her love of culture and beauty to all she met. The material world was not important to her. Friends, family, charity, and graciousness defined her life. The light of our lives has dimmed, but we carry the torch of her essence forever, in the hope to once again light the world with joy and goodness. Jane and Richard

title: Forehead Billboards
description: In January, Andrew Fischer, a 21-year-old Web-site developer from Omaha, Neb., went on eBay and auctioned off advertising space on his forehead. "As I go around town doing my thing. . .your domain name will be plastered smack-dab on my noggin," he proposed. In exchange for a winning bid of $37,375, Fischer sported a temporary tattoo of the logo for an over-the-counter sleep remedy called SnoreStop for a full month. "It took me forever to do errands and stuff," Fischer says. "Everywhere I went people couldn't help noticing -- they had to talk to 'the forehead guy.' I guess that's what the advertiser was after."

title: Correction
Hollywood-Style Documentary, The
description: When critics want to praise the realism of a fictional film, they sometimes liken it to a documentary. But as filmmakers and distributors have discovered the commercial potential of nonfiction movies, the comparison more often runs in reverse. The documentaries that look most attractive are those that mimic the tried-and-true conventions of Hollywood, telling unusual or exotic stories in reassuringly familiar ways.

title: Global Savings Glut, The
description: That the United States, with a current account deficit equivalent to more than 6 percent of its gross domestic product, is living beyond its means is not in dispute. And, at least until recently, there was general agreement among economists that the shortfall was mainly due to American profligacy, in the form of record federal budget deficits and a household savings rate that has now officially hit zero.

title: Gauging the Impact Of Acquisitions Is a Slippery Science
description: DALLAS, Dec. 9 - At this week's winter meetings, where the hotel lobby droned with talk of ballplayers' on-base percentages and earned run averages, it was not uncommon to hear a veteran baseball man grumble, "The only statistic that matters is team wins."

title: Ralph and Me
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: The Truth (with Jokes)
A Better Budget Fix
description: Last month, New York voters wisely rejected an amendment to the state Constitution that had been mislabeled "budget reform." Rather than actually reforming the unspeakable way Albany creates a budget each year, that amendment would have made matters unthinkable -- by shifting power over $100 billion or so a year from the governor to 212 hungry legislators.

title: Patti Smith, New Jersey's Truest Rock-Poet
description: THERE are lots of ways to frame Patti Smith: as punk's poet laureate/godmother; as the defiantly genderless, caterwauling muse of the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe; as the fearless bad influence who opened her 1975 album "Horses" with the line "Jesus died for somebody's sins, but not mine," and followed it with a 30-year streak of subversiveness.

title: Other Voices: How Can The Times Report on Itself?
description: Providing links to other newspapers is a fine idea, so far as it goes, but it doesn't go nearly far enough. First, of course, most readers of the newspaper continue to read the print version. More to the point, providing multiple links doesn't address -- and won't affect -- the actual coverage in The Times. To get truly independent and critical coverage of yourself, you need to hire reporters that do not work for The Times (I argued this in a Nov. 9 op-ed article in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer).

title: Doctors and Patients Fighting a Giant
description: To the Editor:

title: Every Hour, It's Dj Vu All Over Again
description: John Marzano and his friends had come to the fork in the road -- so they took it. They were sitting around talking baseball about two years ago and one of them pulled out "The Yogi Book: I Really Didn't Say Everything I Said" (Workman, $8.95) by Yogi Berra, the Hall of Fame Yankee catcher, longtime Montclair resident and master of the English language. "Somebody said, 'Hey, wouldn't it be great to have a talking watch, with Yogi doing the talking?' " said Mr. Marzano, a West Orange resident who sells commercial and residential real estate in Newark. "None of us was in retail, but we all loved the idea."

title: Eligibility rules could pit brother against brother
Dolphin Culture
description: Sometimes, when a dolphin in Shark Bay, off the coast of Western Australia, prepares to forage, she drops to the sea floor, rips a fat conical chunk of sea sponge out of it, covers her beak with the sponge cone and sets to work. After she finds the fish she wants, she drops the sponge. "Sponging," as the scientists at the Shark Bay Dolphin Research Project call this behavior, is an unusual instance of an animal using another animal as a tool, but that is not what makes the sponging interesting to biologists. It's that dolphins learn to use the sponges - to probe deeply for food while protecting their beaks - from their mothers.

title: Madness About a Method
description: Science is the distinctive achievement and crowning glory of the modern age. So, at least, we are often told. It is also something that, relatively speaking, the United States is pretty good at. By many measures, this nation leads the world in scientific research, even if our dominance has been slipping of late. Oddly, though, Americans on the whole do not seem to care greatly for science.

title: Myths Made Modern
description: A SHORT HISTORY OF MYTH

title: Preventing Suicide Bombing
description: How do you stop a suicide bomber on his way to a target? Until recently, that wasn't an urgent question for scholars in the West. But it is now, and scientists, military strategists and security experts are scrambling, in different directions, to find an answer.

title: The Bonds That Fight the Monster Called Inflation
description: DAVID SPOR loves the laughable special effects, ramshackle sets and wooden dialogue that are hallmarks of a wonderfully bad "B" horror movie. His online diary, The Creeping Blog of Terror, is named after "The Creeping Terror," a classic 1964 schlockfest whose infamous monster appears to be a shambling shag carpet of evil.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EMELOCK, HERMAN
description: EMELOCK--Herman. Deceased December 7, 1998. May you rest in peace. Ana

title: NURSING HOMES FACE PROSECUTION
description: Two New Jersey nursing homes where workers have complained of anti-union activity will be prosecuted by the federal government on charges of unfair labor practices. The National Labor Relations Board said the workers' union had presented sufficient evidence that the Wayne View Care Center in Wayne and the Victoria House in Matawan locked out some workers and refused to permit some to return to work after a brief strike, threatened to dismiss some workers and engaged in bad-faith bargaining. The workers have been without a contract since March. Their union, the Service Employees International Union, has carried out a campaign to bring attention to the homes' owners, Elia Zois and Mary Theresa Khawly, who are active in wealthy Manhattan social circles, accusing them of neglecting workers and patients.

title: Robot Jockeys
description: When the new camel-racing season got under way recently in Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, spectators with sharp vision noticed that something was up with the freshman class of jockeys. For the first time in living memory, they were not young children imported from impoverished areas of South Asia and Africa. The jockeys in Qatar were imported from Switzerland; those in the Emirates were local products. And one more thing: they were also robots.

title: Bush and the Locked Door
description: Oh, please. No more disingenuous explanations for The Times's delight in making President Bush an object of scorn or mockery. The Times conducts its own three-card monte political game, and you shill the suckers. What unworthy employment.

title: Fleeting Relationship, The
description: Americans put a premium on sustaining intimate relationships, but could it be that they gain as much emotional sustenance from the relative strangers they meet on commuter trains, in the stands at softball games and even at strip clubs?

title: S.I. Fire Kills Two Siblings And Critically Injures Another
description: Two young siblings were killed and a third was critically injured yesterday morning after a fire raced through a cottage on Staten Island's eastern shore near Oakwood Beach, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KROBOT, SUE
description: KROBOT--Sue, Age 92. Died December 9. Beloved wife of Charlie. Adored mother of Charles (Stephanie). Devoted grandmother of Jonathan & Jennifer. Services private.

title: A Better Budget Fix
description: Last month, New York voters wisely rejected an amendment to the state Constitution that had been mislabeled "budget reform." Rather than actually reforming the unspeakable way Albany creates a budget each year, that amendment would have made matters unthinkable -- by shifting power over $100 billion or so a year from the governor to 212 hungry legislators.

title: Those Anonymous Sources
description: Even if journalists could develop a workable set of standards for dealing with anonymous sources internally, they would face the problem of maintaining confidentiality when the courts and their officers demand to know the names of the sources. Journalists are barking up the wrong tree if they think a national shield law based on the right to freedom of the press will do the job. The courts have repeatedly denied that such a right exists; it is questionable whether a shield law would trump these rulings.

title: Ellen-Jane Erbstein and Ben Moss III
description: Ellen-Jane Erbstein, the daughter of Bonnie Erbstein and Gerald Erbstein of Montreal, is to be married today to Charles Benjamin Moss III, the son of Robin Heller Moss of New York and Charles B. Moss Jr. of Roxbury, Conn. Rabbi Leigh Lerner is to officiate at the Ritz-Carlton in Montreal.

title: Anti-Paparazzi Flash, The
description: If you have ever felt sorry for celebrities hounded by cameras as they go about their daily business -- be that pumping gas or entering a flashy nightclub -- you can rest easy. A group of researchers at Georgia Tech has designed what could become an effective celebrity protection device: an instrument that detects the presence of a digital camera's lens and then shoots light directly at the camera when a photographer tries to take a picture. The result? A blurry picture of a beam of light. Try selling that to Us Weekly.

title: Dukes Up for Cupid
description: IN the corner, past the center ring and beyond the wall of mirrors, a 20-something off-duty Wall Streeter stepped away from his speed bag and toward a petite, toned woman, resting with jump rope in hand. The two exchanged smiles and then breathy hellos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DREXLER, DAVID E.
description: DREXLER--David E. On December 10, 2005. Age 72. Of New York City. Service Monday, December 12, 1 pm, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Kong Through the Ages
description: A glimpse at incarnations of the giant gorilla since the original 1933 "King Kong."

title: Santa Cruz With Kids
Why We Travel
description: A collection of recent photographs from the Why We Travel column.

title: Barrick Extends Date on Placer Dome Bid
description: The Barrick Gold Corporation, the gold producer, extended its offer to buy a rival, Placer Dome, after Placer agreed not to execute a shareholder-rights plan that could have increased the cost of the bid.

title: No Replay for Feely and Giants
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 - If the doubts did not come from the recesses of Jay Feely's mind, they flashed in front of him on full display at Lincoln Financial Field.

title: The Sound Of the N.B.A.'s Dress Code: Ka-Ching
description: When the National Basketball Association instituted a business-casual dress code this season, plenty of grumbling ensued among players, commentators and fans alike.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brookyln: Man Killed After Warning Of Robbery
description: A scrap metal collector was fatally stabbed outside a metal processing business in Brownsville yesterday, said the victim's co-workers. The police said the stabbing occurred shortly before 2:30 a.m. in front of S & R Scrap Metal Processing at 652 Junius Street. They did not identify the victim, but they said he was 47 years old. Co-workers said he collected discarded metal in a small cart. The workers said the victim had yelled to them about a robbery after two men began banging on the front gate of their workplace. The men then stabbed him, the workers said. "There is not enough money around here to die for," said one worker, who gave only what he said was his first name, Sonny. Ann Farmer (NYT)

title: Think Twice Before Discarding That Lowly Three of Diamonds
description: Many players love to bid a small slam, but a grand slam is attempted only when there appear to be 13 tricks. To go down one in seven is a very expensive exercise. But if you are quietly enjoying a club duplicate with only fractions of a master point at stake, why not give one a whirl? Often a grand slam is easy to play. There is no need to count losers; it is more sensible to try to find 13 winners.

title: Popular Demand
description: Two films open this week -- "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" playing David to the "King Kong" version of Goliath. "Burials," which stars Tommy Lee Jones in his feature-film directing debut, won the writing prize for Guillermo Arriaga at the Cannes Film Festival in May, along with an acting award for Mr. Jones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITBECK, MARY RANCK
description: WHITBECK--Mary Ranck. 94, died peacefully at home on December 10, 2005. Predeceased in 1994 by Brainerd H. Whitbeck, her husband of 53 years, she is survived by two sons, B. Hunt Whitbeck Jr. of New York City, and John V. Whitbeck of Paris, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to Vassar College in lieu of flowers.

title: Brazil is ready to use clout to get a fair deal
A Serial Killer Shakes Up a City and a Cultural Myth
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 11 - This much they know: Someone has been murdering older women in Mexico City, strangling them in their homes, pocketing a keepsake and vanishing into the city's streets.

title: 40,000 protest general's arrest
Corrections
description: Credits were reversed for two pictures in some copies on Wednesday about the deaths of three children and an elderly man in a house fire in Queens. The picture showing flames consuming the house was by Gary Marks of Multi Media Network News, not Richard Lee for The New York Times. The picture of firefighters inside the house was by Mr. Lee, not Mr. Marks. The credit for a third picture, showing firefighters aiding an unidentified woman, misstated the photographer's given name. He is Roy Renna, not Victor.

title: Migration's Flip Side: One Big Empty Nest
description: TURKI, Latvia, Dec. 6 - In this poor but proud farming region, where many of the small wooden houses have no electricity and people still read by candlelight, nearly every third home sits empty. Their occupants have gone to pick mushrooms in Ireland.

title: New group for 'Asian century' shuns U.S.
Women's Voices Raised, Singing the Praises of the Medieval and the Modern
description: The conventional wisdom conveyed in music-history classes for decades was that in medieval times, the sound of sacred vocal music was that of men's voices, since the church, the major provider of such music, did not include women in its choirs. Not until the revival in the early 1980's of music by the 12th-century abbess Hildegard of Bingen and the success of the female American quartet Anonymous 4 a few years later were obvious exceptions widely noted: women sang in convents, naturally.

title: New Meaning for a Film the Bronx Cheered
description: Few in the Bronx seemed to mind that the 1993 movie "A Bronx Tale" was filmed not in the Bronx but in Astoria, Queens. The movie was written by Chazz Palminteri, who grew up in the Bronx, and had one other thing going for it.

title: Thudding, Flailing and a Shower of Paper
description: The Norway in New York festival closed this weekend with a typically provocative yet humane program. Hooman Sharifi's "We Failed to Hold This Reality in Mind" communicated less than Mr. Sharifi, its creator and performer, must have intended. But he and his dancing will be hard to forget.

title: AOL Co-Founder Calls for Split of Time Warner
description: As Time Warner nears a decision on a big alliance with Google or Microsoft for its America Online unit, Stephen M. Case, the co-founder of AOL, has spoken out against the plan, aligning himself with the thinking of the financier Carl C. Icahn, who has pushed for a breakup of Time Warner.

title: AOL Choice Will Affect Ad Market on the Web
description: Once Richard D. Parsons, the chairman of Time Warner, decided not to sell an ownership stake in America Online, he was faced with the potentially more difficult prospect of forging a relationship -- with either Google or Microsoft -- that would bolster AOL even as it competes head-on with its partner.

title: No Word From Governor as Execution Approaches
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 - As fervor over the scheduled execution of Stanley Tookie Williams early Tuesday began to boil across California on Sunday, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger declined for a third day to announce whether he would spare the life of Mr. Williams, a former gangster and now world-famous death row inmate, and commute his sentence to life in prison.

title: Seoul scientist faces new inquiry
Savoring Mallomars: Let Us Count the Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article by Reuters on Friday about Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's denial of a report in The Daily News that he planned to retire misattributed reports about possible successors. The reports were in the Daily News article, not in The New York Post.

title: Savoring Mallomars: Let Us Count the Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: SPIGOT WIDE OPEN -- Ministers from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Kuwait City today and are expected to agree to continue producing about 30 million barrels of oil a day. With demand high and prices hovering around $60 a barrel, OPEC sees little reason to cut production now. But the group may privately discuss the minimum price it will choose to defend.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: City Denies Negligence In Ferry Crash
description: The city has filed a 51-page brief in its continuing effort to cap its liability in the 2003 fatal crash of a Staten Island ferry. "The city was not negligent and the vessel was not unseaworthy," Wayne D. Meehan, a lawyer hired by the city, wrote in a brief filed late Friday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. He said the crash, which killed 11 people, was caused by the "sudden and unforeseeable incapacitation" of the assistant captain, the only person at the controls. Anthony Bisignano III, the lead lawyer for some people injured in the crash and relatives of some of those killed, noted that the city's director of ferry operations pleaded guilty in April to seaman's manslaughter for failing to enforce a rule requiring two pilots to be at the controls. "We feel confident that the inaction of the city in educating and training its crew members on the two-pilot rule was a direct cause of this tragedy," he said. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: For the Yonkers Raceway, Every Race Unrun Is a Winner
description: As business arrangements go, Yonkers Raceway might just be the envy of horse racing tracks across the nation: It has not run a race for months, but it is doing as well as ever.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Is Fatally Shot In Fight
description: A man was fatally shot about 5 a.m. yesterday during a fight at 188th Street and Marion Avenue in Tremont, the police said. The man was identified by the police as Miguel Perez, 20, of Valentine Avenue. He was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital and pronounced dead. There were no arrests in the case yesterday.

title: In Race for Fractions, Swiss Skier Stands a Tad Too Tall
description: VAL D'ISRE, France, Dec. 11 - The Swiss pride themselves on being precise and detail oriented, so they may have felt a sting when they found out what happened to their countryman Didier Defago at a World Cup ski race Sunday.

title: Gunfire in Queens Housing Project Kills 2 and Injures 2
description: A man and a woman were killed and two other people were injured early yesterday when gunfire erupted in the vestibule of a building at a public housing project in the Rockaways, the police said.

title: Koznick Is Looking for a Strong Finish to Her Career
description: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 11 - She can streak her hair pink and speak in, like, the vernacular of 18-year-olds, but then Kristina Koznick will have a race like the World Cup slalom Sunday at Aspen Mountain and feel her age acutely.

title: Would You Like Some Fries With That Download?
description: If the Walt Disney Company has its way, McDonald's Happy Meal toys could be replaced with portable media players that hold Disney movies, music, games or photos, according to a pending patent application. Users could add files to the devices by earning points with food purchases.

description: Correction Appended

title: A Ground Zero Grows in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 - Scores of extras loiter, their faces covered in soot. A man sprays gray insulation foam -- in lieu of concrete dust -- at what looks much like the corner of Church and Vesey Streets in Lower Manhattan. Another tosses reams of paper in the air. Nearby, others are debating precisely how to crush a fire truck and an ambulance.

title: French protester Bov freed for WTO meeting
A New Port in Shanghai, 20 Miles Out to Sea
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 11 - China has opened the first phase of what could eventually become the world's largest container shipping port, a deepwater facility on an island about 20 miles out to sea.

description: An article last Monday about divisions within an East Hampton synagogue over allegations that its rabbi, David J. Gelfand, plagiarized sermons and misappropriated synagogue funds misstated the title of Barnet L. Liberman, who said that an investigation by the synagogue board was frustrated when the rabbi cut off talks last summer. He is chairman of the board's personnel committee, not the board president.

description: GAINESVILLE, Fla. - WHAT is it about watching young women being ravished by oversized middle-aged gorillas that presses so many buttons -- and fuels so many King Kong movies, including the latest version opening on Wednesday?

title: Back Home, Knicks Try to Move On
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 11 - The Knicks returned to practice Sunday to try to right their season and find a semblance of normalcy a day after helping Quentin Richardson bury his second brother to be shot to death in an apparent robbery attempt.

Separatists in Quebec Seek Immigrant Votes
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 8 - Viviane Barbot, a Haitian immigrant and parliamentary candidate for the separatist Bloc Qubcois, was passing out leaflets at the city's northern Jarry subway station the other morning to the Chinese, Iranian, Moroccan, Vietnamese and Mexican immigrants rushing to work.

title: Lies We Have to Tell
description: Weeks before ABrokeback MountainA opened or started piling up awards, many movie-going friends started telling me about the trailer. (Real | Windows) The first thing I heard was that it seemed attached to every movie that had opened for months. The next was that audiences were laughing A at the preview, not with it.

title: The Burden of Medicaid Cuts
description: House and Senate negotiators are beginning to grapple with the fateful issue of how best to restrain Medicaid spending. Their decisions will affect not only the ability of hard-pressed governors to rein in Medicaid costs that are eating up state budgets, but also the ability of some of the nation's poorest individuals to get medical care. The guiding principle should be to extract savings not from beneficiaries too poor to absorb the cost but from industries and institutions better able to bear the burden.
