description: HONG KONG, Dec. 13 - With protesters chanting slogans outside, scuffling with the police and even jumping into the harbor, the World Trade Organization ministerial conference began here today as ministers turned their attention to agriculture and the question of assistance for the world's poorest countries.

title: A Holy Man Is Off to the Races With Issues in Black and White
description: You've seen Alex a thousand times. He is a well-groomed, well-spoken white man of the middle classes. His manner is rational and convivial when he walks briskly onto the stage of Performance Space 122.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Production Up 8.5% in October
description: India's industrial output grew 8.5 percent in October from the previous year. Demand has been fueled by rising incomes and increased borrowing because of low interest rates. According to government data, manufacturing output, which accounts for more than three-quarters of production, rose 9.6 percent in the period. Analysts say that the growth may prompt the Reserve Bank of India, the country's central bank, to raise interest rates next month to control inflation. The economy is expected to grow more than 8 percent in the year ending in March.

title: New Drug Mix Against Malaria Is Announced
description: Two simpler, cheaper formulations of anti-malaria drugs will be available next year, a public-private partnership announced yesterday.

title: Hot Technology for ChillyStreets in Estonia
description: TALLINN, Estonia, Dec. 8 - Visiting the offices of Skype feels like stumbling on to a secret laboratory in a James Bond movie, where mad scientists are hatching plots for world domination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTH, ROSE OSZTERN
description: ROTH--Rose Osztern. May 21, 1905--December 11, 2005. Daughter of Frieda and Dr. Leopold Osztern. Widow of Emanuel Roth. Born and grew up in Budapest, Hungary. Earned a Ph.D. in languages at the University of Budapest. Also studied at the Sorbonne on a scholarship. She was separated from her husband for seven years due to WWII. She is a Holocaust survivor having been, along with her daughter, in concentration camp at Bergen Belsen during part of 1944 and 1945. From Bergen Belsen her group was taken to Switzerland prior to the end of the war as part of a barter arrangement with Germany. From Switzerland she went to Prague where she was reunited with her husband in 1946. Rose, her husband and daughter arrived in New York in 1950 and she became an inveterate New Yorker. She got a job at the New York Public Library and to further her career studied at Columbia University where she earned an MLS in Library Science. She worked at the 42nd St. Public Library for more that 30 years. Rose loved New York and was very much a part of it attending the theatre, the opera, museums and loving all its vitality. However, she remained a lady of "old Europe: formal, elegant and chic." In 1996 at the age of 90 she moved into the Salvation Army Williams Senior Residence, where for a good number of years she truly enjoyed herself. She had to move to the Amsterdam Nursing Home in September 2005 where she died. Survivors are her daughter Erika, son-in-law Michael Pearl, niece Eva Foltin, grandnieces Anne & Liz Foltin & nephew & niece Dennis and Lottie Miklos, and grandnephews David and Robert Miklos.

title: It's not too late
Have a hot, dry, stormy life, kids
REALLY?
description: THE CLAIM -- Too much noise can increase the risk of a heart attack.

title: Judge Issues  Injunction Against Transit Strike
description: A state Supreme Court judge issued a preliminary injunction today, barring New York City's transportation worker's union from striking for the first time in 25 years if they fail to reach a new contract by Thursday night's deadline.

title: Saudi Arabia Looks Past Oil in Attempt to Diversify
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia - The ultimate oil state is seeking to shift its economy away from oil.

title: HarperCollins Will Create a Searchable Digital Library
description: In the latest move in the battle between publishers and search engines, HarperCollins Publishers said yesterday it would create its own digital library of all of its book and audio content and make it searchable by consumers on the Internet. Web users will be able to search the HarperCollins archive via search engines like Google and Yahoo or the specialized programs of retailers like Amazon.com.

title: Pope Condemns Terrorism, Praises Human Rights
description: VATICAN CITY, Dec. 13 - Pope Benedict XVI today condemned terrorism, nuclear arms and, in an apparent reference to reports that the terror suspects seized by the United States had been tortured, lack of respect for international law.

title: Alexander Reconsidered
description: In the Hollywood Reporter by way of Reuters, Chen Kaige, the Chinese director of Farewell My Concubine and The Promise, a $35 million epic that will compete heavily for best foreign film, said that people had it all wrong with Alexander the Great, Oliver Stones box office and critical miss: In the last two years I have hardly found time to see any films. One that I love a lot, which was a flop in the States was Alexander the Great. I love that film, not because I know Oliver Stone pretty well but because no matter how this movie was received I think its a very powerful movie done with great imagination. I love it.

title: Special Effectiveness
description: Can a film with no visual arts supervisor win an Oscar for visual effects? A story in Variety points out that Sin City, the hyperstylized new noir flick by Robert Rodriguez, was made without someone, besides the director, directing the effects. Three different special effects shops divided up three different story lines as well. It will be tough to sort out, but the radically new visual vocabulary of Sin City will be tough to ignore.

title: Hardware Sales
description: Is it just the Carpetbagger, or is there something mesmerizing in the plink, plink, plink as one award after another is dropped into the giant maw of Hollywood neediness? Defamer does a hilarious job of teasing apart all the pageantry, speculating that, A shut-out Steven Spielberg spends the day shaking his head and repeating to himself, Assassins dont win Oscars. Sad cowboys win Oscars.

title: Neutered Narrative Syndrome
description: Page Six points out what students of the darkened rooms have known for a while  that if you make a film that is actually about something, you might actually end up offending someone. Steven Spielbergs Munich finds itself in a seemingly endless spanking machine. Varietys critic Todd McCarthy panned the movie and now its editor, Peter Bart, hops in, saying the film takes such pains to avoid advocacy that it neuters its narrative. The Carpetbagger is familiar with Neutered Narrative syndrome and has heard that the treatment is both prolonged and painful. Mr. Bart also pipes up about Mr. Spielbergs decision to stay in the weeds rather than swan for an Oscar, and asks the eternal question of whether it is best to lay low or lobby. The question is not settled, but you get the feeling that Mr. Bart thinks a hail of For Your Consideration ads in Variety is the way to go. So what if all it does is salve your A-List star in a B-List clunker? Its all well spent.

title: Sunscapes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Golden, but Not Prescient
description: The Globes have been generally predictive, but they have been known to board the wrong plane. Last year, they were all about The Aviator, but Oscar ended up cradled in the boxing gloves of Clint Eastwood and co. In the best dramatic actor category, Philip Seymour Hoffman took up his reserved slot and was joined by Heath Ledger from Brokeback; Russell Crowe, a palooka playing a boxer and David Strathairn, who played a twitchy, tortured Edward R. Murrow in Good Night, and Good Luck. The fifth nominee was Terrence Howard, whose role as a down-on-his-luck pimp and wanna-be rapper gave Hustle & Flow plenty of both. After getting big hugs from critics awards on both coasts  and bolstered by his buttoned-down co-starring role in Crash  Mr. Howard is in the thick of it.

title: Caviar's Salty Buzz
A Challenge for Bill OReilly
description: After Sundays column about Bushs arrival at the Pearly Gates, I thought I would be pilloried for heresy, sacrilege and who knows what else. And here and there I was.But so far Ive received fewer outraged letters and letter bombs than I had expected (the device is actually an old one: In 1516, Erasmus wrote of Pope Julius II meeting St. Peter  and being sent away). And I did hear from two prominent evangelicals who said they agreed entirely with what I wrote  they think that its absurd for the focus of religion to be boycotting Target or telling people how to greet each other, particularly when there are more urgent problems like, for example, genocide.As one put it in an email: Every time I see the Fox News Channel talking about the War on Christmas, I find myself thinking , or saying out loud, sometimes yelling, What about the War on Poverty and AIDS !?!  (and I could add genocide, trafficking, etc.) You are right on in your column today and I hope to go public soon in saying so.By the way, my main complaint isnt with Bush. As some readers noted, Bush hasnt waged the Christmas campaign, and in fact the White House Christmas cards angered some conservatives because they didnt use the word Christmas or show a religious scene. My problem with Bush is celebrating Christmas by putting up trees and holding parties, while cutting funds to stop genocide.The coverage of the war on Christmas at Fox is also about hypocrisy, but is more blatant at a time when there are so many more important things to cover. Frankly, Foxs campaign seems to me to be more about ratings than anything. Ranting gets viewers, particularly if its ranting at the usual suspects  like liberals. I just wish that Fox would send a camera crew to Darfur and cover something that genuinely violates tenets of not just Christianity but every religion. And thats genocide.So heres a challenge for Bill OReilly: If you want to do something journalistic, come along with me on my next trip to Darfur. Youll have to leave your studio and deal with people who, if they dont like you, will shoot you in a moment. But youll also have the chance to take a genuinely important and overlooked story and bring it into peoples homes. So come on, Bill. Whatll it be? More ranting from your studio? Or real journalism?

title: To Learn More
description: For readers who want more information about the proposal for reintroducing species to the Americas, or Pleistocene Rewilding, I suggest the website of Josh Donlan, the lead author of the paper in Nature that started the controversy. He also has links to several other essays on the subject:http://www.eeb.cornell.edu/donlan/donlan.html

title: That Hissing Sound
description: Todays tour of the real estate markets where the air is leaking out:Massachusetts: Chart of single family homes listed in MLS compared with the number of price reductions.

title: Realtors: We Are on a Plateau
description: The National Association of Realtors has published its outlook for real estate in 2006. Its looking good. The NAR says 2006 will be the second best year in history in terms of sales activity. The median existing home price should rise 6.1 percent in 2006, compared with a 12.7 percent rise this year.

title: Theyve Got the View
description: Is this a great country or what? If you ever have any doubts read the uplifting saga of Lori Sacco and her boyfriend Chris McCook related in the Surreal Estate column in the San Francisco Chronicle. They have built a real estate empire of vacation homes from Florida to California. The columnist, Carol Lloyd, writes, Whats intriguing about Sacco and McCook is that on a virtual shoestring, theyve made a life from most peoples idle fantasies: living and working in gorgeous waterfront homes.

title: New Ceiling? $5,200 a Square Foot
description: The Plaza Hotel in New York is getting a new skylight in the Palm Court, James Barron reports. Its part of the renovation of the grande dame and its conversion into 181 apartments.The price, you ask? The most expensive apartment in the building is a 6,300-square-foot triplex with a terrace for $32.5 million.  DAMON DARLIN

title: Which City Is Most Overpriced?
description: Analysts at Global Insight and economists at National City Corp. took a look at 299 metropolitan areas and discovered that 65 metropolitan areas, representing 38 percent of the US housing market, are extremely overvalued and at risk of a price correction. They do the Housing Valuation Analysis every quarter. Six areas dropped off the list this time: Essex County and Worcester, Mass., Jackson and Bay City, Mich., Portland, Me., and Charlottesville, Va.Four were added: Honolulu, Orlando, Pensacola and Phoenix.And the No. 1 Overvalued City: Naples, Fla.California wins Miss Congeniality for holding eight of the top ten places.The report is available in PDF form here.  DAMON DARLIN

title: Putting Pressure on Wal-Mart
description: David Gross, Palo Alto, Calif.: I agree with you completely [Big Box Balderdash]. In addition, you could cite Costco, as a comparison, as a competing high-volume, deep-discount retailer which pays its employees well, with good benefits. In addition, its social posture is excellent, and quite unique in corporate America, of which Wal-Mart is yet another sordid example.

title: A Simple Layer Cake
description: Mark Bittman gives some tips on making a simple but delicious chocolate cake.

title: Cyrils Serial Saga, or, Be Careful When You Kidnap the Dog
description: I write a serial novel in the Scottish daily newspaper The Scotsman. This requires me to produce a short chapter  eleven hundred words  every day for the six months for which the serial runs. Then I have a break of six months and I start again. Sisyphus was in a similar position with his rock, although I understand he had shorter holidays between ascents. He also had less fun. The reason why my labours are non-Sisyphean is that I actually enjoy what I do.

Arts, Briefly; Stephanopoulos Promoted
description: George Stephanopoulos, below, the Clinton White House senior adviser whose glamorous insider aura and good looks helped make him a television personality, has been named the new chief Washington correspondent for ABC News. Mr. Stephanopoulos, 44, an almost decade-long veteran of the network, will continue as host of "This Week," the Sunday morning talk show. In announcing his expanded duties on Monday, the president of ABC News, David Westin, cited Mr. Stephanopoulos's "terrific reporting, keen insight and outstanding sources." Mr. Stephanopoulos, who has been the host of "This Week" since 2002, is to start his new job at the beginning of 2006. "This will be even more intense reporting on top of analysis," Mr. Stephanopoulos said in a telephone interview yesterday. "This has more aspects of covering a beat." Linda Douglass, ABC's senior congressional correspondent, is leaving at the end of the year to pursue other interests, a spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe Frees South African Spy
description: A South African intelligence agent arrested in Zimbabwe a year ago returned to Johannesburg, saying that his stay in custody there had been difficult but that he had emerged "with all my limbs." The agent, Aubrey Welken, was apparently assigned to gather details of dissent within the government of President Robert G. Mugabe. After his arrest, 15 leading Zimbabwean figures were implicated in supplying political intelligence to South Africa. Zimbabwe released Mr. Welken as a gesture of good will during the holiday season, South African officials said, adding that the spy scandal had not seriously damaged relations between the nations.

description: In the last few decades, the North Atlantic cod fishery has declined precipitously because of overfishing, making cod, once the backbone of the winter catch, a rarity. For cod lovers, though, there is good news. Johnson Seafarms, a company that has invested $38 million in codfish aquaculture off the Shetland Islands in northern Scotland, has started exporting its fish to the United States.

title: Invisible New Yorkers
description: Kacike Ren Cibanakn, 64, helps to affirm the identity of his people, the Taino, the indigenous Indiansof the Caribbean. His interest was kindled in 1988, at an American Indian powwow at a Manhattan YMCA.His journal entry translates as: "Taino that's what I am in my soul spirit and in life. They felled a tree.They could not yank the roots, the ones that are now sprouting!" His story can be heard at nytimes.com/nyregion. LENS

title: Arts, Briefly; More Surgery for Maria Friedman
description: Maria Friedman, right, the star of "The Woman in White," the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical at the Marquis Theater, had surgery on Monday as part of continuing treatment for cancer. Sonia Friedman, one of the show's producers and the star's sister, said the surgery, which did not require hospitalization, would force Ms. Friedman, 45, to miss several performances of the show this week. "It was quick, simple and very successful," said Sonia Friedman of the surgery, which removed cancerous cells from her sister's chest. "The Woman in White" opened on Nov. 17, just 10 days after the cancer was diagnosed and just a week after an initial surgery to remove a lump in Ms. Friedman's left breast.

title: Hola, Seora Crocker
description: Holidays mean tradition. And now, Betty Crocker cookbooks has published "Cocina Betty Crocker: Favorite American Recipes in Spanish and English" (Wiley Paperback, $19.95), which is filled with recipes printed side by side in Spanish and English.

title: Oslo firm goes mobile in battle of browsers

Who Can Grace Lee Be? Personalities Behind a Name
description: Are we imprisoned by our names? In her small, witty autobiographical documentary, "The Grace Lee Project," a Korean-American filmmaker named Grace Lee, born in Columbia, Mo., and living in Los Angeles, explores the personal and social ramifications of a name she finds oppressive. All her life, Ms. Lee says at the beginning of the film, she has felt pressure to live up to the qualities that many of the people randomly interviewed in the documentary associate with a name that conjures the kind of precocious high achiever who enters Harvard at 16.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Infection Connected To Religious Rite
description: City health officials said yesterday that they had identified two new cases in which infants were infected with herpes this year during a circumcision ritual practiced by some Orthodox Jews. During the circumcision, the practitioner, or mohel, sucks the blood from the circumcision wound to clean it. Since 1988, health officials have identified at least five infants believed to have been infected during such procedures by Type 1 herpes, commonly carried by adults. One baby died and another may have suffered brain damage, health officials said. Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the commissioner of health and mental hygiene, disclosed the new cases yesterday in an open letter to Orthodox Jews in which he called upon parents to consider other religiously viable options, including using a tube or sponge. But he did not ban the practice. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Impeached President Cleared
description: The Supreme Court cleared former President Rolandas Paksas of disclosing state secrets to a campaign contributor and adviser, Yuri Borisov, a Lithuanian-Russian businessman suspected of links to Russian organized crime. Mr. Paksas was impeached by Parliament last year, less than 14 months after he took office, accused of violating his oath of office. He has vigorously defended himself, saying he is a victim of political revenge.

title: Darcy, You Big Ape!
description: Finding the perfect date movie can be a problem. She wants a period romance, like APride & Prejudice.A He wants an action movie like AKing Kong.A Thank heaven, then for The Underfinanced Production Company, whose unique derivative productions manage to provide the best of both worlds.

title: Redistricting Tom DeLay
description: The Supreme Court agreed this week to review Texas' 2003 Congressional redistricting, which added five Republicans to the state's delegation. The plan, engineered by the former House majority leader Tom DeLay, is rightly being challenged as partisan and discriminatory against minority voters. It is encouraging that the court has decided to step in.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Man Arrested In Killing Of Family
description: A Fort Wayne man was charged in the killings of his wife and three children, who were found dead in their home. The suspect, Simon Rios, 33, was charged with four preliminary counts of murder and will have a hearing today. The deaths appeared to be related to a family dispute, said Robin Thompson, a police spokeswoman. Ms. Thompson said the police responded to a 911 call from a man in the house where the victims were found. The police would not identify the victims, and the coroner has not ruled on a cause of death. But Adolfo Puebla, a family friend and godfather of one of the children, identified the victims as Ana Casas, 27, and the couple's three daughters, ages 10, 4 and 1.

For many of the officers, it was their second funeral for a slain comrade in just eight days. They had packed a Brooklyn church last Tuesday to remember Officer Dillon Stewart, who was fatally shot while pursuing a driver who ran a red light on Nov. 28.

title: European Court to Rule on G.E. Merger Appeal
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13 - The latest chapter in Europe's biggest merger case, the quashed $42 billion deal between General Electric and Honeywell International, will be decided Wednesday as a court rules on the companies' appeal.With the takeover now moot, and after a string of measures that addressed harsh criticism of the European Commission's decisions on mergers since then, the court decision may be little more than a case study, competition lawyers here said Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILES, PHILIP
description: MILES--Philip. Love forever to Philip Miles, adoring husband of Estelle, incredible father, outrageous grandfather, dearest friend to so many. One of the greatest, dynamic press agents defining an era all but gone. From big bands (Artie Shaw, and many others) to '40's movies (MGM) to the heydays of Restaurant Associates in the '50s and Loews Hotels in the '60s. Died comfortably but without a vodka martini, near his home in Monroe Township, NJ on Tuesday, December 13. Missed by his children Seymour and Meredith, grandchildren Richard, Audrey, Anna and Rose and legions of his extended family who he cherished, and took in as his own. Services to be held on Thursday 11 A.M. at A.S. Cole, Cranbury, NJ.

World Business Briefing | Europe: European Panel Moves Against Italy
description: The European Commission began a legal procedure against Italy yesterday for obstructing takeovers of domestic banks by foreign financial institutions. The first action will be a letter to the Italian government giving it two months to explain its actions. If the explananation is not judged satisfactory, a case could be brought before the European Court of Justice. A spokesman could not confirm whether the case would focus on both of this year's foreign bank takeover bids in Italy, or just one. The governor of the Bank of Italy, Antonio Fazio, has been under scrutiny by European officials since he appeared to favor Italian banks over foreign banks in two takeover bids this year. The Bank of Italy regulates Italy's banks.

title: A Look at Tomorrow in New Orleans Before the Flood
description: There may be a story hidden amid the attractive bits and pieces that make up the film "Happy Here and Now," but goodness knows, I can't find it. Set in New Orleans, this collection of loosely connected set pieces was written and directed by Michael Almereyda, who is perhaps best known for his 2000 iteration of "Hamlet," an inspired reconsideration of the classic text in which the moody Dane poses his famous question while strolling the aisles of a video store. That scene suggests Mr. Almereyda has a conflicted relationship with mainstream narrative; in both "Hamlet" and films like "Nadja," that conflict greatly works to the director's dreamy advantage. Alas, here it does not.

He is Robert Schulz, not Schultz. The date of the S.& P.'s downgrade of G.M.'s credit rating to below-investment-grade was also misstated. It was May 5, not May 9.

title: Post-Soviet Voting, and Dogging the Watchdogs
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13 - Early this year, as President Bush began his new term, he declared a vision with allure for many people living within the stunted democracies or autocratic governments in the former Soviet Union. "The policy of the United States," Mr. Bush said, "is to seek and support the growth of democratic movements and institutions in every nation and culture, with the ultimate goal of ending tyranny in our world."

title: Prosecutors in DeLay Case Look Into Ties With Lobbyist
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - Texas prosecutors in the criminal case against Representative Tom DeLay revealed in subpoenas made public Tuesday that they were investigating ties between Mr. DeLay and a lobbyist who is at the center of a bribery scandal that prompted another House Republican to resign from Congress last month.

title: Corzine Sees State Deficit of $6 Billion
description: ISELIN, N.J., Dec. 13 - First, there was the promise. Now, there is the price tag.

title: Bank chief in Italyfaces fresh calls to quit
Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the planned expansion of nuclear power in Finland misstated the business of a large Finnish industrial company that supports the expansion and is one of the country's biggest users of energy. The company, Outokumpu, is a leading producer of stainless steel, not steel in general.

title: E.P.A. to Clean Apartments Despite Objections to Plan
description: Despite being rejected by residents, denounced by members of Congress and disowned by the panel of experts that was supposed to shape it, the plan by the federal Environmental Protection Agency to test and clean a limited number of Manhattan apartments for World Trade Center dust will go forward early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATOWITZ, LEONARD M.
description: KATOWITZ--Leonard M., of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Rose, devoted father of Miriam Katowitz (Arthur Radin), Sara Katowitz and David Katowitz (Linda Lendman), adored grandfather and great grandfather. Services at Agudath Achim Cemetery, W. Bangs Ave. Neptune, N.J. Wednesday noon. Call 1-800-938-6372 for info.

title: Political Bargaining Likely to Follow a Split Vote in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 13 - Tens of thousands of American and Iraqi troops fanned out across the country today to prepare for Thursday's parliamentary elections, while Iraqi leaders predicted that the vote would split almost evenly between secular and Islamist parties and usher in a period of protracted political maneuvering.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Federal Reserve Raises Rates Again And Says Its Work Is Not Finished As expected, the Fed raised the benchmark federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 4.25 percent from 4 percent, its 13th consecutive increase. The bank also dampened hopes that it was near the end of its campaign to tighten its monetary policy, saying its work was not finished. [Page C1.]

title: It's Star Wars on Satellite Radio
description: Bob Dylan shocked his fans 40 years ago by embracing the electric guitar. Now he's stunning a few more by embracing another technological innovation: satellite radio.

title: Her Film Project Happens to Be Her Project
description: Selena M. Blake lived at Queensbridge Houses during the many years when the gunfire of drug dealers crackled through the night and confirmed the public's view of the projects as a place of mayhem and menace.

title: Corrections
description: The "Movie Box Office" listing in the Most Wanted chart in Business Day on Monday misstated the weekend estimate for the film "Chronicles of Narnia." It was $67.1 million, not $67.7 million.

title: Comparing Cameras Under $300
description: A list of features, prices and performance for 12 cameras.

title: Has Iraq helped America's energy security?
U.S. Ranks Sixth Among Countries Jailing Journalists, Report Says
description: The United States has tied with Myanmar, the former Burma, for sixth place among countries that are holding the most journalists behind bars, according to a new report by the Committee to Protect Journalists.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the fatal shooting of a New York police officer gave an erroneous identification in some copies for the pistol he was carrying. It was a Kahr semiautomatic, not a KHR. A related article in some copies about Lillo Brancato Jr., one of the two suspects in the shooting, misstated the name of a newspaper that interviewed him about his role in "Falcone," a CBS television series. It is The Times Leader of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., not the Wilkes Barre Time Leader.

title: Pfizer to Finance $100 Million Safety Study of Celebrex
description: Pfizer, the pharmaceutical giant, is betting big on the safety of its cox-2 painkiller, Celebrex.

Buyer: Michael Leone Seller: Mario Canzoneri Broker: Joseph Sitt, Massey Knakal Realty Services

Paid Notice: Memorials   STEINBERG, RICHARD
description: STEINBERG--Richard. 12/14/18 - 1/22/01. Wish I were sitting here writing your birthday poem right now. Miss your wonderful smile, terrible jokes and incredible warmth. Love you always Dad. Vicki

title: A Sendup of the White House and All of the President's Men
description: For those who shake with blinding fury every time George W. Bush makes a speech, a reviewer's complaint about the artistic and intellectual deficiencies of "Fear Itself: Secrets of the White House," the latest cartoonish parody of the members of the current administration, might be like nit-picking about character development in a pornographic film. It's beside the point.

title: Transit Negotiations
description: To the Editor:

title: Can a Hard-Goods Executive Rescue Havas?
description: SURESNES, France - WHEN the French investor Vincent Bollor won a showdown for effective control of Havas, the troubled French advertising company, he tried to calm worried investors and employees by insisting he was not Darth Vader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLETCHER, HELEN LAMB ''LAMB'' AND ''LAMBIE''
description: FLETCHER -- Helen Lamb "Lamb" and "Lambie". Widow of David W. Fletcher. Born May 8, 1927 in New York City. Died December 9 on St. Croix. She was the daughter of Dr. & Mrs. Albert R. Lamb.

title: Text of Fed Statement on Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to raise its benchmark interest rates a quarter-point:

title: Two Utilities Said to Hold Merger Talks
description: The parent of Florida Power and Light is in advanced talks to acquire the Constellation Energy Group for more than $11 billion, according to people briefed on the negotiations. A deal would create a utility behemoth with operations all along the East Coast, from Maine to Florida.

title: Among the Empanadas, an Elvis Sighting
description: EMPANADAS are many things to many people. They are a savory-sweet knife-and-fork food in Bolivia and a corn-flour-crusted snack in Venezuela. In Chile, empanadas are often stuffed with seafood, which would be an unlikely filling at an empanaderia in Argentina, the country most Americans associate them with.

title: People: Rolling Stones, Kim Basinger, John Updike
Lady Bears Grow by Leaps and Bounds
description: When Kim Mulkey-Robertson arrived in Waco, Tex., to take over a Baylor women's basketball team that had won only seven games the previous season, she wanted to choose a mantra that was practical and to set goals that were attainable. She decided "baby steps" was a sensible way to measure the progress of a down-and-out program, as well as that of a first-year head coach.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Maryland: 3 Convicted In Firebombing
description: A federal jury convicted three Baltimore men of firebombing the home of a neighborhood activist who repeatedly reported drug dealing. Jurors found the three men guilty of witness tampering and attempted murder in the Jan. 15 firebombing of the North Baltimore home of the activist, Edna McAbier, who had been president of the Harwood Community Association. Ms. McAbier was not injured, and the Molotov cocktails hurled at her house did little damage, but she moved out soon after the firebombing. The men convicted -- Nakie Harris, 30; Richard Royal, 21; and Terrence Smith, 24 -- each face at least 40 years in prison.

title: Taking On Crime Aboard Cruise Ships
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - Five months after a Connecticut man disappeared from a cruise ship while on his honeymoon, a congressman implored federal law enforcement and Coast Guard officials to determine whether the cruise industry has been lax in reporting and investigating crime at sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALD, FANNI
description: WALD--Fanni. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the mother of our member, Clarissa Kirschenbaum. May her entire family be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Joseph S. Kaplan, President Paulette Papilsky, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWIEBERT, ERNEST G.
description: SCHWIEBERT -- Ernest G. The American Museum of Fly Fishing mourns the passing of Ernest G. Schwiebert. Ernie was a remarkable friend, a staunch supporter and a respected trustee of our institution since its inception in 1968. There can be no doubt that the formation, development and healthy growth of our institution has been greatly shaped and guided under his careful watch. We will deeply miss his eloquence, counsel and companionship. We express our condolences to his wife Sara and son Erik. Robert G. Scott, Chairman Board of Trustees The American Museum of Fly Fishing Manchester, Vermont

title: News Analysis: In Bush victory plan, some hurdles
Stealing From the Poor to Care for the Rich
description: HEATHROW, Fla. - FOR nearly 30 years I was chief of medicine and director of medical education at a Catholic hospital in a small Pennsylvania town. Because American-trained doctors usually preferred university hospitals or metropolitan areas, foreign medical graduates, mainly from Asia, filled all of the residency slots at our hospital, and we were happy to have them.

title: A Long-Track Speedskater Embraces a New Turn
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Dec. 13 - Of all the Olympic hopefuls who have trekked to this frigid city at the edge of nowhere for short-track speedskating's Olympic trials, Shani Davis cuts a unique figure.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Public Inquiry Into July Bombings
description: The government said it did not plan a public inquiry into the London terrorist bombings similar to the one by the commission that investigated the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in the United States. Four bombers killed 52 people in attacks on three subway trains and a double-decker bus on July 7. Muslim organizations and opposition politicians have called for a full public inquiry, but the Home Office said it was considering what details it might release to other inquiries to be held by lawmakers.

title: Doping: U.S. sprinters are given 2-year bans
News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-23

title: Democrat Returning Donations From Abramoff's Tribal Clients
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - The ranking Democrat on the Senate committee investigating the Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff announced on Tuesday that he was returning $67,000 in political contributions from Mr. Abramoff's former partners and Indian tribe clients.

title: In cancer battle, U.S. to crack genome codes
Looking Back, Tenderly, at a Career With the Blues
description: Abbey Lincoln's great folk-jazz song "Throw It Away" revolves around the phrase "You can never lose a thing if it belongs to you." Those words go a long way toward describing the spirit conveyed by Baby Jane Dexter, the blues-oriented cabaret singer who performs the song in her new show, "Time Travels," at Helen's.

title: Ohno (Despite Collision) and Kim Hold Lead at Short-Track Trials
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Dec. 13 - Apolo Ohno survived a collision in the finals of a 500-meter race and Hyo Jung Kim dominated the women's events at the Olympic trials for short-track speedskating Tuesday night.

title: The Execution Of Tookie Williams
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALSBERG, RICHARD MARC
description: SALSBERG--Richard Marc on December 12, age 60, of Montvale, NJ. Beloved husband of Andi; loving father of Brian, Corey and Jamie; devoted father-in-law of Abbie and Sandy; adored grandfather of Ari; dear brother of Judy. He was a partner at Scarinci & Hollenbeck, a Lyndhurst based law firm. Services are today, 1:30pm at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ. Memorial donations to American Brain Tumor Association. (www.abta.org)

title: Bright Spot on Gulf as Casinos Rush to Rebuild
description: BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 9 - Anyone visiting this town in the days after Hurricane Katrina might reasonably have concluded that it would be a long while before slot machines were again ringing their incessant chimes. The storm destroyed 9 of 10 floating casinos in Biloxi, and the tenth suffered significant damage.

title: House Approves Renewal of Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - Renewal of the anti-terrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act was approved overwhelmingly by the House of Representatives today, but the measure's prospects in the Senate remained uncertain.

title: Robert Newmyer, 49, a Producer of 'sex, lies and videotape,' Dies
description: Robert F. Newmyer, a prominent independent-film producer whose credits include "sex, lies and videotape" and the "Santa Clause" movies, died on Monday while on location in Toronto. He was 49 and had homes in Los Angeles and Telluride, Colo.

title: Doughnuts That Left Yeast Behind
description: Mark Isreal, who owns the Doughnut Plant on the Lower East Side, made his name with yeast-raised doughnuts slathered with unusual glazes. He has also spent the last five years developing cake doughnuts. It was not time wasted. They are superb, especially the one dipped in bittersweet orange glaze, which would glorify a Hanukkah celebration. The cinnamon-sugar, center, has an alluring crunch, and his chocolate doughnut with chocolate glaze hints of poundcake. They are $1.50 each at 379 Grand Street (Essex Street), (212) 505-3700.

title: At Jakarta festival, tales of hardship
TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: Early Maya Mural Found Archaeologists in Guatemala have uncovered a masterpiece of Maya art that tests reveal to date to about 100 B.C., well before the Maya classical period that began after A.D. 250.

title: Fans Don't Let Fans Get Too Rowdy
description: HAMBURG, GERMANY - EVERYBODY braced for trouble four years ago when England and Argentina were drawn to play in the first round of the World Cup. The common wisdom was that a new version of the Falklands-Malvinas war was going to break out in Japan.

title: Poor nations balk at trade proposals
Fed Gives Mixed Sign on Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - After raising interest rates for the 13th time in a row on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve said that its work was not yet finished.

title: Iraq's Most Important Election
description: Tomorrow, Iraqis, who never had a chance to cast a meaningful vote until recently, will be participating in this year's third nationwide election. This vote, for the first full-term Parliament since the fall of Saddam Hussein, is the most important one yet. The outcome will not only determine how governmental power will be apportioned over the next four years, but will also decide the makeup of the special committee that is supposed to rewrite the flawed Constitution. This is perhaps the only chance Iraqis will get to organize a unified, democratic country that can ultimately stand on its own.

title: The Senator Who Cried Wolf
description: Strange things are afoot as Congress presses to end this year's woefully inadequate session by the weekend: coverage of impotence drugs has been restored in a Medicare budget proposal, while an emergency subsidy to help poor people pay their heating bills this winter is getting only anemic financing. But the biggest money issue being haggled over -- the House and Senate dispute over cutting up to $50 billion in spending from assorted vital programs -- is somehow tangled up in the Bush administration's insistence on drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska.

title: Challenging State Shackles on Juveniles
description: Jenny P., a juvenile delinquent being held at a center upstate, trudged into Brooklyn Family Court one morning in September, her wrists and ankles shackled, a restraint belt circling her waist and a metal box restricting her hand movements.

title: Montgomery Is Suspended 2 Years for Steroid Use
description: Tim Montgomery, the American sprinter who held the world record for the 100-meter dash from September 2002 to last June, was suspended yesterday for two years by international sport's highest court.

title: Palestinian Gunmen Storm Election Offices in Gaza and West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 13 - Palestinian gunmen stormed four election offices in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank on Tuesday, adding to the political instability in advance of parliamentary elections planned for next month.

title: Her Son Is Safe Now, but Other Soldiers Remain
description: NEW WINDSOR, N.Y. - THERE'S still a big yellow ribbon on the front door and small yellow bows hanging from bare branches on the red maple out front. Stacked neatly in the frigid garage are cartons of Red Bull and Colgate toothpaste, Yoo-hoos and Milk Duds, white socks and Tampax. She still seems like a tight coil of maternal resolve balancing two currents: a loathing for the war and a mother's protective embrace of the young people fighting it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALLER, ELLIOT
description: FALLER--Elliot. 73 on December 13, 2005. Beloved husband of Barbara and the late Rita Faller. Devoted father of Noel and Jill, Samantha and Scott, Craig and Jennifer. Adoring Poppy of Danielle, Sammy, Toby, Jesse and Cole. Brother and brother-inlaw of Dr. Hugh and Diane Unger, Mona and Arthur Sherman and Shirley Herman. Elliot had a long and distinguished career as a jeweler. He was the rock and patriarch of this family and will never be forgotten. Services Thursday, December 15 at 10 a.m., Boulevard - Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, L.I.

description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Waiter Sentenced To 18 Years For Murder
description: A hotel waiter convicted of killing his wife's lover had made a "selfish, emotional" decision to kill his romantic rival, a judge said yesterday before sentencing the waiter, Elio Cruz, to 18 years to life in prison. Mr. Cruz, 34, was convicted of second-degree murder last month for fatally shooting German Cabrera on a Chelsea subway platform in February. Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan said that Mr. Cabrera, 26, had to some degree provoked Mr. Cruz's anger by taunting him by telephone about the affair. But she said it would have made more sense for Mr. Cruz to be angry with his wife, since "she was the one who was unfaithful." Anemona Hartocollis (NYT)

Lebanon won't die. Freedom won't die."

Say #!%* and Pay $$$, Hartford Tells High School Students
description: HARTFORD - Reprimands did not work. Neither did detentions or suspensions. Frustrated over their inability to stop high school students from cursing aggressively, educators and police officials decided it was time to get tough.

title: New Army Rules May Snarl Talks With McCain on Detainee Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - The Army has approved a new, classified set of interrogation methods that may complicate negotiations over legislation proposed by Senator John McCain to bar cruel and inhumane treatment of detainees in American custody, military officials said Tuesday.

description: On Monday night, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority surprised union leaders by proposing a 27-month contract, with a 3 percent raise in the first 15 months and a second 3 percent raise effective on March 16, 2007. The contract would expire at the end of March 15, 2008.

description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Nathalie Babel Brown, who edited the writings of her father, Isaac Babel, misstated the year "The Complete Works of Isaac Babel" was published by Norton. It was 2002, not 2001.

description: DETROIT, Dec. 13 - First, Robert S. Miller, the chief executive of Delphi, had his turn to capture the public spotlight, looking for deep cuts from unions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, SEYMOUR ''SY''
description: GOLDBERG--Seymour "Sy". Shortly after his 84th birthday. Beloved husband of Micki. Loving father of Jay Goldberg and Michael and Suzy Appelbaum. Adored grandfather of Sydney and Mia. Dear uncle of Stefan and Eileen Gorkin and Mitchell and Sandy Gorkin. Services Wednesday, 10:30am, Platt Memorial Chapels Inc., Cherry Hill, NJ. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery. Contributions to Camp Ramah in the Berkshires, 25 Rockwood Pl., Englewood, NJ 07631.

title: Golden Globe Nods for 'Brokeback' and Art-House Films
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 - Golden Globe voters turned their backs on Hollywood's major studios Tuesday, spreading best drama nominations among small, art-house films including the director Ang Lee's "Brokeback Mountain," about a romance between cowboys; George Clooney's "Good Night, and Good Luck," about the television newsman Edward R. Murrow, and Woody Allen's thriller "Match Point."

title: Dead Man Rising: An Odyssey in Texas
description: As a vision of the American West and the wide country around it, "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" strikes both fresh and familiar chords, most of them pleasingly dissonant. Directed with a steady hand and an eye for eccentric detail by the actor Tommy Lee Jones, who also stars, this western about a Texas ranch foreman trying to bury his Mexican friend is an accounting of those borders that separate rich from poor, men from women, friend from stranger, and as such, is less an act of revisionism than one of reconsideration. As in most westerns, as in John Ford's "Searchers" and Cormac McCarthy's "Crossing," the journey here is as spiritual as it is physical, as much inwardly directed as outward bound.

title: A Baker Rolls With The Technology
description: PASTRY chefs say that cooks with an inborn knack for baking have a "white thumb." I am not one of them, lacking cool hands (for keeping pie crusts flaky) and a cool head (for measuring ingredients scrupulously). Still, I keep at it: the baker's high that comes from an occasional stunning layer cake erases the bitter memories of the collapsed cupcakes and the shrunken tart shells.

title: Free Flow: When rail expansion is crossing the line
How One Suburb's Black Students Gain

title: Six Flags Appoints a Chief as Its Chairman Takes Hold
description: Six Flags, the theme park company at the center of a roller-coaster battle for control, named a new chief executive last night in a move that suggests its new chairman, Daniel M. Snyder, has a firm grip on the company.

title: Protest movement shifts terms of free-trade debate
He's Everywhere in Films, on Duty to Promote Them
description: Some actors so weren't born to dumb down that it can be painful to watch them try. When Ralph Fiennes appeared on "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" in August to promote "The Constant Gardener," a sophisticated thriller about corrupt pharmaceutical companies in Africa, Mr. Leno immediately asked whether he'd held any weird day jobs when he was a struggling actor. Usually effortless on screen, Mr. Fiennes maintained a wide, forced smile as he gamely recounted a brief, unsuccessful moment selling shirts; it may be the only wince-inducing performance he has ever given.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOAS, MARGARET K.
description: BOAS--Margaret K. Of New York City on December 13 at age 104. Loving aunt of Susan Hirschman, beloved grandmother of the Venerable Nicholas Vreeland and Alexander Vreeland. Revered stepmother of Gilbert, Francoise and Jean Pierre Boas, devoted great-grandmother of Diane Reed, Victoria and Olivia. Funeral private.

title: American Co-Author Wants His Name Off Stem Cell Paper
description: After several days of serious accusations about the validity of a prominent article on the cloning of human cells, the senior author, Gerald Schatten of the University of Pittsburgh, has asked for his name to be removed as co-author, the editors of the journal Science said yesterday.

title: Warnings on Transit Strike as Mayor Outlines Plan to Cope
description: With a contract deadline of 12:01 a.m. Friday, representatives of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its largest union met intermittently today to stave off a strike as the agency's top negotiator warned "we are not in a good place" and the city announced a sweeping emergency plan to contend with any walk out.

description: THOUGH Champagne will ennoble just about any hors d'oeuvre at a cocktail party, including foie gras on toast, pigs in blankets or mini-latkes, dessert pairings are more problematic.

title: Time Inc. Lays Off 105, Including Top Executives
description: Time Inc. announced yesterday that it would lay off 105 employees, including several longtime high-ranking publishing executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAGAN, PATRICIA (MRS. WARD S.)
description: HAGAN--Patricia (Mrs. Ward S.). The Board of Governing Trustees, Kevin McKenzie, Rachel Moore, The Dancers and Staff of American Ballet Theatre mourn the passing of friend and long time Board member Patricia Hagan. Having served on the Board since 1980, Patricia will be remembered for her tireless dedication to ABT. Her kind and generous spirit will live on in the beauty of ABT's performances. The ABT family will miss Patricia tremendously.

title: In Its Busy Season, Foie Gras Battles Its Image Problem
description: MUGRON, France - IN a gaggle of about 30 squat ducks on Jol Cabannes's farm, two geese stand out for their erect bodies, long necks and incessant honking.

title: Swiss Re Is Reported to Be Selling Investment Bank
description: LONDON, Dec. 14 - The insurance company Swiss Re has put its research and investment banking subsidiary Fox, Pitt, Kelton on the block, according to one executive who has been briefed on the strategy.

title: The Cake On the Bed
description: WHEN it's my turn to make a dessert for a holiday gathering I head straight for chocolate layer cake. Since I refuse to compromise on ingredients, a certain amount of work is involved, but I streamline the process as much as possible.

title: As a Face Transplant Heals, Flurries of Questions Arise
description: PARIS, Dec. 13 - It was a startling feat of medicine, the world's first partial face transplant.

title: 2 Musicians Facing Order to Surrender Instruments
description: What would be a wrenching moment for any musician has arrived for two members of the Audubon Quartet: the loss of their instruments, casualties of a bitter legal feud with the member they cast out five years ago.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - And just like that, the one promising sign the Nets had going for them of late -- solid play on the road -- went out the window.

title: Blast at New Jersey Apartment Building Kills 3 and Hurts 5
description: BERGENFIELD, N.J., Dec. 13 - Three people were killed, five were injured and at least three others were unaccounted for Tuesday after a thunderous explosion and fire ripped through a three-story apartment building here shortly after 9 a.m.

title: Bitter split roils EU on eve of summit
Invisible New Yorkers: Guido de Gorgey
description: Now he lives on Staten Island, but during the war, Guido de Gorgey lived in Hungary when the Germans were there. Now he's 85. He remembers how his mother used a tragedy to save the life of a Jewish girl, Ann Stricker, who lived next door. Mr. de Gorgey's sister had died in her infancy, but she would have been the same age as Ann, so his mother gave her the sister's identity, and she was saved.

title: Tlcom bids for Telindus

With Rentals Cold, a Shift to Retail
description: GDC Properties of Hawthorne, N.Y., a prominent Westchester real estate company that owns and develops income properties in the Eastern United States, has begun a major shift in its portfolio. It has sold many of its rental apartment complexes and is reinvesting the capital in shopping centers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENSCH, HOMER R.
description: MENSCH--Homer R. Bassist and pedagogue, 91, died at home. He was Chairman of the Bass Department at the Juilliard School, and served on the faculty of the Manhattan and Mannes Schools of Music, Yale, Rutgers, Dalcroze School, Queens College, and Catholic University. Assistant Principal Bass of the Pittsburgh Symphony, with Reiner and Klemperer. Member of NY Philharmonic under Barbirolli, Bernstein, Boulez, and the NBC Symphony under Toscanini, staff member at CBS, played for Eileen Farrell, Ernie Kovacs, Jack Parr, Tonight Show and Ed Sullivan. In 1975 he began playing Principal Bass for Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, NY Chamber Symphony, NY Choral Society, Little Orchestra Society, and NY Pops. He played on recordings of Heifitz, Piatagorsky, Stern. Milstein, Bach Aria Group, Casals Festival Orchestra, Columbia Symphony, and on virtually every commercial recording made in NY. Recorded with Sinatra, Streisand, Paul McCartney and more. Taught 45 students a week including young beginners, conservatory students, and both classical and jazz professionals. Teaching until his death, he was held in highest esteem by all. His wife, the late Constance Mensch, a violinist and teacher, died in 2000. Homer R. Mensch is survived by former students carrying on his traditions and dedicated to his memory. Donations to the Homer and Constance Mensch Scholarship Fund to be created at the following schools: The Juilliard School, Manhattan School of Music, and Mannes College of Music. Service Wednesday, December 14, 3PM, Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel, Madison at 81st.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTH

title: Bush Defends Iraq Strategy on Eve of Parliamentary Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - A day before Iraq's first parliamentary elections, President Bush said today that Americans would have to remain patient and should expect more bloodshed as Iraqis struggled toward stability and democracy.

title: Wikipedia Complaints
description: Is it the end of an era for Wikipedia, the popular Internet encyclopedia?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONOHUE, DONALD STEPHEN
description: DONOHUE--Donald Stephen, December 11, 2005. Beloved husband of Jeanne. Loving father of Tracy and Terence. Cherished grandfather of Kristina, Kylie, Aidan, Grace and Lauren. Caring brother of Mary Clark. Loving uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Wednesday, December 14th, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, December 15th, 10am, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St., NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDOR, GYORGY
description: SANDOR - Gyorgy. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with great sadness the passing of the renowned pianist Gyorgy Sandor on Friday, December 9 in New York at the age of 93. Mr. Sandor was a highly valued member of our Steinway Artist family beginning in 1944; a sixty-one year association of which we are enormously proud. A native of Hungary, Mr. Sandor was a pupil of Bela Bartok and he championed the composer's works throughout his illustrious career, both in performance and in acclaimed recordings. He was a featured artist in Steinway & Sons' Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953, and his devotion to the Steinway piano and to our Company knew no bounds. In addition to his worldwide concert appearances, Mr. Sandor was a celebrated writer and teacher, whose gifted students represent an enduring legacy. He will be deeply missed. To his son Michael and to his family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities.

title: UN meets over series of killings in Lebanon
Lovers of Caviar, Look to the Farm
description: THOSE who want a last legal taste of beluga in the United States still have time, if they have the money. For most caviar lovers, there are plenty of other options. And more than ever, they are farm-raised.

title: City Seeks Stiff Fines for Workers and Transit Union if They Strike
description: With three days to go before a threatened transit shutdown, the Bloomberg administration stepped into the middle of the fray yesterday, asking a judge to fine the transit workers' union $1 million and each striker $25,000 on the first day of a strike and to double the fines successively each day after that.

title: Procter & Gamble Predicts Higher Earnings
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the consumer goods maker, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings would rise more than forecast on higher sales and lower-than-anticipated costs from its acquisition of the Gillette Company.

title: Morton Birnbaum, 79, Champion of Mentally Ill, Dies
description: Dr. Morton Birnbaum, a physician, lawyer and mental health advocate who worked to establish and expand rights for mentally ill patients, died on Nov. 26 at Cabrini Medical Center in New York. He was 79 and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: S.E.C. Decides Not to Act Against Taser on Safety Statements
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided not to take action against Taser International in connection with statements about the safety of its electric stun pistols, the company said yesterday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Running Over the Reruns
description: On Monday, the Atlanta Falcons, a team that still has playoff hopes, beat the woeful New Orleans Saints, a team that does not. The "Monday Night Football" broadcast of the game defeated the rerun-heavy schedule on the other networks. In Nielsen's estimates, ABC was No. 1 in both total viewers and adults 18 to 49. But football will not be a ratings boon to ABC's primetime schedule for much longer. On Dec. 26, it will broadcast the final edition of the Monday sports institution, which will move to ESPN, the network's Disney sibling, next season. This Monday, CBS's all-repeat schedule placed second in total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. On NBC, a new special, "Elton John: Red Piano," drew 8.34 million viewers at 8 p.m., and the network finished the night in third place, as it usually does on Mondays. And for those interested in the "Arrested Development" death watch, that Fox comedy delivered an audience 3.95 million, and was fifth in its time period, ahead of only "One on One" on UPN.

title: Another Moment of Acclaim for a Gifted Young Cellist
description: At only 26, Efe Baltacigil is already the associate principal cellist of the Philadelphia Orchestra. This gifted Turkish artist won acclaim in February when a bad snowstorm in Philadelphia prevented most members of the orchestra from getting to the concert hall in time for a performance. With just 10 minutes to rehearse, Mr. Baltacigil and the scheduled soloist, the pianist Emanuel Ax, performed Beethoven's Cello Sonata No. 1 as a gesture to the hardy audience members who showed up.

title: Something New: A 4-Year Degree at a 2-Year College
description: When Annette Torna, a Miami homemaker, chose to return to college to become a teacher, she initially planned to get her two-year degree at Miami-Dade Community College and then transfer to a four-year institution for her bachelor's degree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILE, JULIUS
description: WILE--Julius. Wine expert and educator, on December 12, 2005 at home in Scarsdale, NY. Loving husband of the late Ruth Wile. Beloved father of Barbara Wile Schwarz and Andrew Wile, and fatherin-law of Paul Schwarz, Kathleen Wile and Regina Burg. Devoted grandfather of Susan Schwarz, Stephen Schwarz and wife Kristen Couse, and Max Julius Wile. Adoring great grandfather of Wile Taylor Schwarz-Couse. Donations to the Ruth & Julius Wile Endowed Scholarship Fund of the Culinary Institute of America, Hyde Park, NY, or to White Plains Hospital Center. Services at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains Friday, December 16, 11am

title: Study backs allegations about CIA
Comics tell how Pryor risked all for the show
Recalling an Early Act of Terrorism
description: To this day, it remains unknown who threw the bomb at the police advancing on a workers' rally in Haymarket Square in Chicago in 1886, or how many of the seven policemen who died fell to police bullets. Eight anarchists were tried, and four were hanged, including the newspaper editor Albert Parsons, who with his wife, Lucy, a former slave, are at the center of Zayd Dohrn's new play, "Haymarket."

title: Enron's Chief Offers His Case
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 13 - The well known and the powerful often appear before the Houston Forum, one of the city's elite spots for speakers. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, gave a recent talk, as did Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary.

title: Tough Border Security Bill Nears Passage in the House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - The Republican-controlled House is poised to pass one of the toughest border security measures in more than a decade, cracking down on illegal immigrants and their employers and defying President Bush's call for a comprehensive bill that would grant millions of illegal immigrants already in the United States a right to work here temporarily.

title: Latest Assassination and Funeral Heighten Anxiety in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 13 - The billboard-size digital counter said 303 days, as in 303 days since Rafik Hariri was assassinated, or 303 days since Lebanon entered the latest deadly phase of its modern history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALLACE, EMMETT
description: WALLACE - Emmett. My childhood neighbor, playmate, and lifelong friend. Your generous, considerate spirit, and good humor will be remembered with affection by all who knew you. Tobias J. Bermant

title: Hewlett Chief Tells Wall St. Efficiency Drive Is Still On
description: In his first appearance before Wall Street analysts yesterday, Mark V. Hurd, who took over eight months ago as the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, delivered a clear message: The company's business strategy has not yet changed, but the management style and focus certainly have.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, JEROME B.
description: GROSS--Jerome B. Beloved husband of Barbara-Ruth Thackston Gross. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., Thursday, December 15th, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. with service Friday 9:30 AM.

title: Harold Newman, 84, Who Led Public Employees Board, Dies
description: Harold Raymond Newman, former chairman of Public Employment Relations Board of New York State and a behind-the-scenes catalyst in many labor negotiations with public employees, died on Nov. 25 in West Palm Beach, Fla. A resident of Lake Worth, Fla., he was 84 and formerly lived in Albany.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the planned expansion of nuclear power in Finland misstated the business of a large Finnish industrial company that supports the expansion and is one of the country's biggest users of energy. The company, Outokumpu, is a leading producer of stainless steel, not steel in general. (Go to Article)

title: Doughnuts That Left Yeast Behind
description: Mark Isreal, who owns the Doughnut Plant on the Lower East Side, made his name with yeast-raised doughnuts slathered with unusual glazes. He has also spent the last five years developing cake doughnuts. It was not time wasted. They are superb, especially the one dipped in bittersweet orange glaze, left above, which would glorify a Hanukkah celebration. The cinnamon-sugar, center, has an alluring crunch, and his chocolate doughnut with chocolate glaze hints of poundcake. They are $1.50 each at 379 Grand Street (Essex Street), (212) 505-3700. FOOD STUFF

title: The EU budget face-off: Netherlands
Berlusconi gets boost on voting
Pirro's Persistence Is Causing Friction in the State Republican Party
description: Jeanine F. Pirro chalks up her success as Westchester County district attorney to a certain mindset: analyzing her cases and options, consulting with her most trusted advisers and then following her gut and standing by tough decisions, come what may.

title: E.P.A. Deals $16.5 Million Penalty to DuPont
description: Washington, Dec. 14 - The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had agreed to a $16.5 million settlement with the chemical giant DuPont regarding accusations that the company had concealed information about the dangers of a chemical used to make Teflon.

title: Canadian Leader Angers U.S. Envoy
description: TORONTO, Dec. 13 - The American ambassador, David H. Wilkins, interjected himself into the Canadian national elections on Tuesday with an implicit but strong warning to Prime Minister Paul Martin to stop attacking the United States while on the campaign trail.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Legislators Increase Property Tax
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators approved a $1.54 billion budget for 2006 yesterday, raising property taxes by 3.9 percent. The board trimmed back the proposed 4.5 percent tax increase first proposed by Andrew J. Spano, the county executive. Mr. Spano's spokesman said he would sign the budget later this week. Most of the tax increase, 3 percent, will be used to finance the struggling Westchester Medical Center, a public benefit corporation not operated by the county. The board was able to lower the tax increase by raising revenue projections. The board also set aside money to study the Department of Social Services' child welfare case management system, which has come under attack in recent months. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Wilson Foundation Names Chief
description: Arthur E. Levine, president of Teachers College at Columbia University, will become president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation in Princeton, N.J., next summer, the foundation announced yesterday.

title: Vodafone to Buy Turkish Phone Company
description: LONDON, Dec. 13 - Vodafone agreed Tuesday to buy the Turkish mobile operator Telsim for $4.55 billion, making an expensive bet that it can fix the company and that Turkey's youthful population will rapidly embrace the use of cellphones.

title: Aromas Return to Le Cirque Space
description: ABOUT a year ago Le Cirque 2000 moved out of the New York Palace Hotel and left one of the most elaborate and glamorous restaurant locations in the city without a tenant. But tomorrow Gilt, the hotel's new restaurant, will open its doors, serving food by Paul Liebrandt, an inventive young chef.

description: To the Editor:

title: A New Balducci's, Back Downtown
description: The grand new Balducci's in the 1897 landmark bank building at 81 Eighth Avenue (14th Street), opens tomorrow. Produce, prepared foods, baked goods, fresh and smoked seafood, meat, charcuterie and groceries fill the more than 10,000 square feet.

title: Los Angeles Times Is Ending Its National Edition Next Week
description: After a 13-year run, The Los Angeles Times is shutting its national edition next week, officials said yesterday.

description: For Rangers Coach Tom Renney, last night's game against the Canucks was not a grudge match between Dominic Moore and Vancouver's Todd Bertuzzi.

War Changes the Borders, and Even Beds Are Divided
description: Explosions of artillery rattle the walls at the opening and the close of "The Other Side," the new play by Ariel Dorfman that opened last night on City Center's Stage I, courtesy of Manhattan Theater Club. Violent warfare is roiling the countryside where an old couple, played by the redoubtable Rosemary Harris and John Cullum, toil in solitude, burying the dead and awaiting the balm of a long-promised peace.

title: Execution Ignites New Fire in Death Penalty Debate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 - As plans were under way to hold a large public funeral for Stanley Tookie Williams, the former gangster executed by lethal injection early Tuesday morning, and scatter his ashes in South Africa, his death was stirring fresh passion on both sides of the debate over capital punishment in California.

title: When It's Mahler, a Single Work Can More Than Fill an Evening
description: The Juilliard School's student ensembles perform off campus with fair regularity, but with the school celebrating its centenary this season, the programs are -- or at least seem -- grander, and the attention they draw is more sharply focused. When James Conlon led the Juilliard Orchestra and Choral Union, augmented by the Brooklyn Youth Chorus, in Mahler's enormous Symphony No. 3 on Sunday afternoon, Carnegie Hall was well packed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZACCOR, EUGENE E.
description: ZACCOR--Eugene E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eugene E. Zaccor, associated with The Times from June 1956 until February 1986.

title: A Comic Walks Into a TV Studio, and He Turns to Another Comic...
description: You might say that "Sit Down Comedy With David Steinberg," which begins a six-episode run tonight on TV Land, is to comedians what "Inside the Actors Studio" is to actors.

title: Report Cites City Mistakes in the Deaths of 2 Children
description: In one case, a 16-month-old boy drowned in a bathtub while his mother listened to CD's in another room. In another case, a 7-year-old girl died after her father kneed her in the stomach and beat her with a belt over two days. In both cases, the city's child welfare agency had been involved with the family and had removed the children from their homes, but eventually allowed them to return.

title: U.N. Considers Widening Inquiry Into Lebanese Slaying
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 14 - The Security Council met today on a resolution extending the term of the United Nations investigation into the February assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Harari and expanding its scope to include other recent politically motivated killings.

title: On the Eve of Decision in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: No Sign of Progress on Farm Issue as World Trade Meeting Opens
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 13 - With protesters chanting slogans outside, scuffling with police and even jumping into the harbor, the World Trade Organization ministerial conference began here on Tuesday with ministers quickly starting talks on agriculture and assistance to the world's poorest countries.

title: Curator spotlights Spain's unique architecture
U.S. airlines missing out on upswing
OFF THE MENU
description: TELEPAN -- Bill Telepan, above, who earned three stars from The New York Times while he was the executive chef of Judson Grill, which closed last year, is opening his own restaurant in an Upper West Side town house on Friday. The design, by Larry Bogdanow, suggests the 1960's and 70's, with avocado walls and simple modern furnishings. There are four stone fireplaces. Mr. Telepan will feature locally produced ingredients in dishes like house-smoked brook trout, roasted cauliflower with winter greens and heritage-pork cassoulet. The restaurant will be open every day for dinner and plans to serve lunch beginning in late January: 72 West 69th Street, (212) 580-4300.

title: GE and Honeywell lose merger appeal
Earliest Known Maya Painting Found
description: Archaeologists reported yesterday that they had uncovered a masterpiece of Maya art showing a surprisingly early flowering of the civilization, well before the classical period that began after A.D. 250.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidence Soars
description: Investor confidence in Germany, Europe's biggest economy, rose the most in more than 12 years on signs that the export-led expansion was accelerating. A gauge of institutional and analyst expectations increased to 61.6, the highest since February 2004, from 38.7 in November, the ZEW Center for European Economic Research said yesterday in Mannheim. That was the biggest increase since July 1993. Sales by German companies like BMW are getting a lift as a weaker euro increases demand for products abroad, encouraging investment at home.

title: U.S. sanctions on Iran seen as putting airline passengers at risk
Slump? Real Estate Tax Revenue Keeps Rising
description: Real estate values in New York have risen so much that a modest decline in the market will not seriously disrupt the stream of revenue from property-transaction taxes that has helped balance the city's budget in recent years, according to a new report by independent analysts.

title: To Halt Abuses, U.S. Will Inspect Jails Run by Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 13 - American military officers will inspect hundreds of detention centers and embed with Iraqi police commando units and other Interior Ministry forces to try to halt widespread abuses uncovered by raids on two Iraqi-run detention centers in Baghdad in the last month, the American ambassador pledged Tuesday.

title: Pope Condemns Both Terror and Violations of Geneva Pact
description: VATICAN CITY, Dec. 13 - Pope Benedict XVI on Tuesday condemned terrorism, nuclear arms and, apparently in a reference to allegations that the United States has tortured terror suspects, lack of respect for international law.

title: Get Lost
description: LIKE many American males, I tend to be pro-gadget. I like my cellphone (Motorola Razr) and Bluetooth headset, my iPod (third generation, 15 gigabytes), my Palm device (cool thing with a full keyboard called a Dana). I scan for the latest versions of computer software and adopt them readily. But despite a barrage of pre-Christmas entreaties by advertisers, what I do not want is a portable global positioning system.

title: For Perfect Cookies, Add a Big Dollop Of Blithe Abandon
description: WHEN it comes to improvising in the kitchen, pastry chefs are adamant. Winging it may be fine when making savory dishes, but for baking, they insist: follow the recipe exactly and do not stray. Substituting honey for granulated sugar could make your meringues weep and your gingerbread houses come crashing down.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brookyln: Man Arraigned In Killing Of Officer
description: The man accused of killing a police officer at a traffic stop on Nov. 28 pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court. The man, Allan Cameron, was arraigned on charges of first-degree murder in the shooting of Officer Dillon Stewart and attempted murder in the shooting of an off-duty officer, Wiener Philippe. He was ordered held without bail. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Brown Stops Juggling and Settles on a Lineup
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 13 - Larry Brown has tinkered and tweaked, pushed and prodded and given 16 players a chance to make the Knicks something better than substandard. The result has been six victories in 20 games, so Brown is preparing a new template.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Legalized gaming is going to be what saves us."

title: Amid Recovery Efforts, a Rift Threatens to Grow
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10 - In a neighborhood that had not flooded, near orderly streets of dolled-up antebellum homes that now seem almost a fantasyland, a construction crew was chewing up a park the other day to install trailers for the legions of homeless people. And then abruptly, work halted.

title: The State of Iraq: An Update
description: DESPITE President Bush's articulation of a new strategy for victory in Iraq, the American debate remains polarized. An increasing number of critics argue that the war is already lost and that we may as well withdraw, while others claim we are clearly headed to victory, and Americans would know that if only the press would stop emphasizing the negative.

description: CARLSON -- Eileen Evers, Esq., 79, of Carefree, AZ passed away December 11, 2005. Mrs. Carlson was retired chief legal counsel for the Securities & Exchange Commission, the Legal Aid Society of New York and also served as CEO of the Arthur J. Evers Corporation. She was a member of Our Lady of Joy Catholic Church in Carefree and the Circumnavigators Club. Her husband Robert preceded her in death in January of 2005. Memorial Services will be held at 10:00 AM, Saturday, December 17, 2005 at Our Lady of Joy Catholic Church, 36811 N. Pima Road, Carefree, AZ. For info. Messinger Pinnacle Peak Mortuary.
