Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about Chile's presidential election reversed the names in some copies for the candidates shown in the top and middle photographs. The woman was Michelle Bachelet and the man was Sebastin Piera.

title: Sunni Bastion Now Turning to Ballot Box
description: TIKRIT, Iraq, Dec. 13 - Along the main boulevard here in Saddam Hussein's hometown, hundreds of campaign posters have flowered where insurgents once tossed homemade bombs at American troops.

title: Romney Won't Seek 2nd Term in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14 - Governor Mitt Romney of Massachusetts said today that he would not seek a second term as governor next year, an announcement widely interpreted to mean that he will run for president in 2008.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIND, EDNA (NEE LUNDAHL)
description: LIND--Edna (nee Lundahl). On December 11, 2005. Formerly of Lyric Opera and Metropolitan Opera. Known as Aunty Bun to her nephews Richard, Gene, Warren. We all love you Aunty Bun. Funeral Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, Thursday 2-5, 7-9 & Friday 2:30.

title: Iran leader renews furor, calling Holocaust a 'myth'
For Wheat Watchers, a Chance to Indulge
description: DURING the holidays, a woman cannot live on poached pears alone -- even if she is allergic to wheat.

title: TIME FOR SANTA TO WORRY
description: Santa Claus does not have much job security these days. At least not among Mets who have donned the costume at the team's annual holiday party for children.

title: Where the Lore Is Part of the Lure
description: THERE'S a secret to the surprising mellowness of the "legendary mutton chop" at Keens Steakhouse, a restaurant long synonymous with that gargantuan slab of meat. (The menu announces it with a verbal trumpet blast.)

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Investigating The Levee Failure
description: Sheet piles pulled from the levee at the 17th Street Canal in New Orleans reached more than 17 feet below sea level, the depth called for in construction documents. Louisiana researchers and the United States Army Corps of Engineers had previously conducted sonar tests that suggested the sheet pile, which anchors the levee and blocks the flow of water underneath, only reached 10 feet, which could have meant corners had been cut in the construction process. Col. Lewis F. Setliff III, who leads the corps' restoration task force, said the new findings did not solve the mystery of the levees' failure but would lead to fuller understanding. Louis Capozzoli, an engineer with the state group investigating the levee failure, said the additional seven feet "wouldn't make much difference," because the soil contained a thick layer of peat, and the piles would have had to be much deeper to get past that layer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRON, PAUL F. JR.
description: HARRON--Paul F. Jr. Cable television pioneer Paul F. Harron, Jr. died on December 8, 2005 at the University of Pennsylvania's Intensive Care Unit in Philadelphia, after a brief battle with lung cancer. He was 63. Mr. Harron was the President and Chief Executive Officer of Harron Communications Corp., a cable television and broadcasting company, which was founded in 1976. Mr. Harron lived in Malvern, PA, near his company's headquarters in Frazer, PA. In 1999, Mr. Harron sold his company's cable subscribers to Adelphia Communications Corp. The deal was the mostnoted of Mr. Harron's 35-plus year career. Mr. Harron's life and his business attitude could be summed up by the gold-plated plaque on his desk that read: "No Guts, No Glory." An entrepreneur who owned racehorses and a sailboat named the "Miss Conduct," Mr. Harron cultivated and expanded the cable and broadcasting business of his late father, Paul F. Harron, Sr. Within 20 years, Harron Communications was one of the largest cable television companies in the nation. Mr. Harron invested in television, radio, independent films, and venture capitalism during his career. He also expanded his business into nine states: New Hampshire, Maine, Massachusetts, Vermont, Michigan, New York, California, Maryland and Virginia. Mr. Harron also started a cable advertising firm, Metrobase Cable Advertising, which was later sold to Comcast Corp. He was also a founding board member of C-Span. Outside of communications, Mr. Harron owned the Vesper Club, a Philadelphia eating club. He was also a member of the New York Athletic Club, the Indian Creek Country Club in Miami, the Surf Club in Surfside, FL, and the Aronimink Golf Club in Newtown Square, PA. He was a graduate of the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, MA, and a graduate of Malvern Preparatory School in Malvern. Mr. Harron was a significant benefactor to the school and to many other charitable causes. He is survived by his mother Margaret E. Harron, sister Patricia H. Imbesi, nephews James J. Bruder Jr., Anthony M. Imbesi, Paul H. Imbesi, Charles L. Imbesi, and nieces Giovanna C. Imbesi, Margaret Anne Bruder Nolen and Jennifer M. Bruder. He was also brother to the late Margaret "Peggy" Anne Bruder. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, December 14, 2005 at S.S Simon and Jude Catholic Church, 8 Cavanaugh Court, West Chester, PA, at 12 noon. Family and friends are invited to call after 10 AM on Wednesday at S.S. Simon and Jude Catholic Church. Interment will be at Calvary Cemetery in Conshohocken, PA. In lieu of flowers the family would greatly appreciate donations, in the name of Paul F. Harron, Jr. to Malvern Preparatory School, 418 South Warren Avenue, Malvern, PA. 19355; or the Lung Center at the University of Pennsylvania, 3400 Spruce St., Ground Floor, Rhoads Pavilion, Philadelphia, PA 19104. For further information please call The Donohue Funeral Home, West Chester, PA; (610) 431-9000.

title: Controversy Still Clouds Prospects at 9/11 Site
description: A sense of despair about the prospects for cultural activity at ground zero pervaded a panel discussion on the issue on Monday night, even as some speakers suggested that the idea could be resurrected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MICHIELLI, NATALE
description: MICHIELLI--Natale. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Natale Michielli, associated with The Times since July 1996.

title: Police Seize Forged Ballots Headed to Iraq From Iran
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 13 - Less than two days before nationwide elections, the Iraqi border police seized a tanker on Tuesday that had just crossed from Iran filled with thousands of forged ballots, an official at the Interior Ministry said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUM, HELENE L.
description: BLUM--Helene L., age 96, of Larchmont, NY, died peacefully at home on December 13. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Blum and Max J. Blum. Most loving mother of Elaine Merians and son-inlaw Melvin Merians. Beloved grandmother of Diane and Thomas Burrows, Linda Merians, and Edward and Amy Merians. Cherished greatgrandmother of Joshua and Gabriella Burrows, Rachel Burrows, Sarah Burrows, Leah Burrows, Addie Merians, and Ethan Merians. Beloved sister of the late Sidney Miller and sister-in-law Barbara Miller. Caring aunt and friend to many. Active as a life-long member of Hadassah. Long time member of Larchmont - Mamaroneck Rotary, Larchmont Temple, and Central Synagogue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Larchmont Hadassah or a charity of your choice. Funeral service at Larchmont Temple, December 14 at 1 pm.

title: Two Paths to Glory: Smashing Desserts
description: THE easiest part of holiday cooking is the dessert course. If you are not a baker, you almost certainly won't believe me, but it is true.

title: Democracy Is Most Attractive for Shiites Leading in the Polls
description: BASRA, Iraq, Dec. 13 - With the election two days away, caravans of honking cars parade slowly through the streets of this sprawling southern city every day now, surrounded by people holding up banners bearing the number 555, symbol of the Shiite alliance that is the country's most powerful political group.

title: Bundesbank official is pick for ECB
Outlook is positive for Japan's economy
World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Court Won't Split Milosevic Case
description: Judges trying Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav leader, withdrew their proposal to split his war crimes trial, now in its fourth year, into two parts, forgoing the possibility of an early verdict on charges related to the Kosovo war in 1999. The trial will now proceed, encompassing that war as well as the wars in Bosnia and Croatia. The court also refused to give Mr. Milosevic the extra time he wanted to bring in 200 more witnesses. Further, it turned down his request to travel to Moscow during the Christmas recess to treat his heart problems.

title: France sells toll roadsto pay debt
Voting, Central Asian-style
Paid Notice: Deaths   MARDER, JOHN GERALD (JERRY)
description: MARDER--John Gerald (Jerry), 78, of New York, East Hampton, and Anguilla B.W.I., died peacefully at home in NYC on December 10th after a brave and inspiring fourand-a-half-year struggle with pancreatic cancer. Son of the late Rhea and Joseph T. Marder, D.D.S., Jerry was an advertising executive, real estate investor, buffalo rancher, avid Long Island fisherman, jazz buff, and family man. A former Executive Vice-President of Grey Advertising (now Grey Global), he was born in N.Y.C. in 1926. He attended Fieldston School, Cornell University and graduated from the Columbia Business School (1950). During WWII, he was a radio officer in the U.S. Maritime Service and U.S. Army Transport Service. He served during the Korean conflict as a 2nd Lt. in the U.S. Army. He spent 30 years at Grey, managing accounts for clients including Macy's, Proctor & Gamble and Revlon. A pioneer in government advertising, he managed campaigns for the U.S. Navy, Joint Recruiting Advertising Program, and U.S. Department of Transportation. After his retirement in 1986, he was instrumental in the rebirth of Miami's South Beach and served on the boards of LIM and Lesley College, among others. With his brother, he built (by hand) and ran BelleAir Farms, a buffalo ranch in Northeastern PA, home of "Buffalo Belle" brand bison. His first marriage to the late Barbara Sand Marder ended in divorce. He is survived by his second wife, Joan Kron, the author and Allure editorat-large; son, Jonathan Marder and his partner Gregory Grimes of NYC; daughters Susan Zelouf and her husband David Zelouf, M.D., of Merion, PA and Jane Martin and her husband Matthew J. Martin of NYC; stepson, Daniel Kron and his wife Geane Brito of Miami Beach, FL; brother Michael Z. Marder, D.D.S. of Rockland County, and five grandchildren. He was adored by all. The fluke swimming off Montauk Point may sleep more securely now, but Jerry will be sorely missed by the family he was devoted to and by his friends and colleagues. Donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, H-918, NY, NY 10021 for Dr. David Kelsen's research in pancreatic cancer. A funeral service will be held at 11:30 a.m., Wednesday, December 14, at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street).

title: Gyorgy Sandor, Pianist Who Trained Under Bartok, Is Dead at 93
description: Gyorgy Sandor, a pianist who studied with Bartok and remained a champion of his music throughout a long career as a performer and teacher, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: The Gladiators: History's Most Dangerous Sport
New Genome Project to Focus on Genetic Links in Cancers
description: The government is beginning a project designed to unlock the genetic abnormalities that contribute to cancer, an effort that would exceed the Human Genome Project in complexity and could eventually lead to new diagnostic tests and treatments for the disease.

title: Best Buy Profit Declines 6.8 Percent
description: The Best Buy Company, the electronics retailer, reported a 6.8 percent decline in fiscal third-quarter profit yesterday and said high expenses would hurt fourth-quarter results.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: Police Fire On Mob In Cannibal Rumor
description: Furious residents swarmed to the home of a Chinese businessman after rumors spread that he had kidnapped and eaten several boys from Bvumbwe, a rural village in a tea-growing belt about 15 miles south of the nation's commercial capital, Blantyre. Police officers searched the home and found no evidence of wrongdoing, but the crowd was undeterred. Officers shot and injured two people as they tried to disperse the mob. Malawi's small Chinese population, which first arrived in the 1800's to help build rail lines, has long been linked in local folklore and rumor to cannibalism.

title: Gazprom is seeking a foothold in the U.S.
Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, CELIA
description: HOROWITZ--Celia. Holocaust survivor. Beloved wife of the late Kalman. Devoted mother of Florence and Michael Barkan, Leo and Dina and Robert and Debby. Cherished grandmother of Molly and Brett, Matthew, Yael, Ellana, Keren and Miri.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GROSS, JERRY
description: GROSS--Jerry. We mourn the passing of a devoted friend who we loved and respected, who shared with us his incredible joy of living with music and song. May he rest in peace. Herbert, Frank and Carol Feinberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, WILLIAM T.
description: CUNNINGHAM--William T. 63, of Denville died on December 4, 2005 at Morristown Memorial Hospital. Husband of 32 years to Janice D. Cunningham nee Dolan, of Denville. Also surviving is his mother Nellie S. Cunningham of Chatham, a brother, Robert, of Newtown, PA. and three nieces and a nephew. A memorial service will be planned for a later date. He graduated from the University of Iowa. Mr. Cunningham retired in 2000 as the Vice President of the Bank of New York. Bill was a long-time member of the Northern New Jersey Region Porsche Club of America and a HAM radio operator with the call sign K2WTC.

title: Making the Global Local
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Globe-hugging
description: Just in case you are longing for some Oscar Pilates  reactions from the stars that will serve as warm-ups for a turn at the podium  you can tune into Entertainment Weeklys round-up of interviews with Globe nominees.

title: Gender Bent
description: The old Venus and Mars motif is overlaid on Kong at the Hollywood Stock Exchange. The distaff side of the review team says it is the male equivalent of a chick flick (keep those rhymes to yourselves, kids), and the dude gives the ape big ups for a bravura performance. Cant we all just get along?

title: Reversing the Megaphone
description: Whew, that was some serious stuff. The Carpetbagger must be longing for his days as a real actual reporter. But why pick up the phone when there is so much to be dealt with back at headquarters. Lets check to see what kind of feedback were getting in the Carpetbag.

title: Embargo Schmembargo
description: Yesterday, The New York Times reviewed King Kong, a step that usually signals that a film is opening. In this instance, it signaled something very different  that the Los Angeles Times had jumped the embargo and run its review the day before. Kong didnt start banging his chest for the public until today. The L.A. paper did the same thing with Chronicles of Narnia, running its review a week ago Wednesday, two days before the movie opened.

description: These handhelds make getting around easier.

description: "Some of my students have hands. Others have trunks," explains Katya Arnold, an artist and teacher, in her new book, "Elephants Can Paint Too!"

description: This week the Mortgage Bankers Association reports that mortgage applications are down sharply. Its a mercurial index, but one that bears a mention. Here are the highlights.

title: Housing Prices Push Up Tax Revenues
description: A story by Mike McIntire in todays Times says any slump in real estate prices is not going to affect New York City tax revenues much. He reports that the citys Independent Budget Office thinks that the city has been understating its projected revenues from real estate and mortgage taxes. The confidence in a good stream of tax revenue comes from a quirk in the tax structure.

title: The 1980 Transit Strike
description: During the city's last transit strike, commuters hiked or biked across bridges and roads.

description: Members of the New York City police force attended the funeral of Officer Daniel Enchautegui in the South Bronx.(Video: Angel Franco and Matthew Orr)

title: For Curb (and Sex) Appeal, A Bus That Acts Like a Train
description: Buses have an image problem in Los Angeles, even though hundreds of thousands of Angelenos use them. So the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority has created a fleet of sleek articulated buses, reminiscent of streamlined trains, for the new Metro Orange Line Transitway, for buses and bicycles, opened this fall in the San Fernando Valley. "People tend to think a bus is a lower-class system and since the Orange Line is a dedicated line and has landscaping on both sides, the whole image we decided to push was that of a train," explained Maya Emsden, a spokeswoman for the system. The bus -- "sexy, flexy," as Ms. Emsden describes it -- was designed by Alabama-based North American Bus Industries, and has fabrics by the artist Pae White and the architect Tom Marble, of Beep Inc. CURRENTS: LOS ANGELES -- TRANSPORTATION

title: Confidence Underground. Or Was That Denial?
description: Grumpiness? Sure. Dread? Absolutely. Complete ignorance that there might be a problem? Sadly, yes.

title: Bush Gives State Dept. Priority in Helping Nations to Rebuild
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - President Bush has designated the State Department as the leader of efforts to assist countries engulfed by conflict, a step aimed at avoiding a repetition of the disputes that erupted between Foreign Service officials and the Pentagon in the early months of the occupation of Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about preparations by New York City businesses for a possible transit strike referred incorrectly to an effort by the Clearing House, a company owned jointly by more than 20 major banks. It is arranging a fleet of buses for the banks' employees, not for its own.

title: On The Street: Then
description: IN the late fall of 1989, women bent on releasing the wildcat within were slipping into fake fur coats. Fun furs, as they were euphemistically called by their marketers, were as dense as a rug, though a mite more glamorous, enveloping the wearer in a sumptuous pile that might have been salvaged from "Wild Kingdom." The coats' synthetic markings, from tiny black leopard spots to the big broken doughnut pattern of the ocelot or jaguar, were achieved via photo printing, a process that made them as bold to the eye as they were plush to the touch.

title: 'Mary,' mosaic of redemption
Heinz Heinemann, 92, Innovative Industrial Chemist, Dies
description: Heinz Heinemann, an industrial chemist who helped develop methods of transforming coal and natural gas into gasoline, died on Nov. 23 at a hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 92.

description: ROTH--David Fred. Beloved husband of Marilyn (Mickie). Devoted father of Bennett (Judith), and Gene. Cherished grandfather of Brandon, Helena & Alexis. Services Friday 10AM, "Sinai Chapels", 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

description: Striking Back The 1972 Munich Olympics Massacre and Israel's Deadly Response By Aaron J. Klein Translated by Mitch Ginsburg Illustrated. 256 pages. Random House. $24.95.

title: W. G. Speed III, 87, Developer of Treatments for Migraines, Dies
description: Dr. William G. Speed III, a physician and researcher at Johns Hopkins who helped establish migraines and other severe headaches as legitimate medical disorders and developed medicines to treat them, died on Nov. 15 at Greater Baltimore Medical Center. He was 87.

title: House bill cracks down on illegal immigrants
Specs: Where 2 or 10 Can Pull Up a Chair
description: CHARLES ROSE designed the mahogany origami desk at left as a gift for his wife, Pam Moore, a writer, and their son. It has a tray that pulls out for his wife's laptop, and a lower shelf where their 3-year-old son can sit and draw. The desk cost $15,000 and was made by Bill Bancroft Furniture Design (37 Antwerp Street, Brighton, Mass. 02135, (617) 797-4004). It looks like -- but is not -- a single piece of wood folded into sharp angles.

title: Verbal war refuses tocool down
A Lexus for Christmas? It Happens
description: AS Christmas presents go, a Lexus is not high on most lists.

title: Where doctors are needed most
Riots revive notion of Australians as racist
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Estate Of Freud's Grandson To Get Holocaust Funds
description: The estate of Sigmund Freud's grandson will receive about $168,000 in the latest awards in the $1.25 billion settlement of a lawsuit against Swiss banks brought on behalf of Holocaust survivors and their descendants. Freud's grandson, who made the claim several years ago, died in February 2004, according to court documents. The award to Freud's grandson, Anton Walter Freud, was among 23 payouts authorized yesterday by Edward R. Korman, the chief judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Four Are Found Shot to Death in Illegal Club in Paterson
description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 14 - Three men and a woman were found shot to death early Wednesday morning at an illegal after-hours club in a graffiti-tagged warehouse here near Route 80, the authorities said. It was the city's first multiple homicide in more than a decade, the police said.

title: As Season Starts to Slip Away, It's Clear Nets Need Changes
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 14 - With a pitiful performance against one of the Eastern Conference's worst teams Wednesday night, the Nets showed why a trade might be their only way to improve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALLER, ELLIOT
description: FALLER--Elliot. 73 on December 13, 2005. Beloved husband of Barbara and the late Rita Faller. Devoted father of Noel and Jill, Samantha and Scott, Craig and Jennifer. Adoring Poppy of Danielle, Sammy, Toby, Jesse and Cole. Brother and brother-inlaw of Dr. Hugh and Diane Unger, Mona and Arthur Sherman and Shirley Herman. Elliot had a long and distinguished career as a jeweler. He was the rock and patriarch of this family and will never be forgotten. Services Thursday, December 15 at 10 a.m., Boulevard - Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Anthony C. Russo, 88, Labor Negotiator, Dies
description: Anthony C. Russo, a former director of labor relations for the City of New York, died last Thursday in Queens. He was 88 and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Senate Is Set to Require Details on Secret Prisons
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - The Senate is poised to approve a measure that would require the Bush administration to provide Congress with its most specific and extensive accounting about the secret prison system established by the Central Intelligence Agency to house terrorism suspects.

title: Islamists march into the breach
World Briefing | Africa: Eritrea: U.N.'S Western Peacekeepers To Be Withdrawn
description: The United Nations Security Council agreed to Eritrea's demand to remove about 160 North American, European and Russian members of its peacekeeping force from its border with Ethiopia. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

title: The Crime-Fighting Working Mom
description: The legal drama "Close to Home" revolves around an attractive assistant district attorney with a 100 percent conviction rate, an infant daughter, a carpenter husband and a home life so equitably organized that she would seem to be the one working mother in the country exempt from the double shift.

title: Bush Says U.S. Needs Patience On Iraq War; Admits Errors
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - A day before Iraq's first parliamentary elections, President Bush said Wednesday that Americans would have to remain patient and should expect more bloodshed as Iraqis struggled toward stability and democracy.

title: Once Again, a Farewell for a Fallen Officer
description: Officer Daniel Enchautegui had two families: one he was linked to by blood, the other by a badge. Yesterday, both reached out to him one last time, wheeling his coffin into a yellow-brick church, touching it with one hand while making the sign of the cross with the other and, finally, escorting it to a cold patch of soil in a Bronx cemetery.

title: Briefs: S&P lifts Russia's rating for debt, citing oil prices
Arts, Briefly
description: The Saga Ends For 'Sweet Charity'

title: Williams Is Off His Stride, but Seems at Peace
description: DAVIE, Fla., Dec. 14 - Ricky Williams returned to pro football in July amid much hoopla. After all, Williams, the Miami Dolphins running back who unexpectedly retired before training camp in 2004, was professing a renewed vigor for the game after a self-imposed exile of 13 months.

title: Mutual-Aid Network Links South Asia and the U.S.
description: As recent investments by Microsoft, Intel and Cisco Systems attest, corporate America has come to view India not just as a source of low-cost talent but also as an emerging economic power to be reckoned with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWMYER, ROBERT
description: NEWMYER - Robert. Inde pendent producer, died at 49. The Board of the Gordon A. Rich Memorial Foundation (GAR) mourns the loss of one of its founding members, Robert "Bobby" Newmyer. Bobby was a wonderful family man, a prolific independent film producer, a great friend and a tireless supporter of philanthropies, such as GAR and the Lost Boys of Sudan. He will be sorely missed.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Corzine Appoints Staff Members
description: Governor-elect Jon S. Corzine yesterday tapped Stuart Rabner, criminal division chief for the United States attorney in Newark, to be his chief counsel. Mr. Rabner, 45, is a career prosecutor who has worked for Democrats and Republicans, focusing on corruption and terrorism. Mr. Corzine made two other appointments: Heather Howard, 37, his chief of staff in the United States Senate, will be his policy counsel; and Ivette Mendez, 53, his campaign press secretary, will be his communications director.

title: Asian Leaders Search for Common Interests, in America's Absence
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 14 - Japan and China were not talking. Russia was talking to everybody. Australia was fending off bad press. The Philippines was denying coup rumors. India was offering to teach English. And the United States, for once, was looking in from the cold.

title: House Backs McCain onDetainees, Defying Bush
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - In an unusual bipartisan rebuke to the Bush administration, the House on Wednesday overwhelmingly endorsed Senator John McCain's measure to bar cruel and inhumane treatment of prisoners in American custody anywhere in the world.

title: BlackBerry Dispute Aids Rivals
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 14 - The patent dispute between NTP and Research In Motion, maker of the BlackBerry, has become a marketing opportunity for its competitors in the wireless e-mail business.

title: Lost in Bitter Legal Battle: Chamber Players' Instruments
description: What would be a wrenching moment for any musician has arrived for two members of the Audubon Quartet: the loss of their instruments, casualties of a bitter legal feud with the member they cast out five years ago.

title: Boys and Adults Gathered for a 'Messiah' Spectacle
description: Handel's "Messiah" reappeared at St. Thomas Church on Tuesday night, a grand affair made grander by its surroundings. This big and richly appointed Episcopal church on Fifth Avenue can, with the St. Thomas Choir School in play, offer possibly the best alternative on this side of the Atlantic to the British tradition of young male voices in treble parts.

title: Giants' Whitfield, a Comedian Who Gets Respect
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 14 - Bob Whitfield stood in front of his locker Wednesday wielding a protein shake as if it were a microphone as he turned the Giants' locker room into a comedy club with his one-liners.

title: Lawmakers Question Louisiana Governor on Storm Response and Preparation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - On a trip intended to drive home her state's urgent need for billions of dollars in additional federal aid, Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco of Louisiana came under sharp questioning from Republican lawmakers on Wednesday about her handling of the prehurricane evacuation of New Orleans and the postflood rescue effort.

title: 'War and Peace': A tactical advance
VIDEO TEST WITH -- Carol Scott, Fitness Trainer; From Couch to Cardio
description: COLD, snowy weather can make it harder than ever to get to the gym. But the gym is not the only place where you can get a workout. Many people burn calories and build fitness at home in front of the television.

title: At Historic Apollo Theater, Restored Facade Is the Star of the Day
description: Like any 92-year-old, the Apollo Theater has been alternately cherished and neglected. There was one moment when the theater was scheduled for demolition, then one when it was declared a historic landmark. But through it all, the Apollo, a 1913 former burlesque hall designed by George Keister, has stood on West 125th Street as a beacon of black entertainment, an aging Harlem icon.

title: Talks Continue as Transit Deadline Nears
description: The transit workers' union and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were bargaining feverishly tonight, struggling to bridge large gaps over wages and pensions, as they sought to avert a transit strike threatened for Friday morning in New York City.

title: The O.C. Park: Outdoorsy, But Not Without Artifice?
description: Orange County may be known for Disneyland and shopping malls, but after the El Toro Marine Corps Air Station closed in 1999, the county's citizens voted to create a vast public park out of 1,350 of the base's nearly 4,700 acres. (The rest will be a housing development.) Three design firms were short listed -- EMBT from Barcelona; Royston Hanamoto Alley & Abey from Mill Valley, Calif.; and Ken Smith Landscape Architect from New York -- and, after a lengthy public review process, a winner will soon be announced, possibly as early as today. Residents of the O.C. asked that the park, to be called the Orange County Great Park, include sports facilities, a memorial to veterans, restored wetlands and water features. EMBT also proposed a large lake, while Ken Smith, whose proposal is shown above and at right, wants to create a zone of respite in the park, with an artificial shady canyon running the length of a site that he called "awesome, because it is huge and intimidating and empty and hot." CURRENTS: LOS ANGELES -- LANDSCAPING

title: Suit Challenges California's Tuition Rule for Illegal Immigrants
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - About three dozen students filed a lawsuit against the University of California on Wednesday, charging that it had violated federal law by allowing illegal immigrants to pay in-state tuition rates at its campuses while maintaining higher rates for out-of-state students.

title: See Baby Touch a Screen. but Does Baby Get It?
description: Jetta is 11 months old, with big eyes, a few pearly teeth -- and a tiny index finger that can already operate electronic entertainment devices.

description: LINKER--Jack. On December 13, 2005, at age 90. Beloved husband of Gertrude for 62 years, father of Arthur and Martin, father-in-law of Diane and Amy, grandfather of Beth, Jennifer, Michael, Anne, Harrison and William. We will miss you dearly. Services Thursday, December 15, 11AM, Bloomfield-Cooper Funeral Home, Englishtown, New Jersey.

title: Bending the nuclear taboo
World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechnya Wants To Rename Ruined Capital
description: Chechnya's new Parliament voted to ask the Kremlin to change the name of the capital, Grozny, to Akhmad-Kala, after Akhmad Kadyrov, the Kremlin-backed Chechen president who was assassinated last year. Grozny, variously translated in Russian as "menacing" and "terrible," has been the scene of civil war since 1994 and is a ruin. But its symbolic meaning is high. The underground rebel government has proposed renaming it Dzhokhar, after the separatist leader Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, killed by Russian forces in 1996. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Canal Plus has TPS's agreement on merger
Inquiry in Italy widens

description: NEW YORK

title: As Negotiations Continue, City Prepares for Transit Strike
description: With a contract deadline just after midnight tonight, representatives of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the transit workers' union met intermittently yesterday to stave off a strike as the agency's top negotiator warned that "we are not in a good place."

title: Briefly: Scores arrested in raid on trafficking ring
What Can We Learn From How a Manager Invests His Own Money?
description: IN the simplest textbook model of financial markets, companies pay cash dividends each year to their shareholders, who can then invest this money where they expect it to have the highest future return. Thus, each dollar flows to its most profitable use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFBAUER, HELGA
description: HOFFBAUER--Helga. My beloved wife of 71 years, Helga Hoffbauer, my anchor and my companion left us peacefully on December 13, 2005 in her 92nd year. She is survived by a daughter, Stephanie Brody, three grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Gerhard Hoffbauer

title: A Convenient Amnesia About Slavery
description: Americans typically grow up believing that slavery was confined to the cotton fields of the South and that the North was always made up of free states. The fact that slavery was practiced all over the early United States often comes as a shock to people in places like New York, where the myth of the free North has been surprisingly durable. The truth is that New York was at one time a center of the slave trade, with more black people enslaved than any other city in the country, with the possible exception of Charleston, S.C.

title: Readers Respond: 'Jihad Daniel' vs. Dr. Scala
description: I almost never do this but I got so much mail about the Jihad Daniel column, I'd like to do a group reply. My mail was either, "She's a P.C. jerk. Thanks for telling this appalling story about the thought police run amuck."or "You're an insensitive jerk for condoning this man's hate speech and homophobia."

title: Baby Wrap 101
description: PEOPLE stopped on the sidewalk to point. Behind the window of Starwich, a sandwich shop on the far western reaches of 42nd Street, a bonanza was unfolding -- folding and unfolding, actually -- for women who preferred to wear their babies using a long swath of fabric.

title: Also, He Tends to Eat the Paparazzi
description: Also, He Tends to Eat The Paparazzi

title: Not Much That's Useful, Maybe, But Treats for the Senses
description: The rose thorn vase, top, is one of the more functional pieces on sale at Rose, a recently opened shop at 1225 Abbot Kinney Boulevard in Venice, Calif., that its owner, Mark Rose, calls a "style store." "There's not a lot of function in here," Mr. Rose said. "Function is incidental." The gilded ceramic vases were designed by Kathleen Walsh, a sculptor, and are 8 and 10 inches tall ($145 and $165); also available in black, (310) 399-0040.

title: EU leaders carry competing visions of Europe into crucial meeting
Deutsche chief looks at a legacy of change
Higher Limits on Donations From Unions to Take Effect
description: In a reversal, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will allow a law to take effect today under which labor unions can sharply increase their donations to political candidates. It would be the most significant loosening of contribution limits since the city's campaign finance program was set up in 1988.

title: Looking at Stars Beneath Their Glitter, or Hanging Celebrities With Their Own Ropes
description: Celebrities, not being all they're cracked up to be, can't quite rival the writers who come up with things for them to say onscreen. Their own literary devices prove rickety, laughably so on "Celebrity Autobiography: In Their Own Words."

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "If parents are thinking, 'I need a break, I'll put my 4-year-old in front of this nice harmless video,' that's one thing. But if parents are thinking, 'This is good for my 3-month-old, it will help her get ahead in the world,' that's another."

title: Main Palestinian Faction Splits Sharply Ahead of Election
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 15 - The divisions within the main Palestinian faction, Fatah, broke sharply into the open today, as the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, threatened to resign unless a rival slate of younger Fatah members for the Jan. 25 legislative elections is withdrawn, Palestinian officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, JEROME B.
description: GROSS--Jerome B. Beloved husband of Barbara-Ruth Thackston Gross. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., Thursday, December 15th, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. with service Friday 9:30 AM.

title: Anna Benson Stands by Her Man, and Then Some
description: On a normal day, the sight of the 6-foot-4, antenna-thin Kris Benson in a Santa Claus outfit would have inspired some intriguing looks at Shea Stadium. But when Mrs. Claus sauntered out of the elevator behind him yesterday wearing a strapless crimson dress and a fur headband, heads swiveled toward her and eyes widened. Once again, Anna Benson had diverted attention from her husband.

title: A Guitarist Asserts Himself, Thoughtfully and Quietly
description: The guitarist Lage Lund exudes a diffident and self-deprecating kind of cool. He's not a talker, or even much of a frontman. But as he demonstrated at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center on Tuesday night, his playing and presence can both be casually magnetic. Like Jim Hall, one of the guitarists in his heroes' gallery, he channels reticence into a whisper-quiet mystique.

title: Bush's Path Forward Has Many Ifs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - It took a thousand days after he ordered the invasion of Iraq for President Bush to describe in considerable detail his strategy for transforming the country and the region, and to lay out the benchmarks that he said Wednesday would lead to "complete victory."

title: Stem-cell scientist said to fake study
Briefly: Romney won't seek 2nd term as governor
World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 2 Northern Attacks
description: A suicide bomber in northern Mazar-i-Sharif died when he set off an explosion outside the shrine of Hazrat Ali, the famed blue mosque. Two bystanders were wounded, and there was no damage to the shrine. A roadside bomb killed two Swedish peacekeepers in the city late last month. Another bomb, this one reportedly strapped onto a donkey and exploded remotely, damaged a German aid agency vehicle in northeastern Badakhshan Province. The country's north had been largely peaceful in the last year. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEVLER, LEONA
description: NEVLER--Leona. My friend and special advisor. I will miss you. BDSE

title: Bush Expresses a Belief in DeLay's Innocence
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - President Bush said on Wednesday that he thought Representative Tom DeLay, under indictment in Texas, was innocent and that he hoped Mr. DeLay could return to the post of House majority leader.

title: Spielberg's Movie, Mideast Passions
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Snowy Season, the Promise of Sunshine
description: IF you are wondering what to give the gardener in your life, why not keep it simple with a thought-provoking book, an unusual pot or a fine pair of garden gloves.

title: A Video Game Chair That Vibrates in Time to the Action on Screen
description: As if video games weren't intense enough, the Pyramat PM220 chair transfers the rollicking action from the screen to your stomach.

title: Talks Stalled, U.S. Envoy Matches Insults of North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 14 - North Korea's state news agency recently proposed a novel punishment for the new United States ambassador here, Alexander Vershbow: South Koreans should force him to stand in the midst of Seoul's notorious downtown traffic, and then "punish him in the name of the nation and immediately expel him from their land."

title: Keeping The 'Festive' In Festival
description: HANUKKAH begins on the evening of Sunday, Dec. 25, and there are many new styles of menorah, the ceremonial candleholder, to use in celebrating the eight-day festival.

title: Police Deaths and Stalemate on Gun Laws
description: LEAVE it to Albany. Two police officers are dead, killed by bullets from illegal guns, and the leaders in our state capital got caught playing politics as usual.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILE, JULIUS
description: WILE--Julius. Wine expert and educator, on December 12, 2005 at home in Scarsdale, NY. Loving husband of the late Ruth Wile. Beloved father of Barbara Wile Schwarz and Andrew Wile, and fatherin-law of Paul Schwarz, Kathleen Wile and Regina Burg. Devoted grandfather of Susan Schwarz, Stephen Schwarz and wife Kristen Couse, and Max Julius Wile. Adoring great grandfather of Wile Taylor Schwarz-Couse. Donations to the Ruth & Julius Wile Endowed Scholarship Fund of the Culinary Institute of America, Hyde Park, NY, or to White Plains Hospital Center. Services at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains Friday, December 16, 11am

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Accounting Changes To Save City Millions
description: Accounting changes by the city's public employee pension boards will save the city $1.4 billion over the next two years, helping to further reduce next year's projected budget deficit to a manageable $647 million, according to a report released yesterday by State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg originally forecast a $4.5 billion deficit for the fiscal year that begins next July, and then reduced it to $2.3 billion last month based on higher-than-expected tax collections. The latest reduction stems from the pension changes, which mostly involve delaying some city contributions to the retirement funds for a year and phasing in investment gains and losses over a longer period, the report said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THORNE, EDWARD
description: THORNE--Edward. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward Thorne, associated with The Times from May 1970, until retiring in June 1989.

title: Berlusconi Changes Rules to His Benefit
description: ROME, Dec. 14 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi realized Wednesday the dream of almost any politician, like him, in deep electoral trouble: he rewrote the rules.

title: In North, Kurdistan Comes First, Iraq Comes Second
description: ALTUN KOPRI, Iraq, Dec. 15 - As lines of voters snaked out of two polling stations along the main road, and as celebratory gunfire resounded through the neighborhood, a group of children chanted Kurdish songs and waved Kurdish flags as they barreled through the middle of this village.

title: Shopping Crowds Seem Lighter at the Mall This Year
description: Something is missing from consumers' shopping lists this holiday: the mall.

title: Security Agency Running 6-Day Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - The Transportation Security Administration began a six-day pilot program this week to send security personnel to bus, train and subway stations in six cities, the agency said Wednesday. Some of the personnel are undercover federal air marshals.

title: At Age 69, Vermeil May Be Near a Last Run
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 14 - Dick Vermeil has walked away from two head-coaching jobs in the National Football League, and neither exit came off the way he would have liked.

title: In Messages, Lobbyist Says DeLay Pressed for Donation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - Newly disclosed e-mail messages from the lobbyist Jack Abramoff show that he told an Indian tribe client that he was being pressured by Representative Tom DeLay for a contribution for a $25,000-a-table Republican fund-raiser and that Mr. DeLay had personally phoned the lobbyist's office in search of the money.

title: Climate Change: U.S. and the World (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Merry, but Not Christmas
description: Options abound for people looking to imbibe a little Christmas cheer at the theater. The Rockettes' snappy routines have virtually become a semaphore for holiday spirit at Radio City. A new stage version of "White Christmas" is now being mass-manufactured like candy canes in cities across the country. Old Scrooge's frozen heart is melting just about everywhere you look.

title: French minister urges collecting minority data
Vera Wang's Business Is No Longer All Dressed in White
description: VERA WANG remembers the many times she was asked on red carpets, in interviews or when dropping her daughters at school why she was not wearing clothes of her own design. What were people thinking, she wondered, when all she really made was wedding gowns. It is only in the last two years that Ms. Wang, who has been in business for 16, has been successful at designing anything else.

title: Borrowing From Other Times And Far-Flung Places
description: The Los Angeles decorator Michael Smith has used antique textiles as the basis for his Jasper line of hand-printed hemp fabrics. Indian Flower, left, is adapted from an Indian Mogul panel, while Remy, right, is from a Belgian fabric. Both are $120 a yard. Mr. Smith, whose clients include Michelle Pfeiffer, Rupert Murdoch and Steven Spielberg, also has a new monograph, "Michael S. Smith: Elements of Style" (Rizzoli, written with Diane Dorrans Saeks). The fabrics are available at showrooms and retail outlets; for information: Michael Smith Inc. at info@jasperfabrics.com. CURRENTS: LOS ANGELES -- FABRICS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, SEYMOUR
description: GOLDBERG--Seymour. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Seymour Goldberg, beloved father of Suzanne Appelbaum and father-in-law of Michael Appelbaum, cherished leaders of the New York Jewish community whose commitment and generosity strengthens our ability to serve those in need. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Suzy and Michael, and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Iraqis Open Vote for Parliament; An Islamist-Secular Split Is Seen
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Thursday, Dec. 15 - Iraqi voters began streaming to the polls Thursday morning in nationwide elections as Iraqi leaders predicted that the vote would split almost evenly between secular and Islamist parties and usher in lengthy political maneuvering.

title: Climate Change: U.S. and the World

title: Susan Butcher's Race for Life
description: TAPED to the wall above Susan Butcher's hospital bed is a photo of her gregarious little girl dressed as a clown and another snapshot of her pensive older daughter flashing a thoughtful stare.

title: After a Century, an American Writer's Library Will Go to America
description: SETTRINGTON, England, Dec. 12 - In an English house in this small Yorkshire village, a defining moment in American letters unfolded on Monday, rounding a circle begun a century ago when Edith Wharton, the writer, packed up and left the United States to live in France.

title: Heavy Sunni Turnout as Iraqis Vote for Parliament
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 15 - In a day remarkable for its calm, millions of Iraqis from across the country cast ballots today to elect a parliament to a four-year term, with Sunni Arabs turning out in what appeared to be very heavy numbers and guerrillas mounting relatively few armed attacks.

title: Infinity Broadcasting to Become CBS Radio
description: Viacom, the No. 3 United States media company, will rename the Infinity Broadcasting unit CBS Radio after the split of its businesses into two companies.

title: Amgen to Buy Abgenix, Getting Complete Control of New Colon Cancer Drug
description: The biotechnology giant Amgen has agreed to acquire Abgenix for $2.2 billion in cash, giving it full ownership of a promising cancer drug the companies have been developing together.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARRUBBA, ROBERT WILLIAM
description: CARRUBBA--Robert William. 71, former vice president of academic affairs at Fordham University and Latin Scholar, died on Monday, December 12 at his home in New City, New York. Mr. Carrubba is survived by his wife of 40 years, Joanne Carrubba and his four children Robert, Maria, Peter, and Carla. Mr. Carrubba was a native New Yorker who pursued undergraduate and masters degrees in Classics at Fordham University and doctorate studies at Princeton where he received his PhD in Classics in 1964. He began his teaching career at Columbia University, was professor of Classics and associate dean of the graduate school at Pennsylvania State University and founding dean of the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. Most recently, Mr. Carrubba was the vice president of academic affairs at Fordham University until retiring to teach classes in Classics and working on his fourth book. He has published extensively on the poetry of Horace and the writings of Engelbert Kaempfer, and has presented more than 30 papers around the world. A funeral service will be held at Fordham University at 11:00 A.M. on Friday, December 16. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Robert Carrubba Memorial Fund at Fordham University c/o Judith Katz, Development Department, 113 West 60 Street, NY NY 10023. 212636-7957. Visiting at Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main Street, New City, NY on Thursday from 3-9 P.M.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Is Set to Require Details on Secret Prisons The Senate was poised to approve a measure that would require the Bush administration to give Congress specific and extensive updates every 90 days on the Central Intelligence Agency's secret detention system set up after Sept. 11 for terrorism suspects.

title: Chip division of Philips to be separate company
Bloomberg's Strategy: Plan for Worst and Hope for Best
description: Reduced to little more than a bystander in talks that could lead to a crippling transit strike in his city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been walking a perilously thin line these last few weeks. He has been choosing his words carefully to avoid directly antagonizing the transit union, while trying to scare it away from a strike by taking action in court.

title: Macquarie affirms bidLSE rejected
Finding Success on the Rebound
description: CONCERNED viewers of "Project Runway" this season may wonder at the fairness of including as a contestant Daniel Franco, who was eliminated in the first round last season. But in fashion there are second chances, sometimes even more.

title: Restrictions on Meth Ingredients Are Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - A bipartisan group of lawmakers announced an agreement on Wednesday to restrict the sales of cold medicines that can be used to manufacture the illegal and highly addictive drug methamphetamine.

title: Fire Officials Defend Action in Collapse
description: One day after an apartment building in Bergenfield, N.J., was destroyed by a natural-gas explosion that killed three people, fire officials faced sharp questioning yesterday about their decision not to evacuate the building or test the air for leaking gas after being alerted that a nearby pipeline had been damaged by a work crew.

title: Seeds That Need the Cold
description: Seeds That Need the Cold

title: Arts, Briefly; Eminem's Fourth No. 1
description: New albums by Eminem, Lil Wayne and Korn top the Billboard chart this week. Eminem's "Curtain Call: The Hits" (Aftermath), a compilation with three new songs, became his fourth album in a row to reach No. 1. It sold nearly 441,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. "Tha Carter II" (Cash Money) by Lil Wayne, the New Orleans rapper, is No. 2 with 240,000 in sales, and Korn's "See You on the Other Side" (Virgin) was a close third with 220,000. In a relatively strong week at record stores in which almost every title in the Top 20 that was not new had big sales gains, the 20th volume of "Now That's What I Call Music!" reached No. 4 in its sixth week out; Carrie Underwood's "Some Hearts" (Arista) is at No. 5; and Nickelback, Mariah Carey and the Black Eyed Peas continue to hold strong in the lower rungs of the Top 10. "The Legend of Johnny Cash" (Hip-O/Universal), a 21-song sampler released in October, has been a strong seller. It rose two spots this week to No. 12, with 103,000 copies, and in its seven weeks in stores has sold a total of 447,000 copies. BEN SISARIO

title: City Orders Labs to Submit Data From Tests of Diabetics
description: As part of a broad new effort to better understand how diabetics manage their illness, the New York City Board of Health is ordering laboratories to pass along detailed information on individual tests that measure blood sugar levels to the city's health department.

title: A Happy Hipster Hanukkah
description: "HELLOOOOOOOO Jews!" the M.C. shouted to the 1,000 or so people sipping drinks and jostling elbows in the hazy purple light of Crobar, the Chelsea club, on Sunday evening. Disco balls twinkled. Electric menorahs glowed. In the candlelighted V.I.P. area, people bit into chocolate Hanukkah gelt. From a stage on the dance floor Rachel Dratch of "Saturday Night Live" bemoaned being Jewish at Christmastime, and Triumph the Insult Comic Dog, the foul-mouthed puppet, belted out a joyous rendition of "Shalom Aleichem." It was not long before people were waving their arms above their heads and lobbing inflatable dreidels through the air like beach balls.

title: Germany Says It Pressed U.S. Over Detention of One of Its Citizens
description: BERLIN, Dec. 14 - Over several months between September 2004 and January of this year the German police and a senior government official repeatedly pressed the United States for information about a German citizen abducted in Macedonia and held in prison for five months in Afghanistan, Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier said Wednesday in a speech to Parliament.

title: The Mormons Are Coming, the Mormons Are Coming
description: "No Mormons were harmed in the making of this film," runs the memorable disclaimer of the instantly forgettable "Trapped by the Mormons." This would-be cult curiosity represents the cinematic debut of Cherry Red Productions, a Washington-based theater company whose self-proclaimed psychotronic productions include "Cannibal Cheerleaders on Crack," "Romeo and Juliatric" and "Worm Girl." I can't speak for the stage work, but the joke of this movie ends with the title.

title: Physical Culture; Chronically Ill Patients Turn to Yoga for Relief
description: JACK WATERS credits yoga with saving his life four years ago. Riding the subway in Paris, he began experiencing chest pain. He knew that signaled a heart attack because he'd had two already, side effects of an H.I.V. medicine that raised his cholesterol. He needed to get to a hospital, but first he wanted to do a yoga pose.

title: Unicef Warns of the Increased Vulnerability of Poor Children
description: Hundreds of millions of children -- orphans, the homeless, child brides, soldiers and refugees among them -- suffer from extreme forms of discrimination and exploitation that often are not addressed by mainstream development programs, according to a report released yesterday by the United Nations Children's Fund, known as Unicef.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEFF, SYDNEY
description: LEFF--Sydney, 104. On December 10, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Rita Leff. Loving father of Joan Miller and Gail Raab. Grandfather of Wendy Miller, Paul Miller, Jonathan Raab and Nina Fox. Cherished great-grandfather of Marc Miller, Joshua Raab, Sonya Raab, Rachel Fox and Mia Fox. Pioneering graphic designer, last of the great illustrators of popular sheet music and member of the Big Band Hall of Fame. Formerly of West Palm Beach, FL and Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. Services Friday December 16 11AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (91st St), NYC. 212-769-4400

title: John Langstaff, Founder of 'Revels,' Dies at 84
description: John Langstaff, who founded the "Christmas Revels," the long-running seasonal pageant of traditional music, dance and theater that plays in Boston, New York and other cities around the country, died on Tuesday in Basel, Switzerland. He was 84.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ex-Manager Sues Dave Chappelle
description: Dave Chappelle's former manager, Mustafa Abuelhija, has filed a breach-of-contact suit against the comedian. This news comes just days after Comedy Central announced that it would begin broadcasting a third season of "Chappelle's Show" next year. According to court documents posted on www.thesmokinggun.com, Mr. Abuelhija contends that Mr. Chappelle owes him at least $864,500. In the suit, Mr. Abuelhija says he helped negotiate deals that earned the comedian at least $10 million. He says that he was fired after Mr. Chappelle returned from an impromptu sabbatical in South Africa in June. The suit alleges that Comedy Central paid Mr. Chappelle $4.5 million when he opted to continue his hit show through 2006 and also agreed to pay him $275,000 for each episode and $25,000 for each repeat. The agreement, the suit says, also guaranteed that Mr. Chappelle would receive 50 percent royalties from the show's DVD's. LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: Soldiers Versus Defense Contractors
description: It's what passes for crunch time at the Pentagon. Word has now gone out that $32 billion in savings must be found out of the $2.3 trillion the Defense Department is planning to spend in the next five years. After the Pentagon's spending orgy over the past five years, there is plenty of scope for cutting, without weakening America's defenses -- but only if the cuts come out of the most costly and least needed Air Force and Navy weapons programs, not from the money required to replenish and re-equip the Army and Marine ground forces that have been worn down by Iraq.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - The Environmental Protection Agency said Wednesday that it had reached a $16.5 million settlement with DuPont, which it had accused of failing to report information about the health and environmental risks of a substance used in making Teflon and other plastics.

title: Weimar Journal; In the Ashes of a German Past, a Vision of Europe's Future
description: WEIMAR, Germany - When a fire swept through the rococo library in this fabled city of Goethe and Schiller last year, the loss of some 30,000 books, manuscripts and irreplaceable, handwritten musical scores from the 16th to the 18th centuries was clearly incalculable.

description: Report From Spitzer Says Ex-Chief Of A.I.G. Defrauded Foundation Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, submitted a report as part of his lawsuit against Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of American International Group, contending that Mr. Greenberg unfairly enriched himself and other A.I.G. executives in a series of transactions that violated the will of Cornelius Vander Starr, the company's founder, and defrauded a foundation he created. [Page C1.]

title: Outside Baghdad, Ink-Stained Fingers and Hope for Future
description: RAMADI, Iraq, Dec. 15 - The main boulevard that runs through this defiant Sunni Arab town is a corridor of dread. Its bullet-pocked buildings harbor sniper's blinds, its potholes conceal homemade bombs. American troops drive it at high speed only, darting from base to base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, HERBERT S.
description: ADLER--Herbert S., 63. Undaunted by the vicissitudes of life, Herbert Adler flourished. He selflessly gave of himself to scores of friends, family members, coworkers and even random people he happened to meet in delis, dry cleaners, and fancy balls. His untimely passing leaves a void that can only be filled by knowing how many people carry his love in their hearts forever. He was a prominent businessman, tireless philanthropist, and patron of the arts. The Adler family will try very hard to continue to live by his example. Contributions may be sent to The Adler Family Fund for the History of Art at Williams College, c/o Diana Elvin, 75 Park Street, Williamstown, MA. 01267.

title: Few State Prisoners Freed Under Eased Drug Law
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki signed a law a year ago reducing what he called "unduly long sentences" for drug crimes, he predicted that hundreds of nonviolent drug offenders would be released from prison.

title: No clear winner forseen in Iraq
William Proxmire, Senator Who Abhored Waste, Dies
description: William Proxmire of Wisconsin, the longtime gadfly of the United States Senate who thrived on exposing frivolous federal spending and dispensed Golden Fleece Awards to spotlight what he considered bad uses of taxpayers' money, died today at a nursing home in Sykesville, Md. He was 90 and had remained a resident of the Washington metropolitan area after he announced in 1987 that he would not seek re-election, ending a colorful Senate career of 31 years.

title: Israeli Attack Kills 4 in Gaza; Fatah Factions Contest Ballot
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 - An Israeli airstrike on Wednesday killed four Palestinian militants near the eastern edge of the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said that the Palestinians' car was packed with explosives and that they were on the way to carry out an attack.

title: Ford to Save $850 Million in New Health Care Pact
description: Local auto union officials said yesterday that they had approved the Ford Motor Company's demands for lower annual health care costs, saying the agreement would save the automaker $850 million annually. The decision paves the way for a ratification vote by union-represented factory workers.

title: Morgan Will Pay Chief $11.5 Million for '05
description: Morgan Stanley said yesterday that it would pay John J. Mack $11.5 million in stock for his five months as chief executive. The sum is a prorated portion of the $28 million that the board's compensation committee agreed to pay its new chief executive for 2005.

title: Niedermayers Are Now One Big Happy Family
description: When Scott Niedermayer left the Devils as a free agent last summer to sign with Anaheim, the No. 1 reason he cited was the chance to play with his younger brother, Rob, for the first time since they were teenagers.

title: A silencing in Lebanon
New York, Paris and Los Angeles
description: Sergio Rossi, the Italian shoemaker, is to open another lounge-inspired Manhattan boutique next Wednesday, in Midtown. It will offer shoes for both sexes (including women's knee-high riding boots, cherry suede wedges and python round-toe pumps), handbags from the fall-winter collection and free refreshments, including Italian wine and Champagne, tea and -- on very cold days -- hot toddies. At 694 Fifth Avenue, between 54th and 55th Streets, (212) 941-0529.

title: Point, Click and Strut
description: THE failure of online luxury shopping five years ago was so dramatic that it was easy to deny its potential, which was a little like condemning the history of aviation to 12 seconds at Kitty Hawk. The amount of money spent on sites, and the fact that it was spent by public companies, compounded the suspicion that people would not buy luxury goods online. The creators of boo.com dumped a reported $150 million into their site before closing it down in 2001, and LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton spent even more to introduce eluxury.com.

title: S.E.C. Puts 3 Hollinger Directors on Notice
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has notified three high-profile current and former directors of Hollinger International Inc. that they may be sued for failing to spot fraud that senior executives of the newspaper company are suspected of committing.

title: ABRAHAM LOOKING BEYOND JETS
description: John Abraham, the Jets' All-Pro defensive end, hopes to secure a long-term contract for next season, and it does not have to be with the Jets. Abraham, who is the team's top pass rusher with eight and a half sacks, was designated the franchise player last season and has a one-year, $6.7 million contract. He managed only two full seasons in five years, but he has played in all 13 games this season, after sitting out training camp.

title: Appreciating What Jets Have Lost
description: Hempstead, N.Y. - ALL of Curtis Martin's practice equipment was there. His Jets helmet, white jersey with the green No. 28, shoulder pads and two dozen black football shoes were in one locker. Five game balls, gray sweat pants, more shoulder pads, two dozen white football shoes and a blue box of chess pieces were in his adjacent locker. But yesterday he wasn't there.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trump Sued Over Commissions
description: Barbara Corcoran, below left, who founded the Corcoran Group, one of the city's best-known real estate firms, sued Donald J. Trump yesterday for nearly $1.3 million in commissions related to the developer's West Side project, once known as Riverside South or Trump Place. Ms. Corcoran and two brokers say Mr. Trump agreed to pay them a $4 million commission in 1994 for finding a group of Hong Kong investors to invest in his project. But Richard C. Seltzer, a lawyer for Ms. Corcoran, said Mr. Trump had paid only $2.7 million, despite the sale of the project this year for $1.76 billion. Mr. Trump, who is now suing his Hong Kong partners, called the suit a "ridiculous" publicity ploy by Ms. Corcoran, "who no one cares about."

title: Georgia Seeks Talks With Breakaway Region
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14 - President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia on Wednesday offered to meet with the leadership of the breakaway region of Abkhazia, seeking to begin talks on economic cooperation and development between what have been bitterly opposed sides.

title: Gadgets of the week:Don't sit still, do play
Common Marvels and Rare Finds
description: OF the thousands of design books published each year, what makes one worth giving? For me, the ideal is an obsessed author exploring underappreciated material, illuminating how spaces and objects are dreamed up and why they catch on. I also wish for practical and visionary decorating ideas, mixed with gossipy anecdotes about the eureka moments of inventors and the colorful lives of patrons. And, especially at this time of year, I crave imagery that transports the reader far from the slush and the madding crowds.

Plug In a U.S.B. Hub, Then Plug In a Lot More
description: With most devices using a U.S.B. connection to link to your computer, you can't have enough ports. Printers, digital cameras, camcorders, P.D.A.'s and iPods all need to connect to the computer to transfer data and, in some cases, power themselves. A U.S.B. hub allows using a single U.S.B. port to create additional links, so you can plug in all those devices at the same time.

title: U.S. Forces in Ramadi Leave Security to Iraqis to Raise Voter Turnout
description: RAMADI, Iraq, Dec. 14 - As participatory democracy has accelerated throughout much of Iraq this year, its failure to take hold here in the Sunni Arab heartland of western Iraq weighs heavily on this dangerous and broken town.

description: Leona Nevler, a prominent book editor who 50 years ago helped secure the publication of a first novel set in an imaginary town called Peyton Place, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. She was 79 and had homes in Manhattan and Westport, Conn.

title: It's No Longer Enough to Be Wireless. The Cellphone Elite Have Designer Headgear.
description: Bluetooth wireless technology will be in more than 140 million cellphones by the end of this year, according to IMS, a market research firm. And the leading Bluetooth accessory is the headset, with 32 million expected to be shipped this year.

Greenberg, the former chief executive of American International Group, contending that Mr. Greenberg unfairly enriched himself and other A.I.G. executives in a series of transactions that violated the will of Cornelius Vander Starr, the company's founder, and defrauded a foundation he created.

title: If There Is a Strike: A Guide to Commuting
description: Taxis, Car Services and Commuter Vans Vehicles will be permitted to pick up more than one passenger, using a zone fare system for maximum fares. Riders will be allowed to hail car services at bus stops with no bus service.

title: Trade Deficit Hits Record, Threatening U.S. Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - The United States' trade deficit ballooned to a record in October, the government said Wednesday, with imports climbing much faster than exports even though prices for imported oil declined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIND, EDNA (NEE LUNDAHL)
description: LIND--Edna (nee Lundahl). On December 11, 2005. Formerly of Lyric Opera and Metropolitan Opera. Known as Aunty Bun to her nephews Richard, Gene, Warren. We all love you Aunty Bun. Funeral Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, Thursday 2-5, 7-9 & Friday 2:30.

description: In percent

title: Act III, Scene 1 for a Sunset Strip Landmark
description: This Hollywood classic has been through more facelifts and name changes than many of the town's denizens. The Art Deco landmark, on Sunset Boulevard, designed in 1929 by the architect Leland A. Bryant, was popular with film industry glitterati for decades, first as the Sunset Tower Apartments, then as a hotel. It later fell on hard times and was rehabilitated in the late 80's as the St. James Club/L.A., and in the 90's as the Argyle hotel. Now it is under new ownership -- Jeff Klein, the owner of the City Club Hotel in New York -- and as of this month, it is the Sunset Tower Hotel. Mr. Klein commissioned the Los Angeles-based designer Paul Fortune to completely redo the interior, aiming for an understated elegance and comfort reminiscent of Hollywood hangouts of the 30's, 40's and 50's. "I loathe over-styled boutique hotels," Mr. Klein said.

title: Pataki Offers Liberty Bonds to Keep Tower on Schedule
description: Eager to ensure that construction begins on the Freedom Tower next year, Gov. George E. Pataki bypassed the city yesterday and announced that the state would provide the developer Larry A. Silverstein with $1.67 billion in Liberty Bonds for the project, the most visible symbol of both the rebuilding effort at ground zero and the governor's legacy.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) THE APPRENTICE -- It has been a busy season for Donald Trump's would-be apprentices. They designed a holiday parade float, put together a technology convention for the elderly and promoted a variety of products, including the newest "Star Wars" movie and a fragrance named for Shania Twain. In the two-hour finale, live from Lincoln Center, the two finalists (above) are Rebecca (who was almost eliminated early in the game when she went ice skating and broke her ankle) and Randal. There's a cast reunion too.

title: Moves at S.E.C. to Loosen Rules on Many Companies
description: In strong moves to reduce the burden of securities regulations, the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed rules yesterday to make it easier for foreign companies to get out from under such regulations, while an advisory panel put forward guidelines that would exempt 80 percent of American companies from having to comply fully with the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a European investigation of reports that American intelligence agents kidnapped people in European countries, detained them and illegally transported them across national borders omitted the contextual background of the investigator, Dick Marty, and his authority to conduct the inquiry. Mr. Marty, a Swiss senator, is chairman of the Committee on Legal Affairs and Human Rights of the Council of Europe, a 46-nation group based in Strasbourg, France, that functions as Europe's human rights monitor.

title: U.N. Debates Wider Inquiry Into Killings in Lebanon
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 14 - The Security Council struggled Wednesday night over a resolution extending the term of the United Nations investigation into the assassination of the former prime minister of Lebanon, Rafik Hariri, and expanding its scope to include other recent politically motivated killings in Lebanon.

title: Looking at Stars Beneath Their Glitter, or Hanging Celebrities With Their Own Ropes
description: Celebrities, not being all they're cracked up to be, can't quite rival the writers who come up with things for them to say onscreen. Their own literary devices prove rickety, laughably so on "Celebrity Autobiography: In Their Own Words."

title: Sandwich Chain Decides It's Time to Sell
description: Quiznos, the second-largest sandwich restaurant chain in the United States behind Subway, has a new item on its sale menu: itself.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman's Body Found Behind Theater
description: Workers at a movie theater on Coney Island Avenue came across a woman's body in a large oil drum in an alley behind the theater last night, the police said. The body, which was found about 8:15 p.m. near 1170 Coney Island Avenue, was partially wrapped in bedding, said one employee, an 18-year-old man who said his name was Kam. The woman was white and appeared to be in her 50's, the police said. Her identity and the cause of death remained unknown last night. MICHELLE O'DONNELL (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Charged With Racketeering
description: Two men reputed to be Genovese crime family figures were arrested yesterday on racketeering, loan-sharking and extortion conspiracy charges. Both men, Joseph Ida, 69, of Staten Island, and Anthony Conigliaro, 67, of Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. They were released on $500,000 bond and home detention. John Buretta, an assistant United States attorney, identified Mr. Ida as a captain in the crime family and Mr. Conigliaro as an acting captain. Mr. Conigliaro told the judge that he operated a cheesecake distribution company, making about $500 a week, in addition to his Social Security payments. James J. DiPietro, a lawyer for Mr. Ida, said the case was based in part on his client's conviction on state charges, for which he received probation in 2000.

title: Call It Stayman, but Think Marx
description: Several bidding conventions are eponymous. Examples are Blackwood, Gerber and Michaels Cue-Bids. But some conventions are misnamed. One example is Stayman, which was not invented by Sam Stayman.

description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14 - Ukraine announced on Wednesday that tests had confirmed that a potentially deadly strain of avian flu had established itself among birds in the Crimean Peninsula and that thousands of birds were being culled in an effort to contain the virus's spread.

Both victims had multiple slash wounds, apparently made by a machete, an investigator said, but did not appear to have been robbed.

description: HONG KONG, Dec. 14 - Trade ministers at global talks here said Wednesday that they had reached a broad agreement to limit government subsidies to the fishing industry, the first initiative raised by environmental groups that is expected to become part of new trade rules.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - The House voted Wednesday to renew the broad antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act, but opposition was growing in the Senate, where members of a bipartisan coalition predicted they would block the measure by filibuster when it comes up for consideration on Friday.

title: Old Images of Prostitutes in India are Newly Wrenching
description: "Picturesque" is what the West has called India for centuries. But when the American photographer Mary Ellen Mark started visiting in the 1960's, she didn't head for the Taj Mahal. She hung out on a jammed and noisy street in Bombay called Falkland Road, the city's busiest low-rent, red-light district.

title: Bush and McCain Reach Deal on Treatment of Terror Suspects
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 - The White House, after weeks of resistance, agreed today to Senator John McCain's call for a law specifically banning cruel or inhuman treatment of terror suspects anywhere in the world.

title: Getting Around, Made Easier

In yet another leap into the mainstream, G.P.S. technology, cheaper yet more sophisticated than ever, is increasingly finding its way into the palms of everyday users.

description: Hundreds of thousands of Gulf Coast families, hoping to rebuild their homes after the hurricanes using low-interest government loans, are facing high rejection rates and widespread delays at the federal agency that administers the disaster loan program.

title: Impasse on Agriculture Impedes Progress at Trade Talks
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 15 - Global trade talks here are making scant progress because of an impasse over agriculture, reinforcing worries that the negotiations may resolve little before ending on Sunday, trade ministers said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDOR, GYORGY
description: SANDOR - Gyorgy. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with great sadness the passing of the renowned pianist Gyorgy Sandor on Friday, December 9 in New York at the age of 93. Mr. Sandor was a highly valued member of our Steinway Artist family beginning in 1944; a sixty-one year association of which we are enormously proud. A native of Hungary, Mr. Sandor was a pupil of Bela Bartok and he championed the composer's works throughout his illustrious career, both in performance and in acclaimed recordings. He was a featured artist in Steinway & Sons' Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953, and his devotion to the Steinway piano and to our Company knew no bounds. In addition to his worldwide concert appearances, Mr. Sandor was a celebrated writer and teacher, whose gifted students represent an enduring legacy. He will be deeply missed. To his son Michael and to his family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities.
