description: The English designer Sir Paul Smith says that one of the big challenges in expanding his fashion and products empire is ensuring that each new store feels unique. His newly opened Los Angeles retail space in a 5,000-square-foot concrete box is painted pink to attract passing drivers. The large warehouse interior has wooden bow trusses and is divided into Hollywood-inspired "sets"; shown above right is part of the women's-wear collection contained in a white painted and paneled wooden interior from a French 18th-century house. Like all Paul Smith stores, the Los Angeles branch sells an eclectic array of found objects, from books on English pigs to vintage jewelry display cases. Paul Smith is at 8221 Melrose Avenue, (323) 951-4800. CURRENTS: LOS ANGELES -- STORES

title: Bias Seen in Expulsion at Greenwich Beach
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 14 - When the wives of two former Mets players and other members of their physical fitness group complained this spring that they were turned away from the town's beach, they charged that it was because they are black. The town's affirmative action officer investigated, but cleared Greenwich employees of wrongdoing by concluding that they were simply enforcing the rules.

title: General Dynamics to Acquire Information Systems Concern
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the military contractor, announced yesterday that it would acquire the Anteon International Corporation for $2.1 billion in a move by a company known for its warships and tanks to expand its technology services business.

Arts, Briefly; CBS Finishes Strong With 'Amazing Race'
description: The members of the Linz family are reality television's newest millionaires. On Tuesday's episode of "The Amazing Race," the athletic, toothy clan -- three brothers and a sister -- won the show's family edition. The two-hour conclusion of this eighth season drew an audience of 11.37 million in Nielsen's estimates and helped CBS win the night in total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds. Although that total represented this season's largest audience, it paled in comparison with ratings for the previous installment's finale, which delivered 16 million viewers. On Tuesday the first hour of "Race" was solidly beaten by Fox's "House" (14.52 million viewers) at 9 p.m., but was able to win the 10 p.m. hour among total viewers against a repeat "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" (11.14 million) on NBC and a new "Boston Legal" (9.92 million) on ABC. CBS's average was bolstered by its leadoff show, "NCIS," which brought in 16.77 million viewers. Fox placed a solid second for the night over all. KATE AURTHUR

title: Skin Deep; Mix It Up: Makeup for Any Skin and Any Mood
description: LAST week Kelly McMenamin, a 31-year-old financial analyst in New York, stopped into Henri Bendel for a new lip gloss to wear to holiday parties. Unwilling to settle for any of the ready-made lipsticks, which never seem to match her pale skin and light blond hair, she walked straight to the Giella Custom Blend Cosmetics counter. Maria Giella Poblocki, the makeup artist who created the brand in 2002, looked carefully at Ms. McMenamin's skin tones and decided a medium intensity gloss would complement her coloring best.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Major Suspect In Bombings Caught
description: Security forces in Dhaka captured Ataur Rahman, the suspected military commander of Jamaat-ul-Mujahedeen, the banned Islamist militant group blamed for a series of recent bombings and suicide attacks. He is a brother of the group's fugitive supreme leader, Sheik Abdur Rahman, and the authorities hailed the arrest as a breakthrough. The police said they also seized a large cache of weapons and explosives for about 300 bombs. DAVID MONTERO (NYT)

title: The Rock Star's Burden
description: Hale'iwa, Hawaii - THERE are probably more annoying things than being hectored about African development by a wealthy Irish rock star in a cowboy hat, but I can't think of one at the moment. If Christmas, season of sob stories, has turned me into Scrooge, I recognize the Dickensian counterpart of Paul Hewson -- who calls himself "Bono" -- as Mrs. Jellyby in "Bleak House." Harping incessantly on her adopted village of Borrioboola-Gha "on the left bank of the River Niger," Mrs. Jellyby tries to save the Africans by financing them in coffee growing and encouraging schemes "to turn pianoforte legs and establish an export trade," all the while badgering people for money.

title: Tapping Silver Toes and Heels
description: The two works that Compagnie Marie Chouinard from Montreal is offering this week at the Joyce Theater are very clearly the products of the same sensibility. They both use a complex, highly original movement style, indebted to all kinds of dance, Western and beyond. They are sexy and handsomely performed. They are clothed in glitzy costumes. I loved the first and was put off by the second.

title: White Sox to Strengthen Their Staff With Vazquez
description: The Chicago White Sox won the World Series in October because of a deep pitching staff that was the best in the major leagues. But White Sox officials felt they could fortify their superb staff even more, so yesterday they agreed to obtain Javier Vazquez from the Arizona Diamondbacks.

title: Colombia President Ready for Hostage Talks
description: With France, Spain and Switzerland offering mediation, Colombia has signaled that it is moving forward with a plan to demilitarize an area of Valle del Cauca Province as part of a prisoner exchange with leftist rebels that could free dozens of hostages, including three Americans and a former presidential candidate, Ingrid Betancourt. The rebels, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, have not yet responded. JUAN FORERO (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Labor Troubles at Washington Ballet
description: Labor issues at the Washington Ballet threaten to disrupt performances of "The Nutcracker." The dancers' union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, says overly strenuous rehearsals have exhausted and hurt the performers. "They are getting injured at an alarming rate," said Eleni Kallas, the union's local representative. The company canceled rehearsals on Tuesday and yesterday, but refused to sign an interim agreement proposed by the union. The company said that it had not suspended any performances and would try to resolve differences to avoid a strike. Without at least an interim agreement, Ms. Kallas said, the dancers plan to perform this morning for a group of students, but not during the evening as scheduled. Dancers are seeking a new contract with the company in an effort, they say, to protect their jobs, safety and health. Among other issues, dancers want more control over rehearsals and how management handles dismissals. The company canceled a tour of Italy this year in a dispute related to per-diem allowances for the dancers to pay for meals. The company's production of "The Nutcracker" is scheduled to run through Dec. 24 at the Warner Theater. JOHN FILES

title: House Supports Ban On Detainee Abuses

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: 4 Men Are Shot In Boston
description: Four young men were shot to death Monday night in one of Boston's worst acts of violence in a decade. The men were in a basement that contained recording equipment in a house in the Dorchester neighborhood of Boston. The police identified two of the victims as Edwin Duncan, 21, who lived in the house, and Jihad Chankhour, 22, of Wakefield, Mass. The others' identities were not released. The city has had 71 killings this year, the highest number in 10 years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Suspect In U.S. Jihad Camp Held
description: American authorities have announced the arrest in Prague on Sunday of Oussama Kassir, a Swede of Lebanese descent accused of conspiring to create a camp in Bly, Ore., in 1999 to train fighters for jihad. He is accused of working with Abu Hamza al-Masri, a radical Islamic cleric based in Britain, to set up the camp. According to a complaint unsealed Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Kassir traveled from London through New York to Oregon in November 1999. He said he was a "hit man" for Mr. Masri and complained that there were not enough recruits to make the Oregon camp worthwhile, the complaint said. The United States is seeking to extradite him, as well as Mr. Masri and a third suspect, Haroon Aswat, from Britain. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

title: A Mellow Weinstein
description: Liz Smith finds Harvey Weinstein in a happy circumstance, having already garnered eight Golden Globe nominations for his fledging Weinstein Co.. And she notices that Harvey seems to have, once again, mellowed. Of his new life, the once-derailed, terrible-tempered Mr. Big of independents, says, I am calmer, better. After almost three years of soap opera with my previous business partners, I am feeling the excitement of a fantastic freedom. Disneys Bob Iger and I have a wonderful relationship. The pressures down. And I think even the people who work for me every day would say Im in a less tumultuous frame of mind.

title: Christmas in Santa Fe
description: Lit by the flickering light of farolitos, Sante Fe becomes a magical place at Christmas.

title: Only the Rich May Rebuild?
description: Leslie Eaton and Ron Nixon report into todays Times that hundreds of thousands of low-income homeowners have been rejected for government loans to help them rebuild their homes destroyed by the hurricanes earlier this year. It seems the class divisions that were exposed so dramatically when the hurricanes hit are in danger of being exacerbated: the loans that have been approved appear to be going to wealthy New Orleans neighborhoods, but not the poor ones. MOTOKO RICH

title: Smog Doesnt Just Come From Cars
description: The clean air police are turning their attention from the auto makers to builders. According to the L.A. Times, regulators in Californias Center Valley are today expected to begin dinging homebuilders whose developments encourage auto use. Clearly, regulators are starting to recognize the direct connection between suburban sprawl, increased auto use and more air pollution.Now, all we have to do is persuade Cameron Diaz to buy a smog-free house to go with her Toyota Prius, the hybrid vehicle that is sweeping Hollywood. MOTOKO RICH

title: Open Space Thats On the Ground
description: A drive through Miami quickly pegs it as a fast-growing high-rise town. The condo boom has created a large crop of sky-kissing towers that some critics say are starting to cut off views of the beach. A Miami Herald article says the City Commission will today vote to eliminate a loophole that allows developers to meet a requirement to include open space by building roofdecks with some shade.

title: At the Polls in Iraq
description: Iraqi officials said that initial indications were that as many as 11 million people cast ballots to elect a Parliament.

description: Beware of articles beginning: When I was boy . . . This is a sign that a bout of nostalgia is about to begin, or a warning that some aspect of the modern world is about to be ranted against. Perish the thought.

description: CLARK--Selden "Sully" B. Former Senior VP at N.W. Ayer died Monday, December 12, in Scottsdale, AZ. Mr. Clark is survived by his sons Selden of Houston, TX and Randall of Scottsdale, AZ. Donations in lieu of flowers can be sent to Nassau Hockey c/o Doug Farr 109 Stony Brook Rd. Hopewell, NJ 08525.

title: China reports 6th human bird flu case

Finding the Perfect Tree Can Become a Perfect Outing
description: WHEN Diane Wahl accepted Raymond Azzaro's invitation to choose a Christmas tree, she didn't know that for aficionados "choose a tree" is a rigorous branch of shopping. She spent hours tripping through snow-covered hills in spike-heeled suede boots and a thin jacket. But she maintained her enthusiasm, and on a recent Sunday, 24 years and 24 trees later, long married to Mr. Azzaro and now more comfortably clothed, she was at the same tree farm again, presiding over the annual Azzaro family tree-choosing tailgate party.

Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 - Months after the Sept. 11 attacks, President Bush secretly authorized the National Security Agency to eavesdrop on Americans and others inside the United States to search for evidence of terrorist activity without the court-approved warrants ordinarily required for domestic spying, according to government officials.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8:30 P.M. (11) A SCOOBY DOO CHRISTMAS -- Scooby and the gang, above, come across a depressing little town called Winter Hollow, where everybody dreads Christmas. That's when a headless snowman arrives every year and destroys people's houses. Understandably their holiday spirit is also damaged. In this new animated special, Scooby's friends decide to spend Christmas Eve at the local inn and try to solve the mystery. The likelihood of success is very high.

title: Soccer: French club snatches UEFA knockout place as holders bow out
Paid Notice: Deaths   ROIPHE, HERMAN, MD.
description: ROIPHE--Herman, MD. Born January 10, 1924. Died December 14, 2005. Psychiatrist and psychoanalyst. Es teemed clinician, author and researcher in infant psychiatry, longtime member of NY Psychoanalytic Institute and faculty member of Mt. Sinai School of Medicine. Beloved husband of Anne. Devoted father of Margaret, Jean, Emily, Katherine and Rebecca. Cherished grandfather of Daniel, Zachary, Rachel, Violet and Ella. Services Friday 12:45 PM at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Price Index Shows Big November Drop
description: The nation's chief measure of inflation, the Consumer Price Index, fell by six-tenths of a percent in November, the biggest monthly drop since the Truman administration, but that did not diminish expectations that the Federal Reserve will continue to raise interest rates at least through early next year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Unidentified Dead Woman Was Strangled
description: A woman in her 50's whose body was discovered in a cardboard shipping container near a Brooklyn movie theater on Wednesday night was strangled, the medical examiner's office said yesterday. An employee of the Kent Theater, at 1170 Coney Island Avenue, called the police shortly about 8 p.m. after glimpsing a woman's foot when trying to move a heavy container. The body was nude and covered with a blanket, the police said. Shadi Rahimi (NYT)

title: Taking the Kids, Guided by Gut and Guesswork
description: For some time now, in addition to fulfilling the requirements of my day job, I have been moonlighting as an unpaid parenting consultant, on perpetual call to deal with a rather specialized but nonetheless urgent concern. Movie reviews are written for -- and despite occasional appearances to the contrary, by -- grown-ups, which means they don't always contain the information some adult readers want most. And so, through phone calls, e-mail and occasional grocery-store checkout-line buttonholing, I am continually tapped for what my friends and acquaintances seem to believe will be expert advice. Can I take my 10-year-old to "King Kong"? they want to know. Will my daughter like "The Chronicles of Narnia"? Should I bring the kids along to see "The Squid and the Whale"?

title: Art in Review; Clifford Ross
description: Sonnabend 536 West 22nd Street, Chelsea Through Dec. 21

title: Ohno Leaves Competition Behind at the Olympic Trials
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Dec. 15 - Four laps from the end of the men's 1,000-meter speedskating competition at the Olympic trials Thursday night, Apolo Ohno made the kind of move that flummoxes his American competitors. Rounding a turn, Ohno powered through several strokes, leaving his previously close pursuers staring at an empty track ahead of them. He was instantly a quarter of a lap ahead.

title: Getting a Jump on New Year's Eve
description: CHAMPAGNE in a fabulous party space or a bottle of Bud in a rock club? Dinner in elegant surroundings or a frosty run in Central Park? Times Square or your easy chair? The myriad choices for New Year's Eve entertainment in New York can leave the most decisive reveler befuddled. For those whose plans are still up in the air, seven critics and reporters of The New York Times suggest itineraries involving clubs, restaurants, theaters and, yes, Central Park:

title: China, parched and polluted, puts a price on water
Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, SANFORD
description: FRIEDMAN--Sanford, 79. On December 13, 2005. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Betty; his three children, Steven, Kathy and Richard; and his brother, Arnold, as well as his four grandchildren, Chanel, Kristina, Alex and Andy. He lived in Boca Raton, FL following his retirement from his position as a textile industry executive in 1989. A great husband, father and grandfather, and a dedicated family man who will be deeply missed. The family will be available for visitation from Saturday through Tuesday, December 17-20 at 87 Centre Street, Woodmere, NY for those wishing to share their memories of a life well lived. Funeral services will be held on Monday, December 19 at 11:30 AM at The Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY (516295-3100). Donations can be made in Sandy's name to the American Cancer Society.

title: Drawing investors back to Africa
The Listings: Dec. 16 -- Dec. 22; JOHN WATERS CHRISTMAS WITH THE TRACHTENBERG FAMILY SLIDESHOW PLAYERS AND KIMYA DAWSON
description: The filmmaker John Waters has always found warmth and joy in the profane. In his garish films like "Pink Flamingoes" and "Hairspray," he has also shown a keen instinct for finding the sweet spot where rock and schlock merge in ecstatic, trashy musical expression. It should come as no surprise that his antidote for depression surrounding this season's rampant commercial greed is to revel in its excesses -- and to subvert its pieties. This year, he has put together a live musical revue inspired by the wonderfully weird songs on his new collection of scavenged holiday nuggets, "A John Waters Christmas" (New Line). The director himself will be on hand offering his insight and reactions to songs like a Baltimore DJ's local hit "Fat Daddy (Is Santa Claus)," as well as a vanity recording of "Happy Birthday Jesus" by someone named Little Cindy, and the novelty cut "Santa Claus Is a Black Man" by AKIM & the Teddy Vann Production Company. Joining Mr. Waters in his celebration are two perfect co-conspirators. The Trachtenberg Family Slideshow Players -- the father, mother and daughter act (above, from left, Tina Pia Trachtenberg, Rachel Pia Trachtenberg and Jason Trachtenberg) who are performing their own holiday send-up, from Dec.18 to Dec. 23 at Performance Space 122 -- will sprint over from that earlier gig to add their hipster family values to Mr. Waters's mix. The singer-songwriter Kimya Dawson, who, with her erstwhile band, the Moldy Peaches, used to dress in a bunny suit, has often posited the worldly wisdom of children. Aside from her own always quirky adult musings, she brings to this wacky assemblage her distinctive insight into the minds of little misfits. (Wednesday at 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111; $35 in advance, $40 at the door.)

title: Time to Drop the Cellphone and Pick Up a Casserole
description: All happy families resemble one another, Tolstoy famously wrote, and each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way, but Tolstoy didn't know the Stones, who are happy in a Hollywood kind of way and unhappy in a self-help kind of way. This tribe of ravenous cannibals bares its excellent teeth at anyone who doesn't accommodate the family's preening self-regard. Its most recent target is Meredith Morton, an executive played by Sarah Jessica Parker, who probably hopes to marry into the clan, little realizing that this will leave no Stone unturned and all aimed straight at her head.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Arms Smuggler Sentenced
description: A Yonkers man was sentenced to 40 months in federal prison yesterday for shipping weapons to the island of Mindanao in the Philippines, the United States attorney, Michael Garcia, announced. The man, Fernando Sero, 40, pleaded guilty to violating the arms export control act on June 29. Prosecutors said that Mr. Sero smuggled assault rifles and ammunition by disassembling them and hiding them in containers with household goods. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents intercepted a shipment containing weapons parts in March.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,148 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Singing Between the Beats, as Her Band Reads Between the Lines
description: It's not for nothing that the jazz singer Tierney Sutton and her longtime trio -- the bassist Kevin Axt, the drummer Ray Brinker and the extraordinary pianist Christian Jacob -- like to think of themselves as the Tierney Sutton Band. Unlike most jazz ensembles, in which the players take turns stretching out, these four exceptionally communicative musicians collectively shape every song into an integrated musical whole.

description: KOHLMAN--Alice E. (nee Rosenfeld). Gone Snoopin' on December 14, 2005 at age 92. Predeceased by husband, Lawrence Whitehead and son, Lawrence M. Survived by daughter Nancy K. Freeman (Peter), three grandchildren and five great grandchildren.

title: Casino Partner Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15 - A former business partner of Jack Abramoff, the former Washington lobbyist at the center of a sweeping corruption investigation, pleaded guilty on Thursday to conspiracy and fraud charges involving his purchase of a casino boat fleet with Mr. Abramoff in 2000.

title: The Listings: Dec. 16 -- Dec. 22; 'BINGO'
description: Over the last few years, theater producers -- especially on Broadway -- have increasingly aped their counterparts in film, adapting beloved movies, casting Hollywood stars and incorporating computer technology into their designs. But there are still some things that are considered too lowbrow for even the Great White Way. Sequels, for example. Revivals may be a theater staple, but don't ever expect to see "Death of a Salesman II: Biff Strikes Back" on a midtown marquee. Selling popcorn is another no-no. Despite being a profit center for the movie business, popcorn is frowned on by theater people because of its loud, crunching sound, as well as the difficulty of cleaning the kernels off the floor. But those aren't the only reasons that most producers and owners ignore this potentially lucrative concession: according to several Broadway insiders, theater would sacrifice a certain snob appeal if ticket-buyers were licking the butter off their fingertips in the middle of the second act. But some theater owners are starting slowly to change their ways. Since the beginning of the fall, the Brooklyn Academy of Music has sold popcorn in the lobby, but not allowed ticket buyers to bring it into the theater. And in the production of "Bingo," an Off Broadway musical about a clique of ladies (above, from left, Liz Larsen; Liz McCartney; Janet Metz, seated; and Klea Blackhurst) dead serious about the game, every audience member receives a bag, making this otherwise forgettable show perhaps the first popcorn musical in the history of New York. (St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200.)

title: King Kong doesn'tdestroy just any old town
Corrections
description: The Shikabe Journal article on Tuesday, about Japan's effort to merge small towns like the fishing village of Shikabe on northern Hokkaido island, misidentified Japan's main island, which is to be linked to Hokkaido via a bullet train extension. It is Honshu, not Kyushu.

title: Inspectors Examine Damaged Gas Line
description: Investigators examining the explosion and fire at an apartment building in Bergenfield, N.J., that killed three people and left at least 75 others homeless or displaced started to examine a nearby excavation site yesterday where a gas line was damaged when the walls of the hole collapsed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, HERBERT S.
description: ADLER--Herbert S., 63. Undaunted by the vicissitudes of life, Herbert Adler flourished. He selflessly gave of himself to scores of friends, family members, coworkers and even random people he happened to meet in delis, dry cleaners, and fancy balls. His untimely passing leaves a void that can only be filled by knowing how many people carry his love in their hearts forever. He was a prominent businessman, tireless philanthropist, and patron of the arts. The Adler family will try very hard to continue to live by his example. Contributions may be sent to The Adler Family Fund for the History of Art at Williams College, c/o Diana Elvin, 75 Park Street, Williamstown, MA. 01267.

title: Culpepper Among 4 Vikings Charged Over Cruise Boat Allegations
description: SPRING PARK, Minn., Dec. 15 - Four Minnesota Vikings players, including the three-time Pro Bowl quarterback Daunte Culpepper, were charged Thursday with lewd and lascivious conduct during the team's now-infamous Oct. 6 cruise on Lake Minnetonka.

title: 36 Hours in Houston
description: THAT'S right -- you're not from Texas. It's O.K. According to Lyle Lovett, Texas wants you anyway. On the other hand, however, there's long been little love returned for Houston, the state's biggest city and the nation's fourth largest. Houston doesn't have a clear-cut positive reputation, like Austin (the laid-back slacker capital), or even a good nickname, like Dallas (Big D). As far as most of the country is concerned, it's got Enron and robber baron oilmen and heavy people, all in a climate requiring enough air-conditioning to power a rocket ship to Neptune. But Houston also has extraordinary museums, an innovative alternative arts and hip-hop scene, a rapidly growing cache of upscale hotels and haute cuisine and the neighborliness to take in tens of thousands of people displaced by Hurricane Katrina. And, of course, it has rocket ships; that is, NASA's Johnson Space Center. In the end, maybe that's what makes Houston such an unusual and wonderful place -- there are so many different Houstons to see.

title: As Winter Sets In, Some Coaches May Soon Be Out in the Cold
description: Not long after the regular season ends, coaching changes in the National Football League will begin.

title: Jets' Martin Says Operation Was a Success
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 15 - Curtis Martin walked to his locker Thursday afternoon, a trail of reporters on his heels, as if it were merely another day at the office.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged In Electronics Swindle
description: A Manhattan man who the police said posed as a Best Buy manager to swindle would-be electronics buyers, has been charged with fraud, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, announced yesterday. In a statement, Mr. Brown said that the man, Michael Ballister, 50, of 418 Central Park West, contacted small business owners in Queens and offered deep discounts on electronics including plasma television sets and computers. Mr. Brown said that Mr. Ballister met the owners at a local Best Buy, asked them to select the items, collected cash and after telling them he would meet them at the loading dock, absconded with the money.

title: Push to Rescue Met Recordings
description: In a Metropolitan Opera House studio jumbled with tapes and 16-inch lacquer discs one day last week, nine of the most famous high C's ever sung shot out from the throat of Luciano Pavarotti. It was the recording of a live, broadcast performance of Donizetti's "Fille du Rgiment," at the Met on Jan. 6, 1973.

title: Heathrow rations fuel because of oil depot fire
Deeper Fixes at the Red Cross
description: Another disaster and yet another president of the American Red Cross has resigned. It's starting to feel as if every time a major catastrophe strikes, the Red Cross is roundly criticized and the top dog steps down. Then the organization continues as it did before, with business as usual and no significant reforms.

title: News Analysis: A Russia-Ukraine game of chicken
HAVENS | Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.; The Latest 'It' Destination in Southeast Florida
description: WHEN you talk to people who have recently bought homes in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., it's inevitable that they will liken their town to some better-known fun-in-the-sun South Florida city. For Jeff Wallner, 38, a Philadelphia furniture-company representative who owns a vacation home in the Gardens, it was Boca Raton. "I think you're seeing Palm Beach Gardens become Boca-ized," he said.

On the other hand, however, there's long been little love returned for Houston, the state's biggest city and the nation's fourth largest. Houston doesn't have a clear-cut positive reputation, like Austin (the laid-back slacker capital), or even a good nickname, like Dallas (Big D). title: This time, banks hit in Tokyo trade error
Paid Notice: Deaths   FREIDSON, ELIOT
description: FREIDSON--Eliot died December 14th at the Laguna Grove Zen Hospice in San Francisco. He leaves his wife, Helen Giambruni, his children, Jane and Matthew Freidson, daughter in-law RachelBurr, grandchildren Sam, Molly, Charlie and Conrad, and sisters Adele Feldman and Ruth Kavesh. A distinguished Professor and writer on the Sociology of professions Eliot was a pioneer in the field of Medical Sociology. He was Professor Emeritus at NYU, and the author of numerous books including the award winning "Profession of Medicine". Contributions in his honor may be sent to Electronic Frontier Foundation, Doctors Without Borders or Human Rights Watch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROMAN, MIRIAM
description: ROMAN--Miriam. Age 75, died peacefully after a more than ten-year valiant struggle with the debilitating Multiple Sclerosis disease. Despite the illness that took away one kidney and put her in a wheelchair for the past five years, Miriam refused to give in to the disease, and she insisted on spending time with her friends and family at restaurants, Broadway shows, and visiting ill people.Whether she was having lunch with Donald Trump or just talking with the janitor cleaning her room, she treated all good people with the ultimate respect and courtesy. She was the "Rock of Gibraltor" guiding her beloved sons Steve and Larry through severe asthma, numerous broken bones and every other problem they encountered. She was selfless, being a dutiful wife, raising two boys while working full time with no help. She also cared for her elderly parents, who moved to the house next door so she could better aid them. Her friends and family loved her and visited her right up to the end, and they know she would have done the same for them. She is survived by her children Steve, Larry, Julia and Kathy, and her grandchildren Mark, Amy, Carly, Jordanna and Faryn.

title: House Votes for 698 Miles of Fences on Mexico Border
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 - House Republicans voted on Thursday night to toughen a border security bill by requiring the Department of Homeland Security to build five fences along 698 miles of the United States border with Mexico to block the flow of illegal immigrants and drugs into this country.

description: Court Rejects Judgment Against 'Light' Cigarettes The Supreme Court of Illinois threw out a $10 billion judgment against Philip Morris USA in a class-action suit that had accused the company of deceiving smokers in a campaign for its "light" cigarettes with lower levels of tar and nicotine.

An Ill Wind Off Cape Cod
description: AS an environmentalist, I support wind power, including wind power on the high seas. I am also involved in siting wind farms in appropriate landscapes, of which there are many. But I do believe that some places should be off limits to any sort of industrial development. I wouldn't build a wind farm in Yosemite National Park. Nor would I build one on Nantucket Sound, which is exactly what the company Energy Management is trying to do with its Cape Wind project.

title: Former Brooklyn Democratic Leader Convicted Again
description: Clarence Norman Jr., the former Brooklyn Democratic chief and state assemblyman, was found guilty of larceny yesterday for putting a $5,000 check made out to his Assembly campaign into a personal account. It was his second consecutive conviction on corruption charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, ANITA S.
description: GOODMAN--Anita S. On December 11, 2005. Devoted mother of Meredith Bernstein, Jane Pollak, Barbara Raho and Andy Goodman. Adoring grandmother to Lindsey, Robert and Laura Pollak; Nick, Joe and Emily Raho; and Daniel and Olivia Goodman. Loving wife of the late Larry Goodman for more than 50 years. All who knew her will agree there was only one Anita. Her indomitable spirit will be with us always. Funeral services were held on December 13 at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains, NY.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Court Sets One-Year Deadline For Schools
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that the General Assembly had failed to raise the public school system to the level that the State Constitution and court mandates required and ordered corrections by next December. The court did not specify the steps but noted that the legislature had failed to increase per pupil spending this year and had appropriated less than 10 percent of $1.9 billion in agreed-on capital improvements for schools. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

title: The Rush to Renew the Patriot Act
description: Four years ago the Patriot Act was hurriedly passed before anyone had a full grasp of its potential to infringe on citizens' rights. Lawmakers argued that 9/11 had made quick action to expand the government's surveillance and investigative powers essential. But key parts of the law were written with expiration dates so Congress could reconsider them when there was more time. Now the time for thoughtful deliberation has arrived and Congress is once again in a rush -- this time to go home for the holiday recess.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHBEIN, EDWARD
description: FISHBEIN--Edward. 86, died December 15th in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Born in Brooklyn, he graduated from Boys High and USC. He served as a captain in the US Army for five years during WW II. He owned and operated Foam Products, Inc. and the Empire Staple Corp in the Bronx, NY. He was a longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY, Stamford, CT, and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. An accomplished golfer, he was a member of Elmwood, Rockrimmon and High Ridge Country Clubs. He is survived by his loving wife of 24 years, Anita Haims Fishbein; children Matt Fishbein, Janet Cohen and Nancy Fishbein; stepchildren Steven Haims, Daniel Haims and Cathie Caccia; and 12 grandchildren. He was married for 33 years to the late Ruth Goldman Fishbein, who died in 1980. A memorial celebration will be held on January 15 in Palm Beach Gardens. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to The Brooklyn Youth Chorus, The Nature Conservancy of CO, and Hospice of Palm Beach.

The voting, which comes six weeks ahead of crucial parliamentary elections, was a considerable blow to the Fatah faction, which has dominated the Palestinian Authority but has fractured in the year since the death of Yasir Arafat.

Arts, Briefly; Bobby Fischer's Stuff At Auction on eBay
description: Chess enthusiasts eager to own a bit of the game's history have a unique opportunity, at least for a few more days. Someone is selling several personal effects of Bobby Fischer, the former world champion, on eBay. Most of the collection (one example, above), according to the list on the site, consists of chess books and magazines, many of them foreign, some of them inscribed by Mr. Fischer with his name. Also included are an original manuscript for Mr. Fischer's "My 60 Memorable Games"; 20 small handwritten notebooks detailing the openings played by some of his top competitors; and legal papers surrounding his attempt to copyright a chess move. In all, the seller says, the trove includes about 16 cardboard boxes full of material. The minimum bid is $15,000, and at least one has been received, from the Netherlands. The auction, which started last Friday, ends on Monday. The seller said the material was bought at a flea market six years ago and evidently came from a storage locker that Mr. Fischer rented in Pasadena, Calif. The contents were seized for nonpayment of rent. Mr. Fischer went into a tirade about it several years ago in a radio interview with a Philippines radio station, saying the seizure was illegal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, JEROME B.
description: GROSS--Jerome B. Merrill Lynch mourns the passing on December 12 of Jerry Gross, whose 59-year career at Merrill Lynch took him from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange to a seat on the firm's board of directors. Jerry loved his work and loved to help others. He was a friend to all, and his colleagues and clients were like family to him. A veteran of World War II, he began his Merrill Lynch career on September 20, 1946, as an account executive in the sales office at 70 Pine Street. In 1951, he was recalled to the Army during the Korean War and returned to the firm 18 months later. In 1966 he was named head floor broker on the floor of the American Stock Exchange and that same year was elected to the board of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. Nine years later, he was appointed head floor broker for all of the firms' brokers on the floors of the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange, the CBOE, as well as the Midwest, Pacific Coast and Philadelphia Stock Exchanges. A piano player, jazz lover and Yankees fan, he kept himself in good shape by playing singles tennis three times a week and walking everywhere. He worked nearly to the end, making the walk to his office on 53rd Street daily from his home on 57th Street. He is survived by his wife, Barbara - Ruth Thackston Gross; and three daughters by his first wife Alexandra: Marjorie Steinman, of Albany; Jill Gross-Marks, of Manhattan and Ellen Gross Polkes, of Scarsdale. Funeral services will be held on Friday, December 16, at 9:30 a.m., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Washington: Criticizing President In Delay Case
description: Two leading Congressional Democrats pounced on President Bush's statement that Representative Tom DeLay, who stepped aside as House majority leader after having been indicted on criminal charges, was not guilty. The White House called the remark "presidential prerogative." The Democratic leaders in the House and the Senate said Mr. Bush was inserting himself into an investigation. The House minority leader, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, said, "I don't know what the president knows," adding that it would be interesting to know "what the president knows, what he knows about Mr. DeLay, what he knows about the Plame case." SHERYL GAY STOLBERG (NYT)

title: A Studio for the Coolest Guy in the Room
description: LIVE large. Vent large. David Lee Roth, attired in several layers of urban black outerwear and very much at home in this penthouse suite at the W New York hotel, is doing both. And no, that's not the air-conditioning that's inexplicably cranked up: He has, on purpose, left the door to the patio wide open to admit the frigid evening air. Bracing! Similar to a large dose of him.

title: Show Proves Less Knicks Is More, More or Less

But there is one way to mitigate all that turnover-borne ineptitude: "Knicks in 60," the MSG Network's edited, stripped-down, hourlong version of a full-length, two-and-a-half-hour broadcast. title: High Sunni Turnout Suggests a Deal for an Election Day Truce

title: Arts, Briefly; Warrior Writers
description: Random House will publish "Above and Beyond," an anthology of fiction, nonfiction and poetry written by members of the United States military who served in Iraq and Afghanistan since 9/11 and by members of their families, in September. The anthology grew out of Operation Homecoming, a project of the National Endowment for the Arts, which from April 2004 through July 2005 sent prominent authors to 24 domestic and overseas military installations to work with troops and their families on writings about their wartime experiences. The collection will be edited by Andrew Carroll, founder of the Legacy Project, an effort to seek out and save wartime letters of armed services members. The Legacy Project resulted in two books published by Scribner, "Behind the Lines" and "War Letters."

title: The Listings: Dec. 16 -- Dec. 22; COMPOSERS AND CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: Dance and music are (mostly) inextricably linked, yet students of both art forms often have little to do with one another, even when they are studying at the same school. Thirteen years ago, Juilliard decided to do something about that and asked aspiring choreographers and composers to create short works together, to be performed at a lunchtime concert, open to all, but mostly attended by students and friends. This year, the school is offering two additional free evening performances, giving a bigger audience the opportunity to find out whether another Stravinsky-Balanchine pairing is in the making. "Music and dance are created together in every culture except ours," said Pia Gilbert, the music division supervisor of the project. "What the students tend to find out is that we use some of the same means of expression, even if our instruments are quite different." The 12 students work together for two weeks -- playing music and dancing for one another -- before pairing off. Then they spend about two months making a six-minute work. "Six minutes is not an insignificant amount of time for students to get a real sense of how an idea can come to fruition," said Elizabeth Keen, the dance division overseer. Laura Careless (above with Andrew Murdock), a third-year dancer who is collaborating with Jonathan Keren, a post-graduate composition student, said: "To work with a composer so closely has really been eye-opening. If you understand another kind of process, it can help you find ways of working that you wouldn't necessarily find on your own." (Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Peter J. Sharp Theater, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, (212) 799-5000.)

title: Around the World: Irish photos

Arts, Briefly; Washington Ballet's 'Nutcracker' Is Canceled
description: The Washington Ballet canceled last night's and tonight's performances of "The Nutcracker" after negotiations with dancers and their union over a new contract ended without an agreement. More talks were not planned, the company and the union said, putting further performances in doubt. The dancers have said they will not perform without a new contract. The executive director of the ballet, Jason Palmquist, told the union that the ballet was not willing to negotiate under the threat of a strike, which he said would be "profoundly devastating not only for the entire institution, but also for the community and for the families and friends of our performers." He added, "We have been negotiating with the dancers in good faith and wish for those conversations to continue." The dancers' union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, contends that the dancers have not declared a strike and had also sought to continue negotiations. Dancers, who performed "The Nutcracker" since Dec. 1, are seeking a new contract with the company in an effort, they say, to protect their jobs, safety and health. They want more control over the scheduling of rehearsals and performances and how management handles dismissals. "The Nutcracker," which makes more money than any other show for the company, was scheduled to run through Dec. 24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRIST, PETER CHRISTOPHER
description: KRIST--Peter Christopher. Age 86, of Westport, CT, died Wednesday, December 14, 2005 at his home. He was the husband of 59 years of Vede Makarion Krist. Born in Ansonia, CT August 23, 1919, Mr. Krist was the son of the late Nicholas and Marianne (Vasil) Krist and was a longtime Westport resident. He graduated magna cum laude in Psychology from Dartmouth College, Class of 1942 and was a veteran of WW II, having served in the U.S. Army Air Force, discharged honorably as a Major. Mr. Krist was retired from the ExxonMobil Corp. where he had been senior V.P. of Employee Relations and was a member of the Board of Directors. He was also on the Board of Directors for the WestportWeston United Way, United Way of Tri-State, National Society to Prevent Blindness, Citizens Crime Comm. of N.Y. City and the Regional Plan Assn. He was also a member of the Business Advocacy Council for the NAACP Special Contribution Fund, the Commerce and Industry Council for the National Urban League, Inc., Labor Management Commission for the National Council on Alcoholism and was a Trustee for the John E. Gray Institute. Survivors also include two sons; David Peter Krist and his wife Stephanie of Weston, CT and Robert Peter Krist and his wife Candice of New Canaan, CT, five grandchildren, Alexandra, Nicole, Peter, Spencer and Geoffrey Krist and several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by a sister, Katherine Benas. Funeral services will be held Saturday, December 17, 10 AM at Saint Barbara Greek Orthodox Church, 480 Racebrook Rd, Orange, CT with entombment to follow at Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport, CT. A 40-Day Memorial service will follow at the same church on January 22, 2006 at 10:45 AM with a repast to be offered at the church afterward. There are no visiting hours. For info: The Magner Funeral Home, Norwalk, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be directed to the Alzheimer's Association, 607 Main Avenue, Norwalk, CT 06851.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In Attempted Rape
description: A judge sentenced a Brooklyn man, Ralph Gardella, 36, to 23 years in prison yesterday, after telling him that his drug and mental health problems were no excuse for attempting to rape and murder a 74-year-old retired actress in her SoHo apartment. The actress, who was not identified, left her apartment door ajar last July to let fresh air in, and Mr. Gardella entered and attacked her. Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan dismissed Mr. Gardella's apology as "crocodile tears," saying that "apologies are very big in this millennium." She said Mr. Gardella's lawyer's plea that he needed therapy was "an insult to people who suffer from mental illness." Anemona Hartocollis (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; A Stripper Leads CBS To a Ratings Victory
description: Without a new episode of ABC's "Lost" on Wednesday's schedule, CBS's all-original lineup overwhelmed its network competition. Its "CSI: New York" was the night's most-watched program, according to Nielsen estimates. The forensic crime show, in which a stripper was murdered after wrestling a customer in a vat of lubricant, delivered an audience of 16.13 million. That total was nearly matched by "Criminal Minds," the CBS mystery that preceded it, as the Mandy Patinkin series drew 15.3 million viewers. The network's only weak spot on Wednesdays is during the 8 p.m. hour. Its comedies "Still Standing" (7.48 million) and "Yes, Dear" (6.86 million) lost to ABC's combination of "George Lopez" (7.17 million) and "Freddie" (7.59 million) among adults 18 to 49. And though CBS won the hour in total viewers, it barely beat both ABC and NBC's rerun of "E-Ring" (7.33 million).

title: The Listings: Dec. 16 -- Dec. 22; TIM BERNE'S PARAPHRASE
description: There may not be a jazz musician more in tune with the notion of rugged individualism than the alto saxophonist and composer Tim Berne. More than 25 years ago, Mr. Berne released the first album on Empire, his own label. He has trafficked in the above-ground music industry since then -- recording for the Polygram imprint JMT, and, more fleetingly, Columbia Records -- but nothing seems to satisfy him more than self-reliance. Since 1996, Mr. Berne has channeled his autonomy through Screwgun Records, which he runs out of a brownstone in Brooklyn. The label faithfully mirrors its founder's ethos of hardscrabble abstraction: until recently, Screwgun CD's came in industrial brown cardboard, with graffiti-like scribbles by the graphic artist Steve Byram. "Pre-emptive Denial," the label's 16th release, bears more colorful packaging but leaves the music raw; its source material was a bootleg of Mr. Berne's band Paraphrase, performing in the East Village just seven months ago. Dividing evenly into two 25-minute tracks, the album follows the sort of wide exploratory arc that has long typified Mr. Berne's compositional voice. The catch is that Paraphrase is a free-improvising trio, shaped as much by the sensibilities of Drew Gress, the bassist, and Tom Rainey, the drummer, (above left, with Mr. Berne, center, and Mr. Gress). Appearing in Mr. Berne's native Park Slope next week, the musicians will see their work supplemented with spontaneously arranged projections by Mr. Byram and another artist, Jonathon Rosen. This cross-disciplinary experiment could succeed or fail; either way, it should jibe with Mr. Berne's intrepid ideals. (Wednesday at 8 and 10 p.m., Barbes, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177; cover, $8. www.screwgunrecords.com)

title: How Much Did They Spend?
description: Most cities are posting real estate information online. These sites arent just for the chronically nosey  and who hasnt had an urge to find out what an office mate paid for his McMansion?  but for those doing some solid research before buying or selling a home.The model for every city government is the Portland, Ore. site. It gives you recent sales data as well as information on building permits and then maps the information so you cn check on a neighborhood.The best private sector site, hands down, is PropertyShark. It has data for about 15 cities and some of the databases, like New York Citys, is searchable by name.  DAMON DARLIN

How could she avoid a 50 percent estate tax on the $2.9 million worth of property? With the way property values have soared in many parts of the country, this is something many people should be worrying about.She recently reported the answer to her question, a Qualified Personal Residence Trust, or QPRT. She explains how it works:

title: How to Spot a Flip
description: I am full of advice today.If you want to be wary of house flippers  speculators who buy a property and then quickly sell it after some cosmetic upgrades  here is a list of things to watch for. Its from a new blog devoted just to flipping, though I cant see what is wrong with flipping. A flipper takes an undervalued piece of real estate and makes it more attractive. The neighborhood benefits, as does the seller. The buyer may pay more, but then he probably passed up a bargain because of the lime-green shag carpet and the smell of the cat lady who had lived there.As with any real estate, it pays to be vigilant. There are a lot of shoddy flips, with substandard construction and low quailty applicances. Id watch for that.The highlights of the list:

He just got back from a brokers open house, which he used as a barometer of the health of the market. You see, brokers are lured into the development with the promise of catered meals and an open bar.

title: Still Sunny in California?
description: Dataquick, which compiles real estate sales data, has just issued its November reports for Southern California and the Bay Area. In short, in Southern California, sales activity is still strong and prices are up.

description: Having just read the report from Dataquick on the health of the California market, I stumbled across this discussion of foreclosures in Orange County, Calif., just south of Los Angeles proper.

title: Price-Induced Migration
description: This blog, new though it is, has been intently following the effects of the sharp rise in home prices on Americans. One of them is out migration. Its been seen in California, but it is happening in individual communities as well. This report out of Cape Cod, Mass., says young adults, those between 18 and 34, are leaving the region. In 1990, that cohort had 44,635 people; In 2000, it had 38,141 people, a 14.5 percent decline.The blame is placed on the lack of affordable housing, though the study by Clyde Barrow, profesor of policy studies and the director of the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth Center for Policy Analysis, says the region is economically healthy.  DAMON DARLIN

title: A Chill in the Air
description: The latest tour of housing markets around the country brings these reports of a market that is slowing down. I know, it is dog bites man at this point, but thats one of the things blogs are good for. The thing to watch for, more than sales activity, is inventory buildup. Price declines are harder to track because there often isnt enough data in one town to get a good reading. Several expensive homes selling can easily skew the numbers upwards. It takes several months of data to track a trend.That said, the reports:Clark County, Washington: Clark County home sellers and recent buyers are beginning to find out that the red-hot residential real estate market, where median prices have shot up as much as 27.6 percent this year, is cooling.Phoenix, Ariz.: Because it is difficult to sustain the levels of activity evident in the last year, the cooling is a good sign for the sustainability of the market, says Jay Butler, director of the Arizona Real Estate Center at Arizona State University.Sacramento, Calif.: Some local markets appear to be overvalued, and in those markets there may be some price adjustments to bring sales and pricing back in line, said analyst Greg Paquin of the Gregory Group, a Folsom-based real estate data and consulting firm.

title: A Chinese Massacre
description: Ive been tempted to write something about the incident this month in Guangdong Province in which the Peoples Armed Police opened fire on protesting peasants, in the most lethal such episode since the Tiananmen Massacre of 1989. Since I was living in China in 1989 and on the Square when the troops then opened fire, the latest incident has stirred all sorts of memories and thoughts.

title: Volunteering Doctors

He had a headache. His elbow hurt. He couldnt do it, you know. And as you said, hes got a movie out now, so hes running around. I think Cheadles a phony.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bill On Radiation Compensation

Until now, so-called downwinders receiving federal benefits have been from parts of Utah, Nevada and Arizona, although recent studies have shown that four Idaho counties received some of the highest doses of radiation from the fallout of the open-air atomic bomb blasts. SARAH KERSHAW (NYT)

title: Turks Defer Trial of Novelist Who Cited Armenian Deaths
description: ISTANBUL, Dec. 16 - A Turkish court put off the trial of a prominent novelist on Friday after a brief hearing, giving the government until Feb. 7 to decide whether to go ahead with criminal proceedings against him. The charge involves his mentioning the killing of a million Armenians by the Turks in 1915 when he gave a magazine interview, in which he also said 30,000 Kurds had been killed since the late 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUCKERMAN, SIDNEY, M.D.
description: ZUCKERMAN--Sidney, M.D., 87. On December 14 in Boca Raton, Fl. Beloved husband of Irene, his wife and partner for 60 years. Born in New York City, he graduated from Stuyvesant High School, Columbia College and New York Medical College. A Captain in the Army in World War II, he was a prominent allergist in Forest Hills and Manhasset, where he lived for 40 years. Former Medical Director of Unisys and a "Jack of all trades", he enjoyed gardening, carpentry, electronics, bridge and baking his famous apple pies. He is survived by devoted daughters Elaine, Laurie and Amy, sons-in-law Paul, Steve and Jeff, grandchildren Noah, Josh and Christine, Jillian, Ashley, Adam and Jason. He is predeceased by son, Jed. Memorial service will be held at 3PM at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 7240 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, Fl.

title: Arts, Briefly; Howard Stern's Farewell to Earth
description: After talking about this moment on television shows, in magazine and newspaper articles and on his own radio show for months, Howard Stern, left, finally signed off terrestrial radio yesterday morning outside his studio on West 56th Street, where the final hours of his show were broadcast. Thousands of fans, some from as far away as Florida and Ohio and many who had to get out of bed by 4 a.m. even to get near the stage, drank, cheered and waved worshipful signs despite a cold drizzle. Bound for Sirius Satellite Radio, Mr. Stern addressed his fans for the last half-hour of his show, before the festivities moved to the Hard Rock Cafe in Times Square, which was surrounded by a phalanx of 20-something men spilling out into the street and trying to get a glimpse of the self-described King of All Media as he arrived atop a double-decker bus. Martha Stewart, who also has a show on Sirius, introduced Mr. Stern. The move to Sirius takes Mr. Stern outside the jurisdiction of the Federal Communications Commission, which has levied more than $2 million in decency fines on his old bosses at Infinity Broadcasting and the stations that carry his program. Sirius is going to pay him $100 million a year over five years to produce his own morning show and to program two radio channels. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Broadest Measure of Foreign Trade Shows Slight Improvement in 3rd Quarter America's current-account deficit -- the broadest measure of international trade -- showed a slight improvement in the July-to-September quarter although it was still at the third-highest level in history. The Commerce Department reported that the deficit in the current account totaled $195.8 billion in the third quarter. That was down 1 percent from the deficit of $197.8 billion in the April-to-June quarter. The third-quarter figure was below the $205 billion imbalance that had been forecast. Analysts said payments by foreign insurance companies to settle damage claims stemming from hurricanes helped to narrow the gap. Analysts are predicting that the current-account deficit for 2005 will set a record, exceeding $800 billion, and that it will rise above $900 billion next year. (AP)

title: Succinct Bits of Melody in Search of a Film Score
description: As a producer for Sheryl Crow and Elvis Costello and a member of Los Lobos' spinoff, the Latin Playboys, Mitchell Froom has been fond of brittle sounds, the twang of roots-rock and the song structures of pop. On his own, performing on Wednesday night at Joe's Pub with the guitarist Val McCallum, he was far different. At the piano, reading from sheet music, he played melodic reveries from his instrumental album "A Thousand Days" (Inner Knot) that hinted at Chopin, Debussy, Ellington, Randy Newman and hymns: nothing flashy or harsh, yet nothing predictable or sappy either.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: Manna Or Bird Flu?
description: Thousands of migratory birds fell dead on a hilltop in central Malawi, causing officials to send blood samples from the flock to South Africa for testing for fear that the birds were victims of the virulent H5N1 strain of avian influenza that has killed scores of Asians since 2003. Dozens of villagers used pails to collect the fork-tailed drongos, which range through much of sub-Saharan Africa and parts of Asia, in preparation for "feasting on mysterious manna from heaven," Wilfred Lipita, the country's director of animal health, was quoted as saying in news reports. A Malawi newspaper, The Nation, reported that one resident was found with 700 of the birds and that one dead bird appeared to have been banded in Israel. Officials warned residents not to eat the birds because of the risk that the flu virus might be present. In most of the human cases reported in Asia, the disease was contracted while preparing fowl for slaughter or by handling infected birds. The flock of birds died in Ntichisi Province, about 125 miles east of Malawi's administrative capital, Lilongwe. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: Spotting an Aesthetic Dispute and Embracing All Sides
description: Matthew Day Jackson's bracing solo debut, "Fortunate Son," enumerates sundry contemporary art tics with an easy power that is simultaneously original, predictable and a tad impersonal. What makes the show immensely engaging is its reckless disregard for the distinctions between supposedly contradictory aesthetic positions and art factions, as well as its obsession with American history.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: Poll Officials Dismiss Loser's Fraud Claims
description: The National Elections Commission dismissed George Weah's claim of fraud in the presidential election last month, which he lost by nearly 20 percentage points to Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf. Speaking at a news conference in Monrovia, the presiding officer of the commission, Joseph Blidi, said the evidence presented by Mr. Weah's campaign was "grossly insufficient." Mr. Weah, above, a former soccer star, contends that the vote was rigged, and his supporters have clashed with the police and peacekeepers in Monrovia in the past few weeks. Mrs. Johnson-Sirleaf, the Harvard-educated economist who will be inaugurated next month as president and as the first woman elected head of state in modern African history, just completed a trip to the United States during which she met several top administration officials, including Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice. LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARR, FRANK WILLIAM
description: CARR -- Frank William, passed away at his home in Palm Beach, FL on December 15, 2005. He was 94 years old. Born December 9, 1911 in Judsonia, AR, he was one of seven children. Mr. Carr graduated from high school in Farmington, IA in 1928, from the University of Pennsylvania in 1932 with a B.A. degree and from the University of Pennsylvania Law School in 1935 with an L.L.B. degree. He worked as an attorney with E. I. Du Pont et Nemours and continued to practice law for many years. His primary career involved oil and gas exploration in Texas and in France. Mr. Carr served in the United States Navy during World War II from 1943 to 1945 and remained in the reserve until his honorable discharge in 1949. He was a Naval aviator and primarily taught beginning pupils to fly for the French government, one of whom was Phillipe de Gaulle, the son of General de Gaulle. His great joy in life was French food and wine. He spent many years motoring through the lovely French countryside and eating in their great restaurants. He was an accomplished student of Shakespeare. He is preceded in death by his former wife May Dougherty King, his wife Edith Backus Carr, and his son Frank William Carr, Jr. Mr. Carr is survived by his daughter Frances Carr Tapp and her husband Felix; granddaughter Elizabeth Rachael Carr; great grandson William Carr Phillips; his brothers James Edward Carr and Sydney Lanier Carr; a sister Betty Carr Frasier and several nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will be held at 1:00 P.M. on Tuesday, December 20, 2005, at the Chapel of Bethesda-By-The-Sea in Palm Beach. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Make a Wish Foundation or to your favorite charity. QUATTLEBAUM FUNERAL HOME Family Owned and Operated www.Quattlebaum.org
