title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINSOHN, PERRY F., DDS.
description: LEVINSOHN--Perry F., DDS. of Tenafly, NJ. On December 15, 2005. Devoted husband of Corinne (nee Bree). Beloved father of Roann and husband Jay Rubin, Keith Arnold and wife Marilyn Levinsohn and Craig Louis and wife Iris Levinsohn. Proud grandfather of Benjamin, Emily Brett, Ryan, Daniel, Ari and Kyle. Services 11:30 A.M. Sunday at Congregation Ahavath Torah, 240 Broad Ave, Englewood, NJ.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Annan's Deputy To Leave
description: The deputy secretary general, Louise Frchette, left, who came under criticism for management failures in the oil-for-food program, is leaving her post in April to lead a research project on nuclear arms proliferation at the Center for International Governance Innovation in Ontario. Ms. Frchette, 59, a former Canadian government minister and ambassador who took the newly created post in 1998, will not be replaced, said Stphane Dujarric, the spokesman for Secretary General Kofi Annan. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

title: Time Warner to Sell 5% AOL Stake to Google for $1 Billion
description: Rebuffing aggressive overtures from Microsoft, Time Warner has agreed to sell a 5 percent stake in America Online to Google for $1 billion in cash as part of an expanded partnership between AOL, once the dominant company on the Internet, and Google, the current online king.

title: Behind Power, One Principle as Bush Pushes Prerogatives
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 - A single, fiercely debated legal principle lies behind nearly every major initiative in the Bush administration's war on terror, scholars say: the sweeping assertion of the powers of the presidency.

title: Tempers Heat Up at Trial in Italy on Antiquities
description: ROME, Dec. 16 - Tempers became heated today as the Italian state presented new evidence in its case against Marion True, a former antiquities curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, who is on trial here on charges of dealing in looted antiquities.

title: Financial Executive Set to Quit Stewart
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, which is on track to report its first profit in two years in February, said yesterday that its chief financial and administrative officer, James Follo, planned to resign in March.

title: Manhunt Comes to Bloody End in Case of Fake Firefighter
description: After weeks on the run, a writer accused of posing as a firefighter so he could sexually attack a woman in her Chelsea apartment was cornered yesterday by campus police at the University of Memphis, where he stabbed himself in the throat before his arrest, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTER, T. BRIAN
description: CARTER--T. Brian. Of Bronxville, on December 15, 2005. Husband of the late Dorothy. Beloved father of Pamela Foss (Warren). Dear grandfather of Heather and William. Brother of Tony and the late Michael. Service at Christ Church Bronxville on Monday, December 19, at 10:30 A.M. Calling hours at Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 1-4 PM Sunday.

title: Among Queens Bus Riders, the Last Are Unhappy to Be First
description: Riders of private bus lines in Queens have long complained of coming in last: from long waits for service, to second-rate buses, to the missed deadlines for the bus companies to be taken over by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Iraq Votes for a Third Time
description: Iraq's Election Day was a glorious success. Now on to the hard part.

title: Hark! The Heralded Jazzmen Swing Some Familiar Melodies
description: Somewhere between ritual and remnant lies the jazz Christmas concert. As a manifestation of pure secular middle-class civility, it represents a vague and probably disappearing middle ground, even in Manhattan.

title: A Flush Goldman Pays Its Chief $37 Million
description: The Goldman Sachs Group paid its chief executive, Henry M. Paulson Jr., about $37 million in shares and stock options after posting a second consecutive year of record earnings.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It's always nice when they come home. And it's always nice when they leave."

title: James Ingo Freed, 75, Dies; Designed Holocaust Museum
description: James Ingo Freed, an architect and partner of I. M. Pei, whose own buildings ranged from the provocatively somber United States Holocaust Memorial Museum to the sprawling crystal palace of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, died Thursday at his home on Gramercy Park in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: Arts, Briefly; A 'Nutcracker' Canceled
description: The Washington Ballet canceled its production of "The Nutcracker" yesterday after negotiations with dancers and their union over a new contract ended without a resolution. Dancers had said they would not continue to perform without an agreement. The two sides reached an impasse this week when the company said the dancers were on strike, and the dancers' union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, contended they had been locked out. The dancers said they were seeking a new contract to protect their jobs, safety and health. They specifically cited concerns over the scheduling of rehearsals and performances and how management handled dismissals. The company said problems revolved around artistic control.

title: Columnist Resigns His Post, Admitting Lobbyist Paid Him
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 - A senior scholar at the Cato Institute, the respected libertarian research organization, has resigned after revelations that he took payments from the lobbyist Jack Abramoff in exchange for writing columns favorable to his clients.

title: Torture Is an Issue? What's Become of My Country?
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Matchups
description: Kansas City Chiefs (8-5) at Giants (9-4) 5 p.m.

title: A Longtime Fan, Villone Is the Newest Yankee
description: It took 10 clubs, 11 seasons and countless trade rumors, but Ron Villone finally landed with his hometown team yesterday. Villone, a left-handed pitcher who lives in Upper Saddle River, N.J., joined the Yankees in a trade with the Florida Marlins.

title: With Financing Secured, Millrose Games Are a Go
description: The Millrose Games, which were threatened by sponsorship problems, will return to Madison Square Garden on Feb. 3 with new financing.

title: Pursuing the Scarcer Moviegoers
description: SANTA MONICA, Dec. 16 - With evidence increasing that the American moviegoing habit is in decline, theater owners are undertaking a concerted campaign to bring it back.

title: Trade Officials Haggle on Issues From Lower Tariffs to Cotton Subsidies
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 16 - Trade negotiators from around the world moved behind closed doors in nearly around-the-clock meetings here as they homed in on reaching a narrowly worded four-part deal by Sunday night. But any agreement still faces formidable obstacles, officials said late Friday.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 8 about the House's vote to block an increase in the alternative minimum tax misstated the year that taxes for stock dividends and capital gains were initially cut. It was 2003, not 2001. (The error was repeated in an article on Dec. 9 about the House's completing a vote on $95 billion in tax cuts.)

title: Senators Thwart Bush Bid to Renew Law on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 - The Senate on Friday blocked reauthorization of the broad antiterrorism bill known as the USA Patriot Act, pushing Congress into a game of brinksmanship with President Bush, who has said the nation will be left vulnerable to attack if the measure is not quickly renewed.

title: World Briefings: Africa, Europe, Middle East, Asia
description: AFRICA

title: Torture Is an Issue? What's Become of My Country?
description: To the Editor:

title: Capitalism at Work on Unwanted Gift Certificates
description: Sheryl and Dale Huber have saved hundreds of cats and dogs in the last few years, but recently they discovered a way to save hundreds of dollars. The Hubers scour the Internet for store gift cards that can be bought, sold and traded online at deep discounts.

title: Laying Bare Dust Bowl's Scar Tissue
description: The Worst Hard Time The Untold Story of Those Who Survived the Great American Dust Bowl By Timothy Egan Illustrated. 340 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $28.

title: Metal's Faithful Laud a Label and Embrace the Hearing Loss
description: Surely it wasn't the only office party this season where people were jostled, shoved and punched in the head. But it must have been one of the only ones where people were jostled, shoved and punched in the head on purpose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREED, JAMES INGO
description: FREED--James Ingo. The partners and staff of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners Architects mourn the passing of their dear friend and colleague James Ingo Freed, on December 15, 2005. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his daughter, Dara, and her family.

title: Iraqis Take Another Hopeful Step
description: To the Editor:

title: The Time Warp of Christmas Past
description: Imagine a Christmas past: under the tree assorted boxes bulge with coats, sweaters, mittens and pajamas. There are albums, record players, a bottle of Scotch, a Barbie doll and Legos.

title: Living in the Enron Dream World
description: THIS past Tuesday, Kenneth L. Lay, the disgraced former chairman of Enron, gave a remarkable speech before a hometown crowd in Houston. It's not every day that a prominent white-collar defendant makes an impassioned public defense barely a month before his criminal trial is set to start. That sort of thing tends to tick off prosecutors, not to mention judges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINFIELD, BABETTE
description: LINFIELD--Babette, on December 15, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. She is survived by her son Jeffrey Mann, daughter-in-law Amy Mann, granddaughters Jessica Mann Gutteridge (Corin) and Rachel Mann Rosan (Seth), great grandchildren Rafe Gutteridge and Lily Rosan, also by her sister Judy West and step son Michael Linfield. She led a productive life retiring at age 85 as the Executive Director of Professionals Network for Social Responsibility. She was concerned with the safety and health of a peaceful world. Service Sunday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Spying in America, By Our Government
description: To the Editor:

title: The Collapsing Claims on Cloning
description: South Korean scientists reported an incredible series of coups over the past two years in the difficult fields of stem cell research and therapeutic cloning. They claimed to be the first to clone human embryos and extract stem cells from the embryos, the first to clone a dog, and the first to derive embryonic stem cell lines tailored to match the DNA of patients suffering from specific diseases or spinal cord injuries. It sounded almost too good to be true, and now it turns out that some, if not all, of it probably was too good to be true.

title: Delaware Court Upholds Calpine Ruling
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec 16 - The Delaware Supreme Court upheld a lower court decision on Friday requiring the Calpine Corporation to restore $312 million to an escrow fund by Jan. 22.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis yesterday about a colleague's statement impugning the stem cell research of Dr. Hwang Woo Suk, a South Korean scientist, misstated what Dr. Hwang said about it last month. Dr. Hwang admitted then that an error had been made in submitting photographs that accompanied an article about his research, but he has not publicly admitted that he fabricated evidence, and has defended his research.

title: Home for Holidays, Rocking the Nest
description: Jennifer Larsen is home for the holidays, at least in spirit.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CANTOR, B.
description: CANTOR--B. Gerald My darling Bernie, Happy Birthday. I will always remember how you touched my life. Love, Iris

title: Ties to Industry Cloud a Clinic's Mission
description: Dr. Eric J. Topol, a cardiologist, has been perhaps the most public face of the prestigious Cleveland Clinic Foundation, a prominent medical center regarded as one of the nation's best.

title: Looking for Quick Cash (and Losing It) in Oil
description: I SENSED I might have gotten in over my head the moment I stepped onto the trading floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange. The three-story-high windowless walls were covered with giant electronic screens flashing rows of red, green and yellow numbers like a high-tech gambling casino. But the place looked, smelled and sounded more like a standing-room-only football stadium.

title: Murder of Police Officers
description: To the Editor:

title: Aide to Rell Is Suspended Following Furor Over Ethics
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 16 - Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Friday suspended her chief of staff, M. Lisa Moody, after Ms. Moody acknowledged that she had violated the governor's policy prohibiting political work on state time. Ms. Moody recently distributed a fund-raising invitation for Mrs. Rell's 2006 election campaign to the heads of several state agencies.

title: Chinese Pressing to Keep Village Silent on Clash
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 16 - Ten days ago, the sleepy fishing village of Dongzhou was the scene of a deadly face-off, with protesters hurling homemade bombs and the police gunning them down in the streets.

title: Patent Challenge to Pfizer Is Rejected
description: A federal judge yesterday rejected a patent challenge to Lipitor, a cholesterol-lowering medicine from Pfizer that is the world's top-selling drug.

title: Pataki Wants Death Penalty for Killers of Police
description: Gov. George E. Pataki will call state lawmakers into a special session on Wednesday to vote on new legislation that seeks to curb illegal gun trafficking and permit the death penalty for those convicted of murdering a police officer.

title: Stalking the Crowded City, a Loner With a Lens
description: From May 1952 to June 1966, a troubled recluse named Angelo Rizzuto stalked Manhattan with a camera. He saw a city of solitary beings isolated amid the architectural grandeur, cold streets prowled by disillusioned women, exhausted men and vulnerable children. He ended every roll with a portrait of himself, alone in a spare room, sullenly staring or bizarrely grimacing into the camera, a loner among loners.

title: School Safety Agent Dies After Escorting Student From Holiday Dance
description: A school safety agent at a Brooklyn middle school died last night, apparently from a heart attack, after a 12-year-old student struck her outside a holiday dance, officials said.

title: This Year's Top Blockbusters? They're So Last Year
description: In the video game industry, this is supposed to be the happiest time of the year. According to the industry's holiday script, customers are supposed to be gushing over the top blockbusters of the year right about now while executives are supposed to be gloating over big year-end profits. With the introduction of a brand-new console, the Xbox 360, millions of players are supposed to be raving about the new machine and buying tons of new games to play on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORENSTEIN, FAYE W.
description: ORENSTEIN--Faye W. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Formerly of Paterson, NJ, Fire Island, Palm Beach, FL, and currently of Manhattan. Funeral services Sunday 11am at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at Elmwood Park, NJ.

title: Arts, Briefly; Video-Game Bill Introduced
description: Three prominent Democratic senators yesterday introduced legislation that would regulate the sale of video games. The bill, the Family Entertainment Protection Act, would impose fines on retailers who sell or rent games rated Adults Only, Mature or Ratings Pending to consumers under 17. "The content of many cutting-edge games is becoming more and more vivid, violent and offensive to our most basic values," Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, a sponsor of the bill, said in a statement. The bill's other sponsors are Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York. SETH SCHIESEL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUTSON, FRANK A., JR.
description: HUTSON--Frank A., Jr. Attorney Frank A. Hutson Jr., 88, of Providence and Little Compton, RI died Sunday, September 11, 2005 in Providence, RI. He was the husband of Jean (Crobaugh) Hutson and the late Catherine "Kay" B. (Halsey) Hutson. Born in New York, NY a son of the late Atty. Frank A. Hutson and Irene (Rigby) Hutson, he resided in Bronxville, NY until 1956, Cohasset, MA from 1956 to 1960, Essex Fells, NJ from 1960 to 1991 before moving to Little Compton, RI. He also wintered in Lake Wales, FL. Mr. Hutson received a Bachelors Degree in 1937 from Swarthmore College in PA and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He continued his education at Yale Law School graduating in 1940. He enlisted as Private, in the U.S. Army on December 8, 1941. A Combat Liaison Officer with Free French Forces, North Africa, Italy, France and Germany, he received four battle stars, a U.S. Bronze Star, the French Croix de Guerre with Palm, and a Silver Star. He was discharged as Captain in December of 1945 and was nominated for the French Legion of Honor. Atty. Hutson practiced law in NYC and Boston, initially with Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam and Roberts in NYC. Thereafter for 30 years, he was an Atty. and Officer with the American Telegraph and Telephone Co. and its subsidiaries including N.E. Tel & Tel. In 1982, he retired from AT&T as General Attorney and Corporate Secretary. Mr. Hutson was a former Director of American Bell Inc., AT&T, International and Bellcom Inc. He was a planner of early space flights including the 1969 moon landing. He received commendation "In recognition of his contribution to manned space flight." He also was on the Board of Mount Vernon Mills Inc., Halsey Securities Corp., The American Cross, the Boy Scouts and Planned Parenthood. He was a former member of the Sakonnet Golf Club, the Montclair Golf Club and the Warrens Point Beach Club. Surviving in addition to his wife: one son, Dr. William H. Hutson and his wife, Susan, of Little Compton, RI; two daughters, Wrenn Boulton and her husband, John, of Idaho Springs, CO and Jean H. Lister and her husband, James, of Evergreen, CO. He is also survived by five grandchildren. Memorial Contributions may be made to the Yale Law School Fund, P.O. Box 208341, New Haven, CT 06520 or St. Andrews by the Sea Episcopal Church, P.O. 491, Little Compton, RI 02837. For information: Waring-Sullivan Home of Memorial Tribute at "Cherry Place", 178 Winter Street, Fall River, MA.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 8 about the House's vote to block an increase in the alternative minimum tax misstated the year that taxes for stock dividends and capital gains were initially cut. It was 2003, not 2001. (The error was repeated in an article on Dec. 9 about the House's completing a vote on $95 billion in tax cuts.)

title: Demolition of Thousands of Houses Is Set to Begin
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 - The city will begin demolishing several thousand of the most severely hurricane-damaged houses in the next few weeks, marking the completion of an arduous door-to-door inspection of more than 120,000 structures that began months ago.

title: New Jersey Awards $5 Million in Grants for Stem Cell Research
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16 - New Jersey officials on Friday announced $5 million in grants for stem cell research, including studies involving human embryonic stem cells. The awards are said to be the first instance of a state using public funds for such research.

title: Speaking Like a Winner (Even if You're Not)
description: A flood of new books, many with up-to-the-minute glossaries, continue to inundate store shelves. Avery Cardoza's "Poker Talk: Learn How to Talk Poker Like a Pro" is an informative 304-page glossary, period. In the spirit of both the well-named Cardoza -- and the patois-happy anchor of "Sports Center," Stuart Scott -- let's define a selection of old-school argot along with some fresher Americanisms overheard during last week's Five Diamond Classic.

title: Australia's Dangerous Fantasy
description: ADELAIDE, Australia - LAST Sunday on Cronulla Beach, a suburb of Sydney, thousands of drunken white youths attacked anyone they believed was of Arab descent. Inspired by reports that Lebanese-Australians had assaulted two white lifeguards, text messages calling for a Lebanese "bashing day" appeared on thousands of cellphones. Some of Sunday's assailants wore T-shirts that proclaimed, "We grew here; you flew here," or, "Ethnic cleansing unit."

title: Red District, Blue Candidate, Purple Heart
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, JERRY
description: GROSS--Jerry. We mourn the passing of a devoted friend who we loved and respected, who shared with us his incredible joy of living with music and song. May he rest in peace. Herbert, Frank and Carol Feinberg

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Independent Broadcasters Arrested
description: The police arrested three journalists working for a Dutch-based broadcaster, Voice of the People, and charged them with possessing signal-transmitting equipment without a required government license. Voice of the People is one of two independent radio stations still broadcasting into Zimbabwe, using shortwave transmitters outside the nation to evade Zimbabwe laws that place all broadcast media under government control. Rights activists said the arrests were in line with a stepped-up harassment of government critics in recent weeks. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: New Transit Talks Set; Strike Is Put Off to Tuesday
description: Throwing New Yorkers off balance with fluid deadlines and rigid demands, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the transit workers' union broke off talks yesterday morning, leading the union to call a strike against two Queens bus companies on Monday and the whole system on Tuesday if no settlement is reached.

title: Union Challenges N.B.A. Over Its Fining of Artest
description: The National Basketball Players Association is preparing to file a grievance to protest the $10,000 fine that Ron Artest received Thursday from the N.B.A. over his public request for a trade from the Indiana Pacers.

title: Rodney Whitaker, Writer, Is Dead at 74; Best Known as Trevanian
description: Rodney Whitaker, a writer best known by one of his many pen names, Trevanian, who was the only writer of airport paperbacks to be compared to Zola, Ian Fleming, Poe and Chaucer, died on Wednesday in the West Country of England. He was 74.

title: Putin Plays Headhunter for Oil Company
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16 - President Vladimir V. Putin confirmed Friday that Russia's state oil company, Rosneft, was seeking a "high-class" foreign manager, after reports surfaced this week that he had offered Donald L. Evans, the former United States commerce secretary, the post of chairman.

title: Correction
description: An exhibition review in Weekend on Dec. 2 about "Sarah Bernhardt: The Art of High Drama" at the Jewish Museum included an apparently apocryphal story from the catalog about the amputation of her leg in 1915. The story was that P. T. Barnum offered Bernhardt $10,000 to display the leg after the amputation. But in fact Barnum died in 1891, and there is no evidence that the story is true.

title: L.I. Is Ordered to Give Notice of House Raids
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that Long Island officials cracking down on houses overcrowded with Hispanic day laborers must give advance notice, unless there is an immediate threat to safety.

title: Oy Tannenbaum
description: MY earliest Christmas memory: I am 5 years old, sitting on the bench seat close beside my father in our aqua and white Buick, the one that looked like a saddle shoe, on a mission to get the best Christmas tree we can find.

title: Soccer Event May Provide Clues on Cuba for Baseball
description: Five months ago, a delegation of Cuban athletes obtained visas from the United States without any difficulty and played games in Seattle and Foxborough, Mass. They were soccer players, not baseball players, but the fact that those athletes were allowed into the country to play has intrigued Major League Baseball officials.

title: Bush, on TV, Says Iraq Vote Won't End Violence
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 - President Bush acknowledged Friday that the elections in Iraq were "not going to stop violence" there, and that "we're behind" on the training of capable Iraqi police forces.

title: Arts, Briefly; Novak Out at CNN, In at Fox
description: Robert Novak, right, the conservative commentator and columnist who was a fixture on CNN since its inception a quarter century ago, said yesterday he was joining its more popular competitor, Fox News, as an occasional contributor. Mr. Novak described his move in a telephone interview after CNN issued a statement saying that his "tenure on the network" would end on Dec. 31, when his contract expires. Mr. Novak has not appeared on CNN since Aug. 4, when he uttered an expletive and then bolted from a live interview in which he had been needled by James Carville, the Democratic strategist, as pandering to "these right wingers." Their interviewer, Ed Henry, later said on the air that Mr. Novak was aware that he was about to be asked about the fallout from the column he wrote in 2003 that identified Valerie Plame as a C.I.A. operative. Mr. Novak said his departure from CNN had been "a mutual decision," one that seemed obvious to him after the network canceled the two main programs on which he had appeared, "Crossfire" and "The Capital Gang." He said, "I turn 75 in February, and I wanted to do a good deal less." On Fox News, he said, he will serve as an occasional contributor, though not for any particular program. JACQUES STEINBERG

description: Novak Out at CNN, In at Fox

title: In the Blink of an Eye, You've Paid
description: ALMOST faster than you can say "Will that be debit or credit?" the next generation of electronic payment options is taking hold in stores across the country.

title: With Energy Prices High, Suitors Are on the Prowl
description: HIGH energy prices benefit some as surely as they injure others. Evidence of both sides of that coin was evident this week.

title: Iraqis Take Another Hopeful Step
description: To the Editor:

title: New Strategy for Growth at Citigroup
description: Declaring that a plan to overhaul internal controls and improve credibility was in place, Charles O. Prince III, the chief executive of Citigroup, said yesterday that the bank was ready to consider another major acquisition.

title: Other Unions and Their Contracts
description: The latest offer to the Transport Workers Union was for 3 percent raises each year over three years, and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority demanded concessions on pensions and health care for new workers. While transit workers are not city workers, their contracts have often been used as a guidepost for agreements with the city unions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHWATSKY, MILTON STUART
description: CHWATSKY--Milton Stuart. On December 16, 2005 at the age of 54. Loving son of Doris and Joseph. Beloved brother of Daniel and the late David. He was a survivor who lived with dignity inspite of physical challenges. Services Sunday 1:45pm at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre. Interment at the Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Lines in Sand Drawn by M.T.A. and Union Show Few Signs of Fading
description: The union is famed for its militancy. The transportation authority is flush with a $1 billion surplus. And now it is demanding sizable concessions on employee benefits.

title: Spying in America, By Our Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Betting on Bird Flu
description: THIS week, Salon.com examines Intrade, an online "futures market" (well, sort of) that allows members to bet on coming events. The site has accurately predicted election results, the selection of Pope Benedict XVI and the severity of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Canadians Audition for New York's Finest
description: So you want to be a New York City police officer, eh?

title: Rough Seas and Rough Sailing
description: If the first leg of the round-the-world Volvo Ocean Race is an indicator of the shape of seas and waves and boat malfunctions to come, the 32,000-nautical-mile, eight-month race may dispel the notion of sailing as the sport of blue-blazered Britons sipping cocktails at sundown.

title: The Psychology of Retailing
description: IF this holiday season you find yourself spending more on presents than you planned, we know just where to put the blame: store merchandisers, who have considered just about every way to separate you from your money.

title: Examining the Eternal Push-Pull of the Sexes
description: Daniel Charon performed with the companies of Jos Limn and Doug Varone for eight years altogether, choreographing in workshop and showcase situations for much of that time. His first formal program, on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo, had the intelligence and subtlety of an artist who knew enough to wait.

title: Worker Is Killed in Fall
description: A construction worker died last evening after falling down an elevator shaft in an empty Brooklyn building, the police said.

title: After Scandal, McCain Offers Bill to Tighten Lobbying Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 - Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who heads a committee in the Senate that helped uncover this year's lobbying scandal, introduced a bill on Friday to increase the restrictions and disclosure requirements that apply to lobbyists and public officials.

title: In the Roslyn School Scandal, Neighbors Are Suing Neighbors
description: ROSLYN, N.Y., Dec. 16 - The Roslyn school district has been promised $7.7 million from its former auditor and from former officials who have pleaded guilty to stealing school funds. But even if all that money comes in -- and people in Roslyn have serious doubts -- the district is still millions of dollars short of recouping the $11.2 million that auditors say is missing.

title: The Soul of New Orleans
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Apprentice's Quick Decision
description: The winner of the fourth "Apprentice," Randal Pinkett, below, was crowned on Thursday night live from Lincoln Center. Things took a surprising turn in the very last moment of the show: Donald Trump asked Mr. Pinkett whether he thought Rebecca Jarvis, the other competitor, should also be hired, and Mr. Pinkett said no. The audience booed, and the show was over, although a heated debate about Mr. Pinkett and Ms. Jarvis continues on Internet message boards. The two-hour episode drew 12.85 million viewers, which was a season high for this installment of the series. Compared with last season's two editions, however, the ratings for this conclusion were down in double-digit percentages. But with CBS in repeats, NBC was able to score a rare Thursday win in the 18-to-49 demographic for the night. In total viewers, CBS won: reruns of "CSI" (17.68 million) and "Without a Trace" (15.06 million) drew larger audiences than "The Apprentice" in every half-hour from 9 p.m. to 11 p.m. KATE AURTHUR

title: Correction
description: The obituary of the comedian Richard Pryor on Monday and in some copies on Sunday misidentified his last movie and misstated the date of an earlier one. His last movie was "Lost Highway," in 1997, not "Another You." "Another You" was released in 1991, not 1992.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Not a Gigantic Opening

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, RUTH (NEE GROSSMAN)
description: WEISS--Ruth (nee Grossman). Of Lido Beach, NY, on December 15. Beloved wife of Sidney. Cherished mother of Joan & Jonathan (Linda). Loving grandmother of Melissa and Wendy. She will be forever remembered and loved deeply by friends and family. Services 11:30 AM Sunday at Boulevard Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, 516-295-3100.

title: Spying in America, By Our Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Competence an Elusive Component for Knicks
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 16 - The Knicks ran into some hot shooters. That could have been the easy alibi, the convenient way to explain a loss on the road. But what Joe Johnson and Al Harrington of the Atlanta Hawks did to the Knicks here Friday night could not be captured with such a simple explanation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis yesterday about a colleague's statement impugning the stem cell research of Dr. Hwang Woo Suk, a South Korean scientist, misstated what Dr. Hwang said about it last month. Dr. Hwang admitted then that an error had been made in submitting photographs that accompanied an article about his research, but he has not publicly admitted that he fabricated evidence, and has defended his research.

title: Looking for Similarities Where Others See Differences
description: Analyzing religion isn't just for the pious anymore. Since the World Trade Center towers were blown away in the name of God four years ago, since the journalist Daniel Pearl and numberless others have been murdered by men and women who seem to believe that heaven will reward their actions, Americans have been forced to acknowledge that religious differences kill, even (or maybe especially) in the 21st century.

title: John Spencer, 58, TV Actor Starring on 'The West Wing,' Dies
description: Correction Appended

title: Barber Made It Here and Doesn't Want to Make It Anywhere Else
description: Every room in the 4,000-square-foot corner apartment on the Upper East Side has a flat-screen television. Even the master bathroom has one, a 15-incher on the wall, viewable from the shower and the toilet and the walk-in closet, where Tiki Barber's impeccable wardrobe resides.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Dream Is Dashed, But the Signs Are Positive
description: Jin Luo, who arrived in New York from China eight years ago, has had more obstacles to building a life in his new country than most immigrants. Lacking literacy in English is only the beginning. Mr. Luo, 50, is deaf and unable to speak English or Chinese.

title: Taking Liberties With the Nation's Security
description: YESTERDAY the Senate failed to reauthorize the USA Patriot Act, as a Democratic-led filibuster prevented a vote. This action -- which leaves the act, key elements of which are due to expire on Dec. 31, in limbo -- represents a grave potential threat to the nation's security. I support the extension of the Patriot Act for one simple reason: Americans must use every legal and constitutional tool in their arsenal to fight terrorism and protect their lives and liberties.

title: D.C. 37 Is Roiled by Reversal of Wage Cut for 2 Officials
description: The city's largest municipal workers' union, already divided by years of clashes between its leader and its executive board, has been roiled by a new and noisy dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELDS, GERALD J.
description: FIELDS--Gerald J. December 7, 1929 to December 14, 2005. Retired Labor Negotiator, Local 144. Adored son of Rea and Irving. Beloved brother of Robert and Martin. Loving father of Melissa Fields, Andrew Fields and Elizabeth Laufer. Cherished grandfather of Alix Steinfeld, Courtney Fields and Samuel and Rachel Laufer. Graveside services Sunday December 18, 2 P.M., Tikvat Shalom Cemetery, St. Rose, Louisiana. Donations to JCC, 5342 St. Charles Ave, New Orleans, LA 70115.

title: Not Just Rattling Their Chains: A Musical 'Christmas Carol'
description: Question: What would Christmas be without Ebenezer Scrooge?

title: South Korean Scientist Says He'll Prove Cloning Method
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 16 - An embattled South Korean scientist struck back at his critics on Friday, declaring that his pioneering technology for cloning stem cells works and that he will produce proof within two weeks.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Sports Briefing column on Wednesday about the new Hofstra University football coach, Dave Cohen, misstated the background of his predecessor, Joe Gardi. He coached for 16 seasons at Hofstra, not Delaware.

title: The Roche Sisters Reunited, With Christmas in the Air
description: For years, the Roches' quirky Christmas shows at the Bottom Line mixed a reverence for holiday music and good will with witty send-ups and candid expressions of snowy loneliness and doubt. The folk-pop sister trio from New Jersey, who once caroled for spare change, released a Christmas collection in 1990, applying their acid-tinged angel voices to mostly traditional songs. By the late 1990's, though, the trio's official Christmas shows had stopped, and the band took an indefinite break.

title: Builders in Central Valley of California May Face Air Pollution Fees
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 - Builders in the fast-growing but smoggy Central Valley of California could be required to pay air pollution fees on new commercial and residential developments beginning in March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DILLON, ROBERT J.
description: DILLON--Robert J., 61, died peacefully at home on December 16 after a short illness. Beloved husband of Phyllis and father of Alexander, Ph.D. Anthropology, Columbia University, 1976. Fund-raising executive for non-profits, most recently, Edison Schools, Inc. A lover of classical music, he played the clarinet. He was generous and open-hearted, and had a life-long passion for social progress and liberal causes. Service on Monday December 19, 11:30am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Excerpt From a Column Favorable to a Client
description: Following is an excerpt from a syndicated column written by Doug Bandow for the Copley News Service in June 1997. Mr. Bandow has resigned from the Cato Institute after it was learned that he took payments for such columns from a Washington lobbyist, Jack Abramoff. The Choctaw Indians were clients of Mr. Abramoff's lobbying firm.

But this tale in New York magazine about how the author, Colin Harrison, moved his wifes aging grandmother to Brooklyn from Los Angeles  and got a brownstone as part of the bargain  is worth it. title: Another Boom  in Agents
description: The number of real estate agents in California is appreciating almost as fast as house prices. The California Department of Real Estate reported that the total number of real estate agents and brokers in California rose 1.1 percent in November to 471,818. Thats up 13.7 percent year over year.   DAMON DARLIN

title: Paperback Row
description: BIG BANG: The Origin of the Universe, by Simon Singh. (HarperPerennial, $15.95.) Singh mixes science, arithmetic and beguiling anecdotes into a biography of the concept of an expanding universe. The book moves smoothly and rapidly -- from the Greeks to Copernicus to Einstein, from Ptolemy's ancient geocentric planetary system to the 20th-century discovery of quasars and dark matter. Singh "tells a fascinating tale," Owen Gingerich wrote here.

title: Marist Upsets St. John's and Coach
description: It is hard to ruffle Norm Roberts. He has endured a lot of bad basketball in his brief time as the coach at St. John's, and he usually responds to setbacks with a positive message.

title: Bush Says He Ordered Domestic Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 - President Bush acknowledged on Saturday that he had ordered the National Security Agency to conduct an electronic eavesdropping program in the United States without first obtaining warrants, and said he would continue the highly classified program because it was "a vital tool in our war against the terrorists."

title: Blogging the Vote in Iraq; Elections, Yes; Democracy, No
description: Web logs invaded the Internet around the same time as the American-led coalition invaded Iraq, so it is fitting that some of the most insightful commentary on the war has come from Iraqi citizens -- students, professionals, homemakers, soldiers, former Baathists and others -- on their personal sites. The Op-Ed page asked several young Iraqi bloggers to write about their experiences during the parliamentary voting on Thursday -- and to share their thoughts about what the election will mean for their country's future.

title: In a Cold Sweat
description: SUSSEX - THE news in my town is that people are coming from all over to snatch up our trees again.

title: Where Children Snicker and Faith Still Flickers
description: ONLY the most delicate of special effects is used in "Mr. Harvey Lights a Candle," and just once, near the end. This may surprise fans of the British actor Timothy Spall, star of the film, which has its American premiere Christmas Eve on BBC America. They are more used to seeing him surrounded by some of the splashiest effects available today -- in the two most recent "Harry Potter" movies, where he plays the scoundrely Peter Pettigrew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITCOME, DR. PHILIP J.
description: WHITCOME--Dr. Philip J. It is with deep regret that the Managing General Partners, Advisory Board, Investors and staff of NGN Capital mourn the passing of their esteemed colleague Dr. Philip J. Whitcome. A friend for over 25 years and a valued counselor to us all. He will be sorely missed.

description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 14 - Peter Laviolette could look back and smile at the firing that turned out to be the best break of his career. But he is not one to dwell on the past, or obsess about the future.

title: Movies on TV
description: BAD EDUCATION (2004) Thursday/Early Friday at 1:50 a.m. on Cinemax Pedro Almodvar's most recent work, named best foreign-language film by the New York Film Critics Circle, is highly satisfying film noir with a kick. Gael Garca Bernal (above), the handsome heartthrob from "Motorcycle Diaries" and "Y Tu Mam Tambin," stars as a young man with a movie idea for his filmmaker friend (Fele Martnez). It's the story of his own sexual abuse by a Roman Catholic priest (Daniel Gimnez Cacho). But a story can be told in more than one way. And people can seem so different at times.

description: ON wintry nights in Manhattan, little bands of smokers huddle under restaurant awnings, shivering as they struggle to light their cigarettes in the icy wind.

title: Chelsea's Oasis
description: THE General Theological Seminary of the Episcopal Church, at Ninth Avenue between 20th and 21st Streets, is an oasis amid the bustle of Chelsea. Visitors stroll through the seminary's landscaped quadrangles nearly every day, especially parents with young children and those who wish to worship in the century-old Chapel of the Good Shepherd.

title: Jack Anderson, Investigative Journalist Who Angered the Powerful, Dies at 83
description: Jack Anderson, whose investigative column once appeared in more than 1,000 newspapers with 40 million readers, won a Pulitzer Prize and prompted J. Edgar Hoover to call him "lower than the regurgitated filth of vultures," died yesterday. He was 83.

description: If you wake up on Sunday and think you're seeing nearly every man, woman and child in New York standing in a row, holding a music book and singing about Christmas, it won't only be your imagination. This, after all, is the season for a lung and a prayer. The only way to be thorough here with so many worthy events would be to send emissaries.

title: A Hand in Two Cultures
description: I WAS born in Osaka in the 40's, and I lost my father in World War II. But it never occurred to my mother to teach me to hate Americans. In those postwar days, there was no food, no clothes, no rice to feed your kids. My mom was a teacher who had to travel two hours each way to get to her school, and she had her hands full just getting on with life. She lost her husband, and she probably had some negative sentiments about Americans, but she didn't have the time to convey them.

title: Evolution Trial in Hands of Willing Judge
description: Driving home one day last December from the courthouse in Harrisburg, Pa., Judge John E. Jones III tuned in to a radio news report about 11 parents in the nearby town of Dover who had filed a lawsuit challenging their school board's decision to include intelligent design in the high school biology curriculum.

title: DOUBLY RARE
description: It is rare for a chief executive to collect a smaller year-end bonus than a junior employee who also happens to be his son, but so it went at Hewitt Associates this year.

description: ARTIFICIAL ponds, which sometimes spring up in new developments and golf courses, would start appearing in salt marsh tidal wetlands under a sweeping mosquito-control and pesticide-reduction plan that Suffolk County is considering.

title: At Home for the Holidays, in New York
description: THE year before I was married, as my future husband and I began to negotiate our holiday plans, he announced that we would not be leaving town for Thanksgiving. We would not be schlepping off to Houston to spend the holiday with his family or to Michigan to spend it with mine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, NANCY OTTIS
description: HARRIS--Nancy Ottis. White Bear Lake, MN, age 75, on December 11, 2005. Graduate of Summit School in St. Paul, Mills College, and ColumbiaPresbyterian School of Nursing. With her intelligence, great good sense and grounded personality, Nancy could be counted on completely by those close to her. She gave very generously of herself to her friends, family and community throughout her lifetime, and she will be missed greatly by all who knew her.

title: Moving to Where the Music Plays
description: THERE were three things Melissa Giges really disliked about her walk-up apartment. First, she had no closet (the one closet in the whole place went to her roommate) so she had to buy a wardrobe for her clothes.

title: A Casual Place Big on Burgers
description: THE Rustic Grill is the quintessential neighborhood restaurant. Occupying a cozy corner on Covert Avenue in Floral Park, it is a good place for locals looking for a nightly meal. Reservations are not needed, you don't have to dress up and you won't spend a bundle for dinner.

title: Loud Church Music, Then Stunning Reverberations
description: New Haven - IF you had to guess which location near the 200 block of Chapel Street would become the scene of an arrest, an ensuing political fracas and a stratospheric court judgment because its habitus were cited for blasting their music too loud and refusing to turn it down, your first choice would probably not have been the Second Star of Jacob Church.

title: Kimberly Connors and Richard Pinkham III
description: Kimberly Blair Connors, a daughter of Debra H. Connors and Timothy J. Connors Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married there on Friday evening to Richard Alden Ray Pinkham III, the son of Anne D. Pinkham and Mr. Pinkham Jr., also of Rye. The Rev. Daniel O'Reilly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Honoring Desegregation, And One of Its Architects
description: ELEVEN years before he won Brown v. Board of Education, the landmark school desegregation case, Thurgood Marshall came to Rockland County in 1943 to fight for integration at an elementary school in the Village of Hillburn. This month, Rockland County officials recalled that moment in history and inducted Mr. Marshall, the Supreme Court justice, who died in 1993, into its Civil Rights Hall of Fame. His widow, Cecilia Marshall, traveled from her home in Virginia to attend the ceremony in which the county's Human Rights Commission was renamed the Rosa Parks Human Rights Commission.

title: Gifts of Gab
description: At the risk of offending members of a variety of religions - as well as humanists, agnostics, atheists, celebrators of cultural traditions and ethnic anniversaries - let me present what I still call my annual "Christmas list" of books about language.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 18-Dec. 24; DANCE
description: MURRAY LOUIS has not been noticeably active in New York in recent years -- and you tend to notice when Mr. Louis is active. But on Sunday afternoon the BOSTON CONSERVATORY will honor Mr. Louis with a performance of his "SCHUBERT," a mostly mellow response to that composer's mellow "Trout" Quintet; "Index ( to necessary neurosis)" and "Four Brubeck Pieces." In the Brubeck work Mr. Louis evokes the energy of jazz in joyful but demandingly virtuoso dance. "Index" is equally demanding, requiring its performers to register the tiniest physical inflections with sharp clarity and fluidity.

title: Loud New Jersey
description: HOBOKEN - ALEX SAAVEDRA doesn't quite cut the figure of a family man. A thin steel lip ring glints at the corner of his mouth and, in a mass of tattoos on his left bicep, an anchor bears the letters "S.S.N.J." (for "Steam Ship New Jersey"). He spends long nights in the din of rock clubs. During the formative years of his company, Eyeball Records in Kearny, he lived a few lean months out of an old Chevy Blazer.

title: Stem-cell researcher vows to prove work
Psst: Want to Know a 'Dirty Little Secret'?
description: The prevailing wisdom on skilled work being shifted abroad - outsourced - is that it is anecdotally alarming but not really a big deal economically. Sure, the thinking goes, some software engineers and others are losing their jobs to low-cost workers in India, but there is always churning in the dynamic American job market of 130 million people. It's what makes the United States economy competitive.

title: QUICK BITE/Madison; Tales of the Klondike: Panning for Lunch
description: If you sit at the counter at Central Lunch here -- which is pretty much a given, since there is only one table -- you will see plenty of conversation starters. A hand-lettered sign for the "John F. Kennedy Jr. Klondike" sits next to a framed condolence acknowledgment from Mr. Kennedy and his sister, Caroline. To the right is not one, but two jars of Vegemite spread sitting on a shelf with miniature cereal boxes and condiments. Amid all this, though, Joseph DiBiase cooks away on an old six-burner stove, churning out Klondikes for his hungry blue-collar customers in cast-iron skillets. Mr. DiBiase, whose father, Carmine, opened Central Lunch in the same spot in 1928, gladly answers any questions you might have.

title: Karin Garvey and Robert Jeremiah
description: Karin Elizabeth Garvey was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Alan Jeremiah. The Rev. Joseph S. Dietz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Video Store and Church To Part Ways in Milford
description: The owner of an adult video store renting space inside a building owned by a Milford church said on Tuesday that he planned to close at the end of the month.

title: Masculinity and Its Discontents in Marlboro Country
description: LESS than two weeks after its release, "Brokeback Mountain" is already on the verge of being embalmed in importance. A lightning rod for attention even before it opened, the film has earned plaudits from critics' groups along with predictable sneers, and provoked argument over its gay bona fides. That "Brokeback" is a landmark is a matter of empiricism; its merits as a work of art are a matter of taste. What has gone missing is that this is also that rare American film that seamlessly breaches the divide between the political and the personal, the past and the present. Here, against the backdrop of the great American West, that mythic territory of rugged individualism and the Marlboro Man, is a quietly devastating look at masculinity and its discontents.

title: A Dispute Over Peruvian Artifacts at Yale
description: THE timing may have been coincidental, but one has to wonder.

title: 'John Paul the Great'
description: It was early morning in the Vatican, July 2, 2003, a brilliant morning in the middle of the worst Roman heat wave in a century. The city was quiet, the streets soft with the heat. It was the summer of the dress code battle between the tourists and the guards at St. Peter's Basilica. The tourists wanted to wear shorts and halter tops; this was in violation of the Vatican dress code (slacks, shirts with sleeves), and the guards wouldn't let them in. There were arguments at the entrance, and angry words. Soon a Roman compromise was achieved: No one lost face; everyone got what they needed. The vendors in St. Peter's Square were allowed to sell paper shirts and pants for a euro apiece. The tourists would put them on over their clothes, walk past the guards, and tear the paper off as they entered the dark cool of the church.

title: Correction
description: To correct an editorial on Nov. 27, each State Assembly district has about 130,000 residents, not voters, and each Senate district has about 315,000 residents, not voters.

title: Let There Be Lights
description: Manhasset - LIKE many Long Islanders, you're probably wondering what I could have been thinking when I took the microphone after a priest finished his Christmas blessing during a tree lighting here earlier this month and stated that this wasn't a religious ceremony, but rather a holiday ceremony celebrating a holiday tree.

title: Fetch! Roll Over! Heel! Now, Let's Dance!
description: YORBA LINDA, Calif. - GRETCHEN MAVROVOUNIOTIS considered the theme songs from "Ghostbusters" and "Footloose" before settling on "Can't Stop the Music" by the Village People. The disco beat, she said, is the best for her dance partner, since it best shows off his forward weave and counterclockwise turns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINKEL, HELEN RUTH
description: FINKEL--Helen Ruth. On December 15, 2005. Beloved wife of Gerald and the most wonderful mom to Margot and Suzanne. Devoted daughter of Irving and the late Jean Perfit. Loving sister of Roberta Jacoby and Steven Perfit. We will forever miss Helen's free spirit, gourmet meals, tales of world travel, beautiful smile, strength and courage. Graveside services, 11 am, Sunday, December 18, at United Hebrew Cemetery, SI.

title: Expelling the Ghost of A.I.G. Past
description: LESS than two weeks after Hurricane Katrina ravaged New Orleans, Scott Tramel, an insurance executive, was sitting in a makeshift office -- a former filing room in a sales office -- in Baton Rouge when he saw a shock of white hair cross the hallway. He turned to his colleague, a fellow underwriter at the American Home Insurance Company, a subsidiary of the American International Group, with a look of surprise. "I think that's Martin Sullivan," he said, referring to A.I.G.'s chief executive.
