title: Entertainment Poverty
description: I work at a university promoting civic engagement to students and faculty, and for the past year my colleagues and I have developed training based on "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (Consumed, Rob Walker, Dec. 4). Students are asked to examine themes of race and class along with other ideas, like who is "deserving" of a home makeover, what the role of choice is in accepting a home or any kind of charity, what happens after the television crew leaves. We challenge students to ask how it is that a family with two full-time incomes can afford only what Ty Pennington calls "a shack." What about other members of the community who remain in abject poverty?

title: Renovating a Hartford Landmark
description: PRESIDENTS have stood on the portico of the Hartford Times building, looking onto crowds lining the long mall that spreads in front, down a full city block to Main Street. The building, with its elaborate Beaux-Arts facade, was designed in 1920. For the portico's interior, the painter Ralph Milne Calder created a series of allegorical works about journalism. One bore the words, "And the Press Endures Within."

title: Once Upon a Time, in the Forest of Arden
description: MADISON - MY favorite line in Shakespeare's "As You Like It" comes well into Act II as Rosalind, the banished daughter of the usurped Duke Senior, disguised as a man to flee undetected into the Forest of Arden with her adoring cousin Celia, rebuffs the misguided sexual advances of the silly shepherdess Phebe. "Sell when you can," she tells her. "You are not for all markets."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NATHANSON, SYLVIA K.
description: NATHANSON--Sylvia K., 93. On December 13, 2005. Adored wife of the late Morton A. Nathanson, loving mother of Lucy Nathanson and Judy Keenan (John B.) of Newtown, Pennsylvania, devoted grandma of Woodie, Matthew, Emily and Teddy, proud great-grandmother of Landon, Davis, Cameron and Mallory. Memorial donations to NPR (www.npr.org), or to a favorite charity. www.lifecelebration.com

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 18-Dec. 24; POP/JAZZ
description: As Christmas looms, so do thoughts of family reunions, making this a good week to hear families that play together.

title: Justices Are Urged to Dismiss Padilla Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 - It would be "wholly imprudent" for the Supreme Court to hear Jose Padilla's challenge to his military detention as an enemy combatant, the Bush administration told the court in urging the justices to dismiss Mr. Padilla's case as moot now that the government plans to try him on terrorism charges in a civilian court.

title: For Suozzi, the Signposts Point to Albany
description: TALK of Thomas R. Suozzi's running for governor began even before he took office as Nassau's county executive four years ago.

title: If Cambodia Can Learn to Sing Again
description: IT seems fitting that Arn Chorn-Pond should take on the inordinately ambitious goal of trying to rescue Cambodia's nearly extinct traditional music. After all, it was the music that rescued him.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 15
description: San Diego Chargers (8-5) at Indianapolis Colts (13-0) 1 p.m.

title: 'Teacher Man'
description: To the Editor:

title: Directing in Every Direction at Once
description: ON a recent afternoon in a Midtown rehearsal room, the director Michael Greif was sandpapering a scene with the cast of Nilo Cruz's new play, "Beauty of the Father." His manner was solicitous, low-key, but his concentration was intense.

title: Redirect Tax Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; So Far, Brown and the Knicks Are Stumbling in the Dark
description: FAR from being the toast of the town, the Knicks are being roasted. After 23 games, they are being skewered by fans and ridiculed in the news media for playing like a bunch of rookies and inexperienced veterans.

title: Who Killed Rafik Hariri? Searching for the Truth in the Middle East
description: CAIRO - A FEW days after Baghdad fell to American forces, an Iraqi university professor selling shwarma sandwiches on the side of a road cursed the United States military for invading his city and reducing him to a street vendor. Not long after, a soldier in full combat gear purchased a shwarma and the man jumped up, shouting pro-American slogans and kissing the man on the cheek.

title: Philadelphia
description: WHY GO NOW -- It's a sweet paradox that Philadelphia, a city once populated by holiday-averse Quakers, embraces the Christmas season so exuberantly. But this year, Philadelphia has more reason to celebrate than in many years past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINFIELD, ISABELLE (FINK)
description: KLEINFIELD -- Isabelle (Fink). Devoted mother of Ronny and Jan. Adored Nanny of Nancy and Doug, Patti and Mark, great-grandmother of Casey, Hayley and Kelly. Loving sister of Alice and Arthur Fink, and special Auntie to many nieces and nephews.

title: 'Cooking With Fernet Branca'
Not Just a Grocery Store, a Destination
description: A LINE of cooks chopped and diced at Bernard's Market and Cafe in downtown Glen Head recently, on the other side of the wall from the take-home prepared-food counter where shoppers pay by the pound for Chilean sea bass dinners or a rack of ribs slathered with the special sauce concocted by the executive chef, John Doran.

title: Faith, Morals, Pretzels and Beer (Confession Optional)
description: Wantagh - THE objective: Draw young adults back to the Catholic Church. The strategy: Good cheer, good chat and a good laugh.

title: Yes, Virginia, There Is a Resale Market
description: COME Christmas, it isn't only children who worry whether Santa will deem them naughty or nice. Grown-ups have their own barometers -- and for many in the art world, the most important is the Peter Norton Christmas Project, a gift from the collector and software entrepreneur that arrives in a few thousand select homes each December.

title: Jennifer Bruder and Edward Lavin
description: Jennifer Marie Bruder and Edward Patrick Lavin were married yesterday by the Rev. Jose C. Tentativa Jr. at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Mobsters Run Amok At Drumthwacket
description: Now, it really is "The Sopranos" State.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 18-Dec. 24; TELEVISION
description: Broadway's newest hot young thing, MATTHEW MORRISON ("The Light in the Piazza," "A Naked Girl on the Appian Way"), and ZOOEY DESCHANEL (the films "Elf" and "The Good Girl") play a young couple in trouble in KATHLEEN MARSHALL's remake of "ONCE UPON A MATTRESS" (ABC, Sunday night at 7). TRACEY ULLMAN plays the central character, Princess Winnifred, not the delicate kind of young woman you'd think would have trouble with less than perfectly luxurious sleeping conditions. But in this musical version of "THE PRINCESS AND THE PEA," the cast member that viewers will be watching most is CAROL BURNETT as the controlling Queen Aggravain. Ms. Burnett started her musical-comedy career playing Winnifred in the original 1959 New York stage production. Time flies when you're getting old.

title: From Deep in the Shadows Steps an Unknown Defender
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 17 - Before the Giants' game against the Kansas City Chiefs on Saturday, Chase Blackburn was a rookie linebacker who had not started a games and had no tackles on defense. His biography in the Giants' news media guide did not even include a photograph.

title: Strong Men, Celestial Music
description: A LONE parishioner sat gazing at a gilded altarpiece of Christ. Bluish light seeped through the towering stained glass windows. On this day, St. James's Episcopal Church at 71st Street and Madison Avenue was a bastion of Christmas serenity, save for an organ chamber resounding with neither Bach nor Handel but the decidedly more corporeal sounds of a grunting crew of workers.

title: Where Have All the Howlers Gone?
description: JUST last summer the air was filled with anxiety about an apparent box-office slump, as journalists and studio executives alike wondered why fewer people seemed to be going to the movies. The most obvious explanation -- or at least the one I favored at the time -- was that the movies just weren't good enough. But now that the season of list-making and awards-mongering is upon us and the slump talk has quieted down, I find myself preoccupied with a slightly different, not unrelated worry: What if the problem with Hollywood today is that the movies aren't bad enough?

title: From a Tuscan Kitchen
description: Cooking With

title: On the Road (They Hope)
description: The highway connecting the Hutchinson River Parkway to City Island in the Bronx is a desolate stretch, windy and wooded and mostly absent of traffic. Driving there at night, it sometimes feels as if the lush darkness of nearby Pelham Bay Park will swallow the road at any moment.

title: Proletarian Science
description: A PEOPLE'S HISTORY OF SCIENCE

title: The Way We Eat: The Golden Bowls
description: There are the sweet rewards of life to be found in Aspen, Colo., and then there are the sweets. A tour of the showy hideaways and privileged spaces of this mountain community reveals industrialists and intellectuals with a surprising dedication to candy, from highbrow to low. For some, it even provides inspiration, for example Richard and Debbie Jelinek, a veteran of four health-care businesses and a board member of the Aspen Center for Integrative Health respectively, who named their chocolate Labrador after the Italian confectionery Baci.

title: Transit Union Tries New Tack on Pensions
description: In a move that could alter the shape of its deadlocked contract negotiations, the transit workers' union intends to file a complaint with a state labor board today, asserting that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority cannot legally insist that the union accept less generous pensions for future subway and bus workers.

title: Basket Brawl
description: CRASHING THE BORDERS

title: Correction
description: To correct an editorial on Nov. 27, each State Assembly district has about 130,000 residents, not voters, and each Senate district has about 315,000 residents, not voters.

title: Turning the High Line Into ... the High Life
description: Correction Appended

title: A Trip to the Desert With the Raging Angel of the Artifacts
description: WASHINGTON - FEW people who knew her could have been surprised when Susanne Osthoff was taken hostage in Iraq three weeks ago.

title: Garciaparra Joins the Los Angeles Dodgers
description: At Dodger Stadium, it's beginning to look a lot like Boston. Pending a physical, Nomar Garciaparra will become the latest former member of the Boston Red Sox to join the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Mary A. Littauer, Self-Taught Expert On Horses of Ancient Times, Dies at 93
description: Mary Aiken Littauer, whose love affair with horses began with a childhood pony, blossomed with her marriage to an officer in the cavalry of Czar Nicholas II, and flowered famously when she became a leading expert on horses of ancient times, died on Dec. 7 at her home in Syosset, N.Y. She was 93.

title: Keeping Condos Off the Fairways
description: IN the great Long Island land rush, developers mining the Island's acreage for open space to build homes selling for hundreds of thousands -- even millions -- of dollars, have uncovered a new lode: the golf course.

title: When PayPal Becomes the Back Office, Too
description: WHEN C. J. Liu bills her clients, all it takes is a few mouse clicks, and for the most part their payments end up in her bank account a few days later. She does not need an assistant to send out invoices or to track accounts payable and receivable. She never has to wait for checks to arrive in the mail, and she does not have to visit the bank.

title: A Radio Show That's One for the Record Book
description: Great Neck - OSCAR BRAND has been a folk singer, a writer and a radio show host for a long time. But he has long wanted to be a Guinness world record-holder, too.

title: Adult Entertainment: Mazda Speeds Up Its 6
description: TESTED: 2006 Mazdaspeed 6 WHAT IS IT? Midsize sport sedan "factory tuned" for performance. UNDER THE HOOD: Turbocharged dual-cam 4 (2.3 liters, 274 horsepower); six-speed manual. ATTRACTIONS: Upgrades include all-wheel drive, turbo intercooler, sport suspension. HOW MUCH? $28,555 base, $33,265 as tested (Grand Touring with navigation unit and moonroof). ALTERNATIVES: Audi A4 2.0T quattro $30,460; BMW 325xi $33,495; Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution $31,994; Subaru Impreza WRX STi $33,620.

title: Stampede kills at least 42 in southern India
RETAIL THERAPY
description: Teaming up last week for an unlikely shopping foray, House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and Commerce Secretary Carlos M. Gutierrez toured stores in a Chicago-area shopping center and talked up the economy. "We're off to a good start" this holiday season, said Mr. Gutierrez, who said that only 9 percent of American families had completed their holiday shopping.

title: A Playground Amid the Library Shelves
description: ENERGETIC toddlers practice newfound motor skills in a brightly colored playscape resembling a farmyard. Older children scamper through the facsimile of a New Haven Railroad engine car and create their own theatrical productions in a puppet theater. Ages in between retrieve letters from a miniature mailbox or count the fish in the aquarium. It is a typical afternoon at the new children's library in Fairfield.

title: M. M. Styles, 75, Who Helped to Define Nursing Standards, Dies
description: Margretta Madden Styles, a nursing educator who conceived and helped establish precise national standards for certifying nurses in pediatrics, cardiology and other medical specialties, died on Nov. 20 at her home in Clearwater, Fla. She was 75.

title: Only the Lonely
description: Park Slope is no stranger to luxuries, among them hot stone massages, artisanal cheeses and puppy manicures. Now it is home to a refuge for lonely dolls whose owners may be headed for the slopes of Vail or the beaches of St. Bart's.

title: The Next Council Speaker
description: The speaker of the City Council may be the most important elected leader New Yorkers do not know and have no voice in choosing. The next speaker will be elected by the 51 members of the Council when it convenes early next month, and while the campaign is mainly a matter of one-on-one conversations behind closed doors, the rest of us have an interest in eavesdropping. New York has a strong-mayor form of government, but it's not good to have only one voice in City Hall.

title: Marvin Schwam, 63, Holiday Display Creator, Dies
description: Marvin A. Schwam, who made it a year-round business to prepare for Christmas -- and Hanukkah and Kwanzaa -- as the founder of American Christmas Decorations Inc., died on Dec. 10 at his home in the Chelsea neighborhood in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: An Artist Whose Performance Delivers
description: MONIKA WEISS'S survey exhibition at the Lehman College Art Gallery is her first ever such show in the New York region, and includes recent performance installations and an overview of her work from 1999 onward. The renown of Ms. Weiss, who is Polish-born and based in New York, has endowed this event with considerable stature -- especially among performance artists and those who follow performance art.

title: Accused of Abusing the Badge
description: Around the 83rd Precinct, one police officer was known as Opie. The other called himself King Clerge.

title: Inflation-Fighting Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: NFL: Chargers trample Colts' pristine record
A Laboratory for Liberals?
description: ON Dec. 1, readers of the popular liberal blog TPM Cafe (www.tpmcafe.com) woke up to a celebratory posting: "In Connecticut, Victory is Sweet!"

title: Meet the Developer, and Your New Neighbor
description: ANYONE thinking of buying a floor-through apartment atop the Aurora, a slim 31-story tower at 556 Third Avenue, might want to meet Mitchel Maidman, a third-generation member of an established New York real estate family.

title: Blogging the Vote in Iraq; Waiting for My Purple Finger
description: Web logs invaded the Internet around the same time as the American-led coalition invaded Iraq, so it is fitting that some of the most insightful commentary on the war has come from Iraqi citizens -- students, professionals, homemakers, soldiers, former Baathists and others -- on their personal sites. The Op-Ed page asked several young Iraqi bloggers to write about their experiences during the parliamentary voting on Thursday -- and to share their thoughts about what the election will mean for their country's future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DILLON, ROBERT J.
description: DILLON--Robert J., 61, died peacefully at home on December 16 after a short illness. Beloved husband of Phyllis and father of Alexander, Ph.D. Anthropology, Columbia University, 1976. Fund-raising executive for non-profits, most recently, Edison Schools, Inc. A lover of classical music, he played the clarinet. He was generous and open-hearted, and had a life-long passion for social progress and liberal causes. Service on Monday December 19, 11:30am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEINBERG, LOUIS, M.D.
description: SCHEINBERG--Louis, M.D., 95. Of Stamford, CT, on December 12, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Edith Scheinberg. Loving father of Hal (Elissa), Paul (Suzy), Phyllis (Harvey) Jay, Judith (Seth) Lerner. Dr. Scheinberg is also survived by twelve adoring grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, his beloved sister Etta Bodoff, and his dear friend, Jacqueline Silver. Shiva is being observed in the family home through Monday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, DAVID F.
description: KLEIN--David F. Noted illustrator and longtime resident of Brooklyn Heights, died at 87, December 9. He is survived by his wife Betsy, sister Pauline Ashley and her family.

title: While Iraq Counts Votes, Politicians Vie for Leverage
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 17 - As election workers continued counting ballots from Thursday's elections, political leaders began talks on Saturday to stake out their positions in advance of forming the new, four-year government.

title: THINKING SMALL
description: Ever since Ithaca College announced its CellFlix festival last month, phones there have been ringing nonstop -- not just with young directors seeking a break, but also with wireless companies vying to sponsor the event. So far, though, the industry is getting a busy signal.

title: If You Can Handle the Perks, Please Stay in the Kitchen
description: Turnover in the restaurant industry is notoriously high, anywhere from 45 percent to well over 100 percent annually, depending on the job and the restaurant. But a recovering economy and a tighter labor market have made the problem even more acute.

title: This Call May Be Monitored ...
description: On Oct. 17, 2002, the head of the National Security Agency, Lt. Gen. Michael Hayden, made an eloquent plea to a joint House-Senate inquiry on intelligence for a sober national discussion about whether the line between liberty and security should be shifted after the 9/11 attacks, and if so, precisely how far. He reminded the lawmakers that the rules against his agency's spying on Americans, carefully written decades earlier, were based on protecting fundamental constitutional rights.

title: Correction
description: To correct an editorial on Nov. 27, each State Assembly district has about 130,000 residents, not voters, and each Senate district has about 315,000 residents, not voters.

title: Big Developments Along the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Never Mind the Fat Lady
description: GAME SIX of the 1986 World Series: I was in the upper deck of Shea Stadium, preparing for what seemed like the inevitable dispatching of my team to a cold, titleless winter by the Boston Red Sox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENSCH, HOMER R.
description: MENSCH--Homer R. My teacher, my mentor, my anchor, my friend. You are irreplaceable. With all my heart, I love you forever. Judy

title: Tensions Rise as More Flee Cuba for U.S.
description: MIAMI, Dec. 17 - The number of Cubans intercepted at sea while trying to reach the United States is at its highest level since tens of thousands took to the Florida Straits on makeshift rafts and in small boats in the 1994 exodus sanctioned by President Fidel Castro.

title: The President's Oval Office Address
description: The following is text of President George W. Bush's speech from the Oval Office regarding the state of the war in Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Inventive Solutions To Newspaper Thievery
description: To the Editor:

title: A View of Ohio By Way of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Gay Cowboys Hit a Home Run
description: WHAT if they held a culture war and no one fired a shot? That's the compelling tale of "Brokeback Mountain." Here is a heavily promoted American movie depicting two men having sex -- the precise sex act that was still a crime in some states until the Supreme Court struck down sodomy laws just two and a half years ago -- but there is no controversy, no Fox News tar and feathering, no roar from the religious right. "Brokeback Mountain" has instead become the unlikely Oscar favorite, propelled by its bicoastal sweep of critics' awards, by its unexpected dominance of the far less highfalutin Golden Globes and, perhaps most of all, by the lure of a gold rush. Last weekend it opened to the highest per-screen average of any movie this year.

title: U.S., Voicing Fears of Tampered Elections, Is Rebuked by Colombia
description: President lvaro Uribe of Colombia, the Bush administration's closest ally in Latin America, demanded Friday that the United States stop interfering in Colombia after the American ambassador in Bogot, William Wood, expressed concern that right-wing paramilitary commanders could manipulate congressional elections in March.

title: Jay Leno, David Letterman and Conan O'Brien
description: Jay Leno

title: A Neighborhood Comes Into Its Own
description: Correction Appended

title: Funny, They Did Look Jewish
description: In 1994, a team of visionaries announced that they would form a new kind of entertainment company, one that would cut through Hollywood's quagmire of ego and create a conduit between film, television, music, animation and software.

title: The Way We Eat: Free Ranging
description: Candy can be made by cooks of all skill levels, as long as they don't mind standing and stirring for what seems like an eternity (but is really only 20 to 30 minutes). Instant gratification can be more easily found at www.bigtipscandy.com, where Will Noonan and Beth Kimmerle stock obscure retro candies. And if you would like to know when Tootsie Rolls and jelly beans were created, Delphine Moreau's "Candy," due out in February, contains a candy time line.

title: Lit Chick
description: THE BRONT PROJECT

title: Celtics' Davis Seems to Be Putting His Selfish Ways in the Past
description: Ricky Davis has decked his lawn with plastic reindeer and hung Christmas lights all around his suburban Boston house. But he insists he is not all for show anymore.

title: Agreement Reached at Trade Talks
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 18 -A The worldAs leading trading nations reached an agreement here on Sunday evening resolving a series of narrow but troublesome issues that have blocked a global trade agreement for the last three years.

title: Water Heaters: Tanks or No Tanks?
description: FEW people would run a car all day so it's warm when they're ready to drive. But many homeowners basically do something just like that when they use tank-type water heaters in their houses. "That's why I like tankless water heaters," said Alex Wilson, executive editor of Environmental Building News, a trade newsletter published in Brattleboro, Vt.

title: Creating Housing for Teachers
description: Santa Clara, Calif. - AIMEE BRINKS, a teacher in her late 20's, lives by herself in a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment with a private garage and patio in the heart of Silicon Valley, one of the nation's most expensive housing markets.

title: The Price of Oil
description: More than 35 years ago, an offshore drilling rig spilled approximately three million gallons of oil into the waters near Santa Barbara. A massive slick covered hundreds of square miles and killed thousands of birds, seals and dolphins; the white beaches of California turned black with crude. Night after night, the TV networks showed oil-covered birds flopping in their death throes on fouled beaches. Popular outrage was heightened by the attitude of Fred Hartley, president of Union Oil, which operated the offending rig. In Senate testimony, he chided environmentalists and journalists for over-reacting to the loss of bird life.

title: Bhutan's king says he'll step down
Catching Early Steps on the Olympic Trail
description: CAN'T get to Turin this February to watch the 2006 Olympics? No problem. Over the next few weeks, you can get a taste of the Olympic experience by watching some top American athletes prepare for the Winter Games on home soil. Whether it's at the U.S. Figure Skating Championship in St. Louis or the U.S. Olympic Snowboarding competition in New Jersey, hundreds of aspiring Olympians (and some former Olympians back for another attempt at the gold) will be going all-out in their efforts to earn a plane ticket to Italy.

title: A Step Too Far on DNA Profiles
description: Gov. George Pataki is intent on expanding New York's use of DNA evidence to help solve crimes. His sense of urgency is warranted. The power of DNA technology to help solve violent crimes and exonerate the innocent is well established, and New York -- one of just seven states at this point not to include DNA profiles of all convicted felons in its DNA database -- could plainly do more to tap its potential to enhance public safety.

title: Hard Rock's First Condo Hotel Is in San Diego
description: Rolling stones who want to gather a little moss now and then will be able to buy space under the Hard Rock's big corporate tent starting this month.

title: Paperback Fiction
Sydney Leff, 104, Artist With an Eye for Music, Dies
description: Sydney Leff, a commercial artist who was almost certainly the last surviving illustrator of sheet music from the golden age of Tin Pan Alley, died on Dec. 10 at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 104 and had lived for many years in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: 'Ringers' Give the Gift of Voice
description: MUSIC fans may notice certain faces popping up regularly in concerts this holiday season, whether the group on stage is the Riverdale Choral Society, the Sound Shore Chorale or a church choir. Known as "ringers" but preferring the terms "added voices" or "fill-ins," they are accomplished volunteers who can sing choral works like Bach's "Magnificat" or Vivaldi's "Gloria" at virtually a moment's notice, making them a godsend to local choral directors wishing to swell their ranks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUSMAN, ALVIN
description: HAUSMAN--Alvin. May 31, 1923 to December 13, 2005; of Pembroke Pines, Florida. Beloved husband of Gloria, loving father of Marc and Bill, devoted brother-in-law of Janet Zagon, David & Audrey Robbins and dear uncle to his nieces and nephews, awardwinning architect in New York City for more than 40 years, avid golfer, culinary master and gracious host. We will miss you.

title: CHILDRENS'S BEST SELLERS: December 18, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Love and Power, Potent Aphrodisiacs
description: THE married man and the younger woman in Rob Handel's "Aphrodisiac," at Long Wharf Theater, are having dinner at an out-of-the-way restaurant when she announces that she's pregnant. He doesn't react the way she wants him to, and she starts smashing dishes.

title: Correction
description: A response in the Q&A column on Dec. 4, about tenants in a condominium conversion, misstated the rights of market-rate tenants 62 and older in New York State. According to the state attorney general's office, unregulated tenants of any age have no protection in either an eviction or noneviction plan if their leases expire before the plan becomes effective.

title: 'Come Back to Afghanistan'
German hostage released in Iraq
Eastford, Dry No More
description: When the residents of Eastford voted for an ordinance last week that will allow a new restaurant to sell beer and wine this spring, they ended more than a century without alcohol sales there. And they left Bridgewater as the only so-called dry town in the state.

title: Finding Travelers Exposed to Disease
description: To address problems brought to light by the SARS outbreak in 2003, federal health officials have proposed regulations that would make it easier to contact travelers exposed to infectious diseases.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: FREE NIGHT IN MIAMI -- The Mandarin Oriental in Miami has a Fifth Anniversary, Fifth Night Free offer that includes a 35 percent discount off normal rates. Until May 31, guests who reserve for at least five nights starting at $405 a night from Sunday through Thursday, and $445 Friday and Saturday, get the fifth night free; standard rates start at $675. A tax of 13 percent is extra. For reservations, www.mandarinoriental.com or call 866-888-6780.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 18-Dec. 24; FILM
description: When it comes to taste in movies, it figures that STEPHEN SONDHEIM's should be as broad, unpredictable and perverse as the subjects he chooses for musicals, no one of which is like any other. Even so, certain themes that recur in this master game player's shows also tend to crop up in his favorite movies.

title: In Madrid, Pinching Euros, by Day and All Night Long
description: AT 5:30 in the morning, on Calle Mara de Molina, a broad boulevard in the Salamanca district of Madrid, it is nearly impossible to get a taxi. This is not because taxis stop running this late -- or early, depending on your orientation -- but because everyone else in the city is also hunting for a ride. This quest isn't limited to Madrid's youth; late-night buses hurtle by shivering taxi seekers, filled to capacity with revelers of all ages.

title: Wally's World Isn't Woebegone In Minnesota
description: Shannon Szczerbiak knew the time. At 12:01 a.m. on Thursday, she informed her husband, Wally, that the trade market was open for business, enabling him to be back in a rumor mill fueled by Ron Artest's demand to be traded from Indiana.

title: Isabel Walcott and Michael Hilborn
description: Isabel Walcott and Michael David Hilborn were married last evening at the Harvard Club in New York. Beth K. Lamont, a chaplain of the American Humanist Association, officiated.

title: On the Web
description: Philadelphia is already starting its yearlong celebration of Benjamin Franklin's 300th birthday. This underdog city used to be overshadowed by New York, but it is now experiencing its own social and cultural renaissance. From Center City to Old City -- and fringe neighborhoods like Northern Liberties, with its new galleries and restaurants -- a video tour is at nytimes.com/travel. ADVISORY: TRAVEL NOTES

title: Thrown for a Yield Curve
description: ALAN GREENSPAN, the Federal Reserve chairman, raised more than a few eyebrows in November when he said in testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress that there was no need to worry that the yield curve had flattened and was close to inverting. The yield curve, he said, has lost its ability to forecast recessions.

title: Inequities Beyond the City
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Is Where the Fans Are
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y. - YOU drive down a rural lane near the base of Mount Overlook, off Route 212 on the east side of Woodstock, and negotiate a stretch of unlit bends and rises until you reach a turnoff marked with only a number. Turn right into the woods, bounce down a pitted dirt road for a bit and you come to a field where an older gentleman with a flashlight helps you find a parking spot. Exiting your car, you find yourself under a canopy of stars outside a large timber building, hearty blues music seeping out into the cold December night.

title: Trip Down a Memorable Lane
description: To the Editor:

title: An Act of Kindness 20 Years Ago, Resonating Today
description: In Liberia, stories about near-death run-ins with the deranged gun-toting maniacs who have run the country into the ground for the last quarter-century are a dime a dozen. Even the president-elect has one.

title: Irsay Can Get Satisfaction as the Laid-Back Owner of the Colts
description: It was a day before the kickoff of what Tony Dungy later called the defining game of the Indianapolis Colts' season, and the team owner was on the line. About a decade ago, this might have been bad news. Robert Irsay, the owner at the time, was known for phoning plays down to the coaches on the sideline or ordering them in ear-splitting midgame tirades to bench a quarterback.

title: After Limping Along, Patriots Show Their Old Swagger
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 17 - Tom Brady stood under center with eye black smudging his cheeks, waiting as his offensive linemen settled in for the next bit of New England Patriots wizardry.

title: Call of the Wild

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 18-Dec. 24; THEATER
description: It's been almost 10 years since the actor MARK RYLANCE became the first artistic director of SHAKESPEARE'S GLOBE, the playhouse on the South Bank of the Thames in London modeled on the Elizabethan original. In that time Mr. Rylance and his company have established the Globe as a thriving artistic enterprise. But only New Yorkers who have seen the company at its home would know why: the troupe has traveled to New York only once, for a brief visit to the Brooklyn Academy of Music with a middling "Cymbeline" in 2002.

title: Bookshelf: Children's Books in Brief
description: A LITTLE HISTORY OF THE WORLD. By E. H. Gombrich. Illustrated by Clifford Harper. Translated by Caroline Mustill. Yale University. $25. (All ages) "What I have always loved best about the history of the world is that it is true . . . often far more exciting and amazing than anything we could invent." This 1936 book, updated and translated from German into English for the first time, takes young readers from early human skulls (people "who were better at biting than we are today") to World War II and the atomic bomb. This "little history" has aged amazingly well.

He was a survivor who lived with dignity inspite of physical challenges. Services Sunday 1:45pm at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre. title: Urban Dread
description: "THESE writings are a strange mix of the scientifically exact and the imprecise." The quotation refers to a bundle of papers in one of the stories in China Miville's LOOKING FOR JAKE (Del Rey/Ballantine, paper, $13.95), but the same description could apply to the narrative strategy he adopts throughout this fine collection. The story in question, "Reports of Certain Events in London," deals with the attempts of a shadowy Brotherhood of self-appointed investigators to map what they call "wild streets" -- bits and pieces of lanes and alleys that suddenly manifest themselves in otherwise unremarkable neighborhoods, then vanish without leaving any physical trace. From this unlikely premise, Miville wrests a compelling tale of obsession.

title: Danger Signs
description: This questionnaire is trawling for mental illness. Here are some questions taken directly from TeenScreen: Has there been a time when nothing was fun for you and you just weren't interested in anything? Has there been a time when you felt you couldn't do anything well or that you weren't as good-looking or as smart as other people? Have you often felt very nervous when you've had to do things in front of people?

description: PESKIN--Ira.Beloved and devoted companion of Beatrice Krassner. Rest in peace.

title: CASTILLO DE SAN FELIPE DEL MORRO, JULY 6, 2005
description: Manuel Gonzales, a second-class petty officer in the Coast Guard stationed in Key West, Fla., with his wife, Rebecca, a third-grade teacher. "We went to Puerto Rico for our first anniversary, kind of a delayed honeymoon. This was our first time there. At the fort, they give you a map. You go by the numbers and then you read off your little brochure about the different sections. My wife, being a teacher, goes by the book, so we had to look at pretty much everything, in order. She's intrigued by all the history. I'm looking out to the water; I'm more intrigued with the boating and the waves. I don't even know if I was paying attention to her."

title: Plan Offers Training For Jobs In Trades
description: New Rochelle - REMEMBERING a period in the late 1990's when New Roc City, a family entertainment center, was being built here, City Councilman James Stowe said recently: "At that time, individuals expressed interest in doing the work but learned that they didn't have the proper training or the resources to enter the trades. This time, we want to be ahead of the curve."

title: Long-Distance Love
description: TUCKED in the shadow of the No. 7 elevated tracks in Woodside, Queens, the photographs resemble the Depression-era images captured by Walker Evans. The people in these pictures wear humble clothes and stark expressions. They are very poor, but they are not Americans from the 1930's. They are 21st-century Ecuadoreans, framed by little luxuries sent by their kin from the big city.

title: Up Front
description: During the 2004 presidential campaign, more than 7,000 scientists, including at least 20 Nobel laureates, signed a petition organized by the Union of Concerned Scientists, an advocacy group based in Cambridge, Mass., charging the Bush administration with distorting scientific information to advance its political agenda. Meanwhile, a political action group called Scientists and Engineers for Change spoke out against President Bush at events in Ohio, Pennsylvania and other swing states.

title: A Step Too Far on DNA Profiles
description: Gov. George Pataki is eager to expand New York's use of DNA evidence to enhance public safety. The power of DNA technology to help solve violent crimes and exonerate the innocent is well established, and New York -- one of just seven states at this point not to include DNA profiles of all convicted felons in its DNA database -- could plainly do more to tap its potential.

title: New World Economy
description: In recent weeks, looking toward next year's midterm elections, leaders of both parties have engaged in highly charged arguments about withdrawal from Iraq, Medicaid shortfalls and allegations of Republican corruption. Anyone bothering to peruse the rest of the front page, however, might have noticed a few items that seemed tangentially related, but that, together, tell a story that is far more consequential for the next 50 years of American life. First, just before Thanksgiving, General Motors, buckling under the weight of $2 billion in losses, announced that it now planned to lay off 30,000 workers and scale back or close a dozen plants. A few days later, at the traditional commencement of the holiday season, thousands of American consumers began lining up in the dark hours of morning to be among the first to pile into Wal-Mart, hoping to re-emerge with discounted laptops and Xboxes under their arms. Wal-Mart has now inherited G.M.'s mantle as the largest employer in the United States, which is why these snapshots of two corporations, taken in a single week, say more about America's economic trajectory than any truckload of spreadsheets ever could.

title: A Symbol of the 60's Is Set to Soar Once Again
description: When T.W.A. ceased to exist as an airline in December 2001, its planes were repainted and its flights relisted under the name of its purchaser, American Airlines. But in New York, the troubled business left a physical legacy, a landmark terminal at Kennedy Airport that by the decade's end may once again help travelers go up, up and away.

title: Asleep in a House of Worship, Because It's Too Cold to Sleep Outside
description: Chappaqua - IT was 26 degrees on a clear December night; by morning, the temperature would be 18. At about 9:30 p.m. there was a knock on the church door, and in came a group, all but one of them men, letting in a rush of frigid wind. It was their third night sleeping at the Congregational Church here, and the group knew the drill. After greeting their hosts, each retrieved an air mattress and a sleeping bag from a storage space, then laid them out in the parish hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUCKERMAN, SIDNEY, M.D.
description: ZUCKERMAN--Sidney, M.D., 87. On December 14 in Boca Raton, Fl. Beloved husband of Irene, his wife and partner for 60 years. Born in New York City, he graduated from Stuyvesant High School, Columbia College and New York Medical College. A Captain in the Army in World War II, he was a prominent allergist in Forest Hills and Manhasset, where he lived for 40 years. Former Medical Director of Unisys and a "Jack of all trades", he enjoyed gardening, carpentry, electronics, bridge and baking his famous apple pies. He is survived by devoted daughters Elaine, Laurie and Amy, sons-in-law Paul, Steve and Jeff, grandchildren Noah, Josh and Christine, Jillian, Ashley, Adam and Jason. He is predeceased by son, Jed. Memorial service will be held at 3PM at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 7240 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, Fl.

Born July 21, 1914 in Yeagertown, PA. to John William and Janet McCartney Riden. Widow of James J. Lucey, MD, mother of Denis J. Lucey III, MD (Toni), Deborah A.L. Kroop (Howard), Jane C.L. Deegan (Joseph) and the late James McC. Lucey. Grandmother of Maya, Catherine, Samuel; Lara, Seth; Seamus, Liam. Great grandmother of Samuel and Una. Private interment, Birch Hill, Burnham, PA. A memorial mass is planned for All Saints Chapel at Springfield Residence, Wyndmoor, PA early in 2006.

The well-heeled crowd was there to celebrate the Eucharist with the leader of Nigeria's Anglican Church, Archbishop Peter J. Akinola.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRESTON, JANE ELIZABETH
description: PRESTON--Jane Elizabeth. 76, of Sarasota, FL, and North Fork, Long Island, died November 15th, 2005, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. Ms. Preston was the daughter of Margaret (Walker) and Harry Preston, and grew up in Fairlawn, NJ. She was an artist, an avid sailor, and a lifelong lover of books and animals. She studied art under the Abstract Expressionist Hans Hoffman at his New York studio and later at the University of California Berkeley. She spent five years studying painting in France. She worked for many years as an art director at Macmillan Publishing in New York City, and continued her painting and book design from her studios in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn and in Jamesport. In the 1980's she became active in local real estate and also rehabilitated several Brooklyn and North Fork houses, doing much of the work herself. She was an enthusiastic sailor, sometimes delivering boats between Newport, RI and Florida, and earned a "sixpack" Coast Guard license that certified her to carry up to six paying passengers. In leisure times, she sailed her blue Bristol on Peconic Bay. She is mourned by her longtime companion Virginia Olga Lee; by her large family, including her sisters-in-law Ruth Preston and Wilhelmina (Billie) Preston and her nieces and nephews; and by her many friends. Cremation was private. Interment will be at Orient Central Cemetery at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to TideWell Hospice, 5955 Rand Boulevard,Sarasota, FL 34238 (attention: donations) or to North Fork Women for Women Fund, P.O. Box 804, Greenport, NY 11944-0804.

Less well known, though, are his writings about race, and how living in Princeton, with its vibrant middle-class African-American community, influenced him in what were then progressive racial views.

title: Illness as More Than Metaphor
description: I read with deep concern David Rieff's article (Dec. 4) about his mother, Susan Sontag, and her pursuit of life in the face of death. We will all face these hard choices someday. Given the nature of medicine and what will happen as the millions of baby boomers age, we will need to make provisions for our own deaths. We need not be so greedy of our days -- why not take as many as are really good, and leave the rest to our children?

title: The Business of Voting
description: Diebold, the controversial electronic voting machine manufacturer, is coming off a tumultuous week. Its chief executive, Walden O'Dell, resigned. It was hit with a pair of class-action lawsuits charging insider trading and misrepresentation, and a county in Florida concluded that Diebold's voting machines could be hacked. The company should use Mr. O'Dell's departure to reassess its flawed approach to its business. The counting of votes is a public trust. Diebold, whose machines count many votes, has never acted as if it understood this.

title: In a Hurry to Diversify Beyond Submarines and Luck
description: IN southeastern Connecticut, long the land of big submarines and, more recently, big gambling, business and government leaders say they have learned their lesson. No more dependency on one or two industries -- or three, if the drug maker Pfizer, which is trying to trim $4 billion from its household budget by 2008, is counted -- and no more betting on dumb luck to keep the economy humming.

title: The Restless Children of the Dalai Lama
description: Early one morning in April 1998, a middle-aged Tibetan named Thupten Ngodup poured gasoline over himself in a public toilet in downtown New Delhi and struck a match. Outside, the Indian police were breaking up a hunger strike organized by the Tibetan Youth Congress, the largest pro-independence organization among the approximately 140,000 Tibetans who have lived in exile since the Dalai Lama fled Chinese-ruled Tibet in 1959. The Tibetans had been protesting for more than six weeks against U.N. inaction on Tibet, which China invaded and occupied in 1950, subsequently killing -- through execution, torture and starvation -- as many as 1.2 million people, according to Tibetans, and destroying tens of thousands of Buddhist monasteries and temples.

title: Corzine's Choice of Counsel Puts the Bosses on Notice
description: In the six years since Jon S. Corzine left his lavish office on Wall Street for the bruising back alley of New Jersey politics, the state's Democratic bosses have treated him with the same regard a gang of bullies usually give to a rich, nave new classmate.

title: On a Creek With a Past, Waterfront Dreams
description: JUST above the last G train stop in Brooklyn, in Greenpoint, there lies a working-class commercial strip lined with bodegas, electronics stores, and Polish and Mexican restaurants. But as a visitor walks north on Manhattan Avenue toward Newtown Creek, and as the alphabetically arranged cross streets descend from Huron to Green to Freeman to Eagle, signs of activity are fewer and farther between: an old furniture store here, a cheap hotel there.

title: Woman, 26, Is Stabbed to Death at Home
description: A 26-year old East Harlem woman was stabbed to death in her apartment on Friday while two of her children were home with her, the police said yesterday.

title: In Madrid, Pinching Euros, by Day and All Night Long
description: AT 5:30 in the morning, on Calle Mara de Molina, a broad boulevard in the Salamanca district of Madrid, it is nearly impossible to get a taxi. This is not because taxis stop running this late - or early, depending on your orientation - but because everyone else in the city is also hunting for a ride. This quest isn't limited to Madrid's youth; late-night buses hurtle by shivering taxi seekers, filled to capacity with revelers of all ages.

title: What Are the Blogs Saying About Me?
description: ALMOST every author I know with a new book does it -- the embarrassing, nearly irresistible, ritualistic dip into Internet-assisted narcissism. I know I do. Prodded by a combination of curiosity and dread, I'll scour the Web not just to ascertain sales (impossible) or check out the press coverage, but to get a sense of what ordinary readers are saying about my book when they think I'm not listening.

title: Crews Cleaning Heating Oil Spill in Rahway River
description: Environmental crews are spending the weekend cleaning up roughly 84,000 gallons of heating oil and water that spilled from a feeding pipe at the ConocoPhillips Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J., and into the Rahway River and onto its banks, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Cowboys, Just Like in the Movie
description: Lusk, Wyo. - THERE are missile silos tucked throughout the hills around the high plains here, a town 140 miles north of Cheyenne with more sheep than people, with one stop light, no bowling alley or movie theater and a year-round population just above 1,000. Although the silos, with their sinister nuclear payloads, are well concealed, most locals know where to find them. Wyoming's wide-open spaces are like that, with space enough to conceal wide-open secrets, and good reasons to do so.

title: Yes, We Shop, but We Don't Really Want To
description: An abiding mystery of Christmas (sorry, "the holidays") is why people spend so much time doing something they don't really want to do. If they truly believed in devoting a good part of several weeks to struggling through crowded stores, agonizing over lists, making purchases they can't afford -- if they really thought it was time and money well spent -- that would be one thing. But here's the season's little open secret: A lot of them don't think so.

"Don't ask questions," he shouts in response. "What've you got hands for, huh? Take!"

Wagner, of 2929 Entertainment, a holding company encompassing a movie production and distribution complex that is moving toward all-digital delivery.

description: Dori Kayli Pasternak, a daughter of Lois and Paul Pasternak of Coral Springs, Fla., was married last evening to Jason Randall Busell, the son of Sandra and Richard Busell of East Meadow, N.Y. description: When Gov. George E. Pataki took a political trip to New Hampshire last week as the threat of a transit strike loomed in New York City, he was chided by Democrats and union officials for absenteeism in the face of a potential crisis that could strand millions of subway and bus riders each day.

title: 'The Gang That Wouldn't Write Straight'
description: "New Journalism" is a slippery phrase. When Tom Wolfe made it the title of a 1973 anthology featuring pieces from such writers as Gay Talese, Hunter Thompson, Joan Didion, Norman Mailer, and others, he meant it to be a declaration of independence from any journalism that had preceded it. But there were others-particularly the New Yorker crowd that had been stung by "Tiny Mummies"-who criticized Wolfe for trying to trademark a technique that had existed for over two hundred years. They contended that there was nothing new about New Journalism.

title: The Young Lionesses

title: Keep the Big Wheels Turning
description: IF you're coming out of "The Color Purple" on a Friday night and find every yellow cab taken, all is not lost: waiting nearby is probably a three-wheeled, human-powered rickshaw known as a pedicab. In recent years, pedicabs have become ubiquitous in Midtown. They pick up theatergoers on Broadway, courting couples in Central Park and give gawking tourists a new way to stare at the tall buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, RUTH (NEE GROSSMAN)

She will be forever remembered and loved deeply by friends and family. Services 11:30 AM Sunday at Boulevard Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, 516-295-3100.

description: NEW ORLEANS - More than 100 of them drowned. Sixteen died trapped in attics. More than 40 died of heart failure or respiratory problems, including running out of oxygen. At least 65 died because help -- shelter, water or a simple dose of insulin -- came too late.

title: The Fires Last Time
description: I LIKED it when it had just snowed because it hid what was underneath. The piles and piles of uncollected trash, the vacant lots that resembled pastures sprinkled with government powdered milk. I couldn't see the charred bricks, the junked furniture, the dirty diapers or anything that lay waste atop the rubble.

description: Leach may have some revolutionary ideas about offensive football, but he also must have one heck of a defense. You cannot beat a team like Nebraska 70-10 on offense alone. How about some credit for the defensive coach?

description: GOLDRING--Frederick Martin passed away suddenly Saturday, December 10, 2005 in Fresno, CA. He was a good and loving friend and we will miss his loyal and cheerful manner, we send condolences to his marvelous wife Cookie and his children, Wendi and Neil Steinman, Stacy Goldring, Michael and Kimberly Goldring, and his six wonderful grandchildren. His love and devotion and intellectual curiosity will be missed by everyone he touched. Love, Elissa Epstein, Jill and Starker White, Mark Epstein and Debra Epstein

title: GASOLINE TAX COULD RISE
description: A possible increase in the state's gasoline tax is back on the table. During his election campaign, the governor-elect, Jon S. Corzine, said he would not raise the tax while gasoline prices were so high. But with the state facing a projected budget deficit that could be as much as $6 billion, he told reporters last Tuesday that he could not rule out an increase to the 14.5-cent-per-gallon tax. Speaking at a meeting of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association in Iselin, Mr. Corzine echoed a theme that has marked nearly all of his significant speeches since being elected last month: with a hole in the state's $38 billion budget, New Jersey faces challenges to put its economic house in order.

title: Bush on the Patriot Act and Eavesdropping
description: Following are excerpts of a transcription of President Bush's weekly radio address yesterday as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript is on the Web at www.nytimes/washington.

title: Black and White and Technicolor All Over
description: WHEN Rob Reiner's "Rumor Has It" opens on Christmas Day, audiences will meet Jennifer Aniston as a surprisingly diffident New York Times obituary writer who characterizes herself as a journalist "only in a manner of speaking." She mentions her profession as an afterthought when trying to crash a conference to meet Kevin Costner, the man who may or may not be her father, and who may or may not be the inspiration for the character played by Dustin Hoffman in "The Graduate." While counting the ways in which her life is not working, she laments to him, "I'm in a career that is going absolutely nowhere."

title: King Cab
description: NEW YORK, Dec. 18, 1984 - You're late. The Checker cab you hail lurches to the curb, brakes squealing like a throttled pullet. You reach for the trademark stripe of black-and-white checkers on its yellow doors and climb in. Slamming the door shut makes a bucket-of-bolts clatter that goes on like an echo in a box canyon. The back seat is way back there, a short stroll from the door. You pass the two "jump seats," folded into the floor. They look ravaged, though rarely have you seen them used.

Visiting Sunday 7:009:00 and Monday 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM, Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Funeral service Tuesday, 10:00 AM, St. John's Episcopal church. Interment Kensico Cemetery. title: When You Ride With Jesus, Don't Tailgate
description: IT was a cold night in a quiet Staten Island neighborhood, but Christ Episcopal Church, a Gothic Revival marvel of gray limestone and stained glass, was full of people and light and singing. The lights were of the klieg variety, though, and many of the well-scrubbed people had been hired to fill the pews.

title: Psst: Want to Know A 'Dirty Little Secret'?
description: The prevailing wisdom on skilled work being shifted abroad -- outsourced -- is that it is anecdotally alarming but not really a big deal economically. Sure, the thinking goes, some software engineers and others are losing their jobs to low-cost workers in India, but there is always churning in the dynamic American job market of 130 million people. It's what makes the United States economy competitive.

Malloy, and other city officials who it said encouraged illegal immigration by setting up an a special area for day laborers to be hired.

title: We Are (Still) Family
description: I was 16 the first holiday my boyfriend took me to his parents' house in Riverside, Calif. It was Memorial Day, 1976, and there was a crowd in the driveway where the barbecuing was going on. I was the only white person there, and I was partly terrified and partly amused, in my halter dress, navigating the relatives. The men were fairly gleeful at the sight of a small blonde with Farrah Fawcett hair holding hands with a 6-foot-4 basketball player with a giant Afro. But I was also introduced to curious faces and a few baleful frowns. Two women refused to shake my hand when I held it out -- my boyfriend's older sister and his older cousin, who said, "I don't believe this."

title: Correction

title: Reading Between the Lines and Weapons
description: THE Housatonic Museum of Art is displaying an exhibition of the work of Matt Ernst and Rob Roy, two midcareer American artists with much on their minds. Most prominently, both are interested in war, and the conflict in the Middle East in which the United States finds itself embroiled. Their images, in "Icons for a New Century," are an artistic amplification of this.

title: And an Award For the Governor
description: Speaking of ethnic New Jersey, Mr. Codey received an Irishman of the Year award from an organization called the St. Patrick's Guard of Honor last weekend. The criteria for the award, presented in front of some 400 Irish New Jerseyans at Mayfair Farms in West Orange, are straightforward: it goes each year to a "successful Irishman," according to the governor's spokeswoman, Kelley Heck.

title: And in the Center Ring, Grace at 14
description: THE boy on the platform faces a pair of curlicued bronze candelabra bearing scarlet candles. He removes the central taper from one of them, inserts the index finger of his right hand into the metal hollow, upends himself and balances, his svelte, perfectly proportioned body taut and unwavering, supported only by the one finger.

title: With a Wink, Pointing the Way to the 'Authentic'
description: RUBIES is a dark, popular wine bar on a fashionable street in Phnom Penh, and on any given night there you can find foreign aid workers carping about Cambodia and, next to them, other expatriates carping about foreign aid workers. One evening at the end of March, however, my friend Patrick and I arrived early enough to find Rubies empty, the wide sofa at the rear of the bar unoccupied but for a guidebook forgotten by some hurried backpacker.

title: The Dread Days When the Pipes Went Haywire
description: On the Sunday morning after Thanksgiving, a smelly brown liquid started to leak into Maysa Abdullah's toilet and bathtub. By 4 p.m., the trickle had become a two-foot-high geyser of sewage. It splashed Ms. Abdullah in the face when she got too near, flowed out of the bathroom, and ran through the apartment she rents in a semiattached house on a working-class block of Lodovick Avenue in Pelham Gardens, in the North Bronx.

description: To the Editor:

title: Home for the Hostages
description: The Thanksgiving dinner, lovingly planned, was before us. That's when a friend of my host went on the attack about something I had carelessly said last summer that still bothered her. Well, F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote that you never know how much space you occupy in other people's lives. That is, I'd add, until you run into them for the holidays. At any rate, I told her I had meant no offense. But she wasn't having it, and left me quivering like a cranberry mold.

description: GEORGNELL ADDISON isn't sure which is worse -- the math she is struggling with at White Plains High School or the cold weather.

title: Lutes + Synthesizers +Rock Beats = America's Most Popular Christmas Music?
description: The Kansas Coliseum is a 12,200-seat hockey arena that rises above a wind-lashed plain 11 miles north of Wichita. On a brisk evening a few days before Thanksgiving, 36 snowmen, gingerbread men and elves -- local theater students, concealed beneath sports mascot-style costumes -- were standing outside, greeting a throng of arriving concertgoers. The crowd had come to see the instrumental ensemble Mannheim Steamroller, but the music onstage was just part of what the band likes to call "the complete Mannheim Christmas experience," a full sensory immersion in holiday pomp. Carolers roamed the arena corridors. Santa-hat-wearing ushers distributed programs. Balconies were festooned with holly. The pice de rsistance, located at the rear of the arena floor, was the 2,000-square-foot "Christmas village" diorama: a snow-dusted Old World hamlet inhabited by glassy-eyed dolls and encircled by a chugging miniature train. About a half-hour before the show started, four men dressed as toy soldiers marched out in lock step to stand sentry around the diorama's perimeter, a well-timed bit of theater, since several kids looked ready to break free from their parents' grasp and stampede across the thing, crushing houses and villagers underfoot.

title: Ending Aid to Rich Farmers May Hurt the Poor Ones
description: BY now, it's almost a truism: the protectionist agricultural farm policies of the big, rich nations -- mainly the European Union, the United States and Japan -- are essentially barring poor countries from development.

He says he is leading the company through this crisis by concentrating on a handful of priorities and communicating the right messages to multiple constituencies. title: Return to Peyton Place
description: CHRISTMAS is a lot like a fling. First there's the flirtation of Thanksgiving, hinting with a batted eyelash and a turkey leg of delights to come. Then comes December's wooing, the desperate thrill of pursuing the elusive, perfect gift. Once caught, there's the heated frottage, the fumbling to seal the deal with pretty paper and ribbon. Finally the gifts are exchanged, the paper comes off, and your Christmas tree lights up like a Christmas tree. Then your lover asks for a cigarette.

description: In what would be the first time a developer in New Jersey could lose property rights to another developer through eminent domain, a state Superior Court judge ruled last Monday that Pennsauken Township had the right to acquire 140 acres of privately owned land to move forward with a planned $1 billion waterfront development.

description: Blahnk by Boman Shoes, Photographs, Conversation. By Eric Boman. 224 pp., Chronicle Books. $85.

title: The Robert Rauschenberg Reunion Tour
description: Captiva, Fla. - IT'S 7 o'clock on a Saturday evening, and Robert Rauschenberg has just entered his studio, a white loftlike structure overlooking the Gulf of Mexico. At 80, he moves with great difficulty, relying on a walker and two assistants, although he still has his bluff good looks and easy smile. And his excitement is evident as he takes in a bronze sculpture that has just arrived from nearby Sarasota.

title: Latin America Looks Leftward Again
description: TACAMARA, Bolivia - AT first glance, there's nothing cutting edge about this isolated highland town of mud-brick homes and cold mountain streams. The way of life is remarkably unchanged from what it was centuries ago. The Aymara Indian villagers have no hot water or telephones, and each day they slog into the fields to shear wool and grow potatoes.

title: Carlsen, Brilliant Rookie at 13, Matures Into Solid Player at 15
description: The second year of a baseball pitcher's career is proverbially a comedown from the bright prospects he evinced at his debut. That's probably because the hitters know how he throws his curve, fastball or knuckleball. He needs the third year and beyond to mature into his final form and learn to cope with whatever problems he must face. I believe that's the way it goes in many vocations -- including chess.

It was the first day of the 35th annual Pipeline Masters, the final and most prestigious event on the world championship tour, and the Pacific Ocean had come alive with 15-foot surf.

title: Will It Be Different Now?

There in Adhamiya, a neighborhood ordinarily considered lethal for a Western reporter, Iraqi men and women, often with their children, some pushing wheelchairs, walked to the polls, cast their ballots and sometimes even waved. Perhaps as many as 11 million Iraqis, more than anyone could have reasonably hoped for, turned out to vote, and not a single suicide bomber stepped forward to darken the show.

title: Cost of New Jail Jumps by $22 Million
description: The estimated cost of building the first 580-bed phase of a new Suffolk County jail has risen by $22 million because of design changes and increased prices for building materials. The higher estimate has refueled the debate over how the county should pay for the jail, its largest capital project ever.

title: TOUGH JOB
description: Running a Russian oil company is not for the faint of heart. Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former chairman of Yukos, is cooling his heels in a Siberian prison after irritating President Vladimir V. Putin, and Boris A. Berezovsky fled to England to avoid a similar fate.

title: Nations Reach Agreement at World Trade Conference
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Dec. 19 - Trade ministers representing most of the world's governments reached a deal here on Sunday night that sets a deadline for wiping out subsidies of agricultural exports by 2013, realizing a goal that United States negotiators have been pursuing for two decades.

title: DATEBOOK
description: MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA The first grand slam tennis tournament in 2006, the Australian Open, starts Jan. 16. Roger Federer will try for his third consecutive grand slam event title, following Wimbeldon and the U.S. Open, with the field likely to include David Nalbandian (below), who recently ended Federer's 35-match winning streak at the Tennis Masters Cup in Shanghai. On the women's side, the draw may include Martina Hingis, the retired three-time champion, who has expressed hopes of playing in Australia.

title: Gibraltar: A British Outpost With a Sunny Latin Flavor
description: THE rock of Gibraltar, one of the Pillars of Hercules in Greek mythology, has been instantly recognizable for thousands of years. But driving west in Andalusia along Spain's new coastal expressway, the A7, not a single road sign mentions the British territory of Gibraltar. You just have to figure out when to exit the highway (at La Lnea de la Concepcin, the Spanish city at the foot of the rock). By the time you see a sign for Gibraltar, you'll be within walking distance.

title: Deborah Bauml and Ethan Schultz
description: Deborah Bauml, a daughter of Steven Bauml of Maplewood, N.J., and the late Elaine Katz Bauml, was married last evening to Ethan Schultz, the son of Jacky Schultz and Harvey Schultz of Rockville, Md. Rabbi David A. Moss performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: Scholarships Send Saudis To the U.S. As Students
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 - Urgently trying to improve relations with the United States, the Saudi Arabian government is promoting a scholarship program that has already more than doubled the number of new Saudi enrollments at American colleges and universities since last year.

title: Against the Current
description: MUSIC THROUGH THE FLOOR

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Ordinary People, Not-So-Ordinary Lives

title: In Honolulu, Arts Revive Chinatown's Fortune
description: A FEW years ago, Honolulu's Chinatown was perceived as the scruffy, even ugly, side of town. Art galleries had come and gone, and only a few survived the stereotype of Honolulu's historically gritty district: a demimonde of drug dealers and prostitutes who ruled the streets while strippers twirled their tasseled pasties in clubs named Hubba Hubba and Risqu, now defunct.

title: The Making of an Ice Princess
description: Though floral tributes have long been discouraged at skating competitions -- petals and stems are dangerous underfoot -- the twiggy-limbed preadolescents deployed to clear the ice are still called flower girls, as if they were at a wedding. For them, at least, the events are joyous: all dress-up and no comedown. At the Skate America competition in Atlantic City in October, during what is quaintly called the ladies' short program, they were the only people on the ice who seemed consistently happy. After each program, as the competing skaters retired to the Kiss and Cry (where television cameras stare at them in hopes of catching a glitch in their composure as they await their scores), the flower girls gaily collected stuffed animals and foam tchotchkes, then returned to their holding pen to dump the swag into big sacks and await the next competitor.

title: Complicated Probate

title: The Boss Actually Said This: Pay Me Less
description: BLIZZARDS swept through Wall Street last week -- bonus blizzards, that is. Henry M. Paulson Jr., chief executive of Goldman Sachs, received $37 million in shares and options. Richard S. Fuld Jr. of Lehman Brothers got $15 million in restricted stock, while John Mack, Morgan Stanley's new chief executive, pocketed an $11.5 million stock grant for six months' work.

title: Repower Play
description: The Long Island Power Authority took a small step in the right direction last week when it declared that it would extend its often-strained relationship with KeySpan Energy by five years, buy and upgrade two KeySpan power plants, lower electric rates a bit and then freeze them for two years.

title: INSIDE

description: LEIGH--Arthur, of Los Angeles. We'll always miss you and "the good times." All our love, Toby, Ellen and Phil

title: A Family of Restaurants Made Up of Individuals
description: MORE than two decades ago, the first Rosa Mexicano restaurant opened on First Avenue near East 58th Street in Manhattan. Instead of finding routine permutations of rice, beans and cheese, diners devoured more ambitious fare, like tequila-marinated lamb shank roasted in parchment paper, grilled filet mignon smothered in tequila and mushroom cream sauce, pomegranate margaritas and guacamole prepared tableside.

title: Taking a Long View of the Iraq Conflict
description: Over the past few years, the Iraq war has morphed from a war of liberation against Saddam into a civil conflict between Sunnis and Shiites. And when you look at this civil conflict -- or civil war if you want to call it that -- you see how typical it is of many of the civil wars we've seen in the world over the past six decades. Over that time, there have been 225 civil wars, and many of them have featured the same sort of insurgency and counterinsurgency, the same ethnic feuding and the same pattern of elections intermingled with violence that we see in Iraq today.

title: Terror Suspect's Ordeal in U.S. Custody
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 14 - When Muhammad Saad Iqbal finally got a chance to plead his case to a panel of military officers at the American prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, he insisted that he had nothing to hide.

title: The Neediest Cases; With Help, Disabled Student Stays on Road to a Degree
description: A broken elevator is inconvenient for anyone. For Tamara Morgan, it is the difference between freedom and confinement.

title: Protesters march on last day of WTO meeting
In the Wood A Landscape Is Born
description: HIROSHIGE, as he is simply known, like Cher, or Madonna, was one of the last great Japanese masters of the color print style known as ukiyo-e, which roughly translates as images of the floating world. In practice, the subject matter of his prints was the urban life of Edo, the old name for Tokyo and de facto capital of Japan after 1603. It became the official capital in 1869.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENNETT, PATRICIA EGAN
description: BENNETT--Patricia Egan. On December 14, 2005 at age 81. Wife of the late William F. Bennett. Survived by her children and their spouses, William (Constance) of Dedham, Ma., Catherine Frailey (Fred) of McLean, Va., Jeff (Kelsey) of Lebanon, NJ, Betsy Henkel (Bill) of Mason Neck, Va., and Robert (Julie) of Norwell, Ma. Cherished grandmother of 15. Graduate of St. Elizabeth College (Convent, NJ) and founder of Peapack Interiors, Inc; former resident of Morristown, NJ, Delray Beach, Fla. and Watch Hill, RI. Past Board member of Peck School and the Watch Hill Improvement Society. Devoted to her family, her many friends, and, in the good old days, her bridge games. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Peck School, 247 South Street, Morristown, N.J. 07960. Services private. A celebration of her life will be held in early summer in Watch Hill.

title: Hey, Bartender, Can You Break $1,000?
description: CHICAGO - GEORGE SANTIAGO, a 23-year-old nightclub promoter, wanted to impress Danielle DiCantz, 22, whom he had met at a club, on their first date. So on a recent Thursday night he took her to Reserve, a lounge and dance club that is a favorite of the trend-setting crowd here.

description: THE MAN EVERYBODY KNEW

title: The President's First Draft of the Iraq War
description: THE history of the Iraq war and occupation is already being written -- by journalists and key players like L. Paul Bremer III, the former senior American in Iraq, by generals and grunts and bloggers who were all present at the creation. But what is perhaps most striking is that over the last few weeks, in his four speeches laying out his strategy for Iraq, President Bush provided something of his own draft of the history of the war -- a steady march to freedom, by his telling, with a few miscalculations.

title: Ferry + Train - Car = No Bridge Woes
description: KRISTEN KOZIAK has given up her two-year quest for a permit to park at the Beacon train station. Instead of driving across the Newburgh-Beacon Bridge every morning, she now leaves her car in Newburgh and rides the New York Waterway ferry across the Hudson to meet the train in Beacon.

title: Take It! Take Another Little Piece of the 60's
description: Remember Steve Mann, that seminal 60's guitar picker? Those who don't may perhaps be forgiven: he played with the greats, but made very few recordings. Then mental illness, made worse by drugs, cut his career short. Some fans assumed he was dead.

title: New York: Royalton Hotel
description: THE BASICS -- The fellow who brought breakfast to the door gave a good-morning grin -- was chatty, even. At any other lodging, this would be a good thing. Parsing solicitude at the Royalton, however, is more complicated. Indifference by the runway-ready help was a hallmark of the 169-room Royalton after Ian Schrager and partners opened it in 1988. Seventeen years later, how is the country's first hotel-as-happening holding up? The verdict: This aging party girl still looks good in Mr. Schrager's dim mood lighting and still attracts a crowd, even if it's not the everybody-who's-anybody crowd of a decade ago.

title: U.S. Women Finish 1-2 in World Cup Downhill
description: VAL D'ISRE, France, Dec. 17 - Lindsey Kildow and Caroline Lalive, two gravity-embracing women from the resurgent United States ski team, finished first and second in a difficult World Cup downhill on Saturday.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 4 about Texas Tech Coach Mike Leach misidentified the hand signal used by fans of the University of Texas Longhorns in a sign to suggest their bovinity. It is the index finger and the pinkie, not the thumb and the pinkie.

title: The devastation continues; AIDS activism
Danger Signs
description: I would suggest that a test like TeenScreen would not have a positive effect and might even do harm by giving a false sense of taking care of the problem (Paul Raeburn, Dec. 4). Having worked for nearly 30 years in a high school and more as a social worker, I would propose that the greatest safeguards that can be put into schools are the people who work there: teachers, administrators and all other support staff, including bus drivers and food servers and the traditional helpers like guidance counselors and social workers. These people get to know the children in school very well and in a different way from the families with whom they live. Suicide prevention is best achieved not by a test but by a school that incorporates a sense of power and trust in its community. No test will ever accomplish what a tuned-in community can.

description: FOR a change of pace this season, it is nice to find an oasis of quiet where you can have a quick, reasonably priced meal and a little relief from the shopping hassle. I found such a place in a strip mall on Route 7 in Wilton recently. It is the East Cafe, which is usually tranquil, with a small menu and prices to match.

title: Inside the List
description: JOHN, PAUL: The Beatles may not be bigger than Jesus -- as John Lennon famously remarked in 1966, causing consternation, album-burning and later an apology -- but this week they may be bigger than the pope. "The Beatles: The Biography," by Bob Spitz, lands at No. 15 on the hardcover nonfiction list, while "John Paul the Great," Peggy Noonan's breezy remembrance of that pope, climbs to No. 21 on the extended list. Spitz's account charts the trajectory of John, Paul, George and Ringo from their bleak Liverpudlian boyhoods through dazzling superstardom and their ultimate breakup. It's actually one of a whole shelf of Beatles books out now, albeit the only on the list. Most of the others are about Lennon, 25 years after his murder. "John," by Cynthia Lennon, who was married to the Beatle from 1962 to 1969, paints the picture of a man wounded by the deaths of family and friends, and tells the difficult story of the domestic front during Beatlemania. "If there is to be a balanced picture of Dad's life, then Mum's side of the story is long overdue," Julian Lennon, the couple's son, writes in the foreword. "Memories of John Lennon," edited and introduced by Yoko Ono, is a collection of remembrances, including one from Mick Jagger: "He was the one I really got on with the most. We weren't buddy-buddies but we were always friendly." There's also "Lennon Revealed," by Larry Kane, a reporter who traveled in the Beatles' entourage during their 1964 and 1965 North American tours, and "John Lennon: The New York Years," a book of recollections and photos by the rock photographer Bob Gruen. To top it off, Paul McCartney's trippy children's book, "High in the Clouds," spent two weeks on the children's picture-book list earlier this fall.
