title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: 740 PARK: The Story of the World's Richest Apartment Building. By Michael Gross. (Broadway, $26.95.) The unexamined life may not be worth living, but it can be worth reading about -- especially if it takes place at 740 Park Avenue, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. In a sprawling book brimming with detail about the building's ashlar-patterned Indiana limestone facade, co-op board and mortgage interest, and yet stingy on insights into its inhabitants, a group that has included Jacqueline Bouvier, John D. Rockefeller Jr., Saul Steinberg, Henry R. Kravis and Ronald O. Perelman, Gross tells the story of a building "conceived in 1929 as the most expensive, the most exclusive, simply the best apartment house in the world." Gross, who has written for New York magazine and Vanity Fair, describes how 740 went from a 1930 co-op to a 1936 rental building and then back to a co-op in 1953, and throws in gobs of real estate porn: descriptions of winding marble staircases, marble-floored vestibules and, best of all, huge, untrammeled living space. Non-New Yorkers might glaze over at his Genesis-like recitation of quickie marriages, offspring and Reno divorces of dozens, if not hundreds, of the building's residents, ranging from Marshall Field III to Jerzy Kosinski, who wrote "The Painted Bird" while living there. And even sophisticated New Yorkers may balk at the way Gross covers emotional terrain (one divorce becomes "inevitable," he writes casually, when money runs low). Finally, the book's thematic organization -- "Old Money," "Oil Money," "New Money," "Borrowed Money" and "Other People's Money" -- precludes a narrative flow, as Gross skips frantically across the decades.

title: FOOTBALL STADIUM PLANS
description: The Jets and Giants unveiled preliminary plans for a joint stadium in the Meadowlands last Monday at a news conference that turned into a homage to New Jersey's acting governor, Richard J. Codey, who will leave that office next month. Team owners and the chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority complimented Mr. Codey on his role in fashioning what would be the first time that two National Football League teams have sought to build one stadium together. The preliminary master plan places the new complex between the existing stadium and the nearby Meadowlands racetrack, with links to a retail complex, a new rail station and the Xanadu entertainment and retail center now under construction near the Continental Arena.

title: Illness as More Than Metaphor
description: My thanks and admiration to David Rieff for his article about his mother's last fight against her illness. I can only marvel at his compassion and generosity, not to mention his willingness to struggle with the moral and economic issues of access to health care in our society. These are not easy things to consider, especially when one is witnessing one's own mother's determination and even anger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREED, JAMES INGO

Father of Dara Michaella Freed and her husband Niels Thorsen and grandfather of Haakon Zev Freed-Thorsen. His impact upon those who knew and loved him and his brilliant architecture will be his lasting legacy. Funeral service private. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: TOUGH TIME FOR SCHOOL BONDS
description: Voters turned down almost two-thirds of the proposed school construction bond issues in 19 districts last Tuesday. Twelve proposals were defeated and seven passed, according to Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association.

title: An Orgy of the Senses, a Checkered History
description: IT is an avenue of wonder and vice; of hoodlums and mobsters; of caramel pastries and chicken doused in tomato sauce; of gambling dens and sex slavery; of live poultry stores; of Muslim women in veil and robe lining up to glimpse Santa Claus; of new arrivals to America looking to scratch out a dollar; of old, beaten men from Cuba hand-rolling cigars; of young men full of swagger in puffy jackets and chunky jewelry.

title: Is That King Kong?
description: WEST ORANGE - I PROMISED my editor I'd write this review without once using the words "view," "spectacular" or "panorama." O.K., I give up. Mitchell Altholz, the new executive chef at the Highlawn Pavilion, could serve boiled frankfurters and tuna casserole, and diners would still come here for the view.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 18-Dec. 24; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: CLARENCE JOHN LAUGHLIN's photographs of New Orleans at the PHILADELPHIA MUSEUM OF ART offer a sugary escape from the heartbreaking views of the city we know from recent news photographs. Laughlin, a photographer for the Army Corps of Engineers, had the task of documenting that agency's levee projects in the 1930's and 40's, and one wonders what he would have come up with had he focused his attention more intently on the heroic infrastructure that defined that era. Instead, he turned his attention to romantic subjects -- from antebellum mansions to frayed relics of a dying Southern aristocracy. The pictures have the dark, dreamy quality of Eugne Atget's Paris, although their impact is more fleeting. Benjamin Franklin Parkway at 26th Street, (215) 763-8100, through April 30.

title: Critical but Stable
description: It's looking ever more possible to imagine a future without medical metaphors for the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla. When that time comes -- when the hospital, restored to financial health, stops bleeding, hemorrhaging, ailing or even limping, unplugs the life support and hops off its deathbed -- about the only option left for clich-mongers will be to murmur about certain chronic conditions that darken the prognosis for long-term recovery. But that will be O.K., given the dire alternatives.

title: Masculinity and Its Discontents in Marlboro Country
description: LESS than two weeks after its release, "Brokeback Mountain" is already on the verge of being embalmed in importance. A lightning rod for attention even before it opened, the film has earned plaudits from critics' groups along with predictable sneers, and provoked argument over its gay bona fides. That "Brokeback" is a landmark is a matter of empiricism; its merits as a work of art are a matter of taste. What has gone missing is that this is also that rare American film that seamlessly breaches the divide between the political and the personal, the past and the present. Here, against the backdrop of the great American West, that mythic territory of rugged individualism and the Marlboro Man, is a quietly devastating look at masculinity and its discontents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLEICK, DONEN
description: GLEICK--Donen. 81, died December 17. He was the devoted husband of 52 years to Beth, beloved father of James, Peter, and Elizabeth, and grandfather of Daniel, Harry, Jeremy, Margaret and Julia. He was a lawyer in New York City for 50 years, most recently at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hayes & Handler, where he headed the Wills and Estates Department. Born October 11, 1924, in St. Louis, he served during World War II in the Army Air Force and the Counter Intelligence Branch of the U.S. Occupation Headquarters in Vienna, graduated from Yale College (1945W), Phi Beta Kappa, and received his law degree from Yale Law School. Before moving to New York, he worked in Washington as an attorney for the Air Force and Small Business Administration. He was a passionate lover of books, a lifelong Cardinals fan, a bridge enthusiast and a birder with a life list of more than 600 species. Memorial service on Wednesday, December 21, 3:30 pm, at Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of choice.

title: Knowing a Man (Ben Franklin), but Not Melons
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 - There was something insufferable about Benjamin Franklin, and many of his contemporaries knew it. John Adams wrote, "Had he been an ordinary man, I should never have taken the trouble to expose the turpitude of his intrigues, or to vindicate my reputation against his vilifications and calumnies."

description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: The Lunch-Pail Guy Behind the Plate
description: When the Los Angeles Dodgers traded Paul Lo Duca to the Florida Marlins in July 2004, aftershocks rumbled through Chavez Ravine. So moved by the departure of someone he calls "one of the best people in baseball I've ever met," Manager Jim Tracy wanted to offer a small tribute. Without hesitation, Tracy gave his longtime No. 12 to Steve Finley, who was acquired the day after the Lo Duca trade, and snapped up Lo Duca's old No. 16.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, BENJAMIN H., DPM

Devoted grandfather of Rachel and Julian. For 50 years he cared for his patients with creativity and dedication. He had the ability to see the excellence in all experience. His optimism, enthusiasm and gratitude for the blessings of life will continue to inspire us. Services today, 5 P.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: For HDTV Viewing, the Set Is Just the Start
description: Only about half of the homes in the United States with HDTV sets are able to watch high-definition television, according to a study by Jupiter Research and a separate study by Scientific-Atlanta, a maker of set-top devices. The main reasons are that the HDTV set owners either are not signed up for HDTV service or are not using the proper equipment.

title: A Good but Not Great Start for 'King Kong'
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 - "King Kong," the big-budget, three-hour epic gorilla tale that is Universal Pictures' biggest bet of the year, tread rather gently into the moviegoing market on its opening weekend, taking in an estimated $50.1 million at the domestic box office.

title: The Quiet Man
description: ON Nov. 30, 1967, I traveled to Washington for The Saturday Evening Post to cover a speech by Senator Eugene McCarthy. McCarthy, who died this month at 89, was planning to announce that he was going to take on President Lyndon Johnson for the Democratic nomination for the presidency.

title: The Little Show That Could
description: "I'm Kassandra, and I'm 10," the girl with the half-moon eyes said, then pointed to the boys seated beside her. "That's Anthony and he's 6, and that's Albert. He's 8." Anthony beamed into the camera as Albert reticently looked down at a game he was holding.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Banks Are Slow To Locate In Poor Areas
description: A study released yesterday by Representative Anthony D. Weiner of Brooklyn found that while banks have expanded their presence in New York City in the past five years, they were much more likely to do so in wealthy neighborhoods. Since 2000, the number of bank branches in the city has increased by 18.4 percent, contrasting with the previous five years in which the number of branches fell by 11.5 percent, Mr. Weiner said. Since 2000, the city's wealthiest neighborhoods have gained 53 more banks, while the poorest gained 3.

title: Employing the Old Flip-Flop and Finding the Way to Game
description: In Saturday's column, I discussed the Truscott two-no-trump response over an opponent's takeout double. When an opening bid of one of a major is followed by a takeout double, responder's jump to two no-trump shows (at least) a game-invitational limit raise with four-card or longer support. If instead the responder jump-raises to the three level, his bid is pre-emptive, promising four trumps with some 4 to 8 high-card points. What happens, though, when responder has no four-card or longer major but a good minor-suit fit after his partner's one-club or one-diamond opening bid is doubled?

title: Knicks Not Consumed by Mounting Losses
description: There is frustration and then there is despair, and among the more seasoned souls in the Knicks' locker room, there is enough wisdom to know the difference. Maurice Taylor began his career with the Los Angeles Clippers and is therefore an authority on the subject.

title: Her Profession, Herself, Her Daughter Problem
description: It has become popular for postfeminist writers to cast a scornful backward glance at the once-ballyhooed notion that is possible for women to "have it all," in the famous phrase marketed by the Cosmo queen, Helen Gurley Brown. High-powered career, loving husband, contented family, hot sex life -- a heady combo not as easy to secure as it is to slap phrases on the cover of magazines.

description: The 13-year-old boy sat in his California home, eyes fixed on a computer screen. He had never run with the popular crowd and long ago had turned to the Internet for the friends he craved. But on this day, Justin Berry's fascination with cyberspace would change his life.

Schulz, whose Peanuts characters live on). Tonight it's Fred Astaire as the voice of a postal carrier (above) who explains, in this 1970 Rankin-Bass animated show, all about who Santa is (a boy named Kris brought up by toymakers) and why he does the things he does.

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: TRAVEL TIPS -- The cheapest days to fly before the coming holiday are today, tomorrow and Christmas Day, according to Priceline.com. The most expensive are Thursday and Friday. Of course, you have to have the day off to travel. Alternatively, you can join the masses of American workers who will be goofing off in the run-up to Christmas. In a recent poll by Accountemps, an employment agency, 44 percent of corporate executives said workers were less productive before a major holiday. But cynics take note: 23 percent of managers said their employees were more productive than ever.

title: French Faces, Farewell: Belarus Has Beauties of Its Own
description: MINSK, Belarus, Dec. 15 - Something has changed on the boulevards of this city, though it is not so easy to spot at first. This much can be said: Cindy Crawford, reported to be a precipitating cause, has disappeared from Minsk's billboards. So have the likes of Kate Moss or "those Frenchwomen with grubby faces."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLOHOJIAN, JON ANDREW
description: WOLOHOJIAN--Jon Andrew. Of NYC and Saugerties, NY. July 26, 1961 to December 17, 2005. Beloved son of John and Anita. Cherished brother of Michael and Lucine, nephew of Florence, Rose and Gregory, cousin of Gabrielle, Stephan, Lauren and Eric. We will never forget his miraculous way of lighting up a room, of changing people's lives, of turning the antique cafe into a neighborhood haven. He will be remembered by his family and his wide community of adored friends for his vision, generous and free spirit, courage and radiance. Wake at St. Gregory the Illuminator Church, 1131 North St, White Plains, NY, 2 pm and 8 pm, Tuesday. Funeral service at church on Wednesday, at 11 am.

title: Moscow Rally Held to Protest Growing Rate of Hate Crimes
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18 - First, more than 1,000 nationalists marched openly down Moscow's central thoroughfare on Nov. 4, some handing out racist fliers. Then, about three weeks later, the police broke up a counterprotest on the same street and detained some of the organizers of what was called an "anti-fascist" response to the original rally.

title: A Resounding Pairing of Tragedy and Tintinnabulation
description: Some smart people were behind the Dicapo Opera Theater's Rachmaninoff double bill at St. Jean Baptiste Church in Manhattan on Saturday. If the composer is beloved for his piano music and his symphonies, his operas are virtually unknown. Assured ahead of time was a convergence of theater lovers, concert audiences and loyal Russophiles, each fascinated for different reasons to hear what kind of opera Rachmaninoff would write.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOLDWERT, MARVIN
description: GOLDWERT--Marvin.Remembering you with love. Suzanne and Sidney

title: The Long-Term Care Conundrum
description: A graying population and the fiscal woes of Medicaid are forcing the nation to reconsider how best to provide long-term health care for the aged and disabled. States are experimenting with ways to reshape their long-term care programs, the National Governors Association has proposed measures to restrain Medicaid spending for the needy and encourage greater use of private insurance, and Congress is moving to close loopholes that allow some well-off Americans to hide assets so as to qualify for Medicaid. The flurry of activity won't come close to solving the nation's long-term care problems, but it usefully highlights how far the country is from seriously confronting this issue -- either through public programs or private insurance.

description: For fans of shopping television, fewer than 150 shopping hours remain until Christmas, with operators always, always standing by. It's an urgent season, and urgency is the forte of the big home-shopping channels, where hour after hour the breathless hosts pitch their wares at an auctioneer's pace, and merchandise comes in limited editions perpetually poised on the brink of selling out. With home shopping, it's forever your last chance to buy.

He was struck by the train shortly after 2 a.m. and pronounced dead at the scene, the police said.

title: Study Shows the Superrich Are Not the Most Generous
description: Working-age Americans who make $50,000 to $100,000 a year are two to six times more generous in the share of their investment assets that they give to charity than those Americans who make more than $10 million, a pioneering study of federal tax data shows.

title: Arts, Briefly; Insight on an Early Text
description: The Rabula Gospels, the first dated Christian manuscript, has been shown at an academic conference in Florence to have been repainted. Pigment tests and scientific analyses of the illustrated manuscript have revealed that the illustrations of A.D. 586 were repainted after it entered the Medicis' Laurentian Library in the 16th century, where it remains today. The oversized book, originally produced in a Syrian monastery, includes the first dated pictorial representation of the Crucifixion. Tests revealed, among other things, that in the repainting, Jesus's curly red hair was restyled as black and straight. The findings were presented at a conference this month at the Max Planck Institute organized by Gerhard Wolf, director of the Kunsthistorisches Institut in Florence, and Massimo Bernab, who teaches at the University of Pavia, in Italy. Mr. Bernab said the discovery would force scholars to re-evaluate this significant monument of early Christian art and subsequent attitudes toward it. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

But a back injury? That's priceless -- or at least timeless, which is to say that you can collect workers' compensation payments for the rest of your life.

title: Playing Bach and Company With a Touch of Je Ne Sais Quoi
description: What's so funny about Baroque music? Nothing at all, to judge from the ultra-serious performances of many period-instrument ensembles. But when Les Talens Lyriques played at Zankel Hall on Friday, there was on more than one occasion a ripple of something through the audience that lay just below the surface of laughter. Nothing was actually risible, but the warmth and character of the music, with its sharp-edged oboes and tirelessly burbling bassoon, evoked smiles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARGO, WILLIAM IRA (BILL)
description: CARGO--William Ira (Bill). Age 88, on Tuesday, December 13, 2005, of Columbia, MD. Beloved husband of Margaret "Margot" Grace Ludwig Cargo for more than 67 years, died at the Gilchrist Center for Hospice Care in Baltimore, MD, following a brief illness. He is survived by one son, David Paul Cargo; one daughter, Ruth Cargo and three grandchildren, all of Columbia, MD. Services will be held at Shaw Funeral Home, Lehman Chapel, 205 N. Elizabeth St, Bellevue, MI, on Tuesday, December 20, 2005, at 2 pm. Interment to follow at Riverside Cemetery, Bellevue, MI. A memorial service will be held at the Vantage House, 5400 Vantage Point Road, Columbia, MD, on Saturday, January 21, 2006, at 1:30 pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made in William's honor to Doctors Without Borders USA, PO Box 1856, Merrifield, VA 22116-8056, and the Hospice of Howard County, 5537 Twin Knolls Rd, Suite 433, Columbia, MD 21045; (410) 265-0075. description: A replica of a hand grenade found last night in a passenger's carry-on bag caused the evacuation of the Jet Blue terminal at Kennedy International Airport and delayed about eight flights, a spokesman for the Port Authority said. The replica was found as the passenger, a man whose name was not released by the authorities, passed through a security checkpoint shortly before 9 p.m., the spokesman, Marc Lavorgna, said. About 500 passengers were evacuated from Terminal 6, Mr. Lavorgna said. Officers from the New York Police Department's bomb squad determined the device was a fake.

title: Late-Career Debussy, Then Bernstein at the Beginning
description: Little chats with the audience, a wink and a private joke or two, along with mutual pats on the back, generated a feel-good evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night. In between the bits of agreeable shtick came some dauntingly serious music from Europe and some sophisticated entertainment from here at home. Richard Stoltzman and Emanuel Ax played the clarinet and the piano, respectively: Debussy and Brahms before intermission, then recent Robert Beaser and 1940's memorabilia from Leonard Bernstein and Lukas Foss after.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Band' Draws for MTV
description: At the end of the first season of "Making the Band 3," the MTV reality show in which Diddy, right, auditioned women across the country for a pop group, he was so unimpressed with the candidates that he decided to begin the search again. In the second season, which ended Dec. 8, the hip-hop entrepreneur took a more active role, and the results were better and he was able to choose five women for the band. The finale drew an audience of 4.58 million and was the fourth most-watched cable program of the week that ended Dec. 11. In the young demographics that MTV courts -- 18 to 34, 12 to 34 and 12 to 17 -- the show was No. 1. That week, MTV also had the premiere of another season of "The Real World/Road Rules Challenge," in which former cast members of the channel's flagship reality series compete for money and prizes. In the first episode, Jo, from "The Real World: San Francisco," left because people were getting drunk and having sex. (She must not have watched previous seasons.) Among adults 18 to 34, the episode ranked third for the week, behind "Making the Band 3" and a football game on ESPN. KATE AURTHUR

He relies on videotapes and Alberto del Saz, co-director of the company and director of his foundation, to keep his works alive.

MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE word "restraint" is probably not often associated with the actor/rocker Jack Black, but the restraint he and the director Richard Linklater exercise in SCHOOL OF ROCK (2003) make the film a funny, sublime gem. Mr. Black is Dewey Finn, who as the movie begins is a really bad front man for a rock band. After his bandmates fire him, he becomes a really bad substitute teacher instead. The school is of the snooty private variety, but Dewey finds his calling when he starts teaching his buttoned-down students to be rockers. Joan Cusack is terrific as the straight-laced principal who finds her inner Stevie Nicks -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/EarlySunday at 4 a.m. on Showtime.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Attack Suspect Is Out Of Hospital
description: The suspect in a sexual assault in Chelsea on Oct. 31 was released from a Memphis hospital yesterday, two days after stabbing himself on the University of Memphis campus, the hospital said. The suspect, Peter Braunstein, 41, left, was expected to appear in court in Memphis as early as today and be returned to New York, the authorities said. He was charged with kidnapping, burglary, robbery and sexual abuse by Manhattan prosecutors on Saturday. On Friday, a campus police officer stopped Mr. Braunstein, a former journalist, after another campus employee recognized him. Mr. Braunstein cut his own neck with a knife, the police said. He has been accused of setting small fires and posing as a firefighter to persuade a woman to let him into her apartment. The police say he drugged the woman and sexually abused her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, ALBERT EDWARD, PH.D
description: JOHNSON--Albert Edward, Ph.D. Educator, philosopher, mentor, business executive, civil leader and philanthropist, passed away peacefully, with his loving wife and family at his side, on December 15, 2005, after a courageous and graceful battle with lung cancer. Dr. Johnson, born in Gibraltar, came to this greatcountry on March 4, 1950. Dr. Johnson earned a Doctor of Philosophy degree in Economics from New York University and an M.B.A. in International Finance and Economic Theory as well as a B.A. in Accountancy. He served as Professor of Economics and Finance for more than twenty years at Long Island University during which time he was, for more than a decade, the Dean of the Graduate and Undergraduate schools. He held the lifelong position of Emeritus Professor of Economics and Finance. Beyond his academic career, Dr. Johnson was President and Chief Executive Officer of a medical imaging corporation as well as a nuclear facilities corportation. In addition, over the years he has served as Consultant to the U.S. Treasury, major banks, corporations and universities in the U.S. and has served as member of the board and trustee of several not-for-profit institutions and civic organizations. He has received numerous awards for his civic contributions. Dr. Johnson is survived by his loving wife of many years, Madelyn Antoncic, his two children, Valerie and Matthew, and his grandson Gavin. He has selflessly enriched the lives of countless individuals, has taught many how to live and love life and will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family wishes he would be remembered through donations to the Weill Cornell Medical College Lung Cancer Research Institute which he was instrumental in helping establish this past year. A memorial service celebrating his life will be announced at a later date.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ISHIKAWA, ROKURO
description: ISHIKAWA - Rokuro. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Dr. Rokuro Ishikawa, who has been a devoted friend and colleague for the past twenty years. He served as honorary trustee and was also chairman--and in recent years chairman emeritus--of the Museum's International Business Committee. His impressive leadership of a major fundraising effort enabled the Metropolitan to put on display its extensive collection of Japanese arms and armor in newly renovated galleries. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EARLY, TRACY
description: EARLY--Tracy. Free-lance religious journalist, Dec. 16, of complications from pneumonia. Wrote hundreds of articles for Catholic News Service, Religion News Service, Christian Science Monitor, Baptist Standard, Christianity and Crisis, New World Outlook, and many others. His wide circle of friends from many faiths enjoyed conversational soirees at his booklined NY apartment. Edited books and wrote on assignment for the World Council of Churches. Wrote Simply Sharing: A Personal Survey of How Well the Ecumenical Movement Shares Its Resources. Born William Tracy Early on Feb. 20, 1934, Snyder, TX, survived by his mother, Lillian Early, of Mason, TX, and brother, Grady G. Early, also of Tex. Burial in Snyder Dec. 22. Memorial service Saturday, Jan. 7, 2 p.m. Christ Chapel at The Riverside Church. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to Friends of Music at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Dr., NYC 10027, or The Burke Library at Union Theological Seminary, 3041 Broadway, NYC 10027.

title: One Readers Inside View of the Crisis in Health Care

I would guess that about 75 percent of the patients that end up on dialysis are there due to either non-compliance or poor access to primary health care. I always wonder if Americans have any idea how expensive chronically ill kidney patients become once they are on dialysis.

title: The Year of Africa
description: This has been the year of Africa, and its coming to a fitting end with the naming by Time magazine of Bill and Melinda Gates, along with Bono, as the People of the Year. All three have done great things for Africa, with the contribution by the Gates Foundation to the combating of disease in Africa being magnificent. There have been others who might be mentioned, of course: Gordon Brown, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, has battled for debt relief  and achieved a great deal  and Bob Geldof has sung and talked himself hoarse to get people to pay attention to Africas suffering. These are all people who have made a real difference to the continents year.

title: Corrections

It is the Family and Medical Leave Act, not Family Medical Leave Act. It covers workplaces with 50 or more employees, not 15.

description: HAMBLETON--T. Edward. On December 17. Beloved husband of Merrell Hopkins Hambleton, devoted father of Linda Hambleton Panitz, Susan Hambleton, Edward Hambleton, Mary Hambleton, Mark Hambleton and the late Anne Brooks Crawford Hambleton. Also survived by seven grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, December 21 at 11 AM at Trinity Episcopal Church, West Allegheny Avenue in Towson, Maryland. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Theatre Development Fund (The T-Fellowship), 1501 Broadway, NY NY 10036. A memorial service will be held at a later time. $(6$)HAMBLETON--T. Edward. The Board of Trustees and staff of Theatre Development Fund mourn the loss of one of the 20th Century's theatrical giants. T.'s expertise in all things theatrical, his generosity of spirit, and his humility, made him one of the theatre's most innovative, prolific, and beloved producers. We were fortunate to have T. as a Trustee from 1987 to the present. His contributions to TDF were extraordinary. He will be sorely missed. David D. Holbrook, Chairman Victoria Bailey, Exec. Dir.

title: Arts, Briefly; Twice-Told Tales Fail ABC
description: With ABC's popular shows "Desperate Housewives" and "Grey's Anatomy" in repeats, viewers looked elsewhere on Sunday and found their attention divided between CBS and Fox. In Nielsen estimates, CBS was No. 1 in total viewers by a large margin; a new episode of "Cold Case" at 8 p.m. was the most-watched program of the night, with 15.29 million viewers. But Fox attracted the 18-to-49-year-olds on Sunday. Its spillover of the Washington Redskins' slaughter of the Dallas Cowboys began the night with a victory in that demographic, and Fox never gave up its lead. From 7 to 10 p.m., the network won every half-hour among adults 18 to 49: "The Simpsons" was its highest-rated entertainment program. NBC placed fourth for the night in both total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds. In place of "The West Wing" at 8 p.m. was a Tom Brokaw special about soldiers from the Iraq war. It fared even worse than the political drama usually does during that hour, drawing only 6.04 million viewers. At 9 p.m., CBS delivered the largest audience for President Bush's 20-minute address about the war, followed by ABC, Fox and NBC. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANDERSON, JACK
description: ANDERSON--Jack. PARADE magazine mourns the loss of a dear friend and colleague. In addition to his long and illustrious career as a Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper columnist, Anderson was the Washington bureau chief for PARADE, penning more than 200 articles on politics and world issues since the mid 1950s. Whatever his focus, Anderson employed tenacity and integrity with equal measure. We will miss him. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife, Olivia, their children and grandchildren. Walter Anderson Chairman, PARADE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, ROBERT
description: GROSS--Robert. December 17, 2005, at the age of 78, loving husband of Gloria Lipson Gross for 54 years, devoted father of Donald, Kenneth, Jeffrey, Elizabeth, grandfather of Lisa and Noah, son of George and Anna Gross, brother of Alice Gross Newhouse and Gerald Gross, father-in-law of Su Kwak and Don Hurowitz. Bachelor of Civil Engineering, Cornell University, 1949. Masters in History, Long Island University, 2001. Real estate developer, business executive, civic leader, WWII Navy veteran, historian, enthusiastic traveler, outdoorsman, and photographer, he will be greatly missed by all who knew him for his kindness, wisdom, humor and intellectual curiosity. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Tuesday, 12:30 pm. Interment Salem Fields Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about L. Tammy Duckworth, an Army veteran of the Iraq war who is running for Congress in the Chicago suburbs, omitted one of her opponents in the Democratic primary. In addition to Christine Cegelis, a software engineer, Lindy Scott, a professor at Wheaton College, is also seeking the nomination.

title: Rushing to Execute in Texas
description: The Supreme Court has held that it is unconstitutional to execute the mentally retarded, and Marvin Lee Wilson appears to fall into that category. But Mr. Wilson, who is on Texas' death row, may be executed anyway, because his lawyer missed a deadline, and the federal appeals court that rejected his claim last week is blind to the injustice of what is happening. Mr. Wilson's execution should be blocked. Beyond that, his case should cause Congress to stop its reckless campaign to make it even easier than it is now to carry out executions.

title: ISHII OUT, OLIVER IN
description: On the same day the Mets cut ties with the left-hander Kazuhisa Ishii, General Manager Omar Minaya followed through on his plan to sign inexpensive relief help by adding the left-hander Darren Oliver to the bullpen mix. Oliver, 35, signed a minor league contract, and the Mets hope he will be as successful as Roberto Hernandez, who signed a minor league deal last season and established himself as the setup man. Oliver, who has an 87-79 record in 12 major league seasons, pitched in the minors for three organizations last season before retiring in May.

title: Heavy Machinery for a Lighthearted Display
description: BEGUILING, and as highly choreographed as the innards of a Swiss watch, the animated holiday windows at Macy's Herald Square illustrate a gossamer theme, "It's Christmastime in the City," in six familiar scenes: the tableau starts with the Thanksgiving Day Parade and concludes with the New Year's Eve ball drop, with nostalgic treats like the Nutcracker Ballet, the Rockefeller Center tree, and the Rockettes' extravaganza sandwiched in between.

title: Uzbekistan Accuses Opposition Figure of Financial Crimes
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan, Dec. 20 - Uzbekistan today accused one of the country's few remaining domestic critics of tax evasion and other financial crimes, suggesting that the opposition figure, who was arrested on Monday, now faces a long incarceration in the repressive state.

title: U.S. Patent Office Likely to Back BlackBerry Maker
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 19 - The technology patents at the heart of an infringement lawsuit by NTP against Research In Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry wireless e-mail device, are likely to be struck down by the United States patent office, both companies said on Monday, a move that would be a setback for NTP.

title: In Mississippi, Canvas Cities Rise Amid Hurricane's Rubble
description: PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss., Dec. 18 - From a distance, it looks like an Army base camp, or perhaps the old set from the television series "M*A*S*H." But here, a little more than a stone's throw from the Gulf of Mexico, on a muddy gravel lot that used to be a Little League field, a makeshift village has emerged for some of the many families who, as winter approaches, are still homeless because of Hurricane Katrina.

description: PAGE--Patrice Dominique. Humanitarian aid worker and Executive Director of Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) in Canada, on December 12, 2005 at age 33. His loss is mourned by his father, Andre Page, and Andre's partner, Micheline Harbec; his sister, Natalie Page; his girlfriend, Stacy Baker; and all his colleagues and friends at MSF around the world. Visitation and ceremony at JacquesCartier Urgel Bourgie Funeral Home in Longueuil, Quebec, Tuesday, December 20, 2005. In lieu of flowers please send donations to an organization that cares for women and children living with HIV/ AIDS in Africa--one of the many causes Patrice defended with extra-ordinary talent and passion.

title: What to Expect When Expecting Heaven
description: There's no contest. Of all the major religions, the Muslims have the most graphic view of heaven. It's refreshing, in fact. They don't mess around invoking vague spaces of peace and light; they come through with Relais et Chteaux specifics. One imam tells Barbara Walters on her ABC special tonight: "We will be in comfortable homes, reclining on silk couches. We will have people coming - servants, lovely servants, young youths to regale you, Barbara. Residing in gardens beyond which rivers flow."

After this information was published, Mr. Bush said, Mr. bin Laden stopped using the phone.

description: When cream is stirred into coffee, it is no surprise to see the swirls of white and brown become tan. It would be a shock if stirring in the opposite direction separated the liquid back to the original brown and white swirls.

The operation will be led by Peter Rice, who will continue in his role as president of Fox Searchlight, the studio's art house division.

The field is Yuzhno-Russkoye, not Yuzhno-Rossisk, with estimated reserves of 700 billion cubic meters of gas, not 23 billion to 30 billion.

title: Measuring Sound and Time on a Geological Scale
description: Imagine, for a moment, how an insect might perceive human music. Measured against its shorter lifespan, the time taken for a human-scale melody could seem hugely prolonged. Measured against the tiny sensors it uses to hear, the wavelengths could seem deep, gargantuan, body-shaking. A human listener could experience the same sensations hearing Sunn0))) when it performed at Northsix on Sunday night.

It is an enduring tradition of militancy that dates to the union's creation during the Great Depression.

description: People who have chronic pain may be able to reduce their suffering by using brain-scanning equipment that lets them see their brain activity and try to modify it, researchers say.

title: Sharon eager to get back to business after stroke

description: Echo is the musical gift that keeps on giving, sometimes longer than you wish it did. We get a lot of echo this time of year. Christmas music belongs in churches, and the big ones are bighearted enough to make sure we hear a single performance not once but a number of times in quick succession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROTHEER, GEORGE J.
description: GROTHEER--George J. 86, died December 17. A 50 year resident of Katonah, he is survived by his loving wife Selma, his three children, Alan, Laurence and Lisa and six grandchildren. He was predeceased by his sister Louise and his eldest son George Jr. His successful career with Mobil Oil Corp. was followed by many happy years in retirement. A loving man with a gentle spirit, he cherished his family and the life they shared. A service is planned for 2PM December 21 at the Lutheran Church in Mount Kisco, NY. Contributions may be made to the church music fund or Mount Kisco Hospice.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Google Earth's Satellite Images Cause Concern About Security Among Government Officials When Google introduced Google Earth, free software that marries satellite and aerial images with mapping capabilities, the company emphasized its usefulness as a teaching and navigation tool and the pure entertainment value of high-resolution flyover images of the Eiffel Tower, Big Ben and the pyramids. But since its debut last summer, Google Earth has received attention of an unexpected sort. Officials of several nations have expressed alarm over its detailed display of government buildings, military installations and other sensitive sites within their borders. [Page A1.]

description: Few filmmakers have a problem when their work wins a coveted spot in the Sundance Film Festival lineup. But for Paul Rachman, word that his documentary about early American punk rock had been accepted to the 2006 festival meant he had to make a choice.

title: Some Economic Indicators Leave Room for Optimism

title: A Year With My New Knees: Much Pain but Much Gain
description: It's been a year since my seriously arthritic knees were replaced by manufactured titanium ones. Many readers who recall the postoperative difficulties I wrote about last February have asked for an update. They want to know how I'm doing, and whether I would do it over again if I had to.

title: Clippers' Gains May Be Loss for the Nets
description: IF you were lucky enough to run an N.B.A. franchise, there would normally be no better feeling to have, no more enviable position to be in, than to start a season with the Los Angeles Clippers' first-round draft pick in your back pocket.

title: A Mission That Ended inInferno for 3 Women
description: The 120-degree June heat and rising tension in Falluja had already frayed the nerves of the Marine women when the cargo truck they were riding in pulled onto the main road and turned toward camp. It was only a 15-minute trip. But the blast took mere seconds to incinerate lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELTZER, JOSEPH
description: MELTZER--Joseph, longtime resident of Stamford, Ct. Died on December 19, 2005 in Stamford Hospital. He was 90. Loving father, beloved grandfather. Husband of Lillian Meltzer. He is survived by his son Gordon, daughterin-law Dorothy, grandson Jordan and friend Elaine Tashman. Joe defended his country with honor in World War II, flying combat missions in Europe in 1943 and 1944. Funeral services will be at Temple Beth-El, Stamford, Wednesday, December 21 at noon. Burial to follow at BethEl Cemetery. For more information contact Leo Gallagher and Son, Stamford, Ct.

title: Transition to Digital Gets Closer
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - The House of Representatives moved early Monday to provide millions of households with coupons to buy equipment to keep their television sets working after broadcasters switch from analog to digital signals. But consumer groups warned that the new law would still impose significant costs on viewers.

title: Sharon, Health an Issue, to Face Netanyahu
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 19 - Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel is expected to be released from the hospital on Tuesday with little damage from the mild stroke he had Sunday night, his doctors said Monday.

description: LONDON, Dec. 19 - More than two years after beginning an ambitious push into investment banking, HSBC is still struggling to win work as an adviser on big deals.
