Global Trend: More Science, More Fraud
description: The South Korean scandal that shook the world of science last week is just one sign of a global explosion in research that is outstripping the mechanisms meant to guard against error and fraud.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: City To Help Hospital Expand
description: The city will contribute $4.9 million toward the $25 million modernization of Staten Island University Hospital's North Campus Emergency Room, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The scheduled expansion is expected to nearly triple the size of the emergency department and serve as the ground floor of a new hospital wing. A statement issued by the mayor's office said that the emergency room was built in 1979 to handle 20,000 visits per year and that it currently handled nearly 70,000.

title: Bush claims 'power' to spy at home
Remembering the Unexpected Gift of Good Service
description: IF you think customer service is a lost art, meet David Kinkel.

title: Aid Effort in Africa Undermined by New Violence, U.N. Reports
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 19 - The United Nations emergency aid coordinator, Jan Egeland, said Monday that fresh outbreaks of violence across Africa were seriously undermining relief efforts at a time when those efforts were starting to produce positive results.

title: F.D.A. Bars Imaging Drug After Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - Federal drug regulators on Monday removed from the market a radiological drug called NeutroSpec after 2 people died and 20 others became gravely ill moments after receiving it.

title: 'Clone-Gate' scoop hits Korean news program
But How Elusive?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Leader Condemns U.S. for Migrant Bill Passed by House
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 19 - Furious about a tough immigration bill passed Friday by the United States House of Representatives, President Vicente Fox spent the weekend publicly condemning the measure. He repeatedly described it as a "shameful" setback in bilateral relations and as a troubling reflection of America's willingness to tolerate "xenophobic groups that impose the law at will."

title: Two Electricity Giants to Combine, With Focus on Coal and Nuclear
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 19 - The FPL Group announced its $11 billion acquisition of Constellation Energy on Monday, one of the largest such transactions in the history of the American electricity industry, with a focus on using two decidedly retro energy sources, coal and nuclear power, to make the deal work.

title: Cheney Defends Eavesdropping Without Warrants
description: MUSCAT, Oman, Dec. 20 - In his first discussion of the underpinnings of the Bush administration's decision to eavesdrop without warrants on communications between the United States and abroad, Vice President Dick Cheney cast the action today as part of a broader effort to reassert powers of the presidency that he said had been dangerously eroded in the years after Vietnam and Watergate.

title: Cablevision Cancels a $3 Billion Dividend
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation canceled a $3 billion dividend yesterday after saying that the company had violated the terms of a bank loan, the latest in a series of strategic reversals at the company.

title: A Remote Boomtown Where Mainly Newcomers Benefit
description: KORLA, China - The prop plane packed with businessmen swoops into this once sleepy oasis town in far western China, flying in low over the spectacular Tian Shan mountain range, now snowcapped.

title: Corrections
description: The Insider column in Business Day on Dec. 9 about a securities law, known as the short-swing rule, that enables a company to sue certain major stakeholders for short-term profits if the investor bought and sold within a six-month period described that law imprecisely. If a registered investment adviser holds less than 20 percent of a company's stock for customer accounts without seeking to influence control of the company, those shares are not counted in the calculation of ownership that determine who is subject to the rule. If the adviser seeks to influence control, however, then the ability to exclude those shares is lost, and the adviser is subject to the rule.

title: Last-Minute Budget Madness
description: As 11th-hour ploys go in Congress, the Republican leadership lowered the bar into the permafrost by ignoring rules and slapping Alaskan oil drilling onto a must-pass bill to pay for the Iraq war. The House, which earlier voted against drilling in the Alaska wildlife refuge, retreated and went along with the gimmickry orchestrated by Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, the diehard champion of opening his state's pristine resources to the oil industry.

title: City Officials Put Academy for Principals Under Review
description: Junior High School 8 in Queens and Middle School 22 in the Bronx were sorely in need of a steady hand when they were assigned leaders fresh out the New York City Leadership Academy, the elite, $70 million principal-training program that was at the core of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's efforts to remake the school system.

title: Frequent-Flier Miles for Families of Soldiers
description: FRUSTRATED by all those frequent-flier miles you've piled up and are unable to use? Then you should know Pam Lea-Maida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, ALBERT EDWARD, PH.D.
description: JOHNSON--Albert Edward, Ph.D. Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University mourns the passing of our dear friend, Dr. Albert Edward Johnson, beloved husband of Dr. Madelyn M. Antoncic, our esteemed Overseer. Together with Madelyn, Dr. Johnson was a steadfast supporter of the Medical College, and his outstanding commitment to furthering advances in education, research and treatment in the area of lung cancer will forever be remembered at Weill Cornell. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Madelyn and the entire Johnson family. Sanford I. Weill Chairman Board of Overseers Dr. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

title: Recipe: French Chopped-Liver Pt
description: Time: 45 minutes, plus refrigeration

title: The New German Novel: Less Weighty, More Exportable
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 19 - Through all the hard-drinking nights and hazy mornings, the characters in Sven Regener's novel "Herr Lehmann" take scant notice of the seismic shifts happening on their doorstep in Berlin. It is 1989, the year the wall fell, but Mr. Regener's motley crew of down-and-out characters can't be bothered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TREVAS, SEYMOUR
description: TREVAS--Seymour. On December 17, 88 years old, after a long, rich life and a brief illness. The son of Anna and David Trevas, brother of Rita, he was born in The Bronx, raised in Far Rockaway, and graduated from Columbia University. He was the loving husband of the late Doris Trevas and cherished father of Marjorie Zolot and Carole Trevas Fleisher. Generous and playful, he was the beloved grandfather of Bruce Zolot, Deborah Zolot, Jake Fleisher, and Diana Fleisher, and he gave warmth and delight to his great-grandchildren, Gabriel and Jillian Zolot. He will also be missed by his sons-in-law Barry Zolot and Michael Fleisher, and grandchildren's spouses, Joan Zolot and Kevin Sher. Seymour was a businessman, an active member of Three Arrows Cooperative Society, an avid learner, and a passionate supporter of justice and social causes. His enjoyment of life--tennis, snorkeling, travel, connecting with people everywhere--was an inspiration. He is irreplaceable and will remain unforgettable for all who knew him. Donations to Workmen's Circle Division of ORT or UJA Federation.

title: Curses, Narwhaled Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Holding Pattern
description: The World Trade Organization might as well just adopt the slogan, "Why do today what you can put off until tomorrow?" Because, once again, negotiators have postponed until next year difficult decisions to open up closed markets in agriculture.

title: In the Chaos of Homelessness, Calendars Mean Nothing
description: I knew from a note left by her case manager that the homeless woman I was waiting to see had a history of trauma, terrible mood swings, past suicide attempts.

title: Religious Groups Take Early Lead in Iraqi Ballots
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 19 - Early voting results announced by Iraqi electoral officials on Monday, with nearly two-thirds of the ballots counted, indicated that religious groups, particularly the main Shiite coalition, had taken a commanding lead. The secular coalition led by Ayad Allawi, the former prime minister, had won only meager support in crucial provinces where it had expected to do well, including Baghdad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEBOWITZ, JAY
description: LEBOWITZ--Jay. Of Garden City and Quogue, NY on December 19, 2005. Founder of Mr. Jay Appliance and TV, and the President of Intercounty Appliance Corporation. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Bruce, David and Lisa. Devoted father-in-law to Lyn, Amy and Laszlo. Cherished grandfather to Jamie, Kari, Heather, Cory, Jake, Madeline and Ava. Funeral at 9:30am Wednesday, December 21 at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Burial at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations may be made to YISHUV METZAD, PO Box 14015, Old City Jerusalem, Israel 91145

title: Pressel Receives Permission to Join the L.P.G.A. Early
description: Morgan Pressel, the teenager who has twice petitioned the L.P.G.A. Tour to waive its minimum-age requirement, will be granted full Tour membership beginning Jan. 1, nearly five months before her 18th birthday, Commissioner Carolyn Bivens said yesterday.

title: Margaret Hodges, 94, Author of Children's Stories, Dies
description: Margaret Hodges, who filled bookshelves with retold legends and other books for young readers and with the awards she received for them, died on Tuesday at her home in Verona, Pa. She was 94.

title: New Drugs Offer More Choices for Psoriasis
description: In her closet, Doris Byrne has at least seven pairs of sandals to wear with her painted toenails and Capri pants, and she is shopping for more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERGER, LEO
description: ROSENBERGER - Leo. On December 17, 2005, at age 102. Beloved wife of the late Garald E. Rosenberger. Loving mother of Joann Lang and Gerrie Soman, and their husbands, Robert Todd Lang and Roger D. Soman. Cherished grandmother of William Gerald Lang, James David Lang, Nancy Lang Adler, Carolyn Lang Kay, Judy Soman Osiecki, Roger D. Soman Jr., and 13 great-grandchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Monday and Tuesday, 7-9 pm, with service Wednesday, 9:30 am. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65 St, NYC 10023; or Lang House (Safe Horizon), 2 Lafayette St, NYC 10007. $(6$)ROSENBERGER--Leo. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our long time cherished member Leo Rosenberger. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. George Asch, Sec'y

title: Doctors Re-examine 'Strawberry Marks' in Babies
description: When a small red mark appeared on Amy Sidaway's face a few days after her birth last April, her mother did not have to ask what it was. The mother, Elizabeth Sidaway, recognized the vascular birthmark, a hemangioma or "strawberry mark," because she was born with one, too.

title: Yankees Appear to Be on the Verge of Adding Dotel to Their Bullpen
description: The only pitching move the Yankees officially made yesterday was to re-sign Ramiro Mendoza to a minor-league contract. But they want to make another, and could do so very soon.

title: Fault Found by Advocate in System for Medical Exams
description: TRENTON, Dec. 19 - The independent monitor charged with the oversight of New Jersey's child welfare system issued a report on Monday that was sharply critical of the state's slow progress in carrying out new comprehensive medical exams for foster children.

title: 'Brokeback' and the gay frontier
Ronaldinho on top of the world again
Ex-Publisher, Now Agent, Looking Both Ways
description: Three days into his new life as a literary agent, Laurence J. Kirshbaum, the former chairman and chief executive of the Time Warner Book Group, admits he is not yet an expert on the agent business. He still has some things to say, however, about the problems facing the publishing industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKOVICH, MICHAEL
description: MARKOVICH--Michael. On December 14, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Ursula (nee Becker). Loving father of Patricia Markovich and Claudia Markovich. Proud grandfather of Bradley Landberg, Samantha Van Zoeren and Nathaniel Van Zoeren. Mr. Markovich taught as a Professor of Economics at Long Island University from 1961 to 1997. Family to receive friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, NY, Thursday 7-9 P.M. Religious service at funeral home Friday at 11:00 A.M. followed by interment at Maple Grove Memorial Park.

title: Budget Accord Could Mean Payments by Medicaid Recipients
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - The final Congressional agreement on a budget bill gives states sweeping new authority to impose premiums and co-payments on Medicaid recipients, freezes doctors' pay under Medicare and toughens work requirements for welfare recipients.

title: Delphi to Negotiate With Unions on Wage and Benefits Cuts
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19 - Delphi, the troubled auto parts maker, told its unions on Monday that it would withdraw its most recent proposal to cut wages and benefits and that it would delay any court action to cancel the contracts in an effort to negotiate a settlement.

title: The Furor Over Spying and Presidential Power (9 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPER, BARRY
description: HALPER--Barry. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Barry Halper, on December 18, 2005. Services will be held on Tuesday at B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, N.J. at 11AM. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Japanese Web Site to Offer Video for Sale
description: The Softbank Corporation, Japan's second-biggest provider of high-speed Internet services, and its affiliate, Yahoo Japan Corporation, are offering 100,000 movies and video clips on a Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREED, JAMES INGO
description: FREED--James Ingo. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. His loss will be deeply felt by the world of architecture.

title: Vincent Gigante, Mob Boss Who Feigned Incompetence to Avoid Jail, Dies at 77
description: Vincent Gigante, who feigned mental illness for decades to camouflage his position as one of the nation's most influential and dangerous Mafia leaders, died yesterday at the United States Medical Center for Federal Prisoners in Springfield, Mo. He was 77.

title: Advice: Talk, Talk, Talk: When a Doctor Says Too Much
description: Getting advice from a doctor is a good thing, but after a certain point enough may be enough, a new study suggests.

title: The Furor Over Spying and Presidential Power
description: To the Editor:

title: When Football Is Fundamental
description: To start a high school football program from scratch, first assume that the prospective players know nothing about the game.

title: Albanian Gang Portrayed as Aspiring Mafiosi
description: A gang led by Albanian immigrants transformed itself into a sixth organized crime family in New York City, administering ruthless beatings and using intimidation and sheer bravado to take over lucrative gambling operations once controlled by Italian mobsters, a federal prosecutor said.

title: N. Korea vows to buildown light-water reactors
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a mild stroke suffered by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of his statement, as quoted by Israeli Army radio, that he had no plans to step down. He made the statement before his illness.

title: The Furor Over Spying and Presidential Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENSPAN, SYLVIA WELLS
description: GREENSPAN--Sylvia Wells. 86, of Delray Beach, FL. Passed away on December 2, 2005. She is survived by a daughter, Suzanne Goldwert, her son-in-law Sidney Goldwert, two grandchildren Mark and Ilaina Goldwert, and her sister Estelle Jablon.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about what seems to be an absence of good will during the holiday season misspelled the given name of a Nassau County legislator who said people should come together at this time of year, not be divided. She is Lisanne Altmann, not Liseanne.

title: Orthodoxies on Trade Worn Down in Marathon
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 19 - The low point of the World Trade Organization conference here came on Saturday evening, as ministers were despairing of progress, while outside, protesters' steel pipes rained down on the shields of police officers and tear gas grenades spewed choking clouds.

title: Young Killer Is Ruled Competent; Lawyers Acknowledge His Ruse
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 19 - A youth convicted in 2001 of stomping a 6-year-old playmate to death was ruled mentally competent on Monday for a hearing to determine whether he is returned to prison, perhaps for life. The ruling followed his lawyers' acknowledgment that he had faked being suicidal.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Have Thieves Scrapped a Moore Sculpture?

title: Cheney and Afghan Milestone
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 19 - Afghanistan's first democratically elected Parliament in more than 30 years convened here on Monday with heavy security, and was sworn in before President Hamid Karzai, as well as the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, and foreign dignitaries. It was a moment of national pride in the country's success in emerging from more than 20 years of conflict.

title: Accountant Pleads Guilty to Trading in Sirius Shares
description: The former president of the accounting firm that manages Howard Stern's tax and financial affairs pleaded guilty yesterday to illegal insider trading in shares of Sirius Satellite Radio after learning that Mr. Stern was contemplating a move to the satellite radio company.

title: U.S. to Cut Force in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld signed orders on Monday that will reduce American troop levels in Afghanistan next year, meaning that 3,000 soldiers in Louisiana will learn before the holidays that they will most likely not have to deploy as previously scheduled.

title: The Fog of False Choices
description: After five years, we're used to President Bush throwing up false choices to defend his policies. Americans were told, after all, that there was a choice between invading Iraq and risking a terrorist nuclear attack. So it was not a surprise that Mr. Bush's Oval Office speech Sunday night and his news conference yesterday were thick with Orwellian constructions: the policy debate on Iraq is between those who support Mr. Bush and those who want to pull out right now, today; fighting terrorists in Iraq means we're not fighting them here.

title: Three Faiths, One Lesson
description: It could have been any class outing as about 90 elementary school students squealed hellos, whispered urgent secrets and stuck tight to their allies.

title: Mayor Bloomberg's Statement
description: The following is the statement by Mayor Bloomberg on the transit strike, as provided by the Office of the Mayor.

title: Legal Shield for Vaccine Makers Is Inserted Into Military Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - Companies making vaccines to protect against biological agents or pandemic viruses would be shielded from lawsuits, even if they are negligent or reckless, under a provision inserted into a military spending bill by Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader.

title: Bolivia's Newly Elected Leader Maps His Socialist Agenda
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 19 - After his decisive win in the election for president on Sunday, the Socialist indigenous leader, Evo Morales, vowed Monday to respect private property but repeated his pledge to increase state control over the energy industry and reverse an American-backed crusade against coca, the plant used to make cocaine.

title: Think Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Scramble Continues for a Spot in the Playoffs
description: With 14 games down and 2 remaining, the National Football League has fans right where it wants them: in suspense.

title: Bill O'Reilly and Darfur
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Speech on Iraq: Did He Make the Sale?
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors and Retailers Skirmish Over Scarce Flu Vaccines
description: Every day, Dr. Arleen Sharpe of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., sees patients who need a flu vaccine but cannot have one because her office received fewer than half of the 800 doses it ordered for a large family practice of 10,000 patients.

title: U.S. Approves Grant to Armenia, but Urges Greater Political Rights
description: President Bush's foreign aid program aimed at reducing poverty in well-governed developing countries announced its second-largest grant yesterday. It will give $236 million to Armenia over five years, but warned the country's rulers that the assistance would be suspended or canceled if its record on political rights continued to deteriorate.

title: Honeywell Buys Maker of Gas Detectors
description: Honeywell International, the world's largest maker of airplane cockpit controls, agreed to buy First Technology of Britain for about 207 million ($366 million) to expand in gas detection gear.

title: What to Expect When Expecting Heaven
description: There's no contest. Of all the major religions, the Muslims have the most graphic view of heaven. It's refreshing, in fact. They don't mess around invoking vague spaces of peace and light; they come through with Relais et Chteaux specifics. One imam tells Barbara Walters on her ABC special tonight: "We will be in comfortable homes, reclining on silk couches. We will have people coming -- servants, lovely servants, young youths to regale you, Barbara. Residing in gardens beyond which rivers flow."

title: Amid Devastation, Mounds of Toxic Waste Vie for Attention
description: EMPIRE, La., Dec. 15 - There is so much storm debris in Louisiana that some of it has to be destroyed again.

title: Checkpoints Create Demand, and Then Supply
description: Normally it is the frustrated would-be passenger who searches for an empty cab, but today, a few hours after transit workers went out on strike, the tables were reversed.

title: A Holocaust Survivor With a Burden of Guilt
description: Victor Attar does his best to breathe some life into Shmuel Refael's solo play "Golgotha" at La MaMa E.T.C. But there is nothing even a veteran actor can do to turn this heartfelt effort at memorializing the Greek-born Sephardic victims and survivors of the Holocaust into anything but a tedious guilt trip.

title: Addiction: Supplement May Stifle the Craving for Cocaine
description: A nutritional supplement widely sold as an antioxidant may help cocaine addicts give up the drug, researchers have found.

title: Terrorists in Cyberspace
description: Until you see a video of Iraqi insurgents taking a terrified, hogtied man and sawing off his head with a butcher knife, you don't know what "blood-curdling" truly means.

title: Scientists' Discovery in the Deep Casts Some Squid Mothers in a Brighter Light
description: With their slimy tentacles and big, unblinking eyes, squids have, over the centuries, acquired a bad reputation.

title: The Neediest Cases; Immigrant Finds His Stride After Cancer Ends a Dream
description: If you don't have English, you can substitute endurance. That is the immutable law of the American food chain. Fruit picking, poultry processing, meatpacking plants, New York City restaurants -- all have a ravenous appetite for immigrant workers, legal or illegal. Feeding New Yorkers is a series of strenuous and physical tasks. It is an endless routine of 12-hour days standing in a hot kitchen, pedaling through snarled Midtown traffic or washing stacks of dishes.

title: New Jersey's Democrats Unite to Support Essex County Chief
description: NEWARK, Dec. 19 - In a show of Democratic unity, the otherwise routine re-election campaign announcement of Essex County Executive Joseph N. DiVincenzo Jr. on Monday drew some of the state's most powerful elected officials, including Gov.-elect Jon S. Corzine and Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey.

title: Spain arrests 15 as Qaeda suspects
Queens Riders Find Ways To Handle Their Strike
description: With the main strike deadline still many hours away, workers at two private bus lines in Queens that serve 57,000 riders had already walked out early yesterday, leading to angry picket lines, busless bus stops, bewildered passengers and commuter vans and livery cabs trying to fill the breach.

title: Insurance Concern in China to Sell 25% Stake to Carlyle
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 19 - In one of the largest private equity deals ever done in China, the Carlyle Group, the global private equity firm, has agreed to invest $410 million for a minority stake in the China Pacific Life Insurance Company.

title: Q & A: Blake Krikorian
description: Blake Krikorian, the co-founder of Sling Media, is a veteran of the convergence wars, having worked 15 years in Silicon Valley with companies trying to merge audio, video, computers and other technology. After many hits and misses, he may have found his calling with the Slingbox, a device that allows users to stream their cable or satellite television signals to their laptops.

title: Ex-Yonkers Mayor Is Ready to Take on Senator Clinton
description: ALBANY, Dec. 17 - New York State Republican leaders have made it clear, or at least most of them have, that they no longer want Jeanine F. Pirro to run for the United States Senate.

title: Flying in Style for Less
description: FLYING IN STYLE FOR LESS MAXJet Airways, which began offering all-business-class flights between New York and London at heavily discounted fares last month, says that in February it will add a new route, five days a week, between Washington Dulles and London. The airline's Boeing 767's are configured with 102 business-class seats, each with 60 inches of legroom. The current round-trip fare between New York and London is $1,358. Another new discount all-business-class airline, Eos, started flying daily between New York and London in October, using Boeing 757's configured with only 48 flat-bed seats. Its current round-trip fare is $5,000, substantially below the major carriers' walk-up business-class fares of $8,000 and up for the round trip.

title: Jets' Kicker Wants the Opportunity to Try to Hit the Long Ball
description: Late in the third quarter Sunday at Dolphins Stadium, the Jets drove to the Miami 30-yard line, where they faced third-and-13. According to the numbers that Mike Westhoff, the special-teams coach, had fed Coach Herman Edwards after gauging place-kicker Mike Nugent's performance during pregame warm-ups, the Jets were in Nugent's field-goal range.

title: U.S. Team Chooses Experience Over Youth
description: When the two generations of United States hockey convened in Colorado Springs for an orientation camp at the end of the summer, they golfed together, fished together and drank beer together. The older players told stories. The younger ones listened.

title: The Furor Over Spying and Presidential Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Arrests 6th Man in London Bombings That Failed
description: LONDON, Dec. 20 - The British police arrested a new suspect today after months of investigations into an attempt on July 21 to mimic the July 7 London bombings that killed 56 people, including the 4 attackers, two weeks earlier.

title: Militants Briefly Take Over Bethlehem Building
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, Dec. 20 - Bethlehem always expects guests in Manger Square around Christmas, but today's visitors caught everyone by surprise.

title: Is That a Finger or a Jell-O Mold?
description: Identity thieves are always looking for new ways to pry out personal information, from trolling through trash cans to phishing for bank accounts online. But here is one method they may not have tried: using fake fingers made from Play-Doh and gelatin, or taking digits from a cadaver's hand.

title: With Terrorism Concerns in Mind, Police Prepare to Guard a Shuttered System
description: As a strike deadline passed last night, officials prepared to put in effect an ambitious security presence to safeguard a sprawling subway system designed never to close.

title: Just Another Displaced New Yorker
description: BATH, England - A Cincinnati newspaper announced in 1844 that "the sterling old Dutchman, Santa Claus, has just arrived from the renowned regions of the Manhattoes," or Manhattan, "with his usual budget of knickknacks for the Christmas times."

title: Judge Bars 'Intelligent Design' From Pa. Classes
description: HARRISBURG, PA., Dec. 20 - A federal judge ruled today that it is unconstitutional for a Pennsylvania school district to present intelligent design as an alternative to evolution in high school biology courses because intelligent design is a religious viewpoint that advances "a particular version of Christianity."

title: Miller Upton, Innovative Head of Beloit College, Dies at 88
description: Miller Upton, who during 21 years as president of Beloit College found innovative and widely imitated ways to maximize the college's educational and financial resources, died yesterday at his home in Fontana, Wis. He was 88.

title: Bush's Speech on Iraq: Did He Make the Sale?
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Inquiry, Chief of Italy's Central Bank Resigns
description: ROME, Dec. 19 - It was a drama that engrossed Italy's political and financial circles.

title: Putting the Skill Back Into the N.H.L.
description: TORONTO - Hang around with Stephen Walkom, the National Hockey League's recently installed director of officiating, and the exhortation "stick to the standard" is bound to issue from his lips.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Sleepy Hollow: Baby's Mother Pleads Guilty
description: A 24-year-old Sleepy Hollow woman pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree manslaughter in the death of her 13-month-old child in April, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, announced yesterday. The woman, Rosa Crespo, was charged after her daughter, Anita, was taken to a hospital on April 29 with severe brain damage, and died two days later. Investigators said that Ms. Crespo originally denied harming the baby, but that after an autopsy showed signs of shaken baby syndrome, she admitted shaking the child. She faces up to 15 years in prison when she is sentenced on March 16. Her lawyer, Louis Ecker, did not immediately respond to a message left at his office. ANAHAD O'CONNOR (NYT)

title: 24 Ex-Hussein Officials Freed From U.S. Custody
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 19 - Iraqi lawyers said Monday that a group of 24 former officials in Saddam Hussein's government were released from an American military detention center over the weekend and that they included four leading figures in Mr. Hussein's program to develop weapons of mass destruction.

title: The Furor Over Spying and Presidential Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Diamond-Grading Laboratory Faces Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors are gathering information about a bribery scandal at a diamond-grading laboratory in Manhattan that is known as the nation's most trusted evaluator of the quality of precious gems, people close to the inquiry said.

title: Artest Seeks Forgiveness From Pacers
description: The agent for Ron Artest said yesterday that he hoped the Indiana Pacers would "find it in their hearts to forgive" Artest and keep him on the team.

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: President of Tokyo Stock Exchange resigns
Changing Transit Workers' Pension Plan Might Pose Dilemma for Legislature
description: ALBANY, Dec. 19 - One of the main sticking points in the transit contract negotiations this week has been the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's effort to reduce pension benefits for future transit workers. But by state law, such pension changes are supposed to be decided by the State Legislature, not at the bargaining table.

title: Governments Tremble atGoogle's Bird's-Eye View
description: Correction Appended

title: Drug Survey of Students Finds Picture Very Mixed
description: Alcohol use and cigarette smoking among teenagers are at historic lows, but the number of high school students abusing prescription drugs like Oxycontin is rising, and sedative abuse is at its highest in 26 years, according to an annual national study released yesterday.

title: Think Again
description: To the Editor:

title: AOL Coaxes Google to Try Busier Ads
description: Users of Google's search engine will soon see something they are not used to on the notoriously spare site: advertising with logos and graphics. And the advertisers will not be limited to America Online, whose talks with Google prompted the change in policy, according to two executives close to the companies' negotiations.

title: All 20 Killed as Seaplane Crashes Off Miami Beach
description: MIAMI, Dec. 19 - A seaplane built in 1947 crashed off the southern tip of Miami Beach on Monday, killing the 17 adults and 3 children aboard as it plunged into calm blue waters while surfers and fishermen looked on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STURGIS, NANCY DAHN
description: STURGIS--Nancy Dahn. Born July 7, 1924, passed away at age 81 on Thursday, December 15, 2005 in Manhattan where she had lived her entire life. She leaves behind two daughters, Lisa Sturgis of Stamford, CT and Victoria Sturgis Neely of Manhattan, two grandchildren, Henry and Carolina Neely of Manhattan, and her sister Barbara Dahn of Pasadena, CA.

title: Lawmakers Prepare for Showdown Over Arctic Oil Drilling Provision
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - With tensions rising in the Capitol, Senate Democrats threatened on Monday to derail a $453 billion military spending bill over an Arctic oil drilling dispute, just hours after the House approved the measure in an all-night session that also included passage of a $40 billion budget-cutting bill.

title: Bush's Speech on Iraq: Did He Make the Sale?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about efforts to find out why some people are more likely than others to be bitten by malarial mosquitoes misstated the affiliation of the lead author of a paper on the work in the journal Nature. The author, David Smith, is an epidemiologist at the Fogarty International Center of the National Institutes of Health, not at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Chad Chases Rebels Into Sudan
description: Chad's military crossed into Sudan to pursue a rebel force that attacked a town in Chad near its border with Sudan over the weekend, Chad's foreign minister said, according to Reuters. The claim is likely to raise tensions along the border. Chad also reported that its forces had killed about 300 rebels after their raid on the town, Andr, was pushed back and they began their retreat into Sudan. LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

title: Judge Bars 'Intelligent Design' From Pa. Classes
description: HARRISBURG, PA., Dec. 20 - A federal judge ruled today that a Pennsylvania school board's policy of teaching intelligent design in high school biology class is unconstitutional because intelligent design is clearly a religious idea that advances "a particular version of Christianity."

title: Transit Union Calls for Strike in Divided Vote
description: Leaders of the transit workers' union rejected the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's latest contract offer last night, and voted to call a strike shortly after 1 a.m., according to two members of the union's executive board. But the vote to call a strike was not unanimous, and so for at least a half an hour after the formal vote, union leaders remained divided on whether to actually proceed with the walkout.

title: China Says It Grew Faster Than First Thought
description: SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Dec. 20 - China said on Tuesday that its economy, the fastest growing in the world, is larger than it had previously reported. The government reported this morning that its gross domestic product was nearly $2 trillion in 2004, not $1.6 trillion as it had previously reported, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,150 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Youth Says Father Admitted Killing L.I. Couple in 1988
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Dec. 19 - A young man testified in court here on Monday that his father admitted killing a Long Island couple in 1988 and then bribing a police detective with $100,000 to avoid prosecution.

title: Holidays' Convergence Adds to December Dilemma
description: On Sunday afternoon, millions of families in the New York area will sit down to Christmas dinner.

title: Messengers of Cheer, Clad in Sailor Suits
description: The Vienna Choir Boys ensemble is generally considered to have been founded in 1498, when Emperor Maximilian I, having set up court in Vienna, included a roster of boy choristers among his palace musicians. For centuries the choir thrived. Among its illustrious graduates are Schubert and the conductors Hans Richter and Clemens Krauss.

title: Readers Share Their Commuting Stories
description: I live on the UWS and work in Midtown East. I needed to be at work at 48th and Park at 7:00 a.m. today so I left my home on 89th and Amsterdam at 5:40 a.m. It took me about 1 hour to make the trip. There was a display near Columbus Circle that read 18-degrees for the temperature at 6 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PESKIN, IRA
description: PESKIN--Ira. Longtime resident of Lido Beach, NY. Died on December 15, 2005, at age 78. Beloved husband of Marilyn, devoted and loving father of Jill and Jeffrey, loving grandfather of Michael and David, devoted and loving son of Gussie and Isaac Peskin, and loving and caring brother of Ruth and Lester Peskin, and special friend to his devoted and loving son-inlaw Jeffrey Saunders. Ira, along with Marilyn, his partner for more than fifty years, represents the best that there is in life. He will be remembered fondly by all who knew him. His family

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Denies Guilt In Agent's Death
description: A 12-year-old girl accused of striking a school safety agent who died a short time later appeared in court yesterday to deny misdemeanor charges of resisting arrest and obstructing government authority. The girl, a student at Intermediate School 390 in Brooklyn, was arrested on Friday after kicking and flailing at the agent, Vivian A. Samuels, 56, as Ms. Samuels escorted her from a holiday dance, the authorities said. Ms. Samuels was struck at least once in the head, they said, and was pronounced dead at Kings County Hospital Center, where she was taken after complaining of shortness of breath. Judge Maureen A. McLeod set a court date of Jan. 13 for the girl, who went home with her family. MICHAEL BRICK (NYT)

title: Aging: Quick Quiz Can Predict Weight Loss in the Elderly
description: Answers to four simple questions may help medical workers predict when elderly people are at a higher risk of malnutrition, researchers say.

title: A Frenzied Rush Hour That Came Around Midnight
description: Up until the 11th hour -- almost 12 a.m., to be exact -- New Yorkers remained steadfastly optimistic that the city's transit service would remain in its perpetual motion.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sex Abuse Suspect Arraigned
description: The suspect in an Oct. 31 sexual assault of a woman in Chelsea was arraigned early today in Criminal Court after being flown from Memphis, where he was arrested on Friday on the campus of Memphis State University. Judge Ellen M. Coin ordered the man, Peter Braunstein, 41, held without bail and ordered a psychiatric evaluation at the request of his Legal Aid lawyer. Prosecutors said that writings were found on him when he was arrested indicating that he had been aware of a nationwide search for him since the assault. He was charged with aggravated assault and carrying a weapon onto school property, but those charges were dropped after he waived extradition to face charges that include sex abuse, robbery, burglary, arson and kidnapping. He is accused of posing as a firefighter so he could attack the Chelsea woman. MATTHEW SWEENEY (NYT)

title: The Final Word on the Last Ball
description: GOOD morning, ladies and gentlemen. For those of you who don't know me, I am Shyam Das, and I am the arbitrator in this case, the Boston Red Sox vs. Doug Mientkiewicz. This grievance is about ownership of a baseball, and I'd like to go directly to the heart of the dispute. I think we can save a lot of time if the Red Sox' representatives can answer one question:

title: Aspiring Rapper Is Shot and Killed in Tompkins Houses
description: An aspiring rapper known as Brooklyn Hooks was shot and killed in an apartment hallway yesterday afternoon as he returned from walking a relative's dog in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Welcome to the Potemkin Mall
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Dec. 16 - At the Garden State Plaza, a sprawling marble and skylight-filled shopping center just outside Manhattan, discriminating consumers can find a $400 fur-trimmed handbag at Coach, a $60 pair of distressed jeans at American Eagle Outfitters and a $25 make-your-own giraffe at Build-a-Bear.

title: Remarks of Roger Toussaint, President of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union
description: With a $1 billion surplus, this contract between the M.T.A. and the Transport Workers Union should have been a no-brainer. Sadly, that has not been the case. Our contract expired on Thursday at midnight. In an attempt to save mass transit, and in deference to our riders, we postponed our deadline and attempted to continue talking to the M.T.A.

title: Complex Motives
description: Last week I wrote about the lawsuit concerning Wikipedia, whose trustworthiness is suddenly under the microscope. I wondered if the lawsuit was evidence that trust in Wikipedia is further deteriorating, but a reader has just let me know that the lawsuit may, in fact, have more devious purposes:

title: Pilot sentenced for killing activist
Fishing Industry's Fuel Efficiency Gets Worse as Ocean Stocks Get Thinner
description: If the fishing industry were a country, it would rank with the Netherlands as the world's 18th-largest oil consumer, a team of fisheries scientists is reporting.

title: No New Stadium, No San Jose Team
description: Major League Soccer played the first game in its history in San Jose, Calif., in 1996. It is quite possible that the last M.L.S. game in San Jose was played Oct. 29. That is because the Earthquakes (at least the front office and the players) picked up and moved to Houston last week when a deal for a publicly financed stadium in Northern California collapsed.

title: EU accord on budget linked to WTO deal
Sharon Leaves Hospital After Mild Stroke
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20 - Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, was released from a hospital today, two days after suffering a mild stroke, and he displayed no visible signs of illness.

title: Global Trend: More Science, More Fraud
description: The South Korean scandal that shook the world of science last week is just one sign of a global explosion in research that is outstripping the mechanisms meant to guard against error and fraud.

description: A Pain in the Back

title: Trying to Tell if Reagan Was a Leader or Was Led
description: President Reagan The Triumph of Imagination By Richard Reeves Illustrated. 571 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30.

title: Spain Seizes 15 Linked to Al Qaeda in Iraq
description: MADRID, Dec. 19 - The Spanish police arrested 15 people on Monday on charges that they had formed a recruiting network linked to Al Qaeda that sent Islamic militants to Iraq, the Interior Ministry said.

title: Robinson Steps Down, and Lamoriello Slides In
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 19 - Wearing a black jacket, old skates and borrowed gloves, Lou Lamoriello stepped briskly onto the ice Monday morning to run his first practice since he coached at Providence College nearly 23 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, MURRAY
description: LEWIS--Murray. To a very important and dear friend, who was always there for all of us. You have left a void in our lives. Gilbert, Juju, Lucille & Sybil

title: Barry Halper, Baseball Memorabilia Collector, Dies at 66
description: Barry Halper, who began collecting autographs as an 8-year-old hanging around the Yankees' minor league ballpark in Newark and went on to assemble the nation's most acclaimed private collection of baseball memorabilia, died Sunday at a hospital in Livingston, N.J. Mr. Halper, who lived in New Vernon, N.J., was 66.

title: Iranian's Oratory Reflects Devotion to '79 Revolution
description: TEHRAN, Dec. 19 - The morning after the ultra-conservative mayor of Tehran, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, was elected president in June, he made a pilgrimage to the tomb of the father of the Iranian revolution, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, an act that appears to have foreshadowed exactly how the president-elect planned to lead his country.

title: Indian Drug Maker Says It Will Keep Attacking Patents Despite Pfizer Loss
description: BANGALORE, India, Dec. 19 - The Indian drug giant Ranbaxy Laboratories says it will not back down from its patents-busting strategy, despite its loss to Pfizer on Friday in a United States federal court.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: First Gay Union Ceremonies
description: A lesbian couple exchanged vows in Britain's first same-sex civil partnership ceremony, in Belfast, under a new law that will take effect in Scotland today and in England and Wales tomorrow. The women, Grainne Close, at right in photo, 32, a social worker from Northern Ireland, and Shannon Sickels, 27, a playwright from New York, were followed by a male couple and another female couple. The law gives gay couples the same property and inheritance rights as married heterosexuals and the same pension and tax benefits. The Northern Ireland ceremony was the first because of a shorter statutory waiting period than on mainland Britain. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

title: Afghans Demonstrate Two Different Styles of Democracy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec 20 - Afghanistan's two houses of Parliament began their first sessions today, and in just a few hours provided a glimpse of democracy Afghan style, with the upper house ignoring the rules of procedure and the lower house getting bogged down in debate.

title: Suicide Reveals Strife in Group Behind the Globes
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 - As Hollywood primps for next month's Golden Globes ceremony, the small group of foreign journalists behind the awards has been shaken by the suicide of a colleague who was suspended in one of several disciplinary actions to roil the organization in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COSGRIFF, STUART W., M.D.
description: COSGRIFF--Stuart W., M.D. Of Tenafly, NJ, on December 17, 2005. Born in Pittsfield, MA on May 8, 1917. Son of Thomas W. and Frances D. Cosgriff. Devoted husband of the late Mary Shaw Cosgriff. Beloved father of Mary, Thomas, Stuart, Richard, and Robert. Grandfather of Thomas Jr., Jason, Matthew, Stacy, Stuart III, Heather, Kate, Spencer, Wesley, and Benjamin. Great-grandfather of Shannon, Thomas III, Wyatt, Savannah, Sasha, and Annie Kate. Graduated Cum Laude from Holy Cross College in 1938. Earned a medical degree from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942. Professor of Medicine at Presbyterian Hospital, New York City, 1951-1983. Professor Emeritus, Presbyterian Hospital, New York City, 1983-2005. Specialized in Internal Medicine and Vascular Diseases. Served as a Captain in the U.S. Army in World War II from 1943-1945. Dr. Cosgriff's family wishes to acknowledge Mary Conneely, Vera Daly, Eileen Prior, Philomena Sheridan, and Mary Towey for the dedicated care they gave to Dr. and Mrs. Cosgriff.

title: New DVD's
description: The Chronicle of Anna Magdalena Bach

title: Showdown Nears on Hong Kong Political Changes
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 19 - Another showdown on constitutional change is looming in Hong Kong, as the territory's Beijing-backed leaders said Monday that they would make a modest change to their complex plan for limited democracy and then demand that the legislature vote later this week.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Opposition Figure Arrested
description: The authorities arrested a prominent and outspoken opposition figure, the latest in a string of repressive acts, according to Human Rights Watch and Ferghana.ru, a Moscow-based news Web site. The figure, Nodira Khidayatova, a leader of the Sunshine Coalition, was arrested at the airport in Tashkent on allegations of tax evasion. The Tashkent director for Human Rights Watch, Andrea Berg, said the arrest was "one more piece in the Uzbek government's attempt to silence every critical and independent voice in Uzbekistan." Sanjar Umarov, the head of the Sunshine Coalition, was arrested in October, and Orifjan Oydin, Ms. Khidayatova's brother-in-law and a member of the group, died last week after being shot by unidentified gunmen. ETHAN WILENSKY-LANFORD (NYT)

title: Ex-Chief of Qwest Is Indicted
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive officer of Qwest Communications International, was indicted today on charges of insider trading involving stock sales worth more than $100 million.

title: In foreign policy, Merkel has a good first month as chancellor
Put the City in the Driver's Seat
description: ARE New York's subways and buses running this morning? Is the Transport Workers Union on strike? When this article went to press, New Yorkers did not know the answers to these questions. They did know, however, that the system that got us to this dismal state of affairs is broken and seemingly beyond repair.

description: GORDON--Kenny. KG, 7 years have past and, while we miss you more then words can describe, the wonderful memories we shared together can not fade. The love, laughter and joy you brought to our lives and all who knew you still brightens our days. All our love mom, dad and Jonny.

description: To the Editor:

title: Germany Frees Hijacker Who Killed U.S. Sailor
description: BERLIN, Dec. 20 - A German parole board has released a Lebanese man convicted 16 years ago of killing an American Navy diver during the 1985 hijacking of a T.W.A. jetliner, German officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about the question of links between cancer and the environment misstated the name of an advocacy group in San Francisco whose director urged the use of the least toxic alternatives to chemicals that may cause cancer. It is Breast Cancer Action, not the Breast Cancer Action Coalition.

title: ABN to Pay $80 Million for Violations
description: ABN Amro Bank, a global banking giant based in the Netherlands, has agreed to pay a total of $80 million in fines for violating regulations to prevent money-laundering, regulators and the bank said yesterday.

title: '01 Resolution Is Central to '05 Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - At the heart of the debate over the legality of the program to eavesdrop on the international communications of American citizens without a court order is a Congressional resolution passed a week after the Sept. 11, 2001, hijackings that authorized the president to use force against those responsible for the attacks.

title: Cabs With Strangers, and Other Ways to Work
description: New York City's subways and buses were replaced by rusty bicycles, old walking shoes, ferries and $20 cab rides today, as millions of New Yorkers who usually take public transportation were left to make it to work any way they could.

title: New Chancellor Selected to Lead SUNY's 64 Campuses
description: The State University of New York yesterday elevated John R. Ryan, the acting chancellor since June, to chancellor, effective immediately.

title: What's Worse Than Getting Sick? Getting Sick While Traveling
description: "Please don't let me die here." That is what Bill Hart, vice president of global information technology operations for McCormick & Company, remembers saying to himself over and over again after he collapsed during a heart attack in the bathroom of a plane headed for Paris in 2005.

title: Toyota, With 2006 Forecast, Challenges for Top Car Maker
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Tuesday, Dec. 20 - The Toyota Motor Company announced on Tuesday that it planned to make 9.06 million cars worldwide in 2006, a goal that could help it to snatch from General Motors the crown of world's largest carmaker, a title the Detroit company has held since 1932.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Speaking in Tongues
description: Theres loads of foreign intrigue in the scrum to see what foreign films end up being considered for the Oscar. According to Variety, getting lined up for the ultimate American recognition can be a political minefield that makes the United Nations look veritably zen-like, with each countrys entry functioning as a diplomatic envoy to the all-powerful King Oscar. Hopefully, they are more effective than the U.N. when it comes to intervening in global conflicts.

title: A Valid Conclusion?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Thats Our Girl
description: Speaking of operating in that over the top realm, our pals at Defamer  they arent actually our friends and Carpetbagger would not know Defamer if he were punched in the nose by them, but its just a bit of blogging convention  points us to a wonderful story about Shirley MacLaine defending Jennifer Aniston, her co-star in Rumor Has It  a bit of Oscar season anti-programming. During a press opportunity, Ms. Aniston was asked about her fling with Vince Vaughn and mama MacClaine stepped in. Id like to confirm that Vince Vaughn prefers older women and that Jennifer is just my beard. It was me in the car with Vince in Arizona and I was looped. Im having a ball and Jennifer is taking all the guff. Defamer, as is their wont, plays the scenario out and beyond, suggesting, what can start as a mere PR ploy of convenience can quickly escalate into MacLaine locking Jennifer in an empty FAO Schwarz, as she manically performs a mysteries of reincarnation stuffed animal puppet show for her terrified captive audience. Confused? Well, its a meta, meta, meta world. Follow the links and it will all become clear.

title: Playing Small of Its Size
description: The industrys addiction to giantism and its perils was writ large in the coverage of King Kongs box office. How is it that a movie that opens to the tune of $66 million dollars  the same amount that The Godfather III took in during its long and illustrious life  is deemed something of a flop? Peter Jacksons willingness to go over-the-top and stay there is part of what gives Kong its campy charms, but camp does not come cheap. If you want your dinosaurs to chase dinosaurs with other dinosaurs in their mouth, its going to going to cost you $200 million, give or take. And thats a lot of popcorn.

title: Good Night Picks Up a Little More Sparkle
description: Good Night, and Good Luck, the little movie that could, was chosen by the West Coast Writers Guild of America for its Paul Selvin Award. According to the Hollywood Reporter, the award goes to a script that best embodies the spirit of constitutional and civil rights and liberties, according to the guild. No surprise that a bunch of writers would find it in their hearts to give big hugs to the Edward R. Murrow biopic. They are a lefty bunch to begin with, and the idea that Murrow and his team could use well-chosen words and images to conquer a sitting United States Senator, JosephMcCarthy, no doubt fires the imagination among a bunch of ink-stained wretches.

title: Ten-Fold Confusion?
description: For truly dedicated Oscar theorists, the deconstruction of the various Top 10 lists is a hardy perennial. Movie City News synthesizes the practice into one handy-dandy scoreboard. Its early yet, and the sprawl of opinion would make a Las Vegas odds maker flinch, but suffice to say that so far, Brokeback Mountain is not the runaway choice for critics. But in a more rarified look with hand-picked crits, the prohibitive favorite continues to gallop. No one knows anything, right?

title: Oscars Brain Buster
description: Ever wonder about the actual process of Oscar voting? Us neither, but there is a fairly lucid explanation that seems to suggest a complicated mathematical formula is followed by the throwing of lots mixed with burning sage.

title: Brutal Outcome
description: The Golden Globes, which are the source of piles of fun and speculation in Hollywood, have a dark halo this year. As Sharon Waxman writes, Nick Douglas (left, with Colin Farrell), an Irish member of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, hanged himself after he was suspended from the group in a disciplinary action.

title: The Real Competition
description: This time of year, massive campaigns are waged, alliances are formed and friendships are trashed, all part of the ultimate fight for the ultimate prize in Hollywood: tickets to the Oscars. In a town that runs on money and dines on power, the tickets, which are directly doled out in relation to the number of nominated movies a particular studio has, are the one thing that dollars and sheer corporate might cannot purchase. It can get mighty nasty, and Hollywood titans have been known to get into a lot of feelings come Oscar time. Harvey Weinstein, who typically controlled gobs of tickets by virtue of his touch with the little statue, was known to be charry with his corporate overseers at Disney. And this year, it will be interesting to see how many tickets Focus Features sends up the food chain. With Brokeback Mountain in the thick of it, and Pride and Prejudice along with The Constant Gardener bound to pick off a few nominations, the division of NBC/Universal will have some love to spread around come Oscar time. Will the owners have to come on bended knee, or will Focus decide that managing up is a strategically sound business strategy?

title: Home Buying Buddies
description: Real estate brokers are noticing a new trend among first time home buyers. It seems that many new buyers are partnering with friends instead of a spouse to buy their first homes.

title: Heres the Bad News
description: The Housing Bubble 2 blog (what happened to the Housing Bubble 1 blog?), has seven posts in a row of gloom and doom. It gives us troubles in Virginia, south Florida and Raleigh, N.C. as well as less confident builders and some mortgage-investment company cutting its dividend.

title: The Transit Strike
description: Millions of New Yorkers who usually take public transportation were left to make it to work any way they could.

title: Central Park: $528.8 Billion
description: Jonathan Miller of Miller Samuel, an appraiser in New York, calculated the value of Central Park at $528.8 billion or about $627 million an acre, says New York magazine. Wow, you say? A sign of the bubble?

title: The Soothsayers of Housing Prices
description: Whats your house going to be worth next year? How about in 2007?

title: Home Building Is Up, So Why are Builders So Glum?
description: Housing starts and permits increased last month and remain close to records set earlier this year, the Commerce Department said today. So, naturally one would expect home builders would be pleased and optimistic. But one would be wrong. The National Association of Home Builders reports its members confidence dropped to its lowest level in more than three years this month. The group reported a similar dip last month even as the government reported new home sales hitting a new high in October. What gives? Is the new-housing market great or not, or are home builders just a dour lot?

title: Now to Get Home
description: After struggling to reach the city in the morning, New York commuters faced the daunting task of getting back out on the first day of the transit strike.

title: More OReilly Fans
description: Bill OReilly generates passionate views. Ive gotten e-mails and calls from people, including embarrassed conservatives, who say hes a nut. And Ive also gotten plenty from people who say hes a hero and Im not only a nut, but an anti-Christmas nut who should be executed. I admire the warm Christmas faith of those who want to celebrate their religious feeling on Christmas by having me killed.

title: Think Tank Transparency
description: More reader response to Paul Krugmans Dec. 19 column, Tankers on the Take

title: How Good Is Old?
description: We went into Fife, my wife and I last Saturday, or shall I say into the Kingdom of Fife. Fife is, in fact, only a county, but it used to be a kingdom and indeed one finds there the old capital of Scotland, Dunfermline. Dunfermline might mean something to Americans, or at least those Americans who live in Pittsburgh, as it was the birthplace of that great philanthropist Andrew Carnegie. I was in Pittsburgh a few months ago and was vastly impressed by it. I had expected a rusty industrial landscape, but I was several decades out of date. A friend who grew up there told me once that when his mother hung out the white shirts to dry they came back in grey. No longer.

title: Troubled Calpine Files Bankruptcy
description: The Calpine Corporation, the power-plant owner saddled with more than $17 billion in debt, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday after soaring natural gas prices left it unable make loan and bond payments.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Government To Pay Indians $7 Million
description: A federal judge has ordered the government to pay $7 million to cover legal fees and expenses in a long-running lawsuit on behalf of about 500,000 American Indians, who contend that the Interior Department squandered about $137 billion in grazing, energy and mineral royalties from Indian lands in the last century. The judge, Royce C. Lamberth of Federal District Court in Washington, instructed the government to pay $4.5 million in legal fees and $2.5 million for other expenses. The Indians had sought more than $14 million. The government opposed the ruling, questioning the "legal entitlement" to such an award and arguing that the request for compensation was not sufficiently documented.

title: People: Paul Winter, Britney Spears, Queen Elizabeth II
Morgan Stanley Posts 49% Gain in 4th-Quarter Profits
description: Morgan Stanley reported a 49 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, exceeding expectations, as it rode a surge in investment banking business and strong trading results. The firm's shares rose nearly 2 percent, to $57.71.

title: Big Trouble in Prewar China
description: With Ralph Fiennes and three Redgraves aboard, you couldn't ask for a tonier cast than the one that gamely tries to pump oxygen into the thin, filtered air of "The White Countess."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Durst Arrested In Galveston
description: Robert A. Durst, the scion of a New York real estate family who was acquitted of murdering his neighbor in Galveston, Tex., was arrested yesterday because he returned to Galveston in violation of his parole. Mr. Durst, left, was acquitted of shooting his neighbor in 2003 after he testified that he accidentally shot the 71-year-old man in a struggle over a gun, then cut up the body and dropped the parts into Galveston Bay. But Mr. Durst, now 62, served nearly six months in prison for carrying two guns across state lines while fleeing prosecution in the case. In violation of the terms of his parole, Mr. Durst returned last Friday to the house in Galveston where the shooting took place, alarming a witness in the case who called the police, according to Joel Bennett, a Galveston County district attorney. CHARLES V. BAGLI (NYT)

title: Even With Strike, Garden Keeps Filling Seats
description: The transit strike made it harder for many people to get to Madison Square Garden last night. But the Garden, which was sold out for last night's game between the Rangers and the Devils, appeared to be at least 90 percent full by the end of the first period.

title: A Modern Space in Mexico City's Historic Center
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 20 - On a recent afternoon, Ricardo Legorreta stood on the terrace of a new office tower he has designed here, surveying an anarchy of styles from the 23rd floor. The panorama below is a tumult of sizes, forms and motifs, but he seems amused rather than frustrated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERGER, LEO
description: ROSENBERGER - Leo. On December 17, 2005, at age 102. Beloved wife of the late Garald E. Rosenberger. Loving mother of Joann Lang and Gerrie Soman, and their husbands, Robert Todd Lang and Roger D. Soman. Cherished grandmother of William Gerald Lang, James David Lang, Nancy Lang Adler, Carolyn Lang Kay, Judy Soman Osiecki, Roger D. Soman Jr., and 13 great-grandchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Monday and Tuesday, 7-9 pm, with service Wednesday, 9:30 am. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65 St, NYC 10023; or Lang House (Safe Horizon), 2 Lafayette St, NYC 10007. $(6$)ROSENBERGER--Leo. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed, honorary life member, Leo Rosenberger, and extend our heart felt condolences to her family. Richard D. Katcher, Pres Neda Birbrower, Secy

title: After a Hard Year, a 'Messiah' Played Out on a Grand Scale
description: Many of the city's "Messiahs" are based on long annual performance traditions, but when it comes to history, none can beat the Oratorio Society of New York. The group was founded in 1873, before Carnegie Hall was even a twinkle in Andrew Carnegie's eye. Its singers performed under Tchaikovsky's direction at the hall's opening in 1891, and since then the Oratorio Society has sung Handel's "Messiah" at Carnegie every year except one (in 1960, when demolition of the hall seemed imminent). It returned on Monday evening for this year's performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWERS, FREDERIC B., JR.
description: POWERS--Frederic B., Jr., 72, died at his home in Larchmont, New York on Tuesday, December 20, 2005. Frederic Powers, Jr. was born in the Bronx in 1933 to Irene and Frederic Powers, Sr. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Virginia Van Deventer, four sons Christopher, Jeffrey, Stephen, Frederic III, their wives and thirteen grandchildren. Frederic Powers graduated Iona Preparatory and Fordham University. After college, Fred served as a First Lieutenant in the Marine Corp at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina where he was in charge of a Tank Platoon. He later served as the Brigg Officer at the Marine Barracks at the US Naval Base in Brooklyn, New York. In 1957 he received an honorable discharge, after which he served in the Marine Corp Reserves while starting his civilian life. Frederic Powers started in business owning a small fastener company founded by his father and developed it over the past 50 years to become the largest concrete fastener manufacturer in the United States. The company was started as the Rawlplug Company, Inc. based out of New Rochelle, New York. Fred added manufacturing in Michigan, Indianapolis and Chicago; acquired a Canadian company and established 28 locations in the USA. He felt his most notable achievement was the continued operation and expansion of the business by his his four sons. In 1995 the business name was changed to Powers Fasteners, Inc. with the intended purpose of international expansion. The company has continued to prosper adding locations around the globe including Australia, New Zealand, Europe and South East Asia. In February 2006 the company will open its new world headquarters in Brewster, New York on its 16 acre site. Fred Powers served on the boards of several charitable organizations throughout Westchester. He served as Chairman of the Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle as well as Chairman of the Pinnacle Heatlh Care Group. In 1997, he was the Honoree at the Sound Shore Hospital's Annual Gala at the Waldorf Astoria. He was the former President of the Boys and Girls Club of New Rochelle and was a former Board Member of the National Board of Junior Achievement. He served on the Board of Directors of Westchester Federal Savings and Loan. Fred was also Chairman of the Howard Foundation whose contributions were almost entirely earmarked for Westchester charities. His most notable charities were those in Westchester and Vero Beach, Florida. Fred was a devout Catholic and both he and his wife Virginia have been active parishioners of the St. Pius X Church in Scarsdale, New York for more than 38 years. Fred Powers was honored by many of the charities and groups he served. He was awarded "Man of the Year" by the New Rochelle Boys and Girls Club; awarded "Citizen of the Year" by the Young Men's Christian Association and given the Civic Achievement Award by the Knights of Columbus. The Savings and Loan Association awarded him the "Community Service Award" and he was inducted into the "Fastener Hall of Fame" by the National Industrial Fastener Association. Fred and his wife Virginia have homes in Larchmont, New York and Vero Beach, Florida. Fred belonged to Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, New York and Shenorock Shore Club in Rye NY. He was also a member of Johns Island and Quail Valley located in Vero Beach, Florida. Fred enjoyed golf, painting, and gardening in addition to his family, friends and philanthropy. Services will be held at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home at 767 E Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY, (914)-698-5968 on Wednesday and Thursday, December 21st and 22nd from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The Funeral Mass will be held Friday December 23rd at the St. Augustine's Church at 18 Cherry Avenue (corner of Larchmont Ave and Cherry Ave) in Larchmont, New York at 10:00AM. He will be buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Rye, New York. The family requests that donations in lieu of flowers be sent to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, New York 10601, or Sound Shore Medical Center, 16 Guion Place, New Rochelle, NY, 10801. $(6$)POWERS--Frederic B. Sound Shore Health System mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Frederic B. Powers. Together with his family, Fred was a steadfast supporter of the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester and a devoted member of the Board of Governors. He served from 1967 to 1983, and returned in 1987 to the present. During this time he served as Vice Chairman in 1990, Chairman from 1994 to 1997, Chairman of the Sound Shore Health System from 1999 to the present, and on the Pinnacle Board from 1999 to the present as Chairman. His commitment to providing his community with the highest level of health care services by furthering the mission of the Medical Center will be forever remembered at Sound Shore. We will miss his guidance and support. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife, Ginny, and their children and grandchildren. Lawrence J. Ruisi, Chairman John R. Spicer, President and CEO

World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 45 In Chechnya Mysteriously Ill
description: A mysterious illness has sickened at least 45 people in Chechnya, many of them children and teachers from a village school, a spokesman for the emergency services in southern Russia, Oleg A. Grekov, said in a telephone interview. The cause of the outbreak, which began late last week, remains unclear, though some of the victims are gravely ill with symptoms that include respiratory difficulties, fever and loss of consciousness. A local doctor cited a nerve or chemical agent as a possible cause, but other officials discounted that. Chechnya's prosecutor announced an investigation into sanitary conditions at the school, in Starogladkovskaya, about 40 miles from Grozny. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

It is a chance to indulge in a good novel or catch up with work, knowing their children are safe in their beds.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: School District Approves Book For Bible Course
description: School district trustees in Odessa, Tex., voted 4 to 2 yesterday to adopt a disputed textbook for a Bible literacy elective, prompting some local parents to say they plan to sue the district for promoting religion. The book is published by the National Council on Bible Curriculum in Public Schools, a conservative Christian advocacy group. Critics object in part because they say the book includes sections promoting creationism. The district decided not to adopt a competing textbook produced by the Bible Literacy Project and endorsed by a wide range of religious and legal organizations.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: PHILIPPE -- You might expect a restaurant with this name to serve French food. But the chef and a partner is Philippe Chow, above, a native of Hong Kong who was the chef at Mr. Chow (no relation) on East 57th Street for 26 years. He makes Chinese crowd-pleasers like corn and crab meat soup, squab wrapped in lettuce, shrimp or lobster spring rolls, and main courses like crispy flounder with asparagus or beef with oyster sauce. Main courses are listed as servings for two ($28 to $50) but half-orders are available. The simple black and white dcor does not hint at China, and it does the most with the long, narrow room, which had been RM: 33 East 60th Street, (212) 644-8885.

title: Arts, Briefly; Nielsen to Track Univision
description: Next week, Nielsen Media Research will begin measuring the national audience of Univision, the Spanish-language television network, according to a joint announcement made by the companies on Monday. It will be the first Spanish-language network to subscribe to the Nielsen Television Index and will be compared with ABC, CBS, Fox, NBC, WB and UPN. By tracking Univision's ratings, Nielsen will be able to reflect more accurately the preferences of Hispanic viewers, a growing segment of the television audience whom Nielsen has been accused of underrepresenting in recent years. Until now, Univision has subscribed to Nielsen's National Hispanic Television Index, which calculates only the Hispanic audience and is often ignored by advertisers. In 2007, Nielsen will have only one ratings system, the National People Meter sample, which will be used by the networks, cable and syndication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAIG, SHIRLEY
description: BAIG--Shirley. Born in 1921 in Canada she lived most of her life in the New York metropolitan area. Shirley passed away on Sunday, December 18 in Santa Monica, California. She is survived by her sister Dell Looney, her nieces Karen Byrd and Anne Greene and her nephew David Brown. Shirley worked for 40 years for the New York Times until she retired in 1986. Her titles ranged from Manager of News Services to head of photo operations at various points. She set a great example for women in the workforce in general and specifically for those coming to work at the New York Times. She obtained her BA from Fordham University in 1973. She became a bridge player late in life continuing her quest for intellectual challenges until the end. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITE, THOMAS S. JR.
description: WHITE--Thomas S. Jr., 79. Of Green's Farms, Connecticut and Willsboro, New York, died Friday afternoon, December 16, at Bridgeport Hospital. Mr. White was a graduate of Peekskill Military Academy and Princeton University, Class of 1948, with a BA in psychology. At Princeton, he was a member of Cap and Gown Club and active in varsity lacrosse. He took a military leave of absence in January 1945 to join the Army Air Force where he trained as a cryptographer and was sent to Italy as an information and education specialist. Mr. White was employed by L. Bamberger and Company in Newark, New Jersey and then worked for Proctor and Gamble in Cincinnati from 1953 to 1965. He joined the Bristol-Myers Company as Plant Project Manager for Clairol in Stamford, Connecticut. He was transferred to the parent company as Director, and then Vice President, of Industrial Relations and Personnel. He ultimately became Vice President, Office of the Chairman until his retirement in 1989. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Helen Lawler White; two sons, Mark Thomson White of Fairfield, Connecticut and Frank Carpenter White of Montpelier, Vermont; and a daughter, Christine White Babson, her husband Rob and two granddaughters, Esther and Margaret Babson of Medfield, Massachusetts. His brothers David W. White and Stephen P. Elliott, sister-inlaw Patricia C. Lawler, along with their families also survive him. Mr. White was a commissioner on the National Commission for Accreditation of Law Enforcement Agencies from 1984-1996 and a member of the Princeton Club in New York. He served as a governor at the Pequot Yacht Club in Southport and a member of the board of trustees at Earthplace in Westport. He was a former vestryman of Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport and a member of the Country Club of Fairfield. He also played Santa Claus for the children of Devon Road, Green's Farms for many years. He will be sorely missed by his family and many friends. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Trinity Episcopal Church Outreach Fund and the American Heart Association. Spear-Miller Funeral Home in Fairfield will handle funeral arrangements and a memorial service will be held at 11:00 at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, Connecticut on Friday, December 30, 2005.

Loving sister of the late Rose, Ben, Sonia, Jen, Will. Beloved aunt to Ruth Turner. Adored adopted mother and grandmother to her entire family. She shared her great heart and wisdom with all who knew her, and all who knew her, adored her. She will be greatly missed. Memorial to be held in April. Ahead, Fire Island was on the horizon, a rough black line between the bay and the sky, and off to the west, the Robert Moses Causeway faded in and out of the morning mist.
