description: Gotham has the Bat Signal, pilots have Mayday and New Yorkers have the Brooklyn Bridge. When herds of pedestrians crowd that span of granite and steel, trudging toward the towers of Manhattan or fleeing them, the world knows the city is in a bad way.

title: Afghan Parliament Opens, and Finds Democracy Is a Bit Untidy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 20 - The two houses of Parliament began their first sessions on Tuesday, and in just a few hours provided a glimpse of democracy Afghan style, with the upper house ignoring the rules of procedure and the lower house getting bogged down in debate.

title: A Trial Against News Corp. Is Allowed to Go Forward
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 20 - A Delaware judge has ruled that a trial against the News Corporation can proceed in a lawsuit filed by 13 institutional pension funds that accused the company of reneging on an agreement to let shareholders vote on a takeover defense.

title: Toyota Closes In on G.M.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 20 - After reigning atop the global auto industry since the depths of the Depression in the 1930's, General Motors may finally cede its spot next year to Toyota. The Japanese company's ascendancy underscores the enormous obstacles faced by G.M. on many fronts.

title: From Casting to Curtain Call, a Group's Special Challenge
description: If you're an actor or if you've ever been part of community theater or even a school play, you know the exhilaration of the curtain call. But the one in "Yellow Brick Road," a touching documentary that has its premiere tonight on Cinemax, is more emotional than most.

title: Hong Kong Democracy Advocates Reject Beijing-Backed Plan
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, Dec. 22 - Democracy advocates on Wednesday night defeated a government-backed legislative proposal to revamp the political system, dealing a sharp setback to the territory's chief executive and to Chinese leaders in Beijing, as well as to prospects for any substantial political changes here soon.

title: New Airline Navigation System Is Displayed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 - The jet approaching Reagan National Airport followed the complicated turns required for the prescribed route over the Potomac River, banking sharply left and right as it descended smoothly toward Runway 19. But the two pilots never touched the controls. The plane was being guided by the autopilot, which was taking its cues in three dimensions, from satellites in orbit.

title: After Autopsy, Mother Is Held in Boys' Deaths
description: Three-month-old twins who died after they were found unconscious in their cribs in a Brooklyn apartment on Oct. 20 -- leading to initial suspicions about the porridge they were fed -- were actually smothered, the police said yesterday. Their mother was charged with murder.

title: Briefly: Sharon, out of hospital, says he's ready to work
New Drug Points Up Problems in Developing Cancer Cures
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 - Despite promising discoveries and multibillion-dollar investments, cancer research is quietly undergoing a crisis. Federal drug regulators will soon announce several initiatives that they hope will help salvage the field.

title: Promotions at Times Company
description: The New York Times Company announced promotions in its legal department yesterday.

title: Oh Joy, a Wild and Crazy Family
description: An unnecessary sequel to a mediocre remake, "Cheaper by the Dozen 2" follows the release of the similarly themed "Yours, Mine & Ours" by a month, making any rationale for its existence all the more dubious. Sure, there always seems to be room for more lightweight family fare during the holiday season, but this messy blend of silly slapstick and oversentimentality probably won't please children, teenagers or adults.

title: Russia Puts New Pressure on Private Groups
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21 - Russia's lower house of Parliament today amended legislation intended to increase the government's control over charities and other private organizations, while leaving in place core provisions that critics said would open the groups to political pressure and even closing.

title: Scientist asks for broader inquiry
We've got a budget. Now let's build on it.
Invisible New Yorkers
description: Genesis Johanny Perez, 4, stands in an empty living room. She and her mother moved into the housing project in Yonkers three weeks ago. Genesis will eat her dinner sitting on her bed watching television. She will also sit on her bed to daydream. LENS

title: Head of Tokyo exchange quits over trade mishap
Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, SHIRLEY OTTER
description: ROSENFELD--Shirley Otter. The Jewish Theological Seminary community mourns the death of Shirley Otter Rosenfeld, the mother of Gerald Rosenfeld, a member of JTS's Board of Trustees. A generous, dedicated member of the Jewish community, Mrs. Rosenfeld will be dearly missed. May all her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman $(6$)ROSENFELD--Shirley Otter. The members of the NYU Leonard N. Stern School of Business community mourn the passing of their dear friend, Shirley Otter Rosenfeld. A passionate believer in the power of education, she was an inspiration and will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to her son, Jerry, her daughter in-law, Judith Zarin, and their family.

title: A Land of Northern Lights, Cybercafes and the Flat Tax
description: TALLINN, Estonia - Estonia, one realizes after a few days in the abiding twilight of a Baltic winter, is not like other European countries.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-25

title: Russia's gas weapon
Ex-Chief of Qwest Is Indicted
description: Federal prosecutors announced yesterday that Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, had been indicted on charges of insider trading involving stock sales worth more than $100 million.

title: China economy even larger than thought
Under the Elevated Track, a New Sensation: Silence
description: It has been a fact of life along Roosevelt Avenue in Queens for almost 90 years: The audible world comes to a stop every few minutes to make way for a mandatory 20-second imposition of noisy train clatter loud enough to banish thought itself.

title: Germany Frees '85 Hijacker Who Killed American Sailor
description: BERLIN, Dec. 20 - German officials said Tuesday that they had released a Lebanese man jailed 19 years ago for killing an American Navy diver during the 1985 hijacking of a T.W.A. jetliner, an ordeal that shocked Americans during a tense 17-day standoff.

title: W. J. Oswald, 86, Algae Miracle Worker, Dies
description: William J. Oswald, a scientist who pioneered ways to use algae to address immense human problems -- including treating sewage, increasing food supplies, generating energy and facilitating voyages into deep space -- died on Dec. 8 at his home in Concord, Calif. He was 86.

title: But the Blog Kept Running
description: On the Internet, a blog set up by Local 100 to help its members stay abreast of strike developments quickly morphed into a forum for frustrated commuters to vent their rage.

title: Tough Talk by U.S. Envoy Aids Prime Minister of Canada
description: TORONTO, Dec. 20 - The initial weeks of the first winter national political campaign in Canada in 25 years had been a tepid affair short on issues and excitement. Then a blunt speech by the American ambassador spiced things up a bit.

title: Derrick Z. Jackson: Iraqi deaths mount - and count
Strike halts transit system in New York
World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Ex-Airline Chief Gets 20 Years For Ferrying Cocaine
description: Fernando Zevallos, who went from flying one-engine planes in Peru's jungle to running the country's biggest domestic airline, has been convicted of cocaine trafficking and money laundering and sentenced to 20 years in prison. Though he was classified as a drug kingpin by American officials last year, he had repeatedly beaten back charges, and the verdict was his first conviction. Mr. Zevallos's airline, AeroContinente, which the authorities said was used to ferry drugs and money, has gone out of business.

title: Attending Jets-Patriots Game Will Be a Sobering Experience
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 20 - Nothing will be at stake for the Jets when they meet the New England Patriots on Monday night at Giants Stadium, and no alcohol will be sold.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   AMES, BERNARD N.
description: AMES--Bernard N. Dearest Bernie, sadly missed and lovingly remembered. Fran

title: In France, It's Not All Chopped Liver
description: FOR a long time I thought that all chopped-liver recipes were essentially the same. Then someone shared this tasty French recipe, the perfect start to a dinner at Hanukkah or on any other special occasion.

title: Two Sweets In One Pot
description: MANY candy-making procedures are too precise for the casual cook, but some are dead easy. Unbelievably (at least to me, the first time I tackled them), caramels fall into the second category. It's harder to mess them up than it is to produce them perfectly.

title: EU needs to reconnect with citizens, Blair says
They Walked, We Walked: Tales From the Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Gem Made in '57 Is a Favorite of 2005
description: My favorite jazz record released this year, and one of my favorites of any year, was made in 1957. I first heard "Thelonious Monk Quartet With John Coltrane at Carnegie Hall" (Blue Note) at the Library of Congress in April, after the news of its discovery had been made public. It sounded pretty good then, but you can never really tell when hearing something over a high-quality sound system in front of interested parties. I have listened to it repeatedly since, and it seems to be much better than I first thought -- solid, juicy, truly great.

title: Martnez's Toe Hasn't Healed
description: The inflamed toe that bothered the Mets' Pedro Martnez throughout last season has not healed, preventing him from proceeding with his off-season regimen. Martnez, who is in the Dominican Republic, told The Associated Press that he was wearing a protective shoe but that he still felt pain in his right big toe. He stopped pitching with a week and a half remaining in the season partly because of the discomfort.

title: Regulations Are Proposed to Cut Back Particulates
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 - The Bush administration on Tuesday proposed new air quality regulations intended to reduce modestly sooty pollutants that health officials blame for thousands of premature deaths and illnesses each year.

title: A Stroll Above as Nothing Rolls Below
description: WHEN the subway hums, we nod along. We board in silence. We gaze dead-eyed at the flickering underworld revealed through clouded windows. Then we disembark, never thinking of the city life that just passed above our gently rocking heads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGLEY, STANLEY JAMES
description: LANGLEY--Stanley James. Of Cambridge, MA. December 14. Beloved husband of Kathleen Mary (Longmore) Langley. Funeral services are private.

title: Seagate Seen Buying Maxtor, a Rival Storage Maker, for $1.9 Billion
description: Seagate Technology, the giant digital storage company, reached a deal yesterday to acquire a rival, the Maxtor Corporation, for $1.9 billion in stock, according to executives involved in the transaction.

title: Tuning in hometown TV fare, anywhere
When Everyone's Fabulous, Especially Our Genial Host
description: Correction Appended

title: Frank Lowe returns to advertising business and trolls for clients
Big resort is planned
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about efforts of food companies to sell healthier products to children referred imprecisely to the work of the Children's Advertising Review Unit. The group monitors the marketing and advertising of all products to children 12 and under -- including junk food -- for fairness and accuracy, but it does not concern itself with the nutritional content of the products.

title: Teach, Don't Preach, the Bible
description: YESTERDAY'S ruling by a federal judge that "intelligent design" cannot be taught in biology classes in a Pennsylvania public school district has the potential to put the teaching of the Bible back where it belongs in our schools: not in the science laboratory, but in its proper historical and literary context. An elective, nonsectarian high school Bible class would allow students to explore one of the most influential books of all time and would do so in a manner that clearly falls within Supreme Court rulings.

title: President of Tokyo Stock Exchange Resigns
description: TOKYO, Dec. 20 - The president of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, Takuo Tsurushima, resigned Tuesday to assume responsibility for a computer error that contributed to a $350 million trading loss and raised doubts about the exchange's ability to handle increasingly heavy volume.

title: Recipe: Spicy Orange Segments
description: Time: 3 1/2 hours, plus 3 days' soaking

title: Soccer: FIFA plans tough look at racism
New Orleans Wonders What to Do With Open Wounds, Its Canals
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 - It was the canals that betrayed this city, but they never left the scene of the crime. The fingers of water that overflowed sit there like open wounds, and many residents and engineers would prefer never to see them again.

title: S.I. Ferry Is Called on for a Few Runs From a Brooklyn Pier
description: City officials, who had not drawn up a plan to supplement ferry service during a transit strike, had to improvise yesterday to rescue hundreds of shivering commuters stuck on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Toyota Discloses Output Projections That Threaten G.M.'s Reign at the Top After reigning atop the global auto industry since the depths of the Depression, General Motors may cede that spot to the Toyota Motor Company. Toyota said it planned to make 9.06 million cars worldwide in 2006, a 10 percent increase over 2005 and a rate that puts it about even with G.M. [Page C1.]

title: Out of the Fryer, Into the Lights
description: SOME Jewish foods take a lifetime to love. The gelatinous sheen of my great-grandmother Ida's jellied calf's foot, last made more than 20 years ago, disturbs me still. It can take years of practice to truly enjoy the baby food flavor and clammy texture of gefilte fish. And as festive desserts go, the dry honey cakes baked for the Jewish New Year are hardly alluring.

title: The Measure of Success
description: I would like to propose a ban -- a ban on Bush administration officials measuring our success in Iraq by the number of Iraqi soldiers we have "trained." I propose this ban because it is an utterly misleading metric, and if we become addicted to it we are going to make some even bigger mistakes in Iraq than we already have.

title: The Patriot Act and Our Civil Rights (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pensions Were Last Sticking Point
description: At first, several issues divided Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in their contract talks. But in the end, negotiations collapsed late Monday over one issue: pensions. The authority made an 11th-hour demand that new workers contribute 6 percent of their wages to their pension funds, up from 2 percent for current workers, a position that Roger Toussaint, above, president of Local 100, said the union could not accept. And for all the rage and bluster that followed, a costly strike for New York City was called over a plan that would have saved the transit authority less than $20 million over the next three years.

title: 2 Arrested in 4 Killings at a Club in Paterson
description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 20 - The police have arrested two Passaic men and are searching for a third in the killings of four people last week at an after-hours club in Paterson.

title: Take Your Cable Channels With You on the Road
description: In 2002, Blake Krikorian and his brother Jason were beside themselves. Their beloved San Francisco Giants were in a pennant race, yet Blake and Jason, two Silicon Valley engineers, were traveling so much that they missed many of the games on television.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Time Warner Names President
description: Time Warner appointed a new president and chief operating officer today, choosing Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the head of its movie and television businesses, as part of a long-anticipated succession plan that also includes the retirement of another member of the triumvirate that has run the media and entertainment company since 2002.

title: Next Stop: Anywhere Else
description: At 3:30 a.m. yesterday, police officers at the last stop on the A train faced one of the first problems of the strike.

title: Branch Locations
description: Not every Christmas tree can be a towering 74-foot Norway spruce, as the one in Rockefeller Center is this year. Nor can every Christmas tree lighting be broadcast live on national TV. The Parks Department sponsored dozens of more modest Christmas tree lightings in quiet corners of the city this year. Here are snapshots of a few:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEFINE, RUTH (NEE SONNENSCHEIN)
description: DeFINE--Ruth (nee Sonnenschein). December 20, 2005. Beloved wife of 69 years of Robert. Devoted mother of her pet Tucky. Long time resident and friend of many at 47 E 87th St. NY and Seaview, Fire Island. She was a true original. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Wednesday, December 21, 3-4PM. Funeral private.

title: On Foot, on Bridge and at City Hall, Bloomberg Is Irate
description: Presented with a defining test for a New York mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg started the first day of the citywide transit strike yesterday emulating his storied predecessor, Edward I. Koch, by walking across the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Getting There, Any Which Way
description: On a day when just getting to work called for grit and ingenuity, New Yorkers walked, biked and skated, but most of all, they car-pooled. Packing at least four to a vehicle to be allowed into Manhattan, they made arrangements by phone, on the Internet and at curbside, even lowering their guard long enough to ride with strangers, trading the anonymity of the subway for the intimacy of an unfamiliar car. And at least one livery driver thwarted by the four-person rule at the Queensboro Bridge sought three passengers for free rides, calculating that the financial sacrifice would be worth it if he could just get to Manhattan, where the real business was.

title: Saddam claims he's been beaten in detention
Some Crossed the Bridge. Others Were Simply Cross.
description: Gotham has the Bat Signal, pilots have Mayday and New Yorkers have the Brooklyn Bridge. When herds of pedestrians crowd that span of granite and steel, trudging toward the towers of Manhattan or fleeing them, the world knows the city is in a bad way.

title: They Walked, We Walked: Tales From the Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Citywide Strike Halts New York Subways and Buses
description: Shivering, intrepid and occasionally befuddled, New Yorkers yesterday faced down the first citywide transit strike in a quarter-century, walking, biking and car-pooling through their city as transit workers and the state agency that employs them remained locked in intransigence.

title: They Walked, We Walked: Tales From the Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: WTO yields little for poorer states
Excerpt From the Ruling on Intelligent Design
description: Following is an excerpt from the ruling by Judge John E. Jones III that the policy of the Dover, Pa., school board to introduce intelligent design as an alternative to evolution violated the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. The full text of the opinion is at nytimes.com/evolution.

title: Transit Union Lacks Support of Its Parent
description: The transit workers' union, despite taking the extraordinary step of calling its first strike in 25 years, has revealed itself over the last 48 hours to be an organization wrestling with considerable discord -- a local union, in fact, that is at complete odds with its larger parent organization.

title: Philips takes E460 million loss from TV tube joint venture
Home Construction Is Up; Producer Price Index Falls
description: Home building picked up speed in November, the government reported yesterday, indicating that the housing market in much of the country remains robust, though below records set earlier this year.

title: Curry's Injuries Leave Knicks Hurting Inside
description: Two months ago, when the optimism flowed and the only concern was Eddy Curry's heartbeat, the Knicks treated his arrival as a rare blessing. On the night they acquired him, the team president, Isiah Thomas, called Curry the kind of player who comes along "every 15 to 20 years."

title: A Sicilian Christmas With a Nod to the North
description: ACI CASTELLO, Italy - WE never had the Sicilian tradition for Christmas because we are such a mixed-up family," Ornella Laneri said as she poured another glass of Almerita brut from the legendary Tasca d'Almerita cellars. "Mixed-up" means her mother was born in Padua, in the north; her father is Sicilian.

title: Sprint Nextel Agrees to Buy an Affiliate
description: Sprint Nextel reached an agreement yesterday to acquire its affiliate Nextel Partners for $6.5 billion, ending a vicious dispute between the companies about the value of such a deal.

title: An Oily Christmas Carol
description: Christmas Eve, Houston. EBENEZER SCROOGE, the grasping, wrenching, buttock squeezing, covetous CEO of Texas energy giant ConOilCan is alone in his 60th floor corner office, brooding over the drilling rights to the tiny middle northeastern nation of Syracusiana, which have been awarded to an unforeseen competitor, Budweiser.

title: Briefly: EU-U.S. wine accord approved amid rancor
The Poor Need Not Apply
description: On Sept. 15, speaking from New Orleans's Jackson Square, President Bush was eloquent: "As all of us saw on television, there is also some deep, persistent poverty in this region as well," he said. "We have a duty to confront this poverty with bold action. So let us restore all that we have cherished from yesterday, and let us rise above the legacy of inequality."

title: Q & A with Sling Media co-founder
Israeli Leader Leaves Hospital, Looking Healthy After His Stroke
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20 - Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was released from the hospital on Tuesday, two days after he had a mild stroke, and he displayed no signs of illness.

title: Ibsen with a bleak, wild rush
Estonia port is vying to win back the ships
New Jersey Plans Broad Steroid Testing for School Sports
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 20 - New Jersey's acting governor signed an executive order Tuesday that requires random steroid testing for athletes on high school teams that qualify for postseason play. The order makes the state the first to test high school students in all sports for performance-enhancing drugs.

title: New Jersey Plans Broad Steroid Testing for School Sports
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 20 - New Jersey's acting governor signed an executive order Tuesday that requires random steroid testing for athletes on high school teams that qualify for postseason play. The order makes the state the first to test high school students in all sports for performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Yankees' Pursuit Pays Off As Dotel Agrees to Terms
description: A crowded pitching staff did not stop the Yankees from aggressively pursuing Octavio Dotel this off-season. Dotel, a free-agent reliever who agreed to a one-year, $2 million contract with the Yankees yesterday, received calls from Manager Joe Torre, the first-base coach Tony Pea and the Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, among others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEBOWITZ, JAY
description: LEBOWITZ--Jay. The members, Board of Governors, and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Helen and the entire family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: Shares Fall a Fourth Day; Interest Rate Worries Cited
description: Speculation that an increase in housing starts will give the Federal Reserve a reason to keep raising interest rates sent stocks lower yesterday, their fourth day of declines.

title: An Unnecessary Transit Strike
description: The bar for job actions by New York City transit workers is set, legally, out of reach for good reason. A strike that halts buses and subways that daily carry seven million riders can devastate New York's economy and countless lives. The New Yorkers who took to the streets yesterday, some walking miles to work or other appointments, deserved better than the explanation they got from leaders of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union -- who said they had no choice but to tell their 33,000 members to begin an illegal walkout. That's ridiculous.

title: Tapas With a Disco Beat
description: YOU walk in, confront a tangle of diners around the host's station, slalom through the bodies to get to your table, and think: Got it. The crowd, chaos and cocktails are the point of Bara 18. The food won't be.

title: When Right Train Is Wrong: Suburbanites by Accident
description: Correction Appended

title: New York burdened by transit strike
EU growth forecasts up
Judge rejects call for teaching 'intelligent design'
Corrections
description: A caption with a front-page article yesterday about security concerns surrounding Google Earth, the satellite imaging service, misidentified the building in the picture. It was the Cathedral of St. Basil the Blessed in Red Square, not the Kremlin.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Romania: Austrian Lender Buys Bank
description: Erste Bank, Austria's second-biggest lender after Bank Austria Creditanstalt, won the bidding for Banca Comerciala Romana, Romania's largest bank, with an offer of 3.75 billion euros ($4.45 billion) to add more than five million clients. The Austrian lender beat a competing bid from Banco Comercial Portugus of Portugal to buy 61.9 percent of Banca Comerciala. The banking industry in Romania, a former communist country scheduled to join the European Union in 2007, offers one of the clearest opportunities for growth in Europe, analysts said.

title: Militants, Seeking Jobs and Aid, Briefly Seize Offices in Bethlehem
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, Dec. 20 - Bethlehem always expects guests in Manger Square around Christmas, but Tuesday's visitors caught everyone by surprise.

title: In Final Hours, M.T.A.Took Big Pension Risk
description: On the final day of intense negotiations, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, it turns out, greatly altered what it had called its final offer, to address many of the objections of the transit workers' union. The authority improved its earlier wage proposals, dropped its demand for concessions on health benefits and stopped calling for an increase in the retirement age, to 62 from 55.

title: INSIDE
description: Sunnis Reject Iraqi Tally And Call for an Inquiry Sunni Arab leaders said the vote had been fixed in favor of Iranian-backed religious Shiites, and they called for an investigation into possible fraud. Secular politicians also denounced the results. The growing fury threatened to build into a confrontation that could delay the new four-year government.

title: Entr'acte: Want to draw a crowd? Try some tasteless art.
Balky time travel for this 'Boris'
Reviving the Glory of Hoboken Terminal
description: Correction Appended

title: As Traffic Dwindles, Strike Inflicts Broad Economic Pain
description: At Century 21, the discount department store near Wall Street where shopping is usually a contact sport, a smattering of customers yesterday found the retail version of a Christmas miracle: entire aisles to themselves and no lines at the registers.

title: Arts, Briefly; NBC Gets a Good 'Deal'
description: In its second-to-last matchup on ABC, "Monday Night Football" was saddled with another loser game. The weekly sports show, which will move to ESPN next season, broadcast the dreadful Baltimore Ravens' 48-3 defeat of the even worse Green Bay Packers. Brett Favre's last appearance on the show will be remembered as the worst Packer loss since 1980. Needless to say, the game did not have wide appeal to viewers, who preferred CBS's Monday lineup of original programming. It was a dual storyline of death by toxic shock syndrome and a reopened rape case on "CSI: Miami" that drew the night's largest audience, with 19.87 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. NBC, in third place in both total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic, began its weeklong "Deal or No Deal" broadcasts at 8 p.m. The debut of the game show, with Howie Mandel as host, performed well, winning the hour, delivering 11.6 million viewers and giving the network its largest audience in that time period in more than a year.

title: Stranded on the Flip Side of the American Dream
description: The documentary "Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room" wrested only tragedy from the corporate scandal of its title, but it probably should come as no great surprise that now Hollywood is looking to mine big laughs from the same. Hence the sort-of-new Jim Carrey vehicle "Fun With Dick and Jane," what may be the first post-Enron comedy. Based on the 1977 Me Generation laugh-in of the same title with Jane Fonda and George Segal, this comic redo doesn't so much update the plight of its fast-sinking upwardly mobile couple as dust off the story's central conceit: namely, the flip side of the American dream is a nightmare but, you know, also kind of funny.

title: Saudi Women See Changes, and Reasons to Expect More
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia - Manal al-Sharif, a Saudi journalist in this Red Sea city, was in Manhattan when the Sept. 11 attacks occurred. She scrambled to contact her editors and send reports, but was rebuffed because they did not trust the work of a woman.

title: They Walked, We Walked: Tales From the Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TULCHIN, STANLEY
description: TULCHIN - Stanley. The Board of The American Academy of Dramatic Arts notes with great regret, the passing of its distinguished colleague and friend, Ted Tulchin. A member of the Board of The American Academy of Dramatic Arts and its Treasurer for many years. He will be sorely missed. Sam Davis, Chairman Robert E. Wankel, Chairman Emeritus Roger Croucher, President $(6$)TULCHIN--Ted (Stanley). We will cherish your friendship forever. Our deepest sympathies to Patsy, your children, grandchildren and brother. The world lost a sensational person upon your passing. We had ten wonderful years together at the Jewish Community Center in Sherman, CT. Your counsel, guidance and generosity, in a large measure, contributed to our success. We miss you already. Ruth and Bernard Hoberman $(6$)TULCHIN -- Stanley. The Board of Directors and staff of The Topps Co mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague, counselor and friend of 25 years. He will be well remembered and sorely missed. Heartfelt concondolences to his wife, Pat and loving family. Arthur T. Shorin, Chairman

title: British arrest suspect in July 21 bomb plot
Both Resentment and Regret for Strikers on the First Day
description: Outside the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's power command center, a brick building on West 53rd Street, a dozen subway workers paced the picket line yesterday, carrying their green and white strike placards and dissecting each of the reasons that they said led them there.

title: They Walked, We Walked: Tales From the Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arabic Translator Admits He Lied
description: An Arabic translator who worked for an Army intelligence unit in Iraq pleaded guilty yesterday to federal charges that he lied to gain United States citizenship and a security clearance. Federal authorities said they were still seeking to determine whether he served as a spy for the Iraqi insurgency. The translator, Noureddine Malki, 46, was surrounded by federal marshals during a brief proceeding before Chief Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court. A federal prosecutor explained that the heavy security stemmed from unexplained telephone calls Mr. Malki made from Brooklyn to people linked to the Iraqi insurgency, and to the sensitive classified military documents found in his Brooklyn home. Mr. Malki's lawyer, Mildred Whalen, said "he categorically denies having any knowing intentional contact with anyone who had any interest against the U.S. or designs against the U.S." Mr. Malki faces up to six months in prison when he is sentenced early next year. WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: We Meet Carmen Electra, More Popular Than Tattoos
description: We Meet Carmen Electra, More Popular Than Tattoos

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 3 about rules on tattoos for members of the military and police departments referred imprecisely to the Coast Guard policy for recruits. It allows tattoos that do not cover more that 25 percent of an exposed limb if their content is not objectionable and bans those on the head, face, neck and hands. It does not ban all visible tattoos.

title: An Evening of Sensuous and Serious Modernism
description: An uninstructed observer could have mistaken Monday night's Speculum Musicae program at Merkin Hall for a rear guard action in behalf of modern composition. An audience of 50 or so listening to four new-music veterans negotiate five pieces might indeed have seemed forlorn, but this was only new music doing its business -- leading its quiet, everyday and worthwhile life removed from grand events, big-five orchestras and major concert halls.

title: Leading diamond appraiser in bribery inquiry
Tax Gain Aids Palm Profit
description: Palm, maker of the Treo mobile phone and hand-held computer, said yesterday that its quarterly profit increased more than 900 percent because of a tax gain.

title: Lottery Numbers
Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, SANFORD
description: COHEN - Sanford. Beloved husband of Sandra, devoted brother of Barbara and loving uncle. Services Thursday 12 Noon, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Thrown Together, Strangers Share Cars and Life Stories
description: The BMW in Brooklyn held an office temp, a lawyer and a technology worker. The courier's van in Queens was crowded with the driver and his buddies and a man who had flagged them down.

title: A Korean TV Show Reports, and the Network Cancels It
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 17 - Last June, Hwang Woo Suk, South Korea's celebrated stem cell scientist, was named Supreme Scientist of the nation. Korean Air gave him first-class air tickets for a decade.

title: Uzbek Dissident Could Face Hefty Sentence on Tax Charges
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan, Dec. 20 - Uzbekistan on Tuesday accused one of the country's few remaining domestic critics of tax evasion and other financial crimes, a situation that suggests the opposition figure, who was arrested Monday, now faces a long incarceration in the repressive state.

title: They Walked, We Walked: Tales From the Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancing and Dallying but Taking the Story Seriously
description: For an operetta of such enduring popularity, Johann Strauss's "Fledermaus" has suffered from more than its share of clueless productions. Many opera companies seem uncomfortable with the mix of silliness and cynicism in the story. It's a given that almost everyone in the Viennese society of the 1870's that the work depicts, from wealthy married couples to their ambitious chambermaids, engages in dalliances. Angry protestations over infidelity are for public posturing only.

title: Elton John Makes It Legal With Longtime Partner
description: WINDSOR, England, Dec. 21 - If there were any anti- or pro-gay demonstrators in the crowd, they were being unusually quiet. No one was screaming religious slogans, carrying angry placards, wearing in-your-face outfits or loudly forecasting the end of civilization as we know it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 6 about Saudi Arabia's efforts to monitor daily oil production referred imprecisely to a trip to the kingdom by the energy secretary, Samuel W. Bodman. His trip last month was the first by an American energy secretary in two and a half years, not four.

title: Devils Get Behind Lamoriello, the 'New' Guy Behind the Bench
description: The Devils were less than six minutes away from being shut out last night in Lou Lamoriello's first game behind the bench in more than 17 years, when their evening turned in a 16-second span.

title: Lobbyist Is Said to Discuss Plea and Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 - Jack Abramoff, the Republican lobbyist under criminal investigation, has been discussing with prosecutors a deal that would grant him a reduced sentence in exchange for testimony against former political and business associates, people with detailed knowledge of the case say.

title: Uzbek regime arrests a leader of country's decimated opposition
A Bully on the Wrong Side of the Principal's Desk
description: ON a Sunday evening in October 2004, Roberta Lehrman opened an e-mail message from her immediate supervisor, the assistant principal for English at Brooklyn Tech High School. "Congratulations!" began the message. The assistant principal, Tracy Atkins-Zoughlami, had selected Ms. Lehrman to display her teaching abilities for a group of local educators visiting Brooklyn Tech later in the month.

title: Insurer's Rating Is Raised
description: The credit rating of the New York Life Insurance Company, the biggest life insurer in the nation that is owned by policyholders, was raised one level yesterday to Aaa, the highest rating possible, from Aaa1 by Moody's Investors Service.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 7TH ANNUAL A HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS -- This entertainment special celebrates the joys of adoption, with music and real-life stories. Performers include Sheryl Crow, doing "Every Day Is a Winding Road"; Yolanda Adams, singing "I Believe I Can Fly"; and the Goo Goo Dolls performing "Better Days." Jamie Lee Curtis (right), adoptive mother and host, is joined by nonmusical guests like George Lopez, Virginia Madsen and Victoria Rowell (Drucilla on the daytime soap "The Young and the Restless"), who was brought up in foster care for 18 years.

title: Qwest ex-chief is indicted
Swami Jagdishwaranand, 71, Spiritual Leader, Dies
description: Swami Jagdishwaranand, a prominent Hindu spiritual leader in New York City who was responsible for establishing several temples here, died last Thursday at the Geeta Temple in Elmhurst, Queens. The swami, who founded the temple more than 30 years ago and made his home there, was 71.

title: Conviction Is Overturned for Schizophrenic Killer
description: New York's highest court yesterday overturned the conviction of Andrew Goldstein, a schizophrenic who pushed a young woman to her death in front of a subway train in 1999, finding that Mr. Goldstein's rights had been violated when a psychiatric expert testified about statements made by people who were not cross-examined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TREVAS, SEYMOUR
description: TREVAS - Seymour. We mourn the loss of a former president, wise cooperator, and beloved friend. Three Arrows Cooperative Society, Inc. Cate Crowley, President

title: Appeals Court Rejects U.S. Bid to Transfer Terror Suspect
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 - A federal appeals court delivered a stunning rebuke to the Bush administration today, refusing to allow the transfer of Jose Padilla from military custody to civilian law enforcement authorities to face terrorism charges in criminal court.

title: Academy Set to Keep Training Program for School Principals
description: The New York City Leadership Academy, a nearly $70 million principal training program that was one of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's signature education efforts, will continue to exist as a private nonprofit group, its board announced yesterday.

title: A Town in the Spotlight Wants Out of It
description: DOVER, Pa., Dec. 20 - In family-owned shops and along the streets near the town's only traffic light, where Christmas trees stood at all four corners, the talk of Dover turned again Tuesday to the fundamental question of how humans got here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IRVINGS, ABRAHAM I.
description: IRVINGS--Abraham I. On December 19, 2005. Beloved husband of Augusta. Devoted father of Mark and Perri Beth and father-in-law of Susan. Cherished grandfather of Sivon and Ari. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at Beth El Cemetery, N.J.

title: Hussein Says U.S. Guards Beat Him
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 21 - After another day of testimony about torture, beatings and executions under his rule, Saddam Hussein sought to turn the tables on his accusers today with a courtroom outburst in which he accused American military guards of beating and torturing him and his co-defendants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANGUILLECOURT, SERGIO
description: DANGUILLECOURT - Sergio. The Manhattanville College community mourns the loss of one of its most dedicated and beloved alumni and trustees, Sergio Danguillecourt, and his wife, Jacqueline Kriz Danguillecourt, who died on December 19, 2005. Few individuals have so consistantly lived the college's mission, to educate ethically and socially responsible leaders for the global community. Mr. Danguillecourt, a 1990 graduate, served on the college's Board of Trustees for ten years. Over his impressive career, Mr. Danguillecourt was widely respected for his vision and commitment to education, students, and diversity. In honor of his mentor, Professor Edward W. Ryan, he established the college's first endowed chair, The Ryan-Bacardi Chair in Economics. Friends and alumni may wish to make contributions in Mr. Danguillecourt's memory to the Ryan-Bacardi Chair, Manhattanville College, 2900 Purchase Street, Purchase, NY 10577. We are deeply saddened and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family, especially his two children. Richard A. Berman, President Manhattanville College, Purchase, NY

title: Corrections
description: The On Education column last Wednesday, about efforts by Shaker Heights High School in Ohio to close the racial gap in educational achievement, misstated the college at which Charles Inniss, a black Shaker Heights graduate, is a freshman. It is Swarthmore College, not Princeton, as school district officials said.

title: Last-Minute Bottles to Throw in the Sleigh
description: SHAME on you. You left your holiday shopping practically to the end, didn't you? Maybe you were hoping I'd bail you out with a few last-minute suggestions. Is that it? You may think you're clever, but first I'm going to tell you exactly how I feel about you.

title: From Casting to Curtain Call, a Group's Special Challenge
description: If you're an actor or if you've ever been part of community theater or even a school play, you know the exhilaration of the curtain call. But the one in "Yellow Brick Road," a touching documentary that has its premiere tonight on Cinemax, is more emotional than most.

title: Humble and Hot
description: IN Thailand, most meals include nam prik, the pungent paste used as a dip for vegetables and as an embellishment for plain rice. Yet it is still uncommon in New York, where Thai restaurants have thrived for decades. In fact, it has taken 15 years for Sripraphai Tipmanee, the owner of Sripraphai in Woodside, Queens, by almost every measure the top Thai restaurant in town, to put the dish on her rarely changing menu.

title: Trial starts in massacre of Bosnians
Empty Tables, Empty Stores
description: As hundreds of thousands of commuters and shoppers stayed away from Manhattan, stores and restaurants that rely on human traffic were hit hard by the strike, which threatened to ruin their busiest season. Many other businesses found themselves hampered by the absence of workers, and some made unusual arrangements to keep functioning. At F. Illi Ponte, above, a TriBeCa restaurant that gave its employees cab fare to make sure they would show up to work, half the day's reservations were canceled. And at Lord & Taylor in Midtown, so many sales clerks were absent that executives were pressed into service.

title: Correction
description: The Wines of The Times column last Wednesday about Champagne misstated its location in relation to other fine-wine regions. It is the northernmost fine-wine region in France, not the world. The Mosel region in Germany is more northerly.

title: Big shiftin strategy at utility
World Briefing | Europe: Russia: General Dismissed Over Forced Labor
description: Of the nagging problems facing Russia's military, one of the worst abuses has been the persistent use of draftees to carry out menial tasks for their commanders. Now, in an unusual case of disciplinary action, the minister of defense, Sergei B. Ivanov, has dismissed a senior army commander, citing a new decree forbidding the practice. The officer, Maj. Gen. Yevgeny Veselov, a deputy commander of the Moscow Military District, had ordered four soldiers to build a country house for an unidentified woman, Interfax reported. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

title: Pirro Ends Senate Bid and Will Run for Attorney General
description: Jeanine F. Pirro said today that she would abandon her plans to unseat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York and would instead run for state attorney general, saying, "my head and my heart remain in law enforcement."

title: Sample Sale
description: Garritan is a company that sells samples (that is, high-quality instrument sounds for professional music synthesizers). It's come up with a truly ingenious way to promote their flexibility: a set of Christmas-carol arrangements -- not 30-second previews, but an entire playlist of full MP3 songs--created by Garritan customers and posted online for everyone to play, download and enjoy. That's what I call win-win marketing.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Man Arrested In Failed July Attacks
description: The police arrested a 23-year-old man in connection with the failed bomb attacks on London's transportation system on July 21. The man, who the police said was from North London, was seized as he landed at Gatwick Airport on a flight from Ethiopia. The police said he had been out of the country since June and was suspected of giving logistical support to the bombers. A total of 15 people, including several with family ties to countries in the Horn of Africa, including Ethiopia, have been charged with involvement in the attempted July 21 suicide attacks, which went awry, the police said at the time, because explosives did not detonate properly.

title: Statement From Jeanine Pirro
description: Today, after consultation with the leaders of my party, particularly Governor Pataki, Senator Bruno, Chairman Minarik, and leaders of the Conservative and Independent parties, I have decided that my law enforcement background better qualifies me for a race for New York State Attorney General than a race for the United States Senate.

title: Practice, Practice, Practice. Go to College? Maybe.
description: Correction Appended

title: Turkey on Trial, Part 1
description: The trial of Orhan Pamuk, the best-selling Turkish novelist, had barely gotten under way in Istanbul the other day when the judge postponed the proceedings until Feb. 7. We can only hope that this delay signals that Turkish leaders are looking for a way to drop the charges against Mr. Pamuk, who is being prosecuted for "insulting Turkish identity."

title: Global Climate Change
description: Entertainment Weekly recasts the Golden Globes to suit its own ends, including suggesting that Heath Ledger, a best actor in a drama nominee for Brokeback Mountain, actually should get a comeback award for extracting himself from the depths of Four Feathers and Lords of Dogtown. And they elevate Terrence Howard, who is riding the hum of constant mentions, for breaking through in Hustle and Flow and buttoning up in Crash. What, no award for bravery for Charlize Theron heading into the maw of Aeon Flux?

title: Jumping the Gun and the Shark at the Same Time
description: As part of the Oscar scrum, the Carpetbagger follows every wiggle and wobble of the handicapping and may eventually jump in. If he does, listen very closely and then start laying your bets the other way as fast as you can. Fun is fun, but over at the Oscar Igloo, things seem to have gotten completely out of hand. Their picks so far? Dreamgirls, Che, and Marie Antoinette. You say those movies arent even out? Thats okay, the snowhut site is picking contenders for  next years awards. That seems like a premature, ahead-of-the-curve, over-soon, half-baked, half-cocked, ill-conceived notion of a whim, but maybe thats just the Carpetbagger. Hes new around here.

title: Have the Terrorists Won?
description: Munich, which got pounded coming out of the gate, seems to be enjoying a bit of a bounce. Patrick Goldstein, one of our papers sworn enemies in the egg-head death match that is cinema and Oscar writing esteemed and learned colleagues, still favors Brokeback, but says that Munich has a shot, in part because people are starting to see the movie instead of just the controversy.

title: Keeping It Real
description: Mark Urman, head of U.S. theatrical for THINKFilm, which has two of this years better docs in Aristocrats and Murderball, tells indieWIRE (whats with this indie film guys and their random capitalization, anyway? From now on, Im going to be the CARPETbagger. No special reason. It just feels right.) that documentarians are still finding a way to break through the clutter of releases. Even though the vast majority still remain in a limited-audience ghetto, the same could be said for most indie films, and unlike low-budget fiction fare and foreign language films, docs have gained ground while the other varieties of alternative film have lost ground in the marketplace.

title: A Fiction Thats Better Than Fiction
description: Most fiction writers writhe in agony as their prose is set to Hollywood music. First the producers concept it to a pulp, and then a director applies his or her deeply held personal vision, and then actors play the dialogue through the prism of their egos. But Annie Proulx, above, told Sandy Cohen of the Associated Press that she was knocked out of the saddle by Heath Ledgers turn as Ennis, the lonesome cowboy, in Brokeback Mountain. She said his portrayal was really beyond description as far as Im concerned. He got inside the story more deeply than I did. All that thinking about the character of Ennis that was so hard for me to get, Ledger just was there. And thanks to Zeke, one of the Rugrats in the comment section, we find out that a light-hearted Ledger said that when he was looking for a model for a frustrated Western ranch guy who had trouble with the language, his thoughts turned to the 43rd president of the United States. I wanted him to be a clenched fist and essentially my mouth became a clenched fist and the words became part of the battle. Too bad he never had to get his lips around nuclear in the role.

title: This Buds for You. Not.
description: When the Carpetbagger said yesterday that neither love nor money could buy you Oscar tickets, he was not altogether correct, although he wasnt far off. In general, the $350 floor seats are impossible to obtain, but it can be done, as long as you are willing to break the law and pay $30,000 to $40,000 a pair. Thats the word from a suit filed by the Academy, which sued a number of brokers who it alleged were attempting to sell tickets to last years Oscars, some for more than 50 times face value. The suit, which was filed last spring, was briefly noted in the press at the time, but seems about to conclude with stipulated judgments all around and a promise from the defendants never again to do what they denied doing in the first place. Aint justice grand?

title: Youve Been Warned
description: (A warning label from the Carpetbagger: First item contains excerpts from real, actual court documents and reads like homework with a side of brussels sprouts. The highlights? Someone paid $40,000 for a pair of Oscar tickets last year. And this year, the price could go to $30,000 per seat. But its okay because you probably cant find them anyway, and if you do, you could end up throttled by the Academys lawyers. Now if you were just here for a bit of quality wisecracking time with your old/new pal the Carpetbagger, skip to the next item. Otherwise, youve been forewarned. Send the assistant out for another cup of French roast  just the tiniest smidge of non-fat milk, thank you  and tell him to hold your calls.)

title: Striking Up a Conversation
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Gear Test With: David Felkley, Snowshoe Guide
description: The co-author of "Snowshoeing"  recently tested snowshoes and poles near his home outside Denver.

title: Foreclosing Hype
description: The Matrix, a blog written by Jonathan Miller, president and chief executive of the residential real estate appraisal firm Miller Samuel, has a smart take on why we should cautiously interpret foreclosure statistics.

title: Who Left the Cake Out in the Rain?
description: David Berson, the chief economist at Fannie Mae, isnt getting gloomy about the housing market. In an interview during the Nightly Business Report on PBS last night, the economist said real estate sales will slow and prices may not climb, but thats only because investors  what many would call speculators  are dropping out of the market. But crash? No way, he says.

title: Caught in Between
description: Have you ever wondered about people who buy a new home before they sell the old one? Emily Rooney, host of a PBS show in Boston, just bought a $1.5 million-plus Back Bay condo on Marlborough Street but still hasnt sold her West Newton home. She wants $1.7 million for it, and it has been on the market for three months, The Boston Herald reports.

title: It Worked for GM  Didnt It?
description: Centex, the big national home builder, is offering handsome holiday discounts on its Phoenix homes: $25,000 off. The base price of many of its new homes there is about $250,000, so we are talking about a 10 percent incentive to move the inventory. It is a way for Centex to drop prices without dropping prices, just like the auto makers do with incentives.

title: Comparing the Models
description: Units below $1,000 are available from most major notebook makers and offer a range of features.

title: Currents
description: Kate Spade's new line; a beanbag chair for baby; snowing in Dubai and more.

title: Transit Strike: Day Two
description: Commuters struggled to get to work on the second day of the transit strike in New York.

title: Hair Today, Gone Tomorrow
description: The Yankees have a history of cutting it kind of close.

title: A Fair Solution or a Fence?
description: By constructing 27 terminals, Israel hopes to ease the burden on Palestinians and soften international criticism. But Palestinians say the barrier still fences them in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYERS, SAMUEL
description: MEYERS--Samuel. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Samuel Meyers, beloved father of Robert Meyers, whose generosity and enthusiastic leadership strengthens lives and enriches the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and throughout the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to Bob and his wife, Harriet, and to his entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: A Good Old-Fashioned Modernist and Associates, Doing What They Do Best
description: The pianist Cedar Walton suggests tradition of a not-so-old kind. Twenty years ago musicians like him were imposingly present: players who had started in the 1950's or 60's, nourished by the work of Bud Powell and Thelonious Monk and Horace Silver, had come through the straits of jazz fusion and were still determined to play acoustic jazz.

title: Day 2 of the Strike: Brrr and Grrr
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters:Devan Nair
Against Spurs, Knicks Hit New Low
description: There is no telling when or how the Knicks' startling free fall will end, but in so many ways, they seem to have already bottomed out -- spiritually, emotionally and otherwise.

title: Two Choices for Game? Consider the Nuances of Scoring
description: You and your partner have game-going values and an eight-card major suit fit. When should you play in four of your major and when in three no-trump? Does it matter if you are playing in a team event (or Chicago) or in a matchpointed pairs duplicate?

title: Other Views: The East African, The Business Times, Yemen Observer
Diabetes Study Verifies Lifesaving Tactic
description: A 17-year federal study has finally answered one of the most pressing questions about diabetes: Can tight control of blood sugar prevent heart attacks and strokes?

title: S.E.C. Accuses a New Jersey Hedge Fund
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has sued HMC International, a small New Jersey hedge fund company, and its two principals, accusing them of misappropriating $5.2 million of the firm's $12.9 million to pay for their lavish lifestyles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUSON, MICHAEL
description: GRUSON--Michael. Former Partner and Of Counsel, Shearman & Sterling (1936 2005) Michael Gruson, a key figure in international banking and capital markets, died in New York on December 20 of a brain tumor. Mr. Gruson, a long-time partner with Shearman & Sterling, was a well-known and highly respected attorney practicing in the United States and Germany. A noted specialist in foreign banking and securities law, he represented government-owned and private European, Asian and Latin American banks and companies, as well as helped usher in commercial relations between the United States and Germany. He was fundamental to the establishment in New York of many foreign banks, including the Bank of China and Credit Anstalt. Mr. Gruson was a pioneer in international law, and helped inaugurate Shearman & Sterling's German practice. He was very instrumental in developing the firm's foreign associate program in which many well-known lawyers and business executives participated, including the General Counsel of the Frankfurt stock exchange. Born in 1936 in Berlin, Mr. Gruson received his legal education in Germany (University of Mainz, Freie Universitat, Berlin, Dr. Jur. 1966), and in the United States (Columbia University, MCL; LLB). He joined Shearman & Sterling in 1965 and was elected to partnership in 1973. A respected academic, he was the author and co-author of several seminal books in international banking and lectured widely. He was a visiting fellow at numerous international universities. He is survived by his wife, Hiroko, sons Rudolf, Andreas, Sebastian, Matthias, Florian and Konrad, and grandchildren Luis, Manuel, Alexander, Sebastian, Federico Hermann and Sophia. Services will be private. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the New York Brain Tumor Project of the Cornell Weill Medical College, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021 in honor of Mr. Michael Gruson and in care of Dr. Susan C. Pannullo.

title: A self-inventor, many times
Ex-Executives of Health Care Firm Sued
description: Former executives of National Century Financial Enterprises, a defunct health care financier, were sued yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which claimed they had schemed to defraud investors.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The silence is unbearable; it's keeping me up."

title: Time Warner Chooses an Insider as President
description: Jeffrey L. Bewkes was named president and chief operating officer of Time Warner yesterday, putting him in line to succeed the chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, who is fending off efforts by some investors to break up the company.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Qatar Finds a Currency of Its Own: Natural Gas
description: DOHA, Qatar - "This was a sleepy little town when I moved here eight years ago," said Mohamad Moabi, from an office overlooking the turquoise waters alongside this city's crescent-shaped corniche, where dozens of half-built skyscrapers are going up. "Now it's on the frontier of the global economy."

title: Tough Stance, Tougher Fines:Union Leader Is in a Corner
description: When Roger Toussaint, the president of the transit workers' local, defiantly announced a strike, he proclaimed that his union was taking a proud stand against the concessions that employers had demanded nationwide.

title: Redefining the 'Opening Weekend'
description: Several weeks ago, in preparing a segment for "CBS News Sunday Morning," I interviewed Todd Wagner. He's the CEO of 2929 Entertainment, the company, cofounded by Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban, that's experimenting with the "simultaneous release" program that's described in this recent Times story.

title: Some Motherly Advice: How to Be Cool
description: WHEN she picked out her first pair of glasses, Emily Kloppenburg had her vision tweaked in more ways than one. Several weeks ago Ms. Kloppenburg, 16, set aside several frames for her mother's approval at Robert Marc, an optician in Manhattan. But when her mother inspected them, "she gave me a kind of blank stare," she recalled. "Finally she told me, 'Why don't you look at something else, something that is a little bit more of a statement?' "

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIMOND, THOMAS
description: DIMOND--Thomas. Born January 24, 1916, of New York, NY, died on Sunday, December 18, 2005. Mr. Dimond was the son of George A. and Jessie Kennedy Dimond; brother of Jessie K. Dimond (deceased), Jane Dimond (deceased) and Patricia Pfeiffer; uncle of Lisbeth Pfeiffer. Mr. Dimond attended Princeton University with a BA magna cum laude 1939, and Harvard University with an MBA 1941. He was a USAAF Captain 1941-46. He was a faculty member of Wharton School 1948; Economist, Account Manager of Lionel D. Edie & Co. 1948-50; Economist, Manager of Commercial Research of Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. 1951-56; Sr. Account Manager, Security Analyst of deVegh & Co. 1956-60; President of Humes-Schmidlapp Associates 1960-2003. He was on the Board of Directors of Mercer Management Corp. and Co-Manager of Mercer Fund 1963-67; Board of Directors of Scudder Special Fund 1967-72; Scudder Duo-Vest 1968-71; General Partner of H S Special Fund; Contributor of articles to professional publications; Trustee of Humes Foundation. He was a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts, Racquet & Tennis Club and DownTown Association. He will be greatly missed by the HumesSchmidlapp family and staff. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about questions surrounding Dr. Hwang Woo Suk's research on stem cells and cloning referred incorrectly to a proposed test of Snuppy, a dog that Dr. Hwang said he had produced by cloning. If Snuppy is a true clone, the test would show that his mitochondrial DNA differed from that of the dog that donated the nucleus, not from that of the donor of the egg.

title: St. John's Gets a Lesson From Duke
description: DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 21 - The rebuilding process at St. John's is still in the early stages for its second-year coach, Norm Roberts. It remains to be seen if he can lift the Red Storm back to respectability and into contention among the national college basketball elite.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS: ROBERT REDFORD ON PAUL NEWMAN -- Mr. Redford (above right), 68, goes to Connecticut to interview his old pal and one time co-star ("Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" and "The Sting"). Mr. Newman, 80 and fabulous, talks about old times and teases Mr. Redford about his chronic punctuality problem. This, the last in the six-part "Iconoclasts" series, is not untouched by commercial motivation. Both men use the meeting to promote their causes, including the Westport Country Playhouse (Mr. Newman's wife, Joanne Woodward, is retiring as artistic director there) and Mr. Redford's Sundance empire (the channel, the film festival and the rest), but how often do we get to see two truly major movie stars shooting the breeze?

title: Day 2 of the Strike: Brrr and Grrr
description: To the Editor:

title: Spirited bottles of last-minute gifts
Edited to Conform to High Standards
description: A FEW weeks ago I was eating at my favorite kind of New York restaurant -- the kind where everyone has to sit at the same table and the eavesdropping is easy -- when I heard a conversation that went something like this:

title: Chill Grows as Japan Calls China a Military Threat
description: TOKYO, Dec. 22 - With diplomatic relations between Japan and China already chilled by successive events this year, the Japanese foreign minister bluntly described China's military build-up as a threat today, immediately drawing an angry response from Beijing.

title: Excerpts From Court Ruling in Padilla Case
description: Following are excerpts from the decision by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth District refusing to allow the transfer of Jose Padilla from military custody to civilian law enforcement authorities to face terrorism charges.

title: Deutsche chief is assailed by German politicians
Destitute Victims of Storm Remain Stuck at Hotels
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 14 - The hurricane evacuees still living in a string of flophouse motels here three months on are among the most down and out. They were the hidden underclass in New Orleans, with no steady jobs or addresses, and they will be the hardest for government officials to move into apartments.

title: Well, the Baby Lambs Were Mean and Ill-Mannered
description: Well, the Baby LambsWere Mean and Ill-Mannered

title: Jim Ostendarp, Coach at Amherst, Dies at 82
description: Jim Ostendarp, who coached at Amherst for 33 years and once held the record for most coaching victories in the history of New England small-college football, died Dec. 15 at the Soldier's Home in Holyoke, Mass. He was 82.

title: Barrack agrees to buy Placer
To Elton John, the song is 'Here come the grooms'
Roundup: India wins series
Shaking Off the Rust, New Suburbs Are Born
description: Bethlehem, Pa. - IN the shadow of the hulking industrial carcass of the Bethlehem Steel site here, a cozy boutique called Comfort and Joy is selling "aromatherapeutic" cleaning products, herbal teas nested in silk pouches and $1,200 designer quilts. Down the street, another store, Home and Planet, is offering $800 end tables made from recycled steel beams.

title: Senate Backs 6-Month Extension of Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 - With time running short on Capitol Hill, the Senate breathed new life late Wednesday night into the moribund USA Patriot Act, agreeing to extend it by six months. President Bush said he appreciated the move, but it was unclear if the House would approve it.

title: Bolivian president to nationalize oil and gas reserves
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Argument Leads To Fatal Stabbing
description: A fistfight yesterday morning in Washington Heights left one man stabbed to death and another charged with second-degree murder, the police said. The fight began shortly after 3 a.m. in front of 584 Academy Street, with the argument between Louis Gomez, 22, and Humberto Fernandez, 52, escalating until Mr. Gomez punched the older man in the face, the police said. The police said that Mr. Fernandez, who had no criminal history, ran into his home, returned with a knife and stabbed Mr. Gomez, who ran to his own home at 129 Sherman Avenue and collapsed. He was taken to Columbia University Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead.

title: Briefly: EU calls for cuts of 20% in exhaust from vehicles
Allergan to Buy Inamed

title: Yankees Outhustled Red Sox to Get Damon

He will field as many questions about his hair as the Beatles did when they landed in New York in 1964. description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 - In a chaotic conclusion to the Congressional year, the Senate blocked an effort on Wednesday to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling and struck a last-minute accord to extend the antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act for six months.

description: CROTTY--Edward Owen, age 64, on December 20, 2005. Son of the late William E. Crotty and Thelma Mullen Crotty. Brother of William Mullen, Tim and Helen Lee Crotty, Betty Ann Ory, Pat Palmer, Mary Noel Ignal, Susan Michlik and the late Eileen (Sister Mary Thelma, RSM) and Wilma Crotty. He was a native of New Orleans and a resident of Manhattan for 30 years. All are invited to attend the Memorial Mass from St. Mary's Assumption Church, New Orleans on Thursday, December 22, 2005 at Noon. Visitation will begin at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to be sent to The American Cancer Society, 2405 River Rd., New Orleans, LA, 70121.

World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: 3 Convictions In Bombing
description: Two brothers who are former policemen and their cousin were convicted in the death of a prosecutor, Danilo Anderson, who was investigating opponents of President Hugo Chvez when he was killed by a bomb a year ago. Rolando and Otoniel Guevara, the former policemen, and their cousin, Juan Guevara, received sentences of up to 30 years, Attorney General Isaas Rodrguez said. The government contends that Mr. Anderson was killed for investigating 400 opposition leaders said to have supported a coup that briefly ousted Mr. Chvez in 2002. Opposition leaders say the killing was politically motivated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Man Acquitted In Second Rape Trial
description: After two criminal trials and 18 years in prison, a 41-year-old Long Island man was acquitted yesterday in the rape and murder of Theresa Fusco, a 16-year-old from Lynbrook, in 1984. In a nonjury trial, Acting Justice Victor Ort of State Supreme Court found the man, John Kogut, not guilty on three counts. Mr. Kogut, then an unemployed landscaper, was one of three men who were convicted, based on his videotaped confession. He was freed in 2003, after improved DNA technology demonstrated that a semen sample from Ms. Kogut's body did not match any of the three men convicted. A few months later, however, the Nassau County district attorney, Denis Dillon, announced that he would retry Mr. Kogut. Mr. Dillon has not said whether he will seek retrials of the other two men, John Restivo and Dennis Halstead. "Justice was finally done after 20 years," said Paul Casteleiro, Mr. Kogut's lawyer. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Heaven' Scores for ABC
description: The masses may be curious about heaven, but the 18-to-49 demographic loves a game show. In Tuesday's Nielsen's estimates, "ABC News Presents a Barbara Walters Special: Heaven -- Where is it? How Do We Get There?" drew an average of 13.7 million viewers from 9 p.m. to 11 p.m. On its strength, ABC ascended to No. 1 among total viewers for the night. But the new game show "Deal or No Deal" led off NBC's primetime schedule, and anchored a victory for the network among adults 18 to 49. Drawing an audience of 12.61 million, the game of chance pulled in one million more viewers than its Monday premiere did. Also on NBC, "My Name Is Earl," which will soon move to Thursdays, showed that it repeats well. It attracted 10.3 million viewers and won its half-hour in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

This is a dismaying result of the quartet's losing a $611,000 judgment in a lawsuit brought by its former first violinist, David Ehrlich, over his ouster five years ago.

title: The Second Time Around, Marriage With Jewels
description: THE first time she got married, in 1986, Kaethe Cherney was an aspiring actress. Her wedding was a modest ceremony at New York's City Hall. And the ring, fittingly, was "a simple silver band," said Ms. Cherney, 44, who now works in the film industry and lives in London. At the time she thought it romantic, but the ring's no-fuss aspect also signaled some indifference on her part. "I had never considered a traditional engagement ring," Ms. Cherney said. "It hadn't even crossed my mind."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWERS, FREDERIC B.
description: POWERS--Frederic B. Sound Shore Health System mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Frederic B. Powers. Together with his family, Fred was a steadfast supporter of the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester and a devoted member of the Board of Governors. He served from 1967 to 1983, and returned in 1987 to the present. During this time he served as Vice Chairman in 1990, Chairman from 1994 to 1997, Chairman of the Sound Shore Health System from 1999 to the present, and on the Pinnacle Board from 1999 to the present as Chairman. His commitment to providing his community with the highest level of health care services by furthering the mission of the Medical Center will be forever remembered at Sound Shore. We will miss his guidance and support. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife, Ginny, and their children and grandchildren. Lawrence J. Ruisi, Chairman John R. Spicer, President and CEO

description: The Constitutional Court upheld a year-old law that banned direct gubernatorial and regional elections, reinforcing President Vladimir V. Putin's control over local politics. In a rare show of opposition, two of the court's judges, Anatoly Kononov and Vladimir Yaroslavtsev, publicly protested the ruling. "There is a serious problem with the separation of power," one of the dissenters, Judge Kononov, told the news agency Interfax. RACHEL THORNER (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Eminem Holds at No. 1
description: Eminem's "Curtain Call: The Hits" (Aftermath/Interscope) holds the top spot on the Billboard album chart for a second week with sales of more than 323,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Stockings will be stuffed with a lot of "American Idol" this year, with three albums by alumni in the Top 10: "Some Hearts" (Arista) by Carrie Underwood, above, sold 270,000 copies last week, climbing three spots to No. 2; "The Real Thing" (RCA) by Bo Bice reached No. 4 with 227,000 sales in its first week; and Kelly Clarkson's "Breakaway" (RCA), released more than a year ago, re-entered the Top 10 at No. 8 with 180,000. As the new-release schedule has wound down for the year, the remaining Top 10 slots are filled with some of this season's biggest hits: "Now That's What I Call Music!" Vol. 20 (No. 3), Kenny Chesney (No. 5), Nickelback (No. 6), Mariah Carey (No. 7), the Black Eyed Peas (No. 9) and "The Legend of Johnny Cash" (No. 10). BEN SISARIO

But as a director, Mel Gibson has had an unfailing instinct for knowing what moviegoers want before they know it themselves. And while he may have set off one of the largest cultural debates in years with "The Passion of the Christ," in Hollywood terms the yammering hardly matters. His little self-financed movie made so much money that he's free to do whatever he wants next.

The company reported on Wednesday that profit rose 33 percent, to $120.1 million, while revenue grew 53 percent, to $560.6 million, compared with a year ago.

title: Infants Need to Relax, Too; A Beanbag Chair for Baby
description: Everyone loves to lounge, even a baby. The Doomoo is a beanbag chair for infants and toddlers that comes with two covers (one with a safety harness) that can be changed to alter the size and depth of the seat. The chair is made in Belgium and filled with micro-balls and soft filling that mold to the shape of the body. It makes an ideal perch for a baby and a comfy lounge chair for a toddler. The Doomoo is $165 from modernmini.com or (888) 233-1558.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Philips to Take a Charge on a Venture
description: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's largest maker of consumer electronics, will take 460 million euros ($553 million) in fourth-quarter costs related to its unprofitable LG.Philips Displays venture. Philips will take charges of 290 million euros for "accumulated negative difference in currency translation" and about 128 million euros for writing off the remaining book value of the venture, the company said in a statement. A cash charge of 42 million euros linked to an existing guarantee provided to the venture's banks will also be taken. LG.Philips Displays, a maker of glass tubes for televisions and monitors, said earlier that it would write off about $725 million because of falling product prices and adverse business conditions. The venture has posted four consecutive quarterly losses, partly because consumers are switching to slimmer liquid-crystal or plasma display panels. LG Electronics will book combined charges of about 52 billion Korean won ($52 million) because of LG.Philips Displays during the fourth quarter, a spokeswoman, Judy Pae, said. The venture is separate from the LG.Philips LCD Company, a maker of L.C.D.'s used in computers and TV's, which is also jointly owned by LG Electronics and Philips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, BELLA

Much beloved and sorely missed by sister Bertha Heller, brothers Phil and Jerry Reiner, nieces Fran Richter, Randy Amick, Janice Kot ofsky, and Melinda Reiner, nephews Philly Heller, Abe and Harvey Tanenbaum, Brian and Harrison Reiner. Alas, some multiformat readers show up in a file manager as a panoply of separate drives, forcing you to guess which one is needed.
