title: Getting Fit, Even if It Kills You
description: WHILE many gymgoers complain that they might not survive a tough workout, Brian Anderson can speak from experience. For his first CrossFit session, he swung a 44-pound steel ball with a handle over his head and between his legs. The aim was to do 50 quick repetitions, rest and repeat. After 30 minutes, Mr. Anderson, a 38-year-old member of the special weapons and tactics team in the sheriff's office in Tacoma, Wash., left the gym with his muscles sapped and back pain so excruciating that he had to lie in the driveway to collect himself.

title: PHYSICAL CULTURE/Gear Test With David Felkley, Showshoe Guide; In Stride, With Snowshoes
description: WHY is snowshoeing is one of winter's fastest-growing recreational sports? "Because it's easy," said Claire Walter, author of "The Snowshoe Experience," (Workman, 2004). "If you can walk, you can showshoe," she said. "The joke is that it's a 12-step program -- take 12 steps, and you are a snowshoer."

title: Arts, Briefly; Netrebko Cancels Carnegie
description: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko, below, has charmed opera crowds around the world, but she is not yet ready for Carnegie Hall. Ms. Netrebko, 34, has canceled her debut there on March 2, saying "I do not feel artistically ready yet to present a recital program on the great stage of Carnegie Hall," according to a statement released by Carnegie yesterday. "I know that with more recital experience this will change, and I feel a strong responsibility to present only my very best at this great concert hall and to the New York public," she added. In her statement, Ms. Netrebko asked for permission to postpone the concert, but Carnegie said it would not be rescheduled. Tickets will be refunded, the hall said. BEN SISARIO

title: Taking Scalpel to a Premise of Surgical Perfection
description: The Carver, that masked mutilator who gives his victims what soccer thugs used to call a Chelsea smile, was unmasked Tuesday night on the season finale of FX's "Nip/Tuck." He's Quentin Costas (Bruno Campos), a plastic surgeon. It turns out he was cutting up people because he was feeling emasculated.

title: Russia modifies plan to curb charities
Federal Monitor May Step in to Oversee Medical University's Finances
description: Correction Appended

title: U.N. Chief Bemoans 'Really Difficult' Year and Looks Toward '06
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 21 - Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, on Wednesday devoted a news conference to expressions of concern over events of a past year he described as "really difficult" and said he was "raring to go" on the coming year, his last in office.

title: The last greatelephant hunter
Mediaset to buy Europa TV frequencies
From Scorching Desert to Snowy Peaks: In Dubai, It Takes Just Minutes
description: Tucked inside a 25-story building at a mall in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, is the first indoor ski resort in the Middle East. After a day in the scorching desert heat, visitors can now head for the slopes, just minutes away.

description: ALBANY, Dec. 21 - With the first transit strike in a generation stranding millions of New Yorkers and harming businesses across the city, the elected official with the most sway over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Gov. George E. Pataki, has played a largely low-key role, at least in public.

title: Isles Leave Devils Looking Mediocre
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Dec. 21 - Two Devils players thumped into each other near the goal Wednesday night. Believing he had collided with a member of the Islanders, Devils defenseman Colin White swatted hurriedly at a wobbling puck and watched it dribble off his stick.

Paid Notice: Deaths   TURNER, EDITH CANDACE ROSENBLATT
description: TURNER -- Edith Candace Rosenblatt, 100. Died peacefully in her sleep on December 19, 2005. Loving wife of the late Al, beloved mother of her adored Jon, and Margaret Helfand. Loving sister of the late Rose, Ben, Sonia, Jen, Will. Beloved aunt to Ruth Turner. Adored adopted mother and grandmother to her entire family. She shared her great heart and wisdom with all who knew her, and all who knew her, adored her. She will be greatly missed. Memorial to be held in April. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UJA or The Hebrew National Fund.

title: Israel Is Easing Barrier Burden, but Palestinians Still See a Border
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 21 - Israel is overhauling its separation barrier along the West Bank and Jerusalem to cut the crossing time for people and goods from hours to minutes. Aimed at easing the burden on Palestinians and softening international criticism, it is also proving contentious by giving the barrier more than ever the feel of an international border.

title: Congress Slinks Toward the Holidays
description: The good, the bad and the ugly were on display yesterday in the Senate's mad dash toward recess. Ugliest of all was a 51-to-50 vote approving unfair budget cutbacks that would burden the poor with Medicaid, child-support and workfare restrictions. Vice President Dick Cheney rushed to the Capitol to cast the tie-breaking vote for what amounts to a $39.7 billion smokescreen for the Republicans' plan to sneak back into town after the holidays and pass up to $100 billion in tax cuts favoring the affluent.

title: What remains to be done in the Balkans
The Bench Does Its Part to Do More in Less Time
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 21 - The usual suspects were at the forefront of the Nets' solid effort Wednesday night, and the team continued to feed off the things that have made it successful lately.

title: Filipino children behind bars
Another airline tax
Lobbyist Nears Terms on Plea Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 - Jack Abramoff, the Republican lobbyist under indictment for fraud in South Florida, is expected to complete a plea agreement in the Miami criminal case, setting the stage for him to become a crucial witness in a broad federal corruption investigation, people with direct knowledge of the case said.

title: News analysis: Retrial ruling reflects German mood
World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Rebels Kill 8 Policemen
description: Remnants of the Shining Path, a guerrilla group largely wiped out in the 1990's, attacked a police patrol and killed eight officers, officials said. The attack in a remote coca-growing region in northeast Peru, was the second by rebels in a month. Authorities attribute the attacks to rebels working with drug traffickers.

title: Year in Sports: A conversation
Paid Notice: Deaths   COSGRIFF, STUART, M.D.
description: COSGRIFF -- Stuart, M.D. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University Medical Center mourn the passing of our respected friend and colleague, Dr. Stuart W. Cosgriff, Consultant Emeritus at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Clinical Professor Emeritus in Medicine at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. Dr. Cosgriff, 88, was renowned for his role in clinical anticoagulation, a therapy used to treat vascular disorders. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Cosgriff's five children, 10 grandchildren, and six greatgrandchildren. Dr. Herbert Pardes President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Dr. Gerald D. Fischbach Executive Vice President and Dean Columbia University Medical Center

title: Surviving the Holidays
description: Surviving the Holidays

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Alan Shields, an artist known for radiantly colored three-dimensional paintings, misstated the date of his death. It was Dec. 13, not Dec. 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REISS, ARTHUR
description: REISS--Arthur. Passed away on December 21, 2005 at the age of 92. Beloved husband and patriarch of an adoring family. Survived by his wife Arline and his children Roberta Miller (Joshua), Marvin Reiss (Susan) and Linda Heffner (Edward), his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He was the epitome of a trully straightforward, successful businessman and a pillar of his secular and religious community. He was trusted and admired by his associates and family as a model of moral conduct in today's complex and confused world. He founded the I. Reiss and Son real estate investment firm with his father Isidor in 1930. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, New York at 12 noon on Thursday, December 22.

title: Stealth Sounds That Missed the Charts but Merit a Hearing
description: Obscure ain't what it used to be. Thanks to all kinds of online distribution, both legal and il-, it's getting harder to find any music at all that's hard to find. It keeps getting easier for fervent fans of underground acts to find one another, which means it keeps getting easier for casual browsers to find the music, and sample it free. This seems to work especially well for indie-rock acts, and somewhat less well for musicians in genres a little further from the rock-critical mainstream.

title: Albertson's Sale Is in Limbo as Board Rejects $9.6 Billion Bid
description: Albertson's Inc., the giant supermarket chain, terminated talks last night with a consortium of investors that had been the leading bidder in an auction for the company, people involved in the talks said.

title: Day 2 of the Strike: Brrr and Grrr
description: To the Editor:

title: Seagate to Buy Top Competitor
description: Seagate Technology agreed yesterday to buy the Maxtor Corporation for $1.9 billion in stock, removing its biggest competitor and bolstering its position as the No. 1 maker of computer disk drives.

title: Egyptian Opposition Leader, Echoing Iran, Calls Holocaust "Myth"
description: CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 22 - Two weeks after the Muslim Brotherhood won 88 seats in Parliament and established itself as Egypt's only significant political opposition organization, the group's leader issued a statement condemning America while declaring that the Holocaust was a "myth."

title: Schools Nationwide Study Impact of Evolution Ruling
description: When the school board in Muscatine, Iowa, sits down next year for its twice-a-decade evaluation of the district's science curriculum, the matter of whether to teach intelligent design as a challenge to evolution is expected to come up for discussion.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about questions surrounding Dr. Hwang Woo Suk's research on stem cells and cloning referred incorrectly to a proposed test of Snuppy, a dog that Dr. Hwang said he had produced by cloning. If Snuppy is a true clone, the test would show that his mitochondrial DNA differed from that of the dog that donated the nucleus, not from that of the donor of the egg. (Go to Article)

title: Kuwait moving to reopen oil business to outsiders
Paid Notice: Deaths   VIETOR, ANNA GLEN
description: VIETOR--Anna Glen. Died peacefully at home in NYC, surrounded by her children on December 20, 2005. Funeral service to be announced.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Inquiry Into Subsidies That Aided Berlusconi Company
description: European Union regulators threatened to outlaw more than 200 million euros ($240 million) in subsidies that helped a television broadcaster owned by Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy and the state-run RAI win digital TV viewers. The European Commission, the union's regulatory arm, said that government grants to help consumers buy or rent digital decoders in 2004 and 2005 may have given an unfair advantage to RAI and to Mediaset, owned by Mr. Berlusconi. Mediaset and RAI dominate Italy's television market. Both run three free-to-air channels, controlling about 90 percent of the market for TV advertising and viewers. "The subsidy seems to help free-to-air operators enter the pay-TV market," said Europe's competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes, above. Sky Italia, a pay-TV satellite broadcaster, had complained about being ineligible for the aid. The investigation, likely to last a year or more, could result in Italy being forced to recover the money from the two million consumers who benefited.

title: Celebrity Trumps Sexuality at a Civil English Ceremony
description: WINDSOR, England, Dec. 21 - If there were any demonstrators in the crowd, either pro- or anti-gay, they were being unusually quiet. No one was screaming religious slogans, carrying angry placards, wearing in-your-face outfits or loudly forecasting the end of civilization as we know it.

title: Long Shot Pays Off for Jets: Law Picked for Pro Bowl
description: The timing was easily as good as it had been on any of Jets cornerback Ty Law's six interceptions this season. He was named to his fifth Pro Bowl yesterday as the Jets were preparing for their game Monday night against the New England Patriots, the team that let Law go in February after 10 fruitful seasons.

description: In percent

title: Kuwait set to expand in China
Bill to Increase Russia's Control Over Charities Moves Ahead
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21 - Russia's lower house of Parliament on Wednesday amended legislation intended to increase the government's control over charities and other private organizations, but left in place core provisions that critics said would open the groups to political pressure or even force them to close.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Plainfield: Driving School Owner Pleads Guilty
description: Jose L. Flores, the owner of Mr. Pepe's Driving School, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to illegally create state driver's licenses for more than a decade, federal prosecutors announced. Mr. Flores, 45, of Watchung, admitted that he paid employees of the Division of Motor Vehicles across the state $20 to $100 to help manufacture each driver's license, prosecutors said. Mr. Flores said he paid the employees from 1993 to 2003 to produce licenses for illegal immigrants, complete written tests, test students without a road test appointment and exercise leniency in grading, according to prosecutors. He faces up to 15 years in federal prison when he is sentenced in March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUPHEIMER, JOHN D.
description: LAUPHEIMER--John D. Died peacefully after a long and courageous battle with cancer on Monday December 19, 2005 at age 75. The funeral service will be at the Saint Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, NJ, on January 4th at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to CancerBACUP at 3 Bath Place, Rivington Street, London EC2A 3JR.

title: Umenyiora and Strahan Have Pro Bowl Bond
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 21 - Osi Umenyiora's father called from Nigeria early in the morning, one of those phone calls without a concrete purpose but with plenty of meaning.

title: EU takes new legal steps against Microsoft
Some quiet victories for human rights
On The Street: Then
description: THEY say a woman's hair is her glory, but in the autumn of 1991 her modish "do" was often eclipsed by her hat. Bangs, spit curls, ringlets and Pre-Raphaelite waves all vied for attention with giddy toppers, some wreathed in leaves and feathers, others trimmed with wide bands of silk or patterned with an elephantine houndstooth design. A few mad little hats, reminiscent of those designed in the 1930's and 40's by Elsa Schiaparelli, even made a handy nesting place for stray bows or birds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASELLA, REV. THOMAS A., C.M.
description: CASELLA--Rev. Thomas A., C.M. religious superior of the Vincentian Community at Niagara University and Provincial Director of the Northeast Province of the Daughters of Charity, died December 20, 2005 in St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 60. Father Casella is survived by two sisters, Barbara T. Ferro of Murrieta, CA, and Elaine J. Cain of Phoenix, AZ, and several nieces and nephews. Calling hours will be Thursday, December 22, from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at the Vincentian Residence at St. John's University, 8000 Utopia Pkwy. Queens, N.Y. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Friday, December 23, at 10:30 A.M. at St. Thomas More Church at St. John's University. Burial will be in the Vincentian Cemetery at St. Joseph's Seminary in Princeton, NJ. A memorial service will be held at Niagara University at a date to be determined. For information Leo F. Kearns Funeral Homes. In lieu of flowers donations to the Congregation Of The Mission, Eastern Province USA would be greatly appreciated.

title: Briefly: Panel is formed to help war-affected countries
2 Who Died From Avian Flu in Vietnam Were Resistant to an Antiviral Drug
description: Two patients who died from avian influenza in Vietnam had developed resistance to the antiviral drug Tamiflu, scientists are reporting today.

title: 14th Street and Below
description: GABAY'S OUTLET -- a longtime favorite of fashion insiders on the Lower East Side -- has made a name for itself by offering overstock designer clothes and accessories (by the likes of Chanel, Manolo Blahnik and Prada) at hefty discounts. Today, when Gabay's Home, below, opens next door, shoppers may be pleased to find designer deals for the abode (including bedding, china and furniture) as well as the body. At 227 First Avenue, between 13th and 14th Streets, (212) 529-4036.

title: Miss America as She Used to Be
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 15 - When the Miss America Organization announced this year that its next pageant would be broadcast on Country Music Television -- a basic cable channel where, heretofore, the standard of poise and elegance was probably set by Daisy Duke strutting past the General Lee in popular reruns of "The Dukes of Hazzard" -- die-hard followers of the competition worried that an American icon was about to get chicken-fried.

title: A President, Not a King
description: To the Editor:

title: Dutch leave NATO hanging on Afghan force
Tamil Rebels Abduct 3 Sailors in Firefight with Sri Lankan Navy
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 22 - Suspected ethnic separatist rebels attacked two Sri Lankan Navy ships today, resulting in the abduction of three Sri Lankan sailors and pushing the battered island nation ever closer to the precipice of war.

title: Hong Kong Democrats Defeat Beijing-Backed Political Changes
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, Dec. 22 - Democracy advocates on Wednesday night defeated a government-backed legislative proposal to revamp the political system here, dealing a sharp setback to the chief executive and to Beijing, as well as to the prospects for any substantial political changes here soon.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Criminal Penalties For Political Action
description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko signed into law severe criminal penalties for political activities or statements. The United States and the European Union have warned that the legal changes "have the potential to severely undermine freedoms of assembly, association and expression in Belarus." Starting Jan. 1, it will be a crime punishable by up to three years in prison to organize antigovernment protests or to provide "patently false information" about Belarus.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, SIDNEY SOLWAY
description: MILLER--Sidney Solway. Of Baiting Hollow, NY. On December 19, 2005. Beloved husband of Marie. Predeceased by his adored first wife Hilda. Cherished father of son David and daughter-in-law Patti and daughter Roberta and son-in-law Doron. Devoted brother of Miriam. Adored grandfather of Hope and stepfather of Cathleen. A man of grace, compassion and humor. He will be missed by many. Services Thursday, 10am Beth Shalom Chapel, Smithtown, NY.

description: Correction Appended

title: Top Banker to Be Retried in Germany
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 21 - A German federal court ruled on Wednesday that the chief executive of Deutsche Bank, Josef Ackermann, would be tried again in a corporate criminal case, casting him back into legal limbo and stirring doubts that he will survive at the bank's helm.

title: China punishes general for talk of strike at U.S.
Rutgers Exits New Jersey for Bowl Game This Time
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 21 - The last time the Rutgers football team played in a bowl game -- the only time Rutgers played in a bowl game -- the trip was short and not so sweet.

title: From SoHo to Chelsea, With Remade Classics in Tow
description: The Frank Rogin Inc. gallery, a 10-year fixture on Mercer Street in SoHo, has moved to 24th Street in Chelsea. And it is introducing reproductions inspired by some of the best pieces that have passed through the shop, said Frank Rogin (left), who runs it with his mother, Anne Rogin.

title: For Some, a Little Loan Goes a Long Way
description: With Hurricane Ivan bearing down on Pensacola, Fla., last year, Kimberly and Ronnie Whitman moved the equipment and files of their landscaping business to a back room of their rented office. It was not enough.

title: Tokyo-Beijing ties endure more strain
Tech Brief: Bern limits Swisscom on foreign acquisitions
Talks With Iran on Nuclear Plans Resume; Little Progress Is Seen
description: BERLIN, Dec. 21 - Representatives of three European countries and Iran met Wednesday for the first time since negotiations over Iran's nuclear development program were suspended four months ago in bitterness. After five hours of closed-door meetings in Vienna, the delegates said the two sides had agreed to hold further talks in January.

title: Germany nominates Stark to ECB board
The New Trail to Work: Longer and More Inventive, Complicated and Crowded
description: On a normal day, Diana Rivas is too young, urban and hip to be caught riding something so square as the Long Island Rail Road. But yesterday, on the second day of the first New York City transit strike in a quarter-century, Ms. Rivas and tens of thousands of other New Yorkers grudgingly rode the suburban rails.

title: A 'Messiah' Without the Masses
description: The holiday spirit seems to have permeated this year's "Messiah" crop in New York. They have been drawing uncommonly warm reactions, and the second performance of Musica Sacra's annual "Messiah" on Tuesday night -- a tradition going back to 1973 -- nearly filled Carnegie Hall in spite of the transit strike.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Opposition Party Excluded
description: Barely two weeks after President Nursultan Nazarbayev followed an eyebrow-raising 91-percent re-election victory with promises of democratization, his government refused to register the main opposition party, Authentic Ak Zhol. Its four leaders accused him of aiming to destroy opposition to his 16-year rule, which has been marked by oil-fueled growth, corruption and nepotism. One of the four, Bulat Abilov, said he was charged this week with a felony involving a property transaction dating from 1999, before he went into politics.

title: Briefly: Parliament passes bill against terrorism
Counting on the Viagra brand in India
Along No. 7 Line, It Can Be Hard to Stand the Quiet
description: For nearly 90 years, life along Roosevelt Avenue has been pre-empted every few minutes by a sustained interruption of train clatter, as the elevated No. 7 train rumbles overhead. The 20-second interjection is loud enough to banish thought itself. It halts conversations and forces newcomers to hold their ears.

title: The Art of Civilized Conversation: A Guide to Expressing Yourself With Style and Grace
Streets Paved With Fares for Tireless Livery Driver
description: The big black Town Car was a money machine, and there was a pink air freshener hanging from the gearshift and another from the rear-view. The CB was broken and the wiper fluid light was on and so were some other warning lights and sometimes there was a beeping noise.

title: China tries to dilute chemical spill
Paid Notice: Deaths  TULCHIN, STANLEY''TED''
description: TULCHIN--Stanley"Ted". A man of vision and integrity. Theater producer. Founder of STA Intl; Maidstone Productions; and Continental Bank of Garden City. Brother to Norman and the late Gertrude Rosenfeld. Adored husband of Patsy. Devoted father of Jeffrey, Jill and Steven. Proud grandfather to Gregory, Jessica and Sara. Loved by all who knew him. He will be greatly missed. Memorial service Thursday (12/22) at 10:30 at Community Reform Temple in Westbury, NY. Donations may be made to New Dramatists.

title: Bus Strikes New York Firefighter, Seriously Injuring Him
description: An off-duty New York City firefighter was struck by a bus and seriously injured while riding his bicycle to work this morning, Fire Department officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Sentenced For Credit Card Fraud
description: A Garfield man, Gemal Sheika, 38, was sentenced yesterday to 78 months in federal prison for participating in a scheme that cost credit card companies more than $417,000, Christopher Christie, the United States attorney, announced. Prosecutors said that Mr. Sheika was part of a group that incurred credit card charges that were never paid. They said that he created a bogus company, Sheika Crystal, to collect money from the credit card companies, and that it had no assets other than a credit card swipe machine and checking account.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Convert to Digital TV
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 - The Senate approved legislation on Wednesday that would complete the transition from analog to digital television by 2009 and create a federal program to help millions of households pay for equipment so that their analog television sets could continue to work.

title: Turnout in the Iraqi Election Is Reported at 70 Percent
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 21 - Seventy percent of registered Iraqi voters went to the polls during last week's election, the highest participation in a vote since the fall of Saddam Hussein, according to preliminary turnout figures released by the Iraqi electoral commission on Wednesday.

title: In Czech Victory, Kostelic Proves She Is Bulletproof
description: SPINDLERUV MLYN, Czech Republic, Dec. 21 - Not much bothers ski racers more than snowstorms. They need a smooth and rock-hard surface, which they affectionately call bulletproof, to carve their way down a course. Fresh snow is almost always an unwelcome hassle.

title: FedEx Profit Up 33% in Quarter
description: The FedEx Corporation said yesterday that fiscal second-quarter profit climbed 33 percent as deliveries rose around the world and it raised surcharges to cover higher fuel prices.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the education of professional dancers misstated the number of schools in the Ivy League that offer dance majors. In addition to Barnard, which is part of Columbia University, Cornell offers one.

title: A Razr for Many Razrless
description: Until recently, Verizon Wireless subscribers could not partake in Motorola Razr mania. Earlier versions of the superslim cellphone, now available in black, blue and magenta, were built with G.S.M. cellular technology, which worked only with Cingular and T-Mobile service.

title: Labels Reveal, and Labels Conceal
description: IN some ways, all cosmetics labels are alike. The Food and Drug Administration requires every jar of skin cream, every bottle of shampoo and every tube of lipstick to reveal certain facts: the product name and how much of it the package contains; the company that makes, packs or distributes the product; and an accurate list of ingredients in descending order from the greatest amount to the least.

description: BRONSON--Fay. Tireless fundraiser for Camp Sussex for over 50 years, she will be missed by all.

description: In 1966, Michael J. Quill ended the 12-day transit strike by thrusting four fingers through the oxygen tent of his Bellevue Hospital room.

title: I.B.M. to Buy Micromuse for $865 Million
description: I.B.M. announced yesterday that it would pay $865 million for Micromuse Inc., whose software is used to manage Internet-based computing networks that handle voice, video and data.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: Soccer Star Drops Election Dispute
description: The soccer star George Weah dropped his claim that he had won Liberia's presidential election, ending a dispute that threatened the long-awaited transition from civil war to democracy. He told reporters in Monrovia, the capital, that he would not appeal a rejection by the National Election Commission of his claims of fraud. Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf won nearly 60 percent of runoff votes in November. She is scheduled to be inaugurated Jan. 16. LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

description: ALBANY, Dec. 21 - Spurred by the recent shooting deaths of two New York City police officers and showing an unusual spirit of compromise, state lawmakers approved legislation on Wednesday to stiffen penalties for illegal guns and mandate a life sentence for anyone convicted of murdering a police officer.

title: Police Infiltrate Protests, Videotapes Show
description: Undercover New York City police officers have conducted covert surveillance in the last 16 months of people protesting the Iraq war, bicycle riders taking part in mass rallies and even mourners at a street vigil for a cyclist killed in an accident, a series of videotapes show.

title: Police Infiltrate Protests, Videotapes Show
description: Undercover New York City police officers have conducted covert surveillance in the last 16 months of people protesting the Iraq war, bicycle riders taking part in mass rallies and even mourners at a street vigil for a cyclist killed in an accident, a series of videotapes show.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Business Day on Monday with an article about Maine's effort to provide high-speed Internet service to rural areas incorrectly located the town of New Vineyard. It is in southwest Maine, near Farmington, another town on the map, not in northwest Maine. A corrected map can be found online at www.nytimes.com/2005/12/19/technology/19maine.html.

title: Sleek Radiators
description: Q. Is there a way to replace my bulky radiators with something slimmer -- maybe even invisible?

title: Arts, Briefly; Mining Oscar Gold
description: If you are of a mind to attend the 2006 Oscars but are neither a member of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences nor likely to be nominated for an award, you may be in for a bit of sticker shock -- and breaking the law besides. According to a civil case that is winding down in Los Angeles Superior Court, a pair of good seats for the Oscars, which have a face value of $700, went for as much as $40,000 this year and could cost up to $60,000 for next year's event, which takes place on March 5. In the case, which pitted the academy against various ticket brokers who allegedly sold or tried to sell tickets to the Oscars, an investigator for the academy who solicited tickets was told by a broker he should consider: "a pair of Oscar tickets ($30K) total. For a little more, they could turn this into a once-in-a-lifetime experience that they will both cherish forever. Also, please note that the price will increase significantly next year, probably to $30K per person." The academy has reached a negotiated settlement with most of the defendants and will be sending out a letter, as it does every year, reminding them and others that Oscar tickets may be used only by the lucky few who actually are eligible to receive them. DAVID CARR

title: Blowing the Whistle on Gangsta Culture
description: BOSTON - Edwin "E. J." Duncan was a young man from a decent family who spent a great deal of time with his friends in an amateur recording studio his parents had set up for him in the basement of their home in the Dorchester neighborhood.

title: Smart Enough to Understand Your Moisturizer?
description: MEMO to Homeland Security Department: Mata Hari has nothing on Este Lauder. Around the globe under cover of darkness company agents are at work in unsuspecting households, neutralizing up to 90 percent of the free radicals they find: "berserk" radicals, which in the words of Daniel Maes, a nuclear chemist and vice president for global research and development at Este Lauder, are unstable and can create a lot of damage. But Este Lauder does not fight alone. Fellow beauty companies have joined in the struggle, including L'Oral, Origins, Clinique, Olay, Prescriptives, Kiehl's, Lancme and Neutrogena.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,153 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Afghans Pick Rival of Karzai as Chairman of Parliament
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 21 - President Hamid Karzai's chief political rival, Yunus Qanooni, was elected Wednesday as chairman of the lower house of Afghanistan's new Parliament in a close race that split the lower house down the middle and revealed an ethnic divide that might plague future debates.

title: Dutch Indecision on Troops Hinders NATO's Afghan Mission
description: BERLIN, Dec. 22 - One of NATO's most ambitious missions was hanging in the balance today after the Dutch government said it would send up to 1,400 more troops to Afghanistan but then left the final decision to its Parliament, which is deeply divided on the issue.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: $440 Million From Wall St. as Restitution
description: The checks -- as many as 20,000 of them -- will soon be in the mail.

title: Tolls Start to Mount: Financial, Medical, Emotional
description: For a day, maybe, it felt like a communal challenge, a dare to New Yorkers to demonstrate their pluck and ingenuity. But by yesterday, the reality of a transit strike had wiped away any sense that this was an adventure. It was an annoyance, a hardship, a source of suffering.

title: Don't Use the 'L' Word to Describe These Devices
description: LaCie, a manufacturer of computer hard drives, is trying to think outside the silver-and-black box. Its new Brick line tries to improve on the typical rectangular storage device with brightly colored desktop and mobile hard drives.

title: Sleek Attack: Take Your Tea With Just a Touch Of Precious Metal
description: An austerely elegant tea set by the Italian designer Paola Navone is made of white biscuit porcelain with a hand-painted glaze. The pieces look as if they had been partially dipped in liquid platinum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DANAHER, GERALDINE M. (NEE GRAMES)
description: DANAHER -- Geraldine M. (nee Grames) of Lindenhurst on December 19, 2005. Born in Brooklyn, April 5, 1920 to Evelyn and Clarence Grames. Devoted wife of the late John. Beloved mother of Joanne Shea (Jim), Aileen O'Brien (Bob), Patrick (Leslie), John (Mary Lee), Peter (Mayra), Pamela, Gerald (Beth), and Joseph (Meg). Cherished grandmother of eighteen. Reposing at the Lindenhurst Funeral Home Inc., 424 South Wellwood Ave, Lindenhurst. Visiting hours Thursday, December 22 from 2-5pm & 7-9pm. Religious services Thursday evening. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Perpetual Help RC Church, Lindenhurst, Friday December 23, at 11AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Capuchian Friars, Province of St. Mary; The Right to Life Foundation; or OLPH Education Fund.

title: When Big Brother Is You
description: Let's play "You're the President." Let's put you in the Oval Office and see what kind of decisions you make in real-world circumstances.

description: To the Editor:

title: White House Door Opens for Some Black Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 - Relations between President Bush and the N.A.A.C.P. have been rough from the moment Mr. Bush came to Washington. The civil rights organization was among his toughest critics, and Mr. Bush was the first president in 80 years to go a full term without once attending its annual convention.

title: Taser Files Delayed Results
description: Shares of Taser International, which makes stun guns, rose 11 percent yesterday after the company filed its delayed third-quarter report.

title: Rescuing European unity
Day 2 of the Strike: Brrr and Grrr

title: Monetary Losses Starting to Be Felt by Workers
description: Early on Dec. 12, two days after bus and subway workers voted to authorize a strike, Muriel Scott borrowed $2,500 from her 401(k) plan and set it aside in a savings account. With her husband sick at home, a mortgage to pay, Christmas gifts to buy and two teenage daughters to raise, Mrs. Scott, a bus driver, felt she needed some cushion in case transit employees staged a walkout.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sanyo to Sell Shares to Goldman and Daiwa
description: The Sanyo Electric Company, which is expecting a second year of record losses, will sell 300 billion yen ($2.6 billion) worth of new shares by the end of February to help pay for job cuts, capital spending, and research and development. The Goldman Sachs Group and Daiwa Securities SMBC will each buy 125 billion yen of preferred stock, which does not have voting rights, according to a statement from Sanyo, based in Osaka. The Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group will buy 50 billion yen of shares.

title: The Yankees' Hair Apparent in Center Field
description: JOHNNY DAMON could average 175 hits and more than 100 runs scored for the next four years in the Bronx, but in his establishment pinstriped baseball suit, he may never be the character or even the commodity he was as the hirsute antihero of Fenway Park.

title: Top Afghan Lawmaker Quits Opposition to Back Karzai
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 22 - The new chairman of Afghanistan's Parliament, Yunus Qanooni, said today that he would resign as leader of the opposition and support the government of Afghanistan in the interests of the people.

title: Notebooks Come in at Under a ThousandWith Speed and Style
description: The first notebook computers to dip below $1,000 were slow, not very stylish and not widely embraced by consumers. That was more than five years ago, which in the digital era is a lifetime.

title: OPEC talks open with China
Correction
description: The credits for pictures by Albert Vecerka accompanying an article last Thursday about the renovation of a house in Belmont, Mass., omitted the name of his agency. It is Esto.

title: In Afghanistan, Rumsfeld rejects a quick pullout
Breaking the cycle
National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Small Bombs Explode At Mosque
description: Two pipe bombs exploded Tuesday night outside a mosque complex in Cincinnati, damaging two buildings. No one was inside the adjoining buildings at the Islamic Association of Cincinnati when the explosions took place on the front porches about 10:15. Michael Brooks, a spokesman for the F.B.I., which is investigating the incident, would not speculate on a possible motive. Karen Dabdoub, director of the Cincinnati office of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, a Muslim civil liberties group, said that the mosque had not received any threats and that the explosion was the first such act at a Cincinnati mosque. The mosque was open on Wednesday.

title: Shooting Movies With Zoom
description: If you haven't been shooting movies with your still camera, you're missing a great thing. The quality and smoothness nearly rival camcorders--it's just that until recently, you couldn't change zoom or focus once you'd started filming.

title: Daimler Settles U.S. Charges
description: The DaimlerChrysler Corporation agreed to spend $90 million to fix defective emission controls on 1.5 million vehicles and pay a $1 million penalty to settle charges that it failed to report the problem to regulators, the Justice Department said yesterday.

title: Kate Spade Finds a New Object For Her Minimalist Attentions
description: Kate Spade will introduce a line of Crane's stationery next week with colorful patterns that include brightly colored stripes and florals. The stationery can be ordered engraved or with letterpress type. "Great letter writing is an art I really admire, especially with so many people sending e-mails and tapping away into their BlackBerries," Ms. Spade said. A set of 100 personalized notecards and envelopes, as shown, will be $500 to $750, and a set of 100 wedding invitations, $1,500. For store locations: katespade.com or (866) 999-5283. CURRENTS: STATIONERY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGORON, MALCOLM W., SR.
description: ENGORON--Malcolm W., Sr. Passed away peacefully December 21st, 2005 on his 89th birthday. Beloved husband of Edna. Dear father of Malcolm (Elan), Arthur (Dawn), Frank (Ida), Daniel (Debbi) and Gerald (Diane). Loving grandfather of Stacey, Ian, Eric and Jack. Graveside services Friday, 11 AM, at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Arts, Briefly; Back to Folsom for Johnny Cash
description: Thirty-eight years after Johnny Cash sang for a hall filled with hard-core convicts at Folsom Prison in Represa, Calif., the prison has invited Twentieth Century Fox to screen "Walk the Line," its film about Cash, there in January. The 1968 concert, depicted in the film, became a best-selling album and was a touchstone for Cash, who said frequently that he felt a connection to the prisoners. "The lesson of Johnny Cash is that it's never too late for a man to turn his life around, and that's a story these men need to hear," said Joe Avila, California executive director of the Prison Fellowship Ministries, an organization founded in 1976 by Chuck Colson, the born-again Watergate figure. The star of the film, Joaquin Phoenix, above left, is to attend the screening, on Jan. 3. SHARON WAXMAN

title: News Analysis: How rapid should the march of science be?
Obituaries
Dialogue to resume with Iran on uranium
Want to Start a Hedge Fund? First, Read This Book
description: Ah, the grand life of the hedge fund manager: the annual paychecks in the tens, if not the hundreds, of millions; the mansions in Greenwich; and the ski vacations in Aspen.

title: Israel Threatens to Hinder Palestinian Vote
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 21 - Israel said Wednesday that if the militant faction Hamas took part in next month's elections for the Palestinian parliament, Palestinians would not be allowed to cast ballots in East Jerusalem. The Palestinian leadership responded by saying that it might postpone the voting, which is scheduled for Jan. 25.

title: A retrial is ordered for German bank chief
Blair arrives in Basra on surprise visit
Wish You Were Here, Customers: After 39 Years in Business, a SoHo Shop to Close
description: Although sales of status stationery appear to be healthy, the market for inexpensive postcards seems to be drying up. Untitled, an atmospheric postcard and art book shop in SoHo, will close next month after 39 years.

title: Tonight's Supplemental Percussionist: Master of Tap
description: Savion Glover's most prominent New York appearances this year have found him earnestly trying to vary his routine -- and, maybe, to win tap-dancing some highfalutin respect. First there was his "Classical Savion" program in January at the Joyce Theater, absolutely brilliant at its best (the opening Vivaldi). Then came his appearance at American Ballet Theater's gala at the Metropolitan Opera House in May. For that one, he wittily even sort of went on toe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TULCHIN, STANLEY ''TED''
description: TULCHIN -- Stanley "Ted". WLIW21 New York Public Television mourns the passing of our Board Member, generous supporter and friend, Stanley "Ted" Tulchin. As an award-winning producer for Broadway and the London stage, he lived public television's mission to preserve and promote the performing arts, and as an entrepreneur and founder of STA International and other companies, he personified our commitment to the community. Our condolences to Patsy and the Tulchin family. Terrel L. Cass, President & General Manager Barry Shapiro, Chairman Board of Trustees, LIETV Council, Inc.

title: Oil rivals join forces for energy acquisition
City Noise Code Gets Stricter; Fancy Meters Will Aid Ears
description: New York City's nightclubs and bars will face tougher restrictions on how loudly they can play their music under the city's new noise code, which will also equip many police officers with noise meters for the first time.

title: Treating Guests to a Cloud of Comfort
description: THREE years ago we moved smack into the middle of what passes for a downtown in Northern California on the theory that it was preferable to have the teenagers set up headquarters at our house, where we could spy on them easily, rather than slink over to someone else's.

title: Metro Briefings
description: NEW YORK

title: Fashion Is Two Clicks Behind
description: IN 1920 the French dressmaker Gabrielle Chanel put a number on a bottle of perfume. The idea would have appealed to her for several reasons, not least that numbers celebrated logic and in some ways the defeat of romanticism following World War I. Numbers also represented the success of new forms of expression, namely Cubism, with its reduction of objects to basic geometric forms, an idea that Chanel pursued in fashion. Whatever the reason, the public sensed it was getting something new and different. Chanel No. 5 has remained one of the world's top-selling perfumes.

title: A President, Not a King
description: To the Editor:

title: Race Bubbles to the Surface in Standoff
description: The standoff between the Transport Workers Union and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, tense and perilous, was already taking a harsh physical and economic toll on New Yorkers.

title: Texas District Adopts Disputed Text on Bible Study
description: Correction Appended

title: Op-Art; Alternate Transit
description: Facing the first citywide transit strike in a quarter-century, millions of New Yorkers have responded with their customary ingenuity to the challenge of getting successfully from point A to point B, and back again.

title: A U-turn on reforms could starve North Korea
Lee Miller: A Life
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Shot Dead On Harlem Street
description: A Harlem man was fatally shot outside an apartment building last evening after a dispute with a man who then fled, the police said. They said that the victim, Walter Everhardt, 24, was shot several times in the head and body in front of 158 West 131st Street about 7:20 p.m. Investigators said he ran down the street and collapsed as he was trying to enter a grocery story on the corner of West 131st Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard. "He hits the door, falls backwards and he's dead," said an investigator on the scene. Mr. Everhardt did not live at 158 West 131st Street, but had relatives there, said Katrice Davis, 18, a niece who lives in the building. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

title: Don Caswell, Times Copy Editor, Is Dead at 65
description: Don Caswell, a veteran copy editor in the culture, style and foreign news departments of The New York Times, died on Tuesday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 65.

title: Reinventing Collage
description: Robert Rauschenberg's over-the-top contraptions, as seen at the Metropolitan Museum, still manage to seem incredibly fresh and almost otherworldly.

title: Munich Bombed Anew
description: Munich has become this years cinematic piata, with various Oscar watchers and political hands beating on it with sticks in hopes that it will finally burst apart at the seams. One of the more vivid slams on its prospects  he sets some kind of record for use of boxing metaphors in a single item  comes from Jeffrey Wells at Hollywood Elsewhere. Its funny, and effective, but once you jump down the hobbit hole of Oscar prognostications as the Carpetbagger has, you find out that there is no end to the deconstruction and analysis. He will be in need of serious deprogramming by the time the actual awards roll around in March, including spending a month with dial-up access only and some really good books from the Western canon to regain parts of his I.Q. Lets skip the Pride & Prejudice (or any other Jane Austen) just to speed the process. (For those who are interested, Wells suggests in our comments section that the Carpetbagger has tagged him as a terrorist. Thats just plain silly. I was thinking more linguistic Unabomber.)

title: Critical Heat
description: If you are looking for deep analysis, and we mean deep, of the movies who have received the most lavish, sloppy kisses from the critics, stop on over to the Critics Top Ten List. Brokeback is the obvious pet pony, but there are surprises down the list, including the appearance of Grizzly Man, Werner Herzogs portrait of obsession tht the Carpetbagger cant stop watching. His wife and daughter think Timothy Treadwell is an absolute freak and that the Carpetbagger needs to let go of his inner-bear, but we cant stop looking. Whatever happened to those cute little foxes, anyway. And History of Violence continues to creep up the list. As the supposed prohibitive favorites pick up ack-ack of one kind or another, David Cronenbergs look at the downside of redemption starts to look pretty damn smart. And Mario Bellos turn as a wife who comes to know her husband by turns is a remarkable and meaty performance in a year when even the A-list had to settle for some less-than-nutritious roles.

title: Not-So-Plain Vanilla
description: Over at MSNBC.com, John Hartl makes the argument that Jeff Daniels, long written off as a second-rate scoop of vanilla, actually deserves the serious props hes getting for his role as the diffident self-involved dad in The Squid and the Whale. Between his performances in The Hours and Pleasantville, Hartl argues that Daniels has put together a decent career. Of course, fans of Mr. Daniels, whose characters generally make a virtue of opaqueness, will have to forgive and forget Love Hurts and Chasing Sleep, which should be a simple matter because most of us missed them with a quickness.

title: The Bagels Must Go On
description: LA Observed strikes a tone of elegy in the departure of long-time Los Angeles Times critic Kevin Thomas. As it turns out, Thomas, who took a recent buy-out offer, did not attend his modest farewell because of ill health. The bagels were served anyway.

title: Can You Picture That?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Great, Grand Oscar DVD That Never Was
description: Use your best Andy Rooney voice here: Did you ever wonder why there is no DVD of the Oscars? An industry that is increasingly built on those shiny little discs does not produce one celebrating the glitziest events on the planet? Turns out that a myriad of releases and one-time-use approvals are necessary to produce the live show, and it would be a nightmare if they had to include provisions for the production of a DVD memorializing the event. As it turns out, the Academy produced a VHS a few years ago called Oscars Greatest Moments and had to go through the clowns mouth and over the windmill to clear rights and the whole thing ended up being such a pain in Oscars shiny rear that they decided it wasnt worth it. So if you want to relive those golden moments this year, set the DVR on stun and make sure that you only enjoy the recording in the privacy of your own domicile.

title: Theyre All Gone.
description: Jim McKay, who gets screen time in Munich by way of televisions people gather around to figure out exactly what is going on, sits for an interview with the Associated Press. He hasnt seen Steven Spielbergs movie yet  McKays memorable theyre all gone line still packs an emotional punch in the film  but remembers what happened when he got back to the office after broadcasting for 16 hours straight: McKay walked into the ABC Olympic offices and saw a yellow slip of paper poking out of his mailbox. It read, You did honor to your country, your network and yourself yesterday and it was signed Walter Cronkite.

title: Were Not Worthy. Or Interested?
description: As we have gotten started, the Carpetbagger has zoomed in and out of the comments section, hoping to find a throbbing tribe of Oscar fetishishs. There are a few hardy souls, and one windy one in particular, but for the most part, its a little quiet in here. Perhaps its because the Carpetbagger has dubbed some of the contributors Rugrats. Maybe I need to think of another honorific, something that clearly communicates the heft and interests of our contributors, something like  Baggies. Send thoughts about that if you have them. So anyway, Zimmergirl, a sassy contributor, who admits that she didnt read the Carpetbaggers prolix missive from yesterday about scalpers and the Oscars, sounded as if she wouldnt go if she were paid. She has a friend  dont we all? who went to the Oscars and it did not go well: She had to sit up in the nosebleeds (there really arent nosebleeds at the Kodak) and her only comment from the entire night (it was a disappointing Oscar ceremony where the worst possible film won, nothing new there) was that Julia Roberts has a weird nose. So there you go. Watching them on TV is the only way to go. Besides, we really should know our place among gods and goddesses. We dont REALLY DESERVE to be among them. The Carpetbagger bows to the brilliance and straightforwardness of Zimmergirls analytics.

title: Oscar Isnt Gay, But He Is Liberal
description: A story in Reuters suggests that the smoke is beginning to clear in the Best Picture race and what it seems to reveal is two cowboys riding through the high lonesome and finding solace and companionship in the tent.  Brokeback, the first gay romance to make a bid for mainstream respectability, has already won the top awards handed out by critics in New York and Los Angeles and copped seven nominations for the January 16 Golden Globes, often a key indicator as to which way the Oscar wind might be blowing, the story says. There is a reminder down low in the story that Munich must not be counted out and of course, the caveat remains that many early leaders in past Oscar races came up lame before the finish line. Like many, the Carpetbagger is exceedingly fond of Brokeback Mountain  he held hands with a friend during some of the more rugged parts, but that was just in the spirit of male bonding  but wonders whether the demographics of the Academy, which skew toward the ancient, will accommodate a full-on, smack-on-the-lips cowboy love story. Any thoughts?

title: Team Oscar
description: The Carpetbagger will remain ensconced in the New Jersey headquarters  is there anything that brings to mind the glitz of the Oscars more readily than the Garden State?  because all is transportational chaos on the island of Manhattan. But a thought occurred to him  actually it came to him from a brilliant Oscar autodidact who would throttle the Carpetbagger if he revealed his name. To wit, after more or less co-writing  he wrote the good parts  the Carpetbaggers take on how hard and ultimately futile it is to get into the Oscars, he said, If the security at the 72 Olympics had been as good as security at the Oscars, there would be no Munich to nominate. Wish Id thought of that. Lets pretend I did.

title: A Look at the Exhibits
description: "Artists' Books, Revisited" at Printed Matter, Brian Jungen at the New Museum, Asuka Ohsawa at Freight + Volume and more.

title: Part I: N.Y.C. Police Surveillance
description: Videotapes show that police officers have conducted covert surveillance of people at seven public gatherings since August. The Times' Jim Dwyer reports.

title: Cellphones for Kids
description: If you're going to issue your child a cellphone, it had better be ultra-simple, ultra-limited, ultra-rugged and ultra-parent-controlled

title: Openings: PIXAR at the MoMA
description: Roberta Smith of The Times previews the Pixar exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Potato Nik
description: Mark Bittman preps for Hanukkah by creating a potato nik, a perfect alternative to the labor-intensive latke.

title: Puberty and Education in Africa
description:
A lack of girls-only latrines, water and sanitary napkins in schools throughout sub-Saharan Africa causes one in 10 school-age African girls to either
skip school during puberty or drop out entirely.

title: The Athlete's Edge
description: Recruiting for athletes has become competitive even among smaller colleges like Haverford. Articles in this series are periodically examining how Haverford coaches decide whom to support in the admissions process, how the athletics and admissions offices interact, and how potential recruits view the system.

title: Have Our Civil Liberties Put Us in Danger?
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Dec. 22 column, When Big Brother Is You:

title: More Passengers for Darfur
description: Another typical day in Darfur: a Janjaweed attack on Abu Sarouj village in the state of West Darfur, killing 20 people and wounding 16. The attackers also burnt 50 shelters, temporarily displacing several thousand people, said Andy Pendleton, of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Fifteen men, three women and two children were killed. Two of the victims were burnt alive when their homes were torched.

title: Day Three of the Strike Begins
Someones Listening
description: Im a little less offended by the wiretaps without warrants than many people. Basically, Im happy to see those conversations tapped, and tapped immediately. So the problem doesnt seem to have been wiretaps that were illegitimate in the first place, but wiretaps that shortcut the legal process and may have been illegal. But the legality seems murky, and I find end runs around the FISA process offensive  but much less so than keeping Jose Padilla out of the judicial process or than defending torture.

title: Sorry, Temple Money-Changers
description: Plenty of emails on the Bill OReilly column. First, Deborah writes that Ive wronged the money-changers in the temple: Contrary to popular misconception, they were not there by mistake  as if they were defiling a sacred place  the Israelites were supposed to bring one of the tithes to the Temple but if Jerusalem were to far to travel with the actual animals and grain, they could convert the tithe to money and carry the money to Jerusalem. Once they were there, however, they had to convert part of the money back to animals so that they could be sacrificed, because the tithe had to be animals and first fruits, not money. So the money changers were actually a legitimate service of the Temple, helping people fulfill their religious duties  not whatever debased slur has entered into popular, ignorant misunderstanding. Sounds plausible, and if so, my apologies to the Association of Temple Money Changers.

title: Low or No-Cost Real Estate Data
description: When it comes to reporting trends in real estate, the information is usually presented at the national, city or metropolitan-area level. If a buyer or researcher needs information at a more narrow level, say a ZIP code, or to compare areas across the country, there are few places to get it without paying a bundle. One of the best sites around offering some regional and ZIP-code level data is DQNews.com, which is run by a public records company based in California. Although most of their information is focused on California, they offer tons of data from other areas of the country. Want to find out which ZIP code in Las Vegas saw the largest increase in single-family residences and condos last quarter? Click on a regional chart and the information is at your fingertips. Click on another area and you can compare how ZIP codes there compare to Las Vegas or other places.  RON NIXON

title: War On Christmas
description: Another battleground has opened in the War on Christmas, and OReilly missed this one. Heres the opening of Andy Borowitzs article at www.borowitzreport.com:

title: Investors Like Real Estate Stocks
description: There may be plenty of concerns about a slowdown in the real estate market, but stock market investors dont seem to mind. Real estate continues to be a top choice for investors despite a slowdown in the market during the latter part of the year, according to a new survey from Better Investings Voice of the American Shareholder.

title: New York's Revolutionary War Sites: Just Squint, and It's 1776
description: AT the crest of a hill in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn one day in early December, a gust of wind makes the just-below-freezing temperatures seem just above tolerable. A voice - three parts honey, two parts gravitas with a grain or two of gravel thrown in - rises to be heard above the wind. It is the voice of God, only friendlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWELLS, WILLIAM WHITE
description: HOWELLS--William White. On December 20 at home in Kittery Point, ME. Predeceased in 2002 by his wife of 73 years, Muriel Gurdon Seabury, survived by a daughter, Gurdon Metz of New York City, a son, William Dean Howells of Kittery Point, ME, four grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. A Memorial service will be held at First Congregational Church, 23 Pepperell Road in Kittery Point, ME on December 29 at 11:00AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Strabery Banke Museum, Box 300, Portsmouth, NH 03802-0300, or The Hooton Fund, C/O Harvard Development Office, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA. 02138.

description: EUROPE

title: Where Timber Was King, the Golf Club Replaces the Ax
description: WHEN you own a home in the sixth-fastest-growing region in the country, you worry about letting the cat out at night because of the coyotes howling in the forest. You scribe fresh powder turns down 9,000-foot-high bowls and muscle bicycles through high-desert hills. At some point, perhaps on a fairway between Holes 4 and 5, you wonder whether those lonely volcanoes lingering on the skyline will ever blow. The thing you rarely do is call your town rural.
