title: The President And the Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review; Rob Fischer
description: Whitney Museum of American Art at Altria 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street Through Jan. 22

title: Giants, Vulnerable to the Run, Must Now Face Portis
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 22 - The Giants have been brimming with excitement this week. They are one victory away from winning the National Football Conference East title, and five Giants were named to the Pro Bowl team Wednesday. But concerns linger as the regular season draws to a close. Eli Manning's accuracy remains shaky, and the number of injuries has become alarming.

title: New Effort by M.L.B. for Cuba to Take Part
description: Major League Baseball renewed its effort yesterday to have Cuba participate in the inaugural World Baseball Classic in three months by resubmitting an application for a license with the United States Treasury Department. Last week, the Treasury Department denied the Cubans permission to play because they would have received revenue in violation of the Cuban embargo.

title: Talks to Buy Sensor Maker
description: Bain Capital, the private equity firm, is near a deal to acquire the sensors and controls unit of Texas Instruments for more than $2.4 billion, executives involved in the deal said last night.

title: Swede Skier Gives Herself an Early Christmas Present
description: SPINDLERUV MLYN, Czech Republic, Dec. 22 - Anja Paerson of Sweden won a World Cup slalom on Thursday after standing in the start hut atop the mountain and telling her rivals how happy she was that the circuit was giving them a four-day break for the holidays.

title: Rising Through the Ranks, Again
description: WHITE PLAINS - FIRST impressions count, particularly for the type of fellow who believes shipshape is more than just a colloquialism and for whom spit and polish is a fact of life: just check out his black wingtips. So John R. Ryan, the former three-star Navy admiral who was named chancellor of the 64-campus State University of New York system on Monday, after surviving a 64-candidate search, is mildly worried about making a bad one. Impression, that is.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Surcharge On Air Tickets To Aid Poor Countries
description: Parliament has approved a tax on airline tickets to be levied beginning in July with proceeds to help developing countries. The tax, which was opposed by the airlines, will add up to 40 euros, about $47, to the price of tickets for flights leaving French airports. Algeria, Brazil, Britain, Chile and Norway have all publicly endorsed the idea and say they may follow suit. JOHN TAGLIABUE (NYT)

title: Mr. Cheney's Imperial Presidency
description: George W. Bush has quipped several times during his political career that it would be so much easier to govern in a dictatorship. Apparently he never told his vice president that this was a joke.

title: When Virginia Was Eden, and Other Tales of History
description: Toward the end of Terrence Malick's elegiac film, "The New World," the young Indian princess known as Pocahontas -- the "delight and darling" of her father, the king of the Powhatans of coastal Virginia -- pauses in front of a gilt cage containing a live skunk. Brought from the New World to the Old in 1616, this morose creature, curled as tight as a fist, is being presented to the English court alongside a bald eagle, an Indian priest and Pocahontas herself. The princess, dressed in Jacobean costume, a ruff collar fluting around her throat, and played by the sublimely lovely newcomer Q'orianka Kilcher, looks both at ease and entirely foreign. When she sees this pitiful captive, does she see any part of herself?

title: Approval Process of Generic Drugs Still Not Set
description: Amgen's patents on Epogen and Aranesp are not the only barriers to competing drugs in this country. The federal government still needs to figure out how to approve generic versions of biotechnology medicines.

title: The Listings: Dec. 23 - Dec. 29; FELIX SCHRAMM: 'COMBER'
description: Destruction and creation have long gone hand in hand in modern art, sometimes indistinguishably, as in Jean Tinguely's self-destroying machine from 1960 called "Homage to New York." A recent entrant to the destruction-creation field is Felix Schramm, a young German sculptor whose large environmental sculptures made of lumber, drywall, paint and other Home Depot-type materials give the impression that part of a house has undergone some violent calamity. For his first New York solo exhibition, Mr. Schramm has produced a room-filling, tilting and disheveled configuration of walls and corners (above). It looks as though parts of an existing house had been ripped off, mixed up and slammed into the gallery by a passing tornado or -- as the title, "Comber," suggests -- by an ocean wave. The effect is viscerally physical and art-historically resonant. Cubism, Kurt Schwitters's "Merzbau," Gordon Matta-Clark's architectural deconstructions and the junk sculptures of John Chamberlain and Nancy Rubins all come to mind. There is no obvious narrative or symbolic intention, but because Mr. Schramm uses the forms and materials of vernacular residential construction, his installation can't help but call to mind real-world anxieties about threats to our safety -- political, meteorological, seismic and otherwise. The home is no longer a protective haven from the unpredictable flux of modernity and neither is the art gallery. It is impressive that Mr. Schramm achieves all this not by acts of real destruction or deconstruction but by carefully calibrated design and assembly. (Grimm/Rosenfeld, 530 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-2388, through Jan. 28.)

title: Surveillance, New York Style
description: It's a sad day when a police force generally known for its professionalism is caught using underhanded tactics to spy on and even distort political protests and mass rallies. Yet that is precisely what an archive of videotapes shows New York City police officers or people working with them doing at seven public gatherings since August 2004. The sorry tale was laid out by Jim Dwyer in yesterday's Times in an article based on civilian and police videotapes gathered by a forensic analyst critical of the tactics.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KESSLER, MARY FENKANIN
description: KESSLER--Mary Fenkanin. 12/3/12--12/23/01. Beloved wife and mother. Rest in peace, Mom. Harvey

title: Underground still facingNew Year's Eve strike
World Briefing | Asia: India: U.S. Approves Generic Aids Drug For Children
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved for the first time a generic AIDS drug made for children. The approval, of a liquid pediatric formulation of stavudine by an Indian company, Aurobindo Pharma, does not allow it to be sold in the United States, but allows it to be purchased for poor countries in Africa and Asia under the $15 billion President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief. DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDSMAN, EDA
description: LANDSMAN--Eda, 84, of East Elmhurst, NY. Beloved wife of Sol for 65 years, devoted mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Nani-you will be forever in our hearts. Donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1775 Broadway, Ste 300, NY, NY 10019

title: His Career Is Over, but Chrebet Still Needs Football in His Life
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 22 - Once or twice a week, Jets wideout Wayne Chrebet visits the New Jersey barn where his standardbreds are stabled. "It's almost like therapy for me," Chrebet said. "It's real calming."

title: LIVING HERE | Great Fireplaces; The Winter Must-Have
description: WHO -- Michael Sullivan, 50, a land developer in Annapolis, Md. WHAT -- 11-bedroom main house with several outbuildings WHERE -- Mount Victoria, Md.

title: Idiot Is Not the Only Role Damon Knows How to Play
description: Somewhere deep inside Johnny Damon, hidden under all those layers of famous scruff, was a Yankee just waiting to get out.

title: British Agent Tells (a Bit) of Years Undercover in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 21 - For decades, Denis Donaldson was a prominent insider in the Irish Republican movement in Belfast. He served in prison with Gerry Adams, leader of its political arm, Sinn Fein, and Bobby Sands, the hunger striker, who died in 1981. He trained in Lebanon with Hezbollah militants.

title: Fund Set up for Libyan Children Infected with H.I.V.
description: PARIS, Dec. 23 - Libya, Bulgaria, the United States and the European Union have agreed to set up a fund to support hundreds of Libyan children infected with H.I.V., Bulgarian officials said today.

title: Ukraine's dance of the oligarchs
Paid Notice: Deaths   MULLIGAN, JAMES DONALD
description: MULLIGAN--James Donald. 80 years old of Arlington, VA and Palm Beach, FL passed away peacefully with his great sense of humor intact, on Wednesday, December 21, 2005. Beloved husband of Shirley Hensel Mulligan; loving father of Kathleen Mary Price and her husband, Virgil M. Price II, Patrick John Mulligan and Michael Mark Mulligan; devoted grandfather of Virgil and Brittany Price, Seagh, Siobhan, Jaimie, Anastassia and John Mulligan; dearest brother of Norma Riley and beloved brother-inlaw to Arnold and Raymond Hensel. Mr. Mulligan attended Niagra University and graduated from St. John's Law School. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus, Elks Club, American Legion and Friday Board Club. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to a Memorial Mass in St. Edward Catholic Church, 144 North County Road, Palm Beach, FL on Tuesday, December 27th at 11:00AM followed by a luncheon reception at the Sailfish Club of Florida, 1338 North Lake Way, Palm Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. Quattlebaum Funeral Home 561-832-5171 Family Owned and Operated www.Quattlebaum.org

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: 2 Convicted Of Publishing Insults To The State
description: A week after Orhan Pamuk, Turkey's top novelist, went on trial, charged with insults to the Turkish identity, an Istanbul court convicted two other intellectuals on the same charges. Zulkuf Kisanak, who compiled stories of forced evacuations of Kurdish villages by the Turkish military in his book "Lost Villages," received a $2,200 fine. Aziz Ozer, a publisher whose magazine carried articles titled "80 Years of the Turkish Republic, 80 Years of Fascism" and "No to a Partnership of Invasion in Iraq," was fined $4,400. Turkey has revised its laws in line with European freedoms of expression, but the publication of insults to the state or army is still considered a crime. SEBNEM ARSU (NYT)

title: The Listings: Dec. 23 - Dec. 29; 'ECLIPSE: VISIONS OF THE CRESCENT AND THE CROSS'
description: Abdel R. Salaam came to dance almost accidentally as a student and athlete at Lehman College in the 1970's. But it didn't take him long to ponder why his college dance teacher talked about the predictability of black students like Mr. Salaam recycling Alvin Ailey in their choreography classes. Why then, he wondered, was it permissible for white students to redo Twyla Tharp? Mr. Salaam likes to think about what lies behind accepted truths. Twenty years ago he founded a company, Forces of Nature, that blended traditional West African and modern dance in distinctive ways, well before that choreographic technique became fashionable. The lithe, stretched bodies of late-20th-century modern dance surged through dance that told the stories of the creation of the world and of black American myths, with intensity and an appreciation for the power of ritual. Now, he and his vibrant company will tackle the historical and cultural conflicts and confluences, as he puts it, of Christianity and Islam in "Eclipse: Visions of the Crescent and the Cross"(above). Mr. Salaam, who has described himself as "an ecumenical Muslim," combines ballet, hip-hop, martial-arts techniques and even Irish dancing with his more familiar African-contemporary mix in the new work, a journey that begins with the ancient Moors and winds its way through history up to the teaching of Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X. The score ranges from music by M'bemba Bangoura and Paul Winter, with whom his troupe has performed, to Gregorian chants and Islamic prayers. And the list of guest artists leading the multiracial cast reads like a Who's Who of black modern-dance performers, among them Sarita Allen, Dyane Harvey and Nathan Trice. (Forces of Nature will present the premiere of "Eclipse: Visions of the Crescent and the Cross" on Thursday at 7:30 p.m. at Aaron Davis Hall, City College, 135th Street and Convent Avenue, Hamilton Heights, (212) 650-7100, www.forcesofnature.org; $25 to $45.)

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Cyndi Lauper on Broadway

title: Chinese toxic spill met by confusion in Russia
Little Help From Justices on Spy Program
description: The Supreme Court has never addressed the question of whether the Fourth Amendment, which prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures, is violated by electronic surveillance of people in the United States of the sort that President Bush authorized after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Ted Tulchin, 79, a Producer of 'Sweeney Todd' Revival, Is Dead
description: Ted Tulchin, a businessman and theatrical producer, died on Monday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 79 and lived in Floral Park.

title: Polar Bear Club Swims: New Year Parties (Don't Hold the Ice)
description: ON New Year's Day, as the world slowly sloughs off hangovers and cleans up confetti, crowds gather to watch people throw themselves into frigid bodies of water. Like the Rose Parade, black-eyed peas and collard greens, polar bear swims have become a fixture of the holiday, with new ones popping up almost every new year. What is it about the day that makes people yearn for hypothermia?

title: Foreigners May Soon Play a Part in Kuwait Oil
description: KUWAIT CITY, Kuwait, Dec. 16 - Thirty years after foreign oil companies were expelled from Kuwait, the state is close to opening its lucrative oil production business again to outsiders.

title: A Teacher Gets a Lesson in Redemption
description: Two things on earth are truly unbearable.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Scientist resigns after faking stem cell research
Finding God on Broadway
description: It's a show with little advertising, no stars and a book that is much older than your average matinee audience. But every Sunday evening, the 6 o'clock Mass at St. Malachy's, the Roman Catholic church on West 49th Street known as the Actors' Chapel, draws a regular crowd of religious-minded actors and other theater professionals who come seeking something that not even the applause of thousands of strangers can provide.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the Los Angeles Lakers' Kobe Bryant, who scored 62 points in a victory against Dallas, referred incorrectly in some copies to Pat Riley's relationship to Bryant. Riley is a former Lakers coach, but Bryant never played for him.

title: Egyptian Leader of Muslim Group Calls Holocaust a Zionist 'Myth'
description: CAIRO, Dec. 22 - Two weeks after the Muslim Brotherhood won 88 seats in Parliament and established itself as Egypt's only significant political opposition organization, its leader issued a statement Thursday condemning America while declaring that the Holocaust was a "myth."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Restaurant Sues Over Lost Business
description: A theater district restaurant, the Russian Samovar, complained in a lawsuit filed yesterday in State Supreme Court that the three-day transit strike crippled its business. In its suit against Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the city, the restaurant seeks $25,000 a day in damages for each day of the strike. The lawsuit also asks the court to create a $5 million general fund to compensate small businesses for strike-related losses. But a spokeswoman for the city's corporation counsel said the state's highest court had found that only a government entity, not a private one, has standing to sue for "ordinary damages" resulting from illegal strikes by public employees. The restaurant's lawyer, John N. Iannuzzi, said that even though the strike ended yesterday, "the season is shot." ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

title: Law Eases Residency Rule for City Sanitation Workers
description: New York City sanitation workers will now have an option like that for police officers, firefighters and teachers -- to live in less costly suburban areas while still keeping their city jobs -- under a state law signed this week by Gov. George E. Pataki over opposition from the Bloomberg administration.

title: Thomas Puts Pressure on the Knicks to Play Better at Home
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 22 - The players assembled by Isiah Thomas over the past 24 months have performed miserably, making his anniversary as Knicks president an occasion to ignore, if not forget.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Shell Oil Pipeline Attacked
description: Nigeria put security forces in the Niger Delta on high alert after two explosions crippled oil production in the restive oil-rich region that makes Nigeria the world's eighth-largest producer of crude. Vandals attacked a Shell pipeline 30 miles west of Port Harcourt on Monday evening, causing an explosion that killed several people and forced the closing of an export terminal. Militant groups in the Niger Delta have attacked pipelines frequently in recent years, both to highlight the destitution in the Niger Delta despite the region's oil wealth and to steal oil and sell it on the black market. LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

title: An Action Film About the Need to Talk
description: WITH his latest film, "Munich," Steven Spielberg forgoes the emotional bullying and pop thrills that come so easily to him to tell the story of a campaign of vengeance that Israel purportedly brought against Palestinian terrorists in the wake of the 1972 Olympics. An unsparingly brutal look at two peoples all but drowning in a sea of their own blood, "Munich" is by far the toughest film of the director's career and the most anguished. Mr. Spielberg has been pummeling audiences with his virtuosity for nearly as long as he has been making movies; now, he tenders an invitation to a discussion.

title: In New York, Nurse With TB Prompts a Search for Patients
description: A New York City maternity-ward nurse who had infectious tuberculosis exposed as many as 1,500 patients to the disease over two months in 2003, and most likely infected at least four infants, according to a joint investigation by the city's health department and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Workers Choose to Come Back and Talk
description: Correction Appended

title: 2 Sued on Trading Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued two former hedge fund managers in San Francisco yesterday, asserting they used a loophole in a Bear Stearns trading system to place thousands of illegal mutual fund trades at other investors' expense.

title: Aceh is building peace from its ruins
New York's Subways and Buses Operating on Normal Schedules
description: Subways and buses operated on normal schedules, taxis used their meters instead of charging by zones, and the morning rush returned to normal today as the transit union completed 24 hours back on the job.

title: What About MetroCards?
description: The three-day strike will not cost riders any days on their unlimited-ride MetroCards, New York City Transit said yesterday.

title: Arcelor raises offer for Dofasco
Amid Growing Wealth, Nepotism and Nationalism in Kazakhstan
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan - A few years ago, the youngest daughter of Kazakhstan's president visited the Luxor temples in Egypt. Like many tourists, she later told an interviewer, she left deeply impressed with the site.

title: A suspect in Rwanda genocide is found dead
U.S. Plans Slight Force Cut, Up to 5,000 Troops, in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 - In the first reduction of American troops in Iraq approved since last week's elections there, President Bush has ordered the core force of 17 combat brigades inside Iraq to be trimmed to 15 brigades early next year, senior Defense Department and military officials said Thursday. While the net reduction of American forces under this order is expected to be modest -- 3,000 to 5,000 troops in Iraq overall -- the decision signals that a cautious realignment has begun, one intended to bring troop levels soon to their lowest point since mid-2004, officials said. It is expected to be followed with further incremental reductions in the months to come.

title: Kuwait to Pour More Money Into China Oil
description: BEIJING, Dec. 22 - Kuwait is planning a major investment in China's oil industry, its energy minister said Thursday, on top of a deal already being negotiated to build a $5 billion refinery and petrochemical plant in southern China.

title: Art in Review; Cristbal Gabarrn
description: The Body Image in Cristbal Gabarrn's Art: 1963-2005 Chelsea Art Museum 556 West 22nd Street Through Jan. 14

title: An Inscrutable Traveler Embarks on a Staggered Path of Recollections
description: Claire Denis's magnificent enigma of a film, "The Intruder," explores the troubled soul of Louis Trebor (Michel Subor), a brooding loner with a heart condition who lives with two large white dogs in a forest near the French-Swiss border. As this rugged, ailing 68-year-old outdoorsman travels halfway around the world to begin a new life, his past, present and future, real and imagined, blend into a visually spellbinding depiction of a selfish sensualist's quest for a longer life with a redemptive final chapter.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Rome: Benedict Fretted At Idea Of Being Pope
description: Pope Benedict XVI was a little frightened when he was chosen pope in April, he told Vatican officials in a year-end speech. "Such a job was completely beyond anything I could ever have imagined as my vocation," he said in a speech in the Apostolic Palace where the body of his predecessor, John Paul II, had been laid out after his death in April. "As such, it was only with a great act of faith in God that I could say in obedience my 'yes' to this choice." IAN FISHER (NYT)

title: Proposal to Oust Sovereign Bancorp Board
description: The largest shareholder of Sovereign Bancorp, escalating a two-month revolt by investors, wants to remove all of Sovereign's directors to block the sale of a stake to Santander Central Hispano.

title: Trains Stood Still. Mouths Ran.
description: IF you didn't know better -- if, say, you had just arrived in town from Lower Slobovia -- you might well have wondered why thousands of New York City transit workers went on strike this week to challenge the Supreme Court's ruling in Roe v. Wade. You could have been forgiven for thinking that the whole mess was about abortion.

title: The Tax-Cut Zombies
description: If you want someone to play Scrooge just before Christmas, Dick Cheney is your man. On Wednesday Mr. Cheney, acting as president of the Senate, cast the tie-breaking vote in favor of legislation that increases the fees charged to Medicaid recipients, lets states cut Medicaid benefits, reduces enforcement funds for child support, and more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHMECK, ROBERT E.
description: SCHMECK--Robert E., 85. On December 18, in Ocala, FL. Son of Hazel and Ernest Schmeck of Niagara Falls. A pioneering Industrial Designer, he held 24 mechanical, two electronic, three international patents, and over 50 design patents and copyrights. Survived by wife Jill; children with wife Patricia (deceased) Christian and Heidi.

Dear father of Malcolm (Elan), Arthur (Dawn), Frank (Ida), Daniel (Debbi) and Gerald (Diane). Loving grandfather of Stacey, Ian, Eric and Jack. Graveside services Friday, 11 AM, at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: From Back-Channel Contacts, Blueprint for a Deal
description: On Wednesday morning, Roger Toussaint's closest advisers encouraged him to face his difficult circumstances. The workers in Mr. Toussaint's union, who had brought the city's transit system to a halt, were incurring fines and public scorn with each day of the union's strike.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Nip/Tuck' Weaves a Spell
description: The unmasking of the Carver -- or more precisely, Carvers, since the serial mutilators were a brother-sister team -- on FX's "Nip/Tuck" brought in 5.7 million viewers on Tuesday. Among 18-to-49-year-olds, the broadcast was the highest-rated cable show of 2005, which solidified the show's position as the No. 1 cable attraction in that age group this year. On Wednesday NBC's "Deal or No Deal" continued to gain ratings momentum. Night 3 of that game show drew 14.2 million viewers, its highest total yet, and NBC's largest audience in that time period in almost four years, excluding Olympic broadcasts. Following that, the ratings bomb that was "The Apprentice: Martha Stewart" mercifully came to a conclusion: Dawna Stone, a magazine publisher from Florida, got a job at one of Ms. Stewart's magazines, Body + Soul. The episode attracted 7.47 million viewers, which was good enough for second place during the repeat-laden 9 p.m. hour. NBC was No. 1 for the night in total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic.

Voorhees. Survived by three children, Susan Hunt of McLean, VA, Nancy of Bethesda, MD and Scott of London, England, six grandchildren and two brothers, Ralph of Highland Park, NJ and Fred Zimmerli of Telford, PA. A momorial service will be held on Thursday, January 19 at 3:30 PM at Westmoreland Congregational United Church of Christ, 1 Westmoreland Circle, Bethesda, MD, 20816. In lieu of flowers, a remembrance may be made to Historic Jamestowne Campaign 2007, in care of APVA, 2004 West Franklin Street, Richmond, VA. 23220.

title: A Romantic Entanglement With a Heart of Celluloid
description: "Rumor Has It" abounds with overt movie references, most of them to "The Graduate." The premise, you see, is that a former beau of the heroine's dead mother may have been the model for the hero of Charles Webb's novel "The Graduate," which was of course the basis for the 1967 movie directed by Mike Nichols. Or, to put it more simply, Dustin Hoffman may have grown up into Kevin Costner, while Anne Bancroft might have aged gracefully into Shirley MacLaine.

title: Investing: Picking out quirky stock
A TV Extravaganza of Music! Comedy! Militia! K.G.B.!
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22 - Time and again, a phenomenon unfolds on Russian television. Stiff-faced bureaucrats pack a huge concert hall, and after a speech by a leading Kremlin official -- often President Vladimir V. Putin himself -- the show begins.

title: An Extended Family Holiday Outing, Onstage
description: For the Canadian folkie sisters Kate and Anna McGarrigle, Christmas could never be simply "the holidays." The intuitive and cerebral siblings require that specificity as they mine its place in their own past, familial intimacies, disappointment and heartbreak, and joys metaphysical and quotidian. On Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, they alluded to the sacred nature of their musical inquiry. "We wanted to get pews up here," said Anna, "but it was too expensive."

title: Woman's Boyfriend Is Charged With Murder in Baby's Death
description: A 22-month-old boy who died after his mother found him unconscious on Wednesday had been severely beaten that day, and yesterday his mother's boyfriend was charged with murder, the police said.

title: Belichick Stitches Patriots Into Shape, Fraying Hopes of Conference Foes
description: They're back. And that's bad news for the rest of the league.

title: Sri Lankan Navy and Rebels Clash, Threatening Cease-Fire
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 22 - Tamil separatists attacked two Sri Lankan Navy ships early Thursday morning, abducting three sailors, the military said, and pushing the battered island nation closer to resuming its two-decade civil war.

title: How do film critics count to 10? With difficulty
Spotlight: Makeover artist in Italian banking
Rangers Flip the Switch for 3 Power-Play Goals
description: On a night that looked as if it would belong to the seven Rangers selected to play in the Turin Olympics in February, it was a player overlooked by his national team who ensured the Rangers would end their three-game losing streak.

title: 36 Hours in Pensacola, Fla.
description: WHILE Pensacola is not the nation's oldest city, its residents like to claim it was actually the first choice of the Spaniards. The earliest settlers came ashore at Pensacola Bay in 1559 - six years before the founding of St. Augustine - but fled after a hurricane wiped out most of their ships and supplies. Today, Pensacola is a more welcoming place. Anchored at the western tip of Florida, stretching miles along the Gulf of Mexico, it has mild temperatures, sugary beaches and snapper-rich waters that draw spring-breakers, fishing enthusiasts and environmentalists alike. Pensacola is also home to the Blue Angels, the Navy's precision flying team, and a sprawling air base where generations of Navy pilots have trained. The city was forced to rebuild after Hurricane Ivan battered the region last year, and some hotels and beach sites remain closed for repairs. But Pensacola's identity - a blend of Southern culture and redneck charm, conservative churches and Buddhist temples, and an ever-changing influx of ethnic newcomers, including many Vietnamese immigrants - emerged stronger than ever.

title: Poland's new president is sworn in
Another School Barrier for African Girls: No Toilet
description: BALIZENDA, Ethiopia - Fatimah Bamun dropped out of Balizenda Primary School in first grade, more than three years ago, when her father refused to buy her pencils and paper. Only after teachers convinced him that his daughter showed unusual promise did he relent. Today Fatimah, 14, tall and slender, studies math and Amharic, Ethiopia's official language, in a dirt-floored fourth-grade classroom.

title: The President And the Rule of Law

Postponing Debate, Congress Extends Terror Law 5 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 - In a frantic finish before adjourning for the year, Congress extended on Thursday the broad antiterrorism bill known as the USA Patriot Act by five weeks after the Republican chairman of the House Judiciary Committee balked at a longer extension.

title: Golden Boy: Memories of a Hong Kong Childhood
Jury Rules Wal-Mart Must Pay $172 Million Over Meal Breaks

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (BBC America) CHRISTMAS LIGHTS -- So much for tasteful British restraint. The usually dashing Robson Green (shown above in "Wire in the Blood") stars in this television movie about two suburbanites (Mr. Green and Mark Benton) who have been friends since boyhood and can't get past their childish habit of constant competition. As adults, they are married to sisters, live in the same neighborhood, work for the same company and are now trying to outdo each other's holiday decorations. The neighbors will suffer.

title: 36 Hours in Pensacola, Fla.
description: WHILE Pensacola is not the nation's oldest city, its residents like to claim it was actually the first choice of the Spaniards. The earliest settlers came ashore at Pensacola Bay in 1559 -- six years before the founding of St. Augustine -- but fled after a hurricane wiped out most of their ships and supplies. Today, Pensacola is a more welcoming place. Anchored at the western tip of Florida, stretching miles along the Gulf of Mexico, it has mild temperatures, sugary beaches and snapper-rich waters that draw spring-breakers, fishing enthusiasts and environmentalists alike. Pensacola is also home to the Blue Angels, the Navy's precision flying team, and a sprawling air base where generations of Navy pilots have trained. The city was forced to rebuild after Hurricane Ivan battered the region last year, and some hotels and beach sites remain closed for repairs. But Pensacola's identity -- a blend of Southern culture and redneck charm, conservative churches and Buddhist temples, and an ever-changing influx of ethnic newcomers, including many Vietnamese immigrants -- emerged stronger than ever. WINNIE HU

An ATPAM member, she worked in PR for over four decades. Clients included The Alvin Ailey Dance Company, and The Metropolitan Opera Co. Above all things, she loved New York City and its people. She adored traveling, was a constant supporter of her synagogue, and was a true patron of the arts. Her passing is a great loss to her family and those who had the privilege to know her. Cornell University received $500,000 to build a study center at its Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art. Other institutions receiving challenge grants included the Mark Twain House in Hartford, which received $800,000 for teacher development programs, a writing contest for students and an educational Web site.

They touch each other's sweaters while they sing together around pianos, they get into "the spirit," and here's another bad thing about Christmas that should make Jewish children excited about celebrating Hanukkah: Christmas trees are terrible fire hazards.

title: The Listings: Dec. 23 - Dec. 29; ROY HARGROVE BIG BAND
description: Of all the young musicians to emerge during jazz's major-label prospecting boom of the late 1980's and early 90's, few have stayed in the game like the trumpeter Roy Hargrove. Since his discovery by Wynton Marsalis in 1987, Mr. Hargrove, above, has ranked among his generation's leading proponents of hard bop, with fruitful detours into symphonic strings, Cuban groove and neo-soul. He caused a minor stir in 2003 with the RH Factor, an electric project trafficking in soul, gospel and R & B, along with a sprinkling of organic hip-hop; the group's debut, "Hard Groove" (Verve), featured guest turns by the singers D'Angelo and Erykah Badu and the rappers Q-Tip and Common. At the same time, Mr. Hargrove toured in a postbop band with the pianist Herbie Hancock and the saxophonist Michael Brecker, and he never stopped working with his longstanding acoustic quintet. If it all suggests a double life, that's not far off the mark: Mr. Hargrove's forthcoming album, "Reflections and Distractions," will feature one disc of hard bop and another of RH Factor groove. (The album is scheduled for release in late-February on Verve.) Next week Mr. Hargrove will bring his sharp and assertive trumpet playing, along with his less heralded arranging skills, to yet another ensemble: a 17-piece big band stocked with colleagues like the saxophonist Ron Blake, the trumpeter Darren Barrett and the drummer Greg Hutchinson. The setting will lend the engagement a historical tone -- Mr. Hargrove first convened his big band 10 years ago in the space that is now the Jazz Gallery -- but the music should leave nostalgia behind. (Wednesday through Dec. 30 at 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063; cover, $25.)

The man, Zeeshan Siddique, 25, had been charged with illegally entering and staying in the country under a false name. title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend last Friday about "Pixar: 20 Years of Animation," at the Museum of Modern Art, referred imprecisely to the role of John Lasseter, Pixar's creative chief, in the company's founding. Pixar describes Steve Jobs and Ed Catmull as the company's co-founders, and Mr. Lasseter as "a founding member." He was not the founder. The review also referred incompletely to the title of Steven Higgins, an organizer of the show. He is acting chief curator of the museum's film and media department, not acting curator of it.

title: Lock Up Your Ladies

A movie that begins with a man in a billowy linen shirt writing with a quill pen by candlelight, accompanied by a plummy voice-over -- a "feather film," as my predecessor Vincent Canby might have said -- is rarely headed anywhere very interesting. To make matters worse, this was also "a film by Lasse Hallstrom," a talented enough director, but one whose recent efforts have been more concerned with Quality than with art or insight or surprise. So I sighed and sank down in my seat, preparing for a long, perfumed coach ride to Prestigeville.
