If the path through the chill heads in the right direction, the rewards can be cheerful conversation and a warming glass of wine at a tasting room.

title: Mint
description: Among the various options and strategies for naming restaurants, making monosyllabic reference to a foodstuff of indeterminate ethnicity may well be gaining traction. Recent years have brought us Prune, Bread, Salt and several branches of Rice.

title: Conviction in gassing of Kurds
Iraqis Take Stock of a Trial Where the Accused Holds Court
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 22 - The court trying Saddam Hussein on charges of crimes against humanity adjourned on Thursday for a month, leaving Iraqis to ponder what it has achieved so far.

title: A Teacher Gets a Lesson in Redemption
description: Two things on earth are truly unbearable.

title: THE CHURN
description: Deal Makers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREDERICKS, SAM
description: FREDERICKS - Sam. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sam Fredericks, associated with The Times from January 1977, until retiring in January 1993.

title: Intelligent Design: Church or State?
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater You Can Drop In On
description: Are theater tickets ever an impulse buy? Not for something you'd really want to see, on Broadway or off. But are there destinations Off Broadway that draw theatergoers on the strength of their reputation for booking interesting, rewarding work? That seems to be the dream that animates a handful of emerging Off Broadway houses, which are setting themselves apart by developing audiences who trust the programmers' taste and by keeping admission prices closer to the cost of a movie ticket than to a four-star dinner.

title: A Nice Middle-Class Couple With Their Own Stalker
description: Michael Haneke's "Cach (Hidden)" begins, as many films do, with an exterior establishing shot. We are looking down a narrow Paris street at a nondescript house, fairly certain that cinematic convention will soon invite us inside. But there is something odd about this ordinary, even banal, image. The camera, perfectly still, lingers for an unusually long time, and we begin to suspect we may not be alone. Someone is watching with us, and perhaps even watching us as we watch. It turns out that this is not only the opening shot in a movie, but also part of a surveillance video.

title: Williams's Days Are Numbered, but It's Not Like He's Done Yet
description: Bernie Williams trails Yogi Berra by 97 at-bats, Bill Dickey by 13 runs batted in and Babe Ruth by 4 doubles. It is a near certainty that he will surpass all of those totals next season and move up the formidable ladder of Yankee career statistics now that he has agreed to a $1.5 million, one-year contract.

title: Official Call to New Leader of Bolivia Is Spanish Hoax
description: MADRID, Dec. 22 - The Spanish government expressed outrage on Thursday after a comedian for a conservative radio station here held a five-minute telephone conversation with the new president of Bolivia while claiming to be the Spanish prime minister.

title: Foreign Minister Says Japan Sees Military Threat in China Buildup
description: TOKYO, Dec. 22 - With diplomatic relations between Japan and China already chilled by a succession of events this year, the Japanese foreign minister on Thursday bluntly described China's military buildup as a threat, immediately drawing an angry response from Beijing.

title: Tunnel blast in China raises industrial toll
Placer Dome Agrees to Sweetened Barrick Bid
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 22 - Barrick Gold, one of the world's top gold mining companies, has agreed to acquire Placer Dome after improving its offer to $10.4 billion in a deal that would create the world's biggest gold producer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, SYLVIA F.
description: KLEIN--Sylvia F. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted mother of Seena and the late Edward Parker, Maxene & Steve Greenspan. Adored Bubbie of Jeremy, Adam and Janis. Caring aunt. Pillar of the Workmen's Circle, active member of the UFT and the Forward Association. Funeral Monday, December 26, at 9:30 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and West 91st St.

title: Corrections
description: The TV Watch column yesterday, about coverage of the transit strike, misspelled the surname of an "Eyewitness News" anchor on WABC. He is Steve Bartelstein, not Bertelstein.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Artists' Books, Revisited'Printed Matter195 10th Avenue, at West 22nd StreetThrough Jan. 4

title: Sarkozy rebuts the critics who label him far-rightist
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Spare Times
description: Attractions

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: For Musicians, Another Week Before Giving Up Instruments
description: Today's deadline for two members of the Audubon String Quartet to hand over their instruments to a bankruptcy trustee in Roanoke, Va., was delayed for a week. The two musicians, Clyde Shaw and Doris Lederer, who are married, lost a $611,000 judgment to the first violinist, David Ehrlich, whom they had expelled from the group. Mr. Shaw, the cellist, and Ms. Lederer, the violist, entered bankruptcy and were due to have much of their assets, including their instruments, liquidated today after nearly six years of legal feuding and a number of failed efforts to settle with Mr. Ehrlich. (The other violinist, Akemi Takayama, faces a separate bankruptcy proceeding.) The trustee, George A. McLean Jr., said he delayed the turnover because the parties were in new settlement talks. DANIEL J. WAKIN (NYT)

title: Where to search for masterpieces
On Opinion Page, a Lobby's Hand Is Often Unseen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 - Susan Finston of the Institute for Policy Innovation, a conservative research group based in Texas, is just the sort of opinion maker coveted by the drug industry.

title: Hitting the Beaches in Greenwich, Where Group Hugs Are Few
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 22 - A glance at this town's ordinances makes it clear that anyone wishing to visit Greenwich's well-coiffed beaches must tread carefully. Visitors must refrain from climbing trees or digging in the sand, for instance, or playing horseshoes outside designated areas.

title: Brewery hopes to tap the dividends of peace
Microsoft threatened with daily EU fines
The Listings: Dec. 23 - Dec. 29; THE EIGHT NIGHTS OF HANUKKAH WITH YO LA TENGO
description: As night falls over Hoboken, N.J., at the end of each day of Hanukkah, the indie-rock trio Yo La Tengo will put on a night of reflective and furious music at the local club Maxwell's. The holiday run is becoming something of a tradition for the group -- the bassist James McNew, above front, and the husband-and-wife team of Ira Kaplan on guitar and Georgia Hubley on drums -- and for this, their fourth Hanukkah series since 2001, they'll perform songs from their own catalog, ranging from squallers like "Tom Courtney" to quiescent relationship odes like the beckoning "My Little Corner of the World." But they'll also welcome, on various nights (along with comic M.C.'s to be announced), opening acts like the New Zealand rockers the Mad Scene, the jazzy Chicago polymaths Tortoise, the Sun Ra Arkestra directed by Marshall Allen, the naf rock group Half Japanese and the singer-songwriter Lois, as well as fellow 80's indie veterans the Volcano Suns and the Scene Is Now. For all the comedy and frivolity on hand, one assumes there will be no shortage of seriousness. After all, this is a band that refashioned Sun Ra's "Nuclear War" as an all-purpose anthem of political disgust and wrote a love samba, "Center of Gravity," in praise of sometimes frustrating earthly attachments. (Sunday through Jan. 1, 1039 Washington Street, (201) 653-1703; $20 in advance, $30 at the door.)

title: China Moves to Put Jailed Times Researcher on Trial
description: BEIJING, Dec. 23 - A Chinese researcher for The New York Times was indicted today for revealing state secrets to the newspaper and also on a lesser charge of fraud, a move that should send the case to trial within six weeks, his lawyer said.

title: Art in Review; Brian Jungen
description: New Museum of Contemporary Art 556 West 22nd Street Through Dec. 31

title: The Slow, Ponderous Process of Restarting the Wheels
description: Correction Appended

title: Over a Million on Medicare Sign Up for New Drug Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 - The Bush administration announced Thursday that slightly more than a million of the 42 million Medicare beneficiaries had voluntarily signed up for the new prescription drug benefit, while 10.6 million had been enrolled automatically by the federal government or by health maintenance organizations.

title: Alito Defended Wiretap Protections in 1984 Memo
description: The attorney general should be immune from lawsuits over illegal wiretaps, Samuel A. Alito Jr., President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, wrote in a 1984 memorandum as a government lawyer in the Reagan administration.

title: Fidelity Stands Alone in Its Stand on Research Costs
description: WITH great fanfare, Fidelity Investments announced recently that it would revolutionize how it paid Wall Street for research and trading by separating the cost of research from the cost of trading. Traditionally, trading and research costs have been tied together, making regulators and some fund directors nervous because it is not clear what exactly is included in an all-included price.

title: The Special Olympics, for Laughs
description: Of all the indignities suffered by the intellectually disabled stars of "The Ringer," none are so great as having to share screen time with Johnny Knoxville. You wouldn't guess that Mr. Knoxville, mastermind of "Jackass," would have such a hard time playing a numbskull pretending to be disabled, especially in a movie from the brains behind "Dumb and Dumber." But the real surprise of "The Ringer" is how it bucks this seemingly insurmountable handicap to wind up a fairly winning comedy.

title: The Doctor Who Stands Between New York and the Flu
description: As a medical detective, Dr. Isaac B. Weisfuse has stared down some of the most dangerous germs in a microbe Murderers Row -- hepatitis, H.I.V., and anthrax.

title: Every Which Way, an Old-Fashioned Romp
description: Every Which Way, An Old-Fashioned Romp

title: View Points: Curtain falls on Italian drama
The End of a Senseless Strike
description: Now that there's a truce in the transit strike that should never have happened, a contract can be negotiated without using working New Yorkers as cannon fodder. The illegal walkout by the nearly 34,000 transit union members lasted through two and a half days, six commuter rush periods and countless missed appointments. The tales of perseverance are impressive, but the short strike inflicted plenty of pain -- physical, financial and emotional -- on the millions of people dependent on the city's subways and buses.

title: Bulgaria sees hope for nurses sentenced to die in Libya
Paid Notice: Deaths  REGENBOGEN, STANLEY
description: REGENBOGEN--Stanley. On December 17, 2005. Beloved husband and best friend, devoted father, grandfather and brother. Memorial service January 2, 2006, 11:30 am, at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: The House of Many Doors
description: There have been a lot of choice screenings this season, but nothing quite like what will take place at Folsom prison on Jan. 3. According to Variety, Joaquin Phoenix, who plays Johnny Cash in Walk the Line, will attend at the invitation of the Folsom Prison Fellowship. Thirty-eight years ago, Cash himself stepped up to the mic. Phoenix, who has been acting twitchy in press events for the film, best get a signed agreement that they will let him back out, less he pick up a jail name and a set of prison blues.

title: Young Guns Throw-down
description: Gawker pointed us to an item suggesting the essential redundancy of Dylan McDermott and Dermot Mulroney is another much-chewed-over fact of showbiz. Fametracker suggests that the two are the same side of the same coin, although Mulroney gets big ups for his part in the publicity for The Family Stone, including a nice turn on The Colbert Report. Fametracker, the Farmers Almanac of celebrity worth, is a rapaciously funny site, but digital doofus that he is, the Carpetbagger knew hardly anything about it. The Web is a lot like a New York party. You think you are in the cool room, making nasty jokes about people you have never met, but four rooms away, behind invisible velvet ropes, Scarlett Johansson is making out with Karl Rove. Btw, when you visit Fametracker, dont miss Galaxy of Fame for a look at whats really on the mind of Oscar hopefuls.

title: Party Dress
description: Every once in a while, a movie actually premieres in New York, just to keep the Carpetbagger off-balance. He did not attend a special screening at the Directors Guild of America for The Family Stone  he has a day job that he does at night  but the New York Observer was there, for an evening that seemed to have its share of moments: Sarah Jessica Parker wore a black, billowy dress that kept coming undone in back. Its a breakaway dress, she said.

title: Thats The Ticket
description: Lousy drivers from New Jersey  They dont accelerate and are afraid to make turns, a slam that also seems to describe studio heads  are responsible for everything from clogged intersections in Manhattan to a drop-off in attendance for Brokeback Mountain, according to Roger Friedman, the Fox gossip.

title: Cow Punching
description: When a debate was first raised over whether the characters in Brokeback Mountain were fit to be called cowboys, the Carpetbagger nearly fell off his horse laughing. So what if they were all hat and no cattle? he thought; they are manifestly cowboys. Jack Twist, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, not only rides in the rodeo, but his beard/wife is a rodeo queen. (And we dont mean the kind that performs in leather bars in the East Village). But it turns out that no less than the author Annie Proulx stated that they are not cowboys and she has plenty of supporters among the Rugrats in the comments section, if yesterday was any indication. So far, the discussion has been like herding sheep, with unexpected break outs at every turn. Join in the mayhem if you dare.

title: Giving Voice to the Fringe
description: A History of Violence wins the 7th annual critics poll at the Village Voice, edging out the surging 2046, Kar Wai Wongs Hong Kong noir that has them swooning in bunches. Never mind that most of the Academy thinks that number is the key code that unlocks the wifes Beemer.

title: Whats Next, Peace in the Middle East?
description: Although Christmas may not be a significant holiday inflection point for Steven Spielberg, it came early this year. After weeks of a mostly unseen Munich getting knocked around, the critics are weighing in, and its mostly with bon bons. At the New York Times, Manohla Dargis said all of the controversy was much fuss about not much: Mr. Spielberg is doing nothing more radical here than advancing the idea that dialogue ends when two enemies, held hostage by dusty history and hot blood, have their hands locked around each others throats. And Owen Gleiberman of Entertainment Weekly hands Spielberg a big fat A, calling the film a thriller that seeps into your central nervous system. According to Slates David Edelstein, Munich is the most potent, the most vital, the best movie of the year. (Still, some of Spielbergs antagonists are still armed with intelligence and remain dangerous as a rule.

title: For Your Manipulation
description: In myriad ads offered For Your Consideration  and the Carpetbaggers, incidentally, who channels as a member of the Academy to inhabit the collective mind of that body  George Clooney is offered as a candidate for best supporting actor in Syriana. As my colleague Ed Wyatt pointed out after seeing the movie, who exactly is he supposed to be secondary to? The movie opens on his surprisingly beefy mug and balances on his shoulders for much of the rest of the way. Yes, it is a movie that has an ensemble that is played through a prismatic narrative, but in acting terms  give or take a smashing Matt Damon assist  the movie belongs to him. Let us stipulate that Mr. Clooney is a Good Guy who makes Wonderful Movies about Important Topics. Yes, he is a triple-threat wonder this year who will be doing laps to the podium, but what, beyond studio artifice, has him competing in a supporting role? Call it the Traffic effect. Benicio Del Toro, a leading mans leading man, won best supporting actor in 2000 because he was pitched that way. Now the Carpetbagger was born at night, but not last night, so he knows that the awards are subject to the wiles of marketing and manipulation, but heres hoping that Clooney gets his due for writing, producing, and directing more quality in a single year than most filmmakers accomplish in a lifetime. And if the Academy is just going damp in the pants to give gorgeous George a supporting nod, why not give it to him for his turn as Fred Friendly in Good Night, and Good Luck, where he ably and honorably supported his star, David Strathairn?

title: Part 2: Police Videotape Couple
description: A man and woman who shared an intimate moment on a secluded, dark rooftop one August night last year have learned that they were secretly watched, The Times's Jim Dwyer reports.

title: That Certain Time of Year
description: Is it the Carpetbagger, or is there a little something special hanging in the air? Boys and girls hugging themselves with thoughts of surprises to come, gifts that will keep on giving, a time when everything and everyone seems to have just a bit of extra twinkle? Yes, the homestretch of Oscar season is upon us, and the Carpetbagger is hanging out his stocking in hopes that it will be filled with useless trivia and devastating insights about the little gold guys every wiggle and wobble.

title: 'Rumor Has It'
description: A.O. Scott reviews the new movie starring Jennifer Aniston and Kevin Costner.

title: Video: Best Actress of 2005?
description: Which actresses turned in the best performances of the year? The Carpetbagger to find out.

title: 'Casanova'
description: A.O. Scott reviews the new movie starring Heath Ledger.

title: Making Memories
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Pulse
description: What the marketing director, the author, the event planner, the producer and the denim designers are wearing for New Year's Eve.

title: Last-Minute Real Estate Presents
description: I was trying to think of some last-minute gifts for the person who is nuts about real estate. I mean, other than an apartment on Park Avenue. Id recommend a book about a building on that fabled thoroughfare: 740 Park: The Story of the Worlds Richest Apartment Building, by Michael Gross. The short review in The Timess book review section last Sunday wasnt glowing, but it did mention the key words that make the book worth a read for real estate fanatics:

title: Down, Then Up, and Back Again
description: Spend enough time looking at a graph of new home sales and youll soon be reliving your lunch. The Commerce Department reports today that sales fell 11 percent in November after jumping 11 percent in October. (Heres the Times story.) It is a pattern familiar to economists and housing watchers, many of whom say the new home sales numbers should be consumed with more than a pinch of salt, perhaps even a fistful.

title: Little  Holiday Cheer Here
description: Sorry, holiday revelers, its time to turn your iPod to that saddest of all Christmas songs, Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas, and sing along as we take our irregular tour through the gloom and doom dredged up by various blogs and print publications.

title: Blame Real Estate for the Transit Strike
description: The boom in real estate prices is a favorite bugaboo, but this analysis from The New York Daily News (tip of the hat to Matrix for pointing it out to us) explains why the MTAs coffers are so full  and why they may not be that full going forward. Columnist Michael Goodwin says:

title: The Weather May Be Frightful
description: But the fire is so delightful. Its the perfect time to think about homes with fireplaces. Popcorn popping. Chestnuts roasting. The question is, do you want one with a $7.75 million house in Sun Valley, Idaho, wrapped around it, or a quaint fireplace with carved French limestone dating from 1650? I like this Hobbit-house round fireplace. See them all in this roundup from The Times. More on fireplaces.  DAMON DARLIN

title: Back on Track
description: For the first morning commute in four days, subways and buses in New York operated on normal schedules and the morning rush returned to its normal hectic pace.

title: Part 3: Police Infiltrate Protests
description: Videotape taken at a demonstration during last year's Republican National Convention shows a protester being singled out for arrest. The Times' Jim Dwyer reports.

title: Another Good Year for Funds
description: The Wall Street pundits had thought the party would be over for real estate mutual funds in 2005. After all, the funds returned 32 percent in 2004 and 37 percent in 2003, so they wondered how many more years of double-digit gains were left.

title: A House of Her Own
description: When it comes to buying a home, more single women are going it alone, according to the National Association of Realtors, which has posted some telling statistics about women and homeownership.

title: At Work With Father Christopher
description: An Eastern Orthodox priest offers a glimpse into his life in this first installment of a video series about working people in New York. (Produced by Brent McDonald and Maria Stoian)

title: Where the Mortgage Deals Are
description: So which major city has the best mortgage deals these days? When it comes to 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, that honor goes to Minneapolis, where the average rate as of Dec. 22 was 6.22 percent, according to statistics compiled by HSH Associates. Rounding off the top three were Stamford, Conn., and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., both at 6.26 percent. The nationwide average, according to HSH, was 6.37 percent.

title: The Gay Cowboy Goes Mainstream
description: Readers respond to Frank Richs Dec. 18 column Two Gay Cowboys Hit a Home Run.

title: Luther Vandross
description: Fellow musicians reflect on the life of R & B singer Luther Vandross. (Producer: Calvin Sims)

title: Kristof: Insurgent Videos
description: Insurgents in Iraq are using the Internet to disseminate training and propaganda.

title: Next Generation Cancer Drugs
description: The Times's Gina Kolata reports on the case of retired firefighter Jay Weinstein, whose life was saved when a new cancer drug worked to fight his leukemia.

title: Wellington Mara
description: Longtime fans share personal letters received from New York  Giants owner Wellington Mara.  (Producer: Kassie Bracken)

title: Richard Pryor
description: Longtime friend and collaborator Paul Mooney reflects on  Richard Pryor's groundbreaking comedic style and enduring legacy.  (Producers: Kassie Bracken/Calvin Sims)

title: After Deadly Blast, Lawsuits and a Show of Sympathy
description: BERGENFIELD, N.J., Dec. 23 - Over the past several years Kaye Gonzalez-Dursik bought diamond earrings and other jewelry for her daughters and granddaughters. She had recently decided that this was going to be the Christmas she'd surprise them with the gifts.

title: World Briefings: Asia, Europe, Middle East
description: ASIA

title: Corporations Tidy Up as the Year Ticks Away
description: STRIKING transit workers may have brought subways and buses to a stop in New York this week, but the news kept flowing. Much of it was driven by the time of year, as corporate chiefs and government officials scrambled to tidy up things before the new year.

title: When Losing Involves Life, a Game Is but a Game
description: THREE weeks ago, the burning issue in Quentin Richardson's basketball life was how he could help the Knicks win some games. A week ago, the pressing issue in Tony's Dungy's football life was whether his Indianapolis Colts would remain undefeated.

title: Arts, Briefly; More Washington Ballet Cancellations
description: The Washington Ballet canceled its productions for February and March yesterday because of a continuing dispute with dancers and their union over a new contract. Two of the scheduled performances, the "Bach/Beatles Project" and "7x7: Women," were to be staged at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The company had also planned March performances at the Joyce Theater in New York. The dancers' union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, said it had filed an unfair labor practice complaint against the ballet with the National Labor Relations Board, seeking a reinstatement of the dancers' work schedule. The decision to eliminate the shows came one week after the ballet canceled its production of "The Nutcracker," which was expected to make enough money to help finance the 2006-7 season. The dancers say they need a new contract to protect their jobs, safety and health. The company says problems revolve around artistic control. The season ends in May. JOHN FILES

title: Vendor Tied to Gas Attack Is Convicted
description: PARIS, Dec. 23 - In the first trial involving the mass killing of Iraqi Kurds with chemical weapons, a Dutch court on Friday sentenced a supplier of the weapon ingredients to 15 years in jail.

title: For Some, Just Reading A Column Isn't Enough
description: FOR my last column of the year, I'm letting a few readers have their say. Every column has elicited reaction; however the ones I assume are going to generate the biggest fuss aren't always the ones that do. Somewhat to my surprise, the strongest responses have been to my columns on computers (we can thank the Mac users for that), on hiring private nurses and on the Do Not Call registry (mainly those begging for information on a similar Do Not Fax registry.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: David Patterson, 83, Scholar of European Jewish Culture, Dies
description: David Patterson, a scholar of Jewish life in Europe who established a center for Hebrew and Jewish studies at Oxford University to help revive a discipline that had been virtually destroyed during the Holocaust, died at a hospital in Oxford on Dec. 10. He was 83.

title: Getting Answers in the Right Dose
description: The doctor is about to say something and it does not look good. How can patients elicit information and encouragement?

title: Knicks Save Some Face With Victory After Insult
description: For those keeping score, the updated list of burdens weighing on the Knicks' shoulders looked like this: a seven-game losing streak, a horrific start to the season and, on top of it all, a public insult from their boss.

title: Gigante, Mafia Boss, Is Mourned and Buried With Little Fanfare
description: Sometimes the lines of funeral cars stretched for miles. The floral tributes were crafted with the ambition of sculpture. The mourners hailed from all walks of society, including Hollywood, the sports world, government.

title: For Tribe Nuge, Christmas Bounty From Mother Earth
description: The icicles hanging from my mustache and beard were the real McCoy. No fake decorations allowed in my Christmas tree. And my Christmas tree just happened to be a towering white oak atop a majestic forested ridgeline bordering a stunning southern Michigan swamp.

title: The Goal of Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: For Some, Just Reading A Column Isn't Enough
description: FOR my last column of the year, I'm letting a few readers have their say. Every column has elicited reaction; however the ones I assume are going to generate the biggest fuss aren't always the ones that do. Somewhat to my surprise, the strongest responses have been to my columns on computers (we can thank the Mac users for that), on hiring private nurses and on the Do Not Call registry (mainly those begging for information on a similar Do Not Fax registry.)

title: Carter Equals His Career High and Cuts O'Neal Down to Size
description: MIAMI, Dec. 23 - Vince Carter launched jumpers at will and bounced like a pinball in the paint, banging into Shaquille O'Neal and soaring over him.

title: Under a Microscope: High-Profile Cases Bring New Scrutiny to Science's Superstars
description: In recent weeks, two widely respected scientists have themselves become objects of harsh scientific scrutiny, one accused of serious research fraud and the other criticized for ethical lapses in treating a patient.

title: Man Is Killed in the Bronx
description: A 32-year-old Westchester County man was fatally shot yesterday morning near Sound View Park in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANRAHAN, POM SUN
description: HANRAHAN--Pom Sun. On December 22, 2005. Beloved wife of Joseph, loving mother of the late Joseph Jr., grandmother of Amy Lynn and Ryan. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10AM St. Jean Baptiste Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Viewing Monday 7-9, Tuesday 2-5, 7-9.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture in some copies yesterday with an article about the end of the New York City transit strike, showing a bus with a sign saying "Next Bus Please," was published in error. The bus, a public express service, was driven by a member of the Amalgamated Transit Union, not Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union; it was not one of those idled by the strike. (Go to Article)

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GABRILOVE, HILDA W.
description: GABRILOVE -- Hilda W. Forever in our thoughts and always in our hearts. Lester, Sandra, Janice, Mark, Matthew, Michael S. and Michael D.

title: Alito Memo in '84 Favored Immunity for Top Officials
description: The attorney general should be immune from lawsuits for ordering wiretaps of Americans without permission from a court, Samuel A. Alito Jr., President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, wrote in a memorandum in 1984 as a government lawyer in the Reagan administration.

title: Palestinian Elections: A Place for Hamas?
description: To the Editor:

title: Message in a Bottle
description: London - THE question is simple enough: which wine will you serve on Christmas Day? But the answer is far from straightforward, for your choice of wine is laden with meaning. Is it from the Old or New World? Does it emphasize fruit over terroir? Did you have to put your name down on a boutique winery's exclusive waiting list to get hold of it? And, of greatest importance to many wine buffs, what score did Robert Parker, the world's most influential wine critic, give your chosen bottle on his famed 100-point scale?

title: Indicting Honest Journalism in China
description: After holding Zhao Yan, a journalist, for 15 months without a hearing, Chinese authorities have finally drummed up an indictment. Yesterday, the last working day on which prosecutors could decide whether to go forward with the case under Chinese law, Mr. Zhao, a researcher in the Beijing bureau of The New York Times, was formally charged with revealing state secrets to the newspaper and the lesser charge of fraud. If convicted, he faces a possible minimum of 10 years' imprisonment.

title: Bible Course in Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Damon Starts Short-Haired Portion of His Career
description: With a shave and a haircut, Johnny Damon approached a lectern at Yankee Stadium yesterday and rubbed his naked chin for the cameras. If there were any remnants from his years with the Boston Red Sox, including his once-flowing locks, they were hard to find.

title: Thousands of Sunnis Protest in Baghdad, Charging Fraud in Election
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 23 - Several thousand Sunni Arabs gathered Friday in a residential neighborhood in central Baghdad to protest what they said was broad-based fraud in elections last week, in a sign of deepening Sunni discontent over the vote.

title: For Some, Just Reading a Column Isn't Enough
description: FOR my last column of the year, I'm letting a few readers have their say. Every column has elicited reaction; however the ones I assume are going to generate the biggest fuss aren't always the ones that do. Somewhat to my surprise, the strongest responses have been to my columns on computers (we can thank the Mac users for that), on hiring private nurses and on the Do Not Call registry (mainly those begging for information on a similar Do Not Fax registry.)

title: Trying to Become a Big Act on Campus
description: MARLBOROUGH, Mass. - Like many musicians, Bella Vox is also a salesman, and a good one. Onstage in front of about 1,100 college students on a recent Friday night at the Best Western Royal Plaza Trade Center here, Mr. Vox -- the lead guitarist and vocalist for the Los Angeles-based band Thornbird -- pilots the trio through its pitch: straightforward rock 'n' roll perfect for an attention-deficient 18-to-22-year-old crowd.

title: New-Home Sales Dropped Last Month
description: Sales of new homes fell in November from a record-setting pace, and the number of homes for sale reached a high, the government reported yesterday.

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Wins With Repeats
description: With the holidays looming, fewer people than usual watched television on Thursday. CBS's slate of repeats -- "Without a Trace" (8.58 million), "CSI" (18.9 million) and another "Without a Trace" (14.23 million) -- was No. 1 for the night in total viewers and adults 18 to 49. But NBC's "Deal or No Deal" continued to make a ratings impact in Nielsen's estimates. It yielded 13.42 million viewers and won the 8 p.m. hour by a wide margin. "Deal" also helped NBC score a closer-than-usual second place in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Receives U.S. Approval for Arthritis Drug
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb received federal clearance for its new drug Orencia as a treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, the company said yesterday.

title: Issues and Egos Contend in Congress's Rush to Leave
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - The end of a Congressional year is never a pretty thing. But as the Senate Democratic leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said after the Senate spent hour after hour in a mostly fruitless weekend session, "This is about as un-pretty as I've seen it."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MCGUIRE, MURIEL MARGARET
description: McGUIRE--Muriel Margaret. Dearest Mom, Merry Christmas. Remembering you through smiles and tears. Love, Sissy

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the training of Iraqi security forces by American troops carried incomplete statistics supplied by the United States military on the number of Iraqis who have been trained and equipped. (The error was repeated on Tuesday in an article about President Bush's Iraq speech on Sunday night.) There are 113,399 police officers, commandos and border enforcement workers and 103,182 soldiers -- not 75,000 police officers and 100,000 soldiers.

title: Elrod Hendricks, 64, Baltimore's Favorite Catcher and Coach
description: Elrod Hendricks, who spent nearly four decades with the Orioles as a catcher and coach and came to be revered in Baltimore for his community work and his bonds with the fans, died Wednesday night at a hospital in Glen Burnie, Md., a day before his 65th birthday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLUCCI, DR. RICHARD
description: BELLUCCI--Dr. Richard. 91, passed on December 22, after a brave battle with cancer. Survived by his wife Eleanor DePaoli, M.D. his daughter Eleanor B. Handler. Your vast contributions to healthcare will live on forever. Visitation 2-5 and 7-9 Monday, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st. Mass of Christian Burial at 10AM Tuesday, St. Patrick's Cathedral, NYC.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: HSBC to Join With Former Rival In Offering American Express Cards The British banking company HSBC Holdings said yesterday that it would offer American Express cards in the United States starting in the middle of next year, the latest bank to strike a marketing alliance with its one-time rival. Financial terms of the arrangement were not disclosed, though the impact of the new cards was expected to be negligible for HSBC in the near term. HSBC benefits by ridding itself of a potentially expensive lawsuit. American Express agreed to dismiss HSBC from its antitrust litigation against Visa, MasterCard and a number of major American banks. With HSBC, American Express now has signed up six banks in the United States. (REUTERS)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHERNIN, RHETA
description: CHERNIN - Rheta. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend, died on December 22, 2005. She was 77. Throughout her life, in deep and loving partnership with her husband Albert (who was Executive of JCPA) Mrs. Chernin worked passionately for Israel, women's and civil rights, and for Soviet Jewry. As Director of Intake at NYANA from 1975-1993, she played a major role in resettling Soviet Jewish refugees. Mrs. Chernin is survived by her husband, children Daniel and Anne, daughter-in-law Deborah Handler, and three cherished grandchildren: Arielle, Julia, and Jake. The funeral will be held 12:30, December 26 at Beth Israel Chapel, 11115 Jog Road, Boynton Beach, Florida. A memorial service to be held 3:00, January 15, at West End Synagogue, 190 Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Ghosts in the Department Store
description: WASHINGTON - Perhaps no city in America has buried more hometown department stores than this one. First it was Lansburgh's in 1972, then S. Kann Sons in 1975, Garfinckel's in 1990 and Woodward & Lothrop in 1995. Each closing, from bankruptcy or buyout, brought more grief than the last.

title: A Belgian Mystery: Rwandan Who Aided Tribunal on Genocide Is Found Dead in a Canal
description: PARIS, Dec. 23 - A former Rwandan government minister indicted on charges of genocide has been found dead, his mangled body floating in a canal in Brussels, according to the Belgian police.

title: Spy Agency Mined Vast Data Trove, Officials Report
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - The National Security Agency has traced and analyzed large volumes of telephone and Internet communications flowing into and out of the United States as part of the eavesdropping program that President Bush approved after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks to hunt for evidence of terrorist activity, according to current and former government officials.

title: Biotech Company Closes After Running Out of Cash
description: In a setback for a controversial area of biotechnology, the company that led the way in trying to produce pharmaceuticals in genetically modified crops ran out of money and shut its doors yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUDIS, LUCILLE
description: GUDIS--Lucille, 1933-2005. Beloved aunt, cousin and friend. Died peacefully December 23. Funeral service Monday 10 AM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. Information regarding donations at www.jgsny.org.

title: Korean Cloning Scientist Quits Over Report He Faked Research
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 23 - Dr. Hwang Woo Suk, the South Korean scientist whose research on stem cells and cloning propelled him to international stardom, resigned from his university on Friday, after an investigative panel there reported earlier in the day that he had fabricated the paper in which he claimed to have created stem cell colonies from 11 patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGAL, HELEN
description: SEGAL--Helen. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELAUNAY, JOAN H.
description: DELAUNAY--Joan H. On December 21, at the young age of 106. Climbed on Mt. Everest, also a model, and an antique store entrepreneur. Beloved wife of the late Max. Cherished aunt of Richard and his wife Ruth Vlock, Marsha and her husband Jay Sternin and the late Dr. David Vlock and his wife Maria. Survived by 10 great- and many great-great-nieces and nephews. Private cremation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Stress Cited In Chechnya Illnesses
description: A medical commission in Moscow blamed emotional stress for the mysterious illness that struck 85 people in six towns in Chechnya over the last week. The deputy director of the Serbsky Institute in Moscow, Suraba Kikalidze, said the illness was spread by a psychological chain reaction. Speculation on the cause of the outbreak had ranged from ethylene glycol in the water supply to attempts by the Russian authorities to reduce the population of Chechnya, where civil war and banditry have raged since 1994. RACHEL THORNER (NYT)

title: In Hong Kong, Shopping Is an Art Experience
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 23 - More than a decade ago, the French artist Jean-Michel Othoniel spent a month working in relative obscurity at the Hong Kong Art Museum, making fanciful glass creations for a group show called "Too French." This month, he became very, if not too, Hong Kong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAGNOTTA, ENRICO
description: PAGNOTTA--Enrico. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Enrico Pagnotta, associated with The Times from December 1963, until retiring in December 1982.

title: The Popular Isn't Always the Profitable
description: WHEN stock pickers are asked to name the big winners of the future, they often name winners from the recent past, whose strength makes them obvious choices. Portfolio managers tend to feel safer when they are wrapped snugly in the consensus, and they can grab a piece of the glory that comes from owning a hot stock, even if they bought it 10 minutes ago.

title: For Some, Just Reading A Column Isn't Enough
description: FOR my last column of the year, I'm letting a few readers have their say. Every column has elicited reaction; however the ones I assume are going to generate the biggest fuss aren't always the ones that do. Somewhat to my surprise, the strongest responses have been to my columns on computers (we can thank the Mac users for that), on hiring private nurses and on the Do Not Call registry (mainly those begging for information on a similar Do Not Fax registry.)

title: Capitol's Pariah on Immigration Is Now a Power
description: DENVER, Dec. 21 - For nearly a decade, Representative Tom Tancredo, Republican of Colorado, has been dismissed by his critics as little more than an angry man with a microphone, a lonely figure who rails against immigration and battles his own president and party.

title: 11 Indian Parliament Members Expelled After Bribe Sting on TV
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 23 - The Indian Parliament, no stranger to accusations of graft, on Friday took the highly unusual step of expelling 11 of its members over a televised expos of corruption.

title: A Little Respect, Please, for a High-Kicking New York Institution
description: Everyone seems to forget that Rockettes are serious dancers. As soon as the holidays roll around, they seem to be everywhere they shouldn't be -- posed seductively next to an inane weatherman as he delivers the morning forecast and then, invariably, tries to take part in a kick line, or being ridiculed by comedians on VH1's "I Love the Holidays." At the gift kiosk at Radio City Music Hall, there is even a doll version available to take home.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I apologize to the South Korean people for creating an unspeakable shock and disappointment."

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Palestinian Elections: A Place for Hamas?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Game Show for the Probabilities Theorist in Us All
description: A fascinating spectrum of both magical and strategic thinking about numbers has been on display this week on "Deal or No Deal," NBC's mind-bending nightly game show. As trembling contestants have made bird-in-the-hand gambles for high stakes, viewers have been treated to opinions about probability that range from the simple-minded to the grandiose. One man in the audience shouted, "Eight is my lucky number!" while another declaimed, "The race is not won to the swift, but he who endures to the end!"

title: Rapunzel the Rhino Is Mourned in Bronx
description: Even by the standards of Sumatran rhinoceroses -- shy, solitary creatures that spend as much time as possible nibbling leaves -- Rapunzel, the Bronx Zoo's exemplar of the species, was not especially outgoing.

title: Group Offers a 'Messiah' That Has Evolved From Victorian to Streamlined
description: Most of New York's big choirs have offered their views of Handel's "Messiah" in recent weeks, and with just one concert-going day now left before Christmas the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra's readings (on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, with a second performance scheduled for last night) are just about the last word on Handel's big oratorio, at least for this year.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 16
description: Indianapolis Colts (13-1) at Seattle Seahawks (12-2) 4:15 p.m.

title: Buying Birds for a Song? Well, Not This Year
description: Modern-day woes like avian flu and energy prices are making it more trying and costly than ever to please one's true love with gifts from the classic holiday carol "12 Days of Christmas."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, SYLVIA F.
description: KLEIN--Sylvia F. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted mother of Seena and the late Edward Parker, Maxene & Steve Greenspan. Adored Bubbie of Jeremy, Adam and Janis. Caring aunt. Pillar of the Workmen's Circle, active member of the UFT and the Forward Association. Funeral Monday, December 26, at 9:30 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and West 91st St.

title: Old Business, New Name: Behold the Gallerist
description: A fashionable new word is bubbling up in the New York art scene: gallerist, as a substitute for art dealer. Not, of course, just any art dealer. A gallerist is directly involved with the care and feeding of artists, rather than with the quick turnover of art objects.

title: National Briefings
description: MIDWEST

title: Happy Holidays (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Happy Holidays
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Arts pages on Thursday with an article about a bankruptcy filing by Berry-Hill Galleries, a Manhattan art seller, misstated the name of one of the gallery's directors. He is Frederick D. Hill, not Frederick Berry Hill.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Saturday about John Spencer, an actor on the television series "The West Wing," misidentified the author of the Off Broadway play "Still Life," for which Mr. Spencer won an Obie in 1981. It was Emily Mann, not John Byrne. (Mr. Byrne wrote a different play with the same title.)

title: Lessons From the Three-Day Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWELL, JANE
description: POWELL--Jane. Executive Director and cofounder of Shofar Synagogue in Los Angeles, passed away on Saturday, December 17, 2005 after a battle with pancreatic cancer. She had also served as Executive Director and was co-founder of the Synagogue for the Performing Arts. Born on February 28, 1937, to Samuel S. Burman and Lee Goldstein Burman, she received a journalism degree from New York University in 1958. Her husband Charles M. Powell, who passed away in 1991, was a long-time Governor and Officer of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. She is also the co-author, with Lori G. Berthelsen, of the forthcoming book "Now Playing: Original Movie Posters from the Silent Era through the 1940s." She is no relation to the actress of the same name. She is survived by one son, Mel Powell, a writer and representative of Pre-Paid Legal Services, Inc., and her beloved cats. Donations may be made to Shofar Synagogue, Los Angeles, California. Malinow and Silverman Mortuary, (800) 710-7100.

title: In This Deal, Money Was Not the Only Factor
description: JOHNNY DAMON didn't mention the Florida Marlins, but the word he used to describe the Boston Red Sox was one that has been used the past month just about any time the Marlins have been mentioned.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tightening Reins On Private Groups
description: Russia's lower house of Parliament gave final approval to legislation that would impose new government oversight for charities and other private organizations. Critics, at home and abroad, have complained that the legislation will allow the government to shut down organizations involved in political or other activities seen as critical of the Kremlin. The legislation still requires approval from the upper house, or Federation Council, and President Vladimir V. Putin's signature before becoming law. Mr. Putin has in the past vetoed controversial legislation that appeared to have Kremlin backing, but he has expressed support for the charity-oversight bill, saying it was needed to protect Russia from terrorism and foreign interference in domestic politics. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

title: Japan's Population Fell This Year, Sooner Than Expected
description: TOKYO, Dec. 23 - Japan's population declined this year for the first time since the country began keeping demographic records in 1899, according to preliminary figures released by the government this week.

title: Retailers Try, Try Again After Slow Season
description: Get ready for the Christmas shopping frenzy all over again.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on Wednesday, about New York City and suburban residents commuting by Metro-North train on the first day of the transit strike, misstated the destination of Adam Selkin, who was boarding a train at White Plains. He was headed to New York City for an appointment, not to Mount Kisco, where his office is.

title: Troubled Boys Choir of Harlem Is Facing Eviction
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem, which has long struggled with administrative and financial difficulties, is now facing homelessness.

title: Lessons From the Three-Day Strike (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: As Shoplifters Improve Game, Police Do, Too
description: WOODBURY, N.Y. - Some of them come with their wish lists and shopping carts, dragging fidgety children by the hand. Others arrive at the Woodbury Common Premium Outlets in rented limousines, drawn by the 220 brand-name outlets that have turned this discount haven about 60 miles north of New York City into one of the state's biggest attractions.

title: Home Builders and Energy Shares Put Damper on Rally
description: A year-end rally fizzled yesterday as declines in home builders and oil and gas companies left the market little changed.

title: The Neediest Cases; Keeping Her Son Going, Through Music and Love
description: Sprightly Christmas music was playing in the bright, blue-walled bedroom of the Bronx apartment, and Emmanuel Rodriguez, 21, was enjoying it, according to his mother, Eligia Borbon. She knew that he was, she said, because "if you play music he doesn't like, he screams."

title: Palestinian Elections: A Place for Hamas?
description: To the Editor:

title: Autopsy Shows Suicide in Dungy Case
description: While Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy remained in Florida yesterday with his family, an autopsy indicated that the death of his 18-year-old son, James, was a suicide.

title: Happy Holidays
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking to Improve Bench, Mets Add Chavez to the Mix
description: He does not have a scraggly beard. He does not have shoulder-length hair. And he does not have the cachet of Johnny Damon, another center fielder who has agreed to play baseball in New York.

title: Salon Set at Loose Ends by Ado Over Damon Do
description: The day after the most publicized haircut in the 14-year history of Salon Ishi, a hair salon on Manhattan's East Side, the store's manager shook his head as he tried to understand what the big deal was all about.

title: Young Ears Tune In to Theater on Radio
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Dec. 21 - As Kia and David Ramarui cleared away dinner and prepared to make Christmas cookies, they bopped along to the familiar children's songs playing from the satellite radio on their kitchen counter. The kitchen radio is a constant in their evening routine, and they rolled cookie dough while awaiting another familiar song.

title: Businesses Tally Losses From Strike
description: Businesses did business, workers worked and consumers consumed yesterday, as New York City's circulatory system of subways and buses started pumping again. But it was also a day for tallying the vast costs of three days lost to a transit strike.

title: Box-Office Shortfall Forces Cuts at the Met
description: The tourists are back. New York's economy is humming along, despite the transit-strike blip. Wall Street bonuses are running strong for the third year in a row.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (BBC America) MR. HARVEY LIGHTS A CANDLE -- Timothy Spall (right) stars in this television movie as a middle-aged school teacher supervising a class trip to Salisbury Cathedral. The students see him as ridiculously asexual and over the hill, but they soon learn that he has a romantic past, a tragic one, and the cathedral plays a part.

title: Lessons From the Three-Day Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons From the Three-Day Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Parties Set Stage for Another Turbulent Year in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - With control of Congress hanging in the balance next year, neither party will take much of a holiday break. Even as this session of Congress lurched to a fractious close, both parties were planning for an intense start to the new year, as they try to seize the political agenda for the midterm elections.

title: A Deal Is Reached in Libyan H.I.V. Case, Bulgaria Says
description: PARIS, Dec. 23 - Libya, Bulgaria, the United States and the European Union have agreed to set up a fund to support hundreds of Libyan children who were infected with H.I.V. while in the hospital, Bulgarian officials said Friday.

title: China Indicts Times Researcher, Saying He Disclosed State Secrets
description: Correction Appended

title: Sorry, Wrong Race
description: Jeanine Pirro has examined things thoroughly and concluded that her head and heart remain in law enforcement. She has given up trying to unseat Senator Hillary Clinton and will run for New York attorney general instead, bowing to pressure from fellow Republicans and the dismal reality of being stuck in a campaign without money or a pulse.

title: Irish Playwright Speaks From Hideout
description: LONDON, Dec. 23 - Gary Mitchell, a prominent Northern Irish playwright, has been forced into hiding along with his family following an attack on his Belfast home by what he called rogue paramilitary figures linked to the Protestant loyalist cause.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHARKEY, SUSAN
description: SHARKEY--Susan.December 24, 1995 Always in our thoughts. Barnett Epstein

title: Pricing of Downloaded Songs Prompts Antitrust Subpoenas
description: The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, is investigating whether the four record companies that dominate the industry have violated antitrust laws in the pricing of songs that are sold by Internet music services, according to people involved in the inquiry.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column of Business Day on Thursday about European Union regulators fining three companies for fixing the price of rubber chemicals carried an incorrect credit. It was from Bloomberg News, not Reuters.

title: Transit Union and M.T.A. Are Drawing Closer to a Contract Deal
description: Negotiators from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the transit workers' union met directly yesterday and were reported to be in agreement on a broad range of issues. A final settlement is likely to be reached by early next week, according to two people close to the negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the training of Iraqi security forces by American troops carried incomplete statistics supplied by the United States military on the number of Iraqis who have been trained and equipped. (The error was repeated on Tuesday in an article about President Bush's Iraq speech on Sunday night.) There are 113,399 police officers, commandos and border enforcement workers and 103,182 soldiers -- not 75,000 police officers and 100,000 soldiers.

title: Microsoft Quits MSNBC TV, but Web Partnership Remains
description: Ending a partnership that soured long ago, Microsoft and NBC announced yesterday that they would dissolve their joint ownership of the cable news channel MSNBC, with NBC taking control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWELLS, WILLIAM WHITE
description: HOWELLS--William White. On December 20 at home in Kittery Point, ME. Predeceased in 2002 by his wife of 73 years, Muriel Gurdon Seabury, survived by a daughter, Gurdon Metz of New York City, a son, William Dean Howells of Kittery Point, ME, four grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. A Memorial service will be held at First Congregational Church, 23 Pepperell Road in Kittery Point, ME on December 29 at 11:00AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Strabery Banke Museum, Box 300, Portsmouth, NH 03802-0300, or The Hooton Fund, C/O Harvard Development Office, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA. 02138.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Date Set for 'Survivor' Winner's Trial

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELGOROD, HOWARD H.
description: BELGOROD--Howard H. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and long time friend, Howard Belgorod and send condolences to his family.

title: Ex-Powell Aide Moves From Insider to Apostate
description: WASHINGTON - IT was in early 2004, the beginning of President Bush's re-election campaign, that Lawrence B. Wilkerson first printed out a letter saying he wanted to quit as chief of staff for Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.

title: Arts, Briefly; Fire at Russian Palace
description: Part of the Peterhof palace complex, below, built by Peter the Great outside St. Petersburg, Russia, caught fire on Thursday afternoon, Interfax reported. The site, known as the Farm Palace, was completed in honor of Czar Alexander II in 1830 and consists of 43 main rooms in neo-Gothic style. Restoration was in progress when the blaze began, but most of the historical objects inside had been removed, a spokesman for the palace museum said. No one was injured. PAUL SONNE

title: 'The Baddest Good Guy You'd Ever Seen'
description: Benny Binion, the man who created the World Series of Poker 35 years ago, was born Lester Ben Binion in Pilot Grove, Tex., in 1904. He spent his youth punching cattle, trading horses and sitting on the fringes of card games. Starting with $56 he saved in the Depression, he began his own numbers racket, a kind of neighborhood lottery, netting $800 his first week in business. From numbers he branched into dice, running craps games in the shadow of the Dallas courthouse for, among others, H. L. Hunt and Howard Hughes.

title: Confronting the Demon Within, and Other Good Fun
description: Video games often contain a battle between two sides but in Ubisoft's Prince of Persia: The Two Thrones, the main battle is not between the prince and the demon hordes he fights but between the good and evil within himself.

title: A Lone G.O.P. Senator, Unknown, Holds Up an Intelligence Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - An unidentified Republican senator has blocked the authorization bill that sets guidance for all intelligence spending, and the measure must now wait for Congress to return next month from recess, Congressional officials said Friday.

title: 3 Shot, One Fatally, On Jersey City Street
description: A gunman on a Jersey City street opened fire shortly before 9 p.m. yesterday, killing one person and wounding two others, investigators and witnesses said.

title: Files Show Guidant Foresaw Some Risks
description: Officials of the Guidant Corporation projected in an internal report that some patients might die as a result of short circuits in a company heart device, but it did not publicize the flaw because it apparently viewed the overall failure rate as acceptable, company records filed in connection with a lawsuit show.

description: Correction Appended

description: To the Editor:

title: Gibbs Has Redskins Peaking Again
description: ASHBURN, Va., Dec. 21 - Joe Gibbs enjoys this time of year, and not just because of the holidays.

title: Lost for the Holidays
description: SHE was 6 or 7 that year, and if memory served (sometimes it did and sometimes it didn't, all the clichs about old age being as dishearteningly accurate as they were), it was a particularly cold Christmas Eve in the city.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: New Rescue Vessel In The Works
description: The navy announced that it was set to begin construction of a new naval rescue vessel, whose need was highlighted in August when Russia was unable to save a disabled naval submarine by itself. The new vessel, to be constructed in St. Petersburg, is to be delivered by 2010, Vladimir Masorin, the navy's commander in chief, told Interfax. Its keel is expected to be laid today. Russia's dearth of high-seas rescue equipment was evident in August when a small rescue submarine became entangled off its Pacific coast. Unable to free the vessel alone, the navy called for American and British help, and an unmanned British rescue vehicle was able to save the submarine and its seven-man crew. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Transit Strike Reflects Nationwide Pension Woes
description: Fast-rising pension costs for government employees -- the issue that helped set off this week's transit strike in New York City -- are a problem confronting cities, counties and states nationwide, causing many budgetary experts to predict a wave of painful fights over efforts to scale back government retirement programs.

title: In Britain and Elsewhere, to Cringe, It Seems, Is to Enjoy
description: LONDON, Dec. 19 - It is once again that time of the year when leading British actors camp around onstage dressed as bossy old women telling risqu jokes, while leggy actresses wear tights to portray sweet princes. Yes, for many Britons, Christmas means a peculiar celebration of bad taste known as the pantomime. To cringe, it seems, is to enjoy.

title: Peace on Earth, and Goodwill for Toys
description: Rebecca Nienkamper has a holiday role to play, and she does it with no regrets.

title: Insider Editing at Wikipedia
description: THE debate over Wikipedia has hit a fever pitch in recent weeks.

title: R.& D. Under the Microscope
description: THE idea that the more you spend on research and development the more breakthroughs result is accepted in boardrooms and executive suites, heralded in Washington -- and wrong.

title: Israel Says Its Attacks Aim to Build Anti-Rocket Buffer
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 23 - Frustrated by continuing rocket fire from Gaza, the territory Israel evacuated over the summer, Israel is trying to enforce a buffer zone in northern Gaza through air and artillery strikes, a deputy defense minister, Zeev Boim, said Friday.

title: Doctors' Delicate Balance in Keeping Hope Alive
description: Dr. Joseph Sacco's young patient lay gasping for breath; she had advanced AIDS and now she was failing.

description: FOR my last column of the year, I'm letting a few readers have their say. Every column has elicited reaction; however the ones I assume are going to generate the biggest fuss aren't always the ones that do. Somewhat to my surprise, the strongest responses have been to my columns on computers (we can thank the Mac users for that), on hiring private nurses and on the Do Not Call registry (mainly those begging for information on a similar Do Not Fax registry.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBIN, LAWRENCE
description: LUBIN--Lawrence. 75 years old, on December 22, 2005, of Englewood, N.J. Beloved husband of Ellie. Devoted father of Miriam Bloom (Alan) and Jay Lubin (Francie). Loving grandfather of Matthew, Adam and Jeffrey and loving brother of Melvin and Edward. Larry was a retired Actuary. He waged a 54 year battle against the effects of polio, always with an optimistic attitude. In spite of his handicap, he worked and was a tireless volunteer-tutoring youngsters in the Bronx, working for years with cancer victims to gain benefits for them. He chaired the Tenants-Landlord Commission in Englewood and was an active member of Englewood's Board of Education. The funeral will be at GuttermanMusicant, Passaic and Park Streets in Hackensack, New Jersey at 12:30 P.M. on Monday, December 26.

title: Congress Never Authorized Spying Effort, Daschle Says
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - Tom Daschle, the South Dakota Democrat who was Senate majority leader at the time of the Sept. 11 attacks, has disputed a central element of the administration's case for its eavesdropping program: that Congress implicitly authorized spying on Americans when it endorsed granting President Bush broad power in 2001 to combat terrorism.

description: FOR my last column of the year, I'm letting a few readers have their say. Every column has elicited reaction; however the ones I assume are going to generate the biggest fuss aren't always the ones that do. Somewhat to my surprise, the strongest responses have been to my columns on computers (we can thank the Mac users for that), on hiring private nurses and on the Do Not Call registry (mainly those begging for information on a similar Do Not Fax registry.)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about plans for federal monitoring of the finances of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, so it can avoid a federal prosecution for Medicaid fraud, misidentified the facility accused of overbilling. The allegations concern University Hospital in Newark, not the university's New Brunswick campus, which was shown in the picture.

title: Man in Fake-Firefighter Case Is Indicted in Sexual Assault
description: Peter Braunstein, the freelance writer suspected of posing as a firefighter in an Oct. 31 sex assault in Chelsea, has been indicted in the attack, a prosecutor said yesterday, and his lawyer suggested that he might not be mentally fit to stand trial.

title: Lessons From the Three-Day Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: School That Gave Easy Grades to Athletes Is Closing
description: University High School, a correspondence school in Miami being investigated for giving fast, high grades to qualify high school athletes for college scholarships, is going out of business Dec. 31, its founder, Stanley J. Simmons, said yesterday.

title: House Prices: The State of the Bubble
description: Richard A. Smith figured out how to make to make money in the real estate business early in his adult life. He bought his first home for $39,000 in the Atlanta area in 1979, selling it a year later for $43,000, the first of several transactions that he said made him "nothing more than a good student of the industry."

title: Doctors' Delicate Balance in Keeping Hope Alive
description: Dr. Joseph Sacco's young patient lay gasping for breath; she had advanced AIDS and now she was failing.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Google Will Have the Right to Sell Its 5% Stake in AOL by 2008
description: Google will have the right to sell its new 5 percent stake in America Online as soon as July 1, 2008, according to regulatory filings yesterday by both Google and Time Warner, AOL's parent.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Uzbekistan: Interior Minister Resigns
description: Col. Gen. Zakirdzhon Almatov, Uzbekistan's interior minister and one of the officials implicated in the lethal crackdown in May in the city of Andijon, has retired from his post for health reasons, news agencies reported. Until recently, General Almatov had been undergoing cancer treatment in Germany, where he had arrived before the European Union placed him on a no-visa list for his role in the crackdown. He returned to Uzbekistan this week. Survivors of the crackdown, who say hundreds of unarmed people were killed by troops, many under General Almatov's command, had urged Germany to try him for crimes against humanity. Uzbekistan has given him its highest commendation, the Distinguished Service Order, Interfax reported. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Bringing the Holiday Spirit to Students Far From Home
description: Jake Ford, a 9-year-old, spent last Christmas Day in upstate New York setting up a Lego set in front of a Christmas tree with the help of five visiting college men from different parts of the world, from Nepal to South Africa. A Canadian student at Yeshiva University will make it home to Toronto for Hanukkah, but when she could not get home for Purim or Thanksgiving, she joined dozens of others at a Manhattan dinner given by the dean of students and his wife.

title: Swaziland Accuses 13 Party Members in Firebombings
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 23 - Beset by mounting economic and political tensions, Swaziland's absolute monarchy has accused 13 members of a banned opposition party of firebombing government targets this year as part of a terrorism campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TWHIGG, JAMES SIMON
description: TWHIGG--James Simon. Of Hudson, NY formerly of New York City, native of New Zealand died December 20 at the Albany Medical Center. He is survived by his son Tan Twhigg, brother John Twhigg and sister Mary - Louise Robertson. Donations are suggested for the Catholic Worker at 36 East 1st Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: They Gather to Remember Mama
description: GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL. Christmas 1985.

title: A Different Latin America
description: Bolivia's recent presidential election was almost as history making as Iraq's parliamentary vote. The winner, Evo Morales, will be the first member of the indigenous majority to run Bolivia since the conquistadors arrived nearly five centuries ago. His victory was one of the most decisive since the return of democracy more than two decades ago, ending an era of weak, unstable and ineffective governments.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Christmas is legally observed.

title: Lessons From the Three-Day Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Is Charged in Murder of a Dancer From Ohio
description: An acquaintance of a dancer from Ohio found slain in her Upper East Side apartment last month was charged yesterday in her murder.

title: Ford Puts Up More Money to Aid Jaguar
description: The Ford Motor Company has invested 1.2 billion ($2.1 billion) in its unprofitable Jaguar unit to help pay for a reorganization at the luxury-car division.

title: $29 Billion Package Buoys Hopes for Rebuilding Effort
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 - With a sober Christmas settling in on this still-battered region, the $29 billion relief package Congress sent the Gulf Coast this week provided some moderate holiday cheer, regional leaders agreed on Friday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Revisiting A Wartime Legacy
description: Touching upon a problem that has aggravated relations with Asian neighbors this year, Emperor Akihito stressed the importance of accurately understanding Japan's wartime legacy in a news conference to mark his 72nd birthday. Saying that the period from 1927 to 1945 was "rarely peaceful," the emperor added in comments shown on television: "I believe it is very important for the people of Japan to strive to accurately understand this past history as well as the times that followed. And this is also important when the Japanese people interact with the people of the world." With nationalism rising in Japan, an increasing number of academics, media critics and politicians have tried to minimize Japan's military aggression in Asia. New junior high school textbooks omit or play down Japanese wartime atrocities. NORIMITSU ONISHI (NYT)

title: Widespread Radioactivity Monitoring Is Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - The F.B.I. and the Energy Department have conducted thousands of searches for radioactive materials at private sites around the country in the last three years, government officials confirmed on Friday.

title: Taking the Party Approach Far Beyond Tupperware
description: Move over Tupperware and Mary Kay. Food, gadgets, candles, baskets, jewelry, pet products, scrapbook supplies, clothing and toys are now crowding kitchen tables of home-based entrepreneurs, just waiting to be sold at intimate parties of family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GLICKSMAN, ALBERT. ALY
description: GLICKSMAN--Albert. Aly, Happy Anniversary on the 24th, Merry Christmas on the 25th, and Happy Birthday on the 26th. Love, Fran

title: Offering Up an Even Dozen Odds and Ends
description: YOU know those columns sportswriters dash off as they're heading to vacation -- the ones that start with "thoughts while cleaning up my desk?" I wonder what a business version of that kind of column would be like

title: You Think Your Train Is Crowded?
description: Riders who flooded the subways yesterday after a 60-hour strike ended were, perhaps unknown to them, helping celebrate a special anniversary underground. In the annals of New York City transit history, Dec. 23 holds a special place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RENICK, THEODORE M. ''TED''
description: RENICK--Theodore M. "Ted". Age 79 of Centerville, and Boca Raton, FL. Entered into rest December 22, 2005. Beloved husband of Jacqueline "Jackie" (Zekind). Devoted father of Jamie Elias and her husband Howard, Bruce Renick and his companion Jodie Berro. Loving poppy of Caroline, Jordana Elias, and Sydney Renick. Dear brother of the late Charles Renick. Services at The Falmouth Jewish Congregation, 7 Hatchville Road, E. Falmouth, Monday, December 26 at 12 Noon. Memorial observance will be at his late residence following interment until Monday afternoon, and Wednesday and Thursday at Jamie and Howard's residence. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in his memory may be made to Patient to Patient, Heart to Heart c/o Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Office of Development, 330 Brookline Avenue, GZ-216, Boston, MA. 02215.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPEAR, ESTHER (NEE MARCUS)
description: SPEAR--Esther (nee Marcus) On December 21, 2005, 107 years old, in Providence, R.I. Loving wife of the late Alfred Spear, proud mother of Harvey M. of New York, L. William of Miami, FL. and Dr. Gerald S. of Newport Beach, CA. and the late Evelyn and Arthur, and her daughters-inlaw Ruth, Shirley and Ilene, loving aunt of Dorris, Sandra and Jerome. Much loved and survived by 13 devoted grandchildren, 24 great grandchildren and one greatgreat-granddaughter. Funeral services will be at Temple Emanuel, corner of Sessions Street and Morris Avenue, Providence, R.I. on Moday at 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alfred and Esther Spear Fund at the Miriam Hospital, 164 Summit Ave, Providence, R.I. 02906.

title: Luring Youth to the Card Table
description: Why are there not more young people playing bridge in this country?

title: Homeless for Over a Century, a Tribe Awaits U.S. Redemption
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont. - Here at the base of a rise called Hill 57, a steady, cold wind blows on a cloudless day as James Parker Shield and Russ Boham tell of life for the landless Little Shell Tribe of Chippewa Indians.

title: Hey, W., It's Safe! Read This.
description: WASHINGTON - As a Christmas present for our president, who's been going through a rough time lately, I'm not writing the column this Christmas Eve.
