description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a Texas school district's adopting a course published by the National Council on Bible Curriculum in Public Schools for studying the Bible in history and literature misstated the position of Focus on the Family, a conservative Christian group. Focus on the Family has not endorsed the council or its Bible curriculum.

title: Giants Will Go as Far as Manning Can Lead Them
description: Eli Manning had completed another successful midweek media session, appearing insightful while revealing little about his team or himself.

title: Lessons From the Three-Day Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Balanchine's 'Nutcracker' as a Test for Leading Men
description: The leading man in George Balanchine's "Nutcracker" doesn't have a name; he is simply the Cavalier, who appears right at the end of the ballet to partner the Sugar Plum Fairy in a beautiful pas de deux set to some of Tchaikovsky's most elegiac and haunting ballet music. But even though the Cavalier is onstage only briefly, he is important -- the embodiment of the ballet tradition that offers a modestly virtuosic man showing off his radiant ballerina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISNER, BERNARD
description: WEISNER--Bernard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard Weisner, associated with The Times from October 1969, until retiring in January 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VIETOR, ANNA GLEN BUTLER
description: VIETOR--Anna Glen Butler. On December 20, 2005 at home. She is survived by her six children, David, Richard, Alexander W., Anna Louise Vietor Oliver, Pauline Vietor Sheehan, and Martha Vietor Glass, 23 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. Her husband, Alexander Orr Vietor, and a seventh child, Barbara Foster Vietor, predeceased her. Born 1917 in New York, she was the daughter of the late Arthur Wellman and Anna Robinson Butler, and a member of the class of 1935 at Chapin School. A descendant of several of New Yorks oldest families, she was presented at court to King George VI in 1937. A noted philanthropist with a particular interest in history, education, culture, and beautification, she served on the boards of numerous organizations. As president of The Acorn Foundation, she produced award-winning documentary films. She received many honors and awards including the Order of the Orange-Nassau by Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands in recognition of her efforts to promote pre-colonial Dutch history. A funeral service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York City on January 3 at 11 AM. Flowers welcome.

title: Rejected Bidder Raises Offer for a Canadian Steel Maker
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 23 - The steel maker Arcelor said Friday that it will raise its hostile bid for the Canadian company Dofasco Inc. to $4.17 billion, hoping to derail an accepted offer from ThyssenKrupp.

title: Lessons From the Three-Day Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Alito's Zeal for Presidential Power
description: With the Bush administration claiming sweeping and often legally baseless authority to detain and spy on people, judges play a crucial role in underscoring the limits of presidential power. When the Senate begins hearings next month on Judge Samuel Alito, President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, it should explore whether he understands where the Constitution sets those limits. New documents released yesterday provide more evidence that Judge Alito has a skewed view of the allocation of power among the three branches -- skewed in favor of presidential power.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Dog Sees God" and "Mrs. Warren's Profession."

title: Tsunamis Troubled Legacy
description:
A year after the deadly tsunami in Asia, squabbles
over aid combined with a history of recrimination have so worsened the conflict that Sri Lanka
seems closer to war than ever.

title: More Food for Dumbo
description: If youve been away, like the subject of The Hunt this week, you might not know that Dumbo is the hippest old-new place in New York.

title: Revelations in New York
description: Yuki Endo, born with a rare disorder, has formed an extended family with people he meets on his explorations.

title: South Africas Poor Protest
description: Sprawling shantytowns have begun to erupt, sometimes violently, in protest over the governments inability to deliver the better life that the end of apartheid seemed to herald.

title: Trust and the Voting Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Cereal Hero
description: They are never far from us, the cereal mascots of our youth. Years after we've given up loops and pebbles and puffs, last tipped the pink-tinged sludge from the bottom of a bowl into our mouths, still we can see them. Surely they hang out together at the end of Saturday-morning cartoon duty, when the inevitable Bowlers for Dollars have taken over the airwaves. Picture it: some sugar-lighted lounge. Jingles on the juke. Marshmallow bar stools. No kids allowed, ever.

title: Nevada tops UCF after kick sails wide
Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, SOLOMON
description: MILLER--Solomon. Died December 9, 2005. Buried on his 97th birthday in the Star of David Cemetery in Fort Lauderdale. Survived by his daughters, Evelene Wechsler of East Hampton and New York City & Louise Bressler of Fort Lauderdale, five grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. We celebrate a life well lived.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Christmas is legally observed.

title: Is It the Season to Sell? Some Say Yes
description: JUST as Nandi Wesley, a New Jersey real estate agent, was settling into the rocking chair in the living room of a tidy three-bedroom colonial for sale in Verona, a fire truck passed by with its siren blaring and Santa in the cherry picker. The old guy was waving grandly and tossing candy canes to dozens of neighborhood children who had rushed outside.

title: Tune In Next Week (but Log on Tomorrow)
description: WHILE stand-alone procedural dramas like "CSI," "Without a Trace" and "House" are the backbone of the Nielsen Top 20, this year it was shows like "Lost," "Prison Break," and "24" that incited the most fervor in their audiences. Those series -- with their baffling conspiracies, multifaceted plots and breathless tempos -- required an unusual degree of commitment from viewers. To keep them engaged, or to reward their engagement, the networks use podcasts and episodes on mobile phones to seed discussions on message boards and fan Web sites, those global equivalents of water-cooler conversations.

title: A Giant Among Giants
description: Almost everything about Wellington Mara was old-fashioned, starting with his name. Who anymore names a child after the Duke of Wellington?

description: DAVID LETTERMAN

title: Audit Focus Turns To Water Districts
description: After finding mismanagement and a poor financial controls in several sanitary districts in Nassau County earlier this year, Howard Weitzman, the county comptroller, announced last Monday that he intended to expand his investigation of special districts.

title: You've Opened the Gift. Now Give It a Review.
description: THE wads of wrapping paper are scattered about, the dog is chewing on the discarded bows and you are trying to decide what to keep and what to return. You may have received the gifts you wanted, but are they the best brand, make and model for the money? Does the type of coffeemaker you received from Aunt Ethel tend to leak? Will that digital television from your children turn out to be a lemon? You may want to check the Internet.

title: USUFRUCT
description: WITH Hurricane Katrina, the nation was served up a healthy portion of Louisiana's linguistic jambalaya -- English and Creole, Cajun and French, all tossed together. While it probably soon became clear that a parish is akin to a county, one word that may have caused a lot of head-scratching is usufruct. Don't worry. Most New Orleanians have no idea what it is either.

title: Brazil Opens Former Dictatorship's Files, a Bit
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 23 - Bowing to domestic and international pressure, the Brazilian government has begun releasing intelligence files compiled by the former military dictatorship on government opponents, including victims of torture and those who disappeared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCELWAIN, RUTH
description: McELWAIN--Ruth. 81, aka Beverly Gray, died on December 8, at Holy Cross Hospital, Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Ruth was known for her singing for over 30 years and an advocate for animal rights. Burial at Locust Valley, NY

title: From Buxom Barbarians To Union County's History
description: THE Illustrated History of Union County" is proving to be a lifelong labor of love for Frank Thorne.

title: Three Tyrants, One Test
description: Washington - PRESIDENT BUSH'S "freedom agenda" rests on the idea that promoting democracy abroad is crucial to fighting terrorism. In his view, if democracy can spread to stagnant authoritarian states in the Middle East and elsewhere, it will undercut the roots of Islamic jihadism and other forms of violent political radicalism.

title: Risque Display Sets Off Debate Over Decency in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me. - Felicia Stockford thought the lure of "naughty office girl" costumes, $2 thong underwear and X-rated gadgets probably was not enough to draw customers into her lingerie store, Spellbound.

title: A Town's Growing Pains
description: WOOLWICH TOWNSHIP - JOE CHILA grew up in Gibbstown, a cramped working-class industrial town on the Delaware River in Gloucester County. He was on the championship wrestling team at Paulsboro High School, and went on to become an electrician.

title: Educational Auteur
description: Even though Sy Wexler's name does not appear in most standard histories of American film, the chances are good that if you attended an American elementary school sometime in the last half-century or so, his work belongs to your primal movie-watching memories -- the metal cart being rolled into the classroom, the white screen pulled down over a blackboard behind the teacher's desk, the hiss and whirr of the 16-millimeter projector.

description: To the Editor

title: Since 1938, Many Have Come for the Stamps
description: BETHLEHEM, Conn., Dec. 23 - There's a crche on the town green, a local convent that inspired a classic holiday film, a deli named Little Town and a Church of the Nativity. But what makes this tiny, rural enclave in Litchfield County "Christmas Town" is its beloved post office.

title: First the Audiences Shrank. Now It's the Studios' Turn.
description: LOS ANGELES - AS the number of people going to the movies shrunk in 2005, so did some of the studios making them. That contraction is resulting in reduced horizons in midsize companies, from Revolution Studios, created by Joe Roth five years ago, to Miramax, once the towering totem of the arthouse movie world, now reduced to an operational budget half its former size by Disney, its parent company.

title: 'Condi vs. Hillary'
Knowing When to Fold
description: Before he became a Japanese national treasure, Akira Yoshizawa was a devout pauper peddling preserved fish door to door to sustain his love of folding small squares of paper into the shapes of flying dragons, butterflies and peacocks. A mercurial pixie with fierce eyes, childlike and quick-tempered, Yoshizawa, who never had children of his own, liked to say he regarded his paper models as his offspring. In photographs, you can see him cradling his origami in his hands and beaming like a proud father.

title: Easing the Way When the Spirit Is Willing
description: ONE month before Christmas, the doors of Ridgebury Congregational Church in Ridgefield opened a little wider.

title: U.S., Citing Abuse in Iraqi Prisons, Holds Detainees
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 - The commander of American-run prisons in Iraq says the military will not turn over any detainees or detention centers to Iraqi jailers until American officials are satisfied that the Iraqis are meeting United States standards for the care and custody of detainees.

title: What Can Happen When a Seller of Artworks Plays Curator
description: New Rochelle - IF there is one negative aspect to the visual arts environment in the New York region, it is in the exhibitions organized by commercial gallery dealers to take place in educational or nonprofit spaces. It may be difficult for regional museums to raise capital for their exhibition programs, or to get serious loans, but ethical lines can sometimes be blurred when dealers play curator.

title: Pope calls for peace in Middle East
A Favorite Survives Tinkering
description: FOR over a quarter-century, no list of the Island's top restaurants was complete without La Pace in Glen Cove. Last June, it was sold to Michael Mossallam, who had been the executive chef at the North Hempstead Country Club in Port Washington for 19 years. He has updated the dcor and menu and renamed his new venture La Pace With Chef Michael.

title: HOLD THAT PENSION
description: The Alberto-Culver Company says its chairman, Carol L. Bernick, and its chief executive, Howard B. Bernick, who is her husband, are old enough to retire, according to their employment contracts, although they are only 53. Even so, if they follow the lead of Mrs. Bernick's parents, they could stick around for several more decades.

title: Analyzing Union's Agreement, Marvin Miller Drops the Gloves
description: Since the ratification of a collective bargaining agreement last summer, N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman has often referred to a new partnership between the owners and the players union.

title: Religion and Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: Correction Appended

title: Swagger-Free, but Still Kicking and So Very French
description: AS Jean-Bernard Levy tells it, the lure of being the chief executive of Vivendi Universal is quite simply the opportunity to revive a French industrial legend with a history going back some 150 years. But reminders of the latter-day Vivendi saga -- more sorry than storied -- have a way of popping up every now and then.

title: Paperback Row
description: VILLAGES, by John Updike. (Ballantine, $14.95.) One of America's most eloquent and sincerely raunchy novelists presents a sexual retrospective on the life of Owen Mackenzie, a retired software engineer now living in a cozy Connecticut village. The story begins with a typical day in Owen's life, then doubles back to show his small-town youth, his college years at M.I.T. and his affluent middle age. Through his hero's libidinous adventures, Updike creates a portrait of the sexual revolution. "Villages," our reviewer, Walter Kirn, said, "gratifies in every way."

title: Unfinished Business
description: George Pataki has built a progressive record on environmental issues. His stewardship of the recent agreement involving seven Northeastern states to limit greenhouse gases is only the latest in a long string of accomplishments. But this otherwise solid record will remain incomplete unless he can win Senate approval of three excellent measures that nearly everyone except a small band of Republicans, including the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, seems to want.

title: These Meals, The Critics Would Buy Themselves
description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

title: Pride and Prejudice
description: February 1941, Constance Baker, age 19, a bright and ambitious young woman from New Haven, left home for college. She was slender and stylish, wearing a wool overcoat with a fur collar and black leather gloves. Her dark wavy hair fell from under a slanted wide-brimmed hat. She'd found a hometown mentor -- a white philanthropist named Clarence Blakeslee --who had heard her speak up at a community meeting and subsequently offered to pay her tuition. Despite the fact that female lawyers were rare creatures, and black women lawyers almost unheard-of, Constance Baker had set her sights on law school.

title: Bryant Park: On Frozen Pond
description: There's still time to try out Bryant Park's temporary ice skating rink, the Pond, which is open through Jan. 16. Afterward you can enjoy a fondue or hot chocolate at its companion restaurant, the Ice Cafe, or head to one of these other local places.

title: A different Latin America
The Year That Games Discovered Their Star Power
description: THE history of movie-based video games has not been a pretty one. Since the disastrous sales of the 1983 game "E. T. the Extra-Terrestrial" almost drove Atari into bankruptcy, it has been common knowledge that movie-license games are cheap quickies designed purely to capitalize on a film's publicity.

title: Bucharest: A Checkered Past Adds Intrigue to a Bohemian City
description: FOR a solid week storms saturated Bucharest. On the first day of relief, I put away my foul weather gear, joined the young, chicly dressed Romanians who had just emerged on Calea Victoriei, the city's main artery, and set out to enjoy the architectural treasure chest that is the Romanian capital.

title: The Heir Apparent
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fatal Car Crash After Fatal Shooting
description: A car with two men who were believed to be fleeing a fatal shooting at a popular late-night Hartford pizza parlor collided with a second car early yesterday, killing the second car's driver, the Hartford police said.

title: Hey, Stranger, Share a Taxi? Not Today
description: For three days last week, New York City was one big small town, the sort of place where people talk to strangers, ask them where they are headed and invite them along for a taxicab ride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLUCCI, DR. RICHARD
description: BELLUCCI--Dr. Richard. 91, passed on December 22, after a brave battle with cancer. Survived by his wife Eleanor DePaoli, M.D. his daughter Eleanor B. Handler. Your vast contributions to healthcare will live on forever. Visitation 2-5 and 7-9 Monday, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st. Mass of Christian Burial at 10AM Tuesday, St. Patrick's Cathedral, NYC.

title: Leaving Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES - SIA KATE ISOBELLE FURLER is a very needy girl. "I was craving a bit of attention on me, so I was going to say it was my birthday tonight," she said with a sly smile. "But really, it's not for two weeks, and that's silly."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGAL, HELEN (NEE VERBY)
description: SEGAL--Helen (nee Verby). Our dear sister, who lived her life with grace and style, and always did it her way. We will forever cherish her memory and the many years we shared together. Marjorie and Stanley

title: lamos, Mexico
description: WHY GO NOW -- lamos is always sleepy. That's one of its biggest charms. But winter in lamos, a small Mexican town, brings a hint of excitement in the air. It's when snowbirds from the United States join the locals in occupying the cobblestone streets, the casual restaurants and the restored 18th-century colonial haciendas. It's also when sunny days bring temperatures that hover between 70 and 80, then dip into the 40's at night, perfect for snuggling up in front of the fireplace at an inn. Late January has the added buzz of the Alfonso Ortiz Tirado Festival, a 10-day affair that begins Jan. 20 and brings live orchestral, piano, choir and dance performances to town in honor of the late tenor and lamos native, Dr. Alfonso Ortiz Tirado.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NIERENBERG, YVETTE
description: NIERENBERG--Yvette. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother of Stuart (Carol) and the late Marilyn (Daniel) Nierenberg-Shaoul and loving grandmother of Katherine and Pamela Shaoul, passed away December 23, in Scottsdale. Graveside service at Riverside Cemetery (201843-7600), Saddle Brook, NJ, 10:30 am, Monday, December 26. Memorial service will be held in Scottsdale in January.

title: How Christmas Became Merry
description: IN 1809, under the pseudonym Diedrich Knickerbocker, Washington Irving published "Knickerbocker's History of New York." In this book-length parody of colonial America, Irving took much glee in satirizing the early Dutch settlers of New York and their traditions, including their patron saint, Nicholas, whom they referred to as Sancte Claus. But in doing so, he also created a Christmas tradition.

title: Jacqueline Didier and Noah Scheinfeld
description: Jacqueline Marie Didier and Dr. Noah Simeon Scheinfeld were married on Friday at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony.

title: Art for Non-Art-Lovers' Sake
description: ANYBODY can make a documentary about art that will appeal to art lovers. The filmmakers behind "Imagining America: Icons of 20th-Century American Art" were striving for something more difficult: a film that would interest the uninitiated as well, conveying why Georgia O'Keeffe, Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol and other artistic giants of the last century are relevant to everyone.

title: A Multicultural Sampler
description: NEWARK - ALJIRA, an alternative art space in Newark, is one of New Jersey's most progressive cultural sites. In addition to promoting diversity and inclusiveness, it is host to an annual sampler exhibition of emerging and under-represented artists called "Emerge." An independent curator and critic, Lilly Wei, has organized this year's installment, the sixth.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Park Avenue Co-op $1,200,000 MANHATTAN: 10 Park Avenue (at 34th Street), #18K A 1,001-square-foot two-bedroom, two-bath co-op. Eileen Shannon (646) 442-9865 or Robert Barry (646) 442-9384, Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy; www.cbhk.com MAINTENANCE: $1,092 a month PROS: The renovation is classic, with crown and baseboard moldings, high-end appliances in the kitchen, through-the-wall air-conditioners and closet organizers. The building allows pieds--terre and has a flexible sublet policy. CONS: The kitchen, while well equipped, is a narrow galley, and there is no dining room.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 25, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Mr. Shtick
description: Every weekday at 10 a.m. for more than 30 years, the comedian Gene Baylos left his West 56th Street apartment for his daily walk to the Friars Club. Sonny, his building's doorman, was the first to see the day's comic routine. The walk took a good two hours, because Baylos made stops along the way. Sometimes he would visit Raphael Serrur at his jewelry store on 57th and entertain the customers. Other times, he'd go chat with Kim at Simon Lock and Key, or go to a men's clothing store where he would joke with the clerk. On the way home, at 2:30, he would deliver a sandwich to a homeless man he knew, and each winter Baylos made sure the man had a coat. One day, a friend accompanied Baylos and offered to bring the homeless man some hand-me-downs. "Get your own bum," Baylos said.

title: Tiny Airport Rm (With Amenities)
description: A hotel room that barely allows you to stretch doesn't immediately evoke thoughts of richness, but the plans for two London hotels seek "the airline business class experience at affordable prices," according to the co-founders, Simon Woodroffe, who started the Yo! Sushi bar, and Gerard Greene. Mr. Woodroffe came up with the idea for Yotel after being upgraded on a flight, and he has transformed that concept into a capsule-style hotel. The first Yotel hotels will open in mid-2006 at two airports: 40 cabins at Heathrow's Terminal 4, and 50 at Gatwick's South Terminal.

title: These Meals, The Critics Would Buy Themselves
description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

title: Having Fun. Wish You Were Here, and Here.
description: "RIGHT now I have two suitcases open in the living room, kind of blocking the entrance," Simona Petrova said as she prepared for her family's year-end vacation, "and as I decide what I'm taking, I drop things in the Miami or the London suitcase."

title: A Historic Name, Now in VW's Fold
description: BEFORE World War II, the elegant cars of Bugatti, some of them with hood ornaments in the form of a rearing elephant, were prized by wealthy customers. More recently, collectors have bid models like the Type 41 Royale to high seven-figure prices at classic-car auctions.

title: Iraqi Court Bars at Least 90 Candidates for Parliament
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 24 - An Iraqi court has ordered that at least 90 candidates in the recent national elections are disqualified from serving in the Iraqi Parliament because of their ties to Saddam Hussein's Baath Party. The head of Iraq's electoral commission, Adel al-Lami, said at a news conference here Saturday afternoon that the commission would abide by the court's ruling.

title: Most Unusual 'Messiah': 'Hallelujah,' With Inmates and Casinos
description: Early scenes in William Klein's film "Messiah," with throngs of people moving in fast-forward urban lockstep and wasted technology littering the landscape, may raise fears of something like Godfrey Reggio's 1983 paean to primitivism, "Koyaanisqatsi." For those unpersuaded by what seemed a simplistic message, that film's overriding virtue was a brilliant score by Philip Glass, laid seamlessly onto the action.

description: THERE is likely to be little economic or corporate news to occupy investors' attention in this holiday week, so anyone looking to escape from the family or the stores may have to look into January.

Mohammed Ali Hamadi, who was captured two years later and imprisoned in Germany, was released last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDSMAN, EDA
description: LANDSMAN--Eda, 84, of East Elmhurst, NY. Beloved wife of Sol for 65 years, devoted mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Nani-you will be forever in our hearts. Donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1775 Broadway, Ste 300, NY, NY 10019

title: Another Chapter for the Sutton Hotel
description: THE Sutton Hotel at 330 East 56th Street has been evolving since it opened in 1929. It has been a residence for young adults hoping to make it in the big city, a refuge for literary notables, quarters for Europe-bound World War II soldiers and, more recently, an extended-stay hotel for the rich and famous.

title: The Debunker
description: Philip J. Klass belonged to the small and somewhat peculiar class of individuals known as debunkers. The part of that word to focus on is bunk, short for bunkum, which is what these types attack with vigor and all the obsessiveness of the bunkum spreaders themselves. The most celebrated living debunker is James Randi, a magician also known as The Amazing Randi, who first gained fame for challenging the psychic Uri Geller's claims that he could use his mind to bend spoons -- and then won a "genius award" from the MacArthur Foundation for his ceaseless debunking of faith healers.

title: 'Star Wars's' Stump Speech
description: LOS ANGELES - IF 2004 was the year that Mel Gibson and Michael Moore made it seem safe for moviemakers to wade into the treacherous waters of politics and religion, 2005 saw Hollywood still struggling to find its footing with Important Subjects.

title: Art That Requires a Hard Hat
description: IN the contemporary art world, there's practically nothing that can't be used to get the job done. In recent years, artists have employed everything from plasticized salt to fingernail clippings to gallons of water from the Bermuda Triangle. Even DNA. (Joe Davis, a biological artist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has encoded a fragment of text by Heraclitus into a gene of a fruit fly.)

title: In First Christmas Homily, Pope Reflects on World Conflicts
description: VATICAN CITY, Dec. 25 - In his first Christmas address, Pope Benedict XVI prayed today for peace in poorer, war-torn parts of the world as he warned those who are more comfortable that they "risk becoming victims of their own intellectual and technical achievements."

title: 7 Teenagers Charged With Computer Theft
description: The Norwalk police arrested seven current or former students at Brien McMahon High School on Monday who they say are suspects in the theft of about $40,000 in computer equipment while the school was being renovated last summer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 11 about visiting Santa Cruz, Calif., with children misstated the name of a popular walking route to Natural Bridges State Park. It is West Cliff Drive, not East Cliff Drive.

title: Rules of Engagement for the Holiday Season
description: LIKE "white Christmas," "happy holidays" and "guaranteed delivery before Dec. 25," the phrase, "Will you marry me?" is becoming a familiar refrain this time of year.

description: A Play That Has Actors Panting to Try Out

title: SCALITO
description: WHEN Brad Pitt linked up with Angelina Jolie this summer, the couple became "Brangelina." The Supreme Court nominee Samuel A. Alito Jr. has been called "Scalito," attempting to fuse him ideologically with Justice Antonin Scalia, and when Tom Cruise professed his love for Katie Holmes, they were immediately labeled "TomKat."

title: Pulse: What I'm Wearing for New Year's Eve; The Author
description: Now that she has finished the book tour for her memoir, "Breathing Out" (St. Martin's Press 2005), Peggy Lipton is longing for a quiet New Year's Eve dinner at a friend's house in Jamaica. While she is best known for the role of Julie Barnes, on the 1960's television series "Mod Squad," Ms. Lipton says the literary life suits her quite nicely. Writing the book, she said, forced her to revisit the highest and lowest points in her life. "But just knowing that I'm a published author is wonderful."

description: THE COLBERT REPORT. It started on Comedy Central as a one-man, one-joke routine: Stephen Colbert doing a parody of conservative cable foghorns like Bill O'Reilly and Joe Scarborough. title: The Festival of Loot
description: WHEN I look back on my childhood, I think Hanukkah would have meant a lot more to me if I had been Jewish. I should probably clarify that. I am Jewish in the sense that I have Jewish parents and a Jewish last name, and like to order Chinese. But even though my family is Jewish, we've never been terribly good at doing the things Jews are supposed to be good at. And at the top of the list of things Jews are supposed to be good at is celebrating holidays, possibly because we have an opportunity to do so about 200 times a year. If you can't get good and Jewish with a calendar like that, you're just not trying.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GLICKSMAN, ALBERT
description: GLICKSMAN--Albert. Aly, Happy Anniversary on the 24th, Merry Christmas on the 25th, and Happy Birthday on the 26th. Love, Fran

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, ROBERT
description: LEVINE--Robert. Died on December 17 after a long illness, with his wife, artist Emma Amos, and children, Nick and India, at his side. Born in Brooklyn in 1929, he attended Brooklyn Technical H.S. and the Cooper Union School of Engineering, was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of NYU in 1951, and served in the Army. He was an international and N. American racing champion in the Flying Dutchman Junior Class in the 1960s and 70s, an avid photographer and editor, and an early computer enthusiast and consultant. He began his career as an advertising writer and retired as director of marketing for Standard Motor Products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUTTON, ALFRED M.
description: SUTTON--Alfred M. On December 23, 2005, at age 74. Beloved husband of Carmen Sutton. Loving father of Karen, Theresa, Christopher and Alfred Sutton and dear grandfather. Devoted brother of Michael and Jack Sutton, Rosemary Reddan, Ann Maguffin, Betty Hassett, Kay Giblin and twenty - eight neices and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Thursday, December 29th, 10-1 pm, with service 1:30 pm. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Riverview School, 551 Route 6A, East Sandwich, MA 02537.

title: Testing Egypt, Mubarak Rival Is Sent to Jail
description: CAIRO, Dec. 24 - An Egyptian court sentenced Ayman Nour, a leading opposition figure, to five years at hard labor on Saturday after convicting him in a forgery case widely seen as a political prosecution aimed at silencing a challenge to President Hosni Mubarak's monopoly on power.

title: An Atlanta Rapper's Sluggish Rasp
description: 1. YOUNG JEEZY: 'LET'S GET IT: THUG MOTIVATION 101' (Corporate Thugz Entertainment/Island Def Jam). On his mesmerizing major-label debut, this Atlanta rapper reels off slow-motion rhymes; he pauses whenever he feels like it for one of his famous interjections, often a low, guttural, "Yeeeeah." Despite the shameless jokes ("I'm emotional, I hug the block") and dopeman boasts hidden in plain sight, this is sly, insinuative music. Young Jeezy's sluggish rasp evokes both a ruthlessness no one can touch and a weariness no one can cure.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: MIDWEEK AT MAMMOTH -- As part of its January Midweek Madness promotion, lodgings on Mammoth Mountain, in central California, will be offering midweek packages priced from $99 a person a night, double occupancy, including one free lift ticket for each night's stay. Taxes of 10 percent are extra. Travel must be completed between Jan. 9 and Feb. 1. Among the places participating are Mammoth Mountain Inn, the Village at Mammoth, Juniper Springs Resort and Tamarack Lodge and Resort. For more details, call 800-626-6684 or see www.mammothmountain.com.

title: Risen from the Rubble of the Third Reich
description: 1. The Austrian composer Franz Schreker's reputation was buried in the rubble of the Third Reich and reburied by postwar musical politics. But the excavation has finally begun. "Die Gezeichneten," a once-popular masterpiece that had its premiere in 1918, was brought back to radiant life as the opening opera of this year's Salzburg Festival. Kent Nagano was true to the work's conflicted vision of a dark, fallen utopia painted in beautiful washes of impressionist color.

title: An Answer to the Harried Life: Personal Shoppers
description: EVERY December, Ashley Craig was stuck wearing the same outfit -- a navy blue Ann Taylor cocktail dress, circa 1996 -- to the spate of holiday parties that she and her husband attended. "I needed an update badly," Ms. Craig now acknowledges. "But the idea of taking time to shop for myself at Christmas sent me into a panic." How could she trawl the mall for a new getup when she was frantically playing Santa to her three small children?

At williamsboard.com, an online forum about all things Williamsburg that just made its debut this fall, residents have pondered everything from the subtleties of irony to the ironies of subtlety. Here are excerpts.

title: TRUTHINESS
description: JUST as the most-discussed coverage of the 2004 presidential election was by a fake-news outlet -- "The Daily Show" on Comedy Central -- the pundit who probably drew the most attention in 2005 was only playing one on TV: Stephen Colbert, who presides over a "Daily Show" spinoff, "The Colbert Report."

title: Whose Economy Is It, Anyway?
description: As polls registered public discontent with the economy earlier this month, back-to-back government reports showed strong economic growth and respectable job creation. To explain the discrepancy, Allan Hubbard, one of President Bush's top economic advisers, said that hurricanes and high gas prices had temporarily darkened Americans' collective mood, but that the president was pleased with the economy. "He's more concerned with results than he is about polls," Mr. Hubbard said.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, MAX
description: SCHWARTZ--Max. On December 20, 2005 at the age of 96. Beloved husband of the late May Schwartz. Loving father of Daniel, Harriet and Norma. Cherished grandfather of Allison and (David), Lisa and (Frank) David & (Laura) and Stephanie. Grandfather of seven great-grand children. Max graduated from Columbia University School of Pharmacy in 1931 and was active in his profession for 55 years. He was also the former president of 420 Riverside Drive Realty Corp. He was at the center of an extended family who cherished him until the end. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Dan Marino Foundation, PO Box 267640 Weston, FL. 33326.

title: Dog-Eating Colleagues and a Matron's Roman Holiday
description: IN a year dominated by microwaved revivals and malfunctioning jukeboxes, the play really wasn't the thing in New York, despite the hopeful materializing on Broadway of Martin McDonagh's "Pillowman" and John Patrick Shanley's "Doubt," mighty pillars embodying the dramas electric and orthodox, respectively. The players, on the other hand, offered an encouraging multitude of reasons to keep going to the theater, with an unusual strength in tight and bracing ensemble work. Here, five impeccably synchronized casts and five heroic standout performances.

title: Out With Two Old Favorites for Dogs and Dance
description: FAIRFIELD COUNTY is about to lose two of its best-known local institutions dating from the 1940's -- Swanky Franks hot dog stand in Norwalk, and the Terrace Club, a dance hall in Stamford. The two have lost their leases and are set to close soon.

title: 'The Victory of Reason'
description: Theology is in disrepute among most Western intellectuals. The word is taken to mean a passA form of religious thinking that embraces irrationality and dogmatism. So too, Scholasticism. According to any edition of Webster's, "scholastic" means "pedantic and dogmatic," denoting the sterility of medieval church scholarship. John Locke, the eighteenth-century British philosopher, dismissed the Scholastics as "the great mintmasters" of useless terms meant "to cover their ignorance." Not so! The Scholastics were fine scholars who founded Europe's great universities and launched the rise of Western science. As for theology, it has little in common with most religious thinking, being a sophisticated, highly rational discipline that is fully developed only in Christianity.

title: INSIDE
description: South African Shantytowns Erupting in Protest Residents of South Africa's shantytowns take their frustration with the slow pace of change to the streets in marches and other demonstrations, often resulting in clashes with the police and violence. PAGE 10

title: When Doing Good Also Aids the Devil
description: JOHANNESBURG - IN this season of generosity, of morality plays about Scrooge and the Grinch and the global imperative to help those who are less fortunate, think a moment about this question: what if your gift could relieve Tiny Tim's misery for now, but risked perpetuating it -- or even worsening it -- in the long run?

title: FROTHY
description: ALAN GREENSPAN has earned a reputation in his 18 years as Federal Reserve chairman as a master of the 50-word sentence whose meaning is nearly impossible to untangle. Once in a while, though, he turns a phrase that seems to capture the country's economic anxieties.

title: Movies on TV
description: KINSEY (2004) Saturday at 10 p.m. and Saturday/ Early Sunday at 4 a.m. on Cinemax Alfred Kinsey (Liam Neeson, right) could have spent his professional life studying gall wasps. And almost did. But luckily for him and repressed post-World War II Americans, he and his new wife, Clara (Laura Linney), have a sexual problem. When they seek medical help and see the amazing difference that it makes, Kinsey is inspired. He begins interviewing people about the most intimate area of their lives and ends up with a monster best seller, "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male." In the process, he, his wife and the handsome young men on his staff try to live the sexual openness that seems called for and find that there's more to emotional life than science. Bill Condon, who did "Gods and Monsters," directed.

title: The $12.50 Movie Takes a Brief Bow

When "The Producers" opened at the Ziegfeld a week and a half ago, tickets cost $12.50, a record high for a standard movie in the city, said Jim Kozak, a spokesman for the National Association of Theater Owners.

description: To the Editor:

title: On Gulf Coast, Cleanup Differs Town to Town
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss. - There is an eerie stillness here on Edgewood Avenue. Toys, broken glass and random pieces of furniture are strewn across yards. Not a single person is in sight. The only movement, nearly four months after the passing of Hurricane Katrina, comes from the stray cats that jump in and out of the ripped-open homes.

title: 2 Congregations Unite, and No. 2 Becomes No. 1
description: THE last shall be first -- or at least, in the case of Second Church of Christ, Scientist, at 68th Street and Central Park West, the Second shall be First.

title: Shoppers in a Parallel Paradise
description: SLEEPY HOLLOW - WHEN Pedro Urgils started his accounting business here more than a decade ago, there were only a handful of Spanish-speaking store owners along Beekman Avenue. The village's Ecuadorean immigrants, like Mr. Urgils, patronized few stores. But as soon as he opened up shop, the customers began filing in.

title: Saved by Strangers
description: He was prodded to his feet by rifle barrels. This was northern Tunisia, Nov. 29, 1942. Just after midnight, following faulty intelligence, he had led his men into enemy territory. Now he stood surrounded, trembling, sickened by the gravity of his mistake. A German sergeant jammed a pistol into Joe Frelinghuysen's gut and joked that he'd been easier to catch than a rabbit.

title: The Luck of the Draft
description: I WAS a rough-and-tumble kid. When I was in the fourth grade I would get into fights. My parents made a decision to pull me out of the public school and send me to Greenwich Country Day School. There the teachers were a lot more hands-on.

title: Nagasaki, 1946: Football Amid the Ruins
description: The story of the Atom Bowl is equal parts football and fantasy, but, as Gerald Sanders can attest, it is not fiction. Sixty years ago this New Year's Day, the game was played in Nagasaki, Japan, amid the ruins and radiation of the nuclear blast that ended World War II.

title: Some Tax Advice From (Get This) Florio
description: Beyond the thicket of appointments, there is the thicket of making policy. And as Mr. Corzine considers the possibility of raising the gasoline tax to refill the state Transportation Trust Fund, he has the support of someone who knows a thing or two about the political perils of tax increases -- former Gov. Jim Florio.

title: 'The Worst Hard Time'
description: They had been on the road for six days, a clan of five bouncing along in a tired wagon, when Bam White woke to some bad news. One of his horses was dead. It was the nineteenth-century equivalent of a flat tire, except this was the winter of 1926. The Whites had no money. They were moving from the high desert chill of Las Animas, Colorado, to Littlefield, Texas, south of Amarillo, to start anew. Bam White was a ranch hand, a lover of horses and empty skies, at a time when the cowboy was becoming a museum piece in Texas and an icon in Hollywood. Within a year, Charles Lindbergh would cross the ocean in his monoplane, and a white man in blackface would speak from the screen of a motion picture show. The great ranches had been fenced, platted, subdivided, upturned, and were going out to city builders, oil drillers, and sodbusters. The least-populated part of Texas was open for business and riding high in the Roaring Twenties. Overnight, new towns were rising, bustling with banks, opera houses, electric streetlights, and restaurants serving seafood sent by train from Galveston. With his handlebar mustache, bowlegs, and raisin-skinned face, Bam White was a man high-centered in the wrong century. The plan was to get to Littlefield, where the winters were not as bad as Colorado, and see if one of the new fancy-pantsers might need a ranch hand with a quick mind. Word was, a family could always pick cotton as well.

title: Hi, Mom, I'm Home For the Holidays!
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiona Apple Gets It on the Second Try
description: 1. Fiona Apple: 'Extraordinary Machine' (Epic). Take 2 of this long-awaited, prematurely leaked album is the keeper. On the finished album, a little bit of Jon Brion's surreal cabaret orchestration brackets the newer stripped-down, focused versions of the songs. Ms. Apple continues her obsessive self-examination and convoluted thoughts of betrayal and regret, but now adds something: enough distance for some wry perspective.

title: The Problem With Pensions
description: The walkout by transit workers last week was triggered by an issue of growing concern all across America: pensions. But high-wire, deadline-driven negotiations are no place to resolve an issue that is at once complicated and crucial to the workers and to the solvency of the transit system. We hope the end of the walkout means that the subject can now addressed in a calm and rational way.

title: Marshlands And Mosquitoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Fiction
Great News! It's the Dawning of the Atomic Age
description: IT'S easy to fault the major institutions in classical music for being stodgy and averse to risk. Yet music lovers count on the leading opera companies and orchestras to be custodians of the repertory. Take the Metropolitan Opera. Recalling the first half of this season, among many rewarding nights, I'll remember James Levine's buoyant and insightful performance of Mozart's "Cos Fan Tutte," with a splendid youngish cast that gave you hope for the future of Mozart singing.

title: Life, One Frame At a Time
description: NEW good artists generate considerable excitement nowadays, the more so because there are so few who are really good. One of them is Kota Ezawa, who is exhibiting two of his recent works in Hartford at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art as part of the museum's matrix program.

title: Hanukkah in Legoland
description: Lego, the Danish maker of those multicolored building blocks that clog the vacuum cleaner and gag the pug, is known for its architectural systems: knights and their castles, Vikings and longboats, even the "Star Wars" crew.

title: Another Year, Another Celebration
description: THROUGHOUT the state, organizers are planning elaborate New Year's Eve celebrations. Dance, music and theater performances dominate the calendar, with several cities sponsoring the family-friendly and alcohol-free celebrations known as First Night.

title: Chasing Evil
description: Peter Malkin wore a pair of fur-lined leather gloves when he seized Adolf Eichmann on a street in suburban Buenos Aires. It was 1960.

title: School Taxes And Home Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Up Front
description: Jon Meacham, who grew up in Chattanooga, Tenn., and attended Sewanee, an Episcopal university, became national affairs editor of Newsweek at 25 and managing editor at 29. He has often written about religion for Newsweek, and today, starting on Page 1, he reviews three new books about religion. He's also finishing his own book on the subject: "American Gospel: God, the Founding Fathers and the Making of a Nation" will be published in the spring.

title: The Peacemaker of Flight 847
description: Correction Appended

title: Wild Blue Yonder
description: Wild Blue Yonder

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 25 - Dec. 31.; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: What is it about New Year's Eve that makes us burst into song? Or at least want to listen to other people burst into song? Who knows, but classical music presenters are firm believers in the principle. Hence the lineup for Saturday evening -- New Year's Eve -- when the voice figures prominently on the New York concert stage.

title: Not Much Disappointment to Mask
description: Unlike many goaltenders, Buffalo's Martin Biron was usually not superstitious. That has changed this season.

title: Lives: Grandmother of Thousands
description: I found out about the death of Dr. Georgeanna Seegar Jones, a pioneer in reproductive medicine, when a reporter called me looking for a quote about her. Why me? Because on Dec. 28, 1981, I became the first product of her work in the field of in vitro fertilization: I was the first test-tube baby born in the United States.

title: Lies and the Lying Doctors and Cons Who Tell Them
description: Gregory House ('House') Fox's great diagnostician contends that everybody lies; he was lying when he said that. The writing is witty here, and the English comic Hugh Laurie, as a jerky pill-popping genius, is among few television actors who can sell those scary things called witticisms.

title: A Long Day's Journey Into Night (When the Celebration Will Continue)
description: THE three Lynch children will surely rush to the living room to examine the goods piled under their tree. Their mother and father, Judi and Dan, will no doubt exchange a knowing glance, the one that parents with small children share every Christmas morning, the one that says, "This is why we have children."

title: Colts Not at Their Best
description: The Colts, who had already clinched home field in the A.F.C. playoffs, were without Coach Tony Dungy, whose son died Thursday in an apparent suicide. The team gave its top players a break yesterday in a 28-18 loss to the Seahawks, who clinched home-field advantage in the N.F.C. playoffs.

title: The Domestic Dreamboat
description: She makes her entrance, most often, in a slightly over-the-top hat, and you can be forgiven your first reaction: this is the love interest? For one thing, you're not even sure she's really pretty. Those spoon-shaped cheeks, that high forehead, the timid little girl's hair. But the longer you watch Teresa Wright, whose career -- the substantial part of it anyway -- ran from "The Little Foxes" (1941) to "The Best Years of Our Lives" (1946), paralleling the war years, the more you begin to understand that in that particular slice of the 1940's, there was a female quality that shunted conventional glamour right off the stage.

title: One Last Day, and One Rule: Every Shopper for Himself
description: In the other war surrounding Christmas, the final battle is fought to the piped-in sounds of "Silver Bells."

title: So Far, Corzine's Cabinet Is Empty
description: Maybe he's saving the best for last. After more than six weeks since his election, Governor-elect Jon S. Corzine has Trenton insiders scratching their heads because he has yet to announce any cabinet appointments.

title: PERSISTENT VEGETATIVE STATE
description: IT was at the heart of a wrenching battle, a mouthful of a phrase dissected at dinner tables and ultimately on the House and Senate floors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUDIS, LUCILLE
description: GUDIS--Lucille. The Jewish Genealogical Society mourns the untimely passing of former Vice President and longtime Executive Council member Lucille Gudis. Her tireless and generous devotion to the needs of the Jewish genealogical community, her genealogical expertise and inspiration, her warmth and treasured friendship, will all be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family.

title: Waiting for the Met's New Regime
description: 1. Half-empty houses, lackluster premieres in which the sets are the most colorful thing onstage: the Metropolitan Opera has been having a harder and harder time in recent seasons. Word has it that Peter Gelb, who officially takes over next year, will make big changes. They can't come soon enough.

title: How to Shush the Office Magpie
description: Q. One of your co-workers loves to chat, and whenever he isn't dealing with a pressing deadline, he barges into your work space to shoot the breeze. How do you restore peace and quiet?

title: Delphi's Executives
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Changes at Hayes Theater

title: Clone Scientist Relied on Peers and Korean Pride
description: When Dr. Hwang Woo Suk's recent reports of advances in cloning research were declared to have been fabricated on Friday, his disgrace left scientists wondering how he had risen so fast, deceived so many and fallen so hard.

title: Against Giants, Moss Was Rolling
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 24 - Wide receiver Santana Moss was the most dominant player on the field Saturday, no matter who played quarterback for the Washington Redskins.

title: The Lives They Lived; The Prisoner
description: When Cmdr. James Stockdale parachuted out of his nose-diving Skyhawk over the North Vietnamese jungle in September 1965, the war was still young. Little was known about the fate that awaited American prisoners of war. It didn't take Stockdale long to gain a clearer sense. After a few months in solitary confinement in Hoa Lo prison in Hanoi, he was introduced to "the ropes," a torture technique in which a prisoner was seated on the floor -- legs extended, arms bound behind him -- as a guard stood on his back and drove his face down until his nose was mashed into the brick floor between his legs. The North Vietnamese knew they were overmatched militarily, but they figured they could at least win the propaganda war by brutalizing American P.O.W.'s until they denounced their government and "confessed" that they had bombed schoolchildren and villagers.

title: What Santa Rally? The Market Barely Budges
description: Hopes for a year-end rise in the broad stock market -- the so-called Santa Claus rally -- were dashed as flagging home sales and falling energy prices hit the stocks of companies in those industries. That offset gains in retailing shares, which were bolstered by signs of consumer optimism.

title: President Reagan: The Triumph of Imagination
DATEBOOK
description: DENVER

title: Praise the Lord and Raise the Curtain
description: TEN minutes from the heart of Flushing in Queens, past a welter of store signs in Chinese and a desolate stretch of smokestacks, a 10-story slab of steel and glass shoots up next to a sprawling parking lot. It looks like a convention center, but it has a higher calling. It's a Pentecostal megachurch, and its name is Promise.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article and picture caption last Sunday about planned development along the High Line elevated railroad track in Chelsea misspelled the name of a restaurant that has been in the neighborhood for 18 years. It is La Lunchonette, not La Luncheonette.

title: Street Fighting Man
description: THE QUITTER

title: Wall St. Bets on Gambling on the Web
description: Internet casinos are outlaw operations in the eyes of the federal government, but they look like solid investments to many of Wall Street's largest firms.

title: Pedestrian Is Killed in Queens Accident
description: A 53-year-old man was struck and killed early yesterday in a drunken-driving accident in Woodhaven, Queens, the authorities said.

title: QUICK BITE/Lodi; (Homeland) Security Blanket
description: Trattoria Napoli here takes you back to your nonna's kitchen. This small pizzeria does have all kinds of pizzas, from the hip Hawaiian to thick, traditional slices buried in tomatoes, garlic and onions. But the chef, John Iocovo, along with his mother-in-law (and the trattoria's owner), Dora Panicucci, also cook up dishes that are like a security blanket for the palate.

title: Free-Market Tenants in a Conversion Plan
description: TWENTY years ago, during the co-op conversion boom in New York, most tenants in buildings about to be converted enjoyed the comfort of knowing that even if they did not want to buy -- at an insider price that was likely to be much less than the cost to nonresidents -- they could almost certainly stay on as rental tenants.

title: One Division III Conference Finds That Playing the Slots System Pays Off
description: Tom Parker has been involved in the Division III athletic recruiting process at small, elite liberal arts colleges for 25 years, long enough to remember when civility and common sense were the rule.

title: For East End, a Banner Year
description: A STREAM of first-rate East End wines made 2005 a pleasure for drinking. While I did not taste all of the hundreds sold, I found quite a few standouts; some of them remain available in wineries' tasting rooms, stores and restaurants.

title: A Menu Worth Searching for Bright Spots
description: I have a friend who swears that Peppercorn's Grill serves the best food in Hartford. But I've also heard complaints about the restaurant.

title: Catcher Comparison
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shantytown Dwellers in South Africa Protest Sluggish Pace of Change
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 24 - Sending what some call an ominous signal to this nation's leaders, South Africa's sprawling shantytowns have begun to erupt, sometimes violently, in protest over the government's inability to deliver the better life that the end of apartheid seemed to herald a dozen years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the Queens-Nassau border misidentified the neighborhood where James A. Trent, the president and founder of the Queens County Farm Museum, resides. It is Bellerose Manor, not Douglaston Manor. The article also referred incorrectly to Professor Patricia Caro's research on the history of the part of the border that crosses the Rockaway peninsula. It was originally drawn about a half-mile east of where Beach 9th Street is now, and was later shifted westward to closely match a Colonial-era property line called the Welles line, Professor Caro found; it did not start at the Welles line.

title: Surviving Christmas
description: TINTON FALLS - THEY knew the day could not bring much joy, so Mickey and Audrey Rehbein were trying not to think too much about Christmas.

title: A Nude and a Tight Pair of Jeans
description: ONE of the great pleasures of dance this year was a kind of surprise comparable to what the poet Wallace Stevens described when he wrote, "Out of nothing to have come on major weather." The "nothing" in this case was of my own humdrum expectations. The major weather was contributed by Albert Evans, DD Dorvillier and Sir Frederick Ashton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRIEFF, PAUL
description: BRIEFF--Paul. Of Pompano Beach, Fl. died December 22, 2005. Beloved husband of adoring wife Charlotte, loving father to Bob (June), Jane and Richard, grandson Michael and brother Max. A man who filled many lives with love. Services to be held Tuesday, December 27, 2005, 1:00 P.M. at Gutterman's Inc. Woodbury, 516-921-5757.

title: Chicken Hawker
description: Once he started getting the hang of it -- after he was spending time in the chic New York offices of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, the hot little ad agency he employed for 20-plus years, or on the set of one of the ads he was starring in -- once he became comfortable with the language and rituals of advertising, Frank Perdue started to employ the phrase "U.S.P." It's not the sort of phrase a poultry farmer from Salisbury, Md., was likely to use, but Frank Perdue was not your ordinary poultry farmer from Salisbury, Md. "U.S.P." is ad lingo. It stands for "unique selling proposition." It means that quality -- sometimes tangible, sometimes not -- that sets apart the product the ad guys are trying to sell. It's what makes it special. Coca-Cola has a U.S.P., and so does McDonald's and Disney and Exxon-Mobil and Armani and every other brand name you can think of.

title: These Meals, The Critics Would Buy Themselves
description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
