description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROONES, CAROLYN (NEE STANTON)
description: BROONES -- Carolyn (nee Stanton). Passed away December 21, age 93. Beloved wife of Dr. Otto Broones, cherished mother of Jane Radnay. Treasured grandmother of Dr. Craig Radnay and Richard Radnay Esq. She was always there for all of us and will never be forgotten.

title: 17 Days of Nothing You'd Ever Beheld
description: THE sight of one person taking things into her own hands is nothing new in the cultural sphere of New York, but it's still amazing to witness. Last month, RoseLee Goldberg amazed with Performa 05, billed as the city's first biennial of "visual art performance."

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Turning the Page on 2005

title: Gidget Doesn't Live Here Anymore
description: At the height of her spectacularly short-lived fame, coverage of everything from her dietary habits to her taste in men was enormous, with approximately 15 magazine articles appearing every month. The thing is, it all happened so fast, was over practically before it began, that we can almost be forgiven for misconstruing her as a cultural simulacrum: a blip on the monitor, a media invention, an adorable incarnation of a feminine ideal of the reluctant or unwitting nymphet, rather than a flesh-and-blood creature with needs and wishes (not to mention raging demons) of her own. The lightning speed with which Sandra Dee was first heralded and then discarded may have been just another example of the "now you see her, now you don't" phenomenon endemic to the fever-dream of Hollywood, but it also suggests the dark "Miss Lonelyhearts" side of the American manufacture of celebrity -- the ruthlessness that drives it and the despair it feeds off. She went from being discovered in 1956, at 12, to winning a Golden Globe Award in 1958, to being hailed by The Motion Picture Herald in 1959 as the "Number One Star of Tomorrow," based on her promising pigtailed debut in the sterling weepie "Until They Sail" as well as her performance in "The Reluctant Debutante." Less than a decade later, her career all but ended when she was dropped by Universal, after her divorce, at age 22, from the crooner Bobby Darin. "Sometimes I feel like a has-been who never was," Dee told The Newark Evening News in 1967.

title: Rethinking the Nation's First Suburb
description: WHAT is the future of suburbia in America -- especially on Long Island, where it all began?

title: For Christmas, Some Really Fat Geese
description: ON a recent frigid morning at the Harlem Meer, the tranquil manmade lake tucked into the northeast corner of Central Park, most of the water was topped with a thin skin of ice. In the small remaining circle of water, along with two swans and a half-dozen ducks, there swam about 50 Canada geese, many gliding about and honking with rush-hour intensity. One tore at the dried rushes along the shore, while 20 more worked a nearby hill with their brown bills, fervently nibbling what little brown grass remained.

title: Coaches Draw Diagrams For Admission to College
description: Chappaqua - WHEN it comes to competitive college admissions, a top high school athlete can certainly have an edge. But the recruiting process can be a bit of a mystery for many students and parents. On a recent winter night, coaches from four Northeast colleges came to Horace Greeley High School here to give a kind of Recruiting 101 seminar, explaining everything from how they scout student athletes to how much influence coaches actually have in admissions decisions.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing in the On the Market column last Sunday about a house for sale on Montgomery Place in Park Slope, Brooklyn, misstated the street number. It is No. 45, not No. 25.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: ETHIOPIA
description: HOLY TRINITY CHURCH, ADDIS ABABA, SEPT. 17, 2005 - Edith Sharfman, 59, an electrical contractor from Holon, Israel. "It was wonderful, the Trinity Church. The Ethiopians believe they are related to the Jews. All the time they say that they are the descendants of Solomon and the Queen of Sheba, and we saw a lot of symbols that are very close to our religion. But I was in shock in Ethiopia. I had been in other countries that are very, very poor, but Ethiopia was terrible to see. We didn't think good things about the situation in Israel because we have a great war with the Palestinians, because we are afraid sometimes, we have bombs, and I don't believe there will ever be peace with them. But we have a good life here. We live like in America. After the trip we came back to Israel, and we opened our eyes and thought, 'Thank you, God.' " As told to Seth Kugel

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 18 about two videos for the Kanye West single "Heard 'Em Say" misstated the circumstances of the departure of the director of the first clip. That director, Michel Gondry, finished the video. He was not fired.

title: Rome in Six Hours and Four Decades
description: THIS list is intended neither as prophecy nor as summing up. It is impossible to predict which of the many fine movies released in 2005 will still claim our attention 10 years -- or even 10 weeks -- from now. Nor do the titles below represent, as far as I can see, any important trends in world cinema. Many of them belong to the year just ending by sheer happenstance, having been shown at festivals long before their (often brief) runs in American theaters. What they have in common is only that I loved them, that each one caused me, temporarily, to let go of my critical preoccupations and experience the absorption and surprise that made me want to be a critic in the first place.

title: It Takes a Village of Green Thumbs
description: WHEN a collection of Greenburgh residents decided recently that town locations needed beautifying, they had only to look next door to White Plains for inspiration in their endeavor.

title: Bringing 'Em On
description: THE NEXT ATTACK

title: The Loudest Ringtone: Hello? It's 50 Cent Calling. Collect.
description: While sales of new CD's remain bleak, the music industry is finding a small degree of consolation in the explosive growth of ringtones. This year alone, enough mobile phone users downloaded the tones to rack up retail sales of about $602 million in the United States, more than double the $277 million racked up in 2004, according to a Jupiter Research analysis. Ringtones aren't a large piece of the $12 billion American music industry, but the mobile sector is one of the few in which executives foresee growth.

title: Will You Still Need Me, Will You Still Read Me?
description: WHEN the thousandth issue of Rolling Stone magazine rolls off the presses in May, its cover will feature an elaborate three-dimensional homage to "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band." Drawing inspiration from the lineup of celebrities whose images graced that seminal Beatles recording, the magazine will tip its hat to the trove of musicians, entertainers and politicians who have inhabited its pages since its founding in 1967.

title: Welding Their Way to TV Fame
description: Montgomery, N.Y. - THE pilgrims come from near and far, in cars, in pickups, sometimes in tourist buses, to the tired-looking strip mall on Route 17K in search of what?

title: The Agency That Could Be Big Brother
description: Washington - DEEP in a remote, fog-layered hollow near Sugar Grove, W.Va., hidden by fortress-like mountains, sits the country's largest eavesdropping bug. Located in a "radio quiet" zone, the station's large parabolic dishes secretly and silently sweep in millions of private telephone calls and e-mail messages an hour.

title: An Art School Learns to Go Where the Demand Leads It
description: AMAGANSETT - CHRISTOPHER GOLDEN reached a finger into the plastic tray and swirled a sheet of photographic paper floating in developing solution. "I always seem to do people's heads," he said. "I like this close-up stuff."

title: Libyan Court Orders Retrial in H.I.V. Case
description: PARIS, Dec. 25 - The Libyan Supreme Court on Sunday overturned the convictions of five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor who had been sentenced to death on charges of infecting hundreds of Libyan children with H.I.V.

title: These Meals, The Critics Would Buy Themselves
description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

title: December 25
description: You don't really have to be in the mood for the Fourth of July. No one ever talks about having that Memorial Day spirit. Even Thanksgiving can be distilled, without too much disrespect. But Christmas is something different. Feeling is the point of it, somewhere under all that shopping. To think of Scrooge is to think of his conversion, the cartwheeling of his emotions after his long night of the soul. But the more interesting part of the story is his dogged resistance to feeling the way everyone thinks he's supposed to feel -- about death, about charity, about prize turkeys hanging at the poulterer's.

title: Trust and the Voting Machine (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Call It Sprawl, But It's Smart Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefs: Swiss airline plans to fire pilots who reject contract
Radhika Sarin and Akshay Rangnekar
description: Radhika Sarin was married in a Hindu ceremony yesterday to Akshay Ajit Rangnekar at Le Meridien New Delhi in India. Pandit Vidya Prasad Misr officiated.

title: What's So Great About Merry?
description: I'M dreaming of a blue Christmas, just like the ones well, the fact is that there actually was a blue Christmas in my childhood, one that kind of set the tone for many holidays to come. Whether under the influence of some loopy decorating scheme sweeping the women's magazines of the late 1960's or because she was experiencing an undiagnosed spell of depression, one holiday season my mother mixed herself a shaker of Harvey Wallbangers (orange juice and vodka, poured over ice cubes, shaken and strained into a highball glass, with a lethal sunset swirl of Galliano floated on top) and laid siege to the sort of Christmas we kids had come to expect.

title: The Struggling Kings Are No Longer Able to Relax at Home
description: The Sacramento Kings could always count on Arco Arena as a safe haven -- the din made it a brutal place for opposing teams. But now the Kings cannot find comfort there.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 25 - Dec. 31.; POP/JAZZ
description: OTOMO YOSHIHIDE, a guitarist and turntablist from the Japanese improvised music scene, has juxtaposed different aesthetics, even at the risk of contradicting himself. Since starting out in the late 1980's, he has established himself as the leader of the Onkyo movement in improvising, which insists on pure sonic texture as a basis for sound, rather than structure. At the same time, with his New Jazz Orchestra, he has hired musicians with the chops to concoct new versions of venerable jazz compositions, with considerable emphasis on structure. (The latest, on the Japanese label Doubtmusic, is a fascinating album-length take on Eric Dolphy's 1964 recording "Out to Lunch.") Sunday through Friday, he will be the focus and the star of a mini-festival at the Stone, highlighting different aspects of his work every night. But don't expect jazz. The concerts include solo performances with turntables or guitar; a trio with the bassist BILL LASWELL and the drummer NAKAMURA TATSUYA; a quartet with the bassist MARGARITA GARCIA and the percussionists SEAN MEEHAN and TIM BARNES; and collaborations with other electronic musicians like YASUNAO TONE and IKUE MORI. 8 and 10 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, www.thestonenyc.com; $10 per set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOOLOS, BLANCHE
description: BOOLOS--Blanche. 101, on December 22. Respected ACCO executive. Proud mother of Professor George and beloved wife of Stephen.

title: The Void That Lingers After the Last Ovation
description: IN dance, few occasions are fraught with as much euphoric joy and bare sorrow as a farewell performance. The spring season brought three notable departures: Peter Boal and Jock Soto retired from the New York City Ballet, while Amanda McKerrow stepped down from American Ballet Theater. What lingered wasn't the simple beauty of their final solo bows, or even the surreal showers of bouquets and confetti, but the ways they danced.

title: How Christmas Became Merry
description: IN 1809, under the pseudonym Diedrich Knickerbocker, Washington Irving published "Knickerbocker's History of New York." In this book-length parody of colonial America, Irving took much glee in satirizing the early Dutch settlers of New York and their traditions, including their patron saint, Nicholas, whom they referred to as Sancte Claus. But in doing so, he also created a Christmas tradition.

title: Exercise and the City
description: WE'RE closing in on Jan. 1: a new month, a new year and, sigh, a new commitment to exercise.

title: Bucharest: A Checkered Past Adds Intrigue to a Bohemian City
description: FOR a solid week storms saturated Bucharest. On the first day of relief, I put away my foul weather gear, joined the young, chicly dressed Romanians who had just emerged on Calea Victoriei, the city's main artery, and set out to enjoy the architectural treasure chest that is the Romanian capital.

title: Hut-to-Hut Skiing: Answering the Call of the Trail
description: THERE'S a tugging romance to the idea of escaping the orbit of the local cross-country ski loop and heading out on a long-distance ski journey. Unfortunately, Nordic skiers have relatively few options for point-to-point adventures unless they're comfortable carrying an anvil-heavy pack in the backcountry and sleeping in a drippy snow cave. But here, with the help of Ron Bergin, editor and publisher of Cross Country Skier magazine, are some alternatives: six great Nordic trips around the world where the trail always leads to a clean, well-lighted place. These range from easy to challenging, and the amenities can vary from B.Y.O. sleeping bag to feather duvets, post-ski sports massages and tournedos of beef.

title: GLOSSARY
description: EACH year, words in the national discourse surge forward, endure for a time and then recede. Their importance may be slight or great, they may be novel or commonplace, they may die a mayfly's death or be enshrined in the permanent body of the English language, but as a body, they add to the accreted notions of what makes an American. Here is a sampling of American language that was important this year.

title: Two Generations of Coltrane
description: 1. "Thelonious Monk Quartet With John Coltrane at Carnegie Hall" (Blue Note) Every musician on this newly found recording, of a 1957 fund-raising concert, is dead. But before its chance discovery this year, the only people who had ever heard it were those in attendance, --so we'll count it as new. And what do you know? Articulated and crisply recorded, the album isn't just a collection of persistent ideals in jazz -- with clarity of melody and rhythm, lovely groove (the crisply swinging, underrecorded Shadow Wilson is the drummer) and constant surprise in the moving harmonies -- but a fantastically pleasurable record. Coltrane, like a manic pipe-fitter, connects one winding, original lick to another, yet nothing can overturn the comfortable sense of space in Monk's brilliant compositions: a breeze blows through them.

title: Sale for an Oscar-Winning Actress
description: THE actress Tatum O'Neal sold a loft at 27 Great Jones Street in late October for $2.1 million, according to a deed filed with the city. Ms. O'Neal paid $1.69 million for the apartment in June 2003.

title: These Meals, The Critics Would Buy Themselves
description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

title: Yes, Bone Up on the Openings, but Don't Neglect the Endgame
description: It's getting more and more popular for grandmasters to do their winning in the endgame. They seem to have discovered that lesser players are so busy studying opening theory that they neglect endings. Nikola Sedlak, winner of the IX Mirko Srajber Memorial Tournament in Subotica, Serbia and Montenegro, decided quite a few games in the endgame.

title: Water Main Break Cuts Subway Service; 3 Lines Are Rerouted
description: A burst water main in Manhattan flooded a small stretch of Broadway early yesterday, forcing transit officials to suspend service for several hours at nine subway stations and causing a cave-in that swallowed a section of pavement.

title: Trust and the Voting Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLANK, JERRY
description: BLANK--Jerry. Past President of Paragon Sporting Goods, died December 19, 2005. Born February 26, 1918 in Brooklyn, NY. As a teenage boy Jerry Blank loved and nurtured Paragon Sports, which was founded by his father, to become the preeminent retailing sporting goods establishment in America. In 1943 Mr. Blank joined the United States Marine Corps. He was stationed in Okinawa and China. Mr. Blank was an avid fisherman, nature lover, sportsman and a brilliant storyteller. Jerry Blank was respected by both his business associates and friends for his loyalty, responsibility and honesty. He was a man of his word. He was a generous and loving husband, father and grandfather. Jerry Blank is survived by his wife Pearl Blank, daughter Robin Blank, son Bruce Blank and Jill Kalman, brother Sidney Blank and five grandchildren. Contributions may be made to Riverkeeper or Nature Conservancy.

title: Their Port in a Storm
description: THE city's main post office on Eighth Avenue in Midtown has a majestic facade, its stairs rising to an entrance framed by 20 Corinthian columns, each 53 feet high. To pass through this portal can make even the most mundane task -- mailing a Christmas gift, for instance -- seem loftily important.

title: The Anti-Joads
description: TIMOTHY EGAN'S new book, "The Worst Hard Time," takes the shape of a classic disaster tale. We meet the central characters (the "nesters" who farmed around the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles); dire warnings (against plowing) are voiced but ignored; and then all hell breaks loose. Ten-thousand-foot-high dust storms whip across the landscape, choking people and animals, and eventually laying waste to one of the richest ecosystems on earth.

title: The Rebirth of Sri Lanka
description: AT the opening of a boutique hotel and yoga retreat named Talalla Retreat Center, near a long stretch of white beach, an international crowd of stylish guests sips red wine and snacks on canaps. As evening wears into early morning, conversation shifts effortlessly from comparisons of the latest restaurants in London and Sydney to mutual friends burned out working for big investment banks, to high-end yoga teachers who charge $600 a lesson. One man says he's just returned from his 57th trip to Bali.

title: He Loves New York, and It Loves Him Right Back
description: Among New York City's many powers is its capacity to tolerate and nurture those obsessed with it.

title: Unfinished Business
description: George Pataki has built a progressive record on environmental issues. His stewardship of the recent agreement involving seven Northeastern states to limit greenhouse gases is only the latest in a long string of accomplishments. But this otherwise solid record will remain incomplete unless he can win Senate approval of three excellent measures that nearly everyone except a small band of Republicans, including the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, seems to want.

title: The Battle of the Biggest
description: IN the Middle Ages, monks argued over how many angels could dance on the head of a pin. In 21st-century New York, real estate wonks bring a similarly recondite intensity to the debate over who owns the most expensive apartment.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: The Way We Eat; Man With a Pan
description: The inventor of the Bundt pan made a German cake as American as apple pie.ny success story worth telling begins with a Jewish mother -- as any Jewish mother will tell you.

title: Under a Big Sky, Amorous Cowhands and Hungry Bears
description: ANXIETY that shades into dread and dread that curdles into paranoia; the past hammering on the door of the present like a vengeful ghost: As ominous portents leaked into the movies in 2005, it sometimes felt as though the hurricanes that decimated the Gulf Coast and Florida had torn away the roof separating the movies from reality and let in an acid rain.

title: It's Not the Game, It's the Name
description: MIAMI, Dec. 24 - What sells and what wins are as different as snow and sand, as distinct as suburban Detroit and Miami Beach.

title: Libya court overturns death term for nurses
Paid Notice: Deaths   IRVING, ROBERTA
description: IRVING--Roberta. In memory of Mrs. Malcolm ("Bobbie") Irving of Wilton, CT who was born on Christmas day, 1918 and passed away peacefully at home on December 22, 2005. You'll be missed, Ma. Tony and Alan

title: Gifts of the Magi; Poppy pawned his beloved guitar. Mama had her own ideas.
description: STRUMMING my Poppy's old guitar the other day, I was reminded of the Christmas, in 1961, when he'd lost his job, and my sister Carmencita and me would stand spellbound before a toy-shop window, and he could do nothing more than say, I will get you some nice toys one day, children. I promise you.

title: As Team Struggled, Jets' Vilma Got Lost in Pro Bowl Shuffle
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 22 - Maybe if Jets middle linebacker Jonathan Vilma had put a bug in his opponents' ears when he was not applying bruises to their sides, he would hold a ticket to the Pro Bowl roster instead of being on the waiting list.

title: Soul Men
description: lt was the season of Shaft, of macho guys who patrolled the movie screen and the airwaves in big cars and big shoes, of soul on steroids. While Shaft and Superfly's musical counterparts enforced a tough urban sound with the thwack of a guitar or the hiss of a high-hat, around the corner another man was settling onto a park bench, probably around dusk, drawing up his collar to ward offthe chill. And slowly, quietly, the words fell from his lips like drowsy autumn leaves: "One month ago today, I was happy as a lark. . . ."

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site, at 28 East 20th Street in Manhattan, misstated the month and year Roosevelt was elected vice president. It was November 1900, not January 1901.

title: Soccer: For Owen in '05, a holiday at home
Marshlands And Mosquitoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodbye, Elevator Operator
description: Q -- I have lived in a rent-controlled apartment in a co-op building for more than 40 years. We have an elevator operator who also opens the front door for tenants and guests. Management plans to install a self-service elevator, and the elevator operator will become simply the doorman. One of the reasons I originally moved into the building was that the building had an elevator operator. Is this grounds for a reduction in rent under the rubric of reduced services under the rent-control regulations? Tom Connor, Manhattan.

title: Stringed Instruments in Decatur, Ga.
description: The violinist Elmar Oliveira and several members of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra are regular visitors to a little storefront string store in Decatur, Ga., where for nearly half a century both the professional and the beginner have purchased their string instruments and gotten repairs. Among the 1,500 string instruments in stock, a French Chappuy violin dated to 1776 is available for $25,000. Beginners can find a violin with bow, resin and case starting at $450.

title: How to Sort Through the Maze of New Drug Plans
description: IN response to widespread confusion about Medicare's new Prescription Drug Plan for the elderly, which is to take effect Jan. 1, Westchester's Department of Senior Programs and Services has opened information centers throughout the county.

title: The Neediest Cases; In Pursuit of a Better Life For Their Three Children
description: When Fernando Perez packed his few belongings to leave for New York City in 1990, he said goodbye to his children and their mother, Margarita Peralta, in a small rural town in the Dominican Republic.

title: Consumed: Post-Mortem Tuneup
description: In October 1982, when the news broke that DeLorean Motor Company was shutting down its assembly line and that its founder, John DeLorean, had been arrested and charged with possession of more than 50 pounds of cocaine, there were 345 DeLorean dealers in the United States. DeLorean had famously left a high-powered job at General Motors nearly a decade before and set out to start the first new major American car company since the founding of Chrysler in 1920. The Times described him then as "a tall, handsome man who played tennis, rode horses, was good at golf, sculpted, read extensively, played a jazz saxophone and said he needed only four hours sleep a night." The car that bore his name had a stainless-steel skin, "gull-wing" doors that opened by rising up rather than swinging out and was priced at around $25,000 (or around $50,000 in 2005 dollars). The company's factory, which was in Northern Ireland, operated for less than two years, and it is estimated that about 9,000 Delorean DMC-12's were manufactured.

title: Brooklyn's Railyards: The Fight Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea Straus and Paul Shurin
description: Andrea Clio Straus and Dr. Paul Anton Shurin were married on Tuesday evening at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains. Rabbi Tom Weiner performed the ceremony.

title: Tabletop Ballroom
description: THERE may be no quicker way to an investment banker's heart or perhaps his wallet than through his eyes. At Nikki Midtown one Friday night, men in suits looked on with awe as pretty young things in tiny shorts and fishnet stockings danced on the long wooden table in the center of the club.

title: Hey, It's Good to Be Back Home in India
description: BANGALORE, India- Standing amid the rolling lawns outside his four-bedroom villa, Ajay Kela pondered his street in the community of Palm Meadows. One of his neighbors recently returned to India from Cupertino, Calif., to run a technology start-up funded by the venture capital firm Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 11 about holiday getaways misstated the relationship between King Ludwig II of Bavaria and Nymphenburg Palace in Munich. He was born there; he did not build it.

title: Di Stefano of Real Madrid hospitalized by heart attack
A Vision of a Mobile Society Rolls Off the Assembly Line
description: LET'S be optimistic. Some spectacular buildings were completed this year -- and what matters more to an architecture lover?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROADWATER, BOWDEN
description: BROADWATER - Bowden. Writer and former Registrar at St. Bernard's School. Died on Friday, December 16, 2005. Husband of the late Mary McCarthy. Survived by his stepson Reuel K. Wilson of London, Ontario. Memorial service will be scheduled in February. Contributions in Bowden's memory to the St. Bernard's School Scholarship Fund, 4 East 98 St, NY, NY 10029 will be appreciated.

title: These Meals, The Critics Would Buy Themselves
description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

title: Live at the Apollo: Past Legacy, Future Promise
description: To the Editor:

title: New Orleans Company Plans a Tour of the Catastrophe
description: "The Hurricane Katrina Tour -- America's Worst Catastrophe" is scheduled to begin Jan. 4, and a ticket for the narrated three-hour excursion will sell for $35.

title: Picture This
description: STILL LOOKING

title: Libya orders retrial of Bulgarian nurses
THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 25 - Dec. 31.; DANCE
description: Anyone who hasn't yet made the annual pilgrimage should rush straight off to the NEW YORK CITY BALLET, where George Balanchine's "NUTCRACKER" is a reminder of why this ballet is so beloved. Balanchine drew on his Russian childhood memories of the original 1892 production -- choreographed by Lev Ivanov in St. Petersburg -- when he made the ballet in 1954, and it's as enchanting now as it must have been half a century ago.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: This year, like all years, brought the deaths of many notable people. Among them were Rosa Parks, Pope John Paul II, William H. Rehnquist, Saul Bellow, Peter Jennings, Eugene J. McCarthy, August Wilson, Hans Bethe and Richard Pryor. The year 2005 was also marked by the 2,000th death of a member of the American armed forces in Iraq and of an untold number of Iraqi civilians. Violence, both man-made and natural -- especially the earthquake in South Asia that killed some 70,000 -- claimed thousands upon thousands of lives around the world.

title: CALENDAR
description: MUSIC AND DANCE

title: Getting There
description: New Yorkers made the best of a difficult strike. Fashion showed its functional side, often with flair, in the bitter cold: long coats, walking sticks, goggles and snugly boots. Wheels, like those on children's electric cars and bicycles for two, were in action. With no traffic on Fifth and Madison Avenues, Salvation Army trumpeters could be heard for blocks, undisturbed by honking horns. ON THE STREET

title: A Puzzling Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Filling the Last Rooms, for Pure Profit
description: LAST summer, a group of New York hotels came up with a promotion that used the tagline "Take the Grandkids, Leave the Parents." It was offered when parents were presumably working and grandparents were ready and willing to go on vacation.

title: Parasite Lover
description: Miriam Rothschild lived the 96 years of her life by the minute, and in the minutiae. "Fleas are nearly always in a hurry," she wrote, and she was, too, in their pursuit.

title: A Terrific Spot for a Murder
description: THE setting of a P. D. James novel is always the key to the mystery. Whether it's a theological college slowly toppling off a cliff into the North Sea ("Death in Holy Orders"), an ancient abbey overshadowed by a nuclear power plant ("Devices and Desires") or a small museum devoted to England's history between the two world wars ("The Murder Room"), the setting represents some aspect of English tradition James values highly and feels is under threat. A murder committed in such a hallowed place poses more than a knotty puzzle for Commander Adam Dalgliesh and his crack team of Scotland Yard detectives. It signals another assault on an orderly civilization from the encroaching forces of cultural barbarism and social misrule.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 25 - Dec. 31.; THEATER
description: Ah, Christmas. A time for considering the year gone by: the naughty and the nice, the good and the bad, the funny and the less so. The giggly events will be of particular interest at a faux awards show on Wednesday night at the UPRIGHT CITIZENS BRIGADE THEATER, the city's de facto town hall for alternative comedy. The second annual show, whose title is too racy for a family newspaper, is a summation of all things terrible about 2005, from pop culture to science to politics, with much comic riffing. Performed by a dozen or so of the brigade's regulars, the show is short (75 minutes) and sweet ($5). 8 p.m., 307 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 366-9176.

title: In Alabama, a Poor County Is Rich in Modern Architecture
description: "YOU come just in the nick of time," says Jimmy Lee Matthews, emerging from his house west of Greensboro, Ala. Buttoning his shirt, Mr. Matthews -- who refers to himself as Music Man -- instructs me to drive him to a store to pick up dog food for his mutts. He begins directing me down his driveway to my car, never asking who I am or where I've come from.

title: On the Not-So-Big Screen
description: To the Editor,

title: How Many Democrats Does It Take to
description: Anyone wondering why there were more Democratic dignitaries than baubles on the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree at last week's announcement that Essex County Executive Joseph DiVincenzo plans to seek re-election need only look at recent election figures and the big challenges that confront the state party and Mr. Corzine's administration.

title: Gazprom open to negotiation with Kiev
Memory, Workmaid and Mother of the Muses, Hits the Print Button
description: Frank Conroy, the author of the classic memoir "Stop-Time," succeeded so well at capturing "the attenuated agonies of growing up" that he justified the book's title. Vladimir Nabokov was no less true in the lyrical tale of himself, "Speak, Memory" -- the bounding lepidopterist caught in "the act of vividly recalling a patch of the past." And Allen Ginsberg, the poet who daily worked the dense turf of his own mortality, once offered me a beguiling summary of his obsession with life's flight as treasuring "the dearness of the vanishing moment."

title: Dinner, Movie ... and an Endless Intermission
description: WHEN the rural boarding school where we taught emptied for Christmas vacation, the campus became a deserted outpost. My wife, Elaine, and I were young, far from home and broke. We knew immediately that we had made a mistake by choosing not to travel west and join our families. You can only play so much Scrabble, and we had no television. The empty dorms echoed on every side as we tried to buck up and be brave.

title: Unfinished Business
description: Environmental and energy issues have been near the top of Gov. George Pataki's agenda since the day he took office. His stewardship of this week's groundbreaking agreement among seven Northeastern states to limit greenhouse gases from power plants -- a welcome antidote to the Bush administration's negativism at the recent global warming conference in Montreal -- is only the latest in a string of progressive achievements.

title: 'The Worst Hard Time'
The Most Valuable Art: Ready for Your Close-Up, Marlboro Man
description: In a year full of surprises, art sales in 2005 had the auction houses happily counting their profits. The biggest transaction, the New York Public Library's sudden sale of Asher B. Durand's 1849 Hudson River School masterpiece "Kindred Spirits" for a reported $35 million, was brokered privately by Sotheby's. (When the library tried auctioning its two Gilbert Stuart portraits of George Washington, however, only one sold.)

title: Shiites Decline Sunni Bid for More Iraq Parliament Seats
description: Baghdad, IRAQ, Dec. 25 - Sunni Arab political leaders asked the main Shiite political block today to give them 10 Shiite seats in the new parliament in an early attempt to defuse tensions over the results of last week's election. The Shiites refused the request.

title: What the Hurricane Wrought
description: When it became clear that the hurricane was coming, there was no question that Lawrence Celestine would have to face it. But first, he had his family to worry about. Early Saturday morning, Aug. 27, Celestine called his wife, Andrea, from work and told her to get up, because this "looks like it's going to be pretty bad."

title: Over the Top? Let's Count the Ways
description: NOT only is the Bugatti Veyron 16.4 the quickest, fastest and most expensive production car ever, it comes with a long list of standard superlatives, including these:

title: Patriarch Calls for Peace and Fall of Israeli Barrier
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, Sunday, Dec. 25 - The Latin patriarch of Jerusalem used his annual Christmas sermon in Bethlehem on Sunday to pray for a Holy Land "thirsting for peace" as he urged political leaders to create life rather than death.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 18 about two videos for the Kanye West single "Heard 'Em Say" misstated the circumstances of the departure of the director of the first clip. That director, Michel Gondry, finished the video. He was not fired.

title: BENEFITS
description: Film Honors on the Green JAN. 10 -- Jane Fonda and David Cronenberg will be among those honored and Paul Reiser will serve as the master of ceremonies at a dinner at the Tavern on the Green. The event is to raise money for the grants given to talented students and young filmmakers by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, as well as the board's free educational film seminars. Cocktails begin at 6. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 465-9166.

title: Bugatti Veyron 16.4: To Drive the Impossible Dream
description: MOLSHEIM, France - MANY people figured that Volkswagen lost touch with its customer base in 2003 when it introduced the Phaeton, a luxury sedan perfectly wonderful in almost every way save for a price tag that veered uncomfortably close to six figures.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The "Living In " article last Sunday, about Prospect Heights in Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to a proposal by Bruce C. Ratner to build a nearby complex of shops, offices, housing and a basketball arena. It would indeed be built over the Atlantic Avenue railyards, but also on adjacent land now occupied by residences and businesses.

title: When in Rome, Charge the Battery
description: HOLIDAYS aren't really about family, spiritual reflection and disposable home decorations from Target. They're about meals. We plotted and grew giddy at the thought of one kind of Christmas dinner; we ended up with quite another. Tell me a sadder tale.

title: Gifts of the Magi; For a young doctor far from home, an unexpected present from a homeless alcoholic.
description: BITTER winds churned up First Avenue and tore through the pathetically thin scrubs that Bellevue doled out to its interns. The December sky glowered the same leaden-green color of the bile that Dr. Kamal Singh was siphoning from the gut of Mr. Bill Porter, a homeless alcoholic with a Southern accent, a jauntily curled mustache and a battered walking stick. His skin was sallow and his eyes jaundiced. He squinted at Dr. Singh. "Thought they weren't giving visas to Arabs these days," he rasped.

title: Pulse: What I'm Wearing for New Year's Eve; The Denim Designers
description: Chip and Pepper Foster, who are twins and jeans designers, will bid aloha to 2005 in island style. "We'll be with 15 of our friends and family on Maui," Pepper said. "We've chartered a yacht that will take us out to sea for a five-course meal followed by a champagne celebration. At midnight we'll have a fireworks show over the water."

title: Gifts of the Magi
description: FOURTEEN thousand, seventeen dollars! Jim reread the bank statement, folded it and put it away. And Christmas was only a few weeks off!

title: Good Music and Bad, and Good Bad Music
description: 1. Florence Foster Jenkins -- the intersection of private wealth, ambition and disastrous optimism in New York's 1920's, 30's and 40's -- lives again in Judy Kaye's endearing portrayal in "Souvenir" at the Lyceum Theater. A nice bouquet to leave at music's monument to bad singing. May we cherish her always.

title: Forest Fever
description: Forest Fever

title: A Missing Piece
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying to plant mine, 4 Taliban suspects die
Tackling a Major Health Hazard: No Insurance
description: LINDA SURPRENANT cannot lift her right arm over her shoulder. Physical therapy could have solved that problem after surgery to repair a rotator cuff, but physical therapy is the kind of treatment people receive when they have health insurance.

title: 'A Sudden Country'
description: He carried his girl tied to his front, the trapsack on his back, the rifle balanced like a yoke along his shoulders. He walked all day on snowshoes, lost in effort, in steady breathing. The snow drove thick and clotted on his eyebrows, filled his beard. It cluttered his drawing breath.

title: A CLAUSE THAT REFRESHES
description: The Teamsters' general secretary-treasurer, C. Thomas Keegel, was riding high last week after noting that the Coca-Cola Company recently acceded to the union's plea on executive compensation. The company agreed to ask shareholders before agreeing to executive severance agreements that total at least 2.99 times the annual salary and bonus of the executive being severed.

title: Indicting honest journalism
New Haven's Quiet Man Packs a Powerful Punch
description: CHAD DAWSON grew up in New Haven and used to spend a lot of time at Ring One Boxing, a gym where youngsters from some of the city's poorest neighborhoods go to sweat and dream of one day becoming big-time fighters. But these days, he does not go by there much anymore.

title: Wish List: No More Books!
description: A few months ago, a friend whose iconoclastic, unpredictable behavior I usually hold in high esteem handed me a book entitled "A Navajo Legacy: The Life and Teachings of John Holiday." Apparently, he expected me to read it, despite the fact that I am not really a Navajo medicine man autobiography kind of guy. Flummoxed but gracious, I took the gift home and put it on a shelf alongside all the other books that friends have lent or given me over the years. This collection includes: "Loose Balls: The Short, Wild Life of the American Basketball Association"; "Hoosier Home Remedies"; "A Walk Through Wales"; "The Frontier World of Doc Holliday"; "Elwood's Blues: Interviews with the Blues Legends & Stars," by Dan Aykroyd and Ben Manilla; both "Steve Allen on the Bible, Religion, and Morality" and Allen's somewhat less Jesuitical "Hi-Ho, Steverino!"; and, of course, "Bloodline of the Holy Grail: The Hidden Lineage of Jesus Revealed." If I live to be 1,000 years old, I am not going to read any of these books. Especially the one about the American Basketball Association.

title: 'Living Wage' Approved For County Contracts
description: The Nassau County Legislature unanimously approved a "living wage" bill last Monday despite warnings from the county's state-imposed fiscal monitor that the county should not approve such a measure without first finding the money to pay for its effects.

title: Where the Midtown Direct, Oz and Springsteen Meet
description: IT was an hour before the 7 o'clock performance of the hit musical "Wicked" one recent night on Broadway, and backstage at the Gershwin Theater bubbled with the usual pre-curtain hubbub. One of Glinda the Good's dresses, stiff with blue rhinestones, stood on its own in the hall. Signs as green as the Wicked Witch directed visitors to the right dressing rooms.

title: Raptors' Youth Movement Puts Rose, and His Salary, on the Bench
description: Like a man collecting his pension while sitting on a porch, Jalen Rose has seen the parade of youngsters pass him by in Toronto. He refuses to believe he is finished at 32 years old.

title: Madcap Scores and New Gems
description: 1. For anyone who doubts that Elliott Carter's work is finding its way into the mainstream, James Levine and the Met Orchestra drew a standing ovation for a vivid, magnificently nuanced performance of the epochal Variations for Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in January. Later in the season, the New York Philharmonic caught up with the earlier and more easygoing "Holiday Overture."

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I lost 10 family members, and of course that is not easy. But time goes by, and I will accept it. That's life and death."

title: ONE OF THE GANG
description: Marsh & McLennan's new finance chief, M. Michele Burns, has spent most of her life in Georgia, but she will arrive at the company's headquarters in Manhattan in March with plenty of New York attitude about perks and money.

title: A Chilling Departure From the Capitol
description: One of the shabbiest shell games of the year was played out in the closing hours of Congress in its now-you-see-it, now-you-don't offering of some badly needed winter heating aid to the nation's working poor. The climactic moment occurred when Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, huckstering his most treasured goal, tried to sell oil drilling in his state's pristine wildlife preserve by promising it would help finance a long list of shoppers' bonuses for his colleagues: extra money for flu vaccine, hurricane reconstruction, first-responder radios and -- if you vote yes right away -- $2 billion in extra heating aid for the poor this cold winter.

title: Catfight!
description: CONDI VS. HILLARY

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 25 - Dec. 31.; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: For assorted reasons, the last week of the year is a challenge for the art-inclined. Those hoping to visit commercial art galleries may find that many are closed. So call ahead. As for museums, well, that's where everyone seems to be: from wandering tourists to harried locals shepherding visiting relatives, with or without footloose children.

title: 'The Case for Hillary Clinton'
description: Imagine the moment when a news anchor will say, "Based on all our projections, we can now say that the United States of America has elected its first woman president ..."

title: Ghosts of a Christmas Past, in Plastic and Tinsel
description: On a December day so cold and wonderful that faces flash-froze in smiles, we traipsed about a Christmas tree farm before settling on a Douglas fir as big as your Uncle Bob. I knelt in the snow to saw it at the stump, while my two young daughters cheered hooray and my wife went to pay a man whose knees were dry.

title: And for Bass-Levin, The Long Goodbye
description: One person headed for the private sector is Susan Bass-Levin, a former state commissioner of community affairs who was the Corzine campaign's chief of operations, although Mr. Leone said he hoped she would play a role in the administration.

title: Plans to Build Low-Rent Units Raise Question on Subsidies
description: One of the biggest problems facing New York City is its shortage of housing for people of moderate or modest means (people like the majority of New Yorkers, that is). There are all sorts of programs intended to encourage developers to build lower-priced housing. But, with land prices and construction costs shooting skyward, exactly how much public help does a private developer need?

title: East End Transit Plans Are on Two Paths
description: AFTER a four-year, $1 million federally financed study of transportation options for the East End, local officials have ended up about where they began.

title: Severance Pay Doesn't Go Better With Coke
description: IT may be only one inch on the road to reining in executive pay, but given the way this world works, it is progress nonetheless. Last week, under pressure from one of its big shareholders, the Coca-Cola Company adopted a new policy requiring that its stockholders approve any future executive severance agreements that amount to at least 2.99 times the recipient's annual salary and bonus. The shareholder forcing the issue was the International Brotherhood of Teamsters General Fund, which raised the proposal at Coca-Cola's annual meeting last April.

title: Switch On the Lights: It's Psychedelic Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn's Borough Hall is 83 years older than the Empire State Building, about 98 stories shorter, and infinitely less likely to be scaled by a giant ape on the big screen. The buildings have little in common at all, in fact. But as of this month, they do share at least one thing: Both are equipped with lighting systems that let them change colors on special occasions, much as if they were towering stone-and-steel mood rings.

title: He Said No to Internment
description: In February 1942, a little more than two months after the attack on Pearl Harbor, Franklin Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066, which effectively decreed that West Coast residents of Japanese ancestry -- whether American citizens or not -- were now "enemy aliens." More than 100,000 Japanese-Americans reported to government staging areas, where they were processed and taken off to 10 internment camps. Fred Korematsu, the son of Japanese immigrants, was at the time a 23-year-old welder at Bay Area shipyards. His parents left their home and reported to a racetrack south of San Francisco, but Korematsu chose not to follow them. He stayed behind in Oakland with his Italian-American girlfriend and then fled, even having plastic surgery on his eyes to avoid recognition. In May 1942, he was arrested and branded a spy in the newspapers.

title: Early This Season, Rules Changes Buoy N.H.L.
description: Dave Maloney loves it. A longtime National Hockey League defenseman and a current Rangers radio announcer, Maloney has watched scoring increase almost 20 percent this season, a rise typically ascribed to the league's new rules -- particularly officials' calling of penalties on defensemen who hook, obstruct and otherwise disembowel forwards who dare skate toward the net.

title: A Shelter Draws Attention To the Comforts It Provides
description: VALHALLA - DOWN at the bottom of a hill on Operations Drive, here on the campus of the Westchester Medical Center, is a nondescript three-story building that is home to the county's new $13 million homeless shelter. Inside, its hallways are clean and brightly colored, its communal kitchen spacious and its bedrooms newly renovated, all helping to give the feel of a cozy college dormitory.

title: U.S. AIDS policy
Giants, Playing as if There Is a Tomorrow, Do Not Clinch
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 24 - In a little room in the depths of FedEx Field, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin stood on a podium above the news media, calmly discussing a performance that none of the Giants could fully explain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BJOZE, JACK
description: BJOZE--Jack. Passed away peacefully at home on December 16, 2005. Predeceased by his wife, Ann, cherished father of Judy and Jane, dear grandfather of David, Debby, Jesse, and Michael. Beloved partner of Victoria, proud comrade of The Veterans of The Abraham Lincoln Brigade. We will miss you. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Iraqi Court Bars Candidates
description: An Iraqi court disqualified at least 90 candidates in the recent national elections from serving in Parliament because of their ties to Saddam Hussein's Baath Party. Page 18.

title: From Anti-'Uppity' to Upwardly Mobile
description: WHEN she was growing up in a New York City housing project, Stacy Abrego says, she thought that highly skilled professionals were "uppity." And she had no reason to change that view while holding a series of "little jobs here and there" into her mid-20's, she says.

title: Moving On After Bringing Good Business Sense to the Arts
description: Purchase - WHEN Christopher Beach looks back on his 16 years as head of the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College, he sees a picture of steady growth at the county's busiest arts complex. But he is especially proud of the teamwork he directed there.

title: What's the Meta?
description: Not to get hyper about this, but today's intro is about a usage by Anglos and heteros (as well as nymphos in their minis) that is going not just super but mega before it flames out as retro.

title: Five's a Crowd: The New Year's Eve TV Follies in Times Square
description: Along with thousands of revelers on New Year's Eve, nearly every major television countdown show is squeezing into Times Square. There will be the veterans, like "Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve," and the untested -- that would be "ESPN New Year's Eve." Although CBS is sticking with regular programming, other networks scrambled as the clock ticked down this year, swapping anchors from one broadcast to another.

title: These Meals, The Critics Would Buy Themselves
description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

title: Moving Uptown on Park
description: CHENG-CHING WANG, the father of the fashion designer Vera Wang, has lived for years at 740 Park Avenue, one of the city's most glamorous prewar co-ops. But in October, Mr. Wang bought a three-bedroom, three-bathroom apartment four blocks uptown, at 820 Park Avenue, at 75th Street, according to tax records filed with the city.

title: On advertising: When brands join cast, plot can get murky
Officials Want to Expand Review of Domestic Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 - Congressional officials said Saturday that they wanted to investigate the disclosure that the National Security Agency had gained access to some of the country's main telephone arteries to glean data on possible terrorists.

title: Visions From Nigeria and India and a Van Searching for Utopia
description: ANOTHER season of griping and cheerleading. Art fairs bordering on sales conventions were promoted as the most fabulous things. Aggrieved voices complained about the politics of hype, and about new art looking tiny and shiny and thin. A few old-time idealists dared to wonder if the art world shouldn't, maybe, offer a noncompliant critical alternative to the real world, of which it is at present an indistinguishable (and, let's face it, inconsequential) part.

title: A Woman of Verse
description: The first half of the 20th century, Ladies' Home Journal told a woman everything she needed to be a lady -- how to trim a sleeve, treat whooping cough, write a letter of condolence. But a lady then was not simply mistress of her domain; she was also a keeper of the soul -- a stewardess of culture -- who needed to be as well versed in literature and poetry as in needlework. And so L.H.J. published work by Sarah Orne Jewett, Jane Addams, Edith Wharton and Rudyard Kipling.

title: Trust and the Voting Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: Take It From Japan: Bubbles Hurt
description: KASHIWA, Japan - FOURTEEN years ago, Yoshihisa Nakashima looked at this sleepy suburb an hour and 20 minutes from downtown Tokyo and saw all the trappings of middle-class Japanese bliss: cherry-tree-lined roads, a cozy community where neighbors greeted one another in the morning and schools within easy walking distance for his two daughters.

title: The Most Original Pitch: Once Is Not Enough
description: It won every award imaginable -- the Tony, the Pulitzer, even the Lucille Lortel. It has made its money back (and then some) and repeatedly set box office records. So, do the producers of "Doubt, a Parable" really need repeat visitors? They gave that impression recently when they sent out a personal letter from the actress Cherry Jones. In what may be the most unusual pitch of the season, she asks audiences that have already seen "Doubt" to see it again with her replacement, Eileen Atkins, and a new leading man, Ron Eldard.

title: INTELLIGENT DESIGN
description: WORDS evolve, even those coined by skeptics of evolution. Consider "intelligent design," a phrase used for over a century by critics of Darwin but only recently bursting into prominence as both a concept and a movement intended to explain, its proponents say, the "irreducible complexity" of nature.

title: Rib Sticklers
description: MANVILLE - A DECADE ago, soon after arriving in New Jersey, I was invited to a barbecue. But I was skeptical. Did these people dig a pit in their backyard? Did they have a backyard? And did they need a permit to have a fire?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELGOROD, HOWARD H., DDS.
description: BELGOROD--Howard H., DDS. December 22, 2005. Beloved husband of Madeline (nee Bloom). Loving father of Morie and Barry. Cherished grandfather of Margot, Gregory & Douglas. He will be missed by all those whose lives he touched and improved. Services Monday, December 26, 2005, 10 AM at Temple Emanu - El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street.

title: The Music of Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: No Longer Young, Knicks' Starting Lineup Is Still Restless
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 24 - Moved by whimsy or by the Knicks' recent tailspin, the personnel pendulum in Coach Larry Brown's head swung from youth to experience again Friday night, this time pushing Channing Frye back to the bench.

title: Giving the Gift of Guilt
description: THERE is not much that is holy to Jackie Hoffman. Although she begins her one-woman show at Joe's Pub in Manhattan with an ardent rendition of Hanukkah songs, she quickly lapses into a faith of her own devising, where only humor is sacred and filthiness is next to godliness.

title: Keeping Tabs on PETA: What's Up With That?
description: WHEN it comes to aggrieved critters, the animal rights group known as PETA (People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) has never shied from standing up or suiting down.

title: As a Disaster, a 'Little Strike That Couldn't'
description: As defining moments go, the 60-hour transit strike of 2005 may prove to be pretty forgettable.

title: The Anti-Joads
description: THE WORST HARD TIME

title: In Criminal Cases, a Court Nominee Hews to Rules
description: If Samuel A. Alito Jr. had been on the Supreme Court back in January, Ronald Rompilla might well be a dead man.

title: Trade, Oppression, Revenge
description: The N.S.A. spying story garnered most of the headlines, but surely the Bolivian election was the most important thing that happened last week. That election illustrated many of the combustible phenomena we'll be dealing with for the rest of our lives. It demonstrated that economic modernization can inflame ethnic animosity, that democracy can be the enemy of capitalism and that globalization, far from bringing groups closer together, can send them off in wild and hostile directions.

title: The Truce of Christmas, 1914
Tsunami's Legacy: Extraordinary Giving and Unending Strife
description: JAFFNA, Sri Lanka - Charity came pouring in from far and wide for this island nation devastated by the tsunami a year ago. But on its fragile northern peninsula, Udayarani Sebastian Pillai today lives on the cliff-edge of uncertainty.

title: It's Harder to Change Your Plans These Days
description: Correction Appended

title: The Menendez Story, With All the Chapters
description: In anthropology, it's called the "charter myth," a fantastical beginning that societies invent for themselves to explain their existence or dominance.

title: They Shoot Adverbs, Don't They?
description: ON Dec. 24, 1928, the Volunteers of America gathered at the 71st Regiment Armory, on 34th Street and Park Avenue, to distribute 3,200 bundles of food to the city's poor. Mayor Jimmy Walker stopped by to praise those kind souls committed to spreading seasonal good will. "Christmas can be a pinnacle of joy," he said, "or it can throw one into the depths of sorrow."

title: Working to Keep That Small-Town Flavor
description: MOST residents of Dobbs Ferry, like Lyle and Jerrie Miller, say they have just about everything they need close at hand: good neighbors, fine schools, broad vistas and safe streets.

title: Health Insurance And Doctors' Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 11 about visiting Santa Cruz, Calif., with children misstated the name of a popular walking route to Natural Bridges State Park. It is West Cliff Drive, not East Cliff Drive.

title: Paperback Fiction
A Tempest Over Town Meetings
description: FIRST came the town meeting in New England, where residents were invited to debate issues, then vote on them. But for most municipalities, the sheer size of the town meeting became unwieldy. So along came mayors, first selectmen and town managers to run the show. Every so often, though, there is grumbling about the existing form of government.

title: Rain inundates towns of Western Sahara
Silent Nights on the Gulf Coast
description: Charlottesville, Va. - IN the harrowing days after Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast, the shellshocked and homeless survivors strung up tents and tarps wherever they could find standing shelter, anything to hide from the sun. Now, four months later, many of the tents remain: in the front lawns of once fine houses now gutted and unlivable, in small clearings between mountains of rubble, beside camping trailers too cramped for entire families, on concrete slabs wiped clean by the storm surge, even in the living rooms of houses with few walls but intact roofs. The sun is no longer the problem: instead, the most desperate of the hurricane's victims have stuffed tents of every imaginable make and model with Salvation Army blankets and mattresses to try to stay dry and warm.

title: Plane Crashes Into Caspian; 23 Are Killed
description: Correction Appended

title: Why Investors Don't Live by Currency Bets Alone
description: HEADING into 2005, conventional wisdom said that Americans should invest aggressively overseas because the dollar was expected to weaken further against foreign currencies.

title: Port, a Power Against the Chill
description: A warming Portuguese port is especially welcome during winter storms.

title: Rumor of Capitol's Death Greatly Exaggerated
description: CONTRARY to recent reports, the State Capitol is still standing.

title: Directors of 2 Theaters Announce Departures
description: The managing director of one theater and the executive director of another announced this month that they will be leaving their positions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, RICHARD HENRY
description: GROSS--Richard Henry, 83. Died at his home in Irvington, NY, December 10, 2005. Born February 25, 1922 in New York City to Rose Heiman and Sydney Lee Gross, he lived with his wife and children in Irvington for over 50 years. He had a successful 35 year career at Popsicle Industries, Inc., where he was Senior Vice President. He served on the Board of the YMCA of Tarrytown and was a founding member of the Irvington Volunteer Ambulance Corps. A fighter pilot with the U.S. Army Air Corps in WWII, he was stationed in England, flying the elite P-51 D Mustang. He leaves four children: Carey E. Gross, M.D., Patricia J. Gross, Andrew Jay Gross and Richard Gross, Jr.; a sister, Amy Gross Shimberg of Tampa, FL, a brother, Sydney L. Gross, Jr., of Dayton, OH, a granddaughter, Shauna McCormick and nine nieces and nephews. His beloved wife of 50 years, Betty Blum Gross, died in 2003. Donations may be made to: USAF Museum Foundation, PO Box 33624, Wright Patterson AFB, OH 45433; Friends of Irvington Library, Astor Place, Irvington, New York 10533.

title: Father and Daughter: One Final Connection
description: WHEN my father was fairly well along into the dementia of Alzheimer's -- not as far as he was to go, but four or five years in -- he developed a taste for looking attentively at trees. At the time I was not aware that this is a common pleasure for Alzheimer's patients, some of whom are known to enter a Zenlike state of meditation before them.

title: Kim Robinson and Andries Nel
description: YOU could call the union of Kim Robinson and Andries Nel a marriage of opposites. She is assertive and ebullient, while he is contemplative and reserved; she worships Venus and Serena Williams, while he never touches a tennis racket; she was a middle-class kid from Springfield Gardens, Queens, while his Afrikaner lineage dates from a 1688 landing at Cape Town, South Africa.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Choice Tables column on Dec. 11 about Budapest misstated the location of the Pest part of the city. It is on the left bank of the Danube, not the right.

title: If This Were a Headline
description: WHERE THREE ROADS MEET

title: Pulse: What I'm Wearing for New Year's Eve; The Event Planner
description: What does a party planner do on the biggest party night of the year? She stays home of course. Jung Lee, an owner of Fete, an event-planning company in Manhattan, is planning to ring in 2006 in the warmth of her own home. "I hate going outside on New Year's Eve," she said. "It's so cold, and you can never get a cab." Instead Ms. Lee has invited 20 friends over for dinner. "I love to entertain. I love to cook, to pick a menu, to choose the wine and music."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHLNECKER, LAWRENCE J.
description: STAHLNECKER -- Lawrence J. Died peacefully in NYC, December 23, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Rita. Loving father of Mary Anne, James and John. Loved like a father by son-in-law Kevin Sanborn and sister-in-law Virginia Walsh. Cherished grandfather of Kristin, Christopher, James Jr., Joseph and Eileen, and great-grandfather of Christopher, Alexandra and Lucas. Devoted uncle of Joanne, Thomas Walsh, George, Peter, Amy, Thomas Hart and Eileen. Great-uncle of Matthew, Megan, Thomas, Daniel, Lauren, James, John and Kevin. He leaves behind a large family who will remember him always as he was so loved. Family and friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, NYC, Monday, December 26, 7-9 pm, and Tuesday, December 27, 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial at 10 am, Wednesday, December 28, St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Discovering Auld Angst Syne
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE at the Wolitzer house on Ann Drive in Syosset tended to be as predictable as the celebration in Times Square. While those people caroused and clowned and cheerfully vomited, my sister and I ate rolled-up bologna slices speared with toothpicks, drank ginger ale, endlessly played Sorry, then watched TV as the glittering ball made its wobbly descent into the future. But the year I turned 10, existentialism paid me an unexpected visit, destroying the night and changing my life forever.

title: Theatrical Collectives and European Unions
description: AMID the blizzard of lists swirling through the mass media at this time of year, larger observations can easily get lost in a hail of opinion.

title: Colts, Resting Their Stars, End a Somber Week With a Loss
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 24 - SEAHAWKS 28, COLTS 13

title: Spurring Urban Growth in Vancouver, One Family at a Time
description: Vancouver, British Columbia - ELENITA TORRES and her husband, Dean Sherriff, didn't want to leave the city after having children. So about two years ago, the couple bought a two-bedroom, 1,440-square-foot town house in the Coal Harbour neighborhood, one of several waterfront developments that have sprung up in downtown Vancouver over the last few years.

title: Clone Scientist Relied on Peers and Korean Pride
description: When Dr. Hwang Woo Suk's recent reports of advances in cloning research were declared to have been fabricated on Friday, his disgrace left scientists wondering how he had risen so fast, deceived so many and fallen so hard.

title: A Good Pick
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ANSWER IS:
description: This quiz-show host is about to give up his seat on the board of a Hollywood penny-stock company. If you ask, "Who is Alex Trebek?" you are correct.

title: A Pass Defense in Name Only Versus the Redskins
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 24 - To Giants defensive end Michael Strahan, it didn't even seem as if the Washington Redskins passed very often on Saturday. And they didn't. Mark Brunell and Patrick Ramsey, who replaced Brunell in the third quarter after Brunell strained his right knee, attempted just 18 passes between them.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 25 - Dec. 31.; FILM
description: You could spend the week between Christmas and New Year hunting for masterpieces among the big holiday releases, or you could spend it in the company of an undisputed master. FILM FORUM is in the midst of a monthlong series devoted to "ESSENTIAL HITCHCOCK," and this week brings an excellent sampling of sinister delicacies and blondes in distress.

title: In midnight Mass, pope seeks peace in Mideast
Trying to Catch the Wind
description: ATLANTIC CITY - ED McDONALD, a low roller at the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa, was waiting for a jitney when he paused to gawk at what may turn out to be yet another of this city's tourist attractions -- the nation's first coastal wind farm, whose sleek 380-foot-high turbines stand like immense kinetic sculptures at the entrance to this seaside resort.

title: Editors' Choice
description: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

title: Alternative F
description: Most Canada geese are brave and noble creatures. They cycle mightily between Arctic and temperate zones in lofty V formations that herald the return of spring and fall and send a shiver through the soul.

title: Marshlands and Mosquitoes (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: For Indian diaspora, no place like home
Republican vs. Republican
description: Congress is getting unruly. Last week, the once-disciplined G.O.P. suffered a split over civil liberties, pitting President Bush and the party's leadership against the suddenly considerable weight of a handful of rebels. Four senators joined Democrats in a successful filibuster against renewal of the USA Patriot Act, set to expire this week, unhappy with some of its anti-terror tactics. News that the president authorized secret domestic eavesdropping by the National Security Agency only sharpened their worries and doomed renewal this year.

title: Pols Deserve a Raise? Says Who?
description: TWO years ago during the holiday season, Yonkers City Council members gave themselves and Mayor Philip A. Amicone a roughly 20 percent increase in salary.

title: DAUGHTER TRACK
description: FIRST came the mommy track, the exodus of many young professional women from the workplace when juggling career and children seemed a recipe for shortchanging both. These women interrupted promising careers, usually in their 30's, with the expectation that when their children needed them less they would find a way to return.

title: A horse is a first course, of course, of course
Prodded by Couple, Bronxville Gears for a Tax Revaluation
description: BRONXVILLE - IT has been almost a year since Elisabeth S. Harding and her husband, Thomas C. Hutton, set the village abuzz with talk of inequities in the local property tax roll.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 25, 2005
description: Weeks

title: The Western End Of Long Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, RUBIN
description: GREENBERG--Rubin. Passed away peacefully at his Manhattan home in the presence of his family on December 16, 2005 at the age of 81 after a brief illness. He was a World War II veteran and served as a glider co-pilot in the Army Air Corps 441st Troop Carrier Command and saw action with the 82nd and 101st Airborne Divisions in the European Theater of Operations in the Invasions of Normandy, Southern France, Eindhoven, and the Rhine Crossing. In his military service he earned 4 Battle Stars, and a Presidential Citation and Silver Cluster for bravery. His business career was in the juvenile furniture and toy industries, as the former owner of Kiddicraft Furniture, VP Sales, Bilt Rite Baby Carriage, Brooklyn, NY and President of Rubin Greenberg, Inc. which represented major brands such as Hedstrom and Childcraft in the New York City area. Predeceased by his wife Nancy Greenberg, he is survived by his three sons Dr. Alex M. Greenberg, and Dr. Bruce L. Greenberg, of Manhattan and Mr. Jesse D. Greenberg of Morganville, N.J.; Grandchildren Aurie, Elliane; Lila; Daniel, Hannah, and Sophie; and Daughtersin-Law Sigal, Janine, and Karen. Burial was at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York on December 18, 2005. Donations may be made to: Chabad Lubavitch Mitzvah Tank, 1444 President Street, Brooklyn, NY 11213.

title: Pulse: What I'm Wearing for New Year's Eve; The Producer
description: In the last 15 years Dallas Austin, 34, has produced hits for TLC, Boys II Men, Madonna, Michael Jackson, Shakira, Bjork, Monica and Gwen Stefani. He describes his personal style as eclectic. Mr. Austin, who produced the 2002 movie "Drumline," based on his experience in a high school marching band, plans to celebrate New Year's Eve with family and friends in Miami or Atlanta.

title: Song prices online face an inquiry
Fiddling with Formats While DVD's Burn
description: The war for control of the next-generation DVD is approaching a critical juncture: next week in Las Vegas at the Consumer Electronics Show, companies championing the two competing high-definition DVD standards - Blu-ray and HD DVD - will unveil their lineups of new players and movie titles.

title: Old Masters and New Ethical Lapses
description: Correction Appended

title: Tidings of Pride, Prayer and Pluralism
description: THE VICTORY OF REASON

title: The 10th Beatle
description: The Beatles are the most famous rock group that has ever existed or ever will exist. They are, in fact, the second-most-famous four-human collective within any context whatsoever (the four Gospel writers are No. 1; Notre Dame's 1924 "Four Horsemen" backfield rank a distant third). Moreover, the Beatles are the only band whose population is central to their iconography: John, Paul, George and Ringo shall always be the Fab Four. And because that number is so important, pop historians have spent decades trying to decide who deserves classification as Beatle No. 5.

title: Melissa Goldstein and Joshua Mitgang
description: Melissa Anne Goldstein, a daughter of Lisa Goldstein and Dr. Irwin Goldstein of Merrick, N.Y., is to be married today to Joshua Theodore Mitgang, the son of Linda Mitgang and Dr. Charles Mitgang of Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi Kenneth Hain is to perform the ceremony at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, N.Y.

title: When the Muse Is a Train
description: ON Tuesday, as the city awoke to a transit strike and semipanicked questions about how to get around, perhaps no one was more befuddled by the subway closures than Travis Ruse, a soft-spoken 37-year-old photo editor who lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Thanks and Goodbye
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Albert L. Weimorts, Designer of Big Bombs, Dies at 67
description: Albert L. Weimorts, a civilian engineer for the Air Force who conceived and designed some of the biggest, most powerful nonnuclear bombs ever made, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Fort Walton Beach, Fla. He was 67.

title: Corrections
description: The byline for an article on Dec. 18 about Chita Rivera and her homage to choreographers misspelled the writer's last name. She is Claudia La Rocco, not La Rocca.

title: The Sudden Reporter
description: Correction Appended

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Dec. 25 - Dec. 31.; TELEVISION
description: Ho, ho, ho, it's slim pickings this week. But among the gems is the Monday lineup on Turner Classic Movies, which features some of the best movies ever. It begins at 8:30 a.m. with the philosophical thriller "THE THIRD MAN" (starring JOSEPH COTTEN and ORSON WELLES). That leads into "SUNSET BOULEVARD" (10:30 a.m.), the 1950 evisceration of Hollywood celebrity that is more relevant than ever. Then you've got a marathon of "THE PHILADELPHIA STORY" (12:30 p.m.), "IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT" (2:30 p.m.), "CASABLANCA" (4:30 p.m.) and the original "KING KONG" (6:15 p.m.). There is no reason to leave the couch.
