title: $100 Million Was Just a Nice Start
description: HUGE financial contributions. A newly discovered Beethoven manuscript. Surprising financial health at a number of orchestras.

title: Redstone's double vision
Briefly: Gunmen kill legislator at midnight Mass
The muddied waters of identity
A Fireplace Glows in Brooklyn, Inside Their Weekend Home
description: IT was the double crunch of Friday and Sunday night tunnel traffic -- a vise on each weekend's dose of bucolic escape -- that finally prompted Elaine and Stephen Crane to sell their 1790's farmhouse in Bucks County, Pa.

title: No Headline
description: Company Man: Slade, above, started at Bear Stearns when it had about 50 employees and saw it reach 12,000.; John H. Slade b. 1908 (Photograph by Lisa Kereszi)

title: Digital Altruism and New York Goes Country
description: BEST REASON JENNIFER LOPEZ GOT RADIO PLAY -- First Sony BMG (J. Lo's label), then Warner Music Group paid multimillion-dollar settlements after investigations by the New York State attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, found significant use of payola. Who needs request lines?

title: Drug Convict Wins Grant of Clemency From Pataki
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday commuted the sentence of a Manhattan man serving nine years in prison for drug possession, the 33rd time he has taken such action in his 11 years as governor.

title: Contributors
description: Charles Mcgrath (Wellington Mara, Page 22) Is A Writer At Large For The Times.

title: 2005: In a Word
description: AS the conflict in Iraq has grown older, the lexicon of war has changed, too.

title: Downhill Cycling, Minus One Wheel
description: SIMPLY balancing atop a unicycle looks impressive enough to people who have never tried one-wheeled locomotion. So the mind boggles at the exploits of Kris Holm, whose hobby is unicycling down mountainsides, leaping over any boulders, culverts and logs he encounters along the way. Mr. Holm's most daring forays have included a plunge down Mexico's highest volcano, El Pico de Orizaba, and a unicycling trek through the Himalayas.

title: Sex and the Single Mom
description: I'M NO SAINT

title: The Most Inspiring Location: Turning Every Lens on New Orleans
description: Before Hurricane Katrina, New Orleans made infrequent appearances on the big screen -- in a steamy noir, say, or a history of traditional jazz. But now the city has become perhaps the year's favorite setting as filmmakers race to explore the implications of the storm.

title: CALENDAR
description: Theater

title: At Luxury Hotels, the Last Word in Showers and Tubs
description: Hotels have poured millions of dollars into upgrading mattresses and thread counts on sheets. Now, bathrooms are getting the same luxury treatment with bigger tubs, showers with enough nozzles to mimic a carwash and niche brand bath products.

title: Jumping at the Chance to Return to New York
description: AFTER nine years in Seattle, Mark Marvel was more than ready to come home to New York.

title: Brooklyn's Railyards: The Fight Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: A Man Who Knows That Design Is Personal
description: PRINCETON - THE jittery signature of Michael Graves -- one of the most prominent architects and product designers of his generation -- is a linear motif that graces a range of domestic products. But no nameplate adorns the entry of his own house, here in Princeton. Instead, an open sarcophagus sits by the front door. It is not a macabre display but a visual play on his surname and a nod to the classical tradition that has inspired his career.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: TAB HUNTER CONFIDENTIAL: The Making of a Movie Star. By Tab Hunter with Eddie Muller. (Algonquin, $24.95.) The interesting thing about Hunter has never been his soporific movies, like "Island of Desire" or "Lust in the Dust," or even his treacly 1957 hit single, "Young Love." It's himself. In his memoir, Hunter provides a mesmerizing account of his Candide-like journey through Hollywood. Never a gifted actor, Hunter, who grew up in Southern California, rode his all-American looks to a seven-year studio contract with Warner Brothers, which signed him up at age 23 and transformed him almost overnight into a teeny-bopper idol. The twist, of course, was that Hunter, like any number of Hollywood leading men, was gay. He soon chafed under a rigid studio system that seemed designed to wring any lingering vestiges of spontaneity out of filmmakers and actors, though it had some advantages. It offered not only a steady salary, but protection from scurrilous rags like Confidential magazine, which sought to out the stars of the day. Hunter offers shrewd assessments of the studio moguls Jack Warner and Harry Cohn, as well as hilarious anecdotes about working with Natalie Wood, Rita Hayworth and Lana Turner. After Warner Brothers cut him loose, Hunter's career stalled, but how sorry can you feel for someone who was whizzing around Capri and hanging out with Ingrid Bergman in his mid-20's? His foray into Tinseltown's past should help revive his name, but not, one suspects, his films.

title: A Grand New Studio, and 6 to Spare
description: WHEN it comes to the competition for New York City real estate, dance has often lost. This year, it won. Five new dance spaces have opened in Manhattan in the last year or so, and two more are in the works. Either the dance world is less impoverished than has long been thought, or else it has had a very lucky year.

title: Remains Found in Suitcase in the Bronx
description: A man searching through trash in the Bronx early yesterday found a human torso and a leg in a discarded suitcase, the police said. They said the remains appeared to be those of a man.

title: Job for Life
description: It is hard to say who was getting the better deal: Bear Stearns, a tiny Wall Street investment house, or Hans Schlesinger, who showed up for an interview in March 1936. Schlesinger, who was then 27, had arrived in New York City from Europe the day before with $50 in his pocket; he had decided to emigrate after the newly enacted Nuremberg laws prompted the president at his Frankfurt sports club, where Schlesinger excelled at field hockey, to strike him from the roster. He was a Jew, the president explained, and the opposing team would not play against a team with a Jew. So Schlesinger came to America, and here he was at 1 Wall Street, and there was the promise of another life ahead if he could only land this job. Bear Stearns, a mainly Jewish partnership, then employed some 50 people. When Joseph Bear offered him a position that day, Schlesinger immediately went to work.

title: Dutch Struggle to Prevent Terror and Protect Rights
description: AMSTERDAM - Samir Azzouz is only 19, but for almost three years Dutch authorities have struggled without success to punish him for what they see as plotting terrorism.

title: Reasoning the Need: Which of Our Things Are Superfluous?
description: Since, for an awful lot of people, this is a day that's almost entirely about stuff, it seems a good time to pause and consider exactly what stuff really matters to the American of the species.

title: Finland Makes Its Swedes Feel at Home
description: In many parts of the world, language can be a fiery and divisive issue, one that pits the powerless against the powerful, the small against the big.

title: She Sees Dead People
description: THE MAN FROM BEYOND

title: A Gift to the World, and Ourselves
description: ALTUS, Okla. - Here's a Christmas gift we should give ourselves: a firm commitment to cut farm subsidies sharply, above all for cotton.

title: Power Players
description: To the Editor:

title: Admissions and the Cold Slap of Rejection
description: Kevin Friedenberg was certain he had played by all the rules of the college recruiting game.

title: Got Beef? Not Anymore
description: Soon the meatpacking district will exist in name only, the butcheries and sellers of huge slabs of beef and pork replaced by boutiques, nightclubs and meat markets of another kind. The latest of the old-guard businesses poised to depart is Western Beef, the discount grocer and meat wholesaler on West 14th Street, which will close its doors next summer.

title: Contested Plan In Chelsea
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: These Meals, The Critics Would Buy Themselves
description: SOME restaurants have a special something that exerts a gravitational pull on even the most discerning critic. It's in the details: a perfectly seared steak, a smooth pistachio ice cream, the waiter whose happy bearing and good manners make you feel like royalty.

title: Breathless Duets, and a Giselle for the Ages
description: THERE is a sinful pleasure in compiling 10-best lists, especially in movies and rock 'n' roll -- in imperiously ordering achievements from 1 down to 10. Having matured or mellowed or wimped out, I find it wiser to content myself with a roughly chronological consideration of highlights.

title: Nixon's Real Enforcer
description: Rose Mary Woods loved to dance. In the old days, when they were just a small group in the vice president's office, she and the gang would head out to a Washington hotel, perhaps the Mayflower, which had a dance floor and a small band. In high-heeled shoes with ankle straps, sometimes with one of the Nixon advance men as a partner, Woods was a joyful sight, cutting loose after a 12-hour grind at the vice president's side. "She was a redhead, and fun," recalled Herb Klein, an early Nixon supporter who later became White House communications director.

title: Private equity firm agrees to buy Hilfiger
Mealhada, Portugal: This Little Piggy Is a Tasty Lure
description: SUCKLING pig is to Mealhada, a town in central Portugal, what cassoulet is to Toulouse: a culinary specialty that it calls its own. Since the 18th century, the moist, smoky, crispy allure of the dish, known locally as leito assado, has been a magnet for locals and tourists.

title: Tied Up in Knots
description: FIVE or so years ago, I had a temporary job supervising gift wrappers for the holidays in one of the biggest, most expensive department stores in Manhattan. You know this store. Even if you never shop there, you've heard of it or seen the window displays.

title: Professors' Politics Draw Lawmakers Into the Fray
description: While attending a Pennsylvania Republican Party picnic, Jennie Mae Brown bumped into her state representative and started venting.

title: Rell Wants to Bolster Drunken Driving Cases
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rell gave the State Department of Motor Vehicles recommendations on Tuesday on ways to reduce what she believes is the alarming number of drunken driving cases that are dismissed because of procedural problems.

title: Late Start Doesn't Stop the Dodgers' Rebuilding
description: THE Los Angeles Dodgers' new general manager, Ned Colletti, put the team's bizarre off-season into perspective. "It's never a good sign when you're interviewing managerial candidates and you're running from airport to airport, the music is Christmas carols," he said. "It's the wrong time to be looking for a manager."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBIN, LAWRENCE
description: LUBIN--Lawrence. 75 years old, on December 22, 2005, of Englewood, N.J. Beloved husband of Ellie. Devoted father of Miriam Bloom (Alan) and Jay Lubin (Francie). Loving grandfather of Matthew, Adam and Jeffrey and loving brother of Melvin and Edward. Larry was a retired Actuary. He waged a 54 year battle against the effects of polio, always with an optimistic attitude. In spite of his handicap, he worked and was a tireless volunteer-tutoring youngsters in the Bronx, working for years with cancer victims to gain benefits for them. He chaired the Tenants-Landlord Commission in Englewood and was an active member of Englewood's Board of Education. The funeral will be at GuttermanMusicant, Passaic and Park Streets in Hackensack, New Jersey at 12:30 P.M. on Monday, December 26.

title: Court Fight Overshadows Yonkers Project
description: YONKERS - FOR years, development of Ridge Hill, off the New England Thruway not far from Stew Leonard's, was billed as just the thing that could pull this city out of an economic depression and raise its spirits. The project, a $660 million complex of stores and apartments, would provide desperately needed money and visitors, backers said.

title: What Makes a Nation More Productive? It's Not Just Technology
description: IN 2001, the stock market meltdown and a brief recession threw cold water on the widely held belief that the United States economy, juiced by a technological revolution, had entered a new era of limitless, inflation-free growth. But today, as bubble-era books like "Dow 36,000" collect dust on library shelves, evidence is mounting that there may be a new economy after all.

title: Who Inherits the Tickets?
description: My elderly mother owns two season tickets to the New York Giants. For about 20 years, she has always sold one to me and one to my sister. For the past six years, my sister has declined the offer, and I've bought both season tickets. I believe that after our mother dies, the pair belong to me because my sister persistently relinquished the opportunity to buy one of them. She thinks she can reclaim possession of a ticket. Whose tickets are they? Anonymous

title: Sri Lanka
description: A year after the tsumani, luxury-seeking tourists are discovering an Eden-like paradise.

title: Bucharest: A City in Transition
description: Bucharest is redefining itself again, and in the process, is becoming an intruiging alternative destination in Europe.

title: Face of Sacrifice in Iraq
description:
This summer, Adam Nadel, a photographer, and a
team of five interpreters met with several Iraqis
whose lives have been upended by violence.

title: Why We Travel
description: A collection of recent photographs from the Why We Travel column.

title: Illustrations From 'The Quitter'
description: Harvey Pekar's memoir of a violent youth is illustrated by Dean Haspiel.

title: Trying to Have It Both Ways
description: It might seem counterintuitive that many credit card companies would inundate the recently bankrupt with solicitations for new cards. It's especially perplexing that those same companies would do so after having spent more than eight years and $100 million lobbying Congress to protect them from irresponsible borrowers with a draconian new bankruptcy law.

title: All Christmas, at Least Part of the Time
description: Every year, radio analysts predict a plateau in the number of stations that make a seasonal switch to round-the-clock Christmas music. And every year, they are wrong: the Christmas bandwagon has only been getting fuller.

title: Edwards Is Proud of His Battered Troops
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 22 - A rapping on the door roused Jets Coach Herman Edwards from the couch where he was being interviewed about his team's dysfunctional season.

description: OSBORNE--Ann. 97, hat designer extraordinare, a wizard with the stitch. Beloved wife of the late noted voice teacher, Seymour Osborne. Devoted mother of former broadcast news executive and Cuomo Administration Communication official, Steven. She was always there for me, her loving son, Steven

title: A Quantum Sampler
description: Thoughts on quantum theory by various scientists:

title: Underground Entrance
description: First comes the river crossing -- the cab yards and storage facilities north of the river, the unexpected light, even on a dark night, from the city reflected in the water. Then comes 125th Street and the run of blocks leading south to the maw of Metro-North, the place where the train slips into the tunnel of its own rail clatter on the long descent to Grand Central. I used to be one of the passengers who stayed seated until the end of the trip, happily reading or dozing or dwelling in blankness. But now I get up as soon as we reach the tunnel. I stand by one of the doors. I watch the darkness slip past.

title: Turkey charges editor again
MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF you can get past how flawless Nicole Kidman's eye makeup and blusher look as she suffers Civil War privations, then you can enjoy Anthony Minghella's COLD MOUNTAIN (2003), based on the Charles Frazier novel. Ms. Kidman's character, Ada Monroe, is no Scarlett O'Hara. She spends a lot of time dithering as she waits for the return of Inman (Jude Law), a stunning but shy local boy with whom she shared one long, heart-stopping kiss before he shipped out. Luckily she has the help of Ruby Thewes (Rene Zellweger), an earthy hired hand who knows how to plow, plant, shoot and wring a rooster's neck without blinking an eye. Ms. Zellweger won the best supporting actress Oscar -- Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:05 a.m. on Starz.

title: Seeking a Public Voice on China's 'Angry River'
description: XIAOSHABA, China - Far from the pulsing cities that symbolize modern China, this tiny hillside village of crude peasant houses seems disconnected from this century and the last. But follow a dirt path past a snarling watchdog, sidestep the chickens and ducks, and a small clearing on the banks of the Nu River reveals a dusty slab of concrete lying in a rotting pumpkin patch.

title: Ravens Beat Vikings and Giants Clinch Playoff Berth
description: The Baltimore Ravens did for the Giants late Sunday what the Giants could not do for themselves. They handed the Giants a playoff berth, and took a little pressure off the Giants to win their final regular-season game in Oakland on Saturday.

title: Giving the Elderly Choices on Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Jansen Puts Skating Skills to Work
description: CHICAGO - Dan Jansen left international speedskating in 1994, finally reaching the top of the Olympic medal stand after years of frustration. At the same time, the swiftest skaters in the N.H.L. were beginning to voice their frustrations about the prevalence of clutching and grabbing and about officiating that seemed to favor physicality over speed.

title: Sharon has small hole in his heart
Picturing Some Shocks That Flesh Is Heir To
description: With war photographs confronting us daily, do we need an exhibition to remind us of the body's vulnerability? But the havoc caused by war is only one aspect of it. There is disease, domestic violence, environmental pollution, the enfeeblement of old age, starvation, drug addiction and more -- much more. It's a gloomy picture and "The Body at Risk: Photography of Disorder, Illness and Healing" at the International Center of Photography is not for the squeamish. But the show is not all downbeat.

title: When News Breaks, Flashy Content Loses Out
description: NY1 News, the local news channel for the cable customers of Time Warner in New York, boasts on its Web site that its all-digital newsroom is "one of the most advanced newsgathering operations in the world." But last week the site was not much of a showcase for the channel's technological prowess.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VIETOR, ANNA GLEN BUTLER
description: VIETOR--Anna Glen Butler. On December 20, 2005 at home. She is survived by her six children, David, Richard, Alexander W., Anna Louise Vietor Oliver, Pauline Vietor Sheehan, and Martha Vietor Glass, 23 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. Her husband, Alexander Orr Vietor, and a seventh child, Barbara Foster Vietor, predeceased her. Born 1917in New York, she was the daughter of the late Arthur Wellman and Anna Robinson Butler, and a member of the class of 1935 at Chapin School. A descendant of several of New Yorks oldest families, she was presented at court to King George VI in 1937. A noted philanthropist with a particular interest in history, education, culture, and beautification, she served on the boards of numerous organizations. As president of The Acorn Foundation, she produced award-winning documentary films. She received many honors and awards including the Order of the Orange-Nassau by Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands in recognition of her efforts to promote pre-colonial Dutch history. A funeral service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York City on January 3 at 11 AM. Flowers welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GLICKSMAN, ALBERT
description: GLICKSMAN--Albert. Aly, Happy Anniversary on the 24th, Merry Christmas on the 25th, and Happy Birthday on the 26th. Love, Fran

title: Winners and Losers in Iraq
description: The final votes must still be counted in Iraq, but the trend is already clear. The biggest winners appear to be the Shiite religious parties whose politicians have run the ministries and whose militias have run the streets of southeastern Iraq for a year or more. The Kurdish separatist parties that supported this arrangement in exchange for absolute control of the Kurdish northeast also appear to have fared well.

title: 20 Years Later, Theismann Revisits Replay
description: ASHBURN, Va., Dec. 22 - It was one of the ghastliest sports injuries captured on television, and Joe Theismann had spent 20 years avoiding the replay. He would turn his head if clips were being shown of the tackle by Lawrence Taylor that snapped his right leg during ABC's broadcast of "Monday Night Football."

title: Indians Find They Can Go Home Again
description: BANGALORE, India - Standing amid the rolling lawns outside his four-bedroom villa, Ajay Kela pondered his street in the community of Palm Meadows. One of his neighbors recently returned to India from Cupertino, Calif., to run a technology start-up funded by the venture capital firm Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers.

title: Election Results Suggest Small Role For Sunnis in Security Forces
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 26 - Partial voting results made public today from the recent parliamentary election suggest that in contrast to the remarkable surge in Sunni Arab participation in the political process, Sunnis still have comparatively little representation in the Iraqi security forces.

title: A New Civil Rights Movement
description: One of the cruelest aspects of slavery was the way it wrenched apart black families, separating husbands from wives and children from their parents.

title: INSIDE
description: When Water Hardens From that run-in with Titanic to the prospect of global warming, a science writer examines the power of water in its solid form. Books of The Times, Page 16.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Faces D.W.I. Charges
description: A police officer was arrested in East New York yesterday morning and charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said. The officer, Robert Vargas, from Transit District 33 in Brooklyn, was pulled over and arrested at Williams Avenue and East New York Avenue shortly before 6 a.m. He has been suspended from the Police Department, the police said.

title: Brown's Pain Is Genuine, but Then It Always Is
description: To the delivery man, the doorman and the man on the street, Larry Brown is a walking manifestation of good fortune -- a New Yorker coaching his hometown Knicks, earning tens of millions of dollars for the honor.

title: Three tyrants, one test
Trading Status for a Raise
description: Ricardo Stefano spends 11 hours a day, five days a week brushing the scuffed oxfords and dusty loafers of businessmen near Grand Central Terminal, something he has been doing since arriving from Brazil 15 years ago.

title: Respect Your Elders
description: Nam Khem, Thailand - WHEN I arrived at this small fishing village on the Andaman Sea, a little less than two weeks after the tsunami hit last Dec. 26, I had little hope that it would survive. With the Thai government's relief efforts initially focused on nearby tourist areas, it seemed that Nam Khem, which lost half of its 5,000 residents to four massive waves, had been abandoned. Then, overnight, the world came to the rescue.

title: Investors play a guessing game with dollar
Contender Demurs on Italy Bank Post
description: ROME, Dec. 24 - Mario Monti, a top contender to take over the embattled Bank of Italy, withdrew from the running on Saturday, saying he had other plans.

title: Some pain and gain for media in N.Y. transit strike
A Sure Thing for Kazakhs: Horses Will Provide
description: ILYINKA, Kazakhstan, Dec. 20 - The six Kazakh villagers circled the stallion with movements so nimble and practiced that they disguised the difficulty of the dawn's first task. The animal before them, weighing roughly 550 pounds, was to be rolled onto its back.

title: Holiday Today
description: Christmas is legally observed.

title: Zimbabwe's Opposition Party 'Expels' Its Leader (but Not for Sure)
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 25 - Leaders of Zimbabwe's sole democratic opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, decided to expel their president over the weekend, deepening an already yawning internal split that has brought the party to the brink of insignificance.

title: 2 Jersey Police Officers Drive Off Bridge in Fatal Accident
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 26 - One Jersey City police officer was killed and another is believed dead after their vehicle drove off a vertical lift bridge in dense fog on Christmas Day and plunged 45 feet into the frigid waters of the Hackensack River, the authorities said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brentwood: Man Dies In Fire
description: An unidentified man was killed yesterday afternoon in a basement fire in a Suffolk County home, firefighters said. The fire on, South Fifth Avenue, broke out about 4 p.m. in a two-story wood-frame house, according to the Brentwood Fire Department. The man was found in a basement bedroom, the only area with major damage. Nearly 50 firefighters responded to the scene, bringing the fire under control within 15 minutes, officials said. There were no other injuries, and the first and second floors of the house sustained moderate smoke damage. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, the authorities said. JENNIFER MEDINA (NYT)

title: Collector Cars With Stories All but Impossible to Beat
description: CHATHAM, Ontario - COPS and robbers. Heroes against villains. Good versus evil.

title: Fleeing Sudan, Only to Languish in an Egyptian Limbo
description: CAIRO, Dec. 25 - They started to arrive in late September, first a few who decided to camp out in the middle of a small park, more a median strip in the middle of traffic in one of Cairo's more upscale neighborhoods.

title: An Even Longer SAT
description: To the Editor:

description: Public demonstrations against a newspaper's editorial views are not uncommon. But it is highly unusual for anyone to protest a newspaper's internal business decisions.

description: MIAMI, Dec. 25 - Gary Payton was running his mouth as tirelessly as he had throughout his 16-year career, spewing some trash-talking psychology to get into Lamar Odom's head, all the while blanketing Kobe Bryant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NIERENBERG, YVETTE
description: NIERENBERG--Yvette. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother of Stuart (Carol) and the late Marilyn (Daniel) Nierenberg-Shaoul and loving grandmother of Katherine and Pamela Shaoul, passed away December 23, in Scottsdale. Graveside service at Riverside Cemetery (201843-7600), Saddle Brook, NJ, 10:30 am, Monday, December 26. Memorial service will be held in Scottsdale in January.

title: Dozens Sickened After Gas Is Released  in St. Petersburg
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 26 - The peak of the Russian holiday shopping was disrupted for a St. Petersburg retail chain today when two of its stores were struck by devices that emitted foul-smelling gas. At least 77 people were sickened by the odor, though none seriously, the authorities said.

title: New Magazine for the Wealthy May Not Want You as a Reader
description: Magazines used to try just to be popular, but these days some are more like velvet-rope nightclubs: the reader needs to impress them to get in.

title: The Dark Side Of the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: The Face and Voice of Civilian Sacrifice in Iraq
description: Adam Nadel photographed the Iraqis shown on these two pages in Baghdad from June to August. Five interpreters helped him document their memories of encounters with the violence of war and its lingering effects on their lives. The interpreters are Omar al-Niami, Madeeh Qassem, Hosham Ahmad Hussein, Khalid al-Ansary and Layla Istifan.

title: Penn State Star Seeks His Biggest Victory
description: TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 20 - When Henry Hali's children were young, he had a rule about Christmas gifts: no toy guns. "People with guns, it makes me very nervous," he said in an interview at his home here. "These things were not in our household."

title: Giving the Elderly Choices on Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorism test flawed
Where Pragmatism Begets Beauty and a Subtle Spirituality
description: The first thing you notice about the 80 works included in "Marks of Distinction: Two Hundred Years of American Drawings and Watercolors From the Hood Museum of Art" at the National Academy Museum is how beautifully made many of them are. Organized to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the founding of the Hood Museum at Dartmouth College, the exhibition is a good reminder of what a pleasure it can be to behold fine technique in visual or any other art.

title: Viacom Comes to the Great Divide, and Calls It a Path to Growth
description: On Jan. 3, Sumner M. Redstone will get his wish when Viacom, the sprawling media company he built, is split into two separate entities.

title: New Cultural Approach for Conservative Christians: Reviews, Not Protests
description: Like other reviewers of "Brokeback Mountain," Steven Isaac was impressed by the quality of the filmmaking. But for Mr. Isaac, who reviews movies for the conservative Christian organization Focus on the Family, the movie, about a love affair between two male ranch hands, posed other critical challenges.

title: No gold yet, but Kwan has sterling reputation with advertisers
Lobbyist and Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about a report that a Chinese researcher for The New York Times had been indicted on charges of disclosing state secrets to the newspaper and on a lesser charge of fraud referred incorrectly in some copies to the time and place President Bush raised the matter with President Hu Jintao of China. It was in September in New York, when Mr. Bush presented a list of troubling human rights cases to Mr. Hu, not in November in Beijing.

title: All About Ice: Can't Live With It, Can't Live Without It
description: Ice The Nature, the History and the Uses of an Astonishing Substance By Mariana Gosnell Illustrated. 560 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Medicine: Who Decides?
description: Health care seems to be heading back to the top of the political agenda, and not a moment too soon. Employer-based health insurance is unraveling, Medicaid is under severe pressure, and vast Medicare costs loom on the horizon. Something must be done.

title: Eliot Freidson, 82, Dies; Studied Structure of Professions
description: Eliot Freidson, a sociologist at New York University who studied the inner workings of society's professions, particularly the way doctors are organized to practice medicine, died on Dec. 14 in a hospice in San Francisco. He was 82.

title: Sharon to Undergo Heart Catheterization
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 26 - Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel has a small hole in his heart that apparently contributed to his mild stroke last week, and he will undergo a catheterization procedure within three weeks to repair the problem, his doctors said today.

title: Remembering those lost to the tsunami
Seeing Terrorism as Drama With Sequels and Prequels
description: "There's no peace at the end of this," warns Avner, the morally anguished Mossad assassin, as Steven Spielberg's new film, "Munich," draws to a close. And by "this" he means the targeted killings that Israel is said to have begun after 11 of its athletes were murdered at the 1972 Olympics by members of the Palestinian Black September offshoot of Fatah.

Supporting the Troops?

title: Libyan Court Orders a Retrial for 6 Workers in H.I.V. Case
description: PARIS, Dec. 25 - The Libyan Supreme Court on Sunday overturned the convictions of five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor who had been sentenced to death on charges of infecting hundreds of Libyan children with H.I.V. The politically charged case was sent back to a lower court for a retrial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEENE, CONSTANCE
description: KEENE--Constance. Pianist, teacher, inspiration. She is survived by her husband, Milton Kean; her grandnephew, Justin Fried; her adopted niece, Victoria L. Phillips; her adopted nephew, Christopher Phillips; and her musical proteges at Manhattan School of Music and throughout the world. Services private. Memorial service to be announced.

description: Correction Appended

title: Pistons Bring Back Defense Against Spurs
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Dec. 25 - The Detroit Pistons have put points on the board this season about as fast as they have put up victories. It is the most visible sign of the revamped offense that their new coach, Flip Saunders, has brought with him.

title: Giving the Elderly Choices on Care (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fixture That's Not 'Messiah'
description: Every December since 1968, a few dozen student musicians have made their way to New York for 10 days of intensive chamber music and orchestral coaching at the New York String Orchestra Seminar at the New School, as well as two concerts at Carnegie Hall. The seminar's name -- and that of its public performing arm, the New York String Orchestra -- are inaccurate these days: woodwinds and brass have long been included. But never mind. The musicians, chosen by audition earlier in the year, are 15 to 22 years old, and they attend high schools and conservatories in the United States and Canada.

title: City Can Learn Quite a Lot in 60 Hours
description: THE sages say we can learn from everything, even from a transit strike that burdened millions, gummed up the streets, threatened to rob the city of its Christmas spirit and may have hurt strikers more than it helped them.

title: Selma Jeanne Cohen, 85, a Historian of Dance, Is Dead
description: Selma Jeanne Cohen, a historian, editor and teacher who devoted her career to proclaiming dance an art worthy of the same scholarly respect traditionally awarded to painting, music and literature, died on Friday at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 85.

title: Bears Win North, Completing Packers' Fall
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 25 - Two quarterbacks and two teams going in different directions trotted into Lambeau Field on Sunday.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, HONEY R. (NEE ROUSUCK)
description: ROSENTHAL--Honey R. (nee Rousuck). Wife of the late Leighton A. Mother of Cynthia R. (T. Dennie-deceased) Boardman and Jane R. (Michael J.) Horvitz. Grandmother of Sarah and Samuel Boardman, Kate and Lizzie Horvitz. Services in Cleveland, OH, Monday, December 26. title: It's the Merry Cache Express
description: Fear of Flying Away You can't expect guests to show up without an invite, can you? That's what Miffy thinks when she and Melanie tie invitations to balloons -- only to watch them be swept up in a gust of wind. But their friends are ingenious sorts, and one by one they each show up at Miffy's door for a dose of merriment, 4-year-old style. "Miffy's New Year" has its premiere tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. on Noggin, with repeats on Friday at 10:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. and Saturday at 8:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m.

The only movement, nearly four months after the passing of Hurricane Katrina, comes from the stray cats that jump in and out of the ripped-open homes.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BAGDON, JOSEPH A.
description: BAGDON--Joseph A., 99, at home in Roslyn Hgts. Born in 1906 to Lithuanian immigrants, Joe graduated from Brown in 1928. He worked as an engineer at Bell Labs and Western Electric until 1971. During WWII, he served as a Major in the Army Signal Corps. After retiring, he worked as an Alcohol Rehabilitation Counselor until age 92. Joe was an accomplished painter and sculptor. His strong will, independence, intelligence, and good health amazed and inspired all who knew him. He traveled widely with his devoted wife of 60 years, Annabelle, who died in 2003. Survived by three children Jon, Mark, and Anne, daughter-in-law, Suzanne and two grandchildren, Lydia and Keith. Joe will be missed by his devoted companion, Addy, family and friends. Memorial service on 1/7 at 1:30 at the Bryant Library in Roslyn.

title: Jamie Foxx -- ''Unpredictable'' (J)
description: Between takes on movie sets, Jamie Foxx must have been studying the Kama Sutra. His debut album, "Unpredictable," is nearly all about sex. As he sings in "Three Letter Word," the album's strangest and most obsessive song, "Sex, all the time, sex, on my mind." Despite an occasional mention of love, what really fascinates Mr. Foxx is the mechanics of sex: which room, which surface, which limbs go where. Perhaps it's a movie actor's approach to romance, working on the assumption that if the blocking and angles are right, the scene will take care of itself.

title: Arts, Briefly; Brooks Back on Top
description: Garth Brooks's "Good Ride Cowboy" is on top of the Radio & Records country singles chart for the week that ended Friday, his first No. 1 single in seven years and his first ever as an independent act. His last No. 1 was "To Make You Feel My Love," which reached the top of the Billboard country chart in 1998. Mr. Brooks, left,, has released more than 25 singles since then, many of which failed to crack the Billboard Top 40. That's a marked contrast to the beginning of his career: he racked up 13 No. 1 singles from 1989 to 1993. Billboard and Radio & Records, the leading radio trade papers, calculate country singles charts based on the number of times songs are played the previous week at reporting stations, with a weighting system based on each station's market size. On Billboard's Dec. 31 country singles chart, "Good Ride Cowboy" is No. 3 with a bullet, meaning it has had a big increase in radio plays. Mr. Brooks left Capitol Nashville this year and now records on his own label, Pearl, which is distributed exclusively at Wal-Mart and Sam's Club stores. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: MARKET DEVOTEES LOOK EAST-- Today is the day after Christmas; markets, businesses and government offices are all closed, and economy-watchers have nowhere to turn -- except east to Japan. Tokyo will oblige them by releasing the latest statistics on Japanese store sales, consumer prices, the jobless rate and auto production today and construction orders, housing starts, retail sales and industrial production tomorrow. The avalanche of numbers matters: the world's No. 2 economy is apparently emerging from years of stagnation and deflation and is set to become an engine of world growth once again.

title: Arts, Briefly; Returning Seized Art
description: Responding to pressure from Hungary, Russia's lower house of parliament, the State Duma, approved a bill last week that would return a collection of religious books seized by Soviet forces at the end of World War II. Hungary had been pressing for the return of the books, and a Russian government council had advised the culture ministry to return them, the news agency RIA Novosti reported. The 134 books, taken from the Sarospatak College of the Hungarian Reformist Church, are among countless paintings, archives and other items taken as trophy art from Germany and Eastern Europe. They have been kept in Nizhny Novgorod, a city where numerous paintings that once belonged to Jews living in Hungary are also held. The Duma must take another vote on the bill next year, but that is considered a formality. A number of stolen cultural treasures were also returned to Russia last week. The Federal Security Service, the successor to the KGB, presented Patriarch Aleksy II of the Russian Orthodox Church with 74 icons from the 18th and 19th centuries that had been smuggled out of Russia and were seized in a joint operation with agents from Cyprus. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

But in the third quarter, suddenly his life had never been worse.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Woman Killed In Stabbing
description: A woman was fatally stabbed yesterday morning by a man who then cut his own arm, the police said. The woman, Dimaris Lopez, 22, was stabbed in the chest shortly after 10 a.m. at her home on the Cross Bronx Expressway in Schuylerville, the police said. The suspect in the stabbing, Sheldon Becker, 45, then stabbed himself in the arm, and was later reported in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said. Mr. Becker was charged with murder and attempted rape, a police official said. A police spokesman said the relationship between the suspect and the woman was unclear.

title: In First Christmas Homily, Pope Reflects on World Conflicts
description: VATICAN CITY, Dec. 25 - In his first Christmas address, Pope Benedict XVI prayed Sunday for peace in poorer, war-torn parts of the world as he warned the more comfortable that they "risk becoming victims of their own intellectual and technical achievements."

Loads of Wash (Tons of It) and a Community Haven

Anna Wintour (above), the magazine's formidable editor in chief, searches for the next great young designer. Four unknowns (Alexandre Plokhov, Lazaro Hernandez, Jack McCollough and Doo Ri Chung) compete for that honor, which includes a $250,000 prize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, BARBARA
description: LEVY--Barbara. Age 84, died December 24, 2005 at her home in New York City; daughter of Dr. Robert L. Levy and Beatrice Straus Levy. She leaves her beloved sister Jessica Levy and her brother Gerald D. Levy, sister-in-law Marion F. Levy and nieces Alison Ryan, Elizabeth Levy Ward and nephew Robert Levy. She graduated from Vassar, majoring in French literature and subsequently worked as a copywriter at Macy's before moving to Paris where she wrote a column for the Paris Herald Tribune. She had become well acquainted with Paris during visits to her grandfather, Jesse I. Straus, who was appointed U.S. Ambassador to France by Franklin D. Roosevelt. While in Paris she began research on her first novel, Adrienne. Her book Legacy of Death, also based on French history, won the Edgar Award for non-fiction. Among her other successful novels were the Shining Mischief and the Missing Matisse. In New York, she served on the Auxiliary Board of the New York Philharmonic and on the Board of the Webster House. Interment will be private. Memorial service will be announced.

He's been surgically "refreshed" courtesy of "Remaking," a new reality-based series from VH1 that has its premiere on Saturday at 9 p.m.

title: Move Over, Mondrian: It's Miffy's Turn
description: To thousands of preschool-age viewers in the United States each morning, Miffy is the resolute television bunny seen tootling around the Noggin channel on her red scooter. But to millions of European children from an era when pablum wasn't served up with the remote, Miffy sprang not from a rabbit hutch in Cableland but from a book. In fact, since her birth in 1955, Miffy has become so popular in her home country, the Netherlands, that Dick Bruna, her creator, is popularly known as "Miffy's father."

description: Two men were killed in hit-and-run accidents early yesterday morning, the police said. In the first accident, the police said, Neville Mills, 71, was hit just after midnight by a silver Nissan on Rockaway Parkway near Avenue B in Brooklyn. Mr. Mills, who apparently had been walking back to his home at 700 Rockaway Parkway after dropping off Christmas presents at his nephew's home nearby, was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead about 12:20 a.m., the police said. In the second accident, an unidentified man was hit about 6 a.m. on the Major Deegan Expressway near Willis Avenue in the Bronx. The police had no information about the car or the driver.

Technology isn't the only harbinger of higher productivity
Evaluation of Medical Care Provider in the City's Jails Is Questioned
description: During the five years that a profit-making company, Prison Health Services, has provided medical care in New York City's jails, city health officials have assured the public that they were closely monitoring its work. The centerpiece of that oversight is a quarterly report card that scores the company's performance on all manner of care, a level of scrutiny that the city says is unusually rigorous.

title: Powell Speaks Out on Domestic Spy Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 - Former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said on Sunday that it would not have been "that hard" for President Bush to obtain warrants for eavesdropping on domestic telephone and Internet activity, but that he saw "nothing wrong" with the decision not to do so.

title: Other Views: The Independent, The Press, JoongAng Daily Ilbo
Arts, Briefly; Football Draws for ESPN
description: The winding-down of the pro football season has been a boon to ESPN's ratings this month. A game between the Atlanta Falcons, left, and the Chicago Bears on Dec. 18 was advertiser-supported cable's most-watched program of the week, with 10.45 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. A second N.F.L. game, the Denver Broncos versus the Buffalo Bills, was a distant No. 2, with an audience of 6.01 million. The two games added up to a victory for ESPN in prime time for the third week of December. Among entertainment channels, USA led the list, as its World Wrestling Entertainment "Monday Night Raw" and a viewers' choice marathon of "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" delivered large audiences. The betting show "Deal or No Deal," and its 11.7 million viewers, led NBC to a Friday victory. Excluding sports, the show drew the highest 18-to-49 age group rating in Friday's 8 p.m. hour since the series premiere of CBS's "Joan of Arcadia" in September 2003. KATE AURTHUR

title: Sunnis Protest Iraqi Vote, and Offer Deals
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 25 - Sunni Arab political leaders asked the main Shiite political bloc on Sunday to give them 10 Shiite seats in the new Parliament in an early attempt to defuse tensions over the results of the Dec. 15 election.

title: 2005: Winners, Losers...
Blind to the End
description: London - ONE year ago today we stared aghast at images of the Southeast Asian tsunami. These were mostly improvised clips rendered all the more poignant by their amateurishness. Video cameras taken on vacation to record the everyday pleasures of the beach were suddenly turned to quivering utility as they documented the panic and mayhem of a natural disaster. Somehow, domestic pleasure turned on its head only added to the sense of chaos and loss. Who can forget the disbelief in the recorded voices? This can't be happening to us.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: As Split of Viacom Nears Completion, Investors Ponder Its Founder's Next Move On Jan. 3, Sumner M. Redstone will get his wish when Viacom, the sprawling media company he built, is split into two separate entities. Now investors are asking whether the split is a prelude to a buying spree -- that is, does Mr. Redstone plan to build up two new companies? A bigger question is whether Mr. Redstone will decide to sell off assets if the split fails to bolster the share price of either company. [Page C1.]

description: Teri Marshall remembers the numbers: C1 and C2. Those are the vertebrae that her son lost in a grueling six-and-a-half-hour operation this summer to ease severe headaches and reduce pressure on his brain.

title: Unconventional Queen Hit Still Rocks After 30 Years
description: The record producer Roy Thomas Baker remembers being at the apartment of Freddie Mercury, the singer of the British rock band Queen, one day in 1975 when the flamboyant front man played him a skeletal version of a song he was working on. "He played the beginning bit on the piano," he recalled, "then stopped and said, 'This is where the opera section comes in.' Then we went out to eat dinner."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: OPEC Agrees to Meet
description: OPEC and Russia agreed to hold annual ministerial meetings starting next year in an effort to improve oil market transparency and infrastructure. OPEC's president, Sheik Ahmad Fahd al-Sabah, left, and Russia's energy minister, Viktor B. Khristenko, met in Moscow to discuss how Russia could best represent the interests of oil producers when it took over Group of 8 leadership next year. OPEC's 11 members, which supply about 40 percent of the world's oil, may cut production after March to offset a possible decline in demand and sustain world oil prices, Sheik Ahmad said last week.

title: Christmas Babies, One After Another, After Another
description: The babies were coming too fast.

World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan And Iran Sign Consular Pact
description: Iran's foreign minister, Manouchehr Mottaki, made a one-day visit to Kabul, the Afghan capital, continuing his country's efforts to develop friendly relations with Afghanistan since the fall of the Taliban four years ago. Mr. Mottaki announced that Afghanistan's president, Hamid Karzai, would visit Iran next month, his first visit since the election of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in June. Mr. Mottaki and his Afghan counterpart, Abdullah, signed an agreement on consular cooperation and on aid for hundreds of thousands of Afghan refugees and immigrant workers living in Iran, which shares a 560-mile border with Afghanistan. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

title: Exporters and U.S. Report Help Asian Stocks Rise Again
description: Asian stocks rose for a seventh day yesterday. Exporters including Matsushita Electric Industrial and Samsung Electronics gained after a United States report showed consumer confidence had the largest jump in almost two years.

title: When Teenagers Abuse Prescription Drugs, the Fault May Be the Doctor's
description: Every Thursday evening, I counsel a group of teenagers with serious substance abuse problems. None of the youngsters elected to see me. Typically, they were caught using drugs, or worse, by their parents or a police officer and were then referred to my clinic.

title: Russia's Anti-West Offensive
description: To no one's great surprise, Russia's Parliament voted overwhelmingly last week to increase control of charities, foundations and other nongovernmental organizations in Russia. The vote endorsed a slightly better version of the bill than the original one. Under pressure from the West, President Vladimir Putin dropped proposed rules that would have forced foreign groups to register as purely Russian groups. But they still will have to prove periodically that their work does not contravene Russian national, social or security interests. That is broad enough to make all unofficial groups permanently vulnerable to the Kremlin's whims.

title: Mental Health: Serious Depression Raises Risk of Heart Ailments
description: A large Swedish study published last week reports that men and women hospitalized for depression are about one and a half times as likely as others to develop coronary heart disease. The risk is even greater for people hospitalized before age 50.

title: The Business Traveler Braces

We will remember Stephanie most for her energy and enthusiasm, for life even in the face of many obstacles and her commitment to her family. She was generous with her time and attention, conscious of the details that would make something truly special for others. Stephanie was committed to nonprofit work, especially as an advocate for women's employment and nutritional education. Stephanie will be missed dearly by her many friends and loving family. We cherished the time we had with her. She was the widow of Walter and is survived by her children, Jim and wife Vered, Amy and husband Dan Reisen, Ellen and husband Scott Bull, her sister, Lilo Hoffman, and seven grandchildren.

title: Danger to Kidneys May Lurk in Some Preparations for Colonoscopies
description: No one disputes that colonoscopies save lives. But recent research has prompted concern that in rare instances certain popular bowel-cleansing preparations that patients gulp down the day before a procedure can severely damage the kidneys.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Prices Rise
description: Japan's consumer prices rose last month for the first time in two years, gains the central bank says need to be sustained before it can change its policy of keeping interest rates at almost zero. Core prices rose 0.1 percent from a year earlier, the first gain since October 2003, and only the second rise in more than seven years, the government's statistics bureau said. The gain, which excluded prices of fresh food, matched the median forecast of 30 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. Prices have not kept pace with an economy the government said will expand for a fifth year in the 12 months starting April. Excluding energy and all food, Japan's consumer prices fell 0.2 percent in November.

Phantom Voters, Thanks to the Census
description: The first Constitution took for granted that enslaved people could not vote, but counted each slave as three-fifths of a person for the purpose of apportioning representation in Congress. This inflated the voting power of slaveholders and gave them much more influence in legislative matters than their actual numbers warranted. No American would knowingly tolerate such an arrangement today. But a glitch in the census that inflates the populations of some state legislative districts -- thus exaggerating their voting power -- has led to a contemporary version of that problem. It involves counting prison inmates in the district where they are confined rather than where they actually live. The Census Bureau could fix this problem in a heartbeat, so it needs to get a move on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOCARIDES, CHARLES WIL LIAM, M.D.
description: SOCARIDES -- Charles Wil liam, M.D., on December 25, 2005. Beloved husband of Claire Alford Socarides, loving father of Jacqueline Nicole Socarides, Charles W. Socarides, Jr., Alexandra Socarides, Richard Socarides and Daphne Socarides (deceased), loving grandfather of Archer Fried Socarides and beloved brother of Helen Socarides Covett, and uncle to Dr. Robert G. Covett. Born January 24, 1922, Charles Socarides determined at the age of 13, after reading a book on the life of Sigmund Freud, that he would become a physician and psychoanalyst. Charles Socarides graduated from Harvard College and went on to receive his certificate in psychoanalytic medicine from Columbia University in 1952. He was the author of eight books including his master work, "The Preoedipal Origin and Psychoanalytic Therapy of Sexual Perversions," and "Work and Its Inhibitions - Psychoanalytic Essays" as well as over 80 psychoanalytic articles. Charles Socarides appeared on numerous news programs to discuss his psychoanalytic work and findings including Dateline, 60 Minutes and Larry King Live. Charles Socarides was the past president and co-founder of N.A.R.T.H.the National Association for Research and Therapy of Homosexuality. Charles Socarides was on the board of directors of the Margaret S. Mahler Psychiatric Research Foundation; he was a member of the International Advisory Committee, Second Delphi International Psychoanalytic Symposium, Delphi, Greece, 1988; he was also a member of the American Medical Association, the American Psychiatric Association, the Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine, a life member of the American Psychoanalytic Association where he chaired a discussion group for many years, the International Psychoanalytic Association and he was an affiliate member of the Royal Society of Medicine, London. Dr. Charles Socarides was Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, NYC, 1978-1996. His numerous awards include that of Distinguished Psychoanalyst, Association of Psychoanalytic Psychologists, British Health Service, London, England, April 28, 1995; the first Sigmund Freud Lectureship Award, New York Center for Psychoanalytic Training, NYC, and the 1987 Sigmund Freud Award given by the American Society of Psychoanalytic Physicians in recognition of distinguished service to psychiatry and psychoanalytic research. Charles Socarides was respected and loved by his friends and patients for his generosity of spirit, loyalty, courage, responsibility, loving kindness and goodness. He will be sorely missed by his wife Claire Alford Socarides, for Charlie was her one true love forever and ever. He would say to his patients--"I love you and will love you always and be with you always." A wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM, on Wednesday and Thursday, and a funeral mass will be held at 10 AM, Friday, at the Greek Cathedral of the Holy Trinity on East 74th St.

title: After Withdrawal, Engagement
description: ST. LOUIS - ELECTING a Parliament under the new permanent Constitution was a significant achievement for the Iraqi people, who once again faced down terrorist violence and political intimidation to demonstrate their desire for a democratic future. For better or worse, in the election's aftermath, the United States will almost certainly begin to withdraw its military from Iraq in 2006. But that does not mean that the time has come to disengage. On the contrary, a broader, more diverse engagement with Iraqi society is needed to help Iraqis develop the institutions, practices and values essential to real and enduring democracy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Pilots' Pay Cut Sought
description: Swiss International Air Lines, which is being bought by Deutsche Lufthansa, plans to dismiss 314 pilots from its European fleet if they do not accept by year-end new job contracts that include pay cuts. The pilots would be forced to accept "significantly worse working conditions," the Swiss Pilots union said in an statement Sunday. The new contracts are part of a revamping plan by Swiss International aimed at stemming losses that reached 1.9 billion francs ($1.45 billion) since its 2002 creation from the bankrupt Swissair Group and the regional carrier Crossair. The airline's chief executive, Christoph Franz, said in October that the carrier aimed to break even next year and to post an operating profit in 2007.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Korea: Plan for Foreign Offerings
description: South Korea's government plans to allow overseas companies to hold initial public offerings, starting this week, to bolster its stock market, which is Asia's fourth-largest. Overseas companies will be subject to the same scrutiny of profitability and ownership structure as local companies seeking to sell shares in the country, the Financial Supervisory Service regulatory body said in a statement. Currently, only previously listed overseas companies are allowed to seek a secondary listing in South Korea; none has done so. South Korea's financial regulators are trying to entice creditworthy companies to sell shares to help the development of the country's capital market. South Korean stocks gained 64 percent this year, based on American dollar value, becoming the second-best performer among 15 Asian exchanges tracked by Bloomberg Analytics.

title: Arts, Briefly; TNT Stands at Cable's Top
description: A little Nascar, some NBA and a dash of Kyra Sedgwick, right. Those were the ingredients that led to TNT's being the top-ranked advertiser-supported cable channel in primetime this year. Cable's most-watched programs of the year were mainly football games on ESPN, which ranked No. 4 over all. TNT also got into the Nielsen estimates for the Top 20 with five broadcasts -- two basketball games, two Nascar races and the series premiere of "The Closer," in which Ms. Sedgwick plays a bristly Southern detective with an eating disorder. USA Network experienced a fourth-quarter surge thanks to the addition of World Wrestling Entertainment to its schedule. It finished in second place and began closing the gap with TNT in primetime. Nick at Nite placed third, and Fox News was fifth. Among adults 18 to 49, TNT and USA were Nos. 1 and 2, and ESPN remained fourth; but TBS placed third in this demographic, and Spike was fifth. In this group, Nick at Nite, which appeals to a young audience, ranked No. 12, and Fox News, which seems to draw an older one, fell to No. 19.

title: Ghana's Uneasy Embrace of Slavery's Diaspora
description: CAPE COAST, Ghana - For centuries, Africans walked through the infamous "door of no return" at Cape Coast castle directly into slave ships, never to set foot in their homelands again. These days, the portal of this massive fort so central to one of history's greatest crimes has a new name, hung on a sign leading back in from the roaring Atlantic Ocean: "The door of return."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Trade Surplus Widens
description: Russia's trade surplus widened 44 percent in January through November from the year-earlier period as crude oil shipments increased export revenue. The trade surplus rose to $113.8 billion, the Economy Ministry said in a statement, citing preliminary estimates. The value of exports increased 36 percent, to $222.6 billion, while imports grew 28 percent, to $108.8 billion. The price for Urals crude, the country's main export blend of oil, was 46 percent higher in January through November from the same period a year ago, while prices for natural gas increased 26.7 percent, the ministry said. Oil, gas and metals account for more than half of Russia's total export revenue.

title: Ferry Dispute Tests Ireland's Tolerance for Globalization
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 26 - When nearly 100,000 people took to the streets of Ireland earlier this month to protest the hiring of cheap East European labor for Irish Ferries, they gave voice to old familiar fears about job security that many thought had been forgotten.

World Briefing | Europe: Azerbaijan: Airline Suspends Flights
description: Azerbaijan Airlines grounded its remaining An-140 passenger aircraft and suspended purchase of more of the planes pending results of an investigation into a fatal crash last week, regional news services reported. One of the airline's three An-140's, twin-engine propeller aircraft that are made in Ukraine, fell into the Caspian Sea on Friday shortly after taking off for Kazakhstan, killing all 23 people aboard. The flight data recorder has been recovered and is being studied to determine the cause of the crash. Azerbaijan has been expecting delivery of two more An-140's early next year, Interfax reported. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUNT, CATHI MORGAN
description: HUNT--Cathi Morgan. December 25, 2005, age 66, of New York, NY. She died after a brief hospital stay following a fall and a fractured pelvis. Her passing was quick and she suffered little, comforted by her family. Beloved mother to two sons, Kevin and Ron. She is also survived by her mother, brother, sister, and four beautiful grandchildren. A lifelong learner, she was a graduate of Cornell University '59, Columbia Business School '78 and was a passionate Consumer Affairs professional. She was truly blessed to have so many friends throughout her life. Her great love was for the City of New York. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy can be made in her memory to Lutheran Social Services--LSSNY, 475 Riverside Ave., New York, NY 10115 which helps thousands in the City every year. She will be sorely missed.

World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Top Court Rules Pinochet Fit For Trial
description: The Supreme Court upheld the indictment and house arrest of Gen. Augusto Pinochet for the disappearance of six leftists during his rule in the 1970's, rejecting an appeal by lawyers for the 90-year-old former dictator that he should not be put on trial for health reasons. He was arrested and charged last month in the disappearance of nine dissidents arrested in 1975. They were among 119 people who subsequently disappeared in a case known as Operation Colombo. The court is to resolve a similar appeal for the other three victims. General Pinochet has been exempted from trial three times in recent years after medical exams found him unfit for trial. Recent court-ordered exams concluded that he had exaggerated his symptoms. PASCALE BONNEFOY (NYT)

title: Memo Pad
description: BRITISH AIR FIGHTS BACK -- Book a Club World business-class seat on British Airways between New York and London for, say, mid-March, and the round-trip fare is $8,824 -- about the going rate for trans-Atlantic business-class travel on most airlines. Book the same seat on British Air from Kennedy International Airport and eight other East Coast airports by Jan. 2, for travel through the end of February, and the round-trip fare is $2,798. Round-trip fares from Atlanta, Chicago, Houston, Dallas and Detroit are $3,198, and from Los Angeles, Denver, Phoenix, San Francisco and Seattle, the fare is $3,798. Air travel specialists see the fare sales as an aggressive ploy by British Air to deflect competition from all-business-class upstarts like Eos and MAXJet, which undercut standard business-class fares. The airline is also seeking to compete against domestic carriers, who have been adding capacity on the lucrative trans-Atlantic routes, where fare sales are expected this winter.

Paid Notice: Deaths   KEENE, CONSTANCE
description: KEENE -- Constance. The Manhattan School of Music mourns the loss of Constance Keene, esteemed member of the faculty since 1969, who also served as former chair of the School's piano department, and since 1997 was a member of its Board of Trustees. As one of the world's leading concert pianists and distinguished piano teachers, with her impeccable musicianship, artistry, intellect and grace, Constance shaped generations of pianists who have had an enormous positive impact on the profession. Her performances, both onstage and through her recordings, enriched the lives of so many and her invaluable warmth and giving endeared her to her many students and colleagues. Manhattan School of Music honored her in 2004 with a degree of doctor of musical arts, honoris causa. She will be deeply missed by the entire Manhattan School community. Our most heartfelt condolences to her beloved Milton. David A. Rahm, Chairman Board of Trustees Robert Sirota, President

title: Unwarranted Complaints
description: WASHINGTON - SHORTLY after the Sept. 11 attacks, President Bush ordered surveillance of international telephone communications by suspected members of Al Qaeda overseas, even if such calls also involved individuals within the United States. This program was adopted by direct presidential order and was subject to review every 45 days. Judicial warrants for this surveillance were neither sought nor obtained, although key members of Congress were evidently informed. The program's existence has now become public, and howls of outrage have ensued. But in fact, the only thing outrageous about this policy is the outrage itself.

Arts, Briefly; Country, by Van Morrison
description: Van Morrison, above right, has signed with Lost Highway, a Universal Music/Nashville imprint whose roster also includes Willie Nelson, and is preparing an album called "Pay the Devil," featuring covers of famous and lesser-known country and blues songs, for March release. Billboard reports that the new CD includes Mr. Morrison's versions of Hank Williams's "Your Cheatin' Heart" and "My Bucket's Got a Hole in It," as well as his rendition of Webb Pierce's "There Stands the Glass," a groundbreaking song about alcoholism that many radio stations initially refused to play in 1953. A cover of the blues great Big Joe Turner's "Don't You Make Me High" is also included. Mr. Morrison, 60, the Irish singer whose "Brown Eyed Girl," "Domino" and "Gloria" have all become rock standards, has never had a song on the Billboard country charts.

title: And a Good Mid-Winter to You!
description: Christmas is over now, but it always leaves a bit of clearing up to do. There is all the detritus of consumerism to be tidied up  gift wrapping, unwanted presents and the like  but there are also the pieces to be picked up after the various family arguments and public scraps that Christmas inevitably brings. And this year the whole issue of what to call Christmas has been a good public fight. Should we use the utterly banal term holidays, or should Christmas continue to be called Christmas, just as it has been for hundreds of years? This years battle on that point may be largely over but it is by no means won by those who would change our established linguistic usage. And there is every reason to continue to blow on to the coals of that debate.

So it is not surprising to find new Spanish cookbooks in stores right now, brimming with recipes for paellas and casseroles but paying homage to the ideas of modern chefs as well.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: No Blame For Security Forces In School Raid
description: The federal prosecutor's office announced on national television that its investigation into a terrorist siege and bloody final battle at a public school in southern Beslan last year had found that the government's security forces deserved no blame for the outcome. A total of 331 people, most of them hostages and more than half children, died when Russian forces, visibly unprepared and confused, stormed the school. The prosecutor's assessments were promptly dismissed as a whitewash by relatives of the victims. An earlier regional commission was sharply critical of the government operation.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the death of a cabdriver whose car burst into flames after it was struck by a hit-and-run driver in Queens referred incorrectly in some editions to the gas tank shields installed in some of the Crown Victorias that make up the bulk of New York City's medallion cabs. They were made available to cabbies by the car's manufacturer, the Ford Motor Company, not by the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Defense Lawyers in Terror Cases Plan Challenges Over Spy Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 - Defense lawyers in some of the country's biggest terrorism cases say they plan to bring legal challenges to determine whether the National Security Agency used illegal wiretaps against several dozen Muslim men tied to Al Qaeda.

title: Frustration Over Iraq Vote Unlikely to Trouble Clinton
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's support for the war in Iraq has outraged many liberal activists in the Democratic Party, who are warning of retribution, including a primary challenge to her re-election campaign next year.

title: NEW YORK AREA
description: Even a mayoral election could not ruffle the calm that New York settled into this year. The billionaire Republican incumbent, Michael R. Bloomberg, faced the two-time Democratic also-ran, Fernando Ferrer, and appeared to have him beaten so handily from the start that neither the mayor nor the electorate ever broke a sweat. The year's big event, in fact, looked as if it would be "The Gates" exhibition in Central Park. Then came the strike. And everyone broke a sweat.

title: A Counselor's Resounding Cry, Even From Her Hospital Bed: Go Directly to College
description: Neyda Martinez makes one request of her students at the Bronx Leadership Academy: Go away to college.

title: No Posters From Islamists in U.S. Mission
description: CAIRO, Dec. 27 - The American Consulate here opened its doors to reporters on Tuesday in an unusual step to dispel reports that it employed hard-line Islamists who kept posters of the militant group Hamas on the walls.

title: Genoa Is the New Home of Decorative Arts Collection
description: GENOA, Italy - With a vast heritage of fine arts to conserve, Italian public collections have given scant attention to the applied and decorative arts, especially to those of more recent times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, HOWARD
description: SCHNEIDER--Howard, 77. December 25, 2005. Beloved husband and best friend of Roberta. Devoted father of Lori and Harvey. Cherished father-in-law of Rachel. Adoring grandfather of Scott, Stephen, Lee, Jenny and Evan. Loving uncle and dear friend. He will live in our hearts forever. Funeral service Wednesday, 10 AM, at "Gutterman's Inc." 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. $(6$)SCHNEIDER -- Howard. We will miss you our "Guardian Angel". Isabelle and John Pisacano

Stabbing Kills Woman, 33, in East Harlem
description: A 33-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her East Harlem apartment yesterday, and her husband was arrested later, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUERBACH, GLADYS B.
description: AUERBACH--Gladys B., 88, of Rye, NY. Predeceased in 1999 by her beloved husband of 58 years, Harry M. Auerbach. Survived by her devoted children Kenneth and Susan (Weisenberg) and Jane (Auerbach) and Neal Gelfand & her adoring grandchildren, Philip and Peter Auerbach and Allie and Laura Gelfand. Funeral Services Wednesday at 10 A.M. at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Common Cause, 1250 Connecticut Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20036. $(6$)AUERBACH--Gladys. On behalf of the Board of Directors, volunteers, staff, consumers and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, we offer our heartfelt condolences to the family of our longtime board member, Ken Auerbach. We extend our deepest sympathy to Ken and his wife Susan, and to the entire Auerbach and Gelfand families. Martin Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews Executive Director United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc.

title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Tours Mideast to Praise Troops
description: DOHA, Qatar, Dec. 28 - Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, praised American troops at an airbase in this tiny Persian Gulf state today for their efforts in the campaign against terror, as he opened a week-long tour of six countries in the Middle East and Central Asia.

title: Big Labor's Big Secret
description: AS most Americans are aware, our auto industry is in a crisis.

title: When Scholarship and Politics Collided at Yale
description: David Graeber pulled a green object shaped like a Champagne cork out of his pocket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GULIELMETTI, PAUL M.
description: GULIELMETTI--Paul M., 58. December 24. Husband of Leslie Miller, father of Gabriele and Jack, brother of Philip and John. Fiercely loving father, untiring and creative attorney, advocate of artist's housing rights, and natural-born cook. Memorial to be announced. Gifts in Paul's memory to the Trey Whitfield School/Foundation, 60 Williams Avenue, Brooklyn, NY, 11207. $(6$)GULIELMETTI--Paul M. 1947-2005. You are forever in our hearts and will be passed on to all generations, Gabriele, Jack and Leslie $(6$)GULIELMETTI--Paul M. The partners and staff of the law firm of Gulielmetti Levinson, P.C. send our deepest condolences to the family and many dear friends of our beloved partner. We are proud to have been associated with Paul, whose work over three decades prevented the evictions of countless NYC tenants from all walks of life, enhanced the lives of numerous artists, and promoted the work of many art galleries, publishers and nonprofit organizations. His generous spirit will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VALE, MICHAEL
description: VALE--Michael. Where you are, I am sure, "Their Is Nothing But Winners". Your dear friends. Serena and Tack Levye

title: Trusting in Charity's Human Touch
description: The year-end cascade of charity pleas is under way, and many generous people are undoubtedly wishing for greater human detail to help them make choices among the many solicitations. Consider, then, the $400 extended from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to meet the precise fee required by the government to process the citizenship application reverently filed by Mariely Gonzalez, a doughty Dominican immigrant. After losing her job as an airport wheelchair attendant because of illness, $400 was an impossibility. But Ms. Gonzalez still kept her eye on her goal of a full-fledged future here. Like thousands of others, she found emergency aid through one of the major city charities helped by the Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VIGILANTE, JOSEPH L.
description: VIGILANTE--Joseph L., 80. Died of congestive heart failure. Husband of Florence, father of Amy Dickerson, Carrie Barron, and Theodore Vigilante. He held Master's and doctoral degrees from The Columbia University School of Social Work. As Faculty Member and Dean of The Adelphi School of Social Work, he was the author of many scholarly articles and books. He was also a leader at The Council of Social Work Education. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made: The Joseph Vigilante Fund, C/O Adelphi University School of Social Work, 1 South Avenue, Garden City, N.Y. 11530. A Memorial Service at Adelphi will be announced. $(6$)VIGILANTE--Joseph L. Adelphi University mourns the passing of Joseph L. Vigilante, former Dean of the School of Social Work from 1962 to 1987. His enormous vision, devotion, and talent helped establish the School's prominent national and international reputation. Dr. Vigilante's contributions to the profession beyond his deanship were enormous. He was a well-respected scholar having authored many articles, chapters, and books, served on various editorial boards, and consulted to numerous educational, state, and federal institutions. His legacy will live on in the hearts and minds of students, faculty, administrators, and alumni. Our thoughts are with his wife, Florence, and the entire Vigilante family. Robert A. Scott, President Michael J. Campbell, Chairman, Board of Trustees Andrew W. Safyer, Dean, School of Social Work $(6$)VIGILANTE--Joseph L. The faculty and staff of The Hunter College School of Social Work express their condolences upon the passing of Dean Emeritus, Joseph L. Vigilante, of the Adelphi University School of Social Work. He was an outstanding educator, distinguished author, and nationally-recognized leader of the social work profession. Paul Kurzman, Acting Dean Roberta Graziano, Acting Associate Dean Hunter College School of Social Work City University of New York

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article in Science Times yesterday about the genetic underpinnings of cancer misstated the age of a New York City firefighter whose myelogenous leukemia was diagnosed in 1996. As the article noted, the firefighter, Jay Weinstein, was 36 at the time of his diagnosis, not today.

title: Plea Deal Is Seen for Enron Figure
description: In a reversal that transforms the criminal case against Enron's former top officers, the company's former chief accounting officer has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to violating federal law during his employment there, people briefed on the decision said yesterday.
