title: Outspoken Putin Aide Quits, Scolding Kremlin
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 27 - The most outspoken of President Vladimir V. Putin's senior advisers abruptly resigned Tuesday, warning that Russia's nascent political freedoms have been lost and that the Kremlin's economic choices have been poor. He also said he had no more ability to influence the government's course.

title: A Rejoinder for Fruitcake Haters
description: Sullivan Street Bakery's persimmon cake, darkly fragrant with spices, rich with fruit and thickly studded with dried currants, would be a great addition to a winter dinner. The cake, which will be sold until Valentine's Day, is moist and lightly glazed. It is $30 whole and $4 a slice at the bakery's shops at 73 Sullivan Street (Broome Street) and 533 West 47th Street. title: Nets Stop Cavaliers and Win 7th Straight
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 27 - Before his team faced the Nets on Tuesday night, Cleveland Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown said there was more to the Nets' recent resurgence than the highlight reel that is Vince Carter.

title: J. H. Herz, a Scholar of Diplomacy, Is Dead at 97
description: John H. Herz, a scholar of international relations and law and a professor emeritus of government at City College, died on Monday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 97.

title: Time in a Bottle: One Wine's Evolution
description: UNTIL very recently, Joseph Phelps Vineyards was a midsize California producer that operated with little glory. Napa Valley old-timers like Beaulieu Vineyards, Stag's Leap Wine Cellars, Heitz Wine Cellars and Robert Mondavi got the credit for establishing Napa cabernets as world-class wines, while newcomers like Colgin, Harlan Estate and Screaming Eagle turned cabernet into a cult, with bottles going for hundreds of dollars apiece.

title: Inquiry Criticizes Official Handling of Russian School Raid
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28 - The head of a Russian parliamentary commission investigating the terrorist seizure of a school in Beslan last year criticized the official handling of the crisis today, citing "a list of miscalculations and drawbacks" in the authorities' work and saying the siege could have been prevented if the local police had done their jobs.

title: Stars, They're Just Like Us, Except Farther Away
description: Stars, They're Just Like Us, Except Farther Away

title: Fidelity National to Buy Sedgwick
description: Fidelity National Financial, the biggest United States title insurer, has agreed to buy Sedgwick CMS Holdings for $635 million to offer third-party claims management services to Fortune 500 companies.

title: Blue-Collar Napa Joins the Gold Rush
description: Correction Appended

title: The Sound of Cowboy Music
description: We know. "Brokeback Mountain" is getting raves, but there you are, stuck at home with the children. Lucky for you, The Underfinanced Production Company, anticipating just such a dilemma, has created a sequel suitable for all ages, and already available for home viewing. It is, even more thrillingly, a musical - a particularly stellar achievement, considering our budget.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Plant Approved for FluMist
description: MedImmune Inc. said regulators in the United States approved its new British manufacturing plant for making the FluMist influenza vaccine in 2006, when the company expects an easier-to-use version to be approved for sale. MedImmune, which is supplying three million doses of FluMist this year, will be able to produce up to 15 million doses a month with the new plant, in Speke, England, the company said. MedImmune will start making FluMist in 2006 at the plant, which may also be used to make a new version now under regulatory review and to produce vaccine for a potential flu pandemic, the company said. FluMist, taken as a nasal spray, generated $54 million in revenue last year, about 3 percent of all sales of flu vaccine.

title: Militantsraid Gaza election offices
Newly Aggressive Blue Jays Add Glaus to Their Lineup
description: Suddenly, the Yankees and the Red Sox appear to have competition in the American League East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARKINSON, JOHN III.
description: PARKINSON--John III. Of NYC and Millbrook, NY, on December 25. Born 1934 to Elizabeth Bliss and John Parkinson, Jr. Survived by: his wife, Charlotte; children, John Parkinson, Allston Parkinson (and Susan), and Elizabeth Parkinson-Wyner (and Josh); grandchildren, Jack and Miles Wyner and Schuyler & Ellen Parkinson; and sisters, Zaidee Parkinson and Mary Ann ParkinsonHache. Educated at Buckley and Groton Schools and Harvard University. Blue Water Sailor, U.S. Marine, Vice President of Citibank, ardent golfer and professional ski instructor at Okemo Mountain, Vermont. Past Chairman of the Buxton School and the Cultural Council Foundation. Board Member of Deepdale Golf Club, The Kitchen, and Treasurer for 27 years of the Museum of Modern Art. A Memorial service in February will be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53, NYC 10019; The Kitchen, 512 West 19, NYC 10011; and St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, 1000 10th Avenue, NYC 10019. $(6$)PARKINSON--John III. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the passing of its great Trustee John Parkinson. John, who enjoyed a long and successful career as a banker, joined the MoMA Board of Trustees in 1976. For almost thirty years John served brilliantly in varying capacities as the Museum's Treasurer, Chairman of the Finance Committee, Chairman of the Pension Committee, Chairman of the Committee on Photography, and served as a member on many other trustee committees including the Expansion, Executive, Personnel, House, Investment, and Nominating committees. Since 1966 John was a member of the Museum's International Council and served as its Treasurer from 1973 to 1978. From 1970 onward, his generosity enabled the acquisition of scores of important photographs for the collection. John's relationship to the Museum reached back to its creation, as his mother, Elizabeth Bliss Parkinson Cobb, also a Trustee, was the niece of Lillie P. Bliss, one of the Museum's original founders. The Trustees and staff are profoundly grateful for John's extraordinary contribution to the life of the Museum and will remember him with affection and high regard as a great leader, a true gentleman, and a stalwart defender of the Museum's ideals. We will miss him deeply and extend our sympathies to his wife Charlotte, their children Elizabeth, John and Allston and all members of the Parkinson family. David Rockefeller Honorary Chairman Ronald S. Lauder Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund President Emerita Robert B. Menschel Chairman Marie-Josee Kravis President Peter Norton, Chairman, Committee on Photography Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Brian Urquhart, Chairman Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art $(6$)PARKINSON--John. John and his mother were dear friends of ours. We enjoyed so much visiting John's mother-Eliza Cobb, and her husband, Henry, at their house in their later years. We loved John's love of photography and his great affection for his children-Elizabeth, John, and Allston-and his beloved wife, Charlotte. His love of The Museum of Modern Art, and all his hard work for many years, will always be held close to our hearts. He will be remembered fondly. Aggie and Daniel $(6$)PARKINSON--John III. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed Board Member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President

title: Big Board Seat Price Rises in Latest Sale
description: A New York Stock Exchange membership sold for $3.75 million yesterday, up $50,000 from the last sale.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suspect In Mob Slaying Is Out On Bond
description: An accused Gambino crime family captain charged in the 1992 murder of a couple who had robbed several mob social clubs was released yesterday on $3 million bond. United States Magistrate Judge Viktor V. Pohorelsky released the man, Dominick Pizzonia, 64, after federal prosecutors and Mr. Pizzonia's lawyer agreed in federal court in Brooklyn to delay the trial because the government plans to file more charges in the case. Mr. Pizzonia had been held since Sept. 22 on charges that he killed Thomas and Rosemarie Uva on Dec. 24, 1992, in Ozone Park, Queens. Yesterday, several family members and neighbors put up six properties to secure the bond for Mr. Pizzonia, who will be restricted to his home. WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM (NYT)

title: Only Connect: Sondheim's Intimate Core
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Kraft Unit to Sell Several Brands
description: The Canadian unit of Kraft Foods Inc. plans to sell several brands including Aylmer vegetables and Primo pasta to two buyout firms, Sun Capital Partners Inc. and the EG Capital Group, to focus on faster-growing businesses. The transaction, including the sale of five factories, will result in a charge of about 5 cents a share in Kraft's fourth-quarter earnings, according to a statement from Kraft Canada. Terms will not be disclosed, a Kraft Canada spokesman, Don Blair, said. Kraft is selling slower-growing businesses as it shifts spending to introduce healthier products and increase marketing for cheeses, crackers and Maxwell House coffee. The estimated 2005 revenue for the food brands is about 300 million Canadian dollars ($257 million), Kraft Canada Inc. said.

title: The Neediest Cases; Holiday Joy for Two Children Who Touched the Hearts of Readers
description: The basic situation remains grim: Santa Artiles's two small children suffer from the severest form of a rare, incurable disease that may well kill them in childhood.

title: Japan Records First Rise in Prices in 2 Years
description: TOKYO, Dec. 27 - The Japanese government said Tuesday that consumer prices rose for the first time in two years in November, offering what economists called the most convincing sign yet that the country's long bout of crippling price declines was ending.

title: A Family Feud Sheds Light on Differences in Probate Practices From State to State
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 20 - Lillian Glasser, by all accounts, never intended to spend her twilight years in Texas. Or her $25 million fortune.

title: Ukraine Vows to Divert Russian Gas Exports
description: BERLIN, Dec. 27 - A dispute between Ukraine and Gazprom, Russia's state-owned natural gas monopoly, grew more intense Tuesday as Ukraine threatened to take a portion of the gas exports that Russia sends to Europe. Gazprom called such a move theft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEENE, CONSTANCE
description: KEENE - Constance. The Manhattan School of Music mourns the loss of Constance Keene, esteemed member of the faculty since 1969, who also served as former chair of the School's piano department, and since 1997 was a member of its Board of Trustees. As one of the world's leading concert pianists and distinguished piano teachers, with her impeccable musicianship, artistry, intellect and grace, Constance shaped generations of pianists who have had an enormous positive impact on the profession. Her performances, both onstage and through her recordings, enriched the lives of so many and her invaluable warmth and giving endeared her to her many students and colleagues. Manhattan School of Music honored her in 2004 with a degree of doctor of musical arts, honoris causa. She will be deeply missed by the entire Manhattan School community. Our most heartfelt condolences to her beloved Milton. David A. Rahm, Chairman Board of Trustees Robert Sirota, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLIN, GEORGE
description: COLIN--George. Of Delray Beach, Florida passed away on December 24, 2005. He was the beloved husband of Yetta Colin, father of Jay Barry Colin of Montecito, CA and Delray Beach, FL, Larry H. Colin of Atlanta, GA, and adoring grandfather of six grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. He lived his life helping all those who knew him. He proudly served our Country in the Merchant Marines during WWII. He was a retired Chairman of Colin Service Systems, Inc. one of the largest privately-held Facility Service providers that was recently acquired by ABM Service Industries. George served as president of Congregation Emanu-El of Yonkers, NY. He was past president of the Yonkers Chamber of Commerce, and a Board Member in the Westchester County Association. He actively supported many Jewish and non-sectarian organizations in both Westchester County and the Palm Beach County. It was as if he were a good deed in motion. A true gentleman, George blazed paths for better understanding and harmony among people--we all benefit from his having been with us. The Colin Family invites his many friends, and admirers to celebrate the 86 years that he was with us. Memorial Services were held at the Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel on Tuesday December 27. He will be interred at Mount Hope Cemetery located in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, this Thursday at 10:30a.m. Donations in his memory can be made to the American Cancer Society.

description: "This is not about monitoring phone calls designed to arrange Little League practice or what to bring to a potluck dinner. These are designed to monitor calls from very bad people to very bad people."

title: Two on Council Seen as Strong in Contest for Speaker
description: Just three days after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's second-term inaugural on Sunday, the City Council will select its next speaker, and the battle for that job has increasingly focused on two veteran members who have built competing factions of support in the legislative body.

title: Soccer:The good, the bad and the beautiful (game)
Wrestling With Memories Amid Mounds of Trash
description: NEW ORLEANS - He tossed his family portrait onto the trash pile as if it were a sack of kitchen scraps, and it landed on an heirloom Bible whose pages had decayed back to pulp. Nearby were ruined videos -- of Thanksgivings, his daughter's birthdays, trips to Disney World -- and old records that he had danced to with his wife. He was able to make out the label on only one, Stevie Wonder's cover of "We Can Work It Out," and he almost smiled.

description: Bette Midler is so 2002. So are Wynton Marsalis and the pitcher Al Leiter. At least at City Hall.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 27 - Iraqi political leaders on Tuesday began what are expected to be protracted negotiations to form a "national unity" government made up of Iraq's main sectarian and ethnic groups.

description: Whether or not they embraced his faith, or his brand of the faith, or any religion at all, it seemed that people liked Pope John Paul II. Really liked him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCHINS, DR. ABRAHAM S.
description: LUCHINS--Dr. Abraham S. 91, on December 27, 2005. Predeceased by his wife of 60 years and lifelong academic collaborator, Dr. Edith, he is survived by five children, 22 grandchildren and 21 great grandchildren. A prolific researcher and author, pioneer Gestalt psychologist, Founding Chairman of the Psychology Departments at Yeshiva College and Touro College and taught at McGill University, the Universities of Oregon and Miami and State University of Albany. A tenacious exponent of Torah values, he was involved in numerous scholastic and communal causes. Services will be held at Parkside, 2576 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn at 11:30 AM on Wednesday. Shiva will commence at 20 Park Ave in Monsey, NY and each of the children will be sitting at their own homes from Motzei Shabbat. $(6$)LUCHINS--Dr. Abraham. Touro College mourns the passing of Dr. Abraham Luchins, founding chair of our Psychology Department and beloved father of our colleague, Dr. David Luchins, chair of our Political Science Department. We extend deepest condolences to Dr. Luchins & the entire Luchins' family. Dr. Bernard Lander President Dr. Mark Hasten, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Charles W. Socarides, Psychiatrist and Psychoanalyst, Is Dead at 83
description: Dr. Charles W. Socarides, a well-known psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who maintained publicly, long after it was considered scientifically acceptable to do so, that homosexuality was a condition amenable to treatment and even to conversion to heterosexuality, died on Sunday at Metropolitan Hospital Center in New York. He was 83 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Eight killed in attempted Iraqi prison break
Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, ALFRED PAUL
description: BERNSTEIN--Alfred Paul. On December 26 after a courageous struggle with Parkinson's disease. Beloved brother of Pearl Kay, devoted uncle of Andrew Kay, and cherished companion of the late Robert Garrett. A gentleman of integrity, generosity and intelligence, Paul was an astute businessman and a gracious host. His goodness will be missed by his family, friends and former business associates. Services Wednesday, 12:45 PM, The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Ringing In the New Year With Luxury and Ease
description: SOME people greet the New Year with totemic foods -- black-eyed peas and collards, soba noodles, even grapes -- as symbols of prosperity. But David Burke goes straight for the prime rib.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANCE, CHARLES ENGELL
description: FRANCE -- Charles Engell. Died on Christmas Day, 2005, at the age of 58. Writer, press agent, antiques dealer (specializing in costume jewelry), and former assistant to the Artistic Director of American Ballet Theatre, Mikhail Baryshnikov, with whom he co-authored "Baryshnikov at Work," and "Baryshnikov in Color." Memorial to be announced.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Man Is Found Dead in Apartment in Chelsea
description: A 45-year-old man was found dead, his hands and feet bound, when firefighters broke into his burning Chelsea apartment yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Nortel Buys Internet Company
description: Nortel Networks said it was making a long-anticipated acquisition of an Internet router company, acquiring Tasman Networks of San Jose, Calif., for $99.5 million. Although Nortel acquired Bay Networks in an all- stock deal worth $9.1 billion in 1998 in a bid to compete against Cisco Systems in the market for equipment that moves Internet traffic, it never became a major force in the router business. Tasman, which is privately held, specializes in routers that allow corporations to move their data and voice telephone services through a high-security variation of the Internet. With many of its traditional customers like telephone companies ailing because of innovations like Internet-based voice calling, Nortel is concentrating on selling to a broader range of businesses. IAN AUSTEN (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Outspoken Putin Aide Quits, Scolding Kremlin An outspoken Putin adviser and critic of Kremlin policy, Andrei N. Illarionov, abruptly resigned, warning that Russia's nascent political freedoms have been lost and the Kremlin's economic choices have been poor. He said he could no longer influence government policy and denounced the muzzling of the government's critics.

title: U.S. Racer Puts Focus on Grit and Safety
description: When Noelle Pikus-Pace soared down the chute of ice on her skeleton sled on the track in Park City, Utah, in late November, her right leg was held together by titanium rods and still too weak to walk on. Yet, these were the most uncomplicated moments of her career.

title: Older Teachers Face Bias, Union Claims
description: The city teachers' union has charged that the Department of Education discriminates against teachers older than 40 by disproportionately bringing them up on disciplinary charges and giving them unsatisfactory performance ratings.

title: The Radical Moral Vision of the 'Dumb and Dumber' Guys
description: Of all the dumb teen movies in the constantly expanding dumb-teen-movie universe, "The Ringer" may be the most cautiously constructed and the most anxiously calibrated, the one with the greatest number of good intentions folded into the lumpy batter of its rude and simple plot.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Family Charged With Fraud
description: A couple and three of their adult children were indicted yesterday on charges that they ran a 17-year scam luring people to invest in a gold mine in Brazil. The couple, James and Rita Russo of New City, N.Y., and their children Elizabeth, Rudolfo and Thomas Russo, were indicted on two counts of fraud by a grand jury in Federal District Court in White Plains. According to the indictment, the Russos collected hundreds of thousands of dollars in a scheme they initiated in 1987, falsely claiming the funds were for fees and taxes on a mine in the Brazilian Amazon basin, and promising to pay profits to investors when the mine was sold. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

title: Scrushy Seeks Separate Trial in Bribery Case
description: Richard M. Scrushy, founder of the HealthSouth Corporation, has asked to be tried separately from other defendants on federal charges that he arranged $500,000 in bribes to former Gov. Don Siegelman of Alabama.

title: The Last Laugh Is on the Jets' Assistants
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 27 - One by one, they stepped to the microphone and scanned the crowd. Donnie Henderson, Mike Heimerdinger and Mike Westhoff launched into their routines, haltingly at first, but with greater ease as their spiels drew smiles, nods and laughter.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dear Carl and Sigmund
description: A trove of letters and diaries discovered in a basement in Switzerland in 1977 sparked a revival of interest in Sabina Spielrein, an important figure in the earliest days of psychoanalysis, both as doctor and patient. "My Name Was Sabina Spielrein" by the German-born director Elisabeth Mrton uses Spielrien's words to narrate the story of her life. After a tumultuous childhood and adolescence plagued by the nervous disorder then known as hysteria, Spielrein (Eva Osterberg) became the first psychoanalytic patient of Carl Jung (Lasse Almeback).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASHA, MATTHEW P.
description: KASHA--Matthew P. was the guiding force behind the sound installations at the Mercury Lounge, the Bowery Ballroom, and most recently Webster Hall. His creative genius, unfailing ear, and insistence on quality has given musicians and fans the best sound they can get in New York City. And this longtime Yankee fanatic pitched the Bowery softball team to its championship in 2000! As a sound engineer he was awarded gold records for numerous songs, such as Cameo's "Word Up." But most importantly, Matthew gave much more. Matthew, with your big heart and passion, and with your keen mind and wit, you brought laughter, love, encouragement, and warmth, mischievous fun and incredible perceptive smarts to us all. We will hold on to what you gave us forever-but we so sorely want more. You have no idea how many people will miss you, and how deeply. $(6$)KASHA--Matthew Pawling. February 11, 1960-December 26, 2005. Beloved son of Audrey Sisson Kasha and the late Alfred R. Kasha. Graveside service 11 AM, Thursday, December 29, at the Warwick Cemetery, Warwick, NY.

title: Six Flags Names Two to Unit to Revive Parks
description: Six Flags Inc. has named two executives, including an ESPN television programmer, to lead a new unit to revive the company's struggling theme parks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, KURT P.
description: ROSS--Kurt P. Lifetime resident of New York City and Managing Director of Ross & Lawrence Public Relations passed away on December 9, 2005. He will be remembered for his outstanding professional capabilities, acute intelligence, sophisticated wit, distinctive personal style and unrelenting zest for life. He generously shared with others his knowledge of history, literature, art, music, film and theatre as well as his appreciation of fine furnishings and antiques. He is survived by his business partner and life partner of more than 30 years, Guy B. Lawrence and sisters Irene Jaffe and Flora Nissman. A gathering of friends and family to celebrate his life will be held in the New Year. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation (www.lymphoma.org).

title: Transit Workers in Deal to Share Health Plan Cost
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the transit workers' union announced a settlement yesterday in which the authority abandoned its demand for concessions on pensions and the union agreed to have all workers pay a portion of their health insurance premiums.

title: Nurse Who Killed His Patients Can Donate Kidney, but He Must Get His Sentence First
description: A former nurse who pleaded guilty to killing 29 patients at hospitals in New Jersey and Pennsylvania has received permission to donate a kidney to an acquaintance in New York, as long as he first appears at his own sentencing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GALLAGHER, JOSEPH J., M.D.
description: GALLAGHER -- Joseph J., M.D. Of Upper Saddle River NJ died December 22, 2005 at age 82, with his famed good humor intact. He is survived by his wife Edna, son Timothy and his wife Kristi, daughters Kato and Bronwyn, and two grandsons, Nicholas and Zachary. He was predeceased by a son, Daniel. Dr. Gallagher retired in 1997 from Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, in Englewood, NJ, where he served for many years as the chief of Radiology. He was a graduate of Regis High School, Columbia University and NYU Medical School, all in New York City. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 11AM, Thursday, December 29, at the Church of the Presentation, 271 West Saddle River Road, Upper Saddle River, NJ. Visiting hours are today, 2-4PM and 7-9PM at the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 E. Ridgewood Ave, Ridgewood NJ. Donations in his name to Regis High School, Development Office, 55 E. 84 St, NY NY 10028, attn: Tina Throckmorton, are greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOCARIDES, CHARLES WIL LIAM, M.D.
description: SOCARIDES -- Charles Wil liam, M.D., on December 25, 2005. Beloved husband of Claire Alford Socarides, loving father of Jacqueline Nicole Socarides, Charles W. Socarides, Jr., Alexandra Socarides, Richard Socarides and Daphne Socarides (deceased), loving grandfather of Archer Fried Socarides and beloved brother of Helen Socarides Covett, and uncle to Dr. Robert G. Covett. Born January 24, 1922, Charles Socarides determined at the age of 13, after reading a book on the life of Sigmund Freud, that he would become a physician and psychoanalyst. Charles Socarides graduated from Harvard College and went on to receive his certificate in psychoanalytic medicine from Columbia University in 1952. He was the author of eight books including his master work, "The Preoedipal Origin and Psychoanalytic Therapy of Sexual Perversions," and "Work and Its Inhibitions - Psychoanalytic Essays" as well as over 80 psychoanalytic articles. Charles Socarides appeared on numerous news programs to discuss his psychoanalytic work and findings including Dateline, 60 Minutes and Larry King Live. Charles Socarides was the past president and co-founder of N.A.R.T.H.the National Association for Research and Therapy of Homosexuality. Charles Socarides was on the board of directors of the Margaret S. Mahler Psychiatric Research Foundation; he was a member of the International Advisory Committee, Second Delphi International Psychoanalytic Symposium, Delphi, Greece, 1988; he was also a member of the American Medical Association, the American Psychiatric Association, the Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine, a life member of the American Psychoanalytic Association where he chaired a discussion group for many years, the International Psychoanalytic Association and he was an affiliate member of the Royal Society of Medicine, London. Dr. Charles Socarides was Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, NYC, 1978-1996. His numerous awards include that of Distinguished Psychoanalyst, Association of Psychoanalytic Psychologists, British Health Service, London, England, April 28, 1995; the first Sigmund Freud Lectureship Award, New York Center for Psychoanalytic Training, NYC, and the 1987 Sigmund Freud Award given by the American Society of Psychoanalytic Physicians in recognition of distinguished service to psychiatry and psychoanalytic research. Charles Socarides was respected and loved by his friends and patients for his generosity of spirit, loyalty, courage, responsibility, loving kindness and goodness. He will be sorely missed by his wife Claire Alford Socarides, for Charlie was her one true love forever and ever. He would say to his patients--"I love you and will love you always and be with you always." A wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM, on Wednesday and Thursday, and a funeral mass will be held at 9 AM, Friday, at the Greek Cathedral of the Holy Trinity on East 74th St.

title: Linkin Park Will Stay With Warner Music
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 - Less than eight months after issuing a stinging, public vote of no-confidence in its record company, Warner Music Group, the multiplatinum rap-rock act Linkin Park has signed a lucrative new pact with the recording giant. The six-member Los Angeles band and its management company, the Firm, last week reached a deal with Warner calling for an estimated $15 million advance for the group's next album, executives involved in the contract negotiations said. The pact provides the company's Warner Brothers Records unit with an option for up to five more albums from the band, one more than had been called for in their original deal.

title: Auto Supplier to Appeal Decision on Retirees
description: ArvinMeritor, a maker of vehicle exhaust systems, said yesterday that it would appeal a federal court order that blocks a Jan. 1 reduction in the company's retiree health care benefits.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: G.O.P. Seeks Inquiry Into Spitzer Phone Call
description: Stephen Minarik III, the State Republican Party chairman, has asked for an investigation into whether Attorney General Eliot Spitzer threatened John C. Whitehead, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, during a private telephone conversation. Mr. Spitzer, a candidate for governor in 2006, has denied the allegation. Mr. Minarik, left, made his request, reported yesterday in The New York Post, in a letter that was sent on Monday to Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Ryan Moses, a spokesman for Mr. Minarik, said yesterday that the letter recounted comments that he says Mr. Spitzer made to Mr. Whitehead, including, "I will be coming after you." Mr. Whitehead said last week in an op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal that he had received a threatening call from Mr. Spitzer days after an op-ed article in April in which Mr. Whitehead attacked Mr. Spitzer for making fraud accusations against Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of American International Group. Daniel J. Castleman, a spokesman for Mr. Morgenthau, said yesterday that the letter had not arrived.

title: National Briefs
description: NEW ENGLAND

title: London Calling, With Luck, Lust and Ambition
description: Because Woody Allen's early films are about as funny as any ever made, it is often assumed that his temperament is essentially comic, which leads to all manner of disappointment and misunderstanding. Now and then, Mr. Allen tries to clear up the confusion, insisting, sometimes elegantly and sometimes a little too baldly, that his view of the world is essentially nihilistic. He has announced, in movie after movie, an absolute lack of faith in any ordering moral principle in the universe - and still, people think he's joking.

title: London Calling, With Luck, Lust and Ambition
description: Because Woody Allen's early films are about as funny as any ever made, it is often assumed that his temperament is essentially comic, which leads to all manner of disappointment and misunderstanding. Now and then, Mr. Allen tries to clear up the confusion, insisting, sometimes elegantly and sometimes a little too baldly, that his view of the world is essentially nihilistic. He has announced, in movie after movie, an absolute lack of faith in any ordering moral principle in the universe -- and still, people think he's joking.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GRUDER, PETER
description: GRUDER--Peter. On your birthday, we love you, celebrate with your brother. Mother, Mary and Deborrah

title: A Lotta Latke
description: THE last time I made latkes was at a Hanukkah party about 15 years ago. The scene: 10 or 15 adults and almost as many children, all feeling entitled to eat latkes until sated, which required 100 or so. With two burners going full blast, two large skillets, a quart of oil and a huge bowl of batter, I worked two hours straight. If I had wanted to work that hard I would have been a chef.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, MARGE (NEE MEISEL)
description: ALLEN--Marge (nee Meisel). Of Ellington, Connecticut and Palm Beach, Florida, died December 24, 2005 at the age of 79. Beloved wife of 50 years of Matthew, loving mother of Steven and mother-in-law of Gretchen and adoring grandmother of Rebecca. A native New Yorker, she worked in the television and radio industries prior to her marriage and in real estate sales with her husband afterward. She will be remembered for her sense of style, panache, wit and lifelong activity as a tennis player which originated as a teenager in Central Park. She will be deeply missed. Private services have been held. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: At Los Alamos Lab, Who Will Be Accountable?
description: To the Editor:

title: Toll on Rise in Sri Lanka's 'Shadow War'
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 27 - One could be forgiven for thinking Sri Lanka is at war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUSHNER, STANLEY
description: KUSHNER--Stanley. In loving memory, at 75 years old, passed away peacefully on Monday, December 26 at his home in Stratton Mountain, VT. After retiring from his life long career as an electrical contractor and President of Kushner Electric Company., he persued his dual passion of golf and skiing. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Barbara, his three children, Cheryl, Caryn and Carl, his two sons in-law Richard Mintzer of Mamaroneck, NY and Peter Davis of Jericho, VT., and his four grandchildren, Ross, Emma, Melissa and Skyler. May he rest in peace and forever in the hearts and minds of all those he loved and all those who loved him. He will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be held at "Guttermans Inc.", Rockville Centre, LI at 12 noon on Wednesday, December 28. $(6$)KUSHNER -- Stanley. The Board of Governors of Middle Bay Country Club of Oceanside, NY, on behalf of its membership, wishes to express its sympathy and condolences to the family of its esteemed member and past president, Stanley Kushner. He will be sorely missed.

title: DiSpirito Goes Off the Air
description: A LITTLE more than a year after the chef Rocco DiSpirito became the host of "Food Talk" on WOR radio, he and the station have parted company.

title: The Hand That Kneads the Dough Also Stirred the Grout
description: The focus is strictly Italian at Falai Panetteria, which opened in mid-December diagonally opposite Iacopo Falai's restaurant on the Lower East Side. A roster of morning pastries includes croissants oozing a rich cream filling, flaky sfogliatelle and tender bomboloni doughnuts. Later on there are sandwiches on homemade black cabbage ciabatta, individual focaccias and pastas. Mr. Falai, trained as a pastry chef, does all the baking, using organic flour, in the restaurant, Falai. His bread, ready to sell by 1 p.m., is baked twice more during the day.

title: Limbo, an Afterlife Tradition, May Be Doomed by the Vatican
description: ROME, Dec. 27 - It may seem half a shame to get rid of a church tradition, however cruel and antiquated, if it can inspire poetry like "The Inferno" or spooky lines like these from Seamus Heaney: "Fishermen at Ballyshannon/Netted an infant last night/Along with the salmon."

title: Confronting the Carnage in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Night, It All Works for St. John's
description: When everything clicks and the team performs with a purpose, St. John's can be pretty good. Despite missing its leading scorer, Daryll Hill, the Red Storm played a complete game last night against Columbia in the opening round of the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden, combining a tenacious defense with an efficient offense. The result was a 63-39 victory in what might have been the Red Storm's best performance this season.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Dec. 16 about a decision by President Bush to authorize the National Security Agency to eavesdrop on Americans and others inside the United States to search for evidence of terrorist activity without warrants ordinarily required for domestic spying misstated the name of the court that would normally issue those warrants. It is the Foreign - not Federal -Intelligence Surveillance Court. (Go to Article)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Group To Buy 43-Story Tower
description: In one of the biggest office deals of the year, Hudson Waterfront Associates, a group of Hong Kong billionaires, said it was buying the 43-story tower at 1290 Avenue of the Americas for $1.25 billion. The group signed a contract shortly before Dec. 25 to buy the two million-square-foot building, between 51st and 52nd Streets, from Apollo Real Estate Advisors and Jamestown, a German real estate fund. Hudson Waterfront is paying 68 percent more than what the sellers paid three years ago. CHARLES V. BAGLI (NYT)

title: Trying to Build the Grand Central of the West
description: SAN FRANCISCO - The Transbay Terminal is sometimes referred to by planners and developers here as the missing tooth in a smile. Situated in the rapidly growing South of Market neighborhood, the once-busy rail hub has slowly deteriorated into an underused bus station even as surrounding areas have been transformed by office and residential towers; SBC Park, where the Giants play baseball; and cultural institutions like the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

title: Constance Keene, 84, a Pianist in the Romantic Mold, Is Dead
description: Constance Keene, a pianist and teacher whose recordings of the Romantic keyboard repertory were highly regarded, died on Dec. 24 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 84, and lived in Manhattan.

title: Plucked From Africa, but Still Isolated in Their Classes
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. - IDIRIS MAOW, 14, an eighth grader at Forest Park Middle School, is a refugee from Somalia who arrived here with his family in 2003. He is in his second year in an English language immersion class, yet can barely speak or understand English and cannot read it. Asked in English how long he had been at Forest Park, he could not answer.

title: European Brewer Names Brazilian as Chief
description: InBev, the world's second-largest brewer, has named as chief executive Carlos Brito, who was head of the Brazilian company Inbev bought last year to aid growth in markets like Latin America and Eastern Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, HONEY R. (NEE ROUSUCK)
description: ROSENTHAL--Honey R. (nee Rousuck). Wife of the late Leighton A. Mother of Cynthia R. (T. Dennie-deceased) Boardman and Jane R. (Michael J.) Horvitz. Grandmother of Sarah and Samuel Boardman, Kate and Lizzie Horvitz. Services in Cleveland, OH, Monday, December 26. In lieu of flowers contributions to The Cleveland Clinic Heart Center, 9500 Euclid Ave., Cleveland, OH 44106.

title: Church tradition of limbo heading for, well, limbo
Paid Notice: Deaths   MURDOCK, MADELEINE (NEE HUNTINGTON)
description: MURDOCK--Madeleine (nee Huntington). Died peacefully at home, December 25, 2005. She is survived by daughter, Pamela and stepdaughter, Catherine, and was predeceased by husband, Lewis, and daughter, Frances. A Memorial Service will be held at 11 A.M., Friday, January 6, at St. Lukes Episcopal Church in Gladstone, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation, 450 Shrewsbury Plaza, Shrewsbury, NJ 07702-4332.

title: Democrat Joins Schwarzenegger, and the Grumbling Is Bipartisan
description: SACRAMENTO, Dec. 22 - The enemies were on high alert and the blogosphere had a juicy news flash: Susan P. Kennedy, a prominent Democrat who will soon take over as Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger's chief of staff, was spotted having lunch with the chairman of the California Republican Party at a popular steakhouse here called Chops.

title: U.S. Asks Supreme Court to Transfer Terror Suspect
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 - The Bush administration asked the Supreme Court today to allow for the immediate transfer of Jose Padilla from a military brig to civilian custody to stand trial on terrorism charges, challenging an appellate court ruling last week that blocked the move.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: INDUSTRIA ARGENTINA -- The food, art and crafts of Argentina have a showcase in this new restaurant, owned by Stefano Villa, Fernando Dallorso and, at right, Fernando Trocca. Mr. Trocca's menu features grilled meat, braised specialties cooked in a brick oven (Andean chicken and Patagonian-style rack of lamb) and several Italian dishes (vegetable lasagna). The wine list is all-Argentine: 329 Greenwich Street (Duane Street), (212) 965-8560.

title: If You Must Have a War, Make Sure It's a Cold One
description: The Cold War A New History By John Lewis Gaddis Illustrated. 333 pages. Penguin Press. $27.95.

title: Confronting the Carnage in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FASS, EDYTHE
description: FASS--Edythe. Beloved wife of the late Charles Fass and sister of Judith Greissman, Edythe was a brave, spirited woman, with a passion for literature and friendship. She was struck down in a tragic accident on Dec. 25 at age 70. Her shocking death leaves a void in countless lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EVANS, G. BLAKEMORE
description: EVANS -- G. Blakemore. Shakespeare's editor (the Riverside), Harvard Renaissance scholar, irreplaceable friend of 35 years. Our love and respect to Betty, Pam, and Michael, the grandchildren, and great grandchildren. We miss him so. Susan and Joseph Ferraro

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATTERSON, DAVID, PROFESSOR
description: PATTERSON--David, Professor. Deepest sympathy to the family of this great man, whose life so enriched ours. We will always cherish the times we spent with David and Josie. Frances and Joseph Rechtschaffen, MD

title: Raise a Glass, And Pick A Resolution
description: Want a New Year's resolution served up with your coffee or tea? Hearth, 403 East 12th Street in the East Village, actually uses these "food" coasters year round because the message is a keeper. So are the coasters. "Lots of customers take them home," said Paul Grieco, a partner.

description: Recent Sale $119.5 million Metropolitan Center Route 3 East Rutherford, N.J. This 15-story 423,000-square-foot building, across Route 3 from Giants Stadium, is near the Xanadu shopping center, now under construction, and a planned rail spur. Buyer: ING Clarion Seller: CB Richard Ellis Investors Buyer's broker: Michael O'Connor, ING Clarion Seller's broker: Cushman & Wakefield Metropolitan Area Capital Markets Group

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, GILDA L.
description: GOLDSTEIN--Gilda L. Passed away on December 26, 2005, after a very long illness. Most loved wife of Harvey, devoted mother of Sharon (Neil) Wessan, and Lisa (Stephen) Lebovitz, cherished grandmother of Andrew, Matthew, Abby, and Julia Lebovitz, Eric and Lauren Wessan. She is survived by her caring brother Irwin Feinstein, and his family. Funeral services will be private.

title: Housing That Has a Profit and a Social Motive
description: Contrary to what might seem logical, developing luxury projects for affluent buyers is not the only way to make profits in the real estate business.

title: The Hanukkah Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOBET, MARTIN
description: TOBET--Martin. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Martin Tobet, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife Roslyn and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Marc Goldberg, President

title: Daimler sells 2 businesses
Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Monday with an article about Italy's efforts to settle a dispute with the Metropolitan Museum of Art over antiquities referred incompletely to the painter of "Virgin Annunciate," an Italian work on loan to the Met. He was Antonello da Messina, commonly called Antonello, not da Messina.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Dec. 16 about a decision by President Bush to authorize the National Security Agency to eavesdrop on Americans and others inside the United States to search for evidence of terrorist activity without warrants ordinarily required for domestic spying misstated the name of the court that would normally issue those warrants. It is the Foreign -- not Federal --Intelligence Surveillance Court.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Charged With Arms Violation
description: An off-duty police officer was arrested in Washington Heights yesterday after the officers who pulled him over found three defaced firearms in the truck he was driving, the police said. The officer, Donald Medard, 30, was stopped on West 180th Street near Audubon Avenue about 1:30 a.m. by officers responding to a 911 call about an assault involving a GMC Yukon truck. Officer Medard was driving the truck, the police said. Inside were ski masks and firearms whose serial numbers had been scratched off, which is illegal, the police said. Officer Medard, who was charged with one count of possession of a defaced firearm, was appointed to the force in 2003, and has worked since January in the 104th Precinct in Queens. Internal affairs officers are investigating. Three other men in the truck were also arrested; the police did not release any details about those charges. AL BAKER (NYT)

title: Governor Romney Bails Out
description: Seven Northeastern states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have embarked on a regionwide plan to reduce power plant emissions of carbon dioxide, which contributes to global warming. Two years in the making, the plan is the first collective effort in America to adopt mandatory controls for greenhouse gases. It is further evidence of the states' willingness to address an issue that Washington has largely ignored, as well as a timely antidote for the administration's dispiriting performance at the recent global warming conference in Montreal.

title: Eating Your Way to Health; Companies Are Marketing Fortified Foods to the Drug-Wary
description: Ever since she gave birth to her fourth child in 2003, Michelle Celona, a 43-year-old part-time teacher in Philadelphia, had suffered from annoying bouts of constipation. Figuring it was the stress of carting three children around or the result of something that had changed in her body after pregnancy, she learned to live with it.

title: NATION
description: That one person can make a difference was the clarion message of the life of Rosa Parks, the seamstress who set off the seminal Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott in 1955.

title: U.S. to Punish 9 Companies Said to Help Iran on Arms
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Dec. 27 - The Bush administration announced new sanctions on Tuesday against state-owned Chinese companies that it accused of aiding Iran's missile and chemical programs, insisting that Beijing cut off the trade at a time when Mr. Bush is trying to persuade China's leaders to condemn Tehran's nuclear program.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Square Feet pages of Business Day last Wednesday (12/21) about the planned restoration of the Hoboken Terminal referred incorrectly to the affiliation of Kenneth Murchison, the architect who designed the building a century ago. He had an independent practice; he was not with the firm of McKim, Mead & White. In addition, the article misstated the name of the railroad that built the terminal. It was the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western Railroad, not yet the Erie Lackawanna. It also misstated part of the name of a Baltimore-based company that is a partner in the redevelopment. It is Williams Jackson Ewing Inc., not William.

title: Corrections
description: A Calendar listing on Sunday in the New Jersey section misstated the date of a performance in Westfield. "Guys and Dolls of Broadway," a concert by the Westfield Symphony Orchestra at Westfield High School, 18250 North Union Street, will be at 7 p.m. on Saturday, Dec. 31, not Jan. 31.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Former Enron Accountant to Plead Guilty And Could Testify Against Other Executives In a reversal that transforms the criminal case involving Enron's former top officers, the company's former chief accounting officer has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to violating federal law during his employment there, people briefed on the decision said. As a result of the deal, the former officer, Richard Causey, could serve as a witness for the government in the coming trial of two other executives, Kenneth Lay and Jeffrey Skilling. [Page A1.]

title: Republican Strategist Is Taking Heat for Taking Mexico as Client
description: DALLAS, Dec. 26 - Rob Allyn, the political consultant, meet Rob Allyn, the punching bag.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Charity Oversight Closer To Law
description: Parliament's upper house approved a bill to impose new restrictions on charities and other private groups and require government approval of their activities. It needs only President Vladimir V. Putin's signature to become law.

title: Beslan response 'plagued by shortcomings'
Food to Match the Wines
description: HERE are some of the new restaurants in Napa, Calif.:

title: Labor's Huge Rubber Rat, Caught in a Legal Maze
description: The inflatable rubber rat, bucktoothed bane of strikebreakers and emblem of union wrath, may be headed for retirement. The National Labor Relations Board is now considering a case that could make it harder to employ one on a picket line.

title: China courts turn deaf ear to peasants' cases
In a Shootout, Arizona State Outguns Rutgers
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 27 - Early in the fourth quarter, after Rutgers had taken a 2-point lead over Arizona State in the Insight Bowl, the actor James Gandolfini walked with four dark-suited bodyguards across the back of the end zone near the Rutgers fans.

title: Artists' Personal Visions Reveal a Nation to Itself
description: "Imagining America: Icons of 20th-Century American Art" ends with the Velvet Underground's haunting, upbeat song "I'll Be Your Mirror." The music crosses the final "t" on the documentary's lyrical portrait of a nation as seen through the work of a dozen of its best known 20th-century artists. Ranging from Georgia O'Keeffe to Jean-Michel Basquiat and David Wojnarowicz, with special emphasis on Jackson Pollock and Andy Warhol, it is broad-stroked and somewhat sanitized but still effective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOEN, ARTHUR BOYER, JR.
description: SCHOEN--Arthur Boyer, Jr. Age 52, died at home on Christmas Eve after a valiant battle with cancer. Dear husband of Pam, loving father of Caroline and Artie, devoted son of Arthur and the late Luise Schoen, brother of Diana Shields and uncle of Tommy, Diana, Marina, Christiana and Olympia. A Memorial Service will be held at The Dune Church in Southampton on June 17 at 5 P.M. Contributions in Artie's memory may be made to The Southampton Association Inc. to benefit the Scholarship Fund. Address is P.O. Box 641, Southampton, NY 11969.

title: When Chinese Sue the State, Cases Are Often Smothered
description: SHIQIAO, China - The peasants surrounded the clerk in the busy court anteroom, badgering him to let them sue the officials who had seized their land.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about the career of Alicia J. Graf, a dancer now with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, referred incorrectly to her effort to get a job with New York City Ballet after her previous employer, Dance Theater of Harlem, disbanded last year. She called the ballet, but she did not audition.

title: Sharing the wealth from online searches
Smell Was Noticed, Not Neighbor's Absence
description: Strikingly handsome and tall, James Fallon, 87, had once caught the eye of many of his elderly neighbors in the Plaza Tower, a luxury high-rise in Midtown. But he and his wife, Carole, kept mostly to themselves. So no one grew curious or concerned when he was no longer seen in the building's hallways or elevators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURRAY, ANNE
description: MURRAY--Anne. On December 18, in Florida. Beloved wife of Ira; mother of two deceased sons, Daniel and Edward; dear sister of Fan Walker, the late Tess Blay, and the late Al Schuss; grandmother of Nadya and mother-in-law of Myra Malkin; aunt and great-aunt of many deeply devoted nephews and nieces.

title: Vice Axes That 70's Show
description: WASHINGTON - We start the new year with the same old fear: Dick Cheney.

title: London Calling, With Luck, Lust and Ambition
description: Because Woody Allen's early films are about as funny as any ever made, it is often assumed that his temperament is essentially comic, which leads to all manner of disappointment and misunderstanding. Now and then, Mr. Allen tries to clear up the confusion, insisting, sometimes elegantly and sometimes a little too baldly, that his view of the world is essentially nihilistic. He has announced, in movie after movie, an absolute lack of faith in any ordering moral principle in the universe -- and still, people think he's joking.

title: One Year After the Tsunami
description: The tsunami that cut a swath of destruction through the Indian Ocean region last year was an extraordinary catastrophe. It struck 12 countries and displaced more than two million people, according to the United Nations, destroying their livelihoods, tearing apart families, annihilating entire towns. The ensuing natural disasters that have followed in the 12 months since then -- from Hurricanes Katrina and Rita to the earthquake in Kashmir -- have been measured against the horror of the number left dead by the Indian Ocean tsunami: at least 183,172.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MICHEL, FREDERICK A.
description: MICHEL--Frederick A. on December 26, 2005 of Manhasset & E. Hampton, NY. Beloved husband of Joan H. Loving father of Jennifer, Frederick and Christopher. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey, Juliet and James Bonci, Magdalena Michel, Willem Wallace and Willa Michel. Memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: National Registry Adds 25 Films

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WITTING, CHRIS J.
description: WITTING--Chris J. A pioneer in the early days of television, business executive, entrepreneur, philanthropist, and community leader, died peacefully at his home in Syracuse, NY on December 19. He was 90 years old. Witting retired as chairman, chief executive officer, and director of the CrouseHinds Company (now known as Cooper Crouse-Hinds) in 1982. Under his leadership, beginning in 1965, annual sales at Crouse-Hinds grew from $50 million to almost $900 million, and the company became listed on the Fortune 500. New product introductions and acquisitions over the years helped to transform the modest electrical equipment firm into the world leader in aviation lighting products in the mid-70s, with subsidiaries in South America, Europe and Australia. Witting was known for his belief in the power of individuals and positive thinking. His management style was to empower his employees, delegating responsibility and giving them every incentive to improve their skills and advance. He was often quoted as saying, "Everyone should be Number One in something. It doesn't matter what that is. Since you spend most of your life working, you may as well be the best in your field." A firm believer in the importance of giving back to the community, he was both an industry and civic leader. He served as president of the Manufacturers Association of Syracuse, chairman of the board of trustees of Syracuse University, and a member, board member, and director of numerous other groups, including the Everson Museum, Metropolitan Development Association of Syracuse and Central New York, and Syracuse Symphony Orchestra. In 1973 the Syracuse Herald-American named him "Man of the Year." His contributions were recognized with numerous awards. He held honorary degrees from Clarkson College, LeMoyne College, and Syracuse University. In 1996, Representative James T. Walsh (N.Y.) paid him tribute in Congress, calling him "a true civic leader, a man who has not only led the way for manufacturing interests in Central New York, but has touched the lives of thousands of his fellow citizens with his philanthropy, his counsel, and his encouragement." Witting began his career as a public accountant at Price Waterhouse in New York City. He worked his way through college, earning a B.S. from NYU in 1941. That same year, Price Waterhouse assigned him to Camp Shows USA (later USO Camp Shows), for which he directed all financial work as treasurer and comptroller. During his tenure as executive vice president, Camp Shows had 10,000 entertainers working in all areas where servicemen and women were stationed during World War II. A leading figure in the early years of television, Witting developed the Allen B. Dumont organization from a six-man group to 800 personnel, operating wholly owned stations in New York, Pittsburgh, and Washington, DC, as well as a TV network relationship in 58 cities. Dumont became the first commercial operating television network in the country, with regularly scheduled news broadcast from Washington, DC to New York City. Witting is credited with having brought Sid Caesar, Imogene Coca, Jackie Gleason, Dennis James, and Bishop Sheen to network TV. He left Dumont in 1953 to become president of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, a subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. While he was at Westinghouse Broadcasting, every Westinghouse radio and TV station was rated number one in its market. Witting later joined the parent company in Pittsburgh, as group vice president in charge of the electronic components and consumer products divisions. In 1964 he moved to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corp. (ITT) in New York City, serving as second in command to the president and chairman, Harold Geneen. At ITT Witting directed the world headquarters marketing, manufacturing, and technical activities, as well as two subsidiaries, ITT Export Corp. and Distributed Products Co. He remained active long after his 1982 retirement, operating his own investment company. He devoted his efforts to helping others achieve business success, not only investing in local companies, but also endowing the Witting Chair in Entrepreneurship at Syracuse University's Whitman School of Management. Throughout his long life, Witting enjoyed the outdoors, camping, hiking, and doing chores on his property. Nearly every day he rose before dawn to go jogging, accompanied by one of his beloved dogs, no matter what the weather. For some 35 years he made sure that family members stayed close by hosting an annual reunion at his home for the extended Witting clan, who traveled from all parts of the country to be there. He also maintained a cottage in New Jersey for use by his family. It was a Sears house that he built himself after returning from Europe at the end of World War II. He is survived by his devoted wife, Marshia (Pullman) Witting, sons Leland Witting and Chris Witting Jr., daughters Anne W. Kuhn and Nancy Witting, seven grandchildren, and five greatgrandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Grace (Orrok) Witting, and his brother, Nicholas Witting Jr. Funeral services private. Burial St. Mary's Cemetery, DeWitt. There are no calling hours. Contributions: Francis House (108 Michaels Ave., Syracuse, NY 13208), the Whitman School of Management at Syracuse University (721 University Ave., Syracuse, NY 13244), and the Syracuse Symphony Orchestra (411 Montgomery St., Ste 40, Syracuse, NY 13202. EatonTubbs - Schepp Funeral Home, Fayetteville, NY.

title: Arts, Briefly; Glitches Bedevil New Nielsen Count
description: Monday was the first night Nielsen used its new method of measuring the viewing audience to include digital video recorders. Nielsen has not previously measured any time-shifted viewing made possible by devices like Tivo, which are in about 7 percent of American homes. Nielsen will now have a live viewing total, along with a second total representing those who watched a show the day it was recorded and, beginning in early January, those who watched within a week. First-day glitches in the new system delayed the compilations too long for inclusion here, but the more traditional methods showed that for the last broadcast of "Monday Night Football," above, on ABC, viewers were ready for some football. With little competition, ABC easily won on Monday night in both total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. On Saturday night, NBC's annual broadcast of "It's a Wonderful Life" on Christmas Eve (4.4 million viewers) was good enough for only third place. CBS won the night, with repeats of "NCIS" and "Numbers" and an episode of "48 Hours Mystery." KATE AURTHUR

title: Forgetfulness and Responsibility
description: Some years ago we had a criminal prosecution in Scotland of a man who was found to have a small quantity of marijuana in one of the pockets of his golf bag. These days the police hardly concern themselves with such cases, but at the time the possession of even barely detectable quantities of controlled drugs was a more serious matter. His defense was simple. He had placed it there some years before and forgotten about it. This did him no good. He was convicted. Some may feel sympathy for him; other may not. But whatever ones view on the outcome, this case raises interesting issues of whether you can be said to possess something that you have forgotten you have.

title: Arts, Briefly; Nielsen Works Out Bugs
description: The second day of Nielsen's new ratings system, which measures live viewing and programs watched later on digital video recorders, went much more smoothly than its delay-plagued Monday rollout. The estimates for Tuesday showed that CBS won in total viewers, and NBC was first among adults 18 to 49 years old. CBS's repeat of "NCIS" (11.96 million) was the night's most-watched show. The network's two-hour "Kennedy Center Honors" drew 10.85 million viewers. But because that special's largest demographic appeal was to viewers 50 and older, NBC was able to easily win the night among 18-to-49-year-olds. Except for a repeat of "The Office," soon to move to Thursdays, NBC won or tied every half-hour in that age group. Fox placed second among adults 18 to 49 for the night, and CBS was third.

Often the invitation includes an inducement, like a cash bonus of $25 or $50.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Settlement In Age-Bias Case
description: Austrian Airlines has been ordered to pay $500,000 to a former employee who said he was fired because of his age under an agreement submitted by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission for court approval. The man, William Thoman, a former director of sales for the airline, said he was fired without warning by a general manager in 2002 and replaced by a 32-year-old. Before his firing, Mr. Thoman, then 51, had objected to the manager's characterization of older workers as "worthless and ineffective" and had told him that under United States law, he could not simply "get rid of" older workers, said Raechel L. Adams, a lawyer for the employment commission. In addition to the payment, the agreement calls for the airline to make several changes to its United States operations, including requiring antidiscrimination training for its employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEENE, CONSTANCE
description: KEENE - Constance. The House of Steinway & Sons deeply mourns the passing of the eminent American pianist Constance Keene, in New York City on December 24, 2005 at the age of 84. Constance Keene was a treasured member of our family of Steinway Artists for fiftytwo years. Early in her career she was proclaimed an exceptional interpreter of Rachmaninoff, and with her success in the Naumburg Competition of 1943 her career was launched. She appeared in recital, in duo recital with Abram Chasins, to whom she was married from 1949 until his death in 1987, and with the leading orchestras of the day. Ms. Keene was a featured participant in Steinway & Sons' Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953. An acclaimed teacher at the Manhattan School of Music, Ms. Keene was also an indefatigable traveler, serving on juries of the major piano competitions and conducting master classes around the globe. Our fond memories of Constance will continue to enrich us, as will her recordings and the artistry of her celebrated pupils. We convey our love and heartfelt condolences to her husband Milton. We have lost a dear friend. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Springfield: Woman Killed By Truck
description: A 26-year-old woman from Haledon, N.J., was killed on Route 78 when a truck changed lanes and ran over her sports car yesterday, the police said. The woman, Carrie A. Johansson, was taken to Overlook Hospital in Summit, where she died of severe internal injuries at 4:39 p.m., about an hour after the accident. Charges against the driver, James H. Porter, 67, of Alpha, Ohio, are pending. For three hours, only lane of traffic was open as the accident was being investigated.

title: Hosni Mubarak's Democracy
description: So much for holding Egypt up as a beacon of burgeoning democracy in the Middle East. Last Saturday an Egyptian court, in a move worthy of Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe, sentenced Ayman Nour, the prominent liberal opposition leader, to five years at hard labor for supposedly forging signatures on petitions used to create his political party.

AstraZeneca will pay Targacept an initial $10 million for the treatment, the company said. The payments may reach $300 million over the four years of the collaboration.

title: Officers on Bridge Missed Halting Truck by 40 Feet

Paid Notice: Deaths   PITNEY, DUNCAN
description: PITNEY--Duncan. On December 28 at home. An artist and raconteur. Graduate of Aiken Preparatory School, Milton Academy and Princeton '43. He served in the Army Air Corps during World War II, flying aviation gas from India to China. He was a member of the River, Brook and Somerset Hills Country Clubs. He served on the NJ Water Policy & Supply Council and was State Treasurer for the NJ Republican Party. He leaves his wife of 42 years, Kathleen Troast, sons John and Christopher, stepsons Trygve and Erik Sletteland, stepdaughters Sigrid Franzblau, Karen Jackson and Wendy Macbeth. A daughter, Jenifer Lyle, predeceased him. At his request there will be no service.

title: Arts, Briefly; Holiday Rush in CD Sales

Blige, Jamie Foxx and the Notorious B.I.G. made impressive debuts, and sales were strong all around according to Billboard. Ms. Blige, below, racked up her third No. 1 album with "The Breakthrough" (Geffen), selling 727,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Mr. Foxx's "Unpredictable" (J) was next with 598,000 in sales. Mr. Foxx sings on Kanye West's recent hit song, "Gold Digger," and released his debut album 11 years ago. B.I.G.'s "Duets: The Final Chapter" (Bad Boy) reached No. 3 with 438,000 in sales. BEN SISARIO

title: The Mounting Powers of Secrecy
description: The open government law that guaranteed greater freedom of information to the public will soon be 40 years old and desperately in need of legislative overhaul, thanks to the Bush administration. The White House's sweeping enlargement of agency powers has already nearly doubled the rate of newly classified documents to 15 million a year. At the same time, the administration has choked back the annual volume of documents declassified for public access, from 200 million in 1998 to 44 million lately.

World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Mittal in Talks to Buy Steel Rival
description: The Mittal Steel Company, the world's biggest steelmaker, is in talks to buy as much as 49 percent of the Baotou Iron and Steel Group of China, in what would be its second acquisition in the world's largest market for the metal. The stake would be capped at 49 percent under existing Chinese laws limiting foreign ownership and would bolster output for Mittal, based in the Netherlands, by about 5 percent. The potential cost of the deal was not disclosed.

title: Report on Russia Massacre Faults Officials

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 8 about internal discord in the American Civil Liberties Union referred incompletely to a commitment made by Anthony D. Romero, its executive director, to name a new building for Peter B. Lewis, a major donor. Although Mr. Romero did anger some board members by promising Mr. Lewis that his name would be on the building without first consulting with the board, Mr. Romero subsequently put the deal to the board's executive committee, which then ratified it by a vote of 6 to 1. title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: With Incomes Up and Mortgage Rates Down, Housing in Most of Nation Is More Affordable Despite a widespread sense that real estate has never been more expensive, families in the vast majority of locations around the county can still buy a house for a smaller share of their income than they could have a generation ago. Together, a sharp fall in mortgage rates since the early 1980's, a decline in mortgage fees and a rise in incomes have more than made up for rising house prices in almost every place outside of New York, Washington, Miami and along the California coast. [Page A1.]

title: An Expressionist Fervor, Illuminated by Levine
description: If James Levine could zap himself back in time and conduct the premiere of any opera in history, what among his favorites might he choose? Perhaps the Vienna premiere of Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro." Or the Milan premiere of Verdi's "Otello." How about the Munich premiere of Wagner's "Meistersinger," a work he conducts magnificently? I love the idea of Mr. Levine's giving a sublime account of this humane comedy and forcing the anti-Semitic composer to confront his twisted prejudices.

title: Kurds Are Flocking to Kirkuk, Laying Claim to Land and Oil

title: Hitting the Lowest Notes From Bach the Lesser
description: Forty years ago, when college-age classical music fans decided that Baroque was hot and began snapping up the works of long-forgotten composers as fast as musicologists could rediscover them, Peter Schickele saw a market niche that had eluded everyone else. For Mr. Schickele, a 30-year-old composer only five years out of Juilliard (and back there to teach), musicology and the business of discovering antique composers had comic possibilities.

title: Israel calls northern Gaza area no-go zone
After 500 Years, Can Spain End Cigarette Binge?
description: MADRID, Dec. 28 - Spaniards often seem to live at the corner bar, stopping in before work, during work, and later as they head home. They go to bars to thumb through the newspapers, to gossip and to meet friends for cards. Just as surely as they will reach for a tapa to go with their brandy or Rioja wine, they will reach for a cigarette.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Satellite to Test Navigation System
description: The European Union launched the first test satellite in a multibillion-euro program, named Galileo, aimed at reducing Europe's reliance on American navigation technology. The satellite, Giove A, was launched on a Soyuz rocket from a site in Kazakhstan. The European Space Agency, based in Paris, plans eventually to send 30 satellites into orbit to run the system, which could begin commercial operations as soon as 2008.

title: Report Finds Far-Flung Use Of 9/11 Loans
description: ALBANY, Dec. 28 - The Small Business Administration allowed special post-9/11 loans to go to Dunkin' Donuts and Subway franchises and thousands of other businesses nationwide without ensuring that they had been financially hurt by the attacks, according to a report released Wednesday by the agency's inspector general.

A Concerto That Will Live as Long as There Are Bassoonists
description: Don't assume that composers write concertos for posterity. More often than not, such pieces arise out of the pleas, requests or demands of someone specific. That some concertos outlive the people who commission them sometimes has to do with a superseding musical quality, but a lot depends on what instrument is being written for.

title: New Kamali, With a Nod To the Past
description: "ANARCHY to Affluence," an exhibition opening at Parsons the New School for Design next month, delves into the work of a small band of designers whose work in the mid-1970's, though rooted in rebelliousness and inspired by the underground, became some of the most influential and lasting fashion of the last century. An example of the exhibition's prescience is that one of its central characters, the designer Norma Kamali, happens to be in the midst of a professional revival. She will introduce two collections next month that recall the signatures of her past, with prices to match.

title: Calendar
description: American Gardens New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx; (718) 817-8747.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brentwood: Video Clerk's Death Investigated
description: The Suffolk County police are investigating the death of a clerk they said was killed inside a Brentwood video store. The man, William Kern, 55, was found dead yesterday by the owner of Pine Hollow Video, at 249 Second Avenue, shortly after 10 a.m., the police said. The cause of death was not disclosed. Police investigators were still at the store last night. There were no arrests yesterday, the police said, and no known motive in the killing.

title: A Combined Hub and Hard Drive to Make the Mini a Bit Less Mini
description: The Mac Mini's compact size makes it ideal for those with simple computing needs. But the urge for more storage and more connected devices always arises. One solution is to add an external hard drive for more capacity and an external hub for more devices. Iomega's MiniMax hard drive combines the two in a design that matches the Mini's style.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Roadside Bomb Kills G.I.
description: An American serviceman and an Afghan soldier were killed in a roadside explosion in the unstable eastern province of Kunar, the United States military said in a statement. Two other American servicemen were wounded in the explosion near the provincial capital, Asadabad, during a combat patrol. Another American soldier died in a road accident in southern Afghanistan.

title: Beer by the Barrel, Stories by the Scoop

Collage inspired her architect, Kevin Daly, of Daly, Genik in Santa Monica, Calif., to envision her studio as a series of three silvery corrugated steel boxes.

title: A Lamp That Shimmers In Blue and Gold
description: Axel Schmid, an industrial designer who works with Ingo Maurer, the German lighting designer, has introduced 24 Karat Bleue, a shimmering lamp made of thin layers of hammered gold encased in acrylic panels. Measuring 13 by 13 inches, the lamp casts a hazy blue light; hence, its name.

title: A Dress-Up Doll for Retro Girls (Scram, Barbie)
description: I WASN'T surprised to read last week that Barbie dolls are often mutilated by young girls. According to a new study undertaken at the University of Bath, in England, Barbie torture is considered legitimate play activity. Barbie is so pretty, so thin, so perfect. It's no wonder that among the children in the study Barbie provoked intense responses of "rejection, hatred and violence," as the researchers reported.

title: Rangers Find Scoring Touch Against Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Dec. 28 - Islanders Coach Steve Stirling would later compare the Rangers' top line to a firecracker, but the pyrotechnics started with an earlier request by Rangers Coach Tom Renney. He asked his team just to play hard and smart.

title: Snowboarder Style Grows Up to Be Cool
description: IF the fusty old Winter Olympics want to get everyone's mind off those ugly figure-skating scandals, the organizers should raise the stakes. Here's an idea: Team A, the downhill skiers, schuss down the mountain lickety-split while avoiding Team B, the snowboarders, doing compulsory figures on the slope's half-pipes. The team with the most men left standing gets the gold; losers get a blog to carp about how totally unfair it all was.

description: Millions of people watched the 2006 World Cup draw earlier this month, and saw the introduction of the official ball for the soccer tournament, which starts June 9 in Munich. With 14 panels of resilient foam that are glued, rather than sewn together, the design, + Teamgeist, from Adidas, is a departure from the industry standard, 32 hexagrams and pentagrams.

description: AMY SEMINSKI hates gyms. "Every time I've been, it felt very crowded, and I felt uncomfortable with so many people around," she said. "I didn't like sharing machines or waiting for equipment."

title: A Rap Tale of 2 Cities and 2 Stars
description: This was a great year for Houston rappers. (Probably the best ever.) And it was a terrible year for New York rappers not named 50 Cent. (The worst, perhaps, since the early 1990's.) Southern beats and rhymes boomed out of cars on 125th Street; the vendors on Canal Street hawked CD's from that faraway place they called "Downsouth." While a bunch of Houstonians (and other drawlers) stormed the charts, New York seemed like a fading empire.

title: Donald Dawson, 97, Dies; Master of Truman Whistle-Stop
description: Donald S. Dawson, who as a presidential aide marshaled Harry S. Truman's crucial whistle-stop tour in the 1948 election campaign and who later had a long career as a Washington lawyer, died on Sunday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 97.
