title: A Pact New York Can Ride On
description: If the measure of a fair labor contract is stereo sounds of griping, things worked out reasonably for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its unionized employees. Still, it should not be lost on the 33,700 workers who walked off the job, breaking New York State law in the process, that they wound up with a contract not terribly different than what was on the table before the walkout. This was a strike that never needed to happen, and we hope that message reverberates in the future.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, ARTHUR F.
description: BERNSTEIN--Arthur F. Died on December 27, 2005. Born in Brooklyn, New York June 18, 1933. Arthur was president of Quantum Sportswear, a manufacturer of golf and tennis, and a division of Milady Bra and Corset Co. Inc. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Velma, his sons David and Steven; daughters-inlaw Kimberly and Vicky; grandchildren Cole, Paula, Daniel and Jessica. His brother, Shelley and wife Kathy and all his adoring nieces and nephews--Marc and family, Susan, Eric, Sue and family, and Leslie and John. All who knew Artie couldn't help but love him for his great warmth, compassion and his gregarious personality. We will all miss him terribly, but find solace in knowing that he is finally at peace. The Bernstein Family

title: Enron Figure May Testify,but What Will He Say?
description: At a top-level Enron management meeting in September 2001, a red-faced Richard A. Causey, the chief accounting officer, pounded the table after hearing his colleagues label the company's accounting practices as "aggressive." According to executives in the room, Mr. Causey fumed that he considered such criticism a personal affront, adding that he would stake his career on the propriety of Enron's accounting.

title: Polls: Real Estate Is Going Up
description: Americans are still bullish about real estate, just not quite so bullish as they were at the beginning of 2005. In a recent New York Times/CBS poll, 37 percent of them said that house prices in their area would go up a lot in the next five years, and 34 percent said they would go up a little. A whopping 69 percent called real estate a safer investment than stocks.

title: Housing Markets and Minorities
description: Minority homebuyers will be increasingly important to the housing market over the next decade, Realty Times columnist Blanche Evans writes. According to the National Association of Realtors, members of minority groups already make up 30 percent of first-time homebuyers, and this number is expected to increase to 50 percent by the year 2010, when nearly one-third of the countrys households will be headed by minorities.

title: A Whale of a Plane
description: Joe Sharkey reports on "a whale of a plane," the Airbus A380.

title: Should We Be Practically Perfect?
description: Many of us sit down at some point before the New Year and work out what our resolutions are to be. I say that many of us do this because there are some who do not. These are people who forget to do so, or who cannot face the prospect of the self-evaluation that the process involves, or who believe, like Mary Poppins, that they are practically perfect in every way. Then there is a further group  possibly a large one  of those who do not have to think very much about their New Years resolution because they are the same every year. These are the smokers who intend to stop smoking, the failed dieters who plan to start dieting once more, and those who have some other, unnamed flaw which they have tried many times to deal with, but failed. All of these have our sympathy and understanding. It is not easy being human. In fact, at times it is quite hard.

title: New Sounds and New Approaches
description: Some music -- all right, most music -- wears its structure explicitly, and sometimes even its purpose: trackable melodic arcs, systems of related chords, establishing a home base and then returning to it, call-and-response, division into sections, beats to dance to, long tones to meditate to.

description: COLORADO SPRINGS - At 11 a.m. on a recent Sunday, Emily Hoogenboom, 14, was at church, her second that morning.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Total Power Cut
description: All of Zambia was blacked out Wednesday evening after heavy rains and lightning compounded by an earlier landslide crippled the nation's power-generating grid. Wile scattered locations recovered power, much of the nation remained blacked out yesterday. Zambia's biggest hydroelectric station was forced to close last week after a huge landslide destroyed some generators. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

title: Suicide bomber hits West Bank crossing

description: The once-thriving business for Web sites that offer child pornography generated by Web cameras has suffered a significant setback.

title: Hilton sets the stage for global expansion
The Listings: Dec. 30 - Jan. 5; SANDRA BERNHARD
description: These days, you might catch Sandra Bernhard in a cameo role in a forgettable film, on the couch of a late-night talk show, or on the Showtime series "The L Word" in a self-spoofing turn as an intimidating writing teacher. But anyone who has seen her perform live -- not so long ago this was a requirement for a New Yorker aspiring for downtown cool -- knows that she really belongs in a dark nightclub like Joe's Pub, which is where you will find her on New Year's Eve. Her versatile, intimate brand of entertainment is not unlike an act that you might have seen in the glory days of Las Vegas. She wistfully belts out a few songs, tells some cutting jokes about Hollywood and the fashion world and gossips about famous people as if they were your close, personal friends. In the right role, Ms. Bernhard, a mother who still looks sexy in a see-through dress (she is better preserved than Dick Clark), can be a decent actress, but she always seems most comfortable playing herself -- or at least the acid and soulful persona that passes for herself in her solo shows. (Tomorrow night at 7:30, $100; 10:30, $150; Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778. Note: Ms. Bernhard will relinquish the microphone to John Cameron Mitchell, the host of a dance party beginning at 1 a.m.; $25 in advance; $30 at the door.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Iceland: Airline Opts for Boeing Freight Planes
description: The Boeing Company has won an order from Avion Group of Iceland for four 777 freighter aircraft valued at about $1 billion. The planes, which will be operated by the Air Atlanta Icelandic aircraft-leasing unit, are in addition to the four 777 freighters ordered by the group Sept. 22. The first jet will be delivered in February 2009 and the other seven in 2010 and 2011, Avion said in a statement.

Cherished grandmother of Adam, Natasha, Audrey, Kyra, Nathan and Nicholas. Devoted sister of Michael and devoted sister-inlaw of Barbara. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral service Friday December 30, 11:30A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Three Kings Day: Wrapping Up the Christmas Season With a Parade
description: JUST about the time most suburban curbsides are filling up with dead evergreens destined for composting, some Christmas celebrations have an exuberant encore. On Jan. 6, much of the world renews the festivities with Three Kings Day. Increasingly, communities in this country are joining in -- enough of them so that Hallmark introduced Spanish-language Three Kings Day cards in the United States in 1998.

title: Art in Review; Tamy Ben-Tor
description: Exploration in the Domain of Idiocy Zach Feuer 530 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through Jan. 14

title: Queens Woman Killed by Stray Bullet Through Her Window
description: It is not clear what prompted Selina Akther to move toward a window of her fifth-floor apartment in Queens, the police said. Her two children were sleeping and her husband was on a phone call to Bangladesh in another room, so they did not see the stray bullet that crashed through the closed window and hit her in her right eye, leaving her an unintended homicide victim.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Industrial Production Increases
description: South Korea's industrial production rose 5 percent in November, its fastest pace in six years, as car companies and chip makers expanded to meet record export orders and rebounding demand. South Korea joins Japan in reporting record manufacturing as demand rises at home and in overseas markets like the United States and China.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "They gravitate to where they feel a connection. They're more pragmatic than their parents' generation. They look at what works for them."

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Call For Inquiry Into Torture Claim
description: A British opposition politician, Sir Menzies Campbell, called for an inquiry into allegations that British intelligence officers participated in the interrogation of Pakistani terrorism suspects said to have been abducted and tortured in Greece after the bombings in London last July. Jack Straw, the British foreign secretary, has called the accusations "complete nonsense," but some opposition politicians have drawn oblique parallels between the Greek allegations and the debate across Europe over the so-called extraordinary rendition of terrorism suspects by American agencies to third countries where torture is practiced. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

title: Egyptian Police Kill at Least 23 Unarmed Sudanese Migrants

He will be remembered for his warm and infinite devotion to his patients and friends.

The golf courses were new to him, and so were some of the cities, and most of the other touring professionals were strangers. He was a 20-year-old multimillionaire, a golfing savant with an out-of-this-world swing. He had his goals and his golf clubs and, according to Woods, little else.

There were no arrests yesterday, the police said, and there was no known motive.

Born 1934 to Elizabeth Bliss and John Parkinson, Jr. Survived by: his wife, Charlotte; children, John Parkinson, Allston Parkinson (and Susan), and Elizabeth Parkinson-Wyner (and Josh); grandchildren, Jack and Miles Wyner and Schuyler & Ellen Parkinson; and sisters, Zaidee Parkinson and Mary Ann ParkinsonHache. Educated at Buckley and Groton Schools and Harvard University. Blue Water Sailor, U.S. Marine, Vice President of Citibank, ardent golfer and professional ski instructor at Okemo Mountain, Vermont. Past Chairman of the Buxton School and the Cultural Council Foundation. Board Member of Deepdale Golf Club, The Kitchen, and Treasurer for 27 years of the Museum of Modern Art. A Memorial service in February will be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53, NYC 10019; The Kitchen, 512 West 19, NYC 10011; and St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, 1000 10th Avenue, NYC 10019.

description: GULIELMETTI--Paul M. Lower Manhattan Loft Tenants mourns Paul M. Guielmetti. His legal skill, his cunning, his generosity, and most of all his appetite for the good fight over thirty years helped secure key rights for loft tenants. Paul was there at the start, always played hard, and won precedent-setting cases in every decade. Our condolences to his family, friends and clients past and present. We will all miss him. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAMERON, KATHARINE TORREY
description: CAMERON--Katharine Torrey. Of East Hampton and New York, passed away on December 27 after a hardfought battle with ovarian cancer. Beloved wife to the late William Allan Cameron, her life was defined by her devotion to family and friends, and by her many active interests. A long-time accredited judge for the American Daffodil Society, she also served as past President of the East Hampton Garden Club, and was a Board member of The Nature Conservancy South Fork Chapter. She was a guest curator and lecturer at East Hampton's Guild Hall for exhibitions on the area's nineteenth century artists. She also served on the Board of Managers of the East Hampton Library. Graduating from The Brearley School, she earned a B.A. from Fordham University, and a Master's in History from New York University. Mrs. Cameron was predeceased by her son Thomas Forkner. She is survived by her daughter Karen Wells, her son Stanley Forkner, her grandchildren Brad and Dana, by her stepchildren Anne Cunningham and Jean Cameron Smith, and their children Cameron, Tucker, Hunter and Caroline. She is also survived by her brothers John Torrey, Michael Torrey, and James Torrey, and sister Susan Coppock. Funeral services will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal in East Hampton on January 6, 2006 at 11:00 A.M. A springtime memorial service is planned at St. James in NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the East Hampton Library, 159 Main Street, East Hampton, New York, 11937.

title: Northeast Asia: Defusing a dangerous region
Indian Politics Roiled as Powerful Opposition Leader Departs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAFFE, MARCIA PARIS
description: JAFFE--Marcia Paris.76, of Norwalk, CT, died peacefully at home on December 24th. Mrs. Jaffe was born in Troy, NY, the daughter of Harry and Helen Paris. She graduated from Curry College in Boston and was an accomplished pianist and choral singer. As a charter member of the Fairfield County Choral, she served that organization as President, presenting them in Carnegie Hall on several occasions. She was President of the Mid Fairfield Child Guidance Center for many years and received a Citation from the State of Connecticut for her services to that organization. An active outdoorswoman and conservationist she spent her summers in the Adirondack Mountains where she enjoyed swimming, hiking and sailing. She is survived by her husband Chris, her children Irene, Chris Jr. and Nina, her daughter-in-law Karen, her brother Robert Paris, and her grandchildren, Mathew, Courtney and Kayla. Contributions may be made to the Whittingham Cancer Center Norwalk Hospital Maple St., Norwalk, CT 06856. A memorial service will take place on Saturday, January 14, 2006, at 11 A.M. in the Unitarian Church of Westport, 10 Lions Planes Road, Westport, CT.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Education Ruling
description: In what is thought to be the longest trial in South Carolina history, a circuit judge ruled that lawmakers had violated the state's constitutional guarantee of a "minimally adequate education" by underfinancing early childhood education programs in poor rural school districts. The ruling by Judge Thomas W. Cooper Jr. came in the case of Abbeville County School District et al. v. The State of South Carolina, which was filed more than 12 years ago and is considered a bellwether for other states that have taken similar tacks to increase school financing. According to the Access network, a nonprofit organization that tracks school financing issues, lawsuits challenging state methods of financing public schools have been filed in 45 states. Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina said in a statement that his office was still reviewing the decision. BRENDA GOODMAN (NYT)

description: Alternate-Side Parking Rules in 2006 Following are the days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended this year in New York City. Boldface indicates major legal holidays, on which stopping, standing and parking rules are suspended, except where they are normally in effect seven days a week. Drivers should follow posted signs carefully to avoid tickets.

title: With the First Pick, the Saints Select . . .
description: If the Houston Texans beat the San Francisco 49ers this weekend, five teams could finish the N.F.L. season tied for the worst record at 3-13. If this were to occur, the battle for the first draft pick would be decided by measuring each team's strength of schedule -- the winning percentage of its opponents. The team with the weakest schedule would get the first pick, the second weakest the next pick and so on. Because every game this weekend factors into this formula, there are tens of thousands of possible combinations. Nevertheless, a statistical analysis shows that if five teams do end up at 3-13, the New Orleans Saints would win the tiebreaker and draft No. 1.

title: New York Set to Close Jail Unit for Gays
description: For at least three decades, gay and transgender inmates had their own housing unit inside Rikers Island's sprawling jail complex. To be admitted, all a new inmate had to do was declare homosexuality, or appear to be transgender, and ask to be kept out of Rikers's main jails.

title: Iraqis' Claim of Attack From Lebanon Leaves Confusion
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 29 - An Internet posting on Thursday said the militant group that calls itself Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia had claimed responsibility for firing rockets from southern Lebanon into Israel. The claim was widely dismissed as lacking credibility but served to aggravate tensions here further.

title: Drier, Tainted Nevada May Be Legacy of Gold Rush
description: ELKO, Nev. - Just outside the chasm of North America's biggest open-pit gold mine there is an immense oasis in the middle of the Nevada desert. It is an idyllic and isolated spot where migratory birds often alight for a stopover. But hardly anything is natural about it.

title: Monuments Unrestrained by Laws of Physics or Finance
description: Imagine a major new monument for the United States of America. That was the assignment given by the curator Ralph Rugoff to more than 50 international artists. All their proposals are now on view in a lively, often amusing, sometimes thought-provoking but less than profound exhibition called "Monuments for the U.S.A." at White Columns, the nonprofit gallery in the West Village. It was organized by Mr. Rugoff for the C.C.A. Wattis Institute for Contemporary Arts, a gallery and study center in San Francisco that he directs.

36 Hours in Mexico City
description: WHEN the Spaniards arrived in the Valley of Mexico in the 16th century, they found the sprawling Aztec city of Tenochtitln, destroyed it and built a new one on top of it. But they never really succeeded in burying the past. Mexico City became the largest city in the Western Hemisphere, a nexus of Latin American art and political thought. Today, after difficult adjustments to globalization and the precipitous devaluation of the peso from around 3 to the dollar to nearly 11 over 12 years - often cited as a cause for a spike in crimes like kidnapping and robbery - the city remains a teeming, vibrant and joyful place. Even the skies are blue again because of new laws that restrict auto use. Despite all the layers time has imposed, from the colonial past to the present day of "nuevo cine Mexicano" and "techno-rave en Espaol," even a weekend visitor will still feel the spirit of the old Aztec capital ever present alongside the new.

title: Asian Rebels With Cars but Not Much of a Cause
description: In "Initial D," impossibly handsome Asian boys borrow James Dean's pout and wardrobe to race cars down Mount Akina in Japan. Each boy aspires (we are informed loudly and often) to be "the racing god of Mount Akina," but the film itself is more interested in proving what teenage boys have always known: that cars are much more governable than girls.

The Listings: Dec. 30 - Jan. 5; PRESERVATION HALL JAZZ BAND/DR. MICHAEL WHITE'S ORIGINAL LIBERTY JAZZ BAND
description: When the clock strikes 12 tomorrow night, it will mean the end of a year that most New Orleans natives would rather forget. But forgetting isn't common practice in that city, especially where culture is concerned; many of its best and brightest were haunted by history well before Hurricane Katrina raised the stakes. In the early 1960's, one such individual, the tuba-playing jazz advocate Allan Jaffe, formed the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, an ensemble trafficking in New Orleans jazz and stocked with veteran musicians. Now under the stewardship of the trumpeter John Brunious, a lifelong member, and the bassist Ben Jaffe, who upholds his father's mission, the band has been touring almost incessantly since being displaced. This week's Jazz Standard engagement culminates in a New Year's Eve package, complete with barbecue dinner and Champagne toast. Across town, Champagne and New Orleans polyphony will also pour forth at the Village Vanguard, where the Original Liberty Jazz Band has played more than a dozen New Year's Eve engagements over the years. This year's installment will be more poignant than most, of course: although the musicians all survived Katrina, the band's clarinetist and leader, Dr. Michael White, a prominent historian and scholar of New Orleans culture at Xavier University of Louisiana, suffered the incalculable loss of his collection of antique instruments, documents and rare recordings. A tinge of defiance will accompany the jubilation of the music, which serves not only to usher in a new year but also to highlight the process of renewal that jazz, at its best, is all about. (The Preservation Hall Jazz Band plays tonight at 8, 10 and 11:45, and tomorrow at 7:30 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232; cover, $35; $125 to $175 tomorrow, including a three-course dinner. Dr. Michael White's Original Liberty Jazz Band of New Orleans plays tonight and Sunday night at 9 and 11, and tomorrow at 9:30 and 11:30 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037; $35; $125 tomorrow, including a $25 drink minimum.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Dies In Shooting
description: An 18-year-old Bronx man was fatally shot about 5 p.m. yesterday at the Melrose Houses in the South Bronx, the police said. The man, Carlos Arauz, of East 156th Street, was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, where he was pronounced dead upon arrival. Two men wearing red bandannas were seen fleeing the shooting. No arrests had been made last night.

title: The Listings: Dec. 30 - Jan. 5; THE MURRAY HILL SHOW
description: All dressed up and nowhere to go for New Year's Eve? Have no fear: the irrepressible downtown fixture Murray Hill will be the host of two of his over-the-top variety shows at Mo Pitkin's tomorrow night; there's no rest for the weary, particularly when you bill yourself as "the hardest-working middle-aged man in show business." Both shows are certain to include plenty of off-color remarks, audience harassment and participation, low-tech props and improper song and dance routines performed by a variety of special guests hailing from the burlesque and downtown scene, including Miss Saturn, Carmine Covelli, People Lution and some surprises. As always, the shows feature Lance Cruce on piano, and the Murrayettes, flatteringly described by Murray Hill as "aging showgirls." Bawdy and silly in a charmingly unpolished way, these dancers and singers perform broad physical comedy as well as choreographed numbers. Get there early for a good seat or reserve a table, but avoid the front row unless you are willing to bear the brunt of Murray Hill's leers and merciless one-liners. Those wishing to make a night of it can sign up for a special four-course meal before the shows. They don't call it the House of Satisfaction for nothing. (9 p.m., $35, includes a Champagne toast and gift bag; 11 p.m., $75, includes a three-hour open bar beginning at 10 p.m., comfort food, a gift bag and midnight Champagne toast, with Murray Hill as a rather sudsed Baby New Year; Mo Pitkin's, 34 Avenue A, between Second and Third Streets, East Village, (212) 777-5660, ext. 38.)

But that facade conceals a chamber of vivid horrors -- or unrivaled delights, depending on one's tolerance for the human condition laid bare.

Moving at high speed, she proves capable of unusual stretches and balances, twisting herself into one shape after another. She can also make her dancing seem to explode like fireworks, as she does when she performs the Gypsy-inspired fourth movement of Balanchine's "Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet."

Cherished grandmother of Erik, Christopher and Julia. She lived her life with grace and style and always did it her way. Elaine will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, HELEN FARR
description: SLOAN -- Helen Farr. 1911-2005, died peacefully at the age of 94 on December 13th in Wilmington, DE. Born February 24th in New York City to the late Dr. Charles Farr and Helen Woodhull Farr, Helen enrolled at the age of 16 in the New York Art Students League where she first met and studied with John Sloan (1871-1951) who became her lifelong friend, mentor and finally, in 1944, her husband. Helen Farr Sloan was known as an inspired educator, an accomplished artist, a patron of the arts, and over the past 50 years she quietly created a most remarkable profile as an American philanthropist. Helen Farr Sloan is survived by her nephew, Dr. Charles Farr, of Fresno, CA, and his three children, Michael, Kevin, and Caroline. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Wednesday, January 4, 2006 at 11:00 A.M. at St. Ann's Catholic Church on Union Street in Wilmington, DE. Rev. Joseph R. McMahon, a close friend of Helen's will be the celebrant. Immediately following the Mass, a reception will be held at the Delaware Art Museum located at 2301 Kentmere Parkway, Wilmington, DE. A memory book will be available at the reception for guests to share their reflections of Helen. Donations in Helen's memory may be made to the Delaware Art Museum's Helen Farr Sloan Memorial Fund. For information: Doherty Funeral Home 302-652-6811.

To the organization's shock, it soon had so many hits that the Web site kept crashing, and it has become the most unlikely of cult sensations.

title: When Cubism Fractured Art's Delicate World

It turned the classical Poussin nude into a column of open razors. It transformed the Ingres portrait, that last stand of ancien rgime realism, into a stack of clattering planes in empty space.

Here his acrobatic control, his humor and his ability to win sympathy in the most ridiculous of situations endeared him to all.

title: Corrections
description: An article on quantum trickery in Science Times on Tuesday mischaracterized the results of work by John S. Bell, a physicist, in 1964. Dr. Bell showed that no deeper theory that contained the presumption of locality (namely that distant particles cannot affect each other instantaneously) could duplicate the strange predictions of quantum mechanics. He did not rule out other deeper theories.

title: Corrections

Causey, the former Enron chief accounting officer who agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in their case against two other former top executives of Enron, misstated the date of a meeting with one of the executives, Kenneth L. Lay, that is the basis of one of the charges against Mr. Lay. It was on Oct. 12, 2001, not Oct. 21.

title: Not Much Remains for Texans in Path of Fire
description: CROSS PLAINS, Tex., Dec. 29 - Standing in the ashes of the home they had shared as newlyweds for five months, Johnny and ReNetha Bellew looked in vain Thursday for traces of the Christmas presents they had just exchanged -- a new suit, a Texas Aggie T-shirt, Nike sneakers and ceramic collectibles. Nothing was left.

title: Arts, Briefly; Crime Enlivens the Doldrums
description: Original episodes of "Lost," "CSI" and "Desperate Housewives" will soon grace the airwaves, along with the return of "American Idol" and "24" and numerous midseason premieres. But for now, viewers are stuck with an endless parade of repeats. Wednesday's prime-time network schedule had exactly one original show, and that was Pamela Anderson's "Stacked" (with an estimated four million viewers) on Fox. Amid those doldrums, the shows that excel in repeats, criminal procedurals, were the only programs that did any business. And since CBS broadcast two popular ones, "Criminal Minds" (10.98 million) and "CSI: New York" (11.26 million), it won the night in both total viewers and adults 18 to 49 in Nielsen's estimates. As expected, USA Network was the No. 1 entertainment channel on advertiser-supported cable in the fourth quarter of the year. It overtook TNT among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds for the first time in five years. ESPN was the top-ranked cable channel over all, based largely on the strength of "Sunday Night Football," which was the most-watched series on cable in 2005.

Preserving the National Parks
description: It has been more than two months since the Interior Department released its final draft of revisions to the document that governs the management of the national park system. We are now in that quiet time called the public comment period, which has been extended until the middle of February.

title: At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye; Miranda Weese
description: My favorite City Ballet seasons begin and end with Miranda Weese, whose inherent elegance is allayed by a mischievous, arch wit. Equipped with a startlingly sound technique -- the sort that epitomizes the expression "turn on a dime" -- Ms. Weese gives performances anchored by a razor-sharp musicality and a refreshing absence of self-conscious posturing. This season, she reprises Odette/Odile in "Swan Lake" (her mystical, creature-like Odette is enthralling) and will also appear in Balanchine's "Allegro Brillante," Mr. Martins's "Fearful Symmetries" and Mr. Wheeldon's new ballet, which will have its premiere on Jan. 24. (She was breathtaking in Mr. Wheeldon's "Shambards.")

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, SHIRLEY (NEE BUCHSBAUM)
description: MILLER--Shirley (nee Buchsbaum). Beloved mother of Bruce and Barbara, cherished mother-in-law of Etta Miller and James Alleman, died peacefully in Boulder, Colorado early on December 27, 2005. Devoted wife of Harold C. Miller deceased in 1979. Loving grandmother to Ira and Bo, she is deeply mourned by step-grandson Adam Alleman and his family. Born 87 years ago in New York, she graduated from New College of Teachers College, Columbia University, and resided for nearly all her life in the city she loved. She dedicated her life with energy and devotion to her family and friends; to an inspired teaching career in the New York City public school system; and to the shared beauty of art, music, learning and travel. Her courage, graciousness, and spirit will be much missed by her loved ones including siblings Gertrude Ostrove, Betty Weinstein, David Buchsbaum and their families. Contributions in her name may be sent to Hadassah or the American Diabetes Association. Memorial service will take place at the Riverside Chapel on Friday, December 30, 2005 at 9:30 AM.

title: Fuel Crisis Deepens in Iraq With Lines Forming at Pumps
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 30 - A fuel crisis in Iraq deepened today as the oil minister was suspended for objecting to steep government-imposed price increases in gasoline and cooking fuel.

title: Other Views: DailyStar, Kathimerini, The Age
At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye; Adam Hendrickson
description: As an actor-dancer, Adam Hendrickson is just about invincible: understated, enigmatic and full of eccentricity. From his jet-black eyebrows, which lend his handsome face a range of devilish expressions, to his dignified, graceful line, Mr. Hendrickson is unparalleled in City Ballet's canon of character parts, including Herr Drosselmeier in "The Nutcracker," Puck in "A Midsummer Night's Dream," Dr. Coppelius in "Copplia" and the Jester in "Swan Lake," which he will reprise this season. He enriches each role with exacting nuance, and the effects never appear premeditated; the details are so ingrained that you see the character instead of the dancer.

title: New York City's Big Donors Find New Cause: Public Schools
description: A flair for high-society smooching has not always been an essential skill in running New York City's public schools. But there was Joel I. Klein, the schools chancellor, at Michael Jordan's Steakhouse, grinning awkwardly as he blew a kiss across the room to Elizabeth Rohatyn, the philanthropist and wife of the former ambassador to France.

title: The Listings: Dec. 30 - Jan. 5; JAMES BROWN
description: If anybody is looking forward to 2006, it's James Brown, who will be performing at B. B. King's on New Year's Eve. The Godfather of Soul spent the first part of 2005 recovering from prostate surgery and fielding lingering questions about his much publicized 2004 marital strife and domestic abuse problems. It was reality TV fodder all the way. Now, this hard-living 73-year-old reportedly has in the works both a "Ray"-like biopic and a documentary (produced by his wife, Tomi Rae) called "Life on the Road With Mr. and Mrs. Brown." If his legendary stage show has lost some of its kinetic kick -- those legs don't shuffle and split as they used to -- Mr. Brown's huff and growl are as percussive as ever. His band still freezes and blares at the slightest signal from its leader, and he still falls to his knees as the spirit dictates. Shows in recent years have included overenthusiastic dancers, as well as a drooping sequence in which Mrs. Brown wails a few Janis Joplinesque numbers. The rhinestone-bedecked main attraction may stick stubbornly to his biggest hits, but who can argue with a searing rendition of "It's a Man's World," a buoyant "I Feel Good" or a stripped-down "Sex Machine"? The pleading showstopper "Please, Please, Please" seems to be a live rarity now, but maybe the mood will strike. For his part, Mr. Brown knows that among other achievements, he continues to be the most sampled man in the rap biz. To trade on his legacy, all he needs to do is to keep making it funky and, of course, stay on the scene. (Tomorrow night at 8, standing room, $85; table seating, $150; 10:30 p.m., standing room, $95; table seating, $175; B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144.)

description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 30 - They celebrated his service, his smile and his speed. But mourners at the funeral held today for Officer Shawn Carson of the Jersey City Police Department struggled to come to grips with the way he died.

title: The Spa Experience: Mud Bath, Massage, M.R.I.
description: ON his first visit to Canyon Ranch in Tucson in the 1980's, Steve Akin went for a walk each morning among the giant saguaro cactuses in the quiet desert canyons surrounding the spa. In the afternoon, he had a massage, took a dip in the pool or explored his spiritual side in a meditative yoga class.

title: At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye; Nikolaj Hbbe
description: Nikolaj Hbbe is blessed with great powers of concentration. He can command attention at any moment and attract all eyes to him. There are times when such focus almost makes him glow onstage, one reason he has been able in past seasons to offer a distinctive portrayal of the young god in Balanchine's "Apollo": he radiates nobility.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Arrest In Deadly Taxi Crash
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested on a murder charge in connection with a car crash on Tuesday that killed a cabdriver in South Ozone Park, the police said yesterday. The police say they believe the man, Freddy Ramlochan, 27, was driving the 2000 Chevrolet Astro minivan that sped through a red light on Rockaway Boulevard and struck the side of a Ford Crown Victoria cab, which burst into flames. The cabdriver, Gurbaj Singh, 40, died from the impact, the medical examiner's office said yesterday. Mr. Ramlochan, who has also been charged with driving under the influence of alcohol, told the police that the minivan was stolen from him before the accident.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Online Retailers' Holiday Sales Surge As Wal-Mart and Target Take to the Web Online retailers, whose growth was expected to slow after a decade of dizzying gains, experienced a stellar holiday season, according to two early reports, as traditional stores like Wal-Mart and Target cemented their place on the Web. Consumer spending online reached $18.1 billion in November and December, a 25 percent increase over 2004, according to a report. [Page A1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLINSKY, DR. GLORIA F.
description: WOLINSKY--Dr. Gloria F. Died peacefully at home in New York City, surrounded by her family on December 15, 2005. Dr. Wolinsky was a Professor Emeritus at Hunter College of the City of New York and a former Chairperson of the Education Foundation. Beloved wife of the late Marvin Wolinsky, loving mother of Dr. Philip Wolinsky, devoted sister of Grace Weiner, also aunt and great aunt. She gave generously to her family, charity and friends throughout her life. Her strength of character and strength during her struggle with her illness were inspirational. This extraordinary woman who was always caring and charitable will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Snow Isn't the Only Game in Town Anymore

In the local news, politics and development issues mix with notices of avalanche threats and lost pets and previews of movies in the Park City Film Series.

title: People: Van Morrison, Michelle Yeoh, Tony Parker
At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye; Ashley Bouder
description: Ashley Bouder is one of the most exciting dance artists to come along in recent years. Her repertory for the winter season is likely to include five classics by George Balanchine -- "Symphony in C" (third movement), "Ballo della Regina," "Firebird," "Divertimento No. 15" and "Union Jack" -- and the company director Peter Martins's "Octet." But "Firebird" is hers in a special way. She claimed the title role when she stepped into it on the ballet equivalent of a moment's notice in 2001 as a 17-year-old corps dancer. She was astonishing, and continues to be. She can probably dance just about any technical trick in the book, but her daring, her dazzling clarity and her musical phrasing shine through. And the Firebird is likely to be a role when the fleeting old-time glamour Ms. Bouder has been acquiring of late, reminiscent of ballerinas of the 1940's, can best be enjoyed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEENE, CONSTANCE
description: KEENE - Constance. The House of Steinway & Sons deeply mourns the passing of the eminent American pianist Constance Keene, in New York City on December 24, 2005 at the age of 84. Constance Keene was a treasured member of our family of Steinway Artists for fiftytwo years. Early in her career she was proclaimed an exceptional interpreter of Rachmaninoff, and with her success in the Naumburg Competition of 1943 her career was launched. She appeared in recital, in duo recital with Abram Chasins, to whom she was married from 1949 until his death in 1987, and with the leading orchestras of the day. Ms. Keene was a featured participant in Steinway & Sons' Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953. An acclaimed teacher at the Manhattan School of Music, Ms. Keene was also an indefatigable traveler, serving on juries of the major piano competitions and conducting master classes around the globe. Our fond memories of Constance will continue to enrich us, as will her recordings and the artistry of her celebrated pupils. We convey our love and heartfelt condolences to her husband Milton. We have lost a dear friend. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hamilton Township: Scrutiny For Washington Trip
description: The Hamilton Township school board has approved spending up to $2,276 to send six school officials to the Supreme Court confirmation hearing for Samuel A. Alito Jr., a graduate of the school district. Although she voted for the trip to the Senate hearing in Washington next month, one board member, Wendy Sturgeon told The Times of Trenton that the money could be put to better use. "I don't understand how it benefits the students," she said, noting that the hearing will be televised. The president of the school board, Joy E. Tozzi, who is among the officials scheduled to go, defended the trip. "This district should be on a high" to have a graduate nominated to the court, Ms. Tozzi told the newspaper. Judge Alito, who graduated from Steinert High School in 1968, was nominated by President Bush to fill the vacancy left by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who is retiring.

The law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell advised the other main shareholder, the Marsh & McLennan Companies. LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae advised Fidelity National.

title: At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye
description: IN his later years George Balanchine liked to stress choreography over those choreographed. It was the dance that was important, not the dancers. Of course, he still had his principals and his promising soloists and up-and-coming members of the corps de ballet; stardom, or at least the individuality of the dancers, could never be eradicated. Nor, deep down, did he wish it to be.

title: A College Sports Scam
description: The myth of salvation through college and professional sports is a blight on poor communities all over the country. Suckered into chasing a chimerical "ticket out of the ghetto," young people devote every waking moment to athletics while neglecting studies that would actually prepare them for reachable careers. Those who get to college at all often play their hearts out until they are no longer eligible and end up back on the streets -- without hope, prospects or even college degrees.

title: At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye; Damian Woetzel
description: Damian Woetzel is a daredevil, a virtuoso who knows how to make the most complex combinations of steps look like fun. His dancing is often big and bold. Yet he is also capable of small, intricate shifts of weight, easy turns and carefree bouncy movements. Appropriately enough in a ballet that evokes Gypsy revelry, he can fill the finale of Balanchine's "Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet" with fiery passion, for Mr. Woetzel is more than a technician. He has considerable dramatic gifts.

title: That Suffering Season

title: Internet Sales Show Big Gains Over Holidays
description: Online retailers, whose growth was expected to level off after a decade of dizzying gains, experienced a stellar holiday season, according to two preliminary reports released yesterday, as traditional stores like Wal-Mart and Target cemented their place on the Web.

title: National Briefings
description: WEST

title: Roundup: Australia charges toward victory
Philip Bowring: Defending Malaysia's diversity
A Career of Killing People, Until an Attack of Cold Feet
description: Pithy remarks put into the mouth of a star playing against type impart a greasy sheen of sophistication to "The Matador," a weightless, amoral romp about a professional hit man facing a midlife crisis. The star is Pierce Brosnan, and his character, ironically named Julian Noble, is a gold-chain-wearing sleazeball with a taste for under-age girls. An anti-James Bond, Julian is freighted with enough references to the superspy role Mr. Brosnan recently ceded to Daniel Craig that dudes who read Maxim will feel the glow of pseudo-hip kinship.

title: Scenes From a Marriage Under Playful Shavian Siege
description: A two-intermission play that clocks in at not much over two hours? The Jean Cocteau Repertory manages it with George Bernard Shaw's "Candida," and -- though perhaps this is the television-raised, frequent-commercial-interruption generation talking -- it feels great. Maybe we've lost something in the shift to one- or no-intermission plays: the chance to mill and mull while the story is still unfolding.

title: Surfers in Turmoil With the Loss of a Major Supplier
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. - The thefts began shortly after the day surfers call Blank Monday, when the surfing community from San Diego to Santa Cruz and beyond felt caught in the undertow of what Grubby Clark had done.

title: Speedskaters Making Tracks for Canada
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 29 - While Catherine Raney gleefully talked about her American record in the long-track speedskating national championships at the Utah Olympic Oval this week, she wore her conflicting loyalties on her sleeves -- literally. Adorning each arm of her warm-up suit was a Canadian maple leaf.

title: A Mission to Free the Innocent and Expose the Guilty
description: Strangely, the more doubt that DNA testing casts on the fairness of the American system of justice, the more criminal cases on television dramas become open-and-shut. The "Law & Order" shows all vibrate with moral certainty. The "CSI" series make a religion of forensic science.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Richard L. Grimsdale, a pioneer in transistorized computers, misstated when he joined Associated Electrical Industries. It was in 1960, not the 1970's.

title: Bangalore unnerved by shooting
In Melting Pot, It Takes Time to Bubble Up
description: BARRING some extraordinary event -- a devastating earthquake perhaps or an outbreak of pestilence or, even weirder, Tom Cruise's return to earth -- Michael R. Bloomberg will be sworn in on Sunday for a second term as mayor.

title: Reduced Sentences Recommended in Ferry Crash
description: A high-ranking federal probation official has recommended sharply reduced prison terms for two men who pleaded guilty in the Staten Island ferry crash in October 2003 -- three months for the assistant captain, Richard J. Smith, and six months for his supervisor, Patrick Ryan -- according to papers released yesterday.

title: At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye; Kyra Nichols
description: Kyra Nichols is 47, and she no longer dances very much. But when she does, it is worth walking through a transit strike or braving extreme temperatures to see whatever she is performing.

title: France Fielding Extra Police to Guard Against New Year's Unrest
description: PARIS, Dec. 30 - France is fielding thousands of extra police officers across the country over New Year's Eve to guard against a potential wave of car burning after the civil unrest that drew international attention last month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Teenager Attacked On Roof
description: A 16-year-old Bronx girl was sexually assaulted at knifepoint yesterday evening on the roof of her apartment building and then tied to a satellite dish, the police said. The girl was approached by a man in his late 20's about 5:30 p.m. as she was entering her apartment, on Aqueduct Avenue near Bronx Community College. After the attack, the man took her jewelry. The girl freed herself and was taken by her mother to North Central Bronx Hospital, where she was in stable condition last night. The man was described as Hispanic, with a medium build, and wearing a white baseball cap, light blue jeans and a light-colored jacket with a dark, hooded sweatshirt underneath. The police said he was seen on videotape.

title: Where the Art Grows on Trees (and Everywhere Else)
description: SOMETIMES museum curators installing art, to save their backs and sore feet, use wheelchairs. At the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, the vehicle of choice is a golf cart. Crisscrossing 250 acres is not exactly a walk in the park, if you know what I mean, especially as winter comes. The other day, Gregory Long, the voluble and charming president of the garden, rolled up to the Leon Levy Visitor Center in an electric go-cart with Kim Tripp, the garden's director, to take me on a spin around the grounds.

title: Inside Art
description: The Inside Art column will resume next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOEN, ARTHUR BOYER, JR.
description: SCHOEN--Arthur Boyer, Jr. Age 52, died at home on Christmas Eve after a valiant battle with cancer. Dear husband of Pam, loving father of Caroline and Artie, devoted son of Arthur and the late Luise Schoen, brother of Diana Shields and uncle of Tommy, Diana, Marina, Christiana and Olympia. A Memorial Service will be held at The Dune Church in Southampton on June 17 at 5 P.M. Contributions in Artie's memory may be made to The Southampton Association Inc. to benefit the Scholarship Fund. Address is P.O. Box 641, Southampton, NY 11969.

title: At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye; Maria Kowroski
description: Tall, willowy and graceful, Maria Kowroski may be the most elegant of the current crop of City Ballet principals. She is known for her adagio passages, those statuesque showcases for grace and control. But she is lovely in her running leaps and airy turns, too. Her sweeping, sinuous arms have always seemed particularly captivating. She is as close to the ideal of the classical ballerina as anyone in the company.

title: Canada's leader backs minister
WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (AMC) MOVIES THAT SHOOK THE WORLD: PINK FLAMINGOS "It was a pothead movie," says John Waters (above). "Still is." Mr. Waters's 1972 cult film stars the plus-size transvestite Divine (1945-88) as a redneck striving to establish herself and her family as the most disgusting people in the world. They certainly deserve the title. People who comment on the movie's impact include Mink Stole (who looks like a retired small-town librarian these days), Joe Dallesandro, Peaches Christ, Chi Chi Larue and Pia Zadora. Neither Divine's infamous eating scene nor the chicken sex scene is included in this special. And it's interesting to hear Mr. Waters talk about his childhood dreams of owning "a dirty movie theater" and to learn that in real life Divine's parents ran a nursery school.

title: The Neediest Cases; Afflicted, Yet Looking on the Bright Side
description: On the Sunday before Christmas, Amy Schultz sat on the bed in her apartment in Kingston, N.Y., and pulled a strawberry blond wig off her head.

title: A Lot of the Muscle Flexing in Baghdad Isn't Political
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - Iraq's strongman is back.

title: Hold the Champagne: Lebanon Is in No Mood to Party
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Dec. 29 - The roadblocks begin a few miles before Gen. Michel Aoun's house on a plush green hillside dotted with expansive villas. First, two soldiers and concrete barriers stop traffic. Then a maze of concrete blocks slows cars to a crawl. Then three more soldiers. Then a gate, and more guards, and a metal detector. Cellphones are placed in a cabinet and, finally, there he is, General Aoun, leader of the largest Christian bloc in Parliament.

title: The Crisis in the Black Community (10 Letters)
description: Correction Appended

title: After unsmiling centuries, Koreans need lessons to learn to laugh
General Retreats on Rumsfeld Rift
description: It was a rare moment last month when Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, publicly contradicted his boss, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. Yesterday, however, General Pace essentially said never mind.

title: Hailing the DVD Distributors: The Best Vault Raiders of 2005
description: There were 53,737 different DVD's available in the North American market as of Dec. 14, not counting imports and pornographic films, according to the Digital Entertainment Group, a trade association. That's a lot of titles -- far more than a mere human could possibly keep up with (though I sometimes think most of them are piled in my kitchen).

title: Seminoles Star Is Questioned in Rape Case and Is Suspended
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 29 - Florida State's leading tackler, the senior linebacker A. J. Nicholson, was suspended from the team Thursday after a 19-year-old woman accused him of raping her at the hotel where the Seminoles are staying for the Orange Bowl.

title: American and Austrian own slopes
Riding the Ski Train to Backcountry Alaska
description: ALASKA in winter is an intimidating prospect: one characterized by frigid temperatures, long nights and forbidding landscapes blanketed in snow and ice. At 7 a.m. on a dark winter day last February, when I found myself awake and aboard the Alaska Railroad's annual ski train to Grandview, the sun had yet to rise, and the train was filled with slumbering bodies.

title: Before Returning to Violin, Spotlight Falls on a Bassoon
description: Don't assume that composers write concertos for posterity. More often than not, such pieces arise out of the pleas, requests or demands of someone specific. That some concertos outlive the people who commission them sometimes has to do with a superseding musical quality, but a lot depends on what instrument is being written for.

title: At City Ballet, Some Especially Catch the Eye; Amar Ramasar
description: Gifted dancers tend to grow up in public. That is true of Amar Ramasar, who has taken on a surprising range of roles for a corps dancer. He is never less than fully engaged in performance, and his joy in dancing is infectious, though it sometimes takes him over the top of his assignment. Mr. Ramasar is scheduled to perform featured parts this season in ballets including Robbins's "Fancy Free," "Fanfare" and "Concertino."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Phase Of Adirondack Land Deal Is Complete
description: The first phase of a deal preserving more than a quarter-million acres in the heart of the Adirondack Mountains is complete, state officials announced yesterday. The state's Department of Environmental Conservation will pay the property's owner, International Paper, about $5.5 million in exchange for public access rights for more than 41,500 acres in Hamilton and Franklin Counties. Under the agreement, International Paper will retain the right to harvest wood, with some limitations. The announcement closes the first of three agreements in the largest land protection deal in state history. Gov. George E. Pataki first announced the plan in April 2004. The terms of the two remaining phases are expected to be completed in 2006.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRAVIS, OLIVIA BREWSTER (NEE TAYLOR)
description: TRAVIS -- Olivia Brewster (nee Taylor), 89. Of Laurel Hollow, NY. After a recent fall; December 27. Beloved wife of Martin Bice Travis, mother of Elizabeth Nichols Mugharbil, of Beirut, Lebanon, and Helen Willard Travis, of Woodside, Queens, NY. A memorial service will be held at Old First Presbyterian Church of Huntington, New York, 2 PM, Sunday, January 1, 2006. Donations welcome, Old First Church, 125 Main Street, Huntington, NY 11743.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, BEATRICE
description: EPSTEIN--Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Phyllis, Janet (Jeff Gilbert), and Barry. Adored grandmother of Aaron and Benjamin and stepgrandmother of Cooper Gilbert. Dear sister-in-law of Esther Carro. Services Friday, December 30, 2005 at 1:30PM at the "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to NARSAD.

title: 36 Hours in Mexico City
description: WHEN the Spaniards arrived in the Valley of Mexico in the 16th century, they found the sprawling Aztec city of Tenochtitln, destroyed it and built a new one on top of it. But they never really succeeded in burying the past. Mexico City became the largest city in the Western Hemisphere, a nexus of Latin American art and political thought. Today, after difficult adjustments to globalization and the precipitous devaluation of the peso from around 3 to the dollar to nearly 11 over 12 years -- often cited as a cause for a spike in crimes like kidnapping and robbery -- the city remains a teeming, vibrant and joyful place. Even the skies are blue again because of new laws that restrict auto use. Despite all the layers time has imposed, from the colonial past to the present day of "nuevo cine Mexicano" and "techno-rave en Espaol," even a weekend visitor will still feel the spirit of the old Aztec capital ever present alongside the new. ED MORALES

title: Judge Backs Arbiter Order Against Nokia
description: A federal judge has confirmed a $250 million arbitration award for the InterDigital Communications Corporation in a royalty dispute with the cellphone maker Nokia.

title: 3 Killed by Suicide Bomber at Checkpoint in the West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 29 - Two Palestinian civilians and an Israeli Army officer were killed Thursday when a Palestinian suicide bomber, stopped at a checkpoint near Tulkarm, in the West Bank, blew himself up.

description: A federal judge in San Francisco dismissed a class-action lawsuit against Siebel Systems, saying investors failed to show that the company misled them before it disclosed its Siebel 7 software was not selling as well as expected. Siebel, a big maker of customer service software, made the sales disclosure in 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, HOWARD S.
description: STERN -- Howard S. The Board of Trustees, Associate Board, League, administration and staff of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care & Rehabilitation are deeply saddened by the loss of Trustee Howard Stern. The elderly have lost an understanding & determined advocate and the world has lost a brilliant, generous and wonderful individual. Our heartfelt condolences to his family whom he deeply cherished: Linda, Rachel, Peter, Seth, Tricia & his beloved grandchildren. Jerry Landsberg Chairman of the Board Michael N. Rosenblut President and CEO

title: Manhattan by the Numbers
description: When sales figures for the Manhattan co-op and condo market were released in October showing that the average apartment price had dipped in the third quarter, it led to some overblown headlines and lots of fretting over whether the city was about to reach a rocky end to its wild real estate ride.

title: Records Fall in California
description: Californias hot residential market got a little hotter in 2005, making it a year for the record books. The California Association of Realtors notes that sales of detached existing single-family homes are expected to total 635,000 in 2005, which is 1.8 percent higher than last years record 624,700 sales. At the same time, the annual median sales price is expected to reach a record $523,150, or 16 percent more than 2004.

title: Its Not Just for Kids
description: About half of all senior citizens use the Internet for home buying, according to a research report released last month that was sponsored by the Senior Advantage Real Estate Council, a group that caters to seniors and those approaching retirement.

title: Realtors Hear Their Critics
description: Is the National Association of Realtors creating unnecessary barriers for discount brokers and other upstarts? While the new president of the trade group, Thomas M. Stevens, doesnt seem to think so, he is calling for it to examine its practices.

title: Last Post
description: We have had a snap of really cold weather at last. Scotland, or a large part of it, is covered with white: snow on the high ground, rime on the low. Scots come home now, into this cold weather, if they possibly can, because the Hogmanay celebration on New Years Eve is the most important one in the Scottish calendar and it is a time to be with family and with friends. All is forgiven on that evening: old arguments, failures of charity, neglect  all of that seems very unimportant on the last night of the year.

title: All Your Eggs in One Basket
description: The author of the Flip This blog read in the Sacramento Bee about a couple who bought a $809,000 house as an investment. It turns out six other houses are for sale on the same street. The blogger did a quick analysis of the couples financial planning:

title: Closing Time; A Little Moonlight
description: I. Given inconstancy, the resistless affair that has been my body (as if there were no place to go from anywhere except deeper, into those spaces the hand makes by tugging the flesh, where it is part-able, more open, or as if I believed, utterly, what legend says about violation -- how it leads to prophecy, the god enters the body, the mouth cracks open, and a mad fluttering, which is the future, fills the cave, which is desire, luck and hazard, hazard and luck),

title: Arts, Briefly; If It's Thursday, It's CBS
description: The ratings for the last Thursday of the year produced a final result like most other Thursdays in 2005: CBS won every hour of Nielsen's estimates. CBS broadcast three mystery repeats, and its "CSI" was the most-watched show of the night, with 17.48 million viewers. In place of "Survivor" at 8 p.m., "Criminal Minds" drew an audience of 11.75 million, and at 10 p.m., "Without a Trace" attracted 11.63 million viewers. Despite David Letterman's spike -- courtesy of Oprah Winfrey, who made a highly rated appearance on his "Late Show" earlier in the month -- "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" was No. 1 for the fourth quarter of the year. Mr. Leno drew an average of 5.9 million viewers, compared with Mr. Letterman's 4.5 million. Compared with the same quarter last year, both late night hosts' 18-to-49 ratings declined fractionally, but Mr. Leno continued to beat Mr. Letterman easily. "Nightline," which lost Ted Koppel to retirement in the fall and switched to a new format, brought in an average nightly audience of 3.5 million.

title: Shoppers of the World, Unite
description: THE Consumerist (consumerist.com), the newest blog in the expanding Gawker Media empire, displays a healthy antipathy toward everything it thinks is wrong with the retail and service sectors.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Bush Rejects Quotas on Steel Pipe From China Despite Recommendation From Trade Panel President Bush rejected a request to place quotas on steel pipe imported from China yesterday, saying the cost to American consumers would outweigh the benefit to domestic producers. United States pipe makers and a labor group, which strongly condemned the president's decision, asked the Bush administration to impose the quotas on certain kinds of steel pipe used primarily in construction. They argued that a surge in imports from China was disrupting markets. The International Trade Commission sided with the companies and recommended that the president provide relief. Mr. Bush rejected that, saying it was not in the best interest of the economy. (AP)

Parks Department to Limit Size of Events on the Great Lawn
description: The city's Parks Department formally ended the era of mass gatherings on Central Park's Great Lawn when it announced yesterday that no more than 50,000 people would be allowed onto the lawn's fragile Kentucky bluegrass for each event. Parks officials also said that only six events with 5,000 to 50,000 spectators would be permitted each year on the Great Lawn.

title: Confidence in One Diet Above All
description: Linda Huett walked into a Weight Watchers meeting in the early 1980's, hoping to lose weight after the birth of her third child. It worked, and then some: she soon took a job at the company, was promoted to manager and later to a vice president. In 2000, Ms. Huett was named chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHOTOS, CONSTANTINE
description: PHOTOS--Constantine. Constantine Theodore Photos, 82, died at his home on December 23, 2005. Born in Salem, Massachusetts, graduated Boston University Medical School, and served as an urologist at Lawrence and St. Luke's Roosevelt hospitals for almost 50 years. He will be remembered for his warm and infinite devotion to his patients and friends.

title: Closing Time; The Beautiful Quickness of a Street Boy
description: Where did he come from, this boy pressing his face against the window of the car on that January afternoon in Burdwan? One of the three coins slips from my outstretched fingers & falls somewhere in the small car, & I contort my body to retrieve this touch of alloyed copper. Then, I look up at the boy pointing to the roses on the dashboard. Afternoon light falls between us. I hand him a rose, & he walks away with his nose pushed into the bloom, smiling to himself. In no time, the boy is facing a young man waiting on the platform. They exchange a few words. The man shoves a hand into his pocket & gives the boy a coin, & he dances away, leaving the man holding the flower behind his back. Our car fills with awe & laughter, & someone says, There's a woman somewhere. That street boy, as if he sprung out of me, out of another time, is still pleading with everything he knows: his dusty clothes & eyes lit by Shiva, his half smile & black hair alive with lice, & his wounded song, as a bearded monkey paces the train station's roof-spine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMBELAINE, VERDALEE NORRIS
description: TOMBELAINE -- Verdalee Norris. Passed away December 26, 2005 at Sentara Leigh Hospital in Norfolk, VA. She lived at 340 East 64th Street in New York for many years. She loved the city and enjoyed an active life there. Family and friends will gather in Sanford, NC, at a later date to celebrate her life.

For all practical purposes, the 26-story glass-and-steel building, which officially opened on Friday, is the skyline on the American side of the Niagara River.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Firefighting Help Requested
description: Gov. Brad Henry cut short a vacation and returned to Oklahoma City to oversee state and local efforts to combat grass fires that have plagued parts of his state and North Texas this week. Mr. Henry authorized the state agriculture secretary, Terry Peach, to request 14 firefighting teams from other states, and the state has been approved for some federal aid. Unusually dry conditions, strong winds and high temperatures are expected to last into next week. The Department of Emergency Management attributes one death in the state to the fires and estimates that 30,000 acres have been burned and more than 80 homes and businesses destroyed in 22 counties since Tuesday. ERIC O'KEEFE (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-Police Chief Held In 1975 Kidnapping
description: Federal agents have arrested a second high-ranking former police official in connection with the kidnapping, torture and disappearance of a leftist leader in 1975. The former officer, Carlos Solana, who was head of the police in the northern state of Nuevo Laredo, was arrested on charges that he participated in the abduction of Jess Piedra Ibarra during the government's illegal crackdown on leftists. Mr. Piedra Ibarra's case became a cause clbre largely because of the advocacy of his mother, Rosario Ibarra. The former chief of Mexico's secret police, Miguel Nazar Haro, was arrested in the case last year. Two other police officials are being sought. JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAMERON, KATHARINE TORREY
description: CAMERON--Katharine Torrey. Of East Hampton and New York, passed away on December 27 after a hardfought battle with ovarian cancer. Beloved wife to the late William Allan Cameron, her life was defined by her devotion to family and friends, and by her many active interests. A long-time accredited judge for the American Daffodil Society, she also served as past President of the East Hampton Garden Club, and was a Board member of The Nature Conservancy South Fork Chapter. She was a guest curator and lecturer at East Hampton's Guild Hall for exhibitions on the area's nineteenth century artists. She also served on the Board of Managers of the East Hampton Library. Graduating from The Brearley School, she earned a B.A. from Fordham University, and a Master's in History from New York University. Mrs. Cameron was predeceased by her son Thomas Forkner. She is survived by her daughter Karen Wells, her son Stanley Forkner, her grandchildren Brad and Dana, by her stepchildren Anne Cunningham and Jean Cameron Smith, and their children Cameron, Tucker, Hunter and Caroline. She is also survived by her brothers John Torrey, Michael Torrey, and James Torrey, and sister Susan Coppock. Funeral services will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal in East Hampton on January 6, 2006 at 11:00 A.M. A springtime memorial service is planned at St. James in NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the East Hampton Library, 159 Main Street, East Hampton, New York, 11937.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEENE, CONSTANCE
description: KEENE - Constance. The House of Steinway & Sons deeply mourns the passing of the eminent American pianist Constance Keene, in New York City on December 24, 2005 at the age of 84. Constance Keene was a treasured member of our family of Steinway Artists for fiftytwo years. Early in her career she was proclaimed an exceptional interpreter of Rachmaninoff, and with her success in the Naumburg Competition of 1943 her career was launched. She appeared in recital, in duo recital with Abram Chasins, to whom she was married from 1949 until his death in 1987, and with the leading orchestras of the day. Ms. Keene was a featured participant in Steinway & Sons' Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953. An acclaimed teacher at the Manhattan School of Music, Ms. Keene was also an indefatigable traveler, serving on juries of the major piano competitions and conducting master classes around the globe. Our fond memories of Constance will continue to enrich us, as will her recordings and the artistry of her celebrated pupils. We convey our love and heartfelt condolences to her husband Milton. We have lost a dear friend. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Arts, Briefly; Auction of MAD Artwork
description: The last original artwork from the archives of MAD Magazine is to be auctioned in 2006, starting with a Jan. 21 sale at Heritage Galleries & Auctioneers in Dallas. "We are freeing up some much-needed closet space in our offices," said John Ficarra, the editor of MAD. While this is not the first time artwork from MAD has reached the market, the sales are notable for coming directly from the magazine's archives, as well as for representing "the last major treasure from our vaults," said David Hyde, the director of publicity at DC Comics, which publishes the humor magazine, long represented in popular culture by Alfred E. Neuman, above. Artists represented include Don Martin, Antonio Prohias, Sergio Aragons, Jack Davis and Mort Drucker. About one-third of the artwork will be from the private collections of artists Dick DeBartolo and Richard Williams, and from the estate of George Woodbridge.

title: A Diva, Yes, but Quite Contemporary
description: Angela Gheorghiu sat in the press office of the Metropolitan Opera projecting the look of a diva in repose: jeans with artful holes and rhinestone appliqus, a blue sweatshirt, buttery-leather cowboy boots to her knees, a red down parka draped over her chair. It was a look poised somewhere between Aspen and Bucharest, Romania, where she has just spent the holidays with her family, and it conveyed a studied, expensive down-to-earth-ness. If you believed that these were clothes she just happened to throw on, you might have believed that she was prepared for an informal little chat. But make no mistake: this was a performance.

The doses, which have been in cold storage in Britain since they were ordered from a British wholesaler in October 2004, will be distributed by Pakistani government officials. title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: African Dissident Loses Asylum

Spanish officials had previously said that they would not send Mr. Moto back to Equatorial Guinea, on Africa's west coast, but would look for a country that would guarantee his safety. Spain did not disclose details of the coup attempts attributed to Mr. Moto, who was granted asylum in 1986. RENWICK McLEAN (NYT)

title: The Poker World Is Flat, Part 1
description: In his optimistic best seller "The World Is Flat," the New York Times columnist Thomas L. Friedman uses "flat" as a synonym for connected -- digitally, that is, by fiber-optic cables. Friedman makes a compelling case that a "triple convergence" of Internet technology with economic and political events at the dawn of the 21st century has generated "more horizontal and collaborative" means of creating value. While warning of several dangers lurking in this global topology, he celebrates the more level playing field and the breathtaking variety of opportunities for those with the imagination and technical training to seize them.

title: Closing Time; Iskandariya
description: It was not a scorpion I asked for, I asked for a fish, but maybe God misheard my request, maybe God thought I said not "some sort of fish," but a "scorpion fish," a request he would surely have granted, being a goodly God, but then he forgot the "fish" attached to the "scorpion" (because God, too, forgets, everything forgets); so instead of an edible fish, any small fish, sweet or sour, or even the grotesque buffoonery of the striped scorpion fish, crowned with spines and followed by many tails, a veritable sideshow of a fish; instead of these, I was given an insect, a peculiar prehistoric creature, part lobster, part spider, part bell-ringer, part son of a fallen star, something like a disfigured armored dog, not a thing you can eat, or even take on a meaningful walk, so ugly is it, so stiffly does it step, as if on ice, freezing again and again in mid-air like a listening ear, and then scuttling backwards or leaping madly forward, its deadly tail doing a St. Vitus jig. God gave me a scorpion, a venomous creature, to be sure, a bug with the bite of Cleopatra's asp, but not, as I soon found out, despite the dark gossip, a lover of violence or a hater of men. In truth, it is shy, the scorpion, a creature with eight eyes and almost no sight, who shuns the daylight, and is driven mad by fire, who favors the lonely spot, and feeds on nothing much, and only throws out its poison barb when backed against a wall -- a thing like me, but not the thing I asked for, a thing, by accident or design, I am now attached to. And so I draw the curtains, and so I lay out strange dishes, and so I step softly, and so I do not speak, and only twice, in many years, have I been stung, both times because, unthinking, I let in the terrible light. And sometimes now, when I watch the scorpion sleep, I see how fine he is, how rare, this creature called Lung Book or Mortal Book because of his strange organs of breath. His lungs are holes in his body, which open and close. And inside the holes are stiffened membranes, arranged like the pages of a book -- imagine that! And when the holes open, the pages rise up and unfold, and the blood that circles through them touches the air, and by this bath of air the blood is made pure . . . He is a house of books, my shy scorpion, carrying in his belly all the perishable manuscripts -- a little mirror of the library at Alexandria, which burned.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary from The Associated Press on Dec. 23 about Heinrich Gross, a psychiatrist who worked at a clinic where the Nazis killed and conducted experiments on thousands of children, misstated the number of people killed in Nazi euthanasia programs. The United States Holocaust Museum and other sources say that the number is estimated to be about 275,000, not 75,000. The obituary also misspelled the given name of a German medical historian and ethicist who researched Dr. Gross's involvement in the Nazi killings. He is Matthias Dahl, not Mathias.
