description: WEST TISBURY, Mass. - In late summer, I built a waterfowling blind at the head of Town Cove on Tisbury Great Pond, but it wasn't until the last week of November that my youngest son, Jeff, and I used it for the first time.

title: Patents Rejected for BlackBerry
description: Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry wireless e-mail device, said yesterday that the United States Patent and Trademark Office had issued preliminary rejections of two wireless e-mail patents owned by NTP, the holding company that had won a patent infringement lawsuit against it.

title: Why Road Games Turn Warriors Into Worriers
description: If the Giants beat the Raiders in Oakland tonight, they will earn the right to call themselves division champions. And while that title might help sell shirts and caps, the Giants are after a more practical reward.

title: U. of Michigan Becomes 10th College to Join Boycott of Coke
description: When students at the University of Michigan return to campus next week after the holiday break, they will find the Coke machines and fountain dispensers empty.

title: Padilla Lawyers Urge Supreme Court to Block Transfer
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 - Lawyers for Jose Padilla told the Supreme Court on Friday that it should not grant the government's emergency request to have him transferred from a military brig to civilian custody to face terrorism charges in a civil court.

title: Thousands Aboard Six Amtrak Trains Endure a Long Ordeal
description: Amtrak passengers along the busy corridor between Florida and New York were delayed for up to 20 hours after eight freight cars derailed on Thursday near Savannah, Ga., blocking the tracks in either direction.

title: U.S. Women Accuse a Coach of Harassment
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 30 - Some members of the United States women's skeleton team, including the 2002 Olympic gold medalist Tristan Gale, have accused Coach Tim Nardiello of a pattern of sexual harassment dating to 2002.

title: Middle-Class Kids in Public Schools (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Recall Of Dog Food
description: Diamond Pet Foods recalled some products that federal regulators said might have killed 23 dogs and sickened 18 others because of contamination with a toxin derived from fungus. The Food and Drug Administration urged people who bought pet food made at Diamond's South Carolina plant to stop using it and return it to the store. Diamond said on its Web site that consumers should look on the back panel of pet-food packages for a capital "G" in the 11th or 12th position of the date code on 18- to 55-pound bags, and "Best By" dates between March 1, 2007, and June 10, 2007. The "G" will be in the ninth position on 4- to 8-pound bags.

title: London subway strike likely to damp revelry
World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Blast Kills 4 Policemen
description: Four policemen were killed and seven wounded in an explosion thought to have been set off by Taliban insurgents in southern Helmand Province, officials said. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

title: Boston Archdiocese Halves Offers in Open Abuse Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 - The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston has extended a financial settlement proposal to a second wave of victims of sexual abuse by clergy members, offering far smaller monetary awards than the first settlement in 2003 and establishing a more rigorous burden of proof for accusers.

title: As Ukraine Balks at Gas-Price Rise, Russian Company Renews Cutoff Threat
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 30 - Worries of a winter gas shortage in Ukraine intensified Friday as Russia's energy giant, Gazprom, renewed its threat to cut supply lines to Ukraine on Sunday morning if the country did not accept a nearly fourfold increase in price.

title: Middle-Class Kids in Public Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSZ, MELVIN KYLE
description: GROSZ--Melvin Kyle. Age 61, of Falmouth, MA, formerly of Bedford, NY, died at his home on December 28, 2005. Kyle worked for IBM for thirtythree years, and retired in 2001 from his position as Vice President of Finance for Large Servers. He is survived by his wife, Ann Lindley Grosz; his daughter, Ingrid, of Seattle, WA; his two sons, Erich and Devin, both of Brooklyn, NY; his mother, Agnes Smith Grosz of Short Hills, NJ; his brother, G. Kurt Grosz of Laguna Beach, CA; and his sister, Kristin Grosz of Boca Raton, FL. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice and Palliative Care of Cape Cod, 270 Communication Way, Hyannis, Massachusetts 02601. For obituary or online guest book please visit, www.ccgfuneralhome.com

title: The Life and Death of a Leading Lay Catholic
description: Patty Crowley died on Nov. 23. She was 92. When someone dies at that age, as one of her friends pointed out, it is unusual to find a cathedral four-fifths filled for the funeral. But that was the case at Holy Name Cathedral in Chicago.

title: Teenager Seen as the N.H.L.'s Next U.S. Star
description: Like many parents of hockey players, Kathy Kessel has seen her son Phil nurture his love for the sport at predawn practices, tryout camps and weekend tournaments. She has even seen his passion manifested in unusual locales like Florida.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) DICK CLARK'S PRIMETIME NEW YEAR'S ROCKIN' EVE 2006 -- Mr. Clark (right), 76, is back in Times Square, with Ryan Seacrest of "American Idol" as his cohost. Musical guests include the Bangles, the Pussycat Dolls and the big attraction, Mariah Carey, performing live.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about an effort by the government of Ghana to persuade black Americans to visit, invest and retire there misstated the undergraduate university attended by Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of the African and African American studies department at Harvard, who first visited Ghana when he was 20 years old. It was Yale, not Harvard.

title: To Reflect, Or Not to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Marjorie Kellogg, 83, Writer of 'Junie Moon' and Movies, Dies
description: Marjorie Kellogg, who poured her personal experiences into the bestselling book "Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon," her story of three disabled people keeping house together, died on Dec. 19 at her home in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 83 and was for many years a resident of Manhattan.

title: It's a Quicken World Again for Intuit
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. - What happens when a flagship product becomes an afterthought? At Intuit, that was happening with Quicken, the very brand that made it a software powerhouse in the 1980's and 1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROVER, HENRY CUSHING (HANK)
description: GROVER -- Henry Cushing (Hank). On November 28, 2005 in Houston at 78 years. Served in the Texas State Legislature, 1961-1972. Gubernatorial candidate. Prior to that, a public high school teacher and veteran. Condolences to his wife, children and grandchildren from his four sisters, nineteen nieces and nephews whose lives he greatly influenced. Loved and revered.

title: 2005 in Sports
description: Steroids, a hurricane and a labor dispute supplied the year's most surprising sports stories.

title: The Free-Ride Effect
description: In 1997, the introduction of the MetroCard, with its free subway-bus transfers, had a profound effect on New York Citys real estate market. It turned two-fare trips into one-fare trips, making hard-to-reach neighborhoods more accessible.

title: End of the ARMS Race
description: Reuters had a good story this week looking at why, because of the inverted yield curve in bonds, adjustable rate mortgages will be less attractive to lenders.

title: Readers Respond to Timing of Eavesdropping Article
description: Here are a number of messages from readers about the timing of the N.S.A. article:

title: More on the Eavesdropping Article
description: The public editors column in The Times of Jan. 1 takes a look at how the paper explained to readers the decision-making that led to the publication on Dec. 16 of the article on the warrantless eavesdropping on Americans in the United States.

title: Believing Is Seeing
description: Scientists say that the human brain is wired to look for patterns in the chaotic data that assaults us throughout the day. The trouble is, we are not really good at telling what the pattern is. Thats why we see the face of Jesus in a grilled cheese sandwich or think that a stock graph that looks like a cup means the stock is a good buy.
